title: Police set up special data system in battle against narcotics
author: Author not found
Content: Police have put in place a specialised data system that covers all Police stations across the island, with the aim of streamlining the identification process of individuals arrested in connection with drug-related activities, the Police Media Division said yesterday (14).  The official launch of this data system occurred at the Police Headquarters yesterday (14) during a workshop organised for Provincial Senior Deputy Inspectors General of Police (SDIG), DIGs and Senior Superintendents of Police (SSP) in charge of divisions. The workshop focused on forthcoming special drug-related operations.  The event was held under the patronage of Public Security Minister Tiran Alles and Acting Inspector General of Police (IGP) Deshabandu Tennakoon. The Police Media Division said this data system allows immediate input of details for any individual apprehended, facilitating the retrieval of existing criminal records at all Police stations. As of now, the data system has been updated with information on individuals arrested for drug-related offenses.

title: Fmr K’gala Mayor, four others sentenced to three years RI
author: Author not found
Content: Former Kurunegala Mayor Thushara Sanjeewa Vitharana and four others, were sentenced to three years Rigorous Imprisonment after being found guilty, by Kurunegala High Court, of causing the destruction and removal of the ancient ‘Buwanekaba Raja Sabha Mandapaya’ (Buwanekaba King’s Court) in Kurunegala.  Additionally, they were mandated to compensate Rs 13.5 million in damages, and the failure to make this payment would lead to an extra six-month imprisonment for each individual. The primary accused, the former Mayor, was also instructed to pay a fine of Rs 25,000, while all other defendants were directed to pay fines of Rs 50,000 each. Failure to remit these fines would result in an additional six months being added to their prison sentences. On 6 August 2020, the Kurunegala Magistrate issued arrest warrants against the Mayor, the Municipal Commissioner, an Engineer and two others in connection with the demolition of the ‘Raja Sabha Mandapaya’, a historically significant building dating back to the 13th Century, presumed to be the King’s Court of King Buwanekabahu II. Previously, the Attorney General had directed the Acting Inspector General of Police to obtain warrants and arrest the individuals. However, on 10 August 2020, the Kurunegala Magistrate re-issued the arrest warrants as the Police had failed to execute earlier ones. On 11 August 2020, five individuals, including the Kurunegala Mayor, filed writ petitions challenging the arrest warrants issued against them. The building in question, also known as the Buwaneka Hotel, believed to be the assembly hall used by contemporary rulers in the 13th Century, was demolished by the former Mayor on 16 July 2022, for a road development project. He claimed that the Road Development Authority (RDA) had approved the demolition. However, the Department of Archaeology filed a complaint, asserting that the demolished building was a 13th Century King’s Court and the archaeological site was listed under the Antiquities Ordinance No. 9 of 1940. In response, a five-member committee was formed to investigate the incident under the directives of then Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. Simultaneously, the Attorney General obtained a Court Order to protect and restrict access to the demolished historic building site during investigations, targeting the suspects.  On 28 July 2020, the Kurunegala Magistrate instructed the former Mayor to submit all documents, related to the demolished building, to the Court’s safe custody. Additionally, the Magistrate requested all documents and minutes of the City Development Committee from the Governor of the North-Western Province. BY Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: Four drugs imported sans NMRA registration
author: Author not found
Content: Four categories of medicinal drugs, falsely portrayed as imported from India and lacking registration with the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), have been identified, with no disclosed information about their actual manufacturing location, medical trade unions alleged. Accordingly, it has been revealed that the medicinal drugs, which were currently being used in hospitals, had been supplied to the State Health Service by the supplier involved in the human immunoglobulin fraud, who is now in custody.  The drugs are: Irinotecan Hydrochloride Trihydrate injection (used in treating colon or rectal cancer), Docetaxel Injection (a chemotherapy drug. It targets fast dividing cells, like cancer cells, and cause these cells to die), Fluorescein Sodium injection (a diagnostic tool in the field of ophthalmology and optometry) and Factor V11 Injection (used to stop bleeding from injuries for patients with hemophilia by helping the blood to clot). The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) said, it would not be difficult to bring the criminals responsible for several medicinal drug scams to justice, without being influenced, if the Attorney General’s Department and the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) acted according to their conscientious and committed themselves to achieve at least minute fairness towards the rights of tax payers. MCPA President, Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (14), lamented that the CID had informed the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court that  the four categories of medicinal drugs, sans proper registration with the National Medicines Registration Authority (NMRA), had been brought under false implications of having been imported from India, had been identified. However, no information had been unravelled as to the place where they were manufactured. Dr. Sanjeeva said, it had also been revealed that several other medicinal drugs had been imported to Sri Lanka by other suppliers also on the pretext of importing medicines from India. These too had been imported allegedly without registration with the NMRA.  In addition, Dr. Sanjeeva noted that it has also been revealed in the Magisterial Court that including immunoglobulin some of the medicines had been contaminated with microbials. He said, a country was at a dilemma as to why action had not been taken to bring the responsible parties to justice, notwithstanding their social position, even after a lapse of 75 days. It is apparent that there has been a misappropriation of billions of rupees and drug trafficking with a criminal mind.  Meanwhile, President of the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF) Dr. Rukshan Bellana also expressed his displeasure over the current investigations into the drug scams.  “I don’t know what the Health Ministry is doing. It seems that they want to make it clear to the public that there is no authority to overlook the State Health Sector. It is also sad that the on-going investigations into the substandard medicine are too slow. There are serious problems about the quality of drugs we are using on patients. If I was given the salary of the CID, I can catch those who are responsible for the drug scams faster than the CID,” Dr. Bellana stressed.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SC orders four Police officers to pay compensation
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (14) issued a directive compelling four Police officers to personally compensate an individual with Rs 2 million for violating his fundamental rights, during his detention at the Mirihana Police Station. In its ruling, the Supreme Court concluded that the petitioner, W. Ranjith Sumangala, had his fundamental rights breached through an illegal arrest, detention, and torture at the Mirihana Police Station in 2011, overseen by the four Police Officers. Ajith Wanasundera, a retired Sergeant Major of the Army, involved in the case, was also found responsible and ordered to pay compensation. Additionally, the State was directed to provide Rs 100,000 in compensation to the petitioner. The Supreme Court went on to instruct various authorities, including the National Police Commission (NPC), to initiate disciplinary measures against all implicated Police Officers. Legal representation for the petitioner was provided by Senior Counsel Viran Corea, along with Counsel Sarita de Fonseka and Thilini Vidanagamage, while Senior State Counsel Induni Punchihewa represented the Attorney General. The judgment was delivered by Justice S. Thurairaja, with Justices Kumudini Wickremasinghe and Priyantha Fernando concurring.

title: Eye hospital docs call off strike
author: Author not found
Content: The doctors, at the National Eye Hospital in Colombo, called off their token strike that was initiated yesterday (14) morning. Senior spokesman of the Health Ministry said the strike had been called off following the Health Ministry Secretary’s intervention. National Eye Hospital doctors, headed by the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) branch union, on Wednesday (13) declared a strike in protest against the failure by authorities to so far take action regarding the misconduct of the Administrative Officer of Hospital who allegedly misused hospital property including its ambulance for her convenience.  Meanwhile, the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF) commended the Health Ministry Secretary Dr. Palitha Mahipala for intervening in the issue. President of the GMOF, Dr. Rukshan Bellana said, however, that these were not issues which needed the Health Ministry Secretary’s intervention. The Health Secretary ‘s Office acts in the policy formulating capacity, while the Office of the Director General Health Services acted in operations namely in stepping in during such crisis situations.  “It is unfortunate that the Health Ministry has such DG’s Office, which requires either the Health Minister or the Health Ministry Secretary’s office to intervene,” he said while urging the Health Ministry Secretary to utilise his experience of supporting the health care services of the South East Asian Region to look at what was wrong with Sri Lanka’s health service.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Couple nabbed filming porn
author: Author not found
Content: A couple was arrested by the Kadugannawa Police, on suspicion of producing a pornographic film for online distribution. According to the Police, the two suspects, aged between 28 and 29, had been engaged in this activity while posing as schoolchildren.  The Police arrested the couple based  on a tip-off indicating the production of a pornographic film at a lodge in Kadugannawa.  The search resulted in the discovery of the suspects in possession of several mobile phones, a laptop computer and uniforms from various schools. The Police claimed that during interrogation, the suspects admitted to shooting pornographic scenes, while dressed in school uniforms, with the intent of generating income on the internet. Both were produced before the Kandy Magistrate and released on stringent bail conditions. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Police hunt for Chinese thief
author: Author not found
Content: A joint operation has been initiated by the Police and Tourist Police at Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake to arrest a Chinese national suspected of stealing cash amounting to USD 14,000 from a bag carried by a Lebanese national travelling in Business Class, on an Air Oman flight, on Wednesday (13). According to BIA sources, the 47-year-old Lebanese national, a businessman by profession, arrived in Colombo at around 7.20 a.m. from Muscat on the mentioned flight, accompanied by his mother for medical treatment. In addition to the mother and son, three other Chinese nationals also travelled in Business Class. Preliminary inquiries into the theft revealed that the Chinese national stole the cash from the Lebanese national and allegedly replaced it with a stack of Egyptian currency.  The unsuspecting Lebanese businessman proceeded to a bank branch at BIA to change his USD currency into LKR. However, upon realising his cash was missing, the Lebanese national lodged a complaint with the BIA Police and its Tourist Police Unit. Initial investigations revealed that a Chinese national was the alleged perpetrator of the theft. Efforts are underway to apprehend the suspect, who has reportedly disappeared since the incident. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: COP28 outcome criticised for failing key tests on fossil fuel phase-out and climate finance
author: Author not found
Content: The outcome of the 28th UN Climate Summit, known as COP28, has faced criticism for falling short on crucial tests related to the swift, fair, funded and complete phase-out of fossil fuels required to avert a climate catastrophe, the Friends of Earth International (FoEI) Organisasion stressed.  Despite applause for the ‘UAE Consensus’ among delegates, FoEI expressed dismay over perceived loopholes that may prolong the era of fossil fuels. Sara Shaw, spokesperson for FoEI, stated, “The COP28 deal has fallen short of delivering meaningful commitments on fossil fuel phaseout and urgently needed climate finance.”  Concerns were raised about the inclusion of potentially distracting elements like carbon capture utilisation and storage, hydrogen, nuclear energy, and carbon removal technologies. The equity aspect of the outcome was criticised for not adequately differentiating between the roles of developed and developing countries in the transition away from fossil fuels, despite differing historical responsibilities for emissions. While a global renewable energy target was set, no concrete financial commitments accompanied it. Rich nations, including the US, UK, and EU, were accused of hypocrisy for celebrating language on transitioning away from fossil fuels while having substantial expansion plans for fossil fuel use. Shaw emphasised their failure to provide adequate climate finance needed for emissions reductions, adaptation, and loss and damage in developing countries. Carbon market negotiations collapsed at COP28, delaying the establishment of a global carbon market until the following year. This development was viewed as a victory for climate justice movements seeking to prevent the flood of potentially damaging carbon credits once the market becomes operational. The operationalisation of the Loss and Damage fund at the start of COP28 was acknowledged, but questions lingered about its accessibility, especially considering it will be hosted by the World Bank. Pledges made at the summit were criticised for falling far below the estimated damages caused by climate-related events. The presence of over 2,400 fossil fuel lobbyists at the summit and a perceived crackdown on activists’ voices further fuelled criticism. Lise Masson of FoEI emphasised that climate justice requires respect for human rights and condemned the censorship faced by activists advocating for just outcomes amid the ongoing climate crisis.

title: VAT increase troubles Trade Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Trade and Food Security Nalin Fernando, expressed his personal dissatisfaction at the decision to increase VAT by 18 per cent, resulting in a significant rise in the prices of essential items and imposing an immense burden on him personally.  He made these remarks while addressing reporters at the Mahapola Trade and Education Exhibition held at the Ja-Ela public playground. Fernando clarified that although he was not personally supportive of the government’s choice to raise VAT by 18 per cent, he emphasised the necessity of making tough decisions for the country to achieve economic turnaround. He highlighted that the government made the decision with a focus on long-term benefits for the country, considering the economic landscape beyond short-term consequences. Fernando mentioned that measures would be implemented to prevent intermediaries from taking advantage and profiting at the expense of consumers following the imposition of the 18 per cent VAT on goods. BY Prasanga Pawuluhewa – Ja-Ela

title: President will not revoke civic rights of those found guilty of bankrupting country – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: The Leader of the Opposition, MP Sajith Premadasa said, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has the power to revoke the civic rights of the nepotistic Rajapaksa clan, if he desire’s to but the pledge of allegiance the President and the 134 individuals, who caused the country to fall into bankruptcy, have taken was preventing him from doing so. The Opposition Leader was speaking at the ‘Voice for Justice’ event, held as a part of the public petition campaign launched by the Samagi Jana Balavegaya  to demand the civic rights be stripped from those found responsible, by the Supreme Court, for the economic crisis in Sri Lanka. The event was held at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute on Tuesday (12).  Addressing the event, the Leader of the Opposition said, in addition to the civil and political rights and liberties stated in Article 3 of the Constitution, which refers to fundamental rights of citizens, economic, social, religious and cultural rights must also be included and the necessary constitutional amendments will be conducted under the patronage of a SJB Government in the near future.  Premadasa also added, a transparent, comprehensive and efficient network of anti-corruption institutions will be established by such a government and that they will be able to operate independently and free from political influence. He claims that he hopes to acquire the stolen public funds through this network of institutions and reduce the burden on the public without increasing the VAT. Commenting on the Supreme Court verdict, given against the Rajapaksas and other State officials, holding them responsible for the economic crisis, Premadasa said, President Wickremesinghe has the power as Executive President to appoint a Presidential Commission and revoke the civic rights of those mentioned by the Supreme Court, but such actions cannot be expected due to the cordial relations President Wickremesinghe has with the accused. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: FAO Delivers Climate Resilient ‘Unsinkable’ Boats
author: Author not found
Content: The Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations handed over two specially -designed climate resilient fishing boats and 30 modified fish display stalls to the Ministry of Fisheries, in line with FAO’s commitment to sustainable development and address climate change challenges. The SL20 and SL23 fishing boats, measuring 6.3 and 7 metres in length, were meticulously designed for coastal fishing operations in Sri Lanka. Adhering to FAO/ILO/IMO standards, these boats prioritise the safety of fishers and are built to be capsize-resistant and withstand the challenges posed by climate change, including more frequent and intense storms and cyclones. The designs of these climate resilient boats are freely available through the FAO Fishing Vessel Design Database. The design and construction of these boats were made possible through the generous funding of the Norwegian Government -financed FAO Trust Fund project on “Responsible use of fisheries and aquaculture resources for sustainable development,” with a cost allocation of approximately nine million rupees. In addition to the boats, FAO, in collaboration with the Ministry of Fisheries, introduced 30 model fish stalls across 15 fisheries districts in Sri Lanka. These stalls, designed by the Ceynor Foundation under the Ministry of Fisheries, aim to minimise post-harvest fish quality loss by maintaining high-quality and safe conditions for fish retail selling. A recent study by the NARA revealed inadequate maintenance practices among most fish retailers in Sri Lanka. Outdoor fish stalls often display fish uncovered, without ice, in direct contact with sunlight and environmental hazards. The model fish display stalls seek to popularize retail selling stalls among fish retailers to maintain the quality of fish until it reaches the consumer. Minister of Fisheries Douglas Devananda expressed gratitude for FAO’s support, stating, “The handing over of these specially designed boats and fish stalls is a crucial step in ensuring the safety of our fishers and improving the overall quality of fish in our markets. This collaboration with FAO signifies our joint commitment to the development of sustainable fisheries in Sri Lanka.” Nalin Munasinghe, Assistant FAO Representative for Programmes, highlighted the importance of the initiative, stating, “FAO remains dedicated to fostering sustainable practices and supporting local communities in Sri Lanka. The delivery of these boats and stalls exemplifies our commitment to enhancing the resilience of the fisheries sector in the face of climate change challenges.” The climate-resilient boats and model fish stalls were handed over at a ceremony held at the Cey-Nor Foundation graced by Minister Douglas Devananda, Piyal Nishantha, State Minister of Fisheries, Nalin Munasinghe, Assistant FAO Representative for Programmes, Indu Ratnayake, Secretary to the Ministry of Fisheries, S. J. Kahawatte, Director General of the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, and Dr. Dulan Hettiarachchi, Chairman of the Cey-Nor Corporation.  FAO, together with its partners, remains committed to advancing sustainable practices in Sri Lanka’s fisheries sector, contributing to the well-being of fishers and addressing the impact of climate change on coastal communities.

title: Navy commended for swift medevac of Indian sailor
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Navy officers have been praised for their prompt assistance in the evacuation of an Indian sailor for medical reasons in Trincomalee. The Indian High Commission in Sri Lanka stated that the evacuated individual was an Indian Navy sailor from INS Sahyadri (F49), a Shivalik-class stealth multi-role frigate. “Timely and swift assistance from @srilanka_navy enabled the medical evacuation of @indiannavy sailor of INS Sahyadri at Trincomalee. Another illustration of the goodwill and spirit of camaraderie between our forces,” the Indian High Commission in Sri Lanka said in a post on ‘X’.

title: German Embassy holds spectacular public festival
author: Author not found
Content: The German Embassy in Colombo marked a milestone in bilateral relations between Germany and Sri Lanka by organising a vibrant public festival with about 3,000 visitors on Saturday, 2 December at Galle Face Green. Commemorating 70 years of diplomatic ties and friendship, the event was open to the public and offered engaging activities for attendees of all ages. The festival served as a platform for the broad public to explore German culture, cuisine, education opportunities and innovation, fostering a deeper understanding of the strong ties that bind the two nations. Sincere appreciation was extended to sponsors, partners and all participants for their invaluable contributions to the success of this commemorative event. The festival’s stage programme showcased an array of captivating performances from both countries, including tantalising performances by German learning schools, a delightful puppet show by Power of Play, a mesmerising drumming performance by Ravibandhu and his crew, a graceful dance item by the Temple of Fine Arts and enchanting musical renditions by the ‘Jazz Band’. Highlighting the collaborative spirit, partner organisations, GIZ – the Development Cooperation Agency of the German Government, Goethe-Institute, Delegation of German Industry and Commerce in Sri Lanka (AHK Sri Lanka), German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) and the Friedrich Naumann Foundation (FNF) contributed to the stage programme, set up informative stalls and organised various interactive elements. GIZ organised two containers exhibiting Archive of Memory and findings from the Sri Lanka Barometer on social cohesion as well as a classic Mercedes bus displaying the history of German-Sri Lankan collaboration in the field of Vocational Training in Sri Lanka. A dedicated children’s corner offered a plethora of fun games, allowing young participants to win exciting prizes. A classic car parade by the Mercedes-Benz club and the VW Beetle Club added a graceful touch to the festival.  Distinguished speakers at the event included Ambassador of Germany to Sri Lanka Dr. Felix Neumann, former President Maithripala Sirisena and Guest of Honour State Minister of Foreign Affairs, Tharaka Balasuriya, who delivered insightful speeches underscoring the enduring friendship between the two nations.

title: Ven. Chandima Nayaka Thera receives honorary degree
author: Author not found
Content: Most Ven. Dr. Bodagama Chandima Nayaka Thera, Vice-Chancellor of the Nāgānanda International Institute for Buddhist Studies (NIIBS), was conferred with the honorary degree of Sahithya Shuri at the NIIBS graduation ceremony held on 8 December. Ven. Chandima was born in 1957 in Thanamalwila, a remote village of southern Sri Lanka. In 1970, at the age of thirteen, he was ordained as a novice monk (Pali saamanera) by Dodampahala Sri Rathanajoti, the chief sangha nayaka of southern Sri Lanka and Atthudawe Gnanananda, the abbot of the Ratmalana Sri Vijayarama temple. In 1980, Ven. Chandima received higher ordination (bhikkhu upasampada) from the committee of Malwatte Sangha Community. He attended the Mantinda Pirivena monastery in Matara to receive primary education and then moved to Subhararama Pirivena in Nugegoda for secondary education. In 1982, he began studying at the Buddhasravaka Bhiksu University in Anuradhapura. Here he obtained the Thripitakavedi Degree after completing the five-year programme that encompassed learning Pali, Sanskrit, English, Sinhala, Hindi, Buddhist Philosophy and Culture, Abhidharma and Logic. In 2003 Ven. Chandima was awarded an honorary Doctor of Philosophy degree by the University of Ruhuna, Sri Lanka for his work in propagating Theravada Buddhism internationally and spreading understanding of Buddhist philosophy. He is fluent in Pali, Sanskrit, Sinhala, English and Chinese.

title: Dougy lauds NARA
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda praised the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) for its invaluable role in enhancing the fisheries of the country through timely and crucial research conducted in our territorial waters. Minister Devananda highlighted that NARA, as a research agency under the purview of the Fisheries Ministry, is dedicated to achieving sustainable development in fisheries, aiming to make it one of the primary income generators for the country.  He made these remarks as the Chief Guest at the annual session of NARA scientists titled “Sri Lanka’s economic prosperity and food security as well as sustainable fisheries,” on 13 December. The Fisheries Minister emphasised that it is NARA’s responsibility to formulate a research plan. As the Minister in charge of Fisheries, he assured that he and the institutions under his Ministry are prepared to provide full support to NARA in the coming years. Devananda underscored that NARA scientists should prioritize the well-being of local fisherfolk and the overall development of the fisheries sector. He urged them to address and resolve issues faced by fisherfolk through the regional offices of NARA in Puttalam, Gampaha, Matara and Hambantota Districts. State Fisheries Minister Piyal Nishantha de Silva, addressing the event, emphasized that significant progress can be made in the industry if all stakeholders work together in harmony. The event was attended by researchers from the Republic of China, Secretary of the Fisheries Ministry Indu Ratnayake, NARA Chairman Jayantha Wijeratne and Director General Dr. Kamal Tennakoon. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: N’ Eliya DS expresses displeasure to Police
author: Author not found
Content: Nuwara Eliya Divisional Secretary Prageeth Danansuriya said he has expressed his displeasure to the Nuwara Eliya Police over the latter’s refusal to act promptly on a complaint lodged by him over the alleged threats made to him and his officials by a security officer employed by a property owner. He said the security officer had threatened him and his officials following their efforts to evict the security officer based on an order issued by the Nuwara Eliya Chief Magistrate. The Divisional Secretary said the ‘owner’ had compiled fake documents and had illegally laid claim to the property after the foreign investor who had purchased the property worth Rs 4 billion had left the country following a serious illness. Danansuriya added that the decision to evict the security officer had been taken based on advice received from the President during the District Coordination Committee meeting held recently. Nuwara Eliya Chief Magistrate Kushika Kumarasiri ordered that the occupant be evicted effective 13 December. By Neeta Pathmakumari – Nuwara Eliya

title: Geetha appointed President of SL – Egypt Parliamentary Friendship Association
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs, Geetha Kumarasinghe, was appointed as the President of the Sri Lanka – Egypt Parliamentary Friendship Association last week. The inaugural meeting for the Ninth Parliament of the Sri Lanka – Egypt Parliamentary Friendship Association was held in Parliament and chaired by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana. The Ambassador of the Arab Republic of Egypt to Sri Lanka Maged Mosleh, was the Guest of Honour. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse, several MPs and Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera, were also present at the meeting. MPs Madhura Withanage, Hector Appuhamy and Aravinda Kumar were appointed as Vice Presidents of the Friendship Association. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse was appointed as Secretary, while MP Karunadasa Kodithuwakku was appointed as Assistant Secretary. MP Mohomad Muzammil was appointed as the Treasurer of the Sri Lanka – Egypt Parliamentary Friendship Association. Addressing the gathering, the Speaker expressed his happiness in establishing the Parliamentary Friendship Association between the two countries in line with the 66th anniversary of Sri Lanka-Egypt diplomatic relations. He pointed out that Sri Lanka-Egypt relations can be further developed through this friendship association. The Egyptian Ambassador to Sri Lanka congratulated the newly appointed officials and emphasised his hope to develop the existing friendship between the two countries in various fields. In her speech, State Minister Kumarasinghe expressed gratitude for being elected as the President of the Friendship Association. She underlined her expectation to strengthen relations with Egypt, a country with a rich history, arts and industries. Additionally, she commended the commitment of the Egyptian Ambassador in Sri Lanka to strengthen relations between the two countries.

title: Two arrested in failed murder bid
author: Author not found
Content: The STF arrested two individuals who had attempted to shoot dead another person at Umagiliya playground in Kolonnawa, on Wednesday (14).  As the weapon did not fire, the gunman immediately fled the scene with his supporter. The STF stated that he was arrested based on a tip-off while hiding in a house owned by an underworld member ‘Chandana,’ who is a member of the network involved in the drug business and organised crimes led by ‘Dubai Dhanushka.’ The suspects, aged 25 and residents of Kolonnawa and Dematagoda, were found with seven mobile phones and 7.5 grams of heroin at the house. The motorcycle used for their escape was also seized by the STF. During interrogation, it was revealed that the suspected gunman, following a personal dispute with another individual, attempted to kill him. However, his hand gun malfunctioned, the STF said. The two suspects were handed over to the Mirihana Police. BY S.S.H. Dunuwila – Kalutara

title: SLBFE official arrested for cheating
author: Author not found
Content: An official of the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) has been arrested following allegations that he had defrauded a woman of Rs 500,000 on the promise of overseas employment. The arrest transpired following a complaint filed by a resident of Middeniya, asserting that the official had deceived her by falsely assuring employment in Romania. The Special Investigations Unit of the SLBFE detained the suspect on this complaint. The individual, a resident of Moratuwa, was taken into custody after being summoned for questioning by the SLBFE’s SIU during their inquiry into the reported fraud. The arrest was made on charges of unlawfully obtaining money by offering overseas employment without possessing a valid licence to do so. After the suspect appeared before the Nugegoda Magistrate’s Court on December 14, the Court granted release on bail. The conditions of bail included two sureties of Rs 500,000 each and a cash bail in Rs. 10,000.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Grade 5 Scholarship Exam to be simplified – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: The Education Ministry is to simplify the Grade 5 Scholarship Examination by implementing significant changes in the current education system, starting from the next academic year, Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha said.  Focus will be on assessing students’ literacy and numeracy skills, the Minister added.  Speaking at a ceremony held at the Ministry to evaluate students who achieved the highest marks in the Grade 5 scholarship examination 2023 and those who sat for the Ordinary Level Examination 2022,  Premajayantha said moving forward, students will not be solely judged on obtaining 100% marks in exams. Under the new approach, students will be assessed based on 30% marks obtained in the Grade 5 scholarship exam, along with an additional 30% derived from evaluations conducted in the classroom during Grades 4 and 5. The Minister emphasised the importance of regular attendance for students to benefit from this evaluation method. While acknowledging concerns that some parents may argue teachers could be biased, the Minister reassured that there is no room for such situations. He stressed the need to foster better trust among teachers, parents, and students. School development boards are expected to play a crucial role in monitoring and evaluating students in the classroom. Premajayantha highlighted that even in Finland, renowned for having an exemplary education system, classroom-level assessments are carried out until Grade 9, with formal exams being introduced only from Grade 9 onward.

title: Acting IGP says all narcotics will be destroyed promptly
author: Author not found
Content: Acting Inspector General of Police (IGP) Deshabandu Tennakoon has emphasised that stringent measures will be implemented to promptly destroy all drugs seized during future. Addressing the media, before the destruction of over 100 kg of heroin yesterday (14), on the orders of the Colombo High Court, Tennakoon acknowledged concerns surrounding the handling of confiscated drugs. He acknowledged reports of these drugs potentially finding their way back into the hands of drug dealers or addicts. While recognizing these issues, the Acting IGP assured that going forward, immediate steps will be taken to swiftly destroy all confiscated drugs to address such concerns. Meanwhile, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa pointed out that, in line with amendments to the Poison, Opium, and Dangerous Drugs (Amendment) Act in 2022, the disposal of seized narcotics is authorised after examination by the Government Analyst. He noted that a Gazette Notification on this matter has already been issued by the Minister of Justice. Despite approximately 4,000 kg of confiscated narcotics awaiting destruction, pending Court cases, SSP Thalduwa mentioned ongoing efforts to destroy an additional 1,000 kg of seized drugs. These drugs were taken into custody after the amendments to the Poison, Opium, and Dangerous Drugs (Amendment) Act in November 2022.

title: Insects raid paddy cultivations
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Agriculture announced nearly 22,000 hectares of paddy cultivation, in several districts, have been adversely affected by three species of insects: the White Back Planthopper, Gray Plant Hopper, and Leaf Curl worm.  Currently, these diseases have been reported in the Northern, Eastern and North Central Provinces. If farmers observe the presence of these insects in their fields, the Director General emphasises the importance of immediately informing the Agriculture Department officials and adhering to the instructions provided by agricultural consultants, Malathi Parasuraman, Director General of the Agriculture Department said.  Parasuraman said all these damages by insect can be prevented. Agricultural consultants and other officials have been duly informed, and special agricultural teams have been dispatched for field inspections. Given the resistance of these insects to certain chemicals, it is advised that relying on insecticides or following recommendations from individuals lacking expertise in this matter, as well as mixing insecticides with other types, may not yield proper results.  The Director General further advises farmers to use only pesticides recommended by the Department of Agriculture. In addition, the Department of Agriculture said armyworms have been reported to a certain extent in connection with maize cultivation. Therefore, farmers are encouraged to thoroughly inspect their fields, destroy any worm cells found and resort to chemical control measures only if necessary, she said.  BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: CEJ files FR petition challenging Eppawala phosphate licensing process
author: Author not found
Content: Environmentalists have filed a Fundamental Rights (FR) petition, in the Supreme Court, challenging the alleged irregularities in the licensing process, for foreign companies that conducted excavations at the Eppawala phosphate deposit. The petition, submitted on Wednesday (13), was filed by Dilena Pathragoda, Executive Director of the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) and Hemantha Withanage, its Senior Adviser. The petitioners asserted that the approval granted to foreign firms was obtained through the use of forged documents, resulting in substantial financial losses for the State. They argued that the Eppawala phosphate deposit was a valuable national asset that should not have been handed over to foreign firms, especially when its potential could have contributed to the country’s development. The petitioners claimed that the transaction disproportionately benefited foreign countries, with Sri Lankan parties gaining minimally. They contended that the use of forged documents allowed intermediaries to reap significant profits. In light of these allegations, the petitioners sought a Supreme Court order for the respondents — the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) and its Director-General, the Central Environmental Authority (CEA), and Lanka Phosphate Ltd to initiate a special investigation. Additionally, they requested the appointment of a Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI). Furthermore, the petitioners urged the Supreme Court to issue an order to the Attorney General and the Inspector General of Police (IGP) to take legal action against those responsible for the alleged misconduct under criminal laws.  BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Two arrested in failed murder bid
author: Author not found
Content: The STF arrested two individuals who had attempted to shoot dead another person at Umagiliya playground in Kolonnawa, on Wednesday (14).  As the weapon did not fire, the gunman immediately fled the scene with his supporter. The STF stated that he was arrested based on a tip-off while hiding in a house owned by an underworld member ‘Chandana,’ who is a member of the network involved in the drug business and organised crimes led by ‘Dubai Dhanushka.’ The suspects, aged 25 and residents of Kolonnawa and Dematagoda, were found with seven mobile phones and 7.5 grams of heroin at the house. The motorcycle used for their escape was also seized by the STF. During interrogation, it was revealed that the suspected gunman, following a personal dispute with another individual, attempted to kill him. However, his hand gun malfunctioned, the STF said. The two suspects were handed over to the Mirihana Police. BY S.S.H. Dunuwila – Kalutara

title: SLBFE official arrested for cheating
author: Author not found
Content: An official of the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) has been arrested following allegations that he had defrauded a woman of Rs 500,000 on the promise of overseas employment. The arrest transpired following a complaint filed by a resident of Middeniya, asserting that the official had deceived her by falsely assuring employment in Romania. The Special Investigations Unit of the SLBFE detained the suspect on this complaint. The individual, a resident of Moratuwa, was taken into custody after being summoned for questioning by the SLBFE’s SIU during their inquiry into the reported fraud. The arrest was made on charges of unlawfully obtaining money by offering overseas employment without possessing a valid licence to do so. After the suspect appeared before the Nugegoda Magistrate’s Court on December 14, the Court granted release on bail. The conditions of bail included two sureties of Rs 500,000 each and a cash bail in Rs. 10,000.

title: Ministry must regain public trust in health services
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, observed that it was the duty of his Ministry to rejuvenate the primary, secondary and tertiary health care service, following its recent collapse, to regain public trust. Dr. Pathirana yesterday (13), following a special observation visit to Apeksha Cancer Hospital in Maharagama, said the country had a large infrastructure system in place to provide a well organised health service. The Minister lamented that a large number of children were victims of cancer and that their numbers were growing. Awareness programmes should be implemented to save the public from communicable and non-communicable diseases, he said. Dr. Pathirana observed that Sri Lanka was one of the few countries which provided a free health service complete with food and drink to patients without an insurance scheme in place. The Minister inspected the four-storey complex of the Children’s Wards, constructed with the Ruhunu Maha Kataragama Temple Fund at a cost of Rs 150 million. The Minister also paid special attention to problems faced by staff in the hospital and instructed the Director of Apeksha hospital, Dr. A. Jayasekara to maintain an uninterrupted supply of medicinal drugs for patients. He was instructed to inform the Minister directly if there was a shortage of medicine.  The Basnayake Nilame of the Ruhunu Kataragama Temple, Dilshan Gunasekara, Deputy Director of the Hospital, Administrative Officer, Medical Specialists, Doctors and hospital staff were present.

title: Fertiliser imported for farmers sold to outsiders
author: Author not found
Content: Fertilisers imported over the past six years, intended for distribution to farmers with government approval, were allegedly sold at inflated prices to non-agricultural industries without extending subsidies to the farmers, the CID informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (14). Following this revelation, the Chief Magistrate ordered CID to obtain the bank records of several companies, registered with the Fertiliser Secretariat, suspected of engaging in fraudulent activities and accumulating significant profits. In 2018,  some 18 companies were registered with the Fertiliser Secretariat, ostensibly to supply fertilisers to farmers under a subsidy system. However, farmers are yet to receive fertiliser through this subsidised scheme. Sub-Inspector (SI) Anura Gamage, from the Financial Crimes Investigation Division of the CID, informed the Court that the fraudulent activities came to light during an investigation prompted by complaints lodged by Sumedha Perera and Ruwan Chandra, former secretaries of the Agriculture Department. The CID revealed that the companies had imported fertilisers, claiming that a bag priced at Rs 2,500 would be sold to farmers at Rs 1,100, with the government paying them the difference of prices. Despite the imported fertilisers were meant for farmers at a reduced rate, it has been confirmed that several companies registered with the Fertiliser Secretariat did not distribute them to farmers. Instead, they allegedly sold the fertilisers to non-agricultural industries at higher prices ranging from Rs 2,500 to Rs 3,000. The CID identified approximately seven out of the 18 registered companies involved in this fraudulent activity during their investigation. The CID informed the Court that it is actively exploring whether the remaining companies were also involved in this scheme. Through the investigations, it has come to light that one such company fraudulently misused around Rs 100 million from State funds. SI Anura Gamage informed the Court that a committee appointed by the Fertiliser Secretariat had initiated an inquiry into the matter following the complaints lodged by the two individuals.  However, based on their preliminary findings the committee had only halted the disbursement of State funds to only two smaller companies, neglecting major factories, as some officials had taken bribes from the ‘big-corporations,’ SI Anura Gamage said.  The CID, in its report to the Court, said that, as per the ongoing investigations, seven out of the 18 registered companies are implicated in this fraudulent activity. Further inquiries will be conducted to determine the involvement of the remaining companies in this wrongdoing. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Culprits in drug scam must be named and shamed
author: Author not found
Content: Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) said, it was the duty of the country’s legal system to take immediate action to punish politicians and officials who acted in a conspiratorial manner misusing people’s tax money. MCPA President, Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (13), called for the revelation of names of the high-level political and bureaucratic network that played with the lives of citizens by entering into questionable medicinal drug deals, imported substandard drugs, fearlessly worked with medicinal drug companies and played with the tax payers’ money. “There will be nothing left at the end of these judicial actions if the names of those responsible for the situation were not revealed and we were merely satisfied by the data revealed before the Court,” he lamented. Dr. Sanjeeva said, the Government had a responsibility to investigate all allegedly shady deals that had taken place by falsely claiming that there was a drug shortage. It is being revealed how even the procurement committees involving top politicians and ministry secretaries had been working to import medicinal drugs using a few chosen suppliers quoting high prices. Dr. Sanjeeva said, he hoped to hand over more related documentation to the CID in this regard in the near future. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Appeal Court Upholds Conviction
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal, in a majority decision, upheld the convictions and sentences of three individuals linked to South Asia’s largest VAT scam, yesterday (13).  The Colombo High Court had previously found the trio; Mohammed Subair Fauzool Avami, Mohammed Moujool Ameer Irshad alias Mohammed Nazeer Cader and Mohammed Kamil Kuthubdeen, guilty of criminal misappropriation, involving nearly Rs 3.9 billion in Treasury funds. The High Court had initially sentenced the three accused appellants to 20 years of Rigorous Imprisonment along with fines. The original case involved 14 accused facing 34 charges, including misappropriation of Rs 3.9 billion in public funds from the Inland Revenue Department. While the appeal was pending before the Court of Appeal, the 3rd accused passed away, and the 7th accused decided to withdraw his appeal. Consequently, the Court of Appeal issued its judgment exclusively concerning the three accused. Delivering the verdict, President of the Court of Appeal Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne opted to acquit the three accused of all charges mentioned in the indictment.  However, Justice Sampath Abeykoon with concurrence from Justice R. Gurusinghe, held in his judgment that there was no justification to intervene in the conviction and sentence delivered by the Colombo High Court Judge. Thus, the Court of Appeal dismissed the appeals filed by the three accused. Despite their absence during the High Court trial, the three accused were represented by their Counsel in accordance with the Code of Criminal Procedure Act. Senior Deputy Solicitor General Shanil Kularatne represented the Attorney General, while the accused appellants were represented by Rienzie Arsecularatne PC, Kapila Waidyaratne PC, Zuhair PC, and Counsel Mahendra Kumarasinghe. The offences in question were alleged to have occurred between 15 November 2002 and 15 December 2004. The three accused were sentenced by the Colombo High Court on 26 September 2014, to 20 years of Rigorous Imprisonment with fines. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Eye hospital doctors on one-day token strike
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors at the National Eye Hospital in Colombo will go on a one-day token strike today (14), demanding immediate action against the hospital’s Administrative Officer who was allegedly hampering patient care services.  The token strike will commence at 8:00 a.m. Ceylon Today learns that these doctors alleged the Administrative Officer was using the Hospital Ambulance for her personal trips whilst patients were kept waiting till she finished her work.  They also alleged the Administrative Officer of encouraging Health Assistants (minor employees) to solicit bribes from patients. She has allegedly turned a blind eye to health assistants who engage in drug peddling as well.  The Director and Deputy Director of the National Eye Hospital have appealed to the Health Ministry and the Director General of Health Services to take urgent action against the Administrative Officer but to no avail as her husband had allegedly been on her personal staff at one time.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President says adhering to present trajectory only way
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe asserted that adhering to the present course and bolstering the nation’s economy is the sole means of lifting the conditions imposed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Sri Lanka.  During a special address in Parliament yesterday (13), regarding the IMF Executive Board’s completion of the first review under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) arrangement for Sri Lanka on 13 December morning, Wickremesinghe conveyed his optimism, noting the IMF now acknowledges Sri Lanka’s decisive measures to avert financial collapse. He reflected on the challenges faced upon assuming leadership of a financially distressed country the previous year, emphasising that few leaders were willing to undertake such a responsibility. Despite facing scepticism and mockery, he accepted the challenge with determination and dedication, supported by both MPs and the public. Wickremesinghe underscored the progress made, citing a reduction in inflation from 70 per cent to 1.5 per cent and the stabilisation of the rupee at Rs 325 – Rs 330 per dollar. He emphasised the essential elements of the chosen path, including access to IMF assistance and effective debt restructuring, which yielded positive outcomes. The President pointed out that with the approval of the second tranche from the IMF, the country stands to benefit significantly, including receiving USD 150 million from the World Bank for deposit insurance, fortifying the financial sector. He addressed concerns about imposed taxes, acknowledging the hardships faced by a segment of society and clarifying that the Government had no alternative.  Wickremesinghe dismissed the notion of imposing conditions on the IMF once in power, dismissing such claims as “childish stories” propagated by those with limited economic understanding. He concluded by affirming that escaping the IMF’s conditions is contingent on persisting in the present trajectory and constructing a robust economy within these parameters.

title: Sajith tells House he would re-negotiate IMF deal
author: Author not found
Content: Under a prospective Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Government, there are plans to revisit and renegotiate the International Monetary Fund (IMF) deal, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa claimed in Parliament yesterday (13).  Premadasa said he intended to strike a revised agreement with the IMF, aiming to alleviate any undue burden on the public. “We are committed to renegotiating the terms of the IMF deal,” Premadasa said, addressing a query from State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe about the SJB’s stance on seeking support from the IMF. In response to Premadasa’s claim, Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva said  international entities such as the IMF, World Bank and other organisations would never alter their policies and programmes based on individual characteristics and language proficiency. The minister said, “The public must judge whether the Opposition Leader is lacking awareness of economic theories, analysis, and the operations of international organisations, possesses the qualifications to hold the position.  The IMF, World Bank, and international organisations will not alter their policies and programmes based on someone’s appearance or language proficiency. If he believes otherwise, it is a misguided perspective.” BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Unit set up to probe religious offences made on social media
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the growing concerns over religious offences propagated on social media networks, a dedicated unit has been set up to investigate such incidents, Sri Lanka Police said yesterday (13).  The initiative follows the directives given by Acting Inspector General of Police (IGP) Deshabandu Tennakoon. Police Spokesperson SSP Nihal Thalduwa said, “The Acting IGP has issued orders to the Computer Crime Investigation Division (CCID) to set up a specialised unit to receive and investigate complaints related to religious offences committed through social media networks.” Consequently, a distinct unit within the CCID has been formed to specifically address complaints pertaining to insults against religions. The aim is to ensure a focused and efficient response to such offences. To facilitate reporting, the public is encouraged to notify the newly established unit by calling the hotline at 0112 300 637. Complaints could also be submitted via fax at 0112 381 045 or emailed to [email protected]. The authorities emphasise that complaints can be submitted through any of these channels to enhance accessibility and encourage community involvement in addressing these offences, SSP Thalduwa said.

title: Pre-Trial Conference fixed for 29 Jan 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court (CHC) Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday dismissed the initial objections raised by the Defence, pertaining to the bribery case, filed against MP Wimal Weerawansa. The Judge mentioned that as stipulated in the indictments, the points raised such as the expiry of one year duration, where the accused is alleged to have amassed his illegal wealth and being a public servant needs to be proved to Court beyond reasonable doubt following the conduct of a due trial proceeding. Accordingly Judge Marasinghe decided to hear the case and fixed its Pre-Trial Conference (PTC) to 29 January 2024. CIABOC has charged the ex-Minister before the High Court for having accrued profits exceeding Rs 75 million, while functioning as a Cabinet Minister, from 1 January, 2010 to 31 December, 2014 and for flouting provisions of the Bribery Act. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: STF to withdraw from expressway duties – Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles announced, yesterday (13), that a decision has been made to withdraw Special Task Force (STF) personnel from expressway duties due to their underutilisation.  Speaking in Parliament, he disclosed that STF personnel had been employed on expressways primarily in cases of fires and accidents, totalling only 164 instances over a span of 330 days. Minister Alles emphasised that the deployment of STF personnel on expressway duties costs the State approximately Rs 260 million. He further stated that these personnel would now be reassigned to combat the drug menace in the country, citing a need for their expertise in addressing the issue. In response to a question posed by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa regarding the potential removal of STF personnel from expressway duties, Minister Alles highlighted the substantial vacancies within the STF, totalling 2,300 positions. He stressed the importance of utilising the STF in the fight against the drug trade. The Minister explained that STF personnel were initially assigned to expressway duties in 2011 as an interim measure when the quotation from the Fire Brigade for such duties was deemed excessive. He noted that this arrangement has been in place since then. Minister Alles assured that regular Police will continue their duties on expressways, while emphasising that, in most countries, fire and rescue operations are handled by the Fire Brigade. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Historic COP28 deal agrees to ‘transition away’ from fossil fuels
author: Author not found
Content: Delegates at the United Nations COP28 climate talks in Dubai have agreed to a deal that would, for the first time, push nations to transition away from fossil fuels to avert the worst effects of climate change. COP28 President Sultan al-Jaber hailed the deal, approved by almost 200 countries on Wednesday, as a “historic package” of measures that offers a “robust plan” to keep the target of capping global temperatures at 1.5C above pre-industrial levels, within reach. “We have language on fossil fuel in our final agreement for the first time ever,” said al-Jaber, CEO of the United Arab Emirates’ (UAE) oil company. Officials from around the globe suggested the deal is an important step towards ending the use of fossil fuels. US climate envoy John Kerry said both the United States and China intend to update their long-term climate strategies, hailing the agreement as one which “sends very strong messages to the world”. However, the deal doesn’t go so far as to seek a “phase-out” of fossil fuels, for which more than 100 nations had pleaded. Rather, it calls for “transitioning away from fossil fuels in energy systems, in a just, orderly and equitable manner, accelerating action in this critical decade”. That transition would be in a way that gets the world to net zero greenhouse gas emissions in 2050 and follows the dictates of climate science. Earlier on Wednesday, the latest draft of the document calling on the world to wean itself off planet-warming fossil fuels was discussed by delegates after an outcry over a previous proposal forced the summit, which was meant to end on Tuesday, to be extended. The previous draft offered a list of options that “could” be taken to combat the dangerous heating of the planet, while the final version explicitly “calls on” all nations to contribute through a series of actions. After the deal was approved on Wednesday, French Energy Minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher called it “a victory for multilateralism and climate diplomacy”. “Now we need to put in place a plan to exit fossil fuels and we will be attentive to this,” she added. Earlier, Norway’s minister for climate and the environment, Espen Barth Eide, said “It is the first time that the world unites around such a clear text on the need to transition away from fossil fuels … It has been the elephant in the room – at last, we address it head-on. This is the outcome of extremely many conversations and intense diplomacy.” Intensive negotiations continued well into the small hours of Wednesday morning after the conference presidency’s initial document angered many countries by avoiding decisive calls for action on fossil fuels, the major driver of global heating. The UAE-led presidency presented delegates with a new central document – called the global stocktake – just after sunrise. (Al Jazeera)

title: Indian Envoy makes farewell call on Archbishop, Premier
author: Author not found
Content: Indian High Commissioner in Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay, paid a farewell call on Colombo Archbishop His Eminence Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith yesterday (13) as he is departing the country after completing his tenure in Sri Lanka. The High Commissioner also visited Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena.

title: Budget 2024 passed with 122 votes
author: Author not found
Content: The Third Reading of the Appropriation Bill (Budget) for the financial year 2024 was passed yesterday (13) in Parliament with a majority of 41 votes.  At approximately 6.40 p.m., the vote for the Third Reading took place, resulting in 122 votes in favour of the Budget and 81 votes against it. Thamil Makkal Thesiya Kuttani (TMTK) MP C.V. Wigneswaran abstained from voting.  President Ranil Wickremesinghe in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, presented the Appropriation Bill for the year 2024, also known as the ‘Budget Speech,’ on 13 November.  Subsequently, from 14 – 21 November, the Second Reading debate on the Appropriation Bill unfolded over seven days, excluding Sundays. The Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill was successfully passed in Parliament on 21 November, securing a majority of 45 votes. Following this, the Committee Stage debate on the Appropriation Bill 2024 spanned 19 days from 11 November, excluding Sundays.

title: St. Anthony’s Church Kochchikade Head Priest testifies
author: Author not found
Content: The Head Priest of the St. Anthony’s Church at Kochchikade Jude Fernando, yesterday (13) testified before the Colombo High Court Trial-at-Bar, which is presiding over the Easter Sunday case filed against 25 accused, including Noufer Moulavi. They have been charged before the High Court for conspiring to set off bombs, targeting Catholic Churches and star-class hotels in Colombo and its suburbs, on Easter Sunday (21 April), four years ago. The case was heard, before the Trial-at-Bar, consisting of Judges Damith Thotawatta, Amal Ranaraja and Navaratne Marasinghe. The Priest has been named as the 15th witness to the Prosecution, had functioned as the head of the said Church, at the time of the Easter Sunday blasts, in 2019. Evidence was led by Senior State Counsel Shanthi Jagodaarachchi. All accused including the ninth defendant in the case, Mohamad Jawajith alias Sadeeq Mowlavi, were produced in Court and the latter granted approval to take the ninth accused back to Prison due a sudden illness he developed. The Prosecution was represented by lawyers, including ASG Haripriya Jayasundera and Deputy Solicitor General Sudarshana de Silva, while Neville Abeyratne PC, appeared for the aggrieved party. The Attorney General has leveled 23,270 charges, against the 25 accused, including Noufer Moulavi, before the High Court, while the 17th accused in the case passed away while being incarcerated. BY Hansi Nanayakkara
