title: Historic COP28 deal agrees to ‘transition away’ from fossil fuels
author: Author not found
Content: Delegates at the United Nations COP28 climate talks in Dubai have agreed to a deal that would, for the first time, push nations to transition away from fossil fuels to avert the worst effects of climate change. COP28 President Sultan al-Jaber hailed the deal, approved by almost 200 countries on Wednesday, as a “historic package” of measures that offers a “robust plan” to keep the target of capping global temperatures at 1.5C above pre-industrial levels, within reach. “We have language on fossil fuel in our final agreement for the first time ever,” said al-Jaber, CEO of the United Arab Emirates’ (UAE) oil company. Officials from around the globe suggested the deal is an important step towards ending the use of fossil fuels. US climate envoy John Kerry said both the United States and China intend to update their long-term climate strategies, hailing the agreement as one which “sends very strong messages to the world”. However, the deal doesn’t go so far as to seek a “phase-out” of fossil fuels, for which more than 100 nations had pleaded. Rather, it calls for “transitioning away from fossil fuels in energy systems, in a just, orderly and equitable manner, accelerating action in this critical decade”. That transition would be in a way that gets the world to net zero greenhouse gas emissions in 2050 and follows the dictates of climate science. Earlier on Wednesday, the latest draft of the document calling on the world to wean itself off planet-warming fossil fuels was discussed by delegates after an outcry over a previous proposal forced the summit, which was meant to end on Tuesday, to be extended. The previous draft offered a list of options that “could” be taken to combat the dangerous heating of the planet, while the final version explicitly “calls on” all nations to contribute through a series of actions. After the deal was approved on Wednesday, French Energy Minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher called it “a victory for multilateralism and climate diplomacy”. “Now we need to put in place a plan to exit fossil fuels and we will be attentive to this,” she added. Earlier, Norway’s minister for climate and the environment, Espen Barth Eide, said “It is the first time that the world unites around such a clear text on the need to transition away from fossil fuels … It has been the elephant in the room – at last, we address it head-on. This is the outcome of extremely many conversations and intense diplomacy.” Intensive negotiations continued well into the small hours of Wednesday morning after the conference presidency’s initial document angered many countries by avoiding decisive calls for action on fossil fuels, the major driver of global heating. The UAE-led presidency presented delegates with a new central document – called the global stocktake – just after sunrise. (Al Jazeera)

title: Indian Envoy makes farewell call on Archbishop, Premier
author: Author not found
Content: Indian High Commissioner in Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay, paid a farewell call on Colombo Archbishop His Eminence Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith yesterday (13) as he is departing the country after completing his tenure in Sri Lanka. The High Commissioner also visited Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena.

title: Budget 2024 passed with 122 votes
author: Author not found
Content: The Third Reading of the Appropriation Bill (Budget) for the financial year 2024 was passed yesterday (13) in Parliament with a majority of 41 votes.  At approximately 6.40 p.m., the vote for the Third Reading took place, resulting in 122 votes in favour of the Budget and 81 votes against it. Thamil Makkal Thesiya Kuttani (TMTK) MP C.V. Wigneswaran abstained from voting.  President Ranil Wickremesinghe in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, presented the Appropriation Bill for the year 2024, also known as the ‘Budget Speech,’ on 13 November.  Subsequently, from 14 – 21 November, the Second Reading debate on the Appropriation Bill unfolded over seven days, excluding Sundays. The Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill was successfully passed in Parliament on 21 November, securing a majority of 45 votes. Following this, the Committee Stage debate on the Appropriation Bill 2024 spanned 19 days from 11 November, excluding Sundays.

title: Speaker endorses 2024 Appropriation Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, on Wednesday (13), endorsed the certificate on the Appropriation Bill for 2024, which was passed in Parliament on 12 December. Also, the Value Added Tax (Amendment) and Finance Bills passed in Parliament on 11 December were certified by the Speaker on Wednesday (13). The said Bills will come into effect as the Value Added Tax (Amendment) Act No. 32 of 2023, the Finance Act No. 33 of 2023 and the Appropriation Act No. 34 of 2023.

title: Suwa Seriya adopts MR, AI technology in Asia first
author: Author not found
Content: Suwa Seriya has become the first ambulance service in Asia to adopt Mixed Reality (MR) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology in pre-hospital care emergency management.  The groundbreaking ‘Connected Ambulance’ initiative is expected to further strengthen Suwa Seriya’s mission to save lives.    The latest technological innovation establishes a fully -connected platform seamlessly linking the Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs), Emergency Physician at the Emergency Command and Control Centre (ECCC) with the existing Emergency Dispatch Management system and the rest of the Operations Management systems at 1990 Suwa Seriya. Speaking at an event to launch the platform, pioneer of the free -Ambulance Service, MP Harsha de Silva extended his gratitude to Wavenet in partnership with Microsoft for making this technological feat possible. “This initiative will be launched in Colombo and Jaffna Districts as a pilot project initially, following which it will be expanded islandwide,” de Silva said. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: University education to ensure every graduate secures employment –  President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe was the chief guest at the 2023 graduation ceremony of the National Institute of Business Studies (NSBM Green University). As part of the ceremony, the President inaugurated a new stadium and awarded six students who demonstrated outstanding skills among the 176 graduates. In a celebratory gesture, NSBM Green University Vice Chancellor E. A. Weerasinghe presented a collection of valuable books to President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Addressing the gathering, President Wickremesinghe said,”We aim to revolutionise university education to ensure that every graduate secures employment. Currently, the admission of students to government universities is restricted due to logistical challenges. However, other nations have effectively addressed this issue, aligning with the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights, which asserts the right of everyone to access education. In line with this, governments and private entities worldwide have established universities. As Sri Lanka, we are now prepared to undertake this task. Our goal is to significantly increase the number of universities in the country, potentially doubling or tripling their current count. Simultaneously, leveraging new technology allows students in Sri Lanka the opportunity to earn degrees from foreign universities without leaving the country. We envision Sri Lanka becoming a hub for universities. Additionally, we aspire to complete the task of imparting English proficiency to both school and university students by 2030. Furthermore, we seek to equip students in our country with knowledge of additional languages. In our efforts, we plan to establish vocational training colleges by merging existing vocational training institutes. To enhance employability, we are introducing job-oriented curricula for these courses. Encouragingly, the private sector has pledged support for these initiatives, and we anticipate implementing this programme by the coming year. After that, it is our expectation to bring the necessary laws to reorganise the entire education system in this country. Thus, it should be said that our aim is to start the program of using university education and vocational training education for the development of this country from next year, as knowledge is needed to develop the country. A new education system should be created for that. We should act as a middle income country. We have to decide whether we will remain in this state forever, or whether we will become a high income economy. We all want to go on that journey. So we leave it to education to build the necessary human resources”. Nihal Ranasinghe, Secretary of the Ministry of Education, NSBM Green University Vice Chancellor E. A. Weerasinghe, Deputy Vice-Chancellor Professor Chaminda Ratnayake, Deans and academic staff and parents of graduands participated in this event.

title: FAM Tour of Bangladeshi Tour Operators Strengthens Tourism Cooperation
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of Sri Lanka in Dhaka, with the assistance of the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB), organised a Familiarisation (FAM) tour for a group of six identified tour operators from Bangladesh who are keen to promote Sri Lanka as a viable and most sought after tourism destination. As part of the series of tourism promotional programmes, the eight-day tour to Sri Lanka, was organised from 1-8 December.  During their 8-day stay in Sri Lanka, the tour operators visited several iconic and historically important sites, including the Temple of the Tooth Relic, tea plantations,  a tea factory in Nuwara Eliya, Ella, Yala National Park, Galle, and a few locations in Colombo.   The visiting delegates had B2B meetings with around 50 tour operators and hoteliers in Sri Lanka and discussed the way forward for further collaboration of promoting Sri Lanka as a preferred travel destination among Bangladesh travellers.  The High Commission of Sri Lanka will continue its cooperation and interaction with the tour operators of Bangladesh by arranging various promotional programmes including FAM tours to attract more Bangladeshi tourists to Sri Lanka, targeting its highly potential outbound tourism market.

title: Student evaluation will not be limited to exams – Edu Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education, Susil Premajayantha said several major changes are to be made in the existing education system from the coming year, and it is expected to make the 5th grade scholarship examination simpler, where priority will be given to measuring the literacy and numeracy skills of the students. The Minister was participating in a ceremony held at the Ministry of Education premises to evaluate students who obtained high marks at the Grade Five scholarship examination held in 2023 and students who faced the GCE Examination in 2022. The Minister said in future, students will not be evaluated on getting 100% marks in examinations. The minister also pointed out that students should get 30% marks in the scholarship exam as well as 30% marks should obtained in evaluations conducted in the classroom in the 4th and 5th grades, and for this the continuous attendance of students should be maintained. The Minister said some parents may criticise that teachers will be biased, but there is no room for such situations, and above all, it is important to build a clear trust in teachers between parents and students. The minister also pointed out that school boards monitor how students are evaluated in classrooms in schools. Even in Finland, which is recognised as a country with the best education, only classroom-level evaluations are used in schools up to the 9th grade, and school students in that country are not evaluated through exams.  Here, 20 students who scored high marks in the entire island in the GCE General Examination held in 2022 and 20 students who scored high marks in the Grade Five scholarship examination were evaluated. Abans Institute contributed generously to provide laptops and tablets to winning students.

title: Budget 2024 will transform bankrupt economy – Rangebandara
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara claimed the Budget 2024 will be a boon to transform the bankrupt economy into a developed one as sufficient allocations have been made to every sector, taking its importance into consideration. Rangebandara also praised that this was possible only because a well-experienced  Leader like President Ranil Wickremesinghe who is the Finance Minister managed the Budget. The General Secretary said he was able to fix the burning economic crisis to a significant level finding solutions to burning issues one-by-one by relaxing the livelihood issues of the people in a short span of just one year. While addressing the media at Sirikotha, Rangebandara said that the Budget 2024 will be helpful to wipe out the misconception about Sri Lanka as a bankrupt nation in the presence of the rest of the world. “The allocations for social security and welfare have been increased from Rs 60 billion to  Rs 200 billion, it is more than three-times larger than allocations made in the last budget. President Wickremesinghe has allocated  Rs 30 billion to develop small and medium-scale enterprises this year, realising the truth that it is also one of the most important sectors that moot the economic advancement of the country. Borrowing facilities are available to small and medium entrepreneurs at a low and affordable interest rate of 4 per cent,” Rangebandara further said. He said that budget arrangements have been made to provide permanent deeds to a total of two million to lands where they are living without any ownership, though they are benefiting from it. Government has made arrangements to provide them with permanent deeds under the land ownership programme on Independence Day on 4 February 2024. further, the people living in rented houses in densely populated urban areas will be made owners of these houses and need not pay huge sums as rent while making arrangements to construct a house. Providing land ownership to estate workers acknowledging their 200-year service to the economy of this country was also proposed in the Budget, Rangebandara said. President Wickremesinghe has made a Budget proposal to establish four national universities in addition to the existing universities to expand higher -education facilities to educate young men and women in Sri Lanka, Rangebandara said. Arrangements have been made in the Budget to resume the food and accommodation allowance that had been suspended during the previous regime. Suraksha students’ insurance scheme that was introduced during the United National Front (UNF) Government and suspended during the previous government will be resumed from 2024. Sufficient allocations have been made in the Budget for it, Rangebandara added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Pregnant women face high rates of Intimate-Partner Violence
author: Author not found
Content: In a startling revelation, Consultant Community Physician Dr. Nethanjali Mapitigama, the representative of the Family Health Bureau (FHB) at the Ministry of Health, yesterday (12), underlined significant incidents of intimate partner violence (IPV) during pregnancy among women in Sri Lanka.  Dr. Mapitigama drew attention to this distressing reality by presenting extensive data, revealing that over 20,000 women have fallen victim to various forms of atrocities and violence in the current year alone. This was disclosed during a workshop held in Colombo, dedicated to discussing the contents of the multi-sectoral National Action Plan addressing Sexual and Gender-Based Violence against Women (SGBV). Dr. Mapitigama’s insights cast light on the urgent need for comprehensive action in addressing this critical issue. Speaking to Ceylon Today on a separate occasion, Dr. Mapitigama referenced a study conducted in 2022 in the Colombo and Badulla Districts. The study highlighted that 38.6 per cent of women reported experiencing some form of violence during their cohabitation with a partner, and notably, 15.9 per cent of them were pregnant women. This points to the pressing need for proactive measures to address and prevent gender-based violence, particularly during the vulnerable period of pregnancy. In 2022, a total of 10,871 individuals visited ‘Mithuru Piyasa’ counselling centres set up by the Ministry of Health nationwide, with 796 of them being pregnant women, accounting for 7.3 per cent of the total visits, Dr. Mapitigama said.  She remarked, “In Sri Lankan culture, a pregnant woman is considered a symbol of prosperity. Consequently, there is a natural assumption that she is well taken care of by her partner, family and the community as a whole, particularly by her partner. However, the reality is that many women endure harassment and violence from their partners during their pregnancy, and as a society, we often fail to openly discuss this issue. There is a pervasive assumption that everything is fine with pregnant women, when in fact, the challenges they face are often hidden from public awareness.” Speaking further, Dr. Mapitigama emphasised that global studies have indicated a significant trend regarding the onset of IPV faced by women. Astonishingly, a substantial 30 per cent of respondents reported that the commencement of such harassment occurred during pregnancy.  By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Ceylon Today’s Sulochana is ‘Journalist of the Year 2022’
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Today bagged the main award  ‘The Mervyn De Silva Journalist of the Year 2022’ at the most coveted awards ceremony of the year for Print Journalism in the country, the Journalism Awards for Excellence, organised by the Sri Lanka Press Institute together with the Editors’ Guild of Sri Lanka. Further, the newspaper won another main award and a merit as well. At the 24th edition of the most anticipated Awards night, held at the Mount Lavinia Hotel yesterday (12), Ceylon Today Deputy Editor Sulochana Ramiah Mohan won the Journalist of the Year, Deputy Features Editor Dilshani Palugaswewa won the award for the B.A. Siriwardene Columnist of the Year 2022 (English) and Amitha Thennakoon won Photojournalist of the Year (merit).  Mithun Jayawardhana of Ceylon Today’s sister paper Mawbima won merit for Best Healthcare and Medical Reporter of the Year (Sinhala) while Pramesh Wickramasinghe  won the Business Journalist of the year (Sinhala).

title: Singaporean Premier appreciates resolve to deepen bilateral relations
author: Author not found
Content: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has expressed sincere appreciation for the positive outcomes arising from the fruitful discussions held with President Ranil Wickremesinghe in August, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said.  According to the PMD, Premier Lee conveyed his sentiments through letter addressed to President Wickremesinghe. In the correspondence, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong affirmed his commitment to strengthening ties between Singapore and Sri Lanka, encompassing political, economic, and people-to-people dimensions. This dedication signifies a mutual resolve to deepen the bilateral relationship for the benefit of both nations. While extending his warm wishes, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong conveyed hopes for President Wickremesinghe’s continued good health and success in guiding the nation’s progress. The Singaporean Prime Minister also expressed eagerness and anticipation about visiting Sri Lanka in the near future, underscoring the commitment to sustaining and advancing diplomatic ties between the two countries, the PMD said.

title: 18% VAT hike won’t impact IT sector – President
author: Author not found
Content: The newly imposed Value Added Tax (VAT) of up to 18 per cent on Sri Lanka’s IT sector will not pose a burden on the industry, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said yesterday (12) in Parliament.  Addressing concerns within the sector about the elevated tax rates, President Wickremesinghe drew a parallel with India, where the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate for various IT software supply services and products is set at 18 per cent. He clarified that the revenue generated from the increased VAT would be reinvested in the sector, with Rs 1.5 billion allocated for AI research and an additional Rs 8 billion for broader technological research. The President highlighted that the increased tax would not adversely affect the IT industry, given its export-oriented nature. Emphasising that the export of IT services is considered a zero-rated supply, the President said the IT services provided to individuals outside Sri Lanka, with payments in foreign currency, are exempt from income tax. Stressing the need for the decision to increase VAT to apply uniformly across all sectors without exceptions, he cited comparable practices in other countries. Highlighting the Government’s commitment to supporting research initiatives, the President affirmed that the focus is shifting toward facilitating research and development in the IT sector. He expressed confidence that despite the VAT increase, the industry would thrive in Sri Lanka, fostering digitalisation and expansion over the next two to three years. President Wickremesinghe outlined a collaborative approach, leveraging partnerships with India to propel the growth of the entire digital sector, despite the 18 per cent VAT imposition. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Kanchana proposes to remove outdated power plants from Grid
author: Author not found
Content: Outdated power plants must be removed from the grid and the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) must undergo a comprehensive restructuring, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera asserted.  The Minister said this during a discussion held with ministry officials, Opposition MPs and energy experts at the Ministry premises yesterday (12).  The discussion aimed at allowing experts and other interested parties to provide suggestions to fix electricity tariffs and propose measures to lower them. Addressing the recent decision by the Government and the National Treasury to stop providing subsidies to the CEB, the Minister said these measures were implemented following recommendations from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to reduce government spending. He also emphasised that the restructuring process might involve scrutinising the present number of CEB employees and their efficiency. The Minister highlighted that although a Cabinet decision earlier this year called for revising tariffs twice a year, the Ministry had to conduct an ad-hoc revision of prices in October due to climate forecasts from the Department of Meteorology. Minister Wijesekera stated that, based on data from the Meteorology Department, Sri Lanka would experience drought from 15 November 2023 to early February 2024. However, contrary to the forecast, Sri Lanka has been witnessing heavy rainfall islandwide, resulting in a healthy level of hydro storage for the near future. The Minister also said the decrease in the cost of coal in the global market would benefit Sri Lanka. Further, the Minister added that the Government plans to provide relief to the public by revising tariffs in January 2024 if possible. Minister Wijesekera urged the experts and officials present to submit their suggestions and ideas to the Ministry of Energy in the coming days to achieve this goal. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Protest urging salary hike for private sector in Averiwatta
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was staged in Averiwatta town, Katunayake yesterday (12)  demanding a salary increase from Budget 2024 for private sector employees, including the 248,000 employees working in 14 Free Trade Zones (FTZ) across the country.  The event was jointly organised by the Free Trade Zone Employees’ National Centre and the Inter-Company Employees’ Union. Gamini Ratnayake, Vice President of the Inter-Company Employees’ Union and Convener of the Trade Zone Employees’ National Centre said, “Although a salary increase has been announced for government employees in this year’s budget, there has only been a request for a salary hike for all private sector employees, including those in free trade zones,” he said. By T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Poet Ahnaf acquitted of extremism charges
author: Author not found
Content: Poet and educator Ahnaf Jazeem, who was detained for over 18 months under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), was acquitted of the charges brought against him by the Puttalam High Court.  Jazeem was arrested in May 2020 in connection with accusations of extremism linked to his book ‘Navarasam.’ Under the PTA, he faced allegations of promoting extremism and violence among children, as well as abetting Muslim extremism through his literary work. In November 2020, Jazeem was formally charged in the Puttalam High Court for allegedly delivering extremist speeches to students at the School of Excellence where he taught. After nearly 19 months of detention, he was granted bail in December 2021 on strict conditions. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Cabinet nod to probe century-old killing of Edward Henry Pedris
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved forming a three-member committee to investigate the century-old killing of Edward Henry Pedris.  The committee is mandated to gather information related to Pedris’ death, scrutinise pertinent details and submit a comprehensive report with recommendations to Cabinet to bring justice to his memory. Pedris, aged 27 at the time, faced a military court and was convicted of treason by the British colonial administration in Sri Lanka. The charges against him included rioting and treason against the government, resulting in a death sentence in 1915, despite all appeals. Edward Henry Pedris’ body was subsequently cremated at an undisclosed location following the procedures prescribed for the cremation of a convicted criminal under martial law. However, it later came to light that his death was orchestrated by senior officials governing the country at that time. The Cabinet granted approval for the President’s proposal to establish a three-member committee, chaired by retired Supreme Court Judge Anil Gunarathna, to investigate the circumstances surrounding Edward Henry Pedris’ killing. Edward Henry Pedris, a Ceylonese militia officer and a prominent socialite, was executed for treason during the 1915 Sinhalese-Muslim riots by the 17th Punjab Regiment of the British Indian Army under martial law. His expedited conviction through a three-day Field General Court Martial, bypassing the local legal system, was perceived as unjust by the local population and served as a warning to other leaders in the region, according to Sri Lankan historical accounts.

title: Stockpiling wheat flour during ban leads to undue monopoly
author: Author not found
Content: The Government’s ban on the import of wheat flour for all companies, with the notable exception of Prima and Serendib has led to significant stockpiles of wheat flour by these two companies during the ban leading to an undue monopoly. It came to light during the recent meeting of the Committee on Ways and Means of Parliament as the ban was lifted, Prima and Serendib reportedly profited substantially by implementing a tax of Rs 16 per kg on wheat flour. The committee also discussed the unfair profits earned by companies through the increase in the special commodity tax for sugar from 25 cents to Rs 50, demanding immediate action to collect prescribed taxes related to these instances. Also, the committee directed officials of the Excise Department to suspend the liquor licence of a manufacturing company that failed to pay the due tax installment, in accordance with the installment plan for clearing arrears of excise duty. Additionally, the committee questioned the delay in receiving the report from the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) regarding taxpayers with arrears of Rs 100 million or more, as mandated on 24 July 2023. Despite two requests during committee meetings, the IRD has not yet provided the required report. The committee chair MP Patali Champika Ranawaka revealed that the IRD officials sought the Attorney General’s opinion on the matter, instructing them to submit the list to the committee by 31 December 2023. Expressing displeasure over the non-compliance with recommendations related to the IRD, the committee emphasised the importance of timely implementation.  To recover arrears from taxpayers evading taxes, the committee recommended the preparation of a tax collection plan targeting the recoverable amount of Rs 173 billion. The committee urged the Ministry of Finance and the IRD to collaboratively devise and implement this plan before 31 December. Among the 39 recommendations made to the Excise Department, the committee inquired about the non-implementation of the recommendation to increase the licence renewal fee to a minimum of 10 million rupees. The committee also questioned the failure to provide a list of individuals and companies holding more than one liquor license in a district, as previously ordered. Excise Department officials claimed their data system showed no such instances, prompting the committee to request written confirmation. The committee was informed that there are currently 46 toddy production plants, and a mobile app has been introduced to monitor and calculate their daily production. The committee chair instructed the officers to present the mobile app during the next meeting. Highlighting the need for artificial intelligence (AI) integration into customs scanners, the committee recommended preparing a proposal under a public-private joint project model with the guidance of IT consultants from the Ministry of Finance. Finally, the committee discussed the follow-up on Disaster Management, Welfare Benefit Scheme, and Social Services Department’s survey involving urban beggars. Officials from various departments, including the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Defence, Inland Revenue Department, Excise Department, Sri Lanka Customs, and the Welfare Benefits Board, were summoned for the meeting. MPs of Parliament Ashok Abeysinghe, Sanjeeva Edirimanna, Ishaq Rahman, and Sudath Manjula were also present. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Rs 1.8M fine each imposed on Sakvithi and ex-spouse
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle imposed fines of Rs 1.8 million each on tuition master Sakvithi Ranasinghe and his ex-spouse, Kumari Anuradini, yesterday (12) when the duo pleaded guilty to violating provisions of the Banking Act.  The charges included maintaining an illegal financial institution, conspiracy and aiding and abetting to commit fraud. The Court also issued a warning that if the two accused fail to pay the imposed fines, they may face prison terms extending up to 48 months. During the proceedings, Jayantha Weerasinghe PC, representing the first accused, Ranasinghe, informed Judge Balalle that the defence aimed to expedite the trial proceedings. He explained that his client had agreed to pay a monthly sum of Rs 5 million to depositors associated with a similar but different case filed against him before the High Court. Considering these submissions, Court levied the aforementioned fines on the two accused. The Attorney General had charged the two accused before the High Court for the offences committed from 1 November 2006 to 31 December 2008. In July this year, the former English tutor and his ex-wife admitted guilt to financial fraud charges. The accusations centred on their operation of an unauthorised financial institution, wherein they were alleged to have misused deposits exceeding Rs 164 million obtained from the public. The misappropriation involved funds totaling Rs 164,185,000, derived from the deposits of their illicit financial entity, ‘S.R. Property Sharing Investment (Pvt) Ltd, during the period from 1 January  2006, to 3 September 2008. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Cargills Village to Home : 23rd edition generates Rs 1M for local entrepreneurs
author: Author not found
Content: The 23rd edition of Cargills Village to Home was held on the 2 and 3 December at Cargills Food City Kandana. Participating SMEs earned an income of approximately Rs 1 million,  highlighting the positive  effects of the Cargills Group ecosystem which attracts thousands of customers daily to its stores across the country, Cargills said.  The event showcased a diverse array of products, creating a vibrant shopping experience for customers. From traditional handicraft to homemade food products, the event provided an opportunity for customers to explore and support local entrepreneurs, while enjoying high-quality goods, it added.  Initiated in 2020, during the pandemic, the Village to Home programme aimed to address the challenges faced by SMEs who had lost access to markets, with a broader vision to foster the development of small entrepreneurs. Cargills has continued the programme in the aftermath of the pandemic, given the programme’s growing popularity among SMEs and customers. Thus far, the company has created opportunities for over 900 SMEs to showcase their products ,Cargills further added.  Some entrepreneurs have successfully expanded their markets beyond Sri Lanka, as a result of the visibility gained through the Cargills Village to Home Programme. With the expertise of the Village to Home technical team, these entrepreneurs have strengthened their businesses. As an extension of the programme, selected SMEs are also granted dedicated gondolas inside Cargills Retail Stores to showcase their products. This opportunity allows SMEs to reach an even wider customer base, helping them earn a consistent income throughout the year, Cargills said.  Furthermore, the Cargills Bank plays a pivotal role by providing financial support to these entrepreneurs. Cargills provides the monthly trade stalls free of charge  bearing all expenses associated with the programme.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: GMCA celebrates 60th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: The Galle Muslim Cultural Association (GMCA) celebrated its 60th Anniversary at Marine Grand Banquet Hall on 9 December 2023. The GMCA fondly remembered as “ASSO” by people of Galle is an organisation incorporated by ACT of Parliament in 1976. Al-Haj Hanif Yusoof Group CEO and Patron of GMCA, Al-Haj Elliyas Karim Chairman EAM Maliban Group, distinguished guests, founders and its members were present. The GMCA is a non- profit organisation established in 1963 to develop religious, cultural, educational and intercommunal harmony activities. GMCA managers the first Ahadiyya School established in Sri Lanka , providing scholarships to underprivileged children to pursue their studies and providing school books and stationery for deserving children through its ‘Lend a Hand’ Project, celebrating the birth of Prophet Muhammed (Sal) culminating with conducting various competitions among school children of the Southern Province, conducting hadees majlis for 11 days during the month of Rabi-Ul Awwal, providing assistance to needy families during Ramazan through its ‘Share and Care’ Programme, fostering inter faith activities and promoting unity and understanding among all communities. GMCA has continued its activities smoothly with dedication and commitment by its membership despite the many challenges it faced and has received many accolades from prominent figures commending its activities over the last six decades. GMCA members want to move forward with bigger goals of developing educational activities, poverty alleviation and intercommunal harmony.

title: National launch of the 2024 Asia-Pacific Human Development Report in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The narrative of human development in Asia and the Pacific has been one marked by advancement, inequality, and unforeseen challenges. Against this backdrop, the launch of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) 2024 Asia-Pacific Human Development Report in November, represents a crucial step in revitalising human development amidst a complex landscape of growth. Nationally, the UNDP 2024 Asia-Pacific Human Development Report, titled ‘Making Our Future: New Directions for Human Development in Asia and the Pacific’ was launched today, under the umbrella of the flagship Colombo Development Dialogues. This report serves as a robust foundation, offering in-depth insights to comprehend the hurdles faced by marginalised communities and supporting policymakers in crafting precise and impactful strategies. Utilising the most current data, evidence, and analytical perspectives, the Regional Human Development Report (Regional HDR) offers an extensive and finely detailed evaluation of human development in Asia and the Pacific. Emphasising a proactive outlook, it urges the region to not only learn from prior achievements and established frameworks, but also to surpass traditional methodologies in order to steer human development in this dynamic era. This necessitates reevaluating approaches, a more seamless integration of human development and growth, and a heightened dedication to translating strategies into actionable results. Commenting on the report, Anura Dissanayake, Secretary to the Prime Minister in his message noted that, “As we prioritise rebuilding as a country, we also need to lay out the safety nets in the form of social protection for the most vulnerable and people who have been severely impacted by the crisis. UNDP has provided us through the Multi-dimensional Vulnerability Index and now the Regional Human Development Report evidence that can contribute to an equation that will assist us in getting the formula right to plan accordingly to ensure no one is left behind as we rebuild from the ruins of the economic crisis.” The report marks the commencement of a dialogue aimed at delving into the hurdles and prospects encountered as  Sri Lanka drives towards economic rejuvenation. This event convened key stakeholders, spanning government officials, experts, private sector representatives, civil society organisations, and international partners, fostering an inclusive platform to assess present obstacles, exchange successful methodologies, and cultivate a collective discourse. The gathering aimed to pave the way for a holistic and cooperative strategy, addressing the evolving challenges and issues impacting both the country and the wider region. Highlighting the importance of the report, Azusa Kubota, Resident Representative, UNDP in Sri Lanka said, “The newly released 2024 Regional Human Development Report for Asia and the Pacific, which includes Sri Lanka, serves as a guide to rethink development strategies. UNDP Sri Lanka proposes a framework based on policy levers and initiatives that build on our collective strengths, drawing from past experiences to chart a course towards high-quality development aligned with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.” This report comes in light of the launch of the Policy Report titled ‘Understanding Multidimensional Vulnerabilities: Impact on People of Sri Lanka’ which put forward Sri Lanka’s first-ever Multidimensional Vulnerability Index (MVI). It demonstrates the overlapping challenges faced by Sri Lanka’s population, weaving together a novel set of indicators to capture vulnerabilities beyond traditional income-based measures.  Together, the MVI and Regional HDR, stand not only as representations of challenges and aspirations but also as an urgent call to action to policymakers and influencers, for an inclusive, resilient, and prosperous future. The insights from the Regional HDR must be transformed into impactful initiatives, laying the foundation for a resilient tomorrow for Sri Lanka and the broader region.

title: Saudi Crown Prince MBS unveils Qiddiya City’s Urban Plan
author: Author not found
Content: Saudi Arabia, emerging as a preeminent global tourist destination, is undertaking extensive developmental initiatives across the Kingdom through its Vision 2030 plan. Under the visionary leadership of the crown prince and the prime minister Mohammad Bin Salman, the country has become a model nation, showcasing remarkable advancements and progress in various domains, encompassing tourism, economy, medicine, and astronomy.  In line with that, the Crown Prince unveiled the urban layout for Qiddiya City and introduced Qiddiya’s global business identity on Thursday. Qiddiya City, situated on the outskirts of Riyadh, is set to become an unparalleled destination offering limitless entertainment, sports, cultural experiences, and urban living amenities, ensuring boundless enjoyment for both residents and visitors alike. Situated a 40-minute drive from Riyadh’s City Centre, Qiddiya City boasts a striking vantage point overlooking the imposing cliffs of Tuwaiq mountains. It is envisioned as a hub featuring the inaugural gaming and e-sports district, a speed park track, golf courses, and a substantial water theme park. Qiddiya City’s development advances with contracts totalling 10 billion Saudi Riyals recently awarded. The city, spanning 360 square kilometres, will feature 60,000 buildings and accommodate more than 600,000 residents. Its groundbreaking assortment of  top-tier attractions and venues is projected to draw an estimated 48 million annual visitors. Moreover, the city will house a stadium hosting the world’s largest Olympic Museum. This concentration of diverse sports, cultural, and entertainment offerings in one location is poised to establish Qiddiya as an unparalleled global destination. Qiddiya City aims to generate more than 325,000 jobs and contribute an annual nominal GDP of 135 billion Saudi Riyal. The Crown Prince aims to transform Qiddiya into a renowned global centre for entertainment, sports, and culture, bolstering Riyadh’s economic standing worldwide and fostering the city’s development and lifestyle standards. The initiative, integral to Saudi Vision 2030, reflects a commitment to diversify the Kingdom’s economy and create abundant job opportunities, particularly for Saudi youth, thereby contributing to their growth and empowerment. Plans are underway to unveil the initial assets of Qiddiya City within the next two years. By Khalidh Rizwan

title: Athula Galketiya appointed Chairman of Airport and Aviation Services
author: Author not found
Content: On Monday, December 11, Eng. Athula Galketiya officially assumed the role of Chairman at Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Ltd. The occasion was attended by the Board of Directors of Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Ltd along with other senior officials, according to a statement. A graduate of the University of Peradeniya with a Bachelor of Science Degree in Engineering in 1987, Galketiya is a Corporate Member of the Institution of Engineers Sri Lanka and a Chartered Engineer since 1991. With over 34 years of experience in engineering and management, he is a respected and highly experienced engineering professional, having made significant contributions to the engineering construction field both in Sri Lanka and internationally. In 2011, he was appointed as the inaugural CEO of the Central Engineering Services (Pvt) Ltd., the construction arm of the Central Engineering Consultancy Bureau. He also served as the Team Leader of the Jointly Appointed Employers Quality Representative (JAEQR) for the Project Infrastructure and Landscaping Development of Colombo Port City from October 2021 to August 2022. Engineer Athula Galketiya assumed the role of the 10th Chairman of the Central Engineering Consultancy Bureau and Central Engineering Services (Pvt) Ltd. in August 2022. Subsequently, he was appointed as the Vice Chairman of Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Ltd. in August 2023.

title: SL secures USD 2.2B investment from Canadian firm
author: Author not found
Content: As a solution to the ongoing electricity crisis in the country, Sri Lanka has secured an investment of USD 2.2 billion from a Canadian company to construct Integrated Renewable Energy Power Plants, Agrivoltaics, and introduce Green Hydrogen Energy, a senior official from the Ministry of Energy said. The official stated that the Canadian company, Canada Solar Valley Green Hydrogen Group Co., Ltd., has committed to this investment, and their delegation arrived in Sri Lanka on 3 November. The Canadian delegation stayed in the country for a month, engaging in discussions with government representatives about the project. They met Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera, Additional Secretary to the President Dr. Sulakshana Jayawardena, State Minister for Urban Development Arundika Fernando and MP Nimal Lanza. At the request of State Minister for Urban Development Arundika Fernando, both Sunny Energy Investment Group Co., Ltd. and the delegation from Canada Solar Valley Green Hydrogen Group Co., Ltd. visited Sri Lanka. State Minister Fernando highlighted that the proposed Molten Salt Concentrated Thermal Solar Power Plant, designed as a zero-carbon emission solution, aligns with Sri Lanka’s renewable energy objectives and is poised to make a significant contribution to environmental sustainability. The primary goal is to advance Sri Lanka towards energy independence, transitioning from green power to green hydrogen and eventually to green methanol, as emphasised by State Minister Arundika Fernando. He added that the project is expected to provide over 1,500 job opportunities during the construction phase. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: 50,000 male chicks given to low-income families
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 50,000 male chicks that were to be used as swine feed in piggeries have been released free of cost to low-income families and unemployed youth, a senior spokesman for the Ministry of Agriculture said. Fielding questions, the spokesman yesterday (12) said it had come to light during recent discussions that when there was a gross shortage of eggs and chicken about three months earlier, the National Livestock Development Board (NLDB) was using the male chicks as swine feed in the piggeries functioning under it while keeping the female chicks as layers.  It has been an ongoing procedure that was halted when Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera instructed it to take urgent measures to distribute these male chicks amongst low-income families and youth who were interested in poultry farming to produce chicken for the market rather than using them to feed swine.  The Agriculture Ministry spokesman said the programme would continue. The NLDB has poultry farms and piggeries in addition to cattle farms functioning under it, he added.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Faculty Deans oppose clinical training for S’gamuwa Medicos at Ratnapura Teaching Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: The Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed between the Health Ministry, the Ministry of Education and Higher Education and the University Grants Commission (UGC) to provide clinical training for students of the Sabaragamuwa Medical Faculty is allegedly meeting with mounting opposition from Faculty Deans who view it as a catastrophic move.  Informed sources yesterday (12) said the move had been initiated by Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana after visiting the Teaching Hospital Ratnapura and discussing the issue with the hospital director, specialist doctors, professors and lecturers of the Sabaragamuwa University (SU) and its Medical Faculty.  The Health Ministry has agreed to utilise resources from the Teaching Hospital Ratnapura to facilitate the provision of a Professorial Unit for the final year students of the Sabaragamuwa Medical Faculty for a period of three years till SU established a Professorial Building for its medical students.   According to the MoU the Professorial Unit would comprise; Medicine, Surgery, Paediatrics, Psychiatry, Obstetrics and Gynaecology. Also, the Health Ministry affiliated Consultants who were in charge of the University’s Professorial Units would be referred to as ‘Senior Consultant,’ in the particular discipline.    Sources said however, that disturbed Medical Faculty Deans have called for discussions in this regard from the Dean of the Colombo Medical Faculty, Prof. Vajira Dissanayake who also happens to be the President of the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC). Prof. Dissanayake is also the current Registrar of the Ceylon Medical College Council (CMCC).  “There is a clear conflict of interest regarding appeals to discuss matters pertaining to the MoU signed in the best interest of the final year students of the Sabaragamuwa Medical Faculty. It could lead to dispute among other Medical Faculty Deans and medical students regarding a sensitive matter related to the Ministries of Health and Education and the SLMC,” they said.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Cabinet Green-Lights Appointing Authorised Agent
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the appointment of an authorised agent to facilitate the online submission of visa applications for foreigners visiting Sri Lanka. In September 2023, Cabinet decided to appoint an evaluation committee tasked with assessing the proposal put forth by GBS Technology Services, IVS Global – FZCO and VFS VF Worldwide Holdings Ltd. The purpose of this evaluation was to determine the suitability of these entities to serve as authorised agents for the online submission of visa applications. The Government said the evaluation committee has now submitted its report on the matter. Consequently, Cabinet endorsed the proposal presented by the Minister of Public Security, aligning with the recommendations outlined in the committee’s report. Further, Cabinet approved the signing of the relevant agreement, which has been meticulously drafted according to observations made by the Attorney General.

title: Cabinet nod for legal cooperation with S. Korea
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approval has been granted for Sri Lanka to sign an agreement with South Korea regarding legal cooperation in criminal matters. As outlined by the Government, a delegation comprising senior officials from the Ministry of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Attorney General’s Department, along with a delegation representing pertinent institutions in South Korea, have formulated the agreement. The anticipated outcome is an enhancement in the efficiency of crime prevention, investigation and the process of filing complaints in both nations. Consequently, Cabinet gave the green light to the proposal presented by the Minister of Justice, endorsing the signing of the aforementioned agreement between the two parties, followed by its ratification through the diplomatic missions of both countries.

title: HRCSL issues 17-page set of guidelines for Police
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to prevent custodial and encounter deaths, the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has drafted a 17-page ‘General Guidelines and Recommendations’ for the Sri Lanka Police. Following its inquiries and received complaints, the HRCSL identified 24 instances of custodial deaths and 13 cases of encounter deaths involving the Sri Lanka Police from January 2020 to August 2023. Notably, six custodial deaths and two encounter deaths occurred within the first half of 2023. During this period, the custodial deaths recorded were linked to Police stations or divisions primarily situated in three main districts: Colombo, Gampaha and Kalutara. Except for three victims, all individuals succumbed to their injuries within 24 hours of being arrested by the Sri Lanka Police. These reported deaths occurred during attempts to locate weapons or narcotics, involving cruel, inhuman, degrading treatment or due to the negligence or omissions of the officers on duty. Regarding encounter deaths, most cases reported to the Commission were associated with Police stations or divisions in the districts of Colombo, Gampaha and Galle. Three cases in Colombo were specifically linked to the Special Task Force (STF). All reported encounter deaths occurred either during arrests or when the Police claimed to be exercising their right of self-defence while dealing with individuals displaying violent behaviour. In this context, the HRCSL was of the view that general guidelines and recommendations need to be issued to Sri Lanka Police to prevent custodial and encounter deaths and to safeguard the inherent right to life of all persons. HRCSL recommends the following safeguards before, during and after arrest:  While preparing to arrest a suspect, the HRCSL said the Police officers should respect the right of every person to be free from arbitrary arrest in terms of Article 13(1) of the Sri Lankan Constitution. Arrests should not be carried out in an arbitrary manner. Every Police officer who makes an arrest of a person must be able to justify its necessity on the basis of reasonable suspicion that the person has committed an offence following a preliminary Police investigation. The preliminary investigation must be carried out prior to the arrest. It can either take place at the point of observing a person committing an offence or attempting to commit an offence, or at the Police station to which any information or intelligence regarding an offence or attempt to commit an offence is received. Police officers should respect the right of every person to be presumed innocent until proven guilty as guaranteed by Article 13(5) of the Constitution.  During preliminary investigations, all suspects should be afforded the right not to self-incriminate. Police officers should respect the right of any suspect to remain silent and not be forced under any circumstance to make any self-incriminating statements. Arrest should not be carried out where a person is coerced into making a self-incriminating statement following being summoned to provide a statement to the Police in terms of Section 109 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act, No. 15 of 1979 during a preliminary investigation. When summoning a person to make a statement, the Police should at all times respect the rights of such person under Section 110(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure: Such person shall be bound to answer truly all questions relating to such case put to him by such officer or inquirer other than questions which would have a tendency to expose him to a criminal charge or to a penalty of forfeiture’ (emphasis added). In the event that the Police receive information or intelligence regarding criminal movements or attempts to commit a grave criminal offence, such information or intelligence should be reduced into writing in the Personal Note Book.   The senior Police officer in charge of deploying Police officers to arrest a suspect must assess the risks and challenges the Police may encounter in the process of apprehending the suspect. Based on the risk assessment, the senior Police officer may determine: The composition and number of Police officers that should be deployed in the arrest operation; The type and number of vehicles that should be deployed for the operation; Authorised means of restraint and weapons the Police officers may be equipped with during the arrest operation. In the event of a planned arrest of a female suspect, the composition of the team of Police officers involved in the arrest operation should include at least one female officer.   All Police officers with the knowledge of an arrest operation must ensure strict confidentiality regarding the operation and any other information or intelligence received by the Police regarding the details and locations of the suspect. While arresting a suspect, HRCSL, in its guidelines, said all Police officers making an arrest must bear accurate, visible and clear identification on their uniforms at all times. In the event that a special arrest operation requires the officers to be in civilian clothes, the officers should have their official identity cards in their possession to prove their identity at any given time.  In general, force should not be used when making an arrest.    By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Tasteless food, mosquitoes and inadequate beds
author: Author not found
Content: The Interim Report released by HRCSL, yesterday (11), with its fact-finding mission on the Right to Health and Liberty of Patients at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH), addressed many alarming situations and the status quo of the NIMH in Sri Lanka.  In the 10-page report, the HRCSL expressed its concerns about the forensic psychiatry unit’s lack of prison guards and housing both remand and convicted prisoners (patients in both acute and intermediate stages) in the same space. Further, admitting patients with substance misuse problems to regular acute wards instead of a separate unit was also identified to be a substantial issue. In addition, overcrowding and understaffing appeared to be a common problem faced by a majority of the aforementioned units. While the general structure of the daily routines of these patients was observed to be similar, some differences can be seen in relation to their special needs, and rehabilitating activities. Even though the visitation hours of NIMH are from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. unlike in other hospitals, it appeared that there is a limited number of visitors, and a lot of patients are waiting for their families to return to their homes.  By the powers vested in the Human Rights Commission under the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 21 of 1996, the Commission initiated a fact-finding mission to the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) to address many allegations levelled against the institution to ascertain and assess the present human rights issues relating to NIMH, and to make recommendations to the relevant authorities.  Amongst these allegations are the unsuitable ways the patients are being handled by the staff, the way restraints are used on the patients and the methods that are used when obtaining the patients’ consent for various matters. It should be noted that some of these actions amount to torture and degrading treatment. The most recent incident that alarmed the Commission was the death of a patient suspected to have been caused by some extreme measures used by the support staff. In addition to the Court proceedings that are presently ongoing, the Human Rights Commission is also conducting a separate investigation into this incident, the HRCSL said. The team appointed for the mission has adopted the fact-finding techniques of reviewing existing documentation and literature, conducting site visits and observation of the work environment, administering questionnaires and conducting interviews to collect data.   Also, the HRCSL said the patients are provided with three meals a day at NIMH and are served tea thrice a day. Special diets are provided to patients with diabetes, those suffering from malnutrition, and those who are on feeding tubes. While there were complaints about food being too salty and tasteless, the Commission also observed that the food appeared to be watery. It was mentioned by the hospital kitchen that due to issues regarding the Circular under which the spices should be ordered, the kitchen suffers a lack of spices to properly season the food. While the lighting, temperature and ventilation were acceptable in some wards, problems were identified in relation to the provision of light bulbs, availability of natural light and functioning of the fans. The Commission also observed that the number of beds for the number of patients in some units was inadequate, thereby necessitating patients to share beds or sleep on the floor. There was no proper storage space to store patients’ personal property in the wards. While most locker systems appeared to be broken, some patients have resorted to storing their belongings inside their pillowcases. Further, it was observed that mosquitoes were a serious issue since mosquito nets cannot be put in place due to the suicide risks of patients. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Post offices closed islandwide due to TU action
author: Author not found
Content: Post offices across the country were closed yesterday (11) due to a strike organised by 27 postal trade unions, starting from midnight on 10 December, to expedite resolutions to several of their demands. The trade unions urge the Government to abandon its plans to sell properties of the Postal Department, including the premises of the Nuwara Eliya Post Office.  They also demand sufficient funds to address administrative issues affecting postal workers and a salary increment of Rs 20,000 for postal workers beginning next month. The postal trade unions announced that the strike would continue for 56 hours. By Neeta Pathmakumari – Norwood

title: Fire reported at Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: A fire was reported in a structure belonging to Teaching Hospital Anuradhapura, specifically in the ‘Methsiri Sevana’ building yesterday (11). The ‘Methsiri Sevana’ building, associated with the Kidney Patients Relief Service, Welfare, and Research Centre affiliated with the Anuradhapura General Hospital, was inaugurated by former President Maithripala Sirisena in 2019. The construction cost was Rs 437 million, which was borne by the National Kidney Fund. In response, two fire engines from the Fire Brigade of the Anuradhapura Municipal Council were dispatched to the scene. Immediate action was taken to control the fire, and all patients within the premises were promptly evacuated.  However, as of the latest report, the fire continues to burn on the roof of the building. By Sumedha Karunarathna – Mihintale

title: Thilini Priyamali acquitted of cheque fraud
author: Author not found
Content: Businesswoman Thilini Priyamali, facing allegations of substantial financial fraud, was acquitted from the case in which she was accused of purportedly issuing a cheque from a bank account with insufficient funds to acquire a vehicle worth Rs 8 million. The order for her acquittal and release was issued by Colombo High Court Judge Aditya Patabendige when the case was taken up yesterday (11). Announcing his decision, the Judge stated that he ordered the release of the accused, concluding that it was not possible to sustain the case based on how the charges against the accused had been filed. This case, brought by the Attorney General, charged Priyamali with criminal breach of trust for allegedly issuing a cheque from a bank account lacking sufficient funds to purchase a vehicle valued at Rs 8 million from an individual. By Kumudu Upul Shantha and Hansi Nanayakkara

title: ‘Army’s departure from Mihintale doesn’t pose security threat’
author: Author not found
Content: Withdrawal of Army personnel from Mihintale does not pose any security threat to the sacred site, State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon said yesterday (11) in Parliament. Addressing concerns raised by MP Roshan Ranasinghe, the State Minister clarified that the 252 Army personnel stationed at Mihintale were not assigned for security purposes. Therefore, their withdrawal does not impact the security of the sacred site. Tennakoon emphasised, “There is no security threat as a result of the withdrawal of all 252 personnel. They were not placed there for security purposes. Security is being provided by Sri Lanka Police, and there are over 30 Police personnel present at the site.”  He further explained that while the Sri Lanka Police is responsible for the security of Mihintale, personnel from other defence forces, including the Army, will be deployed if deemed necessary. During the parliamentary sittings on the same morning, former Sports Minister MP Roshan Ranasinghe expressed concerns about the cessation of all development activities at Mihintale due to the removal of Army personnel. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Diesel price will surge by Rs 63 after 18% VAT– Herath
author: Author not found
Content: The price of a litre of diesel will witness a surge of Rs 63 with the imposition of an 18 per cent Value Added Tax (VAT), Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Vijitha Herath said in Parliament yesterday (11).  One litre of diesel is presently priced at Rs 346 and the new VAT rate will come into effect from 1 January.  Addressing the Committee Stage Budget Debate on the Ministry of Fisheries, Herath highlighted that machinery used in the agriculture and fisheries domains will now be subject to VAT, aligning with the conditions set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).  He expressed concern over the already precarious state of the fisheries sector, emphasising that the introduction of an 18 per cent VAT will significantly impact the lives of those involved in the fishing industry. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: BJP President Annamalai writes to Dr. Jaishankar
author: Author not found
Content: Tamil Nadu BJP President Annamalai, on Sunday (10), wrote a letter to Indian External Affairs Minister Dr. S. Jaishankar, highlighting the recent incident involving the arrest of 12 Tamil fishermen from Nagapattinam by the Sri Lanka Navy.  He sought Jaishankar’s intervention in the repatriation of 16 fishermen detained by the Sri Lanka Navy. “On behalf of @BJP4TamilNadu, we request the kind intervention of our Hon EAM Thiru @DrSJaishankar avl for the immediate repatriation of 12 Tamil fishermen arrested by the Sri Lankan Navy and for the release of their fishing vessel,” posted Annamalai on X.  25 Indian fishermen, who were fishing in international waters, were detained by the Sri Lanka Navy along with their two trawlers, off the Point Pedro town in Sri Lanka. According to the Sri Lanka Navy, the fishermen were allegedly involved in ‘illegal poaching’ and were detained during a special operation on Saturday night. Twelve Tamil fishermen from Nagapattinam were reportedly captured on 9 December by the Sri Lanka Navy. “We bring to your kind attention the arrest of 12 Tamil fishermen from Nagapattinam by the Sri Lanka Navy on 9 December, and their fishing boat bearing registration number IND-TN-06-MM-7675 was also apprehended. We request the kind intervention of our External Affairs Ministry for the early repatriation of the detainees and the release of their fishing boat,” Annamalai said in the letter. The arrested fishermen were brought to the Kankesanturai Harbour and they will be handed over to the Myliddy Fisheries Inspector for further legal action. The relatives of the fishermen have expressed their concern about the incident and have requested both central and state governments to rescue them and their two lifeboats. Last month, 27 Indian fishermen were released by the Sri Lankan authorities. They returned to the Chennai Airport on separate days in sets of 12 and 15. Notably, the arrests of Indian fishermen by the Sri Lanka Navy has been a concerning issue for both the Tamil Nadu government as well as the BJP-led central government.  (ANI)

title: Health professionals claim substandard meds ‘normalised’
author: Author not found
Content: Following an incident of an anaphylactic reaction to a medicinal drug at the National Hospital Colombo, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) alleged that the change of heads in the Health Ministry called for normalisation and suppression of references to fake and substandard drugs.   Citing the most recent incident where a patient admitted to the National Hospital, Colombo on Saturday (9) was transferred to the High Dependency Unit (HDU) of the Hospital due to serious complications after being administered Ceftriaxone, a medicinal drug manufactured in Greece, AHP President Ravi Kumudesh said an anaphylactic reaction to the particular drug was allegedly the cause of death of a woman at the National Hospital Kandy.  He accused certain parties of attempting to prove that there was nothing wrong with the medicine as it belonged to a multinational company and was imported by a local agent.  Hospital sources said the patient had been admitted with diarrhoea and gastric pain. On the recommendation of the specialist, the antibiotic Ceftriaxone was administered, they said.  The patient had complained that his arm was growing lifeless as soon as the one-gramme injection was being administered. He was immediately transferred to the HDU. Tests done in the HDU allegedly showed that his blood pressure and oxygen saturation had decreased drastically. However, his condition had improved by yesterday (11) afternoon. ​ Kumudesh stressed that it was the responsibility of the new Health Minister, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana to conduct a formal probe into yet another incident since the dangers of substandard and fake medicinal drugs coming into the country and the import method have not changed despite the change of heads. Therefore, it is unfortunate that the same people who spoke against the low-quality medicinal drugs were now attempting to normalise the situation, he lamented.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: VAT Bill passed with majority of 45 votes
author: Author not found
Content: The Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill was passed in Parliament yesterday (11) with amendments. The Bill was passed with a majority of 45 votes.  Hundred (100) MPs voted in favour of the Bill while 55 MPs voted against it.  Originally scheduled for debate on Sunday (10), the Parliamentary Sittings were adjourned due to a lack of quorum. The approved legislation paves the way for an increase in VAT from the present 15 per cent to 18 per cent. This decision precedes the expected approval by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) of the second tranche of a USD 2.9 billion bailout for the crisis-stricken country. Earlier in the day, the Second Reading of the Bill passed with a majority of 57 votes. A total of 98 MPs voted in favour, while 41, including former Minister and SLPP MP Roshan Ranasinghe and members of the Opposition, opposed the Bill. The debate on the Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill commenced on 11 December evening, following the earlier approval in Parliament to discuss the proposed amendments. During the debate on the Second Reading of the Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill and the Finance Bill, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya emphasised that VAT would be applied to 97 out of the 138 goods that were previously exempt from the tax, aiming to enhance state revenue. The State Minister also mentioned that Short Message Service (SMS) in fixed telephone networks would be subject to VAT due to the increased number of text messages sent. However, he reassured that certain items, such as medicines, equipment used by disabled persons, rice flour, wheat flour, vegetables, fruits, liquid milk and the ‘Suwaseriya’ ambulance service, would remain exempt from VAT. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Entire population to undergo registration – Alles
author: Author not found
Content: In response to rising crime rates, the entire population of Sri Lanka will undergo registration with the Police, Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles announced in Parliament yesterday (11). Addressing a query from MP Mano Ganesan regarding the registration of the Tamil community, especially in Colombo, Minister Alles said, “We have decided to register the entire population, regardless of the ethnic groups to which they belong. Registration forms in all three languages will be distributed.” He further explained, “We are planning to establish an online database of the Sri Lankan population, ensuring that individuals can be identified at any given time.” Ganesan brought up a concern about the Police distributing forms in Sinhala to the Tamil community in Colombo city to gather residents’ personal information. He argued that distributing forms only in Sinhala amounted to a violation of the Constitution. Additionally, he questioned the necessity of collecting personal information and highlighted the inclusion of religion as one of the pieces of information being sought. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport.
