Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: I will never join forces with the President – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa vowed yesterday (11) that he would never collaborate with President Ranil Wickremesinghe.  Premadasa made this statement while addressing certain media outlets in response to Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe’s accusation against a national newspaper for allegedly disseminating false information about the Constitutional Council’s proceedings during the parliamentary sittings on the same day. Minister Rajapakshe claimed that certain journalists and media organisations take pleasure in spreading misinformation and undermining the Government’s ongoing efforts. In appreciation of the Justice Minister’s emphasis on the issue of misinformation, the Opposition Leader asserted that specific media outlets, known for engaging in propaganda for the Government, are purportedly conspiring to launch a disinformation campaign against him. Premadasa said these media outlets are presently spreading misinformation about a supposed alliance between Ranil and Sajith, vehemently denying all such allegations. “Let it be known that Ranil and Sajith will never join forces,” he stated.  The Opposition Leader urged the implicated media networks, which he alleges have received funds from the Government, to cease immediately from disseminating misinformation. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Fire reported at Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: A fire was reported in a structure belonging to Teaching Hospital Anuradhapura, specifically in the ‘Methsiri Sevana’ building yesterday (11). The ‘Methsiri Sevana’ building, associated with the Kidney Patients Relief Service, Welfare, and Research Centre affiliated with the Anuradhapura General Hospital, was inaugurated by former President Maithripala Sirisena in 2019. The construction cost was Rs 437 million, which was borne by the National Kidney Fund. In response, two fire engines from the Fire Brigade of the Anuradhapura Municipal Council were dispatched to the scene. Immediate action was taken to control the fire, and all patients within the premises were promptly evacuated.  However, as of the latest report, the fire continues to burn on the roof of the building. By Sumedha Karunarathna – Mihintale

title: Clinical training to commence for final year Medicoes of Sabaragamuwa Uni
author: Author not found
Content: Secretaries of the Ministries of Health and Education and Higher Education signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to provide clinical training for final year students of the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Sabaragamuwa.  A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry said yesterday (11)that Health Secretary Dr. Palitha Mahipala and Secretary of the Ministry of Education and Higher Education M.N. Ranasinghe had agreed to provide facilities and services to final year students of the Sabaragamuwa Medical Faculty.  “Clinical training for medical students should be provided complying with the criteria of the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC).  Accordingly, there should be Professorial Unit established for this purpose”, the spokesman noted. The Ministry of Health agreed to provide the necessary facilities to establish the relevant professor unit.  The SLMC, the Health Ministry, the University Grants Commission (UGC) and the Sabaragamuwa University discussed the issue while Health Minister, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana visited the Teaching Hospital Ratnapura and discussed with the hospital director, specialist doctors, professors and lecturers of the Sabaragamuwa University and Faculty of Medicine and instructed them to expedite commencement of clinical training. The MoU had been signed only till the University  constructs a building to provide the required clinical training or for a stipulated period of three years.  Further it outlined the disciplines that the Professorial Unit would comprise, namely; Medicine, Surgery, Paediatrics, Psychiatry, Obstetrics and Gynaecology. It also noted that the Health Ministry affiliated Consultants who were in charge of the University’s Professorial Units would be referred to as ‘Senior Consultant,’ in that particular discipline.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Lifetime Achievement Award nominees
author: Author not found
Content: The 24th edition of the annual Journalism Awards for Excellence programme culminating with the ‘Awards Night’ will be held at the Empire Ballroom of the Mount Lavinia Hotel today (12).  The programme is organised by The Editors’ Guild of Sri Lanka in partnership with the Sri Lanka Press Institute and its affiliated unions, the Newspaper Society of Sri Lanka, Free Media Movement and the Sri Lanka Working Journalists Association. The annual programme is to recognise professionalism in journalism and reward those who have excelled. This year 36 journalists will receive the ‘Pen Trophy’ Award and 16 others will receive Certificates of Merit along with five Lifetime Achievement Awardees namely:  H. L. D. Mahindapala,  Stanley Samarasinghe, Seetha Ranjanee,  S. Thillainathan and M. A. M. Nilam H. L. D. Mahindapala H.L.D. Mahindapala began his journalism career at Lake House and rose to the position of News Editor of the Daily News. Thereafter he went overseas but continued to contribute articles to newspapers on different subjects. In 1990, he returned to the country and rejoined Lake House in the capacity of Chief Editor of the Sunday Observer. He functioned in the position till 1994 and during that period he served as the President of the Sri Lanka Working Journalists Association for two years.    Seetha Ranjanee Seetha Ranjanee began her career in the media in 1979 with the Rajarata Service of the Sri Lanka Broadcasting Corporation. At the very inception of the Rajarata Service she worked as a script writer and in 1986 she was part of a group that launched the alternative magazine ‘Vivarana.’ Moving to the print media from broadcasting media, she later edited several magazines including Dharani, Shakthi, Maadhya Nireekshana, Samakali, the women’s magazine ‘Eya’ and the cultural magazine ‘Sankalana.’ She was a founding member of the ‘Yukthiya’ alternative newspaper in 1990 and it was the turning point in her journalism career. In her media career spanning over 45 years she has mostly worked as a freelance journalist contributing to various publications including Irida Lankadeepa, Dinamina, Desathiya and Ravaya. She has also played an important role as an activist for media freedom and human rights. Her contribution to journalism has been recognised by the Editors’ Guild of Sri Lanka in 2004 when she won the award for best reporting on social development issues and in 2012 when she was awarded the Sepala Gunasena award for Media Freedom.    Stanley Samarasinghe Born in Colombo on 24 January 1940, Stanley Samarasinghe commenced his media career in 1962 from The Sun newspaper. Samarasinghe had received further training in the newspaper field in Iraq and the then Soviet Union. With a 58-year career in media, Samarasinghe had worked at Dawasa, Eththa, Divaina, Dinamina, Daily News, Mawbima and Ceylon Today newspapers as well as the electronic media channels of Sirasa. He had served 35 years of his media career as a senior journalist covering the Supreme Court. It was Samarasinghe who first revealed to the country about the controversial killing of Premawathi Manamperi on 17 April 1971 through the Eththa newspaper. It was Samarasinghe who revealed to the country Manamperi’s murder. In order to uncover the story, which was received at the time through an anonymous source, Samarasinghe had travelled to Kataragama on a directive by then Editor of the Eththa newspaper, B.A. Siriwardena, amidst emergency laws and a curfew that were in-place at the time. After uncovering the story in Kataragama, Samarasinghe had then reported the story to the country along with photographs that were taken by him. The story even reached the international arena with human rights activists also taking up the case internationally. Sinnathurai Thillainathan Sinnathurai Thillainathan, a native of Vadamarachchi, Puloli, Jaffna, has been working continuously as a regional correspondent for Virakesari, Sri Lanka’s leading Tamil National newspaper, for more than half a century. He took to journalism in 1968 as Jaffna Regional Correspondent of the now defunct Kandy-based weekly newspaper Seithi. He later joined EezhaNadu daily published from Jaffna and worked there until 1985. Thillainathan, who joined Virakesari as Puloli Correspondent in 1972, was later appointed as Virakesari’s Correspondent for the entire Vadamarachchi region from 1997 to 2009. He was honored with the award for the best journalist of Jaffna district in 2003 by the Sri Lanka Tamil Media Alliance and in the same year The Editors Guild of Sri Lanka presented him with a special award for his news service in Jaffna under trying circumstances. In addition, in appreciation of Thillainathan’s service, Point Pedro Divisional Secretariat awarded the titles of Kalaiparithi and Kalaichakaram.  Al-haj Mohammed Arif Mohammed Nilam Al-haj Mohammed Arif Mohammed Nilam, who was born in 1946, received his early education at the Roman Catholic Mixed School in Negombo. He started his maiden journey in media as the Colombo South Correspondent for Lake House while serving as Kurunegala District Correspondent for Virakesari until 1983. Al-haj Nilam was appointed as a sub editor for Thinakkural Newspaper in 1990 and thereafter he was promoted as a senior sub editor there. He served as consultant for Tamil publications at Lake House from 2015 to 2020. He received the Excellent Journalist Award from the Tamil Journalists’ Forum in 2004 and the Sri Lanka Muslim Media Forum honoured him by presenting him with the Senior Journalist Award. He was honoured by the Ministry of Cultural Affairs with the honorary title Kalabyshanam in 2009. In 2015, he received the lifetime achievement award by the Sri Lanka Press Council. Al-haj Nilam was the first Sri Lankan Tamil language Journalist to attend an event at the White House in USA with former Prime Minister and present President Ranil Wickremesinghe in 2022.

They are Samadhi Anuradha Ranawaka, a student at Mahamaya Girls’ College, Kandy, who secured the top position in the country in the 2022 GCE Ordinary Level Examination and Tharushi Karunarathna who won the Gold medal in the Women’s 800m event at the recently held 19th Asian Games. title: Blood donation camp
author: Author not found
Content: A blood donation camp organised by ‘Group 94’ of Gnanodaya Maha Vidyalaya, Kalutara took place for the 4th consecutive year at the Kalutara Bodhi premises last Sunday (10). Donors were provided with a dry ration pack by ‘Group 94’ who comprise past pupils of Gnanodaya Maha Vidyalaya, Kalutara. The Group was set up in 1994. title: SHMA opens maiden centre of Skills for Sustainable Growth Programme in Matale
author: Author not found
Content: The Swiss Hotel Management Academy Pvt. Ltd. (SHMA) of A. Baur & Co. Pvt Ltd., also known as Baurs, in its pursuit to empower the country’s youth to take on the hospitality industry to greater heights, recently announced its first centre of the Skills for Sustainable Growth (SSG) programme at the Naula National Youth Corps based in the Matale district.  This initiative comes after careful evaluation based on the many hotels in the surrounding areas and considering the low-income levels of potential students in the Matale district. Recently, SHMA signed an MoU with the National Youth Corps of Sri Lanka (NYC) where many other centres will be established across the country in phases. The SSG programme is a private and public sector partnership between Baurs and the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), the agency for international cooperation of the Federal Department of Foreign Affairs (FDFA) of Switzerland.  Currently, SHMA has enrolled 54 students at the Naula National Youth Corps centre, facilitated by Damitha Alwis who inaugurated the batch of students, and applying a centre-learning approach to ensure their success through the facilitation of the programme. The course content, which is based on a Swiss Vocational Skills Development (VSD) curriculum, includes three months theoretical lessons, one-and-a-half months blended learning and four-and-a half- month internship at a star class hotel. Further, soft skills development workshops are being provided to develop underprivileged students to excel in the hospitality trade. NYC is also providing a 14-day life skills training with team building activities and personal development which has a tremendous impact on student transformation. This is evident in every student who is enrolled at NYC. Students also have access to the Learning Management System (LMS) enabling them to engage in their course work at their convenience where each student is monitored and given due consideration and attention with this new approach. Numerous hotels have pledged their support towards the SSG programme and are willing to extend their cooperation to provide blended learning and internship opportunities for students. The SSG project will create 2,240 skilled young men and women by 2025 including increased female participation in hospitality education to 40%. The distinctiveness of the project is that two-third of its curriculum weighs towards practical on-the-job training coupled with internships and possible extension in various hotels, challenging the current practices when it comes to hospitality education. The diverse and experienced professionals at SHMA will facilitate the programme at NYC in producing competent and employable youth, whilst NYC continues to support the SSG project. SHMA survey revealed that 92.3% of students received promotions either in their current employment or within a new organisation, with over 75% of the students employed at 5-star establishments at present, and many have enjoyed a significant increase in their earning capacity. SHMA is an education institute that facilitates high-class education meeting international standards, producing highly qualified hoteliers. The academy is also licensed to deliver the VET (Vocational Education Training) by EHL Professional Diploma program offering specialised tracks in Culinary, Food & Beverage, and Hotel Operations, which is provided by École hôtelière de Lausanne, a pioneer in hospitality education since 1893, with a global network of over 25,000 alumni representing more than 120 nationalities.

title: International Mountain Day observed yesterday
author: Author not found
Content: International Mountain Day was observed yesterday (11). The theme was ‘Restoration of Mountain Ecosystems,’ emphasising the importance of conserving and sustainably utilising mountain resources. The International Mountain Day was declared in 2002. The national event took place at Manewa Kanda in Ipalogama, Anuradhapura, identified as an environmentally-sensitive area with rich biodiversity. The Ministry of Environment conducted an awareness programme for media and tour guides. Various groups were engaged in removing invasive grass and planting native plants in a selected area of the hill. The Food and Agricultural Organisation and IUCN collaborated and sponsored the programme. The site was also of archaeological value. The Department of Forest Conservation, Department of Wildlife Conservation and Department of Archaeology supported the programme and many other State officials participated.

title: Suspect arrested for storing toddy in Matale SLTB Depot
author: Author not found
Content: Matale Police arrested a suspect on the night of 10 December for storing toddy at the Matale SLTB Depot premises. He was rounded up by the Manager of the Depot following a tip-off. The Matale Police was informed and they apprehended the suspect. Another suspect had however fled the scene. The suspect who was apprehended is to be produced before Court. Meanwhile, Police said an engineer and a supervisor attached to the Depot had also been involved in the illegal activity and inquiries were underway to apprehend them as well. BY Priyantha Polwatta – Ukuwela

title: 3 schools in Haldumulla temporarily closed
author: Author not found
Content: Director of the Haldummulla Education Division Nilani Dhammika said three schools in the division have been temporarily closed due to adverse weather.  However, she emphasised that necessary measures have been implemented to ensure the uninterrupted continuation of studies for the affected children. Dhammika said this action was a follow -up to directives from the Bandarawela Zonal Education Director, Dhammika Herath. Specifically, students from Kelipanawela Maha Vidyalaya, facing the risk of landslides, have been temporarily relocated to Wellawaya Gampaha Vidyalaya.  Additionally, students from Blackwood College have been transferred to Tamil Maha Vidyalaya in Haldummulla and those from Maladola Maha Vidyalaya have been temporarily shifted to Harangoda Maha Vidyalaya due to the threat of earth slips in these areas. BY Saman Palitha Nanayakkara – Haldummulla

title: President should declare whether he intends to run for Presidency – Dilum
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Investment Promotions Dilum Amunugama said if President Ranil Wickremesinghe has intentions of contesting the next Presidential Poll then he should clearly state whether he intends to run for it as a common candidate or as a candidate from a single Party. Addressing the media in Kandy on 10 December, the State Minister stated that as the President has already announced his intention to conduct three Elections next year, he should also declare his stance on whether he intends to run for the Presidency or not.  Amunugama added that till the President declares his stance it would be difficult for the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) to take a final decision on whether to back the current President at the next Presidential Poll or not. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Interim Secretariat members meet Northern Governor
author: Author not found
Content: On the recommendation of President Ranil Wickremesinghe members of the Interim Secretariat of the proposed Independent Commission for Truth, Unity, and Reconciliation to be established through an Act of Parliament, met and discussed with Governor of the Northern Province P.S.M. Charles, at her residence in Colombo on 9 December 2023.  A group, including the Director-General of the proposed Independent Commission Dr. Asanga Gunawansa, Policy Division Head of the Interim Secretariat Dr. Yuvi Thangaraja, Legal Division Officer of the Interim Secretariat Nisantheni Ratnam and Executive to Director General and Legal Ashvini Hapangama had a discussion with the Governor. The objective of the proposed independent commission is to provide the necessary facilities for reconciliation, reparations and lasting peace to ascertain the truth about the grievances of Sri Lankan citizens in the post-war period. The Interim Secretariat members met the Governor of the Northern Province yesterday evening to discuss the progress of the work of the Interim Secretariat for the Truth and Reconciliation Mechanism appointed to develop the necessary legal and policy framework, operational procedures and guidelines for the Independent Commission for Truth, Unity, and Reconciliation. Accordingly, they  will meet religious leaders, government officials, university students and the public until today (12) to hear their views on the reconciliation mechanism and provide explanations related to the commission.

title: Commemorating 75th Birth Anniversary of SLMC Leader late M.H.M. Ashraff
author: Author not found
Content: An event will be held today (12) to commemorate the 75th birthday anniversary of the founding Leader of the Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC) and NUA and a former Minister M. H. M. Ashraff. The event organised by the National Unity Alliance (NUA) is scheduled to be held at Jasmin Hall at the BMICJ, starting 4:00 p.m., according to NUA Leader Azath Sally. Sally also emphasised that the NUA was the brainchild of the late Ashraff, founded to unite every Sri Lankan. Former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga will be the Chief Guest and keynote speaker at the event, with the Guest of Honour being the Speaker, Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena. TNA Spokesman MP M. S. Sumanthiran will deliver the Ashraff commemoration speech in Tamil and the former Commissioner of Elections will address the gathering in Sinhala on the same topic, Sally said. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Vote on VAT postponed
author: Author not found
Content: The special Parliamentary Sittings convened to pass the Value Added Tax (VAT) (Amendment) Bill yesterday (10), had to be adjourned until today (11) owing to lack of quorum in the Chamber. The necessary minimum of 20 members was not present during the debate on the VAT (Amendment) Bill.  The debate was scheduled to be held from 9:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. with the vote. During the debate, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya asserted that the Government anticipates Rs 227 billion in State revenue following the VAT increase from 15 per cent to 18 per cent.  He further stated in Parliament that this VAT hike is expected to lead to a 2.5 per cent escalation in inflation rates.  Siyambalapitiya informed the House that last week’s inflation rate stood at 3.4 per cent and is projected to surpass 5 per cent with the additional 2.5 per cent increase. Speaking further, the State Minister said 138 items have been granted exemption from VAT, but under the new Amendment, 97 items will now be subject to VAT.  He said Short Message Service (SMS) in fixed telephone networks will also be subjected to VAT, given the increased number of text messages sent. He clarified that VAT will be imposed on both petrol and diesel, while certain items such as vegetables, fruits, rice flour and medicine will continue to be exempt from VAT. While the debate was underway, the Opposition MPs staged a walkout, citing the unavailability of the list containing 97 items slated for VAT imposition. Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella asserted that without documents providing relevant information, the debate could not proceed. In response, State Minister Shehan Semasinghe stressed that two separate lists, one comprising 300 items subject to VAT and another outlining exempted items, were available.  He urged members to refer to the list of items on which VAT would be imposed.  However, Opposition MPs walked out at that juncture.  Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Nalin Bandara Jayamaha noted the absence of a quorum, even after the quorum bell was rung. Consequently, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse adjourned the sittings until today (11), when the debate on the VAT Amendment Bill is set to resume. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Kelaniya Uni to resume academic activities today
author: Author not found
Content: Vice Chancellor Senior Professor Nilanthi de Silva announced that the faculties of Science, Computer Technology, and Management Studies will reopen today (11) Monday, while the Faculty of Social Sciences and Humanities is scheduled to reopen on 18 December. This decision comes after the closure of all faculties of Kelaniya University, except the Faculty of Medicine on 4 December following an alleged assault incident.  The university took this action following reports of a security officer being abducted and assaulted while asleep in the break room at night. Subsequently, the victim was reportedly tied to the entrance gate at the Student Centre of the university.  Four students were suspended in connection with the incident.

title: 31 families affected by Koslanda landslide
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 31 families, comprising 140 members were affected by a landslide that occurred in Koslanda,  early yesterday (10). This area comes under the Haldumulla Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division, Assistant Director of Disaster Management Centre (DMC), Badulla District E. M. L. Kumara said. When contacted, Kumara said the displaced families have been accommodated in a school and were being provided with cooked food. He said six houses in the landslide location were completely damaged. He said thankfully,  the DMC acted promptly and evacuated the people on detecting signs of a landslide. Approximately 30 acres of land was covered with earth and a decision as to whether to resettle the residents in the same location or relocate them will be made after a thorough study of the soil condition in the area, according to the Assistant Director. Paddy cultivation in the area has been completely destroyed Kumara said. Due to the ongoing inclement weather, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO)has issued various levels of landslide early warning alerts to 34 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions across 10 districts in the Central Hill Country. Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist of the Landslide Early Warning Centre of NBRO, said level two amber – watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Hali-Ela DS Division and surrounding areas in the Badulla District, Ingiriya DS Division and surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Thumpane, Pasbage Korale, and Yatiyantota DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Kandy District. Dr. Senadeera also expressed concern that even a slight rainfall could cause severe damage and advised those living in the vicinity to be on alert particularly landslide-prone areas, to be vigilant. They are urged to exercise caution and immediately inform the DMC and the nearby police station if they notice any landslide signs, such as slanting trees, telephone and light posts, sudden appearance of muddy water or springs from the highlands, or cracks on the ground or walls and floors of residential and other buildings in the neighboring areas. Dr. Senadeera emphasised the importance of moving to safe places in such situations. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: We are okay with VAT but it must be fair, transparent – Harsha
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is planning to impose a Value Added Tax (VAT) on the farmers’ loin cloth too, said SJB MP Dr. Harsha de Silva.  The SJB MP was speaking at a press conference held yesterday (10) at the office of the Leader of the Opposition in Colombo, following the adjournment of Sittings on Sunday (10). Despite the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) recommendations to the Ministry of Finance exempting VAT for infant food, medical equipment and agricultural equipment, MP De Silva claims that the Government was planning to impose a VAT on 97 goods and commodities, including infant food such as Thriposha, locally produced coconut milk products, medical equipment, ambulances, mobile phones, tractors, locally manufactured textiles and many other essential goods. Dr. de Silva also added that the price of diesel, petrol and LP gas could also increase as it is to be subject to the new VAT, following amendments to the proposed Bill.  He claimed that the Sittings were adjourned due to the commotion made by government MPs who were present in the Chamber following concerns raised by the Opposition regarding the lack of clarity surrounding the Bill prior to the debate, as the Government has failed to provide the list of the 97 items in Sinhala and Tamil languages.  The MP also raised concerns over the support by government MPs for the Bill in question as many government MPs were not present in the Chamber yesterday (10).  He also said the Opposition was not denying the importance of VAT but while having a fair tax system, the Government should also be more transparent about the matter as people have a right to know what they are being taxed on, as transparency is a key factor in a healthy democracy, he said. 18% tax to be imposed on the following items, some of which have been announced to be omitted during Committee Stage of the debate.  Eggs Thriposha Milk Mamotee Works of Art – Paintings, carvings and sculptures SMS Stationery Petrol Diesel LPG Latex – Rubber Fertiliser Green leaf – tea Copra Desiccated coconut Coconut milk and byproducts All medical equipments Medical lab equipments Pharmaceutical production Ambulances Solar Panels Locally manufactured textiles not registered with the BOI Locally manufactured Software By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Tax appeals take six years to process
author: Author not found
Content: A recent session of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Economic and Strategic Plans revealed that the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) requires a minimum of six years to process a tax appeal, constituting a significant and inefficient allocation of time. The committee convened under the chairmanship of MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage to gather insights from the Tax Appeals Commission. Potential amendments to the Inland Revenue Department Act were discussed. During the meeting, it came to light that the processing time for tax appeals in the Inland Revenue Department averages over 40 months. Subsequently, these appeals are referred to the Tax Appeals Commission, where they undergo a two-year review. Following this, appeals may further proceed to the Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court, taking an additional minimum of one year to reach a final decision. Surprisingly, the committee revealed that 95 per cent of tax appeals referred to the Commission aligned with the conclusions drawn by the Inland Revenue Department. Recognising the urgency of the situation, the committee stressed the necessity for a prompt revision of the existing timeline for examining tax appeals. Aluthgamage proposed the revision of the prolonged timeframe, advocating for the completion of one appeal within a maximum period of two years. Committee members echoed the sentiment, emphasising the identification of individuals intentionally evading tax payments. They suggested that collecting owed taxes from such individuals would provide relief to the public burdened by VAT, income tax and related taxes. Officials from the Tax Appeals Commission highlighted the significance of introducing a dedicated law to expeditiously examine and resolve tax appeals. In response, Aluthgamage outlined a commitment to amend the Inland Revenue Department Act within six months, ensuring that all relevant departments work diligently to enhance the efficiency of the tax collection process in the country.

title: HRCSL releases three guidelines to authorities
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) released three important guidelines and recommendations to the State and relevant authorities yesterday (10), to mark International Human Rights Day. This year’s International Human Rights Day celebrated under the theme ‘Freedom, Equality, and Justice for All,’ fell on 10 December. The HRCSL launched three main guidelines and recommendations in the presence of representatives from the State, law enforcement authorities, governmental and non-governmental and civil society organisations. These guidelines encompass General Guidelines and Recommendations to the Sri Lanka Police addressing the prevention of custodial and encounter deaths, as well as comprehensive guidance on the protection of human rights defenders. Additionally, an Interim Report from the Fact-Finding Mission focusing on the right to health and liberty of patients at the National Institute of Mental Health was also presented. These initiatives aim to underscore the HRCSL’s commitment to promote and safeguard human rights in various spheres, fostering awareness and accountability within the State and relevant institutions. In his International Human Rights Day message, Justice L.T.B. Dehideniya, Chairman HRCSL called on the State and relevant authorities to uphold the fundamental and international human rights obligations. He urged individuals and organisations to actively educate themselves on the rights guaranteed by the Constitution and other legislations of Sri Lanka. The HRCSL chairman noted that coinciding with International Human Rights Day, Sri Lanka marks the 75th anniversary of adopting the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR). He emphasised the need for reflection, acknowledging the significant developments facilitated by the UDHR to protect and promote the universal rights of all persons. Addressing the challenges hindering the full realisation of rights and values enshrined in the declaration, the chairman pointed to the global pandemic and the political and economic instability in the country. He highlighted systemic inequalities and exacerbated injustices faced by vulnerable communities, emphasising the HRCSL’s commitment to address these issues and create an equitable environment for all individuals to realise the rights and values envisioned in the UDHR.

title: Islandwide power failure cost CEB Rs 6B – Janaka
author: Author not found
Content: Former Chairman  of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Janaka Ratnayake, who convened a media briefing after the islandwide power outage on Saturday (9), alleged that the cumulative loss from the outage to the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) amounts to approximately Rs 6 billion.  “Relying on fossil fuel power plants to compensate for this unit’s inactivity incurs a loss of Rs 60 per unit. This results in an estimated total loss of approximately Rs 1 billion following the major power outages,” he added.  Ratnayake criticised the Ministry of Power and Energy, accusing it of neglecting gazetted orders aimed at preventing nationwide power outages. Ratnayake, who served as the PUCSL Chairman when Gazette Extraordinary No. 2296/38 was issued in September 2022, highlighted that the gazette included seven recommendations to the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and the Power and Energy Ministry to prevent countrywide power failures. He said the Minister of Power and Energy was accountable for this incident, drawing parallels to a similar blackout on 3 December 2021, which caused an economic loss of around Rs 15 billion. Speaking further, the former PUCSL Chairman alleged additional damage, as one generating unit of the Norochcholai Power Plant was left out of order due to the blackout.   By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Church guard killed while attempting to prevent theft of donation box
author: Author not found
Content: A 67-year-old man who served as a guard in a church in Hatton was killed while attempting to prevent cash from being robbed from the church donation box. Following a tip off about the suspicious death of the guard near railway station road in Hatton on Saturday (9) morning, Hatton Police launched an investigation. Preliminary findings indicate that an unknown assailant entered the church premises and assaulted the guard with a weapon, leading to his death. Police suspect that the motive behind the incident was to get access to the donation box and pilfer the funds. The incident was recorded on the church’s CCTV footage. The victim has been identified as a Hatton resident. BY Neeta Pathmakumari – Hatton

title: Women comprise over 15% Police cadre – Sudarshini
author: Author not found
Content: At present women constitute over 15 per cent of the Police Service and despite undergoing identical recruitment, training, deployment, and retirement processes as their male counterparts, female officers report systemic injustice specifically in the promotion phase, it was revealed at the Parliament Select Committee on Gender Equity and Equality. The recent meeting chaired by Dr. Sudarshini Fernandopulle focused on gender-based discrimination and violation of women’s rights in Sri Lanka, recently revealed instances of injustice in the promotions in the Sri Lanka Police Service. The committee raised concerns related to the promotion process. It was highlighted that 92 female chief inspectors, having completed twenty-six years of service with an additional four years in the chief inspector role, faced challenges in their promotion process. Despite undergoing identical recruitment, training, salary structures and deployment processes as their male counterparts, female officers reported a distinct lack of identified vacancies for their promotions. The issue drew attention to the absence of problems related to vacancies during the promotion of male officers. In response to this gender disparity, the Committee proposed the creation of vacancies specifically designated for a 15% female representation in all positions. The objective is to rectify the present situation, establish a promotion system impacting both genders equally and ensure just promotions within a specified timeframe. Officials from the Ministry of Public Security confirmed that proposals for generating new vacancies with a focus on female representation had been forwarded to the Department of Management Services. To address the ongoing concern, the Committee Chair recommended to the Secretary of the Ministry of Public Security that, given the current 15% female representation in the Sri Lanka Police, an equivalent percentage of vacancies should be reserved for female officers to rectify the imbalance in the promotion process.

title: Army moves out of Mihintale Rajamaha Viharaya
author: Author not found
Content: Following a remark made by the Chief Incumbent of Mihintale Rajamaha Viharaya over the presence of Army personnel in the vicinity of the temple, the Sri Lanka Army has decided to remove soldiers deployed at the sacred site. The Chief Incumbent in a recent statement, raised concerns about military personnel in civvies at the sacred site and they could pose a threat.  When Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa made a statement on the matter, State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon said the military personnel stationed at the sacred site would be withdrawn if the chief incumbent perceives their presence as a threat to his life.  Tennakoon said there was a total of 225 security personnel deployed at the site, representing, Sri Lanka Amry, Sri Lanka Navy and Civil Security Department.  Addressing the issue, the state minister clarified, “The two individuals in civilian clothing are military personnel. They were assigned to ensure the security of the temple and the tourists after assessing the security situation. If their presence is deemed threatening, we have decided to withdraw all military personnel from the temple premises.” Meanwhile, Army Spokesman Brigadier Ravi Herath said all soldiers have been evacuated from the premises of the Mihintale Rajamaha Viharaya.  He said this decision was in response to a media statement by the temple’s head, who expressed suspicion about the behavior of two soldiers within the temple premises. Brigadier Herath elaborated that the Army had been deployed to ensure the safety of foreign tourists visiting the premises and to provide security for military personnel involved in construction activities of the sacred site.  However, due to the strained relations between the chief incumbent and the military personnel, the evacuation of all troops from Mihintale Rajamaha Viharaya premises was necessary for their safety. Meanwhile, the Police said no action has been taken to withdraw the police personnel assigned to the Mihintale Rajamaha Viharaya and they will continue duties at the sacred site. BY Mithun Jayawardhana  and Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Nagananda International Institute of Buddhist Studies holds Fourth Convocation
author: Author not found
Content: The fourth graduation ceremony of the Nagananda International Institute of Buddhist Studies (NIIBS – National Institute of Buddhist Studies) was held on 8 December under the patronage of Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha at the institute premises. 97 undergraduates were awarded degrees at the graduation ceremony, organised at the initiative of Ven. Dr. Bodagama Chandima Nayaka Thera, the Vice Chancellor of the Nagananda International Institute of Buddhist Studies.  10 Doctors of Philosophy (PhD) graduates, 48 Master’s graduates (MA), and 39 Bachelor’s (BA), including six foreign students graduated. Minister Premajayantha gave the graduation address  and many local dignitaries as well as foreign dignitaries from Japan, China, Thailand, Vietnam and Pakistan  participated.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: President Ranil Wickremesinghe advised heads of plantation companies to engage in a collective agreement concerning the wage hike for plantation workers, aiming for a minimum of Rs 1700, acceding to their request. Alternatively, they were urged to reach a consensus on the increased wage amount before 31 December. A discussion was held at the Presidential Secretariat on 8 December where the President met heads of plantation companies. The purpose of the meeting was to explore how regional plantation companies could align their programmes with agricultural modernisation initiative outlined in this year’s Budget. The discussion into the programme to grant land rights to plantation workers was also discussed. President  Wickremesinghe expressed his intention to set up committees for future work, proposing one committee to address housing needs of plantation workers and another to represent the interests of both workers and plantation companies. Emphasising his confidence in an export-oriented economy for the country’s economic development, President Wickremesinghe stressed the collective contribution that was needed to ensure the success of the agricultural modernisation programme. He highlighted the growing demand for food due to the increasing population in Asian countries and urged the country’s export economy to prepare for this reality. Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Promotion,  Manusha Nanayakkara, Minister of State for Finance , Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, Secretary to the President, Saman Ekanayake, Senior Adviser to the President on Economic Affairs ,Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, and numerous representatives from local plantation companies also discussed various aspects of the proposed initiatives. Popular

title: 75th Anniversary of Diplomatic Relations between Sri Lanka and Türkiye commemmorated
author: Author not found
Content: A special commemorative postage stamp was issued on Friday, 8 December, to mark the occasion of the 75th Anniversary of Diplomatic Relations between Sri Lanka and Türkiye. Delivering a special statement on this ocassion, Turkish Ambassador in Colombo, Demet Şekercioğlu, said, the significance of year 2023 reverberates beyond the centenary proclamation of the Turkish Republic.  “We also commemorate the 75th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between our Republics. It is worth mentioning that Türkiye was among the first countries to recognise Sri Lanka’s independence 75 years ago. Our relation gained a new dimension with the establishment of our Embassy here in Colombo 10 years ago, indeed serving as a true testament to our growing and flourishing partnership”, he said. The enduring relationship between the two countries was celebrated with the issuance of a special commemorative postage stamp.  The Ambassador said that as much as our deep-rooted connections, the design and decorations on the sides of this stamp feature the iconic regions of Cappadocia in Türkiye and Sigiriya in Sri Lanka, symbolising our intertwined histories.  Cappadocia is a region in Central Anatolia, Türkiye, where nature and history merge. It is best known for its unique geological features called fairy chimneys, underground cities, cave churches.   Cappadocia, sculpted out of the tuff of Mount Erciyes and Mount Hasan through millions of years by sand and water erosion, became the seat of several civilisations, and a silent witness to the cultural history of Anatolia.  Cappadocia was included in the World Heritage List of UNESCO in 1985 under the name “Göreme National Park and the Rock Sites of Cappadocia” on natural and cultural criteria. The stunning landscape of Cappadocia is also one of the most popular destinations for hot air balloon rides in the world.  At the same time, Sigiriya, synonym to Lion’s Rock in Sinhalese, is also UNESCO World Heritage site located in the Central Province of Sri Lanka in the Matale District.  Sigiriya is also monolithic rock rising above the surrounding plain to a height of 349 meters above the sea level.  Adding to the similarities of the two regions, one can also take a scenic view of Sigiriya and its surrounding by hot air balloon rides. It is also a pleasant coincidence that these balloon tours are also organised by SriLanka Balloon, which is a Turkish company.  The stamps were designed by the talented Sri Lankan artist Vasantha Perera, well-known for having designed 39 unique stamps for the Sri Lanka Philatelic Bureau.  The stamps showcase the cultural parallels between the two nations, with traditional elements like tulip and the carnation as side decorations. The tulip and the carnation are also common elements in both of Turkish and Sri Lankan traditional designs. Ambassador Şekercioğlu also said, the stamps’ envelope reflects a drawing of the historic building ‘Villa Stamboul’, linking us to a shared past.  The lavish ‘Stamboul Villa’ was built by Sir Mohamed Marcan Marker, born in 1877 and served as the Honorary Consul for the Ottoman Empire from 1903 until 1923, when the Ottoman Empire ceased to exit. He has named his villa after the capital of the Ottoman Empire, Istanbul.  The street on which the villa is established is a private road, and is also called Stamboul Place. “As we turn the page of a century based upon these monumental milestones, it is with great optimism that I envisage a flourishing future of enhanced cooperation between our two nations. May the friendship between Türkiye and Sri Lanka continue to prosper in the centuries to come and may our shared journey ahead be filled with remarkable milestones of triumph and togetherness,” the Ambassador said.

title: Civil society urges swift anti-corruption reform for economic recovery
author: Author not found
Content: In observance of International Anti-Corruption Day on December 9, a coalition of civil society organisations, alongside Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL), called for immediate and concrete actions towards anti-corruption governance reforms to foster sustainable economic recovery. The ‘Civil Society Initiative on Anti-Corruption Reform for Economic Recovery,’ comprising Verité Research, Centre for Policy Alternatives (CPA), Sarvodaya Shramadana Movement, People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) and National Peace Council (NPC), emphasised the urgency of addressing the economic crisis rooted in weak governance and entrenched corruption. This call was prompted by the recent release of the Governance Diagnostic Report by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report on the Corruption Landscape of Sri Lanka. Both reports underscored the necessity for comprehensive anti-corruption governance reforms. Nadishani Perera, former Executive Director of TISL, highlighted the Supreme Court’s recent landmark decision affirming that the economic crisis resulted from a governance failure. Perera emphasised the need to halt corruption and poor governance, which diverted relief and development funds from reaching those most in need. The coalition stressed the importance of prioritising and implementing governance reforms identified by civil society and the IMF to successfully restore the economy. The recent public uprising and economic crisis underscored the breakdown of public trust, necessitating the government to regain trust through concrete actions and reforms. The coalition advocated for institutions combating corruption to comprise individuals with integrity, appointed through an independent process, enabling them to act independently without fear of repercussion. Moreover, the coalition emphasised the need for a conducive environment for civic engagement, expressing concern about the government’s suppression of public expression and attempts to curtail freedoms through oppressive laws. The President and Government were urged to move beyond promises and demonstrate a commitment to transparent and accountable governance, implementing specified reforms while safeguarding democratic rights and civic space. The coalition called on public representatives in Parliament to demonstrate a commitment to real system change through actions, and international lenders and donors were urged to maintain pressure for governance reforms to ensure funds fulfilled their intended purposes. The public was invited to demand governance and anti-corruption reforms as essential components of economic recovery, marking International Anti-Corruption Day under the theme ‘UNCAC at 20: Uniting the World Against Corruption’.

title: Cricketing legend Aravinda felicitated by DS
author: Author not found
Content: Aravinda de Silva, the accomplished batsman and esteemed alumnus of D.S. Senanayake College, Colombo, was felicitated for his induction into the ICC Hall of Fame, on 8 December.  The ceremony took place at the R.I.T. Alles Hall of D.S. Senanayake College. In attendance were Aravinda de Silva, the former deputy skipper of Sri Lanka, along with his mother, Rani de Silva, sister Araliya and wife Anushka. The event was graced by Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, State Minister of Posts and Media Shantha Bandara, D.S. Senanayake College Principal Sampath Weragoda, along with fellow old boys and students. A first-day cover stamp featuring Aravinda de Silva was issued as part of the event. During the ceremony, Aravinda took a trip down memory lane, reflecting on his school days and offering insights into his transformative journey to becoming a successful cricketer (Pic by Manjula Dayawansa)
