title: Financial aid sought for SLAF officer’s liver transplant
author: Author not found
Content: Warrant Officer (Retired) Wimal Kithulampitiya (Service Number: 12156) from the Administrative Division of the Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) is currently battling a severe liver disease. His doctor has strongly recommended an urgent liver transplant as a critical measure to save his life. The essential liver transplant procedure is slated to take place at ‘Max Hospital’ in New Delhi, India, and the anticipated cost for the operation is approximately Rs 15 million.  While a potential liver donor has come forward, the full amount required for the operation has yet to be secured. Warrant Officer Kithulampitiya earnestly appeals to the people of the country for financial assistance to facilitate the liver transplant surgery. Those willing to contribute can deposit their donations into the Maharagama Commercial Bank branch account with the number 8180038974. For any additional inquiries, please contact the following telephone numbers: 0719941606 or 0774502473. Your generous support is greatly appreciated.

title: 450 Students graduate from Sri Lankan Aviation College
author: Author not found
Content: At a ceremony held at the Nelum Pokuna Theatre, the Sri Lankan Aviation College, affiliated with the International Aviation Association gave graduation certificates to 450 students who completed degree and diploma courses in the aviation sector. The event marked a noteworthy achievement after five years for the premier institution in Sri Lanka which conducts courses in compliance with global aviation standards. Nimal Siripala de Silva, Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation was the chief guest. Suren Raghavan, Minister of State for Higher Education and Ashok Pathirage, Chairman of SriLankan Airlines also attended the event. The Sri Lankan Aviation College offers a diverse range of courses covering pilot training, aircraft engineering, technician programmes, cabin crew, ground operations, air cargo handling, and approximately ten other aviation-related courses. Addressing the gathering, Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva commended the College’s contribution to the aviation industry, emphasising the capabilities of graduates produced by the institution. Despite being a small country with a single airline, Sri Lanka takes pride in the high standards maintained by Sri Lankan Airlines’ aviation college, he said. Minister de Silva acknowledged the challenges faced by the global aviation industry during the Covid crisis, highlighting the worldwide collapse of the airline sector and the subsequent suspension of flights and aircraft production. He recognised the ongoing impact on the aviation industry and the need to strengthen the economy. Expressing gratitude to President Ranil Wickremesinghe for his efforts, Minister de Silva affirmed the Government’s commitment to stabilising the economy in the face of ongoing challenges.

title: Commemorative stamp to mark 66 years of diplomatic relations between Sri Lanka and Egypt presented in Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: A commemorative stamp marking 66 years of diplomatic relations between Sri Lanka and Egypt was presented in Parliament recently.  Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena presented the commemorative stamp to dignitaries, including Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, and Ambassador of the Arab Republic of Egypt to Sri Lanka Maged Mosleh. Addressing the gathering, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena said Egypt was the first Arab State to open a Diplomatic Mission in Colombo in 1957. The Speaker also noted the expectation of strengthening bilateral relations between the two countries in various fields in the future. Egyptian Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Maged Mosleh expressed his anticipation to enhance the friendship between the two countries which have a rich history. The ambassador further said the Egyptian Government would issue a commemorative stamp marking the 66 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries, in line with this programme. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse, Deputy Chair of Committees Angajan Ramanathan, Leader of the House Minister Susil Premajayantha, MPs, Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General Chaminda Kularathna, Ambassadors of several Arab countries attended the event.  Secretary to the Ministry of Mass Media Anusha Palpita, Postmaster General M.R.P. Satkumara, Deputy Postmaster General Rajitha K Ranasinghe, and a group of officials representing the postal department were also present.

title: Dr Mahipala pledges to clean up health sector
author: Author not found
Content: Newly appointed Health Ministry Secretary Dr. Palitha Mahipala, pledged to rebuild public faith with new Health Policies and rectify the disrepute the Health Ministry was facing, within the next three months.  During discussions with the Medical and Civil Rights Association of Doctors (MCPA), he stated that he had identified all the weaknesses in the Health Ministry during the past several months.  The MCPA met Dr. Mahipala on Friday (8), during which he pledged to get rid of questionable procurement processes and start procurement with transparency. It has already been announced that programmes would be prepared under expert advice for the further development of community health services. Steps would be taken to develop public health services focusing on the rural child and maternal nutrition. President of the MCPA Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva lamented that the reputation and trust of the Health Ministry has been completely destroyed in the public eye due to questionable drug deals that occurred during the past few months. It is like an egg which has cracked from its interior and exterior, he added.  Dr.  Sanjeeva presenting facts to the new Health Ministry Secretary noted that the State health service was facing a crisis as a result of the questionable procurement processes, buying substandard drugs, the health professionals lacking confidence in the health system, the collapse of the community health system, the spread of non-communicable diseases, the lack of proper functioning of public health insurance and the crumbling of private hospital regulation.  He pointed out that the responsibility of the Health Ministry should be extended beyond the procurement of medicines to a wider community health service and patient care services. Unfortunately, the public is very displeased and disillusioned as this was not the situation for the past number of months, Dr. Sanjeeva pointed out.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Rs 205B for ‘Aswesuma’ 2024
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe said the application process for the second phase of the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefits programme will commence in January 2024. Emphasising the Government’s commitment to a thorough evaluation of the first phase of the welfare benefit scheme, the State Minister highlighted that a comprehensive review will precede the launch of the second phase. During this review, both challenges encountered in the implementation of the initial phase and suggestions provided by various stakeholders will be taken into consideration, according to Semasinghe. Further, the State Minister reported that ‘Aswesuma’ payments for October have been successfully credited to the accounts of 1,406,930 beneficiaries. Semasinghe spoke of the Government’s intention to expand the number of beneficiaries to two million in the coming year, emphasizing the careful selection of individuals most deserving of the welfare benefits. He added that a budget of Rs 205 billion has been allocated for ‘Aswesuma’ payments in 2024.

title: President inaugurates ‘Stanley Wijesundara AI Corner’ at Colombo Uni
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe announced the largest budget allocation in the country’s history for  technology, science, and research during the 100th birth commemoration of the late Professor Stanley Wijesundara, a renowned figure in Sri Lanka’s science sector. The President stressed the importance of fostering innovation and research to propel the nation’s progress. Revealing an unprecedented budget allocation aimed at bringing artificial intelligence (AI) technology to Sri Lanka, President Wickremesinghe focused on advancing scientific and technological research activities. Emphasising the need for a robust institutional system to cultivate a digital and green economy, the President aims to position Sri Lanka as a global player in these emerging fields. While lamenting the tragic loss of Professor Stanley Wijesundara, President Wickremesinghe expressed gratitude for his significant contributions to higher education and science. The President inaugurated the ‘Stanley Wijesundara AI Corner’ at the University of Colombo, unveiled a statue of Professor Wijesundara and issued a commemorative stamp and a first-day cover, marking the centenary of the esteemed scholar’s birth. Reflecting on his personal connection with Professor Wijesundara, President Wickremesinghe shared childhood memories and highlighted their collaboration in 1977 on the new university Bill. The President acknowledged Professor Wijesundara’s dedication to develop the Colombo University, particularly in enhancing the science department and establishing a computer centre. President Wickremesinghe lamented the broader context of violence during that era, recalling tragic incidents involving students, professors, and monks. He underscored the importance of remembering these events and urged the nation to reflect on the loss of valuable contributors to education and science. Discussing the growing significance of artificial intelligence in the global landscape, President Wickremesinghe highlighted international efforts and proposed legislation by the European Union to regulate and control the use of AI technology. He revealed a budget allocation of Rs 1.5 billion for AI technology in the next year and Rs 8 billion to enhance science and research activities, signalling the government’s commitment to foster innovation. The President reiterated the importance of focusing on science and research to drive the country forward, addressing climate change and promoting green energy. Plans include establishing the Technology and Innovation Council, a digital transformation agency, and the AI Corner at the University of Colombo, pending parliamentary approval. As the President concluded his speech, he urged the nation to embrace the changing technological landscape, emphasising the Government’s commitment to steering Sri Lanka towards a future marked by innovation, sustainability, and global competitiveness. The memorial celebration of Professor Wijesundara symbolised not only honouring a distinguished scientist but also the ushering in a new era of technological and scientific advancements for Sri Lanka. Attendees included Ven. Muruttettuwe Ananda Thera, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena and other dignitaries.

title: Plantation companies urged to increase wages
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has advised plantation company leaders to collectively agree on a wage hike for plantation workers, aiming for a minimum of Rs 1,700, as per the workers’ request. Alternatively, they have been urged to reach a consensus on the increased wage by 31 December. This guidance was provided during a discussion at the Presidential Secretariat on Friday (8), where the President met the heads of plantation companies. The purpose of the meeting was to explore how regional plantation companies could align their programmes with the agricultural modernisation initiative outlined in this year’s budget. The conversation also covered the programme designed to grant land rights to plantation workers. President Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed his intention to establish committees for future work, proposing one committee to address the housing needs of plantation workers and another to represent the interests of both workers and plantation companies. Highlighting his confidence in an export-oriented economy for the country’s economic development, President Wickremesinghe stressed the collective contribution needed to ensure the success of the agricultural modernisation programme. He emphasised the growing demand for food due to the increasing population of Asian countries and urged the country’s export economy to prepare for this reality. The event was attended by Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Promotion Manusha Nanayakkara, Minister of State for Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, Senior Advisor to the President on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga and numerous representatives.

title: 100 MT of sugar for Jaffna to be sold at Rs 280 per kilo
author: Author not found
Content: 100 MT of sugar is to be dispatched to the Northern Province for distribution across five districts, Jaffna, Kilinochchi, Vavuniya, Mannar and Mullaitivu. Minister of Fisheries Douglas Devananda said sugar would be sold through cooperative societies at Rs 280 per kg, a reduction from the market price of Rs 320. The sugar consignment would relieve the sugar shortage in the Northern Province, Devananda said. He said the transport and sale of sugar to the North was under close scrutiny. Devananda said three MT of substandard sugar, identified in an eight MT shipment sent to the North, were promptly returned to the original company. Discussions have already taken place with the said company and they have committed to sending an equivalent quantity of high-quality sugar to the North in the near future. BY Naalir Jamadeen

title: Nutritional intake of troops impacted by economic crisis
author: Author not found
Content: Senior officers of the Army informed the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) that providing a daily diet containing 3,400 kilocalories to soldiers has become challenging due to the present economic crisis. They highlighted that this situation is adversely impacting the morale and physical fitness of military personnel.  It was also revealed at the committee meeting that nearly 30,000 soldiers have left the Army since 2021. COPF Chairman, Dr. Harsha de Silva, expressed concern, saying that the inability to provide meals with the appropriate caloric content is a failure as a country and urgent measures need to be taken to address this issue. Dr. de Silva said this while approving a supplementary estimate of Rs 16.5 billion submitted to settle outstanding bills for suppliers who provide food to the Sri Lanka Army. The COPF Chairman stressed the importance of evaluating whether the Army is receiving nutritionally adequate meals compared to the Government’s expenditure.  Meanwhile, the committee directed Defence Ministry officials to submit a report on the previous estimate, the new estimate and the amount spent on the construction of the Army Headquarters in Akuregoda.  By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: CEB Engineers’ Union blames Kanchana for lack of transparency
author: Author not found
Content: The CEB Engineers’ Union (CEBEU) has voiced apprehensions about the restructuring of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), expressing concerns over the approval of the proposed Electricity Sector Reforms Bill by the Cabinet.  They cite a distinct lack of transparency and consultation throughout the process. Despite assurances from Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera, regarding the provision of the Bill’s copy after Cabinet approval, it hasn’t been shared yet. This delay has led the CEBEU to contemplate legal action on the issue. The CEBEU has also requested an early appointment from Sagala Ratnayake to meet the President to discuss the ongoing Reform Process of CEB. According to the CEBEU, the drafting of the new Acts — replacing the Electricity Act of 2009 and the CEB Act of 1969 was carried out covertly, without involvement from individuals within the CEB or other experts from the power sector. “The approval of the new ‘Electricity Act on 20 November 2023,’ occurring without prior consultation and the absence of input from industry experts or stakeholders during the drafting process has raised significant concerns,” it said. “Chairman of the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) Saliya Wickramasuriya and former Chairman of BOI Thilan Wijesinghe drafted the Bill without involving any stakeholders or experts from the power sector, relying solely on their business groups,” alleged the CEBEU. They highlighted a significant omission in the draft — there’s no clause for customer protection, a fundamental right for ordinary citizens. According to them, the Cabinet approved the draft Bill on 20 November, and the version circulating on social media exhibits numerous flaws, including grammatical and printing errors. The hurried and secretive manner in which it was produced behind closed doors is evident, they alleged.  Despite requests from the CEBEU, Minister Wijesekera had indicated that the draft would be shared after Cabinet approval. However, over 200 stakeholders, including those from the solar and hydro sectors, along with experts, were denied access to the Bill. Its contents have remained confidential till now, despite widespread interest and requests for transparency, the Union charged. The CEBEU said, they had even sent a letter to the Minister to show the draft and they also think that the draft that is circulating on social media is the actual draft confirmed by inside sources of the CEBEU.  But, the worst part they said is yesterday (6), the Ministry website has notified that the Bill was gazetted on 5 November and the new Bill has been uploaded to the website. But, the CEBEU said, the file cannot be downloaded and it is inactive.  Having seen that the draft cannot be downloaded, the CEBEU has visited the Department of Government Printing to obtain the gazetted copy, however, the Government Printer has said there is no such Gazette ready and that “they are proofreading”. “There is no hard copy of the draft and it should be ready if it is gazetted. We have evidence that they still don’t have the Bill ready as yet, but are hoodwinking the public,” the CEBEU said.  On 4 August 2023, the CEBEU sent a letter to the Minister of Power and Energy for a discussion with him regarding the ongoing Power Sector Reforms, including their last communication via the letter dated 18 July 2023. The letter stated that the CEBEU as the major professional stakeholder employee trade union in CEB, has been actively engaging on the need for a reform in the power sector in Sri Lanka, including a substantial restructuring of CEB during the past years. “As a professional trade union, CEBEU has already expressed our genuine enthusiasm for a truthful restructuring of the power sector in Sri Lanka including CEB, through which a significant amount of issues in the Sri Lankan power sector could be resolved. Also, we have emphasised to you that restructuring CEB only, would not solve every problem in the power sector including key issues such as policy inconsistency in the limited discussions had with you.” Further, the CEBEU had pointed out to the authorities that, despite the ambitious timeline of the Government, the reform committee and the Minister have failed to take the open and transparent approach and up to date has not had any consultation with the employees of CEB, who are the main stakeholders in the restructuring process. Moreover, CEBEU has explained that the secretive manner in which the sector reforms are being tried, will eventually lead to lack of trust in reforms and hence to failure of the process via our previous communications. “Also, it needs to be highlighted that, almost all the Trade Unions in CEB are willing to support truthful and honest reform initiatives and emphasised that to ensure the successful implementation of reform plans, genuineness of the Government will be a major deciding factor. Also, it needs to be emphasised that of our unwillingness for any move of privatisation through reform process.” “However, instead of simply agreeing or disagreeing with the current reform proposal presented and the processes continued by the Government, CEBEU opted to independently study pros and cons of reforms, observe the successes and failures of reforms in other countries and what is the optimum level and attributes of reforming of the Sri Lankan power sector. As communicated earlier, CEBEU has prepared a document called ‘An Insight of Power Sector Reforms by CEBEU’ and we were hoping to physically meet the both of you and the Secretary, MOPE to brief of the contents of the said document, along with our comments for the ongoing process of reforms.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Customs intercepts Rs 60M worth narcotics shipment
author: Author not found
Content: Customs Spokesman Sivali Arukgoda announced yesterday (7), that the Sri Lanka Customs Narcotics Control Division successfully intercepted a significant shipment containing several types of narcotics valued at approximately Rs 60 million.  The narcotics were concealed in seven courier parcels. The intercepted substances include 8 kg of Kush, 160 g of Mandy, 350 Ecstasy pills and 8 g of Ice. These parcels were dispatched from the United States, France and Canada to recipients in Colombo, Maharagama and Piliyandala. Following an investigation into the provided addresses, it was confirmed that the addresses were falsified. Arukgoda mentioned that the narcotics were seized during raids conducted at Colombo Cargo Express in Seeduwa. Further investigations will be conducted by the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB).  On Tuesday (5), a consignment of narcotics valued at nearly Rs 43 million from Germany and the UK, was seized. Twenty-five narcotics parcels, sent to individuals in Colombo, Maharagama, Battaramulla, Boralesgamuwa, Panadura, Moratuwa and Kandy were found to have fake addresses. Officers from the Sri Lanka Customs Narcotics Control Division seized these drug parcels at the Central Mail Exchange. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Former CEA Chairman Pathirage files FR petition
author: Author not found
Content: Supun Shashendra Pathirage, the former Chairman of the Central Environmental Authority (CEA), has lodged a Fundamental Rights (FR) petition challenging his arrest on allegations of soliciting a bribe. The respondents named in the petition include the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), its Chairman Eva Wanasundera and the Commission’s members. In the petition, Pathirage contends that he rejected an application for the renewal of a licence related to a marine fuel refining operation for six specific reasons. He asserts that he faced pressure from politicians and various other parties to approve the application against his judgment. Pathirage claims that subsequent to this, he was arrested on bribery charges, alleging that he solicited a bribe of Rs 10 million to process the said application. Thus, the former CEA Chairman is urging the Supreme Court to issue an order determining that the Bribery Commission’s decision to arrest him was carried out with “malicious intent” and that his Fundamental Rights were violated. The petition has been filed two days after his arrest.

title: Trial-at-Bar Judges inspect crime scene
author: Author not found
Content: The Trial-at-Bar Judges of the Gampaha High Court, yesterday (7), visited Nittambuwa to inspect the scene where former SLPP MP Amarakeerthi Athukorala and his body guard were brutally beaten to death last year, during the country’s anti-government riots. The Judges, Sahan Mapa Bandara (President) along with Rashmi Singappuli and D.A. Ruwan Pathirana, visited the area concerned, for their inspection. Forty-one accused have been indicted over the murders on 14 counts.  By Pramodya Gowravi – Pasyala

title: Vadivel Suresh appointed Senior Advisor to President
author: Author not found
Content: MP Vadivel Suresh, who was with the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) representing the Badulla District, has assumed the role of Senior Advisor to President Ranil Wickremesinghe and is tasked with overseeing the comprehensive integration of Upcountry Tamils into  Sri Lankan society and addressing matters related to the Nuwara Eliya, Badulla and Ratnapura Districts.  Jeevan Thondaman, Minister of Water Supply and Plantation Infrastructure Development, expressed support for Suresh, highlighting the significance of having a representative from the hill community in such a role. Thondaman also assured assistance from his ministry if needed for Suresh’s initiatives. MP Suresh has pledged support to the UNP and its Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe. He was earlier with the UNP and crossed over to the SJB later on. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Health Secy, DGHS pay surprise visit to NHSL Accident Service
author: Author not found
Content: Health Secretary Dr. Palitha Mahipala and Director General of Health Services (DGHS) Dr. Asela Gunawardena paid a surprise visit to the Accident Service of the National Hospital, Colombo. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry said, the two had examined the services carried out by the health service staff including the X-ray and CT scan examinations. He noted that the visit had been carried out on the instructions of Health Minister, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana.  The patient treatment and the services that were provided by the Accident Service of the National Hospital, Colombo were scrutinised during the unexpected visit of the Health Secretary and the DGHS on Wednesday (6) night. Attention was paid to the operating theatres, wards and blood bank, as well as essential medicines and other medical equipment including the stocks of antibiotics.  Overall, it was observed that the Accident Service is functioning very well. The Health Secretary and the Director General of Health Services also appreciated the dedication of health staff, including doctors, nurses and specialists in the treatment services. Deputy Director General of the National Hospital, Dr. Kumara Wickramasinghe was informed about the urgent measures that had to be taken to strengthen the treatment services. The Accident Service of NHSL Colombo treats both critical and non-critical patients.  Deputy Director General, NHSL, Colombo, Dr. Kumara Wickramasinghe, was also present. Meanwhile, the Government Radiological Technologists’ Association (GRTA), when contacted, alleged that the main X-ray machine and the backup X-ray machine at the NHSL Accident Service were yet to be repaired.  “Although the Health Ministry attempts to show that all is well, the two machines are yet to be repaired and it would take over a week to repair at least one. It has been almost 2-½ months since the main X-ray machine broke down,” it said.   President of the GRTA, Chanaka Dharmawickrama said the Health Secretary and DGHS had observed that accident victims were taken to the Neuro Trauma Centre for X-rays.  The NHSL is the largest Teaching Hospital in the country, with one of the busiest Accident Service Centres. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SLBFE to repatriate failed job seekers from Dubai
author: Author not found
Content: Efforts are underway to repatriate a group of non-drivers who sought employment at a taxi company in Dubai, UAE, Minister of Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said in Parliament yesterday (7). The Minister was responding to a query from Parliamentarian Wasantha Yapa Bandara, who raised concerns about a group of 200 Sri Lankans facing delays in their employment with a Dubai taxi company. Nanayakkara said, certain individuals who lacked the qualifications to be drivers had deceitfully gone to Dubai seeking employment with a taxi company. However, they encountered difficulties as they were unable to pass the driving test in Dubai. He assured that efforts were underway to repatriate these individuals to Sri Lanka. The Minister clarified that the group had legally gone to Dubai through the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE). He explained that there was a waiting period as individuals needed to undergo necessary training and pass a driving test before being employed. Presently, those who successfully passed the driving test are being recruited.  Some individuals in the group had gone to Dubai fraudulently without the required skills. Additionally, some who possessed the necessary skills failed the driving test. Even among those who passed the test, there were individuals expressing a desire to return to Sri Lanka, he added.   By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: State Minister complains to acting IGP of a nuisance caller
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Primary Industries Chamara Sampath Dasanayake informed Parliament yesterday (7) that he had filed a complaint with the Acting Inspector General of Police (IGP) regarding a person who uses derogatory language and mocks MPs by giving nuisance phone calls.  He specifically highlighted that this individual targeted both him and State Minister Diana Gamage with derogatory language in their phone conversations. Dasanayake said, this during the Committee Stage Debate on the Expenditure Head of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. He identified the individual as Sahan Ganegoda and expressed his surprise that Ganegoda believed he wouldn’t be identified.  Dasanayake claimed that Ganegoda has a history of being involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ and has been an Army deserter.  Further, he alleged that women had filed multiple complaints against Ganegoda.  “I searched for him on social media and his profile contains photos of the Opposition Leader. This person is a criminal, gambler and thief. He is evading the Police now. I request all MPs to remain vigilant regarding his activities,” he said.   By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: CEB workers in Matara uncover possible human skeletal remains
author: Author not found
Content: A group of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) workers, engaged in excavating a pit for the installation of a utility pole in front of the Matara District Election Secretariat at Matara Fort, stumbled upon bones resembling those of humans.  Subsequently, the CEB workers informed officials from the Archaeology Department about their findings. Officials from the Archaeology Department Offices in Galle and Matara District then arrived to conduct an inspection and tests on the recovered bones. In addition to the bones, the CEB workers also uncovered a few old-fashioned nuts and bolts, along with some cups and saucers. The Archaeology Department officers will conduct further tests on the bones to determine to which period they belong. By P.L. Jayawardene – Kamburupitiya

title: ‘Vedda’ and two others remanded till 19 Dec
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, yesterday (7), remanded a suspect, identified as ‘Vedda’ and his two sisters, till 19 December in connection with a case, where they have been charged with, defrauding monies deposited by the public, into accounts of scores of cancer patients who sought donations for their treatment.  The main suspect is Jana Prasad alias ‘Vedda’, a resident of Hanwella and the other two suspects are Sewwandi Perera and Soyana Perera, both residents of Ja-Ela. The CID, prosecuting, told the Chief Magistrate, that the main suspect in the case ‘Vedda’ had carried out the alleged scam, in tow with the suspect sisters. They explained that thus far, 11 complaints had been received by them, linked to the scam, which had been set in motion by the main suspect, along with the suspect sisters. The CID pointed out that initial investigations into the financial racket, had revealed that the three suspects, had defrauded the cancer patients in excess of Rs 25 million, which had been deposited into their accounts, by donors and the public. The Prosecution informed Chief Magistrate Alwis, that the probe into the scam had shown that the trio had defrauded a sum of Rs 7.8 million, which had been deposited to a bank account, by donors of a young cancer patient from Chilaw, to carry out his surgery. They added that when the surgery of the cancer patient concerned, was scheduled to be carried out on 12 December, the three suspects, had pilfered the monies from his account, rather unashamedly. The CID stated that one of the spouses, of the two females in custody, had also been involved in the sordid scam and noted that further investigations were underway, to arrest him. The Prosecution mentioned that the suspects, had conducted their racket, via the use of several cell phones and SIM cards and observed that several documents, linked to the racket, had also been seized by them. The CID stated that the suspects, had responded to ads placed in the print and electronic media by cancer patients, seeking donations to tend to their ailments. They remarked that the suspects, had set in motion their racket, under the guise of collecting the donations, to be given to the cancer patients and that in the process, they had obtained information pertaining to bank accounts, NICs and telephone numbers of the patients. The CID opined that the suspects, whilst utilising those documents, had obtained SIM cards from private telecommunication firms, in the names of the cancer patients and then had illegally entered the bank accounts of the patients, via the data of those SIM cards, after which their monies had been defrauded. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Three arrested for ‘selling’ infant twins
author: Author not found
Content: Three women were arrested in connection with the trafficking of infant twins for Rs 50,000, including the mother of the newborns. The arrested individuals include a 23-year-old woman from Piliyandala, who allegedly “sold” her one-week-old twins. Additionally, two women from Ragama and Kelaniya were arrested for purportedly “purchasing” the babies. The arrests followed an investigation based on an anonymous tip received by the OIC of the Ragama Police regarding a woman in the area. Reportedly, the mother of the infants sold the babies to the two women in Ragama and Kelaniya, for a sum of Rs 25,000 each. The three suspects were produced before the Welisara Magistrate yesterday (7) and remanded till today (8). The twins were born at the Castle Street Hospital for Women, Police said. By B.T. Kotinkaduwa – Ragama
