title: Lankan arrested in India for running online job scam
author: Author not found
Content: The Cyber Crime Wing of India’s Cuddalore Police has arrested a Sri Lankan national for allegedly swindling INR 6 million (approximately LKR 23.5 million) from an IT professional in Cuddalore by offering online part-time jobs. According to the Cyber Crime Police, the complainant S. Sampath, 32 of Kurunjipadi, received a message offering an online part-time job through the Telegram app. He was lured by an unidentified person offering money for completing certain tasks online. Sampath was promised good returns for a small investment for reviewing the app. Sampath was then moved to a bigger Telegram group where he continued to perform tasks and made payments to the tune of INR 60 lakh to a bank account. He eventually lost the money to the fraudsters, following which he lodged a complaint with the Cyber Crime Police. On the directions of Superintendent of Police R. Rajaram, a thorough investigation was conducted by the Cyber Crime wing. The team traced the last transaction of INR 6 lakh made to an account holder and obtained the KYC of the suspected bank account. The details of the account holder and linked mobile number were collected from the bank. It was found that the account belonged to Salman Mohammed Farook, 26, a Sri Lankan national, residing at Ambattur in Chennai. Police said the kingpin of the online scam was from China. The Police arrested Salman in Chennai on Tuesday and brought him to Cuddalore. He was produced in a local Court and remanded to custody in the Cuddalore Central Prison. (The Hindu)

title: CWC holds ILO Occupational Safety and Health Seminar for Tea Plantation Workers
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Workers Congress (CWC) in pursuance of implementing the ILO Occupational Safety and Health Project held a 4 -Day Seminar at CLF, Kotagala from 27 to 30 November for workers in Tea Plantations and Factories, comprising 200 participants. The main focus was on the occupational safety and health of the workers in the plantations and the rights of the workers. As an extension of the programme, 70 youth were enrolled on this programme to create awareness on the prevention of occupational accidents. Comprehensive lectures were delivered by Trainers of Training (TOT), trained by the ILO and the Director of Industrial  Relations, S Rajamany supported by R. Ramesh, Accountant, CWC. The main lecture was delivered by S.A. Jayasundera, District Factory Engineer, Nuwara Eliya District. Participants from the Nuwara Eliya District expressed the usefulness of such programmes for the plantation community and workers. Similar programmes will be conducted in the Badulla District on 10 December and Kandy, Kegalle and Ratnapura Districts on 11 December respectively. This Project is implemented under the direction of  K. Marimuttu, Chief Legal Adviser, CWC.

title: SL Diaspora Should Be Viewed More Positively
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee on International Relations highlighted the need to shift the negative perception of the Sri Lankan Diaspora to a more positive outlook. The committee pointed out that other countries view their migrant populations positively, with Foreign Affairs Ministries advocating on their behalf. The committee emphasised that Sri Lanka’s expatriate community has attained high positions in their host countries, suggesting that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Sri Lanka should pay attention to this aspect. The committee proposed the preparation of salary scales to attract applicants with practical skills into the recruitment process for positions within the Sri Lanka Foreign Service and suggested a reform of the recruitment system. In response, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that a considerable portion of marks is awarded based on the recruitment exam and academic qualifications. Consequently, candidates lacking practical knowledge, skills and the necessary personality traits may still be admitted to the service solely based on their exam scores.  This discussion took place during a recent meeting of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on International Relations in Parliament chaired by MP Namal Rajapaksa. Officials present at the Committee noted that while a significant number of candidates qualified for interviews based on academic qualifications and high scores in the foreign service recruitment examination, the practical knowledge, skills and personality necessary to meet the country’s and the service’s needs were not adequately reflected during the interviews. Additionally, the committee discussed the prolonged and complex process of providing necessary infrastructure for foreign embassies. To address this, the Committee recommended making timely changes to the procurement process. Namal Rajapaksa, Chair of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on International Relations, inquired about the internship programme, instructing officials to report to the committee about the responsibilities, roles and programmes carried out by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for groups undergoing internship training. Members of the committee MPs Niroshan Perera and Madhura Withanage also participated in the meeting. Youth representatives assigned to the Committee were granted permission to present their ideas before the Committee during the meeting.

title: Online Safety Bill discussed with Singapore-based AIC
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation led by Public Security Ministry Secretary Viyani Gunathilaka had a lengthy consultation with Singapore based Tech Industry collective Asia Internet Coalition (AIC) on Sri Lanka’s Online Safety Bill.  Details of the Bill and Supreme Court determination were discussed where the Ministry delegation requested AIC inputs for the possible amendments to the Bill.  This meeting was held in parallel to the Online Safety Forum jointly organised by AIC and Lee Kwan Yew School of Public Policy in Singapore.  The ministry delegation comprised Head of Police Legal Division DIG Ruwan Gunasekera and DG NGO Secretariat Sanjeewa Wimalagunaratna.

title: SL, Russia discuss strengthening bilateral security
author: Author not found
Content: A special discussion on strengthening bilateral security relations between Sri Lanka and Russia, as well as international information security, was chaired by Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles yesterday (7). This special discussion took place at the Ministry of Public Security premises with the participation of Deputy Secretary of the Russian Security Council, Oleg Vladimirovich and Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. During the meeting, there was an exchange of views between the representatives of the two sides regarding Russia’s continued support to strengthen Sri Lanka’s security and enhance international information security. A high-level delegation from Russia, including the Deputy Secretary of the Russian Security Council, participated in the discussion. The meeting was attended by a group of ministry officials and Acting Inspector General of Police (IGP) Deshabandu Tennakoon.  (MJ)

title: Matara dairy farmers in dire straits
author: Author not found
Content: Dairy farmers in the Matara District are presently facing a dire situation due to cattle being afflicted with diarrhoea in the district. These farmers said due to the recent floods in the Matara District and due to flood waters not having receded for over 100 days cattle are facing food scarcity. They said cattle that consumed polluted water have been afflicted with diarrhoea, dealing a debilitating blow to the dairy industry. Farmers also lamented that medicine that is prescribed by veterinarians costs a fortune. These farmers therefore, urge the Government to look into their plight and provide them with relief. By Udaya Ranaweera  – Matara

title: President Allocates 40-Perch Plot to Sri Lanka Law College
author: Author not found
Content: Aimed at enhancing the facilities for Sri Lanka Law College students, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has announced the allocation of government-owned land for this purpose. The President reached this decision during a deliberation held at the Parliament Complex on Wednesday (6). Highlighting the historical significance of the Sri Lanka Law College, which is set to celebrate its 150th Anniversary in 2024, the President emphasised its noteworthy contribution, having produced three Presidents. Minister of Urban Development and Housing, Prasanna Ranatunga conveyed that a plot of land owned by the Urban Development Authority will be provided to the Sri Lanka Law College in accordance with the President’s directive. President Wickremesinghe directed relevant authorities to promptly formulate plans for the immediate enhancement of the Law College’s facilities. In the initial phase, a 40-perch plot will be allocated, with the remainder to be provided as per the requirements outlined in the comprehensive plan, following consultations with the Ministry of Justice. Dr. Athula Pathinayake, Principal of the Law College, expressed gratitude during the event, noting that in the school’s 150-year history, no land had been allocated to improve student facilities. He thanked President Wickremesinghe for the special attention given to this matter. The gathering included Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, Secretary of the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing W.S. Satyananda, Chairman of the Urban Development Authority Nimesh Herath, officials from the Attorney General’s Department and representatives from the students’ union of the Law College.

title: Sri Lankan Food, Tea and Tourism: Showcased at Brooklyn Mall in Pretoria
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of Sri Lanka in South Africa showcased Sri Lankan Food, Tea and Tourism at the Brooklyn Mall in Pretoria recently. The Sri Lankan stall under the theme of ‘Taste of Sri Lanka’ at the Brooklyn Mall was inaugurated by Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner of South Africa Gamini Gunawardena in the presence of the members of the diplomatic community in Pretoria and distinguished guests from the Sri Lankan community in South Africa. The stall was designed to showcase Sri Lankan Tourism, Tea, Food and Handicrafts with a view to promoting Sri Lanka as a travel destination. Sri Lankan traditional delicacies, including Kiribath, Mung Kavum, Kokis, Kottu, Roti, and Cutlets, were served with hot cups of ‘Ceylon Tea’ to the visitors. Basilur Tea facilitated the promotion of Pure Ceylon Tea for the event. The two-day event attracted more than 1,000 visitors. Leaflets and Booklets on Tea and Tourism were disseminated among visitors to promote Sri Lanka as an attractive tourist destination for South African tourists.

title: Ceylon Cinnamon – The true Cinnamon: showcased in Stockholm
author: Author not found
Content: Chefs in Sweden together with Swedish food industry representatives and Sri Lanka’s Ceylon Cinnamon brands joined the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Sweden to showcase the island`s world-renowned spice – Ceylon Cinnamon – at an event on 27 November in Stockholm. The evening featured the versatility of Ceylon Cinnamon through cuisine, scientific and health analysis exploring the benefit of authentic Ceylon Cinnamon, presentations on cultivation, harvesting and delicate processing of Ceylon Cinnamon in Sri Lanka to an audience of restaurant and food industry representatives, Chefs from several cuisine specialities, food ingredient importers and Swedish food brands as well as culinary specialists, food bloggers and journalists. Gracing the evening was Mayor Marith Hesse and delegation of Partille who were among those who lit the traditional Sri Lankan oil lamp. The Embassy’s initiative was partnered by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Colombo under the Economic Diplomacy initiative and was consistent with the policy articulated on Ceylon Cinnamon in President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s Budget Speech for 2023. The evening’s cuisine presented the versatility of True Cinnamon in Western, Eastern, South American, Sri Lankan cuisine and Ceylon Tea. The dishes highlighted Ceylon Cinnamon’s ability to blend, garnish and create starters, mains, desserts, mocktails and tea bringing out the fabulous versatility of the spice and thereby demonstrating why the age-old spice is indeed the King of Spices. The cuisine was prepared by the Chefs with top Alba-grade authentic Ceylon Cinnamon from two Sri Lankan global brands – HDDES and Cinnamon Legends – the event’s Cinnamon partners. Sri Lanka’s Envoy in Stockholm Dharshana M Perera in his remarks highlighted the versatility, authenticity, health and safety of Sri Lanka’s signature spice and the importance of understanding the distinction between Ceylon Cinnamon and ‘cinnamon’ alternatives such as Cassia by the discerning Swedish public.  He spoke of the evening’s opportunity to explore the creativity in cuisine and business with this unique spice particularly in Europe given the EU’s GI certification.  He invited the guests to explore the complimentary Ceylon Cinnamon provided by HDDES and Cinnamon legends in their homes, bakeries, production houses and restaurants. The gift packs included Ceylon Cinnamon Powder, Quills and Liquid Smoke from Cinnamon Legends and HDDES. Through a scientific analysis, Prof. Wimal Ubhayasekera presented the potential health benefits of Ceylon Cinnamon, as the preferred and healthy choice for consumption as against the ‘Cinnamon` alternatives such as Cassia. He enlightened the audience of the concerns relating to the significantly higher Coumarin content in the alternatives. The evening’s dishes specially created for the event included among others, Cinnamon and Chilli-marinated shrimp with Cinnamon aioli, Cinnamon marinated Fried Rice (Chef Sithira Jayasinghe), Cinnamon smoked Gua Bao Bun with Cinnamon braised Pork Belly (Chef Vishwa Tharidu), Cinnamon Hopper with Lunumiris (Navaneethan), Panna Cotta with  Cinnamon Candied Apples(Chef Sithira Jayasinghe), Cinnamon Buns/Cake (by Swedish food brand Naima), Mocktail Cinnamon Supreme with  Ceylon Cinnamon (Dilmah/Tekompaniet with Chewy Cinnamon brand) and a range of other dishes capturing the versatility and flavour of True Cinnamon.  The event also had the guidance and association of Swedish Chef Carola Magnusson (Carola’s EKO), and Margaretha Haglind (Bogawantalawa Tea).

title: 34 Research papers launched
author: Author not found
Content: The launch of 34 Research papers aimed at advancing Sri Lanka’s tea industry took place yesterday (7) morning, at the Grand Monarch Hotel in Thalawathugoda. The National Symposium on Tea 2023, organised by the Tea Research Institute, was held yesterday. Many individuals associated with the tea industry participated in this national conference, chaired by Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries, Mahinda Amaraweera. The release of 34 Research papers, addressing specific issues related to the tea industry in 2023, occurred during the event. Minister Amaraweera highlighted that these research papers were prepared with full sponsorship from the Tea Research Institute, emphasising the need to elevate tea cultivation and industry standards in the country. The Minister said, it is time for Sri Lanka’s tea industry to be integrated into the value-added production process and adopt good agricultural practices. As the second-largest supplier in the world tea market, Sri Lanka plays a crucial role.  The Minister underscored the importance of improving the quality of tea-related products to regain the popularity of the Ceylon Tea brand in the global market. The event was also attended by Prime Minister’s Secretary Anura Dissanayake and Tea Research Institute Chairman Chinthaka Lokuhetti.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Required number of fingerlings released in North
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda has announced that necessary arrangements have been made to release the required number of fingerlings into freshwater bodies across the Northern Province. Minister Devananda said, 200,000 fingerlings have already been released into ponds and freshwater bodies in the Puthukkudiyiruppu Divisional Secretariat Division in the Mullaitivu District. The objective of this initiative is to promote freshwater fishery in the province, meet the protein requirements of the region and provide livelihood opportunities to rural communities relying on freshwater bodies for survival. In addition, Devananda said 50,000 fingerlings were recently released into freshwater bodies in the Puthukkudiyiruppu area in the Karachchi DS Division of the Kilinochchi District. The inaugural ceremony for releasing fingerlings into freshwater bodies took place on 19 November, and a total of 150,000 fingerlings have been released in the Northern Province thus far, Minister Devananda said. Devananda emphasised his close monitoring of freshwater fish hatcheries, providing necessary guidelines and instructions to relevant officials to develop freshwater fishery, not only in the North and East but also islandwide. Minister Devananda acknowledged the pivotal role played by the National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA) in the successful implementation of this project. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Violent gang attacks person in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: A violent gang attacked a person in broad daylight in Kodikamam, Jaffna, yesterday (7), while he was travelling on a motorcycle. The gangsters were fleeing after burgling valuables from his house including cash and jewellery. According to Kodikamam Police, the gang attacked the person, while he was travelling with his friend, causing damage to the motorcycle.  The victim, who managed to escape his attackers, sought refuge in a neighbouring house and the gang, in the commotion, damaged a CCTV camera installed in front of the house. Police said the gang, during the burglary, damaged the main door, windows, television, and refrigerator and made off with Rs 700,000. Kodikamam Police are conducting investigations. The victim is presently receiving treatment at the Chavakachcheri Base Hospital. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: VAT increase effective 1 January 2024
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Finance (COPF) recommendation to the Ministry of Finance to increase the Value Added Tax (VAT) to 18 per cent has been granted, pending amendments, COPF Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva informed Parliament yesterday (6).  He said COPF has recommended exempting VAT for infant food, medical equipment and fertiliser. Dr. de Silva said according to the proposals of the Finance Ministry, the VAT increase would affect several commodities, including infant food items, fertiliser, medical equipment and ambulances, including the ‘Suwaseriya’ ambulance service. He emphasised that, while recognising the importance of tax revenue for State income enhancement, COPF is urging for fairness in tax implementation.  The committee has made an appeal to the Finance Ministry to reconsider the decision to impose VAT on the mentioned goods. He said, “The Government says the cost of importing ambulances would be borne by the Government and only equipment imported by the private sector would be subjected to VAT. But we have to be realistic. Right now, there are so many shortages in the State health sector and patients are being directed to the private sector for certain tests. So, the reality is patients would be more burdened with the VAT increase on medical equipment.” He also pointed out that it is not justifiable to increase VAT on infant food items when malnutrition among children has spiked amidst the economic crisis.  In October, the Cabinet of Ministers approved a raise in VAT from 15% to 18%, effective 1 January, 2024.  BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: MRI unable to carry out medical tests due to reagent shortage
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical Research Institute (MRI), the premier medical research institute in Sri Lanka is unable to carry out 32 medical tests due to the non-provision of reagents, The Joint Council of Professions Supplementary to Medicine (JCPSM) alleged.​ JCPSM President, Ravi Kumudesh yesterday (06) alleged that currently there are several unresolved issues in the State health sector and this was just one of them.  Adding insult to injury there was also a shortage of about 80 types of medicines in state hospitals and in the Medical Supplies Division (MSD). Authorities seemed to be clueless with regard to the delivery date not even the delivery date for the reagents and medicines were known, he accused.  Lashing out, Kumudesh said that as a result patients were being pushed to seek assistance from private laboratory facilities as they needed medication for their ailments. The chaotic situation has escalated as patients coming to state sector hospitals including the National Hospital fight with hospital staff stating that they don’t have money to go to the private sector.  Kumudesh alleged that a special commission was paid by private sector lab facilities for patients referred to their laboratories.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 544,488 disconnections and reconnections in 2023 – CEB
author: Author not found
Content: In the period from 2016 to October 2023, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) documented a total of 2,951,900 instances of electricity disconnections and reconnections.  This information was revealed by Engineer Noel Priyantha, Deputy General Manager (Business and Operations Strategy) and spokesman for the CEB. Breaking down the annual figures, it is revealed that there were 573,073 cases of disconnection and reconnection in 2019, followed by 210,380 in 2020, 94,201 in 2021, and 247,250 in 2022. The most recent data for the last 10 months of the current year shows a significant spike, with 544,488 instances, marking the highest frequency in this timeframe.  An interesting observation is the comparable figures between 2019 (573,073) and the recent months of 2023 (544,488), indicating a consistent pattern in disconnection and reconnection trends over the years. The spokesman emphasised the impact of external factors on these trends.  For instance, fewer power cuts and reconnections were reported in 2020 and 2021, attributed to the disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. In 2022, disruptions were limited and mainly stemmed from island-wide power cuts. Looking ahead, Priyantha projected 35,848 zero consumption accounts by November 2023. This is anticipated due to various reasons such as disconnection, house closures, lack of residents, demolitions, and new constructions. On average, approximately 150,000 new customers acquire electricity connections annually. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Private bus driver given 12 years RI
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle, yesterday (6), sentenced the driver of a private bus, who was found guilty of fatally running over three persons, including a preschool child and her grandmother, while injuring the child’s mother 16 years ago, to 12 years of Rigorous Imprisonment. The driver, Kusantha Gunerathna, was found guilty of reckless driving, along with the bus being driven at breakneck speed and fatally running over three persons, in Udahamulla back in 2007. Delivering the verdict, Judge Balalle stated that he was imposing the said penalty on the accused, as the Prosecution had proved its charges against him, beyond a reasonable doubt. The Court also slapped a fine of Rs 18,000 on the accused bus driver and instructed him to pay compensation amounting to Rs 150,000 to the closest relatives of two of the deceased, who had been named as witnesses in the Prosecution. The Judge also ordered the accused driver, to pay a sum of Rs 100,000, to the National Authority for the Protection of Victims of Crime and Witnesses (NAPVCW) and warned that failure to pay it would result in an additional 54-month jail term, being added to his original sentence. The Court imposed a lenient sentence on the accused driver, having considered a request to that effect by Defence Counsel Asitha Vipulanayake. Judge Balalle, however, acquitted the accused driver, from four other charges, filed against the latter, by the Prosecution. He then imposed a 15-month prison term, on the owner of the private bus and suspended it for a period of 15 years. The Court imposed a fine of Rs 21,000 on the bus owner and instructed him to pay compensation amounting to Rs 250,000 to the relatives of those who perished in the tragedy and ordered him to deposit a sum of Rs 200,000, to the NAPVCW.    The accident had taken place on or before 10 January 2007, at Udahamulla, Nugegoda and on completion of the investigation into the accident, the Attorney General had indicted the two accused, in the High Court, on 8 November of that year. Senior State Counsel Lakshman Perera, prosecuting, told the Court that it is common to see private bus drivers racing each other, without caring for the lives of commuters. He therefore requested the Court, to impose the most stringent punishment on the accused driver, to deter others, from committing similar acts in the future. Perera also urged the Judge to impose a similar penalty on the bus owner, Chamara Liyanage, who had deployed his bus without tending to its requisite repairs, which had contributed to the accident. Senior Counsel Gamini Alwis represented the bus owner. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: B-60 policy for tea production mandatory – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: From 1 January 2024, in order to rebuild the falling global recognition of the ‘Ceylon Tea’ brand, the Ministry of Agriculture and Plantation Industries has made it mandatory that companies follow the B-60 policy to ensure the quality of tea produced in Sri Lanka.  Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera addressing concerns about the decline in the global recognition of the Sri Lankan tea brand due to the activities of certain businessmen, highlighted that the B-60 policy was initiated to ensure the high quality of tea leaves and restore the international reputation of Sri Lankan tea. Amaraweera explained that the B-60 project aims to prevent the mixing of mature tea leaves during the tea leaf-picking process. He stressed that to revitalise the tea industry in the country, the quality of tea must be enhanced. He further emphasized the urgency of implementing the project to establish the best international market position for the tea industry in Sri Lanka. Under the B-60 policy, a minimum of 60 per cent of the leaves used in tea production must meet high-quality standards, he added. To safeguard the quality of tea leaves supplied to tea factories, all stakeholders in the tea industry have unanimously agreed to enforce the compulsory implementation of the B-60 policy. Minister Amaraweera emphasised the need to inform all sectors associated with the tea industry about this decision, urging the implementation of the policy to confirm the quality of tea leaves and notifying all relevant institutions. During a special discussion held on the next steps to verify the quality of Sri Lankan tea, the Minister instructed the Ceylon Tea Board to take necessary measures, including licence revocation, for any factory violating the B-60 project decision. BY Hansi Nanayakkara and Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Sajith, Mahindananda lock horns over alleged Rs 10B misappropriation
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage locked horns yesterday (6) in Parliament, when the latter claimed that an audit report had uncovered a misappropriation of Rs 10 billion during Premadasa’s tenure as the Minister of Housing and Cultural Affairs. Aluthgamage alleged, “A sum of Rs 10 billion has been misused from the Central Cultural Fund, and State funds were utilised to pay salaries for the ten security officers attached to the salon owned by the Opposition Leader’s wife. The Minister of Cultural Affairs should issue a statement on this matter. Aluthgamage also alleged that Premadasa had allocated Rs 1.6 million to repair Sirikotha during his ministerial term. When Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP S.M. Marikkar who defended Premadasa, questioned MP Aluthgamage about his property acquisitions in the UK. Aluthgamage replied, “My grandfather was a millionaire and my father was a businessman and I always had funds to spend. Both my parents have enough money and property. I pay Rs 2.5 million annually as taxes to the State. I’m a businessman and I can even buy property in the US.” Later in the day, Premadasa, who was outraged by Aluthgamage’s allegations, shot back alleging that millions had been utilised from the Central Cultural Fund in 2011 for a cycle race and the swearing-in ceremony of the then-President. He said, he would resign from being an MP if Aluthgamage proves the allegations.  At this juncture, Aluthgamage stepped into the Well and demanded if that is the case, Premadasa should resign immediately.  The back-and-forth talk continued during the committee stage debate on the Appropriation Bill 2024, with Aluthgamage making allegations and SJB MPs asserting that Premadasa had been cleared of all charges. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Minister Alles questions the motive of carrying LTTE flags
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles said he rejects the notion or suggestion that the PTA is being shunned by a majority of people in this country. Speaking in Parliament on Tuesday (5) Minister Alles said, “If I may elaborate further on this issue, three separate Courts had instructed not to press ahead with the staging of the Maha Viru Day celebrations. Also, the Attorney General AG) had clearly mentioned that he will enforce the law if such an event is staged based on a complaint lodged with the Court of Appeal. Anyone has the freedom or the right to commemorate the demise of a family member or a relative. We too attend such events. But we never visit memorials to celebrate another person’s birthday. No party carries its flag to such an event. It was stated here that the flag that had also been used by various political parties.” Minister Alles said he is not aware of a normal civilian carrying a flag with them to mark the death anniversary of a family member or a relative.  It is also clear that a large group had carried a flag with them to mark Prabhakaran’s birthday with ulterior motives. Look at the dress code of certain people who are not originally from the Eastern Province. Hence, we cannot state with certainty that either of these incidents are not linked to terrorism or the LTTE, he added. “I listened to intently related views expressed by all those concerning this proposal.  But when I began to respond to those views and when showing certain photos some MPs had begun to behave in an overly aggressive manner. When we disclose the truth, it is clear that some cannot stomach it. I also urge the Chair not to allow such people to dictate terms. Commemorating events is one thing, but allowing the vanquished LTTE Leader’s photos and flags to be displayed is another and it cannot be condoned and should be banned.” “Therefore, I urge you as MPs of your Provinces and Districts to request your people not to resort to such actions. When incidents of this scale occur, the Police cannot remain deaf and blind. As Ministers we too cannot remain like that. We have to enforce the law concerning such incidents. It has to be emphasised that the actions resorted to by the Police has not been unlawful at any stage.  As per an order issued by Court the suspects arrested were produced before Court within a 48-hour period. They were remanded based on orders issued by the Court. Though we had the chance to detain them in the Police Department we did not resort to it. We have obtained a statement made by the owner of a bakery which had produced a cake embossed with the image of the late LTTE supremo. Based on all these details it is only the Court which has the authority to either enlarge the remanded suspects on bail or not.”

title: Appeal Court rejects request to invalidate CID Detention Order on Harak Kata
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (6) ruled that underworld figure Nadun Chinthaka Wickramaratne, also known as ‘Harak Kata’,  must be promptly produced before a Magistrate if the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) fails to provide new evidence to the Minister of Defence demonstrating that he has committed an offence under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). The two-judge Bench of the Court of Appeal, presided over by Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and Justice Chamath Morais ruled that as the CID had not presented any evidence indicating that Harak Kata had committed offences under the PTA and if no new evidence is provided in this regard, he must be immediately brought before the Magistrate. Additionally, the Bench rejected another petition submitted by him where he sought a writ order to invalidate the detention order issued by the CID to keep him in custody. “It should be borne in mind that this will not preclude the Minister of Defence from issuing a fresh detention order on being satisfied with the material presented before him. Subject to the said directions this writ application is dismissed without cost,” the Bench said.  Senior Counsel Senany Dayaratne with Counsel Nishadi Wickramasinghe, Sanjaya Ariyadasa, Thiru Amirthalingam and Achinika Fernando instructed by Thushari Jayawardena appeared for the petitioner. The arrest of ‘Harak Kata’ took place in Madagascar on 1 March this year, alongside his infamous accomplice Salindu Malshika, alias ‘Kudu Salindu’. The operation was a joint effort involving INTERPOL, Madagascar law enforcement authorities and Customs officials. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Colombo HC issues notice on Mt Lavinia Chief Magistrate
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court (CHC) Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (6) issued notice on Mount Lavinia Chief Magistrate Kosala Senadeera to be present to testify in a case filed against the younger brother (Sunimal Perera), of noted drug kingpin and death row inmate Wele Suda. The noted drug peddler’s younger brother has been charged with attempting to run over a police officer of the Traffic Unit in a traffic accident. Following an inquiry made by the High Court, on 13 October from the Mount Lavinia Chief Magistrate’s Court, over the failure to locate a case file pertaining to the accused, being heard in the Magistrate’s Court, the latter, had informed the High Court accordingly. Judge Marasinghe also advised the Court Registrar to send photo copies of documents, concerning the identification parade which the accused had been subjected to at the Magistrate’s Court to the Chief Magistrate in question along with the notice. The Secretary of the Mount Lavinia Chief Magistrate’s Court had testified before the High Court on 20 October.      BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Former DIG Nalaka de Silva acquitted
author: Author not found
Content: Former Deputy Inspector General (DIG) of Police, Nalaka de Silva was acquitted in the case related to the alleged VIP assassination plot in 2019. Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage acquitted de Silva after the Attorney General informed the Court that there was “insufficient evidence” to substantiate the accusations against him. In September 2018, Namal Kumara, the Director (Operations) of the Anti-Corruption Movement, brought to light an alleged conspiracy to assassinate former presidents Maithripala Sirisena and Gotabaya Rajapaksa and contentious conversations he claimed to have had with former DIG Nalaka de Silva on this matter. Following this revelation, the CID initiated investigations, questioning the former Director of the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID) on multiple occasions. Subsequently, de Silva was arrested by the CID on 25 October 2018. In May 2019, the Colombo Fort Magistrate granted him bail.  By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Bilateral talks over ETCA to continue in Jan 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet announced yesterday that the 12th round of bilateral talks between India and Sri Lanka took place regarding the proposed India–Sri Lanka Economic and Technology Cooperative Agreement (ETCA) from 30 October to 1 November 2023. They have planned to proceed with the 13th round of talks in January 2024.   The two countries had been engaging in 11 rounds of bilateral talks between 2016 and 2018 and the negotiations came to a ‘pause’.   The Sri Lanka Government announced that both active groups from India and Sri Lanka have reached agreements across several relevant sectors. They have decided to convene the 13th round of discussions from 8-10 January 2024 in India. Additionally, there are plans to conclude the technical level discussions by March 2024. The Cabinet said they have considered the information forwarded by President Ranil Wickremesinghe on the 12th round of discussions. Last month, the President announced in Parliament that Sri Lanka is on course to finalise the ETCA with India and establish a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with China. Leading the Sri Lankan delegation ETCA was chief negotiator K.J. Weerasinghe, while the Indian delegation was headed by Shri Anant Swarup, Joint Secretary in the Department of Commerce and Chief Negotiator for the Government.  Throughout the 11th round, both parties assessed the advancements made until the 11th round and delved into discussions covering various chapters, including Trade in goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, trade in services, customs procedures and trade facilitation, rules of origin, trade remedies, economic and technological cooperation, and dispute settlement. Identifying areas of alignment and those requiring innovative solutions was a shared focus. In this phase, both sides conducted a comprehensive review of the implementation progress and collectively agreed to resolve and eliminate nine issues. Additionally, discussions centered on topics such as quotas concerning apparel and pepper, as well as pharmaceutical procurement. Both parties have committed to further dialogues and exploration of fresh approaches to address these matters. India highlighted that concerning the proposed ETCA, mutual agreement exists on the importance of leveraging previous advancements while reassessing positions to accommodate new developments. The successful conclusion of these negotiations is anticipated to unlock fresh prospects for trade and economic collaboration beneficial to both nations. The India-Sri Lanka ETCA is poised to play a crucial role in amplifying bilateral trade, fostering increased economic ties between the two countries. Acknowledging the vast potential within the India-Sri Lanka trade partnership, both sides recognise the opportunities to bolster economic relations across areas of mutual interest. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Job prospects for Sri Lankans in Japan progressing
author: Author not found
Content: Through a collaborative effort between the Sri Lankan Embassy in Japan, the Ministry of Labour and Foreign Employment, and the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE), significant progress has been made in creating fresh employment avenues for Sri Lankans in Japan. The launch of examinations in Construction Skills Test under Japan’s Specified Skilled Worker (SSW) Programme on 1 December 2023 in Sri Lanka marks a crucial milestone. This initiative aims to unlock new job prospects for Sri Lankans in the Japanese job market.  The Specified Skilled Worker programme offers foreign nationals a status of residence to contribute specialised skills in identified industry fields, addressing the shortage of workers in Japan’s labour market. This collaboration stresses the commitment to strengthen bilateral ties with Japan and create pathways for Sri Lankans to contribute to country’s foreign exchange remittances keeping in line with the Government initiatives to increase overseas job opportunities for Sri Lankans. With this addition, four categories will be open for Sri Lankans to qualify under the SSW Programme which comprises of 12 categories including  the Aviation sector, scheduled to commence in March 2024 that promises additional opportunities under this programme.   Up to now, exams in Nursing Care, Food Service Industry and Agriculture categories have been conducted in Sri Lanka.  Ongoing efforts of the Embassy in Japan with the close support and coordination of Ministry of Labour and Foreign Employment and the SLBFE aim to obtain job opportunities in the fields such as Automobile Repair and other SSW categories as well. For information on its registration, the public can visit the following website of Prometric, which conducts the tests for SSW. https://www.prometric-jp.com/en/ssw/ By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sri Lanka Youth Statement unveiled at COP28
author: Author not found
Content: In line with the ongoing 28th United Nations Conference on Climate Change (COP28) in Dubai, the Sri Lanka Youth Statement to COP28 was unveiled at the first-ever Sri Lankan Youth–led Forum organised at the Sri Lanka Pavilion on the summit premises last Saturday (2).  The Youth Statement drafted under the guidance of Chairman of the National Youth Services Council (NYSC) Pasindu Gunaratne and Head of Research, Engagement and Climate Action Bodh Mathura Local Conferences of Youth (LCOYs) country focal Fatima Shamla, UNICEF Sri Lanka Youth Advocate Tharushi Weerasinghe and Environmental Economist Sandev Ferdinando was also presented to President Ranil Wickremesinghe prior to the COP28 Summit. The Youth Statement comprising 10 crucial recommendations addressing the impacts of climate change and potential remedies to mitigate the climate crisis, calls for immediate action to be taken by the government of Sri Lanka and parties involved in COP28  to enhance climate change education, enhanced youth representation in policy-decision making and efforts towards environmental conservation and biodiversity protection.  Some of the key demands made in the Sri Lanka Youth Statement include the recognition of the right to water as a human right and calling for the inclusion of groundwater and rainwater  to end the criminalisation of water as a weapon across countries and conflict zones in the world, and to ensure the freedom of expression of climate and environmental activists and concerned citizens  by acknowledging their rights through the establishment of more robust legal mechanisms, the removal of legislative obstacles to freedom of expression and the allocation of resources for their protection and security.  The Youth Statement also calls on the Government of Sri Lanka to ensure that the country’s green energy transitions follows the ‘just transition’ principles to ensure policies that prioritise human life and dignity and adopt the Fossil Fuel Non- Proliferation Treaty Initiative,  to be cautious regarding nuclear and hydrogen energy sources which according to the statement, has had controversial consequences in the Global North. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: SLAF inducts two Harbin Y-12 IV aircraft in momentous ceremony
author: Author not found
Content: In a momentous ceremony held on 5 December at SLAF Base Ratmalana, the Sri Lanka Air Force marked a significant chapter in history with the ceremonial induction of two Harbin Y-12 IV aircraft. The ceremony was graced by the State Minister of Defence, Premitha Bandara Tennakoon and the Ambassador of the People’s Republic of China, Qi Zhenhong. The No. 8 Tactical Transport Squadron, renowned as ‘The Cradle of Transport Pilots,’ laid the foundation for this historic occasion on 2 April 1996. Originally equipped with eight Y-12 II aircraft (SCL 851 to SCL 859) inducted in 1987, these aircraft played a pivotal role in various air operations during the local theatre of war. The formal proceedings commenced with the signing of documents symbolising the transfer of the Harbin Y-12 aircraft to the Sri Lanka Air Force. Air Force Commander, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa and Den Ling from China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC) presided over this key moment, marking the official handover. Addressing the gathering, the Air Force Commander expressed gratitude for the strategic partnership and elaborated on the significance of the new additions to the Sri Lanka Air Force’s fleet. He emphasised the continued commitment to strengthening international collaborations, highlighting the value of the Harbin Y-12 IV aircraft in enhancing the Air Force’s operational capabilities. In a gesture of appreciation, a memento was presented to the Chief Guest, Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, to commemorate the milestone. Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa extended his gratitude to the State Minister of Defence, acknowledging the untiring support in advancing the capabilities of the Sri Lanka Air Force. The Chief Guest expressed pride in witnessing this significant occasion and reiterated the Government’s commitment, guided by the Chief of the Armed Forces and President of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, Ranil Wickremesinghe, to ensuring regional security and stability. This significant occasion was attended by Senior Advisor to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff, Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary to the Ministry of Defence, General (Retd) Kamal Gunaratne, Chief of Defence Staff, General Shavendra Silva, Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, Chief of Staff of the SLAF, Members of the Air Force Board of Management, officials of the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in Sri Lanka, Members of the CATIC from China and representatives of CATIC Sri Lanka, senior officers of the SLAF and other officials.

title: Sunil Dissanayake appointed Jaffna Uni visiting faculty member
author: Author not found
Content: Sunil Dissanayake, Retired DG of BMICH and Hospitality/ MICE and HR Professional has been appointed as a visiting faculty member for the Business Administration Honours Degree in Tourism and Hospitality Management effective November 2023, by the Vice Chancellor, University of Jaffna. He has also been appointed as an Advisor to the Northern Province Tourism Association by the Executive Committee.

title: Rs 5.5B given to Northern PC after polls underutilised – EPDP
author: Author not found
Content: Rs5.5 billion was allocated by the Centre for the administration of the Northern Provincial Council following Elections. However, those in power have often refrained from utilising these funds for the welfare of the people due to personal agendas, saidEelam People’s Democratic Party (EPDP) spokesman, Iyadurai Srirangashwaran. At a press briefing held in Jaffna yesterday, he said the 13th Amendment is currently being considered as a starting point to seek a solution and a significant recognition for the Tamil issue. Srirangashwaran also recalled that when attempts were made by nationalist parties such as the JVP, Sinhala Urumaya and Jathika Hela Urumaya to reduce the powers of the provinces, Muslim parties allied with Tamil-speaking representatives and tried to disrupt these efforts in the provincial councils, receiving support from more than 50 per cent of the provincial councillors. This endeavour was thwarted and halted by the EPDP, he said. “During periods of conflict, we’ve respected the decisions made by Provincial Councils. However, these individuals are now acting independently, disregarding the President’s call and jeopardising the situation. They’ve leveraged events like the Easter attacks and disputes involving Kurunthur Malai, Vedukkunari Hindu Kovil, and other temples, contributing to the present complications while evading the fundamental issues facing the country. “In the meantime, the UNHRC has emphasised the need to address human rights issues while also advocating for the full implementation of the 13th Amendment, a crucial enforcer of human rights. While pushing for the comprehensive execution of the India-Sri Lanka agreement, let’s ensure it genuinely contributes to reconciliation, and let’s focus our efforts there,” he said. “As the 13th Amendment is already a part of Sri Lanka’s Constitution, there’s no hindrance in implementing it. However, the introduction of a new draft could spark intense debates, significant disagreements and multiple complexities, particularly in seeking a 2/3 majority in the Parliament. There is no issue in demanding the 13A implementation and we have to work in order to implement it,” Iyaduraiadded. He further told the media that in addition to the 13th Amendment, it is imperative to address the political resolution of the Tamil people through discussions both in Parliament and within the provincial administration of Jaffna.  “In the ongoing context of recent interactions between some Hindu organisations in India and a few political representatives from the North and East, discussions were held to empower Tamil political rights in Sri Lanka, signifying the need for India to take the lead in implementing the full agreement of Indo-Sri Lanka Pact to ensure Tamil political rights. This was a significant move made public” he added. “After the Eastern Province was cleared of terrorism, we advocated determining the Provincial Council to be handed over to the people of the East, through the determination of the 13A. Through electoral means, we have aimed to provide more authority to the provinces for the people. Especially, we have aimed for the Tamil National Alliance, to collaborate with 22 North and East Provincial Council members.As a single unit,the EPDP, strived to represent it singly rather than as a collective and pressed for it”, he added. During the Sri Lanka Freedom Party convention, there was an advocacy for the provincial administration of Sri Lanka to operate as a unified governance body. At that point, the TNA representatives didn’t articulate their perspective on the preferred method. Our leader Douglas Devananda solely highlighted that our party, the Eelam People’s Democratic Party, stands for governance aligned with both national and provincial systems within the country, Iyadurai further added. Hence, the demand for complete implementation of the 13th Amendment and the international human rights conventions is a significant step towards resolving longstanding issues. As of now, these individuals’ urge to completely implement the India-Sri Lanka agreement in full cooperation with humanitarian ideals is the right approach. “The 13th Amendment has been a subject of contention in Sri Lanka’s political arena, and there should be no hindrance in implementing it. However, any new attempt might face strong opposition and might cause great conflict and polarisation, making it difficult to proceed. Therefore, we strongly advocate for the complete implementation of the India-Sri Lanka agreement without any hindrance, as articulated by them,” Iyadurai further said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Hold presidential, general elections together – Harshana
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Harshana Rajakaruna asserted that the Presidential Election and the general election should be synchronised next year to minimise government spending on elections.  He made these remarks at an event in Kirindiwela yesterday (5) as part of a campaign, urging citizens to sign a petition seeking the revocation of civic rights of Mahinda Rajapaksa, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, Basil Rajapaksa, former Central Bank chairman Ajith Nivard Cabraal and others implicated in the current economic crisis. According to the SJB, the petition, initiated in front of the Fort Railway station in late November, is anticipated to traverse various towns in Sri Lanka. The petition advocates for the confiscation and obligatory compensation for citizens and victims affected by last year’s economic crisis. The SJB MP, addressing the media, accused these individuals of continuing to live off taxpayers’ money, enjoying State-provided luxury housing, vehicles and having their phone and utility bills covered by public funds. He added that the SJB is engaging with the international community to explore avenues for repatriating funds allegedly held abroad by the Rajapaksas, asserting that only a SJB government could guarantee this. Rajakaruna contended that the President and the current government lacked a mandate, asserting that they came to power through illegitimate means after being rejected by the people last year. Consequently, he claimed that the people of Sri Lanka would not grant them a mandate again. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Scam to steal money from bank accounts of cancer patients
author: Author not found
Content: Investigations have been launched into a well-coordinated scam involving the stealing of money from bank accounts of cancer patients, who seek donations for surgery and other treatment, the Computer Crime Investigation Division of the CID informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (5).  This announcement follows an incident where approximately Rs 3.8 million was fraudulently withdrawn from a bank account of a cancer patient in Kaduwela. The racketeers reportedly responded to requests posted online by cancer patients seeking financial assistance, obtaining their personal bank account details and National Identity Card (NIC) details by promising additional financial benefits. The Computer Crimes Investigation Division revealed that the group used this information to obtain new SIM cards from a well-known telecommunication company, using the victims’ bank account numbers, NIC numbers and telephone numbers. The CID further stated that these fraudsters, armed with the acquired SIM cards, employed techniques to access the bank accounts of patients. Subsequently, it was discovered that all the money in these accounts was fraudulently obtained without authorisation from the account holder. The CID informed Court that one individual from the group, responsible for the fraudulent withdrawal from cancer patients’ bank accounts, has been identified. They assured Court that necessary steps will be taken to arrest and bring the culprit to Court. Court granted permission for the CID to obtain reports from the relevant telephone company and the State bank for further investigations into this scam. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: COPA instructs MOD to amend Firearms Ordinance, Explosives Act
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) recently instructed Defence Ministry (MoD) officials to promptly take steps to amending the Firearms (Amended) Ordinance No. 22 of 1996 along with the Explosives Act.  COPA recently convened under State Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna and during its sessions the audit reports of the Defence Ministry, pertaining to the years 2020, 2021 and 2022 and its ongoing work had been reviewed.  The Defence Ministry was represented by a group of officers, including Defence Secretary Retired General Kamal Gunaratne. During the deliberations it had come to light that though the COPA Committee had instructed the Ministry to amend the aforementioned Acts during the past 11 years but it had not been implemented due to various reasons.  The Ministry officers had noted that to date, licences for 37,000 firearms had been given by them. They had asserted that as the amendments of the said Acts are in the final phase they would strive to complete that task forthwith.  The Committee had noted that as the amendments of the Acts are delayed it would prevent the State from accruing revenue via the issuance of licences and instructed the officials to expedite that process. The Committee also ordered to implement a coordinated system where additional services rendered by the armed forces could be conducted. The Committee also instructed to implement a similar system concerning the supply of food to the three armed forces.  Although it was mentioned in the constitution that the revenues generated by the services provided to external parties by the armed forces should be credited to the consolidated fund, attention was also drawn to the fact that it was not implemented properly. Although it was previously informed to prepare a proper system related to it and report to the committee, the committee asked about the fact that it has not yet been prepared. Auditor General’s Department pointed out that since most of the income goes to the welfare associations, a proper system should be set up. Although the services are being successfully carried out, the committee also advised to prepare a clear system in this regard. He also instructed the ministry officials to review this process extensively. Special attention was also paid to the procurement of food items for the three-armed forces. It was revealed at the committee that although earlier recommendations had been given to set up an information management system connecting all the institutions involved in the food items procurement process for the three-armed forces, it is being implemented only in the Navy and the Air Force. Accordingly, the officers were ordered to expedite the preparation of the system for the Army and to submit a report on this. Also, it was emphasised in the committee that parties including the soldiers should receive a meal commensurate with the money spent by the government. There was also a discussion regarding hiring a housing complex with 24 house units on a lease agreement for Rs 72 million in order to provide accommodation for the 31 officers participating in the course of the National Defence Academy. Instead of getting such houses on rent, the Committee Chair advised to pay attention to the possibility of providing accommodation facilities by constructing a new building. The Defence Secretary pointed out that since the construction has been stopped due to the current economic situation, measures will be taken in the future. Attention was also drawn to the misplacement of materials worth Rs 12 million in the consumer goods warehouse. The officials said that the all those persons related to this have been suspended and steps have been taken to collect the related money from the storekeeper. It was discussed why this incident was not revealed by the internal audit until it was uncovered by the audit of the Auditor General’s Department. Apart from this, attention was also paid to the strategic communication network project, procurement process, role of Disaster Management Centre (DMC) etc.

title: Adverse weather affects 123 families
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 123 families, comprising 454 individuals, eight districts across the country, have been affected, up to yesterday, by the adverse weather prevailing in the country, Assistant Director Media and Public Relations at the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) Janaka Handunpathiraja said.  He said the Badulla, Kilinochchi, Kegalle, Ratnapura, Hambantota, Mullaitivu, Jaffna and Kilinochchi Districts were among those that have been affected. Handunpathiraja said 56 houses had been partially damaged and 20 were totally damaged in the Ratnapura District following strong winds and floods. Meanwhile, as the  bad weather persists across most parts of the country, the National Building Research Organisation has issued various levels of landslide early warning alerts to 24 DS divisions in seven districts. The Meteorology Department warned yesterday (5) that showers or thundershowers could be expected over the most parts of the country today (6). While commenting on the prevailing atmospheric conditions, Duty Meteorologist Preethika Jayakody predicted that showers could be expected in the Western, Galle and Matara Districts today. She said showers or thundershowers could occur in several places in the Sabaragamuwa, Central and Uva Provinces after 2.00 p.m and misty conditions could be expected in these provinces in the morning. She cautioned the public to take adequate precautions to minimise damage caused by temporary localised strong winds and lightning during thundershowers. Senior Scientist of the Landslides Early Warning Centre, Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera said level two amber – watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to the Neluwa DS Division in the Galle District, Walallawita DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Pasgoda Korale DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kandy District and Elapatha DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. He said the level one yellow-watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to the Nagoda DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Galle District, Bulathsinhala and Matugama DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Udapalatha DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kandy District, Bulathkohupitiya and Ruwanwella DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Pitabeddara and Kotapola DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matara District, Ambagamuwa DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Nuwara-Eliya District and Imbulpe, Balangoda, Kalawana, Kuruwita, Weligapola, Opanayake, Godakawela, Kolonna, Ratnapura and Eheliyagoda DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: 77% opposes reducing returns on EPF
author: Author not found
Content: Seventy-seven per cent (77%) of Sri Lankan adults believe the Government’s decision to reduce returns on retirement savings in the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) is unnecessary and unfair, a poll conducted by Syndicated Surveys of Verité Research revealed.  Respondents were informed that the Government reduced EPF returns to recover from the debt crisis.  They were then presented with two statements, and their agreement or disagreement was sought for each. Only 10% agreed with both statements, stating it was necessary and done fairly. About 13% had no opinion or were unaware of the issue. In contrast, 44% disagreed with both statements, while 33% disagreed with either of the statements presented. Sri Lanka executed a distinctive Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR) in September 2023, focusing solely on restructuring the retirement provident funds of formal sector workers in local currency.  The banking and financial sectors, along with private creditors and most public sector workers, were excluded. This approach could establish a new global precedent in DDR by featuring adverse rather than preferential treatment of retirement funds. The survey, based on a nationally representative sample of 1,029 Sri Lankan adults, sheds light on public sentiment regarding this controversial decision.

title: Education sector trade unions protest
author: Author not found
Content: A protest organised by various education sector trade unions, including teachers and principals, revolving around several demands, was staged near the Polduwa Junction in Battaramulla last evening.  The issues include the salary disparity between teachers and principals, the right to free education, relieving parents of the financial burden of education and allocating six percent of the budget for the education sector. Police closed the entry road to Parliament due to the protest.  Earlier yesterday (5) the Colombo Chief Magistrate issued an order, on learning of the teacher-principal trade union plans to stage a demonstration in the vicinity of Parliament in Battaramulla.

title: Court employee released on bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige yesterday enlarged on bail, a worker attached to the Court, who had been remanded for close upon five months, on charges of pilfering 534 milligrams of heroin, which had been kept in the Court Productions Room. The envelope containing the narcotic was said to have been found in his bag.  The Court thus released the accused, identified as Kapila Perera, on bail in Rs 25,000 cash and a surety of Rs 500,000.  Senior Counsel Weerasena Ranasewa, appearing on behalf of the accused, informed Judge Patabendige, that his client had been arrested, based on a statement given by another Court employee. He added that the envelope had been discovered in his client’s bag, at a time when the accused had not been present. The Counsel noted that the envelope in his client’s bag had been discovered by the fiancée of the first accused and maintained that hence there were strong suspicions, that it could have been placed in his client’s bag, by another person. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: New Minister, Secy should raise image of State Health Sector – MCPA
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) observed that the new Health Minister and Health Secretary were responsible for improving the image of the collapsed health system and ensuring justice to trade union leaders who had been unjustly treated.  MCPA President, Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (5) said, the duo had the colossal responsibility of negotiating with all stakeholders to raise the image of the State health service owing to the severity of the damage caused to it by the corruption, fraud and irregularities that had occurred during the past two years.  Dr. Sanjeeva noted that the continuous efforts to show the former Health Ministry administration the reasons for the collapse of the State health service, had been to no avail. The ad hoc policies that had been followed by them had led to public mistrust in the free health service. It only served to confirm that questionable medicinal drug purchases had taken place. He noted that even now the corrupt procurement process such as the Immunoglobulin IV was before Court.  The new administration of the Health Ministry was tasked with rebuilding the trust of the Sri Lankan public and the international community regarding the State health system in the island in order to improve the situation. The new State health administration should work flexibly with the professional and civil organisations that were capable of pointing out the weaknesses of the health service and rectifying the deficiencies, he said.   The MCPA President said he hoped to discuss the initiation of new programmes for the development and transformation of the primary health system and to curb the shortage of medicines and conduct transparent procurement processes. Dr. Sanjeeva further stated that it is the responsibility of the new Health Secretary to do justice by the health trade union leaders, who were unjustly treated due to the strict policy adopted by it (the Health Ministry) regarding union leaders. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Woman operating fake educational institute arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Police arrested a woman who operated a fraudulent educational institute under the name of ‘Evolve College of Education’. The suspect is a 24-year-old resident of Giriulla Narangamuwa. This institute issued counterfeit diploma certificates through advertisements on its Facebook page, claiming to offer diploma and advanced diploma education suitable for both local and foreign employment.  The institute recruited students from various regions, conducted online educational workshops and provided education without legal approval. It has come to light that the institute operated without adhering to prescribed standards, both domestically and internationally. For certain diploma courses, fees ranging from Rs 100,000 to Rs 445,000 were charged. Up to now, 43 complaints have been filed related to fraudulent monetary transactions. Despite the requirement for necessary approvals, investigations have exposed that the institution was operating illegally without registration. The suspect served as the director of the company. Investigations have revealed that nearly a thousand individuals, from various parts of the island, have fallen victim to these scams. The institution is reportedly continuing its fraudulent activities by advertising higher education opportunities through various electronic media to collect more money. Bambalapitiya Police are conducting investigations to arrest a 25-year-old resident of Mattakkuliya who served as the co-director of the institution.
