title: Narcotics worth Rs 43M seized at Central Mail Exchange
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Customs Narcotics Control Division officers seized 25 parcels containing drugs, with a market value of nearly Rs 43 million, at the Central Mail Exchange  yesterday (5), Customs Media Spokesman, Senior Director of Customs, Sivali Arukgoda revealed. He said that these 25 parcels were checked on suspicion at the Central Mail Exchange and were found to be containing narcotics. He also said added that 2,193 ecstasy pills, 1,740g of Kush and 29g of Amphetamine were found in the parcels.  Arukgoda also mentioned that those parcels were sent from Germany and England to addresses in Colombo, Maharagama, Battaramulla, Boralesgamuwa, Panadura, Moratuwa and Kandy. He also said that on further investigation of the addresses to which the parcels had been addressed, it was confirmed found that they were fake. He stated that discovery was made by the Narcotics Control Division of the Customs with the assistance Postal Department officers. He further said that at the end of the investigations, the Police handed over the drugs to the Narcotics Bureau for further investigations. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: NHSL Hospital Square teeming with trishaws
author: Author not found
Content: With the Colombo Municipal Council (CMC) blaming the Traffic Police, the National Hospital, Colombo is faced with the dilemma of traffic congestion, in and around Hospital Square, blocking even ambulances from entering through the gates.  NHSL Deputy Director, Dr. Rukshan Bellana yesterday (5) lamented that the entry point into Hospital square, from Regent , on both sides of the road were blocked mainly by three-wheelers which were either awaiting hires or were dropping off or picking patients. “The situation is such that the main hospital gates were blocked by three-wheelers parked in their immediate vicinity preventing even ambulances turning into the hospital,” he said.  Hospital authorities have lodged several complaints with the Maradana  Police who in turn pass the blame on to the CMC for not placing ‘No Parking’ signs, and providing proper parking areas for three wheelers and larger vehicles. It has also been noticed that when the Police take action to drive away the three-wheelers that hover around or remain parked near the NHSL, they simply go around the hospital and return to their spots in close proximity to the hospital gates. In addition when Police ask them to move away, drivers retort claiming that they had either come to drop off  a patient or had come on a hospital visit. There are robberies, damage to vehicles owned by hospital staff in addition to shady deals that take place inside three wheelers, that remain stationary near the Hospital, he charged.  The Deputy Director lamented that the hospital administration and staff were fed up with the situation with regard to the CMC and Maradana Police merely shifting the blame from one to the other. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’

Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Woman operating fake educational institute arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Police arrested a woman who operated a fraudulent educational institute under the name of ‘Evolve College of Education’. The suspect is a 24-year-old resident of Giriulla Narangamuwa. This institute issued counterfeit diploma certificates through advertisements on its Facebook page, claiming to offer diploma and advanced diploma education suitable for both local and foreign employment.  The institute recruited students from various regions, conducted online educational workshops and provided education without legal approval. It has come to light that the institute operated without adhering to prescribed standards, both domestically and internationally. title: Former Secy of Public Administration Y.B. Pussadeniya no more
author: Author not found
Content: A former Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration and Home Affairs, Y.B. Pussadeniya passed away. He was a senior officer in the Ceylon Administrative Service and was 83 at the time of his demise. He held many top positions in the Administrative Service such as Secretary to the Ministry of Cooperatives, Secretary of the Sabaragamuwa Provincial Council, National Housing Commissioner, Director of Institutions and is a father of three.  He is the loving father of Kusina Karaliyadda, a lecturer at the National College of Education, Penideniya. He is also the father-in-law of Court of Appeal Judge, Udaya Karaliyadda. The remains of Pussadeniya will be handed over to the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Peradeniya this evening (6). The body lies at his residence in Aranayake, Hakurugammana for the public to pay their respects.

title: Egyptian Ambassador calls on Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Egyptian Ambassador to Sri Lanka Maged Mosleh called on Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana in Parliament recently. Discussions were held between the Speaker and the Ambassador regarding the 66 years of bilateral relations between Egypt and Sri Lanka. Thus, attention was paid to the issue of a commemorative stamp and the re-establishment of the Sri Lanka-Egypt Parliamentary Friendship Association in line with the 66th anniversary. The future measures that can be taken in various sectors to further strengthen the existing relations between the two countries were also discussed. Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera was also in attendance.

title: Application Process Nears Completion
author: Author not found
Content: The application process for the free solar-powered housing project, valued at Rs 5 million each and comprising 25,000 houses in the Northern Province, is nearing completion. Under the guidance of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, applications for the 25,000 housing project in the Northern Province are presently being accepted through District Secretaries and Divisional Secretaries. Eligible individuals who are yet to apply for this housing scheme are urged to submit their applications through the Divisional Secretaries before 14 December. The selection of beneficiaries for the housing scheme, overseen by Divisional Secretaries at the direction of the District Secretaries and the Governor of the Northern Province, is already underway. In the districts of Jaffna, Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu, Vavuniya and Mannar, eligible applicants who have not yet applied for this housing scheme are encouraged to promptly submit their applications through their respective divisional secretariats. Applicants who have previously been allocated a housing scheme by the National Housing Authority but haven’t seen its completion, those who lost land after resettlement, individuals with their own land yet to receive a housing scheme and those eligible through other means are invited to apply for this special scheme. Through this new housing scheme, the cluster housing scheme will also be implemented for the landless on government land. 710 square-foot houses will be constructed. 1,000 square -feet of solar panels will be installed on the roofs of these houses. The remaining area will be cemented. Under this scheme, which is implemented through a foreign private investment company, the electricity produced from the solar panel to be installed on the roofs of these 25,000 houses, which will be constructed at Rs 50 lakh each, should be provided to the investment company for 20 years only. However, no fee for house construction work will be collected from the beneficiaries. Therefore, those who have not yet submitted their applications for this scheme are requested to submit their applications through the Divisional Secretariats immediately.  If any further information and complaints arise regarding this special housing scheme, it can be reported directly to the Northern Province Governor’s Secretariat by dialling 021 221 93 70. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SAARC Cultural Centre convenes 13th Governing Board Meeting
author: Author not found
Content: The SAARC Cultural Centre in Colombo, Sri Lanka recently convened its 13th Governing Board Meeting at the Galle Face Hotel, Colombo from 28 to 29 November.  In a pioneering move, the meeting embraced a hybrid format, hosting esteemed Governing Board Members physically from Bangladesh, Maldives, Pakistan and Sri Lanka, while Bhutan, India and Nepal participated virtually. The distinguished Governing Board Members were Mizanur Rahman, Joint Secretary (Administration) of the Ministry of Cultural Affairs of Bangladesh; Tshering Choki, Senior Programme Officer, Ministry of Home Affairs of Bhutan; Yash Veer Singh, Director International Cultural Relations of the Ministry of Culture in India; Shamun Hameed, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Dhivehi Language, Culture and Heritage of Maldives; Dr. Suresh Suras Shrestha, Head of Division/ Joint Secretary, Culture Division of the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation of Nepal; Humaira Ahmed, Secretary National Heritage and Culture Division of Pakistan; and Somaratne Vidanapathirana, Secretary, Ministry of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs of Sri Lanka. The meeting also welcomed ex-officio members, Irosha Cooray, Director – Education, Security and Culture of the SAARC Secretariat in Kathmandu, Nepal; T.P. Dharmasena, Director-General of SAARC Division, Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka; and Renuka Ekanayake, Director of the SAARC Cultural Centre, Sri Lanka. Renuka Ekanayake, Director of the SAARC Cultural Centre presented the Governing Board Report, explaining the successful activities conducted throughout 2023 and outlining the proposed programmes for 2024. As the supreme decision-making body, the Governing Board commended the activities conducted by the SAARC Cultural Centre in 2023, which included collaborative ventures such as an Exhibition of Paintings with the Royal Asiatic Society, SAARC Talk Series, SAARC Special Lectures in partnership with entities like the Department of Archaeology, University of Kelaniya, and National Library and Documentation Services Board and the SAARC Film Day in collaboration with the National Film Corporation. Discussions and recommendations ensued, leading to unanimous approval of the proposed programmes and activities for 2024, with Member States pledging their full support. The SAARC Cultural Centre looks forward to an exciting 2024, marked by Food Festivals, Film Festivals, Musical Extravaganzas, Textile and Fashion events, Artists Camps, Research Seminars and Workshops.  The Centre anticipates a vibrant year of cultural rejuvenation across the SAARC Region, showcasing resilience and rebuilding cultural activities post-pandemic.

title: Teacher vacancies filled in Vakarai – EP Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman said yesterday (5) that he has taken every possible step to resolve the problems faced by persons living in Vakarai, Batticaloa. Thondaman said the education-related issue remained severe and warranted immediate action. This follows an official tour of Governor Thondaman to Vakarai recently. “During the visit, those people underscored many problems they are confronting and urged me to take immediate action to appoint two teachers for Mathematics and Science, as these vacancies have remained unfilled for a long time,” Thondaman said. Thondaman said he sent two teachers for the aforementioned subjects in consultation with the educational authorities of the province. He added that as Governor of the Eastern Province, he aims to resolve all issues of residents one at a time. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: A plan to spend Rs 84B for Irrigation sector in 2024
author: Author not found
Content: The government has named 2024 as the year to expand the local agricultural industry. Accordingly, the Ministry of Irrigation has estimated an amount of Rs 84 billion to implement the projects. The Ministry of Irrigation , the Department of Irrigation and the Sri Lanka Mahaweli Authority have planned to carry out the development of 18 major projects. A special discussion on this development activities to be implemented next year was held at the Mahaweli Authority main auditorium yesterday (5) under the chairmanship of the Minister of Irrigation, Wildlife and Forest Conservation Mrs. Pavithra Wanniarachchi. Furthermore, there was also a discussion about providing  deeds  for Mahaweli zones. Accordingly, it was revealed that 13,600 deeds have been planned to be given before the end of the year. The minister paid attention to distribution of these deeds and instructed the relevant officials to take steps to implement this project before the end of this year. Minister Pavithra Wanniarachchi further stated that in a period like this, when the economic crisis in the country is being formally regulated,  President Ranil Wickremesinghe has paid special attention to the development of local agriculture in the year 2024. Accordingly, the Minister further requested that a targeted programme has been given to the Ministry of Irrigation, for which the maximum support of all officials/employees is expected. For this discussion, State Minister of Irrigation Mr. Shashindra Rajapaksa, Secretary of Ministry of Irrigation U.D.C.Jayalal and  many officials from the Ministry of Irrigation, Department of Irrigation and Sri Lanka Mahaweli Authority participated, including  Secretary of the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Conservation, Mrs. Chandra Herath.

title: Ambassador Asirwatham pays a farewell call on Chair
author: Author not found
Content: The Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the European Union Grace Asirwatham paid a farewell call on the Chair of the Friends of Sri Lanka Group in the European Parliament, Member of Parliament (MEP) Tomáš Zdechovský from the Czech Republic, who represents the European People’s Party (EPP), the largest party in the European Parliament, on 28 November 2023, at the Parliament premises in Brussels.  The Friends of Sri Lanka Group in the European Parliament is an informal group of MEPs who support Sri Lanka in the EU Parliament on an issue basis. It was initially established in 2006 and re-launched twice thereafter: when a new Parliament was elected in 2019 and after Brexit in 2022.  During the meeting, Ambassador Asirwatham expressed her sincere appreciation for MEP Tomáš Zdechovsk’s unwavering support for Sri Lanka and his dedicated leadership to the informal friendship group, which serves as a crucial support base within the European Parliament. She highlighted the group’s pivotal role in ensuring the continuation of the provision of the GSP Plus facility to Sri Lanka  MEP Tomáš Zdechovský commended Ambassador Asirwatham for her effective efforts to promote Sri Lanka’s interests within the European Parliament.

title: Malaysia’s Quest International Uni brings unique educational opportunities to SL
author: Author not found
Content: Malaysia’s Quest International University (QIU), a comprehensive private institute of higher learning, is offering a diverse range of unique educational opportunities to the people of Sri Lanka. Based in Ipoh, Perak, QIU offers foundation, diploma, bachelor’s degree, and postgraduate programmes that cover disciplines in medicine, pharmacy, business and management, life sciences, computing, engineering, culinary arts, social sciences, and many more. The university sets itself apart by committing to a hands-on, experiential learning process. Students learn by doing, as a method of augmenting the theoretical aspect of their field. This principle is supported by a diverse selection of industry advisers, adjunct academics, and partnerships with industry and corporate partners. These experts provide insights and input into their curricula, incorporating the latest innovations and advancements in their field. QIU Chief Operating Officer Nicholas Goh said: “In today’s world, the theory you learn as a freshman may be redundant once you graduate. We believe in pedagogy that is constantly updated to mirror changes that are happening in the real world. This gives our graduates an advantage because their hands-on experience will help them hit the ground running when they enter the job market.” “The university is also committed to the principle of leaving no student behind. If a student faces any difficulties during their time at QIU, we have instituted support systems that will help them improve. This includes extra guidance from lecturers, peer-assisted study sessions, and assistance with time management and goal setting. We go beyond teaching; we are here to ensure that our students learn,” he said. “We have proudly welcomed some of Sri Lanka’s talented students to QIU since 2017. Our Sri Lankan joiners have signed up for a wide range of courses, ranging from life sciences programmes like biotechnology to business and arts programmes like hospitality, tourism, advertising and MBA,” he added. At their Faculty of Medicine, four batches of Sri Lankan doctors-to-be are set to graduate in 2024. They will be valuable assets to the medical field in Sri Lanka, healing, saving lives, and helping the people of their country achieve good health. Medical students at QIU can also practise overseas, as their programme is recognised by numerous medical councils around the region. At the same time, they have the chance to specialise and practise in the United States because their syllabus incorporates United States Medical Licensing Examination (USMLE) training. QIU’s overarching goal is to create well-rounded students—equipped with the right knowledge, attitude, work ethic, skills, and university experience to make them truly future-ready.

title: Kelaniya University hosts Multidisciplinary Desk Research Conference
author: Author not found
Content: The first-ever Multidisciplinary Desk Research Conference in Asia has been organised by the Library of the University of Kelaniya. It aims to raise the profiles of research studies derived from secondary sources. The event will take place today (6) at the Faculty of Commerce and Management Studies, University of Kelaniya.  Vice Chancellor of the University of Kelaniya, Senior Professor Nilanthi De Silva will be the Chief Guest. Keynote speakers include Emeritus Professor Ariyarathna Kaluarachchi, former Vice Chancellor of Visual and Performing Arts; Senior Professor D.W.R.K. Somadeva from the Postgraduate Institute of Archaeology, University of Kelaniya; Professor Senaka Rajapakse, Director of the Postgraduate Institute of Medicine, University of Colombo; and Professor Anuradhani Kasthuriratne from the Faculty of Medicine, University of Kelaniya.  By Deshan Wijayantha

title: Plantation workers to get postal addresses
author: Author not found
Content: In a historic development, the Attorney General yesterday (4) informed the Supreme Court that steps have been taken for the first time in 200 years, to assign postal addresses for the plantation worker community residing in the ‘Muwan Kanda’ rubber estate, in Mawathagama, Kurunegala. This marks a significant milestone as it is the first instance of providing postal addresses to plantation workers in the country. This was informed to the Supreme Court, by Deputy Solicitor General Kanishka de Silva, representing the Attorney General during the hearing of the Fundamental Rights (FR) petition filed by Jeevaratnam Suresh Kumar, a resident of the ‘Muwan Kanda’ estate in Mawathagama, requesting the Supreme Court to issue a directive to the State to provide postal addresses to the plantation workers. The petition was heard before the three-Judge Supreme Court Bench comprising Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya, A.H.M.D. Nawaz, and Arjuna Obeysekera. The petitioner’s lawyer, Lakshan Dias, explained that the petition aimed to provide postal addresses to the entire estate workers’ community across the island. He acknowledged the time required for such an extensive task and appreciated the government’s efforts to address the long-standing issue faced by the plantation workers. Deputy Solicitor General Kanishka de Silva emphasised that providing postal addresses for the entire plantation community nationwide is a time-consuming programme. He mentioned that government officials are diligently working to gather information for this task, requiring additional time. Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya noted that this initiative marks a historic moment for the plantation workers, spanning over 200 years and expressed satisfaction over addressing their need for postal addresses. The Chief Justice informed the petitioner’s lawyer that, considering the fulfillment of the relief sought, the hearing of the petition would be adjourned. However, he mentioned that if the petitioner wishes to inquire about the progress after six or nine months, they have the option to bring the petition back to Court and seek an update on the activities’ progress. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Kelaniya Uni closed till further notice
author: Author not found
Content: The administration of University of Kelaniya has taken a decision to temporarily close all faculties, with the exception of the medical faculty, until further notice. This was communicated by the university’s Vice Chancellor, following he that a security officer of the university’s Security Department being abducted while asleep in the lounge. The officer had subsequently been assaulted and found tied to the entrance of the student centre. The Vice-Chancellor also announced the closure effective from 2.00 p.m. yesterday (4). Consequently, all students residing in university hostels were required to vacate the premises by 5.00 a.m. today (5). Until further notice, students are strictly prohibited from accessing any part of the university, including the Dalugama campus of the University of Kelaniya and all internal and external university hostels.

title: NHSL Accident Service X-ray machines out of order
author: Author not found
Content: The Accident Service of the largest teaching hospital in the island, the National Hospital in Colombo, is in a quandary with the malfunctioning of both X-ray machines installed there.  The Government Radiological Technologists’ Association (GRTA), lamented that even the backup X-Ray machine of the Accident Service had also broken down a week ago.  GRTA President, Chanaka Dharmawickrema yesterday (4) said that currently the Accident Service of the Hospital was depending on the X-ray machine in the Neuro-Trauma Centre of the Hospital. The Accident Service had two X-Ray machines. When the main machine broke down the Hospital was depending on the backup machine to conduct X-rays on the accident victims who were brought in for fractures, head injuries, lung damage etc. The Accident Service has five wards. Two and a half months ago, the main X-Ray machine broke down and after that, the X-Rays were conducted using the backup machine. With the technology available in the main X-ray machine the radiological technologist was able of send the test reports to the wards, Dharmawickrema said.  The backup X-ray machine, which was in operation, also broke down last week. Even though all relevant authorities in the NHSL had been informed it was to no avail, he lamented.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Addressing teachers’ salary anomalies a challenge – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Addressing the salary anomalies of teachers during the current economic crisis poses significant challenges in fulfilling the identified priorities for children, claimed Education Minister Susil Premajayantha claimed.  Speaking at an event at St. John’s College in Modara, the Minister emphasised the government’s primary focus on distributing textbooks and uniforms, providing meals, and supplying shoes to schoolchildren.  Despite calls for rectifying teachers’ salary anomalies, the Minister announced the commencement of the new school term on 19 February 2024. The Ministry plans to finalise the distribution of school uniforms, textbooks, and shoes to selected schools and their students. Highlighting the prioritisation of education, Premajayantha expressed the government’s commitment to ensuring the continuous and active attendance of students in Sri Lanka, even amid various economic challenges. Schools are scheduled to reopen on 2 February after the school vacations. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: OMP successfully concludes 4,795 probes – Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs, and Constitutional Reform Wijayadasa Rajapakse said, yesterday (4), that the Office of Missing Persons (OMP) currently manages approximately 14,000 complaints, showing significant progress from the 62 complaints investigated upon assuming duties.  Investigations have been successfully concluded for 4,795 complaints and all outstanding cases are expected to be resolved by the coming year, he added.  Rajapakshe also announced plans to introduce a new legislative framework to regulate microfinance institutions operating in the country.  Expressing deep concern about the unregulated status of certain microfinance entities, Minister Rajapakshe emphasised the need for decisive measures. He highlighted the intention to establish an independent regulatory institution, separate from the Central Bank, dedicated to overseeing and effectively regulating microfinance entities. Minister Rajapakshe made these remarks during a press briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (4) He noted that the Ministry of Justice currently oversees the operational responsibilities of 21 institutions, covering a diverse range of subjects, including law enforcement and law reform. With a caseload exceeding 1.1 million cases in the country’s Courts, concerted efforts have been made to address delays in case adjudication. Measures have been implemented to tackle backlogs and streamline the judicial process, with a focus on the establishment and operation of conciliation boards to facilitate the expeditious resolution of select cases. The Minister also highlighted the global trend of expedited methods for resolving criminal cases and contrasted it with the outdated legal framework in the country, resulting in prolonged durations for case resolutions. To address this challenge, a draft law, aimed at expediting the resolution of criminal cases, is currently under development and is scheduled for submission to Parliament in January. The new legal framework aims to explore alternatives to incarceration for individuals involved in minor offenses, aligning with the paradigm shift in advanced jurisdictions. The proposed legislation acknowledges societal oversights leading to incarceration and provides avenues for release on bail conditions, seeking to strike a balance between societal concerns and individual liberties in the criminal justice system. “To strengthen the judicial process, eight new Bills are set to be submitted to Parliament. Efforts are underway to establish reconciliation societies in each village, independent of direct government or political influence. These societies, guided by village elders and religious leaders, handle tasks like infrastructure development, religious festivals, and cultural events, promoting community ownership and participation. Amid discussions on the country’s economy, challenges persist due to factors like the impact of past conflicts and the unregulated proliferation of microfinance institutions. The absence of legal frameworks and regulatory oversight, coupled with the lack of Central Bank registration, has led individuals to seek loans from microfinance institutions, exacerbating economic challenges. To address this, there is a need to establish a dedicated regulatory body, separate from the Central Bank, to oversee and govern microfinance institutions. Comprehensive laws are being introduced to regulate these entities and ensure responsible practices, contributing to the nation’s economic stability,” he said.

title: Water cannon used on JJB Women’s Wing protesters
author: Author not found
Content: A protest, organised by the women’s wing of Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) yesterday (4), near the Parliament Roundabout, was dispersed by using water cannon.  The protest was aimed at addressing concerns regarding the escalating cost of living, the burdensome tax load on the public and other issues in the country. Riot Police utilised water cannon when the protesters sought to march towards the Parliament along the Parliament Road.  JJB MP Dr. Harini Amarasuriya also participated in the protest.

title: Matron remanded over teen’s death at detention centre
author: Author not found
Content: The matron of a juvenile detention centre in Kalmunai, who was arrested in connection with the death of a 14-year-old boy at the facility, has been remanded until 18 December after being produced in the Kalmunai Magistrate’s Court yesterday (4).  The 28-year-old woman, a resident of Trincomalee, was taken into custody on Sunday (3). The 14-year-old, a resident of Kokuvil, had been held at the juvenile detention centre since 17 November, on a Court order following his arrest in connection with a theft. It is alleged that the boy had stolen two lamps from a Kovil.  On Thursday morning (30), the warden of the juvenile detention centre reported to Kalmunai Police Station that a child detained in the centre was found unconscious.  Upon inspection, the Police discovered that the teenager was, in fact, dead and reported it to the Kalmunai Magistrate’s Court. Subsequently, a post-mortem was conducted at the Ampara Hospital on Saturday (2), revealing that the child’s death was a result of internal bleeding caused by assault. Further Police investigations revealed that the matron of the detention centre had recently subjected the child to physical abuse. The matron surrendered to the Kalmunai Police Station and was arrested.  The Kalmunai Police is continuing investigations.

title: Internal probe launched into child detainee’s death – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: An internal investigation has been initiated into the death of a child, at a children’s detention centre in Kalmunai, State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe said in Parliament.  She highlighted that the matron involved in the incident had passed the required examinations, but lacked vocational training. The Minister emphasised the inadequacy of solely passing examinations and pointed out the need for specialised training for all detention centre wardens, in the country, to effectively handle matters related to children. She announced the government’s commitment to providing comprehensive training for wardens, acknowledging that passing examinations alone is insufficient in ensuring the well-being of children in detention centres. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Rs 9.1M equipment meant for Radar project missing
author: Author not found
Content: Equipment worth Rs 9.1 million, intended for the unsuccessful Gongala Radar project, has been reported missing and the responsible officials have not only failed to identify the missing equipment, but also neglected to take any corrective action, a report by the National Audit Office revealed.  The audit report disclosed that the Department of Meteorology’s damage and loss register did not record one item, a Three-phase Jinasena water pump, resulting in a stated loss of Rs 8.74 million. The report stated that the Department of Meteorology has mentioned ongoing investigations by the Police and the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC). Following these revelations, the Auditor General recommends recovering the complete loss of the failed project from the responsible officials. A senior official, from the Meteorological Department, stated that the failed radar project, initiated in 2008, with a total expenditure of Rs 402 million (Rs 323 million from the World Meteorological Organisation), resulted in a government loss of Rs 78 million. He revealed that an official had advised against bringing the non-functional machine to Sri Lanka before the project began. The prolonged preparation of the road to the site, along with a crane collapse and subsequent damage, led to the destruction of some equipment and the disappearance of the rest. In a Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) meeting, held on 10 August, chaired by Minister of State Lasantha Alagiyawanna, it was emphasised that the Department of Meteorology needs to focus on implementing effective projects for accurate forecasts with modern technology instead of ventures causing significant losses. The committee expressed dissatisfaction with the department’s poor administration, noting its low score in the COPA programme measuring government institution efficiency. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: NHSL told to get a count of health assistants
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry urged the National Hospital, Colombo to assess the number of Health Assistants serving in the Hospital, before pressuring the Ministry to recruit more. Senior sources at the Ministry yesterday (04) said a little over 2,740 health assistants (minor employees) were currently affiliated to the NHSL, Colombo that is even more than the doctors, nurses and professions supplementary to medicine serving in it.  But, the NHSL continuously pressures the Ministry to recruit more Health Assistants for the Hospital.  It seems that the Hospital Administration is unaware that they are doing two jobs – transporting patients in their three-wheelers, running taxi services, standing around tea kiosks and manning parking lots.  There are 27 minor staff supervisors, seven Administrative Officers, three Deputy Directors and one Deputy Director General. It seems that with all of them put together they have been unable to maintain the discipline of the Health Assistants working in the hospital, they charged.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: MoD refutes reports on entertainment spending of Rs 1.1M
author: Author not found
Content: The Defence Ministry yesterday (04), issuing a statement, refuted media reports of spending Rs 1.1 million as entertainment expenses (food and refreshment) in five days.  The MOD statement read: “The Ministry of Defence emphasises that there is no truth behind media reports, published recently, giving a wrong interpretation that a lot of money has been spent in the year 2022 for entertaining military heads, who periodically arrive on inspection visits to the Defence Services Command and Staff College (DSCSC). “The DSCSC plays a unique role in imparting military officers of both Sri Lankan and foreign nations with combat tactics and advanced knowledge. Accordingly, 148 military officers including 25 military officers from foreign countries and 123 military officers from Sri Lanka participated in the DSCSC course held in 2022. “In accordance with any other Defence Staff College in the Commonwealth Nations, the Secretary of Defence, Chief of the Defence Staff and Tri Forces Commanders conduct lectures every year on national security to student officers which is an integral part of this DSCSC course. These lectures are done on separate occasions due to the nature of the duties and the practical issues of conducting the lectures on one occasion. Thus, such lectures were conducted on 5 separate occasions. “It is a military norm for the Defence Secretary, Chief of Defence Staff or the Commanders of the Armed Forces to have refreshments at the conclusion of their lecture with the participants of about 200 personnel which may include student officers, directing and permanent staff members providing an opportunity to expand their knowledge.  “Thus, it shall be noted that such expenditures are not incurred only to host the Secretary of Defence, Chief of Defence Staff or the Tri Forces Commanders and such media reports may mislead public perception.” The media reports were based on a National Audit Report DEF/DSCSC/22/04 published by the National Audit Office and submitted in Parliament on 28 November which stated: “In contravention of Treasury circulars outlining expenditure limitations amid the current crisis in the country, the Defence Service Command and Staff College (DSCSC) has spent Rs 1,144,658 as entertainment expenses (food and refreshment) on Defence Ministry Secretary, Chief of Defence Staff and three Commanders of the Army, Navy and the Air Force in five days.”

title: Two monks, driver assaulted by drunks
author: Author not found
Content: Two monks and their driver, residing at Nandimithra Aranya Senasanaya in Diyatittawewa, Horowpathana have been hospitalised following an assault allegedly carried out by a group of intoxicated persons, who forcibly entered into the Aranya Senasana premises, the Horowpathana Police said.  A Police officer attached to the Horowpathana Police Station confirmed that the assaulted individuals the two monks residing at Aranya Senasanaya and their driver, are currently at the Horowpathanana Hospital.  The attack allegedly occurred during a protest against the perceived forced entry into the Aranya Senasana, with the alleged assailants being described as a group of intoxicated individuals. Notably, two of the individuals allegedly involved in the attack were identified as belonging to the Army and the Civil Security Department. One of the monks, who came under the attack, has lodged a complaint at Horowpathana Police regarding the incident.  Police said that the suspects have also filed a complaint and two of them have been hospitalised. No arrests have been made so far. However, Police said the suspect duo would be arrested upon being discharged from hospital. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Attempts to import bermuda grass raise concerns
author: Author not found
Content: An attempt by certain parties, backed by a businessman involved in poultry business, to import Bermuda grass for ‘research purposes’ has raised concerns with environmentalists and activists questioning the rationale behind the attempt. The interested parties have claimed that this variety is to be imported from the USA for research purposes, as it is deemed to be highly effective as fodder and would increase the livestock yield especially as Sri Lanka is planning on popularising local liquid milk production.  They also allege that all key government agencies, who are authorised to permit the importation of plants, were against the move and had initially refused to grant permission, are now under immense political pressure to reconsider their initial objections.    Ceylon Today was able to acquire a letter, sent by the National Plant Quarantine Service, of the Department of Agriculture, to the Conservater General of Forests, earlier in October, for his consideration ofn the import application submitted by the Director of the Veterinary Research Institute, Peradeniya to bring down Tifton 85 Bermuda Grass. Interestingly, the letter observed that Cynodonspp is an invasive species and the requested party has placed the application for permission on the basis of conducting research to explore the potential of pasture to increase milk production in the country. “The NPQSD in their letter has requested to reconsider the permit on the mere purpose of this importation notwithstanding this being an invasive species. The points made in the letter makes one wonder if the officials were forwarding these reconsideration letters to one another due to political pressure they were put under,” a group of environmentalists, who want to drag this to the notice of those in decision-making level, allege. Environmentalists pointed out that Tifton 85 Bermuda grass can be invasive, especially in warm climates with well-drained soils.  “It is a hybrid of two other Bermuda grasses, Coastal Bermuda grass and Tifton 68 Bermuda grass, and it has inherited the aggressive growth habits of both of its parents. Tifton 85 spreads rapidly by both rhizomes (underground stems) and stolons (above-ground stems) and it can quickly outcompete other plants in an area. Tifton 85 is also very drought-tolerant and can survive in low-fertility soils. This makes it a popular choice for lawns and pastures in many parts of the country. However, it can also become a problem in natural areas and agricultural fields, where it can displace native plants and crops,” they pointed out.  There are a few things that can be done to control Tifton 85 Bermuda grass, such as: Mowing regularly: Mowing can help to slow the spread of Tifton 85 Bermuda grass to prevent it from producing seed. Herbicides: There are a few herbicides that can be used to control Tifton 85 Bermudagrass, but they should be used with caution and according to the label directions. Physical removal: Tifton 85 Bermudagrass can also be removed physically by digging up the rhizomes and stolons. However, this can be difficult and time-consuming, especially if the grass has spread over a large area. Meanwhile, when the Biodiversity Secretariat was contacted on the matter, an official said once they get a request letter such request will be given to an expert committee to do an assessment of potential threats.  “Bringing plants from an alien environment means it is bringing foreign soil, flora and fauna and various other bacterial funguses as well. Once an invasive plant enters our eco system it only creates problems in our eco system. This is why we need to be extremely careful,” the official added. As per the National Early Warning System for Invasive Alien Species (Pre-entry risk assessment), risks are assessed under four main categories. These include potential ecological and socio economic impacts, assessment of invasive potential, distribution and management aspects. Professor Siril Wijesundara, when contacted to inquire about the claims made by environmentalists, said any plant species, be it a member of the grass family or otherwise, should be imported under Director General of Agriculture following the provisions stated in the Plant Quarantine Act. He also lamented the fact that local experts and researchers were not paying attention to develop grass varieties from what is locally available despite the country having thebest scientists in the field. “Paddy is also from the grass family and how many varieties have we developed. These were done through research and development by the utilising the skills and knowledge of local scientists. We have developed paddy varieties with higher yield and these were done in Bathalegoda or Mahailuppallama. Have you ever heard of us importing seed paddy varieties to the country with better yield in the past one or two decades? No, because we have done enough research. Despite being self-sufficient we still import rice, but that is due to a completely different game by the mill owners,” he added. Prof. Wijesundara said that it is pathetic that our experts resort to the easy way out and go after wrong targets. “This is the same thing that happened with organic fertiliser. Without following proper and systematic procedure few insisted on implementing these policies without a cost assessment and that too with the involvement of complete outsiders who have no expertise in the relevant period. If the livestock industry is genuinely interested in increasing milk production or anything else, why don’t they invest in research and find grass varieties locally available to be developed as fodder?” he queried.   Even though Bermuda grass is to be imported under the guise of research purposes on a comparatively small land area, is Sri Lanka known to be equipped with better management and follow-up of such lands and plants? Are the parties involved 100% positive about the grass not becoming invasive by the time research ends?  By Gagani Weerakoon

title: SLANSHEI hosts Inaugural National Education Conference
author: Author not found
Content: In a significant stride towards shaping the future of higher education, The Sri Lanka Association of Non-State Higher Education Institutes (SLANSHEI) hosted the National Higher Education Conference focusing on the significant contribution by TNE (Transnational Education) to Higher Education in Sri Lanka, on 28 November 2023, at the Cinnamon Lakeside Colombo. SLANSHEI was established in 2016 through the initiative of a few leading private higher education institutes to address the needs and provide leadership to the non-State higher education sector in the country. Its strategic plan focuses on aspects vital to the non-State higher education sector such as expansion, improving the quality and standards, attracting increasing numbers of foreign students, enhancing the research profile and research output, and promoting internationalisation. The inauguration of the National Higher Education Conference was marked by the ceremonial lighting of the traditional oil lamp. The event was graced by the distinguished presence of the Chief Guest, Dr. Susil Premajayantha – Minister of Education, Andrew Patrick – The British High Commissioner, along with dignitaries such as Orlando Edwards – Director British Council, Paul Eeles – CEO, Skills & Education Group, Dr. Anita Hayes from Keele University, Professor Sampath Amaratunge– Chairman of UGC-Sri Lanka, and Dr. Dayan Rajapakse, the President of SLANSHEI, as well as key local and foreign contributors to the conference. The conference commenced with the address of the President of SLANSHEI, Dr. Dayan Rajapakse who made an insightful speech, highlighting the indispensable role TNEs play in enhancing the quality and diversity of higher education offerings in the country. Dr. Rajapakse’s address underscored SLANSHEI’s commitment to fostering partnerships that transcend geographical boundaries. Following Dr. Rajapakse’s address, Orlando Edwards, the Country Director of the British Council, took the stage to share his perspectives on the role of international collaboration in advancing the quality and global standing of Sri Lanka’s higher education system.  The much-anticipated highlight of the conference was the keynote address delivered by the Chief Guest, Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha. His speech resonated with the audience, emphasising the government’s unwavering dedication to fostering an environment conducive to academic excellence. Minister Premajayantha articulated the policies and initiatives aimed at steering Sri Lanka’s higher education sector towards international standards. The first keynote address by was by Dr. Aneta Hayes, Chair of the Evaluation & Monitoring Group for Universities UK International (UUKI) which advises the UK higher education sector on TNE matters. Dr. Hayes emphasised that TNE is part of a university’s role in society and contributes in numerous ways to achieving the millennium development goals. She emphasised the need for quality an equity in transnational relationships and gave an example for the co-development, co-delivery and co-accreditation of TNE curricula.  The second keynote was by Dr. Athula Pitigala-Arachchi, an academic with significant contributions to both State and non-State higher education sectors. He is currently the CEO of SLIIT international. Dr. Pitigala-Arachchi emphasised that TNE education is a permanent feature in the global as well as Sri Lankan education landscape; a reality. He concluded that with suitable measures and frameworks put in place by the State, it will continue to grow to be a force in higher education helping to meet the ever-increasing demand for quality higher education, reducing capital outflow and brain drain, attracting foreign students and generating foreign exchange and catalysing the development of Sri Lanka as an education hub.  The National Conference on Higher Education was a full-day programme, facilitating peer-to-peer exchange, networking and collaboration.  The aim of the conference was to present the key contributions made by TNE to higher education in Sri Lanka, to bring together all stakeholders of TNE education – academics and scholars from key TNE partner universities, Sri Lankan academics from both State and non-State sectors and key personnel from quality assurance agencies in Sri Lanka to elicit their views, experiences, and visions for the future of TNE and to promote a robust and inclusive quality assurance and accreditation mechanism in Sri Lanka The conference consisted of presentation and two panel discussions. In summary, the National Higher Education Conference served as a platform to celebrate and recognise the profound impact of TNEs in shaping the educational landscape of Sri Lanka. The event highlighted the necessity of continued collaboration between local and international entities to ensure a robust and globally competitive higher education sector.

title: Education Ministry unveils reform proposals
author: Author not found
Content: This disclosure took place last Friday (1 December) during the presentation of the progress of the year 2023 and plans for the year 2024, for the Ministry of Education, by Education Minister Susil Premajayantha to Ministers and MPs.  Under the proposed reforms, it was outlined that every child would have the opportunity to complete their schooling in 17 years. The educational structure would include four years of pre-school education, Grades 1-5 as the primary section, Grades 6-8 as the junior section, and Grades 9-12 as the senior section. As part of the reforms, the Ministry of Education suggested a certain percentage of marks from school-based evaluations and exams for the Grade 5 Scholarship exam. There was also a proposal to simplify the Grade 5 Scholarship exam and eliminate competition. Additionally, the new reforms proposed conducting the Ordinary Level examination in Grade 10, while the Advanced Level examination is scheduled for Grade 12. The number of subjects for O/Ls would be reduced from nine to seven, including the introduction of three new mandatory subjects: Information and Communication Technology (ICT), technical and professional skills and religion and values. The officials highlighted that, under the new reforms, no child would fail and those passing the ordinary level examination would have the opportunity to pursue vocational training courses. A-level subjects were classified into academic and vocational education, providing a path for every child to obtain a degree. Administrative restructuring in the education service was also emphasised, with an increase in the number of educational zones from 100 to 122 and the classification of the existing 10,126 schools into cluster schools of 1220. All existing national schools would become flagship schools in a provincial-level cluster. The Ministry allocated Rs 517.05 billion for the year 2024 budget, with funds allocated for school textbooks, uniforms, and shoes. Additionally, provisions were made for providing lunch to an increased number of school children.

title: Susil inaugurates free footwear for schoolchildren prog
author: Author not found
Content: The inauguration ceremony to distribute free footwear to schoolchildren was held yesterday at St. John’s College, Modara, under the chairmanship of Minister of Education, Dr. Susil Premajayantha.  A total of 747,093 students will receive shoes worth Rs 2,200 million. A gift card of Rs 3,000 per student will be given as part of the programme. The Ministry of Education has provided facilities to obtain shoes from a registered store from 9 to 27 December 2023.

title: Indian, Dutch investors interested in seaweed cultivation
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda has announced that investors from the Netherlands and India are interested in investing in seaweed cultivation in Sri Lanka. Devananda expressed confidence that by maintaining a suitable atmosphere in the seas belonging to Sri Lanka, more foreign investors can be attracted to cultivate seaweed. The minister revealed that he held extensive discussions with a few investors from India and the Netherlands at the Fisheries Ministry. These investors expressed satisfaction with Sri Lanka’s providing of a conducive atmosphere for seaweed farming. During the discussions, Corban Blueplant Chairman Prof. Sopaan informed Devananda about taking necessary action to cultivate seaweed on a 100-acre stretch in Settikulam and Ambigainagar areas in the Northern Province. Devananda highlighted that Prof. Sopaan expressed willingness to expand the project to other suitable locations in Sri Lanka. With Prof. Sopaan’s experience of over 30 years in the industry, Devananda believes that implementing these projects could generate more than 600 jobs and individuals could earn over Rs 50,000 per month. The Fisheries Minister mentioned that many investors have already invested in sea-cucumber, shrimp, crab, and seaweed cultivation in the Northern Province. He emphasised that collaboration with the local community could result in mutual benefits for both investors and the local community. Devananda concluded by stating that there is an atmosphere conducive to seaweed cultivation not only in the Northern Province but also in some other parts of the country. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: MoJo for Governance Story Summit Champions Women’s Rights
author: Author not found
Content: The Centre for Media and Information Literacy (CMiL) orchestrated the MoJo for Governance Story Summit on 25 November in Galle.  This transformative event brought together government bodies, NGO representatives, advocates and women’s rights activists in a collective effort to confront and find solutions to the pervasive issues surrounding women’s rights. Also, this programme emphasises on leveraging Mobile Journalism (MoJo) to amplify women’s voices and communicate powerful messages resonating globally. Timed to coincide with the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, the summit served as a dynamic platform for meaningful dialogue and collaborative action. Dignitaries from government bodies, NGOs, Women’s Rights Activists, and representatives from various sectors converged, demonstrating a commitment to protecting and advancing women’s rights, LGBTIQ+ rights and addressing broader social issues. The summit’s central theme revolved around advocating Women’s Rights through Mobile Storytelling, exploring the role of mobile storytelling in shaping narratives, challenging societal norms, and promoting gender equality. The sessions facilitated engaging discussions that delved into the multifaceted aspects of women’s rights. MoJo stories presented during the summit covered a spectrum of women’s rights issues, including Gender-Based Violence, educational rights, nutritious diet concerns, estate workers’ issues, minimal female representation in politics and challenges faced by transgender non-binary females.  Several State entities also engaged in discussions, recognising the imperative need for collaboration between the public and private sectors to bring about meaningful change. Divisional Secretary Shafraas praised MoJo’s effectiveness in communicating complex topics to society due to its easy accessibility. Renuka from the National Integration Office emphasised the need for sexual education, citing instances of young girls facing challenges due to ignorance. The summit also addressed local issues, with officials highlighting the need for safe resting areas for students and women in the Matara District. Participants who created MoJo stories addressing these concerns were commended, emphasising the tangible impact of mobile storytelling. Media professionals and journalists expressed the necessity to empower young girls in MoJo storytelling, urging NGOs and Government Bodies to provide platforms for their voices. Women’s rights activists shared personal narratives, stressing the urgency of addressing systemic challenges. Dr. Wimal Dissanayaka, Chairman of the Habaraduwa Development Foundation, commended participants for bringing women’s rights violations to light through mobile storytelling, acknowledging its resonance across digital platforms. The summit concluded with a resounding call to action, urging participants and guests to carry the momentum forward. The commitment to utilising MoJo for governance and advocacy purposes was echoed in the creation of a collaborative framework, fostering ongoing dialogue and partnerships between government bodies, NGOs and activists. The programme is supported by the US Embassy in Colombo under its small and mighty grants programme managed by Sri Lanka Unites. By Isuri Abeykoone

title: SOC on Econ crisis advises CRIB to educate public
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee, on Alleviating the Impact of the Economic Crisis, convened in Parliament recently. It was chaired by MP Gamini Waleboda.  During this sitting, a group of officials from the Sri Lanka Credit Information Bureau (CRIB) and Lady Lochore Loan Fund were summoned before the committee. During the committee presentation, the Sri Lanka Credit Information Bureau officials noted a lack of correct understanding among the public regarding their institution (CRIB). In response, the chair advised taking necessary steps to widely inform the public about the processes of the Sri Lanka Credit Information Bureau (CRIB). The officials informed the committee of ongoing considerations to change the term CRIB in the future. The officials from the Sri Lanka Credit Information Bureau (CRIB) explained their institution’s role, emphasising that it solely releases information about the financial affairs of individuals and institutions. The chair commended the services provided by the Sri Lanka Credit Information Bureau in maintaining the country’s banking and financial system in an orderly manner.  However, he highlighted the need for immediate measures to prevent banks from approving loans to entities and individuals unable to settle their debts or facing bankruptcy. Emphasising the importance of preventing the wastage of public money, the chair recommended that the Sri Lanka Credit Information Bureau include a rating report along with the information provided about institutions and individuals when approving loans.

title: Rs 1.1M on five officers for five days for meals in 2022
author: Author not found
Content: The Defence Service Command and Staff College (DSCSC) has spent a staggering Rs 1.1 million as entertainment expenses (food and refreshment) over just five days on  five officers, Defence Ministry Secretary, Chief of Defence Staff and three Commanders of the Army, Navy and the Air Force in 2022, a National Audit Report submitted in Parliament on 28 November revealed.  According to the report, the five officials had visited the DSCSC to monitor the operations of the institute.  The report DEF/DSCSC/22/04 published by the National Audit Office highlights that these activities were carried out in contravention of Treasury Circulars outlining expenditure limitations amid the current crisis in the country. In another bizarre move, the purchase of 30 black colour dining chairs for the hostel, costing Rs 350250 left unused in the DSCSC warehouse as the colour was deemed unsuitable and mismatched to the ambience of the hostel. Furthermore, the audit reveals that contributions for civilian staff at DSCSC from 2009 to 31 August 2022, have not been remitted to the Employees’ Trust Fund, with outstanding contributions for 64 current employees amounting to Rs 7.58 million.  The procurement of a heavy-duty photocopier for DSCSC saw a discrepancy, with the machine acquired at Rs 2.2 million instead of its listed price of Rs 1.6 million, resulting in a loss of Rs 600,000 in the procurement process. The audit report also notes a delay in the procurement process for the heavy-duty copier due to a lack of specifications tailored to the needs of DSCSC, contributing to the higher acquisition cost. Additionally, a four storey library and examination hall building, constructed at a cost of Rs 133 millions for the college, reportedly suffered substantial damage to its electrical system and upper-floor walls due to water leakage. Despite the issues dating back to 2019, there has been no restoration. In summary, the total expenditure for the staff college in 2022, dedicated to enhancing the professional knowledge of selected Student Officers from the tri-forces and Police, amounted to Rs 171 million. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: President launches ICCU at COP 28 in Dubai
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe officially launched the International Climate Change University (ICCU) yesterday (3), at the United Nations Climate Change Conference 2023 (COP28) in Dubai, UAE.  The President emphasised the need for institutional change following the Paris Climate Agreement and highlighted the absence of alternate bodies to tackle the ongoing climate crisis, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said in a statement.  “President Wickremesinghe pointed out that despite the global commitment to the Paris Agreement, no significant institutional changes were implemented to assist the world in achieving the agreed targets. Identifying the urgency of the situation, the ICCU aims to fill this void by developing postgraduate-level capacity building, serving as a crucial support system for climate sciences. The ICCU campus is to be established on an initially allocated 600 acres of land in Sri Lanka. However, President Wickremesinghe clarified that the university will not be confined to Sri Lanka; it will be an international stakeholder university, welcoming collaboration and contributions from around the world,” the PMD said.  Highlighting the global nature of climate responsibility, President Wickremesinghe said Bangladesh, Seychelles, and Moldova have already pledged their support to the ICCU. He said climate action is not the sole responsibility of a single nation and called on the international community to join hands in this endeavour. President Wickremesinghe concluded by urging nations and individuals worldwide to recognise the shared responsibility for climate issues and actively participate in the International Climate Change University.

title: Project causing extensive environmental damage – CEJ
author: Author not found
Content: Extensive environmental damage is being caused by the construction of an electric fence against wild elephants along Pambahinna Mawatha in Rajawaka Forest Reserve.  This expansive fence, stretching over 57 km, has resulted in the marking of 8,338 trees within the Rajawaka Reserve, the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) said.  The CEJ alleged that the entire contentious project is being led by Secretary Ranjith Pushpakumara, operating under the authority of Minister of Wildlife and Forest Conservation Pavithra Wanniarachchi. Despite an anticipated project cost of Rs 10 million, the CEJ discloses that the actual cleared distance is less than 28 km. Further, it is asserted that no agreement has been reached with the Provincial Council concerned regarding the fence’s construction, and no authentic cost estimate has been conducted. The CEJ emphasised that bulldozers are being utilised to clear the area for the fence, marking the first use of heavy machinery for an undertaking of this nature. This has resulted in extensive and immeasurable environmental damage, the CEJ said.  By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Special ‘tactile ballot paper’ at next Poll
author: Author not found
Content: To enhance the electoral process for the visually impaired community, a special ‘tactile ballot paper’ will be provided in each polling station during the next national election, Commissioner General of Elections Saman Sri Ratnayake said.  He said this during a media briefing held at Waters Edge Hotel in Battaramulla on 1 December, to commemorate the International Day of Persons with Disabilities. Chairman of the Parliamentary Caucus for Persons with Disabilities, MP Dullas Alahapperuma, emphasised the commitment to advocating for the rights of the disabled community in Sri Lanka beyond party politics. The media briefing saw the participation of MPs, representatives from the Disability Organisations Joint Front, the Commissioner General of Elections, election monitoring organisations and civil organisations. Alahapperuma highlighted the bipartisan nature of the caucus, formed in September, with the primary goal of championing the rights of disabled individuals within and outside Parliament. Expressing gratitude to the National Democratic Institute (NDI), Alahapperuma announced a proposal to allocate funds for the purchase of buses tailor-made for the disabled community as a pilot project. He acknowledged the existing gap between Sri Lanka’s commitment to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities since 2006 and the present state of affairs, expressing the caucus’ dedication to fostering coordination between the disabled community and policymakers. Rasanjali Pathirage, President of the Disability Organisations Joint Front (DOJF), underscored the challenges faced by the disabled community in accessing public transport and public spaces. She advocated for the drafting of a new law to legally enforce the rights of persons with disabilities and emphasised the importance of their representation in politics. Brian Kingston, a visually impaired student, shared his experiences and challenges, shedding light on issues faced by his community. MP Premnath Dolawatta presented a Braille-prepared visiting card at the event. The event, supported by USAID and NDI, highlighted the collective effort to address the rights and needs of persons with disabilities in Sri Lanka.

title: Five arrested for selling narcotics stored in Court Production Room
author: Author not found
Content: Five individuals, including three officers from the Multi-Purpose Development Task Force employed at the Matara Magistrate’s Court, were arrested by the Matara Crimes Division, over suspicions of engaging in the sale of narcotics and firearms stored in the Court Production Room to organised criminals. According to Police, the other two suspects in custody are a boat owner and an individual accused of serving as an intermediary in a firearm deal. The investigation was initiated on 21 July when the Court Registrar reported the disappearance of two parcels of heroin from the Court Production Room. Subsequent investigations led to the arrest of two Multi-Purpose Development Task Force Officers working at the Court.  During questioning, Police uncovered an ongoing scheme involving the sale of narcotics and firearms to organised criminals from the Court Production Room. By Keerthi Mendis

title: SLTDA launches tourism data system
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) has introduced a new tourism data system. This system will provide real-time information on tourist arrivals, demographics, spending patterns and other key indicators. Data gathered from this system will aid tourism policy and marketing decisions, as well as help in tracking progress towards sustainable tourism goals.  SLTDA Chairman Priantha Fernando said the new system will be a valuable tool for the tourism industry.  “This data will help us to better understand our tourists and their needs,” he added. “It will also allow us to measure the impact of our tourism initiatives and ensure that we are on track to achieve our sustainable tourism goals,” he said. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: Liquor raids lead to Excise income increased by Rs 1B
author: Author not found
Content: The Excise Department has collected a monthly revenue increase of Rs 1 billion, through successful raids targeting liquor bottles with fake stickers and labels, Additional Commissioner General at Excise Department Kapila Kumarasinghe said yesterday (3). He said officials from the Excise Department, Department of Inland Revenue and the Department of Customs were summoned before the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Economic and Physical Plans to discuss the report they had presented to the President. During the discussion, attention was focused on amendments made to the Excise Ordinance, Kumarasinghe added. The Committee recommended that conducting frequent raids on liquor outlets and retail sales centres would be effective to prevent liquor items with fake stickers getting into the open market. They also advised maintaining the increased income level achieved through these efforts, stated by Additional Commissioner General Kumarasinghe. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Recycled plastic imported sans any regulation
author: Author not found
Content: It was disclosed at the recent meeting of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Environment, Natural Resources and Sustainable Development that industrialists have been permitted to import recycled plastic sans any regulation.  The meeting chaired by MP Ajith Mannapperuma, included participation of MP Akila Ellawala and a group of officials from the Ministry of Environment and the Central Environmental Authority. Officials said Sri Lanka imports 400,000 MT of plastic raw material and 20,000 MT of waste plastic annually. Despite approving the import of 20,000 MT of waste plastic last year, only 5,179 MT were imported for local industries. It was also disclosed that although the country generates 938 MT of plastic daily, only 32 per cent is collected, with a mere 4 per cent undergoing mechanical recycling. Officials said uncollected plastic is disposed of into the environment. It was brought to light that industrialists have been permitted to import secondary plastic without proper regulation. In response, the Sectoral Oversight Committee directed the Central Environment Authority to issue licences based on industry requirements in the future. Considering this, the chairman recommended aligning permission with industry needs and setting up a system to collect imported plastic within a specified five-year period. Officials also informed the committee that high cost deters many from collecting plastic for recycling. In response, the committee chairman suggested increasing incentives for plastic collection to boost collection. He also said the importance of setting up dedicated collection centres across the island was vital. Further, the committee discussed the urgency of finalising and implementing the proposed environmental bill.

title: ECT poised to become largest container terminal in Colombo Port
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has reaffirmed that construction is actively underway for the East Container Terminal (ECT), poised to become the largest container operations terminal in the Port of Colombo.  The Sri Lanka Ports Authority is working to complete the construction by middle of the upcoming year to initiate operations, Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva said.  The planned jetty for the ECT is set to be an impressive 1400 metres long, facilitating the simultaneous berthing of three mega ships. The terminal is expected to feature 12 gantry cranes and 40 transfer cranes, with an expansive container yard covering an estimated 75 hectares. Designed to handle a capacity of three million containers annually, the ECT is slated to operate as a semi-automated terminal, integrating cutting-edge digital technology. A substantial financial allocation of USD 585 million has been earmarked to develop the terminal, with the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) overseeing the financial provisions.  Construction is to be carried out China Engineering and Access Engineering appointed as the designated contractors.The Minister recently conducted an inspection visit at the construction site of the terminal. Keith Barnard, Chairman of Sri Lanka Ports Authority, GayanAlagewattege, Vice Chairman, MD Prabath Malavige and several other officials were present. During the inspection, Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva called for collaborative effort to ensure the immediate and high-quality construction of the terminal, emphasising that any setbacks would impact Port employees more than him. The Minister further said the Port of Colombo’s potential to be recognised as one of the main ports in Asia and advocated to set up a suitable process to position it as the hub port of Asia, attracting more ships to Colombo.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
