title: India-SL ink deal to construct 10,000 houses in plantation areas
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of India signed two significant agreements for the construction of 10,000 houses in plantation areas of Sri Lanka under Phase IV of the Indian Housing Project on 28 November. Separate agreements with the two implementing agencies, namely the National Housing Development Authority (NHDA) and State Engineering Corporation (SEC) are aimed at the early rollout of construction of the 10,000 houses. Counsellor and Head of Development Cooperation Wing, Eldos Mathew Punnoose, Chairman of SEC, Rathnasiri Kalupahana and General Manager, NHDA, Kankanamalage Ajantha Janaka were the signatories to the two agreements. Phase IV of the Indian Housing Project is spread across 11 districts and 6 provinces of Sri Lanka. It may be recalled that the overall commitment of the Government of India under the Indian Housing Project presently stands at 60,000 houses. While 46,000 houses were completed in Northern and Eastern Provinces in the first two phases, the third phase for the construction of 4,000 houses in plantation areas is nearing completion. Housing receives focused attention in India’s people-centric development cooperation partnership with Sri Lanka. Beyond the Indian Housing Project, 2,400 houses are being built across the 25 districts of Sri Lanka under different housing projects. India’s development cooperation portfolio stands at around USD 5 billion, with close to USD 600 million being in grants.

title: NSB Nawala Branch moves to new premises
author: Author not found
Content: The NSB Nawala Branch, which was relocated recently, was first established in 2003 and has been renowned for its customer service for over two decades. Anoma Gomes, Deputy General Manager of National Savings Bank graced the opening of the relocated Nawala Branch at the new address No. 221, Nawala Road, Nugegoda. Further, the former General Manager/ CEO of NSB, Eastman Narangoda, Dr. Anura Wickramasinghe of the Open University of Sri Lanka and  Dr. Hector Jayawardane graced the occasion as special invitees.  The top management of NSB and guests, including Assistant General Manager – Nalika Wijesinghe, Regional Manager – Charini Ekanayake and Branch Manager of Nawala Branch – Chaminda Piyathilake were also in attendance. First-day deposits were accepted by Deputy General Manager Gomes.  Equipped with ATM facilities and state-of-the-art banking facilities, the relocated NSB Nawala Branch is housed in spacious premises to deliver supreme customer service catering to all the financial requirements of the public.  NSB, being the only bank with 100% government Guarantee on deposits and interest is poised to serve even better with the efficient expansion of its branch network.

title: Residents’ complaint of severe stench goes unheeded
author: Author not found
Content: Villagers and residents of Gamagewatta, in Ihala Bope, Padukka have complained of an unbearable stench spreading in the surrounding areas due to harmful waste liquid being released to the environment, by an alcohol distillery and a garment factory. They also allege that due to the waste and garbage being disposed haphazardly, by these two factories, the contents seep into their wells as well, preventing them from utilising the water for their daily needs. These villagers and residents charged that as wells are used by most of the people the harmful content being released in an ad-hoc manner to the environment had complicated matters for them as their lives have also been placed in danger. They further added that though they had brought this issue to the notice of the Central Environmental Authority (CEA), the Grama Niladhari and the PHI in charge of the area, the latter had refused to act on it and advised them to lodge an official complaint with the Police. These residents stated that when they complained to the Police, they were instructed to complain to the PHI Officer. They charged that due to this tug of war between the PHI and the Police their lives have been placed at serious risk. The residents also stated that though the CEA officers had carried out an inspection of the said area the issue has still not been resolved to their satisfaction. BY S. Priyalal – Habarakada

title: Fisheries Act to be amended – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda has announced the addition of new regulations to the existing Fisheries Act to safeguard our marine resources from exploitation and provide enhanced services to local fishermen. Minister Devananda addressed baseless and unwarranted allegations and criticisms from certain politicians who, for political mileage, expressed discontent about the proposed amendments to the Fisheries Act. “The aim of these amendments is to protect aquatic resources and privileges within the fishing industry,” he said. Highlighting the need for sustainable solutions to combat poaching by foreign vessels or trawlers in territorial waters, Minister Devananda emphasised that the new regulations would address these challenges. He cautioned against certain factions attempting to mislead fishermen on the matter. Devananda clarified that under the Fisheries Act enacted in 1979, foreign vessels are permitted to fish in Sri Lanka’s territorial waters. He criticised those making unfounded allegations against the Government, particularly the Fisheries Ministry, for their lack of awareness regarding this provision. “The proposed regulations aim to resolve various fisheries-related issues,” he added. Asserting his commitment to prevent the plundering of marine resources and unauthorised fishing in territorial waters, Minister Devananda stated that he, as the Minister in charge of fisheries, will not tolerate any actions that compromise the integrity of Sri Lanka’s invaluable marine resources.  By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: 35 migrant workers deported from Kuwait, more to follow
author: Author not found
Content: Thirty-five Sri Lankan migrant workers who had remained in Kuwait illegally were deported to Sri Lanka and arrived at the BIA, Katunayake last morning (29). Meanwhile, a spokesman from the Sri Lankan High Commission in Kuwait stated that to date 3,450 migrant workers who are currently stranded without valid visas have been registered with them to head back to Colombo. The official added that presently discussions were being held with the Kuwaiti government, the Sri Lankan Foreign Affairs Ministry and the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment to bring these migrant workers back to Colombo via charter flights. The group that was deported comprised 33 domestic workers and two males. Of them, some of their visas have not been extended while in the case of the rest, employers had not given them their visas. The Sri Lankan High Commission in Kuwait having held talks with the Home Affairs Ministry in Kuwait and the Department of Immigration and Emigration had deported them. Meanwhile, some Sri Lankan migrant workers had had legal cases being filed against them by their employers in Kuwait while some have had bogus cases being filed against them. However, the Sri Lankan High Commission in Kuwait had intervened to resolve the pending cases against these migrant workers. The High Commission had also taken measures to release salary arrears to certain migrant workers while those who did not have passports and air tickets had been given temporary passports and air tickets by the High Commission enabling them to return to Colombo. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Dilapidated 7-storey building a threat to lives
author: Author not found
Content: The seven-storey building, which currently houses the Galle District Secretariat Office, is in a highly dilapidated state. According to sources, most of the pillars erected at the site, which is believed to be the biggest and largest administrative building within the Galle town limits, are in a dilapidated condition and there is a serious threat of it giving way at any given moment putting the lives of scores of people in grave danger. It is said this particular building had been declared open on 8 October, 19 years ago by the then Head of State Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga. Currently, several administrative offices in the Galle District are being operated in this building, while the workforce has been estimated at over 500. When contacted Engineer P. K. Weerakkody, of the Galle District Secretariat Office, mentioned that they have already notified the Engineering Faculty of the University of Ruhuna about the parlous state of the building and stressed that the latter had informed them that they will commence the renovation work shortly. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Ministry of Finance absolves itself
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation, and National Policies has issued a clarification, in response to media reports concerning the procurement of Human Immunoglobulin drugs, under the Indian Line of Credit, by the Ministry of Health. In a statement yesterday (29), the Ministry said the CID has been directed to gather statements from Treasury officials regarding the procurement guidelines applicable to funds from the Indian Line of Credit.  The relevant Treasury departments overseeing procurement guidelines and the administration of the Indian Line of Credit are the Department of Public Finance and the Department of Development Finance. The CID officials visited the Treasury on 27 and 28 November and obtained statements from the Director, Department of Development Finance and the Deputy Director, Department of Public Finance. These statements address the procurement guidelines and the process involved in utilising funds from the Indian Line of Credit, as per the Ministry of Finance, the statement said.  “Contrary to media reports, no Treasury officials visited the CID Headquarters. They solely assisted the CID in understanding the procedures for procurement and fund utilisation from the Indian Line of Credit, providing documents related to communications between the relevant departments in the Treasury and the Ministry of Health. The Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies explicitly states that it had no involvement in the specific procurement under question. The Ministry affirms its commitment to fully support the CID and the courts in conducting the investigation,” the statement added.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Farmers’ Trust Fund fails to utilise Rs 5.4B for farmers’ welfare
author: Author not found
Content: Contrary to the primary objective of introducing the ‘Govisetha’ lottery, designed to generate funds for the Farmers’ Trust Fund, the administration of the fund has failed to utilise a substantial sum of Rs 5.4 billion remitted to the fund over the past 28 years, since the lottery’s introduction.  A senior official at National Lotteries Board (NLB) told Ceylon Today although a portion of the Govisetha lottery income was credited to the Farmers’ Trust Fund, it was not utilised for its intended purposes. Instead, the funds were consistently invested in Fixed Deposits and Treasury Bills. NLB introduced the Govisetha lottery in 1995 on behalf of the Ministry of Agriculture and Lands to generate funds for the Farmers’ Trust Fund. The fund aims to promote agriculture and the welfare of the farmers and to provide financial assistance to the farmers whenever necessary.  From 1995 to 2022, 10 per cent of the lottery income, totalling Rs 6.3 billion, was credited to a consolidated fund of the Treasury. However, only Rs 956 million was utilised for the implementation of the Farmers’ Trust Fund’s functions and tasks by the administration of the fund. Thus, the official said, the Rs 5.4 million which should have been utilised for the well-being of the farmers in the country has been continually invested in fixed deposits and treasury bills. Additionally, the official said at the end of the previous year (2022), Rs 465 million was invested in fixed deposits, Rs 90 million in treasury bills and the interest income earned amounted to Rs 73 million. Citing the challenging economic situation in the country, the Board of Directors of the Farmers’ Trust Fund has decided not to implement new projects, leading to the non-execution of planned projects. However, the official emphasised that the fund’s money, invested in fixed deposits and generating interest income, will be utilised for development and loan programmes in the future.  Despite the present situation, the official assured that development and welfare programmes are scheduled to be implemented in the coming years.  The trust deed specifies that the fund’s primary source of income is 10 per cent of the sales revenue from the Govisetha lottery, subject to discussions and decisions with the National Lotteries Board. Cabinet Paper No. 95/1317/105/081 stated that 10 per cent of the Govisetha lottery income should be remitted to the Farmers’ Trust Fund through a consolidated fund maintained by the Treasury.  Established with the goal of enhancing agricultural development and farmers’ welfare, the fund provides short-term agricultural credit facilities to smallholder farmers, organises agricultural inputs and offers support for crop and animal production processes. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Immunoglobulin IV scam probe punishes honest officials
author: Author not found
Content: Despite revealing the real fraudsters behind the Immunoglobulin IV scam, the officials who only followed the instructions given by the Health Ministry are being punished unjustly, alleged the Association of Medical Administrators (AMA).  The AMA called for honest and transparent investigations into the immunoglobulin IV scam in order to arrest and bring to justice the real fraudsters.  AMA Secretary Dr. Priyantha Karunaratne lamented that the scam had occurred as a result of a group having deliberately acted fraudulently during the whole Emergency Purchase process. Instead of studying the place or the process of the criminal act, the ongoing investigation on this issue was trying to trace the methodological mistakes, made by officials in the last stage of the process and were attempting to place the whole criminal charge on them.  Dormant policy related to the procurement board process, technical appraisal committee and the role of the NMRA had mainly given rise to this fraud, he alleged.  Dr. Karunaratne, yesterday (28), said however that if health officers just doing their job were to be pursued and imprisoned on criminal charges their mentality would only be broken.  “The legal investigation was initiated into irregularities in the purchase of the controversial Human Immunoglobulin. Officers were arrested and remanded including the Director of the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) Dr. Kapila Wickremanayake,” he said.  Dr. Karunaratne, explaining the procedure of emergency purchasing, said that after confirming the need for urgent purchase, the order was given to the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC), which acted as the drug purchasing agency to the Health Ministry and they followed the procurement procedures to deliver the order to the MSD. A waiver of registration (WOR) was issued to the import controller, if the Medicine was not registered with the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) which authorises the importation of the medicine.  The WOR was given to the import controller “allowing limited permission to the relevant supplier to bring the medicine into Sri Lanka.”   The medicines ordered this way were cleared by the customs and given to the MSD by the supplier. He said that at the time of importing human immunoglobulin, the drug in question, Sri Lanka had been facing a severe economic crisis and had not had the sufficient forex to import essential materials such as medicine and fuel.  The government had taken a decision to purchase more than 180 other drugs, including the particular medicinal drug which created the controversy, under the Indian Credit line (ICL).   The AMA Secretary said, however that the normal procurement partners the SPC had informed the Health Ministry that it was difficult for them to purchase these medicines under the conditions of the ICL, which had led to a series of decisions taken by the Cabinet, the State Ministry Production, Supply and Regulation of Pharmaceuticals and the Health Ministry. The procurement process commenced.  The NMRA, the Procurement Committee, the Technical Evaluation Committee have great responsibility in this regard.  Once the MSD received the final import of the medicinal drugs, they had distributed it by checking them with the documents on the decisions issued by the Procurement and Technical Committees, he said noting that the lab facility of the NMRA had minimal resources to contribute to the process of quality testing of imported drugs.  BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President unveils comprehensive tourism strategy
author: Author not found
Content: At the 58th Annual General Meeting of the Hotels Association of Sri Lanka (THASL), President Ranil Wickremesinghe delivered a groundbreaking address, unveiling a comprehensive strategy to elevate the country’s tourism sector to unprecedented heights, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said.  Held on Monday (27) at the Shangri-La Hotel, Colombo, the meeting saw President Wickremesinghe highlighting his vision, which aims not only to surpass the 5 million tourist target but also to redefine traditional approaches by aspiring to achieve 7.5 million visitors in the coming years. The President stressed the imperative of innovative thinking and collaboration within the industry to ensure sustainable growth. President Wickremesinghe declared, “When I took over the government, I realised that sustainability alone is not sufficient. How are we going to earn foreign exchange? How are we going to have a positive balance of trade? In that, there were many suggestions. But what is the low-hanging fruit? And one of the low-hanging fruits was tourism. Let’s promote tourism fully.” Recognising the need to move beyond existing frameworks and embrace competition to elevate Sri Lanka’s global tourism standing, the President drew comparisons with countries like Vietnam and questioned why they attracted more tourists despite being in the industry for a shorter period. He underscored the importance of increasing the number of tourists to 2.5 million in the upcoming year and expanding on this figure subsequently. Central to the President’s vision is the enhancement of the tourism product, urging the industry to specialise and tap into Sri Lanka’s unexplored potential. President Wickremesinghe emphasised the need for a nuanced approach to promotion, drawing inspiration from historical practices during the Anuradhapura period. President Wickremesinghe remarked, “Look at our food. From one area to another. Have you utilised it? Let’s do that. We have to be special in many ways. You remember, tourism was not something that was new to us. It was there even in the time of the Anuradhapura period.” Acknowledging the role of hospitality in attracting and retaining tourists, the President stressed the necessity for a comprehensive experience, encompassing accommodation, cuisine, and cultural offerings. He proposed the diversification and improvement of Sri Lankan cuisine, advocating for a fusion of local and international flavours to cater to diverse tastes. Highlighting the potential for collaboration with expatriates to enhance the industry further, President Wickremesinghe underscored the significance of niche markets, citing golf tourism as an example. The President’s address also focused on the development of tourism infrastructure beyond traditional attractions. He outlined plans for transforming Colombo into an entertainment hub, emphasising the need for diverse activities to engage visitors. Addressing the issue of minimum rates, President Wickremesinghe advocated for a shift towards higher rates, emphasising the need for a quality product that justifies the cost. He encouraged the industry to embrace a new mindset to achieve the ambitious target of 5 million tourists. “In this new era, we need new thinking. We can’t get there with the old mindset. Just forget it and put it aside. Think of the new people who will come. Then we can achieve our five million,” President Wickremesinghe asserted. The President concluded by expressing confidence in the industry’s ability to achieve the 5 million tourist target and urged stakeholders to aim higher, setting a goal of 7.5 million with higher-paying tourists. He emphasised the importance of maximising earnings and attracting tourists from both domestic and international markets without unnecessary restrictions. During the event, President Wickremesinghe honoured two stalwarts of the hotel industry, presenting lifetime achievement awards to Srilal Miththapala and Hiran Cooray for their significant contributions. Key government figures, including Minister of Tourism, Lands, Sports, and Youth Affairs Harin Fernando, Secretary of the Ministry of Tourism and Lands H.M.P.B. Herath, and officials from the Hotels Association of Sri Lanka, as well as experts in the hotel industry, attended the event. The PMD suggests that as Sri Lanka embarks on this transformative journey to position itself as a premier tourist destination, President Wickremesinghe’s vision sets the stage for a dynamic and prosperous future for the country’s tourism sector.

title: Major distilleries settle overdue taxes
author: Author not found
Content: Two major distilleries in the country, W.M. Mendis & Co Ltd and Randenigala Distilleries Lanka (Pvt), paid their overdue taxes to the State, shortly after the Department of Excise halted their production of alcohol. The Department yesterday (28) suspended alcohol production at the two companies. Following the announcement, the companies paid Rs 116 million within a few hours and their licences were reinstated. Top of Form On 2 November, the distillery licences of Synergy Distilleries (Pvt) Ltd, Finnland Distilleries Corporation (Pvt) Ltd, Wayamba Distilleries, W M Mendis & Co Ltd and the Randenigala Distilleries Lanka (Pvt) Ltd were suspended. The Excise Department said these companies had a total of Rs 6 billion in unpaid taxes.  The blame for not paying excise taxes cannot be placed solely on the liquor distillers. In fact, the mistake is made by the retailers. They fail to return the collected tax money to the distillers on time. Kumarasinghe stated that it is a fraud being committed by retailers.  By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Media Minister slams State Media for not promoting Govt projects
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Mass Media, Bandula Gunawardena, accused the State media of failing to adequately promote the various development projects implemented by the Government. As Chairman of the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Mass Media, Gunawardena said that it is important that public media broadcasts the hardship faced by the public due to deteriorating buildings, roads, bridges, etc be highlighted but the need to inform the public about the facilities provided once the shortcomings have been looked into was pertinent.  He was speaking at a recent meeting of the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Mass Media in Parliament. Further, Gunawardena instructed the Sri Lanka Press Council (SLPC) to compile a report on measures that could be taken to regulate media propaganda activities, which may negatively impact culture and personal well-being. This report is to be submitted in the coming days to the Committee for further action.  Talking about the Sri Lanka Rupavahini Corporation (SLRC) and the Sri Lanka Broadcasting Corporation (SLBC) Gunawardena claimed that both entities have been consistently incurring losses and in light of this, there were plans to convert these entities into public companies, following a final Cabinet decision. He highlighted that the SLRC reported a loss of Rs 277 million in 2023, while the SLBC incurred a loss of Rs 457 million in the same year. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Sabaragamuwa Uni final-year med students in a bind
author: Author not found
Content: Final-year medical students of the University of Sabaragamuwa, particularly those associated with the Professorial Unit at Teaching Hospital Ratnapura, are presently experiencing a predicament in relation to their examination scheduled for the end of 2024. Informed sources, yesterday (28), lamented that they had lost at least one month of training whereas their counterparts in other State-run medical faculties could possibly be ahead of them in their final-year training. “It is unfortunate that these students are wasting their precious time instead of doing what needs to be done.”  In response to questions, sources pointed out that to set up a Professorial Unit at Teaching Hospital Ratnapura there need to be infrastructure facilities such as wards, clinics for patients and theatres with professors and lecturers who are affiliated with the Medical Faculty of Sabaragamuwa University. However, presently Consultants attached to the Health Ministry are tasked with training the third- and fourth-year students from the university.   The Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) conducted an assessment of the Sabaragamuwa University Medical Faculty doing sight visits and holding discussions with the university and specialists from the Health Ministry before submitting recommendations. It advised that the student batch should be distributed amongst the accredited medical faculties for their professorial training. The University was informed of the SLMC’s recommendations. They said the SLMC had said as much at the recent Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) hearings.  Sources said should the SLMC’s recommendations be implemented, the final-year students of the Sabaragamuwa Medical Faculty could sit their final examinations with their counterparts from the other medical faculties. They noted that doing the Council’s bidding would be the most responsible move at this juncture.  However, there was undue pressure from a retired Paediatric Professor and a few other professors from different specialities who were attempting to force the SLMC to give accreditation to the Sabaragamuwa University minus its absent infrastructure and human resources for a proper Professorial Unit, they claimed.  They warned that should this happen, even the private medical colleges would attempt to force the SLMC’s hand in recognising them.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Hearing fixed for 7 May 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe, yesterday (28), fixed the hearing of testimony, in the bribery case filed against three accused, including former Chairman of the National Livestock Development Board (NLDB) Muttu Sivalingam, to 7 May next year. The former NLDB head and two others have been charged in the HC by the Bribery Commission, of seeking a bribe of Rs 1.2 million from a businessman, to lease its canteen at the Melsiripura Farm and then receiving Rs 600,000, from that bribe. Assistant Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption Thanuja Bandara, prosecuting, prayed Judge Marasinghe, to issue an order to the three accused, to hand over the entire bribe, sought from the plaintiff, back to the latter. A group of lawyers, headed by Kalinga Indatissa, PC, represented the three accused.    By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: CID questions Finance Ministry Officials over Immunoglobulin scam
author: Author not found
Content: The Criminal Investigation Department (CID) questioned several officials of Finance Ministry, yesterday (28), over the Immunoglobulin scam.  The CID also obtained statements from the Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMA), the Association of Sri Lankan Neurologists and the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) on a media briefing they held on the Immunoglobulin IV scam.  SLMA President, Dr. Vinya Ariyaratne and GMOA President, Dr. Dharshana Sirisena, yesterday (28), when contacted said the CID had sought expert opinion on the particular drug following a media briefing held recently.     Earlier, the CID arrested four high-ranking officials including the Director of the Medical Supplies Division of the Ministry of Health, over allegedly importing substandard Immunoglobulin vials. Director of the Medical Supplies Division  Dr. Kapila Wickramanayake, Assistant Director Devashantha Soloman, Accountant (Supplies) Neran Dhananjaya and the Stock Controller of the Medical Supplies Division Sujith Kumara were arrested in connection with the incident. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Probes into missing Rs 5M from CBSL vault continuing– Semasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: The investigations into the missing five million rupees in cash, from a vault at the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), have not concluded as yet, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe revealed in Parliament yesterday (28).  Semasinghe, in response to an Oral Question raised by MP Niroshan Perera, said a  report, including details of those responsible, will be made public upon the conclusion of the investigations, adding that CCTV camera footage was being viewed in the investigation. The State Minister disclosed that an internal investigation has been initiated by the CBSL, with parallel inquiries being conducted by the Sri Lanka Police and the Criminal Investigation Department (CID). He also revealed that discussions, on expediting the inquiry, have already taken place between the CBSL and the then Inspector General of Police (IGP). The incident was reported in April this year. The Fort Police informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawala regarding the cash loss, following a complaint filed by S.R. Dayananda, the Superintendent of the Forensic Finance Department of the CBSL, on 11 April. The Police said statements were recorded from six individuals associated with a particular department. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Mill owners creating artificial Keeri samba shortage – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: There is no scarcity of keeri samba rice. Some rice mill owners have orchestrated an artificial rice shortage, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said.  In the preceding Maha season, keeri samba was cultivated on seven per cent of the paddy fields, yielding 5000 metric tons. Despite an ample supply of rice and paddy in the country, the government’s failure to safeguard reserves has allowed these individuals to manipulate the market, leading to an increase in keeri samba prices, he said.  Amaraweera made these remarks, addressing a fruit and vegetable exhibition at the BMICH in Colombo, He said there were some rice traders who deliberately created the scarcity, anticipating higher demand during the upcoming festival season in December and January. Nonetheless, the minister assured the public that the country possesses abundant rice and paddy stocks, with some farmers holding onto their supplies in anticipation of rising prices. He said, to address the situation, the Government has opted to import 100,000 MT of Samba and Keeri Samba rice.

title: Blood donation camp held
author: Author not found
Content: A blood donation camp, organised by Sarath Premalal de Silva, the Managing Director of S.P.J. Garments (Pvt) Ltd in Waskaduwa, Kalutara, took place on the Ill Full Moon Poya Day.  The event, held for the third time at the factory premises, aimed to bestow merits on the late parents of de Silva. Accompanied by his staff and his wife, Priyanthi Ayoma de Silva, the camp saw the participation of nearly 200 donors from the local village and surrounding areas.  The donated blood was subsequently transported to the National Blood Transfusion Center in Narahenpita, Colombo.  BY H.H.S. Lunuwila – Kalutara

title: Artefacts seized by Dutch return home in December
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands has announced the forthcoming repatriation of six Sri Lankan colonial artefacts, currently housed in the esteemed Rijksmuseum Amsterdam. Among the artefacts to be returned are the notable Lewke’s cannon, a Golden Kasthane, a Silver Kasthane, a Sinhalese Knife, and two Guns. These historical items are set to make their way back to Sri Lanka in the first week of December, concluding their more than 200-year stay abroad. Leading the repatriation effort, on behalf of the Netherlands, is Dutch Ambassador for International Cultural Cooperation, Dewi van de Weerd. The formal handing over ceremony is scheduled to occur during a two-day event at the Colombo National Museum on 5 and 6 December. Open to the public, this event will not only witness the physical return of these artefacts, but also include activities aimed at educating people of all ages about the extensive shared history between Sri Lanka and the Netherlands. In an official statement, the Embassy underscored the significance of this restitution, highlighting the Netherlands’ commitment to strengthening bilateral ties with Sri Lanka and addressing its colonial past.

title: ROSHAN AXED FROM CABINET
author: Author not found
Content: Roshan Ranasinghe’s discord with President Ranil Wickremesinghe over the nation’s cricket affairs, has seemingly led to the revocation of both of his Ministerial Portfolios yesterday (27). This follows a special statement by Ranasinghe, where he levelled serious allegations against the President and his Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake. Ranasinghe held the portfolios of Sports and Youth Affairs, and Irrigation.  Ranasinghe, expressing concern for his safety, alleged that he perceives a potential threat to his life, asserting that the Executive should bear responsibility for any untoward incident. “I may face harm today or tomorrow, and I firmly believe that the Executive must shoulder responsibility in such circumstances,” Ranasinghe alleged.  He specifically singled out Chief of President’s Staff Sagala Ratnayake, questioning the security arrangements provided to Ratnayake while highlighting the lack of security extended to him, despite holding a Cabinet position. Hours after Ranasinghe’s allegations, he was sacked from both his ministerial portfolios, by the President under the powers vested in him according to the Section 47 (3) (a) of the Constitution. It is said the letter conveying the sacking was handed over to Ranasinghe during yesterday’s (27) Cabinet meeting held in Parliament.  In the evening Ministers Harin Fernando and Pavithra Wanniarachchi were sworn in as Minister of Sports and Youth Affairs and Minister of Irrigation respectively.  Ranasinghe, in Parliament, said he received an alleged warning from MP Namal Rajapaksa about potential dangers to his life. He claimed that Namal Rajapaksa cautioned him to be alert, describing President Wickremesinghe as vindictive. MP Rajapaksa, however, refuted the claim, emphasising that parliamentary privileges should not be exploited to make such statements. “Standing orders should be amended to prevent MPs from making such utterances,” Namal Rajapaksa asserted. In response, Ranasinghe contended that the message was relayed to him by MP Rajapaksa through a third party. Regarding accusations from President Ranil Wickremesinghe about tarnishing the reputation of the judiciary, Ranasinghe defended himself, saying that he only mentioned a specific judicial officer and challenged the accusations of insulting the judiciary. He detailed a series of challenges he faced in establishing businesses across multiple countries, asserting his commitment to legal practices. He then exposed an alleged irregularity involving Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC), claiming that SLC spent Rs 234 million on a LED screen estimated to cost Rs 9.7 million. He asserted that his efforts to uncover such frauds within SLC have resulted in him being unfairly targeted. Speaking further, Ranasinghe suggested that the cricket-related issues would likely be resolved after the next presidential election, indicating that a swift resolution was not anticipated. Meanwhile, there are allegations that the President removed Ranasinghe from his portfolios due to the former’s inability to provide satisfactory answers to two questions posed by the President. These inquiries reportedly revolve around Ranasinghe’s alleged connections with the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) concerning cricket matters and the purported distribution of Mahaweli lands to his supporters and relatives. In the aftermath of Sri Lanka Men’s National Cricket Team’s disheartening loss to India at the ICC Men’s World Cup 2023, Ranasinghe has been in a contentious relationship with Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) and its President Shammi Silva. Following the team’s dismal performance, Ranasinghe took decisive action by dismissing the cricket governing body, led by Shammi Silva and appointing an interim committee. This committee, comprising seven members, was headed by the former cricket captain Arjuna Ranatunga. However, the ICC promptly suspended SLC, citing government interference and Silva secured a Court order suspending the interim committee. Accusing Silva and other SLC board members of orchestrating the ban from the ICC, Ranasinghe labelled it a “significant betrayal of the country.” In response, SLC initiated a defamation lawsuit against Ranasinghe, intensifying the administrative turmoil within the country. The crisis brewing within SLC then escalated into a conflict between the President and Ranasinghe, when the President thwarted Ranasinghe’s attempt to establish the Interim Cricket. The President said that neither the government nor he knew anything about the appointment of an interim committee for SLC. Afterwards, the President appointed a Cabinet Sub-Committee, led by Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Sabry to oversee SLC operations.  Following this, Ranasinghe launched a verbal attack on the President in Parliament, accusing him of instructing him to disband the interim committee. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Over 80 delegates to Dubai for COP 28
author: Author not found
Content: With over 80 delegates, including Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, Minister of Environment Keheliya Rambukwella and Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekara, led by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, along with international non-governmental organisations, private sector entities and stakeholders, the largest-ever Sri Lankan delegation is set to attend the upcoming United Nations Climate Change Conference of Parties (COP28) Summit in Dubai next week.  However, this extensive representation has sparked public scrutiny on social media. In response to those allegations, Secretary of the Ministry of Environment, Dr. Anil Jasinghe, told Ceylon Today that the 80+ delegation comprises three distinct groups: the Political Delegation, Technical Delegation and the Overflow Delegation. While Dr. Jasinghe refrained from commenting on the political delegation, he explained that the technical delegation consists of 24 individuals, with 11 delegates from the Ministry of Environment and seven climate change experts. Of the 11 government-funded delegates, only three are supported by the Sri Lankan Government; the remaining seven experts are self-funded and the rest of the technical delegation is funded by organisations such as the UN Environment Program and WHO. Dr. Jasinghe clarified that the overflow delegation comprises 20 youth delegates funded by organisations like the British Council, UNICEF, and SLYCAN Trust. These youth representatives were chosen by the funding organisations, not the government. Additionally, over 40 businessmen are part of the overflow delegation, attending the summit to discuss and attract potential investments to Sri Lanka. During yesterday’s parliamentary sittings (27), Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Dr. Harini Amarasuriya questioned the affordability of such a large delegation attending COP28, especially at a time when the government faces criticism for unregulated spending and is imposing increased taxes on the general public amid economic hardships. Dr. Amarasuriya also raised concerns about the qualifications of the Sri Lankan delegation, alleging that the government is leveraging this platform to greenwash its numerous flaws and appease the international community. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: 40 hospitals closed, 100 on brink of closure
author: Author not found
Content: In a dire revelation, it has come to light that the State healthcare system is facing a severe crisis, with 40 State-run hospitals shuttered and an additional 100 teetering on the brink of closure.  The gravity of the situation is particularly pronounced in the Northern Province, as well as the Puttalam and Nuwara Eliya Districts, where hospitals are either already shut down or slated for closure.  This alarming trend has been attributed to the exodus of medical professionals, including doctors and health service staff, who are opting to go abroad, retiring, securing transfers, or exiting the service altogether. The ramifications of this healthcare upheaval are profound, casting a shadow over the accessibility and quality of medical services for the populace. These revelations came to the light during a meeting between Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana and the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA).  Accordingly, the Health Minister instructed the officials of his Ministry to immediately assign medical practitioners in countrywide hospitals that were closed and about to be closed due to the shortage of doctors.  A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry said yesterday (27) Dr. Pathirana instructed officials, during his meeting with representatives from the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) yesterday (27), to take the necessary steps to re-start the hospitals that were closed or about to be closed to start patient care services. The Spokesman said that Dr. Pathirana  had issued instructions to his officials to form a Committee Chaired by the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) and inclusive of representatives from the GMOA to expedite the procedure of appointing the necessary medical practitioners to these hospitals so that patient care could be resumed.  Meanwhile, Media Committee Member of the GMOA, Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe said they had also discussed issues regarding the transfer, training and assigning doctors to hospitals based on service requirement, transfers of medical administrative officers were also discussed. Transfers and appointments of Consultants, Grade and Administrative Grade Medical Officers were also taken up, he said. There are 6,000 unimplemented transfers.   He said that the meeting had ended on a positive note while the Minister had instructed his officials to resolve the transfer issues of medical practitioners.    Acting Health Secretary Dr. Sunil de Alwis, Director General of Health Services Dr. Asela Gunawardena, Deputy Director General (Laboratory Services) Dr. Sudath Dharmaratne, Director (Tertiary Services) Dr. Priyantha Athapatthu, Director (Medical Services)  Dr. Priyantha Karunaratne and  GMOA Representatives Dr. Darshana Sirisena (President) and  Dr. Haritha Aluthge (Secretary) were also present. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Schoolgirls to receive free sanitary napkins
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha announced in Parliament yesterday (27) that preparations have been finalised to supply sanitary napkins to girls in schools starting next year.  The Minister made this revelation in response to a statement made by State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe.  Premajayantha said the initiative is framed as a corporate social responsibility (CSR) project. “I was planning to announce this during the debate on Expenditure Head on Education. This initiative will be carried out as a CSR project and I’m trying to get State funds as well,” he said.  Based on the data, there are 1.6 million students in primary classes and 2.4 million in grade 6 and above. Out of these, 1.2 million are girls. By supplying sanitary napkins to one million of them, I believe we can effectively reach and support every girl child, Premajayantha elaborated.  Speaking further, Premajayantha disclosed that the initial phase of the programme aims to distribute sanitary napkins to 300,000 girls, especially in rural areas as a pilot project.  BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Rajapaksha stuck in lift
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Gunathilaka Rajapaksha, who is also the Chairman of the Kandy District Coordinating Committee (KDCC) and two of his security officers, who had been unexpectedly stuck in a lift, whilst on their way to attend a meeting, held at the Kandy District Secretariat Office, had been rescued after a valiant effort lasting 25 minutes. The MP, explaining his ordeal, stated that he had been on way to the second floor, of the Kandy District Secretariat Office, when the lift he had used had suddenly malfunctioned. He said both him and his two security officers had been stuck inside the lift for close upon half an hour and he had begun to sweat profusely fearing for his life. Rajapaksa added that even the button in the lift, which could be pressed in a case of emergency, had not functioned, further complicating matters for him and his security and noted that he had notified the incident to the Kandy District Secretary Chandana Tennakoon. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Kandy MC Management Chief remanded over misappropriation
author: Author not found
Content: The Chief Management Service Officer (CMSO), attached to the Cashier Division of the Kandy Municipal Council, has been arrested by the Special Crimes Branch of the Kandy Police, for utilising Rs 5.1 million for her daughter’s wedding.  A complaint had been lodged with the Special Crimes Branch, of the Kandy Police, by the Chief Accountant of the Kandy MC regarding the misappropriation of the cash. It has been alleged that the Police had failed to apprehend the suspect for over one month since the complaint had been lodged. Already a separate probe has been launched into the actions of the suspect officer, who was interdicted by the Provincial Commissioner of the Central Province Chamila Atapattu. The suspect who was produced before the Kandy Chief Magistrate’s Court has been ordered to be remanded till 1 December. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Court orders Wele Suda’s health be checked
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige yesterday (27) instructed the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO), of the Teaching Hospital Karapitiya, to visit the Boossa Maximum Security Prison and look into the health of death-row inmate Gampola Vidanage Samantha Kumara alias Wele Suda, who is currently incarcerated there and submit a report to him accordingly. The death-row inmate was not produced in Court both yesterday and for the previous hearing of the trial, due to his deteriorating health The Director of the said Prison, had informed Judge Patabendige via facsimile, that theywere due to produce the inmate concerned, before a doctor, to determine the state of his ill health. Afterwards the Judge instructed the said JMO, to inspect the health condition of the prisoner, which had prevented him from being produced in Court, for successive hearings and file a report to that effect. The Court then deferred further hearing of the trial, to 24 January, 2024 and advised the Director of the Boossa Prison, to produce the inmate in Court, without fail on that date and instructed a copy of his order, to also be sent to the Prisons Commissioner General. The Attorney General has indicted Wele Suda, his spouse Gayani Priyadarshani and her sister Wasanthi Wasundara, for having flouting Provisions contained in Sections of the Penal Code and the Offences against the Money Laundering Act and on charges of amassing cash and property amounting to Rs 170 million, via smuggling of heroin, from 2010 to 2012. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Wele Suda’s sis-in-law gets five years jail for money laundering
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday (27) sentenced the sister-in-law of death row inmate and drug kingpin Wele Suda, to five years Rigorous Imprisonment (RI), after she pleaded guilty, to violating Provisions contained in Sections of the Offences against the Money Laundering Act. The accused had been unable to disclose to Court, as to how a sum of Rs. 10.6 million, had come to be deposited in her bank account and how she had received that amount. The accused was identified as P.B. Chandima Dilhani. When the case was called yesterday, President’s Counsel Shavindra Fernando  representing the accused, stated that his client, was willing to plead guilty, to the charge filed against her. Fernando then urged Judge Ranaraja, to impose a suspended term on his client, as the latter, was pleading guilty, to the charge filed against her. Later, the Court imposed the said penalty on the accused and it was read out by its language interpreter Sulaiman Yaseen, while Senior State Counsel Vishwa Wijesuriya, prosecuted, on behalf of the Attorney General’s Department. The Attorney General had charged the accused before the High Court, for having deposited the aforementioned amount in her bank account, as well as due to her inability, to reveal as to how she had come to possess it, from 1 December, 2010 to 1 May, 2014, which had been accrued in Nugegoda. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Four Sri Lankans stranded in Gaza arrive home safely
author: Author not found
Content: A four-member Sri Lankan family, who were stranded in the Gaza, safely arrived in Sri Lanka on 24 November. The Consular Affairs Division of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs facilitated the repatriation of the family.  Upon their arrival in Colombo, officials from the Foreign Ministry received the returning Sri Lanka family. The officials from the Sri Lankan Embassy in Cairo, working in coordination with the Egyptian authorities, visited the Rafah border between Egypt and Gaza and received the stranded Sri Lankans.  The Ministry of Foreign Affairs facilitated the arrangements of logistics and air transportation for the returnees with the assistance of the International Organisation for Migration (IOM). A total of 15 Sri Lankans have been rescued from the Gaza Strip through Rafah border and they were safely repatriated to Sri Lanka in coordination with Sri Lanka Missions in Cairo and Ramallah since the beginning of the recent crisis on 7 October 2023.

title: CCD probes Kidney trafficking racket
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Crimes Division (CCD) informed Colombo Magistrate’s Court yesterday (27) that a formal investigation has been initiated into an alleged kidney trafficking racket targeting underprivileged families. It has been revealed that these investigations were launched based on complaints filed with the CCD by four residents of Colombo 15 and Mattakkuliya. The individuals responsible for providing the kidneys and the recipients of the money have not been identified as yet. However, considering the complaints received, the CCD has taken steps to commence a formal investigation. Additionally, the CCD has initiated procedures to obtain a report on whether illegal kidney removal surgeries have been performed in private hospitals in the Colombo area during the past year. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Placing of ‘robe’ on Avukana Statue meets with criticism
author: Author not found
Content: Following the controversy surrounding several images depicting a group placing a saffron robe (siwura) on the Avukana Buddha statue, with some individuals attempting to climb the statue, the Department of Archaeology has emphasised that modifying a statue of archaeological significance is subject to legal consequences under the Antiquities Ordinance. The Avukana Buddha Statue, standing at a towering height of over 46 feet, is a renowned tourist attraction and is considered one of the finest examples of an ancient standing Buddha statue in Sri Lanka. Believed to have been commissioned by King Dhatusena in the fifth century, the incident raises concerns about the preservation of this culturally-significant monument. The incident drew significant criticism, prompting Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious, and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickremanayake to call for a comprehensive investigation into the dressing of the Avukana Buddha statue with a robe. In response, the Assistant Director of Archaeology in Anuradhapura, along with the Zonal Officer, has been dispatched to the site to gather additional information. Meanwhile, Chief Incumbent of Aukana Raja Maha Viharaya Ven. Shashthrawelliye Dhammakiththi Thera explained that the saffron robe was placed on the historic Buddha statue following a request made by a group residing in Wattala, on Il Poya Day (26). BY Chinthaka Krishantha Balasooriya – Anuradhapura

title: Sri Lanka High Commission in Singapore celebrates Deepavali
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka High Commission in Singapore celebrated Deepavali, the ‘Festival of Lights’, at Sri Senpaga Vinayagar temple in Singapore on 18 November 2023, hosting over 120 participants. The event was attended by representatives of the diplomatic corps in Singapore, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Singapore, representatives of Singapore’s Inter-Religious-Council, representatives of Sri Lankan associations, including Singapore Ceylon Tamils Association and the Sri Senpaga Vinayagar temple and Sri Lankan expatriate community among others. Welcoming the guests, , Actg. High Commissioner  Ahamad Razee highlighted the significance of Deepavali, that symbolises the spiritual victory of good over evil, the light over darkness and knowledge over ignorance. He stated that Deepavali assumes a special significance in multicultural Sri Lanka and is celebrated as an important national festival. Actg. High Commissioner also added that the celebrations at the Sri Lankan heritage temple will provide an impetus in further strengthening relations with the Sri Lankan community in Singapore. Addressing the gathering, Guest of Honour and Member of Parliament of Singapore Neil Parek , stated that he was delighted to experience the Deepavali celebrations organised by the High Commission of Sri Lanka. Appreciating the participation of Sri Lankan cultural groups in the ‘Little India’ Deepavali lighting ceremony and the road parade, he stated that it further fosters cultural ties between the two countries. He also noted the efforts of the Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce to strengthen ties between Sri Lankan and Singaporean businesses. The invitees at the celebrations were treated to classical dance forms, including Bharathanatyam and Kathak, and classical songs performed by the students of Music and Dance Academy of Sri Senpaga Vinayagar Temple, Dance Academy of Sri Arasakesari Sivan Temple as well as the professional dancers of Apsaras Art Dance Company and Tatva productions. At the conclusion of the official programme, guests were treated to traditional sweets and a vegetarian dinner, in keeping with the spirit of Deepavali.

title: One Sri Lanka Dialogue: Impact of Budget 2024 on Youth and SMEs
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion organised by the Colombo Young Men’s Buddhist Association, in association with the Jaffna Chamber of Commerce, will be held on 20 November from 4.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. at the Board Room of the Colombo YMBA. This collaboration aims to provide a platform for insightful discussions on the budget’s impact, specifically focusing on the youth and SME sectors. The Jaffna Chamber of Commerce, in particular, will bring a unique perspective to the dialogue by highlighting the economic problems faced by the northern community and proposing practical solutions. Moderator: Mahendra Jayasekera – President, Colombo YMBA.Speakers: Sanjaya Bandara–President,CASri Lanka. Janith Wickramasinghe–Fiverr Community Leader Sri Lanka. Chaaminda Kumarasiri – Chairman/Principal Consultant–H.C.P. Consulting. Dhananath Fernando–Chief Executive Officer – Advocata. Ramalingam Sentilcumaran –Attorney-at-Law, Corporate Secretary–Jaffna Chamber of Commerce. Ajra Azhar–IBA2023 Scholar, Attorney-at-Law, Director– Colombo Associates We believe that engaging in a dialogue on the budget’s impact on the youth and SMEs is critical or fostering economic growth and inclusivity in our nation and this discussion serves as a platform for constructive discourse and collaborative thinking.
