title: Jailed for 14 years on bribery charge
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle yesterday (27) sentenced an accused, charged with soliciting a bribe of Rs 70,000, from an individual, under the guise of getting him a job in the Sri Lanka Railways Department, to14 years of RI. The Court also ordered the sentence to be served in a seven-year stretch and slapped a fine of Rs 20,000, on the convict. The convict was identified as Upul Alwis. Assistant Director General of Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) Diana Kodithuwakku prosecuted. The Bribery Commission had charged the convict before the High Court, for having sought the aforementioned bribe, from an individual, from 10 April to 20 October, six years ago.   BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: HC acquits woman of heroin trafficking charge
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday acquitted a woman, who had been charged with possession and trafficking of 6.86g of heroin, within the Welikada Prison premises. The accused, identified as R. Dulanjani, had allegedly carried out her actions, whilst being incarcerated, after being arrested on charges of peddling of heroin. Announcing his verdict, at the end of a lengthy trial, Judge Ranaraja, stated that he was acquitting the accused, as the prosecution, had failed to prove the charges against her, beyond a reasonable doubt. The accused was represented by Attorney-at-Law Asitha Vipulanayake. The High Court language Interpreter Sulaiman Yaseer, read out the verdict, while Senior State Counsel Vishwa Wijesuriya, prosecuted on behalf of the Attorney General’s Department. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Police probe mysterious resurrection
author: Author not found
Content: Gampola Police have launched an inquiry into the appearance of a dead , along with his mother and relatives, before the Gampola Coroner Nalin Mediwaka, after his remains had been buried upon the completion of his post mortem seven days after his death. A person had apparently died from a heart attack at the Gampola bus stand around two months ago but, as the deceased had not been identified, his remains had been kept at the mortuary of the Gampola Hospital. During this time the Police had identified a group said to be the relatives of the deceased from the lower division of Marywilawatta, Udahentenna. In the meantime, the mother and siblings of the deceased had identified the victim at the Gampola Hospital mortuary and the mother had stated that he was her 59-year-old son Laser Michael. As the remains of the deceased had also been identified by the latter’s siblings and relatives, Gampola Coroner Mediwaka had released the remains to them and it had then been taken to Marywilawatta, where the funeral had been held and the body buried. However, three days after the burial the victim had returned home and called for his mother. The mother and gobsmacked relatives had stated that they had buried him only three days ago following his demise. But the victim had insisted that he had not been to Gampola and that he had been to Nawalapitiya and that they had come across the remains of a different person at the Gampola bus stand. Later the victim’s mother and relatives had escorted him to the Gampola Coroner Mediwaka. During the inquest the relatives of had informed the Coroner that they had incurred an expense of Rs 75,000 for the funeral. Afterwards being noticed by the Gampola Coroner, Gampola Police had initiated a fresh probe to determine the identity of the person who had been buried. It had come to light that the person who had died had been identified as L. Michael, and a father of two whose his wife had left him. Police said accordingly he had been used to spending time at homes of his daughters and away from his hometown. During his final days the deceased had lived at Nawalapitiya and he had not spent much time at his daughter’s house. The victim’s brother had also informed the Coroner that he had seen the deceased a few days before his death at the Gampola town. BY Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: LG bodies urged to provide essential service to all
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee, on Open and Accountable Government, has instructed the heads of Local Government bodies to provide essential services with equal consideration for the public seeking assistance.  This directive emerged during the committee’s session in Parliament recently, chaired by Jagath Kumara Sumitraarachchi. Representatives from Urban Councils, Municipal Councils, and Divisional Secretariats in the Western Province were summoned to address the committee. The Committee Chairman underscored that adhering to the Establishments Code by all government officials would ensure that individuals seeking services do not face inconvenience. The Chairman also highlighted the importance of responding to public letters, concerning various matters, addressed to institutions. In response, Local Government Officials urged the committee to appoint an IT officer for each Local Government body to curb corruption and irregularities. The committee advised officials to put in place an efficient system for approving various plans within government institutions after thorough examination. Additionally, the committee emphasised on not accepting incomplete files from the public and noted that many issues could be prevented by ensuring the submission of complete files.

title: Protest demanding pay hike
author: Author not found
Content: A nationwide protest was held yesterday (27), during the lunch break, with the aim of pressuring the government to concede to a minimum salary increase or allowance of Rs 20,000 for State sector employees, declared by the State and Provincial Public Service Unions Association. Additionally, the union strongly opposes the budget proposal suggesting an eight per cent deduction from government employees’ salaries for Widows’ and Orphans’ pensions. (Pix by Jayantha Dissanayake – Boyawalana, Kamal Wijehewa – Galle, Sajith Gayan – Medawachchiya and D. Wanniarachchi – Menikhinna)

title: Compensation for Yala crop damage initiated
author: Author not found
Content: The Agriculture and Agrarian Insurance Board has initiated the disbursement of compensation to farmers, who experienced crop damage during the last Yala season drought. Compensation distribution for crop damage in the Walawa-Mahaweli zone, severely affected by water scarcity in the previous Yala season, commenced on Sunday (26). The ceremony, held at the D.A. Rajapaksa Memorial Hall in Embilipitiya, saw the participation of Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries, Mahinda Amaraweera. Minister Amaraweera revealed that 16,500 acres of land, cultivated by 15,000 farmers in the Walawa Zone, incurred damage, prompting the government to allocate Rs 3,628 million for compensation. Nationwide, a total of 65,000 acres of paddy cultivation was destroyed during the last Yala season drought, with an additional 11,000 acres affected by subsequent rains. This brings the total affected paddy fields to 76,000 acres. Minister Amaraweera emphasised that the government, in a historic move, allocated 5.5 billion rupees, the largest sum ever designated for crop damage compensation. The compensation event, attended by Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources, Pavithra Wanniarachchi, and Member of Parliament, Akila Ellawala, featured Minister Amaraweera expressing gratitude and outlining the swift compensation process. Minister Amaraweera stated, “Compensation will be given today to 1,030 farmers who suffered crop damage. The Walawa Zone is one of the highest rice-yielding areas in our country. Normally, compensation for crop damage takes about a year. But the government decided to provide crop damage compensation two months before the end of the cropping season, a first in history. I am thankful to the government led by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, which provided the financial allocation for this.” Minister of Wildlife and Forest Conservation Pavithra Wanniarachchi, expressed appreciation to Minister Amaraweera for expediting compensation and highlighted his persistent efforts in securing Cabinet approval. She noted that without Minister Amaraweera’s dedication, the swift provision of compensation would not have been possible. The Chairman of the Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board, W.M. M. B. Weerasekera, also participated in the event.

title: Urgent need to regulate private security
author: Author not found
Content: There is an imperative need for regulating privately owned security services provided for personal protection of individuals, the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Security pointed out.  This was discussed during the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Security meeting, in Parliament, with former Inspector General of Police, C. D. Wijewardene, the Secretary to the Ministry of Public Security and other officials and senior Police officers.  During the meeting, chairman of the committee Rear Admiral (retired) Sarath Weerasekara, emphasised that the general public is experiencing inconveniences due to certain private individuals being escorted by private security guards. In response, senior Police officers, present at the meeting, said that the Police cannot intervene in the personal security of an individual due to the lack of legal provisions. The committee members decided to inform the Ministry of Defence to establish criteria for regulating private security services, especially considering that these private security personnel possess lethal weapons, exacerbating the inconveniences caused by their entourages. There was also a lengthy discussion in the committee about the growth of underworld activities. It was also revealed in the committee that certain persons in the service of the armed forces show an increase in resorting to crime. The former IGP pointed out that there is some weakness in the identification of criminals. He further commented that if there are competent OICs to identify criminals in their areas, crime can be prevented before it happens and therefore attention has been paid to identify competent Police OICs and send them to the respective areas for service. Drug control was also discussed at length in the committee. The Police officials pointed out that the drug traffickers are working to make the schoolchildren addicted to drugs by giving them pills. They further commented that the first thing that should be done in drug control is to prevent those drugs from entering the country. The committee also discussed the need for strict enforcement of laws such as confiscation of property of drug traffickers. The oversight committee, comprised MPs Rauf Hakeem, Chandima Weerakodi, Channa Jayasumana, Charles Nirmalanathan, Major Pradeep Undugoda and Major Sudharshan Denipitiya. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Benefit to be given to consumers in April 2024 – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: If the loss-making Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) registers any operating profit in December, due to the torrential downpours in the country during the recent past, a decision has been taken to pass on these gains to consumers in April 2024, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera revealed.  Addressing a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) on 25 November, Wijesekara said the relevant departments have been instructed to revise fees charged for re-connection following power cuts. Accordingly, it is expected that the reconnection fee, which is currently Rs 3,000 be revised to between Rs1,000 and Rs2,000, he added. Wijesekera highlighted the current financial deficit faced by the Electricity Board, amounting to Rs 12 billion. However, he expressed optimism about a potential positive turn in the financial outlook, as indicated in the upcoming December financial report due to the prevailing rainy conditions. The Minister further elaborated on the recent Cabinet approval to restructure the CEB based on a report that was already submitted. The proposed new Electricity Bill received approval, marking a significant step to enhancing efficiency and effectiveness of the electricity sector in line with national objectives. Efforts are underway to gazette and present the Bill in Parliament within the next two weeks. The goal is to facilitate a comprehensive debate on the proposed Bill during Sittings scheduled for January 2024. The misconceptions in Parliament regarding the configuration of electricity generation, transmission, and distribution will be discussed. He proposed restructuring power generation into four distinct companies, emphasising that the entire hydroelectricity sector, constituting 100%, will remain under Government control. The management of power plants near the Mahaweli, Laxapana and Samanalawewa will also be retained by the Government. As part of the restructuring initiative, the Norochcholai Power Plant will be consolidated under a single company, while all other power plants will be grouped together under a separate entity. This decision aims to optimise operational efficiency and enhance the overall effectiveness of the power generation sector. “The proposal includes the establishment of a distinct company dedicated to transmission work, with the main control system remaining entirely under government ownership. Further, it is suggested that the four distribution zones be transformed into four separate companies, each tasked with efficient and independent operation. This strategic proposal aims to streamline transmission and distribution, ensuring enhanced effectiveness and response within the electricity sector. The restructuring of the Electricity Board is anticipated to bring efficiency, quality and reduce wastage. The initiative takes into consideration existing laws and regulations in various countries worldwide. The implementation of the plan is scheduled to follow the submission of the draft, incorporating feedback and suggestions from various stakeholders, including experts in the relevant field. The continuity of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) is expected to remain unchanged, operating in a manner consistent with current practices,” he said.  The nation has suffered the loss of numerous power plants due to delayed policy decisions and the prolonged non-implementation of previously made decisions. The proposed construction of the Sampur power plant, a project under consideration for several years, faced a significant setback when the decision was made in 2016 to forego its construction. Originally slated for completion in 2020, the non-realisation of the Sampur Power Plant has resulted in an annual loss of Rs 95 billion, he claimed.  Speaking further, the Minister said as part of the Government’s strategic initiatives, five significant projects have been identified for immediate implementation with plans to sign agreements for five more projects before the end of the year.  “These agreements include collaborations with the Adani wind power plant in Mannar, construction of a solar panel power plant in Siambalanduwa, the Hambantota solar panel project, as well as projects proposed for Batticaloa and Poonakary,” he added.

title: Inmate damages 23 CCTV cameras in Boossa Prison
author: Author not found
Content: An inmate at the Boossa High Security Prison had tampered with 23 CCTV cameras within the facility. The inmate, classified as a ‘special category’ prisoner, is said to have engaged in this vandalism on Saturday (25) morning. Investigations are currently in progress, directed by an Assistant Superintendent of Prisons. Rathgama Police will also be informed to initiate legal action against the inmate for damaging public property, Commissioner General of Prisons Thushara Upuldeniya said.  Upuldeniya disclosed that the prisoner had been transferred between prisons multiple times in the past due to recurrent unruly behaviour. He is currently facing charges related to the damage of public property in an ongoing Court case. Disciplinary action is to be taken against officers on duty at the time of the incident as they had failed to carry out their duties properly, Upuldeniya added. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: President introduces ‘Urumaya’ Freehold Deeds for farmers
author: Author not found
Content: If a foreign hotel like Shangri-La could be allotted a freehold land in Sri Lanka, why can’t a comparable privilege be granted to diligent farmers who have tilled the land for generations, President Ranil Wickremesinghe questioned yesterday (26). President Wickremesinghe introduced the Urumaya Freehold Deed Programme during the initial phase of the public awareness campaign as per 2024 budget proposal. The President underscored that this programme pays homage to farmers who have been the backbone of the nation for generations. President Wickremesinghe outlined the primary goals of the initiative, emphasising the transformation of each village into an enterprise village to significantly strengthen the export economy. He also disclosed plans to establish agriculture modernisation service centres to provide essential facilities supporting the growth of the agricultural industry. Speaking at a gathering in Nochchiyagama, Anuradhapura yesterday (26) the President raised a pertinent question regarding the allocation of freehold land for the Shangri-La Hotel. He questioned why a similar privilege couldn’t be extended to hardworking farmers who have cultivated the land for generations. Emphasising the potential for generating foreign exchange through strategic land allocations, he highlighted the importance of modernising the agriculture industry to bolster the export economy. A significant aspect of the programme involves allocating two billion rupees in the 2024 budget for ‘Urumaya’ freehold Deeds. President Wickremesinghe proposed a departure from existing Title Deed categories, such as Jaya Bhoomi, Saumya Bhoomi, Swarna Bhoomi, in favour of a unified freehold Deed system scheduled to be implemented in 2024. In his address, President Wickremesinghe urged unity in working for the country, transcending political differences. Reflecting on challenges faced on assuming office, he highlighted successful efforts to stabilise the country’s economic situation, steering it away from bankruptcy. The President announced plans to resume stalled development projects and emphasised the importance of safeguarding cultural and historical sites like Malwathu Oya and Maha Viharaya in Anuradhapura. Additionally, a budget allocation of one and a half billion rupees for cricket development in rural schools was disclosed. Governor of the North Central Province, Maheepala Herath, commended the President for his pivotal role in navigating Sri Lanka through legal and economic challenges. Describing the state of the law in the country as ‘wild’ at one point, Governor Herath praised the President’s acceptance of this challenge and emphasised the commendable efforts that led to the country’s economic recovery. The Governor highlighted the President’s visit to Anuradhapura and the Urumaya programme as a significant step in empowering the agricultural community. Minister of State for Finance, Shehan Semasinghe revealed that the President has included a groundbreaking provision in this year’s budget, granting freehold land rights to all citizens. Despite challenges in incorporating this proposal in the 2023 Budget due to prevailing circumstances, the President’s commitment to fulfilling the people’s need for land rights remained unwavering. Minister Semasinghe emphasised the President’s proactive measures in addressing agricultural concerns, particularly the provision of essential fertilisers to farmers, ensuring the entire requirement for yielding seasons has been met. The President’s comprehensive programme has not only established political stability but has also laid the foundation for social and economic stability in the country. He expressed satisfaction in resolving a fundamental issue faced by the people, allowing them to enjoy land with rightful ownership determined by the President’s decisive actions. MP Duminda Dissanayake expressed gratitude to President Wickremesinghe for his leadership and the implementation of the Urumaya programme, granting farmers the heritage of their great-grandfathers. Dissanayake commended the President’s political maturity, highlighting the effectiveness of this year’s budget in demonstrating the President’s thorough preparation. The MP praised the President’s decision to allocate a ten-thousand-rupee allowance to public servants, provide freehold deeds to farmers and grant tenants the rightful ownership of their houses. This, according to Dissanayake, underscores the President’s commitment to addressing the needs of various segments of society and showcases his leadership acumen. MP S.M. Chandrasena commended the President on the significant financial allocation to the Anuradhapura District in the latest budget announcement. Notably, funds have been designated for crucial projects such as the Malwatu Oya initiative and the Maha Viharaya. MP Chandrasena underscored the President’s commitment to the agricultural community by highlighting the proposal in this year’s budget to grant freehold deeds to farmers. He emphasised that these measures, aimed at providing relief to a nation grappling with economic challenges, exemplify the President’s political maturity and his dedication to addressing key issues faced by the country. The event witnessed the presence of prominent figures, including the Chairman of the Anuradhapura District Development Committee H. Nandasena, MP Uddika Premaratne, former Chief Minister S. M. Ranjith, Former Minister P. Harrison, Attorney-at-law Kasthuri Anuradhanayake and Land Commissioner General Bandula Jayasinghe.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sugar shortage soon due to hoarding
author: Author not found
Content: There could be a short-term shortage of sugar in the market in coming days, as importers have suspended sugar imports, exacerbating the distribution issues in the market following the recently imposed Maximum Retail Price (MRP). This was revealed by Nalin Fernando, the Minister of Trade, Commerce and Food Security during the recent sittings the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Trade, Commerce, and Food Security held in Parliament. The minister highlighted a reported shortage of sugar in the local market due to the concealment of sugar stocks following the imposition of a maximum retail price. Importers have suspended sugar imports, exacerbating the distribution issues in the market. Considering the risk of a sugar shortage, the Minister announced the removal of the maximum retail price on sugar, taking various factors into account. He also announced that initiatives have been implemented to import a supply of rice similar to Keeri Samba to meet the demand for the upcoming festive season.  Expanding on this matter, Fernando said significant efforts have been made by the primary large-scale paddy mill owners in the country to address the artificial scarcity of keeri samba and samba rice. This scarcity has reportedly been created by withholding stocks without releasing them into the market. Additionally, the Minister outlined plans to establish a system that supports the business community, with a specific focus on addressing challenges faced by small and medium-scale paddy mill owners. Further, the minister commended Lanka Sathosa for successfully providing essential products to consumers at affordable prices. In an effort to offer relief to consumers during the upcoming festive season, Lanka Sathosa has taken steps to reduce prices on nearly 400 items, including essential food products. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: No entry fee for tourists to Galle Fort – Pathirana
author: Author not found
Content: The Galle Heritage Foundation will not be permitted to charge foreign tourists visiting Galle Fort and any attempt to do so will not be sanctioned, Minister of Health Dr. Ramesh Pathirana said. He revealed this at a special discussion on 25 November at Sudharmalaya Temple, Galle Fort.  Previously, the Galle Heritage Foundation had spoken of its intention to impose a fee of USD 15 on foreign tourists entering the Galle Fort.  In response to this announcement, local residents of the Fort, including individuals from various business sectors and those connected to tourism, voiced their objections. They submitted a letter of protest to the Galle Heritage Foundation and initiated a black flag protest against the proposed fee. Minister Pathirana said the decision to charge a fee was not correct and had not been communicated to any authority. He confirmed that he had discussed the matter with the Minister of Buddhashasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickramanayake and Secretary, Somaratne Vidanapathirana. Minister Wickramanayake explicitly stated that such an initiative would not be endorsed, he added. “It is impractical to collect a fee from tourists entering the Fort and such a practice cannot be allowed. Galle Fort is a place that impacts all of us as well as the tourism industry. It hosts nearly a thousand people directly and another ten thousand indirectly. Tourists come to Galle to witness its beauty and for relaxation. Charging a fee would hinder this. Preservation is possible only with public support. Therefore, the decision to impose an entry fee will not be approved or permitted under any circumstances,” Pathirana said. BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle

title: Protesters block Central Expressway entrance
author: Author not found
Content: Members from approximately 600 households affected by the construction of the final stretch of the Central Expressway from Mirigama to Kurunegala staged a protest yesterday (26), demanding compensation for damage to their property.  Approximately 800 members from families in Gattuwana, Teliyagonna, Vedaruwa and surrounding areas participated in the protest. They blocked the Kurunegala entrance of the Central Expressway, saying that their houses were on the verge of collapse due to the substandard construction of the road. They expressed dissatisfaction with the authorities’ lackadaisical attitude. In a collective effort, they drafted a petition with over 2,000 signatures, intending to present it to the United Nations. The letter highlighted the violation of their fundamental rights and the indifference shown by the Government. The petition was signed at the Royal Reception Hall in Theliyagonna where the protestors gathered and commenced the march.  They questioned the need for an expressway that jeopardises lives, harms the environment and traps people in debt. The protestors, forming a human blockade obstructed the highway entrance, chanting slogans such as “We gave our land, they stole our compensation” and “Does the President only see damage to Ministers houses?” Residents blocked the expressway causing a huge traffic block. Most vehicles were redirected causing frustration among those attempting to use the expressway. Officials who diverted the vehicles had to face the brunt of the anger. In response to the escalating situation, Kurunegala SP Priyantha Kasturiarachichi, IP (Acting) Pushpalal and Gattuwana IP Kelum Herath arrived on the scene to control the crowd. However, the protestors insisted they would not disperse until their grievances were addressed. Protestors demanded a written assurance from the Police that they would intervene and hold a discussion between protesters, the construction company and other relevant parties. The entrance was eventually reopened when Police issued a letter instructing the affected parties to negotiate with officials of the construction company in three days. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Sinopec to build USD 4.5B refinery
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka will likely approve on Monday a proposal, from Chinese State refiner Sinopec, to build a USD 4.5-billion refinery. “It’s on the agenda for Monday. Once the Cabinet approves, we will invite them to sign the agreement,” Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera told Reuters. Sri Lanka, trying to recover from its worst economic crisis in more than 70 years, is hungry for new investment and local fuel supplies. Sinopec’s investment of at least USD 4.5 billion “will go up in value as and when they do additions, but they must first come and sign the agreement for us to give any more details,” Wijesekera said. For Sinopec, the world’s top refinery by capacity and one of the largest petrochemical makers, the investment would mark a breakthrough in a long effort to expand beyond China’s borders. It owns refinery assets in Saudi Arabia and petrochemicals production in Russia. The Sri Lanka investment follows State-run China Merchant Port Holdings’ 99-year lease at Hambantota port and a USD 392 million deal to build a logistics and storage hub in Colombo port, Chinese State media reported in April. That fits into Beijing’s ambitious Belt and Road Initiative, billed as recreating the ancient Silk Road to boost global trade infrastructure, experts say. Sinopec will start basic engineering design, including finalising the size of the refinery and technical configuration, after getting official approval, a senior company official told Reuters this month. The investment will add to Sinopec’s recently started fuel retailing business, the third international company with a foothold in Sri Lanka, with a license to operates 150 petrol stations. In August Sinopec and commodities trader Vitol were shortlisted by the Sri Lankan Government to bid for the refinery. Vitol subsequently dropped out, the Sinopec official said. The refinery may target markets beyond Sri Lanka, where local fuel consumption is low, and use its partnership with China Merchants Port to expand bunker fuel supply at Hambantota, a deep-sea port near busy shipping lanes between Europe and Asia, analysts say. Sinopec’s fuel oil division, which runs the retail business there, began in 2019 supplying marine bunker fuel at Hambantota, another Sinopec official said. Sri Lanka’s refinery at Sapugaskanda, commissioned in 1969, can process 38,000 barrels of oil a day. (Reuters)

title: Badulla Provincial Hospital upgraded to Teaching Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: The Badulla Provincial General Hospital was upgraded as a Teaching Hospital yesterday (26). This development marks the expansion of Sri Lanka’s teaching hospital network to 22 facilities, Health authorities said. Dr. Asela Gunawardena, Director General of Health Services said yesterday that the Badulla Provincial General Hospital was elevated to the status of a Teaching Hospital yesterday. The announcement coincided with the commencement of the construction for a ten-storey building designated as the Professorial Unit of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Uva Wellassa. A sum of Rs 2.26 billion has been allocated for the project and is scheduled for completion by December 2025.  Fifty students will be enrolled to the Medical Faculty in January 2024 and will commence clinical training at the new Teaching Hospital. BY Prasanna Pathmasiri – Lunugala

title: Demonstration decrying violence against women
author: Author not found
Content: A demonstration decrying violence against women and girls and calling for increased protection of women’s rights, took place yesterday (26) morning in Biyagama.  Over 100 women workers participated in the protest, organised by the Dabindu Collective. The protesters came from Free Trade Zones (FTZs) in Biyagama, as well as Kilinochchi and Vavuniya. Placards were used to get the message across. Chamila Thushari, Executive Director of the Dabindu Collective, was also in attendance. Since its establishment in 1984, the organisation has been dedicated to safeguarding and advancing the rights of women workers in the Biyagama and Katunayake FTZs, as well as the Northern Province.   By Kusum S. Hennadi – Kelaniya

title: MOP fertiliser price slashed to Rs 9,000
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera has announced a reduction in the price of Muriate of Potash (MOP), commonly known as ‘Bandi Pohora,’ to Rs 9,000 for the ongoing ‘Maha’ harvest season. The Minister said Cabinet has approved his proposal for the price adjustment of MOP fertiliser, bringing it down from Rs 19,000 to Rs 9,000 per bag. Both State-owned fertiliser suppliers will implement this revised pricing, Amaraweera added. Amaraweera made this announcement in Embilipitiya yesterday (26) morning, while awarding compensation to farmers whose crops suffered due to the arid weather earlier this year.  The Government has allocated Rs 100 million for this compensation initiative, Amaraweera said.

title: 168 child sexual abuse cases in September – COPF
author: Author not found
Content: In September of the present year, 168 cases of child sexual abuse were reported, leading to 22 girls under the age of 16 becoming pregnant. This was disclosed at the recent meeting of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF).  The COPF convened a special discussion in Parliament last week with representatives from civil organisations, including the Westminster Foundation for Democracy (WFD). The aim was to gather ideas and suggestions on the budget proposals for the year 2024 and the formulation of policies in the country. The committee was chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva. During the meeting, representatives from civil organisations highlighted several areas in the budget proposals that received insufficient attention but warranted careful consideration. They drew attention to the potential problems arising from the lack of focus on women’s welfare, with a detailed discussion on the challenges faced by school girls. In response, the COPF directed its attention to identifying the number of school girls in need of various facilities, including sanitary facilities, and proposed the establishment of a system to provide them with the necessary amenities. The committee also learned that civil society representatives expressed the urgent need to implement a systematic programme to provide sex education for children. Another extensive discussion in the committee centred on the necessity of formulating new policies to implement special programmes for the care of the elderly in the country. The committee chair emphasised the need to amend the existing legislation concerning mental health development to make it more suitable for the present context.

title: 56% respondents fear Online Safety Bill will limit social media freedom
author: Author not found
Content: In a recent survey commissioned by Sri Lankan think tank Verité Research, findings indicate that a significant portion of respondents who were aware of the proposed Online Safety Bill expressed concerns about its potential impact on social media freedom.  The survey, conducted in October 2023, involved responses from 1,029 Sri Lankan adults and sought to gauge public awareness and sentiments regarding the Bill. When asked if they were aware of the Government’s initiative to regulate behaviour on social media, one-third (34 per cent) of respondents answered in the affirmative. Among those who indicated awareness, a notable 56 per cent expressed apprehension that the Online Safety Bill would curtail the freedom of using social media. Meanwhile, 25 per cent believed it would not significantly impact social media use, and 19 per cent thought it would help in reducing the misuse of social media. The Online Safety Bill, officially published in the Government Gazette on 18 September and tabled in Parliament on 3 October, aims to establish an Online Safety Commission endowed with specific powers and functions. However, the Supreme Court has determined that 31 clauses within the Bill require amendment for it to be passed with a simple majority. As it stands, a special majority of two-thirds is necessary for its passage. Verité Research conducted the survey using an islandwide, nationally representative sample, garnering responses from 1,029 Sri Lankan adults.  The polling partner for this syndicated survey was Vanguard Survey (Pvt) Ltd. The results, with a maximum error margin below ±3 per cent at a 95 per cent confidence interval, provide insights into the sentiments of the Sri Lankan public regarding the Online Safety Bill.

title: Kantale PS sanitary workers face numerous issues
author: Author not found
Content: Sanitary workers who are residents of Nagarasabha Mawatha, Kantale and work for the Kantale Pradeshiya Sabha claim that their basic rights have been overlooked.  They said 45 years ago they were given houses where two houses share a single electricity connection, creating difficulties to residents.  Further, obtaining drinking water was a persistent issue. The houses have structural issues such as cracked walls and roof slabs that leak during the rainy season as well.  Compounding the situation, four families are forced to share a single toilet, they alleged. Inadequate sanitation facilities often result in toilet pits overflowing, causing inconvenience to residents. As a result, school-going children frequently find it difficult to attend school due to these issues. Despite these concerns being brought to the notice of the authorities, they claimed that their pleas have been turned on deaf ears. The neglect by the authorities has left them in untold misery especially considering their role in maintaining the city’s cleanliness, they said.  BY W.M. Wickramarathne – Kantale
