title: Two nabbed at BIA with fake documents
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons aged 25 and 27 were apprehended at the BIA on 25 November for attempting to leave the country with fake documents. Border Control Unit officers from the Department of Immigration and Emigration at the BIA detained the suspects as they tried to board a Turkish Airlines flight bound for Austria. According to Police, the duo hailing from Kilinochchi and Mulleriyawa possessed fake visa documents procured through a broker in Borella. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Problems faced by Negombo fishers to be solved soon
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (26) that many problems faced by Negombo fishers would be resolved by the first quarter of next year. He also said numerous issues confronting Negombo fisherfolk required immediate attention.He said so while on an inspection tour of the Negombo Fishery Harbour.  Devananda opened a new fish stall and  pledged to promptly address the problems faced by Negombo fisherfolk, including fuel concerns and the soaring prices of fishing gear such as fishing nets. He assured that President Ranil Wickremesinghe would be informed and their major issues would be resolved. Devananda highlighted the recent tax relief on fishing gear imports and sales, expressing hope that this would lead to reduced prices for fishing gear beginning the next year. He said stalls constructed within the vicinity of the harbour have been allocated to Fisheries societies in the Negombo area taking their needs into consideration. In urging shop owners to maintain cleanliness in their stalls, Devananda said the importance of providing people with the opportunity to purchase fresh fish at affordable prices was pasramount. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Court rejects Diana’s injunction plea
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Sandun Vithana on Friday (24), rejected a petition, filed by State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage, seeking an interim injunction, against Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and SJB General Secretary MP Ranjith Maddumabandara. After taking into consideration, the submissions produced on Friday, the Judge deemed that the petitioner had willfully abstained, from divulging certain details, in her complaint. He further added in his ruling, that both the Leader and the General Secretary of the SJB, have ceased to be members of the UNP, since 2021 and that they were currently holding posts within the SJB.    Accordingly, he declined to deliver an interim injunction, against the SJB Leader and his General Secretary, as sought by Gamage. In her petition, the State Minister, had sought an interim order, preventing Premadasa from functioning as the SJB’s Leader and Parliamentarian Maddumabandara as the party’s General Secretary, alleging that the duo, were unsuitable to hold their respective positions, in the main Opposition. The petitioner had pointed out that, pursuant to the SJB’s Constitution, a member of another political party (UNP) cannot hold membership in the SJB.  She said there are already separate pending Court cases, filed by the Opposition Leader and Maddumabandara, with regard to their membership in the United National Party (UNP). As such, Gamage prayed for an interim order ruling, that it is unlawful for the two lawmakers, to hold their respective positions in the SJB, as they are still members of the UNP. During Friday’s Court proceedings, Judge Vithana, ordered the petitioner concerned and the respondents, to submit their fresh responses on 12 February, next year. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Dengue cases shoot up to 74,195
author: Author not found
Content: With the number of high-risk dengue areas leaping from 45 to 50 almost overnight, statistics issued by the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) showed that aided by inclement weather, the total number of dengue cases in the country had shot up to a startling 74,195 by Friday (24).  Statistics issued by the NDCU’s DenSys Surveillance system showed that the total number of dengue deaths had also increased to 45. From the beginning of the year till date, Colombo alone has recorded 15,722 cases amounting to 21.2 per cent of the total number of cases. Gampaha (14,786) has 20 per cent of the cases while Kalutara District has 4,625 dengue cases from the beginning of the year till date.  The Western Province alone has 47.4 per cent (35,133) of the total number of dengue cases in the country. The DenSys statistics show that Kandy has 7,296 dengue cases.  Director General of Health Services (DGHS), Dr. Asela Gunawardena said a special dengue control programme would be carried out over the weekend in the Colombo District. He urged the public to seek medical attention at the nearest government hospital.  People should also refrain from trying out home remedies while only taking Paracetamol for the fever.  The DGHS appealed to all communities as well as the clergy to clean up their environs of mosquito breeding places as the inclement weather being experienced would only increase mosquito breeding sites.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Speaker vows to respond to President’s concerns about CC
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, in response to President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s recent statements on the Constitutional Council (CC), assured that matters concerning the approval of the IGP and members of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) would be resolved within two weeks. Acknowledging the error in the 22nd Amendment where the Constitutional Council was mistakenly referred to as the Constitutional Board, Speaker Abeywardana emphasised that this error caused the delay in appointing members to the Bribery Commission. He said no one should be held accountable for this oversight, stating, “You cannot blame anyone for this error.” In his capacity as the Chairman of the CC, the Speaker expressed his commitment to responding to concerns raised by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa during a recent session. The President, on Thursday (23), advocated for the formation of a select committee to investigate delays attributed to the CC. The Speaker affirmed his plan to address the President directly, stating, “I will write to the President and clarify the CC’s stance on the issues he raised.” By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Landslide alerts issued for 33 DS divisions – NBRO
author: Author not found
Content: As adverse weather persists across most parts of the country, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has extended various levels of landslide early warning alerts to 33 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and surrounding areas spanning four districts. Dr. K.G.P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist of the Landslide Early Warning Centre at NBRO, identified the affected districts as Ratnapura, Badulla, Kandy, and Kegalle. Dr. Senadeera highlighted that the level three red-watch evacuation alerts, initially issued for Balangoda, Weligepola, Opanayake, Imbulpe, and Kolonna DS divisions, along with the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, will remain in effect until further notice. Residents in these areas are advised to exercise caution and be prepared to move to safer locations if they observe any signs of landslides, such as the slanting of trees or telephone posts, sudden emergence of muddy water or springs from the Highlands, ground cracks in the neighbourhood, or cracks on the walls and floors of residential buildings and other structures. The extension also applies to level two amber-watch landslide early warning alerts issued for Kuruwita, Kalawana, Elapatha, Godakawela, Eheliyagoda, and Ratnapura DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. Further, the level one yellow-watch landslide early warning alerts, originally issued for Hali-Ela, Haputale, and Passara DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Badulla District; Ganga Ihala Korale, Gangawata Korale, Doluwa, Pasgoda Korale, Thumpane, and Udunuwara DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Kandy District; Galigamuwa, Ruwanwella, Aranayaka, Kegalle, Yatiyanthota, Bulathkohupitiya, Mawanella, and Warakapola DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Kegalle District; and Kiriella, Ayagama, Nivithigala, Pelmadulla, and Kahawatta DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, have also been extended until further notice, Dr. Senadeera said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Woman beaten to death
author: Author not found
Content: The body of an elderly woman was found on Saturday (25) suspected to have been beaten. Preliminary investigations revealed that the victim was a 69-year-old woman and a resident of Makura in Mirigama and that an argument had broken out between the victim and her son-in-law which had escalated leading the suspect fatally beat the victim. Mirigama Police have initiated a manhunt to apprehend the suspect, who fled the area after the incident. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Pre-dawn joint Op leads to 40 arrests
author: Author not found
Content: A joint operation conducted by the Police, Special Task Force (STF) and the Army in Sinhapura, Wellampitiya resulted in the arrest of at least 40 individuals for possession of drugs and weapons. The pre-dawn operation on Sunday (26) involved a total of 138 Police personnel and 200 Army personnel.  A thorough search of 61 houses and 196 persons was carried out, leading to the finding of  narcotic substances such as heroin and crystal methamphetamine (ICE), illicit alcohol, swords, and other weapons. Twelve mobile phones were also found during the raid. The operation was executed under the directive of Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon, Western Province DIG (South) Gayanga Marapana, and Western Province South District Crime Division SP Lalith Abeysekara. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: PSC to probe Constitutional Council’s delays
author: Author not found
Content: The on-going ‘rift’ between the Executive and the Constitutional Council (CC) has seemingly deepened further, as President Ranil Wickremesinghe openly criticised the conduct of the CC yesterday (23) and the day before yesterday (22) in Parliament.  The President announced that a Parliamentary Select Committee (PSC) will be established to investigate the delays caused by the CC in approving appointments to key positions in Sri Lanka. The President made this declaration following a vigorous Parliamentary discussion addressing the prolonged approval process by the Constitutional Council for high-ranking positions in the country. He emphasised that these delays have led to the absence of crucial roles, such as Inspector General of Police (IGP) and judges, resulting in the compromised functioning of both the Police and Judiciary. Regarding the appointment of Court of Appeal President Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne to the Supreme Court, the President expressed unawareness of the reasons behind the delay. He clarified that the nomination was made by the Chief Justice and submitted to the Constitutional Council by him. He made these statements, while addressing the questions raised by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, MPs Harsha de Silva and Rauf Hakeem. It paved the way for a lengthy discussion between the Opposition MPs and the President. President Wickremesinghe alleged that certain members within the CC were actively working to obstruct its functioning. Consequently, the decision was made to form a Parliamentary Select Committee to deliberate on matters related to the CC. The President highlighted the current inability to make appointments in the Sri Lanka Police and the Judiciary. He revealed that a letter from the Speaker to the CC received a response stating their inability to take decisions. Additionally, he disclosed that one member is yet to be appointed to the Constitutional Council, causing a split among the six existing members and two members abstaining from voting, further delaying appointments. Concerns were raised by the Opposition on the delay in appointing Tamil National Alliance (TNA) MP Dharmalingam Sithadthan as the last member of the Council, as proposed by the Opposition. Premadasa alleged that the Speaker had failed to appoint MP Sithadthan to the Constitutional Council, and the Opposition cannot be held accountable for the Speaker’s inaction. The President also pointed out the challenges in appointing an Anti-Corruption Commission despite the passing of relevant laws due to similar issues with the CC. He emphasised that, despite being considered a Parliamentary Committee, the Council falls under the Executive and is responsible for evaluating the eligibility of nominees for high-ranking positions. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Aragalaya’ diverted Police, military attention away from drugs, underworld – Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles, claimed in Parliament yesterday (23) that, in his view, deploying the Police and Military exclusively to address the Aragalaya and its associated incidents for about a year, resulted in diverting the attention of the law enforcement agencies away from underworld activities and drug-related issues in the country.  Speaking during the Committee Stage debate on Expenditure Heads on Defence and Public Security, the Minister explained that the Police had to divert their full attention to Aragalaya, thereby shifting their focus from other duties and responsibilities. Highlighting the challenges faced by the Police Department, the Minister mentioned that there are more than 20,000 vacancies within the department. He outlined steps being taken to gradually address this shortage, considering the ongoing economic crisis. “We have successfully recruited 2,000 Police personnel this year, and our plan is to recruit an additional 5,000 personnel in the coming year,” Minister Alles added. In response to a statement made by MP Dullas Alahapperuma, during the debate, claiming that at least 50 deaths occur monthly due to underworld-related activities, Minister Alles contested that figure, asserting it to be significantly overstated. “Over the past four months, we’ve recorded 28 murders, with 16 involving shootings. Of these incidents, eight involved shooters, resulting in three deaths. Additionally, we made arrests in nine cases involving motorcycles, one of which resulted in a fatality. Furthermore, 67 individuals have been arrested for aiding and abetting these activities. Many of the key perpetrators have either been apprehended or neutralised during Police encounters. We have implemented a comprehensive programme, particularly in the Southern Province, although we cannot disclose all the details here. Rest assured, we are systematically working to suppress the activities of the underworld. We’ve extradited certain underworld figures from abroad and there are plans to bring in more in the future.” MP Thalatha Atukorale’s suggested to track the phone records of underworld figures like Harak Kata.  We are actively undertaking that task and taking measures to trace their assets as well, he added. “MP Rauff Hakeem expressed concern that Police Officers involved in the Easter Sunday attacks are facing retaliation, citing as an example the remanding of former DIG Ravi Seneviratne after his arrest for drunk driving. I personally know DIG Seneviratne and he was involved in a drunk driving incident where he damaged three vehicles. The arrest drew significant media attention and granting Police bail could have led to accusations of Police favouritism,” Minister Alles clarified. He said, Seneviratne was produced in the Court on the following day and remanded. Hakeem emphasised that this decision was made not by the Police, but, by the judiciary. Speaking further, Minister Alles responded to the allegations made by Colombo Archbishop His Eminence Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith and the Catholic Church about the investigations into the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. “There are 42 cases filed in the High Court. There are 80 respondents, with 23 individuals in remand at the moment. The investigations are 90% complete. Cardinal Malcolm Ranjith and the Catholic Church expressed a desire for the full Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) report into the terror attacks. Upon discussing this matter with the President and I provided the full report to them and requested time for a presentation on the progress of the investigations.” However, there has been a delay in receiving the requested time, with them citing the extensive nature of the report as the reason for the delay. Despite this, periodic letters have been sent making allegations against several individuals. The President has also faced criticism during interviews conducted by the authorities, he stressed. Expressing his concerns, the minister alleged that there is a perceived lack of genuine interest from the Catholic Church’s in resolving the case. “There is another important thing. I have to request Cardinal Ranjith not to provoke racism in the country. It seems consistently attempt to interfere with government affairs using this issue. I have to reveal that the Cardinal tried to force the former President not to appoint then Justice Minister Ali Sabry to the post in 2020, just because he is a Muslim. These things should not happen. I request everyone not to work aiming at gaining votes,” he stressed.  BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Rains displace 460 families in Badulla
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the adverse weather conditions, a total of 460 families, comprising 1,582 individuals, have been impacted in the Badulla District. A total of 91 houses have been partially damaged and 2 have been completely destroyed, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) revealed. Tragically, two fatalities have occurred, and one individual who had been swept away by flood waters is reported missing. To address the immediate needs of those affected, 11 welfare centres have been established, accommodating 409 families (1,413 persons) with provisions of food and essential facilities. Necessary measures have been taken to provide compensation to the families of two young women, aged 21 and 22, who tragically lost their lives when a mound of earth collapsed onto their house in the Uduwara area of the Hali-Ela Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division in the Badulla District. The Disaster Relief Service Officer, for the Badulla District, confirmed these actions yesterday (23).  The official outlined that a compensation of Rs. 250,000 would be disbursed to each victim’s family, with an initial sum of Rs. 50,000 released, to cover immediate funeral expenses, through the Hali-Ela Divisional Secretariat — Rs 25,000 for each victim’s family. The remaining compensation will be provided upon the submission of the victims’ death certificates. Additionally, a housing construction programme is underway to relocate those residing in the affected area to a safer location, he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SL won’t allow India’s security to be hurt – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said that the country’s relationship with India does not depend on New Delhi’s ties with China, adding that the island nation won’t do anything to hurt India’s security. In an exclusive interview with Firstpost, India Wickremesinghe said, “India worried about its own security. Sri Lanka won’t do anything to hurt its security.” When asked about his meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi last year, Wickremesinghe said, “I have known Narendra Modi since he was a Chief Minister. Our vision was a step forward. We talked about trade and investment.” He also highlighted India’s help when the country underwent an economic crisis last year. In May, India extended a one billion USD credit line for Sri Lanka by a year. The credit line is part of the four billion USD in emergency assistance extended by India. Commenting on the current economy in Sri Lanka, Wickremesinghe said, “We are not out of the woods yet, but will come out. We still have to balance the budget and trade and increase our revenues. I hope things will get better in 2024-2025. We can’t go on in transitional mode and need a new economy.” He also said there was no evidence to suggest that the Chinese research vessels that had recently docked in Sri Lanka were espionage vessels, emphasising that the nation requested evidence but none was provided, clarifying that these vessels were civilian in nature. Addressing concerns raised by India and the United States, regarding the arrival of the Chinese research vessels, Wickremesinghe assured that Sri Lanka welcomes both research and military vessels, not only from China but also from other countries. He pointed out the disparity in media coverage, noting that only the arrivals of Chinese vessels tend to make headlines, despite Sri Lanka routinely allowing vessels from various nations. When questioned about Sri Lanka’s position in the perceived ‘great power battle’ between China and India, Wickremesinghe asserted that the country would not take actions jeopardising the national security of its neighbour. Regarding the debt restructuring process, the President highlighted that China, as the largest bilateral creditor, chose to negotiate separately with Sri Lanka due to dissatisfaction with the terms offered by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank. He explained that China believes it should play a more significant role in the IMF, leading them to opt out of the negotiation process and complicating matters for indebted nations. Wickremesinghe acknowledged the challenges in negotiating Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring within the context of international geopolitics. He mentioned that the terms of the debt deal with China have been shared with other creditors. Discussing the country’s economic recovery, the President acknowledged the challenges faced in the past year but expressed optimism. He emphasised the need for Sri Lanka to balance its budget, trade, and increase revenues. He hoped for improvement by 2024-2025. Regarding the upcoming presidential election in 2024, Wickremesinghe stated that his current priority is to stabilise the economy. Once this goal is achieved, he will decide on his future course of action. He expressed confidence in unlocking the remainder of the IMF’s bailout package, indicating that Sri Lanka has met the global lender’s benchmarks.

title: Principal who forced students to eat polythene transferred
author: Author not found
Content: The Principal of Rambukpitiya Central College, who allegedly compelled a group of students to ingest polythene lunch sheets, has been swiftly transferred to the Gampola Zone, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha told Parliament yesterday (23).  The unsettling event came to light on the previous day (22), when reports surfaced that students at Rambukpitiya Central College in Nawalapitiya were forced to swallow polythene lunch sheets and newspaper used to wrap their lunch. In response, the principal allegedly mandated the students to consume the forbidden lunch sheets and newspapers as a form of punishment. Unfortunately, two of the affected students fell ill and sought medical attention at Nawalapitiya Hospital the following morning.  Premajayantha, in a special statement regarding the incident, said when he was informed about it, he promptly contacted the Central Province’s Education Director for further information. Investigations revealed that a group of Grade 11 students at the school had brought lunches wrapped in polythene sheets, despite the institution being designated a polythene-free zone. The minister said, the remaining five students involved in the incident attended school yesterday (23), and the Nawalapitiya Police received a formal complaint on the matter on the previous day (22).  An on-site investigation was conducted by the Pasbage Divisional Director of Education, leading to the immediate transfer of the implicated principal to Gampola Zone, Premajayantha added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Doctors who left for greener pastures now returning – Dr Mahipala
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Health has observed an increasing trend in medical practitioners, who had left the country to work overseas, returning, newly appointed Health Ministry Secretary Dr. Palitha Mahipala said.  Responding to questions during a media briefing at the Health Ministry yesterday (24), Dr. Mahipala said, “The trend is coming down and there is a noted decline in the number of medical practitioners and other health category employees leaving the country. Even medical specialists who had left the country during the economic crisis have been returning.” The Health Ministry has observed that even those who had left the country, for their period of foreign training, had begun to return. Dr. Mahipala said, the brain drain was a common issue for all categories of employees, not only in the health sector. But, it takes eight to 10 years to train a specialist doctor and to lose him or her to another country was a heavy loss to the Sri Lanka. The Ministry too, on its part, had held several discussions, with medical and other health services, on the issue. “They have all explained the issues facing them while as the Health Ministry we too, are working towards finding solutions to their issues as much as possible,” he explained.  Meanwhile, Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, who praised Dr. Mahipala, said the newly appointed Health Ministry Secretary, before assuming the position had served as the Permanent Representative of the Government of Pakistan to the World Health Organisation (WHO). At a time when there is much talk about brain drain, he has left a job with great recognition to assume this position in Sri Lanka, Dr. Pathirana said.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Special discussion held on restructuring SL energy sector
author: Author not found
Content: A special discussion took place on Wednesday (22) between the Ministry of Energy, the Reforms Secretariat and the Committee,  to deliberate on the next steps for restructuring Sri Lanka’s energy sector, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara revealed yesterday (23).  Wijesekara, shared on social media that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has appointed  Dr. Pankaj Batra, the former Chairman of the Central Electricity Authority of India, to assist in the restructuring process of the country’s energy sector.  Additionally, Professor Arosha Adhikaram, from the Human Resource Management Department at the University of Colombo, will support human resource management at the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and the Asian Development Bank, while Dabasis Mahapatra, an executive ADB Consultant, will contribute his expertise on institutional strengthening. During the meeting, various issues were addressed, including the recently approved electricity bill by the Cabinet, which is awaiting being gazetted and parliamentary approval. Minister Wijesekara stated in the announcement that the President, Cabinet members, Asian Development Bank, Japan International Cooperation Agency, World Bank, and American International Cooperation Agency, among other development agencies, are closely monitoring and preparing constitutionally required regulations for consumers. Security measures, system setup guidelines, and modifications to the Sinhala translation of the Act were also discussed. Minister Wijesekara further indicated that the proposed restructuring programme of the Electricity Board received approval during the Cabinet meeting held last Monday. Consequently, the new Electricity Bill is slated to be presented to Parliament for adoption in the near future. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: “I regret, but…” Sanath Nishantha writes to Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister Sanath Nishantha, who was suspended from attending Parliamentary sittings for two weeks, has penned a letter to Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena protesting his suspension.  In his comprehensive six-point communication, Nishantha expressed remorse over the incident in Parliament that led to his suspension. He acknowledged that such occurrences should not happen within the parliamentary settings. Furthermore, Nishantha detailed the reasons behind his actions and highlighted alleged transgressions by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Nalin Bandara during the same time.  Arguing that singling him out for disciplinary action amounted to a breach of his Parliamentary privileges, MP Sanath Nishantha urged the Speaker to conduct an investigation and take appropriate measures against Sajith Premadasa and Nalin Bandara in connection with the incident as well.  “I was put in that situation (brawl) due to several reasons. The Opposition Leader was violating his privileges with regard to making statements under the Standing Orders 27/2. Also, he was continuously insulting former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, who is also an MP, violating the Standing Orders 91(h) and 92 (g). Also, Nalin Bandara was recording the incident without obtaining our constant. You (the Speaker) also warned him not to do that, but he disobeyed. That unfortunate incident happened due to these reasons,” he claimed.   On Wednesday (22) Speaker Abeywardena announced Nishantha’s suspension from parliamentary activities for a two-week period, following the unruly incident that took place on the previous day (21). The Speaker, invoking Standing Order 146 of the Parliament, expressed his strong disapproval of the brawl that unfolded during the sittings.  A pandemonium enraged when Premadasa raised questions about individuals, including the Rajapaksa brothers, held responsible by the Supreme Court for the economic crisis. SLPP MPs, including State Minister Sanath Nishantha, reportedly disrupted the speech and surrounded Premadasa’s seat, prompting a suspension of the session. Accusations were also levelled against State Minister Nishantha for allegedly snatching the Opposition Leader’s binder, containing official documents, during the brawl.  BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Keheliya allowed to travel overseas
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (23) granted approval for Environment Minister Keheliya Rambukwella to go overseas temporarily, when a case filed against the latter, was heard. Ramukwella, the former Minister of Mass Media along with former Director of the Sri Lanka Rupavahini Corporation (SLRC) Liyanage Chandrapala and the former Accountant of SLRC Wimalasena Rubasinghe, have been charged before the High Court, by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC with causing a loss of Rs 900,000 to the Government, by the illegal purchase of 600 GI Pipes, for political work, via the SLRC coffers, while serving as the then subject Minister from 2 to 10 December, nine years ago and for having flouted Provisions contained in Section 70 of the Bribery Act. Judge Marasinghe accordingly lifted the foreign travel ban imposed on the former Health Minister, from 30 November this year, up to 29 February, next year. The Counsel for Rambukwella, urged the Court, to temporarily lift the overseas travel ban clamped on his client, as he was expected to attend a few international events, in his current capacity, as the Minister of Environment. The Judge, then lifted the said travel ban, imposed on the accused, as Deputy Solicitor General Asath Nawavi too, did not oppose it. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Rights Group urges to empower Magistrates
author: Author not found
Content: The Right to Life Human Rights Centre (R2LHRC) strongly condemned the tragic death of 25-year-old Alex Nagarasa, a resident of Vaddukoddai, Jaffna which occurred while in the custody of the Vaddukoddai Police.  The international non-governmental organisation advocating for human rights in Sri Lanka issued a statement yesterday (22), urging the Government to implement comprehensive reforms, including amendments to the Criminal Procedure Code and empowering Magistrates to visit Police Stations and Prisons. R2L asserted that Alex Nagarasa’s death, allegedly caused by torture during his time in the custody of the Vaddukoddai Police, raises serious concerns. The organisation emphasised the urgency of amending the Criminal Procedure Code and granting Magistrates the authority to visit law enforcement facilities. The statement highlighted the need for an impartial and thorough investigation into the incident, underlining that torture and ill-treatment by Police Officers violate international human rights law, fundamental rights, and principles of justice guaranteed by the Constitution. According to the Police Media Division, the Chief Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) at the Jaffna Teaching Hospital determined that Alex Nagarasa succumbed to kidney failure resulting from inflicted wounds.  The statement outlined that a Police team, led by the Jaffna Assistant Superintendent of Police and CID officers, will conduct further investigations. If the investigations reveal criminal action by certain officers, they will face punishment under the penal code.  Additionally, if any officers are found to have violated the code of conduct, appropriate disciplinary measures will be taken. The tragic incident has prompted heightened security measures in the Jaffna Peninsula amid rumours of potential protests. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: WHO asks China for more details on unexplained pneumonia outbreak
author: Author not found
Content: The World Health Organization (WHO) has asked Beijing for more information on an outbreak of mysterious pneumonia in Northern China that appears mostly to be affecting children. “The WHO made an official request for detailed information on an increase in respiratory illnesses and reported clusters of pneumonia in children,” the United Nations health agency said in a statement on Wednesday. China has been experiencing an increase in cases of influenza-like illnesses compared with the same period in the previous three years when strict measures were in force as part of its zero-Covid strategy. That policy was abruptly abandoned in December 2022. The WHO noted that China’s National Health Commission told a press conference, earlier this month, that there had been an increase in the incidence of respiratory diseases, attributing them to the lifting of Covid-19, measures and the spread not only of Covid-19 but pathogens such as influenza, mycoplasma pneumoniae (a common bacterial infection which typically affects younger children), and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). Earlier this week, ProMED, an online medical community, that raised questions in late 2019, about an unknown illness circulating in Wuhan, that later became Covid-19, noted a growing number of media reports of clusters of undiagnosed pneumonia among children in northern China.  (Al Jazeera)

title: MRI report on controversial medicine with Health Ministry – DGHS
author: Author not found
Content: While reluctant to divulge specific details, Dr. Asela Gunawardena, the Director General of Health Services (DGHS), acknowledged that the Medical Research Institute (MRI) had submitted a report to the Ministry regarding the controversial immunoglobulin IV sourced from ISOLEZ BIOTECH PHARMA AG, sparking controversy within the State health service. Speaking at a media briefing, held at the Ministry, Dr. Gunawardena refrained from providing further details from the report due to the ongoing Court case related to the matter.  Responding to queries from the media about former Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella’s statement suggesting the presence of saline in the contentious medicinal drug, the DGHS emphasised his inability to elaborate, citing the ongoing Court proceedings. Regarding concerns about a potential conflict of interest, given the reappointment of former National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) CEO Dr. Vijith Gunasekara as the MRI Chief, Dr. Gunawardena clarified that the report had been submitted to the Ministry before Dr. Gunasekara’s reappointment. He assured that Dr. Gunasekara’s involvement would not affect the findings, as the testing had been conducted independently in the Immunology Department of the MRI. Dr. Gunawardena highlighted that three separate investigations into the immunoglobulin IV matter were underway and being conducted by the CID, the Auditor General’s Department and the Health Ministry. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SriLankan Airlines Hosts top Indian Media journalists on a FAM Tour
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to promote Sri Lanka as a top travel destination in India, SriLankan Airlines organised a familiarisation trip for Indian journalists from leading mainstream print and electronic media. The journalists are touring the country from 19 to 24 November and will get to experience cultural attractions and traditional sites, indigenous cuisine, exotic beaches, nature trails, shopping and night life in Colombo.  Aviareps India, the official PR agency for SriLankan Airlines that holds a great responsibility in organising and coordinating the entire familiarisation tour sourced Media personnel from Key metro cities such as Cochin, Chennai, Bangalore and Delhi.  The Familiarisation tour was organised in collaboration with Cinnamon Hotels and Resorts, the hospitality and logistic partner of the Airline. Sri Lanka’s national carrier constantly endeavours to grow inbound tourism into the country through PR activities.

title: Justice for Animals organises Aluth Pola Christmas Market
author: Author not found
Content: Justice for Animals’ pop-up fundraiser, The Aluth Pola Christmas Market will take place on Sunday, 3 December, from 10:00 a.m.–6:00 p.m. at Body Bar, 3 Jawatte Avenue, Colombo 05. The Aluth Pola is organised by Justice for Animals, a registered non-profit animal welfare organisation whose core programme is population control and rabies eradication via the only humane method of spay-neuter, to reduce starving, injured, sick homeless cats and dogs and prevent future suffering. Justice for Animals has, since 2020, spay-neutered over 11,000 and vaccinated 13,000 cats and dogs providing one of the largest spay-neuter-vaccinate-treat programmes by a Sri Lankan animal welfare group. Their fundraiser Christmas Market features more than 30 small businesses, many of which practise sustainability, local manufacturing, and sourcing.  Vendors will be selling many unique and exciting products: jewellery, plants, food, baked goods, artisanal bread, handloom clothing, soaps, up-cycled clothing, pre-loved books, and much, much more. In addition, the market provides a free platform for other charities to fundraise. This December, their Charity Participant, the RCCI (Rehabilitation Centre for the Communication Impaired) will be raising funds for their school. What better place to find a gift that keeps on giving than their Christmas market? Please do drop by the Aluth Pola Christmas Market and support this fundraising initiative for the voiceless, homeless dogs and cats of Sri Lanka.

title: UN country rep assures support for agricultural development
author: Author not found
Content: The United Nations representative in Sri Lanka, Mark Andre Franche, said that the support provided by those affiliated to the United Nations organisation will continue to be provided for the agricultural development in Sri Lanka. Yesterday (23) morning, he met the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industry, Mahinda Amaraweera and discussed the future goals of the country’s agriculture sector developments. This discussion was held at the Ministry of Agriculture, Battaramulla. Commenting on this, the minister mentioned that in the last three cropping seasons, organisations like the UNFAO, IFAD provided a lot of support. Fertiliser, fuel and financial assistance were also given to the farmers to increase the agriculture contribution to economic stability especially with the economic crisis in the country. The Minister also mentioned that the assistance was a great relief to the farmers and that the government expressed its gratitude to the United Nations Organisation and its affiliated institutions for their efforts in this connection. The representative of the United Nations Organisation stated that he will take steps to further extend the support of his organisation as well as its affiliated institutions to Sri Lanka. He also stated that priority will be given to areas such as agricultural environmental development, water management, protecting agriculture from climate change, and introducing agricultural technology. A group of officials including Janaka Dharmakirthi, Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture and Plantation Industries participated in the discussion.

title: Ali Sabry says comprehensive solution needed
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry has highlighted the critical need for a comprehensive and sustained programme as the primary solution to tackle the economic crisis presently affecting the country. During a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) on Wednesday (22), Minister Sabry emphasised the complexity of the economic challenges and asserted that short-term solutions would not be sufficient. He underscored the importance of strategic planning and continuous efforts to achieve economic stability. Addressing the issue of tax evasion, Sabry stressed the necessity of bringing tax evaders into the tax net to uphold the country’s status as a welfare State. A programme slated for implementation this year aims to enhance tax compliance. The Minister provided an overview of positive economic progress, citing significant achievements such as a substantial reduction in inflation from 70% to 2.5% and a 100% increase in tourist arrivals. He stated that these indicators signify the country’s movement in the right direction economically. Acknowledging the authority of politicians to make diverse decisions, Sabry emphasised that citizens bear the resulting burdens. To overcome present challenges and attract new investments, the nation must focus on job creation, particularly by integrating the creative youth community into the job market. The 2024 Budget is designed with these goals in mind, setting the country on a path toward a new economic paradigm. The Minister highlighted substantial allocations for digitisation, modernisation of agriculture, and education in this year’s budget. He emphasised the need to avoid bureaucratic obstacles and promote collaborative efforts in executing these initiatives. Key decisions include granting rights to individuals in flats and rented houses, as well as providing land rights to farmers. Minister Sabry emphasised fiscal responsibility, noting that 70 per cent of this year’s Budget has been allocated for loan instalments and interest payments. He drew attention to Sri Lanka’s position as the 8th country with the lowest taxes globally, emphasising the importance of bringing tax evaders into the system. A dedicated programme for this purpose is set to commence this year to restore transparency. He stressed that there are no quick fixes for the economic crisis. Instead, a viable way forward involves the implementation of a comprehensive, long-term targeted programme.

title: Korea gifts fully-equipped IT Room to school
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of the Republic of Korea in Sri Lanka, orchestrated a momentous event yesterday (23) by handing over a fully-equipped IT Room to Kahatana Kanishta Vidyalaya in the Gampaha District. The rural school, Kahatana Kanishta Vidyalaya, serves as an educational haven for approximately 375 students from vulnerable families in the Gampaha District. With an investment of approximately six million rupees, the newly established IT Room is anticipated to alleviate classroom congestion and significantly enhance the IT learning facilities, providing students with an enriched and technologically advanced learning environment. Miyon Lee, the Korean Ambassador, graced the event along with Country Director of KOICA, Kim Myung Jin.  Ambassador Lee personally handed over the IT Room to the eager students of Kahatana Kanishta Vidyalaya, symbolising the enduring friendship and cooperation between the Republic of Korea and Sri Lanka. The ceremony was marked by expressions of gratitude from the school’s Principal, Amila Udayanga Balasooriya and the staff, who praised the initiative for its significant contribution to the educational development of their students. Underlining the commitment to educational development, the Government of Korea believes that this project will play a pivotal role in augmenting the learning abilities of students and fostering a more conducive educational environment at Kahatana Kanishta Vidyalaya. Education stands as a robust area of collaboration between the two nations, with the Korean Government having invested significantly in the Sri Lankan educational sector through KOICA projects. Notably, between 2021 and 2025, 47% of the total assistance from Korea has been allocated to the education sector, showcasing a steadfast commitment to the future of Sri Lankan youth.

title: Eppawela flooded due to clogged drains
author: Author not found
Content: Following the heavy torrential rains experienced in the afternoon of 22 November, several shops and boutiques, situated in the Eppawela town, were flooded. The owners of these shops and boutiques stated that one of the main reasons for their workplaces being inundated had been the blocked drains in the Eppawela town. The entire Eppawela town was flooded by the heavy rains, which lashed the area on that day, as the flood water had got blocked due to the clogged drainage system, residents said. Some paddy fields and bare lands had also been flooded. BY Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: Argentina hand rivals first-ever home WC qualifier defeat
author: Author not found
Content: Lionel Messi believes there ‘could have been a tragedy’ during the crowd trouble that delayed Argentina’s World Cup qualifier against Brazil. Police charged at away fans following scuffles before kick-off in a section of the Maracana Stadium that Messi says contained players’ friends and family. Argentina captain Messi and his players went over to try and calm the situation before returning to the dressing room. “It was bad because we saw how they were beating people,” said Messi, 36. “The Police, as happened in the Libertadores final, were once again repressing the people with night sticks. “We went to the locker room because it was the best way to calm everything down, it could have ended in tragedy. “You think about the families, the people who are there, who don’t know what’s going on and we were more concerned about that than playing a match that, at that point, was of secondary importance.” The trouble began when rival fans clashed in a stand behind one of the goals at the stadium in Rio de Janeiro during the national anthems, prompting Police to charge at Argentina’s supporters, some using batons. Some supporters ripped out seats and threw them at Police in response, while others spilled out onto the pitch to escape the trouble. The Argentina players and some members of the Brazil team walked over to try to calm the situation, with Aston Villa’s Emiliano Martinez trying to grab a baton out of a Police officer’s hand. The players eventually left the field before returning after Police had gathered the Argentina fans into a separate section of the stand and the game was able to begin after 30-minute delay. The trouble unfolded a fortnight after scuffles between fans of Brazilian side Fluminense and Argentine club Boca Juniors before the Copa Libertadores final – the South American equivalent of the Champions League final – which was also staged at the Maracana. Brazil captain Marquinhos, who joined the Argentina players on the pitch calling for calm in the stands, added: “We were worried about the families, women and children that we were seeing in panic up there in the stands. “Down on the pitch it was hard for us to understand what was going on, it was a very scary situation.” World champions Argentina won 1-0 thanks to a goal from former Manchester City defender Nicolas Otamendi. Newcastle United midfielder Joelinton was sent off for Brazil, who lost a home World Cup qualifier for the first time. The five-time World Cup winners have now lost three successive qualifiers to sit sixth in the South American qualifying table, eight points behind leaders Argentina and in the last spot that guarantees a place at the 2026 finals.

title: Hospital attendant jailed for 20 years
author: Author not found
Content: Embilipitiya Provincial High Court Judge Buddhika Sri Ragala, on 21 November, sentenced an attendant, who was convicted of attempted murder, to 20 years imprisonment. The attendant was charged with introducing pesticides and other poisonous substances into water tank at the official quarters of the Chief Medical Officer, Chaminda Vithana, attached to the Sewanagala Regional Hospital, with the intention of causing the death of the doctor and his family. The Judge also ordered the 20-year prison term to be served in a 10-year stretch and slapped a fine of Rs 20,000 on the convict, who was identified as N. Nimal Ranjith, an attendant attached at the hospital. The accused had been arrested by the Sewanagala Police following a complaint by the doctor concerned on 3 February, 11 years ago. The suspect was then produced in the Embilipitiya Chief Magistrate’s Court and the Attorney General had released a doctor, who had been arrested on suspicion in this connection. Having perused the reports filed by Government Analyst K.A.P.B. Perera and Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) Prof. Ravindra Fernando the Judge deemed that the charges filed against the accused had been proved beyond a reasonable doubt and hence passed sentence on him. BY S. Kuttapitiya – Sewanagala

title: Rehan resigns as SJB Youth VC
author: Author not found
Content: Vice Chairman of Samagi Jana Balawegaya Youth Wing Rehan Jayawickrama resigned from his role on Wednesday (22).  In a letter addressed to Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, the former Vice Chairman of SJB Youth stated that the main reason for his resignation was to focus on the upcoming General Election in the Matara District. He said the competitive and challenging nature of winning a seat in the Matara District was of prime concern and that was the main reason for his resignation. Jayawickrama further explained that relinquishing positions aligns with his belief in leading by example. He said his support for the Leader of the Opposition remains unwavering despite the many obstacles he had to face. He expressed a strong belief that the Leader of the Opposition would be the next leader of Sri Lanka. The letter was later made public by Rehan Jayawickrama on his X platform, where he expressed the desire to secure a Parliamentary Seat from the Matara District in the Election.  Further, the former Vice Chairman told the media that he would continue to carry out his duties as a member of the SJB Working Committee, the Chief Organiser for the Weligama electorate and the Chairman of the SJB Committee on LGBTQ reforms. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: ‘STD/AIDS prevention goals hindered’
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s failure to decriminalise same-sex relations by repealing Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code, has become an obstacle to achieving objectives of the National STD/AIDS Control Programme (NSTD/AIDSCP), Ceylon Today learns. Director of the NSTD/AIDSCP, Dr. Janaki Vidanapathirana said they were hopeful that the Ministry of Justice would take measures to amend Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code as the Supreme Court has already determined that repealing them doesn’t violate the Constitution.  Fielding questions, she said yesterday (22) that it would largely help the programme to achieve further success should the stigma and discrimination be removed even if it was from the Constitution to help vulnerable groups.  She noted that the Supreme Court had determined the constitutionality of a Private Member’s Bill titled, ‘Penal Code (Amendment) Bill 2023,’ whose stated objective had been to repeal “provisions that made sexual orientation a punishable offence.” It would be a considerable leap should the Minister of Justice move to amend or repeal these two sections, namely Sections 365 and 365A which criminalise same-sex relations at least after the Budget was passed in Parliament.  She lamented that Sri Lanka’s NSTD/AIDSCP was somewhat lagging behind targets set by UNAIDS and Global Development Goals as possible vulnerable groups of persons were reluctant to obtain their services owing to fear of discrimination and stigma. “HIV testing is the first key to achieve the colossal goal of ending AIDS by 2030 and UNAIDS recommended 95-95-95 targets by 2025 for any country that commits to this goal,” Dr. Vidanapathirana said.  Accordingly, 95 per cent of people living with HIV should know their HIV status. But to achieve that the way should be open for people to test themselves without fearing that they were being looked down on, she pointed out.  Meanwhile, the lack of Age-Appropriate Sexuality Education was highly important in preventing the increasing number of teenage and youth infections of HIV. Dr. Vidanapathirana said since 2018 there has been a gradual increase in the number of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infections among young people between the ages of 15 to 24. Of the 607 new cases diagnosed with the HIV infection 73 (12 per cent) were aged 15 to 24. She lamented that 66 of them had been males. While some teachers were known to provide this knowledge and create satisfactory awareness amongst their students, others merely brushed through the lessons on sex education. “What we presently do is try to get hold of a few adults and attempt to bridge this gap in their knowledge about sex education,” she lamented. She pointed out that HIV testing was the first key to achieving an end to AIDS by 2030. And UNAIDS had recommended achieving the 95-95-95 targets by 2025 for any country committed to the goal. Accordingly, she noted that this meant that 95 per cent of people living with HIV should know their HIV status and 95 per cent of the people who know they are HIV positive should be on life-long antiretroviral therapy (ART) and 95 per cent of people on ART should be virally supported. President, Sri Lanka College of Sexual Health, Dr. Thilani Ratnayake noted that the National Programme had taken precautions to make HIV tests available to a wider population using many different innovative and user-friendly methods such as the self-testing kit. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President assures Presidential, Parliamentary Polls in 2024
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, yesterday (22), affirmed that both the Presidential Election and the Parliamentary Election would take place next year and that there would be no postponements.  He made this announcement while delivering a special statement in Parliament, addressing various matters, including the ongoing Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) crisis. “We have established democracy in this country. So, now how can you say that we are afraid of an election? We will hold the elections. The Presidential Election and the Parliamentary Election will both be held next year. None of them will be postponed,” President Wickremesinghe said. “The year after that, we can hold the Provincial Council and Local Government elections—all that. There is no problem,” he added.  Meanwhile, speaking at a media briefing on Tuesday (21), State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said Rs 10 billion has been allocated for future elections.   By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: G.C.E. A/L Exam 2023 to beheld as scheduled
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education, yesterday (22), informed the Supreme Court that the G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination 2023 will not be postponed, dispelling any uncertainties surrounding its schedule. Accordingly, the exam will be held from 4 – 31 January 2024.  The Supreme Court, addressing Fundamental Rights (FR) petitions that called for the postponement of the 2024 Advanced Level Examination, dismissed one petition yesterday (22). Simultaneously, the petitioners withdrew the other petition. The petitions were filed by a group of students seeking postponement of the A/L Examination 2023.  The petitioners argued that the standard criteria for examination preparation allows for 495 days to complete their syllabi. However, they argued that various challenges, including last year’s electricity crisis and frequent power cuts, limited their effective study period to only 300 days. They also asserted that this shortfall in study time has hindered their ability to cover the syllabi comprehensively for all subjects.   By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sanath Nishantha suspended from Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister Sanath Nishantha has been suspended from attending Parliamentary Sittings for two weeks owing to his disorderly conduct within the Chamber on Tuesday (21), Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana announced yesterday (22). The Speaker conveyed this decision to MPs following the commencement of the Third Reading or the Committee Stage debate on the Appropriation Bill 2024 yesterday (22) morning.  Expressing strong disapproval for the tense situation that arose during Tuesday’s sittings, Speaker Abeywardana highlighted the disruptive behaviour that occurred. Pandemonium reigned in the Parliament Chamber on Tuesday (21), when Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa raised questions about the recent Supreme Court verdict which found the former President, Prime Minister and certain Cabinet members responsible for the economic crisis that began last year. A brawl erupted between the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MPs and ruling party MPs including Sanath Nishantha, while Premadasa was raising a series of questions, under Standing Order 27/2, regarding the recent Supreme Court verdict on the economic crisis. This forced Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana to suspend the sittings for five minutes. However, 30 minutes were taken to resume the sittings.  The chaos worsened when the Opposition Leader as well as Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella alleged that State Minister Sanath Nishantha ran away after forcibly grabbing a file from the Opposition Leader’s desk, which contained several important documents.  The Speaker, later in the day said he received Premadasa’s missing file and the latter can collect it. However, Premadasa alleged that several important documents had gone missing from the file and he would not take it back.  By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Mission Heads visit Hambantota Port
author: Author not found
Content: Seven Sri Lankan Heads of Mission/Ambassador Designates to Foreign Embassies and High Commissions, were given a detailed orientation by Hambantota International Port (HIP) on port operations and activities. Tissa Wickramasinghe, COO of the Hambantota International Port Group (HIPG) briefed the group of diplomats on these aspects, covering the port’s progress over the last five years. The designates are assigned to embassies and high commissions in the Republic of Italy, the Arab Republic of Egypt, the Republic of Singapore, the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, the Kingdom of Belgium and the European Union, the Republic of Cuba and the Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal. Wickramasinghe said, “From our perspective, this interaction was very welcome as this gave us the platform to showcase the progress HIP has made in terms of milestones achieved and what we are planning for the future to benefit our region as well as the country’s economy, so that the port will be portrayed in the right light to an international audience. This will also help to dispel any disinformation that may be spread about the port internationally. The session was proactive, with the active participation of the delegates from the foreign affairs office. The participants asked interesting questions which were answered by the relevant port officials present at the session,” the COO said.  The participants were given a briefing on HIP’s service scope covering Port Services, Integrated Logistics, Marine Services, Port-related Industries Development, Bunkering, and the role of HIP Services. A brief overview was also given on integrated logistics, industrial park and port-based industries, marine services, energy hub, the port’s key business as well as achieved standards, awards and accolades won by the port. The corporate social responsibility projects completed and undertaken over the five-year period were also covered.  They included the Hope Village Development project, fully-fledged PCR Testing Laboratory, Tissapura Junior School Development project, fact-finding project on the Human-Elephant Conflict, Human-Elephant Peace Fund, Electric Fence project under the Human-Elephant Peace Fund, Beach clean-up programmes and installing Garbage Collection Bins. The port has invested over USD 1.1 million in these projects. (SRM)

title: Heroin worth Rs 270M seized at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: In a joint operation, the Sri Lanka Customs Narcotics Prevention Unit and the Katunayake Air Cargo Terminal Customs Office seized 10.5 kg of heroin worth Rs 270 million concealed in a stock of imported towels. Senior Customs Director and Customs Media Spokesman Sivali Arukgoda said this drug consignment, consisting of eight parcels, originated from Lahore, Pakistan and arrived on board an Oman Air flight on 10 November. The heroin consignment, cleverly concealed in between towels, was destined for an import company located in Nittambuwa, Thihariya. A thorough inspection was conducted in the importer’s presence, leading to the uncovering of the hidden heroin weighing 10.5 kg. Arukgoda further said the importer, along with two clearance agents attempting to release the cargo from Customs, was promptly arrested by Customs Officers on suspicion of their involvement in the incident. Subsequently, the drug stock and the three suspects were handed over to the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) for further investigation. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Subversive move by Expressway employees to cause loss to Govt – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena said in Parliament yesterday (22) the strike launched by Expressway employees was a deliberate attempt to cause a loss to the Government. “This is not a trade union action but a subversive move,” he said. Issuing tickets at toll booths on Expressways islandwide was managed by the tri-forces yesterday (22) as all ranks of employees from the Road Development Authority (RDA) including expressway employees reported sick.  Director General of the Road Development Authority, L.V.S. Weerakoon, speaking to Ceylon Today, explained that the tri-forces were called in to ensure the safety of the expressway and other roads, as well as to minimise loss incurred by operating vehicles without collecting fees.  Weerakoon said employees working on the expressways had planned to leave their posts while keeping the toll gates open. If such a situation had taken place , it could have led to a significant number of accidents on expressways, he said.  As a result, he stated that the Government sought the support of the tri-forces to manage the security of expressways, in the hope that the employees would return to work by today (23).  He also said that on Tuesday (21), the Army was given an opportunity to gain a better understanding of the management activities of the expressway network due to the sudden strike of employees.  Weerakoon said that manual ticket issuance will be implemented, and after the return of thos working in the highway network, the military will hand over duties and the money to the RDA.  Brigadier Ravi Herath, Army spokesman said military officials who were deployed on expressways provided support for the administrative work on the request to carry out  duties on the highway.  He said administrative work of the Southern Expressway is handled by the Army, the administrative work of the Central Expressway is managed by the Navy, and the administrative work of the Katunayake Expressway is overseen by the Air Force.  Brigadier Herath added that 30 officers and 250 other ranks have been assigned for duties on the Southern Expressway.  He said that when the tri-forces took over yesterday, the ticket machines were disabled on the Expressways, allowing people to travel without charge for the first two hours.  Meanwhile, Yohan Gunasinghe, President of the All-Ceylon Expressway Employees’ Union, explained that due to several issues, including plans to privatise the expressway network, employees from all ranks of the RDA reported sick.  He said employees have withdrawn from duties at toll booths on all expressways and maintenance on Expressways.  Gunasinghe said the strike is based on three key issues which are attempts by the Finance Ministry and RDA to privatise the Expressway network, delayed payments for unused sick leave for 2022 and delayed approval for the System for Optimised Recruitment (SOR) which deferred the grade-to-grade promotions of all employees.  He added that a letter detailing these issues, with the signatures of representatives from 26 trade unions of all grades was sent to the RDA Director General.  A discussion was also held at the Ministry of Transport Highways on Tuesday (21) regarding these matters but was unsuccessful.  BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Legal solution needed to resolve SLC administration issue – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has called for the resolution of the Sri Lankan cricket crisis through the implementation of relevant laws to ensure the selection of the most qualified individuals for the administration of the sport. In a special statement delivered in Parliament yesterday (21) morning, the President addressed allegations of ‘protecting’ Shammi Silva, the President of Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC), and other higher-ups in the cricket governing body. Wickremesinghe dismissed these claims and described the cricket turmoil in the country as a long-standing issue, attributing the decline of the sport to a power struggle between two groups. Acknowledging the need for a legal solution to the cricket administration issue, President Wickremesinghe revealed that he advised the Sports Minister against engaging in a legal battle, as it could result in a ban from the International Cricket Council (ICC) and negatively impact the country’s tourism sector. Expressing concern over certain individuals criticising Court judgments related to the cricket matter, the President denounced MPs for targeting judges within the parliamentary setting, emphasising the importance of letting the judiciary perform its duties independently. President Wickremesinghe also highlighted the necessity for MPs to adhere to the Standing Orders of Parliament. In response to the ICC’s concerns about government involvement in Sri Lankan cricket, the President acknowledged that accusations of political interference cannot be dismissed, particularly after MPs collectively presented a resolution against the SLC. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Principal forces students to chew lunch sheet and newspaper
author: Author not found
Content: Two students of Rambukpitiya MV, Nawalapitiya were admitted to the Nawalapitiya District Hospital on 21 November as the principal had compelled them to chew the polythene sheet and newspaper that their lunches had been brought in. This school falls under the purview of the Nawalapitiya Zonal Education Office. The two Grade 11 students had brought their lunch wrapped in polythene and newspaper. Though 33 students are in the class, only seven students had brought their lunch in this manner. When the students had attempted to put the polythene and the newspaper sheets back into their bags, the principal who had arrived unannounced into the class had forced these seven students to chew the polythene and newspaper and swallow it. Of the seven, two students who had eaten the polythene and newspaper had begun to throw up, and developed stomach pains and were admitted to hospital by their parents on 21 November. Following a complaint lodged by a father of one of the admitted students, Nawalapitiya Police had commenced a probe into the incident. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Chinese Government delegation meets Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting between a delegation led by the State Councillor of China, Shen Yiqin, and Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena took place at Parliament on Monday (20).  Cabinet Ministers, State Ministers, Members of Parliament, Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Chaminda Kularatne and Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Qi Zhenhong were present. The Speaker expressed gratitude for China’s support in Sri Lanka’s economic development and various forms of cooperation. He highlighted the successful implementation of development activities, including the Colombo Port City, through collaboration with China. The Speaker expressed a desire to further strengthen bilateral relations. Shen Yiqin expressed the Chinese Government’s eagerness to provide necessary financial support for emergency humanitarian assistance, including providing uniforms for Sri Lankan school children. She emphasised the growth of mutual trust and practical cooperation through the development of political, economic, cultural, and people-to-people relations. Yiqin expressed hope for the swift conclusion of the Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement and reiterated the commitment to strengthening the close relationship between the two countries. MP Thalatha Atukorale briefed the delegation on the initiatives undertaken by the Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus for the advancement of women in Sri Lanka. She requested China’s support for the caucus’s future activities.

title: Death sentence for killing 52-year-old woman
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Mahesh Weeraman, yesterday (22) handed the death sentence to an accused, who was convicted of two charges of unlawful entry and manslaughter committed five years ago.  The convict had been charged with breaking into the house of 52-year-old woman at night, who had been living alone, and stabbing her to death. The Judge convicted the accused of the first charge and sentenced him to death. He then convicted the accused of the second charge, that of unlawful entry and sentenced him to 20 years in jail and fined him Rs 10,000. The convict was identified as Buddhika Kumara, alias Ajith Pushpakumara, a 41-year-old father of one, employed as an assistant lorry worker. Judge Weeraman, announcing the verdict stated that he was imposing the said penalties on the convict, as the Prosecution had proved its charges against him, beyond a shadow of a doubt. During testimony in the trial, it had come to light, that when the convict had been travelling with his lorry driver, to bring down a stock of cement, from a store in Peliyagoda on 23 January, five years ago, the said crime had been committed and that afterwards the suspect, had been rounded up by the residents of the area and handed over to the Peliyagoda Police. The Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) in his testimony had mentioned to Court that the victim, who had been admitted to the National Hospital Colombo, with injuries to her throat, had succumbed to her injuries, seven days after the incident. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: House destroyed in Haldummulla earth slip
author: Author not found
Content: Haldummulla Divisional Secretary K.A.J. Priyangani said due to an earth slip, a house situated at Kosgama in Haldummulla had been destroyed on Wednesday (21).  She said as they had witnessed warning signs of the earth slip, they had been able to move the eight occupants to safety. She added that after her officers had witnessed signs of an impending earth slip close to the house at Kosgama, Grama Sevaka Janaka Chathuranga was alerted and he managed to save the eight occupants before tragedy struck barely 15 minutes later. By Saman Nanayakkara – Haldummulla
