title: CSI College Annual Prize Giving 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Annual Prize Giving of Colombo South International (CSI) College was held at the College Auditorium on 11 November, with the participation of Managing Director Mangala Wijekularathna and Founder Directress Grashanthi Wijekularathna. The directress of the AMI Montessori is Marie Silva. The chief guest was Dominic Hudson, Director Examinations – British Council Sri Lanka and the Maldives. The special guest was Wijerathna Warakagoda. The Principal of the College is B.A. Abeyrathna.

title: Deepavali celebrations at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs celebrated Deepavali with the participation of the Diplomatic Corps and members of the staff of the Ministry.  Foreign Minister Ali Sabry speaking on the occasion stated that this event demonstrates how different communities of our country live side by side in unity and share the joy of each other’s festivals.  He highlighted the equal rights guaranteed to all communities by the Constitution. Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane in her welcome remarks highlighted the diversity and talent of the staff members of the Ministry as well as their teamwork in jointly organising the Deepavali celebrations. The High Commissioner of India Gopal Bagley and the Ambassador of Nepal Bashu Dev Mishra spoke on the significance of Deepavali. The Deepavali celebrations included religious observances conducted by Swami Gunatitananda Saraswati followed by traditional dances, invoking blessings performed by members of the staff of the Ministry and the Indian Cultural Centre in Colombo. The vote of thanks was delivered by President of the Welfare Society Manisha Perera of the Ministry, who was responsible for organising the event. The Deepavali celebrations were preceded by a ‘Kolam Competition’ organised with the participation of the staff representing all communities.  Prizes were awarded to the winners of the competition. The event was followed by a reception with traditional food served for Deepavali.

title: Service extensions solely in the hands of appointing officers
author: Author not found
Content: A senior State official who allegedly declined to extend the service years of medical practitioners in the State Health Service and another eight high-level State officials such as Ministry Secretaries are scheduled to retire by 31 December 2023, according to informed sources. Sources revealed that among those slated to retire were top-level officials from the Ministries of Education, Transport, Wildlife, and Irrigation. The Secretary to the Ministry of Health retired on 18 November 2023 and Ceylon Today learns that attempts to reinstate him in the State service after retirement faced opposition from health service trade unions proving the effort futile. Meanwhile, it is also reported that an official serving in the Ministry of Public Administration, was refused a service extension beyond sixty, he was given a new appointment to work in a different ministry and a fresh appeal was made for an extension to his successor. The second appeal led to a  positive outcome. However, he was later removed from that ministry after a letter was sent to all District Secretaries instructing them not to accept nominations for the Local Government Elections. Medical professionals had to resort to legal measures to secure a service extension from 60 to 63 years, according to sources. Sources highlighted that, according to the Constitution, public employees must retire by the age of 60. When it comes to top-level officials such as Ministry secretaries, etc., it depends on the ‘Appointing Officer,’ who, in this case, is the President, on whose discretion it depends, they added. Including a senior official who allegedly refused to extend the service years of medical practitioners in the State health service, another eight high-level state officials are slated to retire from service by December 31, 2023, according to informed sources. Sources indicated yesterday (21) that among those scheduled to retire are top-level officials from the Ministries of Education, Transport, Wildlife, and Irrigation. The Secretary to the Ministry of Health retired on 18 November 2023, and informed sources noted that although there had been an effort to reinstate him in the State service after retirement, opposition from health service trade unions had thwarted the attempt. Meanwhile, it is also reported that a particular official had been serving at the Ministry of Public Administration and had allegedly refused to extend the service term of medical practitioners beyond the age of 60 years. However, when he received an appointment to another ministry from the Ministry of Public Administration, the appeal had reportedly been made once more to his successor with more favourable results. However, he too had later been removed from that Ministry after sending a letter to all District Secretaries instructing them not to accept nominations for the Local Government Elections. Medical professionals later had to resort to legal measures to secure an extension in the service term from 60 to 63 years, according to sources. Sources mentioned that, according to the constitution, state service employees must retire by the age of 60 years. When it comes to top-level officials such as Ministry secretaries, etc., it depends on the ‘Appointing Officer,’ who in this case is the President, on whose discretion it all depends, they added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: House on Fire Over Sajith’s Statement
author: Author not found
Content: Pandemonium reigned in the Parliament Chamber yesterday (21), when Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa raised questions about the recent Supreme Court verdict which found the former President, Prime Minister and certain cabinet members responsible for the economic crisis that began last year. A brawl erupted between the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MPs and ruling party MPs, while Premadasa was raising a series of questions, under the Standing Order 27/2, regarding the recent Supreme Court verdict on the economic crisis. This forced Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena to suspend the sittings for five minutes. The chaos went deeper, when the Opposition Leader as well as Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella alleged that State Minister Sanath Nishantha ran away after forcibly grabbing a file from the Opposition Leader’s desk, which contained several important documents.  During his speech, Premadasa highlighted that individuals such as former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, former Finance Minister Basil Rajapaksa, former Central Bank Governors Ajith Nivard Cabraal and Prof. W.D. Lakshman, former Finance Secretary S.R. Attygalle, former Presidential Secretary P.B. Jayasundera and members of the Central Bank’s Monetary Board continued to enjoy their privileges despite the Supreme Court’s judgment of 14 November holding them accountable for the economic crisis. Premadasa emphasised that these individuals showed no respect for the Supreme Court judgment, and ordinary citizens are still bearing the consequences of their incorrect decisions. The Opposition Leader asserted that leniency cannot be extended to these individuals, considering the heightened public anticipation for decisive action against them. As Premadasa posed questions about the Government’s stance, the legal measures it intends to implement and whether it will recover the State’s losses due to those implicated, a group of infuriated ruling party MPs interrupted the address and later approached the Opposition Leader’s seat. When the ruling party MPs, including Sanath Nishantha, Prasanna Ranaweera, Mahindananda Aluthgamage and Janaka Thissakuttiarachchi approached the Opposition Leader, Sergeant-at-Arms Narendra Fernando and several Parliament staff members hurried into the scene and tried to defuse the situation. SJB MP Nalin Bandara started to go on Facebook live at this juncture and the Speaker repeatedly warned him to stop the recording. Sanath Nishantha who grabbed the Opposition Leader’s microphone shouted, “You have to reveal the thefts conducted by your sister too” (Nangige horakamuth kiyanna). Thissakuttiarachchi shouted, “Why are you doing this to our Mahinda Rajapaksa?” After a few minutes, the Speaker suspended the sittings for five minutes. After the sittings resumed, Premadasa finished reading the statement. The Opposition then alleged that Sanath Nishantha stole a set of files belonging to the Opposition leader during the brawl. They alleged that Sanath Nishantha took the Opposition Leader’s microphone and seized the file from which Premadasa was reading his questions. The Opposition Leader brought attention to this incident, in the presence of the Speaker, asking what action and steps would be taken against MP Sanath Nishantha over his behaviour.  The Opposition Leader argued that this incident infringed upon the rights and privileges granted to him. He urged the Speaker to treat all MPs equally, emphasising that in the past, the Speaker has taken disciplinary actions against such behaviour. Furthermore, Premadasa criticised the Speaker for not taking the incident more seriously. He emphasised his commitment to hold those responsible for the country’s economic downturn accountable, unlike others who celebrated the birthdays of those allegedly involved. In response to the Speaker’s announcement of an investigation into the incident, Premadasa asserted that a mere investigation is insufficient. He demanded the immediate return of the files, along with all the documents he alleges were stolen by MP Sanath Nishantha. Lakshman Kiriella also demanded disciplinary action against ruling party MPs who disturbed Premadasa’s statement. Meanwhile, the Speaker announced that video recording of sessions and going live on social media will be prohibited. “MPs who video record sessions and go live on social media will be severely dealt with,” he said. Furthermore, the Speaker said he received Premadasa’s missing file and the latter can take it. However, Premadasa alleged that several important documents had gone missing from the file. “Sergeant-at-Arms gave that file to me. But when I checked I found several important documents have gone missing. I refused to take the file after that and I won’t take it without those documents,” he stressed. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Primary school teachers banned from giving tuition
author: Author not found
Content: Uva Province Education Secretary Gamini Mahindapala has issued a circular prohibiting primary school teachers from conducting tuition classes after school hours, for students who are enrolled in their respective classes in schools. This decision comes in response to numerous complaints from parents and guardians, expressing concern that some primary teachers in schools discriminate against children who do not attend their tuition classes. The circular comes into effect from today (22). He said that a circular had already been issued to principals of schools in the Uva Province and to Educational Zonal Directors. Mahindapala warned that disciplinary action will be instituted against teachers who continue to act in violation of the circular. BY Prasanna Pathmasiri – Lunugala

title: Broadcasting Regulatory Commission Bill for electronic media approved
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the formulation of a Bill for the establishment of a Broadcasting Regulatory Commission for electronic media. The Minister of Mass Media proposed a resolution to create a regulatory body for electronic , to ensure ethical media practices and safeguard the freedom of expression.  This resolution was discussed at the Cabinet meeting held on 22 September 2022. A Cabinet sub-committee led by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms was appointed to recommend policy matters to be considered when drafting the Bill. The sub-committee has formulated a draft, incorporating provisions for consideration for the proposed Broadcasting Regulatory Commission. Cabinet endorsed the resolution put forward by the Minister of Mass Media, directing the Legal Draftsman to create a draft based on the draft provided by the sub-committee.  (MJ)

title: Sugar imported at 25 cent tax to be sold at controlled price
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet has decided to acquire sugar stocks imported at a 25-cent tax and sell them at the controlled price of Rs 275 within a month, Trade, Commerce and Food Security Minister Nalin Fernando said.  The Minister said this quantity of sugar will be distributed through Lanka Sathosa, supermarkets, and selected cooperatives to eliminate the sugar shortage and ensure an adequate supply for consumers. He said the sugar stock will be acquired from importers and wholesalers starting today and the Consumer Affairs Authority is currently assessing the quantity of sugar stocks imported at the 25-cent tax.  Fernando clarified that the controlled price was not applicable to this programme and sugar imported at the Rs 50 tax could be sold at the new price. Meanwhile, Cabinet approved the import of 100,000 MT of rice, to address the shortage of Keeri Samba in the country.  The Minister said a substitute rice for Keeri Samba and Samba will be imported and if there is a further need, during the festive season in December, more rice will be imported. He said the controlled price of a kilo of Keeri Samba rice was Rs 260 but was being sold between Rs 300 and Rs 310. Fernando expressed concern that three major rice businesses were attempting to increase the price of rice. He added that the Consumer Affairs Authority was investigating these rice businesses and a report will be released in the coming days. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: MCPA accuses Health Ministry of discrimination
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) accused the Health Ministry of discrimination even when conducting probes, against trade union leaders, for speaking to the media.  MCPA President Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (21) urged the new Health Secretary, Dr. Palitha Mahipala to probe his Ministry’s intimidation of trade unions. He alleged that the Ministry was notorious for singling out trade union leaders that they wished to investigate.  In fact, the Health Ministry itself has officially accepted it had initiated investigations against himself, Dr. Rukshan Bellana and Medical Laboratory Scientist Ravi Kumudesh for allegedly speaking to the media.  He alleged that investigations had seemed to evade members of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) and President of the Government Nursing Officers’ Association (GNOA), who now holds a top post in Presidential Secretariat, who voiced their opinion to the media- especially during the time of the pandemic.  Dr. Sanjeeva said that Senior Assistant Secretary of the Health Ministry, Sudath Ranaweera in a letter (No. MH/FS/AD/B/IN/ACT/2020) on 14 November 2023 had informed him that probes had not been conducte against several trade unionists serving under the Health Ministry for voicing their opinions to the media during the past number of months.  The MCPA President said that he had requested the information from January 2020 to November 2023, under the Right to Information Act, on the investigations initiated by the Health Ministry against health trade unionists for talking to the print and electronic media.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Narcotics valued at over Rs 66M seized
author: Author not found
Content: Customs spokesman Sivali Arukgoda yesterday (21) said officials from the Revenue Supervision Division of Sri Lanka Customs seized a consignment of narcotics valued at over Rs 66 million brought from America to Sri Lanka. This stock was found in a parcel processed through a courier service. Customs officers subsequently arrested another individual, including an Assistant Superintendent of Customs, suspected to be involved in the drug racket.  The narcotics include 511 grams of cocaine and 5.161 kg of marijuana having a value of Rs 66,940,000. Arukgoda said the consignment was shipped from America to a woman in Gampaha. The items were discretely packaged in tins resembling food containers. Further, Arukgoda said a 46-year-old resident of  Wellampitiya, who arrived to collect the goods for the woman from Gampaha, was apprehended by Customs officials.  Based on information given by the suspect, an Assistant Customs Superintendent associated with a well-known shipping agency, was also taken into custody for further investigation. The narcotics and the suspects have been handed over to the Police Narcotic Bureau (PNB) for investigation. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Budget 2024 Second Reading passed
author: Author not found
Content: The Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill for the Fiscal Year 2024 was passed in Parliament with a majority of 45 votes yesterday (21).  Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena announced the results of the division at the conclusion of the debate on the Second Reading, noting that a total of 122 MPs voted in favor of the budget, to 77 against it. On 13 November, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, presented the 2024 Budget, the country’s 78th Budget, in Parliament. Subsequently, the debate on the second reading of the Appropriation Bill spanned seven days, starting on the day after the budget presentation. The committee stage or the third reading of the Appropriation Bill’s debate is scheduled to begin today (22) and will run for 19 days, concluding on 13 December excluding Sundays. As per the schedule, the vote on the Third Reading of the Appropriation Bill 2024 is set to take place at 6.00 p.m. on 13 December. The Appropriation Bill of 2024 outlines a total expenditure of a record Rs 6,978 billion, reflecting a nearly 33% increase compared to 2023. The budget deficit for the fiscal year 2024 is estimated at Rs. 2,851 billion or 9.1% of the GDP, surpassing the revised 8.5% of GDP in the current year. The initial target for 2023 was 7.9%. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: US-based RM Parks inks USD 110M fuel agreement with SL
author: Author not found
Content: Shell Petroleum and California-based US fuel distribution company RM Parks Inc. yesterday (21) inked a deal with the Board of Investment for a USD 110 million investment in Sri Lanka’s petroleum sector. The Cabinet, in March 2023, announced that the government had decided to grant licences to foreign oil companies to sell oil in the domestic retail market. The three companies were China’s Sinopec, United Petroleum of Australia, and RM Parks of the United States, in a collaboration with Shell and said they will will soon start operating in the country. Already, Sinopec is in operation in Sri Lanka.  Shell PLC is an energy and petrochemical company in Europe, Asia, Oceania, Africa, the United States, and the rest of the Americas.  The company operates through the integrated gas, marketing, chemicals and products, renewables and energy solutions segments. It explores for and extracts crude oil, natural gas and natural gas liquids, markets and transports oil and gas, produces gas-to-liquids fuels and other products and operates upstream and midstream infrastructure necessary to deliver gas to market. The company also markets and trades natural gas, liquefied natural gas (LNG), crude oil, electricity, and carbon-emission rights and markets and sells LNG as a fuel for heavy-duty vehicles and marine vessels.  In addition, it trades in and refines crude oil and other feed stocks, such as low-carbon fuels, lubricants, bitumen, sulphur, gasoline, diesel, heating oil, aviation fuel and marine fuel and produces and sells petrochemicals for industrial use. Additionally, it generates electricity through wind and solar resources, produces and sells hydrogen,; and provides electric vehicle charging services, as well as electricity storage. The company was formerly known as Royal Dutch Shell plc and changed its name to Shell plc in January 2022. Shell plc was founded in 1907 and is headquartered in London, the United Kingdom. RM Parks Inc. is a leading fuel distributer in California and has more than 50 years in the petrochemicals distribution industry.   The company engages in the business of the development of infrastructure relating to petroleum by, setting up, conducting, and operating one hundred and fifty (150) franchise fuel stations, which are owned by  Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, and fifty (50) new fuel stations as per the Long-Term Contract entered into with the Ministry of Power and Energy and further to import, store, distribute and sell petroleum products including petrol, diesel, jet A-1, kerosene and furnace oil and related value-added products and to expand its business to distribution of other petroleum or gas products, by-products (including aviation fuel), EV charging and provision of value-added services such as car wash, car servicing, department stores/ convenience stores, internet café, ATM and food courts in the local market. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Navy nab nine illegally harvesting sea cucumber
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy apprehended nine persons illegally harvesting sea cucumber in Arippu, Mannar, during a special operation conducted in the early hours of Monday (20). The operation also led to the seizing of about 1,384 illegally harvested sea cucumbers, diving gear and three dinghies. The Special Boat Squadron (SBS) personnel, attached to the Naval Detachment Thalvupadu of SLNS Gajaba, in the North Central Naval Command, madewere involved in the search operation in the Arippu sea area. During the operation, SBS personnel intercepted a suspicious dinghy and nabbed nine individuals for their involvement in harvesting of sea cucumber, without valid licence.  The individuals apprehended during this operation were identified as residents of Mannar, from 25 to 47 years of age. The suspects along with their equipment and sea cucumber were handed over to the Assistant Directorate of Fisheries, Mannar for onward legal action.

title: Cabinet nod for acceptable levels of Aflatoxin in Thriposha
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet endorsed a decision to adjust the acceptable levels of Aflatoxin in local food supplement programmes to align with internationally recognised standards for food supplements. The proposal, presented by the Minister of Health, received approval during the Cabinet meeting held on Monday (20). The revision of permissible Aflatoxin levels was specifically discussed concerning the Thriposha programme, a component of the Maternal and Child Health Programme implemented by the Ministry. Thriposha is distributed under this programme to children aged between six months and three years with low nutrition levels, and it serves as an additional nutrient for pregnant women and lactating mothers. The Ministry of Health highlighted challenges in procuring maize for Thriposha production due to the stringent permissible limits for Aflatoxin outlined in the existing regulations under the Food Act No. 26 of 1980. To address this issue, a proposal was put forth to align the limitations on Aflatoxin levels in local food supplement programmes with internationally accredited food supplements (5ppb for type B1 and 10 ppb for total Aflatoxin). The aim is to facilitate the procurement of essential ingredients for Thriposha production, the Cabinet Office said.  (MJ)

title: Rape convict gets 45 years in jail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige yesterday (21) sentenced to 45 years Rigorous Imprisonment an accused who had been charged with raping a 17-year-old girl, who had gone to work as a domestic aid at a house in Rajagiriya. The court was told the victim decided to work as a domestic aid after having abruptly stopped her schooling, due to her father being ill and the death of her mother. The Judge also ordered the convict, identified as Himasha Praminda Ganegoda, to pay compensation in Rs 500,000 to the victim and a fine of Rs 75,000 to the Court.     Court also warned the convict that failure to pay the fine would result in a further period of two years being added to his sentence. Judge Patabendige also issued an open warrant for the arrest of the convict, as he had changed his residential address and continues to avoid Court. He also instructed the Court Registrar, to convey the same, to the Controller General of the Department of Immigration and Emigration. Elaborating further on his verdict, the Judge stated that from the victim’s testimony and that of the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) during the trial, it had come to light that the convict had raped the victim aged 17 at that time, on three separate occasions, from 15 April to 2 June, 20 years ago. He explained in his verdict, that the convict, had even threatened the victim, that if she were to reveal her ordeal to anyone, she would be abducted by his friends in the Army and that the convict had even provided the victim with tablets to prevent her from conceiving. Judge Patabendige also added, that as the wife of the convict’s younger brother, had been employed at an establishment which provided advice on legal matters, he had threatened the victim, that if she were to lodge a complaint against him, he would be able to overcome it. He pointed out, that the crime committed by the convict, to a girl of school-going age, had been grave and serious and noted that, it cannot be condoned and stressed that the severest possible punishment, was being meted out. State Counsel Chathura Bandara, representing the Attorney General, urged the Court to hand down the severest possible punishment to the accused, so as to deter others, from following suit. Attorney-at-Law Thanuj Sandaruwan appearing for the accused, mentioned that he would not be producing any submissions to Court, aimed at reducing the penalty, to be imposed on his client. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Person facing corruption charges unsuitable as Chief Security Officer
author: Author not found
Content: The Railway Trade Union Alliance (RTUA) has written to the Secretary of the Public Service Commission, asserting that the promotion of the Assistant Security Officer, of the Security Division of the Railway Department, to the position of Chief Security Officer (Covering) was unlawful. The letter highlighted that investigations have already been conducted against him and he faces charges related to anti-disciplinary action, financial fraud and misconduct. However, the relevant disciplinary proceedings have been delayed. The union argued that granting such a promotion, in light of this background, goes against the principles of disciplinary control. The letter emphasises that decisions such as this, by the Public Service Commission, encourages government officials to engage in indiscipline. The letter further contended that an individual facing corruption charges is unsuitable for a responsible position like Chief Security Officer and should be removed from that role.  The letter concluded by stating that failure to take such action would set a precedent and the same approach should be applied to any railway employee facing accusations. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Digital Air Traffic Management System at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: The Air Traffic Control Tower and the RADA Operations Centre at Bandaranaike International Airport commenced operations with digital technology. These advancements are integral components of the ongoing modernisation process to enhance Air Traffic Control operations. The inauguration of the Digital Air Traffic Management System took place yesterday (21), overseen by Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. Previously, Air Traffic Controllers manually documented information related to departing and arriving aircraft, a process managed between the Air Traffic Control Tower and the RADA Centre. The introduction of the latest System facilitates real-time dissemination of essential data to pertinent nodes.  This innovation expedites and optimises air navigation within Sri Lankan airspace, accommodating an increased volume of aircraft through the state-of-the-art system. The new System boasts superior technological capabilities. While the former system could solely measure the cruising altitude, position and airspeed of an aircraft, the latest system at the airport enables the acquisition of comprehensive data directly from the aircraft cockpit. This enhancement results in a 100% improvement in data accuracy concerning the safety of aircraft. The financial investment made by Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd to establish this cutting-edge system amounts to approximately Rs 1.2 billion. Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation – K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, Chairman of the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd – Gen. G.A. Chandrasiri and a number of officers also attended the event.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: MCPA accuses Health Ministry of discrimination
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) accused the Health Ministry of discrimination even when conducting probes, against trade union leaders, for speaking to the media.  MCPA President Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (21) urged the new Health Secretary, Dr. Palitha Mahipala to probe his Ministry’s intimidation of trade unions. He alleged that the Ministry was notorious for singling out trade union leaders that they wished to investigate.  In fact, the Health Ministry itself has officially accepted it had initiated investigations against himself, Dr. Rukshan Bellana and Medical Laboratory Scientist Ravi Kumudesh for allegedly speaking to the media.  He alleged that investigations had seemed to evade members of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) and President of the Government Nursing Officers’ Association (GNOA), who now holds a top post in Presidential Secretariat, who voiced their opinion to the media- especially during the time of the pandemic.  Dr. Sanjeeva said that Senior Assistant Secretary of the Health Ministry, Sudath Ranaweera in a letter (No. MH/FS/AD/B/IN/ACT/2020) on 14 November 2023 had informed him that probes had not been conducte against several trade unionists serving under the Health Ministry for voicing their opinions to the media during the past number of months.  The MCPA President said that he had requested the information from January 2020 to November 2023, under the Right to Information Act, on the investigations initiated by the Health Ministry against health trade unionists for talking to the print and electronic media.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Agri Ministry studying palm cultivation
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Agriculture and Plantation Industries will conduct a thorough study of palm cultivation in Sri Lanka, before resuming the project, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said. He was speaking at a discussion with Indonesian Ambassador in Sri Lanka Dewi Gustina Tobing, on Monday (20),  regarding palm cultivation.  The Indonesian Ambassador to Sri Lanka noted that substantial investment could be directed towards palm cultivation if there is an interest. Currently, there exists a Memorandum of Understanding between Sri Lanka and Indonesia regarding palm cultivation. The Ambassador highlighted that the Indonesian Government has committed to purchasing products related to palm cultivation in Sri Lanka under the agreement, with a readiness to invest Rs 4.5 billion to expand palm cultivation in the country. However, the Minister said any decisions regarding this matter will be reconsidered based on the findings of the report on palm cultivation. There are severe objections raised by some environmental organisations concerning palm plantation practices in Sri Lanka. They claim that this plantation poses many a detrimental condition to the environment. Despite the initiation of palm cultivation in Sri Lanka, several decades ago, the endorsement of further cultivation was halted in response to objections and accusations raised by various parties. As per the agreements established at that time, the initial plan was to cultivate 20,000 acres of palm. However, the current extent of palm cultivation is limited to 11,000 acres, indicating a deviation from the initial proposal.

title: Arukgoda promote as Snr Customs Director
author: Author not found
Content: Customs Media Spokesman Sivali Arukgoda has been promoted to the post of Senior Customs Director with effect 20 November. Apart from his previous post, Arukgoda will also function as the new Director ofthe Customs Policy Planning and Inspection Unit. The appointment letter to Arukgoda was handed over by Director General of Sri Lanka Customs Sarath Nonis. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Wall collapses at Wattegama school, no casualties
author: Author not found
Content: A part of a wall, in the Primary Section of Wattegama Balika Maha Vidyalaya collapsed due to torrential rains experienced in the Central Province during the past few days. The Sri Lanka Army has undertaken the clearing of the school premises while the principal decided to close the school on 21 and 22 November until clearing was completed. Torrential rains lashed Wattegama on 20 November and several buildings of the school had been submerged, in the process a part of a wall had also collapsed. However, residents were of the view that had the incident occurred during school hours it would have resulted in a calamity. However, fortunately the wall had collapsed during non-school hours. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Diplomatic approach to be taken – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Stating that that the issue of poaching by Indian fishermen, in the Sri Lankan waters, off the Northern Coast, has become a significant concern, Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said a diplomatic approach would be taken to find a lasting solution.  Devananda mentioned that a delegation, comprising MPs representing the Northern people, will soon visit Tamil Nadu to meet political authorities and fisheries societies there. He said that the matter involves the Navy and is a livelihood-related concern for local fishermen in the province.  According to statistics and information from the Navy, the number of Indian poaching vessels has significantly decreased in the recent past, suggesting that diplomatic discussions could contribute to resolving the issue.  Devananda disclosed that the Fisheries Ministry plans to enhance Navy patrol operations in Sri Lankan territorial waters, off the Northern coast, to counter illegal fishing activities by Indian fishermen. Additionally, assistance from the Special Task Force (STF) and the Police will be sought to address issues such as the use of dynamite in fishing.  The Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources has formally requested the assistance of the Inspector General of Police (IGP) to combat illegal fishing activities and Minister Devananda indicated that amendments to the fisheries law are being considered to empower the National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA) to control illegal fishing activities. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Puredale Kirithe wins Gold at National Industry Excellence Awards 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Puredale, a leading force in Sri Lanka’s dairy industry and the pioneer behind Puredale Kirithe, won a coveted Gold Award at the prestigious National Industry Excellence Awards 2023. Organised by the Industrial Development Board, under the purview of the Ministry of Industries, the awards recognised Puredale for its ground-breaking ‘Kirithe’ milk tea product, lauded for its outstanding taste, superior nutrition and convenient packaging. The accolade is a testament to Puredale’s unwavering commitment to quality and innovation. “We are thrilled to receive this prestigious award, which is a testament to our commitment to quality and innovation,” said Puredale Chief Executive Officer, Lakshitha Weerasuriya. “We are passionate and proud to have created the delicious and nutritious Kirithe, a product that helps millions of people start their day feeling refreshed and energised, while saving time and money — the ideal product for this busy world we live in.” Puredale Kirithe’s 3-in-1 milk tea is crafted with 100 per cent natural ingredients, a blend of milk, tea, and sugar, free from common bulking and solubility agents like whey powder, wheat flour, palm oil, or sodium bicarbonates. Affordable and popular among Sri Lankan households, a cup of this traditional and natural Ceylon milk tea costs only Rs 45. “Our daily objective is to bring only the highest quality premium goods to market, at an affordable price,” added Weerasuriya. “We are tirelessly researching and quality testing as a duty towards the people of our nation, and I would like to thank the organising committee, of the National Industry Excellence Awards 2023 and the Industrial Development Board for recognising our efforts. Puredale is committed to upholding the standard of excellence this award represents and we extend our sincere gratitude to the people of Sri Lanka for recognising our product, Puredale Kirithe.”  The National Industry Excellence Awards is a nationwide competition recognising the best entrepreneurs in Micro, Small – and Large-scale local industries across various sectors. The awards are granted following a rigorous assessment by an impartial panel of judges, adhering to strict evaluation criteria covering a range of metrics. Puredale is a leading manufacturer of dairy products in Sri Lanka. The company is known for its commitment to quality, innovation and sustainability. Exceptional taste and superior nutrition are the key factors within all of Puredale’s range of products. Puredale is committed to giving back to the community through varied community programmes within Sri Lanka.

title: JPs celebrates 30th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: Association of Justices of the Peace in Sri Lanka celebrated their 30th anniversary on Saturday, 29 October 2023, at Heaven’s Gate Banquet Hall, Hunupitiya, Wattala. This memorable occasion was graced by MP Prof. Ranjith Bandara as the Guest of Honour and Attorney-at-Law MP Premanatha C. Dolawatte as a Special Guest.  Among the other participants were Association President Deshabandu Senadisha Chandrasekara, Ex-Co Members, General Sponsorship Members, well-wishers and friends.  The event was marked with the official launch of the Association’s website.

title: Navy finds Rs 40M worth ganja
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy found 101 kg of Kerala Ganja from the coastal area of Sampalodai in Karainagar, Jaffna, during a search operation conducted on 20 November. The street value of the seized consignment is estimated to be Rs 40 million and is currently in the custody of the Navy, until it can be handed over to the authorities for legal action. In the course of the search operation, the Navy identified three suspicious sacks. Upon further inspection of the area, they found 15 parcels of Kerala Ganja hidden in the same location. The Navy is conducting additional investigations and taking action to apprehend the suspects. (NJ)

title: Rains cause havoc in Kegalle town
author: Author not found
Content: Heavy  torrential rains on Sunday (19) resulted in the Kegalle town being severely flooded. Several vehicles, including cars and three-wheelers, parked in the town area, had been washed away due to its severity. Even household items had been washed onto the road due to certain houses being inundated. Residents said they had been forced to tie up their three-wheelers to prevent them from being washed away while some said their washing machines had been washed away by the rushing waters. Bandaranayake Mawatha, in Kegalle had been totally submerged in water and it was rendered unusable for both motorists and pedestrians due to this situation. BY Bandara Pahalawatta – Kegalle

title: Case against Hirunika deferred
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja, yesterday deferred further hearing of testimony, in the abduction case filed against former lawmaker Hirunika Premachandra, to 7 December. When the case was taken up, the accused former MP was present in Court. Judge Ranaraja, then postponed further hearing, to the said date, after submissions produced by a junior lawyer, who mentioned that the lawyer for the accused, was unable to be present in Court, due to being currently indisposed. Later, the Court advised the witnesses to the Prosecution, to also be present at the next hearing, to provide testimony in the trial. The Attorney General had indicted Premachandra and seven of her aides, before the High Court with forced abduction,  disappearance and intimidation of youth Amila Priyantha, who had been working at a textile shop at Colombo 9, on 21 December,eight years ago. However, after the seven aides of Premachandra, pleaded guilty to the sentence to two years Rigorous Imprisonment, suspended for a period  12 years. The Court then advised to press ahead with the charges, filed against the accused former Parliamentarian, as she declined to plead guilty, to the charges. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: MSD director, three others arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Four persons, including the Director of the Medical Supplies Division (MSD), Dr. Kapila Wickramanayaka, were arrested by the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) over the controversial Immunoglobulin IV scam, Police said. Police sources said that Accountant – Supplies, Niran Dhananjaya, Assistant Director, Shanthi Solomon, and Pharmacist, Sujith Kumara were the others arrested. They were arrested over the alleged involvement in the importation of substandard Immunoglobulin injections by using forged documents. They were remanded till 29 November by the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court. The CID has up to now arrested five persons including the owner of Isolez Biotech Pharma. Also based on facts presented by the former, the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court has imposed travel bans on 12 persons, following a motion that the concerned suspects were preparing to flee the country.  The CID launched an investigation following a complaint lodged by the former Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), who accused the owner of Isolez Biotech Pharma of importing substandard Immunoglobulin using forged documents. Dr. Gunasekara was recalled to the Health Ministry and appointed as the Director of the Medical Research Institute (MRI).     By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Security tightened following death in Police custody
author: Author not found
Content: Following the death of a 25-year-old male resident of Sithankerni, Jaffna, who passed away while in Police custody, allegedly due to mistreatment, security was heightened near Vaddukoddai Police Station yesterday (20).  The family of the deceased, Nagarasa Alex, disclosed that he was called in for an investigation by Vaddukkottai Police on 8 November and subsequently arrested on suspicion of involvement in a local theft.  Alex’s health deteriorated during detention, leading Vaddukkottai Police to transfer him to Teaching Hospital Jaffna.  The family also claimed that they were denied access to Alex, prompting them to file a complaint with the Regional Office of the Human Rights Commission in Jaffna. A Police team, led by the Jaffna Assistant Superintendent of Police, has been assigned to conduct investigations. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: SC orders DWC to prevent unlawful deforestation by monk
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court (SC) yesterday, ordered the Department of Wildlife Conservation (DWC) to take prompt measures to prevent the unlawful deforestation activity, being conducted by a Buddhist monk, in a forest land of 4000 acres, in the vicinity of the Nakolagane Purana Raja Maha Viharaya in Ehetuwewa, in the Kurunegala District. The monk has been identified as Ven. Walaththewe Rahula Thera.  The Court also ordered the removal of the electric fence which has been erected illegally around the area.  The petition, filed by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) Executive Director Dilena Pathragoda and Senior Advicser Hemantha Withanage, was called, before a three-Judge Bench of the Apex Court, comprising Justices Murdu Fernando, S. Thurairaja and Yasantha Kodagoda. The SC thus instructed the Director General of the Wildlife Conservation Department, to take swift measures, to minimise the inconvenience caused to wild animals and residents, via the construction of the illegal electric fence, around the land in question and to remove the same. The Bench, which perused a few petitions filed by the CEJ and a few other intermediary parties, then advised the Inspector General of Police (IGP), to give his support towards the measures to be implemented by the Director General of the Wildlife Conservation Department. The SC then deferred, further hearing of the petitions, to 14 February next year. Senior Counsel Ravindranath Dabare, Attorney Savanthi Ponnamperuma, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Thushini Jayasekara, appeared for the petitioners. Attorney Hemaka Senanayake represented the respondent monk.  BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Accident-related hospital admissions to increase by 250,000 in 2025
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Director of the Directorate of Non-Communicable Diseases (DNCD), Ministry of Health Dr. Champika Wickramasinghe cautioned that in 2025, the number of admissions to State hospitals, due to injuries following accidents, would increase by 250,000 patients compared to the number in 2019 and 2020, the Health Ministry revealed.  According to predictions Dr. Wickramasinghe said, during the International Conference on Accident Prevention – 2023 (ICIPSL 2023) yesterday (20), this increase would be from approximately 1.3 million experienced in 2019 to approximately 1.55 million by 2025.  The NDCU noted that one out of every six patients who were admitted to government hospitals were admitted as a result of accidents. It is estimated that about 12,000 people die due to accidents in this country every year. That is about 35 people per day. Accordingly, every three hours, four people die due to accidents. Furthermore, accidents are the main health problem in the economically productive age group of 15-44 years and the leading cause of death in that age group. Every year over a million victims are treated as in-ward patients in public hospitals. Millions more are treated in the out- patient department (OPD) of State hospitals.  While another sizable number go to the private sector to receive treatment from non-western medical professionals. There is a section that resigns itself to self-medicate at home. The Unit said that 25% 30% (250,000, 300,000) of those who are hospitalised due to accidents are those who have fallen due to various reasons and 17% to 18% (200, 000) would be hospitalised due to road accidents. In addition to this, cuts due to various reasons, various objects falling on the body, conscious or unconscious assaults, animal bites (about 250,000 to 300,000 animal bites are treated in government hospitals annually), stings, various poisonings, burns, etc. According to current information, more than 50% of all accidents occur in the home and its surrounding environment. About 25% are road-related, while the majority of the rest of the incidents occur in workplaces, schools, shelters and recreational areas, the Unit explained.  Meanwhile, Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana noted that these statistics were very significantly dangerous and disturbing.  Addressing the International Conference Dr. Pathirana said, the Ministry of Health, was fully committed to ensuring that best was provided in implementation of the policy action that was decided.  “In fact, this is the fourth week that I am in this position as the Minister of Health and I was very moved by the fact that a sheer number has been affected by the injuries. I am very convinced that we should take more strong action, in relation to prevention of injuries and also to support other sectors which have multi-faceted and multi sectoral approach to ensure that Sri Lankan people lead a better life in relation to injury prevention,” he said noting that other ministries, including the Transport Ministry, Ministry of Education should increase awareness amongst the Sri Lankan students and the Ministry of Justice should enact necessary laws to take necessary legal action. (DJ)

title: 32 families evacuated due to landslide risk
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 32 families, residing in Glanor Estate in Thangamale of the Haputale Divisional Secretariat Division, were safely evacuated due to the potential landslide risk amid heavy rains, Gayani K. Ranatunga, the Divisional Secretary of Haputale said.  A total of 89 members from these families, located in house row number 10 of Glenor Estate and neighbouring houses, have been successfully relocated.  The evacuated families are currently housed in a temporary camp at Glenor High School, confirmed the Divisional Secretary. The National Building Research Organisasion (NBRO) recommended the evacuation, based on early signs of landslides, including the presence of water streams and land subsidence during a ground test in the area.  Additionally, the Haldummulla Zonal Education Director announced that due to the risk of loose rocks falling on the school buildings of Blackwood College, Beragala affiliated to the Haldummulla Divisional Secretariat Division, students will be temporarily relocated to a separate hall at Haldummulla Tamil High School today (21).  Dhammika explained that precautionary measures, including the removal of loose rocks, were initiated to mitigate the risk of stones falling on the school building. BY Saman Palitha Nanayakkara – Hamdummulla

title: 2,087 teenage mothers in SL –Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: A staggering number of 2,087 teenage mothers were reported in Sri Lanka, which is an alarming revelation from the Family Health Bureau, State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe said in Parliament yesterday (20).  Bluntly addressing the issue in Parliament, she pointed to a host of contributing factors, which are migrating mothers, crumbling family units, absence of sex education, parental drug addiction, the simultaneous employment of both parents and the pervasive influence of smartphones among children.  In response to MP Jagath Kumara’s question, Kumarasinghe revealed the grim reality of 89,164 single-parent families in Sri Lanka, encompassing a distressing number of 124,482 children.  Despite this dire situation, she asserted that the Government has initiated several programmes, including awareness campaigns and legal aid for victimised children, in an attempt to tackle this deeply concerning problem head-on. The State Minister also revealed that by September of this year, 425 children had been subjected to grave sexual abuse and that is a 17 per cent increase compared to last year. Furthermore, she said that crimes against children have increased rapidly in Sri Lanka and 168 girl children have been subjected to rape each month, 22 of them have become pregnant and nearly 131 children have been sexually abused in October alone. She also mentioned that the number of girl children under the age of 16, who are being sexually abused due to romantic relationships, has increased and that in the face of such a situation, children also have a great responsibility and they should put their educational goals first. Meanwhile, the Statistics Division of Bureau for the Prevention of Abuse of Children and Women revealed 4,342 crimes and misdemeanours have been reported against children in the last nine months of this year.  Accordingly, the number of crimes identified as juvenile crimes has been 2,326 and 2,016 offenses such as sexual assault, assault and injury, domestic violence, verbal threats, indecent exposure of children and making them beg have been committed.  Moreover, there were 506 cases of abuse, 917 cases of statutory rape, 425 cases of grave sexual abuse, 1,086 cases of sexual abuse and 558 assaults and injuries. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Nas Daily Vlogger signs three SL Tourism promotion contracts
author: Author not found
Content: The internationally acclaimed vlogger, Nas Daily recently signed an agreement to create three exclusive videos promoting Sri Lanka Tourism. Nas, whose real name is Nuseir Yassin, is a 31-year-old Harvard graduate known for sponsored content creation.  He is in Sri Lanka at the invitation of Sri Lanka Tourism and interacted with his fans at the BMICH on Monday (20). He will be at the Colombo Race Course on 22 November, and at various other locations in Sri Lanka to gather material for his video on Sri Lanka. Nas, who is of Israeli-Palestinian-Kittitian (Saint Kitts) descent, founded Nas Daily Studios, a global social media agency with offices in Singapore, Dubai, San Francisco and remote teams worldwide. He engages with a vast audience, boasting over 65 million followers and accumulating more than 15 billion views in 14 different languages. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Bandara says will quit if allegations proven
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) Ranjith Bandara vowed yesterday (20) to resign from Parliament, if the sexual bribery allegations, made by SJB MP Hesha Withanage, were proved.  Bandara, who is in soup these days, as a result of recent COPE sitting involving Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC), vehemently denied Withanage’s allegation. “Hesha Withanage alleged that a COPE Chairman has solicited sexual bribery from a female parliamentary staff member. This is a blatant lie made when I was not present in the Chamber. As a result of these false and malicious accusations, my parliamentary privileges have been infringed. I have already informed the Speaker about this in writing and I urged the Speaker to take the matter before the Parliamentary Privileges Committee. I also request the Speaker to take necessary action to reprimand MP Withanage, if his allegations are proven to be false, in order to protect the reputation of Parliament,” Bandara said. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 32 families evacuated due to landslide risk
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 32 families, residing in Glanor Estate in Thangamale of the Haputale Divisional Secretariat Division, were safely evacuated due to the potential landslide risk amid heavy rains, Gayani K. Ranatunga, the Divisional Secretary of Haputale said.  A total of 89 members from these families, located in house row number 10 of Glenor Estate and neighbouring houses, have been successfully relocated.  The evacuated families are currently housed in a temporary camp at Glenor High School, confirmed the Divisional Secretary. The National Building Research Organisasion (NBRO) recommended the evacuation, based on early signs of landslides, including the presence of water streams and land subsidence during a ground test in the area.  Additionally, the Haldummulla Zonal Education Director announced that due to the risk of loose rocks falling on the school buildings of Blackwood College, Beragala affiliated to the Haldummulla Divisional Secretariat Division, students will be temporarily relocated to a separate hall at Haldummulla Tamil High School today (21).  Dhammika explained that precautionary measures, including the removal of loose rocks, were initiated to mitigate the risk of stones falling on the school building. BY Saman Palitha Nanayakkara – Hamdummulla

title: 2,087 teenage mothers in SL –Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: A staggering number of 2,087 teenage mothers were reported in Sri Lanka, which is an alarming revelation from the Family Health Bureau, State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe said in Parliament yesterday (20).  Bluntly addressing the issue in Parliament, she pointed to a host of contributing factors, which are migrating mothers, crumbling family units, absence of sex education, parental drug addiction, the simultaneous employment of both parents and the pervasive influence of smartphones among children.  In response to MP Jagath Kumara’s question, Kumarasinghe revealed the grim reality of 89,164 single-parent families in Sri Lanka, encompassing a distressing number of 124,482 children.  Despite this dire situation, she asserted that the Government has initiated several programmes, including awareness campaigns and legal aid for victimised children, in an attempt to tackle this deeply concerning problem head-on. The State Minister also revealed that by September of this year, 425 children had been subjected to grave sexual abuse and that is a 17 per cent increase compared to last year. Furthermore, she said that crimes against children have increased rapidly in Sri Lanka and 168 girl children have been subjected to rape each month, 22 of them have become pregnant and nearly 131 children have been sexually abused in October alone. She also mentioned that the number of girl children under the age of 16, who are being sexually abused due to romantic relationships, has increased and that in the face of such a situation, children also have a great responsibility and they should put their educational goals first. Meanwhile, the Statistics Division of Bureau for the Prevention of Abuse of Children and Women revealed 4,342 crimes and misdemeanours have been reported against children in the last nine months of this year.  Accordingly, the number of crimes identified as juvenile crimes has been 2,326 and 2,016 offenses such as sexual assault, assault and injury, domestic violence, verbal threats, indecent exposure of children and making them beg have been committed.  Moreover, there were 506 cases of abuse, 917 cases of statutory rape, 425 cases of grave sexual abuse, 1,086 cases of sexual abuse and 558 assaults and injuries. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Speaker strictly prohibits entry to non-members
author: Author not found
Content: Making a special announcement yesterday (20), Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, declared that non-members are strictly prohibited from entering meeting rooms during Parliament committee meetings.  The Speaker’s announcement came following the controversy over Committee of Public Enterprises (COPE) Chairman Ranjith Bandara’s son attending the COPE meeting when Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) was summoned.  Abeywardena emphasised that attendance at these meetings is limited to committee members, other MPs granted approval by the committee’s chairperson, and officials from external institutions summoned before the committee.  Any outsider seeking attendance at a Parliamentary Select Committee Meeting must obtain prior written approval from the Speaker.  Expressing concern over instances where committee chairpersons exceeded their designated roles, the Speaker underscored their obligation to adhere to parliamentary standing orders and preserve the institution’s longstanding traditions.  Additionally, he stressed the importance of issuing press releases containing only committee-approved information and ensuring that government officials summoned before committees face no inconvenience.  The Speaker unequivocally stated that official letterheads should not be misused for personal or political purposes under any circumstances.  BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Dr Mahipala assumes duties as Health Secy
author: Author not found
Content: Former Director General of Health Services (DGHS) Dr. Palitha Mahipala officially assumed duties as the new Secretary to the Ministry of Health yesterday (20).  He has also served as an Additional Secretary of the Ministry of Health and also as a Representative of the World Health Organisation (WHO).

title: 6,000 paddy farmers to undergo training
author: Author not found
Content: Six thousand farmers from the Ampara, Badulla, Hambantota and Polonnaruwa Districts will be trained, by Agriculture Extension Officers, on applying the Integrated Plant Nutrient Management (IPNM) approach in their paddy cultivation, to promote the efficient use of fertilisers, water and other inputs. This programme is by the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) together with the Department of Agriculture and the Mahaweli Authority of Sri Lanka with funding from the European Union (EU).  They recently launched a Farmer Field Schools Programme to train 6,000 smallholder paddy farmers, across four key rice-growing districts, on sustainable approaches to paddy cultivation. By adopting IPNM and more efficient use of chemical fertilisers, smallholder paddy farmers can reduce costs and improve productivity, leading to better profitability and resilience to future shocks. Many paddy farmers in Sri Lanka rely on traditional cultivation methods, often exceeding the recommended amounts of fertilisers provided by the Department of Agriculture without a full understanding of the respective soil nutrient requirements of their fields. To address these challenges, the Farmer Field School Programme will facilitate soil testing and efficient fertiliser use through IPNM practices, emphasising soil management, compost, and biochar production. The programme will also focus on implementing good agronomic practices, including using high-quality seeds, proper land preparation, the parachute method for seed broadcasting, efficient water management and effective weed, pest, and disease management, all integral components of IPNM practices. All  activities are being implemented through the project titled ‘RiceUP’, an innovative project launched by FAO, together with the government of Sri Lanka with Euro 4 million in funding from the EU to tackle the vulnerability of the food security system in Sri Lanka. The project aims to respond to the economic crisis in Sri Lanka by protecting smallholder farmer livelihoods through the safe and efficient use of fertiliser along with boosting the production of quality seed paddy for better productivity in paddy farming. The launch of the Farmer Field Schools comes after 289 Agriculture Extension Officers were trained with the necessary skills and knowledge to guide 6,000 paddy farmers on IPNM practices to enhance yields while reducing dependency on chemical fertilisers. The Agriculture Extension Officers will act as facilitators and work with the selected farmers to adapt appropriate exercises relevant to their local conditions. Through the implementation of sustainable farming practices, including the safe and efficient use of fertiliser and quality seeds, RiceUP aims to enhance productivity, food security, and livelihoods in Sri Lanka’s paddy farming sector. Together with its partners, FAO remains dedicated to ensuring the long-term sustainability and resilience of Sri Lanka’s agriculture sector. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Susil pledges to solve non-academic employees’ issues
author: Author not found
Content: A fast unto death was organised, by the All-Ceylon Educational Non-Academic Employees’ Union and the Trade Union Collective, opposite the Ministry of Education at Isurupaya yesterday (20), seeking solutions to a few of their grievances which had not been resolved over the years. Subject Minister Susil Premajayantha who arrived at the protest then urged them to end their protest and join him for discussions to resolve their grievances. Later two trade unionists, namely Kumudu S. Katapoluge and Deshabandu Maddumabandara were invited for talks by the Minister. The trade unions reps stated that the Minister had assured them that he will intervene to provide solutions to their unresolved issues shortly.

title: PADDY FARMERS TO GET FREE DIESEL
author: Author not found
Content: During the last Maha season, the Chinese Government donated 6.9 million litres of diesel to Sri Lanka free of charge for distribution in support of paddy cultivation, but a surplus of two million litres emerged as some farmers did not fully utilise their allocated quotas. Thus, the Ministry is now implementing a targeted plan to distribute the remaining diesel to farmers facing crop challenges in the ongoing agricultural season. Accordingly, the ministry has decided to provide a subsidy of 40 litres of diesel, per hectare, free of charge. The distribution of fuel for paddy cultivation commenced on Sunday (19). Vouchers for obtaining fuel were issued yesterday during a programme in Angunukolapelessa, with the participation of the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industry Mahinda Amaraweera. This fuel subsidy is accessible to all farmers who experienced crop losses in the Walawa Zone, Hambantota District, Kurunegala District, and all farmers who reported crop losses in the last Yala season. Approximately 65,000 acres, cultivated with paddy in the last Yala season, were adversely affected by drought. In response, the Minister instructed the Department of Agricultural Development to provide this fuel subsidy to those farmers for harvesting paddy in the current Maha season.

title: Ragala fire victims stage protest
author: Author not found
Content: A protest march was staged in the Ragala town on Sunday (19) by members of 28 families who had been aggrieved over the failure of authorities to grant them compensation or solutions after they had been displaced due to a fire that had destroyed a section of the estate houses at Ragala in Nuwara Eliya. The protesters said that the blaze, which had taken place on 5 July at Lower Division Estate, Ragala had totally damaged some 20 houses but to date they have not been provided any compensation or relocated after being displaced. They added that though over four months had lapsed since the incident their plight had been the same and urged the authorities to look into their predicament. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood
