title: Marasinghelauds President’s economic skills
author: Author not found
Content: Former UNP MP Ashu  Marasinghe yesterday (20) said the Budget for 2024 includes the largest-ever fund allocations, aimed at providing relief to the average citizens of the country and supporting various welfare initiatives.  Unlike previous conventional budgets, Budget 2024 introduces numerous features and welfare programmes targeting ordinary citizens, including the provision of land ownership to those residing without deeds or permits, he added.  Speaking at the Sirikotha, Marasinghe highlighted the substantial allocations to uplift the rural economy and make the rural community integral stakeholders in the national economy.  He emphasised the resumption of the Suraksha Insurance scheme from 2024, describing it as a significant package offering Rs 200,000 in medical assistance to students. Marasinghe attributed the government’s ability to generate Rs 2,400 billion by October, with a target of Rs 600 billion more by year-end, to President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s unparalleled economic skills.  Expressing confidence in achieving revenue targets, Marasinghe mentioned key entities, including the Inland Revenue Department, Sri Lanka Customs, and 39 other income-generating entities under government purview.  The estimated State expenditure for 2023, initially at Rs 5,800 billion, was effectively managed by President Wickremesinghe, reducing it to Rs 3,068 billion, with measures in place to keep expenses below revenue levels, stated Prof. Marasinghe.  He noted the current GDP of 10.3%, was just below the targeted 12% and expressed confidence in achieving the nominal percentage by year-end. Crediting President Wickremesinghe’s timely actions, Marasinghe highlighted a reduction in domestic expenses by Rs 2,000 billion. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Proposed Fisheries Bill an injustice to fishers – NFC
author: Author not found
Content: The proposed Fisheries Bill is an injustice caused to the small or medium scale fisherfolks, Convener of the National Fisheries Collective (NFC)Herman Kumara said.  Addressing a media briefing at the Jubilee Hall of St. Mary’s Church, Negombo, he charged that via the proposed Bill the Director General(DG) of the Fisheries Department had strived to take control of the fisheries industry. He charged that if that were to happen it would signal the death knell to the fisheries sector as the fisherfolk would then be at the mercy of the DG. Kumara stated that some 60 per cent of the protein content needed by the consumers were supplied by the small or medium scale fisherfolk and warned if the said Bill is ratified its ramifications will be felt far and wide. BY Nimanthi Fernando – Negombo

title: Lack of Staff Caused RAMIS to Fail – IRD
author: Author not found
Content: Due to a lack of coordination among pertinent State institutions and human resources needed to upkeep the Inland Revenue Department’s (IRD) RAMIS computer system, the department cannot effectively implement the system designed to oversee the country’s tax network. A senior official from the department told Ceylon Today that while the Government is in discussions about utilising the RAMIS computer system to enhance the existing tax network in the country, his department lacks the human resources required to properly maintain the computer system. Despite multiple notifications to the concerned parties, no action has been taken to address this issue, he added. The official disclosed that the National Audit Office has reported a loss of over Rs 904 billion in total arrears of taxes, fines, and interest by the IRD attributable to the RAMIS and Legacy computer systems as of 31 December 2022. Of this amount, Rs 163 billion is identified as chargeable income, while Rs 740 billion is suspended due to specific reasons. Despite these challenges, and with the Government’s new tax policy aiming to strengthen the tax network, the official expressed concern that necessary action is not being taken. He highlighted that these concerns have been raised at the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) on multiple occasions, and the IRD presented a clarification on this matter on 15 November.  During the COPA sitting, it was revealed that six institutions are connected to the RAMIS computer system and there is a delay of the Company Registrar’s Department in connecting to the system due to technical reasons. The Committee recommended that the Company Registrar’s Department promptly update its system and connect with the RAMIS system, instructing them to provide a progress report by 1 January 2024. Meanwhile, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe emphasised the use of a comprehensive digital system to network information about groups not paying taxes accurately. He mentioned the improvement of the RAMIS system, effective from 1 January, to strengthen the existing tax network by integrating new digital systems. Under four main categories—properties, vehicles, income licences, and current accounts—tax registration numbers will be made mandatory to streamline the tax network, aiming for a 15 per cent increase in government income. Despite economic challenges, he expressed optimism that as the country’s contraction eases, the new tax policy will contribute to economic stability without returning to a crisis. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Met Dept issues advisory for heavy rains
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Meteorology has issued an ‘Amber’ level advisory for heavy rains in the Central, Sabaragamuwa, North-western and Uva Provinces. The advisory, effective until 8:30 a.m. today (20) indicates that atmospheric conditions over the island are conducive to thunderstorms during the evening and night. Heavy showers exceeding 100 mm are expected at various locations in the Central, Sabaragamuwa, North-western and Uva provinces. Additionally, the Meteorology Department has issued an advisory for severe lightning in seven provinces. Thundershowers accompanied by severe lightning are anticipated in Western, Eastern, Northern, North-central, Sabaragamuwa, Uva, and North-western provinces, as well as in Kandy and Matale districts. Temporary localised strong winds may occur during thundershowers, as mentioned by the department. The public is strongly advised to take precautionary measures to mitigate potential damage caused by lightning activity. This includes seeking shelter indoors, particularly avoiding areas under trees. It is recommended to steer clear of open spaces such as paddy fields, tea plantations, and open water bodies during thunderstorms. Further, individuals should refrain from using wired telephones and connected electric appliances during inclement weather. The use of open vehicles, such as bicycles, tractors, and boats, is also discouraged. Caution is urged regarding fallen trees and power lines. In case of emergencies, the public is urged to promptly contact local disaster management authorities for assistance.

title: No way for there to be a sugar shortage – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: Although, the consumers claim that there is a shortage of sugar in the market, due to the Government implementing an MRP on rice and sugar, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said there is no chance way a shortage of sugar can be created as the country had imported 19,000 MT of sugar before the tax was increased. With the special commodity tax on imported sugar increasing from 25 cents to Rs 50 per kg, many traders raised sugar prices, prompting the government to enforce a MRT to regulate it. Accordingly, a maximum retail price of Rs 275 per kg for white sugar and Rs 330 per kg for brown sugar has been fixed. Consumers have noted that there is not only a scarcity of sugar, but also a shortage of Samba and Keeri Samba rice in the market. The Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) has declared its commitment to conducting raids to identify sellers offering sugar and rice above the prescribed control prices. Siyambalapitiya instructed the CAA to identify and take action against those selling sugar above the MRT. He emphasised that it is not only the government’s responsibility but also the responsibility of the public to purchase sugar at the correct price and prevent unnecessary shortages. He encouraged people to inform the CAA about instances of overpriced sales. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Students of school threatened with closure shine
author: Author not found
Content: Pathramulla Primary School, situated in the Mullatiyana Education Zone, faced the looming threat of closure, but thanks to a dedicated group of teachers committed to the welfare of the students, the school witnessed a remarkable turnaround, when the results of Grade 5 Scholarship Examination were released.  In a setting where even securing an ‘A’ grade-ranking principal posed a challenge, eight students from Pathramulla Primary School, who sat in this year’s Grade 5 Scholarship Examination, surpassed the district cut-off marks, marking a historic achievement for the school.  Also, Among the 16 students who sat the exam, an impressive number of 14 students achieved scores surpassing the average pass mark of 70. This outstanding performance not only defied the odds but also highlighted the resilience and commitment of the teachers and students at Pathramulla Primary School. Currently,s accommodating a total of 45 students ranging from grades one to five, the school has a staff consisting of one principal, five teachers, four development officers, and four non-academic staff members.  BY Niluka Herath – Gandara

title: Biden Administration values partnership with SL – Power
author: Author not found
Content: The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), Samantha Power, has emphasised the significant value that the Biden Administration places in its partnership with Sri Lanka. In a post on X, the former US Ambassador to the UN mentioned her positive discussion with Sri Lanka’s Head of State, Ranil Wickremesinghe, during the inauguration ceremony of Dr. Mohamed Muizzu, the president-elect of the Republic of Maldives. Power highlighted that during the conversation with President Wickremesinghe, she learned about Sri Lanka’s economic recovery and underscored the importance of political reforms.  Additionally, she pointed out that the recent commitment by the US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) to invest over USD 550 million in Sri Lanka’s port infrastructure reflects the Biden Administration’s strong commitment to its partnership with the country.

title: Tourist arrivals in first 15 days of Nov total 74,664
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 74,664 foreign tourists arrived in Sri Lanka in the first 15 days of November, according to the latest statistics released by the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA). According to SLTDA data, this is the highest number of tourist arrivals recorded within the first two weeks of any month of 2023. The previous highest arrivals in the first 15 days were in March 2023, with 60,882 international visitors. The SLTDA has forecast that 204,114 tourists will arrive in November as peak tourist season starts. The total number of tourist arrivals from 1 January to 15 November is 1,200,119, with an income of USD 1.59 billion having been generated, official data shows. Sri Lanka’s tourism industry is aiming to attract 2 million visitors in 2023.  (AFP)

title: CC wants CJ to evaluate SC, CoA Judges
author: Author not found
Content: In a letter addressed to Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya, the Constitutional Council has requested an evaluation of the conduct of Supreme Court Judges, including the President of the Court of Appeal (CoA).  The letter pertains to appointments made, based on proposals submitted by the President to the Constitutional Council. The letter from the Constitutional Council to the Chief Justice emphasised that the newly appointed judges should be evaluated considering the number of judgments issued in recent years and the performance of each judge.  Additionally, the letter raises concerns about the number of judgments by the respective judges that were overturned by the Supreme Court, along with any observations made by the Supreme Court in that context. The letter underscored the necessity of investigating the behavior of the concerned judges and their contribution to the development of legal jurisprudence.

title: SL Govt releases 22 Indian fishers
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan Government has released 22 fishermen hailing from Rameswaram in Tamil Nadu, who were detained on 18 November by the Navy personnel on charges of poaching. The two seized country boats belonging to the fishermen have also been released, Rayappan, president, the country boat fishermen association, told journalists in Rameswaram on 19 November. According to him, a fishermen’s delegation had met Union Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on 18 November evening and briefed her about the arrest.  She spoke with the External Affairs Secretary in New Delhi and also with the Indian High Commissioner in Sri Lanka seeking their intervention to get the fishermen and their boats freed. The Sri Lankan Government has issued an order releasing all the 22 fishermen and the two country boats, he said. He thanked the Minister for her intervention. According to the information available, the arrested fishermen were being handed over at the IMBL by the Sri Lankan authorities and were being brought back home. “We are planning to meet the Central Minister with our families,” Rayappan added.  (The Hindu)

title: IRD claims 198,253 new taxpayers registered
author: Author not found
Content: The Inland Revenue Department (IRD) claims that 198,253 new taxpayers have been registered in 2023. Officials from the department highlighted that there are approximately 16 million citizens over the age of 18 in the country, and special programmes are being implemented to ensure their inclusion in the tax payment process.  This information was divulged in response to queries raised by the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA), which convened recently in Parliament, under the chairmanship of State Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna. During the COPA sitting, concerns were raised about whether the government is effectively receiving the Value Added Tax (VAT), paid by the public for various goods. Currently, there are around 13,000 organisations registered for VAT and IRD officials mentioned that they are actively monitoring tax payments. The committee emphasised the need for institutions collecting VAT from the public to establish systems ensuring accurate remittance of taxes to the government. The COPA chairman instructed the IRD to provide a comprehensive report on taxes levied through various classifications and a detailed report on the outstanding arrears amounting to Rs 943 billion. These discussions took place during the COPA Committee’s review of the Auditor General’s reports for the years 2019, 2020, and 2021, as well as an assessment of the current performance of the IRD.  BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: HRCSL makes recommendations for Women’s Bills
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has provided recommendations to the Government on three Bills dealing with women. The Bills are: the National Women’s Commission Bill, the Gender Equality Bill, and the Women’s Empowerment Bill. The HRCSL has proposed several recommendations, including exploring the feasibility of consolidating the Gender Equality Bill and the Women’s Empowerment Bill into a unified piece of legislation.  Additionally, the suggestion involves housing the Gender Equality Council within the forthcoming department responsible for the enhancement of the Women’s Bureau, considering the possible renaming of this department as the ‘Department for Gender Equality’ in alignment with the proposed changes.  Furthermore, the HRCSL advises improvements to the appointment process for the National Women’s Commission and encourages the timely publication of the three Bills to facilitate meaningful public consultation on their content. These recommendations were conveyed through a letter sent by the HRCSL to President Ranil Wickremesinghe on 17 November. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Farmers compensated for Yala crop loss
author: Author not found
Content: The first phase of disbursing compensation for crop damage caused by drought and floods in the Yala Season 2023 commenced yesterday (19) morning in Angunakolapelessa.  Accordingly, a ceremony was held in Angunakolapelessa under the patronage of Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries Mahinda Amaraweera. The Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board allocated Rs 389 million from its funds for the initial phase until government financial allocations are received.  During the ceremony, Minister Amaraweera distributed compensation to 375 farmers in the Hambantota District for crop damage, including paddy, chillies, potato, maize, soybeans, and big onions, considering losses caused by drought, heavy rains and wild elephants. Surveys indicate that 65,000 acres were damaged due to drought and 11,000 acres due to rain. Compensation is provided up to a maximum of Rs 100,000 per hectare. The awarded compensation totalled Rs 360 million for 13,451 acres in the Hambantota Mahaweli area and Rs 2,498,400 for 89 acres in Chandrikaweva, Kolonna, Panamure and Thibolketiya agrarian service areas. Minister Mahinda Amaraweera acknowledged the challenges faced by farmers during the 2023 Yala Season due to severe drought and subsequent heavy rains.  Emphasising the unprecedented speed of providing compensation within two months, Minister Amaraweera acknowledged that normally, such payments take about a year. He said even though the Government had not yet received the necessary financial allocations, he advised the Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board to begin payments using available funds. Recognising that the provided Rs 100,000 per hectare may not fully cover the losses, Minister Amaraweera said the substantial compensation being distributed is possibly the highest in history for crop damage. He stressed the difficult situation faced by affected farmers, expressing hope that swift compensation would offer relief. Additionally, he announced the distribution of 40 litres of fuel free of charge to all farmers affected by crop damage. This decision was made using the remaining two million litres of the 6.9 million litres of fuel provided by the Chinese Government. Chairman of the Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board M.M.B. Weerasekera, and others also participated in the ceremony.

title: Policeman stabbed by teen monk dies
author: Author not found
Content: The Police officer attached to the Deniyaya Police Station, who was stabbed in the neck by a novice teenage Buddhist monk following a personal dispute last Thursday, succumbed to the injuries and passed away yesterday (19). The incident occurred on Thursday (16) afternoon on Gangoda Road in Pallegama. Police investigations have uncovered that the 37-year-old deceased Police officer had met the 17-year-old monk last Thursday (16) morning, at the crime scene, following a phone call made by the latter, requesting a meeting.  According to the Police, the conversation escalated aggressively, leading to the monk stabbing the police officer in the neck with a knife concealed inside his tote bag. The deceased officer, a resident of Katuwana, was initially admitted to the Deniyaya Base Hospital and later transferred to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. Deniyaya Police arrested the suspect monk and are conducting additional investigations into the incident. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Land taken on lease for cricket academy still unused – KDVA
author: Author not found
Content: The 5-acre land which Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) obtained in Katugastota, Kandy on a lease basis seven years ago, to build the proposed Cricket Academy, has not been utilised up to now, Thilina Bandara Tennakoon, executive member of the Kandy District Cricket Association (KDVA) claimed. A group of KDCA members, including Thilina Bandara Tennakoon, went to observe the land yesterday (19).  Tennakoon, who was a sports minister of Central Provincial Council and former SLC executive member, after inspecting the land in question, told the media that the said land not being utilised up to now is a huge waste SLC funds.  “Sunil Fernando, the coach of Muttiah Muralitharan and several other Sri Lankan cricketers and former Sri Lankan cricketer Bernard Perera, ran a cricket training school at this place earlier.  talented cricketers were born from that school. But about seven years ago, the SLC got this land saying that it would build a cricket academy. However, no development has been done here so far, except for a half-built pitch. This is the said land not being utilised until now a crime actually,” he stressed.  “We have come to know that a lot of underhand monetary transactions have taken place during the acquisition of this land of high economic value. We have come to know that a huge amount of money has been paid for this. We demand that these crooks be exposed to the country and punished,” he said.  BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Parishkara Puja Held
author: Author not found
Content: A Parishkara Puja Maha Pinkama, was held for the 18th time, to invoke blessings on 5,000 Buddhashravikas, under the patronage of the Vice Chancellor of the Nagahananda International Buddhist University,  Ven. Dr. Bodagama Chandima Thera, at Nagahananda International Buddhist University. Consecutively,  a dana offering was also held. A large number of Maha Sangha, Ministers and MPs attended the event.

title: President expresses eagerness for advancements in digitalisation
author: Author not found
Content: During the Leaders’ session of the Second Voice of Global South Summit, Sri Lanka’s President Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed gratitude to India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi for the invitation, acknowledging India’s pivotal role in organising the event. Prime Minister Modi inaugurated the summit, which was attended by distinguished leaders from various developing countries, according to the President’s Media Division (PMD). President Wickremesinghe reflected on the significance of the inaugural Voice of Global South Summit, commending India’s leadership for its positive impact in drawing international attention to the priorities of the developing world. He highlighted the successful outcomes of the G20 Summit under India’s presidency, identifying key priorities and diverse issues relevant to developing nations. In his address at the First Summit, President Wickremesinghe emphasised the common challenges faced by the Global South, particularly economic issues such as debt settlement difficulties and limited accessibility to international financial markets. He underscored the need for external assistance from multilateral institutions and developed economies, positioning India as a bridge between developing economies and G20 countries to address these challenges. Providing an update on Sri Lanka’s economic progress, President Wickremesinghe mentioned the receipt of the first tranche of the IMF’s loan and progress in the Official Creditors’ Committee on Sri Lanka’s bilateral official debt. He emphasised the complexity of the issue of indebtedness, calling for collaboration between creditors and international financial institutions to find sustainable solutions. Addressing the economic challenges faced by Sri Lanka, President Wickremesinghe presented the budget for the next year to the Sri Lankan Parliament, focusing on ameliorating the condition of the people, especially the vulnerable, amid the worst economic crisis in the country’s history. Looking ahead, President Wickremesinghe highlighted the importance of attracting foreign investment and developing connectivity for long-term growth. The Vision Statement issued with Prime Minister Modi, during his visit to India this year, focuses on promoting connectivity between the two economies across all sectors and between the people of both countries for mutual benefit. President Wickremesinghe suggested a special focus on cooperation in digitalisation, recognising India’s leadership in this sphere. He expressed eagerness for advancements in digitalisation to contribute to both growth and entrepreneurship, as well as more effective governance. The President concluded by wishing the summit success in its deliberations on these crucial matters, according to the PMD.

title: Four including foreigner rescued after boat capsizes
author: Author not found
Content: The Police reported the successful rescue and safe return to land of the four individuals, including a foreigner, who were earlier reported missing at sea following the capsizing of their boat off Mudukatuwa in Marawila. The incident unfolded when six individuals, including a Japanese national, set out for a fishing expedition in a dinghy near the Holy Cross Church in Marawila around 5:30 p.m. on Saturday (18). Unfortunately, adverse weather led to the boat capsizing. The owner of the boat, a Marawila resident, alerted the Police to the situation around 3:30 a.m. the following day (19). The skipper of the small boat communicated the incident to another fisherman on land via phone call, leading to a swift response from a rescue team. Another group set out by boat to the location of the incident, rescuing the two survivors and safely bringing them ashore. The boat owner informed the Police that the remaining four individuals were still missing. In response, a search operation, assisted by the Sri Lanka Navy, was launched to locate the missing persons, as confirmed by Marawila Police.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: High-density cultivation to increase tea yield in SL
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries Mahinda Amaraweera advised the Tea Small Holdings Development Authority and the Tea Board to promote the high-density cultivation method and new technology in the tea cultivation system to increase the yield from tea cultivation in the country. Last Friday (17), the minister engaged in an observation tour of the Welipanna, Peragaswatta high-density tea plantation. Under the guidance and funding of the Tea Small Holdings Development Authority, this seven-and-a-half-acre plantation, cultivated using the high-density cultivation method and Drip Irrigation technology, has yielded a highly successful harvest. While the normal tea cultivation method involves planting 6,500 tea plants per acre, the high-density cultivation method allows for the planting of 13,000 tea plants per acre. Additionally, under the traditional method, only 300 kg of tea leaves can be harvested from one acre, but with the high-density method, a high yield of 1,500 kg of tea leaves can be obtained. Moreover, the use of new technical equipment to pick tea leaves eliminates the need for manual labour, enabling farmers to increase their income fivefold. Notably, this intensive tea cultivation can be achieved with a minimal amount of water and fertiliser. The Tea Small Holdings Development Authority and the Tea Board have successfully implemented 52 such model tea cultivation projects. Further, financial assistance of Rs 1 million per acre has been provided to growers without recovery. This approach allows for maximum yield from a minimum amount of land and ensures a high-quality tea yield. Consequently, the minister urged the chairpersons to encourage the adoption of this high-density tea cultivation system among other growers and to take steps to expand these activities in 2024. Aligning with the vision outlined by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in the Budget document, the minister emphasised his goal to integrate new technology into the agriculture and plantation sector in 2024. He urged all officials to be dedicated to achieving the maximum yield from cultivated land.

title: SJB, JJB also contributed to economic crisis – Namal
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa emphasised that when taxes were reduced in the Budget presented by the former government, both the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) unanimously supported it. He asserted that if the country faced economic challenges due to tax concessions, these two parties also contributed to this situation. Rajapaksa stressed that the responsibility for the economic crisis should be borne by the present leaders of the SJB who were members of the Good Governance Government, as well as the JVP members who supported that Government. During the Presidential Election defeat of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa in 2015, the country’s economic growth stood at 7 per cent, but on returning to power in 2020, the economic growth dropped to 2 per cent, according to Namal Rajapaksa. He highlighted that the Government led by Gotabaya Rajapaksa had pledged to reduce taxes in its election manifesto. Rajapaksa questioned how the reduction of taxes, in accordance with the given mandate, could be deemed a mistake. Rajapaksa noted the irony that academics who went to Court against the tax reduction, including VAT took to the streets when the present government increased taxes based on IMF recommendations. He acknowledged that while some individuals may be offended by criticism of the Budget, if there are mistakes in any government, he will not hesitate to point them out for the sake of the people. Rajapaksa further explained that the present crisis has arisen because Gotabaya Rajapaksa remained silent on incorrect decisions, such as the use of organic fertiliser during his regime. He underscored the importance of learning from mistakes and stated that he would not hesitate to criticise and point out errors not only in the Budget but also in any decision taken by the Government.

title: SLA contingent off to India
author: Author not found
Content: A Sri Lanka Army (SLA) contingent of 29 officers and 94 ‘other ranks’ flew to Pune, India on Wednesday to participate in ‘Mithra Shakthi’, a joint military exercise between the SLA and the Indian Army. The 14-day exercise began on Friday at the Indian Army’s 330 Infantry Brigade Headquarters in Pune. The SLA contingent was led by Major General P.G.P.S. Rathnayaka, General Officer Commanding, 53 Infantry Division and also included Colonel M.J. Ubeysekera (Exercise Director), Colonel B.Y. Nanayakkara (Exercise Deputy Director) and Colonel R.M.S. Ranasinghe (Exercise Log Command). The Exercise, the ninth in the series, aims at developing joint strategies by sharing the expertise of conducting operations, especially in a counter-insurgency and counter-terrorism (CI and CT) environment. It will also include weapon training, basic military tactics and complex battle strategies. The ‘Mithra Shakthi’ military exercise began in 2012. (PA)

title: Four Bills signed into law
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena on last Friday (17) signed four Bills into law, including the Anti-Corruption (Amendment) Bill. Accordingly, the Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (Amendment) Bill, Anti-Corruption (Amendment) Bill, Civil Procedure Code (Amendment) Bill and Local Authorities Elections (Amendment) Bill were signed by the Speaker. The said Bills came to effect from last Friday (17) as Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (Amendment) Act No. 27 of 2023, Anti-Corruption (Amendment) Act No. 28 of 2023, Civil Procedure Code (Amendment) Act No. 29 of 2023 and Local Authorities Elections (Amendment) Act No. 30 of 2023.

title: Distinguished guests from CFA Institute visit Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: CFA Society Sri Lanka is honoured to host esteemed representatives from the CFA Institute, Arati Porwal, Country Head for India and Sachin Naik, Director of Partnerships and Client Solutions for India, who are set to visit the country from 20 November to 24 November 2023. A spokesperson, from the CFA Society Sri Lanka, said during their stay, they are scheduled to participate in the HR Forum organised by CFA Society Sri Lanka. This event is poised to be a significant platform for sharing insights and fostering discussions on the pressing issue of brain drain in Sri Lanka. The visit holds special importance as Porwal and Naik have a packed itinerary, including meetings with various stakeholders. These engagements will span interactions with regulators, top employers, CFA candidates, CFA members, academics and diplomatic missions, learning partners reinforcing the collaborative efforts between Sri Lanka and the globally renowned CFA Institute. The CFA Institute, with its reputation as a global leader in setting the gold standard for professional excellence and ethical conduct in investment markets, has over 190,000 CFA® charter holders across more than 160 markets worldwide. Sri Lanka, with its impressive tally of more than 250 charter holders and approximately 400 candidates, stands as a testament to the institute’s global reach and influence. This visit not only signifies a bridge between the CFA Institute and the vibrant financial community of Sri Lanka, but also presents a unique opportunity for knowledge exchange and collaboration. The shared commitment to ethical practices and professional excellence sets the stage for fruitful discussions that will undoubtedly benefit the local financial landscape.

title: 74 SCHOOLS WITH UNSAFE BUILDINGS IDENTIFIED
author: Author not found
Content: Following the tragic death of a 6-year-old schoolgirl at Weragoda Vidyalaya in Wellampitiya, when a wall collapsed on a group of students, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha announced yesterday (16) that 74 schools with unsafe buildings, including Thurstan College in Colombo and Tangalle Balika Vidyalaya, have been identified. Making a special statement in Parliament, the Minister said the respective schools have been instructed to evacuate children from these hazardous buildings. An alternative arrangement has been implemented to accommodate the students until the buildings undergo renovation. The Ministry of Education yesterday (16) instructed the relevant authorities to investigate a tragic incident and Minister Premajayantha has directed officials at the Zonal Education Office to conduct a thorough investigation and submit a report immediately. Responding to the directive, the Jayewardenepura Zonal Education Office has confirmed their immediate initiation of an investigation into the incident. In Parliament, Premajayantha revealed that at Thurstan College in Colombo, four-storey building housing 24 classrooms was dismantled due to its unsafe condition. The affected students have been relocated to temporary shelters on the school grounds until the reconstruction of the building is completed. In the case of Tangalle Balika Vidyalaya, the entire building has been demolished, and a new structure is being constructed with the assistance of the Army. The Minister highlighted the challenges faced by schools in securing funds for maintenance in the years 2019, 2020, 2021, and 2022 due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and the economic crisis in the country. Emphasising the importance of safety, Premajayantha informed school principals to exercise caution regarding hazardous buildings on their premises and ensure the well-being of the students. The unfortunate event on 15 November resulted in the death of a 6-year-old student, with five others injured as a school wall collapsed on them. The injured students were promptly taken to National Hospital Colombo, with one student admitted to Lady Ridgeway Hospital in Borella. According to the hospital sources, one of the National Hospital patients is in critical condition, while the student at Lady Ridgeway Hospital has fortunately not sustained serious injuries. Following the incident, local residents reportedly attacked the school principal. Subsequently, due to the unrest, the school has temporarily suspended academic activities, with plans to resume on Monday (20). Court orders for post-mortem report BY Kumudu Upul Shantha Colombo Additional Magistrate Shantha Herath yesterday (16) instructed the Colombo Judicial Medical Officer (JMO), to conduct a  post-mortem into the death of a child, after a concrete wall at a school in Wellampitiya collapsed on her on 15 November and submit his report. The Magistrate also advised that the remains of the victim be buried after the post-mortem and informed Grandpass Police, to place a sign at the burial site, for identification purposes.   The Court also instructed to submit a quality report on the construction of the concrete wall at the school premises. These instructions were issued by the Court, based on submissions produced by Grandpass Police. Police told Magistrate Herath, that they will also be recording statements over the incident from the principal and a few teachers of the school. They added that further submissions into the case, will be produced following advice received from Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam. The deceased, has been identified as six-year-old Shehansa Sathsarani, a resident of Wellampitiya and a Grade 1 student of Weragoda Vidyalaya, Grandpass.      BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: President unveils RIT Alles’ Autobiography ‘My Path’
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe unveiled the autobiography of the late R.I.T. Alles, titled My Path, marking the 10th Commemoration of the renowned educationist, who founded the D.S. Senanayake College, Colombo 07.  In a symbolic gesture, the President presented copies of the book to 10 principals.The event was held at BMICH, Colombo yesterday (16).  Speaking at the event, President Wickremesinghe underscored the significance of broadening language proficiency beyond Sinhala and Tamil. He announced the implementation of the ‘English for All’ programme in all schools and universities throughout the country by 2030.  Addressing the Government’s initiatives to reform the education sector in Sri Lanka, President Wickremesinghe emphasised the commitment to realising the late R.I.T. Alles’ vision of ‘Education for all’.    He highlighted the need to end students losing opportunities for higher education due to financial constraints and advocated discontinuing the practice of selling property to send children abroad. President Wickremesinghe outlined plans to establish new universities in both the public and private sectors to ensure access to higher education for all students in Sri Lanka. He assured government support for those in the private sector contributing to this initiative. Moreover, the President invited the Sinhala and Tamil Diasporas to return to Sri Lanka and participate in establishing new universities, emphasising a shared responsibility for the nation’s progress. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena and Education Minister Susil Premajayantha also addressed the event.  The Premier said, “I am honoured to be part of this occasion as we reflect on our encounter with the exemplary figure from Royal College 60 years ago, who also served as our teacher – R.I.T. Alles. His life stands as a beacon for all of us, illustrating a remarkable journey that has left an enduring impact on the field of education in our country.  R.I.T Alles can rightfully be celebrated as an educator who brought about revolutionary change.” Under his guidance, the school transformed into a centre for cultivating outstanding citizens and he demonstrated pioneering leadership in the education sector. Not only did he make a significant impact at Royal College, but he also founded D.S. Senanayake College, charting a new course for children’s education. His profound knowledge in education and administration became evident as we engaged with him not only in the classroom, but also in various extracurricular activities of the school, he said.  “My close association with him, especially during his tenure overseeing the cadets, provided us with invaluable discipline and training, lessons that have continued to fortify us in life. He consistently underscored the importance of respecting the teaching profession,” the PM said.  Minister Premajayantha said, under the visionary leadership of R.I.T Alles, D.S. Senanayake College accommodates approximately 6,000 students across 157 classrooms, ranging from Grades 1 to 13. All classrooms have undergone transformation into friendly learning spaces, funded by the Government. The entire school is equipped with Wi-Fi, demonstrating a commitment to incorporating technology into education. “In response to the challenges presented by the Covid-19 pandemic and the five-year scholarship exam, there is a specific focus on addressing the crisis in primary education. The goal is to streamline the educational process, ensuring that our children’s education aligns with the technological advancements shaping the world.    Efforts have been implemented to minimise delays in education. Textbooks for the year 2024 have been printed, and the first batch of uniforms is scheduled to be received by the end of next month. Plans are also in progress to provide lunch to every student. In collaboration with UNESCO, coupons are being distributed for the production of school shoes for 800,000 children. This initiative is supported not only by government funds, but also aid from the French Government over the next four years,” he said.  Among the attendees were Public Security Minister Tiran Alles, Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayaka, MP Udaya Gammanpila and President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake. The event also saw the participation of Dr. Harsha Alles, family members, principals, school students and special guests. Pix by Manjula Dayawansa BY Amith Maduranga Gamage

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: COPE Chair’s son’s presence at meeting with SLC to be probed
author: Author not found
Content: An inquiry is to be initiated into the involvement of Kanishka Bandara, son of the Chairman of Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE), in a recent COPE meeting with  Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) officials, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena announced yesterday (16). The Speaker made this announcement, when the matter was brought to the attention of the House by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa.  Premadasa asserted that Bandara’s son had no rightful place among COPE members. Premadasa pressed for an immediate response, insisting on clarification about the circumstances surrounding Kanishka Bandara’s presence at the COPE meeting. “I am the Opposition Leader of this country. But, I was barred from attending the COPE meetings earlier. In such a backdrop, how come Bandara’s son was allowed to be at the COPE meeting? Who allowed him to do that?” Premadasa queried.  Premadasa called for temporary suspension of Bandara as COPE Chairman during the ongoing meetings with SLC, citing a potential conflict of interest.  Meanwhile, Premadasa presented documentation in Parliament indicating that Bandara serves as a consultant for SLC on the Kandy Cricket Campus Project. Additionally, another consultancy firm owned by Bandara provides services to SLC. Premadasa questioned whether Prof. Bandara should continue as the COPE Chairman, emphasising the lack of disclosure regarding his connection to SLC and the potential conflict of interest. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Bid to smuggle in illegal drugs thwarted
author: Author not found
Content: An attempt to smuggle into the country nearly six kg of poisonous and illegal drugs was thwarted by the Sri Lanka Customs and a person who had arrived to accept the parcel was arrested yesterday (16). The parcel of drugs, valued at Rs 65 million, had been sent from Canada to an address in Ganemulla.  Customs Media Spokesman Seewali Arukgoda stated that having inspected the parcel they had arrested the suspect who had arrived at the Bandaranaike International Airport to receive it. He added that arrested man was a representative of the owner of the parcel. Arukgoda noted that the precise value of the stock of harmful drugs had been estimated at their Income Inspection Unit in Orugodawatta. He added that the arrestee and the stock of drugs had been handed over to the PNB. Meanwhile, Police Department sources stated that a probe was underway to locate the whereabouts of the owner of the parcel who had dispatched it to Colombo from Canada. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Fingerprint machines at Health Ministry lie unused
author: Author not found
Content: Although 213 fingerprint machines, to register staff attendance had been purchased by the Ministry of Health in 2017, spending Rs 31 million, none of them is being utilised up to now. This information came to light during the recent COPA Sub-Committee meeting on the Ministry of Health held in Parliament.  According to the Health Ministry officials, the fingerprint machines could not be utilised due to vehement opposition from the health workers.  Meanwhile, it was revealed that a raw food supplier, who has refused to reimburse the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH), in Angoda, an overpaid sum, citing bankruptcy, is currently contracted as a supplier to a department under the Health Ministry itself.  Auditor General’s Department officials  present at the meeting, noted that the retrieval process for the unpaid dues from the supplier has become problematic due to the loopholes of the contract.  However, committee members raised concerns about why a supplier, declaring bankruptcy, while working for one entity of the Health Ministry, was permitted to continue supplying another entity under the Health Ministry. Sub-committee Chairman Major Pradeep Undugoda advised officials to cease protecting the supplier in question and urged them to devise a mechanism to recover the outstanding funds from the said supplier. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Ranjith Bandara defends his actions
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) Ranjith Bandara claimed his son attended the recent COPE meeting, with officials from the Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC), in his capacity as his coordinating secretary. He was responding to a query raised by Ceylon Today about the uproar in both Parliament and social media over his son attending the recent COPE meeting with SLC officials.   Bandara claimed that he had obtained permission starting from 13 October 2022 to communicate with his coordinating secretary for discussions, while acting as the COPE Chairman.  Bandara alleged the circulation of false information about his ‘hand signal’ during the COPE meeting and his son’s attendance, emphasising the inaccuracies in the reports. Regarding the ‘hand signal’ controversy, he explained that, due to a large number of people trying to question everyone simultaneously, he gestured for silence by placing his finger on his lips. He said, he is highly disappointed that the Opposition Leader and other MPs have misinterpreted this incident, characterising it as a ‘regrettable situation.’ BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Jaffna’s decades-old neem tree collapses
author: Author not found
Content: A decades-old neem tree, which had been a prominent feature in the Jaffna town landscape, recently fell victim to the harsh weather conditions, resulting in its collapsing.  The tree, situated on the roadside, in front of St. John’s Primary School, fell onto a vacant land much to the relief of local residents. Witnesses recall the tree’s roots being firmly embedded in the soil for several decades. In response to the incident, local authorities, including the Municipal Council, proceeded to trim the branches of the uprooted tree. By T. Pratheepan

title: Health DG to supervise Medical Supplies Division
author: Author not found
Content: Health Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta has placed all duties of the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) under the supervision of the Director General Health Services.  Informed sources said yesterday (16) that in a letter dated Tuesday (14) all duties of the MSD had been placed under the direct supervision of Director General Health Services (DGHS), Dr. Asela Gunawardena with immediate effect.  The move has been made in keeping with the instruction of Health Minister, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana. They said, the letter had been copied to the Health Minister, Additional Secretaries of Pharmaceutical Manufacturing, Supplies and Regulation Procurement, Chairpersons State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC) and National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) and Deputy Director General (Medical Supplies).   Meanwhile, President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva said, his outfit was pleased by the move as it showed that the President, Ranil Wickremesinghe and Health Minister, Dr. Pathirana had both accepted the reality of the situation within the Health Ministry. They have accepted that it is a den of thieves, he alleged.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President off to the Maldives
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (16) left the country to participate in the inauguration ceremony of Dr. Mohamed Muizzu, the President-elect of the Republic of Maldives, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said.  The United States of America has also declared that President Joseph R. Biden will dispatch a Presidential delegation to witness the swearing-in ceremony of President-elect Dr. Mohamed Muizzu. The presidential inauguration is set to take place on 17 November at the Republic Square. Earlier announcements indicated that provisions would be made to accommodate a thousand members of the public at the ceremony.

title: Another Judge recuses himself
author: Author not found
Content: The case against appointment of an Interim Committee, to run the affairs of Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC), has been re-fixed for next Monday (20), by the Court of Appeal, due to another Judge announcing, yesterday (16), that he would rescue from hearing the case. An Appellate Court Bench, comprising Justices D.N. Samarakoon and Neil Iddawela, issued the order during the morning session yesterday.  However, Justice Neil Iddawela recused himself from the case and this has led to the matter being forwarded to the President of the Court of Appeal, Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne, who appointed a new panel of Judges. The case is now due to be heard by an Appellate Court Bench comprising Justices Sobhitha Rajakaruna and D. N. Samarakoon. Notably, three Judges, including the Appeals Court President and Judge Neil Iddawela, have recused themselves from handling this particular case. On 7 November, the Court of Appeal issued a 14-day stay order, preventing the functioning of the seven-member Interim Committee and the corresponding Gazette Notification issued by Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe. This order was issued in response to a writ petition filed by the Chairman of SLC Shammi Silva. The Court has issued three stay orders in total preventing the operation of the Gazette appointing the Interim Committee, the committee members from acting in their positions, and any interference by the Sports Minister and other respondents in the activities of the Cricket Board. On 13 November, Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe filed a motion requesting the lifting of the stay order issued by the Court of Appeal, seeking to enable the operation of the seven-member Interim Committee appointed by him for the SLC and the corresponding Gazette Notification.  BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Five OnmaxDT Directors allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (16) allowed bail to the five Directors of ‘OnmaxDT’, who were charged with operating a fraudulent pyramid scheme.  Bail was set for each suspect at three sureties of Rs 10 million each. Additionally, the Magistrate ordered the accused individuals to report to the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) on the last Sunday of every month. The arrest of the five suspects, by the Financial Crimes Investigation Division (FCID) occurred on 3 November 2023. Earlier, on 24 August, the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) had taken action to prohibit nine entities, including ‘OnmaxDT,’ for engaging in pyramid schemes, which are explicitly forbidden in the country. The CBSL issued a warning, stating that any person involved in initiating, offering, promoting, advertising, conducting, financing, managing, or directing a prohibited type of pyramid scheme would be considered guilty of a punishable offense.  (MD)

title: SL’s Education Minister elected to UNESCO Board of Directors
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s Education Minister Dr. Susil Premajayantha was elected to the Executive Board, of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), for the term 2023-2027, during the 42nd General Conference of the Inter-Governmental Organisation in Paris, on 15 November 2023. Sri Lanka obtained 144 votes out of 188 member States, co-securing the third highest vote count from the region, with Bangladesh. The member States of the UNESCO elected six members, out of nine candidates from the Asia-Pacific Region to the UNESCO Executive Board. The other countries who were elected from the region are Pakistan, Indonesia, Bangladesh, Republic of Korea and Australia. Sri Lanka last served on the Executive Board from 2015 to 2019. The UNESCO contributes to peace and security by promoting international cooperation in education, sciences, culture, communication and information. It also contributes to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. Sri Lanka’s membership in UNESCO in 1949, soon after its independence, is demonstrative of the country’s firm commitment to the values and principles upheld by UNESCO to promote collaboration among nations through education, science and culture, in order to further universal respect for justice, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms of the peoples of the world.  Since the inception, Sri Lanka has played a significant role and made proactive contribution towards the furtherance of the mandate of the UNESCO. Sri Lanka National Commission for UNESCO is the government arm for implementing the UNESCO Agenda in Sri Lanka, under the guidance of the Ministry of Education.    The Ministry of Foreign Affairs together with the Sri Lanka Embassy in Paris and the Ministry of Education (National focal point) is pleased to have spearheaded the successful effort to ensure Sri Lanka’s election to UNESCO Executive Board.  It is notable that in the past months, Sri Lanka has been successful in consecutively being elected to 3 UN bodies/committees: Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW), Committee on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of their families (CMW), and the UNESCO Executive Board.

title: Meetings in Sydney to promote SL-Australia links
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan High Commissioner to Australia Chitranganee Wagiswara called on Minister for Multiculturalism, Small Business, Lands and Property and Sport of New South Wales (NSW) Steve Kamper on 7 November at his office. The Minister spoke of the large number of Sri Lankan expatriates who have made their mark in NSW and noted that most of the Sri Lankans are well-educated and well -integrated into Australian society. The minister has been closely involved with most of the activities organised by Sri Lankan associations in Sydney. The High Commissioner said she was pleased to note the encouraging sentiments expressed by the minister. The two sides discussed avenues for further cooperation and the need for the State Government’s assistance in promoting links between Australia and Sri Lanka especially in the trade sector. It was agreed that the High Commission and the State Minister’s Office would keep in close contact to facilitate and promote further links that would be mutually beneficial. During the visit to Sydney, President of the Sri Lanka and Australia Chamber of Commerce Kalum de Silva organised a Business Round Table on 8 November. Members from the Australia-Sri Lanka Business Council also attended the Round Table. In his introductory remarks, Kalum de Silva highlighted the ongoing activities and programmes that are in place between Sri Lanka and Australia. He also spoke of the visit to Sri Lanka by a business delegation organised in partnership with the Victoria State Government, the Aboriginal Economic Development Group (AEDG) and other stakeholders. Meetings were held in Sri Lanka with the Export Development Board, National Chamber of Commerce, SLASSCOM and other stakeholders as well as visits to places of interest. In addressing the participants at the Round Table, the High Commissioner outlined the areas of cooperation and potential that could be looked into by those interested in business and the investment sectors. Some of those present at the Round Table raised issues that need to be addressed in promoting trade and investment links and made suggestions on areas that could be pursued. The High Commissioner invited the members of the chambers and other interested parties to be in touch with the High Commission as well as the Consulate General of Sri Lanka in Melbourne so that any assistance sought and networking opportunities could be arranged.

title: SL Launches Nationally Determined Contributions Implementation Plan
author: Author not found
Content: From record-breaking temperatures to increasing extreme weather events, in 2022 alone Asia recorded 81 weather, climate, and water-related disasters that directly affected more than 50 million people, costing USD 36 billion in economic damages according to the World Meteorological Organisation’s State of the Climate in Asia report.  The global landscape is changing dramatically with the climate crisis becoming the new normal. Sri Lanka too is reeling from multiple crises and with climate change impacts already being experienced, recovery comes at a high cost. Sri Lanka annually spends LKR 50 billion on climate-induced post-disaster contingent liabilities that arise through floods, droughts, landslides, and storms including relief assistance for damages incurred to housing, infrastructure, agricultural crops, and businesses. The Paris Agreement lays out a collective framework for all countries to address climate change. But, reports come in that there is still limited progress in reducing the emissions gap by 2030, and there is a global call to scale up climate action to keep the 1.5°C objective within reach.  Responding to this call, led by the Ministry of Environment and supported by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)’s Climate Promise Phase II Project, Sri Lanka has ramped up their commitment to achieving the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and has outlined targets in an Implementation Plan till 2030, focusing on an integrated, holistic approach to enable transformative impact across sectors.  To launch Sri Lanka’s NDC Implementation Plan, a briefing was held this afternoon in collaboration with the Ministry of Environment. Speaking at this high-level forum, Dr. Anil Jasinghe, Secretary, Ministry of Environment said, “Sri Lanka accelerated its climate action through the launch of the Climate Prosperity Plan at COP27. The revised National Policy on Climate Change (2023) and 2050 Carbon Net Zero Road Map and Strategy are expected to be launched at COP28 this year. The NDCs act as the base for these strategic interventions and implementing the NDCs will lead to increasing Sri Lanka’s share of renewable energy, adopting adaptation interventions, and increasing our coping capacity and resilience to climate disasters”. Sharing progress on Sri Lanka’s NDCs, Dr. R.D.S. Jayathunga, Additional Secretary (Environment Development), Ministry of Environment highlighted, “The NDCs are a nexus and linking point through which we can reinforce our national sustainable development targets including the targets laid out in our National Environment Action Plan and National Adaptation Plan”. Operationalising the NDC Implementation Plan, especially the unconditional targets will require mobilising significant financial resources and exploring innovative financial instruments and different sources of finance including the private sector. Malin Herwig, Officer-in-Charge, UNDP said, “Smart investments in the NDC sectors and targets can stimulate economic recovery and set Sri Lanka on a trajectory to carbon neutral pathways and improve climate resilience over the longer term”. The NDC Implementation Plan sets out a blueprint for immediate climate action. With the first global stocktake of progress on the Paris Agreement scheduled for discussion at the 28th session of the Conference of Parties (COP28) in Dubai later this year, it is an opportunity for all countries to course correct and accelerate action to tackle the climate crisis.

title: Ambassador Dassanayake presents credentials to Colombian President
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the Federative Republic of Brazil, Sumith Dassanayake, who is concurrently accredited to the Republic of Colombia, presented his Letters of Credence to Colombian President Gustavo Francisco Petro Urrego, at the ‘The Casa de Nariño’ (Presidential Palace) on Wednesday, 8 November, in Bogota, Colombia. Ambassador Dassanayake conveyed greetings and best wishes of President Ranil Wickremesinghe and the Government of Sri Lanka to President Gustavo Francisco Petro Urrego, which was warmly reciprocated. Dassanayake appreciated the Colombian President for the efforts initiated to restore peace and stability in Colombia under his ‘Total Peace’ project. Prior to the Credential Ceremony, Ambassador Dassanayake called on Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs of Colombia Francisco Coy and handed over the Open Copies of his Credential papers. During the meeting with the Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Ambassador briefed on sociopolitical and economic developments taking place in Sri Lanka and also the progress Sri Lanka has made towards addressing the concerns of minority communities. Both the Vice Minister and the Ambassador highlighted the importance of consolidating relations between Sri Lanka and Colombia in diverse fields. Ambassador Dassanayake also held meetings with senior officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Colombia. During the meeting with the Director General for Asia Division Nelsy Munar, the Ambassador underlined the importance of expeditiously concluding the pending agreements between the two countries vis-à-vis Establishment of Political Consultations and Exemption for Visa for Diplomatic and Official Passport holders, to which the officials responded positively. At the meeting with the Director for United Nations and Human Rights, Ambassador Dassanayake underscored that both countries have cooperated at international fora since establishing formal diplomatic relations in 1988 and discussed cooperation in UNESCO matters. The Ambassador briefed on the efforts initiated by successive governments in Sri Lanka to address issues of minority communities and the Sri Lankan peace process facilitated by Norway.

title: Ali Sabry to attend Maritime Security and Safety Conference
author: Author not found
Content: On the invitation of Mauritius Minister of Foreign Affairs, Regional Integration, and International Trade, Maneesh Gobin, Foreign Minister Ali Sabry is set to participate in the 3rd Ministerial Conference on Maritime Security and Safety in the Western Indian Ocean today (16). The Western Indian Ocean holds significant global trade and commercial importance, featuring extensive interconnections with the global ocean space. The region confronts various threats to maritime security, including illicit traffic and smuggling, illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing, human trafficking, and marine pollution. Mauritius has taken a proactive role by organising the Ministerial Conference on Maritime Security and Safety in the Western Indian Ocean. The conference, held twice before in 2018 and 2019, provides a platform for high-level dialogue aimed at formulating tangible actions to enhance maritime capabilities in the region. During his visit to Mauritius, Minister Sabry will engage in a bilateral meeting with Minister Gobin to strengthen the existing ties between the two countries. Additionally, in his capacity as the Chair of the IORA Council of Ministers, Minister Sabry will visit the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) Secretariat to discuss the future direction of IORA. The focus will be on implementing decisions made at the 25th Committee of Senior Officials and the 23rd Council of Ministers meetings, hosted by Sri Lanka from 9-11 October, during which Sri Lanka assumed the Chairmanship of IORA.

title: Akila heaps praise on President
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Assistant Leader Akila Viraj Kariyawasam praised President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (16), stating that he possesses unmatched and unique characteristics of an internationally recognised leader, which was underscored in the budget proposals for the year 2024 that he presented in Parliament. Kariyawasam highlighted the numerous features of the 2024 budget proposal, emphasising its significant impact on improving the living standards of the average population. The allocation of Rs 183 billion for social security is three times higher than the Rs 60 billion set aside in previous budgets for the same purpose. Notably, 1.8 million people have been entitled to the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare programme through Budget 2024, surpassing the number of beneficiaries under the Samurdhi welfare program. Kariyawasam encouraged those eligible but not included to appeal to the relevant authorities in their respective areas. Speaking at the media briefing at UNP Headquarters, Sirikotha, Kariyawasam criticised the politically bankrupt Opposition and other factions for making misleading statements and comments against the budget, both inside and outside the parliament. He suggested that these factions are attempting to derive satisfaction from the situation for their political gain. Kariyawasam noted that Budget 2024 differs significantly from conventional budgets as the President had to balance meeting the recommendations of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) while simultaneously providing relief and concessions to the people. He highlighted the announcement of a Rs 10,000 salary increase for government employees, benefiting a total of 1.3 million State sector employees. Another noteworthy aspect of Budget 2024 is the reintroduction of the Suraksha free insurance scheme for students, previously introduced during the Good Governance Government led by the United National Front (UNF). This scheme will benefit 4.5 million students in government and private schools. Kariyawasam also emphasised the importance of establishing more universities to save significant foreign reserves spent on foreign education annually. Redirecting these funds towards other development purposes would be advantageous, he added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: CPA wants coconuts classified as export-oriented
author: Author not found
Content: The Coconut Planters Association (CPA) has urged the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries to classify coconut cultivation as an export-oriented crop. Concerns were raised during a recent meeting at the Ministry of Plantation, where the association highlighted issues arising in the sector. Despite coconut exports occurring, they are not officially recognised as export-oriented. During the meeting, the association addressed coconut cultivation, export, and domestic consumption. The country’s daily coconut requirement is 4.8 million, while daily production stands at three million. Consequently, 75 per cent of the total harvest is consumed domestically, leaving only 25 per cent for export. Coconut exports generate an annual income of USD 850 million. To boost this figure to two billion USD, the association stressed the need to designate coconut as a plantation crop for export. The international demand for coconut is rising, and the high quality of locally produced coconuts maintains a strong market demand. The association also proposed discussions between the minister and coconut industrialists to revise coconut prices in collaboration with the Treasury. Over the past decade, coconut cultivation has seen a continuous increase in cultivated land, with 100,000 acres of new coconut plantations established. The association emphasised the potential advantages of naming coconut as a targeted export-oriented plantation crop due to the high demand for coconut-related products. The discussion, attended by Ministry Secretary Janaka Dharmakirthi and other officials, aimed to address and find solutions to the challenges faced by the coconut industry.

title: New US Innovation Hub inaugurated in Batticaloa
author: Author not found
Content: US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung inaugurated a new American Innovation Hub (iHub) in Batticaloa on Wednesday (15) and welcomed Governor of the Eastern Province Senthil Thondaman to join as a special guest. A joint initiative between the US Embassy and Dream Space Academy, the iHub in Batticaloa aims to empower the youth of the Eastern Province, foster knowledge exchange, and promote people-to-people ties between the United States and Sri Lanka. In addition to the American iHub in Batticaloa, the US Embassy has interactive American Spaces in Colombo, Kandy, Jaffna, and Matara.   “The Batticaloa iHub, our fifth American Space in Sri Lanka, will be a key link to connect the Eastern Province with the United States, as well as to cultivate connections between young people across the entire island,” said US Ambassador Julie Chung. “As we celebrate 75 years of bilateral relations this year, this space holds great promise for the youth and academic institutions in the region, fostering innovation, leadership, education, and collaboration. This will be a space where all people feel comfortable and inspired, underlining the enduring and robust partnership between the United States and Sri Lanka.”   The Batticaloa iHub is designed to be a hub of intellectual engagement, providing access to a wide range of free-of-charge resources, including books, digital materials, multimedia content, and online databases. It serves as a space where students, researchers, and enthusiasts can gather to expand their horizons, engage in discussions, and collaborate on projects that contribute to educational and social development. The iHub also hosts a variety of free programmes, workshops, and events focused on areas such as English language learning, entrepreneurship, STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics), and American literature and history. These activities not only enhance participants’ skills but also foster a deeper appreciation for the diversity of thought and ideas.   Located at 7A Saravana Road, Kallady, Batticaloa, the Batticaloa iHub will be open to the public from Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. and Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon. All skills development programmes and activities at the iHub will be conducted free of charge.

title: SL High Commission in South Africa welcomes student delegation from University of Johannesburg
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of Sri Lanka welcomed a delegation from the University of Johannesburg as part of its cultural diplomacy programme, marking the second programme in this initiative. The student delegation was led by Head of the Department and Associate Professor in the Department of Politics and International Relations (DPIR) Prof. Bhaso Ndzendze. The delegation comprised 17 students, including PhD students, Master’s students, and undergraduates in the DPIR Department. During the session, the High Commission delivered a presentation containing geographical and economic facts about Sri Lanka, followed by tourism and cultural promotional video clips. A question-and-answer session ensued, during which students asked numerous questions about Sri Lanka and its economic relations with South Africa and the African Continent. Many students expressed their interest in advanced educational opportunities in Sri Lanka and their willingness to visit the country to gain first-hand experiences at educational and cultural sites. The delegation was treated to Sri Lankan traditional delicacies, including Kokis and Ceylon Tea.
