To launch Sri Lanka’s NDC Implementation Plan, a briefing was held this afternoon in collaboration with the Ministry of Environment.  Speaking at this high-level forum, Dr. Anil Jasinghe, Secretary, Ministry of Environment said, “Sri Lanka accelerated its climate action through the launch of the Climate Prosperity Plan at COP27. The revised National Policy on Climate Change (2023) and 2050 Carbon Net Zero Road Map and Strategy are expected to be launched at COP28 this year. The NDCs act as the base for these strategic interventions and implementing the NDCs will lead to increasing Sri Lanka’s share of renewable energy, adopting adaptation interventions and increasing our coping capacity and resilience to climate disasters.” Sharing progress on Sri Lanka’s NDCs, Dr. R.D.S. Jayathunga, Additional Secretary (Environment Development), Ministry of Environment highlighted, “The NDCs are a nexus and linking point through which we can reinforce our national sustainable development targets including the targets laid out in our National Environment Action Plan and National Adaptation Plan.” Operationalising the NDC Implementation Plan, especially the unconditional targets will require mobilising significant financial resources and exploring innovative financial instruments and different sources of finance including the private sector. Malin Herwig, Officer-In-Charge, UNDP said, “Smart investments in the NDC sectors and targets can stimulate economic recovery and set Sri Lanka on a trajectory to carbon neutral pathways and improve climate resilience over the longer term.” The NDC Implementation Plan sets out a blueprint for immediate climate action. With the first global stocktake of progress on the Paris Agreement scheduled for discussion at the 28th session of the Conference of Parties (COP28) in Dubai later this year, it is an opportunity for all countries to course correct and accelerate action to tackle the climate crisis. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SL cinema must achieve global acclaim – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has announced plans to establish a Public Entertainment Classification Board to replace the Public Performance Board. Speaking at the Presidential Film Awards 2023 held at the Nelum Pokuna Theatre on 14 November, he emphasised the need to eliminate the term ‘censorship’ from artistic creation. The President addressed the present challenge faced by artistes, as creative works are subject to various criminal laws. To address this issue, he proposed a programme where films and television productions would be submitted to the Classification Board before enforcement. President Wickremesinghe expressed the Government’s expectation to implement these measures starting next year. The President also highlighted the imperative need for Sri Lankan cinema to achieve global acclaim. In pursuit of this objective, the Government is actively involved in the comprehensive restructuring of the National Film Corporation and its affiliated institutions to seamlessly integrate with cutting-edge technologies. This year’s Presidential Film Awards ceremony holds special importance as it marks a return after a three-year hiatus. Out of 42 films screened in 2019 and 2020, a total of 44 awards were bestowed on actors and technicians. These awards were carefully selected by a jury comprising expert film critics and seven honorary doctors and professors. Additionally, nine more awards were presented during the ceremony, adding to the prestige of the occasion. During the event, Dr. Nanda Malani was honoured as the Best Playback Singer of 2020. President Wickremesinghe personally presented her with the award and acknowledged her significant achievement in receiving an award for background singing in Sri Lankan cinema at the Sarasavi Film Award in 1963. A ‘Yuga Abhimani’ special award was presented to K. Gunaratnam in recognition of exceptional contributions to cinema. The President also conferred ‘Swarnasingha’ awards to distinguished individuals, namely Chandran Rutnam, Suvineetha Weerasinghe, and Cyril Wickramage. Prestigious awards were given to notable individuals in the cinematic realm, with Kamal Addararachchi honoured as the Best Actor of 2019 and Kumara Thirimadura receiving the Best Actor award for 2020. Samadhi Laksiri was recognised as the Best Actress of 2019, and Neeta Fernando received the Best Actress award for 2020. Exceptional direction was acknowledged with Anuruddha Jayasinghe awarded Best Director for the year 2019, and Vishakesa Chandrasekharam receiving the Best Director award for 2020. Outstanding cinematic creations were also celebrated, with the Best Film of 2019 titled ‘Ginnen Upan Seethala’ and the Best Film of 2020 titled ‘The Newspaper,’ both receiving accolades from the President.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Harsha queries House stance on civic rights of ‘economic hitmen’
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Dr. Harsha de Silva yesterday raised a crucial question in Parliament as to what the stance of the House on the civic rights of ‘economic hitmen’ who were responsible for the ongoing economic crisis in the country, as indicated by the Supreme Court decision. Speaking during the second reading debate of the Appropriation Bill 2024, Dr. de Silva pointed out in Parliament that taxes have been implemented without proper reference in the budget speech, he highlighted the 18 per cent Value Added Tax (VAT) on all health equipment. Speaking further, he said, “This budget has been unlawfully presented. Our primary concern should be addressing how people can afford three meals a day, access medicine, and pay their electricity bills. According to the World Bank, poverty in Sri Lanka has surged from 13 per cent to 25 per cent. Census reports affirm that over fifty-six per cent of our country’s population is living in poverty”. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Namal calls for PSC on economic crisis
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa emphasising the party’s respect for the judiciary following the Supreme Court ruling holding former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa et al responsible for the economic crisis, said Parliament, being the authority responsible for financial powers, lawmaking and law enforcement was the most suitable forum for comprehensive discussions on the economic crisis. Rajapaksa proposed the establishment of a Parliamentary Select Committee (PSC) to conduct an in-depth analysis of the matter, emphasising the PSC’s ability to call for evidence, cover various aspects, and engage in extensive cross-examination as part of its ongoing inquiry into the economic crisis. He said, the Court decision, pointed out that the judiciary solely considered written evidence, with no oral testimony involved.  The Court verdict stemmed from a petition filed by Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) in collaboration with activists Chandra Jayaratne, Jehan Canagaretna, and Julian Bolling in the public interest, seeking action against those deemed accountable for the ongoing crisis in Sri Lanka. (MD)

title: Injunction on insurance payments lifted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, yesterday (15), lifted the injunction imposed on Janashakthi Insurance PLC, preventing the payment of insurance, to the family of deceased businessman Dinesh Schaffter for a week, at the previous hearing. This was when the case of the mysterious death of its former Director Dinesh Schaffter, was taken up. The Additional Magistrate stated that it was her view, that withholding the insurance payment to the relevant parties was not necessary anymore. She added that it was also her opinion that no other outside party, has attempted to obtain the compensation thus far. The Court had imposed the said injunction, following a request made by the CID. The CID had informed the Court, at the previous hearing, that as Schaffter’s demise has been proved to be an act of murder, it would be beneficial to the ongoing investigations, if an injunction is imposed for seven days, on the Insurance Companies, preventing them, from paying the requisite compensation, to the parties concerned. The millionaire businessman, who was found unconscious being tied to his car seat at the Borella Cemetery, was later admitted to the National Hospital, Colombo and died on 16 December, last year. Later, complaints were lodged by the family members of the victim, to the Borella Police and the CID, that they were suspicious of the circumstances of Schaffter’s death. Subsequently, Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya formed a five-member panel of forensic medical specialists, to probe in detail, the cause of death of the late businessman. The panel of forensic medical specialists later deemed, in their report to Court, that the death of the businessman concerned, had been a murder. The Court thereafter ordered the CID, to arrest suspects behind the crime and produce them in Court at the previous hearing. The remains of Dinesh Schaffter, which were exhumed, as per a Court order and kept at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, Galle, for the fresh post-mortem, conducted by the panel of forensic medical specialists, were reburied at the Jawatta Public Cemetery, on 4 November. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Rajapaksa brothers should’ve been instructed to pay compensation– Sumanthiran
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK) MP M.A. Sumanthiran yesterday (15) expressing his sentiments where the Supreme Court found former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, former Finance Minister Basil Rajapaksa and others responsible for the economic crisis, said they should have been instructed to compensate the 22 million citizens of Sri Lanka.  Drawing a parallel with the compensation orders given to individuals held responsible for the Easter Attacks, he stressed that the Rajapaksa brothers’ alleged misappropriation of public funds caused the economic collapse. According to Sumanthiran the purportedly embezzled funds are stashed abroad and he emphasised the need to remit this money to the Treasury to kickstart the economic recovery. He also insisted that every Sri Lankan citizen has the right to demand compensation and urged the Rajapaksas to bring the allegedly misappropriated funds back to Sri Lanka for the collective benefit of the nation’s economy. The ITAK MP made these remarks during the second reading debate of the Appropriation Bill 2024.  Speaking further, he raised objections to the President’s budget proposals. He contended that, according to the Constitution, matters of public finance were exclusively within the purview of Parliament.  Sumanthiran argued that an MP, who is not accountable to Parliament, should hold the position of Minister of Finance. He maintained that the President, not being an MP should not be entrusted with this portfolio, despite having the ability to attend sessions and respond to questions. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: COPE Chairman’s ‘hand signal’ infuriates Roshan, SJB
author: Author not found
Content: The cricket turmoil in Sri Lanka entered another tumultuous phase when Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe and main Opposition Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) yesterday (15) started to question the impartiality of Parliament watchdog the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE), when grilling Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) on Tuesday (14) during the committee meeting.  The verbal confrontation started when Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa alleged that Prof. Bandara behaved as if influenced by SLC. He said, “The COPE chairman, using hand signals, advised SLC members not to answer questions raised by MPs at Tuesday’s meeting. This was clearly visible in the videos being circulated over social media.” Chaos erupted in the Chamber as some committee members represent the Opposition and COPE chairman, Ranjith Bandara, exchanged accusations of mishandling the investigation into Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC). Certain COPE members advocated for the temporary removal of Prof. Bandara from the committee’s chairmanship until the SLC probe concluded. SJB MP Hesha Vithanage insisted that Prof. Bandara should not lead future probes on SLC, scheduled for 24, 27, and 28 November. “COPE has summoned SLC, and we requested that Prof. Bandara be removed temporarily and replaced with an acting chairman,” he added. MP S.M. Marikkar expressed reluctance, along with other COPE members, to participate in SLC probes under Prof. Bandara’s chairmanship. Accusing Professor Bandara of violating COPE members’ privileges, MP Chaminda Wijesiri suggested, “The COPE Chairman could be dealt with under Section 18 of the Privileges Act.” MP Premanath Dollawatta also called for the temporary removal of the COPE Chairman. In response, Prof. Bandara accused Opposition members of politicising the probe, stating, “COPE was expected to be independent as far as possible. However, there was a planned effort by Opposition members to politicise the probe on SLC.” Defending his actions, he added, “I put my fingers on my lips and asked the opposition MPs to be quiet as many members were speaking at the same time.” However, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana refrained from issuing any ruling on the matter. Meanwhile, Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe urged the Speaker to establish a distinct Parliamentary Committee, headed by an Opposition MP to undertake an inquiry into SLC as opposed to the ongoing investigations conducted by COPE.  Ransinghe expressed dissatisfaction with the COPE proceedings, asserting that during the summoning of SLC before COPE, irrelevant points were deliberated upon while crucial and pertinent issues were overlooked. “Based on the video footage of the COPE meeting on Tuesday (15), it is evident that discussions veered towards irrelevant subjects, sidestepping crucial and pertinent matters. I am sceptical if the COPE has been compromised in its dealings with SLC,” he alleged. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Two dead, four injured as school wall collapses on students
author: Author not found
Content: Two students, of Weragoda Vidyalaya, Wellampitiya, succumbed to critical injuries they sustained, when a wall of the school, on which a pipeline was fixed, collapsed on a group of students yesterday morning (15). The victims were admitted to hospital but two of them had passed away soon after admission, the National Hospital said. The first victim, a six-year-old, died yesterday morning while the second lost his life while receiving treatment at the Intensive Care Unit. Another student, who also sustained critical injuries is currently under close medical supervision. Six students were trapped beneath the wall and were immediately rushed to the National Hospital. At the time this edition went to press, four students were still receiving treatment at the accident ward of National Hospital Colombo. Pix by Manjula Dayawansa By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Kurunegala residents blocked from meeting RTI Commission
author: Author not found
Content: In a shocking twist, a group of individuals from Kurunegala, who suffered property damage due to the final stages of the Central Expressway construction, were denied access to the Right to Information (RTI) Commission at BMICH, Colombo, by the Police, citing alleged instructions from the RTI Commission itself. The group visited the BMICH yesterday (15) to submit appeals to the RTI Commission regarding the failure of the Road Development Authority (RDA) and the construction company to provide requested information about the construction. The people vehemently opposed this denial of access, expressing their dissatisfaction with the RTI’s actions, which are meant to safeguard the fundamental right of the public’s access to information.  They said this obstruction raises serious concerns about transparency and the citizens’ rights, demanding immediate clarification and redress. Sanjeewa Kulathilaka, speaking on behalf of the victims, deemed the behaviour of RTI regrettable and asserted that decisive measures would be taken against this decision. Following their protest, the affected individuals peacefully rallied in front of the conference hall, protesting the infringement of their rights.  Amidst this controversy, members of the Sri Lanka Young Journalists’ Association (SLYJA) filed a complaint with the police at the BMICH. In response, the legal officer of the RTI commission denied issuing any instructions to prevent public access to the commission premises. However, the Officer in Charge (OIC) at the police post presented a letter purportedly issued by the Director General of the commission, directing the police to restrict public access. However, the legal officer of the commission insisted that no such advice was issued.  The people then staged a protest in front of the BMICH. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Budget 2024 ignores malnutrition among children – MCPA
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) lamented that the 2024 Budget Proposals had not recognised health priorities, such as the state of malnutrition in the island.  MCPA President, Dr. Chamal Sanjeeve yesterday (15), referring to the Budget Proposals for 2024, presented on Monday (13), said it was regrettable that there were no welfare proposals which could at least remedy certain health related issues such as acute malnutrition among children. The budget for next year only paved the way for the meltdown of the free health service in the country as it was sans positive proposals for its (free health service) protection.   The MCPA President, lashing out, said the 2024 Budget merely accelerated the brain drain among doctors and other professional groups.  It is merely just another document without any programme for human resource management or innovative economy, he alleged noting that it would not be able to prevent the collapse of the health system. The only positive proposal in the 2024 budget is that the President had identified corruption among health officials and has focussed on preparing a series of special advisories for procurement process in the health service.  He said the budget failed to provide practical solutions for thelarge scale shortage of medicinal drugs and increase in pricesenvisaged for next year. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Heavy rains in Jaffna in past 24 hours
author: Author not found
Content: Over the last 24 hours, the Jaffna District encountered an overwhelming deluge, surpassing 100 millimetres of rainfall, according to T. Pratheepan, Officer-in-Charge at the Jaffna Regional Meteorological Department.  Simultaneously, the Department of Meteorology has issued a crucial advisory regarding strong winds and turbulent seas, effective until 3:00 p.m. today (16). The recorded rainfall between 8.30 a.m. on 14 November  and yesterday (15) revealed staggering figures, with areas like Achchuveli and Point Pedro reporting 175.4 mm and 170.8 mm respectively. Tellippalai witnessed 139.2 mm, while Mesalai and Tholpuram experienced 133 mm and 118 mm of rainfall respectively. Jaffna itself encountered 68.7 mm, while specific areas noted varying amounts: 58.8 mm at Jaffna Fort, 34.4 mm in Chavakachcheri, 24.7 mm in Amban, 6.8 mm in Nainatheevu, and 2.2 mm in Nedunthivu. Moving beyond Jaffna, Kilinochchi received 99.9 mm, Elephant Pass recorded 56.5 mm, and Akkarayan witnessed 128.4 mm of rainfall, according to the official’s report. In the meantime, the Assistant Director of Regional Office of Disaster Management Centre (DMC) for Jaffna District T. N. Sooriyarajah said yesterday (15) that along with the prevailing inclement weather conditions several low-lying areas in the Jaffna District have been inundated. Assistant Director Sooriyarajah expressed fear that if the inclement weather continues many other areas in the district could be inundated. Sooriyarajah said that a total of 94 families comprising 317 persons have been affected in the Jaffna District so far and added that a total of 59 families consisting of 97 persons in the Kopay Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division and 35 families comprising 120 persons in the Point Pedro DS Division are among them. He said that nine families comprising 36 persons have been evacuated and have been housed in a welfare centre until the water level recedes in those areas and added the police, DMC officers and tri-forces have been kept on alert to face any disastrous situation and to carry out relief works for affected people. Meanwhile, Assistant Director Mannar District DMC regional office K. Thileeban a total of 8 families comprising nearly 20 persons living in the low-lying areas in the Musali DS Division are in evacuation level as the areas they are living in have been submerged under the water.  Thileeban said that the police, try-forces and the DMC officials have been kept on alert to evacuate them from those areas, if the situation takes a turn for the worse. The Department of Meteorology further said a low-pressure system initially spotted over the Southeast Bay of Bengal adjacent to the Andaman and Nicobar Islands has now intensified into a depression. Presently, it is positioned over the West-central Bay of Bengal, situated around latitude 14.5°N and longitude 86.8°E. By T. Pratheepan (Jaffna Corr)  and Naalir Jamaldeen

title: ComBank embarks on another sustainability initiative planting 100,000 ‘Trees for Tomorrow’
author: Author not found
Content: The Commercial Bank of Ceylon has embarked on an ambitious nationwide tree planting campaign to plant 100,000 trees across Sri Lanka in three years, to help achieve country’s self-defined national climate pledges under the UN Paris Agreement, the bank said. Aptly titled ‘Trees for Tomorrow’ the programme commenced on 11 November 2023, four days ahead of National Tree Planting Day – 15 November – with the planting of 12,000 trees at 17 locations in 12 districts, achieving 12% of the target in a single day. More than 1,000 members of the staff of Commercial Bank participated in the tree planting. Among the locations chosen for the planting of trees on the launch day were Giguruwa in the Sinharaja Forest, the lower slopes of the Hantana Mountain Range, the precincts of the Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi in Anuradhapura, the Bellanwila – Attidiya Bird Sanctuary, the banks of the Tissamaharama Wewa, the Victoria Park in Nuwara Eliya and the grounds of several universities, the bank said and added the locations were chosen in consultation with Commercial Bank branches and the relevant stakeholders in the localities to ensure that the most appropriate areas are benefited, the Bank said. The types of plants were also selected according to the requirements of the geographic locationsin consultation with relevant stakeholders, to ensure proper climate transition. The Bank said, the project would continue in selected locations across the country, with Government agencies, universities, the Sri Lanka Army, Department of Forest Conservation and other institutions allocating the land, and supporting the initiative by helping the Bank to protect and maintain the trees till they are self-sustaining. Commenting on this latest commitment by the Bank to promote sustainability on a national scale, Commercial Bank Managing Director/CEO Sanath Manatunge said. “We have already proved that sustainability is not just a buzzword for Commercial Bank, by becoming the country’s first carbon neutral bank. But that was just a beginning for us, not an end. The Bank has funded many other projects to support the regeneration of the environment and combat climate change. It is our hope that a project on the scale of ‘Trees for Tomorrow’ will have a significant impact on improving air quality, rainfall and biodiversity. This initiative not only focuses on achieving the Bank’s environmental goals in the sustainability sphere, but is an initiative by the Bank as a responsible corporate citizen,to support the country achieve its climate goals.” Among other significant environment-related projects sponsored by the Commercial Bank are the reforestation of a 100-hectare swath of degraded habitat belonging to the Kandegama forest in the Dimbulagala Range of the Polonnaruwa District, a mangrove restoration project in Koggala, a marine turtle conservation initiative in Panama, a partnership with Biodiversity Sri Lanka (BSL) to maintain a stretch of beach in Kalutara and numerous beach clean-up projects.

title: Former Indian Navy Chief joins Global Virtual Vigil #be4peace
author: Author not found
Content: Dozens of organisations and individuals around the world joined a Virtual Global Vigil for Peace last Sunday #be4peace “to envision / pray for an end to the violence at home and elsewhere, for a ceasefire in Gaza and in Ukraine, and for hostages and child prisoners to be freed.” The non-performative, multifaith, worldwide event involved individuals as well as groups meditating or praying for peace or simply going into a reflective silence for 10 to 15 minutes at whatever place they were between 10 a.m. and 12 noon of their local time. The countries where vigils took place included Australia, Bangladesh, Croatia, France, India, Israel, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, Sri Lanka, UAE, USA, and UK, say the organisers, Southasia Peace Action Network, a cross-regional, cross-diasporic peace alliance, and the nonprofit Confederation of Voluntary Associations (COVA) based in Hyderabad, India. Nearly 50 participating organisations around the world and dozens of individuals are listed at the Southasia Peace website. Former Indian Navy Chief Admiral L. Ramdas and his life partner, the well known activist Lalita Ramdas, participated from their current base in Secunderabad, a twin city of Hyderabad in the heart of India. “We did our ten minutes of meditation for peace on Sunday 12 November Diwali, from 11.30 to 11.40 am,” Lalita Ramdas told Sapan News. She said, she explained to two caregivers – one a Christian and one a Muslim – “about the need for this joint silent prayer, and how many people were joining from across the world, and the power of such collective efforts to build a world of peace and love” they said and added “We were happy to join, and said it was a lovely feeling of calm that they experienced.”  The historic city of Hyderabad saw participation in the Global Vigil at two separate events. One was Remembrance Day, commemorated to honour soldiers of Hyderabad Lancers and other Commonwealth nations who lost their lives during World War I. Some 40 participants joined in a guided meditation and prayers of different faiths at the event, organised by the British Deputy High Commission in Hyderabad. They included diplomats, bureaucrats, faith leaders, professionals, academics, activists and journalists. The second venue for the Global Virtual Vigil in Hyderabad was at Anuraga Nilayam, a home for elders, where some 40 residents along with 35 guests including children and women also joined in the Global Virtual Vigil. Representing the Hindu, Muslim, Christian and Parsi faiths, residents also participated in multifaith celebrations for Diwali, Mahavir Nirvana Jains and Gurpurab Gurta Gaddi Sri Guru Granth Saheb Ji with prayers of different faiths, bhajans (devotional songs) and firecra ckers. Participants spoke about why the different festivals are celebrated that promote core human values. The programme concluded with multifaith culinary offerings, as is fitting in a city that is famous for its cuisine. (Sapan News)

title: ICTA forges strategic alliance with Brandix to fuel Sri Lanka’s startup ecosystem
author: Author not found
Content: In a commitment to catalyse Sri Lanka’s vibrant Startup Ecosystem, the Information and Communication Technology Agency (ICTA) renewed its partnership with Brandix Apparel Limited for the second consecutive year. This strategic alliance aims to bolster startups by providing essential funding and fostering their swift expansion. The primary focus is to fuel technological entrepreneurship within Sri Lanka, propelling its future digital economy, ICTA said and added under the umbrella of the Spiralation Startup Incubator, early-stage tech entrepreneurs receive comprehensive support. The initiative encompasses seed funding, specialised training, networking opportunities, and avenues for business promotion on both local and international fronts. The memorandum was signed by Professor Malik Ranasinghe, Chairman of ICTA, and Arjuna Sirinanda, the Managing Director of Fortude and Director – IT/Digital of Brandix, on 30 October 2023. As the national host of Global Entrepreneurship Week Sri Lanka, running from 13 – 19 November, ICTA remains committed to driving entrepreneurial endeavours within the country. ICTA has embraced a comprehensive, data-driven strategy for the development of the startup ecosystem, providing support to entrepreneurs at every stage of the startup lifecycle, from ideation to growth. The Spiralation initiative has been instrumental in aiding over 150 startups to date. Many of these startups have not only expanded their reach to more than 30 countries globally but have also collectively contributed to the creation of over 1,000 job opportunities. Brandix Apparel Ltd. has committed to funding a total of 10 million, in addition to providing expert guidance, training, and mentoring for selected Spiralation startups. This partnership aims to offer vital financial support to burgeoning startups in their journey towards development and growth, ICTA said. Professor Ranasinghe said, “ICTA stands as the foremost entity driving the nation’s digital transformation. Under the Digital Economy Pillar, our goal is to promote, encourage, and back technology-focused startups and innovation in Sri Lanka, aiming to establish 1,000 startups by 2025. We are thrilled to join forces with Brandix, whose support will be instrumental in realising this vision for our nation’s advancement.” In response to the memorandum,Sirinanda said, “At Brandix, our digital infrastructure is pivotal in delivering innovative solutions to our customers. Continuously exploring how technology can enhance our operations to offer superior products at competitive prices is our ongoing commitment. With this in mind, we are pleased to enter into a collaborative partnership with ICTA, a like-minded governmental organisation. Our joint efforts will serve to incubate the ideas of Sri Lankan technology entrepreneurs, potentially fostering the creation of world-class digital solutions.” Eng. Nalin Karunasinghe, Board Member of ICTA, Mahesh Perera, CEO of ICTA, Oshadha Senanayake, COO – Digital Transformation at Brandix, along with officials representing ICTA and Brandix Apparel Limited, and a group of technological entrepreneurs were also in attendance.

title: Pakistan Envoy visits Eastern Province
author: Author not found
Content: Major General (R) Umar Farooq Burki HI (M), High Commissioner of Pakistan visited the Eastern Province from 5 – 8 November 2023. During the visit he held various meetings with political, military and social activists of the Province and discussed issues related to mutual cooperation and social welfare. During his visit to Pottuvil and Oluvil, the High Commissioner distributed furniture to schools in the area. He also distributed ration bags to the needy and sports equipment to those who wanted them. The event reflects Pakistan’s commitment to social welfare, friendship and support to the Sri Lankan community irrespective of religion, gender and ethnicity.  The High Commissioner also distributed sewing machines to widows and deserving families of Kalmunai Kudy to enable them to earn a livelihood. The Ambassador thanked the people of the Eastern Province for the warmth that was shown during his visit. He pointed out that the Eastern Province was full of  opportunities for tourism, local small businesses, hoteliering, surfing and much more. “Pakistan and Sri Lanka can come together and learn from each other in so many sectors of mutual bilateral interest. Both countries have huge potential in tourism, education, dairy products, investment and business as well as joint training ventures”, he said and encouraged the local community especially women to identify some areas where Pakistan and Sri Lanka can enter into joint partnerships for the uplift of the local communities in Sri Lanka and Pakistan. During the visit, the High Commissioner also called on the Commander South Eastern Naval Command at Panama and Eastern Naval Commander at Trincomalee. They discussed issues of mutual interest to further strengthen  defence and military relations between the two countries.  S. M. M. Muszhaaraff, MP Eastern Province and Abdul Rahuman Mansur, President of Rahmath Foundation facilitated the tour.

title: PCoI on Election Reforms calls for public input
author: Author not found
Content: The Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) tasked with making recommendations on Election Law Reforms is inviting written submissions from the public, political parties, organisations, and interested individuals, the Commission said in a press release. Accordingly, the PCoI is seeking input on a variety of crucial topics. These include enhancing the representation of women and youth, shortening the period between election declaration and result release, exploring electronic voting options, enabling voting for Sri Lankans residing overseas, allowing individuals to run for both Provincial Councils and Parliament, facilitating postal voting for those serving in election-related capacities in Public Corporations/State-Owned Enterprises/Private Sector on election day, proposing proportional representation and a suitable mixed election system, fortifying the multi-party system, diminishing the influence of money in politics and preventing policy capture, ensuring leadership accountability to political party members, and defining the role of political parties in strengthening national unity.  The PCoI said it welcomes written submissions from the public, political parties, organisations, and interested individuals on these critical aspects of election law reform until December 15. Additionally, the PCoI is soliciting views on how political parties and independent groups should use the media, engage in public affairs, register, and maintain credibility and accountability to the public. Written submissions are accepted until 15 December, and can be sent via email to [email protected] or by post to the Secretary, Presidential Commission of Inquiry to Make Recommendations for Election Law Reforms, No. 21, SEMA Building, Janadhipathi Mawatha, Colombo 01. The PCoI assured that contact information and personal data in the submissions will be treated confidentially. The nine-member PCoI, chaired by former Chief Justice Priyasad Gerard Dep, was appointed on 15 October, to investigate and report on recommendations for amending election laws. The Commission’s powers were expanded through a special gazette notification on November 2, with the appointment of Alan Carmichael Vere David as the 10th member. (MD)

title: Owner of Isolez Biotech further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: The owner of the company that supplied substandard human immunoglobulin vials to the Ministry of Health’s Medical Supplies Division (MSD) was further remanded till 29 November. The 57-year-old owner of the pharmaceutical importing company Isolez Biotech Pharma, a resident of Raddolugama, was arrested by the CID on 31 October in Kompanna Veediya. The suspect, who was produced before the Maligakanda Magistrate, is accused of delivering substandard vials of human immunoglobulin.  Investigations showed that 22,500 such vials, produced using human blood and ordered with forged documentation, were initially thought to be imported but were, in fact, locally produced. The estimated value of the substandard human immunoglobulin consignment is nearly Rs 1 billion.                                                                                                    (MD)

title: Sudden stoppage of project leaves farmers in the lurch
author: Author not found
Content: The farmers of the Ranketha Farming Union and some 150 families of the Dambagolla village have been left in the lurch due to the ad-hoc stoppage of the reconstruction work of the Dambagollawewa Smart Project, at a cost of Rs 10 million. The Dambagollawewa Smart Project is being maintained by the Konwewa Govijana Seva Centre belonging to the Ambagaswewa Grama Seva Division in the Kahatagasdigiliya Divisional Secretariat of the Anuradhapura District. The farmers and villagers said that due to the ad-hoc manner in which the reconstruction work had been, some 270 acres of paddy fields had been left unattended. They charged that due to this situation invaluable public funds had been misappropriated or wasted by officials concerned and urged the authorities to look into their plight and address this situation. BY Chinthaka Krishantha Balasooriya – Galenbindunuwewa

title: Weera Foundation commemorates 8th death anniversary of Maduluwawe Sobitha Thera
author: Author not found
Content: A social welfare programme organised on the 8th death anniversary of Maduluwawe Sobitha Thera, founder of the International Weera Foundation, was held in Alapathgama village, Anuradhapura on 9 November 2023. Several houses built with financial donation of the Government of India and under the supervision of the Ministry of Housing Development were handed over to the people. Former Speaker of Sri Lanka, Karu Jayasuriya and Councillor of the Indian High Commissioner, Eldos Mathew were present at the handing over. Founded by Sobitha Thera in 1992, the Weera Foundation has been implementing various programmes to develop Alapathgama since 1996. Additionally, dry rations and school equipment were distributed among villagers on the same day under the patronage of Alawwe Gunarathana Thera, Chairman of Maha Karuna Foundation. Karu Jayasuriya, patron of the Foundation, presented a special award on behalf of the International Weera Foundation to Alawwe Gunarathana Thera in recognition of the social service he has rendered to the country.. By Induwara Athapattu

title: Self-check-in kiosks, baggage drop introduced at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: An event took place at the Departure Launch (DL) of the BIA yesterday to inaugurate the installation of eight self-check-in machines and a bag drop machine, aimed at significantly alleviating passenger congestion at the airport’s departure area. BIA sources indicated that the national carrier and Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Private Limited, jointly invested in setting up these machines. The self-check-in machines allow all passengers arriving at the BIA to conduct Seat Selection, Boarding Pass Printing, and Bag Tag Printing. After completing these tasks, passengers can then use the Bag Drop machine to submit their luggage before proceeding to the Immigration and Emigration Unit for declaration. According to BIA sources, passengers can complete each of these tasks within five minutes, enabling them to proceed to their respective flights without undue hassle. This initiative is expected to streamline the check-in process and enhance overall passenger experience at the BIA. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Fraudster released on bail
author: Author not found
Content: An individual, who was charged with forging a Power-of-Attorney, for a land measuring four acres and 23 perches in Pannala, was released on bail by the Kurunegala Magistrate’s Court. The suspect allegedly seized control of the property and subsequently sold it for Rs 16 million. This incident, initially reported to the Criminal Investigation Department in 2017, saw the arrest of the suspect, by the Commercial Crime Investigation Division of the Criminal Investigation Department (CID). The suspect, a 72-year-old resident of Athurugiriya, was released on bail in Rs 10,000 cash and a surety of Rs 500,000.

title: SC rules Gotabaya, MR, Basil et al responsible for economic crisis
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court, yesterday (14), determined that former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa and former Finance Minister Basil Rajapaksa and several others, were responsible for the economic crisis that Sri Lanka is currently grappling with. The Apex Court also deemed in its verdict that the actions resorted to by each of the aforementioned politicians had also flouted the Fundamental Rights of the citizens. On that account, the country’s highest Court ruled that the three Rajapaksa brothers, as well as former Central Bank Governors Ajith Nivard Cabraal and Prof. W.D. Lakshman, former Treasury Secretary S.R. Attygalle, former Presidential Secretary P.B. Jayasundera and the Monetary Board members of the CBSL, had violated the Fundamental Rights of the people. The Supreme Court thus instructed the respondents, to pay the petitioners, Court fees amounting to Rs 150,000. The aforesaid ruling was delivered, based on the majority view of the five-Judge Bench, presided over by Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya, in respect of two FR petitions filed by the former head of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, Chandra Jayaratne, former ace swimmer Julian Bolling, Prof. Mahima Mendis of the Open University and several others. The Apex Court Bench also comprised Justices Murdu Fernando, Vijith Malalgoda, Buwaneka Aluvihare and Priyantha Jayawardena. Justice Jayawardena, elaborating on the minority verdict of the Bench, mentioned that he was ordering for the invalidation of the petition, due to it not being filed during the requisite time period and as well due to a few other reasons. Explaining the majority view of the SC Bench, Chief Justice Jayasuriya, stressed that the respondents concerned, had held responsible posts within the Government, from November 2019 up to August last year. He observed that during the period in question, though the respondents mentioned had been aware of an imminent economic meltdown here, it had come to light during testimony, that they had not taken any concrete measures, to overcome that economic downturn. Chief Justice Jayasuriya, continuing, noted that as a result of the actions of the respondents concerned, the country had faced a crisis situation, with masses being unable to obtain essential services, such as electricity, gas, fuel, medicine etc and it had dragged the nation, into a veritable economic precipice. He added in the verdict, that despite constant warnings given to the respondents by the IMF, of an impending economic disaster in the country, the respondents had failed to pay heed to it. The Chief Justice also emphasised, that the Bench, was not prepared to accept the stance taken by the respondents that they had taken adequate precautions, to ward off an economic upheaval here.  The Supreme Court Bench lastly maintained, in its majority verdict, that the actions resorted to by the respondents concerned, had proven beyond a shadow of doubt, that they had acted in an irresponsible manner, whilst eroding the implicit trust placed in them by the public. The Court thus determined that the actions of the respondents, had violated the Fundamental Rights of the citizens, guaranteed in the Constitution. The petitioners had sought an investigation into the State officials responsible for the economic crisis. A panel of lawyers, including President’s Counsels Upul Jayasuriya and Chandana Jayasundara, appeared for the petitioners, while President’s Counsels Gamini Marapana, Shavindra Fernando and Anura Meddegoda PC represented the respondents.  Furthermore, Additional Solicitor General Nerin Pulle appeared for several respondents, including the Attorney General. President’s Counsel Romesh de Silva epresented the Monetary Board of the CBSL. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CEYPETCO to buy gasoil
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CEYPETCO) is seeking to buy term supplies of 500 ppm sulphur gasoil, for delivery between February and June next year, a tender document on the company’s website showed. The State-owned refiner is looking to buy a total of 1.12 million barrels, split into four 280,000-barrel lots, for delivery within the five-month window. The tender closes on 12 December, with validity up to 10 February that could be extended further, the document showed. The company in July sought term deliveries between November and February next year, which some traders saying it should have been awarded at high premiums to Middle East price quotes.  (Reuters)

title: UNP will contest Presidential Poll – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (14) said the United National Party (UNP) will contest the upcoming Elections with the hope of winning. He said their commitment to truth led to their exit from politics, making it their strongest standpoint. However, this strength was being bolstered by the influx of new faces, while other Government and opposition parties are also gearing up for the presidential contest. In a meeting with over 30 media representatives, at the Presidential Secretariat, he highlighted that a majority in Parliament supports the need for a strong Government, acknowledging the public’s desire to overcome the ongoing crisis. “I came alone, but we are three in the UNP and we cannot navigate this path independently. We require support from others. I seek that support, and together, we will progress,” stressed the President, who faced numerous questions during the session. He noted the positive outcomes achieved thus far and underscored the necessity for collaborative efforts to move forward. “My first job is to ensure the termination of bankruptcy. Once we’ve achieved that, we’ll unveil new plans and then assess our next steps. My presence here is to seek your support primarily in ending bankruptcy. We are nearing that, and I wish to navigate this without political contention or debate,” he said. “On the land issue concerning the upcountry plantation matter, the President said he wanted all regional plantation companies (RPCs) to involve the workers as tea out-growers. While acknowledging that some companies’ were moving in that direction, he said he wanted all companies to adopt the out-growers scheme following which they would negotiate as the land belonged to RPCs. Some companies are reluctant but I urge everyone to transit to out-growers. The government is undergoing a transformation in land ownership matters,” he pointed out.  “We have done away with the remnants of the Waste Land Ordinance, where all uncultivated lands are State-owned. He said even government officials were hesitant to grant freehold rights to the people. We’ve revoked the freehold status and are now reforming the entire landscape of government-owned land. Our focus is to provide ownership to those holding land development ordinance permits; it marks the first instance of such ownership being granted,” he added.   He expressed his intent to initiate negotiations after its implementation, stating, “The tea companies may perceive limited options, but I urge everyone to transit to out-growers.” “Our focus is to provide ownership to those holding land development ordinance permits; it marks the first instance of such ownership being granted,” the President said. He highlighted that Sri Lanka’s current situation was notably “much better than Gaza” and the country was moving forward. This he said, in response to the question related to the ethnic and religious divide in the North and the East over land and archeological sites that hampers the national reconciliation process the Government is keen on resolving.  The President emphasised on land matters, saying the Government was adhering to the 1985 Sri Lanka map regarding land disputes. “Where debates arise concerning land usage our decision is clear: if it’s a village on the 1985 map, it remains so,; if it’s designated as a forest, it retains that classification. We’re actively working to resolve these matters.”  Concerning the disputed Kurdundumalai Temple, the President said he had meetings with priests from different faiths, who expressed willingness to find common ground. “I have asked the Police to take action if any outsiders come to the site and create disturbances.”  He also highlighted empowering provincial committees in education, agricultural modernisation, tourism, and export industries, particularly for entities with turnovers of under Rs 600 million. These measures are implemented across all provinces, including the North, he said. Additionally, the President stated he was engaging with MPs regularly to resolve issues. When asked when would the projected end of the IMF loan facility, which was said to end by December 2023, but did not look so, the President responded that December had not concluded yet. He added that discussions with development partners were on, including China, which has presented successful proposals. ‘The IMF meeting is scheduled for 6 December.“Let’s wait and see what transpires by the end of December after the IMF meeting. Subsequently, we will engage with other development partners and explore opportunities with other partners and private partnerships once the IMF process concludes,” he said.

title: IRD ‘batch party’ hits a snag
author: Author not found
Content: Following Ceylon Today’s query about 20 Senior Commissioners going on leave to attend a batch get-together today (15), the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) cancelled the leave of all Senior Commissioners. Twenty out of the 23 senior commissioners of the IRD had planned to take leave today (15) for a ‘batch party’ at a hotel in Kadawatha, Ceylon Today reliably learns.  These officials considered as top management have taken leave from their daily duties and organised the event at a famous hotel in Kadawatha. Ceylon Today inquired from the hotel authorities and a manager confirmed that senior commissioners of the IRD had reserved a hotel in Kadawatha to celebrate the event today (15). However, Commissioner General of the Inland Revenue Department (Acting) D.U.A. Jayawardhana said he was not aware of such a situation but that if it was so, all leave of these employees would be cancelled forthwith. Jayawardhana also said several branches of the IRD were overseen by these senior commissioners, and if they take leave at the same time, operations in those branches will be disrupted. Upon inquiry, a senior commissioner of the IRD stated that the Acting Commissioner General of the department has sent a text message informing that all the senior commissioners’ leave was cancelled. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Cabinet nod vital for interim committee appointments – President
author: Author not found
Content: Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe appears to be facing increasing pressure, with President Ranil Wickremesinghe issuing a fresh directive on 14 November, stating that the appointment of interim committees now require Cabinet approval. A Cabinet sub-committee, tasked with examining the gazette issued by Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe, on the appointment of an Interim Committee for Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC), has been granted the authority to take decisions regarding the International Cricket Council’s (ICC) suspension of SLC’s membership. President Ranil Wickremesinghe has directed Minister Ali Sabry, the Chairman of the Ministerial Sub-Committee for Cricket, to lead efforts to lift the ICC suspension on Sri Lanka Cricket.  The ICC suspended SLC’s membership on 10 November, citing serious breaches of obligations, including the requirement for autonomous management and avoiding government interference. Conditions of the suspension will be decided by the ICC board after their meeting on 21 November. On 6 November, President Wickremesinghe appointed a four-member committee, chaired by Minister Ali Sabry, to investigate matters concerning SLC. This move followed Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe’s decision to appoint a seven-member Interim Committee for SLC, chaired by Arjuna Ranatunga. The Interim Committee was appointed to oversee SLC’s operations until further notice or until an election is held, as authorised by the Sports Law No. 25 of 1973. The President, unaware of the sports minister’s decision, formed the ministerial sub-committee to investigate the matter, with the consent of both the Sports Minister and the President. However, on 7 November, the Court of Appeal issued a 14-day stay order, preventing the operation of the Interim Committee and the relevant gazette notification, following a writ petition filed by SLC president Shammi Silva. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Court issues notice on JMO over Kotalawela death report
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Pasan Amarasinghe yesterday (14) issued notice on the Colombo Judicial Medical Officer (JMO), regarding not submitting the JMO report to Court, over the recent demise of former Chairman of Seylinco Group of Companies, Deshamanya Lalith Kotelawela. The landslide damaged two houses and prompted the evacuation of remaining residents in the area to safer locations. Police investigations were initiated to determine whether the missing family was trapped or had already evacuated. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Compensation disbursement only after entire Rs 311 M deposited – Rajapakshe
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said the disbursement of compensation to victims of the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, will commence only when all respondents, in the Fundamental Rights Petitions, deposit the total sum of Rs 311 million, as directed by the Supreme Court, to the Office of Reparations. In response to a query raised by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Kavinda Jayawardena, in Parliament on 14 November, the Minister revealed that the respondents of the fundamental rights petition have only paid Rs 36.8 million out of the ordered Rs 311 million. Former President Maithripala Sirisena has remitted only Rs15 million of the Rs100 million mandated by the Supreme Court, former IGP Pujith Jayasundara has paid Rs 1.72 million of Rs75 million, former Chief of State Intelligence Service DIG Nilantha Jayawardena has paid Rs 4.1 million of Rs 75 million, and former Defence Ministry Secretary Hemasiri Fernando has contributed Rs 5 million of the Rs 10 million he was ordered to pay. Minister Rajapakshe noted that former Chief of National Intelligence Sisira Mendis and the State are the only respondents who have deposited the full sum of five million rupees and one million rupees, respectively, as ordered by the Supreme Court. He added that the Office for Reparations has presented a compensation mechanism to Court, which will commence once the entire Rs 311 million, ordered by the Supreme Court is deposited with the Office for Reparations. Responding to MP Hector Appuhamy’s question regarding the allegations made in the recent Channel 4 documentary on the Easter Sunday Attacks and the progress of the special committee investigating the matter, Rajapakshe stated that the Attorney General is conducting investigations into the Channel 4 documentary to determine appropriate action. He also said the developments regarding the committee were currently unknown. The Minister clarified that following the Court decision and the recommendations of the Presidential committee, the respective departments will conduct their responsibilities in taking action and the Ministry of Justice holds no authority in this matter. President Ranil Wickremesinghe appointed a three-member committee on 10 September, led by retired Supreme Court Judge S. I. Imam, to investigate the allegations made in the Channel 4 documentary. The committee was advised by the President to submit the report before 31 October but it is still to be submitted. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Human-leopard conflict increasing
author: Author not found
Content: Although not as widely discussed as the Human-Elephant Conflict, there is a growing human-leopard conflict in the country as well, as highlighted by KumarasiriWijekoon, President of the Wildlife Rangers’ Association (WFA).  Speaking at a media briefing, Wijekoon said the increasing difficulty in protecting wildlife was primarily due to the ongoing and unreasonable forest clearing across the country. He claimed thatare forces working to weaken the Wildlife Department. Wijekoon alleged that these unseen influencers are facilitating the illegal clearance of approximately 1,000 acres in Welikanda and masking these actions as legitimate cultivation activities.  He expressed concern that unchecked deforestation in Welikanda has not only adversely affected the environment but has also intensified human-leopard conflicts in the region. “If this type of forest clearing continues, we will not be able to see any wild animals in the future. This is a very unfortunate situation,” he remarked.  The current situation in the country highlights the urgent need for conservation efforts and stricter measures to address environmental challenges and mitigate conflicts between humans and wildlife, he pointed out.  BY A. Vishvanath–Polonnaruwa

title: Doctors lash out at Budget 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors lashed out at the Budget saying that there was a yawning gap between what had been promised to medical professionals and what was read by the President when presenting the Budget for 2024.  Secretary to the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge yesterday (14) said there was no explanation from the authorities regarding that gap and deficiency seen by medical practitioners. “We do not see at first sight that the 2024 budget proposals have provided the solution required to give economic justice to medical professionals and maintain the health system by retaining them in the country.” The GMOA voicing its opinion on the budget proposals for 2024, in relation to the State health service, said there was no clarity in terms of providing economic justice to doctors from the facts that have come out from these 2024 documents., The Union’s Secretary noted that within the next few days his outfit expected a clarification from the authorities in this regard. Therefore, the GMOA will act with restraint within the next few days, he added.  However, there are plus points as well, such as fine tuning the procurement process, in medical education–where opportunities for post graduate studies have been increased, recognising issues pertaining to promotion of grade medical officers and widening the scope for medical research, he said.    The GMOA Secretary said they would act with restraint in the hope authorities would clarify the gaps with regard to his union’s main demand regarding the provision of economic justice for medical practitioners in the hope of encouraging them to remain with the country. ​Meanwhile, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) accused the President of having completely abandoned and avoided the health service in the 2024 budget. “While there were many serious problems related to patients and majority State health service employees, he had chosen to find solutions to demands of a chosen few, AHP President,” Ravi Kumudesh alleged, adding that it was clear that there is no understanding of the real problem facing the health service.  “The health service is suddenly mentioned in the budget speech only to pay some psychological bribes to medical trade unions which arouses serious suspicion that this attention is aimed at obtaining support for the large-scale cuts which are to be made in the health service next year. In relation to that, the number of drugs, surgical equipment and laboratory supplies that should be ordered for next year have been cut by 60 per cent,” he charged.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Arrest of Ramzy Razeek ruled as FR violation
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (14) ruled that the arrest of Ramzy Razeek, under the ICCPR Act in April 2020, violated his Fundamental Rights and ordered the State to compensate him with Rso 1 million.  Additionally, Chief Inspector B.M.A.S.K. Senaratne, the first respondent, and former CID Director DIG W. Thilakaratne, the second respondent, were individually directed to pay Rs 30,000 to the petitioner (Razeek) within one month, from their personal funds.  The Supreme Court further mandated that the Attorney General, the sixth respondent, issue a summary of the judgment’s principles to the Inspector General of Police within one month for dissemination among all Police officers, instructing them to strictly adhere to these principles. The State was also ordered to cover the petitioner’s legal costs. The case was heard by Justices Buwaneka Aluwihare, Yasantha Kodagoda, and Janak de Silva. Attorneys-at-Law Nuwan Bopage and Chathura Weththasinghe, instructed by Ramzi Bacha, represented the petitioner, while State Counsel Induni Punchihewa appeared for the first and third to sixth respondents. Ramzy Razeek, a social media commentator and member of Sri Lanka’s Muslim minority, was arrested on 9 April 2020, under the ICCPR Act and the Computer Crimes Act, a week after posting on Facebook advocating for an “ideological jihad” using the pen and keyboard to counter hate propaganda against Muslims by extremists from the Sinhalese Buddhist majority community. Released on bail on 17 September 2020, the criminal investigation against him remained open.  On 21 September 22023, the Colombo Magistrate’s Court released him from the case after three years. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Bodies of Balangoda landslide victims found
author: Author not found
Content: The bodies of the family of four, who went missing following a landslide that buried a house in Balangoda on Sunday night, were found yesterday (14). All four persons, a married couple and their two daughters, who were reported missing after the landslide in Gavaranhena in Balangoda on Sunday (12), were found during a search operation conducted with the assistance of disaster management officials, Sri Lanka Army personnel and local residents. Though the verdict into the Magisterial Inquest and Post-Mortem into the victim’s death was due to be delivered in Court yesterday, the Additional Magistrate deferred the announcement of the verdict to 27 November, due to not receiving the JMO’s report. The hearing of testimony, into the post-mortem on Kotelawela’s death, concluded at the previous hearing and thus far eight witnesses have testified in Court. A case had been filed before the said Court, following a complaint lodged with the Bambalapitiya Police, by Sherin Wijeratne, a sister of the deceased’s wife, who alleged that she was highly suspicious, of her brother-in-law’s death. During the post-mortem, it had been revealed that Kotelawela had passed away, while being treated at a private hospice in Colombo, on 21 October. The witnesses had mentioned, during testimony, that though the former head of the Seylinco Group had resided at the address No. 28, Elibank Road, Colombo 5, he had been forcibly removed to the address No. 13, Dickman Lane, Colombo 4, at the behest of a few who had served under him, at which point they had detained him against his wishes. They added during evidence, that two groups of persons, who had previously served under Kotelawela, had forcibly taken hold of his property and that they had detained him in that manner, at the Dickman Lane address, to accomplish their ulterior motives. BY Nimal Bandagiriya – Opanayake
