title: Human-leopard conflict increasing
author: Author not found
Content: Although not as widely discussed as the Human-Elephant Conflict, there is a growing human-leopard conflict in the country as well, as highlighted by KumarasiriWijekoon, President of the Wildlife Rangers’ Association (WFA).  Speaking at a media briefing, Wijekoon said the increasing difficulty in protecting wildlife was primarily due to the ongoing and unreasonable forest clearing across the country. He claimed thatare forces working to weaken the Wildlife Department. Wijekoon alleged that these unseen influencers are facilitating the illegal clearance of approximately 1,000 acres in Welikanda and masking these actions as legitimate cultivation activities.  He expressed concern that unchecked deforestation in Welikanda has not only adversely affected the environment but has also intensified human-leopard conflicts in the region. “If this type of forest clearing continues, we will not be able to see any wild animals in the future. This is a very unfortunate situation,” he remarked.  The current situation in the country highlights the urgent need for conservation efforts and stricter measures to address environmental challenges and mitigate conflicts between humans and wildlife, he pointed out.  BY A. Vishvanath–Polonnaruwa

title: Doctors lash out at Budget 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors lashed out at the Budget saying that there was a yawning gap between what had been promised to medical professionals and what was read by the President when presenting the Budget for 2024.  Secretary to the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge yesterday (14) said there was no explanation from the authorities regarding that gap and deficiency seen by medical practitioners. “We do not see at first sight that the 2024 budget proposals have provided the solution required to give economic justice to medical professionals and maintain the health system by retaining them in the country.” The GMOA voicing its opinion on the budget proposals for 2024, in relation to the State health service, said there was no clarity in terms of providing economic justice to doctors from the facts that have come out from these 2024 documents., The Union’s Secretary noted that within the next few days his outfit expected a clarification from the authorities in this regard. Therefore, the GMOA will act with restraint within the next few days, he added.  However, there are plus points as well, such as fine tuning the procurement process, in medical education–where opportunities for post graduate studies have been increased, recognising issues pertaining to promotion of grade medical officers and widening the scope for medical research, he said.    The GMOA Secretary said they would act with restraint in the hope authorities would clarify the gaps with regard to his union’s main demand regarding the provision of economic justice for medical practitioners in the hope of encouraging them to remain with the country. ​Meanwhile, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) accused the President of having completely abandoned and avoided the health service in the 2024 budget. “While there were many serious problems related to patients and majority State health service employees, he had chosen to find solutions to demands of a chosen few, AHP President,” Ravi Kumudesh alleged, adding that it was clear that there is no understanding of the real problem facing the health service.  “The health service is suddenly mentioned in the budget speech only to pay some psychological bribes to medical trade unions which arouses serious suspicion that this attention is aimed at obtaining support for the large-scale cuts which are to be made in the health service next year. In relation to that, the number of drugs, surgical equipment and laboratory supplies that should be ordered for next year have been cut by 60 per cent,” he charged.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Indian CEO Forum engages Dr. Shashi Tharoor
author: Author not found
Content: Awarded by the World Economic Forum as ‘Global Leader of Tomorrow’, Dr. Shashi Tharoor, who is a distinguished diplomat, author, and former Under-Secretary-General of the United Nations, visited Sri Lanka in early November 2023. Participating in a gathering of influential leaders from the business community in Colombo hosted by the Indian CEO Forum, Dr. Tharoor shared his invaluable insights and experiences. During the event, Dr. Tharoor drew from his extensive experience at the United Nations to discuss critical issues and challenges facing both the global community and Sri Lanka. He highlighted several key points and offered suggestions for the improvement and betterment of Sri Lanka’s future. Dr. Tharoor’s visit was a remarkable opportunity for the local business leaders to gain from his vast reservoir of knowledge and wisdom. “In today’s interconnected world, we must work together to address pressing issues,” remarked Dr. Tharoor. “Sri Lanka has a bright future, and we must harness the potential of its vibrant business community to create a better future for all.” The Indian CEO Forum (ICF) has supported the Sri Lankan economy by way of bringing substantial investments into the country, export earnings, employment generation, and building the brand of Sri Lanka to the outside world. ICF, known for its commitment to fostering innovation and collaboration between India and Sri Lanka, was delighted to have Dr. Tharoor as a guest of honour. His insights into international diplomacy, sustainable development, and global affairs provided valuable guidance to the Forum’s members and guests. Dr. Tharoor’s visit was marked by fruitful discussions, a sense of camaraderie, and a shared vision for a more prosperous and inclusive Sri Lanka. His words resonated with the audience and left a lasting impact on all those in attendance. The Indian CEO Forum expressed its gratitude to Dr. Tharoor for his invaluable contributions to this gathering. His visit has undoubtedly inspired the Sri Lankan business community to strive for greater heights and work together to achieve a brighter future for the nation.

title: EthicalX spearheads Entrepreneurs’ Forum on Innovative and Climate-friendly Food Systems
author: Author not found
Content: The Entrepreneurs’ Forum on Innovative and Climate-friendly Food Systems, held on 1 November as a part of the Innovative and Climate-friendly Food Summit hosted by SLYCAN Trust at the Cinnamon Grand Colombo, brought together a diverse and dynamic group of entrepreneurs, industry leaders, and stakeholders to discuss, collaborate, and drive change in the realm of sustainable food systems. Addressing the opening of the forum, SLYCAN Trust Global Executive Director, Attorney-at-Law Vositha Wijenayake emphasised the need to support ethical, sustainable, and climate-friendly food entrepreneurship. “It is important to identify and support approaches that contribute to building long-term resilience in food systems, as well as pave the way for more ethical approaches in our food choices. Food entrepreneurship that is built on cruelty-free, ethical, and sustainable choices provides futuristic and innovative solutions at local, national, and international levels,” she said. Mattias Söderberg from DanChurchAid, who addressed the event as a guest speaker, joined the forum virtually from Denmark and spoke about plant-based food in relation to climate change and the transition in food systems in the European Union. In the course of his address, he shed light on Denmark’s transition from a heavily meat-based culture to more people identifying as vegetarian or vegan in the past decade.  Food entrepreneurs share their stories Following this, food entrepreneurs from Sri Lanka shared their stories on the challenges they faced in trying to be more climate-friendly and how their products stood at the forefront of innovation in this food system. The entrepreneurs who took the stage came from a wide spectrum of sectors, while sharing a common vision of ensuring sustainable and ethical plant-based food production. The speaker line-up included C.T. Gajanaka (CFO, Harischandra Mills), Dinali Dandeniya (Co-founder of Cafe Kumbuk and Founder of Mama D’s), Sahan Bakmeewewa (Founder of Plant-based Studios), Dulara De Alwis (Founder of Ceylon Export & Trading Ltd.), Anushka Kahawela (Co-founder, Veganly Life), and Sulochana Udayakumar (Founder, Vegan Kitchen by Sulo). Innovation was a recurring theme throughout the forum, with participants showcasing pioneering technologies, practices, and business models that are reshaping the food industry. The entrepreneurs shared their solutions, such as plant-based protein alternatives and advanced supply chain management, highlighting the potential for transformative change in the sector. The event served as a pivotal platform for innovators committed to addressing pressing challenges in food production and consumption, sharing solutions from Sri Lanka to the world. Supporting food entrepreneurship SLYCAN Trust, through its Food Systems Work Programme and EthicalX Climate & Innovation Hub, is actively working towards contributing to the need for knowledge-sharing, technical support provision, and addressing gaps in investment-related needs for supporting food entrepreneurship in Sri Lanka. Through its inclusive business model in partnership with CLIMAFUGE, the Food Systems Work Programme and EthicalX, SLYCAN Trust supports ethical and climate-friendly business practices in food systems, as well as inclusive entrepreneurship at local, national and global levels. The forum also saw the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Ministry of Environment and SLYCAN Trust, which aims to expand and further the activities related to supporting entrepreneurship in Sri Lanka, with a special focus on eco- and climate-friendly entrepreneurship at the local level. SLYCAN Trust is a non-profit think-tank working on climate change, sustainable development, biodiversity and ecosystem conservation, animal welfare, and social justice, including gender and youth empowerment. Its work spans the national, regional, and global levels, from policy analysis and evidence-based research to implementation on the ground across Asia and Africa. EthicalX: Climate & Innovation Hub is an initiative by SLYCAN Trust which supports ethical, sustainable, and climate-friendly entrepreneurship through activities related to capacity-building, provision of technical support and expertise, and raising seed funding with a special focus on vulnerable communities, women, and youth. EthicalX works towards building long-term climate resilience, sustainable development, and economic empowerment to scale up entrepreneurship development and support vulnerable communities, women and youth.

title: Salaün Holidays unveils Sri Lanka: A Journey of Wonders
author: Author not found
Content: In a splendid collaboration, Salaün Holidays, one of France’s largest travel agents, brought down 39 of its agents on a captivating tour of Sri Lanka from 9 to 15 November. With Connaissance De Ceylan as the official ground handling agent and SriLankan Airlines as the official airline partner, the week-long excursion promised an immersive and seamless experience. Salaün Holidays, boasting 145 travel agencies across France, strategically selected Sri Lanka as a featured destination. The group explored Kandy, Dambulla, Sigiriya, Polonnaruwa, and Weligama, showcasing the island’s rich cultural heritage and natural beauty. The flawlessly executed itinerary ensured a glimpse of the historical wonders to coastal landscapes.  The tour is to conclude in style with a Farewell dinner at the Sri Lanka Institute of Tourism and Hotel Management (SLITHM) allowing the agents to reflect on their experiences, savour Sri Lankan cuisine, and celebrate the success of a remarkable journey. Salaün Holidays’ exploration of Sri Lanka not only showcased the destination’s beauty but also demonstrated the successful collaboration between the travel giant, Connaissance De Ceylan, and SriLankan Airlines. This venture not only strengthens existing ties but also opens new horizons for travellers seeking extraordinary experiences with Salaün Holidays in Sri Lanka.

title: Agriculture Ministry approves export-based strawberry cultivation project
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Agriculture approved a project presented by a group of local investors to grow strawberries with the aim of export. A discussion was held at the Ministry of Agriculture with the participation of Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries, Mahinda Amaraweera and Minister of Transport and Mass Media, Dr. Bandula Gunawardana, where approval was given to implement the project as soon as possible. Although there is high demand for strawberries in the world market, there is still minimal demand for strawberries grown in our country because they are not cultivated using modern technology. Sri Lanka is ranked 57th among strawberry-exporting countries. Strawberries have a rapidly increasing market annually and are an extremely popular soft fruit. It was agreed to provide one hectare of land belonging to the Ministry of Agriculture in Nuwara Eliya under the first phase of the pilot project. According to the success of the project, up to 10 hectares can be given for strawberry cultivation if needed. By using the new technology, if strawberries are cultivated, it is possible to earn an income of USD 117,600 from one hectare per year. It is also possible to get a yield of 120,000 kg from one hectare. Also, the amount invested to cultivate one hectare is Rs 250 million. Amaraweera said the upliftment of agriculture will be prioritised next year. The Minister also mentioned that the President has made a great contribution to the agriculture of this country by presenting the new Budget proposals. The Minister also mentioned that the Government is prioritising introducing new technology in agriculture. Secretary of the Ministry Janaka Dharmakeerthi also participated in this discussion.

title: Galadari Hotels Lanka PLC Signs BOI Agreement
author: Author not found
Content: Galadari Hotels Lanka PLC successfully signed an agreement with the Board of Investment (BOI) of Sri Lanka as the first step towards the property’s refurbishment process. Galadari Colombo has, over the years, built up an enviable reputation in the hospitality industry and proudly boasts over 39 years of exceptional service. The company has entered into two agreements which include the Hotel Development Services Agreement (HDSA) which will later be followed by a Hotel Management Agreement (HMA) with Radisson Hotels Asia Pacific Investments Pte. Ltd. The property will go through a total transformation which will enable the hotel to set new standards solidifying its high competitiveness in the industry. A world-renowned architectural company based in Hong Kong will overlook the overall design process of the property. The first phase, which includes a project cost estimated at USD 33.5 million will include 200 rooms, restaurant outlets, a guest lobby and common areas and a completely revamped hotel facade. The second phase will commence one year after the completion of phase one. After completion, the hotel will see an elevated star-class status. The BOI signoff is the first of a series of events that will be taking place as the hotel starts its new journey, which will ultimately lead to an engagement with Radisson Hotels Asia Pacific Investments Pte. Ltd. to manage Galadari Hotel Colombo under a new brand name.

title: Correlation between Physical Education and Human Wellness
author: Author not found
Content: Physical Education (PE) is a field of study that focuses on the development of physical fitness and the ability to perform physical activities. It is an essential component of the education system, aiming to promote lifelong health and well-being through regular physical activity. The key aspects of physical education include:  a) Physical Fitness: PE programmes often include activities and exercises designed to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength, flexibility, and overall physical health. b) Skill Development: Physical education classes teach students a variety of motor skills and sports-related activities. This can include team sports like soccer, basketball and volleyball, as well as individual activities like running, swimming, and gymnastics. c) Health Education: PE is not just about physical activity; it also involves educating students about the importance of a healthy lifestyle. It includes discussions about nutrition, the effects of exercise on mental health, and the prevention of injuries.  d) Lifelong Physical Activity: The goal of physical education is not only to promote fitness during the school years but also to instil a love for physical activity that will continue throughout a person’s life. This can contribute to the prevention of chronic diseases associated with a sedentary lifestyle.  e) Social Skills: Many physical education activities involve teamwork and cooperation, promoting social skills and the ability to work effectively with others. Team sports, in particular, provide opportunities for leadership and communication development.  f) Cognitive Benefits: Physical activity has been linked to improved cognitive function and academic performance. Regular exercise is believed to enhance concentration, memory, and the ability to learn.  g) Healthy Habits: By emphasising the importance of regular physical activity, physical education programmes encourage the development of healthy habits that can carry over into adulthood. Physical education is typically a mandatory part of primary and secondary education in many countries. Aims and objectives The purpose of physical education (PE) is multifaceted and extends beyond merely engaging in physical activities. The primary objectives of physical education include: a) Promoting Physical Fitness: One of the central purposes of PE is to enhance and maintain physical fitness. Physical activities and exercises are designed to improve cardiovascular health, muscular strength, flexibility, and overall well-being. b) Developing Motor Skills: PE focuses on the development of fundamental motor skills such as running, jumping, throwing, and catching. These skills are foundational for more advanced physical activities and contribute to overall coordination and movement proficiency.  c) Encouraging a Healthy Lifestyle: Physical education aims to instil the importance of a healthy and active lifestyle. By engaging in regular physical activity during childhood and adolescence, individuals are more likely to adopt and maintain healthy habits throughout their lives.  d) Preventing Health Issues: Regular physical activity has been associated with a reduced risk of various health issues, including obesity, heart disease, and certain mental health disorders. PE contributes to the prevention of sedentary lifestyles and associated health problems.  e) Teaching Sportsmanship and Teamwork: Many physical education activities involve team sports, which provide opportunities to learn about sportsmanship, cooperation, leadership, and effective communication. These skills are valuable not only in sports but also in various aspects of life. f) Building Social Skills: Physical education often involves group activities, fostering social interaction and teamwork. Students learn to work together, resolve conflicts, and develop interpersonal skills that are essential for successful collaboration in various contexts.  g) Cultivating Lifelong Habits: The goal of physical education is to instil a love for physical activity that extends beyond the school years. By promoting enjoyable and varied forms of exercise, PE encourages individuals to adopt and maintain an active lifestyle throughout their lives.  h) Providing Enjoyable Physical Experiences: Physical education should be enjoyable and provide students with positive experiences related to physical activity. This can contribute to a positive attitude towards exercise and a lifelong appreciation for maintaining good health. In summary, the purpose of physical education is to contribute to the holistic development of individuals by promoting physical fitness, motor skill development, healthy lifestyles, and positive social and cognitive outcomes. It plays a crucial role in shaping attitudes and behaviours related to physical activity, ultimately impacting the overall well-being of individuals. Physical education and health Physical education (PE) and health education are closely related fields, often overlapping in their goals and objectives. While physical education primarily focuses on physical activity, fitness, and skill development, health education addresses a broader spectrum of health-related topics, including lifestyle choices, nutrition, mental health, and overall well-being. The key connections between physical education and health are:  a) Overall Well-being: Both physical education and health education contribute to the holistic well-being of individuals. Physical education promotes physical fitness, motor skills, and cardiovascular health, while health education addresses mental, emotional, and social well-being.  b) Physical Fitness:Physical education is a key component of promoting physical fitness through regular exercise and structured physical activities. Health education complements this by providing information on the importance of maintaining physical fitness for overall health and preventing chronic diseases. c) Lifestyle Choices: Health education often includes topics related to healthy lifestyle choices, such as balanced nutrition, proper sleep, stress management, and avoiding harmful substances. Physical education reinforces healthy lifestyle choices through the promotion of regular physical activity and exercise. d) Prevention of Health Issues: Both fields contribute to the prevention of health issues. Physical education helps prevent obesity, cardiovascular diseases, and other physical health problems, while health education addresses broader health concerns.  e) Mental Health: Physical activity has been linked to improved mental health, including reduced stress and anxiety and improved mood. Health education may cover mental health topics, such as stress management, coping strategies, and the importance of seeking support when needed. f) Nutrition Education: Health education often includes nutrition education, providing information about healthy eating habits and the impact of diet on overall health. Physical education programmes may incorporate discussions about nutrition to complement the physical activity component. g) Healthy Habits: Both physical and health education aim to instil healthy habits from an early age. This includes fostering a positive attitude towards physical activity, making healthy food choices, and adopting a balanced lifestyle. h) Preventive Health Measures: Health education may cover preventive health measures, such as vaccinations and regular health check-ups. Physical education contributes to preventive health measures by promoting regular exercise and physical fitness, which can prevent various health issues. i) Social and Emotional Well-being: Physical education often includes team sports and activities that contribute to the development of social and emotional skills. By integrating physical education and health education, schools and educational institutions can offer a comprehensive approach to the well-being of students, addressing both physical and mental health aspects and promoting lifelong healthy habits. About the Author: Dr. Rajkumar Singh is a Youth Motivator, presently a Professor of Political Science along with the Dean, Student’s Welfare (DSW), at B.N. Mandal University, Madhepura (Bihar), India. His 25 Books published in addition to about 1,000 Articles in National and International Journals and Daily Newspapers from 25 Foreign countries. By Dr. Rajkumar Singh

title: CEB TAKESTO e-BILLING
author: Author not found
Content: In a move away from traditional paper billing, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) is ushering in the CEB e-billing system for consumers in various regions, said CEB media spokesman and Engineer Noel Priyantha. The e-billing initiative is set to roll out initially in Dehiwala, Kelaniya, Sri Jayewardenepura, Matara and Ambalangoda. Residents in these areas will exclusively receive their electricity bills in a digital format, either through SMS or email. Noel Priyantha emphasised the importance of consumers nationwide swiftly registering for this convenient service, as the issuance of printed paper bills will be gradually phased out in the coming months. To register, consumers can simply send an SMS with the message ‘REG’ followed by their CEB account number to 1987. Alternatively, online registration is available at http://ebill.ceb.lk, where users can follow the provided instructions. The CEB seeks the cooperation of consumers across the country to ensure the seamless implementation of the e-billing system, which is anticipated to save approximately 100 million sheets of paper annually. This eco-friendly transition aligns with broader sustainability goals and signifies a positive step towards reducing environmental impact.

title: Probe launched into discovery of elephant’s head
author: Author not found
Content: Assistant Director of the Uva Zone Wildlife Conservation Department, Upul Indrajith, has initiated an investigation into the discovery of a wild elephant’s severed head in Kirindi Oya, Wellawaya on 13 November. Local residents reported finding the elephant’s severed head at Huwangamuwa in Kirindi Oya. Subsequently, the Police and the Army launched a joint search operation to locate the remaining parts of the elephant, but as of the latest update, they have not made any discoveries. Wildlife Officers speculate that a wild elephant, which may have entered cultivated areas in the region, could have been fatally shot, and its body parts disposed of in the Kirindi Oya. BY Nadun Gunathilaka – Bibile

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Kanaka Herath inaugurates ‘Global Entrepreneurship Week’
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of State for Technology, Kanaka Herath, inaugurated the ‘Global Entrepreneurship Week’, urging departing youth and entrepreneurs to actively contribute to the nation’s economic development in line with the objectives of the DIGIECON 2030 initiative. During the official launch of the Global Entrepreneurship Week, themed ‘Entrepreneurs Thrive Here’ from 13 November, Minister Herath highlighted the ongoing efforts of the Digi-Econ programme to cultivate a digital economy by fostering a conducive environment for entrepreneurial endeavours. Throughout the week, diverse activities, including conferences, seminars, workshops, and discussions, unfolded across the nation, covering sectors such as entrepreneurship, innovation, start-ups, business economic systems, education, digital interaction, and policies. These events aimed to evaluate and empower innovative entrepreneurs, fostering collaboration among local entrepreneurs, investers, researchers, and industry experts. Over 60 partners in Sri Lanka registered more than 100 distinct operations during the Global Entrepreneurship Week. Minister Herath shared insights on the country’s startup ecosystem, citing a current value of approximately USD 244 million, with a targeted increase to one billion, as per the Start-up Genome report. He emphasised the transformative impact of technology on daily life and the programme’s objective to establish a robust digital economy. In collaboration with the Ministry of Industry, the Digi-Econ programme extends its outreach to district levels, inviting young professionals and departing entrepreneurs to engage and contribute to this initiative. The programme aims to counteract brain drain and bolster the nation’s economic foundation. Thilaka Jayasundara, Secretary of the Ministry of Industry, emphasised the ministry’s commitment to nurturing youth, especially ‘Generation Z’, through initiatives focused on small and medium-scale industries. The goal is to elevate the contribution of women and youth enterprises to 25% of the country’s economy by 2030. Notable figures such as Suresh de Mel, National Ambassador of the Global Entrepreneurship Network (GEN), Mahesha Amarasuriya, Director of Mastercard Sri Lanka, Sachindra Samararatne, Ambassador of Global Entrepreneurship Week (GEW) and the Deputy Chief Digital Economy Officer of the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka participated, underscoring the collaborative commitment to fostering entrepreneurship in Sri Lanka.

title: Budget 2024 at a glance
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, serving as the Minister of Finance, delivered the 2024 Budget to Parliament under the theme “Prelude to a Bright Future.” Here is a comprehensive summary of the budget speech, encompassing key tax proposals. In presenting the 2024 budget, President Ranil Wickremesinghe called for an end to the propagation of political illusions and urged a collective commitment to the country’s improvement. He expressed confidence that persisting on the challenging course would create a more favourable economic environment, citing the country’s trajectory in the past year. President Ranil Wickremesinghe highlighted the removal of legal obstacles hindering the integration of large-scale, low-cost renewable energy into the primary electricity grid. Efforts are underway to restructure the inefficient Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) into a more streamlined institution. The President announced a monthly allocation of Rs 383 billion for three primary expenditures, including public sector salaries, public welfare, and loan interest payments. He revealed a significant reduction in the bank overdraft from Rs 900 billion in 2021 to Rs 70 billion. Emphasising the need to increase State income from 10% to 15% of the GDP, the President highlighted proposals to address shortcomings, including tax evasion. The President highlighted the allocation of the Nuwara Eliya Post Office to the tourism industry as part of a broader development plan. He stressed the importance of utilising historic buildings, such as the Galle Post Office, for foreign exchange earning purposes in the tourism industry. The President noted a turnaround in Sri Lanka’s primary budget deficit, achieving a surplus in the first half of 2023. He highlighted achievements in lowering inflation and replenishing foreign exchange reserves. Starting from January 2024, the Cost of Living Allowance for government employees will be augmented by an additional Rs10,000. Government pensioners will receive a monthly Cost of Living Allowance increment of Rs 2,500. Provisions for Police Officers’ food and lodging allowances will be adjusted for those engaged in remote duties. The disaster loan facility for State sector employees, restricted last season, will be reinstated effective from 1 January, 2024. The allocation for social security programmes has tripled to Rs 183 billion for 2024. Retroactive payments will be made to eligible ‘Aswesuma’ beneficiaries in cases of delayed relief benefits. The Disability and Kidney Disease Allowance will increase by Rs 2,500, and the monthly allowance for senior citizens will be raised to Rs 3,000. A biannual review of insurance beneficiaries will be conducted to promptly add new families to the beneficiary list. The allocation for 2024 will be increased to Rs 205 billion for relief programmes and allowances benefiting disabled individuals, kidney patients, and the elderly. A dedicated provision of Rs10 billion is earmarked to systematically continue the monthly allowance of Rs 4,500 provided to pregnant women. A concessional credit facility of Rs30 billion is established to fortify the upliftment programme for small and medium enterprises that faced challenges in the previous season. President Ranil Wickremesinghe announced a programme to grant full private ownership of traditional farms to farmers who have lost their ancestral properties. The collection of rent from houses provided on an interest basis to urban low-income families will be entirely halted, and efforts will be made to transfer ownership of these houses to the occupants. An allocation of Rs 4 billion is designated for the initial step of acquiring land rights for constructing houses for people residing in plantations. A provision of Rs 600 million is allocated to facilitate the swift completion of the Bim Saviya programme. An allocation of 11,250 million rupees will be designated for the District Coordination Committees to recommence the Decentralised Budget Programme, the President said. In 2024, a comprehensive ten-year multi-purpose rural and community development programme will be launched, covering 89 Divisional Secretariats in hilly areas. A provision of Rs 10 billion is allocated for this initiative in the year 2024. A novel mechanism for project approval and the establishment of a State committee to review new projects has been introduced. No government funds will be allocated to any project outside of this system. The Budget for 2024 includes an increased allocation for capital expenditure, reaching Rs1,260 billion, equivalent to 4% of the gross national product. An additional allocation of Rs 55 billion will be directed towards completing projects that were temporarily halted due to the economic crisis. Starting in 2024, a specialised unit will be established in each ministry to ensure the timely fulfilment of development projects. A dedicated allocation of Rs 10 billion is designated for the rehabilitation of deteriorated rural roads, and Rs 2,000 million will be allocated for the restoration of roads and bridges damaged by natural disasters. Prioritising water projects, decentralised funds, and foreign loan assistance will be deployed to address drinking water issues in every province of the country. A comprehensive series of education reforms will be enacted, leading to the establishment of the National Higher Education Council, the National Higher Education Commission & the National Skills Commission. Initiatives will be taken to ensure that every student who passes the Advanced Level Examination has the opportunity to pursue university education. Four new universities, including the Sitawaka University of Science and Technology, Kurunegala Institute of Technology University under the Kotelawala Defence University, University of Management Technology & International Climate Change University, will be established. Rules for the conversion of private higher education institutions into universities are adopted. An allocation of Rs01 billion for the year 2024 is earmarked to establish the National University of Education by merging 19 colleges of education. A new University of Technology will be established in Kandy under the guidance of IIT University, Chennai, India. State universities will undergo an improvement programme to align with the new era, starting with the University of Peradeniya. A provision of Rs 500 million will be allocated for 2024. The Department of Allergy and Immunology at the University of Sri Jayewardenepura is elevated to the status of the National Institute of Allergy and Immunology, with an allocation of Rs 40 million in 2024. Educational institutions recognised globally are permitted to establish universities in Sri Lanka, subject to a set of robust rules and regulations to regulate private universities. The interest-free loan facility for students in non-government universities will continue, and a concessional student loan system through commercial banks is proposed for implementation. The University Grants Commission and Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission will be merged to establish the National Higher Education Commission. The merging of institutions, including the Vocational Training Authority and National Apprenticeship and Industrial Training, will lead to the creation of the National Skills Commission. Vocational Education Institutions under the Central Government will be transferred to the Provincial Councils, and Provincial Boards of Education will be established to enhance and modernise skill development. A fund for the improvement of technical professional skills will be established, with an additional allocation of Rs 450 million for 2024, in addition to the current allocation. A collaborative training programme with private institutions in the field of information technology will be initiated for graduates seeking employment, with an allocated provision of Rs 750 million. Training programmes will also be implemented for other skill shortage areas such as construction, nursing services & tourism. A sum of Rs 150 million will be allocated to the Sri Lanka Foundation for the technical and physical modernisation activities required to provide training courses for adults working in the public and private sectors to acquire new knowledge. A national programmes to expand English literacy in Sri Lanka will be prepared, with an initial allocation of Rs 500 million to kick-start the programme. The Suraksha Students Insurance Scheme will be re-implemented. Specific guidelines for the procurement of medicines will be issued, and a separate agency for the same will be established. Steps will be taken to increase investment in medical and health research, including the initial phase of strengthening the infrastructure and laboratory facilities of the Medical Research Institute, with an allocation of Rs 75 million. An allocation of Rs 25 million for the year 2024 is earmarked to enhance the facilities of the National Drug Quality Research Laboratory. An allocation of Rs 300 million is allocated for establishing a cardiopulmonary resuscitation unit at the Badulla Teaching Hospital and for acquiring necessary equipment. The introduction of a promotion system that caters to both specialist doctors and graded doctors will be implemented. Measures will be taken to strengthen and promote indigenous medicine. The Indigenous Medicine Division of the Ministry of Health and Ayurvedic Medicines Corporation will facilitate investors for medicinal plants with international demand. An allocation of Rs 100 million will be made for establishing Ayurvedic treatment centres in tourist hotels and resorts in line with the Sri Lankan wellness concept. All agricultural service centres will be upgraded to agricultural modernisation centres. Starting from the 2024 season, the government will allocate Rs 2,500 million to implement a joint programme involving the private sector, farmers & agronomists. Existing legal impediments to conducting alternative cultivations on uncultivated lands will be removed. A total of 300,000 acres of land, owned by public enterprises, Mahaweli “A” and “B” Zones, Land Reform Commission, etc., will be allocated for large-scale agricultural activities. An allocation of Rs 500 million is designated to enhance fisheries in the North Sea, representing 35% of the country’s total fish harvest. A sum of Rs 200 million will be allocated for the development of the freshwater fishing industry. The responsibility for the rehabilitation of small tanks will be transferred to farmers’ organisations in respective areas. A special programme is initiated to increase milk production by 53% within 5 years, with the active participation of the private sector. A new programme is launched to boost the construction sector, starting with the construction of the new building complex for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as its pilot project. A provision of Rs 100 million is allocated to implement national branding efforts to reclaim Sri Lanka’s status as a top tourist destination and an attractive investment hub. Formulation and implementation of an inclusive national logistics policy are initiated to leverage Sri Lanka’s strategic location as a significant economic asset. Introduction of gender budgeting and related legislation, along with legislation for the empowerment of women. An allocation of Rs 300 million is designated for a special programme to economically empower the women and youth community engaged in the handloom industry. An allocation of Rs 2,000 million is made to meet the resettlement needs of homeless families in the North East regions. Additionally, an extra Rs 500 million will expedite the housing programme and provide relief to families left without homes. An additional Rs 1,000 million is appropriated, in addition to the Rs 1,500 million already allocated in the Appropriation Act, to expedite the payment of compensation to the missing and victims of the internal conflict in the North & East. To address the drinking water problem in the Jaffna area, preliminary work on the Paaliaru water project will commence in the first half of 2024, with an allocation of Rs 250 million. An allocation of Rs 500 million is designated for the development of Pooneryn town. A State contribution of Rs 500 million is allocated to restart the construction of the Galle District Auditorium, which was halted halfway. An allocation of Rs 250 million is made as a government contribution for the construction of a Bandarawela economic centre and the provision of necessary infrastructure. An additional Rs 2,500 million will be allocated, in addition to the budget allocation already given, for the Lower Malwatu Oya project. An allocation of Rs 400 million is designated for initiating the establishment of the Maha Vihara University and the preliminary work of the construction programme. An allocation of Rs 100 million is allocated for the year 2024 in the programme to establish a modern international Buddhist library in Anuradhapura. A Sri Lanka Buddhist Museum will be established in Kandy for research and cultural promotion activities focusing on the Buddhist civilisation of Sri Lanka. A provision of Rs 200 million will be allocated for the year 2024 for its construction. An allocation of Rs 1.5 billion is earmarked in the budget for the development of school cricket in the island, providing necessary facilities to players at the provincial level, with priority given to schools and provinces with fewer facilities. Initiation of a pilot project to run 200 electric buses jointly with the Transport Board in the Western Province. The Kandy Multimodal Transport Centre project will start in January 2024, and Rs 1.5 billion will be allocated for the development of its access roads. The complete renovation of the railway line from Anuradhapura to Mihintale will be completed by January 2024, with an allocation of Rs 200 million. It is proposed to utilise the revenue collected by the Provincial Councils as capital expenditure for the development of the province. The promotion of the export industry by the Provincial Councils is proposed, and the limited powers of the Provincial Councils regarding industries under the Industrial Promotion Act No. 46 of 1990 will be amended. An allocation of Rs700 million is designated for the establishment of the National Janasabha Secretariat. Rs 2 billion will be allocated for 2024 for the preliminary work of the construction of Hingurakgoda International Airport. The gem industry has not yet been able to achieve full capacity, and for that, a general programme should be prepared and implemented in the next three months.Rs 250 million will be allocated for the basic work of implementing the Gin Ganga water management programme to prevent floods in the Galle district. This year’s budget allocates Rs 3,000 billion to implement the restructuring of foreign debt and to settle international sovereign bonds under the restructuring of foreign debt. Rs 450 billion allocated to support the capital improvement process in the banking system. Stricter rules regarding the appointment of chief officers and board members of State banks will be introduced. The Public Debt Management Act, Public Finance Management Act, Public Asset Management Act and State Enterprise Reform Law will be presented to Parliament in December or in the first quarter of 2024. The new growth model in Sri Lanka is based on a digitalised social market economy with more efficient, equitable, green growth. Establishing the Sri Lanka Revenue Authority to increase the effectiveness of revenue administration by using international experience to boost government revenue. As a basic step to improve global market relations, there will be a gradual removal of non-tariff import taxes, including import CESS, port & airport tax over a period of 3-5 years. Reorganisation of the National Trade Facilitation Committee headed by the Treasury Secretary, as well as modernisation of Customs laws. An amount of Rs 200 million has been earmarked for the National Single Window to bring all the border management agencies into a single digital platform and to facilitate seamless and timely processing of trade-related regulatory documents. Rs100 million will be allocated for the year 2024 to create a more convenient environment for investors, including automating the functions of all government agencies that provide services to investors. The establishment of a digital authority empowered with full control to provide necessary input and guidance for the digitisation of the public sector is proposed. Additionally, a Technical Innovation Council will be formed to coordinate public sector expert institutions and civil society, fostering technological innovation. Simultaneously, a National Centre for Artificial Intelligence is envisioned to drive economic and social transformation based on AI, with an allocation of 3 billion rupees for these three institutions. An allocation of 8 billion rupees is proposed for the formulation of a national research policy aimed at advancing research in Sri Lanka. A new tourism culture will be nurtured through the implementation of a long-term programme under “Visit Sri Lanka” commencing in 2024. Strengthening Provincial Tourism Boards by entrusting them with the responsibility of meeting the basic needs of the tourism sector at the provincial level is planned. An allocation of Rs750 million will be dedicated to the development of related facilities. To attract both local and foreign tourists, Rs600 million will be allocated for the modernisation of government resorts and the promotion of tourism. A three-year programme for the development of the Pinnawala-Kithulgala tourism corridor will be initiated, with an allocation of Rs750 million. The forward vision of the Sustainable Development Agenda will be underpinned by the climate resilience vision. The establishment of a Climate Change Commission is proposed. Rs 250 million is allocated for a programme ensuring future food security, supporting small and medium-scale food processors. Amendments are proposed  to the Inland Revenue Act, introducing penal provisions for failure to provide tax returns, and enforcing stricter measures for tax audit documentation, with a 6-month time limit for evidence in Sri Lanka and 9 months for other evidence. Mandatory submission of Tax Payer Identification Number certificates will be introduced. The Government is planning a tax administration system for the Sri Lanka Excise Department, including an online licensing system and a new Excise Permit System. Policies are proposed for the Sri Lanka Excise Department, such as establishing liquor quality standards, adjusting excise licence fees, promoting investment in new alcohol products, allowing the sale of local liquor in duty-free shops, and implementing the Revenue Administration System for Excise Department (RASED) by October 2024. For the Sri Lanka Customs,  the development of risk management capabilities are proposed  using modern software, the installation of a system to prevent incorrect invoicing and the identification of Key Performance Indicators (KPI) related to basic administrative functions.

title: Sajith calls Budget 2024 ‘primitive’
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa claimed the President had insulted Buddhism by misquoting Buddhist teachings during his Budget speech in Parliament. He criticised the Government’s failure to meet the revenue targets outlined in the International Monetary Fund’s (IMF) agreement, leading to the inability to secure the second tranche from the IMF. Premadasa characterised the presented budget as “primitive” due to these financial shortcomings. Premadasa made these remarks during a media briefing, following the President’s Budget proposals for the year 2024 in Parliament yesterday (13). He accused the President of attempting to deceive the public and suggested that the President’s references in the speech depicted a luxurious lifestyle enjoyed by the current government’s leaders. The Opposition Leader emphasised the need for the government to fulfil promises made in the 2022 budget before introducing new programmes to benefit working-class citizens in the current budget. He highlighted challenges in implementing previous budget promises, citing various reasons for the difficulties faced. Referring to a statement from the Presidential Media Unit (PMD), Premadasa noted a discrepancy between the living expense allowance mentioned in the budget proposal (from 7,000 to 17,000) and the PMD announcement (from 7,500 to 10,000). He alleged that certain aspects of the budget speech were leaked to the media before being presented to MPs, raising concerns about parliamentary supremacy. Premadasa contended that the entire 2024 budget was part of a propaganda campaign in favour of the government for upcoming elections. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Namal unhappy with Budget proposals
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa raised concerns, alleging that a significant portion of the proposals presented in yesterday’s (13) 2024 budget speech had already been included in last year’s budget. Addressing the media, after President Ranil Wickremesinghe delivered the 2024 Budget Speech in Parliament, MP Rajapaksa questioned whether these repeated proposals had been effectively implemented at the grassroots level. Expressing skepticism, he remarked, “It raises questions as to whether this year’s budget will merely be confined to a speech.” MP Rajapaksa indicated that his party would scrutinise the budget’s details in the upcoming period and would present their observations during the parliamentary debate. He hinted at the possibility of suggesting alternative ideas and policies during this process, with a keen interest on whether the President would be receptive to these proposals. Highlighting the significance of their party’s policies being integrated into the budget proposals, Rajapaksa emphasised that, given the Finance Minister’s role within the SLPP government, the budget should reflect their overarching policies and priorities. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: No relief for people in the Budget – GL
author: Author not found
Content: Parliamentarian Professor G.L. Peiris expressed dissatisfaction with Budget 2024 presented by President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (13), saying that there is no relief for the people in the Budget. He made this remark, speaking to the media after the Budget Speech. According to the MP, government employees will receive the allowance of Rs 10,000 starting from April, and pensioners will also have to wait until April to receive their allowance of Rs 2,500. Professor Peiris highlighted the surge in the cost of living, attributing it to the increase of Value Added Tax (VAT) before presenting the budget 2024. He further mentioned that the prices of all goods would increase from today due to VAT. Professor Peiris emphasised the gravity of the situation, noting that 700,000 people are currently affected, and there is no resolution to these issues in this year’s budget. Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Landslide kills family of four
author: Author not found
Content: Four members of a family were buried alive by a landslide at Bambaragala Kanda. The family were residents of the Wegintenna village in the Gawaranhena Division, within the Weligepola Divisional Secretariat. Three other nearby houses had also been damaged. The landslide had taken place at around 6:45 p.m. on 12 November. The deceased were been the parents and their two daughters, who were studying at Dharmaraja Vidyalaya, Hunuwala. Following the landslide, the house occupied by the victims had been completely buried in soil and rocks. The Army and Police had been involved in searching for the remains of the four deceased persons. Six other, residing in high-risk areas, were evacuated before tragedy had struck. The NBRO is conducting further inquiries into the calamity and dry rations were provided to displaced families by the Army. Residents said the area where the landslide had occurred had previously not been identified as an area prone to such catastrophes by the officials concerned. Sources stated that the landslide had extended up to the Arambe River and the DMC is continuing to monitor the situation and issue warnings of landslides and earth slips to the public in light of the ongoing torrential rains prevalent in the country. BY Nimal Bandagiriya – Opanayaka

title: SC rules commercial banks entitled to parate law
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court, in a unanimous decision, yesterday (13), has overturned the ruling of the five-Judge Supreme Court Bench in the case of Chelliah v Ramachandran and held that banks are entitled to parate execution concerning any property mortgaged to them. Parate execution, rooted in Roman Dutch Law, grants licensed commercial banks the authority to sell mortgaged property as collateral without Court intervention. The Recovery of Loans by Banks (Special Provisions) Act of 1990 expanded this power to all private commercial banks, aiming to enhance the security and flexibility of the banking system by expediting debt recovery and discouraging deliberate defaults. In the Chelliah v Ramachandran case, a prior decision by five judges of the Supreme Court (four to one) concluded that banks were not entitled to parate execution when the property had been mortgaged by a person other than the actual borrower. This decision significantly prejudiced the banks, causing a halt in the recovery process for the money lent and due to be repaid, leading to a substantial impediment in the circulation of money. Given these adverse circumstances, Counsel petitioned for a reconsideration of the Chelliah v Ramachandran judgment to a seven-Judge Supreme Court bench. The bench, comprising Justices Buwaneka Aluwihare, Murdu N.B. Fernando, S. Thurairaja, E.A.G.R. Amarasekara, A.H.M.D. Nawaz, Kumudini Wickremasinghe, and Mahinda Samayawardhena, unanimously held that the majority judgment in Chelliah v Ramachandran was incorrect and, therefore, overruled it. Justice Nawaz and Justice Samayawardene, who wrote lengthy and separate judgments highlighted the rival arguments in the appeal, with the Appellant’s counsel asserting the correctness of the majority decision, while the banks’ counsel, led by Dr. Romesh de Silva, PC, contended that the judgment in was wrong. Dr. De Silva PC emphasised the importance of a stable financial system for economic development, stressing the need for uninterrupted money circulation. Justice Samayawardhena acknowledged that a stable financial system is crucial for robust economic development, facilitating resource allocation, credit access, risk management, and overall growth. He noted the banks’ role as guardians of public funds within the Sri Lankan financial system, emphasising the necessity of a secure payment and repayment system. Furthermore, Justice Nawaz asserted that with the Court’s determination that Chelliah Ramachandran perpetuated an incorrect view of parate execution concerning third-party mortgages, the precedent set by Chelliah Ramachandran would no longer be followed. Justice Nawaz critiqued Chief Justice Sarath N Silva’s statement in Chelliah Ramchandran, asserting that undue focus on the disfavour Roman Dutch Law had for parate execution is akin to looking backward and compared it to the biblical story of Lot’s wife turning into a pillar of salt. He emphasised the need for Sri Lankan jurisprudence to progress and not be bound by historical perspectives. Referring to the SARFAESI Act of India,  he argued that Sri Lankan law should align itself with global credit financing practices and not lag behind. Justice Nawaz further stated that time has come to perform the burial rites of the Chelliah- Ramchandran case. Justice Amarasekara concurred, supporting the final conclusion that, regardless of whether a loan was released in the name of the mortgager, a mortgaged property is subject to parate execution. The unanimous decision overruled the earlier five-judge ruling in Chelliah v Ramachandran, affirming that banks are entitled to parate execution for any property mortgaged to them. BY Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Date set for Nishantha’s Contempt case
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (13) issued notice to witnesses, to be present before it on 31 January next year, to testify in the Contempt of Court case against State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha. The Appellate Court also instructed the Registrar, to set up giant screens within the Court House, to view video footage concerning the evidence, to be put forth during the trial. The Bench gave these instructions, having perused submissions produced by Deputy Solicitor General Lakmini Girihagama, who appeared on behalf of the Attorney General. The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) and a group of lawyers, have filed the case against the SLPP MP, charging him with Contempt of Court, over controversial remarks made by him, during a media conference, held at his party headquarters, in August last year. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Former CEA Chair given bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, yesterday (13) released former Chairman of Central Environmental Authority (CEA) Supun Pathirage on bail. Two suspects along with the former CEA Chairman were arrested by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), on a charge of seeking a bribe of Rs 10 million, to facilitate the release of an environment protection licence, towards a fuel purification project, being funded by the CEA. However, the Magistrate further remanded former MP Anuruddha Polgampola and Tennyson Fonseka till 24 November. When the case was called yesterday, Chief Magistrate Alwis released Pathirage, on cash bail in Rs 25,000 and ontwo sureties of Rs 2.5 million each. Granting bail to the former CEA Chairman, the Magistrate remarked that he was resorting to his action, due to the failure on the part of the Prosecution, to submit adequate evidence, to confirm that the suspect concerned, had either solicited the alleged bribe or even received it. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
