title: SL’s CG in Toronto participates in Katina ceremonies
author: Author not found
Content: The Consul General of Sri Lanka in Toronto Thushara Rodrigo participated in the Katina Ceremonies’ held at the Toronto Maha Vihara and the West End Buddhist Viharaand Meditation Centre in Toronto on 4 and 5 November. The Chief Incumbents of the two temples, the Most Venerable Ahangama Rathanasiri Maha Nayaka Thera and the Most Venerable Kulugammana Dhammawasa Nayaka Thera led the dhamma sermons while Buddhist monks conducted all night pirith chanting. Both Nayaka Theras, while appreciating the Sri Lankan Government’s representation at the ceremonies blessed Sri Lanka and her people. Traditional Buddhist cultural performances conducted by the children of the Dhamma schools of the two temples and the Sri Lankan Canadian Community living in Toronto added colour to the events.

title: Galle town flooded
author: Author not found
Content: Following torrential rains experienced in and around Galle town during the afternoon of 12November, several roads had been submerged while a few low-lying areas too suffered a similar plight. Several avenues and houses in the town limits were seen under water while due to roads being submerged motorists and pedestrians were also hindered. Among the areas affected were Galle town, Dangedera, Thalapitiya, Pettigalawatta, Kongaha, Weliwatta,Cheena Koratuwa, Milidduwa, Beligaha, Kahaduwawatta, Moragoda, Wakwella Road, Galle and Baddegama Road to name a few. Residents said that due to the defunct nature of a water pumping station, the aforementioned areas had been inundated inconveniencing them as water had crept up to at least two feet. They request the authorities to implement a system to allow the smooth flow of water during the monsoon season instead of taking ad-hoc measures aimed at overcoming flood situations in the district. BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle

title: Deepavali celebrated at the Presidential Secretariat
author: Author not found
Content: A special Deepavali celebration took place on Sunday (12),  at the Presidential Secretariat, under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The event, organised by the Presidential Secretariat, was conducted with simplicity and elegance, emphasising Hindu rituals. President Wickremesinghe was warmly welcomed according to Hindu rites. Engaging in a friendly conversation, he extended Deepavali greetings to the Hindu devotees in attendance. The event was also attended by Minister Douglas Devananda, Eastern Province Governor Sendhil Thondaman, former Member of Parliament R. Yogarajan, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake and senior officials from the President’s Office.

title: Amaraweera warns of drought during Yala season
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries Mahinda Amaraweera warned farmers across the country that they would have to face a significant challenge in the upcoming Yala season, as there was a severe drought, despite recent rainfall in various regions. Emphasising the need for prudent water management, the minister urged farmers to use reservoir water judiciously, citing international weather forecasts confirming an impending drought. Addressing the water crisis, the Sri Lanka Hadabima Authority recently took a proactive step by presenting essential equipment sets to 70 farming families in the Hambantota District to boost passion fruit cultivation. The distribution, which took place last Saturday (11), was officiated by Minister Mahinda Amaraweera and attended by Sri Lanka Hadabima Authority Chairman Sarath Chandrasiri Withana. Reflecting on the challenges faced in the previous Yala season, Minister Amaraweera acknowledged the significant impact of El Nino-induced drought, resulting in the destruction of 65,000 acres of high-yielding paddy fields. Furthermore, heavy post-drought rains led to the flooding and ruin of an additional 11,000 acres of nearly ripe paddy fields. Despite recent rainfall, the minister cautioned that the situation may not persist due to anticipated weather conditions, specifically La Nina, expected by the end of December. This could exacerbate the drought, posing a threat to crop cultivation in the upcoming Yala season. Highlighting the urgency of water conservation, Minister Amaraweera stressed the importance of timely cultivation. He noted that compensation for crop damage would not be extended to fields left uncultivated within the recommended timeframe. The minister urged farmers to heed the warnings and take proactive measures to mitigate the potential impact on crops. In an effort to diversify agricultural practices, the Sri Lanka Hadabima Authority initiated a programme to promote passion fruit cultivation in the Hambantota District, benefiting 70 selected farming families. Minister Amaraweera underscored the importance of such initiatives, noting the global demand for passion fruit and the suitability of dry weather conditions for its cultivation. The Hadabima Authority not only provided necessary equipment but also offered training and supervision to ensure cultivation meets international standards. Similar projects are also underway in other regions, such as Dehiattakandiya, as the government seeks to enhance crop diversity and resilience in the face of challenging weather patterns.

title: Court issues Injunction against Thrikonamadu deforestation
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal, responding to a Writ Petition, filed by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) on 10 November, regarding the unlawful deforestation of Thrikonamadu, has issued an injunction halting the activity until 23 November. The petition, focusing on the unauthorised deforestation of 5,000 acres in Thrikonamadu, was submitted before a two-Judge Bench, comprising Justices Bandula Karunaratne (President) and Vikum Kaluarachchi. Alleging that the deforestation had been conducted without the necessary approvals, the petitioners urged the Court to swiftly intervene and prevent further illegal activities in the area. In response, the State Counsel, representing the respondents, which included the Wildlife and Conservation Department, Forest Conservation Department, and the Inspector General of Police (IGP), opposed the petitioner’s request. Despite the objections, the Appellate Court ordered all involved parties, including the Directors General of the Wildlife Department and Forest Conservation Department, the Divisional Secretary, the IGP, Mahaweli Development Authority, and the National Livestock Development Board, to cease the ongoing deforestation in Thrikonamadu until the next hearing. Senior State Counsel Navodi de Zoysa represented the Attorney General’s Department, while the petitioners were represented by a legal team led by Senior Counsel Ravindranath Dabare. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: NATA TO URGE FOR BAN ON SALE OF SINGLE CIGARETTE
author: Author not found
Content: The National Authority on Tobacco and Alcohol (NATA) is planning to urge the government to take necessary action to ban the sale of single cigarette, NATA Chairman Dr. Alen G. Ludowyke announced yesterday (13). Dr. Ludowyke, citing a 2020 World Health Organisation (WHO) report, on tobacco-related deaths, highlighted that 50 per cent of chain smokers succumb to lung-related diseases, including lung and oral cancer. Sri Lanka, he noted, has become a global front-runner in reducing the number of smokers, an achievement attributed to the effective awareness programmes conducted by NATA. Speaking at an exclusive awareness programme organised for the media in Colombo, Dr. Ludowyke emphasised the crucial role of media cooperation and support in raising awareness about the harms of tobacco and alcohol. He acknowledged that the reduction in smoking rates in the country could be credited to the collaborative efforts of the media and NATA. Police Spokesperson SSP Nihal Thalduwa, addressing the event, asserted that issues related to tobacco or other crimes cannot be entirely eradicated but can only be kept under control. He emphasised the importance of ongoing efforts to manage such issues. Attorney-at-Law Viraj Bandaranayake, the Legal Adviser to NATA, revealed the organisation’s continuous campaign against narcotics, including cannabis and their efforts to educate the public about the health risks involved. Bandaranayake disclosed that he had discussions with the Parliamentary Select Committee, urging them not to promote cannabis cultivation in Sri Lanka due to its harmful impact on the nation’s health. Prof. Duminda Guruge, from the Health Promotion Unit of the University of Rajarata, also addressed the awareness programme, focusing on the same theme. The collaborative efforts of NATA, law enforcement, and the media underscore the importance of sustained initiatives to combat tobacco-related issues and promote public health. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Chelsea snatch Man City draw with late Palmer penalty
author: Author not found
Content: Cole Palmer’s stoppage-time penalty denied former club Manchester City victory in a thriller against Chelsea at Stamford Bridge. In a game of the highest quality in treacherous conditions, fortunes swung both ways. City thought they had the three points when Rodri’s shot from the edge of the area touched off Thiago Silva past Chelsea keeper Robert Sanchez with four minutes left. Chelsea, showing superb resilience, were not to be denied and Palmer – a £40m summer signing from Pep Guardiola’s side – stayed cool amid the mayhem to beat Ederson from the spot to leave City just a point clear of Liverpool at the Premier League summit. The reigning champions led in contentious fashion after 25 minutes when they were awarded a penalty for Marc Cucurella’s pull on Erling Haaland, despite Chelsea’s protests that the full-back had been fouled first. Haaland dispatched the penalty with ease, but the hosts were level four minutes later when Brazil centre-back Silva glanced home Conor Gallagher’s corner at the near post. Chelsea turned the game around when Raheem Sterling also scored against his former club after 37 minutes, turning in Reece James’ cross after Josko Gvardiol’s mistake. City, though, levelled on the stroke of half-time when the unmarked Manuel Akanji headed in Bernardo Silva’s cross. Two minutes after the break City went in front again when Haaland scrambled in Julian Alvarez’s cross at the far post. Yet Chelsea again battled back and deservedly drew level in the 67th minute when Nicolas Jackson pounced after Ederson pushed out Gallagher’s low drive. Guardiola’s side thought they had won it with Rodri’s stroke of good fortune – until the late penalty drama capped an entertaining, eventful encounter. Defender Ruben Dias was penalised for a foul on Chelsea substitute Armando Broja and Palmer’s calm finish left honours even.

title: Weather situ remains, landslide warnings to six districts continue
author: Author not found
Content: As inclement weather persists across most parts of the country, particularly in the Central Hill Country, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has decided to maintain various levels of landslide early warning alerts issued to 38 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions across six districts until further notice. Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist of the Landslide Early Warning Centre of NBRO, explained that considering the rainfall in specific areas, the decision has been made to continue the level two amber–watch landslide early warning alerts for Thumpane DS Division and surrounding areas in the Kandy District, as well as Ratnapura, Eheliyagoda, Balangoda, Weligepola, Openayake, Kuruwita, Imbulpe, Kolonna, Godakawela, Kalawana and Elapatha DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. Level one yellow–watch landslide early warning alerts for Haputale and Haldumulla DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Badulla District, Ududumbara and Udunuwara DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Kandy District, Yatiyantota, Udunuwara, Mawanella, Warakapola, Galigamuwa, Aranayake, Bulathkohupitiya, and Kegalle DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Polgahawela DS Division and surrounding areas in the Kurunegala District, Kotapola, Hakmana, Welipitiya, Akuressa, Pitabeddara, Malimbada and Kamburupitiya DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Matara District, and Pelmadulla, Nivithigala, Kahawatta, Kiriella, and Ayagama DS divisions and surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District will remain in effect until further notice, according to Dr. Senadeera. Meanwhile, the Department of Meteorology forecasted showers or thundershowers may occur across most parts of the country yesterday (13). Duty Meteorologist Malith Fernando predicted that showers or thundershowers could occur at times in the North-central, Northern, Central, and Eastern provinces. Showers or thundershowers are also expected in several places in other provinces after 2.00 p.m. Heavy showers above 100 millimetres are likely in some places in the Western, Eastern, Central, and Sabaragamuwa Provinces, according to Fernando. The Duty Meteorologist urged the public to take adequate precaution to safeguard against possible temporary localised heavy winds and lightning strikes. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: AHP claims SPC readying for another scam
author: Author not found
Content: With all attention being focussed on the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC) is preparing for a different type of scam by appointing the Deputy General Manager (Finance) as the Deputy General Manager Technical, Lab and Production (acting) through an internal transfer, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) alleged.  AHP President Ravi Kumudesh yesterday (13) said that the SPC alleged that the Corporation had made an urgent move to appoint an the DGM (Finance) to the position when there were many professionals who had genuine knowledge of laboratory services and Technical Services. Kumudesh accused the SPC of attempting to take decisions outside the box by conferring a person, who had qualifications in finance and accounting, a position in laboratory and technical services, at a time when it was not even possible to trace the root cause of fake immunoglobulin scam, which occurred due to wrong recommendations made by the Technical Evaluation Committee (TEC). The AHP President alleged that the biggest problem lay in the fact that while the SPC had transferred the DGM Finance to the Acting Deputy General Manager position yet another unsuitable appointment could be made to fill his post in Finance. “It is very clear that an unseen hand in the SPC was working strategically to pave the way for informal and irregular transactions, he alleged. Kumudesh said that the AHP and all other trade unions were watchful as to whether the approval of the new Health Minister had been obtained when making these decisions. A temporary transfer, signed by the Chairman of the SPC, was given to the Deputy General Manager (Finance) to the Technical, Lab and Production Division since 7 November 2023 until ongoing a formal disciplinary inquiry against him (DGMFinance) was concluded and the Disciplinary Authority took an appropriate decision based on the outcome of the inquiry. The DGH Finance had also been instructed to hand over office items, files and other official documents in his custody to Accountant (Revenue). By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CEA Chair remanded and suspended from service
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Central Environment Authority (CEA), Supun Shashendra Pathirage , who was arrested by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) has been  suspended from service with immediate effect, Dr. Anil Jasinghe, Secretary to the Ministry of Environment , announced. Pathirage, along with two other individuals, former MP Anuruddha Polgampala and Tennison Fonseka, were arrested by officers of the Bribery Commission in connection with allegations of soliciting a bribe amounting to Rs 10 million. The illegal transaction was reported to have taken place within the premises of the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources. Following their arrest, the suspects were produced in the Colombo Magistrate’s Court on 11 November and remanded until today (13). The Bribery Commission informed Court that the suspects were arrested following a complaint from a businessman seeking an annual environmental licence for a project involving the removal of ship crude oil. According to the complaint, the CEA Chairman had initially demanded seven million rupees to issue the licence. When the businessman delayed giving the bribe, the suspect then sought an additional three million rupees. According to the Bribery Commission, the other two suspects were arrested for aiding and abetting the first suspect. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Putting final touch-ups to Appropriation Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The final discussion regarding the preparation and presentation of the Appropriation Bill 2024 was held yesterday (12) at the President’s official residence in Colombo. The Appropriation Bill 2024 is scheduled to be presented in Parliament today (13) by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is also the Finance Minister. Those present at the discussion included Ministers of State for Finance Ranjith Siambalapitiya and Shehan Semasinghe, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, President’s Senior Adviser on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, President’s Adviser Saman Athaudahetti, Finance Ministry Secretary Mahinda Siriwardena and Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe.

title: MCPA questions delay in arresting masterminds behind scam
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association (MCPA) is questioning the ongoing delay by the Police in apprehending the masterminds behind the incident involving substandard human intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) vials. During a media briefing in Galle, MCPA President Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva emphasised the urgency of producing the suspects, involved in this racket, in Court before 15 November. Additionally, he accused the Ministry of Health of shielding corrupt officials with affiliations to the authorities. Dr. Sanjeeva expressed serious concern about the delay in the arrest of the mastermind of the scam. He highlighted that the scam took place when there were sufficient stocks of immunoglobulin in the country and criticised the appointment of the former NMRA CEO, a suspect in this case, as the Director of the Medical Research Institute (MRI). Dr. Sanjeeva said, “It is highly questionable as to why the mastermind of the immunoglobulin scam is not arrested yet.” He warned that the delay in taking action against the culprits of this scam will further erode the public’s trust in the current administration of the country. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Appellate Court decision on 17 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal would deliver its decision on the Early retirement of medical specialists on 17 November. Informed sources yesterday (12) said that 176 doctors filed Writ Petitions against the Cabinet decision to make medical specialists retire at the age of 60. They noted that earlier the Health Ministry had extended the service period of medical specialists in the State service to 63 years of age. However, the Health Secretary issued a circular stating that the decision regarding the age of retirement of the medical specialists was effective only until 31 December 2024. Sources said that there was a legitimate expectation among medical specialists for an extension of their services. The depletion of medical practitioners, as a result of the brain drain that was taking place, was a major issue to provide equality of service in all State hospitals. Circumstances related to the economic crisis, taxations, placement delays on their return, children’s schooling and the shabby manner in which medical specialists are treated on their return after a period of foreign , have driven many of the medical specialists to serve overseas. They noted that currently there were 790 specialist vacancies with only 1,985 specialists functioning in State hospitals. Earlier there were only about 400 to 500 vacancies that needed to be filled. In addition, the specialities themselves have extended with more State hospitals and units being upgraded. They said that a total 3,000 medicinal specialists were required in order to provide a satisfactory service in State hospitals in 2024. A total 305 including 70 specialist doctors who turn 63 will be forced to retire if the rule was implemented shrinking the number of medical specialists in service even further, they said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Amaraweera blames rice mafia for keeri samba shortage
author: Author not found
Content: The market is grappling with a severe shortage of Keeri Samba rice, a staple in many households and investigations reveal that the scarcity is not a result of natural factors but a calculated move by the so-called ‘rice mafia’ in the country, Minister of Agriculture MahindaAmaraweera claimed. Despite ample stocks of Keeri Samba rice nationwide, certain unscrupulous rice mill owners are artificially creating shortages by withholding supplies. This has led to a surge in prices, with some businessmen attempting to sell Keeri Samba at an exorbitant price of Rs 305-310 per kilo, well above the government-set controlled price, the minister alleged. Amaraweera expressed his concern, noting that while the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) is conducting raids, many business entities are clandestinely engaging in the sale of Keeri Samba at inflated prices. In response, the Minister has directed the agriculture department to encourage farmers to increase Keeri Samba cultivation during the ongoing Maha season. Meanwhile, the Department of Agriculture has submitted a report to the Minister regarding the glucose content in various rice varieties. The report highlights Keeri Samba as the rice type with the highest glucose levels among those consumed in the country. Excessive consumption of Keeri Samba has been linked to an elevated risk of increased blood sugar levels, exacerbating diabetiec conditions. Contrastingly, the report also underscores rice varieties with bran as having the lowest glucose levels, indicating a healthier alternative for those concerned about their sugar intake.

title: Call for revisiting SL-Pakistan FTA
author: Author not found
Content: Consul General of Sri Lanka to Pakistan Jagath Abeywarna mentioned that despite 75 years of good diplomatic relations and a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) since 2005, the Sri Lanka-Pakistan trade volume remains ‘insignificant’ at USD 440 million due to certain barriers preventing trade between both sides. “Pakistan’s exports to Sri Lanka stood at USD 360 million and Sri Lankan exports remained at USD 80 million. To enhance this trade, the FTA has to be revisited and a mechanism devised to facilitate transactions between exporters and importers of both countries which are facing a dire shortage of foreign currency. As we both are going through a difficult economic situation, hence, we have to help each other,” he said during a meeting on his visit to the Karachi Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KCCI). “Pakistan was the number one buyer of Sri Lankan products, particularly Ceylon tea, which, unfortunately, is no longer being exported to Pakistan as the importers here are now importing tea from Kenya and other countries,” he said. He highlighted that collaboration between the private sectors, through participation in trade fairs and regular exchanges of trade delegations, is essential to achieving the common goal of improved trade ties. “Several sectors can promote trade between the two countries, including pharmaceuticals, fabrics, leather, etc., which are being imported by Sri Lanka. We can also provide construction materials, ceramics, false ceilings, cosmetics, rubber-based products, and agricultural products to Pakistan,” he added. (The Express Tribune)

title: ICC’s suspension of SLC rouses debate
author: Author not found
Content: Amidst escalating tensions between politicians and Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) officials, coupled with the suspension imposed by the International Cricket Council (ICC) on Sri Lanka Cricket, various politicians, including Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe, have voiced their opinions on the suspension. Responding to the suspension imposed by the ICC, Sports Minister Ranasinghe deemed the decision illegal, asserting procedural lapses in the due process. He announced plans to engage with the ICC, underscoring his willingness to approach the Dispute Resolution Committee and, if necessary, take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa accused SLC officials of pushing for Sri Lanka’s suspension from the International Cricket Council (ICC). During a comprehensive discussion at the Opposition Leader’s office, Premadasa went as far as labelling SLC officials as betrayers and traitors, expressing deep-seated concerns about potential repercussions, including the suspension of Sri Lankan players from the highly regarded Indian Premier League (IPL) Adding a perspective to the ongoing saga, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake highlighted long-standing concerns about corruption within SLC. Dissanayake pointed out the diligent efforts by the JJB and JVP to address corruption issues, urging the implementation of recommendations made by the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE). Further, addressing the multifaceted crisis, Dissanayake called on the men’s cricket team to prioritise the country’s interests. He emphasised the necessity for discipline and proper guidance from the cricket board, particularly in light of recent instances that have raised doubts about players’ commitment to national representation. SLPP MP Namal Rajapaksa has called for the prompt resolution of disputes to safeguard the future of Sri Lankan cricket and ensure the well-being of its players. Rajapaksa, a former Minister of Sports, emphasised the profound impact of dispute on the sport, stating, “It is Sri Lanka’s cricket which is going to be affected as a result of disputes.” Drawing on his experience, he urged politicians not to exploit sports as a battleground for settling their differences.

title: Grama Niladhari remanded over extortion bid
author: Author not found
Content: Homagama Acting Magistrate Bandu Liyanage remanded a Grama Niladhari, charged with demanding a ransom of Rs 2 million from a female pre-school teacher, with the threat of harming her two children. The suspect, identified as a Grama Niladhari, from the Suwapubudugama Grama Niladhari Division in Pitipana South, Homagama, will be held in remand custody until 16 November. The arrest followed a complaint from the pre-school teacher, who received death threats over the phone and was threatened into paying a ransom of two million rupees. Acting promptly on the complaint, Police sleuths apprehended the 51-year-old suspect in the act of accepting the ransom. The Police also seized the motorbike used by the suspect, along with two mobile phones and the Grama Niladhari identity card. By Keerthi Mendis

title: SLPA hosts discussion with DFC, US Embassy for renewable energy in ports
author: Author not found
Content: A high-level round table discussion with the participation of representatives of the US Embassy and the Development Finance Corporation (DFC) was held at the Head Office of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) on 6 November 2023. This discussion was initiated by Keith D. Bernard, Chairman SLPA, and was attended by local industrial experts and stakeholder groups operating in the port sector. The discussion focused on how DFC can fund projects, explore ways to finance private sector driven renewable energy projects  at ports, seeking potential investors and interested groups to work together on the Green initiative, etc. During the meeting, Keith D. Bernard, the Chairman of SLPA, emphasised the significant potential in working in collaboration to achieve success in making the port green and eco-friendly. He highlighted the importance of this initial discussion to pave the way for the future. “As a country, we are committed to power our ports with green energy in the future,” he said. He mentioned that SLPA would look at updating the Sri Lanka Ports National Master Plan by incorporating green energy initiatives. Capt. Nirmal P. Silva, SLPA’s Harbour Master, stressed the growing interest in green energy in the Ports and Maritime sector. He underscored efforts to reduce emissions, and need to align with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). He emphasised the need to embrace renewable energy but cautiously selecting from the available alternatives. The DFC delegation expressed gratitude to SLPA and the local industry leaders for agreeing to discuss the way forward in this endeavour. They highlighted the advantages of engaging in green energy and appreciated the foresight  of SLPA to introduce green energy products and services to Sri Lanka’s port sector. The DFC stated that renewable energy was a priority and discussed the availability of financial assistance to implement renewable  energy projects  at a national level. At present, DFC offers longer-term financial support, that has benefited the commercial banking sector of Sri Lanka with pay-back periods of 12 to 20 years and a grace period of up to four years. Dustin Bikel, Regional Indo-Pacific Strategy Coordinator from the Regional Infrastructure Office of the US Embassy, Colombo  pointed out that the DFC would be willing  to receive requests for  Green Energy projects in Sri Lanka. “Renewable energy is a key priority, particularly in Sri Lanka’s infrastructure development,” he said. Bikel said he looks forward to working with SLPA in the Green Energy space in the future in line with SLPA’s  Ports National Master Plan. Local experts and industrial leaders highlighted the importance, from a port perspective, of setting milestones to provide shore power to vessels, setting deadlines for green  initiatives, and transitioning from conventional electrification to green energy. It was considered essential to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The US Embassy delegation, the Development Finance Corporation (DFC) industrial experts and stakeholders,  DFC Regional Manager for South Asia – Ajay Rao,  Economic Specialist at US Embassy Colombo –  Joevinie Machado, Regional Specialist /US Embassy – J.S.A.Arachchi, the  Chairman of Access Engineering PLC –  Sumal Perera, Director for Access Logistics Park, Ekala –  Nishan Silva,  Group Chairman at McLarens Holdings Limited – Rohan De Silva, CEO of South Asia Gateway Terminals – Romesh  David and   Managing Director at Hayleys Advantis Limited  – Ruwan Waidyaratne were present.

title: MCPA questions delay in arresting masterminds behind scam
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association (MCPA) is questioning the ongoing delay by the Police in apprehending the masterminds behind the incident involving substandard human intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) vials. During a media briefing in Galle, MCPA President Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva emphasised the urgency of producing the suspects, involved in this racket, in Court before 15 November. Additionally, he accused the Ministry of Health of shielding corrupt officials with affiliations to the authorities. Dr. Sanjeeva expressed serious concern about the delay in the arrest of the mastermind of the scam. He highlighted that the scam took place when there were sufficient stocks of immunoglobulin in the country and criticised the appointment of the former NMRA CEO, a suspect in this case, as the Director of the Medical Research Institute (MRI). Dr. Sanjeeva said, “It is highly questionable as to why the mastermind of the immunoglobulin scam is not arrested yet.” He warned that the delay in taking action against the culprits of this scam will further erode the public’s trust in the current administration of the country. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Appellate Court decision on 17 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal would deliver its decision on the Early retirement of medical specialists on 17 November. Informed sources yesterday (12) said that 176 doctors filed Writ Petitions against the Cabinet decision to make medical specialists retire at the age of 60. They noted that earlier the Health Ministry had extended the service period of medical specialists in the State service to 63 years of age. However, the Health Secretary issued a circular stating that the decision regarding the age of retirement of the medical specialists was effective only until 31 December 2024. Sources said that there was a legitimate expectation among medical specialists for an extension of their services. The depletion of medical practitioners, as a result of the brain drain that was taking place, was a major issue to provide equality of service in all State hospitals. Circumstances related to the economic crisis, taxations, placement delays on their return, children’s schooling and the shabby manner in which medical specialists are treated on their return after a period of foreign , have driven many of the medical specialists to serve overseas. They noted that currently there were 790 specialist vacancies with only 1,985 specialists functioning in State hospitals. Earlier there were only about 400 to 500 vacancies that needed to be filled. In addition, the specialities themselves have extended with more State hospitals and units being upgraded. They said that a total 3,000 medicinal specialists were required in order to provide a satisfactory service in State hospitals in 2024. A total 305 including 70 specialist doctors who turn 63 will be forced to retire if the rule was implemented shrinking the number of medical specialists in service even further, they said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Amaraweera blames rice mafia for keeri samba shortage
author: Author not found
Content: The market is grappling with a severe shortage of Keeri Samba rice, a staple in many households and investigations reveal that the scarcity is not a result of natural factors but a calculated move by the so-called ‘rice mafia’ in the country, Minister of Agriculture MahindaAmaraweera claimed. Despite ample stocks of Keeri Samba rice nationwide, certain unscrupulous rice mill owners are artificially creating shortages by withholding supplies. This has led to a surge in prices, with some businessmen attempting to sell Keeri Samba at an exorbitant price of Rs 305-310 per kilo, well above the government-set controlled price, the minister alleged. Amaraweera expressed his concern, noting that while the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) is conducting raids, many business entities are clandestinely engaging in the sale of Keeri Samba at inflated prices. In response, the Minister has directed the agriculture department to encourage farmers to increase Keeri Samba cultivation during the ongoing Maha season. Meanwhile, the Department of Agriculture has submitted a report to the Minister regarding the glucose content in various rice varieties. The report highlights Keeri Samba as the rice type with the highest glucose levels among those consumed in the country. Excessive consumption of Keeri Samba has been linked to an elevated risk of increased blood sugar levels, exacerbating diabetiec conditions. Contrastingly, the report also underscores rice varieties with bran as having the lowest glucose levels, indicating a healthier alternative for those concerned about their sugar intake.

title: Call for revisiting SL-Pakistan FTA
author: Author not found
Content: Consul General of Sri Lanka to Pakistan Jagath Abeywarna mentioned that despite 75 years of good diplomatic relations and a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) since 2005, the Sri Lanka-Pakistan trade volume remains ‘insignificant’ at USD 440 million due to certain barriers preventing trade between both sides. “Pakistan’s exports to Sri Lanka stood at USD 360 million and Sri Lankan exports remained at USD 80 million. To enhance this trade, the FTA has to be revisited and a mechanism devised to facilitate transactions between exporters and importers of both countries which are facing a dire shortage of foreign currency. As we both are going through a difficult economic situation, hence, we have to help each other,” he said during a meeting on his visit to the Karachi Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KCCI). “Pakistan was the number one buyer of Sri Lankan products, particularly Ceylon tea, which, unfortunately, is no longer being exported to Pakistan as the importers here are now importing tea from Kenya and other countries,” he said. He highlighted that collaboration between the private sectors, through participation in trade fairs and regular exchanges of trade delegations, is essential to achieving the common goal of improved trade ties. “Several sectors can promote trade between the two countries, including pharmaceuticals, fabrics, leather, etc., which are being imported by Sri Lanka. We can also provide construction materials, ceramics, false ceilings, cosmetics, rubber-based products, and agricultural products to Pakistan,” he added. (The Express Tribune)

title: ICC’s suspension of SLC rouses debate
author: Author not found
Content: Amidst escalating tensions between politicians and Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) officials, coupled with the suspension imposed by the International Cricket Council (ICC) on Sri Lanka Cricket, various politicians, including Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe, have voiced their opinions on the suspension. Responding to the suspension imposed by the ICC, Sports Minister Ranasinghe deemed the decision illegal, asserting procedural lapses in the due process. He announced plans to engage with the ICC, underscoring his willingness to approach the Dispute Resolution Committee and, if necessary, take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa accused SLC officials of pushing for Sri Lanka’s suspension from the International Cricket Council (ICC). During a comprehensive discussion at the Opposition Leader’s office, Premadasa went as far as labelling SLC officials as betrayers and traitors, expressing deep-seated concerns about potential repercussions, including the suspension of Sri Lankan players from the highly regarded Indian Premier League (IPL) Adding a perspective to the ongoing saga, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake highlighted long-standing concerns about corruption within SLC. Dissanayake pointed out the diligent efforts by the JJB and JVP to address corruption issues, urging the implementation of recommendations made by the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE). Further, addressing the multifaceted crisis, Dissanayake called on the men’s cricket team to prioritise the country’s interests. He emphasised the necessity for discipline and proper guidance from the cricket board, particularly in light of recent instances that have raised doubts about players’ commitment to national representation. SLPP MP Namal Rajapaksa has called for the prompt resolution of disputes to safeguard the future of Sri Lankan cricket and ensure the well-being of its players. Rajapaksa, a former Minister of Sports, emphasised the profound impact of dispute on the sport, stating, “It is Sri Lanka’s cricket which is going to be affected as a result of disputes.” Drawing on his experience, he urged politicians not to exploit sports as a battleground for settling their differences.

title: Grama Niladhari remanded over extortion bid
author: Author not found
Content: Homagama Acting Magistrate Bandu Liyanage remanded a Grama Niladhari, charged with demanding a ransom of Rs 2 million from a female pre-school teacher, with the threat of harming her two children. The suspect, identified as a Grama Niladhari, from the Suwapubudugama Grama Niladhari Division in Pitipana South, Homagama, will be held in remand custody until 16 November. The arrest followed a complaint from the pre-school teacher, who received death threats over the phone and was threatened into paying a ransom of two million rupees. Acting promptly on the complaint, Police sleuths apprehended the 51-year-old suspect in the act of accepting the ransom. The Police also seized the motorbike used by the suspect, along with two mobile phones and the Grama Niladhari identity card. By Keerthi Mendis

title: SLWJA commences registering new members
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Working Journalists’ Association (SLWJA) announced the commencement of recruiting new members and the renewal of existing memberships for the upcoming year, 2024. Aspiring journalists and current members seeking to renew their memberships are encouraged to apply through the association’s official website: www.slwjalk.org. For the convenience of existing members seeking renewal, the SLWJA has designated representatives who can be contacted for the renewal process:Duminda Sampath: 0711394884, T. Nadarasa: 0779776979 and S. Nishanthan: 0779076532. Additionally, individuals with inquiries or those requiring further information are welcome to contact the SLWJAvia email at [email protected].

title: Consignment of Chillies from Pakistan returned
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Health has returned a shipment of chillies, imported from Pakistan, citing the presence of aflatoxin. It was disclosed that among the exported items, 25 containers contained the affected chillies. The imported chillies were brought into the country by a group of Sri Lankan businessmen. Simultaneously, the Food Control Administration Unit, of the Ministry of Health, has established a hotline, reachable at 0112 112 718, to facilitate the reporting of any issues concerning the quality of food.

title: Wellawatte present credentials in Greece
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s Ambassador in Italy, Jagath Wellawatte, who is also concurrently accredited to the Hellenic Republic, presented his Letters of Credence to President of the Hellenic Republic (Greece) Katerina Sakellaropoulou on 30 October 2023, at the Presidential Palace in Athens, Greece.  At the Credential Ceremony, Ambassador conveyed the greetings of President Ranil  Wickremesinghe to President Sakellaropoulou.  Following the Credential Ceremony, the Ambassador and Honorary Consul of Sri Lanka in Greece Michael Xynos called on the Minister of Labour and Social Security of the Hellenic Republic and discussed entering into a Memorandum of Understanding in the field of Migration Mobility Partnership between the two countries.  Further, the Ambassador and the Honorary Consul had a meeting with the President of the Athens Chamber of Commerce and Industry Sofia Kounenaki and discussed the investment opportunities in Sri Lanka. During his visit to Athens, the Ambassador visited the Athens Buddhist Centre, the Honorary Consulate Office in Athens and met the representatives of the Sri Lankan community in Greece.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Irregularities in CPC administration exposed
author: Author not found
Content: Numerous irregularities at the administrative level of the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) were exposed during a recent meeting of the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE). Issues highlighted by COPE, regarding the CPC, encompass several concerns. These include the actions taken regarding the expansion of fuel storage capacity, the current condition of the pipeline extending to the Kolonnawa Storage Plant, the delayed payments for fuel vessels, the maintenance of sufficient strategic fuel reserves to meet the country’s demand, the losses incurred through the ship-to-party method of distributing fuel to consumers by suppliers, and the disconnection of overdue payments without proper confirmation. In response to these concerns, COPE has decided to summon three former Director Boards, including former Chairmen of the CPC, on 9 January next year before the Committee for further inquiry. The COPE meeting was chaired by SLPP MP Ranjith Bandara on November 7 in Parliament, where these matters were brought to light.

title: ITAK MP meets Aussie Envoy, seeks mediation
author: Author not found
Content: Ilankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam stated on 12 November that the mediation of the Australian Government was vital in finding a sustainable solution to  political and development-related issues the Tamils in the country face. Rasamanickam said that he appealed to the Australian Government during a recent meeting with Australian High Commissioner, Paul Stephens. He said the discussion covered various topics, including the current political situation in the country focussing on the longstanding issues faced by the Tamil people. During the meeting, Rasamanickam and High Commissioner Stephens extensively discussed issues related to grazing lands in the Mathavanai and Mayilathamadu areas, in the Batticaloa District. They explored ways and means to resolve the matter in a manner that did not negatively impact any specific community. Rasamanickam emphasised the need for the Australian Government to address the issue. The discussion also touched on future conventions and the emigration of educationists and youth from the country. He pointed out that Australia, like other countries host a significant number of Tamils, Muslims and Sinhalese under its federal political system. Rasamanickam said the mediation of the Australian Government was crucial to finding solutions to the ethnic and political issues faced by the Tamil people. He highlighted the importance of international collaboration in addressing these longstanding challenges. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Woman and son die in wasp attack
author: Author not found
Content: An 85-year-old woman and her 59-year-old son succumbed to their injuries sustained in a wasp attack in the Hewaheta area, of the Kandy District, in the evening of 11 November, Hewaheta Police said. Police said the attack occurred in close proximity to their residence in Hewaheta. The son was pronounced dead upon admission to the Rikillagaskada Base Hospital, and the mother died while undergoing treatment at the same hospital. According to the Police, the son had attempted to shield his mother from the wasp attack near their home. Despite prompt rescue efforts by neighbours the victims could not be saved. By NaalirJamaldeen

title: Fmr LTTE cadre arrested in India
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian marine Police have apprehended a Sri Lankan national, allegedly a former LTTE cadre and a history-sheeter, while he was trying to illegally enter India via Dhanushkodi on 11 November. According to Police sources, Y. Jeyarasa (41), of Jaffna, in Sri Lanka, was caught at the Kampipadu seashore and brought to the Mandapam Police Station for interrogation. A preliminary inquiry revealed that he was helped by two Lankan nationals. Jeyarasa worked as a labourer in Jaffna and allegedly was associated with the LTTE till the end of the war in 2009. He surrendered to the Sri Lankan Army after the war and was lodged in Poonthotham prison, Vavuniya, for eight years from 2016, Police said. They added that Jeyarasa is married to Raji of Navanthanai, and has four children. He separated from his family in 2019 and lived with his mother. The authorities further said that Jeyarasa has criminal cases registered in the Sahavachery and Oorkavalthurai Police Stations in Sri Lanka. He decided to flee in order to evade arrest and approached one Rokshan, of Pechalai, Sri Lanka, on 9 November, to help him arrange for a boat to India. Rokshan demanded LKR 200,000. On 10 November, he took the money and Jeyarasa set sail on a boat from Pechalai at 4.00 p.m. On November 11, Jeyarasa landed at Kampipadu seashore at 7.00 a.m. and was brought to Mandapam PS for interrogation. Jeyarasa has been booked under section 14 of the Foreigners Act, 1946, and the Passport (Entry into India) Rule, 1950. (The New Indian Express)

title: Maize to be cultivated on 40,000 acres in Maha
author: Author not found
Content: The Small Scale Agricultural Partnership Programme (SAPP), under the Ministry of Agriculture and Plantation Industries, has initiated a project to cultivate 40,000 acres of maize in five districts during the upcoming Maha season. This project is underway in the Anuradhapura, Hambantota, Badulla, Monaragala, and Ampara Districts with the participation of 23,000 farmers. The distribution of 8,000 metric tons of urea fertiliser for maize cultivation, commenced on 10 November in Suriyawewa. Fertiliser distribution was overseen by Minister of Agriculture  Mahinda Amaraweera. Moreover, financial allocations have been made to cover the initial costs of land preparation and this will not be recovered. Amaraweera said these measures have already been put in place. The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) has extended financial support on credit for this programme. Meanwhile, the Anuradhapura District has the largest cultivation area under the Maize Cultivation Project, covering 20,000 acres.  Amaraweera said the cultivated area in the Hambantota District was 5,000 acres. He said, “It was decided to resume maize cultivation in the Hambantota District. While maize was cultivated previously instead of baby corn, this time, cultivation for animal feed will cover 5,000 acres. The objective is to further increase this amount next year.” These initiatives fall under the Small Scale Agri Entrepreneurship Programme and the Minister assured that facilities, including seed, fertiliser and land preparation funds, will be provided to the farmers.

title: Dr. Pathirana visits Ratnapura Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Health and Industry Dr. Ramesh Pathirana paid a visit to the Ratnapura Teaching Hospital, on 11 November, to engage in discussions with the top hospital administration and University of Sabaragamuwa officials, to discuss issues related to the professorial units of the Faculty of Medicine of the Sabaragamuwa University. Following these discussions, all parties involved agreed to allocate an identified unit for professorial training, and to give access to professors and lecturers to both teach and work at the hospital under the guidance of a specialist doctor assigned to the hospital by the Ministry of Health. The parties also came to an agreement to allow university lecturers to carry out clinical work as well. Referring to the previous discussions held with the Director General of Health Services, the doctors present at the discussion said that they are willing to conduct their teaching activities for the medical students of the Sabaragamuwa University and work to rebuild the mutual understanding that has deteriorated between the Teaching Hospital of Ratnapura and the University of Sabargamuwa, by addressing and remedying certain incidents that had taken place. Issues regarding the lack of both equipment and human resources faced by the Ratnapura Teaching Hospital were also discussed at this meeting. Special focus was given at these discussions on the construction of a cardiac unit, a cancer patient care unit, shortage of hospital staff and healthcare workers, squatters within the hospital vicinity and the acquisition of medical equipments for the hospital. It was decided that the construction work will be completed, once funds are allocated for the health services next year. Representing the Ministry of Health, Director General of Health Services Dr. Asela Gunawardena, Director (Tertiary Services) Dr. Priyantha Athapattu, representing the Ratnapura Teaching Hospital, Director Dr. Anuja Rodrigo and specialist doctors, representing the University of Sabaragamuwa, Vice-Chancellor Prof. Sunil Shantha, and the Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Prof. Nirmalee Wickramaratne attended this special discussion. Serving as the main general hospital of the Sabaragamuwa Province, the Ratnapura General Hospital was upgraded to a Teaching Hospital in 2018 following a proposal by then Minister of Health, Nutrition and Indigenous Medicine Dr. Rajitha Senaratne. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: SL’s Brussels Embassypromotes tourism
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Brussels organised a tourism promotion workshop titled ‘Sri Lanka Odyssey: An Ultimate Experience of Lifetime’, in Luxembourg on 8 November 2023. This event aimed to introduce Sri Lanka as a must-visit destination to Luxembourg’s travel operators and tour agencies. The Emirates’ Belgium Office and the agent of Basilur Premium Tea, a Ceylon tea brand in Belgium, also joined the Embassy to promote Sri Lanka tourism in Luxembourg.  The workshop drew over 70 participants, comprising a diverse group of travel industry professionals, including tour operators, travel agents, bloggers, social media influencers, travel journalists, and TV professionals.  Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Belgium and Luxembourg Grace Asirwatham provided a comprehensive overview of Sri Lanka’s tourism sector, showcasing pristine beaches, wildlife, nature reserves, tea gardens, cultural heritage, UNESCO sites, wellness tourism, and cultural activities.  Sales Manager at Emirates Airlines in Belgium Yuves Vanhaack emphasised the robust international connectivity that supports Sri Lanka’s tourism and highlighted the convenience of flying to Sri Lanka with Emirates, underscoring their premium facilities and seamless travel experiences.  Honorary Consul of Sri Lanka in Antwerp Monique De Decker highlighted adventure tourism and shopping opportunities in Sri Lanka, praising the warmth and hospitality of the Sri Lankan people.  Second Secretary of the Embassy Dulmini Dahanayake discussed diverse accommodation options, ranging from luxury to eco-friendly, all offering excellent value for money.  Luxembourg’s affluent tourists are evolving towards eco-friendly and sustainable tourism products, aligning with Sri Lanka’s commitment to responsible travel practices and environmental conservation. This shift positions Sri Lanka as an attractive destination for those seeking enriching, eco-conscious experiences. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Brussels is following these evolving interests and fostering a strong partnership with tour operators in Luxembourg, with the aim of showcasing Sri Lanka as a top-tier holiday destination for their clients in Luxembourg.

title: Tremor in Trinco
author: Author not found
Content: A minor tremor, measuring 3.4 on the Richter scale, was experienced in certain parts of the Trincomalee District yesterday at around 1:15 p.m., according to Senior Geologist Sanjeewa Hettiarachchi of the Geological Survey and Gem Mines Bureau (GSGMB). Hettiarachchi clarified that the tremor was felt in areas including Kantale, Morawewa and Gomarankadawala in the Trincomalee District, assuring the public that it was not harmful. He noted that, in comparison to previous tremors measuring 3 or 3.2 on the Richter scale, this particular tremor was slightly more intense, registering at 0.2 Richter higher. Residents of these areas reported feeling a sudden, minor tremor, prompting them to evacuate their residences in fear, said Hettiarachchi. To investigate the cause of the tremor, the GSGMB, in collaboration with other research bodies, will conduct a comprehensive study in the affected areas. Hettiarachchi emphasised that while the tremor may have caused concern among the public, it is not indicative of a dangerous situation. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: DMT instructed to prepare guidelines
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee on Energy and Transport has instructed the Department of Motor Traffic to prepare a new set of guidelines for the construction of bus halts in the country. These new standards should include the identification of new locations for parking buses until their turn to operate, the committee said. One significant guideline is the mandatory use of GPS technology in buses when issuing licences. The POC emphasises the importance of buses being equipped with GPS for tracking purposes. Additionally, the committee has urged bus owners to install CCTV cameras in their vehicles in the future. Furthermore, the committee directed DMT officers to implement a system allowing users of highways to make toll payments using QR codes in the future. This initiative was discussed during a meeting convened under the chairmanship of MP Nalaka Kottegoda in Parliament on 7 November.

title: JOINT PROPOSAL TO SACK SLC OFFICE-BEARERS UNANIMOUSLY PASSED
author: Author not found
Content: The joint proposal, brought by both the Government and the Opposition, for the removal of Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) Office-Bearers, was unanimously passed in Parliament yesterday (9). The humiliating performance by the Sri Lanka Men’s National Cricket Team, at ICC Men’s World Cup 2023, had sparked many a debate in the country and Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa presented the joint proposal to the House yesterday (9) morning.  It was seconded by Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva. The Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MPs, who participated in the debate, were not present in the Chamber when the proposal was passed. The motion, titled ‘Removal of corrupt Office-Bearers including President from Sri Lanka Cricket’, was debated from 9.30 a.m. until 5.30 p.m., as determined by the Committee on Parliamentary Affairs on Wednesday (8). The proposal emphasised the need for the Office-Bearers of Sri Lanka Cricket to step down and called for the enactment of new legislation, through a new Act, to ensure transparent and corruption-free governance of cricket. When the debate was concluded, the main Opposition Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) wanted to call for a Division. However, Despite the opposition’s repeated requests for a vote by name, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena proceeded with the resolution, claiming that both government and opposition MPs had agreed to its passage. The Speaker’s decision received angry remarks from the Opposition MPs who accused the Speaker of obstructing a vote on the debate to remove SLC officials. SJB MP Harsha de Silva expressed disappointment and stated, “Another blow to democracy in Sri Lanka. The Speaker refused repeated requests for a division, which would allow a vote by name, on the debate to remove the board of Sri Lanka Cricket on charges of gross corruption. Instead, the motion was passed without a vote, potentially concealing a significant division within the government.” Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe, making a strong statement, urged that expeditious measures be taken to suspend the passports of the SLC office bearers. One of them has already left the country. There is no point in closing the stable doors once the horse has bolted, he stressed. He also alleged that a colossal sum of SLC money has been deposited in three foreign bank accounts without obtaining the approval of Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL). The Opposition Leader requested to freeze all the bank accounts belonging to SLC. During the debate, Minister Kanchana Wijesekera who was a member of the Cabinet Sub- committee, appointed to overlook the SLC functions, in response to the resolution being presented, issued a warning, stating that the responsibility for any potential ban to SLC, imposed by the International Cricket Council (ICC), would lie with the Parliament,. It was also reported that President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who met the government MPs in Parliament also highlighted the risk of an ICC ban on SLC. The President who requested to support the joint-proposal, had reportedly told the MPs that he does not represent any party, but the country’s game of cricket. “We are the World Cup winners and we have to restore that glory. I will take all the decisions in my capacity to develop cricket in our country. My only fear is whether we have to face an international ban. I heard that ICC had discussed the current situation,” the President had said. Former President Maithiripala Sirisena stressed the corruption in the SLC is not a new problem. “The corruption at the SCL has been there for a very long time,” Sirisena said. Ilankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK) MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam stressed that the plight of island’s cricket is a mirror of the current situation of the entire country. BY Methmalie Dissanayake
