title: Protesters swarm Nuwara Eliya
author: Author not found
Content: Over 3,000 protesters converged at the 202-year-old Nuwara Eliya Post Office yesterday (9), chanting their opposition to the proposed sale of the British Raj monument to the Taj Samudra Hotel Chain, a plan set in motion by the Government. Several trade unions and associations, lawyers, several post office workers from the neighbouring townships areas and members of civil society joined the protest calling for a halt to the proposed hotel project. The demonstration continued despite the heavy showers and a large number of Police personnel present. The gathering occurred at the Nuwara Eliya Town, where the Post Office is atop a hill.    Asserting the Post Office’s significance as a cherished asset of the people of Sri Lanka, protesters urged the government to reconsider its decision to hand it over to a hotel. They proposed an alternative solution, suggesting that the land behind the Post Office, approximately 30 perches in size, could be allocated for the hotel project, while preserving the historic structure. This, they argued, would contribute to the enduring charm of ‘Little England,’ a concept the country promotes when showcasing Nuwara Eliya to international audiences. The demonstrators holding placards and black flags made powerful statements against the proposed transformation. As the protest paraded around the heart of Nuwara Eliya, all business establishments were closed in solidarity.  The protest caused a temporary roadblock in the town disrupting traffic for about an hour.   The Post Office, adorned with four manually operated clocks on all four sides of the building and featuring rooms available for rent during the April season houses several historical artefacts from the British rule, including the Postmaster’s uniform and vintage writing utensils. This cultural treasure has become a tourist attraction in its own right. Despite the government’s plan to convert it into a hotel, the public is concerned about losing access to the Post Office and its services, a point vehemently contested during the protest. Pic by S. Sathish By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Protest held demanding resignation of SLC Board
author: Author not found
Content: A group of cricket fans staged a protest opposite Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) at Maitland Place yesterday morning (9), demanding the resignation of ‘corrupt’ SLC office-bearers. Though the protesters had planned to stage their demonstration in front of the SLC head office Police informed them that they cannot grant approval for it. The protesters who had planned to arrive at Maitland Place, via the Independence Square, were prevented by the Police, from proceeding to the SLC premises, by placing barricades. Police informed the protesters that they cannot be allowed to go to the SLC office and when they had sought permission to visit the premises one by one, they were turned down again. Riot Police as well as the Armed Forces were summoned to prevent any untoward incidents. Meanwhile, during the course of the protest, a protester had strived to demonstrate against the Government over the country’s worsening health crisis, but the majority of protesters had insisted that they were there to demand the ouster of the SLC office bearers and not over the health crisis. This prompted a heated exchange of words between the protester, protesting over the health crisis and those demanding the resignation of SLC office bearers. Police were then forced to intervene and quell the situation. The protesting cricket fans charged that the protester, who had protested over the health crisis, had been sent by SLC President Shammi Silva to turn the attention of the country to other issues rather than his own predicament. Afterwards, the protesters carried out their demonstration at the entrance to the Independence Avenue via Vidya Mawatha and they peacefully disbursed at around 1.00 p.m. at which point the blocked roads were reopened for traffic by the Police. Pix by Sarath Kumara BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: High overseas demand for Palmyrah products
author: Author not found
Content: The Palmyrah Development Board has earned Rs 78 million from the export of palm-related products in 2023. According to the Board, there is a high demand for Palmyrah-related products, such as jaggery, toddy, and liquor, both in Sri Lanka and foreign markets, particularly in Canada. Recently, the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries Mahinda Amaraweera, visited the premises of the Palmyrah Development Board in Weerawila. Various food items and household equipment produced from Palmyrah trees were displayed during the visit. Currently, Sri Lanka has 11 million Palmyra trees, but unfortunately, 60 per cent of them are not being utilised. To address this, the Palmyrah Development Board has initiated special training programmes to educate people on how to promote Palmyrah-related products and gain economic benefits from them, Krishantha Pathiraja, chairman of the Palmyrah Development Board informed Minister Amaraweera. During the war, about 30 per cent of the Palmyrah trees in the Northern and Eastern Provinces were destroyed, but the board has successfully replanted an equal number in recent years. The board had taken steps to plant 200,000 new Palmyrah trees in the last four years, Pathiraja said. By October 2023, the country’s income from the export of Palmyrah-related products is expected to reach 78 million rupees. The international market has a high demand for Palmyrah jaggery, honey, toddy, and liquor. The Palmyrah Development Board is actively supporting the food industry by promoting various foods that can be prepared from palm trees grown without using any chemical fertilisers or poisons. Amaraweera suggested that more training should be provided for the palm-related food industry and the domestic appliance manufacturing industry. He also urged the Palmyrah Development Board to develop programmes that attract people to these industries. As part of the visit, the Minister presented recruitment letters to 30 trainees, who will be participating in training programmes conducted by the Palmyrah Development Board. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Vijitha queries composition of suspended SLC Interim Committee
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Vijitha Herath yesterday (9) questioned the basis of appointing Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe’s son, Attorney Rakhitha Rajapakshe, to the now-suspended Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) Interim Committee appointed by Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe. Speaking during the parliamentary debate on the joint proposal brought by the government and the opposition to remove the office bearers of SLC, Herath said, “The appointment of an Interim Committee is a positive move; however, doubts linger regarding the selection of its members. Specifically, the appointment of Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe’s son and a member from the Dharmadasa family raise questions about the transparency of the process. It appears that there may be ulterior motives at play, as indicated by the Sports Minister’s honest presentation. Further examination is warranted to uncover the truth behind these actions.” Herath said, the cricket governing body has been dominated by a few influential families. The succession of power has seen the Sumathipala family, followed by the Dharmadasa family and later the Ranatunga family. “However, it is worth questioning whether these families should be solely entrusted with the responsibility of leading. While Arjuna Ranatunga is undoubtedly a talented player, concerns arise about his suitability for administration,” he stressed. “The Cricket Board is plagued by the influence of money and politics, resulting in a detrimental impact on the game. While the cricket players strive to perform at their best, the board seems to be more focused on financial gains. This situation has raised concerns among the public, as the corrupt officials in cricket administration are causing the country to lose its deserved victories. Furthermore, the Cricket Board has evaded the scrutiny of the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE). One particular investigation by the COPE committee pertains to the extravagant expenditure of millions on renting a building in Kandy for the establishment of a university,” the JJB MP pointed out. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Respondents released due to technical reasons
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (9) released Vice Chancellor of the Kelaniya University Prof. Nilanthi de Silva and Secretary K.K. Dharmathileke, who had been charged with failing to furnish requisite details sought as per the Right to Information (RTI) Act. The Magistrate deemed, that though the RTI Commission of Sri Lanka has the legal right to file a case of this nature, the case in question had been filed without the approval of the said Commission, as well as without its official seal and insisted as such, that there were no legal provisions to further maintain the case against the suspects. Magistrate Alwis also observed that despite his order, the RTI Commission of Sri Lanka could yet re-file the case, against the two suspects, under its official name and seal. A case had been filed before the said Court by Prof. Prashanthi Narangoda of the said University, following a complaint lodged by her, with the RTI Commission of Sri Lanka. Prof. Narangoda as per her complaint, had stated that details sought by her, as per the Provisions of the RTI Act, pertaining to an internal probe conducted by the University, into an alleged feud between two of its Professors, had not been furnished to her. President’s Counsel Sarath Jayamanne appearing for the respondents, and raising initial objections, stated that though only the RTI Commission has the authority to file a case of this nature, it had been filed solely by the Directer General of the said Commission and emphasised that the latter, has not been empowered by law, to act in such a manner. He further added that a case of this scale has to be filed always targeting institutions and not individuals. Counsel Jayamanne stressed that the charges filed against his clients, were unlawful and should be deemed null and void. This was also the first such case that had been filed as per the RTI Act, by the RTI Commission before the Court. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Accused granted bail by Appeal Court after 4 years
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (9) granted bail to an accused who had been imprisoned for a period of four years after being arrested on charges of possession of and peddling 18 g of heroin. Enlarging the suspect on bail, the Appellate Court Bench mentioned that it cannot allow either State Counsels or the Police to incarcerate suspects for years on end according to their ‘whims and fancies’. The Court pointed out that until such time, evidence is produced to substantiate the charges, no accused can be found guilty of an offense beforehand. The case was called before a two-Judge Bench of the Court of Appeal comprising of Justices Sampath Abeykoon and P. Kumararatnam. In its bail order, the Bench further added that if the fundamental rights accorded to citizens and enshrined in the country’s Constitution are to be taken away, then hard or foolproof evidence that is acceptable to the Court has to be submitted. The Court accordingly instructed the accused, identified as Dinuksha Fernando, alias ‘Chooti’, to be released on cash bail in Rs 100,000 and two sureties of two million rupees each. Lastly, the Court deemed it unfair to allow the accused to be further remanded when his lawyer had produced sufficient submissions to warrant his release on bail. Attorneys-at-Law Nissansala Dissanayake and Weerasena Ranahewa looked into the interests of the accused. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Current SLC office -bearers should resign – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: If the current office-bearers of Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) have an ounce of self-respect, they should immediately resign from their posts, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa stressed in Parliament yesterday (9). During the debate on a joint proposal brought to remove the SLC office bearers, Premadasa emphasised the need for unity, stating that despite political differences, everyone should work together for the betterment of cricket in Sri Lanka. He stressed the importance of removing the “corrupt cricket administration” and implementing a clear and comprehensive programme to safeguard the future of the sport. Furthermore, Premadasa highlighted the need to protect cricket from alleged drug traffickers, sexual predators and underworld conspirators who maintain control within the Cricket Board. Additionally, Premadasa proposed the formation of a forum called ‘MPs for Cricket’, suggesting that their suggestions and opinions should be sought and that they should be involved in the efforts to protect the game. The Opposition Leader also commended Minister of Sports Roshan Ranasinghe, for his strong and unwavering speech in Parliament on Wednesday, acknowledging his resilience during this critical period. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: MCPA writes to President’s Secy calling for probe
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association (MCPA) called for an inquiry into alleged misconduct, by the Health Ministry Secretary and top health officials, in order to restore confidence in the country’s healthcare system while ensuring that those responsible for upholding the highest standards were held accountable. In a letter sent to the President’s Secretary yesterday (9), MCPA President Chamal Sanjeeva called for an inquiry into the conduct of the Health Secretary and other Ministry officials, not merely for the purpose of disciplinary action, but also to exonerate any officials who were innocent of misconduct. He said, recent media reports and media briefings had shed light on allegations, which had been levelled against the Health Secretary and several top officials of the Health Ministry. “These accusations have raised serious doubts about the conduct of key health sector officials, who are responsible for maintaining the integrity and transparency of our healthcare system,” he lamented. Dr. Sanjeeva said, Sri Lanka’s healthcare system which was regarded as one of the best in the region had remarkable achievements to its credit and had been able to successfully manage the first Covid-19 wave despite the limited resources that were available. “However, the recent alleged malpractices, mismanagement and corruption have tarnished the reputation of our healthcare system and eroded public trust,” he said noting that it had also demoralised the enthusiastic State healthcare workers in the island. Noting that the MCPA possessed credible evidence, he accused the Health Secretary and certain officials in the Ministry of undue influence on government tender procedures, malpractices and falsely framing charges against whistleblowers, prevention of disciplinary action against accused officials, misleading the Auditor General and violating the Human Rights of a Parliamentarian. “We urge you to follow the formal procedures outlined in the Establishment Code to address these allegations properly,” the MCPA President appealed. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Arrest warrant issued for Fisheries Corp FM
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday (9) issued a warrant for the arrest of the Fisheries Corporation Finance Manager, Chandani Perera, who is the first witness for the Prosecution, in the misappropriation case against six accused, including former Deputy Minister of Fisheries Sarath Guneratne. Besides the former Deputy Minister, the other five charged before High Court, by the Attorney General, are former Chairman of the Fisheries Corporation Piyal Abeyekera, former head of the Development Lottery Board (DLB) Upali Liyanage, Chandana Pelpita, Upul Kumarasinghe and Lakshitha Munasinghe. The Attorney General has charged them with incurring a sum in excess of Rs 10 million, which had been set aside for the development work of the Negombo Lagoon, towards a political rally in support of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, in the lead up to the 2015 Presidential Poll and for having flouted provisions contained in Sections of the Offences against the Public Properties Act, via their actions, committed from 20 November, 2014 to 7 January, 2015. The Judge issued the arrest warrant on the witness, after she had failed to be present in Court, despite being instructed to do so at the previous hearing and over her failure to apprise the Court, regarding her absence. Deputy Solicitor General Sudarshana Silva, prosecuting on behalf of the CID, informed Judge Ranaraja, that the witness concerned, had also not even conveyed to him a valid reason, over her failure to be present, at yesterday’s hearing of the case. When the case was called up, President’s Counsels Nalin Ladduwahetty and Sampath Mendis, along with Attorneys-at-Law Asitha Vipulanayake and Lal Kularatne appeared on behalf of the six accused. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: BASL ‘disturbed’ by Court proceedings being discussed in Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) says it is ‘disturbed’ by the allegations made by a Cabinet Minister in Parliament on Wednesday (8), in connection with a case relating to a matter concerning the appointment of an Interim Committee to Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) and the alleged conduct of a Judge of the Court of Appeal. In a statement, the BASL said impartial individuals should be appointed to investigate the truth of the allegations made against the Judge. “If the said purported allegations are proved to be true, it would undermine the integrity of the judicial system and if the said allegations are found to be baseless, the same would undermine the independence of the Judiciary and the integrity of the justice system in our country. Any allegation made against the judiciary if found to be untrue, the same would attract penal sanctions including Contempt of Court. The BASL ‘strongly’ call on the stakeholders to act within the provisions laid down in the Constitution and to protect the independence of the judiciary at any cost,” the statement said. The BASL said, the independence of the judiciary is a fundamental principle of the rule of law, noting that any form of undue interference with judicial independence is ‘extremely serious’ and would erode public confidence in the judiciary. “The statements being made in respect of ongoing Court cases and reference to Judges, purportedly taking cover behind parliamentary privileges, are seen as a direct threat to the independence of the judiciary. The legal fraternity has continuously raised serious concerns regarding this matter. The relevant MPs must be reminded that the right to represent a client is a professional right that has been safeguarded by law, and any threat to the right, is an attack on the profession at large,” the BASL said.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Leprosy awareness among public vital
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana said, new awareness and control programmes should be introduced to create leprosy awareness among the public. He said, the media could contribute largely to educate the people about the control of communicable and non-communicable diseases. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry yesterday (8) said, a special programme was held in Colombo, in collaboration with Government and Non-Governmental Organisations working to  suppress and control leprosy. The programme commenced under the Chairmanship of Health Minister Dr. Pathirana under the theme a ‘Leprosy free nation’. The programme focussed on steps taken to control leprosy, future steps which need to be taken, staff training and methods to be followed. The programme is being held in collaboration with the Leprosy Control Campaign under the Ministry of Health, Colombo Regional Health Services Directorate, Alliance Development Trust, Keveri Kala Manram. Together with the WHO, the Ministry of Health has implemented systematic programmes to control leprosy. The setbacks in control programmes during the Covid -19 pandemic is now on the mend, the spokesman said. Director Leprosy Control Campaign, Dr. Prasad Ranaweera, Colombo Regional Health Service Director, Dr. Chandana Gajanayake, Consultant Community Physician Dr. Kasuni Kalubowila, Batticaloa Regional Health Services Director Dr. G. Sukunan, President Leprosy People’s Association G. Amarasinghe, Dermatologist Leprosy Campaign Dr. Indira Kahawita and representatives of the Government and NGOs and Doctors, public health inspectors were also present. (DJ)

title: Sri Lanka Tourism show cased at World Travel Market London
author: Author not found
Content: World Travel Market (WTM), the leading global event of Travel and Tourism Trade kicked off on 6 November at the Excel Exhibition Hall, London, UK promoting international travel throughout the world. The event was held for three days from 6-8 November. With the intention of promoting Sri Lanka as a renowned destination in world travel, the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) with the support of the Sri Lanka High Commission in London participated in the event, along with 73 partners of the industry. The main objective of this year’s representation is to provide the Sri Lanka travel industry with an opportunity to meet, interact and network with travel and tourism industry partners from the UK and around the world to gain immediate competitive advantage for the Sri Lanka travel industry, stay abreast with the latest developments and to disseminate information about Sri Lanka along with the new products and services. Sri Lanka pavilion at the WTM was declared open on 6 November by Duchess of Rutland Her Grace Emma Manners, and Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, in the presence of High Commissioner of Sri Lanka to the United Kingdom Saroja Sirisena, Chairman of Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau Chalaka Gajabahu,  Chairman, Sri Lanka Convention Bureau Thisum Jayasuriya, Country Manager, SriLankan Airlines Chinthaka Weerasinghe, other officials of Sri Lanka Tourism and distinguished guests representing the UK travel trade. Minister Fernando and the Chairman of Sri Lanka Tourism conducted a series of B2B meetings with leading UK travel companies, associations, and travel media during the three days. A Press Conference by Sri Lanka Tourism was organised for the UK mainstream and travel media on 7 November at the Exhibition venue. The Sri Lanka stall showcased traditional Sri Lankan dancing, providing an opportunity for the visitors to get a glimpse of the culturally rich traditions of Sri Lanka performed by a dance troupe based in London, under the overall theme of “You will come back for more”. A ‘Ceylon Tea’ counter was featured at the Sri Lanka Stall to serve freshly brewed ‘Ceylon Tea’ to the visitors to the Stall throughout the three days. Sri Lanka is one of the most sought-after travel destinations among tourists with arrivals surpassing One Million for 2023, marking a significant milestone after enduring multiple challenges over the past three years. Among the key markets, the United Kingdom has been the second contributor with a share of 11%. The participation of Sri Lanka at the WTM-2023 paved the way to project Sri Lanka among leading UK travel and tour companies, bloggers and social media enthusiasts, as a world-class destination. WTM attracts more than 50,000 visitors, 5,000 trade partners (exhibitors) and over 3,000 journalists around the world each year.

title: Agri Ministry to cultivate 370,000 fish fingerlings
author: Author not found
Content: The Agriculture Ministry of the North Central Province has taken measures to breed 370,000 fingerlings this year under the programme of breeding fish fingerlings in identified reservoirs in the North Central Province. This was revealed in the Provincial Agriculture Ministry’s progress review meeting held on Wednesday (8), under the Chairmanship of North Central Province Governor Mahipala Herath. Currently, the market value of a tilapia fingerling is about Rs 4.50.Under this programme, Rs 17 million will be spent  on farming 370,000 tilapia fingerlings. One of the main objectives of this programme is to boost the income of fishermen in the North Central Province and improve the nutritional status of the people – especially children in the province. The Provincial Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Department under the Provincial Ministry of Agriculture will conduct the programme.  The Provincial Fisheries Department carries out the collection of fish fingerlings annually for farming purposes in identified reservoirs. It was noted that milk production at the provincial level had increased by 5.6 million litres compared to last year.  The income of dairy farmers in the provinces has increased significantly as the price of a litre of milk had increased. It was observed that people in the Province were more inclined towards the management of dairy cattle. The income of the farmers who cultivated  mung bean had increased significantly with success of  mung bean cultivation as a mid season crop in the North Central Province.  There was a decrease in the price of a kilo of mung beans in the past, however, it had seen an increase and was sold at Rs 1,200-Rs 1,400 per kilo. Also, the Provincial Agriculture Department has planned to produce 32,000 bushels of seed paddy this season. Provincial Chief Secretary Chandrasiri Bandara, Provincial Agriculture Ministry Secretary Vijaya Wanasinghe, Provincial Agriculture Director Priyangani Madana, Provincial Animal Production Department Director Vaidya Amarasinghe were also present. ​ By Thisara S. Somarathna – Anuradhapura

title: Dettol paints a Hopeful picture to mark Global Handwashing Day 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Dettol, Sri Lanka’s ‘Most Loved Brand’ and one of the world’s most trusted global brands, recently celebrated Global Handwashing Day on 15 October with a special Art Competition to inspire the next generation to practice good hygiene habits. Launched under the theme of Wishabeeja Nethi Hetak – Suwabara Ratak, ‘A Healthy Country Without Germs’, the Art Competition provided children around the island with a creative platform to showcase their ideas on a cleaner Sri Lanka. Speaking about the competition, Lilani Rajapaksha – Senior Brand Manager-Dettol, Reckitt Benckiser said: “Good habits are best learnt young and it’s important that we give our children a head start on understanding the importance of health and cleanliness. The competition’s theme was designed to get children thinking about hygiene and essential habits like handwashing because these are good practices that they will cherish for life. As a brand that’s committed to safeguarding the health of Sri Lankan consumers, it’s our responsibility to educate the next generation on how they can support a cleaner Nation”. The competition had four age categories including  7 and Under 7, 8-10, 11-13 and 14-16, and each drew in spirited and creative art pieces on the theme of a germ-free Nation. It was judged by an independent panel of judges who awarded the 1st place to Hasadi Akithma from Alawwa in the 7 and Under 7 category, Senuth Sanuja from Wellampitiya in the 8-10, K G Hansi Erandika from Kuruvita in the 11-13 and Danidu Manodhya Bandarafrom Rabukkanain the 14-16 age category, respectively. Beyond celebrating Global Handwashing Day 2023, the Art Competition is another extension of Dettol’s commitment to fostering a society which prioritises good hygiene practices to ensure a healthier and cleaner Sri Lanka. Dettol was developed in 1933 for doctors who needed an effective solution to prevent sepsis following childbirth and has since become a household name across the world. In Sri Lanka, Dettol has been present since 1962, offering a diversified product range across personal hygiene and home care. The brand’s success is built on three iconic foundations: trust, efficacy, and education.

title: Medicinal drugs need to be manufactured locally– Dr Pathirana
author: Author not found
Content: The country will be economically vulnerable if there were no stable manufacturing industries in Sri Lanka, Health and Industry Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana stressed, saying that the need for it has been strongly demonstrated in the past. Dr. Pathirana noted that 15% – 20% of the country’s pharmaceutical requirements are produced domestically and the rest are imported. The Government spends over USD 700 million annually on importations. 1,347 types of medicines are imported into Sri Lanka. 862 types of drugs are used for the treatment of patients on a priority list, out of which 208 types of drugs are produced in the country. The Minister made these remarks during a discussion held with local pharmaceutical manufacturers, at the Ministry of Health yesterday (09). The meeting was held to discuss issues faced by local pharmaceutical manufacturers and to develop cordial relations between the new Health Minister and the local pharmaceutical industrialists. The medicines required by the country should be produced within it, Dr. Pathirana noted pledging the support of the government and his Ministry. He stressed on the need to formalise the process, step by step, noting that all should be accomplished in a clear and transparent manner. The pharmaceutical industry does not have a favourable image in Sri Lanka, Dr. Pathirana said, observing that the people too, looked at the Health Ministry from an unfavourable angle. But, the Ministry wishes to correct and clarify that image. He pointed out that it will be possible to save a lot of money. In addition, neighbouring countries like India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are getting huge incomes from pharmaceutical production. Highlighting the need for timely payments to local pharmaceutical manufacturers Dr. Pathirana also urged the industrialists to ensure that they delivered the medicines, for which they had received tenders from his Ministry, in order to avoid medicinal drug shortages. He noted that local pharmaceutical manufacturers also need to send the related documents to the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) and get the necessary approval in accordance with the procedures, if they want to register new medicinal drug or a pharmaceutical item. State Minister of Health Dr. Seeta Arambepola, Secretary of the Ministry of Health Janaka Sri Chandragupta, Director General of Health Services Dr. Asela Gunawardena, Chairman of the National Drug Regulatory Authority Dr. Ananda Wijewickrama, Chairman of the State Pharmaceutical Corporation Dr. Ajith Mendis, Director of Medical Supply Division Dr. Kapila Wickramanayake and  local drug manufacturers were present. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Hamas victim’s body arrives
author: Author not found
Content: The body of the Sri Lankan national Sujith Yatawara, who was killed by the Hamas in Israel was brought to the island last morning (9). Yatawara was initially suspected to have been taken hostage by the Palestinian militant group Hamas however; he was later confirmed dead in Israel. He had remained missing since 7 October, the day Hamas militants stormed from the blockaded Gaza Strip into nearby Israeli towns to launch an unprecedented attack. Subsequently, the DNA samples provided by Bandara’s children were sent to Israel for further investigations. Yatawara, who hailed from Wennappuwa, had travelled to Israel eight years ago for a job. According to airport sources the Fly Dubai flight FZ579 carrying Yatawara’s remains touched down at the BIA in Katunayake at around 8.37 a.m. yesterday (9). The deceased’s spouse Jayani Maduwanthi and two children, aged 13 and nine, were present at the airport premises to receive the casket. Additionally, Israel High Commissioner in Sri Lanka and a group of State officials including State Minister Arundika Fernando, and Foreign Employment Bureau officials were also present. The final rites of Yatawara are scheduled to be conducted at the Madawalapitiya Public Cemetery in Thulawela, Wennappuwa. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Agbo on the rampage again
author: Author not found
Content: Tusker Agbo, who is currently being treated for an injury to its left leg has shown signs of improving, officials from the Department of Wildlife said. The tusker has been treated for the past four-months by vets attached to the department, while its treatment process had included surgeries, scans, blood tests and application of ointments etc. The officers from the WD had also supplied some 250 to 300 kilos of vegetables, fruits etc to the tusker for its daily intake of food. But the tusker having recovered from its injury had begun to roam about and it had entered the village Diwulwewa in Thirappane during the night of 8 November and had proceeded to damage the kitchen of a house in search of food. The tusker had also damaged several cultivations nearby and residents are seeking the help from authorities to ward off the danger posed to their lives, limbs and livelihoods by Agbo. BY  Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: COPF urges Tax on companies earning super gains due to ‘Midnight Gazette’
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Finance (COPF) issued a directive to Ministry of Finance officials, instructing them to impose income tax on companies that exploited the ‘midnight gazette’ to make significant profits, which COPF refers to as ‘super gains’ in order to compensate for lost revenue. The Committee also tasked officials with developing and implementing mechanisms to collect these taxes or providing detailed explanations if they are unable to do so, along with proposing remedialactions to prevent such incidents in the future. The seriousness of the situation became evident when COPF obtained essential data related to sugar imports for the past three months from the Department of Customs. COPF questioned Ministry of Finance officials about the suspicious timing of this tax increase and the surge in sugarimports by certain companies just before the tax hike. In response, Ministry of Finance officials stated that the tax increase was part of the fiscal-basedrevenue consolidation programme linked to an IMF initiative. Furthermore, they highlighted that the sudden increase in sugar imports was a seasonal occurrence. In light of these claims, the Committee insisted on a comprehensive comparative analysis of previous years to verify these assertions. The Committee sounded the alarm about specific companies importing unusually large quantities of sugar without concrete evidence supporting the necessity for such massive imports. For example, a company that typically imported 2,000 MT of sugar monthly inexplicably imported 10,000 MT in October, just before the tax increase, reaping substantial gains as the tax jumped 200-fold from 25 cents to Rs 50. COPF Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva stressed the importance of ending the use of ‘midnight gazettes’ related to special commodity levies. These practices provide the Minister of Finance with unchecked authority to change tax rates or grant tax exemptions to specific companies. This concern aligns with the recommendations made by the IMF in their Governance Diagnostic Report, urging Sri Lanka to eliminate ‘midnight gazettes’ due to their potential for fostering corruption.

title: Principal spends students’ meal money for private function
author: Author not found
Content: Daily funds allocated to provide a healthy meal to students, of a school in North Central Province (NCP), have been allegedly utilised to hold a private function of the school principal, informed sources said. These sources stated that the principal in question had allegedly informed his students that the free mid-day meal provided to them will be stopped on a particular day and for them to look out for meals  themselves,  whilst he had fraudulently obtained the finances to provide the meal. Assistant Education Director of the NCP B.P.P. Hewamanage said the actions of the principal cannot be condoned and explained that a probe had already been initiated into his alleged actions. He further added that if found guilty of the offence disciplinary action would be instituted against the principal. BY Kithsiri Wanasinghe – Nachchaduwa

title: Eran forwards three Tax proposals towards ensuring stability
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to address Sri Lanka’s ongoing economic challenges and chart a course toward stability, MP Eran Wickremaratne has put forward three visionary Tax Policy proposals. Wickremaratne’s recommendations prioritise the optimisation of public assets, the establishment of a dedicated tax policy committee, and the creation of a centralised revenue collection authority. These proposals, if implemented, have the potential to rejuvenate Sri Lanka’s financial landscape. Foremost among Wickremaratne’s proposals is the transformation of public assets into lucrative income generators. The proposals focus on leveraging State-owned properties and resources to boost government revenue. By converting these assets into income streams, Sri Lanka can lay a solid foundation for sustainable economic growth. To ensure a well-structured and equitable tax framework, Wickremaratne called for the establishment of a Tax Policy Committee. “This dedicated body would be tasked with formulating and overseeing tax policies, ensuring they align with the nation’s economic objectives. A coordinated approach to tax policy is vital for providing clarity and predictability to businesses and investors.Sri Lanka’s tax collection system is set for transformation through the creation of a single, centralised revenue collection authority. This streamlined approach aims to reduce administrative complexities, enhance efficiency, and expedite revenue collection. By implementing this proposal, the Government can boost its fiscal stability and resource management,” he said. Wickremaratne highlighted that the significance of predictability in the tax regime, emphasising that it is often more important than the tax rate itself. This predictability allows businesses to plan effectively and allocate resources without unnecessary waste. The former Minister advocates for avoiding sudden tax changes, such as super gain taxes and surcharges, which can disrupt economic planning.He also addressed the need to reduce financial leakages, lower government expenditure and enhancing revenue collection. Additionally, he emphasises the importance of negotiating foreign currency debt restructuring to bring it to manageable levels. This shared responsibility will play a pivotal role in securing Sri Lanka’s economic future. Furthermore, he expressed concern about the excessive spending on defence and public services, highlighting that Sri Lanka’s defence expenditure exceeds 10 per cent, the highest in Asia. He proposes a reassessment and rationalisation of these expenditures, suggesting that the current ratio of public servants to ordinary citizens must be realigned to match global standards.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: US partners with India’s Adani Group
author: Author not found
Content: The strategic partnership between India and Sri Lanka has joined forces with the United States International Development Finance Corporation (DFC), which extended a USD 553 million loan to strengthen the collaboration between India’s Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd (APSEZ) and John Keells Holdings, who have taken over the Colombo West International Terminal (CWIT) for a Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) operation. The agreement was signed yesterday (8) in Colombo with the arrival of CEO of the US’ DFC, Scott Nathan. In 2021, the Adani Group secured a 35-year Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) operation contract with a target investment of USD 700 million. Adani views the collaboration between India and the US as a strengthening force in their work on the CWIT. This strategic initiative is receiving substantial support from the US’s DFC, which specialises in partnering with the private sector to address strategic priorities in the developing world, said CEO of Adani Ports, Karan Adani. The involvement of the DFC in funding the Adani project is seen as a strong endorsement by the international community of their vision, capabilities and governance. Notably, this project represents the largest FDI for Sri Lanka through a single project he added. Upon completion, it is expected to have a transformative impact on the socioeconomic landscape not only in Colombo but across the entire island, significantly bolstering Sri Lanka’s trade, Adani added.   Foreign Minister Ali Sabry highlighted the significance of a deep-water container terminal and its critical infrastructure impact on the South Asian region. He said last year was economically challenging, but the country successfully secured an IMF deal within a 9-month period. However, he acknowledged that there are more challenges to be addressed and employment and investments are needed for growth. “In that context, the involvement of DFC and Adani, along with John Keells, in this monumental investment is a highly positive development with immense potential. It demonstrates our willingness to partner with everyone around the world, and we are committed to progress,” he said. DFC’s CEO, Nathan, who had visited the CWIT, emphasised that the CWIT represents a major investment and will play a vital role in providing critical infrastructure for the region. DFC’s financing will contribute to the transformation of Colombo into a world-class logistics hub, strategically positioned at the intersection of major shipping routes and emerging markets. DFC’s collaboration with private-sector partners is not only assisting the Sri Lankan people but also generating job opportunities. The Port of Colombo, the largest and busiest transshipment port in the Indian Ocean, has been operating at over 90% capacity since 2021, underscoring the need for additional capacity. The new terminal will cater to the growing economies in the Bay of Bengal, capitalising on Sri Lanka’s prime location on major shipping routes and its proximity to these expanding markets. CEO Nathan, prior to finalising the loan agreement for the Adani Group, was in Athens, Greece, where he signed a financing agreement for a USD 125 million loan for ONEX Elefsis Shipyards and Industries. CEO of CWIT Harikirishan Sundaram, pointed out that over the course of 18 months, they collaborated closely with DFC to develop a state-of-the-art facility at CWIT aimed at attracting transshipment traffic from the region, with a target of handling 3.2 millionTEUs annually for Sri Lanka at the Port of Colombo. India’s strategic partnership with Sri Lanka in the port business dates back to 2017 and Adani Group’s initial project agreement on the East Container Terminal (ECT) that was cancelled due to geopolitical challenges. In 2021, instead of the ECT, Adani was offered the CWIT. The CWIT was awarded on the basis that India’s largest port operator will hold a 51 per cent stake in the terminal and John Keels Holding will own 34 per cent. The remaining 15 per cent of the stake will be owned by Sri Lanka Ports Authority. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Nuwara Eliya postal workers stage token strike
author: Author not found
Content: All post offices in the Nuwara Eliya District, including the Nuwara Eliya main post office, were closed as employees staged a token strike in protest against the Government’s efforts turn the historic post office into a hotel. Meanwhile, an Extraordinary Gazette Notification designating postal services as an essential service was released yesterday (8) evening, disclosed Minister Bandula Gunawardena. The Minister confirmed that he has already submitted a request for the Gazette Notification. However, representatives from the United Postal Trade Unions’ Front (UPTU) said members will launch a protest from today (9) against moves made to turn the Nuwara Eliya Post Office into a Hotel. They said they were prepared to face any legal consequences due to the strike action and vowed that they will not stand for the sale of any resource in the Nuwara Eliya District. Union representatives, speaking at a media briefing, to inform the public of moves made to transform the Nuwara Eliya Post Office into a star class hotel, said they were staging a protest in this regard. They further warned that their protest will not be suspended until the Government shelves its plans to sell the Nuwara Eliya Post Office to a private hotel. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Startling rise in dengue cases
author: Author not found
Content: The National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) said the total number of dengue cases had risen to a startling 70,178, with a total 43 dengue deaths by yesterday (8). According to statistics issued by the NDCU’s DenSys Surveillance the dengue death toll was at 39 by Monday (6).  It increased to 43 on Tuesday (7). The highest number of cases was recorded from Colombo District with 14,884 (21.1%). Gampaha and Kalutara Districts recorded 14,232 (20.4%) and 4456 (6.4%) cases respectively.  The Unit issuing the Current Status of Dengue said that the Western Province had a total 33,557 cases from the beginning of the year till 8 November 2023. Kandy from the Central Province has 6,574 dengue cases while Puttalam and Kurunegala have 3,218 and 3,631 dengue cases respectively.  The NDCU has identified 36 High Risk Medical Officer of Health (MOH) areas by the 43rd week of this year. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 62 shootings, 32 deaths this year
author: Author not found
Content: Sixty-two (62) shooting incidents have taken place this year, while 32 lost their lives in these incidents and another 37 were injured, revealed Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena in Parliament yesterday (8). During the Prime Minister’s question time yesterday, multiple MPs raised concerns about criminal activities perpetrated by organised criminal gangs. “In response to a query from the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Major Sudarshana Denipitiya,  regarding the Government’s measures to combat these activities, the Prime Minister said the Government, in collaboration with the Sri Lanka Police, and the judiciary were implementing a comprehensive plan to reduce crime. Roadblocks have been set up at locations associated with criminal incidents, and regular search operations and raids were being conducted in these areas. Armed officers are deployed to closely monitor and apprehend suspected gang members to prevent criminal activities. The Prime Minister also said a committee, headed by SDIG for the Western Province, Deshabandu Tennakon, was being formed and would work with the State Intelligence Services to combat organised crime. They would be focusing on the Western and Southern Provinces. Maj. Denipitiya inquired about reports of over 30 alleged gang leaders migrating abroad and continuing their criminal activities in Sri Lanka. The Premier said warrants have been issued for these suspects and that law enforcement agencies abroad were cooperating to bring them to justice. Efforts are being made to streamline the process of apprehending these suspects, including collaboration with the BIA to prevent suspects from leaving the country. The Prime Minister also revealed plans for an automated facial recognition project at the BIA using a specialised camera system, which is currently in the early research phase and will be implemented soon. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Delhi Police put Mathews Time-Out to good use
author: Author not found
Content: Angelo Mathews’ timed out dismissal has created much conversation across social media, and Delhi Police, took this opportunity to get across an important point on their Facebook page. On Tuesday, the day after Shakib Al Hasan invoked the first ever instance of a ‘timed out’ dismissal in the history of international cricket at Delhi’s Arun Jaitley Stadium, a picture was posted from Delhi Police’s Facebook page. It featured Angelo Mathews in the aftermath of his dismissal, looking distraught and gesturing that his helmet strap had broken. A message was placed on the image that said, ‘A good helmet can protect you from being timed out’. The message was posted in reference to the high number of road accidents in Delhi in recent years. According to Delhi Traffic Police, there has been a four per cent increase in fatal traffic accidents from 2019 to 2023. In a separate report from 2021, it was said that motorcycle and scooter riders were the second most vulnerable group among those killed in traffic accidents in Delhi. It is widely accepted that wearing helmets reduces the risk of severe head injuries among motorcycle riders. The State Transport Authority of Odisha made a similar post the day before, encouraging riders to wear helmets and secure the strap to play a long innings without running the risk of losing a wicket.

title: NMRA CEO fired
author: Author not found
Content: Dr. Vijith Gunasekara has been removed from the position of CEO of the National Medicine Regulatory Authority (NMRA) following the NMRA’s role in the recent issues related to medicinal drugs, especially the Immunoglobulin IV scam, Ceylon Today learns. A member of the Sri Lanka Scientific Service (SLSS), Senior Scientist D.D. Bulathsinhala was appointed acting CEO of the NMRA. Sources noted that steps would be taken to advertise the position calling for applications.    With the controversial issues surrounding the NMRA, its board members met yesterday (8), for the first time, following the appointment of new Chairman Dr. Ananda Wijewickrema. Informed sources said the meeting had been chaired by Dr. Wijewickrema while nine Board Members, including the Director General Health Services (DGHS) Dr. Asela Gunawardena, participated in the meeting. Representatives from Colleges of Medicine also attended the meeting, they said. Dr. Vijith Gunasekara who has been recalled to the Health Ministry left the office of the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and has been transferred to the Health Ministry, sources noted. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Right kidney never reached Renal Unit – Specialist
author: Author not found
Content: Specialist Doctor in charge of the Renal Unit, at the Lady Ridgeway Hospital, Borella Shanthini Guneratne testifying before Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, yesterday, in the case filed into the death of a three-year-old toddler at the LRH, stated that victim’s left kidney was still in good condition at the hospital, but that the right kidney of the deceased, which was also said to be in good condition, had never been received by them. The hearing of testimony, related to the demise of the toddler, was called yesterday (8) before the said Court and Dr. Guneratne, made the aforementioned submissions, in response to questions posed to her by officers from the Borella Police, who prosecuted. She further mentioned that the left kidney of the victim, which was received by her Unit, was currently in good condition, after being immersed in ammonia. Director of the hospital Dr. Malith Samarasinghe, testifying previously, had informed the Court, that following tests conducted into the deceased’s illness, it had been confirmed that his right kidney was situated at the exact spot, without any unusual state being noticed. The Hospital Director had also insisted, during his testimony, that the functioning of the left kidney of the deceased had been rated at nine per cent, while his right kidney, had functioned at 91 per cent, at the time of the testing process. Attorney-at-Law Y. L. M. Yusuf, appearing for the aggrieved party, at a previous hearing of the case, had stated that though the Hospital Director had mentioned that one of the kidneys of the victim had been removed due to a shortcoming on the part of the doctors during surgery, the JMO having mentioned clearly in his report, that the victim had only a single kidney, had complicated matters. The victim was identified as three-year-old Amdi Aslim, a resident of Colombo 13 and following a complaint lodged with the Borella Police, by the parents of the toddler, that they were suspicious about the demise of their offspring, the Police filed the case against the said Hospital, before the Colombo Additional Magistrate’s Court.  BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Court Registrar, another further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Two individuals, including the Registrar of the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court, who were remanded on various charges, including document forgery, were further remanded, until 22 November, by the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court yesterday (8). The first accused, the Registrar, was taken into custody on 13 October and the second accused was apprehended four days later. Both individuals face allegations of forging documents that falsely indicated the lifting of a foreign travel ban for a suspect, instructing the Controller General of Immigration & Emigration to permit overseas travel. The Colombo Fort Magistrate, Thilina Gamage, filed a complaint with the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) against the Registrar. Furthermore, the CID has taken statements from two officers of the Immigration & Emigration Department in connection with the incident. Statements have also been gathered from approximately ten staff members of the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court.

title: ‘The River to Jaffna’ project to resume – Premier
author: Author not found
Content: To address the drinking water shortage issue in Jaffna, the Government is planning to launch ‘The River to Jaffna’ project, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena revealed in Parliament yesterday (8). In response to a question raised by Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Vijitha Herath, the Premier said relevant departments and engineers are currently engaged in preliminary discussions to find a comprehensive solution to the water scarcity issue, in accordance with the country’s irrigation heritage. A similar project, known as the ‘River to Jaffna’, was initially proposed in 1954 by the late Engineer S. Arumugam. Construction began in the early 1960s but was interrupted in the late 1960s due to floods and was eventually abandoned due to the ethnic conflict that followed in the subsequent decades, he said. The Prime Minister added that due to the high capital cost associated with running sea water desalination plants, the government intends to focus on developing over 40,000 lakes and tanks across the country and harnessing rainwater as a viable alternative. He also said the Government was taking steps to safeguard areas susceptible to frequent flooding. When Herath queried the Government’s decision to seek the support of the International Water Management Institute (IWMI), an organisation accused of having an agenda to commodify water and water access, Gunawardena said Sri Lanka, being one of ten countries facing the highest climate risk, is dealing with adverse weather effects, including unexpected heavy rainfall and severe drought conditions. Therefore, he emphasised the importance of Sri Lanka collaborating with both local and international institutions and experts in the field to find solutions to mitigate these problems and exchange knowledge and expertise on climate change and water management. The Premier also expressed the Government’s intention to work with various organisations and individuals, including the Climate Change Secretariat of Sri Lanka, Sri Lanka Climate Fund, International Centre for Research in Agro-Forestry (ICRAF), World Food Program (WFP), Global Climate Fund (GCF), United Nations Development Program (UNDP), Sustainable Development Council of Sri Lanka, and other local and international organisations, to achieve the goals. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Sevanagala retailers stop selling sugar, blame MRP
author: Author not found
Content: Several owners of retail shops, in villages across Sevanagala, have decided to stop selling sugar with immediate effect, due to the Maximum Retail Price (MRP) imposed by the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA). An owner of a retail shop said they had decided to take this measure following joint discussions with other retail shop owners. He claimed that after the CAA had imposed a maximum retail price for sugar (Rs 275 for white sugar and Rs330 for brown sugar) wholesale owners sell a kilo of white sugar at Rs 290 while a kilo of brown sugar is sold at Rs 330. He said in such a situation they cannot afford to purchase sugar at the price offered to them by wholesale dealers and then sell it back to consumers at the  CAA’s maximum retail price. BY S. Kuttapitiya – Sewanagala
