title: Red alerts issued for 20 districts
author: Author not found
Content: The Natural Hazards Early Warning Centre, of the Meteorology Department, has issued a red alert for thunderstorms with severe lightning for 20 districts. Thundershowers accompanied by lightning are expected in the Western, Central, Sabaragamuwa, North-Central, North-Western, Uva, and Southern Provinces, as well as in the Mullaitivu and Mannar Districts during the evening or night. In the Western, Central, Sabaragamuwa, and Uva Provinces, as well as the Galle and Matara Districts, heavy showers exceeding 100 mm are likely. The public is advised to take necessary precautions to protect themselves from lightning. The affected districts are: Mullaitivu, Mannar, Vavuniya, Puttalam, Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Kurunegala, Matale, Kandy, Gampaha, Kegalla, Nuwara-Eliya, Badulla, Colombo, Kalutara, Ratnapura, Moneragala, Galle, Matara and Hambantota. The Meteorology Department recommends staying indoors during thunderstorms, avoiding open areas like paddy fields, tea plantations and open water bodies and refraining from using wired telephones and connected electrical appliances. It is also advisable to avoid open vehicles such as bicycles, tractors, boats, and be cautious of falling trees and power lines.

title: Street protests if presidential poll not held before 17 Oct 2024 – Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: Presidential election should be conducted prior to 17 October next year and if the election is not held in accordance with the Constitution, people will resort to street protests, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake warned. Addressing a gathering of Sri Lankan expatriates in New York, USA, Dissanayake expressed concerns over the government’s postponement of the Local Government and Provincial Council elections. He emphasised that the Constitution clearly dictates that the executive power of the people should be exercised by a President chosen by the citizens. “While it is possible to manage Local Government bodies through Commissioners and Provincial Councils through Governors, the essential executive power vested in the President, elected by the people, must be upheld. Therefore, it is imperative that the Presidential election takes place before 17 October next year. If the President attempts to evade the election, he may have to step down even before 17 October. Some inquire why people don’t take to the streets despite enduring significant hardships. People are patiently waiting for the Presidential election, but they will mobilise for protests if they sense that the election is being postponed,” he stressed. Dissanayake further highlighted that the JJB encompasses a coalition of various forces committed to transforming the country once they gain power. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Parliament brought into disrepute – Dy Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Preliminary investigations into the altercation involving State Minister Diana Gamage, MP Sujith Sanjaya Perera and MP Rohana Bandara have shown that the actions of these Parliamentarians have damaged the reputation of Parliament, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse yesterday (6) said. The Deputy Speaker is also the chairman of the five-member committee appointed to investigate the brawl involving the trio. The said committee convened in Parliament yesterday (6) to investigate the brawl that occurred on 20 October. All three MPs provided their statements to the committee during the session. State Minister Piyal Nishantha, a key witness to the incident, could not attend the committee meeting due to unavoidable circumstances, but is expected to be present at the next committee meeting scheduled for 9 November. The Deputy Speaker also noted that the committee is focusing on the verbal and physical confrontations, the video recording of the brawl and the general behaviour of the parliamentarians within the parliamentary premises. CCTV footage of the parliament concerning the incident was also reviewed for the committee members during the meeting. The five-member committee, headed by Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse includes Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, Gayantha Karunatileka, Imthiaz Bakeer Markar and Chamal Rajapaksa. Following the final committee meeting on Thursday, 9 November, the parliamentary committee is expected to provide Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena with a comprehensive report on the investigations into this incident. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Railway TUs worried Govt attempts to turn Dept into Authority
author: Author not found
Content: The Railway Trade Union Alliance (RTUA) expressed concern yesterday (6) over the Government’s alleged attempt to transform the Department of Railways into an Authority, by deliberately delaying the providing of solutions to existing problems affecting the railways. The Co-convener of the RTU further said the Government is attempting to undermine passenger confidence in the railway service by causing train delays and cancellations. He emphasised that instead of addressing the department’s solvable issues, the government is provoking trade unions to go on strike, all while working to restructure the department as an authority. Accordingly, 10,000 leaflets were distributed among commuters at the Fort, Maradana and Dematagoda railway stations from 7.00 a.m. yesterday (6), to create an awareness about the critical challenges faced by the public transportation system, he said. He pointed out that the Government’s goal is to hamper railway maintenance by failing to provide the necessary spare parts, accessories and equipment required for the railway service to operate effectively. To achieve this objective, it is essential for the public to understand that the Government’s actions are creating opposition against railway workers and trade unions, he added. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Three B’desh nationals nabbed with fake visas
author: Author not found
Content: Three Bangladeshi nationals were arrested yesterday (6) afternoon at Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) while attempting to escape to Malaysia with fake Malaysian visas. The suspects, aged 41, 37, and 19, had previously entered Sri Lanka from Kathmandu, Nepal, using visitor visas. Upon their arrival at BIA, via an Indigo Airlines flight, they were scheduled to depart for Hyderabad, India, later in the day. However, airport authorities, concerned about the authenticity of their visas and accompanying documents, submitted for airline clearance, referred them to the Immigration and Emigration Border Enforcement Unit. Upon further investigation, it was determined that the Malaysian visas in their possession were fraudulent. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: China will not export seafood to Sri Lanka – Chinese Ambassador
author: Author not found
Content: Chinese Ambassador Qi Zhenhong, during his second visit to the Northern Province, emphasised that China will not export seafood to Sri Lanka especially to the Northern Province, but rather, it will import Sri Lankan seafood to China. He added that during President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s recent visit to China, both countries reached an agreement to facilitate seafood exports to China. Ambassador Zhenhong stressed that China, as the seventh-largest economy in the world, is seeking competitive products from Sri Lanka. He also highlighted the great potential for investors to explore opportunities in the Northern Province. Additionally, he mentioned the attractiveness of the region for tourists. As part of the Faxian Charity Project, Ambassador Zhenhong distributed 5,000 boxes of dry rations valued at Rs 37.5 million to those in need in the Northern Province. He noted that during his previous visit, he had donated water purification equipment to five districts, and this time, they aimed to provide food packages to support the local community during difficult times. Ambassador Qi Zhenhong assured the people of the Northern Province that China would continue to offer assistance to the best of their capacity, standing with them in facing challenges, in the future as done in the past. He announced the Chinese Government’s commitment to provide ongoing support to the Northern Province, including a donation of Rs 15 million for fishing nets, housing units, and additional dry rations. The distribution of dry rations took place in Vavuniya, Mullaitivu, and Kilinochchi, with each district receiving 500 boxes of essential food supplies. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ali Sabri Raheem’s ACMC membership terminated
author: Author not found
Content: All Ceylon Makkal Congress (ACMC) Puttalam District MP Ali Sabri Raheem was expelled from the Party’s membership after being found guilty of illegally importing gold from abroad in violation of customs regulations, Party Chairman and former Deputy Minister M. S. Ameer Ali said yesterday (6). Ameer Ali explained that the decision to expel MP Raheem was unanimous following inquiries conducted by the Disciplinary Committee of the  ACMC. In line with the decision made by the ACMC’s DC, MP Raheem has submitted his resignation letter to the Party’s National Secretary personally, according to Ameer Ali. The National Secretary has assured that they will take necessary action in response to MP Raheem’s resignation letter very soon. “The incident involving the attempted smuggling of gold and mobile phones has garnered significant public attention and raised concerns about the conduct of elected officials. The Party’s decision to take action regarding Raheem’s Party membership underscores the importance of accountability and integrity in the political arena,” Ameer Ali emphasised. He also expressed the party’s deep commitment to upholding its values and standards. He added that any action that tarnishes the party’s reputation or undermines public trust is considered unacceptable by the ACMC. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Police hunt tipper driver who unloaded sand along the road
author: Author not found
Content: Police have launched a hunt for the driver of tipper truck, who intentionally unloaded sand along the road, causing damage to light posts and telephone lines. Police, in the Sirupiddy area on the Jaffna-Point Pedro Road yesterday (6) morning signalled a tipper truck filled with sand, suspected to have been illegally mined, to stop, but the driver ignored the order and drove on for a short distance spilling the sand in the process, before fleeing the area. Residents gathered on the road to collect the spilled sand and take it to their homes while the Police were in pursuit of the driver. Police are currently investigating the incident. BY T. Pratheepan – Jaffna

title: Cabinet Sub-Committee to probe Gazette suspending SLC
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet has taken a decision to appoint a four-member Cabinet Sub-committee, to investigate the Gazette issued by Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe, by which he suspended the previous Board and appointed an Interim Committee to Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC). The Cabinet sub-committee, led by Minister Ali Sabry, includes Ministers Tiran Alles, Manusha Nanayakkara, and Kanchana Wijesekara. Sports Minister Ranasinghe yesterday (6) named a seven-member Interim Committee for Sri Lanka Cricket, with former Sri Lankan cricket Captain Arjuna Ranatunga as its chair. However, this matter was brought up for discussion during yesterday’s Cabinet meeting because President Ranil Wickremesinghe had not been formally informed about the decision to appoint such a committee or its composition. It was reported that the President learned about the formation of the interim committee for SLC through media reports and had attempted to contact Sports Minister Roshan Ranasinghe several times to seek clarification but was unable to reach him. Consequently, during the Cabinet meeting yesterday (6) it was decided to form a ministerial committee, with the consent of the Sports Minister and the President, to examine the relevant gazette notification and the future activities of Sri Lanka Cricket. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Two more arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Two more suspects were arrested in connection with the alleged extortion attempt aimed at Janaka Ratnayake, the former Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL). These two suspects were arrested in the Pelwehera area of Dambulla and their involvement is believed to be related to providing accommodation and assisting the main suspect in the case, according to Police. The arrested individuals are aged 38 and 40 years. On 16 October, Ratnayake filed a complaint with the Kirulapone Police, claiming that he had received a threatening phone call from an individual, who claimed to have been contracted to harm him and demanding a sum of Rs 1.5 million to spare his life. Subsequently, investigations into the former PUCSL chairman’s complaint were transferred to the Colombo Crimes Division (CCD) on the direction of the Senior Deputy Inspector General (SDIG) in charge of the Western Province. On 28 October, three individuals aged 24, 26 and 31 were also taken into custody in connection with this incident. The Colombo Crimes Division (CCD) is currently conducting further inquiries into this matter.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: NIMH workers threaten protest
author: Author not found
Content: Health Assistants at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) warned they would stage a sit-down protest (sathyagaraha) today (7), demanding the Health Ministry immediately release the report of the investigations conducted into the alleged assault and verbal abuse on a colleague by the Institution’s Administrative Officer. President and Co -Convenor of the Freedom Health Service (FHS) H.W.R. Peiris yesterday (6) alleged that the Hospital’s Administrative Officer had allegedly assaulted and verbally abused a Health Assistant on 10 December 2022. Trade union action followed the alleged incident when the Health Ministry hastily appointed a committee to conduct an inquiry into the alleged incident. However even after a lapse of 10 months, the Ministry has failed to even inform the hospital of its findings and implement its recommendations, he alleged. Peiris warned that the Health Assistants would stage a ‘sathyagraha’ and continue their protest till such time the Ministry takes action. The Administrative Officer was neither transferred nor temporarily suspended at the time the Ministry probe was being carried out, he accused. He alleged that the said Administrative Officer had used his influence to take revenge against yet another health assistant by suspending his services from the NIMH as he had allegedly given evidence at the inquiry held into the assault incident, he claimed. The FHS would spread the strike to surrounding State hospitals namely the Colombo East Base Hospital and the National Institute of Infectious Diseases (NIID), if the Health Ministry does not take immediate action to release the inquiry report and implement its recommendations, Peiris warned. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Police boycott Court proceedings
author: Author not found
Content: Activities at the Nuwara Eliya Chief Magistrate’s Court, including the scheduled hearing of cases, were suspended yesterday (6) due to several Officers in Charge (OICs) of Police Stations, within the Nuwara Eliya Police Division, choosing not to engage in Court-related work. The OICs and other Police officers, from various stations, namely Dayagama, Agarapatana, Thalawakele, Lindula, Nanu Oya, Pattipola, and Kandapola, were supposed to be present for the hearing of cases at the said Court. However, they withdrew from their duties due to alleged abuse directed at them in front of suspects within the Court premises. Subsequently, the OICs and other Police officers, who refrained from their duties filed a complaint with the Nuwara Eliya ASP. In their complaint, they stated that the Nuwara Eliya Chief Magistrate had continuously and unfairly berated them in the presence of suspects for several months. They emphasised that such behaviour on the part of the Chief Magistrate had made it impossible for them to carry out their duties while upholding the dignity of the uniform they wear. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: SLT-Mobitel Training Centre and TVEC partner to empower telco professionals
author: Author not found
Content: SLT-Mobitel Training Centre, the education arm of SLT-Mobitel, has joined forces with the Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission (TVEC) to offer National Vocational Qualifications (NVQs) through Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) assessments, with an aim to empower telecommunications professionals and enhance industry competencies. The agreement was inked recently by signatories Janaka Abeysinghe,Chief Executive Officer, Sri Lanka Telecom PLC (SLT), and Dr. K. A. Lalithadheera, Director General, Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission. Senior officials from both institutions also participated in the event. Representing SLT-Mobitel were Janaka Silva, GM, Talent Development- SLT, Dr. Asiri Indika, DGM, Talent Development Centre- SLT, and Leonard Lakmal, Eng. SLTTalent Development Centre – Moratuwa. Dr. Janaka Jayalath, Deputy Director General, Priyanga Nanayakkara, Director, AQA, and Samanmalie Pathiranage, Assistant Director, AQA, represented TVEC. TheSLT-MOBITEL Training Centre is recognised for offering world-class educational solutions and is committed to providing comprehensive training and qualifications to meet the evolving needs of the telecommunications sector and the knowledge economy. Janaka Abeysinghe, CEO, SLT, shared his thoughts, saying, “We are pleased to announce our partnership with TVEC and our commitment to providing National Vocational Qualifications (NVQs) through Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) assessments for the telecom sector using our education arm,SLT-Mobitel Training Centre. Through this collaboration, we aim to empower individuals in the industry by officially recognising their skills and granting National Vocational Qualifications (NVQ). Together, we aim to unlock new opportunities and pave the way for a skilled and competent workforce in the dynamic field of telecommunications.” With the rapid advancements and evolving nature of the telecommunications sector, it is crucial to acknowledge the expertise and capabilities of professionals already working in the field. RPL assessments offer an opportunity for these individuals to have their skills formally recognised and validated, boosting their professional credibility and ensuring career advancement. The collaboration between SLT-Mobitel Training Centre and TVEC marks a significant milestone in the telecommunications industry.With this agreement, the SLT-Mobitel Training Centre will act as an assessment body to award national vocational qualifications through Recognition of Prior Learning, facilitating competency-based assessments specifically tailored to the telecommunications industry. Dr. K. A. Lalithadheera, Director General, TVEC, stated, “Leading the way in technical and vocational education in Sri Lanka, we are committed to certifying skilled technicians through the Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) approach, granting them NVQ certification. By evaluating past work evidence and assessing current competencies according to the National Competency Standards (NCS), we ensure rigorous standards are met. In recognition of their industry leadership, we have entrusted SLT-Mobitel, along with their renowned SLT-Mobitel Training Centre, to conduct RPL assessments and award NVQ in selected occupations. Leveraging the extensive network of training and testing centres at SLT-Mobitel Training Centre, along with our proficient human resources, we offer candidates a significant advantage in this process. We encourage aspiring individuals in the sector to apply for NVQ certification, guaranteeing official recognition of their skills. NVQ holders will gain numerous benefits, including national and international recognition. Furthermore, they are invited to obtain a ‘Skills Passport,’ expanding their skill set to global career opportunities.” Through this initiative, SLT-Mobitel Training Centre is able to promote the importance of lifelong learning and provide professionals in the industry with valuable vocational qualifications. Additionally, as a centre providing RPL assessments,SLT-Mobitel Training Centre offers a formal process to evaluate and certify individuals’ competencies gained through practical experience, enabling them to receive recognition for their skills. SLT-Mobitel Training Centre will also ensure that the RPL assessments adhere to industry standards and best practices. Furthermore, as the SLT-Mobitel Training Centre has been appointed as an assessment body for conducting RPL assessments, employees working in technical, sales, and contact centre fields can now apply for the National Vocational Qualification(NVQ) Level 4 through RPL. The assessment process is designed to accommodate different individuals from diverse backgrounds. By offering this revolutionary pathway, SLT-Mobitel Training Centre aims to streamline the qualification process and provide a more accessible route for individuals to enhance their skills and career prospects in the telecommunications industry. Industry professionals interested in pursuing RPL assessments can find more information by contacting SLT-Mobitel Training Centre on 0112645371 or email: [email protected]. Interested individuals may also visit training.slt.lk

title: Sarath Gamage assumes duties as 43rd President of OPA SL
author: Author not found
Content: Sarath Gamage assumed duties as the 43rd President of the Organisation of Professional Associations of Sri Lanka (OPA) on 27 October 2023.  OPA  is a unique organisation, being the apex body of 52 professional member associations representing 34 professions. As such, it is the only one of its kind in South Asia. Since its inception in 1975, it has functioned as the Voice of the Professionals, working for the development of professions and the nation. In its mission, it has been ably served by a succession of Presidents drawn from the leading professionals in the country. For the forthcoming calendar year, the Organisation will be led by Sarath Gamage, who was the immediate past President of the Institute of Supply and Materials Management of Sri Lanka. (ISMM) Prior to becoming the President of the OPA, he held the Post of President-Elect, Vice President and Chairman of several Standing and Sector committees of the OPA for almost ten years. He organised the 36th Annual Conference held on 9 and 10 August at Kingsbury, Colombo which is the flagship event of the OPA in a grand manner and the event was graced by President Ranil Wickremesinghe.

title: Lions International District 306 A2 conducts Train The Trainer Programme
author: Author not found
Content: A very valuable and meaningful programme was conducted by the District Lions Leadership Institute, Lions International District 306 A2. The Mission of the Lions is to empower volunteers to serve their communities, meet humanitarian needs, encourage peace and promote international understanding through Lions Clubs.

title: SJB’s Branch Committee in the USA
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) established its first branch committee in the United States. SJB MPs Harshana Rajakaruna and Hector Appuhami met a group of Sri Lankans in New York.

title: Public told to keep away from landslide site
author: Author not found
Content: Haldummulla Police yesterday (6) advised the public not to venture out to witness the Bathgoda landslide. They stated that scores of people had begun to trek to the Bathgoda landslide site, on the Colombo-Badulla main road, to witness it, but they mentioned that arrival of a large number of people could lead to further accidents. Hence, the warning. Due to the landslide on the said road the Police have taken measures to introduce alternate routes for motorists till the route is made roadworthy in due course. BY Saman Nanayakkara – Haldummulla

title: Reich apppointed Sri Lanka’s Hony Consul in Haifa
author: Author not found
Content: Newly appointed Honorary Consul of Sri Lanka (SL) in Haifa and Northern Israel Anat Bernstein Reich received her Commission of Appointment from Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Israel Nimal Bandara recently, the Foreign Ministry said yesterday (6). As the President of the Israel – Asia Chamber of Commerce and the Chairperson of the Israel- Sri Lanka Chamber of Commerce, the newly appointed Honorary Consul has been working closely with Sri Lankan business entities over the last twenty years, it said. Bernstein-Reich is scheduled to open an Honorary Consulate in Haifa, the capital of Northern Israel and aims to improve trade relations between the two countries and make facilitation to assist Sri Lankan migrant workers in the area, the statement in closing said. (PA)

title: Health Ministry withholding UNICEF allowance for PHIs, Midwives
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Health has been accused of withholding the allowance provided by UNICEF to Public Health Inspectors (PHIs) and Public Health Midwives (PHMs) since October 2022, who are crucial for safeguarding public health services amidst the economic crisis. Secretary of the Public Health Inspectors’ Union (PHIU), S.I. Bopitiya, has alleged that the Ministry of Health has maintained a silent stance regarding this allowance issue. Bopitiya noted that a significant problem has arisen due to the issuance of a job description that grants administrative powers to the position of Additional Medical Officers of Health (MOH), despite their lack of administrative authority. Furthermore, he emphasised that the delay in implementing administrative training for public health inspectors, along with the absence of a clear promotion path for this profession, presents serious challenges. In response to these issues, the PHIU has formally informed the Secretary of the Ministry of Health that, starting from tomorrow (8), they will suspend all reporting and refrain from participating in meetings, including progress reviews. They intend to take various professional actions over the next few weeks. The letter, to the Ministry of Health, highlights that despite continuous communication regarding the challenges faced by their members, no viable solutions have been found. Therefore, the profession is now compelled to take action. The letter also outlines plans to withdraw from dengue control duties from the 15 November, from all infectious disease-related responsibilities from the 22nd and from all field duties from 1 December. Furthermore, a provincial campaign is set to commence on 15 December. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: USIDFC CEO Scott Nathan to visit to Sri Lanka today
author: Author not found
Content: The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the United States International Development Finance Corporation (USIDFC) for the South Asian region, Scott Nathan, is scheduled to visit Colombo today (7) to attend the launch event for a new DFC investment at the Port of Colombo. This investment will play a pivotal role in enhancing critical infrastructure. Nathan will also participate in a signing ceremony for USIDFC’s investment commitment to Citizens Development Business Finance (CDBF) which, in collaboration with USAID Sri Lanka, will promote inclusive lending in Sri Lanka. Additionally,CEO Nathan will meet with leaders from the country’s top commercial and development banks, engage with high-level Sri Lankan Government officials and tour the facilities of DFC clients to see how DFC’s financing is supporting these businesses in achieving development goals.   The DFC partners with the private sector to finance solutions to the most critical challenges facing the developing world today. DFC invests across sectors including energy, healthcare, critical infrastructure, and technology. Nathan will leave tomorrow (8) The DFC also provides financing for small businesses and women entrepreneurs in order to create jobs in emerging markets. The DFC investments adhere to high standards and respect the environment, human rights, and worker rights. (SRM)

title: Vehicle racketeers nabbed
author: Author not found
Content: Kalutara Division Anti-Vice Squad arrested two individuals during a raid on a centre located in Dodangoda. This centre was involved in buying three-wheelers, motorcycles and small lorries for which the monthly lease payments had not been made, altering their chassis and engine numbers before selling them. The arrested suspects were aged 32 and 39 and are residents of Dodangoda and Pepiliyawatta, respectively. Police said during the raid they had seized three three-wheelers, a motorcycle and a small lorry of which the suspects had changed the engine and chassis numbers. The vehicles had been purchased by the suspects from Kalutara, Matugama and Dodangoda. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: Sluice gates being opened as water levels rise
author: Author not found
Content: Amid the ongoing inclement weather conditions, affecting most parts of the country and several reservoirs and water bodies reaching or exceeding their retention levels, the Department of Irrigation has initiated measures to release excess water. This was revealed yesterday (6) by Engineer S. P. C. Sugershwara, the Irrigation Director responsible for Hydrology and Disaster Management at the Department of Irrigation. Eng. Sugershwara noted that with the rising water levels of Nilwala Ganga, low-lying areas along the river could be inundated. Mini floods have already been reported in Thalgahagoda and Thawalama areas situated within the Nilwala Ganga river basin. A similar situation has been reported in the Morawaka area, which falls under the Walawe Ganga. Residents in low-lying areas and those living in the Nilwala Ganga basin have been advised to follow the precautionary guidelines issued by the Department, exercise caution, stay vigilant, and be prepared to relocate to safe areas if the river’s water level increases, according to Eng. Sugershwara. The Department of Irrigation has opened the spill gates of the Rajanganaya and Deduru-oya reservoirs and nine spill gates of the Thabbowa reservoir. Furthermore, five spill gates of the Deduru Oya Reservoir have been opened, releasing 13,800 cubic feet of water into the Deduru-oya. As the water level of Deduru-Oya rises, residents in low-lying areas are urged to remain vigilant and relocate to safe places if the situation worsens. Additionally, Sugershwara said that the water level of Attanagalu-oya continues to rise, leading to a mini flood in the Moragaswewa area, which is in the low-lying region of Deduru-Oya. The Department of Meteorology, on the same day, predicted that the adverse weather conditions are expected to persist for the next few days. Duty Meteorologist Buddika Banduratne explained that heavy showers exceeding 100 mm are expected in some areas of the Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central, and Uva Provinces, as well as the Galle and Matara Districts. Banduratne also forecasted morning showers in the Northern and Eastern Provinces, along with misty conditions in the morning for the Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central, and Uva Provinces. Duty Meteorologist Banduratne cautioned the public about the possibility of temporary strong gusty winds and lightning strikes during the thundershowers. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Plans afoot to allocate Rs. 237B for Education
author: Author not found
Content: Regarding the budget allocation for the Ministry of Education in 2024, Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha, announced a planned allocation of Rs 237 billion to the Ministry of Education for the year 2024. This allocation covers both capital and recurring expenses related to education in the nine provinces. The Cabinet has already approved a policy framework for education reforms, which will be presented in Parliament after receiving sectoral parliamentary approval. The goal of this initiative is to establish a stable and enduring education policy that transcends different governments and ministers. It focuses on four key areas, aiming to shift from an exam-centric system to a more diverse and inclusive classroom assessment approach, ultimately providing quality education for both students and educators. The Minister highlighted that the upcoming academic year will commence on 19 February 2024, marking the start of the first school term. He stressed that the curriculum spanning from the first to the eleventh year will be completed within the same academic year. Speaking at a press conference, held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) Premajayantha shared further details: “Due to certain delays in the country, the school year began on 27 March 2023. Measures have been taken to prevent such delays, ensuring the start of the new school term on 19 February 2024. Our objective is to complete the curriculum from the first year to the eleventh year within the same academic year, allowing us to conduct the 2025 school year without interruptions. “We have also made arrangements to conduct Advanced-Level Examinations. Despite some professional challenges, we have maintained the examination schedules, ensuring timely examinations. We are prepared to release the results of the Ordinary Level Examinations conducted in the third week of this month. Despite ongoing circumstances, we are determined to manage time efficiently and conduct exams as scheduled. “When we assumed office, there were 808 vacant positions. The Treasury approved the recruitment of 50 per cent of these vacancies. As the examinations have been completed, we are actively preparing for interviews and recruitment. Furthermore, approval has been granted for 707 teacher education service positions and we are working towards their immediate appointment. This move aims to provide training for teachers across 19 faculties. Our goal is to fill all teaching service vacancies before the upcoming school term.” The Minister also addressed the challenges faced in the appointment of teachers and development officers as graduates, explaining that provincial-level vacancies for retired dignitaries and teachers who have left service are being approved and recruitment is in progress. In an effort to strengthen education in specific subjects, the Treasury has approved the recruitment of 5,450 personnel for science, mathematics, English, foreign languages, and technology subjects. These recruitments are taking place at the provincial level, with a Gazette Notification for national schools scheduled for release this week. Minister Premajayantha also revealed plans for textbook distribution, school uniforms and meal provisions. Textbook preparations and distribution for the year 2024 are complete, with 80% of school uniform work finalised. The government is planning to provide meals to all school students starting next year, with the goal of offering lunch to every school child by 2030. Various programmes, in collaboration with the World Food Programme, USAID, and the private sector, are underway to achieve this goal. In conclusion, the Minister emphasised the government’s commitment to providing professional training in skills and technology to students after General and Advanced Level examinations. Selected schools will offer evening classes over a four-month period, focusing on guidance, English, information technology, and various other courses tailored to students’ preferences.

title: Dambulla Economic Centre a Potential Disease Spreader
author: Author not found
Content: Traders are expressing concerns over the high risk of disease spreading, due to the severe lack of cleanliness in the vegetable storage and processing area of the Dambulla Economic Centre, which supplies approximately seventy per cent of the country’s vegetable needs. Despite more than 150 shops operating day and night at the economic centre, the rear areas of the shops and restaurants are in a deplorable, unsanitary condition, primarily due to a lack of attention from any responsible authority. Traders also highlight the presence of large potholes at every entrance to the Dambulla Economic Centre, causing severe traffic disruptions. They are dissatisfied with the maintenance of the centre, which seems to prioritise profit over cleanliness. The Dambulla Economic Centre distributes around seventy per cent of Sri Lanka’s vegetable needs within a single night, receiving vegetables and fruits from all corners of the island. During our site visit to inspect the storage conditions, we observed extreme levels of pollution behind the shops. The storage areas were contaminated with faeces, phlegm, betel spit, and various other impurities. The drainage systems were poorly maintained, with visible signs of worm infestation. Shockingly, vegetables from farmers were stored on top of these unsanitary conditions. Additionally, green vegetables such as curry leaves, rampe leaves and other produce were placed on top of spit. Store owners claim that their employees are responsible for this unsanitary practice but refuse to take responsibility to stop it. In the main canteen of the Dambulla Economic Centre and other canteens, both the cooking and food serving areas were found to be unclean. Cooked food, as well as meat and fish stored in refrigerators, were kept together and served to customers. Restaurant owners were unwilling to allow inspections of these areas. When we spoke with the former president of the Dambulla Economic Centre trade association, U. B. Ekanayake, he acknowledged that the inside of the economic centre is indeed highly polluted and not as it used to be. The Dambulla Economic Centre is managed by a trust. The manager Christy Wijeratne, mentioned that it is challenging to properly oversee all activities within the centre. However, he did not provide a clear response when asked about the potential distribution of diseases and pathogens nationwide, related to the presence of faeces, urine, betel saliva, and waste vegetable and fruit deposits. He claimed to have raised awareness about the issue. BY K.K. Ariyadasa – Dambulla

title: Laws banning polythene seal on bottle caps soon
author: Author not found
Content: New laws will be introduced, in the near future, banning the polythene seal on water bottle caps, the Central Environmental Authority (CEA) said. During a discussion at the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute last week, Sarojanie Jayasekara, Director of the Solid Waste Management Division at CEA said the CEA held several rounds of discussions on banning the polythene wrap in question with corporate sector. “Many companies agreed not to use the polythene wrap. But some of them do keep to the agreement. As a result, laws will be introduced to completely ban the polythene wrap on the water bottle caps soon,” she said. Jayasekara, reporting a concerning disparity in the handling of plastic waste in Sri Lanka, said despite the daily collection of approximately 930 MT of plastic waste in the country, only 50 MT are effectively recycled. Although a national action plan has been formulated to address plastic waste, the authorities emphasise that the nation continues to grapple with mounting garbage issues, including plastic pollution that is adversely affecting the environment. This discussion was convened by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) to address Sri Lanka’s commitment to a global plastic pollution treaty and involved various stakeholders, including the CEA, Ministry of Environment, Sri Lanka Customs, Ministry of Industry and the Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA), among others. Jayasekara highlighted the critical issue of inadequate plastic recycling. She said about 300 MT of plastic waste is collected by the local authorities and 600 MT of plastic waste find their way into the environment daily due to insufficient recycling efforts. Moreover, only 56 organisations have secured licences for plastic recycling activities in the country. Additionally, the Aruwakkalu waste recycling centre is currently non-operational but is expected to become operational next year, she added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Minister Alles urges Police to act without fear
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, expressing his firm stance on combating the underworld and drug-related issues within the law enforcement sector, said officers who are unable to effectively address these concerns will no longer be placed in such critical roles. Instead, he insisted that officers who can diligently perform their duties should be appointed. Minister Alles urged all officers to take resolute action against criminals without fear and assured them of his unwavering support during his tenure in as the Minister of Public Security. He stressed that the station commander of each Police station holds responsibility for handling matters related to drugs, the underworld, and other aspects within their respective areas across the island. Officers who are unable to fulfil these crucial responsibilities will be transferred from their current stations. Minister Alles made these statements while participating in an an event held in Unawatuna, Galle on Friday (3), with the participation of the Officers-in-Charge (OICs) of Police stations in the Southern Province and several other officials. He mentioned that he has gathered reports from the intelligence divisions detailing the occurrences within each Police jurisdiction. Based on these reports, necessary actions will be taken to address the situation effectively. “First and foremost, I must emphasise that since I assumed this ministry, I have made every effort to support our Police officers. However, I have consistently stressed that in return for my efforts, I expect all of you to carry out your duties effectively. Regrettably, the results have not met my expectations. For example, in the Southern Province, we issued clear instructions regarding the placement of roadblocks. To verify whether these measures were being implemented as instructed, we had two individuals, wearing full-face helmets and jackets, ride a motorcycle through the roadblock at Galduwa Junction multiple times. Unfortunately, none of the Police officers deployed at the roadblock noticed this particular motorcycle passing through in a suspicious manner multiple times,” the Minister stressed. “This situation clearly demonstrates that the duties at the roadblocks are not being carried out effectively. The Officers-in-Charge, Deputy Inspectors General (DIGs) and all responsible authorities must bear accountability for this failure. It is imperative that top officials closely monitor these operations. When they neglect their oversight responsibilities, it can lead to a lax attitude among lower-ranked officials. Despite our efforts to establish numerous roadblocks, the current situation reflects a significant gap in implementation. I had discussions with the Inspector General of Police, who also informed me that he had issued explicit instructions regarding the routes to be followed after a shooting incident. Unfortunately, these instructions have not been adhered to. Both the OICs and the DIGs must be held responsible for this failure. It is essential to address these issues promptly and ensure that our security measures are being executed effectively. “Moving forward, it is imperative that the Officers-in-Charge take full responsibility for such failures. While the Special Task Force (STF) is assigned specific tasks, we should not solely rely on the STF to handle all aspects of law enforcement. In the event of a shooting incident within any Police Division, the OIC should assume responsibility. We expect to be promptly informed about the circumstances surrounding the shooting, including how it transpired, whether a roadblock was in place in the vicinity and why the assailants could not be intercepted at the roadblock. Officials must be prepared to provide satisfactory answers to these inquiries. This approach extends to other criminal activities such as narcotics and underworld operations. In cases where OICs are unable to provide adequate explanations for such incidents, they will be subject to transfer. It is essential that we establish a system of accountability to enhance the effectiveness of our law enforcement efforts. “I’m sharing this information now so that you can plan your work accordingly. I will gather intelligence reports to assess your performance and based on that, I will make decisions regarding your positions. If there are ineffective officials in your Police stations, kindly inform the higher authorities and after due process, remove them. Submit a report to the division and ensure the DIG is informed. The current situation is regrettable. It’s unacceptable that underworld figures can contact and threaten Police officers. Isn’t there a sense of shame? These underworld figures are our adversaries and it’s our duty to eradicate them from our society for the sake of our children. Keep in mind that it’s your responsibility to do everything within your means to eliminate these underworld figures from the Southern Province. If you do so, I will always support your efforts. Arrest them, and if they attack you, respond firmly. You have my full backing.” “I have to say that I did not have a chance to rest for two days when we were bringing ‘Harak Kata’ and ‘Salindu’ back to our country. As soon as I became aware of the situation, I engaged in frequent telephone conversations with the Minister of Public Security of Madagascar, at all hours of the day. During the transition from there to ‘Harak Kata’s and Salindu’s arrival on the plane, I maintained constant communication with our CID officers. When the duo was moved to Kenya, there was an issue with the coordination and a communication gap led to a missed handing over of the criminals. Subsequently, I had to liaise with Indian authorities to ensure a smooth transit. Afterward, the situation was rectified, and the operation proceeded. There were some challenges even during the journey Despite these challenges, by working collaboratively, we can successfully address such issues. It’s worth noting that significant financial resources are involved in these operations. Both I and the higher-ranking officials are aware of this fact. I would like to share that, during Harak Kata’s return to Sri Lanka, there was an attempt to offer me Rs 700 million to divert the operation to Dubai instead of Sri Lanka. The President is also aware of this matter. Nevertheless, we must remain resolute and not succumb to such offers. It is noteworthy that the individual who made this offer was killed in the Southern Province. Furthermore, there are ongoing attempts by certain individuals to offer large sums of money to higher-ranking officials in exchange for my removal from this ministry. Harak Kata’s wife has conveyed the message that the Harak Kata’s detention order can be cancelled  if not for Minister Tiran Alles. I am aware that some OICs, whom I won’t name, are engaging in phone conversations with individuals associated with the underworld. I strongly urge them to sever such connections immediately. Following this statement, there will be no leniency shown towards officials involved in such corrupt activities.” By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Eleven Lankans stranded in Gaza repatriated
author: Author not found
Content: The 11 Sri Lankans who had crossed from the Gaza Strip into Egypt arrived in Sri Lanka early yesterday (5) on a flight from Doha, Qatar. This group comprised two families, including two women and nine children. In a statement, the Foreign Affairs Ministry said the Consular Affairs Division of the ministry coordinated their return in collaboration with the Sri Lankan Missions in Cairo, Ramallah, and Tel Aviv. Foreign Ministry officials welcomed the returning Sri Lankan nationals on their arrival at BIA. The entry of these 11 Sri Lankans from the Gaza Strip into Egypt via the Rafah Border Crossing was facilitated by the Sri Lankan Embassy in Cairo, in coordination with Egyptian authorities on 2 November. The Embassy officials were present at the Rafah Border to receive the stranded Sri Lankans, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs managed the logistics and air transportation arrangements for their return with the assistance of the International Organization for Migration (IOM). On 2 November, a group of 17 Sri Lankans who were trapped in the Gaza Strip during the Israel-Hamas conflict were allowed to leave the war-torn Palestinian enclave and enter Egypt through the Rafah Border Crossing, according to communication from the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Tel Aviv. However, 15 of these Sri Lankans were expected to reach Egypt, while the remaining two were likely to stay behind in Palestine, according to the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau (SLBFE). Nonetheless, 13 of the 17 Sri Lankans permitted to leave Gaza were in an area between the entrance to the Rafah Border Crossing and Egypt, as the other four individuals were unable to depart Palestine due to security concerns. Subsequently, on 3 November, the Representative Office of Sri Lanka in Palestine announced that a group of 11 Sri Lankans had successfully reached Egypt after crossing the Rafah border, and preparations were underway to facilitate their repatriation. By Methmalie Dissanayake and T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Annual crop damage Rs 17 to 20B
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture and Plantation Minister Mahinda Amaraweera who said crop damage caused by wild animals, especially toque monkeys, is estimated at Rs 17-20 billion annually, revealed that the Government is planning to distribute more air rifles to farmers as a temporary solution to control wild animals. The Minister said a survey conducted by the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agricultural Research and Training Institute (HARTI) showed that crop damage caused by wild animals would cost the country between Rs 17-20 billion annually. Toque monkeys are the main culprits behind crop damage. Additionally, crop damage caused by peacocks, porcupines, wild boar and giant squirrels has been on the rise. All previous strategies to prevent crop damage by wild animals have proved unsuccessful. The country loses over 31,000 MT of vegetables and fruit annually due to damage by wildlife. In 2022, Toque monkeys consumed and destroyed more than Rs 200 million worth of coconuts. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: 4,672 new principals appointed
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha assured that by next year steps will be taken to fill all the principal vacancies in State schools. He was speaking at a ceremony to hand over appointment to 4,672 new principals, who were admitted to Grade III of the Sri Lanka Principals Service. The ceremony was held on Saturday, 4 November, at D.S. Senanayake College, Colombo. Premajayantha said it was essential to fill existing vacancies in the education sector in order to maintain it continuously and systematically. At present, there were 808 vacancies in the education administration service, and the Treasury has given approval to fill 50 per cent of the vacancies.  The Minister added that there should be about 4,200 teachers in counselling but currently there were only 1,100, stating that a Cabinet memorandum has already been prepared to fill the vacancies. Premajayantha also said although there should be 1,800 officers in the teacher education service, there was just 800 officers and 707 officers are to be recruited soon.  The Minister explained that challenges faced by the newly appointed principals were different from those faced by principals of the past. Premajayantha further said the new principals should be able to identify the needs of students who will face the future with digital technology and has instructed trainers to pay attention to it in the training of principals. The Minister also said this was the first time since 2019 that such a large number of principals had been recruited to the school system in Sri Lanka at one and the same time. He said that all 1AB and 1C schools will be digitised in the coming year and professional development opportunities will be provided for teachers and principals accordingly. He also said measures will be taken to build student confidence in the school system by conducting examinations systematically. “As the Minister in charge of the subject at the time of taking over the ministry this year, there were challenges in many areas such as distribution of textbooks and uniforms and they have been solved so far,” the Minister said and added that information is being circulated that School Development Societies have taken steps to increase school fees by 50 per cent while such a measure was not initiated by the Ministry. Many senior officials of the Ministry of Education, including the Secretary of the Ministry of Education, Colombo District Secretary, and regional and provincial education officials attended the event.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Viharamahadevi Park to be returned to CMC
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Urban Development and Housing Minister Prasanna Ranatunga instructed the Urban Development Authority (UDA) to hand over control of the Colombo Viharamahadevi Park to the Colombo Municipal Council. Viharamahadevi Park, originally under the Colombo Municipal Council’s jurisdiction, was temporarily transferred to the Urban Development Authority in 2011 for renovation. The Minister said the UDA has the authority to take over properties for development purposes, but stipulated that after the development is completed, the property should be returned to its original institution. The Viharamahadevi Park underwent renovation and was officially reopened in 2013 as part of the Colombo Metropolitan City Development Project, which was carried out by the Urban Development Authority with the support of the World Bank.

title: Police hunt for couple over Rs 10M scam
author: Author not found
Content: Police are seeking public assistance to apprehend a couple who had scammed a private company out of nearly Rs 10 million, by falsely claiming to carry out renovations on a building and a garden in Udumulla Road, Battaramulla. The suspects, a 36-year-old female named Rachel Niroshani Rajarathnam, a resident of the Dangedara area in Galle and a 31-year-old male named Wigneshwaran Ganeshan, a resident of the Hendala area in Wattala, operated a private contracting company under the name “D’marc Solutions (PVT) LTD,” located in Nedimala, Dehiwala, as the primary owners of the company. However, they failed to fulfil the promised renovations and took money from the client. The Mirihana Special Crime Division is conducting investigations to apprehend the suspects. The Police Media Division has urged the public to contact the Special Crimes Division at +9471 – 8137373 or +9411 – 2852556 with any information regarding the whereabouts of the suspects. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Jumbo Barana’s skull, tusks exhumed for preservation
author: Author not found
Content: The skull and tusks of the iconic tusker, Barana, from Kalawewa National Park who tragically succumbed to electrocution in August last year, were exhumed on Friday (3) for preservation. With the assistance of Galkiriyagama Wildlife Range Officers and Wildlife Department Officials, the skull and tusks were carefully exhumed from their resting place within the grounds of the Galkiriyagama Wildlife Range Office. The Wildlife Department has announced that after necessary preservation efforts, the tusks will be reattached to the skull and subsequently put on display for the public. Local residents have been vocal in their concerns, blaming influential individuals for their mistreatment of the flora and fauna in the area, which they believe has led to the tragic loss of many elephants within the park. They express a genuine apprehension about the dwindling elephant population and its irreversible impact on their way of life. Ven. Wanawasi Rahula Thera, in discussions with the media, criticised the successive governments’ failure to devise a comprehensive solution to the human-elephant conflict, which, for decades, has resulted in the loss of numerous iconic elephants in the region. He emphasised the need for government officials to be more attentive to this pressing issue, as these elephants play a crucial role in generating revenue for the state through tourism. Last year, three individuals were arrested on suspicion of setting up illegal electric fences, which are believed to have contributed to the untimely demise of Barana. Illegal and unregulated impromptu electric fences continue to be a common cause of wild elephant fatalities and addressing this issue remains crucial in mitigating human-elephant conflicts. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Six undergrads arrested over protest
author: Author not found
Content: Six undergraduates who participated in a protest, held in Batticaloa Town yesterday (5) morning, against the occupation of grazing lands in the Mayilathamadu and Mathavanai areas in the Batticaloa District, were arrested by Batticaloa Police. The protest was organised by undergraduates from the University of Jaffna and the Eastern University of Sri Lanka. Police questioned them in Santhuveli and subsequently arrested them. Among them, four were from the Eastern University and two from Jaffna University. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: RTI to summon institutions that fail to disclose vital info
author: Author not found
Content: The Right to Information (RTI) Commission is actively intervening in cases where State institutions are concealing information that should be proactively disclosed. Such institutions that have failed to disclose essential information will be summoned before the Commission in the near future, Chairman of RTI Commission retired Supreme Court Justice Upali Abeyratne said. In situations where State institutions have not given information that should be proactively disclosed, citizens typically resort to the RTI Act to request such information. However, prompt action will now be taken against State institutions that do not provide the requested information, the Chairman said. Further, it has come to light that certain State institutions have failed to disclose critical information for many years, despite requests to make this information available to the public. In many cases, government websites lack the necessary facilities for public access, he pointed out. These concerns were raised during an appeal for information requested on behalf of 400 families affected by the construction of the final stretch of Central Expressway that has allegedly violated environmental assessments. The Chairman also pointed out that a substantial number of State institutions have not disclosed vital information to the public for an extended period, and legal action has so far not been instituted against such institutions. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: CAA ordered to prosecute vendors
author: Author not found
Content: The Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) has been instructed to carry out raids and prosecute vendors who sell sugar above the maximum retailer price (MRP), State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. Addressing an event yesterday (5), the State Minister said no one would be allowed to gain unfair advantages from the recent tax increase imposed on sugar. Following the tax increase from 25 cent to Rs 50 per kg of sugar, an MRP was announced for brown sugar and white sugar. Accordingly, MRP for white sugar in packets is set at Rs 295 per kg. Additionally, for bulk, unpackaged white sugar, the MRP is set at Rs 275 per kg. The MRP for brown sugar in packets is fixed at Rs 350 per kg. Similarly, for bulk, unpackaged brown sugar, the MRP is set at Rs 330 per kg. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Govt approval ratings drop to 9% – Verité
author: Author not found
Content: A recent Gallup poll has revealed a significant decline in the approval ratings of the Government of Sri Lanka. The survey indicates that the Government’s approval rating has fallen from 21% in June 2023 to just 9% in October 2023. The survey was conducted by the Colombo-based think tank Verité Research Institute, in partnership with Vanguard Surveys (Pvt) Ltd. The poll, titled ‘The Mood of the Nation’, also highlighted a substantial drop in public satisfaction with the state of the nation. In October 2023, only 6% of respondents expressed satisfaction, down from 12% in June 2023. Additionally, the survey shows a notable decrease in economic confidence, with the economic confidence score dropping from -44 in June of the same year to -62. Conducted three times a year, ‘The Mood of the Nation’ poll aims to assess the approval, satisfaction, and confidence of the nation regarding the Government, the State, and the economy. The survey is based on a nationally representative sample of responses gathered island-wide and is designed to maintain a maximum error margin below three per cent at a 95% confidence level. The recent poll was conducted from 21 – 29 October 2023, and received responses from 1,029 Sri Lankan adults. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: President honours Golden Girl Tharushi
author: Author not found
Content: Tharushi Karunaratne, who recently secured the gold medal in the women’s 800m event, at the Asian Games 2023, was honoured with an audience with President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Palace in Kandy yesterday (5) morning. Tharushi Karunaratne received a warm welcome at the President’s House, coinciding with the formal presentation of credentials to the newly appointed Ambassadors to Sri Lanka. During this auspicious occasion, President Ranil Wickremesinghe took the opportunity to introduce Tharushi Karunaratne to the newly accredited Ambassadors, further establishing international recognition of her remarkable achievement. Additionally, 76 students, who are currently pursuing athletics at the Sports School of Walala A. Rathnayake Central College, where Tharushi is completing her education, were invited to join this momentous event. The student-athletes, along with the school’s principal, athletic coach and six dedicated teachers, were present to celebrate this remarkable accomplishment. Expressing his deep appreciation for the exceptional talent demonstrated by Tharushi Karunaratne, President Wickremesinghe conveyed his heartfelt congratulations on her historic achievement, marking the return of a gold medal to Sri Lanka at the Asian Games after a 21-year gap. Following the formalities, the President engaged in an enriching conversation with Tharushi and the aspiring athletes.

title: Licences Of Five Liquor Companies Suspended
author: Author not found
Content: After repeated notices and reminders, the Excise Department yesterday (2) suspended the licences of five liquor distillers, over allegations of long-standing non-payment of excise duties. The Department of Excise announced yesterday that these companies collectively owe a total of Rs 6 billion in unpaid taxes to the Government. The affected distilleries include Wayamba Distilleries (Pvt.) Ltd, Mendis Distilleries, Randenigala Distilleries (Pvt.) Ltd, Finland Distilleries (Pvt.) Ltd, and Synergy Distilleries (Pvt.) Ltd. The owners of these distilleries have neglected to pay their excise duties for an extended period, causing a significant impact on the Government’s revenue collection. Excise Duty is a primary source of income for the State. According to the Excise Department, the annual licences for these companies, with outstanding arrears, had expired on 31 October and were not renewed. Consequently, the production and distribution of their alcohol products have been halted. As some of these companies have not paid taxes for an extended period, the department granted them a deadline to clear the outstanding dues. However, only a few managed to meet this deadline, with one company obtaining a 40-day Stay Order against the decision. This issue came to light during a recent meeting of the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA). State Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna, the COPA Chairman, instructed the Commissioner General of the Excise to suspend the licences of any distillery that had not settled their excise tax arrears by 31 October. Some of the distilleries that failed to pay their excise taxes have also been blacklisted for distributing adulterated liquor with counterfeit stickers. The Commissioner General of Excise revealed this information during a COPA meeting. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SLMC decision on JMO Haq’s future tomorrow?
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) said a decision in connection with Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) Dr. Ruhul Haq’s suspension may be taken tomorrow (4).  Informed SLMC sources yesterday (2) said that the Professional Conduct Committee (PCC) of the SLMC which emulates a judiciary may take up Dr. Haq’s matter when they meet tomorrow (4). They noted that currently the JMO had been asked to refrain from conducting the duties of his office. Fielding questions, sources said however that the Council had not been approached by the College of Forensic Pathologist of Sri Lanka (CFPSL) in this regard till date.  Dr. Haq in a letter to the President of the College of Forensic Pathologist of Sri Lanka (CFPSL), Dr. S.P.A. Hewage on 15 October 2023 urged him to expedite the SLMC registration reinstatement. The JMO’s suspension order came when the SLMC gave Dr. Haq (SLMC Registration 15168) an eight- month suspension with effect from 20 December 2022, following an inquiry into a complaint made by S.A. Rathnasena who according to Dr. Haq’s letter had used his influence as the President of the Nuwara Eliya van society and lodged a complaint against him with the SLMC.  He lamented that he was unable to go on transfer order to District General Hospital Gampaha due to the suspension further delaying the transfer chain which had not been active since 2022. Doctor Haq said that the Director General Health Services had written to him on 1 January 2023 and informed him to refrain from serving in his capacity as a medical practitioner and a JMO. He said that having taken legal advice he had appealed to the Health Secretary through the head of his institution. The suspended JMO said that keeping with section 18 of the medical Ordnance Act which said that the Minister of Health had the power to decide and whose decision was final he had appealed to the Minister who had accepted the appeal and “verbally advised him to continue work. However Dr. Haq has been under fire for his contradictory post-mortem reports issued in deaths of Dinesh Schaffter and the three-year-old child who died following kidney surgery at Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH). By Dilanthi Jayamanne
