title: President acknowledges VAT increase decision challenging
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe acknowledged that the decision to increase VAT by 18 per cent was a challenging one, driven by the need to maintain economic stability. President Wickremesinghe highlighted that true leadership involves being honest with the people and making decisions that benefit the nation. During his address at the National Industry Excellence Awards 2023, which took place on Wednesday (1), at the Nelum Pokuna Theatre in Colombo, Wickremesinghe also announced his intention to address bank loan concessions for small and medium-scale industrialists in the upcoming budget, aiming to strengthen Sri Lanka’s export-oriented manufacturing economy. He expressed confidence in the youth leadership within the government and the group of young ministers dedicated to working for the country. President Wickremesinghe pledged to collaborate with them to improve the country’s economic situation by 2024. The National Industry Excellence Awards 2023, jointly organised by the Ministry of Industry and the Ceylon Industrial Development Board, is a step towards achieving this goal. In this context, 300 successful entrepreneurs were recognised and awarded in various categories, including Platinum, Gold, Silver and Bronze awards, out of a pool of over 4,000 industrial entrepreneurs who had applied to compete in 21 major industrial sectors and 61 sub-industrial sectors. Expressing his views further President Ranil Wickremesinghe said: “As I observed the award recipients today, it brought back memories of the challenges we faced last year. At that time, there were numerous uncertainties about the sustainability of our industries. The absence of electricity and the difficulty in obtaining bank loans had led to the closure of thousands of businesses. Today, it’s truly remarkable to see a substantial number of individuals reinvigorating their industries and achieving success. Small and medium-scale industries have made a swift comeback in a relatively short period. However, some issues remain unresolved, particularly concerning bank loans and market access. Our foremost priority is to address these concerns. In the upcoming budget, we aim to introduce measures that provide bank loan concessions to support small and medium-scale industries. This programme is progressing steadily. We have devised comprehensive strategies to revitalise our nation’s economy, engaging in discussions with both the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and our creditors. Our primary focus always revolves around our capacity to repay the loans we’ve taken. To achieve this, we must consistently increase our income year after year. Gaining the trust of private creditors and multilateral creditors is imperative to reassure them of our commitment to loan repayment. This commitment must be ingrained in our actions. A substantial portion of next year’s budget will be allocated to debt repayment and interest. Failure to meet these obligations could push us back into the old, precarious situation. Therefore, safeguarding our currency and fulfilling our loan obligations is of paramount importance. In the past, when there was a budget shortfall, the solution was to instruct the central bank to print more money. However, this approach is no longer legally permissible and obtaining loans from banks has also become a challenge. These restrictions stem from the informal financial practices of the past. To ensure our financial stability in the coming year, we must significantly boost our income. We have set specific revenue targets that we must work diligently to achieve. It’s crucial for the country’s progress and to prevent bankruptcy in the near future. As a result of these financial constraints, we had to make the difficult decision to raise the VAT to 18%. This step aligns us with the practices of countries like India and Pakistan. Such decisions are never easy for any government. However, failing to take these measures would cast a shadow on everyone’s future. Therefore, making the right choices becomes imperative. These decisions are necessary for the well-being of the country, even if they draw criticism from the public. Both my Cabinet and I have willingly shouldered the responsibility of rebuilding our nation, which had faced economic collapse. We made a deliberate choice not to revert to a state of dependency. Instead, we are committed to moving forward with our own strengths. Regrettably, during a Cabinet meeting held last Sunday evening, we had to make this tough decision. While some may point fingers, failing to act would risk returning to the dire circumstances of the previous year. At the start of this year, our economic growth rate was a negative 0.7%. Today, it has improved to 0.5%, with further progress expected next year. This leaves us with a fundamental choice of whether to advance or regress. This is the essence of leadership – the willingness to make difficult decisions and transparently convey the true state of affairs to the people. Through this decision, we can generate much-needed revenue to support small and medium-scale industries by repaying loans to banks. Without this step, these industries would face collapse, which puts industrialists in a challenging position. Thus, these difficult decisions must be made for the betterment of the country, even if they invite criticism. Our focus should remain on the nation’s well-being.”

title: President pledges equal rights and right to land for upcountry Tamils
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, addressing a full house of upcountry Tamils of Indian origin, gathered at the Sugathadasa Stadium yesterday (2), during ‘Naam2023’, commemorating the arrival of South Indian Tamils in Sri Lanka 200 years ago, said that the community will be integrated into the Sri Lankan society with all equal rights in terms of employment, land rights and right to education. He also announced the formation of a committee, led by the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka, where three key proposals were discussed. Finance Minister of India, Nirmala Sitharaman was the Guest of Honour at the ‘Naam 200’. At the event, Sitharaman, along with President Wickremesinghe, virtually launched phase – 4 of the flagship Indian Housing Project, for the construction of 10,000 houses in plantation areas of Sri Lanka. She spoke on the history of the South Indians’ journey to the island country 200 years ago and thanked them for their service to the country they made their home. She said the Prime Minister of India has been overwhelmingly supporting the Indian origin Tamils of Sri Lanka and has pledged support with grants to uplift the lives of this community. They also virtually inaugurated the upgraded Thondaman Vocational Training Center, built with Government of India grant assistance. The President acknowledged that there are upcountry Tamils, who are no longer engaged in plantation work and expressed empathy for their issues, understanding the challenges they face. He reminisced about his own days as a member of a trade union, alongside the late Savumiamoorthy Thondaman, who represented the Ceylon Workers’ Congress (CWC). The President revealed a plan to transit plantation workers into out-growers, allowing them to supply tea to factories and own portions of tea estates, similar to small and medium-scale tea plantations in the South. “Regional plantation companies will be asked to outsource tea plucking to workers, which will eliminate the existing plantation system, transforming them into tea smallholders with ownership of the land,” added the President. Addressing housing issues, he noted that upcountry Tamils do not have plots of land and committed to providing 10 perches of land to each family and issuing land deeds. Additionally, he emphasised the importance of improving education, promising to explore Jeevan Thondaman’s educational proposals and striving for equal education opportunities for the upcountry Tamil community. The President expressed that these proposals would be implemented and he had gained the support of many plantation political representatives, as well as the Prime Minister, to advance these initiatives. President Wickremesinghe acknowledged India’s contribution by welcoming 10,000 people from the upcountry Tamil community.Minister Jeevan Thondaman emphasised that the upcountry Indian community is equal to any other community in the country. He acknowledged the challenges they had overcome and called for an end to the unchanged life of the past 200 years, urging complete change and recognition of the upcountry Indian origin Tamil community. Jeevan Thondaman stressed the need for economic and social progress, inviting everyone to join forces to uplift the Indian origin community. He said the 115, 000 workers are at the plantation and there is 1.3 million Indian origin Tamils in the country but the 115,000 workers identity has been the identity of the entire community and that has to change. The economic progress is only possible when there is a social progress, noted the Minister.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: India and SL relaunch ECTA negotiations
author: Author not found
Content: India and Sri Lanka have re-launched negotiations, for the once-controversial Economic and Technology Cooperation Agreement (ECTA), after a five-year hiatus. According to the President’s Media Division (PMD), negotiations between Sri Lanka and India unfolded in Colombo from 30 October to 1 November. A delegation of 19 Indian officials, led by Shri Anant Swarup, Chief Negotiator and Joint Secretary of the Department of Commerce in the Ministry of Commerce and Industry of India, visited Sri Lanka. They engaged in extensive discussions on this comprehensive Agreement. Sri Lanka was represented in these pivotal negotiations by the National Trade Negotiating Committee (NTNC), headed by K.J. Weerasinghe, the Chief Negotiator from the Presidential Secretariat. The Sri Lankan Negotiation Team included representatives from various government bodies, such as the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Trade, Commerce and Food Security, Ministry of Industries, Department of Trade & Investment Policy, the Attorney General’s Department, Department of Commerce, Department of Agriculture, Central Bank of Sri Lanka and Board of Investment, among others. According to a statement issued by India’s Commerce and Industry Ministry, both sides reviewed the progress on implementation and decided to drop nine issues as being resolved. Issues such as the quota on apparel and pepper and the procurement of pharmaceuticals were also discussed and both sides decided to continue the discussion and explore new options for resolution of the matter. As per the statement, both sides took stock of the progress made till the 11th round or negotiations and engaged in discussions on various chapters including trade in goods and services, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, and dispute settlement, and identified the areas of convergence and areas where they need to find creative solutions.

title: Obesity, wasting among children a public health emergency
author: Author not found
Content: Current levels of obesity and wasting among children in Sri Lanka have exceeded two per cent of the school-age population, reaching a point that can be classified as a public health emergency by current standards, Dr. Ayesha Lokubalasuriya, Head of the School Health Unit at the Family Health Bureau (FHB) revealed. She made this revelation during a recent media briefing. Addressing the same media briefing Dr. Chithramalee de Silva, the Director of Maternal and Child Health of FHB, addressed the issue of wasting and obesity among school children, linking it to the ongoing economic crisis and financial constraints on families. In response to a question posed by Ceylon Today, Dr. Chitramalee explained that the high cost of living has made it difficult for people to access nutritious food. As a result, parents have resorted to providing cheaper, but less nutritious, food options that are high in sugar and fats.  Their primary focus has become merely “filling up the stomachs” of their children, as they are unable to prioritise nutrition given the current financial situation. Dr. Chitramalee also mentioned that various studies Conducted by several State Universities have identified an increase in diabetes among school children in Sri Lanka. Meanwhile, Dr. Lokubalasuriya also noted an increase in children aged 12 to 13 dropping out of schools. Referring to a survey report, she stated that the attendance of male children in Colombo schools has declined due to them leaving school to engage in menial jobs.  Parents have been encouraging their children to do so due to economic constraints on their families. She mentioned that during her visits to Kurunegala and Batticaloa, even principals and teachers in these districts expressed concerns about declining student attendance records, as parents struggle to afford transportation for their children between home and school. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Central Expressway construction victims protest at RTI Commission
author: Author not found
Content: A group of people from Kurunegala, whose houses were damaged due to the construction of the last stretch of Central Expressway, staged a peaceful protest yesterday (2) in front of the Right to Information (RTI) Commission, Colombo against the Road Development Authority (RDA) and other institutions for failing to provide requested information on the damages to the houses. These residents said they have not received compensation for their damaged houses, which resulted from violations of environmental assessment reports during the construction of the Central Expressway. In an attempt to obtain related documents under the Right to Information (RTI) Act, the affected local residents submitted over 400 Right to Information (RTI) requests on 22 October. They sent 200 requests each to both the Road Development Authority (RDA) and the relevant contractor company,. Their goal was to request information, including damage assessment reports for their houses and associated financial assessments, to be provided within 48 hours. According to Section 25(3) of the Right to Information Act, organisations must respond within 48 hours to requests related to citizens’ lives or personal freedom. The RTI requests sent to the RDA contained 18 questions, while those sent to the contractor company contain 16 questions. The Association of Victimised Families, from the construction of the Central Expressway, stated that more than 400 houses were damaged during the construction of the Central Expressway, specifically the final segment from Mirigama to Kurunegala. Some victims have not received compensation, while others have received inadequate compensation, as low as Rs 5,000 or 10,000 for seriously damaged houses. Despite continuous complaints to the RDA, the Police, and the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL), the residents’ concerns have gone unaddressed. In response to this, the people submitted the 400 RTI requests under the Right to Information Act. As the RDA and other institutions failed to provide requested information, an appeal hearing, related to one RTI request submitted by Sanjeewa Kulathilaka, took place yesterday (2) at the RTI Commission, Colombo. Attorney-at-Law Manushika Cooray represented the information requesters and nearly 40 civil society activists, local residents and journalists were present at the hearing.  Although the human rights activists and journalists requested that the appeal hearing be recorded or broadcast live through the website, the commission refused to do so. However, except for two journalists, all others were allowed to attend the appeal hearing. During the hearing, the RDA claimed that they had not received the RTI request, but it was revealed that they had indeed received it. The RDA also stated that they do not possess some of the requested information. At this point, the information requester Sanjeewa Kulathilaka and journalist Tharindu Jayawardhana made a lengthy statement, explaining that the RTI Act itself requires the disclosure of some categories of information, even before filing requests. They stressed, “We explained with facts that the Minister of Transport and Highways has fulfilled the legal responsibility assigned under the RTI Act. On the other hand, the RTI Commission too has not fulfilled its responsibility under Section 14 (a) of the RTI Act. At this juncture, Upali Abeyratne, the chairman of the Commission, claimed that things were always slow like that for many years and it is difficult to change such things. In response to this, the local residents protested, leaving the commission and staging a peaceful demonstration. Finally, the commission ordered the RDA to provide the requested information within 10 days. No decision was reached on other RTI requests, and further hearing was scheduled on 15 November. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Special commodity levy on sugar upped to Rs 50
author: Author not found
Content: The Finance Ministry has issued a government notification raising the Special Commodity Levy on imported sugar toRs 50 per kg. The previous Special Commodity Levy for a kg of sugar was 25 cents. This updated levy came into effect yesterday (2), and it will remain applicable for a one-year period until 2 November 2024. President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation, and National Policies, has officially issued this government notification, exercising his authority under Section 2 of the Special Commodity Levy Act No. 48 of 2007.

title: 17 Lankans trapped in Gaza allowed to cross into Egypt
author: Author not found
Content: Permission has been granted to a group of 17 Sri Lankans who are trapped in the Gaza Strip amidst the Israel-Hamas conflict to leave the war-torn Palestinian enclave and enter Egypt via the Rafah border crossing. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Tel Aviv has officially communicated this to the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE). SLBFE Deputy General Manager and Spokesman Gamini Senarath, during a special media briefing last morning (2), said 15 of these Sri Lankans were expected to reach Egypt last afternoon. The Sri Lankan Embassy in Israel and the Representative Office of Sri Lanka in Palestine are working in tandem to facilitate the evacuation of Sri Lankans trapped in Gaza, he added. Senarath, citing the Sri Lankan Ambassador to Israel Nimal Bandara, also mentioned that the Sri Lankan man, who remains missing since the surprise attack launched by Hamas earlier this month, is suspected to be among the hostages held by the militant group. The 48-year-old father of two was reported missing after 7 October, the day Hamas militants stormed from the blockaded Gaza Strip into nearby Israeli towns to launch an unprecedented attack. The SLBFE Spokesman said, prompt action is being taken to facilitate the immediate release of the Lankan hostage. By Anjali Withanage

title: Bangladesh to give SL medicines worth USD 58,000
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry announced that Sri Lanka will soon receive medical assistance valued at USD 58,000 from Bangladesh. This information emerged following a recent meeting between Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana and Bangladesh High Commissioner in Sri Lanka Tareq Md Ariful Islam. During the meeting, the High Commissioner disclosed that the aid package encompasses 54 types of essential medications, with a specific focus on drugs for cancer and kidney treatment. Additionally, another aid shipment, with a value of one million, USD is anticipated to be dispatched in the near future by the Bangladesh Ministry of Health. Dr. Pathirana conveyed his appreciation to the Bangladeshi Government for their swift response to Sri Lanka’s request for medical aid. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Water capacity in reservoirs surpasses 50% mark
author: Author not found
Content: Director of Irrigation (Hydrology and Disaster Management) Engineer S.P.C. Sugeeshwara announced yesterday (2) that the water capacity of reservoirs across the island has surpassed 50 per cent due to the recent heavy rains. Addressing the media, he further revealed that certain reservoirs nationwide have already begun overflowing and more are expected to do so tonight if the current rainfall persists. The Department of Irrigation also reported that the Kalatuwewa Reservoir, exclusively constructed within the Labugama-Kalatuwewa Forest Reserve, in the Kelani River basin, to supply drinking water to Colombo and its suburbs, has started overflowing after five years, following heavy rainfall in the Kelani River catchment areas. Residents residing downstream of the Deduru Oya are urged to exercise caution due to the opening of six spill gates of the Deduru Oya Reservoir. These gates have been opened more than 3 feet, releasing approximately 1,000 cubic feet of water per second. The Director also noted that the water levels in Attanagalu Oya have reached the spill level, causing a minor flood situation in Attanagalla, Gampaha, Ja-Ela, and Katana Divisional Secretariat Divisions. However, the situation may change if heavy rainfall continues throughout the day. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SC orders Sirisena, three others to submit assets report
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (2) ordered four respondents, including Former President Maithiripala Sirisena, in Fundamental Rights (FR) Petitions related to 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, to submit affidavits declaring their assets and liabilities by 30 December 2023. These respondents, namely former President Maithripala Sirisena, former Defence Ministry Secretary Hemasiri Fernando, former Inspector-General of Police (IGP) Pujith Jayasundara, and former Chief of the State Intelligence Service (SIS) Nilantha Jayawardena, have been directed to provide information about their financial status. The Supreme Court’s decision stems from the fact that these four respondents failed to fulfil their obligation to pay the full compensation as ordered by the Court. Additionally, the court has called for a detailed report from the Attorney General regarding the disciplinary actions taken against the former SIS chief, Jayawardena, by 30 December 2023. On 12 January 2023, the Supreme Court found these individuals, along with former National Intelligence Chief Sisira Mendis, responsible for violating the fundamental rights of the public due to their failure to take preventive action against the Easter Sunday bombings, despite having received adequate intelligence information. The Court, in its judgment, ordered Sirisena to pay Rs 100 million in compensation to the petitioners from his personal funds, while Pujith Jayasundara and Nilantha Jayawardena were each instructed to pay Rs 75 million. Hemasiri Fernando and Sisira Mendis were required to pay Rs. 50 million and Rs 10 million, respectively. This ruling was issued by a seven-member bench of Supreme Court Judges in response to the 12 petitions filed by various parties who claimed that their fundamental rights were violated due to negligence and failure to prevent the coordinated terrorist attacks on 21 April 2019. In July 2023, it was reported that the former president had made an initial payment of Rs. 15 million ahead of the deadline, while Hemasiri Fernando, Pujith Jayasundara, and Sisira Mendis had paid Rs 1 million, Rs 1,725,588, and Rs 5 million, respectively. Sirisena had also submitted a motion requesting permission to pay the remaining amount in 10 installments of Rs. 8.5 million each, running from 30 June 2024, to 20 June 2033. In this motion, filed through his legal representatives, Sirisena explained that he receives a pension of Rs. 97,500 as the former President, in addition to a sum of Rs. 54,285 for his services as an MP. Therefore, he sought a 9-year period to settle the outstanding sum of the Rs 100 million. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: UN Resident Coordinator offers support for Online Safety Bill
author: Author not found
Content: United Nations Resident Coordinator Marc-André Franche has informed Public Security Minister Tiran Alles that support will be provided for the exchange of ideas and proposals with international organisations concerning the Online Safety Bill. This was communicated during a meeting between the UN Resident Coordinator and the Minister at the Ministry of Public Security on Wednesday (1). The Ministry said, they discussed ways in which Sri Lanka can offer support to the United Nations and the Online Safety Bill during the meeting. When Minister Alles requested comments and suggestions for the Bill, Marc-André Franche assured that support would be provided for the exchange of ideas and proposals with international organisations. Meanwhile, UN Sri Lanka said, they had discussed the importance of conducting broad consultations to generate consensus across political and social sectors on laws and policies such as the Online Safety Bill. Laws should respect freedoms and civil liberties, while creating a conducive environment for Sri Lanka’s sustainable development and digital economy. At the recent Internet Governance Forum, world leaders discussed collective actions to realise a common vision for #TheInternetWeWant by maintaining the Internet whole and open, universal and inclusive, free-flowing and trustworthy, safe and secure, and rights-respecting. Following this vision, the UN in Sri Lanka stands ready to facilitate consultations and continue supporting the country adhering to its international commitments.

title: SL’s Speaker meets Georgian counterpart
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting was held between Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana and Speaker of the Georgian Parliament Shalva Papuashvili. The meeting was held, while attending the 147th Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union in Luanda, Angola. The Speakers exchanged views on strengthening bilateral relations between the two countries. MPs Mohomad Muzammil, Chinthaka Amal Mayadunna, Rajika Wickramasinghe and Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera were present.

title: Navy Commander attends Goa Maritime Conclave 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera attended the Goa Maritime Conclave (GMC) – 2023 hosted by the Indian Navy for the fourth time, under the aegis of Naval War College, Goa from 29 to 31 October. The theme for this year’s GMC was ‘Maritime Security in the Indian Ocean Region: Converting Common Maritime Priorities into Collaborative Mitigating Frameworks’. The fourth edition of the Goa Maritime Conclave was attended by Chiefs of Navies and Heads of Maritime Forces from 12 Indian Ocean Region countries including Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Comoros, Indonesia, Madagascar, Malaysia, Maldives, Mauritius, Myanmar, Seychelles, Singapore and Thailand. Meanwhile, the Keynote address of the conclave was delivered by Defence Minister of India, Rajnath Singh and Minister of State for External Affairs and Culture, Meenakshi Lekhi. The conference offered a valuable platform for stakeholders to share ideas and work together to address a wide range of unlawful activities, including non-traditional maritime issues, in the Indian Ocean Region. Meanwhile, Commander of the Sri Lanka Navy, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera addressed the conference on the topic of ‘Maritime Security in the Indian Ocean Region: Converting Common Maritime Priorities into Collaborative Mitigating Frameworks – A Sri Lanka’s Perspective’. In the address, he emphasised the multifaceted challenges confronting the Indian Ocean Region (IOR), calling for unwavering vigilance and collaborative efforts. Pointing to the intricate web of threats, he underscored the rising presence of non-state actors, transnational criminal organisations, and territorial disputes. Shedding light on the concerning surge in the illicit arms trade and drug trafficking, the Commander highlighted the daunting task of policing the expansive ocean. Moreover, he articulated the profound impact of climate-induced changes on island states, triggering internal and external displacements of coastal communities. Notably, the Commander highlighted Sri Lanka’s commitment to the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea and advocated the collaborative, multilateral approach of the Sri Lanka Navy. He also acknowledged the successes achieved in fostering partnerships with both regional and extra-regional navies, particularly through conferences such as the Goa Maritime Conclave as well as the Galle Dialogue, hosted by the Sri Lanka Navy. Meanwhile, the Navy Commander also expressed his gratitude to the Chief of the Naval Staff India for extending an invitation to address this year’s conclave and congratulated him for the well-organised event. On the sidelines of GMC-2023, bilateral meetings were held among the Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera and Chief of the Naval Staff India, Admiral R. Hari Kumar, Flag Officer Commanding in Chief Western Naval Command India, Vice Admiral Dinesh K. Tripathi, Flag Officer Commanding in Chief Eastern Naval Command India, Vice Admiral Rajesh Pendharkar and Flag Officer Commanding in Chief Southern Naval Command India, Vice Admiral M.A. Hampiholi. Their discussions focused on several matters of mutual interest and bilateral nature while highlighting the long-standing relationship between the two countries. Further, the Navy Commander also explored the native advancements in the shipbuilding sector within the Indian Navy during this visit. Participating in such conclaves within the maritime community inevitably opens avenues for stakeholders to strengthen mutual cooperation and international relations. This, in turn, enables the effective addressing of emerging non-traditional maritime threats and other challenges in the Indian Ocean Region. It also positions them as proactive contributors to the security of the ocean region.

title: Orientation programme for new SL Heads of Mission
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Minister Ali Sabry inaugurated a two-week Orientation Programme for the Heads of Mission designate of Sri Lanka at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 1 November. Minister Sabry outlined key aspects of Sri Lanka’s foreign policy priorities of the present Government under the leadership of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The Heads of Mission have been appointed at a critical juncture where they are called upon to play an important role in supporting Sri Lanka’s economic recovery. Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane spoke on the role of a Head of Mission as a manager and leader and highlighted challenges faced by Heads of Mission in today’s context. The Orientation Programme will cover key areas of focus for Sri Lanka Missions abroad including trade and investment, foreign employment, tourism, consular affairs and public diplomacy. The programme will also include visits to the Northern, Eastern and Southern Provinces as well as interactions with key interlocutors in the private sector and civil society. Following are the newly appointed Heads of Mission: Ambassador-designate to Italy Satyajit Rodrigo (SLFS), Ambassador-designate to Egypt Madurika Weninger (SLFS), High Commissioner-designate to Bangladesh Dharamapala Weerakkody (SLFS), High Commissioner-designate to Singapore Senerath Dissanayake (SLFS), Ambassador-designate to Belgium and the European Union Chandana Weerasena (SLFS), High Commissioner-designate to India Kshenuka Senewiratne (Retd. SLFS), High Commissioner-designate to Pakistan Admiral Ravindra Wijegunaratne, Ambassador-designate to Nepal Air Marshal Sudharshana Pathirana, Ambassador-designate to Cuba Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne, and High Commissioner-designate to the UK Rohitha Bogollagama.

title: Judge acquits suspect, sternly warns WPC against lying
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige acquitted a woman, who had been charged with peddling and possessing 43.150 grammes of heroin, without calling for submissions from the defence due to contradictory evidence given by the Chief Inspector-in- Charge of the raid and the Woman Police Constable (WPC), who had frisked the accused. The Judge stated that the evidence placed before him, by the Chief Inspector-in-Charge of the raid and the WPC, who had frisked the accused, had been contradictory. Hence, he noted that he was acquitting the accused from the charges filed against her. The accused who was acquitted was identified as H.M. Samanthi Priyadarshani. Judge Patabendige, addressing the WPC, sternly warned against her future conduct and advised her to desist from spreading lies, which could hinder her from performing her duty, to the satisfaction of the public. He insisted that as a public official, who is being sustained by the people, she was duty bound 24/7 to always stand up for the truth. He then warned that such embarrassing conduct would land her in hot water one day, if she fails to realise the seriousness of her conduct and rectify it promptly. The Judge stated that from the evidence given by the Chief Inspector, the raid to apprehend the accused had been carried out in the afternoon of 21 December, four years ago. But the Court stated that the WPC, attached to the Keselwatta Police, testifying before the State Counsel, had maintained that the drug was detected in a pocket of a dress, worn by the accused, following a raid done at dawn, on the said date. Following the hearing of evidence, the Judge instructed the accused to be acquitted from the charges filed against her and be released from the trial, whilst sternly warning the WPC, for having put forth bogus evidence before Court. The Court also instructed its Registrar, to submit its verdict in the trial to the perusal of the Inspector General of Police (IGP) and the National Police Commission (NPC), forthwith. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: NCRS programme to minimise road accidents
author: Author not found
Content: The National Council for Road Safety (NCRS) has implemented numerous measures to reduce the frequency of accidents in the country, which have claimed several lives and caused injuries to hundreds of individuals, leaving many permanently disabled, NCRS said The NCRS has initiated a programme to incorporate factors that contribute to road traffic accidents and precautions to prevent them, as well as providing first aid after an accident, into science and mathematics textbooks from Grades 6 to 11, along with teachers’ guidebooks. The NCRS has also taken steps to provide road safety training to 940 school teachers selected from across the country. As part of this effort, a three-hour practical training session was recently conducted for 80 school teachers who teach science in schools in the Sabaragamuwa Province. The NCRS is composed of 17 institutions, including public and private entities. They are dedicated to safeguard lives and prevent accidents. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: President’s decision to increase wages, timely move
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman Wajira Abeywardena said, President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s decision, to increase salaries of public and private sector employees, demonstrates that the economy is on the path to recovery from its state of bankruptcy. MP Abeywardena was speaking during a discussion with a representative of the Ratnapura Youth Front. He appealed to all not to engage in strikes as they could have a negative impact on tax income and other related revenues generated from tourism and the private sector. Abeywardena described President Wickremesinghe’s proposal to increase salaries of public and private sector employees as a significant package offered by the Government to the people. He said, at a time when the country’s economy is getting back on track, it is the responsibility of everyone to cooperate with the Government in resolving all outstanding issues. He also claimed that the process of increasing public servants’ salaries involves income generated from the private sector and the tourism industry. Although the public sector itself does not generate income, it serves the country’s administrative purposes. Abeywardena added, despite political differences all citizens should come together to develop the nation and rescue it from the current dire state of a bankrupt economy. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Court Rules Dinesh Schaffter Was Murdered
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Magistrate’s Court yesterday (1) concluded that the death of the renowned businessman, Dinesh Schaffter, had resulted from external pressure applied to his neck and facial area. In light of this determination, Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya ruled that a criminal act has occurred in connection with this death. As a result, an order has been issued for the Director of the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) to arrest the suspects and produce them in Court. The Additional Magistrate also ordered CID to obtain the instructions from the Attorney General for further investigations. A five-member committee of experts, including Forensic Medical Specialists and Judicial Medical Officers, was appointed to investigate the actual cause of the late businessman Schaffter’s death. The committee comprising Prof. Asela Mendis, Prof. D.C.R. Perera, Prof. D.N.P. Fernando, Dr. Siva Subramaniam and Dr. Rohan Ruwanpura submitted their findings from the post-mortem examinations to the Colombo Additional Magistrate’s Court on 31 October. As per the consensus of four out of five members of the expert committee, the apparent cause of death was identified as pressure applied to the neck and face of the deceased. Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya also ordered to provide copies of the expert committee report to the CID, the Attorney General’s Department and the relatives of the diseased. Dinesh Schaffter, Director of the Janashakthi PLC Group, was discovered bound in his car at the General Cemetery in Borella on 15 December 2022. He passed away one day later while receiving treatment at the ICU of the National Hospital Colombo. Suspended JMO Ruhul Haq initially concluded the death was a suicide and the body was buried in Borella Cemetery following a Court order. However, the deceased businessman’s relatives, who said that the death was suspicious, requested another postmortem. Accordingly, the expert committee chaired by Dr. Asela Mendis was appointed by the Court to exhume his body and conduct the requested post-mortem. The exhumed body of Schaffter was kept at the Teaching Hospital Karapitiya, for several months for the post-mortem and the expert committee held several rounds of discussions in Kandy to arrive at conclusions related to the death. The relatives also had sought permission from the court to allow their legal representatives to present information regarding the second post-mortem report after its submission. Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya, while denying the request, clarified that the primary purpose of a post-mortem examination is to determine the cause of death, and there is no legal provision for external parties to present additional information. Consequently, the Additional Magistrate instructed the CID to facilitate the handover of the late businessman’s remains, currently held at the Teaching Hospital Karapitiya, to his family. Furthermore, arrangements have been made for the burial of the remains at the Jawatte Cemetery in accordance with a previous Court order. It was revealed during the Police investigations that Dinesh Schaffter had left his house located in Flower Road, Cinnamon Gardens in the afternoon of 15 December 2022 and had bought food for two from a restaurant located on Malalasekara Mawatha, Colombo. Since his phone was not answered for a long time, Schaffter’s wife searched for his whereabouts through the GPS and she informed the Executive Director of the company after finding that his last location was shown as near the Borella Cemetery. Following that, Executive Director Kris Perera went to the Borella cemetery and found Schaffter’s car parked at the corner of the cemetery. It was seen that Schaffter was stuck on the driver’s seat of the car and that his hands and neck were tied with a wire. Although, he was rushed to the hospital, he died at midnight on 16 December 2022. Investigations were conducted based on a complaint made by the relatives to the Borella Police and later the investigations were handed over to the CID. No suspect has been arrested so far for the murder. The next hearing of the case will be on 20 March 2024. A group of lawyers including President’s Counsel Anuja Premaratne appeared on behalf of the aggrieved party and a group of lawyers including SSP Prashantha and ASP Kaluarachchi represented the CID. The cause of Schaffter’s death of was stated in open Court by Court interpreter Imani. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Budget Speech 2024 on 13 November
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe will deliver the Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill for 2024, commonly known as the ‘Budget Speech’ on Monday, 13 November, at 12:00 noon in Parliament. Following this presentation, the Second Reading debate of the Appropriation Bill (Budget) will be from 14 November to 21 November, encompassing a full week of discussions, excluding Sundays, announced the Secretary General of Parliament. The vote for the Second Reading of the Budget will be on 21 November, at 6:00 p.m. Following this, the Committee debate will unfold over 19 days, commencing on Wednesday, 22 November and concluding on Wednesday, 13 December. This period will also exclude Sundays. The vote on the Third Reading of the budget for the financial year 2024 is scheduled for Wednesday, 13 December, at 6.00 p.m. During the budget debate period, daily discussions are planned to take place from 9.30 a.m. to 6.00 p.m. The debate will extend beyond the ordinary schedule, from 6.00 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day, except on the date of the budget vote.

title: Harsha lambasts Govt for heaping taxes on public
author: Author not found
Content: Without taking concrete measures to prevent the loss of annual tax revenue of Rs 80 billion via the liquor trade, the Government was determined to heap more misery on the public by imposing more taxes, Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Dr. Harsha de Silva alleged. He charged that the Government was undertaking such measures to fulfill its revenue targets without placing due concern to the cost-of-living factor which affects the ordinary people. He stated that out of tax targets given to the Excise Department this year, which amounts to Rs 217 billion, the latter had only paid Rs 125 billion by 30 September. He said in such a scenario he was not in the least surprised to see the Excise Department being unable to take stringent action to prevent the loss of tax revenue via the liquor trade. The SJB MP was speaking at a media conference held at the Opposition Leader’s Office yesterday (1). He added “The Excise Department claimed recently that they will be cancelling the licences of liquor manufacturers here who have failed to pay the requisite taxes to the State by 31 October.  But, today is 1 November and we are yet to be informed that they (Excise) have cancelled any of the licences. The Justice Minister recently announced in Parliament that a sum of Rs 80 billion had been lost via the counterfeit sticker on liquor bottles racket. “Following constant attention given to the matter by the Parliament Select Committee (PSC), we were able to seize large stocks of liquor bottles containing fake security labels or stickers.” Dr. de Silva stated that following details which had emerged from deliberations of various committees in Parliament, a sizeable number of local liquor manufacturers had refrained from paying the requisite taxes to the State.

title: Health Minister suspends emergency purchases
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana instructed officials to suspend controversial emergency purchases and to import only National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) registered drugs. He also instructed that available data on unregistered medicines should be checked and approved by the NMRA. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry yesterday (1) said that Dr. Pathirana had warned that action would be instituted against anyone acting outside of these instructions. Dr. Pathirana instructed officials to suspend the purchase of medicinal drugs under emergency purchases and arrange for the delivery of pharmaceuticals in short supply as early as possible through the prescribed method. The spokesman said Dr. Pathirana had advised officials from the NMRA, State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC), State Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Corporation (SPMC) and Medical Supplies Division (MSD). Priority should be given to improving the health of the people, the spokesman said quoting the Minister who informed officials to pay attention to essential drugs used to treat cancer, kidney diseases, etc., while maintaining these medicines in State hospitals without there being a shortage. Health Ministry Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta, Additional Secretaries Dr. Saman Ratnayake, Deputy Director General of Medical Supplies Y.L.M. Navavi, D.R.K. Herath, Chairman of the SPC Dr. Ajith Mendis, Chairman of the NMRA Dr. Ananda Wijewickrama, Chairman SPMCDr. Utpala Indrawansa and several other officials were present. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Indian Finance Minister arrives to participate in NAAM200
author: Author not found
Content: India’s Finance Minister and State Minister for Foreign Affairs, Nirmala Sitharaman, arrived in Sri Lanka yesterday (1) to be Chief Guest at the ‘NAAM200’ national celebration, commemorating the arrival of Indian-origin plantation Tamils 200 years ago. The event is scheduled to take place today (2) at the Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium. Minister Sitharaman arrived in the country on the invitation of General Secretary of the Ceylon Workers Congress and Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Jeevan Thondaman. During the event, Minister Sitharaman will inaugurate the 10,000 houses programme and unveil a new cultural and IT centre at the Thondaman Vocational Training College in Hatton. These initiatives are part of the three billion rupee Indian grant allocated for the plantation community in Sri Lanka. Minister Sitharaman was received at the Bandaranaike International Airport by representatives of the CWC. Expressing his gratitude, Thondaman tweeted, “I am thankful to the Government and people of India for their generosity and friendship toward the people of Sri Lanka and the plantation community.” During her three-day visit, the Indian Minister will have meetings with President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, further strengthening bilateral relations and in that regard, a business summit under the theme ‘Enhancing Connectivity: Partnering for Prosperity,’ is scheduled for today (2). The summit will host a high-powered Indian business delegation representing various industries. Notably, both the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) and the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI) will be part of this important event, with more than 30 Indian business leaders in attendance. India has consistently expressed its commitment to supporting Sri Lanka’s economic recovery, emphasising the importance of mutually beneficial investments in bilateral relations. The CII delegation is led by its President-elect, Sanjiv Puri, MD of ITC, a major investor in Sri Lanka. Sri Lankan businesses are also expected to participate in the summit, offering an excellent platform for fostering new partnerships. India remains Sri Lanka’s largest trading partner, and the two countries are actively engaged in the 12th round of the Economic and Technology Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) to expand economic and commercial activities further. Indian Finance Minister, Sitharaman, conveyed to Maha Nayake of the Asgiriya Chapter, Most Venerable Warakagoda Sri GnanarthanaThera, her intention to witness the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for the solar electrification of religious sites throughout Sri Lanka. This initiative marks the first project under the USD 15 million grant assistance announced by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to foster Buddhist ties between the two nations. Minister Sitharaman played a pivotal role in expediting the comprehensive assistance of four billion USD to Sri Lanka in 2022. She also strongly advocated for Sri Lanka with the IMF to secure a special package during the country’s economic and financial challenges. As a result of these efforts, India became the first bilateral creditor to provide a written assurance, which facilitated the approval of the IMF package. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Population and Housing Census kicks off
author: Author not found
Content: The 15th Decennial Population and Housing Census, which is done  every 10 years, kicked off yesterday (1) at the Presidential Secretariat in Colombo. Notably, the Presidential Secretariat became the first building to be documented in this Census. What sets this year’s census apart is the integration of tablet computers alongside the traditional paper documents for data collection. This marks the first-ever use of such technology in a census that has a history spanning over 150 years. The current phase, the listing phase, is underway and will be followed by the enumeration phase scheduled for 2024, stated by the Department of Census and Statistics. The Population and Housing Census is a comprehensive count of all individuals and residential properties within a country during a specific period. This meticulous process ensures that no individual or dwelling is either overlooked or counted twice, emphasised the department. The Population and Housing Census serves as the primary source for official data concerning population and housing information, down to the Grama Niladhari Division level. Approximately 16,000 enumerators, all of whom are government employees, have been recruited for this year’s census. Training for the personnel involved in the listing phase has already commenced at the Divisional Secretariat office.

title: 117% surge in king coconut exports
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is witnessing a remarkable surge in king coconut exports, with a staggering 117 per cent increase in 2023, according to the Sri Lanka Coconut Development Authority. The rise in demand for Sri Lankan king coconuts in the global market has prompted significant growth in exports. In response to this promising trend, Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industry Mahinda Amaraweera engaged in discussions with key officials from the Coconut Development Board, Sri Lanka Coconut Research Institute, and Coconut Development Authority on the future developments of coconut cultivation in the country and the progress achieved so far. While King Coconut hasn’t traditionally been cultivated as a plantation crop in Sri Lanka, its popularity on the international stage is undeniable. In 2022, the country exported 11 million King Coconuts, generating an income of Rs 110 million. Fast forward to the current year, 2023, and the export numbers have already surpassed 14 million King Coconuts, resulting in an income of Rs 140 million. This represents a remarkable 117% increase in exports this year. Recognising the potential of King Coconut cultivation in Sri Lanka, Minister Amaraweera has directed the relevant authorities to conduct soil tests to identify suitable areas for King Coconut cultivation. These identified areas will be designated as ‘King Coconut Cultivation Export Model Villages’. Additionally, Sri Lanka’s Coconut Research Institute has been tasked with researching and introducing new King Coconut species with enhanced taste, attractiveness and quicker fruit-bearing capabilities. This move aims to further bolster the country’s position in the global King Coconut market. State Minister Lohan Ratwatte also participated in the discussions, underscoring the Government’s commitment to boost the King Coconut industry and ensure sustainable growth in coconut cultivation. With the exponential increase in exports, Sri Lanka’s King Coconut industry is poised for a promising future, attracting international attention and acclaim, a spokesman said.

title: Nearly half of A’Pura District residents face poverty
author: Author not found
Content: A large number of residents in the Anuradhapura District are facing poverty and have submitted applications for financial assistance from the Government. Approximately 50 per cent of the families or about 173,622 out of 321,000 families have sought aid through the Aswesuma welfare benefit scheme, shedding light on the pressing socioeconomic challenges faced by the region. This was revealed during a discussion chaired by Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the North Central Provincial Auditorium on 31 October. During the discussion, it was revealed that out of the 321,000 families, in the Anuradhapura District, a staggering 173,622 applications had been received for the welfare benefit scheme. In response, the Premier expressed the Government’s commitment to foster multi-faceted development in the district. He emphasised the need for the Anuradhapura District to contribute to the country’s foreign exchange earnings while also relieving the strain on State finances. Further, the Government aims to enhance employment opportunities for youth in the district, furthering economic progress and social welfare, he said. Meanwhile, MP Duminda Dissanayake submitted a proposal to the Premier for the implementation of a programme to deploy officials to areas known for human-elephant conflicts. This programme seeks to mitigate the escalating conflicts as wild elephants encroach villages in the Anuradhapura District. By Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: Jordan deports 31 Sri Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: Thirty-one (31) Sri Lankans, who entered Jordan on 22 July 2023 on visit/tourist visas, with the expectation of finding jobs, were deported by the Jordanian authorities. The Sri Lankan Embassy in Jordan warned Sri Lankans not to arrive in Jordan on visit/tourist visas without a confirmed job. According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, they were arrested by the North Amman Police and detained in correction centres following a decision taken by the North Amman Court on 12 October 2023. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jordan, in collaboration with the Public Security Directorate of Jordan, facilitated the deportation of the 31 Sri Lankans, who have been issued deportation orders by the Jordanian authorities. The group returned to Sri Lanka on 27 October 2023. The issue of migrant workers arriving on visit/tourist visas and overstaying or attempting to cross international borders illegally has been a recurring trend in the past. From January 2023 up to the present, the Sri Lankan Embassy in Jordan has been actively involved in facilitating the deportation of approximately 120 stranded Sri Lankans, with the support extended by the Jordan authorities. Embassy officials visited the correction centres to ensure the welfare and safety during their stay. The stranded Sri Lankans were provided essential humanitarian support, including medical assistance and access to basic necessities, by the Jordanian authorities. The Embassy strongly advised Sri Lankans not to arrive in Jordan on visit/tourist visas without a confirmed job opportunity and required visa. Many male and female Sri Lankans continue to fall victims of human smuggling and are subsequently subjected to deportation after being held in correction centers. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jordan requested all Sri Lankans to seek overseas job opportunities legally and to register with the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) before departure. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Microfinance to be regularised
author: Author not found
Content: In a significant move, aimed at safeguarding individuals who have availed themselves of microfinance loans, Sri Lanka has issued a Gazette Notification regarding the introduction of the ‘Microfinance and Credit Regulatory Authority Bill’. This Bill, which was issued on the directives of the Minister of Monetary, Economic Stabilisation and National Policy, is expected to bring about much-needed regulations in the microfinance lending industry. The Microfinance and Credit Regulatory Authority Bill is to be presented for the first reading in Parliament next week. The primary objective of this legislation is to establish the Microfinance and Credit Regulatory Authority, oversee moneylending and microfinance businesses and ensure the protection of customers. It also seeks to repeal the existing Microfinance Act No. 6 of 2016, and address related matters. The key objectives of the Authority are to regulate and supervise licenced moneylenders, regulate and supervise licensed microfinance institutions, coordinate with the Central Bank and other relevant regulatory authorities overseeing registered co-operative societies, Samurdhi Community-Based Banks, Samurdhi Community-Based Banking Societies and Farmers’ Organisations, and protect the customers of licensed moneylenders and licenced microfinance institutions. The Authority is empowered with various responsibilities, including licensing and regulating individuals engaged in moneylending and microfinance, supervising individuals involved in the money lending and microfinance businesses, determining policies on market conduct, and supervising and regulating the licensees in line with market developments. The Authority will also coordinate with regulatory authorities to implement responsible lending practices and conduct credit counselling and financial literacy programmes. The administration, management and control of the Authority will be vested in a Board of Directors. The Board comprises ex-officio members, including the Secretary to the Treasury or a Deputy Secretary nominated by the Secretary to the Treasury, the Deputy Governor of the Central Bank in charge of financial system stability, and the Registrar of Voluntary Social Service Organisations or their representative. Furthermore, the Minister will appoint four members, ensuring diverse expertise in the board. The Chairperson of the Authority will be the Secretary to the Treasury or a Deputy Secretary nominated by the Secretary to the Treasury, leading the effort to regulate and protect borrowers in the microfinance sector. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: 11 Health Sector trade unions stage token strike
author: Author not found
Content: Eleven trade unions in the State health services staged a token strike demanding that the Government increase the wages of Government employees in the 2024 Budget. President of the Sri Lanka Janaraja Saukya Sewa Sangamaya (Association of Health Services of the Republic of Sri Lanka –SLJSSS), W. Wimalaratne said 11 trade unions in the State health service had staged a protest from 6.30 last morning and stayed away  from carrying out routine duties even though they had signed in. Lambasting the Government, he said that no measures had been taken to increase wages of State or private sector employees since 2016. The cost of living has soared, with electricity tariffs seeing regular increases, fuel prices rising simultaneously. Wimalaratne warned that State health service employees were prepared to launch a continuous strike if the Government failed to introduce a satisfactory increase in wages through the 2024 budget proposals on 13 November 2023.  He called on the Government to implement wage hikes to create conducive living conditions for State employees. The SLJSSS President pushed the Government to urge the private sector to increase wages as well. By Dilanthi Jayamanne
