title: Token strikes from today at provincial health institutions
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors warned they would launch a series of token strikes, from today (2) at provincial level health institutions, demanding that the Health Ministry and the Government stem the ongoing brain drain among medical practitioners. Secretary Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge yesterday (1) said the Union’s Central Committee decided to step up trade union action by launching a series of token strikes, commencing from the Uva Province today (2), while doctors in the North would stage the strike on Friday (3) in the Northern Province. The last date of the token strike will be 10 November 2023, in the Western Province. On 8 November 2023 token strikes will be conducted in the Central and Eastern provinces while Medical Officers in the Southern and North Central Provinces would stage a strike on 9 November 2023. Dr. Aluthge said they had submitted eight proposals to prevent brain drain. Doctors should be provided with economic justice to encourage them to remain in the country. However, neither is the Government willing to adopt the proposals provided by the GMOA nor is it revealing how it plans to curtail the ongoing brain drain. Meanwhile, informed sources said medical practitioners were provided ambulances that were among the backup vehicles which went with several government bigwigs.  By Dianthi Jayamanne

title: Owner of company involved in importing substandard IVIG remanded
author: Author not found
Content: The owner of the company which used forged documents, to bring in a batch of substandard human intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), was remanded until 15 November. The accused, who goes by the name Aruna Deepthi, was arrested by the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) and produced in the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court early yesterday (1). The Court, last week, imposed travel restrictions on the suspect and two other senior government officials, who have been charged with using forged documents to import a batch of immunoglobulin vials, which were below par. Consequently, travel abroad has been prohibited for Sugath Janaka Fernando, also known as ‘Aruna Deepthi,’ Dr. Vijith Gunasekara, Chief Executive Officer of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) and Dr. Kapila Wickramanayake, the Director of the Supplies Division at the Ministry of Health. Earlier this month, the NMRA revealed that forged documents had been used to obtain Customs clearance for the drug, which subsequently failed quality tests. The product, claimed to be manufactured by Livealth Biopharma Pvt Ltd. in India, was imported by a local medicine supplier named Isolez Biotech Pharma AG (Pvt) Ltd. However, the Indian manufacturer has denied any involvement in this fraudulent activity and has informed the NMRA that it neither produced, nor supplied, nor exported these products to any party. It has been discovered that Rs 130 million was misappropriated through the illicit importation of 22,500 vials of IVIG. The local medical regulator recently reported that the issue came to light after reports of allergic reactions in patients who received the drug at the Colombo National Hospital on 22 August and the Matale District Hospital on 16 September.

title: Pimpri Chinchwad Education Trust Offers Scholarships to Lankan Students
author: Author not found
Content: The Consulate General of Sri Lanka in Mumbai recently held a crucial meeting with the Executive Director of the Pimpri Chinchwad Education Trust (PCET), Maharashtra. The outcome of this collaborative discussion opened doors to educational possibilities for Sri Lankan students, providing them with access to 16 merit-based scholarships spread across eight distinguished schools of PCET. PCET was established in 1990 and since then has expanded in Maharashtra, India with 11 institutes, affiliated to Pune University, spread across 3 campuses that offer educational courses in the fields of Engineering, Management and Computer Applications among others. During the meeting, the Consul General secured 16 scholarships exclusively designated for Sri Lankan students. The significance of this achievement lies in the fact that these scholarships are distributed evenly, with two scholarships available under each of the eight participating schools. The scholarships will enable the students to study in the campuses near Pune, a city known for its vibrant culture and academic excellence. In addition to the scholarships, PCET has generously offered a special fee structure to make studying in Maharashtra more affordable for Sri Lankan students. The tuition fees for courses have been substantially reduced from INR 14 lakhs to INR 9 lakhs, making education at PCET even more accessible. PCET is also going the extra mile to ensure that the cost of living, including accommodation and food, is discounted for Sri Lankan students. PCET’s International Relations cell already has partnerships and agreements with reputed Universities from USA, Europe, UK and Asia, a few of them include Texas A&M University, Texas, USA; University of Arkansas, USA; University of Nevada, Las Vegas, USA; University of Leicester, UK;  University of Wolverhampton, UK and Tor Vergata University of Rome, Italy. Moreover, PCET has an impressive placement record with 2,323 job offers for 1,662 students in the year 2022. Students have secured internships in companies like Microsoft, Google, Morgan Stanley, Amazon and Barclays. A PCET student was able to secure one of the highest salaries of INR 61 Lakhs per annum Cost to Company (CTC). The approach to affordability ensures PCET’s keen interest in promoting educational exchange and cultural diversity with Sri Lankan students. The visit concluded with the Consul General addressing 300 students of PCET on the topic ‘Philosophy for the Futuristic Youth’, a motivational speech on overcoming the psychological, philosophical, social and economic dilemmas and challenges faced by the youth through dedication, determination and focused work culture to excel in all aspects of life.

title: SL Consulate General in Melbourne conducts mobile consular service
author: Author not found
Content: The Consulate General of Sri Lanka in Melbourne conducted a mobile consular service for the Sri Lankan community on 28 October at the Box Hill Town Hall under the guidance of Consul General Sandith Samarasinghe. This initiative aimed at bringing essential consular assistance and services closer to communities, ensuring convenience and accessibility for all. During the service, consulate staff provided a range of services including applications for new passports, dual citizenship, driving licence, and certification of documents. The Consulate processed over 20 applications and provided on-site payment facilities and an online appointment facility, for those who wished to follow up with appointments to the Consulate. Visitors to the booth commended the Consulate for this initiative, saying that it was very convenient for those who found it difficult to come to Melbourne on weekdays, and requested that it carry out similar services in the future.

title: Main gunman of Ganemulla Sanjeewa nabbed while entering country
author: Author not found
Content: Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said a close accomplice of noted underworld figure Ganemulla Sanjeewa had been nabbed by the STF officers while entering the country through the Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake at dawn yesterday (1). He said the suspect identified as B. Don Roshan Wathukar who is a 33-year-old resident of NIttambuwa had functioned as the main gunman of Ganemulla Sanjeewa. According to SSP Thalduwa, the suspect had arrived at the BIA on an Air Arabia flight from Sharjah. Police believe the suspect had been allegedly involved in the murders of Neville the father of Kehelbaddara Padme and Dunumale Sarath besides being linked to several other incidents of demanding extortion money and peddling of illegal drugs, etc. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: SLFP will pay pivotal role in any govt
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Vice President of the SLFP, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera, said the notable features within his party at present include ‘additions and unity,’ in contrast to the previous era characterised by ‘divisions and subtractions’. The Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries was speaking to the media following his participation in a discussion with the SLFP Kandy District Organisers. Amaraweera and Kandy District SLFP Organisers discussed the measures that should be takenn for future elections and how to promote candidates contesting under the SLFP banner. He emphasised that the SLFP is fully prepared to face any election next year, including a Presidential, General, or Provincial Council polls. The Minister claimed any party aiming to establish a new government following the next General Election will need the support of the SLFP. He predicted that his party would play a pivotal role as a decisive political force in such a scenario. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Egg shortage hits Polpithigama
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the shortage of eggs in Polpithigama, those operating eateries and restaurants have been hit hard due to their inability to produce several egg-based food items. These owners said due to the scarcity of eggs in the town, they had been unable to make fried rice, kottu and egg hoppers for customers and as a result their daily income had dipped. They added that before the shortage of eggs, an egg was sold at prices ranging from Rs 45 to 48 per but now there was a severe shortage of eggs. They said the Government should intervene to address the issue or they would  be forced to shut down for want of customers. By Nandana Kelegama – Polpithigama

title: Sand mafia in the North to be curbed
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda has pledged to take action to combat the sand mafia in the Northern Province. Wrongdoers will be brought to justice. Efforts are underway to obtain permission from the Department of Forest Conservation and the Department of Wildlife Conservation to extract sand from identified locations falling under their jurisdiction. Further, arrangements have been made to ensure a continuous supply of sand for construction purposes at an affordable price Devananda said. A meeting was held at the Kilinochchi District Secretariat, bringing together Minister Devananda, stakeholders and the Forest and Wildlife Conservation departments to address the issues surrounding sand mining and to formulate steps to curb illegal sand mining. Devananda said the police were monitoring and combatting illegal activities. He also said the Government was committed to alleviate the grievances of the people by providing them with the necessary means of livelihood. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Voice of masses stifled
author: Author not found
Content: The National Organiser of the All Ceylon Peasants’ Federation (ACPF) Namal Karunaratne said the present regime had strangled the people with a debt entrapment amounting to Rs 35 trillion. He said under such a situation, present-day politicians have no other alternative but to suppress the voice of the masses and stifle dissent and strive to sustain their hold on the reins. Karunaratne said due to the burdens heaped on the masses, they have now reached a point where survival has become out of the question. He warned that the people’s only recourse would be to vote them out of office at the next election. BY Jayantha Dissanayake – Kurunegala

title: 100,000 Euros for flood relief
author: Author not found
Content: The European Union (EU) has allocated Euro 100,000 (over Rs 34.5 million) grant to provide emergency humanitarian assistance to families affected by floods that recently struck large parts of Sri Lanka, the EU in a statement said on 31 October. The aid will benefit close to 15,000 people in the worst-hit localities in Sabaragamuwa, Southern and Western provinces.The EU funding supports the Sri Lankan Red Cross Society (SLRCS) in delivering emergency relief items, including drinking water, clothes, bed sheets and mosquito nets. In addition, affected families will receive cash grants to enable them to meet their basic needs. The assistance will also focus on cleaning up flooded areas and wells while delivering hygiene promotion campaigns. Medical camps will be set up to assist those injured in the wake of the floods. The funding is part of the EU’s overall contribution to the Disaster Response Emergency Fund (DREF) of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC). The southern part of the island started experiencing a series of strong monsoon rains early last month (October), causing floods and landslides, that affected more than 75,000 people in 13 districts. As a result of the continued downpours and strong winds, a number of houses, agricultural lands and crops in low-lying areas were damaged.  Major traffic arteries to several districts were cut off by fallen trees. The floods left many drinking water resources contaminated. The worst affected areas were the coastal districts of Galle, Gampaha and Matara, with most parts flooded for more than a week, the statement in conclusion said. (PA)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: New NMRA Chief can’t escape NMRA irregularities
author: Author not found
Content: The Association of Health Professionals (AHP) said they could only support the newly-appointed Chairman of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) by critiquing his faith in the National Medicines Regulatory (NMRA) Act. President of the AHP, Ravi Kumudesh on 31 October alleged that Dr. Wijewikrama could not escape from allegations that have been levelled against the NMRA. It is what paved the way to a medicinal drug monopoly and enabled decisions based on a single person’s opinion. He alleged that these weak points inthe NMRA Act were responsible for the problems in the State health service.  Dr. Wijewikrama and the team, which contributed to the Act, are directly responsible for discarding the opinion and recommendations of the end user, namely the medical laboratory scientists and technologists when purchasing equipment, including for laboratories, radiology and in the purchase of chemicals including laboratory reagents, he charged.  Also, those who have mastered regulatory science, procurement science and management science should be appointed to chief positions of the Authority in order to enter into the advanced methods of control and regulating. “It cannot be solved by clinical expertise alone. The AHP President warned they would keep a watchful eye on the newly appointed NMRA Chairman to see what course of action would be taken by him to rectify these drawbacks in the NMRA Act itself. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Over 800 train journeys cancelled this year
author: Author not found
Content: From January to September this year, more than 800 train journeys had to be cancelled, primarily due to the failure of railway staff, including guards and drivers, to report to work during the final week of each month, Ceylon Today learns. According to a senior official of the Railways Department, many employees have a pattern of taking sick leave for at least six days in the last week of every month, which creates challenges in taking disciplinary action against them. As a result, the issue of over 800 cancelled train journeys during the past nine months has become a significant concern, and no solution has been found thus far. According to the official, this trend continued during the holiday week that began on Monday (27 October), with more than 40 train journeys being cancelled in the last four days alone. The disruption during the final week of each month has been particularly troublesome for train services. He pointed out that, after the monthly overtime period ends, some officials frequently report sick without returning to work. The lack of effective management exacerbates this problem. Speaking to Ceylon Today, W.A.D.S. Gunasinghe, General Manager of Railways, expressed his awareness of this recurring issue. He attributed it to the need for employees to cover vacancies and undertake additional duties, which often results in railway staff not showing up for work on weekends or during month-end periods. K.K.D. Prasad, Secretary of Railway Guards’ Union also noted that the allocated overtime period for each month coming to end and recent adverse weather conditions had left many employees physically unwell, contributing to the problem. He said such issues stem from factors like vacant positions and a lack of promotions within the Railways Department. The cancellation of train journeys is not solely the responsibility of train controllers; it also involves drivers and driver assistants not reporting for work, he added. Meanwhile, Secretary of the Ministry of Transport, M.M.P.K. Mayadunne, assured that an investigation into these matters would be conducted and necessary action would be taken promptly. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Verdict on Schaffter’s cause of death today
author: Author not found
Content: A five-member committee of expert Judicial Medical Officers, tasked with determining the cause of death of businessman Dinesh Schaffter, has submitted their post-mortem report to the Colombo Additional Magistrate. The Court is scheduled to deliver the verdict on the cause of the businessman’s death today (1). Relatives of the deceased entrepreneur had requested Court permission to have their legal representatives present the post-mortem examination report details after its submission. However, Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya declined the request, emphasising that the sole purpose of a post-mortem examination is to ascertain the actual cause of a person’s death. There is no legal provision for external parties to present additional information on the matter. Consequently, the Additional Magistrate instructed the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) to arrange the handing over of the late businessman’s remains, currently at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, to his family. She also ordered the necessary arrangements for the burial of the remains in accordance with a prior Court orders at the Jawatte Cemetery. Further, the Additional Magistrate expressed her appreciation to the expert committee members for their valuable contribution to the ongoing investigation. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Frequent derailments on upcountry line deter train travel
author: Author not found
Content: The Nawalapitiya and Badulla sections of the upcountry railway line experienced 13 derailments this year and passengers have voiced their concern about the severe inconvenience they face as a result. It was pointed out that foreign tourists frequently commute on the upcountry line and derailments inconvenienced them. The constant derailments on the upcountry line have deterred both local and foreign travellers from train travel. In particular, they highlighted that four derailments took place in October alone. On 16 October, there was a derailment between the Diyathalawa and Haputale railway stations. On 17 October, another incident occurred between the Bandarawela and Diyatalawa stations. Additionally, on 24 of October, a derailment took place between the Talawakelle and Watagoda stations and on 30 October, an incident was reported between the Kinigama and Hiloya stations. Commuters said when trains derail on the upcountry line, they were forced to undertake long walks to access buses, which is a significant challenge. Carrying luggage and goods becomes extremely burdensome, causing severe difficulties. Commuters appeal to the authorities to ensure proper maintenance of the upcountry line and prevent derailment.  BY Chandrasiri Mahagama – NuwaraEliya

title: Man attempts to go abroad with woman using wife’s passport
author: Author not found
Content: At the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake yesterday (31 October) afternoon, immigration authorities apprehended a man who tried to board a flight to Italy with a woman while using his wife’s passport. The incident unfolded when the man, accompanied by his five-year-old son and a 29-year-old woman from Kankesanthurai, initially believed to be his wife, arrived at the Airport to board Air Arabia flight G9509 at 1:45 p.m. On reaching the immigration checkpoint to process their documents, suspicions arose about their identities, prompting the authorities to take further action. Subsequently, the trio was referred to the Border Inspection Unit officers for a more in-depth investigation. Through technical tests and preliminary inquiries, it was determined that while the child was the man’s offspring, the woman travelling with him was not his wife or a family member but an unrelated individual. During the course of the investigation, it came to light that the man had acquired his wife’s passport from Italy a few weeks prior to his arrival in Sri Lanka, falsified the airport immigration stamp, and used it for his travel. Furthermore, it was uncovered that this same passport had been previously used to transport another woman to Italy. Immigration officials subsequently handed over the man, the woman, and the child to the CID at the airport for further investigations. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Missing Lankan man held hostage by Hamas
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan man, Sujith Yatawara Bandara, who was reported missing following the Hamas-led attack on Israel earlier this month, is now believed to be among the group of individuals held hostage by the Hamas in Palestine. This information was officially relayed to the Sri Lankan Embassy in Tel Aviv by Israel’s foreign ministry, Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Israel Nimal Bandara said yesterday (31). Bandara, a 48-year-old father of two, has been missing since the day of the Hamas attack, on 7 October, when militants breached the blockade from the Gaza Strip into nearby Israeli towns for an unprecedented assault. DNA samples provided by Bandara’s children have been dispatched to Israel for further investigations. Bandara affirmed that swift action will be taken for Bandara’s immediate release if his name appears on the list of hostages expected to be freed by Hamas through the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC). Sujith Yatawara Bandara, originally from Vennapuwa, had travelled to Israel in 2015 in search of employment. (MD)

title: ‘Monk’ assaults Wanawasi Padaviya Thera, two Police officers
author: Author not found
Content: Kebethigollawa Police disclosed that a ‘monk’, residing in the Kurulugama Temple in Kebethigollawa, who allegedly assaulted Ven. Wanawasi Padaviya Vijitha Buddhi Thera for conducting the ‘Mathaka Bana’ ritual of a villager has been identified as a person with a criminal record. The suspect has been found to have assumed multiple identities as a monk in various areas of the country, Police added. Initial investigations showed that the suspect monk is involved in three cases filed against him in the Hatton Court, in addition to another case in the Ruwanwella Court. These cases pertain to offences such as house breaking and theft. Further, through fingerprint analysis, it was found that the suspect had taken on three false names while asserting that he did not possess a National Identity Card (NIC). Meanwhile, an invitation had been extended to the chief prelate of Kurulugama Viharaya for a seven-day sermon and almsgiving in memory of a resident from Kurulugama who tragically succumbed to a snakebite. An invitation was also extended to the suspect monk in Kurulugama for the ‘Mathaka Bana’. The monk and the Maranadara Samithiya of the temple declined the invitation, saying that they would only attend if Rs 45,000 was given to them as the family of the deceased had failed to provide three meals and pay fees to the temple in the past. The family, which is poverty stricken, had then invited the Ven. Wanawas Padaviya Vijitha Buddhi Thera to conduct the ritual. After he conducted the ritual and was about to leave, the suspect monk and a mob, which claimed to be members of the funeral society, unexpectedly arrived at the spot causing a disturbance. Subsequently, the Kebithigollewa Police dispatched two officers to the location following a call received on 119, but as the situation had escalated, the Officer-in-Charge (OIC) and a group of Police officers had to intervene. When the suspect monk and the mob threatened and attempted to assault Ven. Wanawas Padaviya Thera, Police intervened to ensure the safety of the latter. However, the mob attacked the Police and grabbed their motorcycles which were later found inside the Kurulugama Viharaya premises. As a result, Ven. Wanawas Padaviya Buddhi Thera and two Police officers were hospitalised. Police arrested the suspect monk, three men and two women on 30 October. By Sajith Gayan

title: Electricity Reforms Bill submitted to Cabinet – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: The proposed Electricity Reforms Bill has been submitted to Cabinet, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said yesterday (31). He said the reforms are designed to revamp the services currently offered by the CEB to improve efficiency, transparency, fostering competition, and enabling greater private sector participation within the electricity industry. The proposed reforms will unbundle the services of CEB, improve efficiency, transparency, competition and allow private sector participation in the electricity industry, the Minister added. Earlier the Bill was to be revised every three months and now it is said it will be reviewed every six months. According to him, the Bill was prepared over the last 10 months with the assistance of energy and legal experts from development agencies and industry stakeholders. The Bill received the certification of the Attorney General last week after the proposed amendments by the AG’s Department was incorporated by the Legal Draftsman.  Once Cabinet approves the Bill, it will be gazetted and tabled and the Energy Minister is vested with preparing a general policy guideline on the supply of electricity for approval to Cabinet as per the Electricity Act No. 20 of 2009.  The electricity charges review period is to be six months as per the existing general policy guidelines. However, considering the inconveniences the public has to face , Cabinet approved the joint Cabinet proposal furnished by the President  with the Minister of Electricity and Power to revise the relevant period to implement power dispatch audit of the CEB and strengthen hydroelectricity forecast with the assistance of the Department of Meteorology so that the general policy guidelines already implemented could be revised. Former, PUCSL Chairman Janaka Ratnayake criticised the Bill speculating that the it would abolish Ceylon Electricity Board and transfer its resources to 14 companies established under the Companies Ordinance No. 7 of 2007. It would further take national energy security under the control of companies who take over the Mahaweli power plant, Lakshapana power plant, Uma Oya and other hydro power plants and all thermal power plants including Norochcholai. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: VAT to be raised from 15% to 18%
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet has approved the increase in the Value-Added Tax (VAT) starting next year. Accordingly, commencing 1 January 2024, VAT will be raised from 15% to 18%. Further, this adjustment will encompass the expansion of the tax to include certain goods and services that were previously exempt. In addition, several new tax measures will be put into effect on 1 January 2024, as part of an effort to meet the tax revenue and primary balance targets established in collaboration with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). This decision comes in response to the observation that the tax collection objectives set with the IMF have not yet been met. The Government highlighted that during the first nine months of 2023, State tax revenue increased by 51% in comparison to 2022, due to the implementation of various tax-related adjustments and developmental tax policies initiated in June 2022. These measures were introduced to ensure the financial stability of State income and sustaining the country’s financial health. BY Mithun Jayawardhana
