title: AG’s annual report, NAO ’s annual work programme handed over to Dep Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: The Auditor General’s annual report for 2022 and the National Audit Office’s (NAO) annual work programme for 2024 were handed over by Auditor General W.P.C. Wickramaratne to the Deputy Speaker, Ajith Rajapakse at his office yesterday (31). The Auditor General has diligently worked to submit audit reports for more than 2,200 institutions, including ministries, departments, corporations, boards, authorities, statutory funds, non-statutory funds, foreign aid projects, provincial councils, local government agencies, State companies, and other institutions in 2022. Activities related to these tasks are detailed in this annual report. Further, several special audit reports were submitted to Parliament by the Auditor General in 2022. This report includes recommendations to enhance efficiency and effectiveness of these institutions. The Auditor General has submitted this annual report in keeping with Article 154(6) of the Constitution. Additionally, the draft annual report of the National Audit Office for 2024 was also handed over to Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse. Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Chaminda Kularatne, Director-Legislative Services H.E. Janakantha Silva, Auditor General W.P.C. Wickramaratne, Deputy Auditor General Nimal Thilakaratne, and Audit Superintendent N.N.K. Divakara were also present.

title: Maminiyawa Vidyalaya faces closure
author: Author not found
Content: Parents are expressing concern over the potential closure of Maminiyawa Vidyalaya in Maradankadawala, that comes under the Kekirawa Educational Zone. Established in 1937, Maminiyawa Vidyalaya has enjoyed a long-standing reputation as one of the most esteemed educational institutions in the region. Over the years, it has accommodated students up to the Ordinary Level with an enrolment of over 250 students throughout its history. Regrettably, the present scenario paints a bleak picture, with only 26 students currently attending the primary section and the majority of its infrastructure lies in disrepair. Sugath Gunaratne, a resident in Maradankadawala, said “Our school possesses a wealth of dedicated educators, including the principal, all of whom make significant sacrifices to sustain our institution. Nonetheless, the number of enrolled students continues to dwindle daily. Not too long ago, Maminiyawa Vidyalaya was the largest educational institution in the area, nurturing many individuals who have gone on to become engineers, doctors, and lawyers. Today, it stands as a mere primary school, with just 26 students, of which 10 are in the sixth grade, and a mere four in the first grade. It is evident that the school is teetering on the brink of closure. We implore the authorities to devise a strategy to get students from the catchment area to enrol and safeguard the school’s future.” Nilanthi Pushpakumari further said the school’s deteriorating condition has led to its present state, adding , “Our school lacks a secure fence, resulting in continuous vandalising of infrastructure. Staff rooms lie in ruin, rendering them unusable. Unsavoury incidents take place in the school buildings after school hours. The restrooms have fallen into disrepair, leaving only one toilet for both students and staff. Many structures have fallen into decay due to disuse. We  request the authorities to intervene and protect the school’s valuable resources, averting its closure.” It is clear that Maminiyawa Primary School, once a pillar of education in the region, is now at risk, and the voices of concerned parents and community members plea for urgent measures to preserve the institution’s legacy and continue providing quality education to local children. BY Krishnaka Sachin – Maradankadawala

title: Korea donates essential medical equipment to Teaching Hospital Kalutara
author: Author not found
Content: In a display of international goodwill, the Government of the Republic of Korea has donated crucial medical equipment valued at approximately LKR 8.83 million to the Teaching Hospital Kalutara. This donation is part of the Official Development Assistance (ODA) programme aimed at enhancing the healthcare infrastructure in Sri Lanka. The donation, coordinated by the Korean International Cooperation Agency (KOICA), includes two state-of-the-art Orthopaedic Power Drill Systems, one cutting-edge Micro Motor System for Dental and Oral-Maxillofacial (OMF) surgeries, and 20 Wall Oxygen and Medical Air Terminals. These essential medical devices will greatly bolster the hospital’s capabilities in providing quality healthcare services to the people of Kalutara and beyond. The donation ceremony was attended by esteemed dignitaries, including Miyon LEE, Ambassador of the Republic of Korea to Sri Lanka, and Myung Jin KIM, Country Director of KOICA Sri Lanka Office. Dr. Madhubashini Karunarathna, Director of Teaching Hospital Kalutara and other hospital authorities were also present at the event. Their collective presence underscored the significance of this contribution. Expressing her gratitude for this timely and vital donation, Dr. Karunarathna, the Hospital Director, highlighted the critical need for this medical equipment, which will significantly improve patient care and enhance the efficiency of surgical procedures at the hospital. The donation couldn’t have come at a more crucial time for the hospital, and heartfelt appreciation was extended to the Ambassador, and the people and Government of the Republic of Korea. The Republic of Korea has a long history of investing in the development of Sri Lanka’s healthcare system. This generous donation reflects their continued commitment to the well-being of the people of Sri Lanka and their dedication to furthering healthcare infrastructure in the country. The medical equipment provided is expected to make a substantial difference in the hospital’s capacity to provide quality healthcare services, ultimately benefiting the patients and the healthcare community of Kalutara. The donation of this cutting-edge medical equipment by the Government of the Republic of Korea is a testament to the strong bonds of friendship and cooperation between the two nations and their joint commitment to improving the health and well-being of the Sri Lankan people.

title: Lankans will hardly benefit from aid – TISL
author: Author not found
Content: “People will hardly benefit from the aid and assistance that Sri Lanka receives as long as corruption persists,” stated Nadishani Perera, Executive Director of Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL). She was speaking during a discussion at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute in Colombo last week. The discussion focused on the recommendations outlined in ‘The Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report on Sri Lanka.’ The event drew a diverse group of civil society representatives who gathered to address the pressing need for governance reforms in the country. Perera emphasised the crucial importance of tackling corruption directly, stating, “No matter how much aid we receive, it will be squandered or misappropriated if we do not tackle corruption head-on. It’s akin to pouring water into a leaky vessel. While there’s much talk about revitalising the economy, there’s an alarming lack of focus on governance reforms and corruption prevention. The masses, who took to the streets in large numbers last year, demanded a ‘system change’ because they recognised that the country’s crisis was not solely economic but rooted in weak governance and deep-seated corruption.” She further explained, “Recognising the public’s heightened interest in anti-corruption, civil society organisations collectively worked on a Governance Diagnostic Report, highlighting a series of governance reforms essential for the nation. By advocating for these recommendations, we can bring about a real system change and ensure sustainable economic development.” ‘The Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report,’ unveiled on 13 September, presented 34 pivotal governance benchmark recommendations. This comprehensive report was a joint effort by ‘The Civil Society Initiative on Anti-Corruption Reform for Economic Recovery,’ led by Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL), in collaboration with a core group including Verité Research, the Centre for Policy Alternatives (CPA), Sarvodaya Shramadana Movement, People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL), and the National Peace Council (NPC). The recent meeting aimed to raise awareness among civil society members about the recommendations in the report. As part of the discussion, civil society recommendations were compared with those made in the International Monetary Fund’s (IMF) recently issued report titled ‘Sri Lanka: Technical Assistance Report-Governance Diagnostic Assessment.’ Dr. Nishan de Mel, Executive Director of Verité Research, stressed the importance of good governance, citing historical data dating back to 1975. He pointed out that countries with multiple episodes of debt restructuring often scored lower in governance assessments. “Without addressing Sri Lanka’s governance issues, our efforts to rebuild the economy are akin to building a house without a solid foundation. Enhancing transparency and minimising discretionary powers are imperative for improving Sri Lanka’s governance indicators,” he underscored. He further warned, “Being content with temporary solutions is a costly mistake we’ve made repeatedly. The future of Sri Lanka now teeters on a precipice, with governance playing a pivotal role in determining whether we tread the right path or venture into dangerous territory.” Sankhitha Gunaratne, Deputy Executive Director of TISL, stressed the urgency of implementing the proposed governance reforms in their entirety and without delay. She pointed out that key measures, such as introducing new legislation for asset recovery and procurement, establishing a ‘Beneficial Ownership Registry,’ and making the asset declarations of high-ranking public officials accessible to the public, are emphasised in both reports. Professor Arjuna Parakrama, the researcher behind the Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report, emphasised that these recommendations hold significance not only from an economic perspective but also in ensuring justice and fair play for the masses. The discussion also saw active participation from leaders of various organisations, including Rohana Hettiarachchi, Executive Director of PAFFREL; Dr. Vinya Ariyaratne, President of Sarvodaya Shramadana Movement; Dr. Jehan Perera, Executive Director of the National Peace Council; Dr. Paikiasothy Saravanamuttu, Executive Director of CPA; and Lasanthika Hettiarachchi, Advocacy and Research Manager at TISL. The governance reforms proposed in the 34 recommendations, derived from extensive islandwide consultation with grassroots citizens and experts alike, garnered overwhelming support from the civil society representatives who attended the discussion.

title: Thondaman remembered
author: Author not found
Content: The 24th Death Anniversary of Senior Saumyamoorthy Thondaman, the Founder of the Ceylon Workers Congress, was commemorated on Monday (30). His statue, at the old Parliament, was garlanded by many of his family members. CWC General Secretary, Jeevan Thondaman, along with several officials from the CWC attended the event. A special pooja was also held at Saumya Bhavan to pay tribute to his memory.

title: Small businesses, tourism operators hail USAID-SLTDA Learning Expo in Galle
author: Author not found
Content: Small business operators in the tourism industry hailed the Sustainable Niche Tourism Learning Expo conducted by United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) in Galle last Tuesday, 24 October. “This is a great initiative and a very informative programme which helped us enhance our knowledge on a wide range of topics,” said one participant who owns a small hotel. “We are relatively new entrants to the tourism industry, and I realised today that there are many more aspects to sustain our business than merely focusing on filling our hotel rooms. It was a very enriching experience,” he added. The event attracted over 100 small businesses and allied stakeholders and was the second in a series of similar events to be held across the country. The first event was held in Colombo in September. Small tourism businesses learned about digital marketing, travel trends and how to incorporate sustainability into their daily operations. Participants also had access to mentoring sessions with industry trailblazers and received toolkits focused on product development, marketing, promotions and sustainability. The Learning Expo was a direct follow-on of the launch of 12 new niche tourism categories in June this year, to enhance the competitiveness of small businesses and allow Sri Lanka to better establish its brand identity, increase its appeal and market share, create jobs and opportunities across the tourism sector, and generate much-needed foreign exchange. A wide variety of vendors showcased products that small businesses can use to enhance their services and incorporate sustainability into their supply chains. Sri Lanka’s diverse tourism offerings hold immense potential for small businesses to cater to the demands of both international and domestic travellers. To establish a thriving tourism sector, it is vital to empower small business owners to innovate, refine their products, and deliver sustainable guest experiences aligned with traveller expectations. Tourism is critical to Sri Lanka’s economy as it exits the pandemic and deals with its internal economic crisis.  Pre-pandemic tourism represented 12 per cent of the country’s GDP, generating USD 4.3 billion in revenue in 2018 and providing employment for three million people.  Sri Lanka is currently experiencing an encouraging resurgence in tourist arrivals and celebrated the landmark achievement of welcoming its one millionth visitor for 2023, in the last week of September, easily surpassing the figure of 720,000 recorded for the whole of 2022. Already popular as a tourism destination for its natural beauty and cultural heritage, in June this year, Sri Lanka repositioned its tourism offering with the launch of 12 new niche tourism categories – from adventure tourism and cultural experiences to hosted/curated experiences and wellness and healing – offering differentiated experiences for travellers seeking an immersive holiday. “I wish to thank USAID and SLTDA for conducting this very informative event which was a real eye-opener to most of us. We have been used to viewing tourism in a very old fashioned way that we have used for generations; today’s event showcased many exciting new approaches which will help us to better market our country and attract more tourists,” said Channa Saliya Mendis, Chairman of Southern Province Tourism Bureau. Niche tourism allows a destination to provide more inclusive opportunities for women, minority communities, and other disadvantaged groups by creating opportunities for them to participate in their own unique way. USAID launched the tourism activity under the Indo Pacific Opportunity Project (IPOP) in July 2022 to support economic reforms and promote foreign direct investment in Sri Lanka.  The two-year project is assisting SLTDA to streamline and implement new policies and procedures to enable fast-tracking and attraction of foreign direct investment in the tourism sector. The learning expo is yet another positive step taken by IPOP to boost Sri Lanka’s tourism industry and its economic recovery.

title: Côte d’Ivoire President Ouattara applauds President Wickremesinghe
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador Kananathan held an impactful meeting with Alassane Ouattara, the President of the Republic of Côte d’Ivoire, at the Presidential Palace in Abidjan on 26 October, marking a significant step towards enhancing the bilateral relations and fostering cooperation between Sri Lanka and Côte d’Ivoire. President Ouattara who graciously received the Ambassador expressed his commitment to strengthening the ties between the two countries. He emphasised that this is a positive development in diplomatic relations between the two countries and a promising sign of strengthened ties. Ambassador Kananathan reiterated Sri Lanka’s eagerness to further engage with Côte d’Ivoire to realise the full potential of their relationship. At the outset, President Ouattara who is an economist and previously worked for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) expressed commendation for the swift and timely effective actions taken by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to stabilise the Sri Lankan economy. Similarly, President Ouattara mentioned to Ambassador Kananathan that he was in charge of the Sri Lanka Portfolio at IMF, a few decades ago. Ambassador Kananathan and President  Ouattara reviewed the current state of bilateral relations and expressed their commitment to expanding cooperation in various sectors such as; Trade and Agriculture. Both acknowledged the potential for mutual benefit in these areas, recognising the need to explore new avenues for collaboration and to create opportunities for their respective business communities. Key points discussed during the meeting included;  Bilateral Relations, Strengthening Economic and Trade Ties and the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), and Trade Opportunities to support Sri Lankan Businessmen to start operations in  Côte d’Ivoire.  President  Ouattara highlighted the benefits of AGOA and encouraged Ambassador Kananathan to invite Sri Lankan businessmen in the textile and Garment sectors to explore the advantages of AGOA. AGOA offers Sri Lankan entrepreneurs to set up operations in  Côte d’Ivoire, an opportunity to export garments into the United States tariff-free, presenting significant potential for Sri Lankan Businesses to expand their presence in the American market. Côte d’Ivoire is the world’s top exporter of cocoa beans, and raw cashew nuts, a net exporter of oil and a significant manufacturing sector; and is the largest economy in the West African Economic and Monetary Union. Kananathan expressed gratitude to President Ouattara and his government for their support to Sri Lanka, in international forums. Cote d’Ivoire is also set to host the 2023 Africa Cup of Nations in Football, scheduled to take place from 13 January to 11 February 2024, featuring participation from 24 African countries.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Interpol cracks down on illicit medicines worldwide
author: Author not found
Content: Interpol’s Operation Pangea XVI which ran from 3-10 October 2023 has led to 72 arrests worldwide with the seizure of potentially dangerous pharmaceuticals worth more than USD 7 million, 325 new investigations and the closure of more than 1,300 criminal websites. Interpol said erectile dysfunction medications continue to be the most seized medicine globally, accounting for 22 per cent of seizures during the operation. Psychotherapeutic agents such as antidepressants, anti-anxiety medicines and stimulants were a close second at 19 per cent, followed by sex hormones and gastrointestinal medicines at 12 per cent respectively. Interpol said the additional seizures included, in Mozambique, authorities seized 9,000 bottles of suspected counterfeit cough syrups, after discovering contradictions between product labels and official documents. Australian authorities seized some 11,000 Covid-19 irregular test kits, demonstrating continued criminal exploitation of the pandemic. Customs officers in Qatar seized 2,500 prescription painkillers hidden in cereal boxes, from a passenger flying in from Bangladesh. Some 13,000 counterfeit and/or expired pain medicines were confiscated during searches at a bus depot between Peru and Ecuador. Secretary General of INTERPOL, Jürgen Stocksaid, “Counterfeit medicines and the misuse of regulated medication is a significant threat to public safety around the world. Operation Pangea XVI removed a large amount of illegal and potentially life-threatening products off the streets and dismantled criminal networks trafficking such goods.  “The operation underlines the continuing need for a coordinated and global response against the threat posed by illicit medicines and transnational organised crime groups.” Interpol had additional support from Europol, the World Customs Organisation, the World Health Organisation, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, the International Narcotics Control Board, national health regulatory agencies and the Pharmaceutical Security Institute in the raid. The annual campaign targets illicit medicines that pose a significant threat to consumer safety, including counterfeit medicines and medicines diverted from legal and regulated supply chains. They also represent a major source of income for transnational organised crime groups and support other crime activity. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sri Lanka studying China’s’ proposed IOMed initiative
author: Author not found
Content: Regarding China’s International Organisation for Mediation (IOMed) initiative, with the aim of resolving disputes between States and commercial entities, the Cabinet yesterday (31 October) said that Sri Lanka had also participated in some of the initial conversations. In July 2022, the preliminary joint statement for the establishment of the proposed IOMed organisation had been issued and about 10 countries, including China had endorsed the joint declaration. Sri Lanka has sought observations from other government agencies, including the Ministry of Justice and the Attorney General’s Department, regarding the approval of the said Joint Statement on the Establishment of the International Organisation for Arbitration and it has been observed that the signing of the Joint statement will not affect any of the international obligations currently undertaken by Sri Lanka. Accordingly the Cabinet of Ministers approved the Proposal presented by the Minister of Foreign Affairs to approve the Joint Statement on the Establishment of the International Organisation for Mediation. In February 2023 China established a Preparatory Office of the International Organisation for Mediation (IOMed) in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) to carry out inter-governmental negotiations over international conventions about the organisation. China said the IOMed will be the world’s first intergovernmental legal organisation dedicated to the settlement of international disputes through mediation. At the inauguration of the IOMed, China’s Foreign Minister Qin Gang said some countries, with their wanton practices of unilateralism and power politics, are going against the trend of history and eroding the international rule of law. In this  backdrop, he said, it is more imperative for China to firmly uphold the international system with the United Nations (UN) at its core, the international order underpinned by international law, and the basic norms of international relations based on the purposes and principles of the UN Charter. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Rs 20,000 fine for setting fire to forest reserve
author: Author not found
Content: Walapane Magistrate S. S. Wickremaratne imposed a fine of Rs 20,000 on a suspect who pleaded guilty to setting fire to the Warakalawita forest reserve, which is also a catchment area near the Pidurutalagala Conservation Forest in Nuwara Eliya. The suspect was identified as a resident of Wimalpura, Rikillagaskada. Halgranoya Beetu Forest Officer Shantha Pushpakumara told Court that as a result of the fire, an area spanning three hectares, with invaluable fauna and flora was destroyed and many wild animals were also displaced. BY Chandrasiri Mahagama  – Nuwara Eliya

title: Appointments to key NMRA positions temporarily suspended
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Minister temporarily suspended awarding the letters of appointment, to several key positions in the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), which had been scheduled for 9.30 a.m. yesterday (30), owing to allegations levelled against those, including a renowned clinician, who were to receive appointments in the Authority.    According to the health service sources, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana had been compelled to temporarily put off the scheduled programme despite the letters of appointment being prepared. Sources alleged that an appointment was to be given to a particular clinician who had been an NMRA Board member at the time that the data scam took place. In an audit carried out, until December 2022, there were issues in which there were nine cases of serious fraudulent pharmaceutical transactions.  However, President of the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF), Dr. Rukshan Bellana said that the new Health Minister Dr. Pathirana should be considered weak if he further delayed taking preliminary action in removing all those responsible for the corruption and fraud in the NMRA. Dr. Bellana said that the new Minister should not allow himself to be intimidated by the drug mafia who were allegedly protecting the incumbent Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and the Chairman of the NMRA. The situation is such that the medicinal drug mafia would use social media and go to any length to ensure that the persons who take over were also prepared to tow their line so much so that they have been lobbying against any move by the Health Minister to remove the incumbent CEO and the Chairman of the NMRA, he alleged.   Although some trade unions who are against the appointments the Minister was to make yesterday (30) the fact remains that an ideal person or persons cannot be found, he said adding that if at all the particular clinician, who was to be appointed, only had his role in the ‘Aragalaya’ to his alleged discredit. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Landslide warning alerts extended
author: Author not found
Content: As adverse weather conditions continue over most parts of the country, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has extended the various levels of landslide early warning alerts that were issued to 54 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and their surrounding areas across, nine districts in the country. Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist of the Landslides Early Warning Centre of NBRO, stated that the districts affected include Ratnapura, Colombo, Badulla, Galle, Hambantota, Kalutara, Kandy, Kurunegala, and Matara. Dr. Senadeera explained that level two amber ‘watch’landslide early warning alerts have been issued for the Imbulpe, Godakawela, Kolonna, Eheliyagoda, Kalawana, Ratnapura, Elapatha, Openayake, Weligepola, Balangoda and Kuruwita DS divisions, as well as their surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. Additionally, level one yellow ‘watch’ landslide early warning alerts have been issued for the Haputale and Haldummulla DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Badulla District, Seethawaka DS Division and its surrounding areas in the Colombo District and the Thawalama, Nagoda, Yakkalamulla, Niyagama, Baddegama, Elpitiya, Galle, Four Gravets, Akmeemana, Ambalangoda, Bope Poddala, Neluwa, and Imaduwa DS divisions, along with their surrounding areas in the Galle District. These alerts will remain in effect until further notice. Dr. Senadeera mentioned that the same landslide early warning level alerts continue for the Okewela, Walasmulla, Beliatta, and Katuwana DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Hambantota District, Ingiriya, and Walallawita DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Ududumbara and Thumpane DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Kandy District, Rideegama DS Division and its surrounding areas in the Kurunegala District, Athuraliya, Pasgoda, Hakmana, Pitabeddara, Matara, Four Gravets, Thihagoda, Malimbada, Kamburupitiya, Mulatiyana, Welipitiya, and Kirinda DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Matara District, and Ayagama, Nivithigala, Pelmadulla, Kahawatta, and Kiriella DS divisions, along with their surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. These alerts will also remain in effect until further notice. Dr. Senadeera added that depending on the rainfall in particular areas within the landslide-prone regions of the Central Hill, more areas may be declared as landslide-prone or existing areas may be removed from the list. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: ‘Aswasuma Week’ to resolve issues affecting programme
author: Author not found
Content: In an effort to streamline the Aswasuma welfare programme and address ongoing concerns, the Ministry of Finance has announced the implementation of an ‘Aswasuma Week’ from 6 – 11 November. The objective of this initiative is to promptly resolve the issues affecting the programme and ensure that deserving beneficiaries receive their entitled support without further delay. State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe, stated that this initiative aims to provide immediate support to families who have not yet received their entitled benefits. Furthermore, it extends support to those selected as relief beneficiaries and those whose benefits have been delayed due to technical complications. During a press conference held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (30) Semasinghe, unveiled the upcoming ‘Aswasuma Week’ and elaborated on its core goals. He emphasised that ‘Aswasuma Week’ will facilitate the swift distribution of benefits to families who have encountered difficulties in receiving their entitled assistance. This includes both families who have not yet received any benefits and those who have experienced delays due to technical issues. Moreover, the State Minister confirmed that various government departments, including the Presidential Secretariat, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Public Administration, and Divisional Secretariats, are dedicated to resolving issues faced by relief beneficiaries during this designated week. In addition to the forthcoming resolution of existing issues, the State Minister announced that all payments for the month of July have been successfully distributed to beneficiaries, with payments for August set to commence from the coming Wednesday. Semasinghe reiterated that ‘Aswasuma Week’ should not be mistaken for a call for applications for the upcoming year. Instead, it is an initiative aimed at addressing unresolved issues from the current year’s application submissions. The Welfare Board is collaborating with Divisional Secretariats to ensure that beneficiaries are informed about the progress made. The State Minister of Finance also provided a financial outlook, indicating that Rs 8.5 billion will be distributed to 1,365,000 beneficiaries within the next two days, enabling beneficiaries to access their funds starting from 1 November. Subsequently, payments for the month of September are expected to be completed before the end of the following month. The State Minister acknowledged that while there haven’t been financial issues, technical complications, such as problems with bank accounts, have posed challenges. Nevertheless, the government is determined to resolve these technical issues promptly to expedite payments. Semasinghe recognised the profound impact of the economic downturn on vulnerable populations and assured that the government is committed to mitigating their hardships. He emphasised the government’s commitment to accelerating the distribution of financial aid, with the goal of finalising payments for July through December by the end of the year. Additionally, the government plans to broaden its focus to address various other aspects when inviting applications. In conclusion, Semasinghe acknowledged the less popular economic decisions taken by President Ranil Wickremesinghe and the government and highlighted their vital role in achieving economic stability. He emphasised that the government’s efforts extend to benefiting both government employees and the general public, ultimately fostering a robust and resilient national economy.

title: Trains cancelled due to shortage of guards
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Railways has reported that a number of office trains, scheduled for last evening (30), were cancelled due to a shortage of railway guards. The department made this announcement as several railway guards had failed to report for duty since morning. As a result of this situation, a total of 12 trains, including office trains, initially scheduled for morning and evening operations, had been cancelled yesterday (30), according to the Department of Railways. Meanwhile, train services on the up-country line were interrupted due to a derailment that occurred yesterday (30) afternoon. A commuter train travelling from Badulla to Colombo derailed between the Kinigama and Heel Oya railway stations at approximately 11.45 a.m. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Two officers suspended over missing paddy stocks
author: Author not found
Content: The Chairman of the Paddy Marketing Board (PMB) revealed that approximately 700,000 kg of paddy, with an estimated value of Rs 65-70 million, had gone missing from two State-owned paddy storage facilities in Kurunegala. In addition to this revelation, he said that two officers have been suspended pending an investigation into their involvement in the incident. Last week, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera requested a report regarding the alleged disappearance of paddy stocks from five State-owned paddy storage facilities in the Kurunegala District. Amaraweera instructed the PMB to provide this report within three days following several complaints from Paddy Marketing Board employees. They informed the minister that individuals from the PMB’s head office and some regional offices were involved in the disappearance of the paddy stocks. Furthermore, the Minister emphasised that a thorough inquiry into this matter would be conducted with the assistance of the Police and the CID. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Pay hike through Budget for Public sector
author: Author not found
Content: The government will take necessary steps to increase salaries of the public sector employees through the forthcoming Budget 2024, a top government official said. President Ranil Wickremesinghe has also announced this salary increase to the Cabinet of Ministers when they met yesterday. President Wickremesinghe further said that along with the increase in the salaries of the government employees, there will be a request to increase the salaries of the private sector employees as well. The President further said that it was a policy decision of the Government  to increase the salaries of the working community to be on par with the prices of goods are increasing day-by-day and with no decline to be seen in the near future. President Wickremesinghe’s third Budget is scheduled to be presented in Parliament on 13 November. This is the first time the government officially announced there will be a salary increase through the Budget. “The President also insisted that this has nothing to do with the JVP and other groups agitating for a salary increase, even though they are trying to capitalise on it by projecting this increase was a result of their demands,” the official further noted. Meanwhile, several public sector trade unions opted for trade union action, including walk-outs and token strikes yesterday and in the recent past demanding the government to increase salaries and reduce taxes. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: Suspended JMO Haq seeks reinstatement
author: Author not found
Content: Consultant Judicial Medical Officer, Dr. Ruhul Haq, who is currently on suspension, for defying an eight-month suspension imposed by the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) in December last year, has written to the College of Forensic Pathologists of Sri Lanka (CFPSL) urging them to inform the Council to expedite and resolve the process of reinstating him. SLMC sources said, when contacted yesterday (30), that a decision with regard to his suspension would be taken when the Professional Conduct Committee (PCC) of the SLMC meets on 4 November 2023. They noted that currently the JMO had been asked to refrain from conducting the duties of his office. A decision with regard to the suspension would be taken on Saturday (4).    Dr. Haq was also criticised for his contradictory post-mortem reports issued in deaths of Dinesh Schaffter and the three-year-old child who died following kidney surgery at Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH). However, his suspension order came when the SLMC gave Dr. Haq (SLMC Registration 15168) an eight- month suspension with effect from 20 December 2022, following an inquiry into a complaint made by S.A. Rathnasena. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Police instructed to seek AG’s advice
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (30) instructed the Cinnamon Gardens Police, to seek advice from Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, regarding further action to be taken against 15 suspects, including former UNP MP Hirunika Premachandra and to produce submissions to him accordingly. Premachandra and former Provincial Councillor Nirosha Athukorala have been charged in Court, for having flouted Provisions contained in Sections of the National Thoroughfares Act and for having hindered the Police from performing their duty. The Chief Magistrate stated that though the prosecution had complained that due to a protest march organised by the suspects, on 14 November last year, Police had been obstructed from carrying out their duties, the prosecution at the same time had failed to submit sufficient evidence, to substantiate their allegations against the suspects. The Defence Counsel stated that the protesters, had only displayed banners and placards, imploring the Government to initiate action, to alleviate the sufferings of women, brought about by the country’s economic woes. He charged that the Police, had strived in vain, to paint the actions resorted to by his clients, as that of a heinous crime. Having perused the submissions, produced by both the Prosecution and the Defence, the Court delivered the aforementioned instructions to the Police. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Court orders seized heroin be sent to GA
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis instructed the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) yesterday (30) to send the seized 219 kg of heroin, which was recently confiscated off the southern coast, to the Government Analyst. The heroin was seized during a joint operation conducted by the Navy Intelligence and the PNB. The Magistrate further directed the PNB obtain the Government Analyst’s report as soon as possible. Six suspects, residents of Kapugama, Devinuwara, and Gandara, were arrested in connection with the heroin haul. They were transporting the drugs oin a multi-day fishing trawler and were detained by the PNB for questioning. These suspects were produced in Court yesterday (30), ordered to be detained until 14 November. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Tharunyata Hetak still to settle Rs 1.2M owed to CEB since 2014 – Jayalal
author: Author not found
Content: Convener of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) Joint Trade Unions Alliance Ranjan Jayalal alleged that a sum of Rs 1.2 million, owed for electricity generators, obtained from the CEB for the Hambantota District Poson Zone in 2014, organized by the Tharunyata Hetak organisation has not been paid up to date. According to the letter WAS/PP/TCN/01 dated 29 May 2014, Rs 1.5 million (Rs 1,522,889.14) had been estimated for the service and the organisasion had paid Rs 400,000 as an advance. Accordingly, the CEB had, on 25 March 2019 sent a letter, requesting settlement of the balance. Prior to that, Jayalal alleged, the CEB’s legal officer had sent a Letter of Demand (LOoD) to the Tharunyayata Hetak Foundation on 31 May 2018 regarding the non-payment of the outstanding amount to the CEB. Through the LoD, the CEB legal officer warned the organisasion that failure to make the payment within a 14-day period would lead to legal action. However, Jayalal accused Tharunyayata Hetak organisasion of not having made the payment to the CEB so far. BY Anuradha Herath

title: Sri Lankans want a JJB-led Govt – Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), Anura Kumara Dissanayake, recently said there is a new type of Sri Lankans, who are unafraid to hold their elected representatives accountable, unlike the people who used to fear their rulers in the past.This statement was delivered by Dissanayake in a speech last Saturday (28) during an event organised in Los Angeles, USA. Dissanayake went on to say that historically, the governance of Sri Lanka has oscillated between the two main parties, the UNP and the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), and their respective alliances. In the past, people typically elected only a handful of JJB representatives to serve as legislative gatekeepers. According to Dissanayake, these representatives were never chosen to lead the government or even to function as the opposition party. Dissanayake claimed that due to significant changes in the country’s political landscape, the current Sri Lankan citizen has evolved and now expects a government led by the JJB. To facilitate this change, Dissanayake emphasised the importance of the current government in Sri Lanka ensuring that elections are held on schedule without delays. Addressing the Sri Lankan expatriate community, Dissanayake stressed on their vital role in making the aspirations of the Sri Lankan people, who desire this change a reality. He mentioned that if the JJB is to come to power at the upcoming election, an ideological struggle (Aragalaya) must be conducted to change the hearts and minds of the people. To achieve this, Dissanayake urged expatriates to utilise social media to influence the thinking of the Sri Lankan voter base. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Ex-SDIG refused bail
author: Author not found
Content: Mount Lavinia Additional Magistrate Sanjaya L.M. Wijesinghe rejected the bail request, submitted by former Senior DIG Ravi Seneviratne, who had been remanded for driving under the influence of alcohol and causing damage to two other vehicles. Seneviratne had filed the bail application using a special procedure. The retired SDIG had been apprehended by the Wellawatta Police after causing damage to two vehicles parked in front of a hotel on Muhudu Mawatha in Wellawatta around 1:20 a.m. on Sunday (20). A breathalyzer test confirmed that he was intoxicated at the time of the accident.

title: HEPAMC to take legal action
author: Author not found
Content: During the Hanthana Environmental Protection Area Management Committee (HEPAMC) Meeting, a unanimous decision had been taken to institute legal action against those who sell or lease plots of land thereby damaging the Hanthana mountain range. The committee had received several complaints that some persons had either sold or leased plots of land damaging the bio diversity and environment of the mountain range and without the requisite approval from the committee. Sources from the HEPAMC stated that for all new constructions adjacent to the mountain range, the due approval has to be sought from the committee but that to date no such measures had been undertaken prompting the HEPAMC to resort to legal action against wrongdoers. This decision had been taken during the committee meeting held yesterday (30) at the Kandy Divisional Secretariat helmed by Kandy District Secretary Chandana Tennakoon. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Budget 2024 includes concessions and relief
author: Author not found
Content: Former UNP MP Achala Jagoda claimed yesterday (30) that the budget for the year 2024 will include various concessions and relief packages targeting the average people in the country. Jagoda also endorsed the recommendations made by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, emphasising the importance of working together beyond party politics and maintaining a multi-democratic approach while preserving individual identities as the only solution to restore the country’s economy to normalcy as soon as possible. Despite the increase in the electricity bill being burdensome for the average person, consumers will need to bear it temporarily. In the meantime, the Government will implement new mechanisms and work towards reducing tariffs before the end of this year, Jagoda stated. During a media briefing at Sirikotha, Jagoda alleged that the JVP was attempting to create problems to further their political agenda by making false statements. He emphasised that President Wickremesinghe firmly believes that the country’s problems cannot be resolved simply by printing more currency notes. He also pointed out that the country’s economy is in the process of recovery, despite negative criticisms from various quarters and suggested that politics should not be played like a game. President Wickremesinghe has proven himself as a statesman on the global political stage, he added Jagoda concluded by saying that if the country follows President Wickremesinghe’s guidance, positive results can be expected in a short period. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Eight girls run away from children’s home
author: Author not found
Content: Eight girls, who had been residing at a Children’s Home, operated by a voluntary organisation at Meetiyagoda, had fled in the night of 28 October, the Galle District Probation and Child Care Service Office said. The officials said it was reported that a feud had erupted between the female head of the Children’s Home and the eight resident girls prompting them to flee the premises. After the girls had fled the centre, its head had lodged a complaint with the Meetiyagoda Police who then managed to locate three of the girls during that night itself after which the five remaining girls had arrived at the Police station yesterday (30). The girls are residents of Bentota, Hikkaduwa, Batapola, Elpitiya and Neluwa. Already, 21 girls who had been directed by the Judiciary and the Child Probation Office in Colombo, are put up at the Children’s Home. BY Farhan Nizamdeen –Galle

title: Ampara Police WHWS gift house to needy family
author: Author not found
Content: The War Heroes’ Welfare Society (WHWS) of the Ampara Police, together with the contribution from the people of the area, constructed a new house for a destitute family in the Ampara Police Division. The house which was built within three months was presented to this family on 23 October by the Senior Superintendent of  Police (SSP) J.H.M.N Jayapathma of the Ampara Division.  The Assistant Superintendent of Police, Inspector Police of the Ampara Headquarters, Police officers attached to the Ampara Police Divisions and the residents of Ampara participated in the event.

title: Franche, Manusha discuss migrant workers
author: Author not found
Content: UN Resident Coordinator Marc-André Franche met Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara, at the latter’s Ministry yesterday (30). During the meeting, Minister Nanayakkara and the UN Resident Coordinator discussed the measures taken by the government to provide facilities for migrant workers. The Minister also explained the government’s plans to digitizse the entire foreign employment service centre in an effort to combat human trafficking. He also briefed Franche on the recently launched Sri Lanka National Policy and Action Plan on Migration for Employment (2023-2027), which received support from the International Labour Organisation. The Minister also informed Franche about the new Labour Bill and explained its new benefits. He pointed out that the Ministry conducts regular reviews of the progress in the key result areas set by the Ministry, which will help achieve the government’s goals. During the meeting, the Minister also noted that the ‘Garu Saru’ initiative, introduced by the Ministry of Labour and Foreign Employment, with the aim of providing better working conditions for employees in the informal sector, will be launched on the 1 November with the support of the International Labour Organisation.

title: Proposals made towards improving farmers lot – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries Mahinda Amaraweera says that proposals had been submitted towards the improvement of the farmers’ lot via the upcoming Budget. He stated he was therefore hopeful of a positive response from the farming community towards such proposals. The Minister made these comments while addressing the media, having attended an event held at Rajanganaya, in Anuradhapura.  Amaraweera mentioned that a request had been made to grant approval for Indian fishermen to indulge in fishing off Sri Lankan waters. He said that despite such a request being made, the Government was yet undecided on whether to approve it or not, as it needs to seriously consider several issues such as the impact on local fishermen and the adverse effect on the environment and the soil etc. He also added that, as the new Minister of Plantation Industries, he would be striving to sustain the country’s tea industry while at the same time looking to boost the earning capacity of estate sector workers. He maintained that there would not be worth in increasing the wages of the estate workers, if the tea industry crumbles at the same time. BY Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: Pavement hawking an obstacle to fire fighters – Chief Fire Officer
author: Author not found
Content: Kamal Wilson, the Chief Fire Officer of Colombo yesterday (29) said pavement hawking poses a significant obstacle to controlling sudden fires in buildings, especially in the Pettah. Furthermore, he noted that many buildings in Colombo were constructed without proper planning and structures that are 50-60 years old often lack fire prevention systems. Wilson emphasised the need for strict enforcement of the law against building owners who neglect safety measures, regardless of the awareness campaigns conducted. Additionally, the bustling traffic in the streets of Pettah further complicates their efforts, exacerbated by building owners neglecting proper fire safety measures. Wilson was raising concerns on the impediments faced by the fire brigade in responding to emergencies in the city, following the most recent fire in Pettah, in which more than 20 persons were hospitalised with severe burn injuries. Wilson pointed out that the recent fire threats in Colombo, were due to many old buildings lacking standard firefighting systems. Illegally conducted pavement trading obstructs the access of fire engines and emergency responders to the affected areas, creating a potentially hazardous situation. The careless placement of flammable objects on pavements was also highlighted as a fire risk, he added. In the event of a fire, if there is a lack of firefighting equipment or knowledge on how to use it, Wilson stressed the importance of informing those in the vicinity about the incident and evacuating the area promptly. Wilson raised concerns about spectators gathering to watch fires, hindering the fire brigade’s duties. He mentioned that some individuals approach fires to capture videos for social media, which can further complicate the situation. This influx of spectators can also disrupt ambulance and Police services. To address these challenges, Wilson suggested that the country’s legal framework related to fire prevention should be updated. He mentioned the development of an educational programme in collaboration with the Police to raise awareness about safety measures to prevent fires. BY Sachithra Perera

title: PHIs strike today, TUs gear for massive protest
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Health Inspectors’ Union (PHIU) yesterday (29) announced a two-day strike beginning today (30), to make a series of demands. The PHIU is scheduled to stage an island-wide strike today (30) and tomorrow (31). Simultaneously, various State sector and provincial public service trade unions are gearing up for an island-wide protest scheduled for noon today.

title: Heads to roll at NMRA
author: Author not found
Content: Major changes are in the offing at the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) today, Ceylon Todayreliably learns. Informed sources said on Sunday (29) that the changes were to be made among the NMRA’s top officials. Accordingly, numerous requests have been made to new Health Minister Ramesh Pathirana to cleanse the Authority of all corrupt officials, following the most recent controversy surrounding the Immunoglobulin IV scam, which was allegedly imported to Sri Lanka with forged documentation. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Three arrested for extortion attempt targeting Janaka
author: Author not found
Content: Three individuals were arrested on charges of attempting to extort money from Janaka Ratnayake, the former Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL). On Friday (28), the individuals, aged 24, 26, and 31, were taken into custody for allegedly demanding Rs 1.5 million from Ratnayake, the Police said. The suspects are residents of Rambukkana and Kurunegala. On 16 October Ratnayake lodged a complaint with the Kirulapone Police, alleging that he had received a threatening phone call from an individual who claimed to have been hired to assassinate him. This individual had demanded Rs 1.5 million to spare his life. Later, the investigations were transferred to the Colombo Crimes Division (CCD) on a directive of the Senior Deputy Inspector General (SDIG) in charge of the Western Province. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Jaffna Teaching Hospital hit by severe blood shortage
author: Author not found
Content: The Blood Bank of Teaching Hospital, Jaffna, informed that they are facing a severe shortage of all blood types. This shortage is significantly affecting the hospital’s ability to conduct scheduled surgeries, according to Blood Bank officials. Officials noted that the number of patients diagnosed with anaemia, cancer and those requiring transfusion of various blood groups is increasing. This rising demand for different blood groups is putting a strain on their resources. They emphasised that the hospital is seeing a continuous increase in the number of accident cases admitted or transferred from other hospitals for further treatment, all of whom require urgent blood. Additionally, the hospital requires a substantial quantity of blood from various groups to save lives. Despite the hospital’s urgent need for a substantial blood supply to be distributed to its wards, the number of blood donors remains at a low level, hospital sources said. Therefore, the hospital administration is appealing to well-wishers, blood donors, and organisations involved in social service to step forward and donate blood to safeguard the lives of those in need. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Cell phones found in high security Boossa Prison
author: Author not found
Content: In a sudden search conducted by the STF, in the high-security Boossa prison, where several organised criminals and drug traffickers, including Podi Lasi, are incarcerated, a number of mobile phones and related devices were seized. Two mobile phones, two SIM cards and two chargers with their outer covers were also found in the cells. The search was carried out for over an hour on 28 October in the cells of ‘A’ and ‘D’, where high-profile criminals, including Podi Lasi are detained. Information obtained by the STF indicates that the operation was carried out and the seized items will be sent to the CID for further scrutiny. The prison is under the purview of the Special Task Force and is located within a high-security zone, equipped with advanced technology, including CCTV camera systems. In the light of these security measures, it raises questions as to how these items found their way into the prison cells, a prison spokesperson said. Both the Prisons Department and the STF have initiated a thorough investigation to determine who utilised the mobile phones to make calls and how these phones found their way into the prison. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ongoing reforms long-overdue – Semasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe reassured that the Government’s decisions will not negatively impact the country’s economy. He emphasised that the ongoing reforms, in alignment with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) agreement, were long-overdue changes. Speaking at the North Central Province Outstanding Entrepreneurs Awards Night, held on Friday (27), the State Minister underlined that the current reforms being carried out by the Government should have been implemented decades ago. Acknowledging the additional burden placed on the people during the economic crisis, he said it is the responsibility of every individual, including policymakers, to support and sustain the ongoing economic recovery in Sri Lanka. Expanding on the IMF agreement, Semasinghe said countries such as India and South Korea experienced economic growth after receiving support from the IMF. He expressed confidence that Sri Lanka will also witness a robust economy once the reforms are fully implemented.

title: Tusker Agbo injured after being shot again
author: Author not found
Content: In a distressing turn of events, the tusker elephant, Agbo, who had previously recovered from gunshot injuries, has once again fallen victim in a shooting incident, according to wildlife authorities. M.J.C. Sooriyabandara, Director of the Department of Wildlife, disclosed that an unidentified individual had shot Agbo near the Wannammaduwa Tank in Tirappane. Swiftly responding to the dire situation, veterinary experts rushed to the location to administer much-needed medical care to the injured elephant. Agbo is a notable figure as one of the last remaining giant tuskers in the wilds of Sri Lanka. At nearly 40- year-old and towering at a height of approximately 10 feet, he roams freely in his natural habitat. This unfortunate incident follows Agbo’s recent brush with critical injury, caused by a gunshot from a trap gun just a few months ago. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Govt will import rice if prices soar – Nalin
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando issued a warning that the Government will import rice, if local vendors fail to comply with the Maximum Retail Price (MRP) set for rice. The Minister, making a special statement in response to a surge in rice prices in the market, asserted that local rice vendors have asserted their inability to adhere to the MRP, attributing the escalating rice prices to the rising cost of paddy. In response to the price hike, Minister Fernando has assured that, under his directives, regular inspections will be conducted throughout the country to ensure that the public is not burdened with increased prices. He further said if the inspections do not lead to stabilising rice prices, the authorities will be instructed to take steps to import rice.

title: Navy apprehends two with smuggled insecticides
author: Author not found
Content: During a search operation conducted in the sea areas of Karaitivu and Palliyawatta in Kalpitiya yesterday (29), the Navy apprehended two suspects with a stock of smuggled insecticides. SLNS Vijaya in the Northwestern Naval Command  n operation in the Karaitivu sea area by deploying Inshore Patrol Craft. In this operation, Naval personnel intercepted a suspicious dinghy in the sea area and apprehended two suspects with 15 sacks of smuggled insecticides. In a subsequent search operation carried out in the Palliyawatta sea area, an additional seven bags of smuggled insecticides, which had been left behind by racketeers, were discovered. It is suspected that the smugglers may have dumped them in response to the ongoing and persistent Naval operations. The suspects held in the operation are residents of Kalpitiya, aged between 43 and 46 years. Meanwhile, the suspect along with smuggled insecticides and the dinghy were handed over to the Katunayake Customs Preventive Office for legal action.

title: Former US Vice President withdraws from 2024 presidential race
author: Author not found
Content: Former US Vice President Mike Pence has withdrawn from the 2024 presidential race, saying “this is not my time”. He made the announcement at the Republican Jewish Coalition in Las Vegas on Saturday afternoon. “We always knew this would be an uphill battle, but I have no regrets,” he wrote in a statement. Pence is the first major Republican candidate to suspend his campaign in a race led by former President Donald Trump. Pence had languished in recent polls and had struggled to gain the support of Republican voters. The former vice president’s campaign had also racked up large amounts of debt, with Mr Pence ending September owing $621,000 (£512,038) and having only US$1.2m (£989,446) in the bank – significantly less than other Republican rivals. “I am leaving this campaign, but I will never leave the fight for conservative values,” he wrote in a statement addressed to his supporters.                                 (BBC)

author: Author not found
