BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SLN arrests 37 Indian fishers, seizes five trawlers
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) seized five Indian trawlers found poaching off Mannar and Delft Island, Jaffna, in two days, to yesterday (29), the SLN said adding that 37 fishermen, who were on those trawlers, were taken into custody. Three of the five poaching trawlers, together with 23 Indian fishers were seized off the coast of Mannar and the rest off Delft Island. The apprehended Indian fishermen and the trawlers were taken to the Talaimannar Pier and Kankasanthurai harbour from where they were to be handed over to the Talaimannar and Jaffna Fisheries Inspectors for onward legal action, SLN said. SLN in the calendar year to date has seized 27 Indian trawlers and apprehended 174 Indian fishermen. Meanwhile, the SLN detected 3,404 Indian fisher boats poaching in Sri Lanka’s territorial waters last year alone, down 63.12 per cent (5,827), from the 9,231 Indian poaching vessels detected in the previous year (2021), data on SLN’s 2022 Performance Report released on the Parliamentary website  last  month (recently) showed .  However, of this number (3,404), only 36 Indian fishing vessels, equivalent to only 1.06 per cent of the total Indian fisher vessels detected (3,404), together with a total of 264 Indian fishermen found on these 36 boats, were arrested by the SLN last year, statistics further showed. Meanwhile, in the previous year 2021, Sri Lanka apprehended 19 Indian vessels, whilst having had taken into custody 264 Indian poachers that year, data further showed. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Fmr SDIG remanded for drunk driving
author: Author not found
Content: Former CID Chief, Senior DIG (Rtd) Ravi Seneviratne was remanded till 1 November by the Mt. Lavinia Magistrate’s Court for causing a multiple vehicle accident whilst driving under the influence of liquor. Seneviratne was arrested by the Wellawatta Police early on Sunday (29) after causing the accident on the Marine Drive, Colombo. Sources told Ceylon Today that SDIG Seneviratne, who was driving at a speed exceeding the prescribed limit, collided with a Wagon R at around 1:30 a.m., subsequently causing it to collide with a tourist bus. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Arrested for stealing van he sold
author: Author not found
Content: In a comical turn of events, a person had stolen a vehicle valued at around Rs 1.8 million, two months after selling it, Athurugiriya Police said. The arrested individual is a 52-year-old resident of the Belihul Oya area. A few months earlier, this individual had sold his van to a private bus owner in Horahena, Athurugiriya, for Rs 1.8 million. However, his greed got the better of him, prompting him to devise a plan to reclaim the van. He arrived on a motorcycle in Horahena, where the bus owner resided. He discreetly parked the motorcycle on a side road, entered the businessman’s house and made off with the van. Upon waking up the next morning, the bus owner discovered that the van was missing. He promptly reported the incident to the Athurugiriya Police, who launched an investigation and CCTV cameras installed around the house were examined. Based on their findings, the Police anticipated that the suspect might return to retrieve the hidden motorcycle. Consequently, they apprehended the culprit when he attempted to reclaim the motorcycle while the they were monitoring the area. Following information obtained from the suspect, the stolen van was located concealed in an abandoned garden in the Belihul Oya. BY Inoka Udayangani – Battaramulla

title: SLPA to felicitate ten veterans at its 68th Anniversary Convention
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Press Association (SLPA) will celebrate its 68th anniversary convention on Wednesday, 1 November at the BMICH from 3.00 p.m. The SLPA, the pioneer and the oldest journalist union in Sri Lanka, during its annual convention will felicitate ten veterans, who have rendered a yeoman service to the country. Foreign delegates including representatives of the Indian Federation of Working Journalists (IFWJ) will grace the event. The SLPA was formed by Ven. Udakendawala Siri Saranankara Thera on 9 October 1955 as the Ceylon Branch of IOJ (International Organisation of Journalists) and was later renamed as Ceylon Press Association by the stalwarts D. F. Kariyakarawana and Hema de Silva in 1957. The association attracted media giants at that time including D.B. Dhanapala, Piyasena Nissanka, Mervyn de Silva, Meemana Premathilake , U. L. D. Chandrathilake, Newton Seneviratne, Evans Cooray, Lakshman Jayawardene, Sivanesa Chelvam, B. H.S. Jayawardene, Eamon Kariyakarawana, David Raju, J. B. Dissanayake, Srimal Fonseka and a host of others.

title: Law should be equal by all – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (29) that those who undermine  reconciliationwill face legal consequences. He said the law applies to all persons and must be upheld equally, regardless of one’s social status. Wrongdoers should be held accountable under the law, irrespective of their standing in society. “I have confidence that President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena will take the necessary steps to provide equal rights to every citizen in the country, transcending ethical or territorial boundaries. Minister Devananda also said that the aspirations and hopes of the Tamil people can only be achieved through a constructive approach and meaningful dialogue with key decision-makers. He expressed his belief that staging protests or criticising the Government for narrow political gain would not lead to any positive outcomes, but rather complicate the process of finding a sustainable solution to the issues faced by the Tamil people. Devananda further pointed out that alongside the challenges faced by the Tamil people, there is a growing trend of religious-based issues in the Northern and Eastern provinces. Failure to address these problems could result in ethnic conflict. Despite numerous recommendations made by President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunge to find a lasting solution to the issues of the Tamil people, Devananda lamented that the Tamil National Alliance has made little progress in resolving these long-standing issues. He also observed that the Tamil people were overconfident that struggles alone could bring about change. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Two held with Rs 41M in Kerala cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons were arrested in possession of 104kg of Kerala cannabis, during a search operation conducted by the Navy in the coastal vicinity of Vaddukoddai, Jaffna yesterday (29). A  three-wheeler was also seized.  SLNS Uththara and SLNS Agbo Naval establishments in the Northwestern Naval Command conducted the search operation on a road in the coastal vicinity of Vaddukoddai. Naval personnel seized about 104kg of Kerala cannabis being transported in a three-wheeler, which was intercepted on suspicion. The stock of Kerala cannabis was in 50 parcels and packed in three sacks.  Meanwhile, the street value of the Kerala cannabis is believed to be over Rs 41 million.      The suspects were residents of Madagal and Kilinochchi and were aged 25 and 40. The suspects along with Kerala cannabis and the three-wheeler were handed over to the Vaddukoddai Police for onward legal action.

title: Landslide early warning alerts extended
author: Author not found
Content: As adverse weather conditions continue to persist across most parts of the country, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) extended landslide early warning alerts to various districts across the country, for an additional 24 hours, starting from 3.00 p.m. yesterday (29) until 3.00 p.m. today (30) Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist of the Landslides Early Warning Centre of NBRO, announced yesterday that level two amber – watch landslide early warning alerts issued for the Walasmulla and Hambantota DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Hambantota District, as well as Weligepola, Kalawana, Eheliyagoda, Openayake, Kolonna, Godakawela, Elapatha, Kuruwita, Balangoda, Ratnapura, and Imbulpe DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, would remain in effect for the next 24 hours. Dr. Senadeera also noted that level one yellow – watch landslide early warning alerts issued for Haputale and Haldummulla DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Badulla District, Galle Four Gravets, Thawalama, Bope Poddala, Niyagama, Ambalangoda, Akmeemana, Elpitiya, Imaduwa, Baddegama, Neluwa, Yakkalamulla, and Nagoda DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Galle District, would be effective for the next 24 hours until 3.00 p.m. today (30). Furthermore, the same level one yellow – watch landslide early warning alerts were issued for Beliatta and Okewela DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Hambantota District, Ingiriya and Walallawita DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Mulatiyana, Kotapola, Matara Four Gravets, Hakmana, Thihagoda, Kirinda, Puhulwella, Welipitiya, Athuraliya, Kamburupitiya, Akuressa, Pitabeddara, Malimbada and Pasgoda DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matara District, as well as Kahawatta, Nivithigala, Pelmadulla, Ayagama, and Kiriella DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, according to Dr. Senadeera. Dr. Senadeera added that based on the amount of rainfall received in the landslide-prone areas in the Central Hill Country, additional areas may be declared as landslide-prone or areas currently on the list may be removed. The Meteorological Department predicted that the ongoing adverse weather conditions will continue for the next few days. Duty Meteorologist Malith Fernando, commenting on the current atmospheric conditions yesterday (29), forecast that showery weather conditions are expected across most parts of the country today (30), particularly after 2.00 p.m. Duty Meteorologist Fernando also predicted that fairly heavy showers exceeding 75 millimeters are likely to occur in some places in the Central and Sabaragamuwa provinces, as well as in the Galle and Matara districts. He further mentioned that misty conditions are expected in the morning hours in the Sabaragamuwa, Central, and Uva provinces. The public has been advised to take adequate precautionary measures to protect themselves from temporary localized heavy winds and lightning during thundershowers, Duty Meteorologist Fernando added. By NaalirJamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Govt facilitating private sector growth – Ports Minister
author: Author not found
Content: The fellowship in connection with the 26th Annual General Meeting of the Sri Lanka Association of Vessel Operators (SLAVO) was held on 27 October at the Courtyard by Marriott, Colombo. The Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva, was the Chief Guest. SLAVO is Sri Lanka’s premier and exclusive member-body representing ship-owners and principals and their direct interests in Sri Lanka. With its inception dating back to 1995 and hailed as one of the oldest associations in Sri Lanka’s maritime industry, SLAVO is actively consulted on matters concerning the industry and holds frequent dialogues with key government agencies, SLAVO said and added SLAVO is committed to promoting industry best practices among its members. It is also focused on liaising with the maritime industry ecosystem partners, such as authorities, State entities, and all other stakeholders, to ensure that international shipping lines utilise the Port of Colombo (POC) as a transshipment hub, thereby driving foreign exchange income generation and employment opportunities in Sri Lanka. Addressing the occasion, the Minister said he recognised the immense capacity, efficiency, dedication, and contribution of SLAVO to the nation-building efforts in Sri Lanka. “We are pleased to acknowledge that the Sri Lanka Association of Ship Owners (SLAO) plays a vital role, representing both ship owners, bulk carriers, and feeder vessels. It is an integral component of Sri Lanka’s maritime industry. Your operations, spanning across ports and maritime transportation in the Indian Ocean, significantly impact Sri Lanka’s reputation in the global maritime community,” he said. The Minister also remarked that the landscape of the maritime industry was rapidly evolving, with a strong emphasis on environmentally friendly practices. “Vessel owners worldwide are increasingly investing in green technology to reduce emissions. Consequently, our ports must be well-equipped to accommodate these eco-friendly vessels. Discussions in this regard have centered around green hydrogen, green ammonia, and enhanced connectivity. While Sri Lanka’s economy may not be as extensive as others, we must align with these global trends and deliver accordingly. This necessitates attracting investment for green hydrogen and green ammonia production in the Port of Colombo, a significant challenge globally in the upcoming years. We have already reached out to institutions for expertise in this regard,” the Minister said. Speaking further, the minister said, “To remain competitive globally, we must also focus on nurturing a new generation of professionals in the maritime sector. While those present here today have accumulated vast experience, it is crucial to encourage young individuals to embrace this industry. Our educational institutions must produce professionals who can compete on a global scale. Furthermore, pragmatic policies are essential to attract foreign and private investors for port development. Even in countries with strong economies like India, the private sector and foreign investments play a pivotal role. Therefore, our Government is committed to facilitating and supporting private sector growth. We currently have private terminals in our ports, and their efficiency should serve as a model for government-controlled terminals. In the near future, we plan to adopt a new model for the East Container Terminal, making it a more private-sector-oriented terminal, with our presence as far as the administration and other things are concerned. With the anticipated growth in the maritime sector, we may soon need additional terminals. Our ambitious North Port Development Project envisions four to six new terminals, all under private sector management, to attract further investment. Moreover, we recognise the need for a Port Community System (PCS) in the Port of Colombo. We are taking steps to address this, and expressions of interest from renowned organisations will be sought shortly. Additionally, we are aware of certain administrative issues within our ports, and we are committed to rectifying these concerns. Automation and closer collaboration with neighbouring countries, such as Bangladesh and India, are essential for the efficient movement of cargo through Sri Lanka’s ports. Politically, we are actively fostering relationships with key players in the region to attract more shipping lines and container ships to Sri Lanka. We aim to establish Sri Lanka as a strong hub in the Indian Ocean for transshipment. It is essential to embrace challenges and adapt to changing circumstances. The recent conflicts globally, including the events in the Middle East and Ukraine, remind us that unexpected events can impact our industry. However, the hallmark of successful businesses and entrepreneurs is their ability to adapt and innovate. Therefore, I encourage all present here to face these challenges with determination and creativity, ensuring the continued success of the maritime industry”, he concluded. Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, Private Secretary of the minister Akila Gayan Kaushalya, Sri Lanka Ports Authority’s (SLPA) Chairman Keith D. Bernard, Managing Director Prabath Jayantha Malavige, Additional Managing Director (Operations) Lala Weerasinghe, Snr. Dy. Harbour MasterCapt. Lakshi Wasantha, SLAVO Chairman – Shamal Perera, Vice Chairman  Arjuna Hettiarachchi and several other officials and reputed members of the maritime industry were also present.

title: COPF wants CBSL opinion
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Finance (COPF) has been informed that the Port City Commission has granted permission for the operation of two crypto currency exchanges. In response, the Committee recommended seeking the Central Bank’s opinion on this matter. Furthermore, the COPF has urged the Attorney General to provide his opinion to the Committee within four weeks regarding the engagement of business companies operating within the Colombo Port City. Following a lengthy discussion regarding the 10 business companies active in the Colombo Port City, attention was paid to the problematic situations regarding the signing of contracts by these companies. It was disclosed that these companies have entered into contracts under three methods. That is prior to the preparation of the port city, during the period of preparation of the Port City and post preparation of the Port City and the Committee pointed out that this agreement was not made according to one system with any legal basis. As a result, COPF recommended that the opinion of the Attorney General be sought within four weeks and the Committee be informed about it. The Committee Chair pointed out that it is important to check the constructions carried out by the 10 companies inside the Port City. In this regard, approval was obtained when the Committee met in Parliament  on 24 October under the Chairmanship of MP Harsha de Silva.   State Minister Suren Raghavan, MPs Chandima Weerakkody,  Nimal Lanza, Patali Champika Ranawaka,  Duminda Dissanayake and U. K. Sumith Udukumbura were present at the Committee meeting. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Anula’s body to arrive from Tel Aviv today
author: Author not found
Content: Anula Ratnayake, aged 49, left the woman she was taking care of, Etty Morado, safely under a bed when she went to see what’s going on and it was then Hamas members entered the room and tragically shot Anula, said Sri Lanka’s Honorary Consul in Northern Israel, Anat Bernstein-Reich. He was speaking during the last rites performed for Anula before her body was dispatched to Sri Lanka. The body was dispatched to Sri Lanka yesterday (26), and is expected to be received by the family today (27), noted Sri Lankan Ambassador to Israel Nimal Bandara. Bernstein-Reich during the last rites held in Israel said, “Anula was an amazing woman. She worked as a nurse and cared for the family and friends around. On Saturday, 7 October, Anula left the woman she was taking care of, Etty Morado, safely under a bed when she went to see what was going on. The monsters entered the room and shot Anula. Anula was lying near the bed protecting the elderly lady for three days and was found dead when the Israeli soldiers had walked in. This is how Anula sacrificed her life. Etty said, she is blind and Anula was her eyes.  The family and people in the area smiled as she introduced Sri Lankan cuisine. Their stories made it clear how wonderful it was to see so many friends from the Kibbutz attend the funeral. Many people from the area came to pay their last respects to her.” Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Israel, Nimal Bandara, stated that following the tragic loss of Anula, the family was able to confirm the identity of their mother when her body was shown to them via video conference. This confirmation made it unnecessary to conduct a DNA tests, he told Ceylon Today. “The family was able to recognize Anula’s body by identifying birthmarks and other distinct features, ultimately confirming that it was their beloved mother. Bernstein-Reich expressed her deep sorrow over the killing of Ratnayake of Kelaniya. She stated that Anula, who tragically lost her life, while working as a nurse near the Gaza Strip, continues to bring tears to those who knew her due to the kindness and love she showed to the elders of the family she served. She added that the members of several Sri Lankan families are among the people who came to Israel from countries all over the world who were helpless due to the inhuman attack by monsters on unarmed people. “The attackers shot and killed many unarmed people. Some children and even adults have been taken hostage and this is how Ratnayake was killed in Kibbutz Bari,” She added. The last rites for Anula were conducted at the residence where she had worked, before the body was dispatched to Sri Lanka.  The ceremony was attended yesterday (26), by Sri Lankan Embassy officials, her colleagues from the Sri Lankan community, representatives from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Directer of Overseas Employment, families who cared for Anula throughout the years, members of Kibbutz Bari, and individuals representing various religious sects. Daniel Carmon, who served as Israel’s Ambassador to India and Sri Lanka, and Morado family members Goral and Gilboa and members of the Sri Lankan community in Israel attended her funeral. Anula’s body was covered with the flags of Sri Lanka and Israel and they were moved by the horrendous death Anula faced. “Thank you for your years of dedicated care for the State of Israel. We express our condolences to the Sri Lankan family,” those stood by her coffin had conveyed.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Principals, teachers in islandwide protest today
author: Author not found
Content: Principals and teachers will hold protests in front of their respective schools Island -wide today (27) condemning the use of tear gas and water cannon to disperse a protest march by teachers in Pelawatte on Tuesday (24), General Secretary of Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) Joseph Stalin said. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Stalin said, the protests will commence at 1.30 p.m. in front of schools across the country, with a commitment to ensuring that regular school hours and study times were not disrupted. Stalin expressed his expectation that protests would occur in front of over 10,000 schools nationwide. He voiced his dissatisfaction with the Ministry of Education’s statement condemning Police actions on Tuesday (24), citing it as insincere. He stressed that this method of oppression affects all aspects of life and goes against international law, pointing out the importance of the Sri Lankan Government ensuring the right to peaceful assembly as part of the Constitution. He urged the government to honour its commitment to uphold the Constitution. Speaking further, he clarified that there would be no central protest in Colombo today (27). He also appealed to parents to send their children to school today (27), assuring them that the protest would not disrupt regular lessons. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Education Ministry voices concern over Police action
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education has expressed deep concern over the events that transpired on 24 October during the teacher-principal protest in Pelawatte. The Ministry has articulated its unease over the use of tear gas and water cannon by the Police in their efforts to disperse the protesting teachers and principals. The Ministry emphasised that these individuals were subjected to such measures, while simply seeking solutions to address the disparities and challenges within the country’s education sector. Consequently, the Ministry conveyed its regret over these circumstances, highlighting the unfortunate nature of such an incident occurring at a time when the Education Minister himself was abroad, attending a conference outside Sri Lanka. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: SC fixes Sathkumara’s petition for argument
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (26) fixed for argument the Fundamental Rights petition filed by author Shakthika Sathkumara, challenging his arrest and detention on charges of propagating religious hatred through a short story titled Ardha (Half). A three-Judge Bench of the Supreme Court, comprising Justices Peethi Padman Surasena, Yasantha Kodagoda, and Arjuna Obeysekera, scheduled the petition for argument on 7 June 2024. Sathkumara was arrested on 1 April 2019, by Polgahawela Police, based on allegations of promoting religious hatred through his short story ‘Ardha’ published on 15 February 2019. The charges were filed alleging Sathkumara’s short story had violated the Penal Code and the draconian International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights Act (ICCPR). Subsequently, Sathkumara was discharged from the case filed at the Polgahawela Magistrate’s Court after the Attorney General recommended against further prosecution. Sathkumara was represented by President’s Counsel Saliya Pieris, along with Counsel Pulasthi Hewamanna and Harini Jayawardhana, under the guidance of Niluka Dissanayake. Deputy Solicitor General Lakmali Karunanayake appeared on behalf of the respondents. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Manusha raises concerns over Jobs in Italy for Sri Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara raised concerns regarding the Job Quota system in Italy and highlighted the challenges Sri Lankan job seekers face, particularly in securing sponsors due to Italy’s unique referral-based quota system. Minister Nanayakkara met Italian Ambassador to Sri Lanka Damiano Francovigh yesterday (26), to enhance bilateral relations and address concerns related to labour migration. The central point of discussion was the renewal of the Bilateral Cooperation on Labour Migration Agreement between the Government of the Italian Republic and the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka. A significant development from this dialogue was the emphasis on establishing a training centre. This initiative, sponsored by the Italian Government, is envisioned to provide pre-departure training for Sri Lankan individuals seeking employment opportunities in Italy. Italian Ambassador Francovigh clarified the absence of recruitment agencies in Italy, differentiating its job market from many other nations. Furthermore, issues regarding the Family Reunion Visa process for Sri Lankans were raised. Minister Nanayakkara underscored the difficulties encountered by Sri Lankan citizens, including prolonged delays, the DNA requirement and outside interventions during visa appointment processes. The Ambassador received a commendation from the Minister for his proactive stance in curtailing external interferences in these processes. Ambassador Francovigh reciprocated by discussing the challenges faced by Italy in obtaining authenticated certificates from Sri Lankan authorities. The meeting, described as both “productive” and “fruitful,” also saw participation from the Deputy Ambassador of the Italian Embassy in Sri Lanka, underscoring the significance of the discussions and the commitment of both nations to nurturing their partnership. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sajith, UNICEF discuss future of healthcare, education
author: Author not found
Content: Sanjay Wijesekara, the Regional Director of UNICEF, held discussions with Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa regarding the future of healthcare and education in Sri Lanka. The meeting took place at the Office of the Leader of the Opposition in Colombo yesterday (26). Christian Skoog, a representative of UNICEF Sri Lanka, also participated in the discussion. According to a statement issued by Premadasa’s Office, during the meeting Premadasa highlighted the active role of his party, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), in contributing to Sri Lanka’s healthcare and education sectors through collaborations with UNICEF, UNFPA, and FAO. He urged UNICEF to play a pivotal role in the improvement of Sri Lanka’s healthcare and educational systems. The discussions encompassed the nutritional challenges faced by Sri Lankan families and the critical issues within the realms of preventive and curative healthcare. UNICEF’s Regional Director commended Premadasa’s profound knowledge of these subjects and emphasised the significance of their collaboration, the statement added. The Opposition Leader reiterated his party’s commitment to women’s and children’s rights, underscoring SJB’s dedication to creating a brighter future for all.

title: Court orders sending reminder to Govt Analyst
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (26) ordered that a reminder be sent to the Government Analyst (GA), to submit his reports pertaining to a DVD containing distorted telephone calls, which had been produced before the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) into Central Bank Treasury Bonds scam. The Magistrate gave these instructions, having perused a request made to him by Attorney Ralitha Amarasena appearing for the suspects, who charged that despite the lapse of four years since the case was filed, the reports linked to the DVD, has still not been produced in Court by the Government Analyst and to consider the same. Director of the Primary Dealer, PTL Private Limited, Arjun Aloysius, its CEO Kasun Palisena, Nuwan Salgadu and Sachithra Devathanthra, have been named as the suspects, in the case. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Lanza says President made right decision
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Nimal Lanza stated that the President has taken a step in the right direction by conducting a Cabinet reshuffle. He added that if the SLPP is unwilling to cooperate with the President, they could potentially reject the upcoming budget and force the President to call for a snap General Election. Lanza made these comments during a media briefing yesterday. Expanding on his remarks, Lanza said, “The Cabinet reshuffle occurred after discussions between the President and SLPP leaders, particularly regarding the Health Ministry.” The primary concern of the SLPP General Secretary is not the reshuffling of the Health Ministry, but the allocation of most of these positions to the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) rather than the SLPP. Merging the Ministry of Plantations with the Agriculture Ministry will allow these ministries to work more effectively together. Therefore, the President’s decision is a sensible one and should not be criticised. In the future, all State institutions to be privatised should fall under the purview of the Finance Ministry. I hope this will be implemented.” Lanza expressed his view that SLPP General Secretary Sagara Kariyawasam is unaware of the careful planning behind the recent Cabinet reshuffle. He encouraged the SLPP to demonstrate their control over the government rather than making unfounded allegations behind the scenes. Lanza advised the SLPP General Secretary to communicate directly with the President if they are dissatisfied with his decisions and leave the government, rather than engaging in media performances. He challenged Kariyawasam and others to participate in a public debate on the topic, rather than making exaggerated claims in the media. Lanza emphasised that the Cabinet consists of MPs from various political parties and that the President has the constitutional authority to reshuffle positions based on his judgment, regardless of whether it’s the SLPP or SLFP. Lanza reflected on the past, mentioning that Ranil Wickremesinghe had to lead the country because the SLPP Government failed to meet the people’s expectations. He acknowledged being part of that regime, but claimed that the SLPP’s autocratic leadership caused their political journey to suffer. He argued that the current President inherited a financially troubled government and that providing immediate relief, as suggested by Namal Rajapaksa, is not feasible due to the conditions imposed by the IMF. Lanza supported the idea of an election to allow the people to choose their government. However, he expressed doubt that the SLPP would take such action because they may fear the consequences. He challenged them to accept his challenge if they have the courage. Finally, Lanza asserted that the President’s actions align with the desires of the people.

The charges were filed alleging Sathkumara’s short story had violated the Penal Code and the draconian International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights Act (ICCPR). Subsequently, Sathkumara was discharged from the case filed at the Polgahawela Magistrate’s Court after the Attorney General recommended against further prosecution. Sathkumara was represented by President’s Counsel Saliya Pieris, along with Counsel Pulasthi Hewamanna and Harini Jayawardhana, under the guidance of Niluka Dissanayake. Deputy Solicitor General Lakmali Karunanayake appeared on behalf of the respondents. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Manusha raises concerns over Jobs in Italy for Sri Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara raised concerns regarding the Job Quota system in Italy and highlighted the challenges Sri Lankan job seekers face, particularly in securing sponsors due to Italy’s unique referral-based quota system. Minister Nanayakkara met Italian Ambassador to Sri Lanka Damiano Francovigh yesterday (26), to enhance bilateral relations and address concerns related to labour migration. The central point of discussion was the renewal of the Bilateral Cooperation on Labour Migration Agreement between the Government of the Italian Republic and the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka. A significant development from this dialogue was the emphasis on establishing a training centre. This initiative, sponsored by the Italian Government, is envisioned to provide pre-departure training for Sri Lankan individuals seeking employment opportunities in Italy. Italian Ambassador Francovigh clarified the absence of recruitment agencies in Italy, differentiating its job market from many other nations. Furthermore, issues regarding the Family Reunion Visa process for Sri Lankans were raised. Minister Nanayakkara underscored the difficulties encountered by Sri Lankan citizens, including prolonged delays, the DNA requirement and outside interventions during visa appointment processes. The Ambassador received a commendation from the Minister for his proactive stance in curtailing external interferences in these processes. Ambassador Francovigh reciprocated by discussing the challenges faced by Italy in obtaining authenticated certificates from Sri Lankan authorities. The meeting, described as both “productive” and “fruitful,” also saw participation from the Deputy Ambassador of the Italian Embassy in Sri Lanka, underscoring the significance of the discussions and the commitment of both nations to nurturing their partnership. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sajith, UNICEF discuss future of healthcare, education
author: Author not found
Content: Sanjay Wijesekara, the Regional Director of UNICEF, held discussions with Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa regarding the future of healthcare and education in Sri Lanka. The meeting took place at the Office of the Leader of the Opposition in Colombo yesterday (26). Christian Skoog, a representative of UNICEF Sri Lanka, also participated in the discussion. According to a statement issued by Premadasa’s Office, during the meeting Premadasa highlighted the active role of his party, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), in contributing to Sri Lanka’s healthcare and education sectors through collaborations with UNICEF, UNFPA, and FAO. He urged UNICEF to play a pivotal role in the improvement of Sri Lanka’s healthcare and educational systems. The discussions encompassed the nutritional challenges faced by Sri Lankan families and the critical issues within the realms of preventive and curative healthcare. UNICEF’s Regional Director commended Premadasa’s profound knowledge of these subjects and emphasised the significance of their collaboration, the statement added. The Opposition Leader reiterated his party’s commitment to women’s and children’s rights, underscoring SJB’s dedication to creating a brighter future for all.

title: Court orders sending reminder to Govt Analyst
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (26) ordered that a reminder be sent to the Government Analyst (GA), to submit his reports pertaining to a DVD containing distorted telephone calls, which had been produced before the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) into Central Bank Treasury Bonds scam. The Magistrate gave these instructions, having perused a request made to him by Attorney Ralitha Amarasena appearing for the suspects, who charged that despite the lapse of four years since the case was filed, the reports linked to the DVD, has still not been produced in Court by the Government Analyst and to consider the same. Director of the Primary Dealer, PTL Private Limited, Arjun Aloysius, its CEO Kasun Palisena, Nuwan Salgadu and Sachithra Devathanthra, have been named as the suspects, in the case. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Corrupt fish importers to be dealt with
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said, any malpractice in the process of importing fish will be thoroughly investigated and addressed within the boundaries of the law. He said, that authorisation has been granted to import rare fish species that cannot be found in Sri Lankan waters. In the event of any fraudulent activities during the importation process, strict legal action will be taken against those involved. He further highlighted that the importation of these rare fish varieties is under close scrutiny, overseen by the Ceylon Fisheries Corporation, which operates under the jurisdiction of the Fisheries State Ministry. Fisheries State Minister Piyal Nishantha de Silva is actively monitoring all aspects of the import process and the likelihood of misappropriation in this process is minimal. Minister Devananda affirmed that stringent legal measures would be taken against any importers involved in fraudulent activities should such incidents be reported. The Fisheries Minister also stated that he has instructed officials to ensure the importation of high-quality, hygienic fish at an affordable price, accessible to the citizens. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Education Minister holds talks with Italian counterpart
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha and his Italian counterpart, Prof. Giuseppe Valditara discussed the possibility of formulating a system whereby educational qualifications between their two countries could be aligned to suit the needs of their people. The two Ministers had been of the view that if both Rome and Colombo could align their education programmes it could go a long way towards further boosting their economies and further developing their social needs. During this meeting, Minister Premajayantha stated that Sri Lanka would be keen to formulate its educational programmes in such a manner to suit the professional needs of Italy which could then be advantageous to both countries. He was of the view that professional training courses in his country should be upgraded to suit the requirements of youths with the support of the Italian educational authorities. The Minister also sought support from his Italian counterpart towards the setting up of an Italian language centre for Sri Lankans to learn the language effectively. Premajayantha further sought help from the Italian Education Minister to further expand higher education opportunities for Sri Lankan youths in Italy.

title: Jeevan briefs UK MPs on challenges faced by plantation community
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman, addressing British Parliamentarians, shed light on the challenges faced by the plantation community of Sri Lanka and recounted their historical struggles, the immense cultural and economic contributions made by the community and the enduring spirit of resilience that defines them. He visited the British Parliament on 19 October where he held a fruitful engagement with Ministers of Government, Members of Parliament and Lords. Minister Thondaman was warmly received to the House of Lords by Lord Nick Herbert and Stuart Andrew, Minister for Sports, Tourism, Civil Society, and Equalities. The Minister emphasised the steps being taken to improve living conditions and opportunities for the plantation community, including the launch of a new land and housing rights programme, as we commemorate 200 years since their arrival in Sri Lanka. The Minister articulated Sri Lanka’s journey of economic recovery following the crisis of last year and the Government’s commitment to comprehensive economic and social reforms. He highlighted the introduction of new social protection schemes and laws designed to ensure safety and equality for all segments of society, especially women and other marginalised communities. The Minister’s presentation was well received by his British counterparts, especially in the context of Sri Lanka’s swift progress in controlling inflation and avoiding a prolonged crisis. Everyone agreed that Sri Lanka’s prudent macro-economic policies offer valuable lessons that can be shared globally. Minister Thondaman engaged in a highly-productive one-on-one meeting with Dr. Matthew Offord, MP, who also serves as the Co-Chair for the All-Party Parliamentary Group (APPG) on Sri Lanka and the APPG on Water and Sanitation. Their discussions delved into critical issues within Sri Lanka, ranging from reconciliation, human rights and the ongoing reforms in the water sector. The Minister advocated for stronger collaboration between Sri Lanka and British water utilities, encouraging investments that align with our vision of an expanded role for the private sector in ensuring universal access to water. Minister Thondaman later led a roundtable discussion on Sri Lanka for British Parliamentarians, chaired by Baroness Barker. During the discussion, the Minister briefed everyone on the progress Sri Lanka has made in several areas, including reconciliation, respect for human rights and economic development. There was consensus on the importance of challenging negative narratives about Sri Lanka through sharing positive stories of progress. The Minister agreed to proactively engage with British Parliamentarians and Sri Lankan diaspora communities in the UK and to share positive stories of progress, especially on reconciliation, economic recovery, and social inclusion. It was agreed that such proactive engagement had the potential to have a positive impact on Sri Lanka’s perception globally. Minister Thondaman’s welcome at the British Parliament is a testament to the recognition given to the contributions made by the plantation community and to his commitment to advancing Sri Lanka’s interests and perceptions abroad. His engagements in the United Kingdom exemplify Sri Lanka’s readiness to re-engage with the world and signal its openness for business. (SRM)

title: Ramesh vows to cleanse Health Ministry of corruption
author: Author not found
Content: Newly-appointed Health Minister, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana vowed to cleanse the Health Ministry of corruption during a sudden meeting with the President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa.       Dr. Sanjeewa, on Wednesday (25), said the Minister had clearly stated that he would do his best to eliminate the corruption, fraud, and irregularities of the present health service officials. The Minister urged all health service trade unions and the public not to have any reservations in this regard. Dr. Pathirana assured that the Health Ministry would be cleansed of corruption and fraud. The MCPA President said his outfit hoped to hold formal discussions with Minister Pathirana shortly to discuss the burning issues facing the state health service. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Doctors threaten to withdraw from VIP ambulance service
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors warned they would withdraw from ambulance services given to VIPs from 1 November, if the Government failed to take measures to retain medical practitioners within the country. Secretary of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge, yesterday (25), warned that his outfit was set to launch trade union action to prod the Government into coming up with a programme to provide equity and economic justice to medical officers remaining in the country. They (the doctors) should be given hope to remain in the country. Despite trying to hide the facts from the public, the Committee appointed to investigate the brain drain taking place from amongst the medical fraternity reported that close to 1,500 medical practitioners had left the island within this period. Dr. Aluthge warned that failure to prevent further loss from amongst medical officers and medical specialists would lead to the collapse of more hospital services. He said from amongst the five trade union measures approved by the Union’s Central Committee a resolution was also taken to withdraw from all mobile clinics conducted outside the State hospitals from the beginning of next month. The Central Committee had also approved the list of peripheral hospitals that the union had decided to temporarily close down as yet another trade union action.  However, the Union cautioned that it would abandon all efforts made by it to retain doctors in the country if health and government officials failed to come up with a concrete plan to retain medical practitioners within the island. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Port TUs to stage protest today
author: Author not found
Content: Port Trade Unions will stage a protest today (26), demanding salary increments, bonus allowances, and other benefits. The protest is set to take place opposite the Port gate in Fort, starting at noon. General Secretary of the All Ceylon General Port Employees’ Union, Niroshan Gorakanage, emphasised that in 2022, the Port generated a substantial profit of Rs 40 billion. Consequently, one of their key demands is the approval of a salary increment in January 2024. Further, he highlighted that their annual bonus has consistently been a fixed amount of Rs 100,000, distributed in two instalments. They advocate for this bonus to be adjusted to 10 per cent of the total profit and to be distributed among the 8,000 workers. Gorakanage underlined that in 2021, they received a salary increment, which is officiated to be once every three years. They anticipate the implementation of this increment in January 2024. He emphasised that the protest serves as a reminder and urged the authorities to acknowledge their demands, as any deviation from these demands is not acceptable to the workers. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: IT Director post vacant due to low salary scale – COPA
author: Author not found
Content: The long-standing vacancy of the IT Director at the Department of the Registrar of Companies cannot be filled as no suitable candidate applies for the position due to the low salary scale, it was revealed at the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA). COPA, which met recently in Parliament, instructed the Ministry of Industry and Commerce to comply with existing legal provisions and promptly fill the vacant position of IT Director at the Department of the Registrar of Companies while offering competitive wages. Chaired by State Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna, COPA examined the Auditor General’s reports for 2019, 2020, and 2021, and also scrutinised the department’s present performance. Further, COPA urged the Department of the Registrar of Companies to explore the possibility of renegotiating their agreement with the company responsible for providing the e-Roc System for digitalising company registration.The committee expressed concern about state information being under the control of a private company. The committee also requested the Registrar of Companies to provide a report detailing an alleged expense of Rs 85 million incurred for document scanning during the initiation of the digitalisation programme for company registration. The report should explain why, despite the expenditure, the digitalisation process remains incomplete. Additionally, COPA called on the Registrar of Companies to take necessary action to amend the Companies Act with a focus on enhancing the department’s efficiency and streamlining its operations. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Fine for cattle theft to be upped to Rs 1M
author: Author not found
Content: In Anuradhapura, a cow that was known for its high milk yield in the region was recently stolen and slaughtered. This rare cow had been consistently providing an impressive 26 litres of milk every day, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. Amaraweera, who announced an increase in the fine for cattle theft to Rs 1 million, with a one-year Rigorous Imprisonment (RI), said the Gampaha District has the highest number of cattle thefts in the country. The Ministry of Agriculture has reported a growing prevalence of cattle thefts islandwide. According to the Animal Welfare Act, the maximum fine for cattle theft is set at Rs 50,000, and there is presently no provision for imprisonment. Considering this situation, Amaraweera has advised the officials of the Livestock Development Division of the Ministry of Agriculture to amend the Animal Welfare Act. The proposed changes include imposing a fine of Rs 1 million and introducing a minimum one-year RI. A discussion regarding the proposed amendments to the Animal Welfare Act took place at the Ministry of Agriculture. MP Udaya Gammanpila, who was part of the discussion with a group of animal welfare association representatives, emphasised the need for amendments in the clauses pertaining to increased penalties for dairy cattle theft. Thus, the Minister has recommended raising the present fine for dairy cow theft from Rs 50,000 to Rs 1 million. Additionally, provisions will be introduced for a one-year RI, as the present law does not include prison sentences for cattle theft. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Residents slam charging tourists to enter Galle Fort
author: Author not found
Content: A group of residents of the Galle Fort and a section of businessmen, holding a special media briefing yesterday (25), alleged that the Galle Heritage Foundation (GHF) along with the Central Cultural Fund (CCF) has decided to levy USD 15 from all foreigners visiting the scenic Galle Fort. The residents of Galle Fort and businessmen of the area, opposing this decision taken by the GHF and the CCF, staged a protest demonstration at the Shri Sudarmalaya Temple at Galle Fort yesterday (25). The Chief Incumbent of the said Temple, Ven. Panangala Hemaloka Thera said to date people of various ethnicities had lived in peace at Galle Fort but charged that due to the crass decision taken by the GHF that harmony had been irrevocably damaged. The monk mentioned that if such a charge is levied from foreigners visiting the Galle Fort it will invariably and adversely impact the livelihood of the people who reside there. He added that the decision taken by both the GHF and the CCF should be annulled forthwith as it would also strongly impact the country’s tourism sector. By Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle

title: Czech charter flight with 252 passengers arrives at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: The inaugural charter flight of a series of charter operations by LOT Polish Airlines, departing from the Czech Republic, arrived in Sri Lanka yesterday (25), carrying 252 international tourists. These charter flight operations are scheduled to run until 26 March 2024, according to Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Pvt) Limited (AASL). These flights are a collaborative effort between Čedokof the Czech Republic, Sri Lanka Tourism, and Jetwing Travels, with Hayleys Aviation serving as the General Sales Agent for LOT Polish Airlines. The arrival of the first flight was celebrated with a water salute, and passengers were treated to a traditional welcome dance performance, as well as gifts of Ceylon Tea courtesy the Sri Lanka Tea Board. Further, the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau is set to launch a joint promotional campaign with Čedok to coincide with the charter flight arrivals from the Czech Republic. This campaign is aimed at increasing awareness of Sri Lanka as a destination within Eastern European markets.The soft inauguration ceremony at BIA was attended by Dr. Sumith de Silva, Head of Marketing and Corporate Communications at AASL, Charith Nalaka, Deputy General Manager of Jetwing Travels, Jagath Perera, Inoka Gayathri (Market Officers)from the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau, and Sasidharan Kumarasamy, Assistant Manager at Hayleys Aviation. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: 168 girls under 16 sexually abused in September – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe, said in September 2023, a total of 168 girls under the age of 16 were reportedly sexually abused. Speaking to the media yesterday (25), she highlighted that out of these 168 cases, 22 resulted in child pregnancies. The State Minister thus called on the Police to take stringent measures and urged for the harshest possible penalties for those found guilty of such offences. She also appealed to parents, schoolteachers, and principals to remain vigilant and protect children from potential harm, underlining that “Most of the time, children are often abused by a close family member, someone in their own home.” Further, Kumarasinghe mentioned that discussions regarding these pressing concerns are scheduled with the President, and measures have already been initiated to introduce new Acts aimed at safeguarding the welfare of women and children. When queried about the root causes of these alarming statistics, Kumarasinghe acknowledged that both the Police force’s negligence and the increased use of narcotics play significant roles in these crimes. She reiterated her responsibility as the State Minister of Women and Child Affairs for the safety of women and children and stressed that Sri Lankan society as a whole shares this responsibility. To report child abuse, dial 1929, the hotline of the National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Local researchers to board ship
author: Author not found
Content: The second Chinese research ship, the Shi Yan 6, arrived at Colombo Port around 3:00 p.m. yesterday (26), following approval from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs over the request from the Chinese Embassy. Initially, the MFA stated that the ship would be allowed to visit Sri Lanka by the end of November, but did not provide an update when the vessel arrived yesterday. The AFP stated that clearance was granted for the vessel to come to Colombo for replenishment. According to the Ports Authority, the Chinese ship is scheduled to depart from Colombo Port on 28 October. The MFA previously announced that the Chinese Embassy had requested permission for the research vessel Shi Yan 6 to enter Colombo Port for joint ocean research with the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA). However, NARA denied inviting the vessel, but several local marine scientists from the University of Ruhuna and the Ocean University of Sri Lanka are expected to board the ship at the invitation of the Chinese, the Ports Authority told Ceylon Today yesterday (26). Fisheries Ministry Secretary, Indu Ratnayake, said if the Chinese on the ship have a request, NARA can assist with their research. The MFA previously stated that the Chinese Embassy had requested permission for the Chinese research vessel Shi Yan 6 to conduct joint scientific research with NARA. The research will primarily focus on ocean-related matters, and it was emphasised that both Chinese researchers and NARA would collaborate on this research. Such collaborations have taken place with other countries in the past, the MFA spokesperson said earlier. When the Chinese Yuan Wang 5, a space-tracking vessel arrived in Sri Lanka last year in Hambantota, it stirred diplomatic tension between New Delhi and Colombo. India raised security concerns, suspecting that China was using the ship for espionage on India’s power plants and nuclear facilities. China this time maintained that the Shi Yan 6 is a “scientific research vessel” with a crew of 60, including cooks, conducting oceanography, geology, and marine ecology tests, News18, an Indian website, reported. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Five-member committee reviews CCTV footage
author: Author not found
Content: The five-member committee, tasked with investigating the alleged assault on State Minister Diana Gamage within the Parliament lobby, reviewed the CCTV footage related to the incident yesterday (25). Following their deliberations, they have scheduled a summoning of relevant parties for 6 November. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse presided over the committee meeting in Parliament yesterday (25), with the participation of former Speaker Chamal Rajapaksa, Gayantha Karunatileka, Imthiaz Bakeer Markar, and Minister Ramesh Pathirana. Further, it was decided to designate two female MPs representing both the ruling party and the Opposition, to join the upcoming meeting on 6 November. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse emphasised that the committee’s findings will be presented to the Speaker upon the conclusion of their investigations during the next session. He also stressed that the committee is committed to taking measures to prevent any future incidents of this nature, as they undermine the dignity of the House. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Kanchana says EOIs to be called soon
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera announced yesterday (25) that Expressions of Interest (EOIs) will soon be called for projects involving the establishment of a floating solar photovoltaic power plant on the Samanalawewa Reservoir. Wijesekera said as part of this initiative, EOIs will be solicited from both domestic and international developers for the construction of two floating solar power plants, each capable of generating 100 MW of power. On 23 October, Cabinet approved a proposal by the Ministry of Power and Energy, allowing for the solicitation of proposals for the development and execution of these proposed solar power plants. Interested parties are expected to adhere to the national procurement guidelines applicable to infrastructure facility projects. This decision was prompted by the recognition that constructing floating solar power plants on the surfaces of reservoirs is a more suitable solution for countries with limited available land for such projects. Consequently, approximately 100 hectares of the Samanalawewa Reservoir, under the purview of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), will be allocated for the establishment of a floating solar power plant. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Court Registrar further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: The Registrar of the Fort Magistrate’s Court, who was arrested by the CID on charges of arbitrarily sending a fraudulent letter to the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration in an attempt to help a suspect, who was subjected to a travel ban, was further remanded till 8 November. The CID told the Court that the suspect registrar had sent another forged document prepared similarly in 2022 for a suspect who was subjected to a travel ban. The registrar was arrested on 13 October evening on multiple charges, which include the alleged forgery of documents and misplacing a case file. The second suspect in the case, who had been working at an insurance company as a chief accounting manager, was arrested on 17 October. The duo was remanded till yesterday (25) by Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage. According to the CID, 86 phone conversations took place between the duo and the second suspect had given Rs 100,000 to the suspect registrar. Also, the second suspect had deposited money in the registrar’s bank account on several occasions. The Court also permitted the CID to check the bank accounts and call records of the suspect registrar. The second suspect was also remanded till 8 November. It is alleged that she falsified documents indicating that a Court order had lifted a foreign travel ban for a specific suspect. These counterfeit documents purportedly instructed the Immigration Controller to allow the suspect to travel overseas. The Colombo Fort Magistrate had filed a complaint with the CID against the registrar in question. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: 224 Lankans deported from Australia
author: Author not found
Content: Australia has intercepted and deported 224 Sri Lankan individuals who arrived in the country illegally through marine routes in 2022 and 2023, Rear Admiral Justin Jones, Commander of the Joint Agency Task Force Operation Sovereign Borders revealed. These statements are in accordance with information available on the Australian Home Ministry’s website. He also emphasised, as reported on the Ministry’s website, that “In 2022 and 2023, ‘Operation Sovereign Borders’ responded to an increase in maritime people smuggling activities originating from Sri Lanka. Smugglers sought to exploit the economic crisis in that country and the heightened interest among vulnerable Sri Lankans to seek opportunities abroad. During this period, 224 Sri Lankan nationals were intercepted and safely returned in a lawful manner. Each one of them had fallen victim to false promises from criminals who had no regard for their safety or lives.” During a recent visit to Sri Lanka in July, Rear Admiral Justin Jones conveyed the Australian Government’s gratitude for the Sri Lankan Government’s efforts and cooperation in combating people smuggling during this challenging time. He expressed deep appreciation for the ongoing endeavours of Sri Lankan authorities, which not only successfully disrupted attempted ventures within the country but also facilitated the safe return of Sri Lankan nationals intercepted at sea by Australian authorities. It’s worth noting that all seven vessels intercepted en route to Australia in 2022 were deemed unseaworthy. (PA)

title: Women strike in Iceland for equal pay, including PM
author: Author not found
Content: Tens of thousands of women in Iceland, including the Prime Minister, walked off the job on Tuesday (24) to demand equal pay and protest violence against women, organisers said. Iceland already tops a World Economic Forum (WEF) ranking for gender equality, but organisers said the country needed to make even more progress and lead by example. “We are keenly aware that we have not reached gender equality, and even though the situation may be better than other places, there is no reason to just call it a day,” Steinunn Rognvaldsdottir, one of the organisers of “Kvennafri” (Women’s Day Off), told AFP. The protest day has been called six times since 1975, this was only the second time that organisers made it a full-day strike, she added. The other times, women walked off the job at a symbolic hour after which they were technically no longer earning a salary compared to male colleagues. The average wage gap between men and women was 10.2 per cent in 2021, according to Statistics Iceland. Around 90 per cent of Iceland’s women took part in the first protest in 1975, “which was momentous,” Rognvaldsdottir said. Prime Minister Katrin Jakobsdottir was among those striking, her office told AFP. “She will not attend to official duties and in that regard, today’s scheduled cabinet meeting has been moved to tomorrow,” a spokesman said. Tens of thousands of women gathered for a large demonstration in the afternoon at the main square of the capital Reykjavik, and protests were also planned in other towns around the country of 400,000 people. In Reykjavik, where 75 per cent of city employees are women, 59 daycare centres and preschools were closed and all city services were affected by the strike. City employees taking part in the strike will not lose pay, the city said. Organisers of the movement said they expected men to take charge of the unpaid work that often falls to women. “For this one day, we expect husbands, fathers, brothers and uncles to take on the responsibilities related to family and home, for example: preparing breakfast and lunch boxes, remembering birthdays of relatives, buying a present for your mother-in-law, making a dentist appointment for your child.” “We always have to be on guard when it comes to our rights,” Lina Petra Thorarinsdottir, 45, told AFP. “In Iceland, we are proud of what we have accomplished and I am thankful for the women that came before us,” said Thorarinsdottir, Head of Tourism at marketing group Business Iceland. She said she would continue to protest until women enjoyed “equal rights in full.” The strikers also wanted their protest to raise awareness of gender-based violence. “We still see that up to 40 per cent of women have experienced some form of violence or will experience some form of violence in their lifetime,” Thorarinsdottir said. “The strike is for both equality when it comes to paid and unpaid work, it also has to do with violence against women and non-binary people,” she said. Fjola Helgadottir, a 41-year-old nurse, was unable to take part in Tuesday’s strike action. “I would have liked to participate in today’s protest but because we work in the children’s emergency room, we have to provide that service,” she told AFP. (AFP)

title: China Foundation for Rural Development to assist Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Vice President of China Foundation for Rural Development Liu Wenkui said his Foundation would assist Sri Lanka’s poverty alleviation programme. He gave this assurance when he called on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the Prime Minister’s Office in Colombo yesterday. The Prime Minister said China’s success in eradication of poverty, rural upliftment and ensuring food security has been exemplary. “I thank China for magnanimous contributions to the efforts of my country as well as other developing nations towards achieving food security,” he said. He expressed appreciation to President Xi Jinping for the offer of continuous support to Sri Lanka during President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s visit to Beijing last week. Liu Wenkui said his Foundation has expertise in rural development and it could assist Sri Lanka in its drive to increase rural productivity for the multiple goals of self-sufficiency, upliftment of rural low income families and increase exports. He said that China Foundation for Rural Development will distribute dry ration packs for primary school children in rural schools in several districts this week. State Ministers Janaka Wakkumbura, Ashoka Priyantha,  Chinese Ambassador, Qi Zhenhong, Secretary to the Prime Minister, Anura Dissanayake and Director of China Foundation, Zou Zhiqiang were present on this occasion.

title: Ambassador Prof. Janitha A. Liyanage speaks at the Russian Environmental Forum 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan Ambassador to Russia Professor Janitha A. Liyanage was among the key speakers at the Russian Environmental Forum (REF) commenced on 13 October 2023. The Forum brought together the main players in the field of solid waste management, including foreign diplomats, experts, industry specialists and entrepreneurs.  The Forum was graced by the Deputy Prime Minister Victoria Abramchenko, Head of the Ministry of Natural Resources of Russia, Alexander Kozlov and CEO of the Russian Ecological Operator  Denis Butsaev.  Speaking at the international session focused on sustainable development– Formula of the Future, Ambassador Liyanage emphasised the commitment of Sri Lanka towards the environment. She also spoke about the functioning waste management system in the country, control over environmental pollution, improving of the environmental literacy and protection of the forest cover, impediments and effective solutions.  The discussion was also attended by the former Minister of Tourism of Thailand, the Ambassadors of Philippine and Mexico and the representatives of Russian government institutions.

title: Right of Reply

It is a pity, of course, that the senior lecturer of the University of Kelaniya doesn’t recognise the very moment for the international relations and the order. This seems to result in the situation when a group of those dependent on the West mislead the youngsters and persuade them to follow these false believes. These actions have no connection to academic science, it is only a ghost of the dark colonial past, when Anglo-Saxon lie and double standards were obligatory to be repeated. Mr. Wijayantha “forgot” the well-known crimes of the Anglo-Saxons. Is he brave enough to criticize them in the situation of their vindictive unscrupulousness? For example, the US, the State that have made profit from all World Wars, that in 20 years of XXI century have invaded at least seven countries (Afghanistan, Iraq, Liberia, Syria, Libya, Yemen, Kameroon) situated thousands miles overseas. The State that has trampled the law and human rights in the Middle East, that created hundreds of hidden prisons for dissenters and claiming them to be terrorists conducted violent tortures against them? Or he has never heard how that country’s executioners distinguished themselves in Abu Ghraib or in Guantanamo (US-occupied territory of Cuba)? How does it comply with the UN Charter, a part of the founding fathers of which was for then Roosevelt administration? How often did they use their veto right? How often did they ignore the resolutions of the Security Council when they wanted to do it? Outrage upon the principles of the UN Charter is a hobby of the US leaders for the last 30 years.
