We have been feeling this “democracy” and “love” by our own since the US and UK intervention in the beginning of the XX century, plans for a military operation codenamed “Unthinkable” with participation of the former Nazi army units against the USSR right after the end of the WWII and their significant efforts to eliminate the very name of Russia after the collapse of the USSR. By the way, they are finalizing these efforts in our brother State Ukraine, by launching a full-scale civil war and massacres of thousands of native Russians.”

title: Govt to form ‘Anti-Narcotic Command’
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is mulling the establishment of an ‘Anti-Narcotic Command’ soon to combat the influx of drugs from foreign nations into Sri Lanka. Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and President’s Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka said this initiative will empower the country’s Armed Forces and the State Intelligence Service to collaborate with international intelligence agencies in conducting necessary operations. Ratnayaka made these comments after inspecting the 200 kg of heroin, valued at Rs 4.5 billion, which was intercepted on the high seas and brought to the Colombo Port yesterday. Ratnayake emphasised that the drafting of essential legislation to create this ‘Anti-Narcotic Command’ is currently underway and will soon be presented to Parliament. Furthermore, Ratnayaka underscored that while 65 per cent of the drug raids result in arrests, the remaining 35 per cent continues to infiltrate the country. He stressed the urgency of implementing a modern programme aimed at entirely preventing the entry of drugs into the country. “First and foremost, I extend my congratulations to both the Navy and the Police Narcotics Bureau for successfully apprehending 200 kg of heroin. Remarkably, this marks the second substantial drug seizure within a brief span of time. The initial operation was executed based on intelligence provided by the Police Narcotics Bureau, while the most recent operation, according to information from the State Intelligence Service, was carried out by the Navy. The widespread global network of drug trafficking necessitates on-going efforts to safeguard our population from this peril. “In collaboration with the Navy, Police and various government agencies, Sri Lanka actively conducts drug raids. These endeavours result in the apprehension of approximately 65 per cent of drugs attempting to enter the country, with the remaining 35 per cent still making their way in. “According to the latest intelligence, these drug shipments arrive at the international maritime border via large vessels and are subsequently transported into the country by smaller boats. This expansive drug network poses a significant challenge. “Furthermore, there is a concerning possibility of arms trafficking intertwined with these drug trades. Vigilance in this regard is paramount, as it could pose a substantial threat to national security. To address these challenges, the development of new legislation is underway, with the creation of an Anti-Narcotic Command in progress. Proposed laws are in preparation and will be presented to Parliament for future implementation,” Ratnayake said. Meanwhile, Police Media Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said Sri Lanka Police and the Police Narcotic Bureau (PNB) will continue their crackdown on drug traffickers despite the threats and intimidation tactics. This statement was made yesterday (24) at a press conference held in Battarmulla. SSP Thalduwa said, despite the threats and intimidation faced by law enforcement agencies in the country, over 812 kilogrammes of heroin had been seized with the help of Sri Lanka Navy, the State Intelligence Services and Sri Lanka Coastguard, from January to October this year.  Responding to a question raised by Ceylon Today, the Media Spokesman said Sri Lanka Police officers and PNB officers had seen an increase in threats and intimidation from suspected drug traffickers and underworld masterminds in the recent years.  He added that unlike in the past most of the drug traffickers and ring leaders have moved abroad through illegal means and are now carrying out their operations from those cities. This includes trafficking, selling and other such organised crimes that are done through delegated criminals loyal to those individuals. SSP Thalduwa further said that this gives these traffickers a false sense of safety which emboldens them to threaten and intimidate officers. He went onto say that as these drug traffickers and their international networks are realising that the crackdowns are intensifying they will try to not only threaten but to persuade officers with the vast wealth at their disposal. SSP Thalduwa said that despite all these efforts Sri Lanka Police and PNB will work with other foreign law enforcement agencies and continue their crackdown on these traffickers and dismantle their criminal networks. By Gagani Weerakoon and Buwanaka S. Perera

title: New Health Minister pledges transparency
author: Author not found
Content: New Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, assuming duties in his new Ministry, explained that measures had been taken to investigate and follow up on the country’s drug and procurement situation. Fielding questions from the media, following the ceremony yesterday (24), at the Health Ministry, Dr. Pathirana said necessary decisions would be taken in this connection. With the recent economic crisis and the financial down turn, the government had to depend on certain credit methods. In the meantime, known long-term suppliers withdrew due to delay in payments and it resulted in a series of events that had taken place. On this basis the Ministry is obliged to take obligatory policy decisions to correct those matters. However those decisions would be taken as the country expects, Dr. Pathirana said. Pledging to work with transparency, the new Health Minister said that he had not had any influence from the medicines mafia.  “I will work with transparency in a way that you can question me again,” he pledged noting that rather than by an individual, a Committees was to be appointed to ensure that high-quality medicines were in continuous supply in terms of purchasing, quality protection, and even supplies. The Minister also vowed to find solutions to the brain drain taking place amongst the medical fraternity. Several issues have arisen in this regard. He said that discussions would be held with the medical fraternity regarding policy issues to provide the necessary solutions within the available economic framework, Dr. Pathirana added.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: No plans to hike water tariff – Jeevan
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development, Jeevan Thondaman, reiterated that there are no plans to increase the water tariff. Instead, the Ministry is diligently working on implementing a water tariff formula, set to roll out in January 2024, he added. Minister Thondaman also revealed that the Ministry of Estate Infrastructure is gearing up to honour the Upcountry community’s 200 years of contributions to the nation on 2 November. He assured the public that following the water tariff hike in August 2023, there will be no further increases. The focus is now on developing a cost recovery formula, a collaborative effort with the Water Board and Asian Development Bank (ADB) project, an integral part of a policy-based sub-programme. This sub-programme aims to contribute USD 100 million to the centralised budget upon completion. Minister Thondaman addressing the News Briefing, at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (24), under the theme ‘Collective path to a stable country’, clarified the government’s stance on water tariffs and announced initiatives to support the Upcountry community. He refuted the recent rumours about the current formula’s intention to guarantee fair water access while safeguarding those in vulnerable segments of society. These individuals are beneficiaries of social welfare programmes such as Samurdhi and Aswesuma, and this speculation is seen in light of the upcoming elections. The Minister emphasised that notably, of the approximately 2.96 million connections within the Water Board, the estate sectors are excluded, as they fall under the Rural Community Water Supply Department. This department extends its services not only to the estate community, but to all rural areas, working closely with 5,000 community-based organisations. Therefore, the water tariff in question applies exclusively to Water Board consumers. In addition to water-related matters, Minister Thondaman said that the Ministry of Estate Infrastructure is preparing to commemorate the Upcountry community’s contributions to the nation spanning two hundred years on 2 November. The Ministry is also actively engaged in initiatives aimed at benefiting the Upcountry community. A charter, featuring seven committees, has been formed within the ministry to address a wide range of issues specific to the plantation sector. These committees are dedicated to the economic uplift of women and children, on gender equality, health, education, sports and other activities. This charter will serve as a comprehensive guideline for all ministries, offering insights into how to address the unique concerns of the Upcountry community and reintegrate them into Sri Lankan society, ending their isolation within the plantation sector. Minister Thondaman underlined the significance of the Upcountry community, comprising approximately 200,000 estate worker families and roughly about 150,000 – 200,000 workers.  Further, an additional 800,000 to 1.2 million individuals, who are part of their families, reside within the estates. He stressed the importance of recognising not only estate workers but also the broader community and their identities in these endeavours. (GW)

title: Minister Alles to amend ‘Online Safety Bill’
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles, has decided to retract the Online Safety Bill he initially presented in  Parliament, opting to reintroduce it with a series of new amendments.                                                                 The ‘Online Safety Bill’ was introduced in Parliament on 3 October by the Public Security Minister. However, it faced criticism and debates from various local and international stakeholders, who argued that there was a lack of clarity in the Bill’s provisions. In response, Minister Alles clarified that the decision to withdraw the Bill was not a result of external pressure but rather a proactive step to refine and enhance the legislation. He expressed his intent to reintroduce the Bill in Parliament after making the necessary amendments. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Keheliya says content with environment portfolio
author: Author not found
Content: Newly sworn in Minister of Environment Keheliya Rambukwella said that giving a new Cabinet portfolio to him, and having removed him from his previous Ministry (Health), by the President, is not something that should be shocking or unnatural to the people. He was of the firm view that an Executive President has been empowered by the Constitution to remove any Cabinet Minister that he deems fit and insisted such scenarios had even taken place throughout the country’s political history. He remarked that he does not believe that his party, the SLPP has felt displeased over him being removed from his previous Cabinet Ministry post but noted that any political party could have internal reservations whenever Cabinet Ministry reshuffles occur. Rambukwella made these comments to the media having assumed duties as the new Minister of Environment at its premises in Battaramulla yesterday. He also added that there could always be issues which tend to crop up from time to time during political journeys of such alliances and affirmed that what counts is how they manage to resolve differences and charter a journey together. The former Health Minister also expressed his contentment at having been offered the portfolio of Environment Minister, particularly as he stated, “at a time when the environment of the world is facing a pivotal time in its efforts to usher in a better environment for masses to live.” He emphasised he will do his utmost to address pressing issues in the sector during his stint as the subject Minister. BY Mithun Jayawardene

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Court quashes Govt Order retiring nurses aged over 60
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal, yesterday quashed a State Order, which sent all those aged over 60, in four grades of the Sri Lanka Nursing Service (SLNS), into compulsory retirement. Accordingly the Appellate Court Bench, comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne (President) and M. A. R. Marikkar quashed the requisite Government order and issued an order recalling all persons above age 60, who were already sent on compulsory retirement, to re-join the service. The Court of Appeal Bench, issued its writ order, having perused a writ petition filed by the Public Services United Nurses Union (PSUNU). The Court, also quashed the decision, taken in this connection by the Cabinet of Ministers. The Court, elaborating on its verdict, stated that the decision taken by the State, to send nurses on compulsory retirement at age 60, had contributed in large measure, to a crisis situation within the country’s State hospital sector.  The Bench also added that currently a severe shortage of nurses and doctors has been evident within the Government Hospital sphere. It noted that this situation had resulted due to such persons going abroad in search of greener pastures and as a result of sending those aged above 60, into compulsory retirement without any consideration of its consequences to the public. The Appellate Court, then deemed that if this situation, is not addressed urgently, this country’s hospital sector could irreparably collapse sooner than later. The Court stressed that the respondents for their part, had also failed to convince the Bench, with regards to how they intend to resolve this burning medical issue and asserted that the said verdict, is being issued, having considered each of the aforementioned facts. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Visa-free entry for tourists from seven countries
author: Author not found
Content: Tourists from seven countries will have the opportunity to visit Sri Lanka visa-free until 31 March 2024, following the Cabinet granting its approval to such a proposal, aimed at promoting the tourism Industry.  Tourists from China, India, Russia, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and Japan will now be able to visit Sri Lanka until 31 March 2024 visa-free. This would be enacted with immediate effect noted Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando. The Government has announced its commitment to enhancing foreign tourists’ access to world heritage and historical sites without being inconvenienced by traffic jams. To achieve this goal, a comprehensive single-payment package ticket will be introduced, allowing visitors to conveniently purchase it either at the airport or through an online system. As for visa fees, the Sri Lankan Government currently charges approximately USD 127.08 per Russian or Chinese tourist. For a Japanese tourist visa and ETA processing the fee is JPY 4,233 (equivalent to Rs 9,254.88). A Malaysian tourist pays USD 20 per head, while visitors from Thailand pay USD 50. An Indonesian tourist, on the other hand, pays a fee of Rs 49,700 while for an Indian it is INR 2,200. Asian tourist destinations are competing to raise their tourism market, which had fallen due to the Covid epidemic. Most of the countries are taking steps to provide visas free of charge to tourists. Therefore , several new tourism promotion programmes have been planned for the promotion of the Sri Lankan tourism industry, which is slow due to the Easter Sunday attack, the Covid epidemic and the subsequent serious economic crisis. Accordingly, the Cabinet of Ministers approved a joint proposal presented by the PrimeMinister, Minister of Tourism and Lands, Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of Public Security with the aim of increasing the number of tourists coming to Sri Lanka to five million a year in the next three years. Also, to promote the tourism industry, a short-term strategy has been established, offering the option to obtain tickets for Sri Lanka Railways’ tourist coaches via an online system or purchase them at the airport as one-time tickets. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Shop and Office Employees Act to be amended
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers has approved the proposed amendment to the provisions in the Shop and Office Employees (Regulation of Employment and Remuneration) Act, No. 19 of 1954, to enable women to work at night. The amendment will allow women working for organisations, whose businesses are based on information technology, knowledge process outsourcing firms, business process outsourcing firms and offices dealing with accounting administrative and technical work for business establishments located in other countries, to engage in nightshifts. The Attorney General’s clearance has been received for the draft Bill of the Shop and Office Employees (regulation of employment and remuneration) (Amendment) Act prepared by the Legal Draftsman. The Cabinet of Ministers granted approval to the proposal submitted by the Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment to publish the said draft Bill in the Government Gazette and subsequently table it in the Parliament for approval.

title: Reserves bleed by USD 10.63M
author: Author not found
Content: The country’s foreign reserves bled by USD 10.63 million (Rs 3,466 million) yesterday, led by Government of Sri Lanka’s foreign debt servicing commitments to multilateral donors.  Consequently GoSL’s non-demand-pull inflationary face value money printing (FVMP) debt increased by Rs 3,466 million yesterday due to inadequate revenue to buy the required US dollars (foreign exchange/FX) from the country’s foreign reserves to service such foreign debt commitments. Subsequently, GoSL’s FVMP debt as a whole increased by 0.03 per cent to Rs 3,024,600.63 million (Rs 3.0246 trillion) yesterday. However, year on year (YoY) to  yesterday, GoSL’s FVMP debt has been reduced by at least a massive Rs 2,924,781.50 million(Rs 2.9248 trillion/49.16 per cent) aided by the recent tax and utility rate hikes, thereby helping  to negate demand-pull inflationary pressure by a large measure. Yesterday’s FVMP debt reduction is also the second largest of such reductions, the largest being a reduction totalling at least Rs 2.9256 trillion) which took place only on the previous day Monday (23). But in the obverse, high tax and utility bills may destablise the political and socioeconomic fabric of the country if unsupported by growth, employment and better employment opportunities.  Meanwhile, yesterday’s FVMP debt of Rs 3,024,600.63 million includes previous provisional advances to GoSL and Treasury (T)-Bill purchases from the primary market amounting to Rs 2,713,144,352,010 (Rs 2.7131 trillion/Rs 2,713,144.35 million) in full made by Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), which, as per IMF diktats, were converted to T-Bills and T-Bonds on 21 September 2023, with their dates of maturities ranging as early as 9 February 2024 and as late as 15 June 2038, respectively. Presuming that a year ago too those provisional advances and primary market T-Bill purchases made by CBSL amounted to at least Rs 2,713,144.35 million (though, in actual fact it would have had been much more!), then, CBSL’s FVMP debt would have had swelled to at least Rs 5,949,382.13 million (Rs 5.9494 trillion) on that day (Friday 21.10.22. Monday 24.10.2022 was a holiday to the markets).  CBSL lacks transparency to make accurate deducements. Further, in making yesterday’s decrease in the country’s foreign reserves deducement, swap settlements between CBSL and the market or CBSL and the GoSL and CBSL’s  sales of FX to the market to prevent rupee depreciation due to demand, are discounted.  GoSL’s FVMP debt in this instance is taken to be equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T-Bill and T-Bond holdings. When there are sufficient revenues, CBSL/GoSL can retire maturing T-Bills and T-Bonds without having those to be reissued to CBSL (the creditor), as the latter and its agents (Ceylon Electricity Board, Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, etc.) are compensated for giving GoSL and its agents (debtor) credit previously, by being repaid their dues upon maturity of such instruments (T-Bills and T-Bonds) by enhanced tax and utility bill collections, thereby resulting in the retiring of such T-Bills and T-Bonds, leading to a reduction in such holdings by CBSL. Consequently, a reduction in circulated money or money printing as well, due to these actions, where CBSL is repaid for previously buying such T-Bills and T-Bonds issued by GoSL on behalf of its agents or to it, itself (GoSL), upon the maturity of such instruments, aided by enhanced tax and utility bill collections by GoSL and its agents results in such money going back to CBSL’s godowns and being removed from circulation, thereby nullifying demand-pull inflationary pressure. CBSL, at least historically, used to print rupees when GoSL and its agents do not have sufficient revenues/money to meet their commitments, or to buy the required FX from the country’s foreign reserves to meet foreign debt service commitments, in this instance to multilateral donor agencies. However, the danger in money printing (MP) is that if it enters the domestic market, it causes demand-pull inflationary pressure. Investing in T Bills and T-Bonds is generally considered as being riskless, because, in the event GoSL is unable to repay such debt, CBSL is normally mandated to print demand pull inflationary money and repay such creditors. CBSL has the sole right to print rupees.  Nonetheless, the new CBSL Act has controlled CBSL’s money printing activities to a great extent. Conversions are based on Friday’s (20) offer rate of the benchmark ‘spot’ which was Rs 326 to the dollar. Swaps between CBSL and GoSL are foreign reserves neutral. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days of trading. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and of its foreign reserves, deals in ‘spot.’ By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Nearly 400 Jumbos dead this year
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Wildlife Conservation says that about 400 elephants have died in Sri Lanka so far in 2023. Director General of the Department of Wildlife Conservation Chandana Sooriyabandara said among them, at least 200 elephants died as a result of the human-elephant conflict, shootings or motor accidents. He added that wild elephants had also died due to several diseases. The Sri Lankan elephant population now stands at about 6,000.

title: PNB officer’s gun misfires during arrest
author: Author not found
Content: A tense situation was reported yesterday afternoon (24) in front of the Central Mail Exchange, on D.R. Wijeyawardene Mawatha in Colombo, when the weapon of a Police officer, attached to the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB), had misfired while taking two suspects into custody. Speaking at a press conference held last evening, the Police Media Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said, a group of officers attached to the PNB took two individuals into custody when they arrived at the Central Mail Exchange to claim a parcel. According to SSP Thalduwa, the parcel, addressed to an apparent female resident in Mattakuliya, had arrived at the Central Mail Exchange last Saturday (21) after which a 45-year-old male employee at the Central Mail Exchange had come with a letter written by the said woman, and her NIC to claim the parcel. When the Sri Lanka Customs officers had asked the man to open the parcel, they found that the parcel contains five kilograms of cannabis and the man fled the scene. “Later, with the help of the Central Mail Exchange employees and the PNB we found that the said individual has worked with another employee from Sri Lanka Post to release the parcel,” said SSP Thalduwa. He elaborated that following interrogations the PNB found that the two Sri Lanka Post employees were working for another 31-year-old resident in Ratthanapitiya, Horana who had instructed them to retrieve the package. The PNB has decided to apprehend the 31- year- old suspect when he arrived at the Central Mail Exchange yesterday afternoon. SSP Thalduwa said the suspect who arrived at the Central Mail Exchange in a luxury vehicle, fearing that he was to be arrested, had decided to flee the scene, during which a Police officer’s gun had misfired once and this had caused the suspect to surrender. No one was harmed in the incident and according to SSP Thalduwa the people in the vicinity have misunderstood the arrest as abduction and had ignorantly spread misinformation about the incident on social media. SSP Thalduwa reassured that the PNB and Sri Lanka Police are carrying out further investigation into the matter. SSP Thalduwa also claimed that Sri Lanka has seen a spike in recent years with regard to the quantity of cannabis that is smuggled into the country via commercial aircrafts. He also said that it isn’t exclusive to Cannabis or Marijuana but is becoming the popular mode of trafficking for most of the high scale illicit drugs. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Cabinet nod to forming body to oversee MPs’ conduct
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers has granted approval for the establishment of an independent body to oversee the conduct of Members of Parliament. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena and Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe have tabled a joint proposal in this connection at the last Cabinet meeting. The government said many countries in the world have recognised the need to establish an independent body to implement a code of conduct for Parliamentarians and Sri Lanka has addressed the need to establish a similar authority. Accordingly, the Cabinet has given permission to obtain the views of the Speaker and leaders of political parties representing the Parliament on the basic draft Bill for setting up of a code of conduct for MPs and appointing a panel to oversee. Cabinet approval was also given to instruct the Legal Draftsman to prepare a draft Bill after taking into account the views of the Speaker and political party leaders. The government has proposed the establishment of an independent body to oversee the conduct of MPs with the aim of increasing the public’s confidence in Parliamentarians. (GW)

title: Navy SEIZES heroin transporting trawler
author: Author not found
Content: Acting on intelligence information received from the State Intelligence Service, the Sri Lanka Navy mounted a special operation and intercepted a drug-carrying local multiday fishing trawler on the high seas, about 292 nautical miles (about 540 km) south of Dondra, by deploying SLNS Vijayabahu. The intercepted local multiday fishing trawler, with over 219 kg of heroin and five suspects  on board were escorted last morning (24) to the Port of Colombo. Upon being brought ashore, the suspicious trawler underwent thorough search where 200 packages of heroin, weighing around 219.634 kg, contained in nine sacks were seized by the authorities. The drug-carrying fishing trawler and suspects  on board were also taken into custody. Meanwhile, the street value of the seized consignment of drugs held in this operation is believed to be over Rs 4,500 million.  The suspects apprehended in this operation were identified as residents of Kudawella, Tissamaharama, Koottagoda and Mamadala areas, aged between 30 and 48 years. The suspects along with the stock of narcotic drugs and the fishing trawler were handed over to the Police Narcotic Bureau for onward legal action.                                       (GW)

title: President’s goal is to merge like ministries, institutions
author: Author not found
Content: The Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industry, Mahinda Amaraweera, said that the goal of the President Ranil Wickremesinghe is to merge the currently divided ministries that come under the same scope. Amaraweera, who was appointed as the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industry, in accordance with the new Cabinet reshuffle made by the President, assumed duties at the Ministry of Plantation Industry last morning (24). Ranjith Siyambalapitiya who was appointed as Non-Government Minister of Plantation Industries, State Minister Arundika Fernando as well as Ministry Secretaries, Additional Secretaries and others participated in this event. Minister Amaraweera, who expressed his views after assuming his duties, said that President Ranil Wickramasinghe has decided to implement a programme to integrate the ministries and institutions that have been merged. The Minister stated that the Plantation Industries Division was merged into the Ministry of Agriculture for that purpose and in the future within a short period of two months, the two government-owned fertiliser companies will be merged into one company, and the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Agricultural Development will be merged into one entity. In particular, the aim of this programme is to increase the efficiency of the institutions, reduce waste, provide efficient service to the public and prepare the institutions so that the government can earn profit.

title: SLAF remembers its heroes
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Air Force held its annual religious ceremony and almsgiving at the Sacred Temple of the Tooth in the evenings of 22 and 23 October, under the patronage of Air Force Commander, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa. The primary purpose of this event was to invoke blessings on the dedicated personnel of the Sri Lanka Air Force, both past and present and to honour the supreme sacrifices made by those who served in the defence of the nation.  This remarkable occasion was orchestrated by the Directorate of Welfare for the 13th consecutive year. Chairperson of the SLAF Seva Vanitha Unit Inoka Rajapaksa too joined the religious ceremonies at Sri Dalada Maligawa in the evening of 22 October 2023 where blessings were offered on those valiant individuals who gave their all for the motherland, as well as for the well-being of the current Air Force members and their families. The significant almsgiving, which included offerings to 72 Buddhist Monks, was conducted on 23 October, under the benevolent presence of Mahanayake of Asgiri Chapter Most Ven. Warakagoda Sri GnanarathanaThera. The SLAF Commander also paid his respects to Mahanayake Theras of the Malwatte and Asgiriya Chapter. This year’s ceremony witnessed the presence of the Air Force Board of Management, all Base Commanders, Commanding Officers, officers, and other ranks. Of  utmost importance was the event being graced by the beloved family members of the SLAF’s heroic individuals who gallantly sacrificed their lives, paving the way for the peace we cherish today. The commitment of the Sri Lanka Air Force to honour its fallen heroes and support its dedicated personnel continues to be a solemn and heart-warming tradition.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Three Batticaloa youths set sea swim record
author: Author not found
Content: Three youths from Batticaloa have created a record having swum across the 30-kilometre stretch of the seas from Danushkodi in India to Talaimannar within a space of 12 hours. The three youths, namely Pultington Dianstin, 19, Irulalakanthan Kiso, 22 and Pultington Prido, 15, had set off on their record setting journey at 12.45 a.m. on 22 October from Danushkodi and they had reached Talaimannar at 12.50 p.m. on the same day. Their record thus had been entered into the Wallen Record Book. Executive Committee member of the Wallen Record Book Company, Perumal Nilamegam, Vice President of its Sri Lanka branch Nagawani Raja and Chairman of the Mannar District Chris Kandaraja presented certificates and medals to the winners.

title: Three new Ambassadors present credentials
author: Author not found
Content: Three newly appointed Ambassadors to Sri Lanka handed over their credentials to President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Secretariat last morning (24). The new Ambassadors represent Switzerland, the European Union and Iran.    Accordingly, Dr. Siri Walf the Ambassador of Switzerland to Colombo, Carmen Moreno the Ambassador of the European Union to Colombo and Dr. Alireza Delkhosh the Ambassador of the Islamic Republic of Iran to Colombo presented their credentials.

title: President delivers shock to Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, who survived a no-faith motion in Parliament owing to the majority number of seats occupied by his Party, the SLPP, in the House, was in for a bitter shock yesterday as he lost his Health Ministry portfolio to Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, in the mini Cabinet reshuffle by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Rambukwella came under severe criticism for making the country’s Health sector, which was once considered as being up to international standards, deteriorate during his tenure. He remained nonchalant despite calls, protests and sathyagraha demanding his resignation. Dubbed as one of the worst Health Ministers in the country’s history, the public complained of losing faith in the public health sector as Rambukwella continued to fail to give ear to the resounding crises erupting in the health sector day after day. In the Cabinet reshuffle last morning, Rambukwella however ensured a Cabinet portfolio as he was sworn in by the President as the Minister of Environment. Mahinda Amaraweera was appointed as the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries. Dr. Ramesh Pathirana was appointed as the Minister of Health in addition to his portfolio as Minister of Industries while Ranjith Siyambalapitiya was appointed as the Non-Cabinet Minister of Plantation Enterprises apart from his post as State Minister of Finance. Meanwhile, various Opposition parties termed this as a move by the President to ‘rectify’ an ‘error’. “We see this as a move by the President to save his Government from losing face further. He appeared to have corrected a mistake committed in Parliament. Even though we in the Opposition collectively voted in favour of the no-confidence motion, brought against him, the SLPP, since it had the numbers, defeated it. So this, we see as a retribution by President to save his face as well as the government from being unpopular,” Leader of Pivithuru Hela Urumaya Udaya Gammanpila said responding to questions from the media. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: Zonal Education Directors empowered to close schools
author: Author not found
Content: The Southern Province Education Director said Zonal Education Directors are empowered to decide on closing schools, due to adverse weather conditions prevailing in Akuressa, Deniyaya, Mulatiyana and Walasmulla. Meanwhile, the Irrigation Department has issued an ‘Amber’ flood warning in some of the low-lying areas of the Nilwala River valley in the Kotapola, Pitabeddara, Akuressa, Pasgoda, Athuraliya, Malimbada, Thihagoda, Matara and Devinuwara Divisional Secretariat divisions. It was reported that the Matara-Kotapala road has been blocked from Kirilipana due to the collapse of an earth mound on to the road, preventing vehicles from passing through. Morawaka-Neluwa Road is also blocked from Morawaka town and Pitabaddara area is flooded due to the Kirama Oya overflowing. By analysing the current rainfall situation and river water levels of Hydrological Stations in Nilwala River, it is warned that there is a possibility of a considerable flood situation occurring in some of low-lying areas of Nilwala River valley situated in, the Kotapola, Pitabeddara, Akuressa, Pasgoda, Athuraliya, Malimbada, Thihagoda, Matara and Devinuwara DS Divisions. Accordingly, residents in those areas and motorists travelling through those areas are requested to pay high attention in this regard. Meanwhile the Disaster Management Authorities are requested to take adequate precautions in this regards. (GW)

title: Cabinet reshuffle a mockery – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa yesterday said the sudden Cabinet reshuffle by President Ranil Wickremesinghe was nothing but a mockery. He pointed out that by appointing Keheliya Rambukwella, who was deemed unsuitable for the Health portfolio, as the Environment Minister, Sri Lanka is not being made a smart nation, but a dishonest one. “Even though the Opposition brought a No-Confidence Motion against Keheliya Rambukwella, the Government protected him. They proclaimed that they have confidence in him despite the nation’s health sector having crashed,” he said. The Opposition Leader, in a statement, stressed that the appointment of Keheliya Rambukwella as the Minister of Environment poses the risk of the environmental sector crashing in the same way as the health sector. The President has made this decision not to safeguard the public or the environment, but to strengthen his power, he alleged. Premadasa further urged the Government to hold a General Election.

title: SLPP unhappy with President’s action
author: Author not found
Content: While expressing their extreme discontent over the mini Cabinet reshuffle, the main constituent of the President Ranil Wickremesinghe Government, the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) claimed the removal of Keheliya Rambukwella as the Minister of Health was a “wrong decision” by the President. SLPP General Secretary Sagara Kariyawasam, addressing media last afternoon, said even though there were several allegations raised against Minister Rambukwella all those allegations were proven false. “Maybe the President must have thought that making certain changes in this regard was the right thing to do at this juncture,” he added. Kariyawasam said, however, that the SLPP has informed the President of its disappointment in the appointment of a Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) member as a Cabinet Minister. “A large number of MPs supporting the President to take this country forward are from the SLPP. There are only five such MPs supporting the President in the SLFP. Thus, it is wrong of the President to remove a ministerial portfolio from an SLPP MP, and give it to an MP belonging to the SLFP, and to also give another SLFP member the portfolio of a State Minister. We are unhappy about this decision. It was a wrong thing to do. We are not afraid to say when something is wrong. If an act is wrong, it is wrong, even if it is committed by the President,” the SLPP General Secretary stressed. Voicing the party’s displeasure with regard to the appointments of two members of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) to both Cabinet and non-Cabinet portfolios, Kariyawasam asserted that they are unafraid to call the President out on his “wrong decisions”. We are not afraid to speak out when something is wrong. If an act is wrong, it is wrong, even if it is committed by the President,” the SLPP General Secretary stressed. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: Anula’s Family rejects death report
author: Author not found
Content: The family of Anula Jayatilleke Ratnayake (49), who died during a Hamas raid into Israel on 7 October, has been requested to provide their DNA for confirmation that the body is indeed that of their relative. The family is in denial of the death, Sri Lankan Ambassador to Israel Namal Bandara told Ceylon Today. Hence, he has urged Anula’s two children, a 29-year-old son and a 23-year-old daughter, to submit their DNA test sample reports to verify the situation. The children, who live in Kelaniya, have said that they cannot identify the body as it’s beyond recognition. “I am waiting for the report to visit the mortuary.” Currently, the body is at the Tel Aviv Police mortuary, according to the Ambassador. “The body is believed to be in a state beyond recognition and the family maintains the belief that their mother is still alive. To avoid any doubts, it has been decided to confirm through DNA testing before sending the remains to the family. They will send the report through the Foreign Ministry.”  Additionally, the family of Yatawara Bandara from Wennappuwa, who has been missing since the raid, has been asked to submit DNA reports of his son and daughter in case any news emerges. In the meantime, there are speculations that many Sri Lankans are attempting to enter Israel through the Jordan border in search of jobs, possibly misled by job agencies. While there have been many reports of such attempts, the Ambassador mentioned that there is no official confirmation. He explained that there is a wide border on the West Bank north of Israel where people can attempt to enter. Tourist entry into Israel is currently restricted due to the ongoing situation, but some individuals are still trying to enter. The Israeli Border Police are monitoring the situation, and so far, there is no information regarding any arrests, noted the Ambassador. The Sri Lankan Bureau of Foreign Employment has urged Sri Lankans not to cross the border nor be deceived by racketeers. They said there are currently no employment opportunities in Israel and going there is a risk. Only two Sri Lankans were caught in the war between Israel and Hamas, where Hamas abducted as many as 222 people, including Israelis and foreigners. Anula was the only Sri Lankan identified so far as having been abducted and murdered. The Sri Lankan Mission is on the lookout for the male who is still missing. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Proposal on restructuring CEB to Cabinet next week – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy, Kanchana Wijesekera, announced that a comprehensive proposal pertaining to the restructuring of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) is scheduled for submission to the Cabinet next week. Minister Wijesekera further emphasised that a mechanism will be developed immediately for a systematic approach to revise the electricity bill once in every six months.   The Minister revealed this during a press conference held yesterday (23) at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC), under the theme ‘Collective Path to a stable country’. The Minister, providing additional insights, remarked that the Public Utilities Commission had recently approved a revision of electricity tariffs for the Electricity Board. Consequently, preparations we made to implement an approximate 18% rate adjustment, effective from the 21 October, with subsequent rate evaluations for the coming months. This price revision adheres to the government’s policy framework established in conjunction with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Pursuant to this framework, no State enterprise is permitted to draw funds from the Treasury to cover its financial losses. Consequently, a specialised price formula has been devised for both the Electricity Board and the Petroleum Corporation. Addressing a prevalent misconception within society, the Minister clarified that the Electricity Board is not confined to revising tariffs only twice a year. Provisions are in place for tariff adjustments in cases of emergency and the necessary Cabinet approval has been secured for this purpose. Furthermore, the Minister also revealed the on-going restructuring efforts of the Electricity Board. The proposals for this endeavour were previously submitted and are presently under consideration by the Legal Draftsman’s Office. The office has finalised its review and has forwarded the proposal to the Attorney General. On a positive note, the Attorney General recently conveyed plans to provide the requisite clarifications within the week, thus facilitating the proposal’s presentation to the Cabinet in the forthcoming week. These developments indicate a significant step forward in the restructuring programme. Moreover, it has come to the attention that there is a prevailing public sentiment regarding the need for a tariff revision due to the current heavy rainfall. It is pertinent to note that not only the Matara District, which I have the privilege of representing, but also the neighbouring Galle District and the Gampaha District have experienced flooding as a result of these meteorological conditions. In light of recent heavy rainfall and its implications for electricity production, it is essential to recognise that the primary reservoirs responsible for hydroelectric power generation, namely Samanala Lake, Victoria, and Randenigala, remain within their existing capacities. The rainfall in these regions has been below the typical levels.  “As of today, we are utilising only 65.81% of the reservoir capacity, a stark contrast to the 84.41% capacity utilisation observed by 22 October 2022. This represents a considerable 20% decrease. Comparatively, the hydroelectricity production from our reservoirs in 2022 reached 5,364 gigawatt hours, a significant decline from 5,639 gigawatt hours in 2021. By 22 October 2023, the figure stands at 2,893 gigawatt hours, only half of the corresponding output in the preceding years. With a mere 70 days remaining in the year, there is uncertainty regarding our ability to meet these targets. Consequently, the exploration of alternative measures is imperative to ensure the continued supply of electricity. (GW)

title: Cabinet reshuffle not a solution – Rajakaruna
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Harshana Rajakaruna said reshuffling the Cabinet or changing the portfolios of Ministers involved in corruption or bribery was not the solution to end corruption or bribery that has become a dominant force issue in the country today. Rajakaruna also claimed that the entire country is waiting for an opportunity to chase away everyone in the government from the top to the backbenchers and reshuffling the Cabinet or changing the Ministers involved in corruption is not a matter of concern. The need of the hour is the Local Government (LG) Elections that have been postponed, showing the country’s bankrupt situation, but not the Presidential Election. According to the Constitution the Presidential Election must be held when the term of existing President ends, he added. “By changing the corrupt in the Cabinet, the problems of this country cannot be resolved. As the Opposition Party in Parliament we had brought a no-confitence motion against the Health Minister. The ruling faction including the then President defended Health Minister Rabukwella. We will never allow to sweep under the carpet, the fraud committed by him, though his position or portfolio was changed,” Rajakaruna said. The people of this country have no means to live. Recently the government increased fuel prices by creating a fuel shortage themselves, showing the ongoing war between the Israel and Palestine it means the government was awaiting a single issue to take place across the world or region in order to implement their pre-prepared plans and to put the pressure on ordinary people in an unbearable manner, Rajakaruna said. He claimed that the pressure being imposed on the ordinary people is more severe than that they underwent during the Rajapaksa regime. It is obvious that the government has taken the pricing formula as a pawn and is making use of it to balance the losses by increasing the price every time. There were such ample occurrences in the past, Rajakaruna added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: 21 Australians travelling around Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: A group of 21 Australians is currently exploring the beauty of Sri Lanka, embarking on a journey of learning to play the ukulele as they move from one location to another. Connaissance De Ceylan in collaboration with Hidden Trails Sri Lanka have designed to introduce Australian tourists to the wonders of Sri Lanka, offering an itinerary that highlights the island’s finest attractions. ‘Sri Lanka’s – The Amazing Adventure’ was put together recognising the Australian holidaymakers love for beaches, taste for local food, a sense of adventure and connecting with local communities. The 16 night / 17 day itinerary is ideally suited to escape the Australian winter but can be easily adapted to cater for singles, couples, families or groups wanting to travel anytime of the year. Today, (24) the group plans to play a few songs on the train from Nanu Oya Station to Hatton Station with local musicians and at the end of their holiday (Sat, 28 Oct) they will be visiting a local school, performing for the children and donating their instruments to the local school. Tour Leader Stewart Kreltszheim, who was born in Kandy and now lives in Regional Victoria says “we are constantly putting on additional tours to cater to the ever-increasing demand by Aussies to visit the country.”  The group is having much fun and really immersing themselves in the local culture. (SRM)
