title: PickMe probes alleged data breach
author: Author not found
Content: Allegations of a data breach, involving one of the biggest ride-hailing platforms in Sri Lanka, PickMe, have emerged on social media with certain members of the public referring to a “leaker” of the information, who claims that over 4 million PickMe customer records have been compromised due to the data breach. According to this claim, it is being speculated that a wide array of sensitive and confidential information, including 1.8 million email addresses, 2.8 million phone numbers and another 1.4 million hashed passwords have been leaked. PickMe started its operations eight years ago and has facilitated a 100 million rides to commuters around Sri Lanka up to this year. Speaking to Ceylon Today in response to the allegations, the PickMe’s Chief Marketing Officer Mohan Gamage said that this matter was brought to public attention last August following which PickMe carried out extensive investigation on whether an internal security breach has occurred. The investigations ultimately confirmed that neither a personal information breach nor a breach in financial data of customers had occurred. Gamage further said that the ‘four million’ claim is factually incorrect and misleading and speculates whether the purported ‘leak’ was more of an attempt to damage the company’s reputation than it being a security concern. Commenting on the surge in which PickMe users are removing their credit/debit card details from the application, Gamage stated that as PickMe does not store any credit/debit card information and instead PickMe ‘Tokenise’ it as a safety measure. Tokenisation, according to Gamage, is the process of replacing sensitive data with unique identification symbols that retain all the essential information about the data without compromising its security with the company. Hence, Gamage claims that it is almost impossible to have such information leaked out. He further requested the PickMe application users to continue using their card payment methods as it is a safe and secure facility that has been provided by the company to give more comfort for the passengers. Nevertheless, Gamage said that the company is concerned about these allegations and will look into them. Regarding the incident, Ceylon Today spoke to prominent cyber security expert Asela Waidyalankara, who said that such data breaches, if occurred, aren’t exclusive to a particular company and that such breaches happen globally. He added that as Sri Lanka does not have a specific authority to look into such matters and as a general rule to practice more caution as citizens when sharing personal and financial details online. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Lecture on ‘Historical Relations between SL and ME’ held in Bahrain
author: Author not found
Content: As an initiative aimed at strengthening the relations between the Kingdom of Bahrain and Sri Lanka, as outlined in the 2014 Memorandum of Understanding, for Collaboration in the Fields of Culture and Arts between the two nations, the Embassy of Sri Lanka in the Kingdom of Bahrain, together with the Bahrain Authority for Culture and Antiquities organised a lecture, titled ‘Historical Relations between Sri Lanka and the Middle East’ by Professor Raj Somaveda, a Senior Professor of the University of Kelaniya, on Thursday, the 19 October 2023 at the National Museum of Bahrain. The chief guest at the event was President of the Bahrain Authority for Culture and Antiquities Shaikh Khalifa bin Ahmed bin Abdulla Al Khalifa while member of the Bahrain Parliament  Hassan Eid Bukhammass, Ambassadors of the UK, India, Pakistan, and Nepal, culture enthusiasts and members of Sri Lankan community organisations in Bahrain were among the guests. Speaking during the event, President of the Bahrain Authority for Culture and Antiquities expressed his gratitude to the Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Bahrain Wijeratne Mendis for the initiative taken to enhance cultural co-operation between the two countries. He also appreciated Professor Raj Somaveda, for his extensive research on Arabic and Islamic cultural heritage in Sri Lanka and its relations with Middle East region. Delivering her remarks, Ambassador Wijeratne Mendis expressed her gratitude to the President of the Bahrain Authority for Culture and Antiquities and, the management committee for their support on the successful conclusion of the event.

title: Farmers to get air rifles to keep away wild animals
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Agriculture will start distributing air rifles at subsidised rates to prevent crop damage caused by wild animals. Farmers have continuously requested the Ministry of Agriculture to provide shot guns to prevent crop damage caused by wild animals. Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera attended all the district agricultural committee meetings of the Vavuniya, Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu, Jaffna and Puttalam Districts and even at those meetings the farmers requested for shot guns. At present, crop damage caused by wild animals has increased and among the animals that cause crop damage, Toque monkeys, peacocks and Giant Squirrels are the most prominent. Currently, these animals have been removed from the protected animal list and wild elephants are still included in the protected animal list. Although the farmers demanded shot guns to prevent crop damage by wild animals, the Ministry of Agriculture started distributing air rifles at a concessional price from Sunday (22). The Minister of Agriculture started the distribution of air rifles to farmers at a programme held in Angunakolapalasse. Accordingly, arrangements had been made to distribute 268 air rifles to the farmers yesterday. The minister said that crop damage caused by wild animals has increased and farmers are constantly requesting to provide them with shot guns to prevent crop damage. “Crop damage is mostly caused by toque monkeys. Because of this, even though the initial steps were taken to provide 100,000 toque monkeys to zoos in China, the programme was disrupted due to lawsuits filed by environmental organisations. However, as there is a risk of a future food crisis, the destruction of cultivated crops by wild animals has created a serious crisis. Proposals presented by these environmental organisations to prevent crop damage caused by animals are not practical at all. The Minister also mentioned that the suggestions presented by these environmental organisations included hanging saris around the cultivated lands, plates tied to the coconut trees and half an acre of cultivated farms should be set aside for wild animals. Therefore, in an effort to prevent crop damage, measures were taken to distribute air rifles at the request of farmers, and the government has allocated the funds for this purpose this year, the minister said. However, the Minister stated that they cannot give shot guns to harm the animals, and asked farmers not to use these air rifles to kill animals, but only to drive them away and not to use these air rifles to injure people under any circumstances. He also mentioned that if any farmer uses these air rifles to harm people, The law would be enforced against them. (HN)

title: Dignifying workers is our priority – Jeevan Thondaman
author: Author not found
Content: “Dignifying workers and providing a safe working environment is our priority. A special monitoring mechanism should be introduced to safeguard the migrant workers of Sri Lanka with the support of the International Labour Organization (ILO),” Minister Jeevan Thondaman said when he met ILO Director-General Gilbert F. Houngbo in Geneva. General Secretary of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress and Cabinet Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman and his delegation made an official visit to Geneva to attend the Global Trade Union Congress of Public Services International. During their visit to Geneva, they had high-level meetings with many international organisations. Minister Thondaman held a discussion with Houngbo at the ILO Headquarters in Geneva. Minister Thondaman further said, “The plantation sector workers of Sri Lanka, who had been the largest contributing element of the Sri Lankan economy, are stepping into the 200th year from their arrival as indentured labourers during the colonial period. In the past, they faced much discrimination, exploitation, and violations. However, with great striving and the support of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress, the community has excelled in various sectors along with the other communities in Sri Lanka. Greater attention will have to be provided to further enhance the economic, health, and education conditions of the community and to revive the historical mistreatment during the colonial era of Sri Lanka.” He highlighted that when workers are exploited by employers, the CWC being one of the pioneer and largest trade unions in South Asia, defends them and ensures their welfare. Minister Thondaman expressed his concern over the proposed Employment Act. He stated, “I have expressed my concerns to the Minister of Labour on the proposed reform of the Labour law in Sri Lanka. Even though 44 laws are in existence in the law only 17 laws are being practiced. All trade unions demanded labour law reform; however, the proposed draft was not what we expected. Therefore, I had a special meeting with all the trade unions representing the National Labour Advisory Council to inform the authorities and the Minister we are not in favour of the proposed reform and the due diligence should be incorporated with the consultation with the NLAC.” The world of work has transformed during and after the Covid-19 pandemic, while Sri Lanka has experienced an unprecedented economic crisis that largely affected the working class. The plantation workers’ wages had become inconsistent and fragile. Subsequent to the abrogation of the collective agreement of the Employers’ Federation of Ceylon, there had not been an increment in daily or monthly wages of the plantation workers for more than two years, despite the cost of living being skyrocketed. “We have informed the EFC and the Regional Plantation Companies to come up with a uniform tea partnership model where the workers will be plot managers and it will increase the productivity of the plantation industry. Unfortunately, there had been no positive feedback from the employers,” Minister Thondaman said. In the recent past, there have been several workplace accidents. Many innocent workers lost their lives or became permanently or partly disabled. To mitigate this, a special ‘Insurance Scheme’ was introduced for the workers and their families to ensure their safety with the collaboration of the State-owned Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation and the Plantation Human Development Trust. “However, we have to take preventive measures to address possible accidents and provide the workers with a safe environment of work,” he added. Minister Thondaman further raised an alarming concern about migrant workers. Due to the economic crisis, many Sri Lankans have left the country seeking employment. However, it was reported that workers who are going as domestic workers are exposed to greater exploitation and grave dangers. These exploitations range from underpaying to sexual abuse, and assault. It was shocking to know that recently a female worker was found with iron nails inserted into her body by their employer. Therefore, the Minister requested the ILO to formulate a special monitoring plan to address these serious concerns which could be a tripartite process to ensure the safety of our migrant workers. Gilbert F. Houngbo, Director-General of the ILO, agreed to support the request of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress and he had assigned a team of experts to introduce the best practices of the Philippines in relation to migrant worker protection. He also thanked Minister Thondaman for defending trade union rights and ensured ILO will always support the activities to defend workers in Sri Lanka. The delegation also thanked the DG and his team and Simrin Singh, Country Director of ILO Sri Lanka, for their support of the trade unions and for ensuring the rights of workers. This meeting was also joined by Barath Arullsamy, Vice President of CWC and Chairman of Plantation Human Development Trust; Aritha Wickramasinghe, Advisor to Minister; Maria Helena, Director of Bureau for Workers’ Activities, and Hitomi Nakagome, Senior Advisor of ILO.

title: SC upholds CCHC order
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday unanimously upheld the interim injunction imposed on four accused, including Chint Power Solution Company, situated in Colombo 3, preventing the manufacture, distribution and sale of electronic items, containing the Chinese electronic items’ brand name ‘Chint’. Accordingly the Apex Court, dismissed the appeal petition filed against the order issued by the Colombo Commercial High Court (CCHC), without taking it up for consideration. The case was called up, before a Supreme Court Bench, comprising Justices Preethi Surasena, Shiran Guneratne and Priyantha Fernando. The SC thus rejected the appeal petition filed by R. K. R. Electronic Private Limited of Colombo 3, along with Sri Skandaraja Rajiv Kumar, against the intellectual Properties Act case, filed by the Chint Group Corporation of China and Chint Electric Company, before the CCHC. The Chint Corporation of China had recently informed the CCHC, that the accused firm had flouted Provisions contained in Section 160 (1) of the Intellectual Properties Act and charged, that the firm in question (Chint Power Solutions Private Limited), had distributed electric items, similar to the brand name of the Chint Corporation of China. Attorneys-at-Law Manoj Bandara and Thivanka Hettiarachchi, appearing for the plaintiff firm, informed the SC, that CCHC Judge Pradeep Hettiarachchi had imposed the interim injunction, on 2 March last year. They further informed the Supreme Court Bench, that the Chint Group Corporation, which had been started in 1984, had proceeded to emerge as the largest manufacturer, producer and supplier of smart energy technology and such equipment in the world and that its network, had been spread across 140 countries in the world. The lawyers explained that the Chint brand name, had existed in the Sri Lankan market since 2008 and that due to the superior quality, its products had become popular amongst consumers here. They added that the accused firm, Chint Power Solutions Private Limited, had proceeded to illegally utilise the brand name of Chint Group Corporation, whilst engaging in distributing and selling its products to the local market, with the sinister intention of earning profits fraudulently, while containing the brand name ‘Chint Power’. The lawyers alleged that the accused firm, had resorted to its unlawful actions, without due approval from the plaintiff firm and having registered the brand name ‘Chint Power’ secretly, they had violated Provisions contained in Sections of the Intellectual Properties Act via their actions. President’s Counsel Kuvera de Soyza, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Sanjaya Fonseka, appeared for the appeal petitioner. The three-Judge Bench of the Apex Court, having perused the submissions produced by both, the accused party and the plaintiff firm, decided to throw out the appeal petition challenging the interim injunction imposed by the CCHC, without taking it up for hearing. The dismissal of the appeal petition by the Supreme Court is due to be read out before the Colombo Commercial High Court on 23 November. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: New Health Minister should focus on patients’ wellbeing
author: Author not found
Content: Unlike outgoing Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, the newly appointed Minister of Health, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana should make the patients’ wellbeing his focal point while endeavouring to promote team work within the State health service.  CMLSSL President Ravi Kumudesh, when contacted yesterday (23), said there were strong possibilities of the new Minister of Health being biased towards medical practitioners as he too was one. However, he should endeavour to remember that there is a gamut of non-medical staff within the health service who contribute towards the smooth functioning of that service. Kumudesh accused Rambukwella of having forgotten this salient factor. The Minister made the mistake of thinking that the Medical Supplies Division (MSD), State Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Corporation (SPMC), the State Pharmaceutical Corporation and the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) was the entire State health service as it was where the money and the commissions were. In other words he allowed himself to be blinded by the drug mafia and forgot the patient community dependant on the free health service. Kumudesh lashing out alleged that this uncaring attitude of Minister Rambukwella had led to the Ministry officials also working with vested interests while the Deputy Directors General (DDGs) in the Health Ministry formed an entity of their own leaving out the non-medical staff of the health service out in the cold.  The shortcoming in management and administration of the State health service has brought the service to a point when the NMRA, tasked with regulating the pharmaceuticals imported to the country or being manufactured within has now been reduced to letterhead and a rubber seal which they cannot safeguard.  Meanwhile, President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva  said that Public Administration Ministries such as the President’s Office and the Criminal Investigation Department (CID)  should urgently conduct investigations into corrupt transactions of the Health Secretary, the Director General Health Services, the Additional Secretaries, the Presidents of the State Pharmaceutical Corporation, the officers of the NMRA, which have been exposed with evidence.  Failing to do so is a grievous injustice towards the people of this country, he alleged. Dr. Sanjeva warned that the public would even take a decision with regard to the newly appointed Health Minister, Dr. Pathirana if he too works in collaboration with the corrupt officials of the Health Ministry and fails to take action against the corruption and malpractices. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Dr Pathirana should avoid clutches of medicine mafia – GMOF
author: Author not found
Content: The newly appointed Minister of Health, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana should be technically sound to avoid the clutches of the medicinal drug mafia, the Government Medical Officers Forum (GMOF) warned. GMOF President, Dr. Rukshan Bellana while congratulating and extending wishes for the success of the new Minister, yesterday (23) said that Dr. Pathirana should be wary of the strategic approaches of the medicines mafia, which has always attempted to control the State health service. “We know that the new Minister is not corrupt. Therefore, he should endeavour to remain so whilst carrying out functions of the portfolio,” he said.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: High tax, utility bills down MP by record Rs 2.93T
author: Author not found
Content: The fall in Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL’s) face value money printing (FVMP) debt year-on-year (YoY) to yesterday (23) moved closer to the three trillion rupees mark,  increasing by at least to a record Rs 2,925,639.50 million (Rs 2.93 trillion), Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s), daily open market operations (OMO) data showed. The previous record was at least 2,900,318.90 million (Rs 2.90 trillion),  established only on the previous Monday (16). Such a sharp reduction (Rs 2.93 trillion) in FVMP debt is possible due to the recent hikes in tax and utility bills. Such a sharp YoY fall in FVMP debt to yesterday helps negates demand-pull inflationary pressure by a large measure. Consequently, whereas a year ago in September 2022 Sri Lanka’s inflation had risen to a record high 73.7 per cent, YoY, it has however since, fallen steeply to 0.1 per cent YoY  to September 2023, Census and Statistics Department’s yesterday’s data showed. But in the obverse, high tax and utility bills which aided in this massive reduction in MP run the risk of destablising the political and socioeconomic fabric of the country if unsupported by growth, employment and better employment opportunities.  Meanwhile, the settlement of swaps between the CBSL and the GoSL, where the former swapped foreign exchange (FX/US dollars) for rupees, increased market’s net shortfall by 2,592.50 per cent (Rs 174,320 million) to Rs 181,044 million yesterday. The value of yesterday’s swap settlements was Rs 156,325 million (USD 480.63 million). Yesterday’s FVMP debt amounted to Rs 3,023,742.63 million, a decrease of 0.59 per cent (Rs 17,995 million), over that of the previous market day Friday (20). This Rs 3,023,742.63 million FVMP debt of yesterday’s includes previous provisional advances to GoSL and Treasury (T)-Bill purchases from the primary market amounting to Rs 2,713,144,352,010 (Rs 2.7131 trillion/Rs 2,713,144.35 million) in full made by CBSL, which, as per IMF diktats, were converted to T-Bills and T-Bonds on 21 September 2023, with their maturities ranging from a minimum of 9 February 2024 to a maximum of 15 June 2038. Presuming that a year ago too those provisional advances and primary market T-Bill purchases made by CBSL amounted to at least Rs 2,713,144.35 million (though, in actual fact it would have had been much more!), then, CBSL’s FVMP debt would have had swelled to at least Rs 5,949,382.13 million (Rs 5.9494 trillion) on that day.  CBSL lacks transparency to make accurate deducements. Further, in making yesterday’s swaps deducements, swap settlements between CBSL and the market or the repayment of GoSL’s loan instalments to multilateral donors or the settlement of CBSL’s US dollar/foreign exchange (FX) sales to the market to stablise the rupee are discounted. CBSL’s daily open market operations (OMO) from which such deducements are made, lack transparency. GoSL’s FVMP debt in this instance is taken to be equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T-Bill and T-Bond holdings. However, when there are sufficient revenues, CBSL/GoSL can retire maturing T-Bills and T-Bonds without having those to be reissued to CBSL (the creditor), as GoSL and its agents (Ceylon Electricity Board, Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, etc.) are compensated for giving GoSL and its agents (debttr) credit previously, by being repaid their dues by the consumer and in turn to the CBSL, aided by high tax and utility bills, , thereby resulting in the retiring of such T-Bills and T-Bonds upon their maturities, leading to a reduction in such holdings by CBSL.  This, consequently, leads to a reduction in circulated money or money printing due to such actions, with such money going back to CBSL’s godowns and being removed from circulation, thereby nullifying demand-pull inflationary pressure. CBSL, at least historically, used to print rupees when GoSL and its agents do not have sufficient revenues/money to meet their commitments, or to buy the required FX from the country’s foreign reserves to meet foreign debt service commitments, in this instance to multilateral donor agencies. However, the danger in money printing (MP) is that if it enters the domestic market, it causes demand-pull inflationary pressure. Investing in T-Bills and T-Bonds is generally considered as being riskless, because, in the event GoSL is unable to repay such debt, CBSL is normally mandated to print demand pull inflationary money and repay such creditors. CBSL has the sole right to print rupees.  Nonetheless, the new CBSL Act has controlled CBSL’s money printing activities to a great extent. Conversions are based on Thursday’s (19) offer rate of the benchmark ‘spot’ which was Rs 325.25 to the dollar. Swaps between CBSL and GoSL are foreign reserves neutral. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days of trading. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and of its foreign reserves, deals in ‘spot’. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Rs 4B worth heroin haul seized
author: Author not found
Content: Five suspects aboard a multi-day fishing vessel were arrested in Dondra Point with over 200 kg of heroin with a street value of over Rs 4,000 million during a joint operation by the Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) and the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) yesterday (22). Including the latest seizure, the Sri Lanka Navy has held drugs with a gross street value of over Rs 15,160 million during operations mounted in 2023. According to the Sri Lanka Navy, the multi-day fishing craft was seized in a deep-sea operation conducted by the Intelligence Division of the SLN together with the PNB based on information derived from a coordinated intelligence operation. The drug-laden local multi-day fishing trawler was intercepted by SLCG Samudraraksha. The intercepted local multi-day fishing trawler was escorted to the Dondra fisheries harbour, where a careful search with the Sri Lanka Coast Guard revealed over 212 kg (including packages) of heroin and crystal methamphetamine (ice) were on board. The special operation mounted about 91 nautical miles (about 168 km) west of Galle, also led to the arrest of suspects aboard. Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, arrived at the Dondra fisheries harbour to personally inspect the seized consignment of narcotics. The Navy said they collaborate closely with the country’s law enforcement agencies, conducting regular operations in island waters with constant vigil to realise the national aspiration of eliminating the drug menace in Sri Lanka. On being brought ashore, the suspicious trawler underwent a thorough search where 160 packages of heroin, weighing about 180.8 kg (including packages), and 28 parcels of crystal methamphetamine, weighing around 31.5 kg (including packages), contained in 12 sacks were recovered. The suspects arrested in this operation are residents of Dondra and Kottegoda areas and are aged 26-53. The suspects, along with the stock of narcotics and the fishing trawler, were handed over to the Police Narcotics Bureau for onward legal action. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: PHIs to stage token strike today
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Health Inspectors’ Union threatened to launch a token strike today (23) over several demands. Union chief Upul Rohana said the strike aims to draw attention to the non-provision of solutions to issues faced by the Public Health Inspectors. One of the key concerns is the failure to increase the mileage rent and transport allowance provided for field duties. These allowances have not kept pace with the rising cost of living, fuel prices and motorcycle maintenance costs, leading to financial difficulties for PHIs, the union claims. “To express their grievances, the association is to engage in trade union action,” the Union head added. However, selected health institutions, such as the port, airport, blood bank, maternity hospitals, children’s hospital, the kidney units and training activities will not be hampered owing to the strike action, he added.

title: Cabinet will reject water tariff hike proposal – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Since there is no need to increase the water tariff at this juncture, Cabinet will not approve such a proposal, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. The Government admits that the increase in electricity tariffs was difficult for the public to bear at this time. But due to the current state of war between several countries, the price of imported materials has increased. Therefore, the Minister of Agriculture said it is regrettable that the public have to pay increase electricity tariffs due to this unfortunate situation. He however added that there was no need to increase the water tariff at this point of time. Therefore, the Minister also said if such a proposal is put forward to Cabinet, it will be rejected. Minister Amaraweera was speaking, while participating in a programme held in Agunakolapelassa recently, to distribute free maize needed for maize cultivation for the Maha season to farmers of the Hambantota district. Through the Small Scale Agribusiness Participation Programme (SAPP) under the Ministry of Agriculture, it has been decided to cultivate 40,000 acres of maize in the three districts of Anuradhapura, Moneragala and Hambantota this season. Steps have been taken to distribute the necessary maize seeds and urea fertiliser to farmers free of charge Rs 350 million is expected to be spent in this connection. The Minister said, “The war situation affecting the world has also affected our country. There is a story that rich countries get colds while the poor countries suffer from pneumonia. Similarly, due to the war between Russia and Ukraine and between Israel and Palestine, there is a danger that the price of imported goods too will increase.” “There were reports in the media that water bills would go up. But I say there is no need to increase water bills at this time. Therefore, if such a proposal is submitted to Cabinet, it will not be approved. The only option to get out of this predicament is for us to work together. If we work separately for political gain, it will only make us fall further into the abyss,” he added. “Increasing electricity tariffs is not a good thing. But in our country, most of the electricity is still produced by thermal power. Even though many areas have received rain these days, the hydropower plants have not yet started generating 100 per cent hydropower,” he added. “The CEB must also make some sacrifices. It is not reasonable to demand that only the public should make sacrifices all the time,” he further added. Therefore, he said everyone must work together to overcome these difficulties.

title: Consumers want concessionary period increased
author: Author not found
Content: Electricity consumers have urged the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to increase the 40-day concessionary period given to pay the electricity bill. The National Movement for Consumer Rights Protection (NMCRP) pointed out that consumers who used 180 units in 2022 paid a monthly bill of Rs 3,755 but were now compelled to pay around Rs 10,500 following two tariff increases this year and this is three times that of the tariff they paid before the revision. They have thus have made a plea to take their plight into consideration and give them a concessionary period of more than 40 days, beginning from the date on which they have to settle their bills. At a time when the country is experiencing a severe economic downturn and pushing the ordinary people into untold hardship paying a large sum of money at once remains a difficult task for these people, NMCRP’s Ranjith Withanage pointed out. Meanwhile, the CEB has issued red notices to 253,465 consumers who failed to pay the electricity tariff for January 2022 and there is an increase of 60 per cent in the issuing of red notices, which goes to show that the people were struggling to pay their electricity bills, the NMCRP said. Though the electricity tariff was increased, the CEB had not given consumers any concessionary period to settle their bills. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Landslide threat still persists in many areas – NBRO
author: Author not found
Content: As the inclement weather persists over most parts of the country the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has extended landslide early warning alerts to several districts in the Central Hill Country. Senior Scientist of the of NBRO’s Landslide Early Warning Centre Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera said the level two amber watch – landslide early warning alerts that have been issued to the Haldummulla and Haputale DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Badulla District, Walasmulla and Katuwana DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Hambantota district, Athuraliya, Malimbada, Thihagoda, Kamburupitiya, Kirinda Puhulwella, Akuressa, Pasgoda, Pitabeddara, Matara Four Gravets, Hakmana, Kotapola, Mulatiyana and Welipitiya DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matara district and Kuruwita, Ratnapura, Eheliyagoda, Weligepola, Kalawana, Openayake and Elapatha DS divisions and the surrounding area in the Ratnapura district will be in effective until the next notice. Accordingly, level one yellow – watch landslide early warning alerts that have been issued to Bandarawela and Passara DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Badulla district, Bope Poddala, Imaduwa, Elpitiya, Galle Four Gravets, Niyagama, Akmeemana, Nagoda, Yakkalamulla, Ambalangoda, Neluwa, Baddegama and Thawalama DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Galle district, Okewela and Beliatta DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Hambantota district, Ingiriya and Walallawita DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara district, Harispattuwa, Udapalatha, Udadumbara, Pasbage Korale, Udunuwara and Pathadumbara DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kandy district, Kotmale and Ambagamuwa DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Nuwara Eliya district and Imbulpe, Ayagama, Balangoda, Godakawela, Pelmadulla, Nivithigala, Kiriella, Kahawatta and Kolonna DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura district have been extended until the next notice, according to Dr. Senadeera. Dr. Senadeera added that depending on the rainfall the particular areas receive the decision whether to continue alerts or lift from the list or include other areas will be taken. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Two hundred victims file RTI requests
author: Author not found
Content: Two hundred persons, whose houses were damaged during the construction of the last stretch of the Central Expressway from Mirigama to Kurunegala, filed 400 Right to Information (RTI) requests yesterday (22). They sent these requests to both the Road Development Authority (RDA) and the relevant contractor company, 200 each. The purpose was to request information, including the damage assessment reports for their houses and related financial assessments, within 48 hours. The RTI requests sent to the RDA contain 18 questions, while those sent to the contractor company contain 16 questions. Sanjeewa Kulathilaka, a victim and activist of the Association of Victimised Families from the construction of Central Expressway, said over 400 houses were damaged during the construction of the Central Expressway, specifically the last stretch from Mirigama to Kurunegala. Some victims have not been compensated, while others received inadequate compensation, as low as Rs 5,000 or 10,000 for seriously damaged houses. Due to continuous complaints to the RDA, the Police and the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) falling on deaf ears, the people submitted 400 RTI requests under the Right to Information Act, he said. According to Section 25 (3) of the Right to Information Act, organisations must respond within 48 hours to requests related to citizens’ lives or personal freedom. Since some houses have further deteriorated due to rain, with cracks widening and walls at risk of collapsing, the RTI requests were filed under this particular section, Kulathilaka said. Meanwhile, an appeal related to Kulathilaka’s previous RTI request is scheduled at the Right to Information Commission as well. If no information is received within 48 hours regarding the 400 RTI requests, the residents plan to appeal to the designated officer, and if necessary, to the RTI Commission. Further, a hearing concerning an earlier complaint made by Kulathilaka to the HRCSL in 2020 is scheduled for 3 November. Additionally, a special team from the Ministry of Transport is set to visit Kurunegala tomorrow (24) to investigate a complaint by Kulathilaka. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: New policies to regulate beedi industry
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has decided to introduce a new set of policies to regulate the beedi industry and imports of beedi leaves to Sri Lanka. On the direction of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, a discussion was held with all relevant parties and stakeholders last week, under the chairmanship of Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake and thus, the formulation of the relevant policy has been assigned to the Ministry of Finance. It has also been suggested in the discussion to remove the Rs 5,000 cess presently imposed on a kg of imported beedi leaves. In addition to the cess, the Government also collects an amount of Rs 2 from each beedi stick produced. Even though the Excise Department has introduced this system, it was disclosed during this discussion that this system has not been implemented properly. Concerns were also raised at the discussion, claiming that due to the cess levied per kg of beedi leaves, a large number of beedi leaves are being smuggled into the country. Therefore, Ratnayake hopes that streamlining the beedi industry will help to streamline the activities of the Excise Department of Sri Lanka as well.  Since about 700 people are presently engaged in the beedi industry, it has been decided to remove the cess charged on imports of beedi leaves and instead increase the tax amount charged on one beedi stick, from Rs 2 to Rs 3.50. This decision has been taken so that even if the rest of the tax is removed, the income will not decrease in any way. The now revised set of policies will be further discussed with Minister of Finance, President Ranil Wickremesinghe prior to implementation. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: UNP effects major changes to Party Constitution
author: Author not found
Content: The Constitution of the UNP was amended at its Convention held in Colombo, bringing structural changes to the Party. A significant amendment allows the UNP to maintain an online presence and engage actively in social media platforms, thus facilitating the digital transformation of the party. The President emphasised the need for the UNP to evolve into a technologically adept and intelligent party, aligning itself with the broader vision of building both a smart nation and a smart party. Powers will be transferred to the party’s Working Committee from the Executive Committee, according to party leader Ranil Wickremesinghe. The number of members in the Working Committee is to be reduced under the new amendments. “There is no need for a large Working Committee now as the party will have an Executive Committee which will have more than 100 members,” Wickremesinghe said. Also, the party will have a High Posts Committee which will be responsible for deciding on tactics. “The UNP will become a digital political party with the introduction of digital groups. Any member of the party can form digital groups after obtaining approval from the party hierarchy. Digital groups can come up at constituency level, district level and at the national level,” Wickremesinghe added. “New leaders should be ready to take over the party before long,” the party leader stressed further.

title: Lankan woman’s body recovered from collapsed Lebanon building
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) said the remains of a 65-year-old Sri Lankan woman was recovered from the rubble of a destroyed building in Lebanon on Saturday. According to the Bureau the victim has been identified as I. Premalatha of Matara. On Tuesday, 17 October, the Sri Lankan Embassy in Beirut confirmed that a Sri Lankan woman was among several individuals trapped under the rubble after the collapse of a residential building in Lebanon. The five-storey building in Mansourieh, Lebanon, collapsed on 16 October, leaving only three of its floors standing. The building owners have said the structure had shown cracks post-Beirut explosion but was promptly repaired, while Brigadier General Raymond Khattar, Director-General of Lebanese Civil Defence attributed the tragedy to two failed columns and recent flooding.

title: Sri Lankan Neurologists emerge World Champions
author: Author not found
Content: A team of Sri Lankan Neurologists emerged world champions in the ‘Tournament of the Minds’ Neurology Quiz, organised by the World Federation of Neurology, at the World Neurology Congress held in Montreal, Canada. The Sri Lankan team bagged the ‘World Cup’ in Neurology out of 136 nations. The members of the successful Sri Lankan team were Prof. Thashi Chang, Dr. A.T. Alibhoy, Dr. Senaka Bandusena and Dr. Manjula Caldera. Sri Lanka were the runners-up in the 2019‘ Tournament of the ‘Minds’. The idea behind the tournament is to produce a series of questions on neurological topics with an entertaining as well as educational element.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President vows to position SL as Smart Nation
author: Author not found
Content: Addressing the Special General Convention of the UNP held at the Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium on Saturday (21), President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised his commitment to bolstering the country’s economy by positioning Sri Lanka as a Smart Nation. The President outlined the timeline for upcoming elections in line with the constitutional provisions, detailing that the presidential election is slated for the following year, followed by parliamentary election. Further, local government elections are expected in the first half of 2025. The theme for this year’s UNP Anniversary Convention was ‘Smart Country – 2048.’ The concept behind this vision is of an intelligent and prosperous Sri Lanka, where every citizen recognises their potential, upholds virtuous goals, and embraces diversity while harnessing modern technology and nature to create a nation of adept and resourceful individuals. The ‘Smart Country’ concept envisions the creation of a prosperous nation. Departing from conventional party politics vying for power, the main objective of this year’s UNP Special Convention was to adopt a nation-centric approach to reorganise the party for this purpose. Party leader, President Wickremesinghe also presented an amended party constitution designed to facilitate this transformation. A significant amendment allows the UNP to maintain an online presence and engage actively in social media platforms, thus facilitating the digital transformation of the party. The President emphasised the need for the UNP to evolve into a technologically adept and intelligent party, aligning itself with the broader vision of building both a smart nation and a smart party. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, leader of the People’s United Front, extended his best wishes to the UNP Special Convention. The Sugathadasa Stadium was packed to capacity, with attendees representing various parts of the country, including the North and East. The event was inaugurated with immense pride.

title: Constructionof SL Temple in China’s Henan Province to Resume
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe announced the commencement of the construction of a temple and a Stupa in Henan Province, China, designed to embody traditional Sri Lankan architectural elements reminiscent of the historic ‘White Horse’ Temple. This temple complex is recognised as China’s first Buddhist shrine. The decision to undertake this project was made during a recent discussion held in Beijing, in which President Wickremesinghe engaged with the head of the ‘White Horse’ Temple, His Holiness Yin Lee. The initial stone for this temple’s construction was laid during the tenure of Ranil Wickremesinghe as Prime Minister, with Karu Jayasuriya, the then Speaker, officiating the ceremony. Regrettably, the project had been put on hold, but now,under the leadershipof President Wickremesinghe, it is set to recommence, with new plans in the making. The President also emphasised that this temple will house copies of Buddhist Pali scriptures, which were brought from Sri Lanka to China by the renowned monk Faxian. These invaluable scriptures will find their new home in this temple, marking a significant cultural exchange between the two nations.

title: 523 Navy recruits pass out in Boossa
author: Author not found
Content: In a vibrant ceremony, 523 recruits from the 252nd intake of the Sri Lanka Navy’s Regular and Volunteer Forces passed out at the main parade Grounds of SLNS Nipuna, Boossa on 20 October. Among these recruits, 423 belonged to the Regular Force, while the remaining 100 were from the Volunteer Force. Commandant Naval Infantry, Rear Admiral Jalaj Ponnamperuma was the chief guest, at the invitation of Commandant and Commanding Officer of SLNS Nipuna, Captain Chaminda Gunarathna. The recruits who demonstrated exceptional performance during their basic training received awards from the Chief Guest. Accordingly, woman recruit W.M.U.S. Wijekoon won the award for the Best Recruit of the 252nd intake and Woman Recruit R.A.C.H. Rathnayake won the award for the highest aggregate in all subjects. Meanwhile, Recruit B.M.T. Didulanga won the award for the Best Marksman. The awards for the Best Sportsperson were won by Women Recruit S.A.I.M. Samaraweera and Recruit M.M.M.J. Sanjeewa. The ‘Walagamba’ Division was selected as the Best Division of the 252nd intake. The passing-out parade featured a ceremonial guard made up of women sailors. This was also the first time, not only in the history ofthe Sri Lanka Navy but also the Tri-Forces that the Ceremonial Guard of a passing-out parade consisted of female representation. In his address to the recruits, Rear Admiral Ponnamperuma congratulated them on their successful completion of training. Further, he emphasised the importance of embodying the qualities of a proficient and disciplined sailor to effectively serve in a technologically advanced Navy. This dedication is crucial in safeguarding the motherland and ensuring that the hard-won freedom is passed down to future generations, he added. Rear Admiral Ponnamperuma also emphasised the Navy’s crucial role in safeguarding the extensive maritime territory under its jurisdiction and stressed the importance of protecting both maritime and fishing communities in distress within Sri Lanka’s Search and Rescue Region. He emphasised that newly passed -out sailors ought to employ the discipline instilled during their training and wholeheartedly dedicate themselves to upholding the Navy’s responsibilities in the years ahead. Finally, he also took the opportunity to express his gratitude to the parents of the newly-passed-out recruits, for giving their consent to their children to join the Navy.  Newly-passed-out recruits added splendour to the ceremony through their drill display in addition to the dazzling performances by Navy Band and Cultural Troupe. Members of Venerable Maha Sangha, Commander Southern Naval Area, Rear Admiral Chinthaka Kumarasinghe, Deputy Area Commander, Commodore Jayantha Bandara, senior officers from the Navy Headquarters and Southern Naval Command, officers and sailors of SLNS Nipuna as well as parents of newly passed-out naval personnel were in attendance.

title: Presidential, Parliamentary Elections Slated for 2024
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe outlined the timeline for upcoming elections in line with the constitutional provisions, detailing that the presidential election is slated for 2024, followed by parliamentary election. Further, local government elections are expected in the first half of 2025. The President was speaking at the Special General Convention of the UNP held at Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium on Saturday (21). “Both the presidential election and the general election will be held next year while the provincial council election will be held in early 2025,” the President said. “Around 50 per cent of the voting population in the country reject all political parties. They want a new political culture. I will be appointing a commission headed by retired Chief Justice Priyasath Dep to look into political parties. There are a large number of political parties in the country. No one knows who leads them. The new commission will look into the details of the parties. Some parties are influenced by persons who offer them large sums of money. The commission will probe all these and make recommendations regarding parties in six weeks. I would like to know the stand of political parties on this move,” he said. “We will also work towards building a smart country. I will announce plans for building a smart nation in the Budget Speech next month. I accepted the presidency to revive the economy. We have taken measures in this regard. The county has become stable once again. The Cabinet which comprises SLPP members have supported me in this endeavour. Also, Opposition MPs like Harsha de Silva and Patali Champika Ranawaka support me through their acts as chairpersons of two parliamentary committees,” he added.

title: Family of three injured in shooting
author: Author not found
Content: A family of three was injured in a shooting incident late Saturday (21) night. The incident took place at around 7.30 p.m. in Ahungalla. A 32-year-old local businessman, residing in the Galvehara area and his wife aged 27 were travelling home with their four-month-old infant when an unidentified group hiding in a cinnamon plantation, by the Uragaha Road in Ahungalla, opened fire at the vehicle. Despite the 32-year-old driver being shot in the mouth and the infant being shot in the foot, the couple had continued the journey home and later on was admitted to the Balapitiya Base Hospital. Even though the injured are not in a critical condition, due to the severity of the injuries the father and the infant were later admitted to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. Speaking to Ceylon Today Police Media Spokesperson SSP Nihal Thalduwa said that the law enforcement agencies have observed an increase in gang related violence in the area in the past few years and that their networks have extended considerably.  This incident could possibly be related to a conflict between organised criminal gangs. SSP Thalduwa further said even though the victim has no affiliation to acriminal gang, he is related to some such persons and so the motive behind the shooting could possibly be a revenge attack from an opposing gang. This, he said is how orgaised criminal gangs operate. Ahungalla Police is conducting further investigations into the incident. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: NIA nabs human trafficking kingpin
author: Author not found
Content: Sleuths of the National Investigation Agency (NIA) of India nabbed the kingpin of a human trafficking racket involved in an attempt to send 61 Sri Lankans abroad illegally after bringing them to India in 2021. The accused, identified as Mohamed Imran Khan (39) alias Haja Najerbheeden, a native of Ramanathpuram, was secured from his hideout in Theni district by the absconder tracker team (ATT) of the NIA from Bengaluru. The NIA said it had been tracking his movements for a few months. The NIA said Mohamed Imran Khan was a smuggler and fugitive wanted by several investigation agencies. “He, along with a Sri Lankan national named Eesan, formerly associated with the LTTE devised a plan to illegally transport 61 Sri Lankan nationals from the island to various locations in Tamil Nadu. They lured these individuals with false promises, including the prospect of obtaining legitimate documentation for emigration to Canada and securing employment,” said the NIA. NIA registered a case in 2021 after the Tamil Nadu Police’s Q branch secured 23 Sri Lankan nationals and four agents in Madurai, which led to the detention of another 38 Sri Lankan nationals in Mangaluru. So far, the NIA has arrested 13 suspects in the case and filed a charge sheet against five named Dhinakaran alias Ayya, Kasi Viswanathan, Rasool, Satham Ushen and Abdul Muheetu. “Investigations revealed that Imran Khan played a pivotal role in a broader conspiracy involving international human trafficking. He acted as the main conduit responsible for transporting Sri Lankan nationals from their home country to India and subsequently to other nations,” said the NIA. (ToI)

title: Caring for Kanneliya
author: Author not found
Content: Richer in biodiversity than the famous Sinharaja rainforest – according to a National Conservation Review (NCR) done in 1997 – Kanneliya has gained popularity over the years due to its numerous varieties of animals and plants; some of which are found only in this jungle.     The forest complex was designated as a biosphere reserve in 2004 by UNESCO and is the last large remaining rainforest in the country other than Sinharaja. The Kanneliya rainforest is home to more than a 100 species of animals, birds, reptiles, amphibians and butterflies and has over the years remained undisturbed. The area is covered by a natural high-forest ecosystem consisting of several forest types, mainly lowland tropical forest, wet semi-evergreen forest, sub-montane tropical wet semi-evergreen forest, and montane tropical wet-evergreen forest. Kanneliya, Dediyagala, and Nakiyadeniya (KDN) forest reserves are located in the south-western part of Sri Lanka, east of Galle. The KDN complex of forests occupies the area between two rivers, the Gin River and the Nilwala River and consists of a series of ridges and valleys. Over 17 per cent of the wet zone flora is confined to this area where the KDN forests are the most prominent. This region has been identified as floristically one of the richest areas in South Asia.  However in recent times, Kanneliya has lost some of its prime biodiversity but a project initiated by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), ‘Restoration of a Degraded Rainforest in a Highly Biodiversity Area in Kanneliya Rainforest (Life Project)’ that commenced in 2018 has finally seen an improvement in the lost biodiversity of Kanneliya. “To develop biodiversity credit accrual system the Forest Department tried to restore this area 40 years back with Eucalyptus. However that project has failed leaving behind a few stunted Eucalyptus trees. Biodiversity Sri Lanka developed a project with the technical assistance of IUCN to restore this degraded land. IUCN implemented the restoration programme in collaboration with the Forest Department and Biodiversity Sri Lanka,” Senior Programme Officer at IUCN, Naalin Perera explained.  “We are in the halfway stage. We developed the methodology in 2017, started in 2018, continued until 2023. We did a survey and identified the species in the rainforest. We selected the plant species in order to match the species in the rainforest.  We have to directly introduce the plant species because the rainforest species are very sensitive,” Perera explained. The site selected for the restoration project by those involved can be described as a degraded rainforest. “The site has been cleared for cultivation and abandoned subsequently resulting in the area being colonised by the pioneer fern species Dicranopteris linearis (Kekeilla). The site has remained in this degraded condition for many decades,” Perera said. Overall aim of the project is to restore highly degraded rainforest using principles of restoration ecology to enhance its ecological functions, habitat quality, species diversity and its capacity to provide biodiversity and ecosystem services that is in close approximation to what has prevailed there before it has been converted to its present state. In the first few years they had to work with the species that tolerated the degraded conditions. Later on when there was a satisfactory shade, other rainforest species were gradually introduced. Based on the progress achieved through the adaptive approaches introduced in the second and third years, an intensive planting methodology was developed to restore heavily degraded rainforest area which was invaded by Kekeilla. The project work included; the removal of Kekilla vegetation, facilitating the natural regeneration of native species (Veraniya/Mahabovitiya) and increasing the planting pit size, application of organic and selected inorganic fertilisers, introduction of soil conservation and improvement methods, introduction of plant protection methodologies, maintaining soil moisture in dry season, watering and introduction of Nitrogen-fixing native herb (legume) species, the introduction of pioneer and shade plants, and using local knowledge on seed collection, germination and plant protection and land preparation. The project wasn’t without its hardships such as heavy rain and/or prolonged drought interrupting the progress, slow growth of plants due to poor soil condition, and plant destruction due to large and small herbivores intrusion. The success of any ecological restoration depends heavily on planning. Yet there can be many unexpected challenges. Monitoring is a critical need as ecological restoration takes time. Progress is not linear but exponential. Among the rich biodiversity are endemic freshwater fish species that can be found from the Kanneliya streams. The Gin Ganga, Udugam Ela and Kanneliya Ela are the most popular and suitable places for spotting ground water fishes in the Kanneliya Forest Reserve. Kanneliya consists of Hora trees and other important tree species. There is a high proportion of endemism among the identified woody plants. Numerous medicinal plants such as Weniwelgata (Concinium fenestratum), Kothala Himbutu (Salacia reticulate), and Rasakinda (Tinospora cordifoli), Kuda Hadaya (Lycopodium Squarrosum), and Maha Hadaya (Lycopodium phlegmaria) are among the rare plants the forest complex harbours.   Sri Lanka has a variety of endemic lobsters and endemic bird species; some of which are found in Kanneliya Forest Reserve. The forest is home to the leopards, wild boar, pangolin, meeminna, porcupine, fishing cat, Southern Purple-faced Leaf Monkey, geckos, butterflies, snakes, mammals, lizards, many other endemic reptiles, and amphibians, and a variety of flora.        There are around 78 villages surrounding the KDN forests. According to historical records the Nugegoda, Rajagala and Dediyagala hermitages are also situated within this forest. “IUCN was initially involved and then we worked with the Forest Department and with the local community. This is one of the best partnership projects. It is the Private, Public and People (PPP) participation project. Biodiversity Sri Lanka funded the project. We can’t stop this now. We have to continue, if not it can revert back. Rainforests are very tall and layered. We can see the rainforest is growing there,” Perera explained. By Risidra Mendis

title: SJB’s MannapPeruma suspended for four weeks
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena suspended Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Ajith Mannapperuma from attending Parliament sittings for a period of four weeks starting yesterday (19). The suspension followed a tense situation that unfolded when Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles tabled answers during the Questions for Oral Answers round. Minister Alles explained that he had to table the answers as the given time for answering the questions had expired due to the heated verbal exchange over the service extension of the Inspector General of Police (IGP). The Opposition strongly opposed this decision, demanding that the Minister answer the questions. A group of MPs, including Mannapperuma, then approached the Well and began protesting. During this commotion, Mannapperuma approached the Mace, insinuating that he might move it. The escalating tensions led to the Speaker suspending the sittings for 10 minutes. Upon resuming the sittings the Speaker announced Mannapperuma’s four-week suspension from Parliament, citing his unruly behaviour as the reason. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: A 15-hour water cut on Saturday
author: Author not found
Content: A 15-hour water cut will be implemented tomorrow (21) in the areas that come under the Ambatale Water Supply project. As the essential improvement works in water supply are to be carried out on the Ambatale Water Treatment Plant, under the Energy Conservation Project, the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) announced. Accordingly, a 15-hour water cut will be in effect from 5.00 p.m on 21 October to 8.00 a.m on 22 October, according the NWSDB officials. The public and the business establishment in the areas such as Colombo 11, 12, 13, 14 and 15 are advised to make pre-arrangements to store enough water to be used until the supply is resumed, Water Board stated. People living in these areas and the business establishments operating in those areas are asked to contact the NWSDB over the hotline 1939 for further information if required. (NJ)
