title: No fuel shortage threat – Chanaka
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Power and Energy D.V. Chanaka stressed that there is no threat of a fuel shortage and emphasised that the necessary tenders, for fuel import up to June 2024, have been completed, ensuring an uninterrupted fuel supply until that time. He also highlighted that by entrusting the supply of fuel to Sinopec Company of China, the Government expects to save more than USD 500 million in foreign exchange. State Minister Chanaka made these statements during a press briefing held yesterday (19), at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) under the theme ‘Collective Path to a Stable Country’. The State Minister further said, “Recently, our country faced a significant fuel crisis, with fuel shortages and long queues at gas stations. However, we successfully resolved this situation within a short period. When considering the month of January 2022, it’s worth noting that crude oil prices in the world market were relatively low, with a barrel of crude oil priced at USD 50. In the following months, it increased to USD 65 and later, due to various factors including the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, it reached USD 100 per barrel. Subsequently, it decreased to USD 80. This year, after a year-and-a-half of gradual increases, the price of crude oil has slightly decreased. Especially, in the first six days of this month, the world market saw a decrease of about 4% in crude oil prices. However, recent events in the Gaza Strip caused a 4% increase in fuel prices globally, nullifying the relief we expected from falling crude oil prices. Though Israel and Palestine aren’t significant fuel producers or distributors in the world market, Iran’s potential involvement in the situation adds to the uncertainty in the global market. Despite the conflict in the Gaza Strip, Sri Lanka’s fuel imports have not been disrupted. Tenders for fuel supply have been awarded up to June of next year, ensuring a steady supply of fuel in the country. Nevertheless, some uncertainties persist. In addition, we have allowed three other suppliers, including China’s Sinopec, to provide fuel to our country. Sinopec has already commenced operations in Sri Lanka, resulting in savings of approximately USD 40 million in foreign exchange per season. It is anticipated that these measures will contribute to saving over USD 500 million in foreign exchange annually. Furthermore, these actions have helped reduce the risk to the dollar reserves maintained by the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation and efforts are being made to pass on these benefits to consumers. Notably, we have established a reserve of USD 200 million for oil purchases for the first time.” (GW)

title: China reaffirms commitment to support SL’s debt optimisation
author: Author not found
Content: Chinese Finance Minister, Liu Kun, has reaffirmed China’s commitment to extend comprehensive support for the implementation of a medium-term and long-term programme that is mutually beneficial to both parties and aimed at optimising Sri Lanka’s debt. Kun conveyed this commitment during bilateral discussions held last morning (19) in Beijing with President Ranil Wickremesinghe.  According to the PMD, Minister Liu Kun emphasised that China has a profound understanding of the economic challenges confronting Sri Lanka and commended the progress and measures Sri Lanka has taken thus far to address the on-going economic crisis. Furthermore, he expressed China’s unwavering commitment to providing robust support for the enhancement of the necessary infrastructure crucial for Sri Lanka’s development. The Chinese Finance Minister also highlighted the in-depth discussions that transpired regarding financial interactions between Sri Lanka and China, underscoring the collaboration with international organisations closely associated with China, aimed at furnishing additional support to Sri Lanka. President Wickremesinghe expressed his profound appreciation for China’s consistent support as Sri Lanka endeavours to overcome economic challenges. Discussions also delved into the programme designed to spur economic recovery and foster the creation of a competitive, digitally advanced and environmentally-friendly economy in Sri Lanka. In attendance during this significant meeting were Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka, Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe and President’s Private Secretary Sandra Perera.

title: Govt to set up ‘State School Nutrition Support Fund’ – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has taken a policy decision to set up a ‘State School Nutrition Support Fund’ by the beginning of next year, as a measure to provide a midday meal to primary students in State sector schools, Education MinisterDr. Susil Premajayantha said.  Speaking at the School Meals Coalition Global Summit, an initiative of the World Food Programme (WFP), held in Paris, France on 18 and 19 October, the Minister further said, the draft legislation has already been drawn by the Legal Draftsman’s Department. “In Sri Lanka, there are 10,135 public schools and about 300 international schools and 110 private schools. In all the 10,135 schools we have a 4.1 million student population in Primary, Junior Secondary and Senior Secondary grades. “In the Primary sections, we have a 1.6 million student population. At the moment, the Government is committed, through the yearly National Budget, to allocate USD 61 million to provide one million students with a midday meal. We are planning to increase the number up to 1.6 million students, covering all primary students by 2024. And by 2030, we hope to cover all 4.1 million public school students, by increasing the Budget allocation to USD 204 million,” the Minister explained.  He further said, at the moment, the Government is being supported by the World Food Programme, USAID and the corporate sector of the country and some NGOs to carry out the midday meal programme. Minister Premajayantha, addressing the Global Summit, elaborated that a salient feature in Sri Lanka for the past 76 years is that from Grade one to the First Degree, the education is free. “We distribute free text books from Grade one to 12, and we also provide free uniform materials for all 4.1 million students.” He emphasised that amidst all its constraints, the Government is still committed to providing midday meals to students. “We have a health policy for students, because in Sri Lanka, our education administrative structure is parallel to the Health M inistry structure. So, at the provincial level, divisional and regional levels, we have a system to coordinate between health authorities and educational authorities. “Every year, for primary students, we have health screening, where we measure their height, their weight and we know exactly what the vulnerable areas are and where we need to pay more attention. “We are going forward with these and the Government is committed to continue providing these. “In Sri Lanka, the literacy rate is 93%. The enrolment to Grade one by the completion of five years of age is almost 99%. Except for the students who need special education, all other students get enrolled to schools at the age of five. And, the primary completion rate is also the same. Only at the Ordinary Level stage you find a three to five per cent dropout rate.”

title: Public servants will be reinstated in previous positions – PM
author: Author not found
Content: All public sector employees, who submitted nominations as candidates for the Local Government Election 2023, will be reinstated in their previous positions, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena informed Parliament yesterday (19). He said, “We have chosen to ensure fairness for State workers who filed nominations for the Local Government Polls, by reassigning them to their previous office roles.” Additionally, State Minister Janaka Wakkumbura said, State sector employees desiring to withdraw from the election will be permitted to do so. “We will introduce amendments to the Local Government Election Ordinance to facilitate withdrawals for those who wish to do it,” he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Customs seizes beedi leaves declared as coriander
author: Author not found
Content: Two containers of beedi leaves that had been declared as Coriander seeds have been taken into custody by the Central Intelligence Bureau of Sri Lanka Customs. According to State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, who inspected the two containers which contained the beedi leaves at the Orugodawatta Rank Container Terminal, only a tax of around Rs 300,000 has been charged due to the shipment being falsely labelled as coriander, when in fact the shipment should have been charged a tax amount of Rs 70 million. Minister Siyambalapitiya also commended the Customs Officials for their exceptional skills that helped to detect the containers. He further said, a high profiled professional has continuously exerted pressure on the customs officials for the release of the containers and that he has asked the Bribery Commission for necessary steps to be taken to conduct an investigation into the matter. Replying to questions raised by the medi, regarding the corruption and flaws in the Sri Lanka Customs, Minister Siyambalapitiya he assured that prompt action will be taken against officials who have has taken bribes and continue to let importers to get away with falsified documents and at the same time he will ensure the safety of the Customs officers who work with “exceptional commitment to increase the country’s income,” as much as possible. According to a Customs official, even under the ongoing importation restrictions and flaws within the tax collecting system, the Sri Lanka Customs is expected to bring in Rs 783 billion this year, almost Rs 500 billion less that the predicted amount. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: One killed, 18 injured as bus falls off precipice
author: Author not found
Content: A bus travelling from Alawwa to Narammala fell off a precipice in the Dampelessa area of Narammala, killing a 51-year-old woman and injuring 18 others yesterday (19). The incident occurred between 11:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. when the bus travelling at high speed, went out of control and veered off the road on the outskirts of Narammala. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Police Media Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said, the injured were admitted to the Narammala District Hospital and seven of the 18 injured were transferred to Kurunegala Teaching Hospital. SSP Thalduwa also said, the patients are recovering and that Narammala Police are carrying out further investigations into the incident. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: USD 1.565B Port City deal signed
author: Author not found
Content: A cooperation framework agreement was signed in Beijing among the Colombo Port City Economic Commission, China Harbour Engineering Company, Browns Investments and Hunan Construction Investment Group for the Phase II development of the Colombo Port City project, with a total investment of USD 1.565 billion. The agreement was signed on Tuesday, 17 October. This significant milestone occurred during President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s visit to the Belt and Road Forum in Beijing. Yesterday (19), he engaged in crucial discussions concerning the Colombo Port City’s development. During these discussions, the President focused on key aspects, including shaping the Port City into an international financial centre, establishing specialised financial regulations for the Port City, and creating a unique judicial and arbitration framework applicable exclusively to the Port City. The President’s Media Division (PMD) also reported that President Wickremesinghe held productive talks with representatives from major Chinese corporations such as China Communications Construction Corporation, Sinopec Company and BYD Company. These discussions highlighted the exploration of potential investment opportunities and avenues within Sri Lanka. The conversations covered various sectors, including advancing Sri Lanka’s transportation systems through electrification, electric vehicle assembly and electric train services. The corporate representatives of these companies expressed their unwavering commitment to providing optimal support for the growth of Sri Lanka’s economy and seizing the investment opportunities the country has to offer. (SRM)

title: IMF must be informed why people opting to buy moonshine– Chamara Sampath
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister Chamara Sampath Dasanayake stressed  in Parliament yesterday (19) that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) should be made aware of the Sri Lankan context regarding liquor consumption. He pointed out that due to a significant increase in taxes on alcohol, the consumption of moonshine has surged, decreasing the liquor revenue to the Government. Dasanayake explained that the government has substantially raised taxes on a specific brand of liquor primarily consumed by the working class, especially labourers. “The government, in compliance with IMF conditions, has imposed a Rs 2,000 tax increase on this particular brand of liquor. We should inform the IMF that when taxes are raised to such levels, people in Sri Lanka tend to refrain from buying legal liquor. Consequently, liquor sales have declined, and people, especially those in the estate sector, have turned to moonshine. It is essential for the IMF to be informed about this unique Sri Lankan context,” he emphasised. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Parliament to debate Gaza conflict
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee of Parliamentary Business yesterday (19) decided to hold an adjournment debate today (20) on the ongoing Israel-Palestine conflict, urging the United Nations and all other parties to stop the conflict and declare an immediate ceasefire. The adjournment motion will be presented by MP Udaya Gammanpila and seconded by a Government MP. The debate is scheduled to take place today (20), from 9.30 a.m. to 5.30 p.m. The Committee of Parliamentary Business convened yesterday (19), under the chairmanship of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Indian Navy’s ALH arrives to train SLAF pilots
author: Author not found
Content: Indian Navy’s Advanced Light Helicopter (ALH) arrived at the SLAF base in Katunayake yesterday (19) for training of Sri Lanka Air Force Pilots and Sri Lanka Navy ships on ship borne helicopter operations. The training is planned to familiarise SLAF Pilots to the ALH and provide co-pilot experience. Further, the training team is also scheduled to undertake extensive Deck Landing Practice onboard a Sri Lanka Navy Ship during the period. The training deployment is in line with the capacity building initiative of the Government of India amongst its neighbours as part of ‘Neighbourhood First Policy’.  The engagement would also foster closer interoperability and seamless conduct of coordinated Maritime Operations. The deployment of the indigenous ALH helicopter in Sri Lanka was undertaken from 23-31 March 2022 for the training of SLAF pilots for co-pilot experience during Deck Landings and Landing training for SLN personnel, which is a niche capability to achieve. The high level of understanding and coordination between the Armed Forces of the two countries further cement the close relations achieved through millennia-old friendly ties between the two neighbours.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Devananda transforming fisheries sector into forex earner
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda claimed that he has taken every possible step to transform fisheries into a prime industry that will bring in more foreign exchange. The Fisheries Ministry has drafted many fisheries related development projects in collaboration with the foreign investors, and collaborating with Indian investors is also one of the prime focuses of his Ministry. Devananda said that every arrangement has been made to establish seaweed farms in collaboration with the Indian investors. Devananda recently met a delegation of Indians, at the Fisheries Ministry, who are willing to invest in fisheries. He said that he is enthusiastically waiting to provide all kinds of support to the Indian investers to resolve the problems they are facing while engaging in the seaweed cultivation in the aforementioned regions. Devananda said that he brought to the attention of Indian investors that the Indian based Algae (Pvt) Ltd has been engaging in seaweed cultivation in the Jaffna, Kilinohchi and Mannar Districts and currently more than 800 rural folk have been employed there and they earn from Rs 50,000 to Rs 80,000 per month. Devananda said that Sri Lanka is conducive to start Agar fish farms as there are ample opportunities to start such farms in any part of the country. The investors had brought to the attention of Minister Devananda that various problems emerge when obtaining the licence to start seaweed farms in the respective areas and sought the Minister’s assistance to resolve it. “As a Minister in charge of fisheries I have taken every possible action to develop the aquaculture industry of this country while resolving the problems that emerge while engaging in cultivation activities. Fisheries Ministry Secretary Indu Ratnayake, scientists from the National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA) and National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) and the officials of Mannar Algie Seaweed farm were also present at the discussion. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Medical Camp for Teachers at Ananda College
author: Author not found
Content: The annual Medical Camp 2023, for Present and Past Teachers, will be held on Sunday, 22 October 2023 at Ananda College premises, Colombo 10, from 9.00 a.m. Over 300 teachers will participate in this event, which is organised by the ‘Old Anandians 75-80 Group’ with the support of the ‘Old Anandians Medical Guild’ and the ‘Old Anandians 125 Anniversary Group’. Over 80 Doctors, including consultants will attend this camp which provides services such as Blood Testing, ECG, Eye camp, Dental Clinic, Cancer detection, Physiotherapy and Ayurveda Treatment. All Past and Present Teachers of Ananda College are invited for this camp.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: Indian Naval Ship Airavat, a Shardul-class Tank Landing Ship (TLS), arrived in Colombo on 18 October. Commanding Officer of the vessel, Commander Rindu Babu, called on Commander Western Naval Area, Rear Admiral T.S.K. Perera during the visit. In line with the Government of India’s ‘Neighbourhood First’ Policy, Assistant Chief of Naval Staff – Foreign Cooperation, Indian Navy, Rear Admiral Nirbhay Bapna handed over valuable Machinery test and trial equipment including machinery items for Sri Lanka Navy on a grant by the Indian Government to Director General of Engineering, Sri Lanka Navy, Rear Admiral (E) K.W.A.R.I. Ranasinghe, in a ceremony held onboard the ship on 18 October. The timely availability of spares would ensure optimal-operational availability of the SLN platforms. The efforts of the Indian Navy are in keeping with its core ideology of ‘Bridges of Friendship’, towards strengthening its relations with friendly neighbours. Popular

title: AHP urges MPs to unite and resolve State health sector issues
author: Author not found
Content: The Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) urged the Government and Opposition to set aside their differences and unite to resolve the current issues facing the State health service. AHP President, Ravi Kumudesh yesterday (19) said that to have only a group of medical doctors in Parliament “uniting to resolve the issues in the State health service” was merely way of hoodwinking the masses. It would only help safeguard themselves rather than safeguarding public interest. Rather than changing the system and protecting the people, they would only save their own species, he said alleging that the problem in the State Health Care System had been created by poor management, and the lack of decision-making. All fraud and corruption were legitimised through the system. While 99% of the Health Service comprised medical practitioners “we cannot expect the doctors who are politicians to do anything to protect the service, Kumudesh lamented The AHP President urged the group of parliamentarians to gather people who could think in a modern way and who had mastered management methods. Those who know information technology and have good management skills and experience should be given the opportunity, he said.  Kumudesh noted that the Health system had not failed due to Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, but due to the officials and companies that were corrupt. The procurement system itself encourages people to steal, cheat, bribe, and take commissions, he alleged.  The AHP President held former officials and former ministers for the corruption in the State health service.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SL Close to Reaching IMF Staff-Level Agreement – Semasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is close to reaching a vital staff-level agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to get funding, while it’s also assessing debt restructuring terms from foreign holders of its dollar bonds, according to State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe. “There are discussions on revenue and other clarifications are being made,” Semasinghe told Bloomberg on Wednesday (18), adding that “we are confident of reaching a staff-level agreement soon.” The move will help unlock another tranche of a USD 3 billion package from the multilateral lender, supporting recovery in the island nation after a default last year. Sri Lanka has been pushing to agree terms for restructuring debt owed to China, India, Paris Club and foreign bondholders to bring indebtedness down to levels the IMF finds acceptable. After concluding domestic debt restructuring and agreeing tentative terms with China Exim Bank, the focus is now on how much progress the nation can make in talks with other official creditors, as well as bondholders who submitted a proposal that included a 20 per cent haircut and new “macro-linked bonds” last week. On the bondholder proposal, Sri Lanka’s adviser Lazard “will look at it and evaluate comparability,” said Semasinghe. Discussions with China continue, “and our principle will be to be transparent and it will be comparable,” while negotiations with the official creditor committee are also ongoing, he said. (Bloomberg)

title: Sri Lanka struggles to meet IMF Commitments, faces transparency deficit: Verité
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is facing mounting challenges in meeting its commitments under the 17th programme with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), according to the latest update from ‘IMF Tracker,’ a platform developed by Verité Research. The report reveals that out of the 71 trackable commitments due for completion by the end of September 2023, Sri Lanka has successfully fulfilled only 40. What’s more concerning is that the country has reached its lowest point in terms of both performance and transparency since the programme began in March. This decline is attributed to approximately 30% of the commitments scheduled for completion by the end of September having an unknown status, while three of the four commitments mandating increased governmental transparency were left unmet, Verité Research in a statement said. This situation exposes a concerning ‘twin deficit in transparency’: the growth of opacity in the programme’s progress and the failure to meet IMF commitments calling for enhanced government transparency. The report indicated that the number of commitments with unknown statuses has spiked to an all-time high of approximately 30%, compared to around 20% in August. This growing lack of transparency poses a risk of eroding public and institutional confidence, both in Sri Lanka’s economic progress and the effectiveness of the IMF programme itself. Furthermore, the statement said over the seven months following the board-level agreement, most requirements stipulating transparency have gone unfulfilled. For instance, the commitment to “Report monthly cash flows from revenues, expenditures, and financing by the third business day of the subsequent month by the Department of State Accounts” remains unmet. Another example is the creation of an online fiscal transparency platform, which was due in March but still hasn’t been implemented. “Sri Lanka’s accountability issues, as highlighted by the two governance diagnostics, are foundational to public accountability in a democratic system. The assessments suggest that the twin transparency deficit could be a leading indicator that the anticipated economic recovery may not materialise as expected,” the statement added.

title: Xi Jinping urges world leaders to unite
author: Author not found
Content: Chinese President Xi Jinping, unveiling the eight pivotal policies that are set to chart the course for the future of the ‘Belt and Road’ Initiative (BRI) during the third BRI Forum, which commenced in Beijing yesterday (18), urged the invitees including leaders of countries, to unite in creating a symphony of friendship in line with the BRI concept. The eight policies encompass the establishment of an international multilateral network, bolstering a globally open economy, advancing practical cooperation strategies, championing green development, nurturing opportunities for scientific and technological innovation, strengthening interpersonal relations, and fostering unshakable bonds among member countries. There were 20 country representatives from over 130 countries and some of the notable speakers at the event were, Russian President Vladimir Putin, Kazakhstan President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, Indonesian President Joko Widodo, Argentine President Alberto Fernández and Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed. United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres, speaking at the event, stressed that adequate infrastructure and information facilities are essential for future world development and noted the invaluable role of the BRI initiative in meeting these needs. He further highlighted its potential in addressing debt relief challenges faced by developing countries. Accompanying President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the event were Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, Presidential Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe, Presidential Adviser Saman Athaudahetti, Ministry of Foreign Affairs Chief Alliance Officer Senarath Dissanayake, Head of the Sri Lankan Embassy in Beijing K.K. Yoganandan, Ministry of External Affairs East Asia Director General Pujitha Perera, Presidential Private Secretary, Sandra Perera and Presidential Director of International Affairs Rishan de Silva. President Xi emphasised that the BRI was founded on principles of peace, mutual support and friendship, serving as a contemporary rendition of the ancient Silk Road. He highlighted that the initiative’s benefits extend beyond a single nation, benefiting many countries. He further stressed that cooperation, rather than competition or suppression, is the bedrock of the BRI concept. He reiterated that goodwill and mutual support among nations lead to positive outcomes for all. Notably, since the inception of the BRI programme a decade ago, all participating nations have achieved remarkable milestones and forged new avenues to strengthen economic ties. (SRM)

title: ‘Wele Suda’ ordered to be produced in Court
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe, yesterday (18), ordered the Superintendent of the Boossa Prison to produce death row inmate Gampola Vidanage Samantha Kumara, alias ‘Wele Suda’ in Court at the next hearing. Wele Suda has been charged with the illegal accruement of Rs 10 million. A case filed against three accused including Wele Suda was taken up yesterday (18) and the prison officials had produced one of the accused, Sameera Udayana, but had not produced Wele Suda, due to him being indisposed. The Judge then ordered the Superintendent of the Boossa Prison, to produce a medical report to him at the next hearing, regarding the illness of the accused, Wele Suda. Thereafter, further hearing of the trial was deferred to 7 February, next year. The Attorney General has filed a case against three accused, including drug baron Wele Suda, in the High Court, over the unlawful acquisition of the said sum of money and for violating Sections of the Prevention of Money Laundering Act. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: No further action will be pursued – CIABOC
author: Author not found
Content: The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) informed the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court yesterday (18) that no further action would be pursued concerning the Rs 17.85 million in cash found within former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s official chamber at the President’s House in Colombo. CIABOC cited the lack of evidence as the basis for their decision and confirmed that no further steps would be taken in this matter. The cash had been stumbled upon by protesters during mass anti-government demonstrations on 9 July 2022, when they occupied the official Presidential House. The money was subsequently handed over to the Fort Police by the protesters that day, and it was handed over to the Fort Magistrate’s Court three weeks later. However, Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage ordered the IGP to conduct an investigation into the delay by the Police in delivering the money, expressing reasonable doubt about why the OIC of the Fort Police had delayed the matter. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: SLBFE allocates USD 10,000
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) has allocated a sum of USD 10,000 to facilitate essential support for Sri Lankan workers in Israel who are experiencing difficulties due to the conflict between Israel and Palestine. In a statement, the SLBFE confirmed that the allocated USD 10,000 has already been transferred to the Sri Lankan Embassy in Israel. This financial assistance is intended to cover the needs of Sri Lankan workers, including provisions for food, medicines, and other essential facilities. Additionally, the SLBFE has proactively taken measures to allocate further funds if the necessity arises in the future, demonstrating their commitment to the welfare of Sri Lankans in Israel. Both President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara have issued directives concerning the safety and well-being of Sri Lankans in Israel. The SLBFE has communicated that its relevant officers have been instructed to undertake all essential actions to ensure safety and provide the necessary amenities for Sri Lankan workers in Israel.

title: Excise Department suspends soft liquor licences
author: Author not found
Content: The Commissioner General of the Excise Department has issued an order to immediately suspend soft liquor licences of hotels, restaurants, and accommodations registered with the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA). This decision was made following an injunction issued by the Court of Appeal in the pending case number 371/2023. Kapila Kumarasinghe, Additional Commissioner General of Revenue Operations and Law Enforcement in the Excise Department, announced this decision yesterday (18). According to the injunction, steps of suspension of the sale or display of soft liquor at these establishments and refraining from issuing application forms for their re-registration will be taken by the Excise Department with immediate effect. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: PM convenes Party Leaders’ meeting
author: Author not found
Content: A Party Leaders’ meeting was convened in Parliament yesterday (18) by Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena to discuss potential electoral reforms. The meeting focused on the two recent Cabinet papers pertaining to the introduction of a mixed-member proportional representation system and the establishment of laws to formalise the deposit of surety deposits at elections. The Cabinet has directed to collate the proposals presented by the party leaders and prepare a report, in accordance with the Cabinet’s request, to be submitted for consideration. State Minister Aravind Kumar, MPs Mano Ganesan, Rishad Bathiudeen and Gajendrakumar Ponnambalam voiced their unanimous rejection of any move to change the current parliamentary electoral system, arguing that altering the system could lead to a loss of representation for minority Tamils and Muslims. Ganesan went on to emphasise that, before considering changes to the Parliamentary Election system, the Government should prioritise conducting Provincial Council (PC) elections under the proportional representation (PR) system, as previously agreed upon in the report of the Parliament Select Committee on Electoral Reform. MPs including Dullas Alahapperuma, Udaya Gammanpila, Tissa Vitarana and Ven. Athuraliye Rathana Thera also expressed their opposition to the proposed reforms. They suggested that the Government may have a hidden agenda behind the push for electoral changes. The Prime Minister concluded the meeting by announcing plans for a follow-up discussion in two weeks, reflecting the need for further deliberation on this sensitive issue. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa informed the PM that his party, the SJB would not take part in the discussions until the postponed Local Government Election is held. The Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) also did not participate in the meeting, citing similar concerns.

title: Nine-member Committee led by ex-CJ appointed
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe issued a Gazette Notification, establishing a nine-member committee led by former Chief Justice Priyasad Dep, to formulate recommendations for electoral reforms in Sri Lanka. The committee members are Justice Wewage Priyasath Gerard Dep, PC – Retired Chief Justice, Suntharam Arumainayaham, Senanayake Alisandaralage, Nalin Jayantha Abeysekara PC, Rajitha Naveen Christopher Senaratna Perera, Ahamed Lebbe Mohamed Saleem, Sagarica Delgoda, Esther Sriyani Nimalka Fernando and Vitharanage Deepani Samantha Rodrigo. The Gazette Notification highlights that changes to the election system and the conduct of elections in Sri Lanka were introduced with the promulgation of the 1978 Constitution. However, there is a need to amend these laws to align with present societal requirements, uphold principles of good governance, and strengthen representative democracy. The notification also emphasises the necessity of introducing a code of conduct and media standards to address improper behaviour in political and public affairs, as well as inappropriate media usage by political parties and independent groups. Further, it mentions that the registration of political parties without a genuine need, often for financial gains or other improper purposes, has eroded public trust in political parties. Therefore, there is a requirement to rebuild trust and accountability by enhancing the legal framework for the registration and operation of political parties. The President has expressed the view that a Commission of Inquiry should be appointed to investigate and report on the matters specified in the notification. The committee is granted the authority to conduct inquiries and investigations as deemed necessary. The committee is expected to submit a report containing its findings and recommendations on the matter within a time frame of six months. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: One of the sextuplets dies
author: Author not found
Content: The Castle Street Hospital for Women said one of the sextuplets born on Tuesday (17) had died due to pulmonary haemorrhage.  Deputy Director General Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH), Dr. G. Wijesuriya when contacted said that the infant who had been transferred from Castle Street Hospital to his institution had died yesterday (18) morning. He said the infant had been brought to the LRH was severely premature and had a birth weight of 620g. He said the LRH provided all the support and care and medication required. However, the infant died of pulmonary haemorrhage as his lungs were under developed, Dr.  Wijesuriya added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Wickramaratne can continue as IGP till month end – Dinesh
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena informed Parliament yesterday (19) that pending the appointment of a new Inspector General of Police (IGP), C.D. Wickramaratne can continue serving as the acting IGP until the end of the month. Gunawardene was responding to Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s inquiry regarding reports claiming that following the rejection of the extension granted to Wickramaratne by the Constitutional Council, the President had re-appointed Wickramaratne as IGP. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena also said, the President has the power to re-appoint IGP Wickramaratne, even if the Constitutional Council had previously rejected the appointment. Opposition MP Udaya Gammanpila also joined the discussion and requested the Speaker and Prime Minister to address several rumours that are currently circulating about the IGP’s service extension. In response, the Prime Minister said, the government is in the process of enacting legislation to combat the spread of false news. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Online Safety Bill to be amended – AG
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General, yesterday (18), informed the Supreme Court that numerous provisions within the Online Safety Bill will undergo revisions in accordance with a decision made by the Government. As a result, the pertinent amendments are set to be presented in Parliament during the Committee Stage, as conveyed by the Additional Solicitor General representing the Attorney General, during the Court proceedings addressing challenges to the legislation. This hearing took place before a three-Judge Bench of the Supreme Court, comprising Justices Priyantha Jayawardena, Shiran Gooneratne, and Achala Wengappuli. Meanwhile, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, on the same day, informed Parliament that a total of 45 petitions have been submitted against the proposed legislation. The Online Safety Bill, published in the Government Gazette on 18 September, seeks to prohibit certain statements in online communication, prevent the use of online accounts for prohibited activities, whether authentic or not, and combat the funding and support of false statements and related matters. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Pope urges to prevent human catastrophe
author: Author not found
Content: Pope Francis expressed his deep concern on Wednesday regarding the dire situation in Gaza and called for every effort to prevent a humanitarian catastrophe. During his weekly General Audience, the pontiff implored all parties involved to cease hostilities, as reported by official Vatican News. “The number of casualties is on the rise, and the situation in Gaza is extremely dire… We must do everything in our power to avert a humanitarian disaster,” he emphasised. The Pope emphasised that war, instead of resolving conflicts, leads to death and devastation, fuels animosity, and perpetuates cycles of vengeance. He stressed that war robs the world of its future and urged individuals to stand for peace. The Pope’s comments came in the wake of a deadly attack on a Gaza hospital on Tuesday (17), resulting in the loss of hundreds of lives.

title: Bail condition on Mohammad Ibrahim lifted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe, yesterday (18), lifted a bail condition imposed on millionaire businessman Mohammad Ibrahim, the father of 2019 Easter Sunday suicide bombers Insaf Ahmed Ibrahim and Ilham Ahmed Ibrahim. Both Insaf and Ilham were behind the bomb explosions at Shangri-La Hotel and Cinnamon Grand Hotel in Colombo, on 21 April 2019. Anuja Premaratna, PC, representing the defendant, told Judge Marasinghe that his client was ailing and feeble at present and was wheelchair-bound. He then urged the Court, to lift the bail condition imposed on his client by the High Court on 25 March last year, which required him to report to the CID, on the last Sunday of each month. Considering the request, the Judge instructed the accused, to henceforth appear at the CID, on the last Sunday of every three months. Thereafter, the Attorney General submitted photos and reports of the three defendants to Court. The Judge then advised objections related to it, to be submitted by 7 November and re-objections to be filed, by 20 November. The three accused have been charged and indicted on two counts, in the High Court, by the Attorney General with failing to inform the Police, of the imminent attack on Catholic Churches and star class hotels in Colombo on Easter Sunday three years ago, despite having prior information and failing to take pre-emptive action on the same and for flouting Sections of the PTA and the Penal Code. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Two Police Sergeants apprehended at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: The Police at BIA, Katunayake arrested two Sergeants attached to the Tourist Police Unit for stealing   two packets of a gel-like substance mixed with over 600 grams of gold, valued in excess of Rs15 million from a passenger who had arrived at the Airport to head to Dubai. The two suspects have been identified as a 50-year-old resident from Kimbulapitiya and a 36-year-old from Munamaldeniya. The BIA Police said a 30-year-old businessman from Nattandiya had arrived at the BIA to take wing to Dubai at around 11.00 a.m. on 17 October. They added that at the time the two suspects were assigned for duty and had surreptitiously taken the two gold mixed gel packets weighing 634 gramme from the passenger. The passenger realising the loss aborted his overseas trip and lodged a complaint with the BIA Police. The BIA Police had then apprehended the two suspects and seized the gel packets from their possession. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 2023 Asian Women Parliamentarian Caucus Meeting Held in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The Annual Forum of Asian Women Parliamentarian Caucus (AWPC) was held on the theme ‘Inclusivity & Diversity in Gender Equality in Parliaments in Asia’ in Colombo. MPs from Thailand, Japan, Vietnam, Taiwan, Nepal, Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Bhutan, the Philippines, Timor-Leste, and Sri Lanka joined this meeting. Following an invitation by Dr. Sudarshini Fernandopulle, Chairperson of the Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus of Sri Lanka, at the annual meeting of AWPC held in Singapore last year, the 2023 meeting was held inSri Lanka. The importance of standing up against various forms of violence against women, including military situations, as well as the importance of creating gender equality in the world, was discussed at this meeting. The policy decisions taken and the services rendered for the betterment of women in Sri Lanka through the establishment of the Sri Lanka Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus received special appreciation at this meeting. The inauguration of the 2023 AWPC was held at Parliament attended by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse, Chairperson of Sri Lanka Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus Dr. Fernandopulle, German MP Romina Catharina Plonsker, Committee Deputy Chairman Angajan Ramanathan, German Ambassador, German KAS Foundation Director Andreas Michael Klein, its Programme Manager Megha Sarmah, Sri Lanka Parliament Secretary-General Kushani Rohanadeera, Sri Lanka Parliament Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General Chaminda Kularatne, Assistant Secretary-General Hansa Abeyratne, and a group of government officials from several foreign countries also joined. Special awards were also given to Speaker Abeywardena, Chairperson of the Sri Lanka Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus Dr. Fernandopulle, and Secretary-General of the Parliament of Sri Lanka, Rohanadeera, for their contribution to the success of the 2023 Annual Meeting of the AWPC. Members of the Asian Parliamentarians’ Caucus, who joined an observation tour of the Parliament, went to the Election Commission and met its members and representatives of civil organisations. Also, the members of the Asian Parliamentarians’ Caucus and the group held discussions with the members of government institutions and non-governmental organisations as well as joined several field visits. With the support of German Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung, a network of 40 Asian women parliamentarians has met annually since 2011 to promote, strengthen and develop women’s political leadership in their countries through policy discussions and capacity-building programmes. Formally established in 2014 through a regional conference held in Singapore, the AWPC aims to achieve the following objectives: =Promote stronger engagement on policy issues by encouraging regional discussions on policies affecting women’s leadership in Asia =Strengthening the capacities of individual parliamentarians through networking, plenary sessions and skill-enhancing workshops =Identify the leadership challenges faced by women parliamentarians in Asia and provide adequate support through leadership training and policy workshops. The Sri Lanka Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus, Sri Lanka Parliament and KAS Foundation jointly organised this year’s annual meeting and the Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung Foundation financed the event.

title: IGP Trophy Police Cadet Corps held at Police College Kalutara
author: Author not found
Content: The ceremony of the Inspector General of Police (IGP) Trophy Police Cadet Corps took place at the Police College Kalutara on 16 October. The event was held under the patronage of Secretary of Ministry of Public Security Viyani Gunathilaka. The IGP Trophy Police Cadet Corps camp was held at the Kalutara Police Academy for a week, with the participation of 1225 cadets from 49 schools, representing nine provinces. The closing ceremony for this camp was also held on 16 October at 8.30 a.m., under the patronage of the Secretary of the Ministry of Public Security. IGP Chandana Wickramarathne, Senior Police Officers, senior members of the cadet corps, and special guests were in attendance. During the ceremony, a male cadet from St. Thomas’ College, Matale and a female cadet was chosen from Holy Angels Girls’ College , Kuliyapitiya and were awarded the IGP Trophy.

title: Two new pomegranate varieties to be grown in Norochcholai
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Agriculture is to introduce two new pomegranate varieties for cultivation in Sri Lanka in the first quarter of the next year, marking a significant development for the agricultural sector. Agricultural experts at the Department of Agriculture have successfully conducted research to identify two pomegranate varieties that are well-suited for cultivation in Sri Lanka. These new varieties have been successfully cultivated in Norochcholai, demonstrating high yields and promising income prospects for local farmers. Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera personally visited the pomegranate cultivation in Norochcholai on 16 October. He said cultivating pomegranates on just half an acre of land can yield an income of approximately Rs 6 million. Moreover, pomegranate trees have a remarkable lifespan of about 30 years. Currently, ongoing field research aims to identify suitable areas for the cultivation of these two new pomegranate varieties. Director General of Agriculture Malathi Parasuraman, informed the Minister that the recommendation for these new varieties will be presented to the Crop Release Committee of the Department of Agriculture in the coming month. These two pomegranate varieties are yet to be officially named, and their nomenclature will be determined upon the recommendation of the Crop Release Committee. Both varieties are known for their sweetness and appealing colour, making them attractive to consumers. Notably, each tree can produce a harvest of approximately 10 kg of pomegranates at a time, and they bear fruit throughout the year. Minister Amaraweera expressed his commitment to fast-tracking the release of these two new pomegranate varieties for cultivation in Sri Lanka. He highlighted that the country spends about Rs 900 million annually on pomegranate imports, primarily from India and other nations. The introduction of these two new, locally cultivable pomegranate varieties aims to reduce the need for imports and further strengthen Sri Lanka’s agricultural sector. Given the high international demand for pomegranates, Norochcholai is deemed highly suitable for pomegranate cultivation, and the private sector has already begun cultivation in this region. Minister Amaraweera praised the success of Sri Lankan agricultural scientists and confirmed that suitable cultivation areas for these new pomegranate varieties will be identified in the first quarter of the upcoming year, enabling local farmers to partake in their cultivation. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: 11th IN – SLN Staff Talks begin in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The 11th Navy to Navy Staff Talks between India and Sri Lanka commenced at the Light House Galley, Colombo on 17 October. On the sidelines of this, the head of the Indian Navy delegation, Rear Admiral Nirbhay Bapna, who is also the Assistant Chief of Naval Staff – Foreign Cooperation and Liaison called on Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera at Navy Headquarters.  The Sri Lanka Navy delegation was led by Director General Training, Rear Admiral Rohitha Abeysinghe, while the Indian Navy delegation was led by Rear Admiral Nirbhay Bapna.  The 11th Indian Navy – Sri Lanka Navy Staff Talks commenced with an initial review of the progress made during the 10th edition. The subsequent discussions primarily centred on enhancing bilateral relations, fostering cooperation and interoperability, facilitating training exchanges, promoting knowledge and information sharing, coordinating hydrography activities, and planning joint exercises, among other topics.  The Staff Talks will conclude today (19 October). Concurrently, the Indian Navy delegation is expected to visit some of the tourist attractions in the country.

title: Every possible step taken to rejuvenate UNP
author: Author not found
Content: Director General of Trade Unions Saman Ratnapriya, claimed onTuesday (17) that every possible measure has been taken to rejuvenate the UNP in a manner that resonates with the majority of the country’s population. Ratnapriya stated that the upcoming UNP convention serves as a platform to transform the party into a modern political entity that aligns with the evolving dynamics of the global political landscape. This special convention will be held at the Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium on 21 October, presided over by Party Leader, President Ranil Wickremesinghe. He emphasised that a significant number of active party members, representatives, former members of Provincial Councils, and Local Government bodies from across the country are expected to participate in the convention. Various matters, including preparations for the Presidential Elections anticipated in the third quarter of next year and the strategies required for the party to emerge as a victorious force, will be discussed during the convention. “The Online Safety Bill (OSB) and the ongoing discussions to secure a second tranche of loan assistance from the International Monetary Fund are topics of significant importance. Passing the OSB is a critical initiative introduced by the Government,” Ratnapriya said. He explained that there are compelling reasons to support the passage of this Bill. “Social media and print media have been used to present a distorted image of Dr. Shafi Shihabdeen. These platforms have also been utilised to propagate ideas that provoke religious or ethnic tensions. Therefore, the Online Safety Bill is of utmost importance in regulating the media industry in the country.” By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Significance of Indian Ocean forsecurity, peace, sustainability discussed
author: Author not found
Content: Nimal Siripala de Silva, the Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation, represented Sri Lanka at the Global Maritime India Summit (GMIS) 2023 in Mumbai, which commenced on Tuesday (17). GMIS 2023, a three-day maritime event taking place from 17 – 19 October is being held at the Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority Ground. The summit is organised by the Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Waterways of the Government of India, in collaboration with the Indian Ports Association and the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry. The event focused on crucial aspects of the maritime sector, featuring sessions, exhibitions, and discussions on topics such as future ports, decarbonisation, finance, insurance, arbitration, innovation, technology, maritime safety, security, and maritime tourism, among others. The summit was virtually inaugurated by the Prime Minister of India, Shri Narendra Modi, and the inaugural session was attended by dignitaries including Shri Sarbananda Sonowal, Union Minister of Ports, Shipping, Waterways, and Ministry of Ayush; Shri Ramesh Bais, the Governor of Maharashtra; Shri Eknath Shinde, Chief Minister of Maharashtra; Dr. Pramod Sawant, Chief Minister of Goa; and Nimal Siripala de Silva, Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation. Additionally, 13 Ministers from 11 countries, including Armenia, Bangladesh, Belarus, Comoros, Iran, Italy, Tanzania, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Spain, and Nepal, attended the event. Further, 16 State ministers and Lieutenant Governors from 11 Indian States and Union Territories were also present. Minister Siripala de Silva expressed gratitude and extended felicitations to the Indian Government on behalf of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the maritime community of Sri Lanka, and the people of Sri Lanka. In his address, the Minister emphasised the significance of the Indian Ocean for security, peace, and sustainability, underscoring Asia’s pivotal and vibrant economy in the world for business, maritime activities, culture, and heritage. He stressed the importance of creating opportunities for Sri Lanka, an island nation strategically positioned, in alignment with the summit’s theme, “Connect, Collaborate, and Create.” The Minister underscored the need for smaller and landlocked nations to join forces, ensuring equal opportunities for all countries while contributing to the formulation of rules, regulations, and innovations. Minister Siripala de Silva commended the Indian Government for the timely selection of topics for the summit, including maritime connectivity, the maritime industry, and utilisation among other vital subjects. He concluded his speech by expressing optimism that professionals and specialists would engage in meaningful discussions during the summit, fostering better policies, legislation, international cooperation, and equal opportunities for people and nations worldwide. Following the Minister’s speech, speeches were delivered by the Chief Minister of Goa, the Chief Minister of Maharashtra, the Governor of Maharashtra, and the Union Minister of Ports, Shipping, Waterways, and Ministry of Ayush. Over the next three days, the summit will feature over 80 international speakers, more than 100 Indian speakers, and over 3,000 international and Indian industry delegates. Minister Siripala de Silva is scheduled to address the possibilities for maritime collaboration between India and Sri Lanka on 18 October at the ‘Roundtable on Regional Maritime Connectivity’. On 19 October he will discuss the experience from Colombo as a model transshipment port in Asia, focusing on financing and regulatory issues in developing transshipment ports during the session on the ‘Roundtable with Indo Pacific’ at the Global Maritime India Summit 2023.

title: Israel-Hamas conflict : Sri Lankan woman confirmed dead
author: Author not found
Content: INTERPOL National Central Bureau (NCB) unit of the Israeli Police has officially informed the Sri Lankan Ambassador to Israel, Nimal Bandara that Anula Jayatilleke Ratnayake (49), one of the individuals who went missing on 7 October during the attacks near the Gaza border, was kidnapped and subsequently murdered by Hamas. It is speculated around 200 persons were missing during the Hamas raid in Israel. Ambassador Bandara told Ceylon Today that her death has been confirmed. Anula was a caretaker who had worked near the Gaza border for over a decade. “She was kidnapped and killed by Hamas,” the Israeli Government has informed the Ambassador. “The family in Kelaniya has been officially notified about the tragic passing of their mother, a mother of two children.” The son, who resides in New Zealand, was also contacted by the Ambassador to confirm the death of his mother. “It’s a day marked by sadness, and despite my desire to hope for a different outcome, I had considered travelling to the Gaza area to inspect hospitals to ascertain her condition. However, I was not permitted to travel due to safety risks. I continued to inquire about the two missing individuals and ultimately received the confirmation of Anula’s unfortunate death,” Bandara said. The Ambassador stated that he is seeking information about the whereabouts of 44-year-old Yatawara Bandara from Wennappuwa who is also missing from the time of the attack.   Anula had been the sole breadwinner, caring for an elderly Israeli family member. According to the Ambassador, the Israeli family identified Anula’s body and expressed their deep sorrow and also appreciated her devoted work. The family, residing in another location, had relied on Anula to care for their elderly mother near the Gaza Strip. The Government will repatriate Anula’s body to Sri Lanka and provide compensation to her family, the Ambassador said. He also stated that, despite a temporary ban, there is no permanent prohibition on workers from Sri Lanka coming to work in Israel. Many individuals express an interest in working in Israel, and opportunities were available. Several countries, including India, Japan, Australia, and China, have successfully evacuated their citizens living and studying in Israel. Bandara said while there is a ban on workers entering Israel, it is not being rigorously enforced, and many people are still trying to come to Israel.  The Israeli government had invited all diplomats stationed in Israel for a briefing on the war situation at the Knesset in Jerusalem on 16 October, Bandara said. He said that even during this briefing, there was an exchange of fire between the two parties and could be heard. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: ‘118’– Hotline for misdemeanours of Police personnel
author: Author not found
Content: The Police Media Division announced that the public could now report incidents of Police personnel misconduct on the ‘118’ hotline. Initially established by the Ministry of Public Security for reporting various crimes, this hotline has been extended to allow citizens to raise concerns about police behaviour as stated in a press release issued by the Police Media Division.  The release states that individuals may provide information on anonymity if desired, and confidentiality of all information made on the 24-hour hotline will be guaranteed.

title: SL workers in South Lebanon requested to register
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, has called on Sri Lankan workers in the southern part of Beirut to register with them so that they can establish contact during emergencies. Currently, the southern part of Lebanon is witnessing exchange of artillery fire and other attacks between the Lebanese armed group Hezbollah and Israel’s military along their shared border. Ambassador Kapila Jayaweera told Ceylon Today that a few Sri Lankans reside in the southern part of Lebanon and expressed the need to register them for emergency contact.   Sri Lankans working in Southern Lebanon are urged to promptly provide their names and telephone numbers to the following WhatsApp numbers or email: 70386754, 71960810, or [email protected] the embassy announced yesterday. Ambassador Jayaweera also said more Sri Lankan workers were in and around Beirut and the northern part of Lebanon. However, he did not specify the exact number of Sri Lankans in the southern part of Lebanon, stating that they would assess the numbers once individuals register with them. The Ambassador who is also the designated Ambassador to Syria said there were around 12 Sri Lankans working in Syria. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  The Writ Petition filed by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) against the illegal construction of buildings on hilltops which can cause visual pollution, pollution in water catchment areas and soil erosion, was taken up in the Court of Appeal yesterday (17). The petitioners, CEJ Senior Adviser Hemantha Withanage and CEJ Executive Director Dilena Pathragoda, seek an order to halt such construction and addresses concerns related to the adverse environmental impacts. When the case was taken up, Justice U.B. Karaliyadda announced that he was recusing himself from the case due to a conflict of interest. Meanwhile, Attorney-at-Law Senani Dayaratne represented the Buddhist monk who had constructed a temple on the top of Bible Rock. The Attorney General appeared on behalf of the respondents of the petition including the Central Environmental Authority (CEA). Senior Counsel Ravindranath Dabare and Attorney-at-Law Savanthi Ponnamperuma represented the petitioners on the instructions of Attorney-at-Law Kanchana Balachandra. Thereafter, the Court decided to fix further hearing of the case to 10 November before a fresh Bench. By Methmalie Dissanayake Popular

title: 34 Petitions filed in SC challenging Online Safety Bill – Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena announced in Parliament yesterday (17) that 34 petitions have been filed in the Supreme Court (SC) challenging the Online Safety Bill (OSB). The petitions were filed as per Article 121 (1) of the Constitution, the Speaker said, adding that he received the copies of the petitions. The 14-day period granted to challenge the Bill in the SC, since its tabling in Parliament on 3 October, lapsed yesterday (17). It is reported that by yesterday afternoon, the number of petitions challenging the Bill, had spiked to over 50, while these petitions had been filed by Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith, the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL), Centre for Policy Alternatives (CPA), Sri Lanka Working Journalists’ Association (SLWJA), Free Media Movement (FMM), various trade unions, civil society organisations and several NGOs. Meanwhile, a petition was filed in the SC yesterday (17), by five members of the Executive Committee of the Sri Lanka Young Journalists’ Association (SLYJA), along with four other civilians, representing a cross-spectrum of society, challenging the Bill. The petitioners were identified, as Head of the SLYJA Tharindu Jayawardhana, its Secretary M.F.M. Fazeer, Convener Shalika Wimalasena, Treasurer Nirosh Maithree along with its Deputy President B. Niroshkumar. The civilians, who had petitioned the Apex Court, are human rights activist Rukee Fernando, human rights activist Suren D. Perera, social media activist and law student Anuruddha Bandara and Dishara Fernando. The petitioners had stated that the Bill, submitted to the House by the Government, if ratified in its present state, could sound the death knell for freedom of expression and dissent, as guaranteed by the Constitution of the country and that most of the Sections of the Bill, were in blatant violation of the Constitution. They observed that as stipulated in the Provisions of the OSB, the decision to grant Judicial powers to a Commission, formed by the Executive President, to oversee the implementation of the Bill, is also in direct violation of the Fundamental Rights of the citizens. Therefore, the petitioners have prayed the Apex Court, to deem that if the Bill is to be passed in the House the Government should obtain not only a two-thirds majority but also opt for a Public Referendum. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ali Zahir Moulana sworn in as MP
author: Author not found
Content: Seyed Ali Zahir Moulana, a former State Minister, who represented the Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC) from the Batticaloa District during the previous Parliamentary Election, was sworn in as an MP before Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena yesterday (17). The Supreme Council of the party decided to remove Naseer Ahamed, the former Minister of Environment, from the membership of the SLMC. The petition filed by him in the Supreme Court against that decision was dismissed on 6 October, according to Article 99(13)(a) of the Constitution, and it was announced that an MP vacancy exists from the said date. Accordingly, Ahamed’s position as an MP has been abolished and Seyed Ali Zahir Moulana has been appointed to fill the vacancy. Moulana, who has been in active politics since 1988, served as an MP representing the UNP from 1994 to 2004. He has previously held the positions of State Minister for Primary Industries and Social Empowerment, Deputy Minister of National Integration, Reconciliation and Official Languages and State Minister of Social Empowerment in the 8th Parliament from 2015 to 2020.
