title: Audio recordings of committees cannot be publicised – Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, yesterday (17), said in Parliament that audio recordings of Parliamentary Committees cannot be made public, emphasising that this decision was reached by Parliament itself. The Speaker made this statement in response to MP Chandima Weerakkody, who raised concerns related to his matter of privilege, asserting the need for access to the audio tape to address threats made against him during a recent Parliamentary Committee meeting. Weerakkody, who raised a Matter of Privilege in Parliament on 6 October, alleged that he was threatened by Defence Secretary Kamal Gunaratne and the Army Commander over his remarks about excessive vehicle usage by high-ranking military officials, on 5 October, during the meeting of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Security. At this juncture, Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella, addressing the issue, highlighted that threatening an MP constitutes a breach of parliamentary privileges. Kiriella stressed that the Speaker has a duty to safeguard the privileges of MPs and requested the release of the audio tape, further questioning whether the Speaker condoned the alleged threats made against Weerakkody. In response, the Speaker clarified that the audio tape could be presented and examined within the Privileges Committee. Weerakkody indicated his intention to pursue legal action concerning the alleged threats. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Shrapnel found in tusker Seetha’s body – Prof. Dangalla
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Professor of the Veterinary Faculty of the Peradeniya University Ashoka Dangalla said following a second surgery performed on tusker ‘Seetha,’ metal balls and aluminium particles had been removed. He added that there could yet be more particles of aluminium and metal balls lodged in the body of the tusker as a result of the shooting but rued the fact that they were incapable of removing those particles for want of necessary equipment. A second surgery on the tusker, who had been shot at following a Perahera, had been carried out on 17 October at Ranawana where the pachyderm is presently being treated. Prof. Dangalla stated that the second surgery on the tusker had been done based on a Court order due to the weakening condition of the animal and to save its life. The owner of the tusker S.M. Roshan said claims made by officers of the Department of Wildlife Conservation that the tusker had been shot at with rubber bullets proved to be false due to the removal of aforementioned items from its body during the recent surgery. He added that Wildlife Officers had opened fire at the tusker with live ammunition. The said officers should be held responsible for the present condition of the tusker, he said. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: To bolster int’l relations, economic prospects
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe embarked on a diplomatic mission to China, where he engaged in a series of significant meetings with world leaders and dignitaries. His visit to the People’s Republic of China aimed to bolster Sri Lanka’s international relations and economic prospects. A notable meeting during his tour was with the Indonesian President, Joko Widodo. At a meeting held in Beijing on 17 October, President Wickremesinghe and President Widodo discussed the need to strengthen the political, economic, and cultural ties between the two countries. Their primary focus was to reinforce the Indian Ocean’s identity which is of significance to both countries. Discussions between the two leaders encompassed a wide array of topics, including the enhancement of political, cultural, and economic cooperation. The economic crisis and the recent palm oil ban were also discussed as it had implications on trade connecting Sri Lanka and Indonesia. President Wickremesinghe underscored Sri Lanka’s ongoing efforts to establish free trade agreements with several Asian countries and formalise the existing agreement with India. In response, President Widodo expressed his country’s interest in a free trade agreement with Sri Lanka, highlighting the timeliness of such an endeavour. The leaders also exchanged insights on global economic and political trends and how they could collectively address these challenges as small states in the Asian region. Subsequently, President Wickremesinghe attended an investment, trade, and tourism forum, where he extended an invitation to Chinese entrepreneurs. He encouraged them to consider Sri Lanka as a strategic hub for emerging green and digital economic ventures, emphasising the nation’s significant progress in these domains. He positioned Sri Lanka as a gateway to Western markets within the broader Asian region and reaffirmed his commitment to rebuilding the nation’s economy. Another significant meeting during President Wickremesinghe’s visit to China was with Pakistan’s Prime Minister, Anwaar-ul-Haq Kakar, which took place on the sidelines of the ‘One Belt – One Road’ international conference. During their bilateral discussions, both leaders stressed the global imperative of fostering a harmonious society that transcends animosity, prejudice, and anger stemming from racial, religious, or ethnic differences. They emphasised the importance of addressing the challenge of creating a unified society founded on shared humanity, where divisions driven by race, religion, or ethnicity give way to unity and mutual understanding. Additionally, President Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Kakar discussed the economic crises affecting both Pakistan and Sri Lanka, with a particular focus on strategies for recovery. Further, the leaders deliberated on the critical developments unfolding in the Gaza Strip and reached a consensus to issue a joint statement reflecting their common stance on the matter. The meeting was attended by delegates, including Pakistan’s Finance Minister, Shamshad Akhtar, and Sri Lanka’s Foreign Minister, Ali Sabry, making it a pivotal gathering of leaders committed to foster global harmony and address pressing economic and political challenges.

title: Hulftsdorp Court Productions Room broken into again
author: Author not found
Content: The Court Productions Room at the Hulftsdorp Court Complex was broken into once again on Monday night (16). This is the second unauthorised entry to the Court Productions Room in one month. The first break-in occurred on 5 October, prompting an investigation by the Keselwatta Police. Despite these recurring incidents, the authorities have yet to identify the individuals responsible for the break-ins in either instance. Scene of Crime Officers (SOCO), arrived at the scene yesterday (17) to commence their investigations. SOCO collected photographs of the storage room and gathered fingerprints from the individuals responsible for that area. Collaborative efforts between the officers overseeing the Court Productions Room and the Police are underway to determine whether any items stored in the room are missing. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Sextuplets born at Castle Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: A 37-year-old woman from Ragama gave birth to sextuplets at Castle Street Hospital for Women (CSHW), yesterday morning (17). Neonatologist, Dr. Saman Kumara, when contacted, said being born prematurely (at 26 weeks) they required a tremendous amount of monitoring and care and were being kept in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU). He said their birth weight had been between 400 and 700 g. Dr. Kumara, fielding questions, observed that supporting such preterm infants was a colossal task. In 2021, sextuplets (three girls and three boys) were born at a private hospital in Colombo to a couple from Angoda. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: New arrest in Court Registrar’s document forgery case
author: Author not found
Content: A new arrest has been made in connection with the case involving alleged document forgery by the Registrar of the Fort Magistrate’s Court. The Colombo Magistrate’s Court ordered to remand the latest suspect until today, during a hearing last morning (17). Following previous arrests and allegations, the Registrar of the Fort Magistrate’s Court was taken into custody on 13 October. She faces multiple charges, including document forgery. It is claimed that she created false documents suggesting that a Court had lifted a foreign travel ban for a suspect, with the counterfeit documents instructing the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration to allow the individual to travel overseas. The complaint against the Registrar was filed by Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage and is presently under investigation by the CID. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Fertliser to be given to northern farmers on time
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said necessary steps have been taken to provide fertiliser on time to all farmers engaged in cultivation this year in the Northern Province. The Minister said this during an event held on Monday (16) at the Jaffna District Secretariat Auditorium. The Minister said the Department of Agriculture will provide maximum support not only for rice but also for crops including vegetables and fruits in the Northern Province. Governor of the Northern Province P.S.M. Charles said that the agricultural activities of the Northern Province contribute a lot to the domestic production of the country and many programmes are being implemented to improve livelihoods. In this discussion, the problems faced by the farmers of Jaffna District were discussed and the Minister gave instructions to the relevant authorities regarding the issues that can be solved immediately and said that steps will be taken to solve other problems. Compensation, Agricultural Protection Fund and Farmers’ Pension were also given on this occasion to farmers who suffered crop damage due to drought in the past. The eent was attended by MP Angajan Ramanathan, Northern Province Chief Secretary Saman Bandulasena, officials of the Jaffna District, and representatives of the Agriculture Organisation were present. Photo and text by T Pratheepan

title: Navy seizes narcotics valued at Rs 94M in Talaimannar
author: Author not found
Content: A special search operation, mounted by the Sri Lanka Navy in the beach area of Urumalei, Talaimannar on Monday (16) led to the recovery of over 4kg of Crystal Methamphetamine (ICE), about 1kg of heroin and over 5kg of hashish concealed in a dinghy. In a similar effort, SLNS Thammanna in the North-Central Naval Command conducted an operation in the Urumalei beach area, in the wee hours of Monday (16) and searched a suspicious dinghy on the beach. That led to the recovery of four packages of Crystal Methamphetamine weighing about 4.194kg, a parcel of heroin weighing around 1.034kg and five packages of hashish weighing about 5.254kg. The consignment of narcotics and the dinghy were taken into the naval custody. Meanwhile, the gross street value of the stock of narcotics is believed to be over Rs 94 million. The assortment of drugs and the dinghy held by the Navy in this operation were handed over to the Police Narcotics Bureau,  Talaimannar for onward legal action.

title: People’s Struggle Movement call on UN to halt Hamas, Palestinian conflict
author: Author not found
Content: A united demonstration organised by the People’s Struggle Movement, took place on Monday (16) evening in front of the United Nations office at Thummulla Junction, Colombo in solidarity with Palestine. They demanded the freedom of Palestine. Several political parties, mass organisations, and dedicated social activists participated in the protest, urging the UN to take immediate action to prevent the on-going conflict and loss of innocent lives among both Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Observation tour of Parliament for disabled
author: Author not found
Content: A group of people with hearing, visual, and physical disabilities were on an observation tour of Parliament yesterday (17). The tour was arranged in response to a request made by the Disability Organisations Joint Front to the Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera to get a better understanding of the parliamentary process and provide an opportunity to meet MPs. The Public Outreach Section of the Department of Communications of Parliament offered the group essential information about parliamentary procedure. Later, the group had a friendly discussion with the Chairman of the Parliamentary Caucus for Persons with Disabilities, MP Dullas Alahapperuma. The group shared insights into the issues and challenges faced by their community, emphasising their desire for equal opportunities rather than special privileges in society. Alahapperuma acknowledged the importance of increased societal discussions to address the needs of the disabled community and ensure equal opportunities for all. The Deputy Co-Chairperson of the Parliamentary Caucus for Persons with Disabilities, MP Madura Withanage, MP Jayantha Samaraweera, Commissioner General of Elections Saman Sri Ratnayake, and various members representing Disability Organisations Joint Front also took part. They took a group photo with Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena.

title: Crucial role of China, Huawei to support SL’s digitaleducation system- President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is on an official four-day trip to China, led the delegation to Huawei’s research and development centre in Beijing yesterday (17). During the meeting, Senior Vice President of Huawei technologies and President of Huawei Asia Pacific, Simon Lin, announced his company’s commitment to supporting an annual study programme aimed at nurturing software and hardware engineers in Sri Lanka. He said Huawei has already initiated collaborations with several Sri Lankan universities, providing not only academic assistance but also technology and infrastructure support. President Wickremesinghe said the purpose of his visit was to discuss the future of Sri Lanka. He highlighted the crucial role of both the Chinese Government and Huawei in supporting Sri Lanka’s digital education system and green energy production. Wickremesinghe said the need was for Sri Lanka to build a competitive digital and green economy to meet the challenges of the future. He said the groundwork for this transformation was already in progress. The discussions also covered the importance of empowering Sri Lankans with digital technology, which is closely linked to the nation’s economic growth. The Sri Lankan delegation was briefed on Huawei’s international services and their latest technological advancements. Further, an agreement was signed during this visit, formalising Huawei’s support for the digitisation of Sri Lankan schools. Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, Minister of Transport and Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena, Senior Presidential Adviser on National Security, and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayaka were also present at this event. Additionally, the Sri Lankan delegation, led by the President held discussions with heads of several leading entrepreneurial organisations, including the China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC).

title: Recognising the contribution of women in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Achieving gender equality and empowering women is not only the right thing to do but is a critical ingredient in the fight against extreme poverty, hunger and malnutrition. As the world celebrates International Rural Women’s Day on 15 October each year, the day shines a spotlight and recognises the significant contributions of women to global development.  To recognise the vital contribution of rural women in Sri Lanka, a commemorative event took place in Polonnaruwa yesterday with over 300 women across seven districts and the participation of high-level representatives including; Roshan Ranasinghe, Minister of Irrigation and Sports; Anupa Pasqual, State Minister of Social Empowerment; Mizukoshi Hideaki, Ambassador of Japan to Sri Lanka; Azusa Kubota, Resident Representative, UNDP in Sri Lanka; along with representatives from local government and civil society organisations. Speaking at the event, Minister Ranasinghe, said, “I appreciate the efforts taken to celebrate Rural Women’s Day here in Polonnaruwa, a testament to their resilience to hardships and challenges faced over the years…We acknowledge the grant support provided by the Government of Japan and other stakeholders through these UNDP-led interventions, to support and empower these communities.” Commenting on the importance of the day, State Minister Pasqual, stated, “Recognising rural women on a commemorative day such as today, not only empowers women, but supports to build and rebuild strong sustainable women’s networks… I encourage all present here today to commit yourselves, as you have been equipped with the right skills to journey on this new path.” The special event saw the opening of the Gal Oya Green Zone, handing over the poultry feed production centre to the Gal Oya Green Women’s Society, and awarding membership to the Rural Women’s Business Forum, among other activities. These efforts are a result of UNDP-led interventions in the field, through the Green Climate Fund (GCF) financed ‘Climate Resilient Integrated Water Management Project (CRIWMP)’, the Japanese Supplementary Budget (JSB) funded ‘Strengthening Smallholder Farmers and Micro/Home-Based Agriculture Industries for  Enhanced Food and Livelihood Security’ project, and financing from the Government of Luxemburg through UNDP’s Funding Windows supported intervention to create an integrated social protection system for long-term inclusive growth and broad-based resilience. Noting the Government of Japan’s priority in strengthening such interventions in Sri Lanka, Japanese Ambassador Hideaki, stated, “I believe these interventions will provide practical means to uplift lives of vulnerable communities with a focus on women’s economic empowerment and enhance the capacity, promoting their productivity and sustainability, which will contribute to the economic recovery of Sri Lanka. The Government of Japan is committed to support the lives of rural women through numerous projects and initiatives.” Through UNDP’s integrated support through the Funding Windows, the Gal Oya Green Zone encompasses a roadside marketplace with 20 eco-friendly sales huts along a kilometre stretch of the Habarana – Trincomalee Road, benefiting 40 women in the area, enabling the sale of ecologically grown home garden agricultural products. In addition, 110 home gardens have been established under the Green Climate Funded CRIWMP and Japanese Supplementary Budget (JSB) supported projects, enhancing nutritional levels, increasing food security among farming families, and creating livelihood opportunities to sell surplus produce at the roadside market. Commenting on UNDP’s role, UNDP Resident Representative, Kubota, highlighted, “From the rising cost of living and food insecurity, women have disproportionally felt the brunt of the compounding crises. Our joint initiatives with the Government of Sri Lanka, generously funded by the Government of Japan, equipped women with livelihood skills and tools to enhance their resilience against these shocks. The women have applied their own indigenous knowledge and innovation to augment the impact of these investments and we clearly see the exponential effect. At UNDP, we are firmly committed to working with women, particularly in rural areas, at this time of difficulty as they can truly be agents of change for the families and communities, and the country as a whole.” Through gender equitable agriculture programmes such as backyard poultry, climate-smart rainwater harvesting and drinking water supply in the Dry Zone to ease the care work burden, quick grant schemes for agro-based enterprises and crop cultivation, engagement of women in micro irrigation systems and water management, Rural Women’s Day is an opportunity to recognise the work of these heroines in the food systems of the world and in Sri Lanka, while striving to create more equitable and sustainable opportunities for all.

title: NMC appoints Mewan Adihetty MD/ Country Manager SL & Maldives
author: Author not found
Content: Noble Manhattan Coaching Ltd (NMC Ltd) announced the appointment of Mewan Adihetty as Managing Director/ Country Manager – Sri Lanka & Maldives of the company with effect from 12 September. Noble Manhattan Coaching Ltd was established in 1993 in the UK by Gerard O’Donovan, Founder and CEO, who has a Masters in Psychology and is a world-renowned Trainer and Coach. NMC Ltd is the world’s longest-established Professional Life Coach and Executive Coach training company. NMC Ltd works with both individuals and companies to raise their levels of self-empowerment and achievement. NMC Ltd multinational UK company has been growing a worldwide network of strategic partners and licensed distributors and is now delighted to be trading in 28 countries around the globe. Also, Noble Manhattan Coaching Ltd is among the top three, from about 900 coaching companies in the world. It is a multi-award-winning organisation with a well-earned reputation for delivering the highest quality coaching courses and for creating superb coaches. Mewan’s career spans over 27 years in the fields of Audit, FMCG, Services, Media, Education, Retail Industry, Petroleum Industry, Entrepreneur and Marketing Consultancy for start-ups and scaling up businesses and working with entrepreneurs. He wields a fresh perspective in management and leads strategic business across Sri Lanka and the Maldives. He previously worked as a Marketing Consultant and he leads several key strategic teams as the DGM Marketing of Lanka Sathosa Ltd. He previously worked as Head of Sales & Marketing at one of the largest retail sectors in Maldives. Mewan completed his Postgraduate Diploma in Marketing from CIM in the UK and achieved Chartered Marketer status from CIM (UK), achieved Certified Professional Marketer status from (AMF) – Singapore. He also completed an MBA from Anglia Ruskin University – UK. Further, he completed Digital Marketing courses at the Indian Institute of Digital Education (IIDE). Mewan is also a member of CIM (UK) and SLIM (SL). In recognition of his professional work and commitment to inspire, he won Practicing Marketer Award from SLIM (SL) as well.

title: Veteran film producer Buddhi Keerthisena no more
author: Author not found
Content: Veteran film producer Deshabandu Buddhi Keerthisena passed away yesterday (17) morning. Keerthisena, who was the co-founder of Buddhi Batiks, was 83 years at the time of his demise. His mortal remains will be placed in repose at his residence on Lake Drive, Colombo 8, starting from Wednesday (18), until 9:00 a.m. on Thursday (19). Thereafter, his remains will be moved to the Buddhi Batiks workshop in Koswadiya, Mahawewa, and can be viewed until 3:00 p.m. on Saturday (21). The final rites of Keerthisena will take place at 4:00 p.m. on Saturday (21) at the Koswadiya Cemetery, in accordance with the family’s wishes. Keerthisena is survived by his wife, Margaret Ranasiri Keerthisena and his children Darshi Keerthisena and the renowned filmmaker Boodee Keerthisena.

title: GRTA slams Health Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: With a shortage of radiologists in the State health service, with a 40% vacancy rate, the Government Radiological Technologists’ Association (GRTA) expressed concern about the suspension of new recruitments for the State health service for over a year, which has led to a severe shortage of professionals in fields related to medicine. GRTA President Chanaka Dharmawickrema on Monday (16) lamented that serious crisis had arisen as a result of the Government’s non recruitment policy in categories of professions supplementary to medicine (PSM).The shortages have been increasing among   radiological technologists, laboratory scientists, pharmacists, physiotherapists and occupational therapists. More than 1,500 PSM categories are awaiting jobs having completed their examinations. However, the Health Ministry is yet to do needful for them to be absorbed into State service. The PSM categories provide their services in nearly 250 hospitals across the island. The shortage of Radiological Technologists and other PSM category have led to the disruption of services provided by them.   At present, there are hospitals where radiation tests, laboratory tests, physiotherapy treatments and dispensing of medicines have been disrupted completely. He alleged that it had resulted in unqualified individuals being deployed to dispense medicines to patients risking patients’ lives. GRTA President accused the Health Ministry of wasting public funds by abandoning recruitment of trained professionals. He accused the Health Ministry of shirking its responsibility by allowing the country’s hospital system to collapse. Dharmawickrema said that steps should at least be taken to provide the relevant internship training to those awaiting PSM jobs and send them for foreign employment so that the country could at least receive foreign exchange as there was a demand overseas for such categories. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: People paying for their election mistakes
author: Author not found
Content: The country continues to grapple with the dire consequences of placing power in the hands of a politically and economically uninformed person who attempted to revolutionise the nation through the introduction of his ineffective policies, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said on Monday (16). He added that many patriots have now emerged in the country and suggested that if they indeed are patriots, they should extend a helping hand to rebuild the nation without insisting on immediate elections. He also expressed concern about the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine, which he believes will significantly impact the global economy, particularly the oil market, alongside the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine. He stressed that the most severe repercussions would be felt by Sri Lanka, as well as other countries worldwide. Nanayakkara pointed out that certain factions are mistakenly hoping that the ongoing conflict between Palestine and Israel will lead to the collapse of Sri Lanka’s economy, which they intend to exploit for political gain. He criticised politically motivated politicians for attempting to manipulate the emotions and poverty of ordinary people as pawns on their political chessboard to achieve their goals. “At a time when the country is grappling with a severe economic crisis, the primary concern of the people is to meet their basic needs, not to rush into an election. As a responsible political party attuned to the needs of the people, we are focused on restoring those affected by the crisis to normalcy, rather than prioritising immediate elections as a way out of the ongoing tragic situation,” Nanayakkara added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: PUCSL asks CEB to submit revised tariff proposal PUCSL asks CEB
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) has requested a revised tariff proposal from the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), expressing concerns regarding some key assumptions made, in their recent submission, to increase electricity rates. The CEB had sought a substantial tariff increase of approximately 22 per cent. The CEB has been instructed to submit a revised tariff proposal on or before Wednesday (18). The CEB, in late September, made a request to the PUCSL for an interim tariff increase, citing two key reasons, which are, the unexpected lower rainfall levels up to August, increased costs incurred as a result of coal plant outages. The lower rainfall was the basis for the previous tariff adjustment, as cited by the CEB. The CEB explained that the dry weather conditions upon which the last tariff revision was predicated had materialised in practice. Furthermore, the anticipated generation of 4,500 GigaWatt hours of hydro energy, which had prompted a larger tariff reduction by the regulator, was no longer likely, even with higher levels of rainfall experienced in the last quarter. The PUCSL, in a letter to the CEB General Manager, on 13 October, pointed out that the CEB’s predictions for a recovery in electricity demand were lower than the actual figures for both September and October. Furthermore, there was a greater accumulation of hydroelectric storage than originally projected, thanks to recent rains. Additionally, coal prices in rupees were observed to be lower than initially estimated. Notably, the cost of coal had decreased from 68.4 rupees per kilogram in a submission dated 15 May to Rs 52.6 in a subsequent submission, as indicated by the PUCSL. This reduction in coal prices did not align with the decrease in coal power generation. Furthermore, the PUCSL said the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) maintained the stability of the LKR at around 323.50 against the USD, primarily through a consistent and accommodating monetary policy. Furthermore, global energy prices were steadying, partially due to a more restrained Federal Reserve policy. While there was a recent conflict between Israel and Hamas, that temporarily increased oil prices, they were also stabilising. In the letter, the PUCSL had adjusted coal generation figures from an earlier 1,444 GigaWatt hours to 1,334 GigaWatt hours. However, the commission anticipates a decline in electricity demand that would surpass the reduction in coal power generation. (MD)

title: PM calls for Party Leaders’ meeting on polls laws
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena has called for a Party Leaders’ meeting tomorrow (18) in Parliament to discuss proposed amendments to election laws. It is expected to discuss the proposal of electing 160 MPs from constituencies and the other 65 through the Proportional Representation (PR) system. In a letter to the Party Leaders, the PM’s Secretary Anura Dissanayake said the PM has submitted two Cabinet papers on holding the election according to the mixed voting system and the preparing of laws in connection with regulating the placing cash deposits for the elections. During a meeting held on 10 October, the Cabinet decided to hold discussions with the Party Leaders and get their opinions on the matter and submit a report to the Cabinet, the PM’s Secretary said. Meanwhile, both Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) have expressed their objections over any type of amendment to existing election laws before holding the indefinitely postponed Local Government Election 2023. The enactment of the Elections Expenditure Regulation Act No. 03 of 2023, the need for corresponding amendments to the Parliamentary Elections, Presidential Elections, Provincial Council Elections and the Local Government Elections Ordinance was recognised by the Cabinet during a recent Cabinet meeting. These amendments were discussed and approved during a Cabinet of Ministers meeting held on 23 January 2023, with the Attorney General having granted clearance for the draft bill prepared by the Legal Draftsman. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Govt decided to not start anymore SOEs – Shehan
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe said the Government has taken a policy decision not to start any State-Owned Enterprise (SOE). He mentioned this during a recent event held in Anuradhapura. He added, “Currently there are around 430 SOEs. Some of these projects show profit while others are incurring losses. Last year alone the Government spent some Rs 1.5 trillion to operate these SOEs, but, if that money had been invested in a private sector the Government should have gained more revenue. “Already, the Treasury has been forced to incur heavy costs to sustain SOEs that do not provide tangible returns. These monies could otherwise be utilised for welfare programmes of the public and development work. Therefore, the Government has taken a policy decision not to start any SOE in the foreseeable future.” The State Minister added that all loss-making SOEs will be restructured in the coming months. BY Samantha Kohombakadawala – Anuradhapura

title: Anuradhapura doctors perform ‘awake’ brain surgery
author: Author not found
Content: In a remarkable incident, a patient who was going through an ‘awake brain surgery’ was able to remain awake and fully conscious and even created a drawing. The Neurosurgery Unit, at Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital, recently conducted this successful brain surgery to remove a brain tumor. This procedure, known as an ‘awake craniotomy’, involves operating on the brain while the patient is awake, allowing communication with the surgical team and voluntary movements. Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital achieved another milestone as this was the first awake brain surgery ever conducted in a State hospital in Sri Lanka. The surgery focused on resecting a tumor located in the patient’s left frontal lobe. The patient remained under minimal sedation without the use of general anesthesia. The patient, a 36-year-old sculptor, created a drawing, during the surgery, to assist the medical team in preserving areas of the brain responsible for speech, motor function, and sensory perception as they removed the tumor. Following the successful procedure, the patient, a resident of Nochchiyagama, was discharged from the hospital without any complications. The surgery was carried out by a dedicated medical team, including Dr. Madushanka Gomez and Dr. Rohan Paris, neurosurgeons at Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital, as well as anesthesiologists Dr. Levan Kariyawasam and Dr. Vishakha Kerner. BY Sumedha Karunarathna – Mihintale

title: Wanted man killed in shootout with Police
author: Author not found
Content: A suspect sought in connection with multiple shooting incidents in the Kandana area was fatally wounded in an exchange of gunfire with Police at Sapugaskanda, on Sunday (15) night. According to the Police, the suspect lost his life during the confrontation when the Police were about to arrest him. Acting on a tip-off, that the suspect was residing in a rented house in Sapugaskanda, a team of officers from the Kandana Police arrived at the location with the intention of making the arrest. During the operation, the suspect opened fire, from within the house, on the Police team, prompting them to respond in kind. The 49-year-old suspect succumbed to injuries sustained in the shootout, confirmed Police.

title: Swindler allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: The CID’s Financial Crimes Investigation Department (FCID) yesterday informed Maligakanda Magistrate Lochani Abeywickrema that the investigation into the illegal depositing of money, by former Operations Manager of Delma Exchange Financial Exchange Center (FEC) in Abu Dhabi, from the remittance of Sri Lankan migrant workers in the Middle East, has been concluded.  The suspect, S. Iresha Wickremasinghe had deposited a sum of Rs 243.1 million from remittances of Sri Lankan migrant workers in Middle East, to five bank accounts belonging to his wife and relatives.  The FCID, prosecuting, told the Court, that they had commenced a probe into the incident, following a complaint by the Delma Company. They stated that by the time the fraud had come to light, after a group of Sri Lankan migrant workers had complained about to the FEC in the UAE, the suspect had returned to the country. Later, the FCD produced the suspect in Court and submitted further submissions. They told the Court, that the suspect concerned, who had been a resident of Chilaw, had served as the Operations Manager of the Delma Exchange from 2010 to 2017. The Police explained that from the money embezzled by the suspect, he had purchased several large plots of land in Chilaw. He had committed the fraud, by illegally changing the numbers of the funds that had been received by the Delma Company. The Police then produced a few copies of land deeds, to further prove the fact, that the suspect had bought plots of land in Chilaw. The prosecution added that after a probe had been conducted into the scam and based on advice from the Attorney Genetal, they had arrested the suspect and that the probe, related to the actions of the suspect, had been concluded. The FCID informed Magistrate Abeywickrema, that the actions committed by the suspect, had flouted Provisions contained in Section 386 of the Penal Code and the Provisions contained in Sections of the Offences against the Money Laundering Act No. 5 of 2006, as Amended by the Act No. 40 of 2011. They said that the Attorney General has therefore decided to institute legal action, against the suspect concerned, before the Colombo High Court and urged the Court, to imprison the suspect until then. Attorneys Dilshan Karunaratne and Deshan Hewawithana, on the instructions of Sudath Perera Law Firm, appeared on behalf of the aggrieved party and the plaintiff from the FEC in UAE. Attorney-at-Law Didula Rajapaksa looked into the interests of the suspect and he requested the Court, to enlarge his client under any suitable bail conditions, as his passport has been impounded. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Magistrate released the suspect under strict bail conditions, as the probe against him, has already been concluded. The Magistrate thus granted bail to the suspect, in two sureties of Rs 15 million each and ordered that his passport to be impounded. She also called for a report containing details of properties owned by the bail guarantors to the suspect, to be submitted to Court and instructed the Colombo Land Registry, to be informed accordingly, preventing the transfer of any properties that had been placed as bail guarantee, to another party. Afterwards the Court informed the Police, to file a progress report on the case on 8 December. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Shift focus from closing to preserving schools – Dinesh
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena called for a shift in focus from closing schools to protecting and preserving them. The Prime Minister emphasised the responsibilities of educaters, stating, “The role of teachers is to fulfill their duties while ensuring that our children become responsible citizens.” He questioned the need to close successful schools, for trivial reasons and urged education officials to take note. He also stressed the importance of resource utilisation for education, suggesting that any resources or donations received for education should be used to enrich schools’ creatively. “We believe that by equipping our children with proficiency in all three languages and information technology, we are shaping a brighter future for them,” he said. The Prime Minister’s remarks were made yesterday (16) during the inauguration of the new ‘Matika Mata’ commemoration building at Wellawatte Visakha Vidyalaya, an institution affiliated to Lindsey Girls’ College in Colombo. Visakha College, established in 1935 through a generous donation from philanthropist E.S. Fernando, had faced the threat of closure in 2016. However, it was resuscitated and linked with Lindsey Girls’ College, Bambalapitiya, through the intervention of the then Sri Devi de Silva, now known as ‘Dasasil Mata, Matika Mata’. Addressing the event, Prime Minister Gunawardena stated, “All education officials in Sri Lanka should deeply contemplate the matter of school closures. It is not solely the government that has provided us with educational institutions. Many of our schools were painstakingly constructed by our own people and it is these schools that have propelled our nation to the forefront of the education sector. We must always bear this in mind.” He also highlighted the significant strides made by Sri Lanka in the field of education through a programme aimed at integrating all schools into a national education initiative. “We have overcome various challenges and achieved excellence in education. It is our duty to continue progressing on the world stage,” the Prime Minister added. Gunawardena also acknowledged the profound contribution of the E.S. Fernando family to Wellawatta and the nation’s literary and cultural heritage. “Wellawatta is a hub of literature and culture, attracting even world-renowned figures like Nobel Prize winner Pablo Neruda. Preserving Wellawatta’s identity is vital for our nation,” he remarked. Prominent figures, including Bambalapitiya Siri Vajiraramadhipati Aggamaha Pandita Most Ven. Thricunamale Ananda Thera, former Speaker Deshmanya Karu Jayasuriya, MP Yadamini Gunawardena, as well as teachers, parents, and students, joined the event.

title: Special consideration to Pastor Jerome not possible
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (16) conveyed to the Court of Appeal that it is not feasible to give special legal consideration to Pastor Jerome Fernando, who is accused of allegedly making offensive remarks about other religions. This statement was made in response to a Writ Petition submitted by Pastor Jerome, in which he sought an Order preventing his arrest by the CID. Representing the Attorney General, Senior State Counsel Shaminda Wickrama provided this information to the Court during the hearing. The petition in question was submitted before a to judge Bench, comprising President of the Court of Appeal, Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and Justice Chamath Morais. On 26 May, Pastor Fernando submitted a Fundamental Rights (FR) petition through his legal representatives to the court, requesting an order to halt his potential arrest. The respondents named in this petition included the Inspector-General of Police (IGP), the Deputy Inspector General in charge of the CID, the CID director, and the Officer-in-Charge (OIC) of the cybercrime’s unit of the CID. In his petition, the Pastor contended that the CID’s efforts to arrest him were unlawful, asserting that the Police had not presented any evidence to the Court demonstrating that his comments posed a threat to religious harmony in the country.

title: Dinesh Schaffter’s family allowed to bury remains
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (16) gave permission to the family of deceased millionaire businessman Dinesh Schaffter, to rebury his exhumed remains at the Jawatta Public Cemetery. Accordingly, she advised the CID, to take requisite measures, to hand over the victim’sremains, to his family members. The Additional Magistrate also instructed Schaffter’s family members, not to cremate the businessman’s remains under any circumstance as the five-member team of forensic medical specialists, appointed to probe the manner of his death had still not returned a conclusive verdict. Magistrate Jayasuriya gave these instructions, following a request made to her by the lawyers for deceased’s family, led by President’s Counsel Anuja Premaratne, at the previous hearing. They had urged the Court, to grant allow Schaffter’s family to cremate his exhumed remains at the Borella Cemetery as per his last will and if not to allow them to bury his remains at the Anglican Section of the Jawatta Public Cemetery. The request to this effect was made to Court, through an affidavit as per instructions issued bythe Additional Magistrate at the previous hearing. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Despite receding floods, residents in low-lying areas still in distress
author: Author not found
Content: Although the flood situation in the Matara District is gradually decreasing, residents living in low-lying areas, near the Nilawala River, continue to endure hardships brought by the lingering floodwaters. In an effort to alleviate their suffering, the Army took action yesterday to provide drinking water and essential sanitary materials to the affected communitiesin the premises of Hitthetiya Rajamaha Viharaya. Regrettably, the situation remains dire for some, as those seeking refuge were instructed to vacate the temple grounds. The villagers remain in a state of desperation as their homes remain submerged, rendering them unable to return. The persistent flooding in lowland areas, around the Nilawala River, continues to pose challenges, leaving residents in distress despite the receding waters in other parts of the district. Text and pix: Amila Gamage

title: Sunrise SC continues beach clean-up
author: Author not found
Content: The beach clean-up programme, initiated by the Akkaraipattu Sunrise Sports Club, on the first Saturday of every month, has been consistently carried out with great enthusiasm by the club’s members, along with the participation of various Social Welfare Organisations in the area.  This month’s programme kicked off at the location of the An-Noor Beach Mosque, where a substantial amount of waste, including used plastic bottles, polythene bags, and other debris, was diligently collected from the beach. These collected items were then transported to disposal sites by the Municipal Council’s garbage vehicles. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Sour banana, mango projects a success
author: Author not found
Content: The Sour Banana Cultivation Project and the TEJC Mango Project, initiated in Jaffna, under the Agriculture Sector Modernisation Project of the Ministry of Agriculture, have emerged as two highly successful ventures. Currently, the sour banana project spans 200 acres, while the mango project encompasses 500 acres. The sour banana and TEJC mango plantations in Jaffna have been established with the goal of exportation. Presently, 10,000 kg of sour bananas are exported to the Dubai market weekly in collaboration with the Rajangana Sour Banana Project. On 15 October Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera visited the Jaffna area to assess the progress of these two projects. Member of Parliament Angajan Ramanathan joined him. Under the TEJC Mango Project, 500 acres of TEJC mangoes are cultivated in the Elutumattuwal area of Chavakachcheri. Additionally, 200 acres of sour bananas have been planted in the Jaffna agricultural region, along with the establishment of a sour banana processing center in Nilavarei. After inspecting these two projects, the minister remarked: “These projects, launched under the Agricultural Sector Modernisation Project, have been very successful. We have decided to further expand these initiatives. Especially through high-density cultivation methods, we aim to maximise yields from the available land.” The minister also noted that paddy cultivation in Jaffna does not yield significant harvests, with an average yield of two metric tons per hectare. Consequently, farmers do not receive adequate income from this crop. As a result, there is a need for new crops and cultivation methods. “We are prepared to provide new cultivation techniques, technology, and all necessary resources to those interested in diversifying into alternative crops.” Both the mango and sour banana projects have become valuable contributors to the country’s economy, generating foreign exchange. The cultivation and processing of agricultural products adhere to the highest standards. Sour banana cultivation in Jaffna is expanding by an additional 400 acres, while the TEJC mango project’s current acreage is deemed sufficient. A substantial mango harvest is anticipated in the near future. Therefore, efforts will be made to maintain market demand for these mangoes. In this regard, the minister emphasised that new mango plantations beyond the current projects should not be promoted. Instead, the Ministry is actively encouraging farmers to explore other exportable crops. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SJB praises Lankan Ambassador to Israel
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) praised Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Israel, Nimal Bandara, saying that the latter has been doing a commendable job in ensuring the safety of Sri Lankans in the Gaza Strip amidst the ongoing conflict. SJB National Organiser Tissa Attanayake, addressing the media yesterday (16) said, “We have observed the effective actions of Sri Lanka’s Ambassador in Israel, particularly his endeavours to visit conflict areas in the Gaza Strip to safeguard Sri Lankan residents. This is indeed praiseworthy. Nevertheless, there are broader concerns for Sri Lanka.”  Attanayake said a significant number of Sri Lankans are employed in Gaza and Israel, and there is a potential impact on remittance collections. This could potentially lead to a new foreign exchange issue for Sri Lanka. Moreover, there is a looming possibility of rising fuel and gas prices. It’s possible that the government may capitalise on this situation to increase fuel and gas prices, he added.

title: UNP convention set for 21 October
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara announced that the UNP convention has been scheduled for 2.00 p.m. on 21 October at the Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium. President Ranil Wickremesinghe will preside. However, due to the adverse weather conditions, the initial plan to accommodate 24,000 participants has been scaled down to avoid potential inconveniences for party supporters. He said that several historically significant decisions will be made during the convention. These include amendments to the party’s constitution, aimed at transforming the UNP into a more formidable force by addressing past issues. While addressing the media at Sirikotha, the UNP General Secretary explained that in January 2021, President Ranil Wickremesinghe took action to appoint a new working committee for the party. This move came after members who were part of the UNP’s working committee formed a new party following the historic defeat in the 2020 General Election. He stated that in alignment with the aspirations of last year’s Aragalaya, the UNP is prepared to support a system change that the country currently needs to overcome its challenges. He further mentioned that the party’s new constitution will be designed to adapt to the ever-evolving geopolitical landscape and contribute to achieving the sustainable development goals set by President Wickremesinghe for Sri Lanka’s 100th Independence Day in 2048. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Meeriyabedda faces landslide threats again
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 800 persons residing near the former landslide site in Meeriyabedda, Koslanda in Haldummulla and its vicinity, were evacuated due to the imminent risk of landslides following heavy rains since Saturday (14) night, Haldummulla Divisional Secretary K.A.J. Priyangika said. According to the Divisional Secretary, this step was taken on the recommendations of the National Building Research Organisasion (NBRO). Some 778 people were evacuated amidst heavy rains. A total of 144 families living on both sides of the Meeriyabedda old landslide site were evacuated. They were relocated to the Koslanda tea factory, while an additional 23 families from the Mahakanda Grama Niladhari Division were moved to the Malvanna tea factory. One family from the Dimbulgasmulla was evacuated to the Koslanda Tamil Vidyalaya. Evacuation efforts were conducted by the Army, disaster relief officers from the Haldummulla Divisional Secretariat and Forest Department officers. These measures were essential also due to the looming threat of encounters with elephants in the nearby forest. The decision to evacuate residents was prompted by a significant and sudden increase in rainfall within a short period, after several years.  Signs of potential landslides in Miriyabedda and surrounding areas heightened concerns for the safety of the local population, the Divisional Secretary said. In addition to the landslide risks, the heavy rain has also created challenges for road safety. Roads between Beragala and Haputale as well as the Beragala- Wellawaya Road and Ella – Wellawaya Road, are susceptible to rock-falls from the mountains. The Bandarawela Police Superintendent’s Office has issued a warning, urging drivers to exercise caution when travelling on these sections of the road. Meanwhile, due to the risk of landslides in Koslanda, ​​Haldummulla three schools are closed today (16). Further, principals of 144 schools in the Bandarawela Zonal Education Division have been informed that prior to re-opening schools today (16), they should ensure that there are no risks related to weather conditions. (File photo) BY Saman Palitha Nanayakkara – Haldummulla

title: President off to China
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe left for China yesterday (15) night to attend the 3rd Belt and Road Forum for International Cooperation. The President will engage in a  four-day official visit to China from 16 to 20 October. During his absence, the responsibilities of the Ministries under his purview have been temporarily entrusted to the respective State Ministers and a Cabinet Minister. As part of this arrangement, State Minister Pramitha Bandara Tennakoon will serve as the Acting Minister of Defence, State Minister Ranjith Siyambalapitiya as Acting Minister of Finance, State Minister Kanaka Herath as Acting Minister of Technology and ActingMinister of Investment Promotion, State Minister Anupa Pasqual as Acting Minister for Women, Children Affairs and Social Empowerment and Minister of Wildlife and ForestResources Conservation Pavithra Wanniarachchi as Acting Minister of Environment with effect from today (16).

title: Couple arrested over assault on woman employee
author: Author not found
Content: Kandana Police arrested a couple, following a video showing a woman being assaulted at a private institution. According to Police, the incident took place on 3 October at a private institution on Aniyakanda Road, Nagoda in Kandana. An investigation was initiated on information received on the Police emergency line. Kandana Police arrested the suspects last night at Lipton Road, Nagoda. Further investigations revealed that the arrested male was a close relative of the assaulted woman. The husband and wife in question were operating an online goods trading business in the Aniyakanda. It was found that the woman had been residing at this relative’s residence for approximately three years and was employed in their company, Police said. The woman did not initially report the assault to the Police due to the connection with the couple. However, she decided to file a complaint with the Police once the video footage of the incident began circulating on social media and television.

title: EP Governor flouts Presidential Secy’s Circular
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman has appointed 21 individuals to his personal staff, in violation of a circular issued by the Secretary to the President, a Right to Information (RTI) request revealed. According to circular PS/CSA/00/1/4/2, issued by the Secretary to the President on 12 October 2018, a Governor could only appoint 15 to his or her personal staff. However, the information obtained through the RTI request indicates that Governor Thondaman exceeded this limit by appointing 21 persons. “Of them, five were appointed on a temporary basis,” stated Eastern Governor Secretary L.P. Madanayake, in the RTI response. Also, among Governor Thondaman’s personal staff, only one is a resident of the Eastern Province. According to the Circular, only two drivers could be appointed for the Governor’s two vehicles. “Governor Thondaman appointed three drivers,” confirmed the Eastern Province Secretariat in response to the RTI request. Governor Thondaman currently operates two offices, one in Trincomalee and a sub-office in Ampara, in addition to the Governor’s Secretariat. Furthermore, the RTI request revealed that Dr. Senarath Hewage, former Chairman of the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB), who was ousted from his post last December, following allegations of corruption by Opposition MPs in Parliament, is currently serving as a coordinating secretary to Governor Thondaman. Dr. Senarath Hewage is using a vehicle registered to the name of the Chief Secretary of the Eastern Province and receives 213 litres of fuel monthly in his capacity as a coordinating secretary to the Governor, confirmed the Governor’s Secretary. Additionally, Eastern Province Governor’s Private Secretary L.L. Anil Wijesiri and Coordinating Secretary Dr. Senarath Hewage visited Wuhan Province in China in August. During this visit, Dr. Senarath Hewage was introduced to Chinese media as an advisor to the Eastern Province Governor. By Rifthi Ali

title: Dozen journalists killed, 2 missing, 8 injured
author: Author not found
Content: The ongoing hostilities between the militant group Hamas and Israel have resulted in the tragic deaths of at least 12 journalists, with two more missing and eight others injured, a journalism organisation reported on Saturday (14). The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) issued a statement on its website, revealing the grim toll inflicted on journalists during the first eight days of the conflict. As of 14 October, the CPJ documented that a dozen journalists had lost their lives while reporting from the region, with two individuals still unaccounted for and eight sustaining injuries. The conflict has taken a devastating toll on both sides, with The Associated Press reporting more than 3,000 fatalities. The prospect of further casualties looms large as Israel prepares for an imminent ground offensive in Gaza. Journalists, particularly those stationed in Gaza, find themselves in perilous circumstances as they endeavour to provide coverage amidst Israeli troop incursions, relentless airstrikes, disrupted communications, and widespread power outages, as noted by CPJ.The organisation’s report specified, “In the first eight days of the conflict, 10 Palestinian journalists have been confirmed dead, one Israeli journalist has been confirmed killed and one reported missing. On October 13, a Beirut-based journalist lost his life during a shelling attack in southern Lebanon while six others were wounded.” Amidst the escalating crisis, Israel ordered the evacuation of approximately one million residents from the northern part of Gaza to the southern territory on Friday. The United Nations has expressed grave concerns about the potential consequences of such a mass movement within a 24-hour deadline. The CPJ stressed the importance of recognising journalists as civilians who play a vital role during crises and must not be targeted by warring parties. Sherif Mansour, CPJ’s Middle East and North Africa programme coordinator, emphasised, “Journalists are making great sacrifices across the region covering this important conflict. Measures to ensure their safety must be taken by all parties to stop this deadly and heavy toll.” (With inputs from agencies)

title: Pay hikes for public sector in upcoming Budget – Aluthgamage
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage said an increase in public sector employees’ salaries is expected to be included in the upcoming budget. While participating in the SLPP Nawalapitiya East electorate re-organisation campaign, Aluthgamage said given the current circumstances, it appears feasible to reach an accord with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in the coming month. He said, “We are all aware that the country’s situation is notably different from that of the previous year. There are presently no power outages and gas and fuel are readily available. Additionally, food prices have seen a reduction and we anticipate further price decreases in goods by November this year. A more citizen-friendly environment is being envisaged. “The IMF has previously shown willingness to engage in debt restructuring in our agreements with them. Consequently, we hold a strong belief that we will be able to formalise a Memorandum of Understanding with the IMF next month,” Aluthgamage added. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Need for comprehensive change in education – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha highlighted the need for a comprehensive educational approach, that goes beyond focusing solely on the development of skills in three main subjects, while preparing children for the Grade five Scholarship examinations. The Minister said ignoring other important subjects can hinder the overall development of children as a result, Sri Lanka must move away from the traditional school curriculum to address this issue effectively. The Minister further spoke of the importance of transforming the education system to adapt to changing global demands. With the rapid proliferation of artificial intelligence, many existing jobs worldwide are at risk of elimination, even challenging the roles of professionals like doctors and lawyers. Therefore, the education system must prepare the future generation to face and overcome these challenges effectively, he said. To address these concerns, a pilot programme for STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, the Arts, and Mathematics) education promotion was jointly organised by the Ministry of Education, the National Science Foundation, and the National Institute of Education. The programme was held from 12 – 14 October. Premajayantha was speaking at the closing ceremony on Saturday (14) at the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Colombo. The pilot programme saw the participation of 500 grade 12 students studying science and mathematics subjects in national schools from all 25 districts, alongside 50 teachers. The programme was conducted at various educational institutes, including the National Institute of Education, Sri Lanka Institute of Nanotechnology (SLINTEC), Sri Lanka Institute of Biotechnology (SLIBTEC), NSBM Green University, Colombo Port City, and the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Colombo. The STEAM programme offered students a valuable opportunity to observe real-world concepts in action across various levels through STEAM subjects. Its primary goal is to instill enthusiasm among students for science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and the Arts.

title: Court registrar remanded over forgery
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Mohammad Rizwan on Saturday (14) remanded, until 25 October, the Chief Registrar of the Fort Magistrate Court over forgery. The registrar identified as Ranjani, a resident of Colombo, was arrested following a complaint filed with the CID. She was produced before Court on Saturday (14). She was arrested by the CID on charges of arbitrarily sending a fraudulent letter to the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration in an attempt to help a suspect, who was subject to a travel ban, to leave the country and misplacing the case file of the suspect. The CID informed the Court that they arrested the suspect in the Court premises on Friday (13) afternoon, after informing the Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage. On 15 February, Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage remanded a suspect, who had seven charges in connection with a case of defrauding a life insurance company of more than three million rupees by forwarding false documents. He was also banned from travelling abroad. However, the CID told the Court that the person who was remanded had appealed to the High Court and was granted bail on the same day. Although the case file must be sent to the High Court to continue further proceedings in the case, the Court staff, including the officer in charge of the Court archives, couldn’t locate the case file. After that they informed the Chief Registrar about it, but she did not pay attention to the matter, the CID told the Court. During the search for the missing case file, the suspect registrar instructed a typist of the Court to type a letter related to lifting the foreign travel ban. The vigilant typist, who suspected the motives of preparing such a letter, informed it to the officer-in- charge of the Court archives.  Upon comparing the case numbers, they found that the letter was related to the case in which the file had gone missing. Subsequently, a Court official informed this to the CID. It was revealed during the investigations that the suspect registrar had sent a fax to the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration claiming that the travel ban on the other suspect had been lifted on 13 October. Several discarded pieces of paper related to the preparation of the letter were found in a trash bin near her desk, the CID said. Analytical reports suggested that the registrar and the other suspect had multiple phone conversations lasting over 20 minutes. The CID also informed the Court that the related case file had not been found as yet. The issue of how she prepared a letter related to lifting the foreign travel ban without the case file remains unresolved. Given the revelation that has emerged during the investigation, indicating that the suspect registrar acted arbitrarily and misled the Court, the CID requested that the suspect be further remanded and also mentioned the possible arrest of another individual in connection with this incident. The lawyers representing the suspect registrar requested bail for her, citing her 25 years of service. After considering the arguments from both sides, the magistrate ordered that the suspect registrar be remanded until 25 October. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Loud underground sounds in Wethalawa prompt swift evacuation
author: Author not found
Content: Nadira Lakmal, Divisional Secretary of Kotmale, took swift action to evacuate several families from the Wethalawa village due to a loud sound from under the ground. The sound was akin to the rush of a river and has raised concerns. Authorities took steps to ensure the safety of local residents. The unusual sound is connected to the heavy rainfall currently experienced in Kotmale and the surrounding areas. Wethalawa village, situated within the Kothmale Divisional Secretariat, lies on the border of the Kotmale reservoir. An ancient tank field is in existence but is now an arid wasteland. However, during periods of intense rainfall, locals report that the tank field fills with rainwater. This time, rainwater failed to accumulate in the tank field, but underground water created a sound, villagers said.  On receiving reports, the Divisional Secretary relocated several families to safer locations. The National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) was alerted to investigate the situation. Nishantha Peiris, Senior Geologist of the NBRO, in the Nuwara Eliya District, confirmed that a comprehensive assessment of the land will be conducted to determine the course of action. BY D.M.D. Sisira – Nawa Thispane

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Thalduwa shooting suspect dies in escape bid
author: Author not found
Content: A suspect, who was in Police custody in connection with a shooting in Thalduwa, Avissawella, which resulted in the deaths of two individuals last month, died while attempting to escape. Hambantota Police had initially arrested the suspect and subsequently transferred him to Avissawella Police. He was being held on a three-day detention order for further questioning. However, yesterday (15) when the Police, in the company of the suspect, were searching the Avissawella area for evidence related to the case, based on information provided by the suspect, he made an escape bid. During the incident, the suspect allegedly tried to strangle one of the Police officers using the handcuffs on his hands. In response, the other Police officers attempted to prevent this, resulting in critical injuries to the suspect. Following the incident, the severely injured suspect was rushed to Avissawella Hospital where he was declared dead on arrival. The Police officer injured during the incident is also in critical condition. The shooting incident occurred late on 20 September when two unidentified assailants, on a motorcycle, opened fire on four individuals travelling in a three-wheeler, resulting in the deaths of two and critical injuries to the other two. The attack took place in Thalduwa, where the assailants used a T-56 assault rifle in the shooting before fleeing the scene. The injured victims were promptly transported to Avissawella Hospital, where a 27-year-old and a 36-year-old succumbed to injuries.
