title: Ferry service between Nagapattinam and KKS flagged off
author: Author not found
Content: The ferry service between Nagapattinam in India and Kankesanthurai (KKS) near Jaffna, in the Northern Province of Sri Lanka, commenced on Saturday (14). The ferry was flagged-off from Nagapattinam by the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Waterways of India Shri Sarbananda Sonowal at the Port and External Affairs Minister of Indian Dr. S. Jaishankar through video link. The ceremony was addressed virtually by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva also joined the event virtually.    In his address, Prime Minister Modi recalled the vision document jointly adopted during the visit of the President of Sri Lanka to India in July 2023 for economic partnership between India and Sri Lanka, with the central theme of connectivity. He highlighted that connectivity brings closer the two countries and its people. Recalling the recent launch of the India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor during the G20 Summit in India in September 2023, Prime Minister mentioned that the people of Sri Lanka will benefit from this connectivity corridor, as multimodal connectivity between India and Sri Lanka is strengthened. He further said that both Governments are working on fin-tech connectivity by linking UPI and Lanka Pay, and for connecting the energy grids to enhance energy security.  Prime Minister added that the Governments will continue to work closely to start ferry services on the traditional Rameswaram-Talaimannar sector too. Highlighting the important role of ferry services in enhancing people-to-people ties between the two countries, President Ranil Wickremesinghe thanked the Government of India and the Shipping Corporation of India for taking steps to commence the service.  External Affairs Minister, Dr. S. Jaishankar underlined that the launch of ferry is an affirmation of the people-centric policies of the Government of India. The focus of GOI’s ‘Neighbourhood First’ policy is connectivity, cooperation and contacts and in the future, connectivity with Sri Lanka will be further enhanced through power grid connection, oil pipeline and setting up an economic corridor. He highlighted that establishment of air and sea connectivity, smooth processing of visas and strengthening tourism links will make the lives of common people easier.  Minister of Ports, Shipping and Waterways of India Shri Sarbananda Sonowal hailed the ferry launch as a historic step which will provide an efficient and cost-effective means of travel for the people of the two countries. In his remarks, Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva thanked the Government of India for the assistance extended in upgradation of the KKS Harbour which will bring immense benefits to the Northern Province of Sri Lanka.    high-speed ferry is operated by the Shipping Corporation of India and has a capacity of 150 passengers. The maiden journey between Nagapattinam and KKS (about 60 nm) was covered in approx. 4 hours. The passengers who arrived at KKS on the maiden ferry were welcomed at the port by the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation of Sri Lanka and the Consul General of India at Jaffna, who also saw off the first batch of passengers on the return voyage.

title: Court orders post- mortem on leopard
author: Author not found
Content: Hatton Magistrate M. Farook Deen, on 13 October, ordered the officers of the Nallathanniya Wildlife Office to send the body parts of the mysteriously deceased Panthera  pardus  kotiya (Sri Lankan Leopard) to a veterinarian at Randenigala Veterinary Hospital for the post-mortem The Magistrate ordered that the body of the deceased leopard be produced before the Hatton District Judge as well. The body of a leopard was found within a tea bush on Ledanti Estate, above the Castlereagh Reservoir, in the morning 13 October. This discovery was made following information provided to the Hatton Police by the estate workers. Hatton Police then informed the Nallathanniya Wildlife Officials, who subsequently arrived at the estate to conduct an investigation into the mysterious death of the leopard. During the investigation, it was confirmed that a part of the deceased leopard’s skin had been removed. The leopard that died under mysterious circumstances was a well-grown female, approximately one and a half years old. Wildlife officials stated that the deceased leopard had been living in the same area within the estate. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: LIOC gifts dialysis machines
author: Author not found
Content: The Lanka Indian Oil Company (LIOC) has donated dialysis machines to Kantale Base Hospital, Trincomalee District General Hospital and the Provincial General Hospital in Badulla following a request made to LIOC Chairman Deepak Das by Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman. The machines were handed over to Governor Thondaman by IOC Chairman Deepak at a ceremony hosted at the LIOC Head Office in China Bay, Trincomalee. Governor Thondaman expressed confidence that the dialysis services for kidney patients at those hospitals would be without any hindrance, and that the rural population would immensely benefit because they no longer need to travel to distant hospitals for dialysis. Thondaman said the loss of lives caused by kidney disease, particularly due to the lack of proper and timely dialysis, could be significantly reduced. “At a time when kidney disease is on the rise, such efforts will be helpful in preventing many people from falling victim to kidney-related diseases,” Governor Thondaman added. (NJ)

title: SJB refining its public policy manifesto
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) participated in a workshop titled ‘Policymaking and Governance: Navigating Geopolitical and Economic Challenges’ on 12 October. This event was organised by the National Council of Professionals, led by the esteemed academic and educator, Dr. Tara de Mel. The workshop is part of a series of dialogues aimed at refining and enhancing the SJB’s public policy manifesto in preparation for the upcoming national elections in 2024. These dialogues serve as interactive platforms for the exchange of ideas, questions, and comments in a professional and constructive manner. They aim to ensure that the final policy manifesto presented to the public reflects extensive stakeholder engagement over an extended period. These events typically attract public policy professionals, academics, and public intellectuals who have a record of accomplishments in their respective fields. During this particular event, Dr. Irvin Studin, an accomplished Canadian academic and public intellectual, delivered the keynote address. He is the President of The Institute for 21st Century Questions, a leading Canadian think tank. Dr. Studin, a highly regarded strategy consultant, started his career as an adviser and analyst on a range of domestic and international issues within Canada’s Privy Council Office and was on secondment to Australia’s Department of the Prime Minister & Cabinet in Canberra. Dr. Studin holds a PhD from York University, as well as master’s degrees from Oxford University and LSE. He is also the chair of the Worldwide Commission to Educate All Kids (Post-Pandemic), an international initiative addressing the educational challenges faced by children affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. Furthermore, he is the founder, editor-in-chief, and publisher of Global Brief magazine. In the past, Dr. Studin held positions as a professor and programme director at the School of Public Policy and Governance, University of Toronto, and served as a visiting professor at renowned schools of public policy in North America, Europe, and Asia. The event also featured Emeritus Professor of Law Savitri Goonesekere, a former Vice Chancellor of the University of Colombo and the first woman to hold that position. Prof. Goonesekere is a renowned scholar and pioneer in the fields of children’s rights, women’s rights, and human rights law. With her extensive experience in various positions, she stressed the importance of adopting an intersectional and multidisciplinary approach to public policy. She emphasised that public policy areas are interconnected and not isolated from other spheres of administration. These contributions are part of an ongoing dialogue project aimed at shaping the SJB’s policy manifesto. Eran Wickramaratne reiterated that the SJB is the “government in waiting” and must be prepared to hit the ground running in the new year. Over the past two years, the SJB has engaged with various worker unions, business chambers, entrepreneurial associations, and professional organisations to develop a comprehensive plan for sustainable economic growth and inclusive human development in Sri Lanka. As emphasised by Dr. Studin and Prof. Goonesekere, this requires a multi-faceted approach that considers education, healthcare, business regulation, taxation, security, defence, social welfare, pensions, and foreign policy, all interconnected. Sri Lanka’s education system must align with the needs of the 21st century and support human capital development and industrialisation while addressing demographic challenges. One of the key themes of the event was the significance of policy consistency to ensure that plans are effectively implemented. The SJB is committed to continuous policy evaluation, with regular meetings to assess progress and establish clear reporting lines. A consistent evaluation process is known to enhance the results of public policy programmes. Historically, Sri Lankan policy has been inconsistent, often driven by the preferences of individual leaders and special interest groups. There has been a lack of a comprehensive strategy, with decisions made reactively and based on short-term needs rather than long-term strategic imperatives. The recent evaluation by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) concerning Sri Lanka’s progress on various conditions highlights international recognition of governance deficits and their impact on policymaking and strategy formation. The geopolitical context in which Sri Lanka finds itself, lacking a clear narrative, adds complexity to the development of an overarching economic and social policy. Before opening the floor for a lively question and answer session, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, provided concluding remarks. He called on the audience to contribute to the future governance structure

title: Hans Terbu back for fifth time
author: Author not found
Content: Hans Terbu, a Product Manager at Kuoni Austria has returned to Sri Lanka for the fifth time. His connection to the island began three decades ago. Now, he’s back in Sri Lanka, leading another group of Austrian travellers. With the help of experienced tour guide Bonny Sudusinghe, his mission is to explore the country and contribute to the economy. Over the years, Terbu has been a strong advocate for Sri Lanka. He has brought around 1,000 Austrian visitors to the country multiple times, promoting tourism and cultural exchanges. In the past, Terbu, along with renowned travel agent Pakeer from Asian Exotica Travel, led a large group of 300 Austrian travellers to explore the beautiful landscapes of Sri Lanka. He made history by introducing the iconic Hitachi Train to transport 167 passengers across the country. At a time when tourism is vital for Sri Lanka’s economy, Terbu’s ongoing affection for the nation demonstrates its charm. His visits not only bring economic benefits but also strengthen the bonds between Austria and Sri Lanka, a spokesman said. BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: District 82: Sailing Towards Growth in the 2023-2024 Toastmasters Term
author: Author not found
Content: District 82 announced its leaders for the 2023-2024 Toastmasters year, igniting a journey of growth and achievement. Toastmasters International, a global nonprofit organisation that nurtures public speaking and leadership skills worldwide, is guided by the principle ‘Where leaders are made’. Founded in 1924 and headquartered in Colorado, it has expanded to 148 countries. Members gain confidence and achieve communication goals through speeches, impromptu talks, and supportive feedback in a nurturing environment, all while enhancing their leadership skills. District 82 represents the Toastmasters community in Sri Lanka, the Maldives, and the British Indian Ocean Territory, fostering excellence with 3.4K+ members across 150+ clubs in 60+ cities, with over 30 years since its establishment. The District Trio, consisting of District Director Mahinda Karunakara, DTM (former Registrar of the Ceylon Electricity Board); Programme Quality Director Ganga Fernando, DTM (Senior Lecturer attached to the University of Colombo) and Club Growth Director Niroshan Nadarajah, DTM (Senior Manager of Brand Marketing at Renuka Holdings PLC), will join forces to expand the district, provide club support, deliver training, and equip leaders for success. District Administration Manager: Lalith Manage, District Finance Manager: P. Babukumar (DTM), District Public Relations Manager: Nimnaka Perera, Immediate Past District Director: Nisal Weerakoon (DTM). The district which is divided into divisions A to K, has passionate Division Directors at the helm, nurturing club growth and development. These leaders include Niroshan Dharmakantha (DTM), Kanapathippillai Pirabakaran (DTM), Mohamed Fawaz Jainudeen (DTM),Raveen Lankanatha, Hiranthi Ratnayake (DTM), Shehara Dissanayake (DTM), Dushyanthi Adikary (DTM), Thakshila Jayasena, Royston Cumine (DTM), Oshan Liyanage (DTM) and Methsiri Herath. Area Directors and the dedicated team of extended leaders play a pivotal role in supporting district operations. title: 18th Sujata Jayawardena Memorial Oration
author: Author not found
Content: The 18th Sujata Jayawardena Memorial Oration will be delivered at 5:30 p.m. on Tuesday, 31 October at the BMICH by Dr Shashi Tharoor, Member of Parliament for Thiruvananthapuram, India, bestselling author of twenty-four books, former Under Secretary-General of the United Nations and a former Minister of State for Human Resource Development and for External Affairs in the Government of India, on the topic ‘Is expansion of BRICS the beginning of a new world order?’ The Annual Sujata Jayawardena Memorial Oration, being a premier annual event of the University of Colombo, is hosted for the 18th consecutive year by the Alumni Association of the University of Colombo, in memory of its illustrious Past President the late Mrs. Sujata Jayawardena who rendered immense service to the University of Colombo. Speaking on the Oration, the Vice Chancellor of the University of Colombo Senior Professor H.D. Karunaratne said, “We look forward to the 18th Sujata Jayawardena Memorial Oration to be delivered by the world renowned Dr. Sashi Tharoor on the topic “Is expansion of BRICS a beginning of a New World Order?” which would undoubtedly be a topic of great interest during these evolving times. University of Colombo Alumni President J.M.S. Bandara, speaking about the upcoming Oration, said that the Association was honoured to have Dr. Sashi Tharoor as the Orator for the 18th Sujata Jayawardena Memorial Oration, speak on a topic which is most pertinent to the Region and Sri Lanka given its special geographical setting. Past Orators have been Prof. Chandra Wickramasinghe,  Jayantha Dhanapala,  Robert O. Blake Jr., Judge C.G. Weeramantry, Vidyajothi Prof. Arjuna Aluwihare,  Lalith Weeratunga,  Gotabaya Rajapaksa,  Mahinda Samarasinghe, Dr. P.B. Jayasundara, Prof. Sudarshan Seneviratne, Emeritus Prof. Carlo Fonseka,  Ranil Wickremesinghe, Chinese Ambassador Yi Xianliang, Indian High Commissioner, Taranjit Singh Sandhu, Tony Weerasinghe, Prof. Neelika Malavige and Dr. Indrajit Coomaraswamy. title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: DP Education Marks Four Years of Nurturing Minds
author: Author not found
Content: The fourth-anniversary celebration of DP Education was held on 11 October 2023 at the Nelum Pokuna Mahinda Rajapaksa Theatre in Colombo. Over 1,200, including clergy, distinguished guests, parents, and students, participated. Dhammika Perera Founder and Chairman of DP Education made the keynote address and spoke of the importance of learning information technology, the demand in the future global job market and the possibility of earning foreign exchange for Sri Lanka, as well as the programmes to create a million coders in Sri Lanka. He further said DP Education was able to create the best education system in Asia in four years. The DP Education programme, offered by the Dhammika and Priscilla Perera Foundation, has been recognised as the best online school education programme in Asia at the Bett Asia Awards held last week in Bangkok, Thailand. The award is given to educational programmes that use innovation and innovative technological solutions to modernise school education. The annual Bett Asia Awards recognises educational technology trendsetters and innovators who are revolutionising education in the Asia Pacific region. It is special that DP Education has won first place as the best online school education programme in Asia, surpassing other competitors such as India, Thailand, Malaysia, Japan, Korea, Singapore, and China, DP Education said. Perera further said to develop Sri Lanka it was necessary to move from the analog to the digital era, and by now, other countries have already gone to the digital age, and he was ready to take Sri Lanka to the digital era. He also said students who studied with DP Education for about seven months were invited by companies for jobs. The opening speech was delivered by CEO,  Kawshi Amarasinghe. She spoke of the role of DP Education in creating a digitally literate workforce and making them participate in the job market of an active digital economy. The guest speech was delivered by Malik Ranasinghe, President of Sri Lanka ICTA, Former Senior Professor, and Former Vice-Chancellor of the University of Moratuwa. Perera launched several new brands of DP Education at the event. They are: 1. DP Education New Websiteand Phone App 2. DP Kids Phone App 3. DP Education IT Campus 4. New courses offered by University of Moratuwa 5. SAP Foundation courses offered by Kelaniya University 6. DP Education Language School – DP Education Language School provides an opportunity for everyone to learn various languages to develop language skills or to acquire high employment opportunities in the global job market. 7. DP Education Olympiad – Anyone can learn Maths Olympiad from DP Education for international competitions as well as to develop their critical thinking capability. 8. DP Education Magic Bits Virtual Robots – DP Education and Magic Bits together develop the knowledge and skills needed to control the robots in the Robot Farm live online. 9. DP Education TVET Education – The brand offers vocational education courses to develop the skills required for NVQ levels 3 and 4 for jobs in high demand in the global job market. 10. DP Education Caregiving Course– Tertiary and vocational course teaching NVQ Level 3 and 4 qualifications required by DP Education in collaboration with KIU to provide caregiving services that are in high demand in the global job market. Microsoft Sri Lanka Institute and Rooster Technologies, which are associated with DP Education, were awarded and appreciated for their partnership and their contribution in providing free quality education.

title: Strengthening of supply chain cause of growing drug use
author: Author not found
Content: The growing issue of drug use in the country, despite the presence of numerous rehabilitation programmes, is caused by the strengthening drug supply chain, Pradeep Kumara Koholanegedara, Assistant Director of the Preventive Education and Training Division at the National Dangerous Drugs Control Board (NDDCB) said. Koholanegedara explained that this situation persists because Sri Lanka’s drug prevention efforts primarily target grassroot drug dealers and users. While Sri Lanka boasts stringent drug distribution and usage laws, compared to other countries worldwide, the assistant director emphasised that many long-term problems may arise due to inadequate enforcement of these laws. BY Thakshila Pathirana

title: Pupuressa faces landslide risk
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Pupuressa, Gampola have raised concerns about the lack of a proper drainage system for the town where water overflowing from heavy rains had no way to drain thus posing landslide risks. Houses in the vicinity of the Subramaniam Temple in Pupuressa were facing a severe risk. According to residents, they said they had repeatedly informed the Doluwa Divisional Secretariat and the  local political authorities, Provincial Council and other relevant authorities about the predicament they face when the rains come down. But no action has been taken to address the issue, they said. BY Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: Keheliya seeks AG’s help to act against local company
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella has requested the Attorney General’s guidance on how to proceed in handling the internal stakeholders, accountable for the matter involving Isolez Biotech Pharma AG Limited, which is responsible for the controversial medicinal drug scam of 22,500 vials of Immunoglobulin IV 5g vials. In a letter to the Attorney General, Minister Rambukwella said, on Wednesday (11), that despite the lack of a purchase order from the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC) for the said stock of Immunoglobulin IV 5g vials, which preceded the procurement of pharmaceutical products, the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) had acknowledged and accepted the delivered goods, complicating matters and raising questions about the internal processes and stakeholders involved, he said. The Minister said, “Given the gravity of this situation and the potential breach of regulatory and legal standards, I request your guidance on how to proceed in handling this matter concerning internal stakeholders who are accountable. Explaining the controversy surrounding the stock of Immunoglobulin of which a portion of the order number had been delivered to the MSD, he said that subsequent complications and adverse events associated with using this drug in State Hospitals had necessitated a comprehensive investigation. Rambukwella said, during the probe it had been revealed that the particular supplier had not possessed the necessary waiver of registration (WOR) from the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) which was a critical requirement for engaging in procuring pharmaceuticals. He explained that on examination, the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the NMRA could not find records of evidence indicating that a WOR had been issued to the particular pharmaceutical supplier, raising suspicions of forgery and fraud. “In light of these concerns and to uphold principals of transparency and integrity, a complaint was filed with the CID to conduct an inquiry into the matter. Meanwhile, Rambukwella, wrote to the Health Secretary and heads of all health institutions urging them to immediately suspend and cancel all the orders given to the Isolez Bio Tech Pharma.  He had also informed all payments to the particular supplier to be stopped with immediate effect until the completion of all investigations by the CID. The Health Minister also instructed the suspension and cancellation of orders given to the concerned company. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President orders swift assistance to Lankans stranded in Israel
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Hamas, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has instructed Government officials to give priority to the welfare and security of Sri Lankan citizens living in Israel, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said yesterday (12). Consequently, the PMD has reported that the Sri Lankan Embassy in Israel, in collaboration with relevant government agencies, has launched a special programme dedicated to providing comprehensive assistance to the Sri Lankan community residing in Israel. Sri Lankans living and working in Israel for various reasons now have accessible channels to directly communicate with Sri Lankan authorities in the event of life-threatening situations or other difficulties. They can relay their needs or obtain essential information through the following contact options: – Phone: (+94) 117966396 – WhatsApp: (+94) 767463391 – Email: [email protected] All Sri Lankans in Israel can utilise these services by following established immigration procedures or through other appropriate means, stated by the PMD in an official statement. Earlier, the President expressed deep concern regarding the attacks and their implications for Sri Lankans and Israelis residing in both countries. Stressing the urgency of ensuring the safety of Sri Lankans in Israel, President Wickremesinghe directed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to locate and ensure the well-being of these individuals. He also called for assistance in facilitating the return of Israelis, including tourists and employees, from Sri Lanka to Israel. Additionally, he urged the Police to implement necessary security measures for Israelis within Sri Lanka.

title: Eye disease spreading among children
author: Author not found
Content: Health Authorities have cautioned children and adults against a spread of an eye infection, in several areas of the country, leading to the closure of schools and the postponing of school examinations.    They said yesterday (12) that paediatric and adult patients with eye disease had been diagnosed in Jaffna, Galle and Colombo during the past few weeks. With the spread of the infection steps were taken to close schools, while cancellation of grade exams conducted by schools, were also reported from the Galle in a bid to stem the disease spread. Consultant Paediatrician at the Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH), Dr. Deepal Perera, when contacted, noted that the reddening of eyes, pain and discharge from the eyes and blurred vision were symptoms of the infection. He said, the disease may be associated with respiratory viral infections. He said, the eye infection could last for approximately four to five days. However, Dr. Perera urged the public to refrain from touching their eyes unnecessarily- especially when visiting public places and transport services as some who have contracted the infection may have touched their eyes and touched any of the surfaces that one may be touching or holding on to while in those areas.   The infection is seen from time to time so, there is no need to panic, the Consultant Paediatrician added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Severed head found on beach
author: Author not found
Content: The severed head of an unidentified person was found lying on the Parana Ambalama Beach in Pamunugama last morning (12). Police said the severed head was found following information received by Pamunugama Police last morning and upon visiting the location Police had found that the head has decomposed beyond recognition. Pamunugama Police are conducting further investigations.

title: Sri Lanka’s ALFT Packaging Wins Gold
author: Author not found
Content: ALFT Packaging, Sri Lanka’s premier packaging solutions provider, with the only purpose-built plant within the Sri Lankan flexible packaging industry, has won Gold in the ‘Wide Web Flexo’ category, at the prestigious Asian Packaging Excellence Awards 2023, held in Thailand recently. The distinguished recognition sets ALFT Packaging apart as the sole Sri Lankan company to be honoured at the event. The Asian Packaging Excellence Awards, now in its 20th year, recognises excellence, innovation, and sustainability in the packaging industry across Asia. ALFT Packaging emerged triumphant against strong competition from China, India and Thailand in the same category. ALFT Packaging is renowned for its pioneering role in revolutionising the industry and has consistently raised the bar by delivering solutions that cater to evolving customer needs, while following global standards. The company’s state-of-the-art plant is the only BRC AA certified packaging facility in Sri Lanka. Established just five years ago, ALFT Packaging has rapidly become synonymous with cutting-edge technology, and cost-effective innovative packaging solutions. Chairman of ALFT Packaging, Lakshman de Fonseka, expressing his elation at winning the Gold Award, emphasised that it is a testament to the relentless efforts and firm commitment of their talented team. The award highlights ALFT Packaging’s deeply rooted principles in the company’s business philosophy and dedication to innovation and quality.

title: Medical Council in mess following VP’s removal
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) is going through choppy waters with the removal of its Vice President Prof. Jayantha Jayawardena, Ceylon Today reliably learns. With Prof. Jayawardena’s removal, there is currently no one to oversee the duties of the SLMC President’s post as he is overseas. According to the sources, SLMC President Prof. Vajira Dissanayake was instrumental in removing Prof. Jayantha Jayawardena by allegedly submitting a letter to Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella. They said, the SLMC was once more in disarray due to its President’s frequent overseas visits and arbitrary actions. No arrangements have been made to appoint anyone from within the SLMC to oversee the functions of the establishment during his absence. Sources accused the SLMC President of behaving in an undemocratic manner, without paying attention to the request of the other council members to have special council meeting to discuss the sudden removal of the vice president, they alleged. They accused Prof. Dissanayake of having allegedly submitted letter to Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella on behalf of the council claiming that he has council approval for it. Prof. Jayawardena was the Vice President of the SLMC, Chairman of its Preliminary Proceeding Committee (PPC), Audit Committee, Member of the Management Committee and the Legislative Committee at the time of removal. It is alleged that the arbitrary removal created a very bad precedence for the independence of the Council which had already been compromised during the time of the former Health Minister and the SLMC should request an explanation for the removal of Prof. Jayawardena from his post from Health Minister Rambukwella. Minister Rambukwella recently told the media, during a media briefing, that Prof. Jayawadena could appeal if he felt that his removal was unjust. “The person who appoints the Vice President only removes him. There was nothing personal in his removal,” Rambukwella said, adding that personal relationships should not be allowed to cloud administrative decisions.      By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Final journey of iconic artiste Jackson Anthony
author: Author not found
Content: The final rites of the veteran artiste Jackson Anthony were held at 3:00 p.m. yesterday (12) at the St. Peter & Paul’s Church in Ragama. The mortal remains of the actor, which had been resting at a private funeral parlour in Colombo, were brought to his Kadawatha residence on Wednesday (11) in the night. A multitude of people, including fellow artistes, politicians, religious leaders, and countless others, gathered to pay their last respects to the late Actor. Anthony, who passed away at the age of 65, succumbed to injuries sustained in a tragic accident on Thalawa Road in Anuradhapura. Subsequently, he was airlifted to National Hospital Colombo for further treatment, where he remained in the ICU for 14 months. Jackson Anthony was a multifaceted individual with vast expertise in various fields, including language, literature, history, and the arts. He was an actor who left an indelible mark on the cinema, stage, and television in Sri Lanka. Beyond his acting, he excelled in directing, producing, screenwriting, singing, novel and column writing, and song writing. He was also a renowned critic, explorer, historian, and presenter. Jackson Anthony achieved an unparalleled record by winning the Best Actor award in Sri Lanka a remarkable 16 times.

title: National Foundation Day of Republic of Korea celebrated
author: Author not found
Content: The Korean Embassy, led by Korean Ambassador Miyon Lee, hosted the National Foundation Day Celebrations of the Republic of Korea on 6 October, at the Shangri-La Hotel in Colombo. It is a monumental year to commemorate the 4,355th anniversary of the establishment of the Korean Nation and the 46th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Korea and Sri Lanka. The National Foundation Day Reception was celebrated with the participation of many Korean nationals and Sri Lankans. Among the dignitaries, present at the National Foundation Day celebration  were the Chief Guest, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera, Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, Cabinet and State Ministers, Secretaries and Ambassadors who have contributed to the strengthening of bilateral cooperation between Korea and Sri Lanka. Members of the Korean communities and representatives of various segments of Sri Lanka were also present at the event. Delivering the opening remarks, Ambassador Miyon Lee engaged the audience on the values Korea has upheld for years, respecting universal principles such as freedom, democracy, human rights and rule of law. She also emphasised on the links Korea has maintained over the years with other nations and how such relationships have given Korea a sense of national identity, pride and unity. The Ambassador, while stressing the importance of Korea’s version of the Indo-Pacific strategy, expressed her desire to increase engagement and cooperation in the region, advocating for freedom, peace and prosperity. Also, referring to the meeting of the two presidents on the sidelines of the UNGA she highlighted that Sri Lanka will remain a key partner for Korea’s endeavour in building regional cooperation The Ambassador also highlighted Korea’s bid towards hosting the Busan World Expo 2030 and presented how Korea aspires to create a global platform to fight against the climate crisis and build a sustainable future. Ambassador Miyon Lee explained in detail of various development projects steered by the Korean development agencies in Sri Lanka and expressed her vision to further strengthen the cooperation between Korea and Sri Lanka in the years to come and to stand with Sri Lanka during these hard times in the midst of an economic recovery in the country. The Ambassador was also pleased to introduce the ‘Korea Dream Team’ that has worked together in implementing the development projects such as KOICA, Korea EXIM Bank, KOTRA, EPS Centre, KOPIA, KOFIH and the Saemaul Foundation. Minister Amaraweera extended his wishes for the 4,355th anniversary and complimented the generous contributions made by the Korean Government to empower the economy of Sri Lanka. He especially appreciated the efforts of KOICA in implementing a research programme for the development of agricultural production in Sri Lanka that made way to reap more harvest. He also expressed his gratitude for job opportunities the Korean Government had offered Sri Lankans in the Korean labour market and how it had been a win-win situation for both the countries. While highlighting trade, investment and tourism links, Minister Amaraweera invited the Korean society to invest in Sri Lanka to further strengthen the economic relations between the two countries. The ceremony also celebrated the abundant cultural amusement of sports, dance and music of Korea. The winners of the K-Pop World Festival entertained the crowd with their dancing talent whereas the athletes of the National Taekwondo Federation showcased their mastery in Korean martial arts. Furthermore, this year’s celebration exhibited and was themed on the beauty of Korea. There were photographs of landscapes and sceneries of various cities of Korea displayed along the hallway at the entrance for the participants to take a view and a photo booth with Hanboks, a Korea corner to click photographs with a backdrop of the ‘World Expo 2023’. Just as any other year, this year’s National Foundation Day was also celebrated with the contribution of  Korean Nationals in Sri Lanka. Their spirit of national identity, pride and unity was palpable. At the Foundation Day reception followed by dinner, the Korean Ambassador Miyon Lee made time to host a photo session with the Korean Community in Sri Lanka and the Sri Lankans who graced the occasion.

title: Wanted man dies in shootout with STF
author: Author not found
Content: Meetiyagoda Police said a man who was admitted to the Balapitiya Base Hospital, after being injured in an exchange of fire, at dawn yesterday (12) at Telwatta, Meetiyagoda, Galle succumbed to his injuries. The victim was identified as a 42-year-old resident of Wadduwa. Police said an STF team went to the area after being tipped off that an underworld figure had been hiding at a house in Meetiyagoda. Police stated that the suspect who was hiding in the house then opened fire at the STF and they reciprocated resulting in the suspect beingfatally injured. Police added that the victim was also wanted in connection with the murder of Police Inspector Dedimuni Balendrasinghe who was shot to death by two unidentified gunmen at Karagoda, Galle recently. BY Anura Priyantha – Habaraduwa

title: Court orders arrest of 12 over threats
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Pasan Abeyratne yesterday (12) instructed the Narahenpita Police to arrest and produce in Court, all suspects behind the illegal entry to a house and threatening its residents with firearms. The Additional Magistrate gave these instructions to the Police, after having perused a personal complaint lodged by Managing Director of Ascent International Private Limited, Malinga Fernando against 12 persons including cricket umpire Kumar Dharmasena, his spouse and Directors of the Pintanna Plantation Private Limited. At the previous hearing, the 12 respondents had been noticed to be present Court and to produce submissions. They complied with the exception of Dharmasena, who is currently overseas, in his capacity as an umpire, on the ICC Elite Panel, presently officiating in the ongoing ICC Men’s ODI World Cup in India. The driver of the residence had, on behalf of the occupants, lodged a complaint with the Narahenpita Police on 17 August, charging that a group led by Kumar Dharmasena, had unlawfully entered the residence bearing firearms and that the Police had failed to act on the complaint to date. President’s Counsel Nalinda Indatissa appeared for the plaintiffs. He told Magistrate Abeyratne, that after a lapse of one month and three days, since the complaint had been made, the respondent party had also lodged a complaint with the Police on 19 September. Indatissa alleged that the Police having failed to act promptly on the complaint, lodged by the plaintiffs, had proceeded to probe, only the complaint lodged by the respondents and that later two suspects had been arrested. He charged that the Police should be held accountable for their actions and dereliction of duty over the incident and their failure to conduct a transparent probe into the alleged incident. Indatissa further added that the conduct of the Narahenpita Police, had been brought to the notice of both the Inspector General of Police (IGP) and the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL). He then stated that the Court, should instruct the Police Department to hand over the probe into the case to a special Police Team as it is obvious that Narahenpita Police had failed to carry out an unbiased probe into the incident thus far. The Magistrate then inquired from the Narahenpita Police as to why they had only acted swiftly over the complaint lodged by the respondents and not the plaintiffs. The OIC and the OIC of the Crimes Division of the Narahenpita Police then informed the Court that they had at no stage favoured either party, over the case and that a certain time period had been spent to probe the complaints lodged by both parties. They both then informed the Additional Magistrate that they will not be dissuaded by anyone to enforce the law and arrest any suspect involved in the case, irrespective of their status or clout wielded in society. Accordingly, Magistrate Abeyratne having considered submissions produced by both the plaintiffs and respondents advised the Police to apprehend all suspects behind the incident. Attorneys Harshana Nanayakkara and Sunil Watagala looked into the interests of the respondents. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Sarana acquitted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle yesterday (12) acquitted former Minister Sarana Gunawardena, from the case of vehicle misappropriation. The former Minister had been indicted before the High Court, by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), over the misappropriation of vehicles belonging to the DLB, while serving as its Chairman, thus causing a loss of Rs 2.8 million to the State. Judge Balalle accepted the initial objections raised by the defence, over the manner in which the case had been filed against the accused by CIABOC and deemed that there were no provisions in the law to further maintain the case against Gunawardena. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Landslide blocks Southern Expressway
author: Author not found
Content: Vehicular movement along the expressway was disrupted yesterday (12), due to the closure of the road between Pinnaduwa and Imaduwa, following a landslide on the Southern Expressway on Wednesday (11) night. A Police Constable and six STF personnel, who were deployed at the site to remove the debris, have been hospitalised after being injured in an additional landslide at the same location. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said, one of the injured officers is in a critical condition and is receiving treatment in the ICU at Teaching Hospital Karapitiya. The Road Development Authority (RDA) said, the landslide occurred due to the heavy rains around the area yesterday and as a result, traffic on both sides of the Expressway between Pinnaduwa and Imaduwa was blocked. Vehicles travelling from Kottawa to Hambantota are advised by the RDA to exit from the Pinnaduwa Interchange and use the Galle-Deniyaya-Madampe Road and re-enter the Expressway from the Imaduwa Interchange. Accordingly, vehicles travelling from Hambantota to Colombo are advised to use the same alternate road after exiting from Imaduwa Interchange and to re-enter the Expressway from the Pinnaduwa Interchange. Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) said, the disrupted bus service on the Southern Express is operating as usual since yesterday (12) afternoon, however, the buses will also adhere to the alternate routes to exit and re-enter the Expressway to avoid the obstructed part of the Expressway and this could have an impact on the commuting time. RDA has further issued notices to residents in the vicinity to evacuate the area and find shelter elsewhere with immediate effect. RDA Director General L.V.S. Weerakoon also said, the RDA is coordinating with the Police and Army personnel to clear the obstructed area along the Expressway. Speaking to Ceylon Today, SSP Thalduwa said, the affected part of the road will remain closed until a safety assessment report is presented to the relevant authorities, due to the current weather conditions in the area. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Prime Minister proposes setting up a joint economic council with UAE
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena proposed setting up of a Joint Economic Council with the United Arab Emirates to promote trade and investment cooperation between the two countries. This proposal was made when the UAE Minister of State of Economic & Trade Affairs of the Foreign Ministry Ahmed bin Ali Sayegh called on him at the Temple Trees in Colombo on October 11. The UAE Minister agreed that official negotiations should be commenced soon for finalising Cooperation of Economic Partnership Agreement for enhancing economic ties as there is immense potential in trade, energy, hospitality and tourism spheres as well as for increasing investments in renewable energy projects in Sri Lanka. The Prime Minister said the UAE has the opportunities now to invest in new sectors such as agriculture as new economic zones have been set up for growth of food crops for exports. He thanked the UAE for the support and assistance provided to Sri Lanka for the development work as well as for providing employment to nearly 300,000 Sri Lankan workers and the UAE Minister said the expatriate Sri Lankan workers are an asset for the economies of both the countries. The UAE delegation included Ambassador Khalid Naser Al-Ameri, Director of the Office of the Minister of State, Sultan Al Mansoori and Deputy Director of the Department of Economic and Commercial Affairs, Ghada Al Nabulsi. MP Yadamini Gunawardena, Secretary, Ministry of Public Administration Ranjith Ashoka and Additional Secretary to the Prime Minister Harsha Wijewardene were also present during the meeting.

title: SL Embassy in Vienna offers alms to Maha Sangha
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy and the Permanent Mission of Sri Lanka in Vienna, Austria, offered an almsgiving (Heel Danaya) to the Maha Sangha in parallel with the annual Katina ceremony of the Dhammazentrum-Nyanaponika in Austria on 8 October 2023. Founder and Chief Incumbent of the Dhammazentrum-Nyanaponika Ven. Dr. Wijayarajapura Seelawansa Thera, together with ten venerable members of the Maha Sangha from Germany, Italy and Sri Lanka, who were in attendance, performed the religious observances. The Maha Sangha invoked blessings on Sri Lanka, its people and the staff of the Embassy.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: UN experts call for truce
author: Author not found
Content: United Nations independent experts yesterday (12) deplored the attacks on civilians, called for a truce and urged the international community to address the root causes of violence. A peaceful solution is imperative in view of the dehumanising language that is increasingly being used against both Palestinians and Israelis, the experts said. They strongly condemn the horrific crimes committed by Hamas of Gaza, the deliberate and widespread killing and hostage-taking of innocent civilians, including older persons and children.  They also condemn Israel’s indiscriminate military attacks against the already exhausted Palestinian people of Gaza, comprising over 2.3 million, nearly half of whom are children. They have lived under unlawful blockade for 16 years, and have already gone through five major brutal wars, which remain unaccounted for,” they said.  “As the civilian death toll from the violence mounts, we call for an immediate de-escalation of tensions in the region and an effective response by the international community premised upon international law and the protection of equal rights and dignity of all,” they said. The experts urged for an immediate end to violations of international humanitarian law and human rights, in particular the right to life. To this effect, support the investigation launched by the Commission of Inquiry on the Occupied Palestinian Territory, including East Jerusalem and Israel, into all violations reported since 7 October, including unlawful deaths and enforced disappearances and the investigation by the International Criminal Court. The agreement of a ceasefire, to be monitored by an independent, international body, the release of hostages taken by Hamas and Palestinians arbitrarily detained by Israel, particularly women, children, older persons, persons with disabilities and those who are gravely ill, the establishment of an international protective presence in the occupied Palestinian territory, the provision of all necessary financial and humanitarian aid and the creation of humanitarian corridors that allow people to leave Gaza and return as soon as the hostilities cease and the dignity of the dead from the latest violence be respected and that they are swiftly handed over to mourning relatives. On 9 October, the Israeli Defence Minister announced that authorities would completely cut essential supplies to Gaza, stating they are fighting “human animals.” The Minister threatened to bomb those attempting to provide humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip. On 9 and 10 October, Israel reportedly bombed the Rafah crossing at the Gaza-Egyptian border, disrupting movement in and out of Gaza, rendering the crossing closed and the enclave completely blockaded. “Besides this appalling language that dehumanises the Palestinian people, especially those who have been unlawfully ‘imprisoned’ in Gaza for 16 years, we condemn the withholding of essential supplies such as food, water, electricity and medicines. Such actions will precipitate a severe humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where its population is now at inescapable risk of starvation. Intentional starvation is a crime against humanity,” the experts said. “Breaking the cycle of violence in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territory is paramount,” the experts said. “Armed attacks and military responses have already proven incapable of leading to security and respect for human rights of all. Restoring international legality, accountability and respect for humanity and dignity of all must prevail, including an end to Israel’s 56 years of military occupation.”  “This amounts to collective punishment,” the UN experts said. “There is no justification for violence that indiscriminately targets innocent civilians, whether by Hamas or Israeli forces. This is absolutely prohibited under international law and amounts to a war crime.” The experts also expressed concern about reports that journalists and media workers reporting on the conflict had been targeted, with seven Palestinian journalists and media workers reportedly killed in Israeli airstrikes. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Two acquitted in heroin possession case
author: Author not found
Content: Panadura High Court Judge K. D. L. S. Kumara, on 11 October, without calling for submissions from the defence, acquitted two accused, who had been charged with possession of 16.980 grams of heroin. This decision was taken by the Judge citing the untrustworthiness of the evidence put forth by the prosecution. The two accused, released from the trial, were identified individuals, who are residents of Pinwatta, Panadura and aged 39 and 35. During the Court proceedings, it had come to light, that the two accused had been arrested at Leslie Gunawardene Avenue, Pinwatta, on 2 July 2014, while they transporting 16.98 grammes of heroin, in a three-wheeler. However, according to the report compiled by the Government Analyst, it had subsequently been revealed, that the net weight of the heroin, seized from the two accused, had been 6.87 grammes. Judge Kumara stated that he was acquitting the two accused, from the charges filed against them and releasing them from the trial, as per a request made to him by the Defence Counsel, based on Provisions contained in Section 200 (1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act and as the evidence put forth by the Prosecution, had been untrustworthy. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: Customs seizes Rs 30M in Undu
author: Author not found
Content: Customs Media Spokesman Seevali Arukgoda said that Customs officers, at the Orugodawatta Yard, had seized a stock of ‘Undu’ valued at more than Rs 30 million yesterday (12), which had been illegally brought down from India without being officially declared to the Customs. He stated the stock of ‘Undu’ weighing 17 MT had been concealed in a manner to suggest that a stock of Kadala had been imported from India by a businessman based in Maradana, Colombo. Customs stated that if the stock of Undu had been released to the market the country would have lost tax revenue to the tune of Rs 5.1 million. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: APMDD members protest against WB, IMF and G7
author: Author not found
Content: Members of the Asian Peoples’ Movement on Debt and Development (APMDD) took to the streets yesterday (12) scolding the World Bank (WB), the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and G7 Governments for worsening economic conditions in Global South countries and for further exacerbating the climate crisis. Timed with the annual meetings of the IMF-WB, Asian activists joined hundreds of other organisations worldwide marking the Global Week of Action for Debt, Climate and Economic Justice. A statement endorsed by close to 500 organisations and individuals from 74 countries across all global regions denounced the IMF-WB, saying that “together with other private and public lenders, they perpetuate a flawed international financial architecture that exacerbates debt, climate and economic crises, violating the basic needs and rights of millions of people and nature who have the least contribution, responsibility or control over these catastrophes.” In Manila, Philippines, hundreds of demonstrators marched to Mendiola, gateway to the presidential palace, with the call “Cancel the debt and pay reparations for historical and continuing injustices!” Ousted dictator Ferdinand Marcos senior remains known for his repressive rule as well as for crony capitalism, massive ill-gotten wealth hidden in tax havens and billions of dollars in public debt that served no benefit for the Filipino people. Protesters also slammed the Philippine government for continued expansion and support for fossil fuel projects that they decried as ‘illegitimate debts’ for contributing to the climate crisis, dislocating communities and violating human rights. “Global South governments should stop paying for these illegitimate debts!” said Lidy Nacpil, APMDD Coordinator. “At the same time, lenders such as the IMF, the World Bank and G7 Governments should stop pushing more loans as climate finance, and swiftly start the process of debt cancellation, adoption of wealth taxes for spending on urgent economic and climate action and the rechannelling of public funds away from fossil fuel subsidies towards renewable energy systems.” APMDD members in other countries also rallied to the calls of the Global Week of Action and mobilised in the hundreds to spotlight debt, climate and economic injustices, and to hold the IMF-World Bank and the G7 Governments accountable.

title: Shoe thief arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Hirana Police said that they had apprehended a suspect yesterday who had been in the habit of illegally entering houses at night and stealing shoes. They stated the suspect had been known under the alias ‘Sapattu Dumiya’. According to the Police they had managed to nab the suspect after carrying out a raid based on a spate of complaints lodged by residents in the area. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: Thondaman pledges equal treatment for all
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman yesterday (12) pledged equal treatment to everyone in the province. He emphasised that there should be no room for problems that arise in the region in the name of religion, community or caste. The Governor stated that as the representative of the Central Government, he has taken every possible action to promote co-existence among diverse communities belonging to various ethnic groups and to foster reconciliation. This commitment follows a meeting with a US delegation led by David Curry who is the President and CEO of Global Christian Relief. During the meeting, Governor Thondaman brought to the delegation’s attention the freedom that the people of this country have to practise their own faith and the government’s commitment to ensuring co-existence among diverse communities. The meeting took place at the Governor’s Secretariat in Trincomalee, and extensive discussions were held between the Governor and the delegation regarding religion-related issues that have arisen in the region. They also discussed the necessity of protecting everyone’s religious rights and the ability to perform rituals without obstacles. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: NMRA halts use of cancer drug
author: Author not found
Content: The National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) stated that it has halted the use of yet another medicinal drug– Rituximab injection 500mg, in 50ml vial, prescribed for cancer patients, which had been imported by the same local agent who imported the controversial Human Immunoglobulin Iv 5-6g vial, Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Dr. Vijith Gunasekara said. Dr. Gunasekara, fielding questions during a media briefing yesterday (11), said that the Authority had received a complaint regarding a cancer drug which had also been imported by the particular local agent from India with documents allegedly issued by the NMRA. He said that here too his official seal had been forged on the documents while the medicines had also been distributed to State hospitals.   Steps had also been taken to cancel the tender which had been given to the particular agent for the importation of another medicinal drug. Dr. Gunasekara said the use of the Human Immunoglobulin had been suspended when complaints had been received from the National Hospital, Colombo, Matale and Matara Hospitals of anaphylactic reactions. Further investigations had revealed that the medicinal drug has been imported using forged documents.  Member of the Board of Directors of the NMRA, Manoj Gamage said, “The media, the public and even a section of the medical fraternity are under the misconception that the NMRA had a hand in the procurement process, whereas the Authority was the least involved in calling of tenders and the procurement process of medicines. According to the NMRA Act the ‘waiver of registration’ (WOR) is given to a medicinal drug even after the procurement procedure on the recommendations of the Health Ministry, depending on the urgency of the particular medical drug, he noted. It is unfortunate that some medical unions are ready to accuse and point fingers at the NMRA feigning ignorance of this fact.” Gamage lashed out saying that those medical trade unions would be better off if they submitted whatever evidence they had with regard to the said medicinal drug scam, to the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) as the Authority had taken urgent action to lodge a complaint against the local pharmaceutical company. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Red alerts issued to Matara District
author: Author not found
Content: As the inclement weather conditions continue to affect various parts of the country, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has issued landslide early warning alerts of different levels to 61 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and their surrounding areas across seven districts. Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist of the Landslide Early Warning Centre (LEWC) at NBRO, provided details on the alerts. At level three, marked with a red-watch designation, the alerts apply to the Akuressa, Pitabeddara and Hakmana DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Matara District. Level two, denoted as an amber-watch, has been issued for several areas in different districts. In the Badulla District, this alert applies to the Haputale and Haldummulla DS divisions and their surrounding areas.  In the Galle District, it encompasses the Yakkalamulla, Ambalangoda, Galle Four Gravets, Thawalama, Baddegama, Akmeemana, Elpitiya, Imaduwa, Nagoda, Neluwa, Bope Poddala and Niyagama DS divisions and their surrounding areas. In the Hambantota District, it pertains to the Katuwana and Walasmulla DS divisions and their surrounding areas. For the Kalutara District, the alert covers the Matugama and Walallawita DS divisions and their surrounding areas. In the Kegalle District, it affects the Ruwanwella, Deraniyagala, Dehiowita and Yatiyantota DS divisions and their surrounding areas. Meanwhile, in the Matara District, the alert includes the Kirinda Puhulwella, Mulatiyana, Thihagoda, Malimbada, Welipitiya, Pasgoda, Kotapola, Athuraliya, Matara Four Gravets and Kamburupitiya DS divisions and their surrounding areas. At level one, indicated by a yellow-watch, the alerts apply to the Beliatta and Okewela DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Hambantota District, the Ingiriya, Agalawatta, Palindanuwara, Dodangoda, and Bulathsinhala DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Kalutara District. The Kegalle and Bulathkohupitiya DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Kegalle District and the Nivithigala, Imbulpe, Kaltota, Pelmadulla, Openayake, Weligepola, Kiriella, Ayagama, Godakawela, Kolonna and Kahawatta DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Year-long waiting lists for MRI scans at State Hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: Teaching Hospitals at Anuradhapura and Karapitiya have an 18-month-long waiting list for Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans, government radiologists said. President of the Government Radiological Technologists Association (GRTA), Chanaka Dharmaratne yesterday (11) said the Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children (LRH) had a waiting list of one year for MRI scans. He said according to details taken in July 2023 there were 8,000 patients waiting Cardiac Catheterisation and angiograms at the Kandy National Hospital. He lamented that the cases requiring procedure, which is test or treatment for certain heart or blood vessel problems, was being delayed. Teaching Hospital, Kalutara has a 12-month waiting list lined up for cardiac catheterisation and angiograms Sri Lanka has 14 catheterisation labs in all at the National Hospitals Colombo and Kandy, Teaching Hospitals, Kurunegala, Ragama, Kalutara, Anuradhapura, Karapitiya and Jaffna, District General Hospital, Polonnaruwa, and Childrens’ Hospitals Lady Ridgeway and Sirimavo Bandaranaike, Peradeniya. By Dilanthi Jayamanne
