title: Three bilateral agreements signed
author: Author not found
Content: India’s Minister of External Affairs, Dr. S. Jaishankar held a meeting with President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (11), the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. During the meeting, extensive discussions were conducted on further strengthening Indo-Sri Lankan relations, and three new bilateral agreements, to enhance cooperation between the two countries, were signed. The inauguration of the third phase of the housing project, supported by Indian loan assistance, also took place during the meeting. While the initial budget allocation was Rs 1.026 million per unit for the fourth phase, it was necessary to revise the budget to Rs 2.8 million per unit due to increased costs. In a commitment to improve the lives of Sri Lankan citizens, the Indian Government pledged additional funding for the speedy completion of nine development projects in the country, currently supported by the Government of India. The agreement for this initiative was also signed on the same day. These projects encompass the modernisation of 27 schools in the Northern Province, housing initiatives in Mannar and Anuradhapura, improvements to the Hatton Thondaman Vocational Training Centre and Pussellawa Saraswati Central College, construction of a multi-ethnic trilingual school in Polonnaruwa, the establishment of 2,889 rainwater harvesting projects in the Jaffna area, promotion of vegetable cultivation in the Dambulla area and the construction of greenhouse facilities with a capacity of 5,000 metric tons for fruit preservation. Further, a new surgical unit for the Batticaloa Teaching Hospital will be  constructed immediately as part of these efforts. An agreement regarding a joint project involving the Indian National Dairy Development Board, the Gujarat Cooperative Milk Marketing Federation of India (Amul) and the Cargills Group of Sri Lanka was also signed to elevate Sri Lanka’s local dairy industry. This agreement stemmed from the President’s official visit to India and funding to modernise the local livestock sector. The primary goal of the project is to increase milk production by 53 per cent within the first five years and achieve self-sufficiency in milk production for Sri Lanka within 15 years. This initiative is expected to empower approximately 200,000 local farmers by providing facilities such as high-quality medicines, animal nutrition and technical support. It also involves digitalisation of the livestock sector, investments in new technology to enhance the quality of milk-related by-products and ensure access to dairy products at affordable prices. A commemorative logo was also unveiled to celebrate 75 years of Indo-Sri Lankan relations. The signing ceremony was attended by Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay, Union Secretaries of the Indian Ministry of External Affairs, Puneeth Agrawal and J. P. Singh, Indian Deputy High Commissioner to Sri Lanka Dr. Satyanjal Pandey, and Indian Ministry of External Affairs Deputy Secretary Raghu Puri. On the Sri Lankan side, attendees included Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, Minister JeevanT hondaman, State Minister Thenuka Widanagamage, MP M. Rameswaran, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayaka, Senior Adviser to the President on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Aruni Wijewardane and Director of Presidential International Affairs Dinuk Colombage.

title: COPA comes down hard on Excise officers
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) instructed the Excise Department to dispense with its current system of imposing lenient penalties for large-scale fraud and irregularities connected to the production of liquor. They advised the Excise Department to mete out severe punishment such as cancellation of licences of firms that continue to be involved in the counterfeit sticker racket and non-payment of tax to the State. Chairman of COPA Lasantha Alagiyawanna, during the recent COPA deliberations on Finance, held in Parliament, advised the Treasury Secretary to submit a new Act and do away with mediation contained in the present Excise Act. Among others who were in attendance at these sessions were State Ministers Chamara Sampath, Suresh Raghavan, MPs Jayantha Ketagoda and Weerasumana Weerasinghe along with officials from the Ministry of Finance and the Excise Department. COPA instructed the Excise Department on the punishment that should be handed out to those found guilty of being involved in placing counterfeit stickers on bottles of liquor. Excise Department officials had told COPA that to date companies found guilty of engaging in the counterfeit sticker racket had refrained from paying taxes, amounting to a staggering Rs 6.6 billion. When inquired as to why Excise officers had not cancelled the licences of such liquor companies, they said provisions in the Excise Act, where such companies could be let off solely through a fine, which is included in the section ‘Mediation or settlement’, had prevented them from doing so. Alagiyawanna had then asked for details of Excise and Finance Ministry officials involved in the counterfeit sticker scam. He then proposed that a tender process should be conducted and a new company selected to print the new security stickers to be placed on bottles of liquor. He informed Excise officials that the present contract given to an Indian firm, to print security stickers, should be annulled forthwith as there were many irregularities and fraud that had been committed.

title: Sending workers to Israel suspended
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara yesterday (11) said that sending Sri Lankan workers to Israel has been suspended due to the current war situation between Israel and Hamas. Addressing the media, Nanayakkara said the Government was deeply saddened by the tragic events unfolding in Israel. He said that another group of Sri Lankans was ready to leave for work in Israel. However, considering the current situation, they won’t be sent, he said. Further, there is no obstacle for any Sri Lankan who is in Israel to return to the country as measures have been taken to facilitate their departure and a hotline has been introduced to obtain information regarding the plight of Sri Lankan workers, Nanayakkara added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Twelve senior Police officers transferred
author: Author not found
Content: Twelve senior Police officers, including eight Deputy Inspectors General of Police (DIGs) received transfer orders following a decision taken by the National Police Commission. According to a press release from the Police Media Division, these transfers took effect from Monday (9). As part of these changes, three Senior Superintendents of Police (SSPs) have been promoted to the position of DIG. Specifically, SSP Gayanga Marapana of the Colombo South Division, SSP Sujith Wedamulla of the Badulla Division and SSP Samantha Wijesekera of the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) have all been elevated to the rank of DIG, effective 27 September. Following these transfers, SSP Marapana now assumes the role of DIG for the Western Province (South) Division, SSP Wijesekera as DIG for the the Wanni Division, and SSP Wedamulla as DIG for the Naval and Tourist Division. In addition to the above, DIGs G M.H.B. Siriwardhana, K. Kadupitiya, and Acting DIGs H. Samudrajeeva, P. Ampawila, D.G.S. de Silva and SSPs I.W.G.R. Kandewatta, H.D.N. Abeywardena, SPs M.M. Kumaratunga, and U.G. Seneviratne have also been transferred.

title: PHIs warn of infectious disease spread
author: Author not found
Content: With the inclement weather, the Public Health Inspectors’ Union (PHIU) has warned of the risk of infectious diseases spreading. PHIUSL President, Upul Rohana yesterday (11) warned of possibilities in the spread of mosquito borne dengue and other viral fever and diarrhoea due to contaminated water sources and receding flood conditions. He said his team hoped to collaborate with local authorities and voluntary organisations to purify drinking water sources. Plans were also underway to ensure food safety by inspecting all eateries and food stores in flood affected areas. Rohana warned that continuous rains would have increased breeding sites for the dengue mosquito. The number of dengue cases in the country by 11 October 2023 had increased to 65,479 with 39 deaths.  (DJ)

title: Harini files Petition challenging Online Safety Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Dr. Harini Amarasuriya, yesterday (11), filed a Special Determination Petition challenging the Constitutionality of the Online Safety Bill. The Petition was submitted through Attorney-at-Law Manjula Balasooriya. In the petition, Dr. Amarasuriya contends that the Online Safety Bill carries significant implications for the fundamental rights of freedom of speech and expression, as guaranteed by Article 14(1)(a) of the Constitution. She asserts that the proposed Bill aims to curtail these fundamental rights. Referring to the Supreme Court’s decision in the case of Joseph Perera vs the Attorney-General, the petitioner emphasises that any permissible restrictions on fundamental rights, even when imposed by duly enacted laws, must not be excessive. Furthermore, the petitioner raises concerns about the appointment process for the Online Safety Commission, highlighting that unlike other independent commissions, members of this commission are not recommended by the Constitutional Council but appointed directly by the President. Dr. Amarasuriya argues that the powers vested in the Commission, as outlined in Clause 11 of the Bill, are vague, overly broad, arbitrary, unreasonable and infringe upon several constitutional articles, including Articles 3, 4(d), 10, 12(1), and 14(1)(a). She asserts that this Commission holds the authority to determine what constitutes a “prohibited statement” or a “false statement” and issue directives, with associated penal consequences for non-compliance. As a remedy, the petitioner seeks a declaration that the Bill necessitates approval via a Referendum in addition to the requisite 2/3 approval of Parliament.

title: Ali Zahir Moulana fills Nazeer Ahamed’s vacant seat
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission (EC) yesterday (11) issued the Gazette naming Ali Zahir Moulana Seiyad to fill the vacant seat of former Minister of Environment Nazeer Ahamed who was unseated. The Election Commission issued a Gazette Extraordinary No. 2353/52, confirming Ali Zahir Moulana Seiyad’s election as a Member of the Ninth Parliament for the Electoral District No. 12 – Batticaloa. This appointment is in response to the vacancy created by the cessation of Ahamed Zainulabdeen Nazeer’s role as an MP. The Gazette states that the Returning Officer, for the said Electoral District was directed by the Election Commission, under Section 64(1) of the Parliamentary Elections Act, No. 1 of 1981, to fill this vacancy as provided for under paragraph 13 (b) of Article 99 of the Constitution. Accordingly, the Returning Officer has made a return to the effect that Ali Zahir Moulana Seiyad was declared elected as an MP for the said Electoral District and has submitted the report to the Election Commission, the gazette stated. Ahmed lost his parliamentary seat following a ruling by the Supreme Court, which upheld the Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC) decision to expel him from party membership. In April 2022, the SLMC decided to expel party member Naseer Ahamed after he was sworn in as the Minister of Environment under the former government. Following his appointment, Naseer Ahamed also endorsed the 20th Amendment to the Constitution in 2020 and voted in favour of the Budget 2022, against the stand decided on by the SLMC. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: IORA recognises Indian Ocean as economic corridor
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka has reiterated its proposal for the Indian Ocean to remain a ‘Zone of Peace’ during the recently concluded three-day Ministerial meeting of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) that concluded yesterday (11) in Colombo. Speaking at a press briefing yesterday (11) Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Sabry highlighted the key focus areas of IORA, including the blue economy. He said the organisation recognises the vast potential of the Indian Ocean for fisheries, aquaculture, renewable energy, and sustainable tourism. Additionally, IORA addresses important issues such as climate change adaptation, disaster risk reduction, and the empowerment of women, making it a comprehensive platform for regional cooperation, he added. The Foreign Minister said they identified six priorities and two cross-cutting areas. Despite differences, IORA members are bound by the Indian Ocean Foreign Ministry Secretary Aruni Wijewardane said, adding that Sri Lanka gives a great deal of importance to the Indian Ocean and reiterated that Sri Lanka’s commitment to continue to work closely with all Member States of IORA and other partners, including the Dialogue Partners to achieve the objectives of IORA. At the 25th Committee of Senior Officials (CSO) meeting of IROA, that concluded in Colombo on 10 October, she added that the theme, ‘Strengthening Regional Architecture: Reinforcing Indian Ocean Identity’, chosen by Sri Lanka for its chairmanship, reflects the country’s deep understanding of the pivotal role that the Indian Ocean plays in shaping the region’s identity and destiny. She said, “It serves as a reminder that, despite their differences, the IORA Member States are bound by the waters of the Indian Ocean, which have nurtured their societies, peoples and economies for centuries.” Senior officials made recommendations including the adoption of the Colombo Communiqué, which is the outcome document, to the 23rd Council of Ministers of IORA met yesterday(11)  Talking to the press, Indian Foreign Minister Dr. S. Jaishankar pointed out that their common objective is to promote greater prosperity in the region and of making the Indian Ocean a free, open and inclusive space, based on the UN Convention on the Law of the Seas (UNCLOS) as the Constitution of the Seas.  He said, “We should be equally clear where the dangers are, be it in hidden agendas, in unviable projects or in unsustainable debt. Exchange of experiences, sharing of best practices, greater awareness and deeper collaboration are part of the solutions.” Jaishankar added that at the initiative of India, IORA’s outlook on the Indo-Pacific was adopted by the 22nd Council of Ministers’ meeting. He said they will again endeavour to give it practical shape in the days ahead.He also drew that the india’s broader vision was of an Indo-Pacific that which is built on a rules-based international order, rule of law, sustainable and transparent infrastructure investment, freedom of navigation and over-flight, and sincere respect for sovereignty and territorial integrity. He said the Indian Ocean is not only a significant body of water but also a crucial economic and strategic corridor, playing a key role in the development and prosperity of the nations around it and beyond it. India’s message of ‘Vasudhaiva Kudumbakam’ or ‘the world is one family’ can act as a binding force for IORA Member States. “India, with its extensive coastline, maritime interests, and historical ties, fully appreciates the importance of fostering collaboration and dialogue in the Indian Ocean,” said the Indian Foreign Minister adding that they  should cooperate on various aspects of the maritime economy, resources, connectivity and security. Dr A. K. Abdul Momen, Foreign Minister of Bangladesh, Dr. Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, Minister of External Affairs of India, Dr. Salman Al Farisi, Secretary General of the IORA Secretariat in Mauritius and Aruni Wijewardane, Secretary, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Chair of the 25th Meeting of IORA Committee of Senior Officials were present at the press briefing. Minister Sabry added that IORA was an intergovernmental organisation established in 1997. It was the brainchild of the late South African President Nelson Mandela, who envisioned an organisation to bring together the coastal States bordering the Indian Ocean to promote regional cooperation and sustainable development. “We are pleased that all Member States and the Dialogue Partners were represented at the Committee of Senior Officials and the Council of Ministers Meetings and Sri Lanka was honoured to welcome the Ministers, the Secretary General of IORA and Senior Officials from IORA countries. It was also a pleasure to welcome our newest Dialogue Partner, Saudi Arabia, which attended the IORA meetings for the first time, in Colombo,” said Sabry. It was also announced at the press briefing that the IORA member countries reviewed progress of the IORA Action Plan for 2022-2027 and identified new areas for collaboration. Sri Lanka selected ‘Strengthening Regional Architecture: Reinforcing Indian Ocean Identity’ as the theme for its IORA Chairmanship. Dr. S. Jaishankar said India had assumed the role of Vice-Chair at the IORA. He added,“India’s commitment to the well-being and progress of nations of the Indian Ocean, including as first responder and a net security provider is based on our Neighbourhood First policy, on the SAGAR outlook, and on our approach to the extended neighbourhood as well. As the Vice-Chair of IORA, the apex regional body of this Region, India will work to further strengthen regional identity and cooperation among IORA Member States, Dialogue Partners for the well-being and prosperity of the Indian Ocean community.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Night inspection of university hostels to curb ragging – Raghavan
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Higher Education Dr. Suren Raghavan claimed that measures will be taken to inspect university hostels at night to curb ragging in State universities. The decision comes in the wake of freshers being ragged in university hostels, which typically occurs between 10.00 p.m. and 5.00 a.m. University security officers and hostel authorities will be actively involved in this initiative, he said. Dr. Raghavan said, “Ragging predominantly occurs in university hostels. From the Vice Chancellor to the head of security, everyone must take responsibility for these incidents, which should not be tolerated. It has been reported that this inhumane treatment of freshers usually takes place in the hostels during late-night hours from 10.00 p.m. to 5.00 a.m. Therefore, we are giving special attention to this issue and will take action based on complaints received from the hostels during these hours. We are collaborating with university security and hostel authorities, as well as the Police.” Additionally, a WhatsApp number (076 545 3454) has been introduced to lodge complaints about ragging incidents and every complaint received through this channel will be promptly investigated, he added. BY Anjali Withanage

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Japan Hands over Grants to SL Under WFP
author: Author not found
Content: The official transfer of grants from the Government of Japan to Sri Lanka through the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) for various critical initiatives took place on Tuesday (10)  at the Presidential Secretariat. Komura Masahiro, the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Japan, and Misukoshi Hideki, the Japanese Ambassador to Sri Lanka, graced the event. Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, the President’s Senior Adviser on Economic Affairs, along with other Sri Lankan officials, also participated. During his speech, Deputy Minister Komura Masahiro expressed his delight in supporting Sri Lanka during its recent economic crisis. He emphasised Japan’s commitment to remaining a steadfast friend and partner to Sri Lanka. Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga the President’s Senior Adviser on Economic Affairs, extended his gratitude to the Japanese Government for their assistance. Sri Lanka Government has been taking steps to mitigate the impact of economic difficulties on vulnerable families. The Emergency Response Programme (ERP), School Meal Programme (SMP) and National Social Security Programme have been key initiatives in this regard. Furthermore, Dr. Samaratunga highlighted the 70-year diplomatic relationship between Japan and Sri Lanka, noting Japan’s consistent support. Under the WFP, Japan has provided food items worth US$10 million. Specifically, Japanese aid under the Emergency Response Programme (ERP) has been directed to the most economically vulnerable families, benefitting 145,000 households across Sri Lanka. Dr. Samaratunga also noted that Japan has contributed 7,270 metric tons of food items to Sri Lanka. These items have been utilised for the school meal programme, benefitting 960,000 schoolchildren, including the provision of red lentils.

title: Australia and Sri Lanka renew MoU on Sports Cooperation
author: Author not found
Content: Australia’s Assistant Minister for Foreign Affairs, Tim Watts MP signed the renewed Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on Cooperation in Sports between Sri Lanka and Australia, together with Sri Lanka’s Minister of Sports and Youth Affairs, Roshan Ranasinghe. The signing of the MoU will further strengthen the longstanding sporting ties between Sri Lanka and Australia. It will encourage cooperation on areas including coach education, training, sports science and medicine, gender equality in sports, and anti-corruption and anti-doping practices, a spokesman said. Following the signing, Assistant Minister Watts tested his cricket skills with members of Sri Lanka’s national women’s and men’s teams. He also reflected on our shared sporting history at the Sri Lanka Cricket Museum with Sri Lankan cricketing legend Aravinda de Silva and representatives of Sri Lanka Cricket, he further added. Quote from Tim Watts MP : “Sport is a shared passion and links us together, highlighted by our friendly but fierce rivalry on the cricket field, andI am pleased to renew the Memorandum of Understanding in Sports Cooperation between Australia and Sri Lanka.” Quote from Ranasinghe: “Whatever our sporting rivalry, we look forward to cooperating under this MoU to find and nurture Sri Lankan and Australian talent. It will provide us the framework to work together to get the best out of our athletes and showcase them to the world.”

title: Making Aeronautical Navigation Information Service efficient
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation – Nimal Siripala de Silva,  inaugurated the  Aeronautical Information Management (AIM) System on 10 October 2023,  at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), representing  a much significant advancement in the delivery of Aeronautical Navigation Information Service. This state-of-the-art system was implemented at a cost of Rs 1.2 billion. The cutting-edge system empowers pilots, air traffic controllers, and airlines to provide and maintain a high-quality Aeronautical Navigation Information Service, which is indispensable for the safe, profitable, and efficient execution of flight operations. Notably, Top Sky Aeronautical Information Management (AIM) system made in France by  Thales,  was fully operational at the BIA from 10 October 2023. By implementing the new computer operating system,  Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP), widely regarded as the cornerstone of Aeronautical Information Service, will be easily accessible and updated using digital technology. This marks a significant leap towards paperless utilisation of Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP), offering exceptional convenience. Quality and efficiency Furthermore, the adoption of this system elevates the quality and efficiency of the Aeronautical Information publication update process, ensuring a high degree of accuracy and precision in the associated database. The digitisation of the cartography section pertaining to the Aeronautical Information Service promises more precise aeronautical maps and charts, along with timely updates for new changes. The enhanced ability to manage the quality of information related to aeronautical maps and chart production represents another notable benefit. For flight planning, the submission of a Flight Plan is a mandatory requirement. With the new system in place, pilots or their representatives can now submit their Flight Plans online without the need to visit the Air Traffic Services Reporting Office, streamlining the process and improving efficiency. Rapid access Moreover, pilots gain rapid access to all Pre-Flight Information Bulletins that impact their safety during flights. Additionally, they can receive updates to their Flight Plan concerning changes in other Flight Information Regions, leading to improved Flight Plan management. Furthermore, the Aeronautical Information Service officer at the International NOTAM office will have greater ease in managing the exchange of temporary changes in Aeronautical Information Publication (NOTAM) referred to by pilots. The installation of this advanced computer operating system will substantially enhance the NOTAM system’s capability for high-level quality management. To optimise these operations, the new computer system at the Aeronautical Information Service Headquarters (AIS HQ) has received an Aeronautical Information Exchange Model Database (AIXM Database), which stands as a fundamental component of the Aeronautical Information Service. The Department of Electronic and Air Navigation Engineering played a pivotal role in achieving these remarkable milestones. Speaking at the occasion the Minister said, “As per the recommendations of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), flight operations conducted at Sri Lanka’s airstrip have been executed with a commendable emphasis on safety. Consequently, our airport has earned a notable evaluation from the ICAO, securing an impressive score of 92, establishing it as a leader in aviation operations across Southeast Asia.” The Minister also emphasised that the utilisation of state-of-the-art technical equipment has been pivotal in elevating Sri Lanka’s aviation services to a highly advanced level. Furthermore, he attributed this remarkable achievement to the exceptional expertise and unwavering commitment demonstrated by the professionals in the aviation sector. Chairman of the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Limited – Major General G.A. Chandrasiri (Retd), Civil Aviation Authority’s  Chairman– G.S.Vithanage and Director General – P.K.Jayakantha and several officials attended the event.

title: Colombo Air Symposium 2023 concludes
author: Author not found
Content: The second and final day’s sessions of the ‘Colombo Air Symposium – 2023’ began on10 October 2023 at the Eagles Lakeside Banquet & Convention Hall, Attidiya, Ratmalana. The Symposium was held under the theme ‘Fostering shared air interests in the IOR: Geopolitical Cooperation, Complexities and Compulsions’ commenced for the second day with the arrival of the Chief Guest for the day, Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa. The second day saw four speakers delivering presentations and fielding questions during the two sessions slated for the day. The first session of the day titled ‘Air Power Challenges and Opportunities’ was moderated by Air Commodore MDAG Senevirathne. The second session of day two titled ‘Regional Coherence and Interdependence’ was moderated by Prof. Maneesha Wanasinghe. The speakers of the first session of the day were Air Commodore SD Jayaweera and Air Vice Marshal KMK Keppetipola. The speakers of the second and final session of the Colombo Air Symposium were Miss Charini Patabendige and Air Commodore SPVK Senadheera. In summary the Colombo Air Symposium 2023 saw 10 experts presenting their researches under following sub themes =Air Space Management =Sustenance under ‘VUCA’ =Socioeconomic Compulsions =Air Power Challenges and Opportunities =Regional Coherence and Interdependence The concluding remarks were made by Director General Training of SLAF, Air Vice Marshal Lasitha Sumanaweera. On completion of all sessions, Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa awarded certificates and mementoes to the moderators, speakers and peer reviewers of this year’s symposium. The two day conference came to an end following the Vote of Thanks being delivered by Chairman of the Symposium Committee, Air Commodore Dammika Dias and thus marked the successful completion of the ‘Colombo Air Symposium – 2023’

title: Strengthening Parliament’s role using evaluation for policy making
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse recently said in Parliament that it was important to strengthen the role of Parliament for policy making by using evaluations. He was addressing the Parliament session on National Evaluation Week 2023. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, MP Kabir Hashim, Global Parliamentarians’ Forum for Evaluation, Secretary of the Forum MP Mayantha Dissanayake, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary General of Parliament Chaminda Kularatne, President of the International Development Evaluation Association Ada Ocampo, Resident Representative of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Sri Lanka Azusa Kubota and President of the Sri Lanka Evaluation Association Dr. Asela Kalugampitiya were present. The Deputy Speaker said the Colombo Declaration on Evaluation signed in  Parliament in the context of Eval Colombo 2018 has become the guideline to institutionalise evaluation in Parliament. He also said the institutionalisation of evaluation based on these statement had already started. The National Evaluation Policy was approved by the Government in 2018, and the Deputy Speaker expressed his appreciation for the exemplary role played by a group of Parliamentarians in approving the National Evaluation Policy. Speaking at the event, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary General of Parliament Chaminda Kularatne said Sri Lanka is the first and only country in South Asia to  approve the National Evaluation Policy. He also said the implementation of the National Evaluation Policy in Sri Lanka was commendable especially through the  vision, leadership and guidance of the President. Dr. Harini Amarasuriya, Chair of the Sub Committee on Identifying the Priorities in Formulation of Short, Medium and Long-Term National Policies of the National Council and Namal Rajapaksa participated in the panel discussion held pertaining to the importance of institutionalising evaluation in Parliament; Implementation of the recommendations of the Parliamentary Select Committee report.

title: Ready to oust Govt, if Elections not held
author: Author not found
Content: JVP politburo member K. D. Lalkantha said if the Government does not hold Elections, his party would do its utmost to send the present regime packing through a people’s struggle or through an anti-government movement like what  was seen last year. He said the working class was ready and willing to join such a struggle and a movement to that would fulfil eight requests of the working class. Lalkantha was of the view that if a corrupt regime is to be ousted from political office, Elections were not necessary and that present day politicians of the Government should bear in mind that the JVP and the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) had ways and means towards that end. He added that if the present Government is unwilling to go before the masses fearing their wrath at an Election, the JJB was ready to give leadership to another anti- government movement on behalf of the public and usher in a genuine system change in the country. BY Anuradha Herath

title: Protest over illegal gem mining on school playground
author: Author not found
Content: A group of local residents and parents staged a protest, blocking the Kahawatta- Andana road, to demand an end to unauthorised gem mining within the play ground of Yayinna Vidyalaya, Kahawatta. This protest, which took place yesterday (11) morning, lasted for nearly an hour. The protesters recently discovered an illicit gem mining operation on the school playground. The mining pit was dug to a depth of 150 feet, making it possible for a person to stand within it. This revelation drew the attention of the authorities after media reports. Subsequently, the Sabaragamuwa provincial education authorities decided to launch an investigation into this illegal gem mining activity. Additionally, the Police also commenced an investigation. During the protest yesterday (11), parents voiced concerns over this illegal gem mining operation posing a threat to the safety of their children. The Acting Divisional Secretary of Kahawatta and the Assistant Superintendent of Police in Ratnapura addressed the protesters, assuring them that a comprehensive investigation into the gem mining would be conducted. A few months prior to this incident, the Ratnapura District Coordinating Committee reported that a 150-foot trench had been dug beneath the Kahawatta -Andana main road near Yayinna Vidyalaya, causing potential damage. BY L. Niroshana – Kahawatta

title: Employment Bill report handed over to Premier
author: Author not found
Content: The report containing observations on the proposed Employment Bill, aimed at repealing 13 existing labour regulations related to employee-employer relations, was recently presented to Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena by several trade union representatives. The report was prepared after extensive discussions with the Commissioner General of Labour, the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL), the Employers’ Federation of Ceylon and representatives from 17 trade unions. Former Minister Gamini Lokuge was also present at the  handing over of the report to the Premier.

title: Rains make Kumana a paradise once again
author: Author not found
Content: Kumana Bird Sanctuary has once again become a paradise with the arrival of rain, which ended the severe drought in Panama in Lahugala Divisional Secretariat division of the Ampara District. In the past few months, various animals that could only be seen near water sources, are now freely roaming the area, asserting their right to their habitat. Now, migrant birds and various animals such as deer, elephants and wild boars could be spotted roaming freely in the sanctuary following the rain. The administration of the Kumana National Park requested the tourists to watch their moves, refrain from making excessive noise and avoid littering which could harm the environment. They said the water problem that the animals faced is fully solved with the rain and a large number of local and foreign tourists are visiting the sanctuary these days. BY Chinthaka – Panama

author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Rains make Kumana a paradise once again
author: Author not found
Content: Kumana Bird Sanctuary has once again become a paradise with the arrival of rain, which ended the severe drought in Panama in Lahugala Divisional Secretariat division of the Ampara District. In the past few months, various animals that could only be seen near water sources, are now freely roaming the area, asserting their right to their habitat. Now, migrant birds and various animals such as deer, elephants and wild boars could be spotted roaming freely in the sanctuary following the rain. The administration of the Kumana National Park requested the tourists to watch their moves, refrain from making excessive noise and avoid littering which could harm the environment. They said the water problem that the animals faced is fully solved with the rain and a large number of local and foreign tourists are visiting the sanctuary these days. BY Chinthaka – Panama

title: SJB gears up for policy reform
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to chart a new course for Sri Lanka’s policy landscape, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) is diligently working on a comprehensive policy platform and manifesto. The party is determined to implement these policy reforms in the near future, and the process has gained momentum with the involvement of various stakeholders. The SJB’s policy platform is a product of extensive engagement and dialogue with a diverse array of stakeholders. Worker unions, business chambers, entrepreneurial associations, and professional organisations have all contributed to shaping the party’s vision for sustainable economic growth and human development in Sri Lanka. This multifaceted approach takes into account issues that span education, healthcare, business regulation, taxation, security, defence, social welfare, and pensions, recognising the interconnected nature of these facets. Sri Lanka’s foreign policy is another critical aspect of the party’s reform agenda. It acknowledges the importance of balancing strategic imperatives and local political and social dynamics that influence the nation’s relationships within the region and global perceptions of the State. Education is at the forefront of their concerns, emphasising the need for the education system to align with the demands of the 21st century technological era and contribute to human capital development and industrialisation, all while addressing demographic challenges. The party has criticised past policy approaches in Sri Lanka, which have often lacked a coherent, long-term strategy and have been reactive rather than proactive. The recent evaluation by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) highlighted governance deficits in Sri Lanka, further underscoring the need for comprehensive policy reform. Sri Lanka’s geopolitical context in the Indian Ocean region and the wider Western Pacific adds layers of complexity to policy development, necessitating delicate negotiation to manage relationships while safeguarding national interests. To navigate these challenges, the SJB’s policymaking team and membership will participate in a workshop titled ‘Policymaking and Governance: Navigating Geopolitical and Economic Challenges’. This event is organised by the National Council of Professionals and will feature a keynote address by Dr. Irvin Studin, a renowned Canadian academic and public intellectual. Dr. Studin is a respected strategy consultant in Canada and has been an advocate for reshaping Canadian geopolitical and political strategy. His experience includes contributing to the development of Canada’s first-ever national security policy and serving as the principal author of Australia’s 2006 national counter-terrorism policy. He holds a master’s degree from the University of Oxford and a PhD in constitutional law from the University of York. Dr. Studin’s involvement in various public policy development initiatives and his contributions to education reform make him a valuable source of insights for Sri Lanka. Dr. Studin is a critique of Canadian geopolitical strategy and its relations with the USA and traditional allies can offer valuable lessons for Sri Lanka as it seeks to position itself effectively in its immediate neighborhood and global alliances, the SJB said.

title: Mawbima Janatha Party office opens
author: Author not found
Content: The national headquarters of the Mawbima Janatha Party (MJP) was formally opened at 11 Park Avenue, Colombo 08, by the party’s leader, Dilith Jayaweera, senior party figure Dr. Hemakumara Nanayakkara, and members of the party’s executive committee. The MJP seeks to address a significant gap within the Sri Lankan political sphere. It aspires to be a political force with a clear vision for achieving short-term and long-term economic, social, and political sustainability, ultimately contributing to a happier populace. In discussing the party’s future plans and potential, Jayaweera said, “The establishment of the Mawbima Janatha Pakshaya headquarters represents a pivotal step in our party’s mission to empower the people of Sri Lanka, particularly our youth and women, encouraging them to unleash their creativity and contribute to the development of a Sri Lankan State that embraces an entrepreneurial spirit.” Speaking further, Jayaweera said he firmly believes that the nation should be a hub for entrepreneurs. “It is of paramount importance that we concentrate on nurturing a politically aware Sri Lankan community to address the pressing need for a National Policy framework, which has been historically elusive due to the enduring socio-economic and political impacts of colonial rule. We anticipate that this will pave the way for a more impactful and collaborative political landscape,” he added.  Pix by Sarath Kumara

title: SLMC condemns violence committed by Israel, Hamas
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC) said it unequivocally condemns all forms of violence and terror committed by ‘both parties’ in the war between Israel and Hamas. SLMC Leader Rauff Hakeem, in a statement on Tuesday (10), said, “While we denounce all acts of terror, which are often rooted in continued provocations of unprecedented intensity in recent months, we urge all parties to exercise restraint and engage in good-faith negotiations to achieve a sustainable and practical solution of two States coexisting side by side within the pre-1967 borders, fostering peace and prosperity, “The ‘New Middle East’ unilaterally pursued by current Israeli leaders, who have adopted forcible annexation as State policy, will only further exacerbate this century-old conflict. As long as the Palestinian people have breath in their bodies, they will persist in their struggle for the right to breathe the air of freedom and the right to worship,” he alleged. “We appeal to all parties in the Middle East and the Arab World to be cautious of those who use the guise of diplomacy to offer questionable incentives that further subjugate an occupied population. “Hatred only begets more hatred, and it cannot be quelled by further hatred. Encouragement of hatred from any source, whether it involves supporting one faction over another or one party over another in the theatre of conflict, must cease immediately. “The double standards evident in the policies and positions of North America and Europe concerning the Palestinian people, which also characterise much of the official stance on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, do not meet our expectations. “Responsible powers, whether they are global, regional, or self-proclaimed leaders, should act with maturity, prudence, and balance. They should refrain from provoking further animosity and instead exercise their responsibility delicately to guide the parties toward lasting peace with justice,” he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Police instructed to file charges against Secretary
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Pasan Abeyratne, on Tuesday (10), instructed the Bambalapitiya Police to file charges against the Secretary of the South Asia Co-operative Environment Programme (SACEP), on charges of criminal intimidation and assault on the Executive Director (ED) of the SACEP, who is in the country with diplomatic privileges. The SACEP ED has been allegedly criminally intimidated and assaulted, within the SACEP Institute premises, by the secretary. The Police produced submissions to Court, based on a complaint lodged by the SACEP ED, Bangladeshi national Dr. M. Rahman. The Police then requested the Court, to issue notice to the suspect Secretary of SACEP, to be present in Court, but the Additional Magistrate, dismissed it and advised the Police, to first and foremost file charges against the secretary. The Police also added that initial inquires conducted into the incident, had revealed that a request made by the suspect Secretary to the ED, seeking a service extension had been rejected by the ED, which had prompted her to assault him, having been incensed by the refusal. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ensuring transparency, efficiency of NMRA vital – Neurologists
author: Author not found
Content: In a perplexing twist of events, authorities are yet to determine how a supply of substandard intravenous immunoglobulin, which resulted in anaphylactic reactions at District Hospital Matale and National Hospital Colombo in September, was acquired through fraudulent means, evading the entire procurement process with forged documents. Following this, the Association of Sri Lankan Neurologists (ASLN) urged the Health Ministry to take urgent legal action against the person or persons responsible for the procurement of the controversial intravenous immunoglobulin. The company based in India, which was purportedly involved in the production of the controversial Human Immunoglobulin IV 5g vial, has denied any association with the product, and informed the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) that they did not manufacture these vials. It was then come to light that documentation with regard to registering the product at the NMRA was forged as well. However, up to date, the authorities have failed to identify the responsible parties who carried out the scam. President of ASLN, Dr. Pyara Ratnayake in a letter to Health Minister, Keheliya Rambukwella noted yesterday (9) that the Ministry should be able to ensure the safety of patients and prevent the breakdown of public confidence in the State-run healthcare services. “The ASLN is highly perturbed by the alarming facts revealed by the NMRA regarding 22,500 Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG) that were to be procured,” he said. Dr. Ratnayake said IVIG was a medication often prescribed by neurologists in life-threatening serious neurological disorders. Adverse events recorded for the said product occurred in patients under the care of two neurologists who were instrumental in bringing it to the notice of the authorities.  He said that as the main body that advocated for patients with neurological disorders, his Association was prepared to highlight the gravity of the situation to health authorities who dealt with it. It is the primary responsibility of the Health Ministry to avoid further endangering of patients by ensuring that the product has been recalled while monitoring and addressing safety concerns of patients who had already been given the IVIG. He said the Health Ministry needed to mediate and track patients in order to test and monitor them for potential adverse reactions to diseases such as blood-borne viral infections such as hepatitis (B and C) and HIV as well as for immunological reactions and other unforeseen long and short-term side effects. Dr. Ratnayake said emergency purchase of medications using waivers of registration (WOR) had become a common practice in the Health Ministry. “It is not a secret that emergency purchasing using WOR increased the cost significantly benefiting vendors and the intermediaries,” he said adding that it compromised patient safety as the stringent registration process had not been adhered to. Emergency purchasing with registration waivers should be avoided as much as possible and when undertaken an investigation should be carried out to find the responsible person or process that made it necessary to purchase IVIG urgently with a WOR, Dr. Ratnayake said. He lamented that this controversial procurement of IVIG had eroded any confidence that professionals had in the NMRA as the supreme medicinal drug regulator in the country. The ASLN stressed the need to ensure transparent and efficient function of the NMRA. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SC to hear Harin, Manusha’s case tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (10) fixed hearing of the Fundamental Rights (FR) Petition, filed by Ministers Harin Fernando and Manusha Nanayakkara, for tomorrow (12). Fernando and Nanayakkara filed the Petition seeking an order nullifying their suspension from the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and disqualification from their parliamentary seats. A three-Judge Bench of the Supreme Court fixed the hearing date when the petition was considered yesterday. The lawyers for the respondents informed the Court that, according to the Constitution of Sri Lanka, the hearing of this petition should be completed within two months from the date of filing. In light of this information, the Court instructed the petitioners to file any counter objections they may have by yesterday (10). Ministers Fernando and Nanayakkara submitted this petition on 15 August, naming SJB General Secretary Ranjith Maddumabandara among the respondents. On 18 July, the SJB Working Committee had decided to expel Fernando and Nanayakkara from the party. In May 2022, the SJB initially suspended the party membership of the duo when they accepted ministerial portfolios. Fernando and Nanayakkara explained that they accepted these ministerial positions under President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s administration to address the ongoing economic crisis, as many political party leaders did not show interest in a collective effort. They later resigned from their ministerial positions on 9 July 2022, along with the entire Cabinet, following President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s announcement of his intention to resign. However, they were both reappointed to the same ministerial portfolios by President Ranil Wickremesinghe when he formed a new Cabinet on 22 July 2022. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Embassy in Israel looking for two missing Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan Ambassador to Israel, Nimal Bandara told Ceylon Today that he will be travelling closer to the Gaza Strip today (11) to make inquiries about two Sri Lankans who went missing, during the attacks carried out by Hamas on Israel, in an unexpected raid on 7 October. The Ambassador has already communicated his travel plans to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Colombo and requested assistance for his journey to the Gaza area, which involves approximately 300-kilometre, a two-hour journey. Ambassador Bandara  said his purpose to visit the Gaza area was to assess the situation in hospitals and mortuaries to identify the two missing persons: Anula Ratnayake (49) from Kadawatha and Bandara Yatawara, a 48-year-old male from Wennapuwa. He said amidst abductions and casualties, he is journeying with an assistant to the hospitals and mortuaries in Gaza, to ascertain whether these two individuals were among the injured or deceased. Hamas militants launched rockets into Israel and carried out incursions into southern Israeli cities and towns along the Gaza Strip border. This led to the deaths and injuries of hundreds of soldiers and civilians, as well as dozens being taken hostage. The Ambassador stated that he had received information from some of Anula Ratnayake’s relatives indicating that she was killed. However, the Ambassador said he could not confirm the death until he personally investigates the situation. He has gathered all available information regarding the missing Sri Lankan woman. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has been responsible for handling the bodies, and he plans to check on the status of the missing individuals. The Israeli government has announced that they are conducting a door-to-door operation around the Gaza Strip as part of a rescue mission of Israelis taken hostage by Hamas. Consequently, they have declared the area a no-man’s land. It is estimated that approximately 20- 40 Sri Lankans are working as caretakers in the vicinity of the Gaza Strip and they would be evacuated in the coming days. The majority of Sri Lankan workers reside in and around Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. Further, there is speculations of potential attacks on Israel by allies of Hamas, such as Lebanon from the north of Israel which is the West Bank. Given the entry of a US warship into the Mediterranean Sea, there is a growing concern of an escalating conflict, reminiscent of the intense warfare experienced in 1967 which was known as 1967 Arab–Israeli War that lasted for six days. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: China says Exim Bank, SL reached preliminary debt deal
author: Author not found
Content: China said one of its financial institutions has reached a preliminary agreement with Sri Lanka to resolve China-related debt, a major step to resolve the South Asian nation’s fiscal woes. The deal involving Export-Import Bank of China was reached late last month, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin said Tuesday at a regular press briefing in Beijing. Wang didn’t give details on how the debt was resolved, and officials in Sri Lanka didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. “Chinese financial institutions have fully participated in creditors’ meetings as observers, maintain friendly communication with other creditors and have shared developments on debt disposal,” Wang said. The deal puts Sri Lanka closer to completing its debt restructuring, as the nation boosts efforts to win agreements with other creditors such as Japan and India, as well as with holders of its foreign bonds. China accounts for about 52% of the bankrupt nation’s bilateral debt. Reaching a deal quickly will allow Sri Lanka to keep tapping funds from its USD 3 billion bailout programme with the International Monetary Fund. Sri Lankan dollar bonds due 2030 were steady at 45.8 cents on the dollar. The nation’s dollar bonds had returned more than 50% this year, according to a Bloomberg index. Bloomberg News reported last month that some members on the committee of Sri Lanka’s official creditors were pushing to reach a deal to restructure the nation’s debt without China’s participation. The members wanted the group of major creditors to sign a memorandum of understanding with Sri Lanka around the time of the IMF and World Bank meetings which are ongoing in Marrakesh, Morocco. Separately, Sri Lanka may be able to draw the outlines of a deal with holders of its defaulted dollar bonds as early as this month, Bloomberg reported in September. Sri Lanka in September agreed to restructure about USD 10 billion of local debt.  (Bloomberg)

title: Easter attacks trial prosecution testimony commences
author: Author not found
Content: The hearing of testimony for the prosecution, in the case filed against 25 accused, including Naufer Moulavi, who have been charged with the explosion of bombs targeting Catholic Churches and star class hotels, on Easter Sunday (21 April 2019) and conspiracy to set off bombs, commenced before the Trial-at- Bar of the Colombo High Court, yesterday. The High Court Bench comprised Judges Damith Thotawatta, Amal Ranaraja and Navaratne Marasinghe. ASG Haripriya Jayasundera, prosecuted on behalf of the Attorney General’s Department. Before the commencement of the hearing of testimony,  ASG Jayasundera delivered the opening statement and she requested the Court to mete out justice on behalf of the scores of victims, of the Easter Sunday carnage. She then noted that during the hearing of testimony, the prosecution would seek to explain to the Court, the manner in which the 25 accused had spread extremist views across the country, prior to the blasts, along with how they had coaxed certain people to take part in the suicide blasts, the way in which they had gathered and collected explosives and how the carnage, had been planned meticulously. ASG Jayasundera then stated that the prosecution will also be submitting to Court, statements that had been recorded from the 25 accused, as per Provisions of the PTA and the Code of Criminal Procedure Act, CCTV Camera Footage, along with evidence from specialists. The prosecution informed the Bench, that in the aftermath of the carnage, the Attorney General, at the time, had filed charges against the 25 accused, before the High Court, on 10 August, 2021. She further added that upon the demise of the 17th defendant in the trial, the prosecution had amended the charge sheet, filed against the defendants and that to date charges were being sustained against 24 of the accused. Ishanka Hansamali, who had worked as a receptionist at the restaurant, ‘Table 1’ at Shangri-La Hotel and who had been named as the 943rd witness to the prosecution, then testified. She mentioned that on the day, which was Easter Sunday, special cuisine had been put on display at the restaurant for both locals and tourists alike and observed that at around 10.15 a.m., the loud noise of an explosion had been heard, from the side of the restaurant. The witness explained that the restaurant, where she had been stationed, had been separated into four sections called A, B, C and D and that the first explosion, had taken place between the C and D sections. She added that after the first explosion, the people had begun to run helter-skelter having become afraid for their lives and that a second explosion had then taken place near the lift of the restaurant. After that, the prosecution showed the witness, four photos and she then identified Zahran Hashim, who was in one of the photos and stated that on the day of the incident he had been behind her and that she had not known him as Zahran, at the time. Later, further hearing of testimony was put off to today, (11) and the prosecution informed the Court, that they will be submitting CCTV Camera Footage, captured from the hotel premises, as evidence. The Court had also summoned DIG P. Ampawila and Chief Inspector Saman Perera, to testify for the prosecution and the judges advised them to be present to give evidence, when noticed again. BY Hansi Nanayakkara
