title: EC informed of Nazeer Ahmed’s seat falling vacant
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera yesterday (9) informed the Election Commission (EC) that the Parliamentary seat of former Minister of Environment Nazeer Ahmed has become vacant. Thus, the next candidate in the Batticaloa District preferential votes list, of the Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC), will be appointed to fill the vacant seat in Parliament by the EC. After Ahmed, the next candidate on the vote list is Ali Zaheer Maulana. The gazette announcement regarding the appointment of the new MP is scheduled to be issued this week. It is reported that the new MP will be sworn in next week, most probably on 17 October. The Supreme Court last week determined that the decision taken to remove Ahmed from the SLMC is valid and legal. In April 2022, the Sri Lanka Muslim Congress decided to expel party member Naseer Ahamed after he was sworn in as the Minister of Environment under the former government. Following his appointment, Naseer Ahamed also endorsed the 20th Amendment to the Constitution in 2020 and voted in favour of the Budget 2022, against the stance of the SLMC.  Based on these reasons, the SLMC took measures to expel Naseer Ahamed from the party. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Raids increase Excise revenue by Rs 1B in a month
author: Author not found
Content: The Excise Department has managed to increase its revenue by one billion rupees in a month, as a result of raids to seize bottles of liquor with the fake security sticker and the imposition of fines, it was revealed yesterday (10). The Parliamentary Committee on Ways and Means yesterday ordered the Department to commence seizing bottles of liquor bearing counterfeit stickers and it was stated yesterday that this course of action would serve as a shining example on how best the State could explore further avenues to accrue revenues.  The Parliamentary Ways and Means Committee also has recommended that the Excise Department call a fresh tender for a new security feature for bottles of liquor following widespread issues over the current security sticker supplied by an Indian company. The Committee, which presented its first report to Parliament last month, identified many issues related to the implementation of the security feature.  “The security sticker is supposed to be foolproof but we found that it has been widely forged,” the Committee observed. Acting on instructions from the Ways and Means Committee, the Excise Department has been conducting island-wide raids over the past few weeks to take into custody bottles of liquor suspected to bear the fake security sticker. The scam is believed to have resulted in the loss of millions of rupees in tax revenue to the Excise Department. Over 100,000 bottles of liquor, were taken into custody on suspicion of containing the fake security sticker. The fines comprise compounding fees, defaulted excise charges and late fees. The Committee also observed that the current security sticker system is also not customer-friendly, with only Excise Department officials having the technology to identify genuine stickers from fake ones. As such, the Committee has recommended the introduction of a mobile application with QR-based technology to enable customers to easily identify fake security stickers. Accordingly, a customer must be able to scan the QR code on the security sticker to verify whether the product they are purchasing is genuine or not.

title: Cabinet nod to recognise foreign medical degrees
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the initiating of a legal procedure to recognise medical degrees from foreign universities, ranked within the top 1,000 internationally, in Sri Lanka. In a previous decision taken in May, Cabinet sanctioned the formation of a committee chaired by the Prime Minister’s Secretary. This committee was tasked with developing a national policy outlining the standards and criteria to recognise medical degrees from globally renowned universities within Sri Lanka. Additionally, the committee was responsible to make recommendations to amend provisions of the Medical Ordinance to align with current requirements. Subsequently, approval has now been granted for a joint proposal submitted by  President Ranil Wickremesinghe and  Minister of Health, Keheliya Rambukwella.

title: Two STF officers killed, five injured in accident
author: Author not found
Content: Two STF personnel, attached to the STF camp in Madukanda, Vavuniya were killed and five other officers were injured, when their vehicle collided with a cow, veered off the road and crashed into a wall in Velikulam on Monday (9). According to Police, the accident occurred at around 9:30 p.m. amidst a heavy downpour causing reduced visibility and challenging road conditions, while the STF personnel were travelling towards Vavuniya town. CCTV footage, from a nearby residence, showed the Land Rover Defender belonging to the STF, carrying seven officers from the camp, driving at high speed, moments prior to hitting the cow standing in the middle of the road. The two victims aged 29 and 31, residing in Kurunegala and Medawachchiya succumbed to injuries following admission to the Vavuniya Hospital. Later that day the cow also died from critical injuries it suffered in the accident. Two sergeants, a sub inspector and the Police constable, who was driving the Defender jeep, were receiving treatment at the Vavuniya Hospital. Police also said two of the injured were in critical condition. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: CT scanner at LRH out of service
author: Author not found
Content: The computerised tomography (CT) scan service at the Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH) has collapsed, causing severe inconvenience to young patients. President of the Government Radiological Technologists’ Association (GRTA), Chanaka Dharmawickrema said the said CT scanner had stopped functioning on Monday (8) and lamented that this was the only CT scanner available at the hospital. Repairing the machine has become a serious problem as the annual service agreement related to the item had not been upgraded. The Hospital is specialised in treating paediatric patients while they are referred to LRH from all parts of the island. However, the collapse of the CT scanner had caused serious impediment to children who needed it. Dharmawickrema said 25 to 30 paediatric patients underwent CT scans daily. Since they are children, they have to be either sedated or anaesthetised prior to subjecting them to the scan. He said patients with head injuries, neuro and cancer diagnosis were among those who underwent CT scans. He said the LRH CT scanner had patients on a waiting list of three to four months.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Three Bills to ensure gender equality, safety soon – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment Geetha Kumarasinghe said yesterday (10) that three important Bills concerning gender-based violence will be introduced soon. These Bills include the Gender Equality Bill, the National Commission for Women Bill and the Women’s Empowerment Bill, all of which are crucial steps in advancing gender equality and safety in the country, she added. Addressing a media briefing, at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Kumarasinghe said to bolster the social security of women, plans are underway to establish women’s care centres in ten districts. These centres will provide a secure environment for women in need, offering support and assistance. In addition, a 24/7 emergency hotline, 1938, has been introduced to permit women to seek assistance and report incidents in confidence. Identifying the importance of safeguarding the welfare of children without parental care and protecting their identities, the Government has launched the ‘Window’ programme. Further, the Ministry of Women, Child Affairs, and Social Empowerment is considering reducing taxes on sanitary napkins, aiming to make essential products more affordable for women. “A comprehensive programme to prevent gender-based violence is also on the cards in collaboration with the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). Spanning the next five years from 2024 to 2028, this initiative includes self-employment schemes to empower young women, widows, women from incarcerated families, women in the estate sector, and low-income urban women entrepreneurs.” The Ministry of Women, Child Affairs, and Social Empowerment has initiated various programmes for children’s welfare, including a nutritional allowance programme for pregnant women and lactating mothers, offering Rs 45,000 over ten months. This programme provides critical support for six months during pregnancy and four months during lactation, she said. Furthermore, in 2023, the Government launched a programme to provide breakfast to pre-school children, targeting 155,000 beneficiaries. As part of this initiative, pre-school teachers will receive a monthly stipend of Rs 2,500 under the ‘Guru Abhimani’ programme. To combat nutritional deficiencies, high-nutrition biscuits are being distributed to pre-school children in several districts, including Monaragala, Galle, Mullaitivu, Anuradhapura, Nuwara Eliya, and Ampara. Monthly district-level meetings are being held to address concerns of children and women, ensuring the success of these vital initiatives. The Government’s commitment to gender equality, women’s welfare, and children’s well-being marks a significant step tocreate a more inclusive and stable country, Kumarasinghe said.

title: Cabinet approves compensation for farmers
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers has decided to provide compensation to farmers who suffered crop damage, due to the dry weather conditions during the 2023 Yala season. This proposal was presented to the Cabinet by Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera. It was determined that the required funds to compensate all impacted farmers will be allocated through the existing crop insurance programme. Approximately 58,770 acres of paddy and other crops were adversely affected due to the insufficient water supply caused by the arid weather conditions. This situation impacted nearly 53,965 farmers.

title: UK Minister seeks to strengthen IORA work on climate mitigation
author: Author not found
Content: UK Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Minister for the Indo-Pacific Anne-Marie Trevelyan, who arrived in Sri Lanka yesterday (10), on a three-day visit to Colombo and Jaffna, stated that they are working together with Sri Lanka on climate action, peace-building and human rights. Minister Trevelyan will also seek to strengthen Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) work on climate mitigation. Through collaborative programmes, that underpin biodiversity objectives and the Glasgow Pact (agreed at COP26), the Minister will highlight UK support for Sri Lanka’s environmental work. This builds on the UK’s strong track record as the first major economy to legislate for Net Zero, cutting carbon emissions faster than any other G7 country. Her visit to attend the IORA meeting also coincides with UK celebrating 75 years of diplomatic relations with Sri Lanka. Minister Trevelyan, whose first visit to Sri Lanka in her role, said she will emphasise the UK’s long-term commitment to the region at the IORA Ministerial meeting hosted by Sri Lanka. She said through key regional forums like IORA, they can accelerate progress towardsenhanced security for the Indian Ocean region, collaborate on shared climate goals and on boosting maritime security. While in Colombo, Minister Trevelyan will meet members of the Sri Lankan Government including President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Foreign Minister Ali Sabry as well as business leaders and civil society. Discussions will focus on climate finance and green growth, bilateral trade discussions, human rights, justice reform and opportunities to enhance UK-SriLanka diplomatic ties. Travelling to Jaffna, in the Northern Province, Trevelyan will meet Governor P. S. M. Charles and regional parliamentarians, civil society and the local business community. She will visit a landmine clearance site in Muhamalai to see demining and sustainablere settlement work which is supported through the UK’s Conflict, Security and Stability Fund(CSSF). Following her engagements in Sri Lanka, the Minister will travel to India as part of a wider trip to reaffirm the UK’s commitment to a free and open Indo-Pacific. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Naula-Arangala rock fire causes severe damage
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘Dumbara Mithuro’ Environmental Organisation claims that the fire which erupted on the Naula-Arangala rock last Saturday (8), has caused significant damage to the ecosystem in the area. Ananda Kanaherarachchi, an adviser to Dumbara Mithuro Environmental Organisation, revealed that numerous native                         plants and animal species in the vicinity of the Knuckles Mountain Range have been devastated as a result of the fire. A few hours after the incident, the Naula Police arrested five youths, although it was later revealed that they were not responsible for igniting the fire. However, residents living near Arangala Rock claim that the flames spread due to unauthorised visits to the area. According to Kanaherarachchi, the ecosystem around Arangala Rock, which stands approximately 700 metres high, offers a panoramic 360-degree view. From the summit of Arangala Rock, visitors can easily observe the Atipola Mountain, Brandigala, Ambokka, and Knuckles ecosystems. Arangala Rock, a magnificent natural formation, along with the diverse plant and wildlife within its ecosystem, can still be appreciated despite the fire. To prevent the recurrence of such incidents, Dumbara Mithuro strongly advocates for the establishment of formal mountain climbing regulations and the designation of the Arangala ecosystem as a protected area. BY I.A. Kumara – Naula

title: Station Masters’ Union celebrates its 100th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Station Masters’ Union (SLSMU), which is the oldest trade union in the State sector in Sri Lanka, celebrated its 100th Anniversary last week. Established in 1923, as the Ceylon Railway Station Masters’ Union, it consists of 1,050 members. It commemorated its centennial year 6 on October. Union members organised a series of events throughout the year to mark this occasion, including a cricket festival, a donation campaign for the Apeksha Hopital, Maharagama, and a musical show at the Railway Grounds in Borella last month. In conjunction with the centenary celebration, the 4th annual summit took place at the Marino Beach Hotel in Colombo on 6 October.  State Minister of Transport Lasantha Alagiyawanna, graced the event as the chief guest.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 314 Army officers, other rankers 1,565 promoted
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 314 Officers of the Sri Lanka Army (Regular and Volunteer Force) and a record 1,565 Other Rankers of the Army (Regular Force and Volunteer Force) have been promoted to their respective next ranks in view of the 74th Anniversary of the Sri Lanka Army yesterday (10). They were promoted by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces, on the recommendation of the Ministry of Defence and Army Commander, Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage. Accordingly, seven Brigadiers have been elevated to the rank of Major General, 12 Colonels to the rank of Brigadier, 37 Lieutenant Colonels to the rank of Colonel, 41 Majors to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel, 50 Captains to the rank of Major (Including Quarter Masters), 84 Lieutenants to the rank of Captain (Including Quarter Masters) and 83 Second Lieutenants to the rank of Lieutenant (Regular Force & Volunteer Force) in the Officers’ category. In the category of Other Rankers, a total of 83 Warrant Officers-II to the rank of Warrant Officer-I, 183 Staff Sergeants to the rank of Warrant Officer-II, 263 Sergeants to the rank of Staff Sergeant, 414 Corporals to the rank of Sergeant, 374 Lance Corporals to the rank of Corporal and 248 Privates to the rank of Lance Corporal (Regular Force and Volunteer Force) were promoted. According to the Sri Lanka Army, seven Senior Brigadiers who have been elevated to the two-star Major General rank in the Army included Major General D.A. Amarasekara, Major General R. Elvitigala, Major General I.H.M.R.K. Herath, Major General W.M.P.M. Wijesooriya, Major General W.P. Kariyawasam, Major General K.M.P.S.B. Kulatunga and Major General H.H.K.S.S. Hewage.

title: Foreign consultant roped in for SriLankan
author: Author not found
Content: In order to revitalise Sri Lanka’s national carrier, SriLankan Airlines, the government has appointed an international consultant renowned for their expertise and proficiency in implementing best practices within the aviation industry, said Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. He revealed this during a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC). The primary objective of this restructuring is to enhance the airline’s operational efficiency and financial stability. “A crucial aspect of this endeavour is the government’s unwavering commitment to safeguarding the job security of approximately 6,000 employees associated with the airline, throughout the restructuring process. The consultant is expected to play a pivotal role in guiding and steering the restructuring efforts towards a more sustainable and prosperous future for SriLankan Airlines,” he said. Sri Lanka’s aviation sector has reported a substantial profit of Rs 22 billion in the period from January to August 2023. The Minister said, approximately Rs 10 billion from this profit has already been contributed to Treasury, providing a much-needed boost to the country’s finances. The Minister highlighted the success of operations at Palali International Airport, emphasising that the airport has completed 200 flights. This achievement underscores the airport’s increasing significance and efficiency in handling air travel. The Minister acknowledged the challenges faced by the aviation sector in the past, including the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, reduced tourist arrivals and a dollar crisis that affected fuel supply for airplanes. He mentioned that, at one point, fuel for airplanes had to be procured by sending aircraft to Madras to obtain the necessary fuel. To address these challenges, the Minister of Petroleum and Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva intervened and facilitated the import of aviation fuel by the private sector, ensuring a stable supply of fuel for airplanes. Additionally, modern technology was employed to develop Bandaranaike International Airport, earning it recognition as a prominent airport in Southeast Asia. Efforts were made to increase the frequency of flights by different airlines operating in Sri Lanka. This likely contributes to improved connectivity and accessibility for travellers. These developments in the Sri Lankan aviation sector signify a positive turn in its financial performance, reflecting resilience in overcoming challenges. The government’s interventions, such as facilitating fuel supply and enhancing airport infrastructure, have contributed to this success. Increased profitability in the aviation sector is expected to have a positive impact on the country’s overall economic stability.

title: Hamas attack on Israel: Two Sri Lankans missing, one injured
author: Author not found
Content: As the conflict between Israeli troops and Hamas in Palestine intensifies, the Sri Lankan Embassy in Tel Aviv, Israel, has reported that two Sri Lankans are currently missing, while one had been injured on Saturday morning (7).  Sri Lankan President Ranil Wickremesinghe has called for the urgent need for immediate action to ensure the safety of Sri Lankan citizens who are working in Israel. These incidents happened during a surprise attack by Hamas from the Gaza strip on Israel. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Israel, Namal Bandara said that they have not yet confirmed any fatalities among Sri Lankans, as there have been no bodies identified to substantiate such reports. However, he added that one male worker, aged 38, sustained minor injuries and is currently in the process of recovery. According to the Ambassador, there is uncertainty regarding the two missing individuals, a 48-year-old male and a 49-year-old woman. He speculated that there may be several individuals who have been potentially kidnapped by Hamas, but this also requires further confirmation. The Ambassador stated that yesterday (9), three officials from SLFBE arrived in Tel Aviv to assess the situation of the Sri Lankan workers. They reached their destination at around 12:30 pm, noted by the Ambassador. The President directed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to locate and ensure the well-being of these individuals. Additionally, he called for assistance in facilitating the return of Israelis, including tourists and employees, from Sri Lanka to Israel and urged the Police to provide necessary security measures for Israelis within Sri Lanka. Currently, there are 8,000 Sri Lankan workers primarily employed in the healthcare and agriculture sectors in Israel. The Ambassador emphasised that the ‘war’ is primarily targeted against Hamas and not the Palestinian population and further highlighted that the country remains peaceful for the most part. “It’s normal right now and the buses and people are on the move as usual in Tel Aviv,” he said. He also added during air strikes by Hamas, they go to the bunkers as all buildings have bunkers to hide.  Rockets fired from Gaza have been intercepted by Israel’s air defence system and there were no serious damages and those who died came under physical attacks by the Hamas militants. Hamas fighters initiated a surprise attack, utilising both land and air operations, targeting the Israeli settlements surrounding the Gaza Strip last Saturday. The SLBFE said that the Sri Lankan Government is working with the Sri Lankan Embassy in Israel to ensure the safety of Sri Lankans employed in Israel. If there are any Sri Lankans living in Israel who have undergone any issue due to ensuing war, the SLBFE said that they can reach contact 0094-716640560 via WhatsApp. The SLBFE also said that if anyone needs to find information on Sri Lankans living in Israel, information can be accessed by contacting the hotline number 1989. The Sri Lankan Embassy in Israel has asked all Sri Lankans in Israel to be vigilant and exercise caution while following the safety protocols advised by local law enforcement authorities. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka said that the Sri Lanka missions in Tel Aviv and Ramallah are keeping a close eye on the escalating situation and are in contact with the Sri Lankans living in the affected areas. The matter was discussed at yesterday’s Cabinet meeting and President Ranil Wickremesinghe briefed the Cabinet about the current situation in Israel, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. “There are many Sri Lankans working in Israel. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs must locate them and ensure their safety. There are a number of Israelis in Sri Lanka – some are tourists and some are employed. We must help them to travel back to Israel. I have also asked the Police to lookafter the Israelis in Sri Lanka,” the President said. The President also said Sri Lanka always supported two States concept of Israel and Palestine. We are steadfast in our support. At times we have condemned Israel’s actions. Nevertheless, all this does not justify Hamas attack on Israel killing a large number of civilians. The Government of Sri Lanka condemns this unprecedented attack.” He also warned about potential economic repercussions on Sri Lanka owing to the ongoing war with Hamas. The fighting and violence must be brought to an end immediately. Sri Lanka is in agreement with the African Union proposal. There is another impact of this crisis. The petrol prices were expected to rise to USD 100 per barrel and thereafter recede from end February. This crisis will only create a further shortage of fuel ensuring that fuel prices will remain high for a longer time. This is a big blow to the developing economies, he pointed out.  Meanwhile, major airlines around the world have cancelled flights to Israel or warned of travel disruption as the security situation deteriorates. Virgin Atlantic warned of cancellations and delays to Tel Aviv and British Airways (BA) has altered its schedule. Also, three US carriers, as well as Air France, Lufthansa and Emirates, have suspended services. Palestinian militants Hamas said that they had targeted Israel’s Ben Gurion airport with missiles on Monday. Virgin Atlantic said it had made eight cancellations between Tel Aviv and London Heathrow, from Saturday until this coming Wednesday.UK budget carrier Wizz Air confirmed it had cancelled flights to and from Tel Aviv until further notice, while EasyJet halted flights on Sunday and Monday, adding that it would alter it schedule for the rest of this week. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan and Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Jackson Anthony’s last rites on Thursday
author: Author not found
Content: The funeral of the veteran actor Jackson Anthony, who passed away early yesterday (9), has been scheduled for this week. As per information from family sources, the remains of the departed actor will be placed at the ‘Jayaratne Respect Home’ Funeral Parlour in Colombo, where the public can pay their respects, from 07:30 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. today (10). Subsequently, the actor’s remains will be at his residence in Kadawatha on Wednesday, 11 October and Thursday, 12 October. The final rites for the esteemed Sri Lankan actor Jackson Anthony will take place on Thursday, 12 October, at 03.00 p.m. at St. Peter & Paul’s Church in Ragama. Jackson Anthony, who was 65 years old at the time of his passing, breathed his last at the National Hospital in Colombo early on 9 October. His demise followed an extended period of treatment at Colombo National Hospital, stemming from an accident he was involved in July 2022. The accident had occurred when Anthony’s vehicle collided with a wild elephant in Thalawa. Conganige Joseph Malsi Jackson Anthony was widely regarded as one of Sri Lanka’s most renowned artistes, having received the national award for Best Actor an impressive 16 times. His multifaceted talents extended beyond acting, encompassing roles as a director, producer, singer, screenwriter, television host, novelist, columnist, lyricist, historian and traveller.

title: CBCSL asks President for copies of Int’l Easter attack probes
author: Author not found
Content: The Catholic Bishops’ Conference of Sri Lanka (CBCSL) appealed to President Ranil Wickremesinghe to share with them the copies of investigations conducted by several international intelligence agencies, over the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, which he had mentioned during his interview with Germany’s DW News. In a letter to President Wickremesinghe, the Bishops’ Conference said that during the interview with the ‘Deutsche Welle News’ the President had stated that the Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI), British Police, the Australian, the Indian, the Chinese and the Pakistani secret services had given reports concerning the attacks. “The fact has been bought to the attention of the general public as well as the Bishops’ Conference for the first time,” the Bishops observed. They noted that the President had repeatedly stated that his dealings with the Catholic Church were with the Bishops’ Conference of Sri Lanka and not with the Cardinal. They pointed out that the Cardinal himself was the Archbishop of Colombo and did not “exist alone.” He was an integral and most vital member of the Catholic Bishops’ Conference in Sri Lanka. “Hence, the reference to the Cardinal in a singular manner undermines the collegiality of the Catholic Bishops’ Conference which comprises the bishops of the 12 Dioceses of Sri Lanka and the three Auxiliary Bishops of Colombo,” they pointed out. While thanking the President for handing over the volumes of the Presidential Commission of inquiry Report into the Easter Sunday attacks, they appealed to him to also share with them the reports on the investigations carried out by the several international secret service services. (DJ)

title: Algae cause of mass fish deaths
author: Author not found
Content: The mass death of thousands of fish in the Kumbichankulama lake, situated in the heart of Anuradhapura, has now been effectively managed and it is believed that this situation is attributed to an issue with algae, Ruwan Wijesinghe, Anuradhapura Municipal Commissioner said. Although various animals, including birds, dogs and other creatures, may have consumed the deceased fish, there is no evidence to suggest that poisoning was involved, according to the Health Department Anuradhapura. Wijesinghe revealed that approximately 75 per cent of the fish population in Kumbicchankulama lake has perished, but the situation is now under control. The Municipal Commissioner emphasised that this occurrence may have been triggered by a decrease in oxygen levels and an increase in algae due to a rapid reduction in the lake’s water volume and a surge in the fish population caused by the severe drought affecting the area. Furthermore, the municipal council has taken measures to remove dead fish daily and steps have been taken to disrupt the water using boats in order to manage the algae issue, which has now been successfully addressed. In addition, water samples and samples of dead fish have been forwarded to relevant health and other departments for the reports. Anuradhapura East Divisional Secretary Sampath Dharmadasa said these reports will be received soon. By Chula Bandara Kulasekara and Ananda Jayasiri – Mahawilachchiya

title: Former IP shot dead
author: Author not found
Content: A former Inspector of Police (IP) was killed in Rathgama yesterday (9), while his brother sustained injuries in a shooting incident. The shooting was carried out near his house by unidentified individuals riding a motorcycle. According to the Police, the 40-year-old former IP passed away after being admitted to hospital. The former IP had reportedly spent a year and a half in remand custody due to an alleged offence committed during his tour of duty. He was recently released on bail. This shooting occurred as he was returning home from the Balapitiya Court. Rathgama Police have launched investigations into the shooting.

title: Import restrictions on all items bar vehicles to be relaxed
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya announced that a Gazette Notificationwas expected to issue at midnight yesterday (9), relaxing import restrictions on all items, with the exception of vehicles. In an earlier statement, made in September, Siyambalapitiya had indicated that restrictions on imported goods, excluding vehicles, would be lifted in October, aiming to stabilise prices. These restrictions had led to price increases in certain goods due to insufficient supply to meet the demand. On 14 August, through a special Gazette Notification, the government had already eased restrictions on the importation of public transport buses and special-purpose heavy vehicles, such as tankers, bowsers, and fire trucks. Additionally, the government had decided to release heavy vehicles, imported during the restricted period, that remained un-cleared at ports. This marked the first instance of Sri Lanka rolling back import restrictions on vehicles, which had been imposed in March 2020. However, import bans on passenger vehicles are not expected to be lifted in the near future. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Data Protection Authority Director Board appointed
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has initiated the appointment of a Board of Directors for the Sri Lanka Personal Data Protection Authority (PDPA), established with the primary objective of safeguarding personal data within the nation, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. This is Sri Lanka’s Personal Data Protection Act No. 9 of 2022 (PDPA) which has been making strides toward full implementation. The Act, certified by the Speaker on 19 March 2022, aims to safeguard personal data held by various entities, including government bodies, banks, telecom operators and hospitals. This legislation, the first of its kind in South Asia, was developed through a transparent process, with draft versions made available for public comment since June 2019. The PDPA is set to be implemented in phases, with Part V brought into operation through a Gazette Notification on 21 July 2023. This crucial step allowed the government to appoint the Board of Directors, comprising seven individuals with expertise in engineering, accounting/finance, law and regulatory affairs. Heading the Board of Directors is Arjuna Herath, a Senior Chartered Accountant and former Consulting Leader of Ernst & Young in Sri Lanka and the Maldives. Other notable members include Attorney-at-Law and Former State Counsel Nisith Abeysooriya, President’s Counsel Saumya Amarasekera, Digital Law Expert & Chair of the PDPA drafting Committee Jayantha Fernando, Additional Secretary to the President Dr. Sulakshana Jayawardana, ISO Lead Auditor and Technology Management Specialist Bimsara Seneviratne and Electronics Engineer and Digital Strategy Specialist Shehan Wijetilaka. The PDPA assumes paramount importance in light of the government’s and the private sector’s digital strategies, along with global privacy law developments. It is expected to attract investment and promote the digital economy, aligning with the National Digital Strategy and the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity (SL-UDI) project. President Wickremesinghe highlighted the need for data protection in his November 2022 Budget Speech, promising the establishment of the Data Protection Authority in 2023. This independent regulator will collaborate with various sectoral regulators to ensure the proper governance of personal data. Currently, the Board of Directors is in the deliberation and planning phase for the creation of the Data Protection Authority. The first step involves recommending the operation of Part VIII (Fund of the Authority) and Part IX of the Act to design the organisational framework, recruitment procedures, and roles of key officers, including the Director-General. To meet the Act’s enforcement deadline of 19 March 2025, the Authority plans to formulate policy frameworks and regulations. It will hold public consultations and engage with advisory committees representing key sectors of the economy and other stakeholders to ensure comprehensive and effective data protection measures. The Authority is set to commence public consultations and awareness campaigns once it has the necessary capacity, a process expected to take several months. Sri Lanka is on its way to establishing a robust framework for personal data protection in the digital age, making strides toward safeguarding citizens’ privacy and promoting trust in the digital ecosystem.

title: MCPA warns of increased AIDS, hepatitis risks
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) warned that there was a risk of an increase in Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and hepatitis due to the accumulation of substandard drugs and blood components in the health system. MCPA President Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (9) called President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s attention to the risk of a spread in harmful diseases such as HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) /AIDS and hepatitis due to the recent trend in importing medicinal drugs sans proper testing. “It is highly unfortunate that the medicinal drugs which come into the State Health service, through the Medical Supplies Division (MSD), lacks this international accepted standard of going through a proper laboratory testing to ensure that they do not carry substances which could be harmful.” He noted that this was vital when producing medicines with human blood or using components obtained from living people. These should be tested in suitable laboratories before giving them to a patient as they may lead to the transmission of diseases. He also urged the Director General Health Service to test those patients who had been administered the immunoglobulin, which even the parent company in India had disowned, according to the Health Minister and the Chairman of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), for blood-related communicable diseases. The MCPA President said that according to the statements made by the Health Minister and the Chairman of the NMRA, the said stock of Immunoglobulin had been imported using forged documents. It is the President’s responsibility to ensure that the public do not lose faith in the State health system, Dr. Sanjeeva noted urging President Wickremesinghe to initiate a probe against the local pharmaceutical company and the Health Ministry officials who were involved in the tender procedure. “It is also the responsibility of the legal bodies to inform the public on the current status of controversial Immunoglobulin as the Health Ministry nor the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) was revealing the progress of their investigations into the matter,” the MCPA President added.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

Other notable members include Attorney-at-Law and Former State Counsel Nisith Abeysooriya, President’s Counsel Saumya Amarasekera, Digital Law Expert & Chair of the PDPA drafting Committee Jayantha Fernando, Additional Secretary to the President Dr. Sulakshana Jayawardana, ISO Lead Auditor and Technology Management Specialist Bimsara Seneviratne and Electronics Engineer and Digital Strategy Specialist Shehan Wijetilaka. The PDPA assumes paramount importance in light of the government’s and the private sector’s digital strategies, along with global privacy law developments. It is expected to attract investment and promote the digital economy, aligning with the National Digital Strategy and the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity (SL-UDI) project. President Wickremesinghe highlighted the need for data protection in his November 2022 Budget Speech, promising the establishment of the Data Protection Authority in 2023. This independent regulator will collaborate with various sectoral regulators to ensure the proper governance of personal data. Currently, the Board of Directors is in the deliberation and planning phase for the creation of the Data Protection Authority. The first step involves recommending the operation of Part VIII (Fund of the Authority) and Part IX of the Act to design the organisational framework, recruitment procedures, and roles of key officers, including the Director-General. To meet the Act’s enforcement deadline of 19 March 2025, the Authority plans to formulate policy frameworks and regulations. It will hold public consultations and engage with advisory committees representing key sectors of the economy and other stakeholders to ensure comprehensive and effective data protection measures. The Authority is set to commence public consultations and awareness campaigns once it has the necessary capacity, a process expected to take several months. Sri Lanka is on its way to establishing a robust framework for personal data protection in the digital age, making strides toward safeguarding citizens’ privacy and promoting trust in the digital ecosystem.

title: MPs who changed sides now in a quandary – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Most of the MPs who had changed political parties and joined different political coalitions, in the recent past, are currently in utter trepidation following the recent verdict issued by the Supreme Court regarding an issue concerning Environment Minister Nazeer Ahmed, claimed Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera. He made this comment addressing the media last morning, when asked for his take on the recent decision given by the country’s Apex Court, regarding changing of political parties by MPs. Speaking further, Amaraweera said, “In the aftermath of this decision delivered by the Supreme Court, I know it for a fact that there are a sizeable number of lawmakers, who had resorted to such measures in the recent past, but who are currently shaking in their boots. There are some who are even in the present Cabinet. Hence, they have a genuine and strong fear that their Ministerial posts and parliamentary seats will be in serious jeopardy if it is challenged before the Supreme Court.” When asked whether he is not unduly concerned about his own position, the Minister replied there is no such fear.  “No, I have no such fears because I never changed my original political party from which I contested the last General Election. I have continued to be an SLFPer and that will be my party even in the future. None of us ditched our party and therefore we are not concerned about any ramifications. The decision to support this regime was taken by the party Central Committee. But I know it with certainty that most of those who had visions of ditching their political parties are now shivering in their boots in the wake of this momentous decision by the Supreme Court.” BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Private bus owners say no to emission test
author: Author not found
Content: The private buses will no longer undergo emission testing, effective January of the upcoming year, the Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) said. During a press conference held in Colombo, LPBOA Chairman Gemunu Wijeratne explained that this decision was taken due to the absence of a practical emission testing programme. He stressed that the association would formally communicate this decision in writing to the transport authorities within the current week. Wijeratne highlighted the significant challenges related to emission tests for private buses, emphasising that these tests are not being conducted effectively. Additionally, Wijeratne raised concerns about the quality of fuel provided to buses, stating, “We have consistently raised issues regarding the deteriorating quality of diesel fuel. There is a genuine problem with the diesel quality supplied.” Moreover, he pointed out that emission tests are not being conducted on buses operated by the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) or other government vehicles. He argued that since private buses charge the same fares as SLTB buses and offer comparable services, the law should be applied consistently to all. Consequently, the LPBOA intends to submit a written notification to the Ministry of Transport next week, officially declaring their decision to discontinue emission testing for their buses from January.

title: Amaraweera requests S Korea to restart agri sector training
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera has formally requested the South Korean Ambassador to Sri Lanka to restart the training programme for officers and scientists in Sri Lanka’s agriculture sector, which was previously conducted under the auspices of the Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA). Recently, Miyon Lee, the South Korean Ambassador to Sri Lanka, held a meeting with Minister Mahinda Amaraweera and officials from the Ministry of Agriculture. The discussions centered on the future development of Sri Lanka’s agriculture sector. Among the topics discussed were strategies to increase paddy yields, the use of both chemical and organic fertiliser, the application of genetic technology for hybrid seed production, the adoption of new agricultural technology, and training opportunities for officials in the agricultural sector in both South Korea and Sri Lanka. Minister Amaraweera recalled that Sri Lankan officials and scientists had previously received advanced agricultural training under the KOICA programme, which is currently suspended. He requested the Ambassador’s support in resuming this valuable programme. In response, the Ambassador expressed her willingness to convey the request to the Korean Government. Regarding fertiliser use, the Ambassador highlighted that South Korea employs a combination of chemical and organic fertiliser to achieve high agricultural yields. South Korean farmers receive comprehensive training in this regard. She also emphasised that, for various crops, including paddy, optimal results can be achieved by using a mix of chemical and organic fertilisers. In response to a query from the Ambassador, about the progress of Sri Lanka’s livestock sector, Amaraweera explained that while the country had achieved self-sufficiency in poultry and egg production until 2020, challenges stemming from the economic crisis and the Covid-19 pandemic in the last two years had disrupted these industries. However, he expressed optimism that the poultry and egg production industry is on a path to recovery and expected significant growth in the sector by April of the coming year. The meeting was attended by Gunadasa Samarasinghe, Secretary to the Ministry of Agriculture and other officials. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Sri Lanka begins Single Super Phosphate Fertiliser production
author: Author not found
Content: Single Super Phosphate (SSP) Fertiliser production has been launched in Sri Lanka as a substitute for Triple Super Phosphate (TSP) Fertiliser which is used to obtain phosphorus required for paddy cultivation and other crop cultivation, according to the Department of Agriculture. The SSP Fertiliser produced by using Eppawala Rock Phosphate, is very suitable for rice and other crops and can be used as a substitute for TSP which is currently imported. The annual cost of importing TSP Fertiliser is about three billion rupees. Most of these fertilisers are produced in the countries under the Russian Federation and due to the current war between Ukraine and Russia, there are problems in importing TSP. Therefore, by producing this single superphosphate, the country will be able to save three billion rupees. The government took steps to provide free TSP in the last Yala season. Currently, another stock of that fertiliser is with the government-owned fertiliser companies and farmers also have some quantity of that Fertiliser.  Four local companies in Sri Lanka have taken the necessary steps to produce SSP Fertiliser  locally and the representatives of those companies met the Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera recently. This discussion was held at the Ministry of Agriculture. The amount of TSP Fertiliser required in this country is about 65,000 MT. Fertiliser manufacturing companies have the capacity to produce this required amount and currently have nearly 4,000 MT of Single Super Phosphate fertiliser in stock. The company representatives said that they are able to produce the SSP Fertiliser that the country needs. Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said that under the full supervision of the Department of Agriculture, the fertiliser can be produced and distributed by Lanka Fertiliser Company and Commercial Fertiliser Companies. Gunadasa Samarasinghe, Secretary to the Ministry of Agriculture, Dr. Jagath Perera, Chairman of the two government-owned fertiliser companies and Chandana Lokuheva, Director of the National Fertiliser Secretariat, also participated in this discussion.

title: Judge recuses himself from hearing Rajiv assasination convict’s petition
author: Author not found
Content: Justice Sunder Mohan, of the Madras High Court, on Monday (6) recused himself from hearing a writ petition, filed by former Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi’s assassination case convict, Santhan alias T. Suthendraraja, seeking a direction to the Union Home Ministry as well as the Tamil Nadu Government to take immediate steps for his deportation to Sri Lanka. When the case was listed before a Division Bench of Justices S.S. Sundar and Sunder Mohan, the latter recused himself from hearing the petition since he had been a counsel on record in a connected case before the Supreme Court of India. Hence, the Bench directed the Registry to list the case before a Bench led by Justice D. Krishnakumar as per standing instructions. In an affidavit filed through his counsel P. Pugalendhi, the petitioner stated that he was a Sri Lankan national, and hence had been detained in a special camp (Foreigners’ Detention Centre) under the Foreigners Act, 1946 ever since he was released from prison on 12 November 2022 pursuant to a Supreme Court order. Santhan claimed that the Union Home Ministry had passed an order on 11 November 2022 ordering that he should not move out of the boundaries of the special camp till his deportation to his home country. The petitioner said that he wanted to go to Sri Lanka immediately, since his 75-year-old mother residing in Valvetti in Jaffna was seriously ill. Referring to a representation made by him in this connection to the Centre as well as the State government, he said, his representations were yet to be considered. (The Hindu)

title: Four drown in three areas
author: Author not found
Content: Four men tragically lost their lives in separate drowning incidents in the Kattankudy, Ja-Ela and Gokarella areas. In the first incident, on 8 October 2023, two youths lost their lives when the canoe they were travelling was capsised in the Nawadi lagoon, within the Kattankudy Police Division. There were six people on the canoe and four managed to escape. The two deceased youths, aged 18 and 19, were residents of Mamangam in Batticaloa. On the same day (8), in the Ja-Ela Police Division, a 47-year-old man tragically drowned in Yakkaduwa. His body, dressed in a jacket and helmet, was discovered in a paddy field along Niwandama Road in Ja-Ela. It is suspected that the man drowned when the motorbike he was riding got submerged due to flooding. The Police located a motorbike believed to belong to him. In the third incident, a 52-year-old man from Thuduwawela, Gokarella went missing while bathing in the Bathalagoda River during the evening of 8 October.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SLPP will support President till next election
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) will support incumbent President Ranil Wickremesinghe until the next Presidential Election and decide whether to endorse a candidate from the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna or a common candidate at the next election, SLPP MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage said. He revealed this on Sunday (8) during a party meeting in Nawalapitiya. He further said, the SJB and the JVP are attempting to create public opinion suggesting that the government intends to ban social media, but he emphasised that the government has no intention of doing so. Instead, the government aims to regulate it. Aluthgamage highlighted the negative consequences of unregulated social media, such as the sharing of private and inappropriate content. He emphasised that the people of the country prioritise their right to live over social media and he mentioned that the second tranche of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance is expected in October or November. With the IMF assistance and the Budget 2024, the government plans to provide numerous concessions to the people, he said. Aluthgamage also said there is still one year left until the Presidential Election, and during that time, they will work to support Ranil Wickremesinghe. Regarding the future, they will assess whether to field a candidate from their party for the Presidential Election or support a common candidate. BY Nita Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Criminal injured asPolice open fire
author: Author not found
Content: Police opened fire at a suspect who attempted to grapple with them while they were attempting to take him into custody over a number of criminal acts. This happened in  Alvai, off Point Pedro, Jaffna, yesterday afternoon (9). As a result of the shooting, the 27-year-old suspect sustained injuries and was subsequently taken into custody by the Police. He was initially admitted to Point Pedro Hospital. However, the arrested individual was later transferred to Jaffna Teaching Hospital for further attention. The suspect is believed to be connected to various criminal incidents in the Jaffna region, including sword attacks and theft. Moreover, he is said to have several outstanding arrest warrants against him.

title: Police probe Rs 1.1M stolen from under monk’s pillow
author: Author not found
Content: The Kalutara North Police have launched an investigation, following a complaint, made on Sunday (8) by the Chief Incumbent of a temple in Kalutara that nearly Rs 1.1 million, belonging to him had been stolen. Police said that it was noted in the complaint that nearly Rs 1.1 million had been stolen from under the pillow on the bed in the Thera’s room. It is said that the stolen money was reserved for a construction at the temple. Police said the suspects had not been identified as yet. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: Intellectuals leaving SL ‘lack wisdom’– Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Intellectuals who choose to leave the country during its challenging times, despite being prime beneficiaries of the free education system and having enjoyed the associated social benefits, actually “lack wisdom,” Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said. He was speaking at the ‘Guru Prathiba Prabha’, award ceremony for teachers and principals held at the Ministry of Education yesterday (8). He said to realistically meet the challenge of providing a ‘quality and equitable education’ which is the fourth of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals, teachers have been assigned a crucial role in the new transformative education process in Sri Lanka. The Ministry of Education, coinciding with World Teachers’ Day on 6 October, held this award ceremony and 70 principals and teachers belonging to 26 schools who were sensitive to the various problems faced at the school level were appreciated. Regarding the issue of ‘brain drain,’ which is presently affecting numerous professions in Sri Lanka, the Minister asserted that intellectuals who are leaving the country during challenging times are, in fact, individuals who have benefited from the country’s free education system and have enjoyed the associated social advantages but are now displaying a lack of commitment or foresight. He emphasised that their responsibility, particularly during such challenging periods, should not be to leave the country but rather to stay and utilise their skills to confront and overcome these challenges. Minister Premajayantha highlighted the crucial role of graduate teachers who possess the requisite knowledge and training skills in implementing transformative educational changes. These changes aim to foster a high-quality generation of students proficient in new STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) education methods, which incorporate practical classroom activities to apply theoretical knowledge effectively. Further, Minister Premajayantha affirmed that the upcoming establishment of the University of Education, formed by merging all 19 National Colleges of Education, will serve as a hub for achieving these educational goals. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Israel declares war on Hamas
author: Author not found
Content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office says his Security Cabinet has declared the country at war following a deadly Hamas assault in southern Israel. The decision, announced on Sunday (8), formally authorises “the taking of significant military steps,” it said in a statement. “The war that was forced on the State of Israel in a murderous terrorist assault from the Gaza Strip began at 06:00 on Saturday (7),” it said. It gave no further details. But Netanyahu had previously declared the country at war, and the military has promised a harsh response in Gaza. Israeli media say at least 600 people have been killed in the surprise cross-border incursion by Hamas militants from the Gaza Strip. Israeli soldiers battled Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel on Sunday and launched retaliation strikes that levelled buildings in Gaza, while in northern Israel a brief exchange of strikes with Lebanon’s Hezbollah militant group raised fears of a broader conflict. There was still some fighting underway more than 24 hours after an unprecedented surprise attack from Gaza, in which Hamas militants, backed by a volley of thousands of rockets, broke through Israel’s security barrier and rampaged through nearby communities. At least 600 people have reportedly been killed in Israel — a staggering toll on a scale the country has not experienced in decades — and more than 300 have been killed in Gaza. The militants also took captives back into the coastal Gaza enclave, including women, children and the elderly, who they will likely try to trade for thousands of Palestinian prisoners held by Israel. The high death toll, multiple captives and slow response to the onslaught pointed to a major intelligence failure and undermined the long-held perception that Israel has eyes and ears everywhere in the small, densely populated territory it has controlled for decades. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the country was at war and would exact a heavy price from its enemies. Hamas leaders said they were prepared for further escalation. A major question now was whether Israel will launch a ground assault into Gaza, a move that in the past has brought intensified casualties. Netanyahu vowed that Hamas “will pay an unprecedented price.” But, he warned, “This war will take time. It will be difficult.” Civilians paid a staggering cost for the violence on both sides. Several Israeli media outlets, citing rescue service officials, said at least 600 people were killed in Israel, including 44 soldiers, while officials in Gaza said 313 people had died in the territory. Some 2,000 people have been wounded on each side. An Israeli official said security forces have killed 400 militants and captured dozens more. Israeli TV news aired a stream of accounts from the relatives of captive or missing Israelis, who wailed and begged for assistance amid a fog of uncertainty surrounding the fate of their loved ones. In Gaza, residents fled homes near the border to escape Israeli strikes, fleeing deeper inside the territory after warnings in Arabic from the Israeli military. In neighbouring Egypt, a Policeman shot dead two Israeli tourists and an Egyptian at a tourist site in Alexandria, the Interior Ministry said. Egypt made peace with Israel decades ago, but anti-Israel sentiment runs high in the country, especially during bouts of Israeli-Palestinian violence. The flare-up on Israel’s northern border also threatened to draw into the battle Hezbollah, a fierce enemy of Israel’s which is backed by Iran and estimated to have tens of thousands of rockets at its disposal. Hezbollah fired dozens of rockets and shells on Sunday at three Israeli positions in a disputed area along the border and Israel’s military fired back using armed drones. Two children were lightly wounded by broken glass on the Lebanese side, according to the nearby Marjayoun Hospital. Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, an Israeli military official, told reporters the situation at the northern border was calm after the exchange. But he said fighting was still underway in the south and that there were still hostage situations there. He said troops had moved into every community near the Gaza frontier, where they planned to evacuate all civilians and scour the area for militants. “We will go through every community until we kill every terrorist that is in Israeli territory,” he said. In Gaza, “every terrorist located in a house, all the commanders in houses, will be hit by Israeli fire. That will continue escalating in the coming hours.” Hamas said that overnight it had continued to send forces and equipment into “a number of locations inside our occupied territories,” referring to Israel. Hamas-linked media reported that the son of Nizar Awadallah, a senior political official, was killed. The Islamic militant group has not reported any senior members being captured, killed or wounded. The surprise attack Saturday was the deadliest on Israel in decades. In an assault of startling breadth, Hamas gunmen used explosives to break through the border fence enclosing Gaza, then crossed with motorcycles, pickup trucks, paragliders and speed boats on the coast. They rolled into as many as 22 locations outside the Gaza Strip early Saturday morning, including towns and other communities as far as 24 kilometers (15 miles) from the Gaza border, while Hamas launched thousands of rockets at Israeli cities. (AP)

title: ‘Don’t display cut-outs of me’ – President
author: Author not found
Content: After pictures of a mammoth cut-out of him displayed near Chenkalady Central College in Batticaloa went viral, President Ranil Wickremesinghe issued a directive urging against the use of his images on billboards, cut-outs, and posters. He also called on fellow political leaders to refrain from incorporating their photos in their campaign material. President Wickremesinghe emphasised the importance of addressing the people’s needs over the use of political slogans, noting that such practices have had adverse effects on the country’s economy. The President reiterated his long-standing opposition to the use of slogans and cut-out-based politics and encouraged everyone to embark on a new political journey together. These remarks were made during his participation in the 149th anniversary celebration of Chenkalady Central College in Batticaloa yesterday (8). In addition, the President instructed the relevant parties to remove the said large cut-out as well.

title: Batti livestock farmers protest against pasture land encroachers
author: Author not found
Content: While President Ranil Wickremesinghe was attending the 149th anniversary celebration of Chenkaladi Madhya Maha Vidyalaya in Batticaloa yesterday (8), livestock farmers staged a protest demanding the removal of encroachers from their pasture land. During the event, the President unveiled an ambitious 10-year initiative aimed at boosting agriculture and tourism in the Eastern Province, with a focus on the development of Trincomalee.    There were protesters from two communities, one led by ITAK MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam, who led a group of MPs and other organisations close to a venue where the President was attending an event in the school. The issue has been highlighted since the Mahaweli Development Authority settled people for corn cultivation on pastoral land. Protesters wanted to meet the President to express their grievances but Police objected and asked the protestors to leave the site which led to a tense situation between the Police and the public. The President later met some State officials to discuss the issue related to pastoral land. However, protesters said that discussions were futile as he did not speak to them. Banners were destroyed and several women were injured in the commotion with the Police Rasamanickam accused the Government of allowing chena cultivators to illegally encroach on grazing land in the Mayilathamadu District, traditionally used by cattle farmers during the period, October to February. “The State is responsible for capturing land for farming purposes without paying adequate heed to the 200,000 cattle that use the land for grazing and produce 17,000 litres of organic milk daily,” said Rasamanickam. Meanwhile, Ven. Ampitiye Sumanarathana Thera protested by sitting on the road and confronted Police urging that pastoral land be given to corn cultivators. BY Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Devastating Matara floods affect 64,834 persons
author: Author not found
Content: Flooding has impacted 64,834 individuals from 17,993 families in Matara as of 8:30 a.m. on Sunday (8). Y. Wickramasiri, District Secretary of Matara, reported that within the Matara District alone, 23,108 people from 6,301 families have been forced to evacuate their homes due to the floods. At present, 41,726 individuals belonging to 11,692 families remain stranded in their affected areas. The floods have damaged 390 houses, with two houses being destroyed in the Matara District. Despite the challenges posed by the flooding, there is some relief around the corner. The Department of Meteorology said rainfall in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, and Southern provinces will temporarily decrease in the next 48 hours. Meanwhile, owing to the adverse weather conditions, the Southern Province Education Ministry has decided to temporarily close all schools in the Galle and Matara districts both today (9) and tomorrow (10). This decision was reached after consultations with Southern Province Governor Willy Gamage.

title: Colombo Air Symposium – 2023 begins today
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Air Symposium-2023 (CAS), an annual International Academic Forum organised by the Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) is to commence for the sixth time after a three-year hiatus, the event is scheduled for today (9) and tomorrow (10). The symposium will be held at the Eagle’s Lakeside Banquet and Convention Hall, with the participation of intellectuals, diplomats, military leaders, policymakers, and technological experts. It aims to delve into the realms of defense and security, exploring the multifaceted dimensions of airpower, interaction, and juxtaposition. Under the direct guidance and supervision of the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, CAS 2023 adopts the theme ‘Fostering shared air interests in the IOR: Geopolitical Cooperation, Complexities, and Compulsions’. This thematic choice establishes a platform to enhance cooperation and mutual understanding among nations in the Indian Ocean Region (IOR), particularly regarding shared air interests. The symposium prioritises discussions that promote transparency and trust-building, serving as a means to prevent conflicts within the airspace of the IOR. It also delves into strategies aimed at achieving efficient, safe, and sustainable airspace management within the intricate and complex IOR environment. Furthermore, CAS 2023 critically examines the role of airpower within developing nations, especially within the challenging context of the geopolitical landscape, and assesses its far-reaching impacts on regional and global dynamics. It underscores the utilisation of airpower for the betterment of human security through humanitarian endeavours, disaster response, and conflict prevention. The symposium also addresses the imperative of ensuring the long-term effectiveness of airpower in developing nations despite the prevalent political and economic challenges. Notably, CAS 2023 seeks to identify strategies and cooperative measures that can bolster airpower capabilities in a region marked by Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity, and Ambiguity (VUCA). Chief of Staff and National Security Adviser to the President, Sagala Ratnayake will be the Chief Guest. Additionally, Professor Adam Leong Kok Wey, a prominent figure in strategic studies and the Director of the Centre for Defence and International Security Studies (CDISS) at the National Defence University of Malaysia, will deliver the keynote address. Colombo Air Symposium will be represented by Ambassadors, High Commissioners and foreign delegates attending from over 40 countries including United Kingdom, United States of America, Canada, India, China and more. Furthermore, foreign research authors and highranking officers from the defence forces will complete the lineup of papers presented at the event. The Air Symposium will explore a wider understanding and stronger collaborations under the session themes, air Space Management, airpower, socioeconomic compulsions, sustenance under ‘VUCA’ and regional coherence and interdependence
