title: Two domestics murdered in Matara
author: Author not found
Content: Two female domestic workers employed at a residence in Brown’s Hill, Matara were found murdered, Police said yesterday (8). The homeowner had briefly stepped out of the house at the time of the incident. On her return, she noticed the absence of the two maids, prompting her and concerned neighbours to search for them. Shockingly, the bodies of the two women were found inside the bathroom they commonly used, Police added. On further investigation, Police determined that 12 bangles, two gold necklaces, one golden spoon, and 39 foreign currency coins had been stolen from a cupboard in the house. The two victims are aged 67 and 70. Matara Police arrested a suspect in connection with the murders. The arrested individual is a 25-year-old resident of Thudawa. Further, Police said the stolen jewellery was recovered from the suspect.

title: NBRO issues evacuation alerts to 66 DS divisions
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the prevailing adverse weather conditions, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has identified numerous locations as landslide-prone areas. The NBRO issued evacuation alerts of varying severity levels, including level three red-watch, level two amber, and level one yellow, to several Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions situated across the Central Hill Country. Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist of the Landslides Early Warning Centre at NBRO, has disclosed that a total of 66 DS divisions, in ten districts throughout the country, have been designated as landslide-prone areas. These districts encompass Galle, Kalutara, Matara, Badulla, Ratnapura, Hambantota, Kegalle, Gampaha, Colombo and Kandy. In accordance with Dr. Senadeera’s statements, level three red-watch evacuation alerts have been officially issued for several DS divisions and their surrounding regions, including the Yakkalamulla, Elpitiya, Nagoda, Imaduwa, and Galle Four Gravets DS divisions in the Galle district, the Walallawita, Matugama and Ingiriya DS divisions in the Kalutara district and the Hakmana, Pitabeddara, and Akuressa DS divisions in the Matara district. Likewise, level two amber-watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued for the Haputale DS division and its vicinity in the Badulla District, the Akmeemana, Niyagama, Thawalama, Neluwa, Bope Poddala, Baddegama and Ambalangoda DS divisions in the Galle District, the Walasmulla and Katuwana DS divisions in the Hambantota District, the Bulathsinhala, Dodangoda and Palindanuwara DS divisions in the Kalutara District, the Deraniyagala, Ruwanwella, Yatiyantota and Dehiowita DS divisions in the Kegalle District, the Kamburupitiya, Kirinda Puhulwella, Kotapola, Matara Four Gravets, Malimbada, Thihagoda, Athuraliya, Pasgoda, Mulatiyana and Welipitiya DS divisions in the Matara District and the Eheliyagoda, Kuruwita, Elapatha, Ratnapura and Kalawana DS divisions in the Ratnapura district. Furthermore, level one yellow-watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued for the following regions: the Haldummulla and Bandarawela DS divisions in the Badulla District, the Padukka and Seethawaka DS divisions in the Colombo District, the Mirigama DS division in the Gampaha District, the Okewela and Beliatta DS divisions in the Hambantota District, the Agalawatta, Kalutara, and Beruwala DS divisions in the Kalutara District, the Pasbage Korale DS division in Kandy, the Kegalle and Bulathkohupitiya DS divisions in the Kegalle District and the Pelmadulla, Openayake, Kolonna, Kiriella, Ayagama, Godakawela and Nivithigala DS divisions in the Ratnapura District. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Thirty new breast clinics to be set up in State hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: Thirty (30) new breast clinics will be set up in State hospitals soon. They will come under the supervision of oncology surgeons and are a crucial addition to the existing Suvanari clinics and cancer early detection centres, Dr. Hasareli Fernando, the Head of the National Cancer Control Programme in Sri Lanka revealed. During an interview in the ‘One-to-one Katha’ programme, conducted by the President’s Media Division (PMD), Dr Fernando said the primary aim of these clinics is to enhance the early detection of breast cancer, a disease that ranks as the most prevalent form of cancer among women both in Sri Lanka and globally, the PMD said. Dr. Fernando said while breast cancer cannot be prevented, early detection offers the potential for complete cure. This expansion of healthcare infrastructure is a significant step forward in ensuring better healthcare access and outcomes for the people of Sri Lanka. “Breast cancer is not limited to women, as men can also be affected, albeit at a significantly lower rate. Over 80% of breast cancer cases occur in individuals aged 50 and above. Risk factors for breast cancer include family history, genetic mutations, late childbirth, and a history of previous breast cancer battles. Other factors such as early puberty, late menopause, and hormonal birth control usage may also contribute to the risk,” she said. While some risk factors are beyond an individual’s control, there are modifiable factors that can be addressed, including weight management, dietary choices, regular exercise and alcohol and tobacco consumption. The most effective method for early detection of breast cancer is through regular breast self-examinations, especially for women over the age of 20. Routine self-exams should be conducted on a specific date each month, and individuals should be vigilant for any new changes, such as the presence of a lump, changes in skin texture, color or shape, nipple discharge, or nipple inversion. The Ministry of Health has also taken steps to establish five cancer screening centres in Narahenpita, Ratnapura, Matara, Batticaloa, and Jaffna, in addition to the 30 new breast clinics supervised by specialist cancer surgeons in government hospitals across Sri Lanka. Individuals are encouraged to visit these facilities for necessary tests and medical advice. Cancer cases are on the rise in Sri Lanka and globally. In 2020, Sri Lanka witnessed over 37,000 new cancer diagnoses, with breast cancer being the most common form, accounting for 26% of women’s cancer diagnoses. Worldwide, breast cancer remains a significant health concern, with 2.2 million cases reported in 2020, resulting in 685,000 deaths. Dr. Fernando also emphasised the importance of dietary choices in preventing cancer, recommending the reduction of fast-food consumption and mindful weight management. Additionally, engaging in regular exercise, avoiding smoking and smokeless tobacco products, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle are vital steps in cancer prevention.

title: IORA Council of Ministers to convene in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Ministers of Foreign Affairs from the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) and other senior ministers of IORA Member States and Dialogue Partners will convene in Sri Lanka next week for the 23rd IORA Council of Ministers, hosted by Sri Lanka on 11 October, in Colombo. Sixteen ministers, including the Foreign Ministers of Bangladesh, India, Iran, Mauritius, Malaysia, and South Africa, as well as ministerial and senior-level participation from Australia, Comoros, France, Indonesia, Kenya, Madagascar, the Maldives, Mozambique, Oman, Seychelles, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Somalia, Tanzania, Thailand, the United Arab Emirates, and Yemen (member countries). Additionally, representatives from China, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the Russian Federation, Türkiye, the United Kingdom, and the United States of America (dialogue partners) will be in attendance. The Council of Ministers serves as the highest decision-making body of IORA are expected to participate in the meeting. Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Sabry will preside over the Council, taking over the chairmanship from the current Chair, the Foreign Minister of Bangladesh. The Council’s sessions will be preceded by the 25th meeting of the Committee of IORA Senior Officials scheduled for 9 and 10 October to be chaired by Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane. IORA, established in 1997, is an intergovernmental organisation comprising States around the Indian Ocean. Its membership spans regions including Africa, West Asia, South Asia, Southeast Asia, and Oceania. Currently, IORA has 23 Member States and 11 Dialogue Partners. Sri Lanka is set to assume the chairmanship of IORA for the 2023-2025 period, with this transition to be formalised at the 23rd Council of Ministers’ Meeting. During the meeting, the Ministers will deliberate on collaboration within the six priority areas identified by the Association, such as Trade and Investment, Maritime Safety and Security, Fisheries Management, Disaster Risk Management, and Blue Economy. These discussions will be guided by recommendations from the 25th Committee of IORA Senior Officials. Dr. Salman Al Farisi, the Secretary-General of the Indian Ocean Rim Association, and the directors of the IORA Secretariat in Mauritius will also participate in the meeting. Additionally, visiting ministers will collectively meet with President Ranil Wickremesinghe and engage in bilateral discussions with Sri Lankan Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, as well as other ministers, during their stay in Sri Lanka. Notable attendees from the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) include Tim Watts, Assistant Minister for Foreign Affairs of Australia, Dr A. K. Abdul Momen, Foreign Minister of Bangladesh, Dr. Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, Minister of External Affairs of India, Ambassador Adam Mulawarman Tugio, Adviser to the Minister on Political, Legal, and Political Affairs (equivalent to Deputy Minister) of Indonesia, Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Iran, Dato Seri Diraja Zambry Abdul Kadir, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Malaysia, Maneesh Gobin, Minister for Foreign Affairs, Regional Integration, and International Trade of Mauritius, Sheikh Khalifa bin Ali bin Issa Al-Harthy, Undersecretary for Political Affairs (equivalent to State Minister) of Oman, Dr Mohamed Maliki Bin Osman, Minister in the Prime Minister’s Office, Second Minister of Education, and Second Minister for Foreign Affairs of Singapore, Dr. Naledi Pandor, Minister of International Relations and Cooperation of South Africa,  Sihasak Phuangketkeow, Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs of Thailand and Sayeed Mubarak Al Hajeri, Assistant Minister for Economic and Trade Affairs of the United Arab Emirates, among others. Moreover, Dialogue Partners, including Masahiro Komura, Parliamentary Vice-Minister for Foreign Affairs of Japan, Hon Chung Byung-won, Deputy Minister for Political Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Korea, and Anne Marie Trevelyan, Minister for Indo-Pacific of the United Kingdom, will also participate in the meeting.

title: Soldier, ex-soldier arrested with pistol, ammo
author: Author not found
Content: The Police, on Saturday (7) night, arrested both an active soldier and a former soldier in Elpitiya, in possession of a firearm and ammunition while they were lying in wait to gun down a local businessman in Pituwala, Elpitiya. According to Police, the individuals were arrested with a pistol, along with 10 rounds of 10 mm ammunition, false vehicle number plates, and a motorcycle. The arrest occurred as they were stationed on a motorcycle near a shop, purportedly owned by the targeted businessman. Further investigation showed that the intended victim maintains close ties with an organised criminal figure who is presently evading law enforcement overseas, according to Police sources. Meanwhile, the targeted businessman had reportedly received death threats on the phone, from another leader of an organised criminal gang who also resides overseas. A formal complaint has been lodged with the Elpitiya Police. Elpitiya Police launched a thorough investigation into the incident to determine whether it is linked to recent events involving two underworld gangs that operate in the Southern Province.

title: Accessing world of fashion through cotton industry
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said we need to enact new rules instead of relying on old regulations to get out of the prevailing crisis. He was addressing the Sankathana Mandapaya held at Temple Trees on 7 October to mark World Cotton Day. The Prime Minister said, “World Cotton Day is a special day declared by the United Nations. It is declared a special day because it is useful for the people of the world. We dedicate ourselves to making this day meaningful for the cotton industry. In every district, we encounter thousands of acres of uncultivated land belonging to the Government. There is a possibility of using these lands for a useful purpose like cotton cultivation. We are ready to extend our support and commitment in this regard. By expanding cotton cultivation through a continuous national programme, the income of the rural people can be increased and the foreign exchange of the country can be saved. I appreciate the attempts of the private sector to this end. Farmers and entrepreneurs need confidence to engage in this kind of cultivation. It is necessary to cooperate with our universities and other research institutes to expand this industry. An innovative system should be introduced to cultivate cotton in small gardens as an additional income. Almost a hundred years have elapsed since we started creating agricultural colonies with the belief that we can raise our heads through agriculture. In those colonies, there is the possibility of cultivating on every piece of land. People need to be directed to that. We are ready to have discussions on this matter with relevant institutions. Imported weaving machinery was available in certain buildings. Some were gifted to our country. These resources should be given to universities or entrepreneurs to focus on achieving goals. We must undergo such a change if we want to recover from the crisis. It’s necessary to enact new rules instead of relying on old rules. Countries such as the United Kingdom, US, India, China, and Egypt are still engaged in cotton production. We have to explain to the people about the production of seeds and the many benefits associated with them. By opening the doors of working generation of villages to universities, the children can be trained and those who graduate from university will contribute to the nation’s productivity in the future. We also import pieces of gauze from overseas. The quality of life index has decreased. But the prices of goods are not cheap. Even if the farmers produce surplus, the price is determined by the purchasing power of the people. Farmers need a satisfactory purchase price. An agreement should exist between the private sector and the government sector on the prices.” Azusa Kubota, Resident Representative of the United Nations Development Programme said, “The support of UNDP will be rendered to the Government’s efforts to develop the cotton industry of Sri Lanka with the active participation of the private sector and farmers. This industry with a history of more than 2,500 years can be used to boost the economy of rural farming families. In addition to the production of cotton cloth, there is the possibility of starting various industries related to the cotton industry, which generates valuable products such as cotton oil and animal feed. Especially, this is a gateway to the world of fashion from the cotton industry and I call it ‘Farm to Fashion’. The perseverance of Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena to uplift the rural people including small farm owners and small and medium scale entrepreneurs, especially women is highly appreciated.” Speaking at this occasion, Buddika Marasinghe said, “It is possible to start this cultivation on a large scale as well as in home gardens. Although it is a project that brings foreign exchange to the country which the Government should actively intervene in, the support of the Government is inadequate. The Government should implement a speedy programme to encourage the private sector, the farmer as well as the young entrepreneur to expand this cultivation.” At this function, Polonnaruwa Welikanda cotton farmers presented a casket containing cotton seeds and products to the Prime Minister. Minister Douglas Devananda, State Ministers Seetha Arambepola, Ashoka Priyantha, Vijitha Berugoda, Kader Mastan, MPs Jagath Samarawickrama, Yadamini Gunawardena, Secretaries to the Ministries, University Vice Chancellors, heads of government and non-government institutions, young entrepreneurs, and farmers were present at this occasion.

title: Third Bangladesh Film Festival Illuminates Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The third Bangladesh Film Festival unfolded on Friday (6) at the prestigious Tharangani Theatre of Sri Lanka National Film Corporation with the screening of the internationally acclaimed movie ‘Rehana Maryam Noor’ directed by Abdullah Mohammad Saad. The Film Festival was organised by the Bangladesh High Commission in Sri Lanka and concluded on 8 October. A sizeable cinema crowd including renowned personalities of Sri Lankan cinema and cinema connoisseurs braved the heavy rain in Colombo to experience the Bangladeshi movie. Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Minister Vidura Wickremanayake, Prof. G.L. Peiris, Patali Champika Ranawaka and Heads of Diplomatic Missions were among the dignitaries present. Renowned actress Swarna Mallawarachchi, who is known as the Golden Star of Sri Lankan Cinema, was the Chief Guest. Eminent film critic and director Anomaa Rajakaruna as the curator of the festival introduced the movie to the audience before the screening. Bangladeshi High Commissioner Tareq Mohammad Ariful Islam inaugurated the Festival. In his welcome address, he highlighted the resurgence of Bangladeshi cinema culture in recent times in the hands of a new generation of talented film directors who are bringing in many international accolades. He stated that such film festivals would foster cultural ties between Bangladesh and Sri Lanka. He expressed hope that due to the socio-cultural affinities of the two countries, the Sri Lankan audience would be able to connect deeply with the essence of those movies.  An impressive line-up of four more contemporary Bangladeshi movies was screened during the weekend. Among them, ‘Raat Jaga Phool’ and ‘Nona Joker Kabbo’ were screened on Saturday (7 October) at 3:30 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. at the same venue, while ‘Damal’ (at 3:30 p.m.) and ‘No Dorai’ (6:00 p.m.) were screened on Sunday (8 October).  This third version of the festival builds on the success of the first and second editions held in April 2014 and March 2018. This is a part of the Bangladeshi High Commission’s efforts to strengthen cultural relations through cinema.

title: SL urges peace amid escalation of violence in Israel and Palestine
author: Author not found
Content: In light of the recent escalations of violence in Israel and Palestine, Sri Lanka has expressed its deep concern and called for an immediate halt to hostilities. The conflict has tragically resulted in the loss of many lives, sparking international concern. In a media release, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Sri Lanka urges all parties involved to exercise maximum restraint to prevent further civilian casualties and to seek a peaceful resolution to the ongoing conflict. “The nation remains steadfast in its commitment to supporting a negotiated settlement that aligns with internationally agreed parameters, with a vision of two states coexisting peacefully along the 1967 borders. As the conflict continues to unfold, Sri Lanka extends its heartfelt condolences to all those who have lost loved ones and expresses its sympathies to the affected families who are enduring the hardships of this dire situation.” Sri Lanka’s Missions in Tel Aviv and Ramallah are actively monitoring the evolving situation and are maintaining close contact with Sri Lankans residing in the affected regions. Regrettably, one Sri Lankan national has already suffered minor injuries, emphasising the urgency of the situation and the need for a peaceful resolution, the statement concluded.

title: NFPB to purchase entire stock of soya beans
author: Author not found
Content: The National Food Promotion Board (NFPB) has decided to purchase the entire stock of soya beans, cultivated by farmers in the Anuradhapura District, who had been unable to sell 500,000 kg of their harvest recently. These farmers had lodged an official complaint with the Agriculture Ministry over their inability to obtain a justified price for their soya bean harvest. Having looked into the plight of these farmers, subject Minister Mahinda Amaraweera had advised officials from the NFPB to address the issue and mete out some sort of justice to the scores of farmers affected by it. Chairman of NFPB Palinda Sagara stated that they have decided to purchase a kilo of soya beans at Rs 250 from these farmers and that the process of purchasing the stocks will be kicked off from their Upuldeniya Stores. He added that a sum of Rs 80 to 110 has to be incurred to produce a kilo of soya beans and with the decision taken by them to purchase a kilo at Rs 250, the farmers would be able to receive a fair price for their harvest and earn sizeable profit.  BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Promotion of Ceylon Tea in Chile
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Brazil, which is concurrently accredited to the Republic of Chile, in collaboration with the Sri Lanka Tea Board organised a ‘Sri Lanka pavilion’ with the participation of 12 Sri Lankan Tea exporting companies namely; Dilmah Ceylon Tea Company PLC, Millennium Teas (Pvt) Ltd, Shan Teas (Pvt) Ltd, TDK Tea Solutions, Heritage Teas (Pvt) Ltd, Expoteas Ceylon (Pvt) Ltd, Maltras International (Pvt) Ltd, Bogawantalawa Tea Ceylon (Pvt) Ltd, Nature Ceylon,  Akbar Brothers (Pvt) Ltd, Lumbini Tea Valley Ceylon and Tea Talk (Pvt) Ltd at the Espacio Food Service EXPO, which is one of the largest beverage exhibitions held in South America, from 26 to 28 September in Santiago, Chile. Parallel to the exhibition, a media briefing attended by over 35 journalists from electronic, print and social media platforms and a cocktail reception with the participation of over 175 guests representing Chilean tea importers, members of the Chilean Chambers of Commerce and other business entities, senior officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Chile and other government officials and journalists were held on 27 September evening to promote Ceylon Tea in the Chilean market. Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Brazil Sumith Dassanayake, addressing the media briefing and the reception, highlighted Sri Lanka’s commitment to developing the country as a maritime and investment hub and also to modernise its economy to have a highly competitive green and digital economy. Ambassador Dassanayake also stated that Sri Lanka has already initiated discussions with many countries to expeditiously conclude bilateral trade agreements and also to join regional comprehensive economic and technological partnership arrangements to gain wider access to Sri Lankan products and services to new markets, especially to emerging markets. Referring to Sri Lanka’s lucrative tourism industry, the Ambassador informed that Sri Lanka is a famous destination amongst international tourists as the island is the best place to visit by tourists with diverse interests. Ambassador Dassanayake also encouraged foreign direct investment from Chile and other South American countries to newly established industrial zones in Sri Lanka, especially to the Southern Hambantota Port area, Colombo Port City and tea plantations. He further highlighted that Sri Lanka, being the first country in South Asia to liberalise its economy in 1978, has the knowledge and expertise to cater to the requirements of foreign investors and also that legal guarantees for foreign investment are ensured by Sri Lankan laws. Addressing the events, Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tea Board Niraj de Mel elaborated on the uniqueness of Ceylon Tea and the reputation it holds for its taste, aroma, purity and health benefits. The Chairman requested the Chileans to consume more Ceylon Tea and encouraged the importers and buyers to purchase more Ceylon Tea and experience its benefits. He also ensured that Sri Lankan tea exporters, under the supervision of the Sri Lanka Tea Board, would continuously supply high-quality Ceylon Tea to the Chilean market. Responding to questions raised by journalists, Chairman de Mel explained the measures taken by the Sri Lankan tea manufacturers to maintain high quality and how the quality and taste are affected by the geographic and climatic conditions in Sri Lanka to produce the best quality tea. Some Sri Lankan exhibitors conducted tea tasting-sessions at their stalls to showcase the premium quality and different fusions of Ceylon Tea. In appreciation of prominent Ceylon Tea importers of Chile, they were awarded plaques for their contribution to promoting Ceylon Tea in the Chilean Market by the Ambassador and Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tea Board. Sri Lankan Tea exporters who participated in the exhibition were able to make a large number of business contacts and also secured satisfactory orders to export Ceylon Tea to the Chilean Market. Deputy Director of the Ceylon Tea Board Danushka Karunathilake and First Secretary (Commercial) of the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Brazil Chathurika Perera were associated with the promotional event.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Eight arrested over illegal motorcycle race
author: Author not found
Content: The Nilaveli Police arrested eight individuals in Sambaltivu, Trincomalee yesterday (8). They were apprehended while participating in an illegal race involving eight motorcycles that are banned in Sri Lanka. Preliminary investigations revealed that these motorcycles were brought to the area for the purpose of racing and two of them had not been registered with the Department of Motor Traffic. The arrested individuals were aged between 20 and 25 and are residents of Negombo and its neighbouring areas. The Nilaveli Police are currently conducting further inquiries while detaining the individuals in custody. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Malaysian FM to strengthen diplomatic ties
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs of Malaysia, Dr. Zambry Abdul Kadir, is set to embark on an official visit to Sri Lanka from 8 to 12 October, to strengthen bilateral relations between the two countries. During this diplomatic visit, the Malaysian Foreign Minister is scheduled to engage in bilateral discussions with his Sri Lankan counterpart, Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, at the Foreign Ministry. Additionally, Minister Zambry will pay courtesy calls on Sri Lankan President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena. Accompanying Minister Zambry will be a high-level Malaysian delegation, including Syed Mohamad Bakri Syed Abdul Rahman, Undersecretary of South and Central Asia Division (SCA), Ahmad Kamrizamil Mohd Riza, Undersecretary of the OIC and Regional Cooperation Division (ORCD), and Abdilbar Ab Rashid, Special Officer to the Foreign Minister, all representing the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Malaysia. In addition to bilateral meetings, the Malaysian delegation will actively participate in two significant events during their stay in Colombo. First, they will join the 25th meeting of the Committee of IORA Senior Officials on 9 and 10 October. Subsequently, on 11 October, they will participate in the 23rd IORA Council of Ministers, further emphasising Malaysia’s commitment to regional cooperation and diplomatic engagement.

title: Avoid taking sea baths near Oluvil Lighthouse
author: Author not found
Content: The All Ceylon Jamiyyathul Ulama’s (ACJU’s) Oluvil Branch requests all those who visit Oluvil Lighthouse and beach areas in the vicinity of the South Eastern University of Sri Lanka, for holidaying and past time not to go for sea baths. The sea is rough and several beachgoers have drowned over the past two weeks, it warned. People from all parts of the island, especially youth after their G.C.E. O/L and A/L Examinations, who are on holiday, are tempted to go for a sea bath. They are swept away by waves as they are unfamiliar with the surroundings and cannot swim. Parents have been unable to locate their bodies as well. The bodies washed ashore after several days. To avoid this situation, the ACJU wants Pradeshiya Sabha officials to display sign boards cautioning beachgoers not to take sea baths in the vicinity. They urged authorities to act promptly to save lives. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: First India Alumni Art Exhibition
author: Author not found
Content: The cultural arm of the High Commission of India, Colombo, Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre will organise the first India Alumni Art Exhibition titled, ‘Chitralekha’ at JDA Perera Art Gallery, University of the Visual and Performing Arts, from 10 to 12 October. The exhibition marks the Year of India Alumni, observed by the Indian Council for Cultural Relations. The unique Art Exhibition also commemorates other significant milestones such as 75 years of the establishment of diplomatic relations between India and Sri Lanka and 25 years of the establishment of the Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre (erstwhile Indian Cultural Centre). The exhibition which is being held in collaboration with the National Gallery of Arts will feature special works of eminent Sri Lankan artists who studied in India. Nearly a hundred paintings by Indian Alumni artists from all over Sri Lanka shall be on display at the Exhibition. This includes veteran artists like Ananda Samarakoon, Somabandu Vidyapathi, Ven. L.T.P. Manjusri Thera, George Keyt, Harry Pieris and Upasena Gunawardena, among others. The exhibition is a testament to the enduring friendship and cooperation between the two nations as well as the universal appeal of Arts, transcending boundaries. A total of 25 contemporary Sri Lankan artists studied in different universities in India like Visva-Bharati of Santiniketan, Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda, and Rabindra Bharati University of Kolkata during the last five decades on various scholarship programmes.

title: COPE severely criticises NMRA
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) on Wednesday (4) severely criticised the National Medicine Regulatory Authority (NMRA) over its failure to furnish details sought by the National Audit Office (NAO). During these sessions it had come to light that though the NAO has given five previous reminders to the NMRA, seeking requisite details, the latter had continued to ignore those reminders drawing the ire of COPE MPs. It has been revealed that during a Board Meeting convened by the NMRA, on 18 August, a decision had been taken not to submit any information to the NAO in this regard. However, it has also been disclosed that the Secretary to the Health Ministry had been totally in the dark over the decision taken last August by the NMRA Board of Directors. Chairman of COPE MP Prof. Ranjith Bandara stated that the actions of the NMRA had flouted Articles of the Constitution, the arbitrary takeover of the authority of Parliament as well as infringing on the independence of the Auditor General. During the sessions the Auditor General had warned that if the NMRA declines to furnish information sought by him, he would henceforth withdraw from his work related to the institution concerned. Afterwards the COPE instructed the NMRA to forthwith withdraw its stance on refusing to comply with the request of the Auditor General and warned them that failing to comply with this order will result in them to be ready to face up to consequences over the same. By Lalith Ruhunuge

title: Water Cut in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: A 15-hour water cut will be imposed in several parts of Colombo this weekend for essential maintenance work, the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) announced. The water cut will be implemented in the Colombo 11, 12, 13, 14, and 15. Accordingly, the water supply will be disrupted from 5.00 p.m. on Saturday (7) until 8.00 a.m. on Sunday (8).

title: Anura Kumara queries tax concessions to Sagala’s associate
author: Author not found
Content: At a time when every dollar holds significant value for the country, the Government has decided to grant tax concessions to a company involved in the assembly of electric and hybrid vehicles, whose owner is a close associate of President’s Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake alleged in Parliament yesterday (5). Raising a question, under the Standing Order 27/2, Dissanayake asked on whose behalf and on what basis these concessions were granted. Dissanayake, who alleged that the tax concessions were granted to the said company by changing the agreement with the Borad of Investment of Sri Lanka (BOI), questioned, “The President always tells other parties to join him. Is he inviting us to join and support these frauds?” He pointed out that the government has previously granted tax concessions to friendly companies. Dissanayake expressed a desire to understand the Ministry of Industry’s stand on this specific Cabinet Paper to grant tax concessions to the vehicle assembly company. He also sought clarification on the specific criteria for providing tax relief to this company, emphasising the importance of every dollar to the country’s economy amid challenging circumstances.  He raised concerns about the government offering tax concessions to associates, drawing parallels with previous instances that initially led to sugar tax scam etc. In response, Leader of the House Susil Premajayantha said, a reply for Dissanayake’s question would be provided today (6). BY Anuradha Herath

title: Restaurants hike prices
author: Author not found
Content: With the increase in gas prices, restaurant owners have decided to hike the cost of several food items. President of the All Ceylon Restaurant Owners’ Association (ACROA) Harshana Rukshan yesterday (5) said accordingly the cost of a plain tea would be increased by Rs 10, the price of a Kottu by Rs 20 and fried rice by Rs 50. He lamented that his outfit had continued to cater to people despite the increase in fuel, electricity and water bills. However with the increase in the price of gas, the union has taken a decision to hike the cost of the above mentioned food items, Rukshan noted. However, President of the National Consumer Front (NCF), Asela Sampath, lashing out, said the Government should urgently slap a price formula to decide on the maximum price for food items such as the lunch packet, kottu, fried rice, plain tea, milk tea, raw rice, coconut, big onions, dhal and sugar. Failing to do so would only boost the level of malnutrition by 60 per cent, he warned.      By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Issuing of tickets to visit Sri Pada irks Chief Incumbent
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Incumbent of Sri Pada Ven. Bengamuwe Dhammadinna Thera expressed his dissatisfaction with the Department of Wildlife Conservation’s (DWC) practice of issuing entrance tickets to local and foreign tourists, who visit Sri Pada via the Hatton and Ratnapura roads during the off-season. In a special statement to the media yesterday (5), Ven. Thera highlighted that historically, no charges were imposed on pilgrims visiting Sri Pada, whether during the peak season or the off-season, dating back to the reign of the kings. Consequently, he deemed it unjust for the Department of Wildlife Conservation to levy fees and issue tickets to local and foreign tourists during the off-season. Yesterday (5) morning, a group of tourists from Bhutan, having obtained permission, embarked on a visit to Sri Pada. Tickets were issued to them by the Wildlife Conservation Office located near the Makara Thorana (Dragon’s Arch) on the Nallathanniya – Sri Pada Main Road, at a fee of USD 5 per tourist. When queried about the issuance of tickets to tourists travelling to Sri Pada during the off-season, an official from the Nallathanniya Wildlife Conservation Office referred to a Gazette issued by the Department of Wildlife Conservation in 2022. The Gazette specified that, as of the afternoon of 4 October, the department had been instructed by senior officials to charge USD five from foreign tourists visiting Sri Pada via Nallathanniya and USD four from those coming from SAARC countries. Additionally, a fee of Rs 40 would be imposed on local tourists and these tickets would be available exclusively during the off-season. Nallathanniya Tourism Hotel Owners’ Association also voiced its objections to the Wildlife Conservation Department’s practice of issuing tickets to tourists visiting Sri Pada during the off-season. By Nita Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: President orders to provide immediate flood relief in Matara
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has issued direct instructions to government officials, including the Matara District Secretary, to assess the urgent needs of the flood-affected people in the Matara District resulting from heavy rainfall. The President has emphasised the need to swiftly implement relief measures. The President’s directives also encompass the provision of vital facilities such as cooked meals and medication to those affected, along with the engagement of the Armed Forces to ensure the efficient delivery of aid. Additionally, the President has alerted relevant agencies to formulate contingency plans for the safety and well-being of the populace in the event of worsening flood situations. In the interim, President Wickremesinghe has issued directives to relevant government departments to remain vigilant regarding potential disaster situations that may arise in other districts due to adverse weather conditions. A total of 9,448 individuals from 2,350 families across 16 Divisional Secretariat Divisions in the Matara District have been impacted by various calamities including floods, strong winds, landslides, heavy rains, rock falls, and tree falls. Among these, 399 houses have sustained partial damage, with 37 other properties affected. Community food processing centres have been set up in Malambada, Akurassa, Kamburupitiya, and Thihagoda to provide meals for those in need. At present, 6,967 families comprising 25,553 individuals are stranded due to the floods, and the Army is actively engaged in providing them with cooked food. Simultaneously, the Sri Lankan Army has initiated a specialised relief programme for the residents of the Malimbada Divisional Secretariat Division within the Matara District, which has been severely affected by the flooding. On the instructions of Major General Janaka Ranasinghe, Commander of the 61st Infantry Division, and Colonel Roshan Kannangara, Commander of the Matara Area, two Army battalions have been actively engaged in relief efforts. A total of 6 dinghies and 3 motor boats have been deployed to assist affected individuals, while special military vehicles are on standby for potential emergency rescue operations. To report emergencies and related information in the Matara District, individuals are urged to contact Major General Janaka Ranasinghe on 076 690 7042 and Colonel Roshan Kannangara on 076 690 7146. Concurrently, a high-level discussion addressing the state of emergency in the Matara District and outlining forthcoming relief measures was convened on 4 October at the Matara District Secretariat on the President’s directives. The meeting, presided over by Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera, included the participation of Southern Province Governor Willy Gamage, MP Karunadasa Kodithuwakku, District Secretary Y. Wickramasiri, the Governor’s Secretary, Additional District Secretaries, all Divisional Secretaries of the Matara District, and representatives from law enforcement, the armed forces, and various government departments. The discussion extensively covered immediate relief measures for affected individuals and strategies for the post-flood recovery process. It was agreed that daily disaster management meetings would be held, uniting Divisional Secretariats and Pradeshiya Sabhas to coordinate efforts. Additionally, decisions taken during these meetings will be conveyed to the District Disaster Committees through Zoom on a daily basis.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: EP teachers’ one-day pay deduction will be refunded
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General pledged to the Supreme Court yesterday (5) that the one day’s salary, deducted from the teachers in Eastern Province, in May 2020, for the Itukama Covid-19 fund, without their consent will be returned to those teachers before 30 November. This pledge was given in view of the fact that the Supreme Court ruled that it was illegal to deduct any amount from the salaries of the teachers without their consent. According to a request made by the Secretary to the President Dr. P B. Jayasundara, a day’s pay has involuntarily been deducted from the salaries for the month of May 2020 to contribute to the ‘Itukama’ Covid-19 fund The Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) filed a Fundamental Rights Petition in June 2020 challenging this salary deduction, naming the Eastern Province Director of Education, the Chief Secretary, former Governor Anuradha Yahampath and the Attorney General as respondents. Based on the pledge given by the Attorney General, the petitioners informed the Supreme Court that they would withdraw their petition and the Supreme Court Bench of Justices Vijith K. Malalgoda, Jagath De Silva, and Gamini Amarasekara gave permission to the petitioners to do so. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SC sets date to consider Petitions challenging DDO
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court has set 23 January 2024 for consideration of the Petitions, seeking a ruling that the Government’s decision to reduce benefits from investments made by the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF), under the Domestic Debt Optimisation (DDO) programme, violates the Fundamental Rights of the public. The Court issued this directive during a session presided over by a three-Judge Bench, comprising Justices Preethi Padman Surasena, A.H.M.D. Nawaz, and Mahinda Samayawardena. MP Prof. G.L. Peiris and General Secretary of the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Ranjith Maddumabandara, filed the FR petitions on 26 September. The respondents in these petitions include the Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe, the Monetary Board, the Attorney General, and the Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, among others. The petitioners have raised concerns about the decision to lower the interest rates on investments made by the EPF in government securities, under the DDO programme. They argue that this reduction, which lowered the interest rate to nine per cent, violates the fundamental rights of approximately 2.5 million working individuals with active accounts in the EPF, whose funds are primarily invested in Treasury Bills and Bonds. Furthermore, the petition contends that the CBSL’s Monetary Board failed to seek the input of EPF members before involving the Fund in the DDO programme.

title: Diana heats up the House
author: Author not found
Content: A heated exchange erupted in Parliament, yesterday (5), between State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage and Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MPs, when Gamage slammed SJB MP Ranjith Maddumabandara, claiming that he had subjected her to verbal sexual abuse in the Parliament Chamber. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (5), Gamage made a strong speech alleging that Maddumabandara had used derogatory language towards her in Parliament. “Verbal abuse constitutes a form of sexual harassment through these types of words, which is not only offensive to me, but also an affront to all women in the country, who make up 52 per cent of the population and actively participate in the electoral process. There should be a disciplinary action against Maddumabandara. How dare he use such language on a woman in this House?” she stressed. She further addressed the grudges held by some Opposition members, suggesting that if they struggle to perform their duties adequately, they could learn from her and exchange roles for a day to gain experience. “Maddumabandara is in this Parliament only because I gave him the post of General secretary of the SJB. He is in the House because of me,” she asserted. At that moment, SJB MP Chaminda Wijesiri said it was not fair to accuse Maddumabandara as he was not in the Chamber. Gamage then slammed Wijesiri saying it was not her fault that Maddumabandara failed to attend the Parliamentary sittings. Following this, the SJB MPs started to shout in protest. “This Bandara (Maddumabandara) and several other Bandaras have grudges against me. These men cannot do their jobs properly. I can lend them one of my sarees, so they can do a woman’s job and I can wear a trouser to show how to do a man’s job properly. If these people continue to insult women, I will not hesitate to give them an earful,” she stressed. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Saliya Wickramasuriya appointed CPC, CPSTL Chair
author: Author not found
Content: A new chairperson assumed duties at both the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) and the Ceylon Petroleum Storage Terminals Ltd. (CPSTL) yesterday (5). Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera announced that Saliya Wickramasuriya had been appointed as the chairperson for both organisations. This appointment follows the resignation of Mohamed Uvais Mohamed on 4 October. Wickramasuriya brings with him an expertise in the energy industry and currently serves as the Chairman of the Board of the Petroleum Development Authority. Additionally, he holds a membership on the Colombo Port City Economic Commission. In a related development, Darshana Rathnayake, the Managing Director of CPC, has been named as the new Managing Director of CPSTL.

title: Wheezing among children increases
author: Author not found
Content: Prevailing rains and chilly climatic conditions were causing an increase in the number of young patients suffering from wheezing and upper and lower respiratory illnesses, Consultant Paediatrician at Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH), Dr. Deepal Perera warned. Dr. Perera, fielding questions, when contacted yesterday (05), said that the prevailing rains, floods and the cold weather had increased wheezing amongst children while there were also new cases of wheezing seeking treatment. Identifying symptoms, he said cough, a runny nose, high pitched or laboured breathing and sometimes tightness (pain like) of chest. The cold weather also increases viral infections of which a majority were fever. There are respiratory viral infections which may end in secondary bacterial infections. However, unless prescribed, antibiotics should not be taken, he noted. The Consultant Paediatrician urged fathers and grandfathers who smoke at home to refrain from doing so especially in the presence of their children.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: More countries want Toque monkeys – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Besides China, numerous other countries have also expressed interest in obtaining Toque macaque monkeys for their zoological gardens, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera claimed yesterday (5). He said in Parliament that the Government has advised these countries to submit their requests through their respective embassies. In response to a query from Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Niroshan Perera, the Minister noted that the export of monkeys has been temporarily halted due to legal challenges from animal rights organisations and activists. Amaraweera emphasized that Sri Lanka faces an annual loss of over Rs 20 billion in crops due to animals such as monkeys, wild boar, and peacocks. He further revealed that he engaged in discussions with animal rights organisations opposed to monkey exports, seeking practical solutions to mitigate crop damage. Regrettably, none of these organisations had presented viable proposals thus far, he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: President highlights climate crisis
author: Author not found
Content: In an address at the 5th Forum of Ministers and Environment Authorities of the Asia Pacific, in Colombo yesterday (5), President Ranil Wickremesinghe highlighted three critical points: the urgency of the climate crisis, Sri Lanka’s ambitious climate plans and the dire state of global biodiversity. He began by underlining the alarming projections from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), emphasising the existential threat posed by global warming. President Wickremesinghe stressed the interconnected nature of climate change, biodiversity loss and pollution, and their devastating impact on individuals and communities worldwide. The President then pledged Sri Lanka’s commitment to addressing these challenges. He announced plans to accelerate nature-based solutions, including renewable energy, through the Climate Prosperity Plan and unveiled an ambitious Net Zero 2050 roadmap. Despite Sri Lanka’s small global emissions contribution, the country aims to achieve significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, increase renewable energy generation, expand forest cover, phase out coal power, and reach net-zero emissions by 2050. President Wickremesinghe also expressed deep concern over the state of global biodiversity, emphasising the rapid loss of species and the threat of extinction due to habitat destruction and invasive species. He concluded by calling for collective action and addressing the need for financing to support climate initiatives, highlighting the challenges in current discussions regarding funding for vulnerable countries. President Wickremesinghe proposed alternative mechanisms, including using the balance sheets of New Development Banks (NDBs) to leverage private funds and calling for debt relief for low-income countries. He also touched upon the Vanuatu Resolution, which has taken climate change before the International Court of Justice, emphasising climate justice as a human right.

title: Which South Asian Country is Performing on SDGs? – Sorry… None!
author: Author not found
Content: Out of seven countries in South Asia (Bhutan, the Maldives, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan), only two countries; the Maldives on poverty reduction, the Maldives and Sri Lanka on quality education are on track, for achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), says Sustainable Development Goals (SDR) Review Report 2023, published by the United Nations (UN) Agency. The Sustainable Development Report (SDR) reviews progress made each year on the Sustainable Development Goals since their adoption by the 193 UN Member States in 2015. At the halfway mark to 2030, the SDR 2023 takes stock of progress made and discusses priorities to restore and accelerate SDG progress. This analysis has taken the top 7 SDG indicators for discussion; Poverty, Hunger, Health, Education, Gender Equality and access to Clean Water and Sanitation to make an assessment of where we stand today in the region on important development parameters. Mostly on Red Zone Halfway to the deadline for the 2030 agenda for sustainable development, South Asian countries are mostly in the ‘major challenge group’ category.  The SDG progress report shows that just 2 countries in South Asia- the Maldives is on track with only one indicator of ‘No Poverty’ and the Maldives and Sri Lanka are making some progress on ‘Quality Education’.  The progress on most of the other SDG indicators in these countries is either weak or/and insufficient.  Worst of all, most of the South Asian countries have stalled or gone into reverse (major challenges-red zone) category. The performance of 5 out of 7 countries on Hunger and Health, and 4 on accessing Clean Water and Sanitation are completely in bad shape.  Unless these countries act first, it will be an impossible task for these countries to achieve SDGs goals by 2030. The report says that Hunger has increased in most of the South Asian countries and is back at 2005 levels, gender equality is some 300 years away.  Such progress on key SDG indicators means that something is fundamentally wrong with the governance of the system that delivers such a negative outcome. If the execution of SDGs falls short, what may happen? Looking at the present progress, it looks like, many human development SDG indicators may not be achieved; neither by 2030 nor 2050. So, what are the possible consequences if the execution of the SDGs falls short, what may happen if the targets are not scored in 2030?  The consequence of not executing the SDGs may lead to an exacerbation of problems such as poverty and hunger. Moreover, complex issues related to gender equality and other indicators are likely to remain underachieved. If existing trends continue to persist, by 2030, 575 million people will be trapped in extreme poverty and an estimated 84 million children and young people will be out of education globally importantly, most of these people, affected will be either from South Asian or African countries.  The failure to reach the target SDGs indicator is likely to negatively affect millions of people in these developing and least developed countries in the South Asian region, with substantial damage to livelihoods, an exacerbation of poverty and the spread of diseases. Hunger in the region- Most Priority area The SDG implementation in South Asian countries assumes much significance as there are more than 33 per cent of the people living in extreme poverty globally live in this region. The pandemic further trapped millions in the region to fall into the poverty trap, worsening the hunger situation. The Global Hunger Index (GHI) 2022 ranks South Asian countries with Sri Lanka (64th) followed by Nepal (81st) and Bangladesh (84th). Both Sri Lanka and Nepal are placed in the ‘moderate’ severity level. Afghanistan (109th), India (107th) and Pakistan (99th) are the bottom three countries in the South Asia  2022 GHI index. It is extremely worrying to find that poverty and hunger continue to diminish South Asia’s development progress significantly and in a way show how SDG is implemented in the region.  India, Bangladesh, Pakistan and Nepal have child labour populations of 5.8 million, 5 million, 3.4 million and 2 million respectively, as per a survey by the International Labour Organisation (ILO), which indicates that quality education for children in the region is not on the track as expected and committed by  South Asian leaders on SDG. Failing SDG reflects, nothing but the policy failure Without a renewed commitment and energy (after global disturbance due to the pandemic), we can risk putting many of the SDGs permanently off the track. With only seven years remaining for implementation of the Goals, the South Asia region cannot afford slow progress and these countries have to take strong actions to reduce extreme Poverty and Hunger as data shows, the number of people living in extreme poverty and hunger is increasing for the first time in a generation. Each hungry person, each desperately poor person, each child without education, and each person without having access to safe and clean drinking water, reflects nothing but a policy failure. No country can afford to see them fail. About the Author: Sachi Satapathy is the Director, AF Development Care, New Delhi, India: [email protected] By Sachi Satapathy

title: ‘Architect 2024’ launched
author: Author not found
Content: In the hope of developing the built environment in the country and identifying today’s social, economic and environmental goals, the Sri Lanka Institute of Architects set out to launch Architect 2024, Architects’ Work, Lifestyle & Trade Exhibition at Cinnamon Grand Hotel, Colombo on 25 September 2023 at 6.00 p.m. To a distinguished audience, represented by its stakeholders, the evening’s proceedings were set in motion with a welcome speech by President SLIA, Archt. Rohana Bandara Herath, FIA (SL), followed by an overview of the oldest and the most grandest 42nd Exhibition in the building industry and its content by the committee. The Architect 2024 is a much-awaited and sought-after event in the beginning of each year in the construction industry. “We cannot achieve the goals set for each year without our trusted sponsors who have been with SLIA and the support given by the print and electronic media throughout the good and difficult times. Today, with the country facing with many challenges, next year’s theme ‘Resilience, Resourcefulness, Revival (RRR): A formula for recovery’. Architects 2024 examines how architects’ influence communities and shape the future emphasising the importance of these concepts in the face of adversity and change. The aim of the Architects’ work, lifestyle and trade exhibition is to increase public awareness, access and interaction, with greater emphasis given to local entrepreneurs and locally manufactured building materials as well as importers. It will also be a novel experience for the public with many opportunities available to interact with Architects, particularly the opportunity of a one-on-one free help desk service with a panel of architects for guidance and direction in all construction-related problems encountered by them; apart from viewing the various projects undertaken by Architects depicted in their Panels on display. An Architects Forum will provide educative sessions encompassing the various aspects of the profession of architecture, lifestyle market, outdoor installations, fusion food carnival, live music and fashion shows throughout the 3-day duration of the Exhibition and a stall with the publications done by SLIA will enable purchases by the public. The students from four architectural schools will also showcase their work in stalls allocated to them and the opportunity to display their talents. A stallholders briefing by SLIA will be held on 9 February  2024 at the BMICH at which stallholders will be briefed and provided related documents and information on their participation with the opportunity given to clarify their concerns. Architect 2024 Architects’ Work, Lifestyle & Trade Exhibition is scheduled from 23 to 25  February 2024 at the BMICH complex and opens to the public daily from 10.00 a.m. to 10.00 p.m. The opening ceremony will be in the evening of 22 February 2024.

title: Sanjanani 2023 – Communication and Public Relations Festival
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Sanjanani 2023 – Communication and Public Relations Festival’ organised for the 50th anniversary celebration of the Department of Mass Communication, University of Kelaniya was held on the 3 October 2023 at the auditorium of the Faculty of Social Sciences, University of  Kelaniya. The event was held to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the Department of Mass Communication and to award Dr. Sarath Amunugama for his great contribution to the media industry. Senior Professor Nilanthi de Silva, Vice Chancellor of the University of Kelaniya participated as the Chief Guest, while Dr. Sarath Amunugama participated as the Guest of  Honour. Dr. Sarath Amunugama was awarded the ‘Harasara Award’ presented by the department at the inaugural ceremony. This award was for his great service in the field of communication. Regarding the 50th Anniversary, a special commemorative cover and stamp was issued. The scholarly publications Sannivedana and the 9th and 10th volumes of ‘Madhya Vimarshi were launched, and Prof. Shelton Gunaratne Memorial Scholarships were presented to the students who obtained higher marks studying for the honors degree. A tribute was also organised for the retired academic staff who have performed pioneering work for the department. Present at the occasion were Deans of the Faculties, Heads of the Departments, academic and non-academic staff, and undergraduates of the Department of Mass Communication.
