title: Tamil Schools Short of A/L Maths, Bio Teachers
author: Author not found
Content: Tamil medium schools in the Ratnapura District are facing a severe shortage of teachers, particularly in the Advanced Level Mathematics and Biology streams. According to recent reports, there should be 616 teachers in these schools, but the current number stands at only 455. This alarming shortage of teachers came to light during a District Coordinating Committee meeting chaired by MP Akila Ellawala, organised by District Secretary Wasantha Gunaratne. In 2022, despite 651 Tamil medium students appearing for the scholarship exam, only 27 of them managed to achieve the cutoff marks, a startling revelation made during the committee meeting. Chairman of the committee, MP Akila Ellawala, discussed potential solutions for primary schools through the Provincial Council. However, he stressed the need to make a written request to the Ministry of Education and the responsible minister to address the acute shortage of Advanced Level science and mathematics teachers in national schools. Chief Secretary of the Province Mahinda S. Weerasuriya proposed seeking special permission to recruit graduate teachers from the North and Eastern Provinces to alleviate the shortage of Advanced Level Tamil language teachers. He highlighted that while teachers were previously recruited from these regions, they were transferred back after five years, exacerbating the problem. In response to a question from MP Varuna Liyanage, the Provincial Assistant Director of Education reported that in 2022, only about 4.1% of the 651 Tamil medium students who took the scholarship examination managed to pass. Additionally, it was revealed that poverty among plantation workers has led to many children discontinuing their education after grades three, four, or five. As a humanitarian concern, it was suggested, during the meeting, to establish a committee to investigate and address this issue. BY K.A.S. Piyathilaka – Kuruvita

title: MEPA dodges RTI Commission again
author: Author not found
Content: In a concerning turn of events, the Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) dodged appearing before the Right to Information (RTI) Commission for the second time, when an appeal was taken up over the MEPA not providing its investigation report, on MV X-Press Pearl disaster, to the public. The report, which was completed by a 40-member expert committee and submitted by the country’s Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA), details the extent of the environmental impact of the blaze that occurred on the Singapore-flagged containership X-Press Pearl, while it was anchored off the coast of Colombo on 20 May 2021. It was reported that the report was later submitted to the President. This unsettling lack of cooperation spurred the filing of an appeal under the provisions of the RTI Act No. 12 of 2016, over the MEPA’s refusal to release the said report to Ceylon Today following an RTI request. Despite being notified to appear before the RTI Commission on 3 August, the MEPA failed to appear for the hearing. Consequently, the Commission sent a follow-up notice to the MEPA and the journalist who filed the RTI request via email and registered post, instructing them to appear before the commission on 5 October. These notices were issued by the commission Chairman, retired Supreme Court Judge Upali Abeyratne. During the hearing held yesterday (5), only the journalist was present, and representatives from the MEPA were notably absent. Subsequently, the RTI Commission attempted to contact the MEPA via phone and they expressed their willingness to participate in the sessions via Zoom, thus avoiding physical attendance. Considering the MEPA’s previous avoidance of two notices, the journalist raised concerns about granting another opportunity. Section 39(1) of the RTI Act No. 12 of 2016 allows for legal action to be taken against the MEPA before a Magistrate’s Court. Retired Judge Abeyratne announced that the final decision on the appeal would be delivered on 30 November and instructed commission officials to inform the MEPA of this decision. He also stated that, in the future, officials from the MEPA would not be given the option to participate via Zoom for appeals related to Colombo and nearby areas. Furthermore, he acknowledged certain shortcomings in the issuance of notices to the MEPA and emphasised the need to rectify these issues in the future. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Asia-Pacific Environment Forum concludes
author: Author not found
Content: Asia-Pacific Environment Forum concludes yesterday (5), at the Shangri-La Hotel, Colombo. In his address at the forum, Minister of Environment, Nazeer Ahmed noted the critical importance of multilateral partnerships in addressing the ongoing global climate crisis. Minister Ahmed referenced an analysis report by Oxfam, asserting that the current global financial system has proven inadequate, with G7 countries collectively owing low- and middle-income nations a staggering USD 13.3 trillion in unpaid aid and funding for climate action. He urged all attending nations to expedite the establishment of a Climate Justice Forum, akin to an OPEC for climate justice, for climate-vulnerable and developing states in the Global South. This proposal aligns with the vision previously put forward by President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the COP 27 summit last year. Minister Ahmed said, “The Climate Justice Forum (CJF), as the collective voice of climate-vulnerable nations, shall seek to rectify the unequal distribution of environmental burdens on vulnerable groups and economically disadvantaged populations and States, from landless farmers to all forms of disadvantaged communities.” Moreover, Minister Ahmed advocated for the establishment of a Biosphere Reserve Bank, a new 100% climate finance and green transition-focused Multilateral Development Bank (MDB) for the Global South. This MDB would serve as the institutional arm of the Climate Justice Forum, enhancing accountability in the pursuit of climate justice. President Ranil Wickremesinghe, delivering the keynote speech, echoed the call for nations to unite in addressing the current climate crisis. A multilateral meeting involving Sri Lanka, the Republic of Korea, Iran, Tuvalu, Nepal, Fiji, Bangladesh, Palau, Cook Islands, Samoa, and Japan was also held concurrently with the forum. Minister of Environment for Tuvalu, Ampelosa Tehulu, stressed the necessity for small island nations and other developing countries to present a unified voice when advocating for climate justice. She urged the countries, at the multilateral meeting, to prioritise efforts to find a solution to the worsening situation in Tuvalu, which faces imminent submergence due to rising sea levels caused by global warming. The Forum of Ministers and Environment Authorities of Asia-Pacific serves as a platform for governments and intergovernmental organisations to deliberate and prioritise environmental issues in the Asia-Pacific region. Its objective is to develop a comprehensive plan ahead of the sixth session of the UN Environment Assembly (UNEA-6), scheduled from 26 February to 1 March 2024 in Nairobi. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: President’s comments portray SL’s sovereignty – Jagoda
author: Author not found
Content: Former UNP MP Achala Jagoda claimed that the comments made by President Ranil Wickremesinghe during an interview with DW News in Germany unequivocally portray Sri Lanka’s sovereignty and courage before the rest of the world. During a media briefing at Sirikotha on Thursday (5), Jagoda emphasised that the President’s objections to the UNHRC resolution concerning Sri Lanka seemed reasonable to a certain section of the population. “Sri Lanka is fully capable of addressing every internal issue. Moreover, a report has been submitted to the authorities regarding the present state of children’s health and malnutrition. We possess such reports and have our own perspective on these matters. Many factions had been making baseless allegations that the Government was attempting to suppress the people by enacting oppressive laws. In reality, such laws are essential in tandem with technological advancements,” Jagoda said. The lack of proper awareness and education regarding the use of social media is a matter of concern. While allegations are being made, laws were enacted to protect the innocent and ensure the well-being of ordinary citizens, according to Jagoda. Jagoda also pointed out that European countries have included social media in their school curriculum, starting from the primary level and emphasised that the introduction of such programmes is very important for countries like Sri Lanka. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SLSMU celebtaes a century of service
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Station Master’s Union (SLSMU), is celebrating a historic milestone – 100 years of unwavering service and solidarity. Established in 1923 as the Ceylon Railway Station Masters Union, it later transformed into the Sri Lanka Station Master’s Union. To commemorate this significant centenary, the SLSMU has meticulously prepared arrangements for a grand celebration today (6).

title: Boy (14) killed while playing
author: Author not found
Content: A tragic incident occurred at the Pussellawa Hindu National School on Wednesday (4), resulting in the unfortunate demise of a 14-year-old student. According to the Police, the student sustained a head injury when he climbed onto a chair placed on a table, while playing with some fellow students. Tragically, he came into contact with an operating ceiling fan during this activity, leading to a severe injury. The student passed away while receiving treatments at the Gampola Hospital. The victim hailed from the Delta South Division in the Pupuressa. Preliminary investigations suggest that the incident occurred after a school event which concluded the previous afternoon.

title: Thousands of Train Commuters Stranded
author: Author not found
Content: A chaotic scene unfolded yesterday (4), leaving thousands of train passengers greatly inconvenienced as a private dispute between a security officer and a deputy railway guard at Maligawatte railway yard escalated into a flash strike by railway guards. The striking guards demanded the immediate termination of the said security officer’s service, plunging the railway system into turmoil. The strike originated from an altercation between a railway deputy guard and a sergeant attached to the security at Maligawatte yard, reportedly triggered by the deputy guard’s smoking inside the Chief Engineer’s Office, Dematagoda inside the railway yard. The argument escalated, resulting in injuries to both individuals, who were subsequently admitted to the Colombo National Hospital. The strike caused widespread disruptions to train services in Sri Lanka, with over 78 train journeys cancelled in a single evening.  Many train journeys were cancelled due to controllers not reporting for duty. Commuters were left stranded at railway platforms, leading to unrest among passengers, including schoolchildren and daily commuters. Due to the limited availability of train services, passengers resorted to unsafe means of transportation, further escalating the situation. Frustrated commuters confronted station masters, leading to the suspension of ticket issuance and station operations at various locations, including Dehiwala, Bambalapitiya, and Maradana. In response to these incidents, the Sri Lanka Railway Station Masters’ Union decided to withdraw station masters from their posts for safety reasons. They also requested Police and military presence at railway stations to ensure security. SSP Nihal Thalduwa confirmed that Police were deployed to protect railway stations and maintain order. While instances of altercations were reported, there were no reports of property damage or loss of life. Measures were taken to prevent possible clashes. Additional security was deployed at several key railway stations, including Colombo Fort, Maradana, and Kompannavidiya, with preparations in place for further intervention if necessary. The sudden strike action drew criticism from other railway unions, who viewed it as an abuse of power and strongly condemned the disruption caused to passengers. They called for an urgent investigation into the incident, emphasising the severity of paralysing the entire railway service over a personal dispute between two employees. General Manager of Railways, W.A.D.S. Gunasinghe expressed concern over the disruption of public transport due to the sudden strikes. Numerous attempts to contact the Minister of Media and Transport regarding the incident were futile. It is reported that the authorities are examining CCTV footage of the incident as part of the investigation.  By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: A/L exam to commence on 4 January 2024
author: Author not found
Content: The Commissioner General of Examinations announced yesterday (4) the revised dates for the G.C.E. Advanced Level examination 2023. According to a media release issued by Commissioner General H. J. M. Amith Jayasundara, the 2023 G.C.E. A/L exam is scheduled to begin on 4 January 2024 and will continue until 31 January 2024. Further, students who missed the application deadline for the 2023 Advanced Level examination due to delays in the previous exam session and the re-scrutiny of the 2022 G.C.E. Advanced Level exam session have been granted an opportunity to apply for the 2023 session. They can submit their applications from October 6 to October 10 through the online application portal athttps://onlineexams.gov.lk/onlineapps/ or via the official Department of Examinations website at www.doenets.lk.

title: FR Petitions to be heard on 6 May 2024
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (4) granted Leave to Proceed with two Fundamental Rights Petitions challenging former President Maithripala Sirisena’s decision to grant a Presidential Pardon to Bodu Bala Sena (BBS) General Secretary Ven. Galagoda Atte Gnanasara Thera. The petitions were granted Leave to Proceed under Article 12(1) of the Constitution, which relates to the right of equality. The Centre for Policy Alternative (CPA) and Sandhya Ekneligoda, spouse of missing journalist Prageeth Ekneligoda submitted the petitions. A three-judge Supreme Court Bench comprising Justices S. Thurairaja, Yasantha Kodagoda, and Arjuna Obeysekera scheduled the petitions to be heard on 6 May 2024. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Road development to resume only after DDR – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Resumption of stalled road development work can only be carried out if the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provides the USD 60 million pledged once the Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR) process is successful, Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena said. Gunawardene added that though a sum of Rs 13 billion had been set aside by the Treasury for road development work this year, thus far only Rs 1 billion had been received. Speaking further the Minister said development activities related to the districts would require the approval of the respective District Development Committees. He said instructions to this effect was given to all officers and said this measure is to overcome unnecessary issues which arise in this regard.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Independent body to oversee EPF,ETF
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe informed Parliament yesterday (4) that the Government was in the process of establishing a new independent body to oversee the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) and Employees’ Trust Fund (ETF). He expressed the Government’s willingness to engage in discussions with the Opposition and consider their proposals regarding this matter. President Wickremesinghe also said the need to deliberate on whether the EPF and ETF funds should be allowed for investments abroad, indicating the Government’s inclination to permit such investments while remaining open to discussions with the Opposition. Currently, the Central Bank administers the EPF, while the ETF falls under the purview of the Labour Department. In response to a question posed by SJB MP Eran Wickramaratne regarding the establishment of an independent public execution body, the President expressed the possibility of such a setup. He indicated that further discussions and implementation could take place occur if the Opposition supports the proposal. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Amaraweera instructs to supply chemical fertiliser for Maha
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera on 3 October instructed officials to facilitate the release of chemical fertiliser without any shortage for paddy and other requisite crops during the Maha Season. A meeting was held at the Agriculture Ministry to review fertiliser stocks presently in possession of the two State-owned fertiliser firms and with the private sector. Among those who attended the meeting were Secretary to the Ministry Gunadasa Samarasinghe, Chairman of the Lanka Fertiliser and Commercial Fertiliser firms Dr. Jagath Perera and Agrarian Commissioner General H. M. A. L. Abeyratne. During the meeting the Minister had looked into the stocks of urea fertiliser, TSP and MOP fertiliser presently in the country. It had been revealed that currently the private sector was in possession of 75,000 metric tons of urea fertiliser while the State had 21,000 metric tons. It has been revealed that the State has 29,000 metric tons of MOP fertiliser while the private sector has 15,000 metric tons of TSP fertiliser. It has then been decided to supply adequate stocks of TSP fertiliser via the private sector. Accordingly Amaraweera advised officials to distribute stocks of both chemical and carbon fertiliser sans any shortage to farmers for paddy and relevant crops during the Maha Season. He had also instructed them to ensure that the price of fertiliser does not increase any further as the private sector has assured him that they were willing to supply fertiliser at the price the two State-owned fertiliser firms provides fertiliser to the farmers. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: No plans to recruit foreign doctors – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has no intention to recruit foreign doctors to address the current shortage of medical professionals in State hospitals, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said yesterday (4). The Minister made this statement in Parliament responding to a question raised by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa regarding the Government’s plans on recruiting foreign doctors. Minister Rambukwella said there were only two options to address the scarcity of medical professionals: either expanding medical faculties or permitting the setting up of private medical faculties in Sri Lanka. He said approximately 3,000 medical students who graduated from foreign countries were currently unable to sit for the Act 16 examination in Sri Lanka. To address this issue, he suggested amending the Act to enable students who have qualified from the top 1,000 recognised medical faculties worldwide to sit the examination. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Gas price hiked
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas Lanka yesterday (4) increased the price of domestic Liquefied Petroleum (LP) gas. During a press conference held at the Litro Head Office in Colombo, Litro Chairman Muditha Peiris confirmed that the revised prices were coming into effect from midnight yesterday (4). Under the new pricing structure, the 12.5kg cylinder will see a hike of Rs 343, resulting in a new price of Rs 3,470. Similarly, the 5kg cylinder will experience a price increase of Rs 137, bringing the new price to Rs1,393. The 2.3kg cylinder will also see a rise of Rs 63, with the new price set at Rs 650. Meanwhile, Laugfs Gas PLC also announced a revision in the prices of domestic LP gas on the same day. Under the updated pricing structure by Laugfs Gas, the 12.5kg cylinder will see a Rs 150 increase, resulting in a new price of Rs 3,985. Similarly, the 5kg cylinder will experience a price increase of Rs 60, with the new price set at Rs 1,595. The 2kg cylinder will undergo a rise of Rs 24, making the new price at Rs. 638.

title: Only twelve MPs have declared assets – Harsha
author: Author not found
Content: Only twelve out of the 225 MPs have disclosed their assets and liabilities at present, Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Dr. Harsha de Silva revealed in Parliament yesterday (4). Dr. de Silva highlighted that disclosing assets and liabilities is also a condition set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He emphasised that as per one of the IMF’s sixteen recommendations, stipulated under anti-corruption legislation, senior officials including the President, Prime Minister, Ministers, and all MPs are required to make their asset declarations accessible to the public. He also noted that these declarations should be made available on a designated website by 24 July 2024. “This is only one condition. There are 16 conditions of the IMF just like this. Are these conditions wrong? You (the Government) will be able to get the second instalment of IMF somehow. What about the future? We have to do these for the country,” he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: 800,000 students to get vouchers to buy shoes – Edu Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said 800,000 students will receive vouchers worth Rs 3,000 each, within the next two to three weeks, to buy school shoes. The Minister added that this allowance, which is presently given to children with economic difficulties, will be further increased in the coming year. He said from 2024, the transformation in education will be implemented. Administrative changes will be initially approached and curriculum development will be given priority. In view of these new activities, the Minister said it was mandatory for students to come to school daily, stay in the classroom and engage in modular activities. He also said it is expected to minimise examinations in primary classes as much as possible, to streamline pre-childhood teaching, and to raise the quality of primary education by recruiting trained teachers as primary teachers. The Minister was speaking at a ceremony held at Ginthota Zahira College. Premajayantha said announcements have been issued to recruit 5,450 graduates for science, mathematics, English and technology and said 1,700 of them will be recruited to national schools for all three mediums. He said approval has been given to recruit to fill teacher vacancies that have arisen at provincial level due to retirement and leaving the country to minimise teacher shortage in the country. Also, based on the new administrative structure and the cluster school concept, the Minister pointed out that if any shortage of teachers arise it will be possible to manage it by balancing teachers within the school clusters. Premajayantha recalled the restoration and maintenance of school discipline, also said by next year, the digitisation process of about 3,000 schools with A-level subject streams will be completed. He said from next year, more money will be allocated for essential construction work in schools and it will then be possible to complete the construction work of half-completed school buildings and carry out essential constructions such as new laboratories.

title: Rehabilitative process for children accused of offences recommended
author: Author not found
Content: In a step to ensuring the safety and well-being of children in Sri Lanka, the Committee appointed to Study and Make Recommendations for the Protection of Children has presented its exhaustive report to President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The handover ceremony took place at the Presidential Secretariat on Tuesday (3), the President’s Media Division (PMD) said yesterday (4). Established on 19 April 2023, under President Wickremesinghe’s instructions, the committee had a vital mission to investigate and offer recommendations for the protection, care, and overall welfare of children who have experienced various forms of violence within Sri Lanka. Over nearly five months, the committee diligently conducted 21 meetings to comprehensively understand existing issues and formulate practical solutions. The committee was composed of diverse members, representing institutions such as Children Homes, Remand Homes, Certified Homes, Child Development Centres, legal experts, business associations, education authorities, and more. The report, submitted to the President, addresses a broad spectrum of child protection issues, including those related to institutionalised environments, parental care deficiencies, family separation, digital media exposure, child labor, and more. It assesses the adequacy of existing institutional, administrative, and legal safeguards, aiming to adapt to modern society’s needs. Moreover, the report explores strategies to improve the physical and mental health of children who have faced violence, abuse, and neglect. It also delves into the troubling trend of children engaging in violent acts and suggests innovative community-based approaches to child care. The committee has carefully considered measures to reduce the institutionalisation of children, promote family-based care alternatives, and outline a ‘restorative rehabilitative process’ for children facing accusations of various offences. The report also contains recommendations for the successful reintegration of children from care institutions into society, with a focus on life skills development and individual care plans. The report encompasses short, medium, and long-term policy recommendations to prevent and mitigate factors exposing children to violence, address the consequences faced by such children, and strengthen reporting, management, and response mechanisms. The committee chaired by Attorney-at-Law. A K Weeratunge and comprising dedicated experts from various fields, has taken a significant step to enhance the well-being and safety of children in Sri Lanka.

title: PM urges ADB to initiate renewable energy, digitalisation projects
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, while thanking the Asian Development Bank for the assistance provided to agriculture, rural small and medium sectors and other development projects, urged the regional funding agency to initiate new projects in areas such as renewable energy, digitalisation, and public transport systems, especially the railways. He said this when ADB Country Director Takafumi Kadono called on him at the Prime Minister’s Office in Colombo on Tuesday (3). The Prime Minister thanked the ADB for extending support to Sri Lanka for economic stabilisation following the unprecedented economic crisis. Kadono briefed the Prime Minister about the ADB’s mid-term and long-term projects for economic progress and infrastructure development. The ongoing projects cover areas such as strengthening public financial management and governance, fostering private sector development and improving access to public services and deepening inclusion, social protection, equitable access, health, climate and agriculture modernisation. He said ADB Governing Board Members will arrive in Sri Lanka to study the progress of projects and to inquire about future projects, for which the Prime Minister’s proposals could be considered. Secretary to the Prime Minister Anura Dissanayake and ADB Deputy Country Director Utsav Kumar were also in attendance.

title: SLIC Offers Rs 1M Free Life Cover to Parents of Children Born on World Children’s Day 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Insurance commemorated World Children’s Day by providing a Free Life Insurance cover worth Rs. 1 million for the parents of every child born on 1 October 2023. The programme covered all hospitals islandwide. This special Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiative was launched in 2022 to protect the future of the children of the country. Realising the value this initiative has added to the community, SLIC decided to continue this initiative for the year 2023 as well. As the national insurer and a responsible corporate citizen of the country, Sri Lanka Insurance has initiated many projects to uplift the communities they operate in. SLIC’s CSR strategy focuses on three main pillars, that is Child Education, Community Development and Preserving Culture for future generations that contribute to the socioeconomic sustainability of the country. Commenting on this initiative, CEO of Sri Lanka Insurance, Chandana L. Aluthgama said, “As a responsible organisation, our commitment towards the well-being of children goes beyond just financial protection. With the present challenging economic conditions demanding a safety net for everyone, we believe that Insurance for all is mandatory. As a result, we initiated this special project to provide a free life cover for children born on World Children’s Day 2023. Further, we have introduced many insurance solutions such as the ‘Minimuthu’ product range and the ‘School Fee Protector’ education plan to ensure uninterrupted education for our children. Our efforts as an organisation is not only insuring the lives of our children but also nurturing their dreams and protecting their aspirations today and always.” President’s Counsel Ronald C. Perera, Chairman of Sri Lanka Insurance said, “Children are the future of the country and to ensure a secure future for them is the responsibility of every citizen of the country. Therefore, as a responsible corporate citizen, SLIC has come forward to offer a free life cover to the parents of all children in Sri Lanka who are born on World Children’s Day to secure their future.” A special event was organised to mark this initiative at Castle Street Hospital on 1 October in the presence of the Corporate Management of SLIC.

title: President won’t comply with all IMF demands – Namal
author: Author not found
Content: MP Namal Rajapaksa said President Ranil Wickremesinghe had informed the international community that he wouldn’t comply with all of the IMF’s demands. He was responding to a question from the media regarding the ongoing dialogue between the Sri Lankan Government and the IMF. MP Rajapaksa added that the Government plans to persist with raising taxes and place the burden on the public under the pretext of adhering to the IMF’s directives. He also questioned whether the public is happy with the price hikes, especially since they ousted former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, blaming him for not seeking IMF assistance sooner. Rajapaksa further claimed that his party has proposals to strengthen the rural financial system and emphasised that the present economic crisis cannot be resolved solely through taxation. When queried whether the public should trust the IMF, the MP suggested that they should place their trust in the Sri Lankan model, viewing the IMF as a supplemental aid rather than the sole solution for the crisis. However, he failed to elaborate on what exactly the “Sri Lankan model” entails. He also said President Wickremesinghe was appointed thanks to the ‘Aragalaya’ movement last year. MP Namal Rajapaksa further asserted that if Gotabaya Rajapaksa were still the President, there would not have been increases in gas prices, fuel prices, electricity prices, or taxes. He argued that if the ‘Aragalaya’ movement had not toppled the Gotabaya Rajapaksa regime, the economic situation would have improved through an organic and national mechanism. By Buwanaka S. Perera
