title: TID ordered to give comprehensive report
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Pasan Amarasena issued an order yesterday (4) instructing the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID) to promptly provide a comprehensive report to Court regarding the alleged plot to carry out bombings in various locations in Colombo. The Magistrate issued this directive after reviewing the information presented by the TID in Court on the same day. They were investigating reports suggesting a plan to execute such a bombing raid in Colombo. It was also disclosed in Court that details pertaining to the attack were found written on a piece of paper discarded by a prisoner who was being transported in the prison bus. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Iranian Vice President proposes bilateral collaboration
author: Author not found
Content: Iranian Vice President Ali Salajegheh proposed to Sri Lanka, yesterday (4), a collaboration between the two nations to enhance conservation efforts of mangrove forests and invited Sri Lankan students to pursue studies in Iranian universities to support these efforts. He said this during a bilateral meeting with Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed at the Shangri-La Hotel, yesterday. This meeting was part of the Fifth Forum of Ministers and Environment Authorities of Asia Pacific 2023 (5th AP Forum), which was hosted in Colombo from 3-6 October. The meeting began with formalities and recognition of longstanding diplomatic ties between the two countries. Salajegheh emphasised Iran’s challenges in dealing with the present climate crisis. He highlighted issues such as the increasing occurrence of dust storms, rising sea levels, and seawater contamination of freshwater sources in Southern Iran. These challenges have had significant adverse effects on both the Iranian population and its mangrove forests. Notably, both Sri Lanka and Iran boast substantial mangrove forest cover. In light of this, the Iranian Vice President proposed collaboration between the two nations to enhance their conservation efforts. He also extended an invitation to Sri Lankan students to pursue studies in Iranian universities to support these efforts. Vice President Salajegheh expressed gratitude for the sanctions imposed on Iran by certain “developed countries,” as they have compelled Iran to seek innovative solutions to its environmental issues. He assured continued support and technology sharing to strengthen Sri Lanka’s safety and security. In response, Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed expressed appreciation for Iran’s continuous support, particularly during Sri Lanka’s conflict with the LTTE. Regarding the climate crisis, Minister Ahamed noted that though Sri Lanka, as a small island nation, has made a limited contribution to the issue, developed countries responsible for a significant portion of global emissions have not provided adequate support to mitigate the problems arising from their actions. He mentioned that President Ranil Wickremesinghe had called for the creation of a Climate Justice Forum at COP27 to hold developed nations accountable for their role in the crisis. Minister Ahamed acknowledged Iran’s resilience in the face of sanctions and expressed the Sri Lankan Government’s interest in sending officials to Iran for training and knowledge-sharing on more effective climate change mitigation strategies. In a gesture of further cooperation, Vice President Salajegheh extended an invitation to Minister Naseer Ahamed to visit Iran, to strengthen collaboration between the two nations in conservation efforts and addressing the climate crisis. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Parent company disclaims manufacture
author: Author not found
Content: In a surprise turn of events, the company based in India, which was purportedly involved in the production of the controversial Human Immunoglobulin IV 5g vial, has denied any association with the product, and informed the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) that they did not manufacture these vials,  NMRA Chairman Prof. S.B. Jayaratne said. It has now come to light that documentation with regard to registering the product at the NMRA was forged as well. With this unexpected twist, now the authorities suspect that a local pharmaceutical company has been behind this fraudulent scheme. Prof. Jayaratne issuing a statement to the media on the turn of events following the locally-based pharmaceutical company’s allegedly importinga stock of quality failed Immunoglobulin with forged documents prepared for customs clearance. He said the NMRA had received complaints regarding anaphylactic reactions to the said drug on 16, 20 and 22 September 2023 from District Hospital Matale and National Hospital Colombo respectively. He said investigations into the drug had shown that neither was it registered nor had the IV5g vial been afforded the Waiver of Registration (WoR). It was established that no written documentation regarding the particular item was available with the NMRA. The NMRA Chairman alleged that instead forged documents using the NMRA’s letterhead had been used to obtain Customs clearance. Also, it was noted that even the official seal of the NMRA’s CEO which had been used was fake. Measures had been taken to suspend the use of the drug stocks by 21 September 2023 while by Tuesday (3) the NMRA had also lodged an official complaint with the Criminal Investigations Department against the company, he said adding that even the Indian- based manufacturer had disowned the Immoglobulin. Meanwhile President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Chamal Sanjeeva said  nowthe NMRA had accepted that the Immoglobulin in question had been brought to Sri Lanka violating standard procedure. Also adding insult to injury,the parent company had disclaimed manufacturing the drug. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: GMOA meets former President Sirisena
author: Author not found
Content: The Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) met former President Maithripala Sirisena to create awareness regarding the present issues facing the State health service. GMOA Secretary Dr. Haritha Aluthge said an adjournment debate had been scheduled for tomorrow (6) in Parliament on a request made by the Opposition based on the present brain drain and its impact on the country’s economy. He said the former President had pledged to discuss the issue according to the time allocated to him. He noted that the Opposition would utilise the information which had been given by his outfit on the issue. Dr. Aluthge said discussions should also be held with the President and the authorities to work towards retaining medical practitioners in the country. “The former President is quite aware of the value of doctors while medical professionals too had been able to maintain cordial dealings with him during his tenure as a former Minister of Health,” the GMOA Secretary added. Sirisena told the media that it was essential to resolve the present shortage of medical professionals in the State health service. A large number of State hospitals in rural areas were being closed as a result. “There is information that at least 20 to 25 rural hospitals had been closed due to the shortage of doctors. Some hospitals do not have VOGs or cardiac surgeons,” he lamented. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Inclement weather to continue
author: Author not found
Content: As the inclement weather conditions are still active over the most parts of the country, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has issued level two amber – watch and level one yellow – watch early warning alerts to 39 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions in seven districts across the country. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Senior Scientist of Landslide Early Warning Centre (LSEWC) of NBRO Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera said Galle, Hambantota Kalutara, Kegalle, Matara, Ratnapura and Colombo districts were issued warning alertss. Dr. Senadeera said level two – amber watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Neluwa DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Galle District, Ingiriya DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Ruwanwella and Deraniyagala DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Kotapola and Pitabeddara DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matara District and Nivithigala, Eheliyagoda, Kalawana, Kuruwita, Pelmadulla, Kiriella, Ratnapura, Elapatha and Ayagama DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the  Ratnapura District. Meanwhile, level one yellow – watch early landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Seethawaka DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Colombo District, Elpitiya DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Galle District, Walasmulla DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Hambantota District, Matugama, Bulathsinhala, Agalawatta and Walallawita DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Yatiyantota, Kegalle and Dehiowita DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Kirinda, Puhulwela, Weligama, Matara, Akuressa, Welipitiya, Hakmana, Athuraliya and Mulatiyana DS  divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matara District and Imbulpe, Opanayake, Kahawatte, Kolonna and Godakawela DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, according to Dr. Senadeera. The LSEWC has advised people living in the landslide prone areas in the central hill country where heavy rains occur to exercise caution and to be prepared to move to safe places after informing the relevant authorities authorities if they notice any landslide signs, Dr. Senadeera added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: MCPA lambasts Health Minister over statements made in Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) accused  Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella of misleading Parliament on allegedly false information provided by pharmaceutical companies. The Health Minister should submit to Parliament the information certified by his Ministry Secretary or the Director General Health Services (DGHS) and not the false information given by pharmaceutical companies, Dr. Sanjeeva observed yesterday 4. Information provided by the data system of the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) and the letter issued by the Chairman of the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC) show that there was a sufficient stock of the antibiotic Meropenem. He urged the Health Minister to make representations certified by the Health Secretary or the DGHS instead of misleading Parliament and the public. It is a grave misfortune for the people of this country if the Health Minister and his Ministry were more interested in protecting private pharmaceutical companies rather than the free health service, he lamented. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Navy apprehends seven for illegal fishing
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy apprehended seven persons for engaging in illegal fishing, during separate operations conducted off Norway Island, Trincomalee and in Erakkandi on 2 October.  A dinghy, lorry and unauthorized fishing gear were seized in the operarion.  The Navy carries out regular operations in the coastal and sea areas around the island to prevent illegal fishing practices which threaten the sustainability of fish stock.  SLNS Parakumba in the Eastern Naval Command carried out a search operation on the night of 2 October off Norway Island and apprehended the six persons for fishing with unauthorised nets.  Meanwhile, SLNS Vijayaba belonging to the same Naval Command apprehended a suspect  when a search operation was carried out in the Erakkandi area on  2 October .The suspect had 105 kg of fish caught using explosives and was being transported by lorry.  The suspects are residents of Wellemnal, Kinniya and Erakkandi areas and were between 23 to 47 years. The suspects together with the fishing gear were then handed over to the Muthur Fisheries Inspector while the suspect  held in Erakkandi raid was handed over to the Trincomalee Fisheries Inspector.

title: USD 56B stashed overseas by exporters – Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Making a shocking revelation in Parliament, Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe yesterday (3) said exporters have stashed a total of USD 56 billion abroad over the past few years, with an additional nine billion USD being parked overseas, as revealed by Pandora Papers. He made these revelations referring the Global Financial Integrity Report. Rajapakshe proposed a special motion to compel these individuals to repatriate their offshore funds, alleging that some secretaries of MPs have hidden more than USD 150 million each abroad, according to some reports. “If these funds are brought back, it could potentially be used to settle Sri Lanka’s debts to other nations,” he said. Meanwhile, the Minister levelled severe criticism at the Constitutional Council (CC), headed by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, for not nominating members for the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC). “The newly enacted Anti-Corruption Act mandates the CC to send its nominees to the President for the Bribery Commission. There is a discrepancy in the legislation, where the term ‘Constitutional Board’ appears instead of ‘Constitutional Council’ in some sections. But the correct terminology is used in the section governing the appointment of Bribery Commission members. This inaction of the CC is a big problem and I would ask public opinion on this. Is the CC asleep? Is that why it has failed to nominate the new members to the Bribery Commission?” he queried. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Do you think we are second class?’
author: Author not found
Content: A one-on-one Deutsche Welle (DW) interview with President Ranil Wickremesinghe, conducted by Martin Gak of the German State-owned international broadcasting station, Deutsche Welle, unexpectedly turned into a heated debate, with President Wickremesinghe criticising the German DW interviewer. Gak said, “One of the biggest stories was the Channel 4 report on the Easter Sunday attacks and the revelation on the ‘presumed collusion’ of members of the State with the terrorist group, which is one of the worst events in the Easter bombing.” The President responded saying, “Why do you treat Channel 4 as sacred?” Gak responded, “I don’t, actually I don’t,” and the President interrupted saying that lots of people in Britain don’t take Channel 4 seriously. Gak then said, “Do you flatly deny Channel 4?” and the President interrupted, “No no, why are you only asking about Channel 4” to which Gak said, “I am not asking about Channel 4 but I am asking if these are concrete accusations.” The President responded, “Just because a media makes an accusation, why should I?” The President added, “The former Attorney General has made an accusation, a former DIG has made accusations, why are you asking only about that. Ask me about all of that.” Gak then said, “It is not only Channel 4 but the Catholic church as well that is asking for an investigation and about the former President under whom you served.  The President then said, “I am asking you. You did not ask me that at first and it was when I pressed you, that you asked me about the former President asking for an investigation. You came with the Channel 4 report as gospel truth.” The President then clarified that firstly, he had appointed a committee headed by a judge, and comprising the former Commander of the Air Force and a renowned lawyer. When the President wanted to explain the second part of it, Gak said, “Nobody would believe that these commissions have teeth enough to do anything” and the President responded, “That is your view and not mine.”  Gak said the Cardinal wanted an investigation and the President quipped, “I am dealing with the Bishops’ Conference and not with the Cardinal. And the Bishops Conference wanted all the proceedings of the Commission and I gave it. I gave the final report to the Bishop’s Conference.” Gak said they are looking for an independent investigation. The President then said, “I deal with the Bishops’ Conference and they come to meet me and not you. You sit here with a piece of paper. I talked to the Bishops’ Conference and I will talk to them after I return. I have nothing. I am not involved in anything and I want to resolve it and you take a piece of paper about the Cardinal. Have you spoken to the Bishops’ Conference?” Gak replied in the negative. “Then you don’t have the right to ask me this question,” the President said. Gak said he was posting questions in the public interest to which President Wickremesinghe said, “I am in the public interest asking you, who are you?” The President said, “You did not come to question me but to corner me that the Government is not doing anything. You take this western attitude out. You are doing it.” Gak said several people have requested internationally aided independent investigations on the Easter bombings. The President said, “The Sri Lankan Government does not have international inquiries, full stop. The FBI report said no outsiders were involved,” noted the President. Gak queried, “Do you realise that this makes you look like paying lip service to reconciliation.” The President then said, “If the FBI, UK, Australia, India and Chinese secret service have given their reports then what are you saying? What I can say is you are talking nonsense.” Gak responding said, “You can answer whatever way you want but let me ask the questions.” The President retorted, “I am telling you, don’t come and accuse me. Look, I have been in this game long before you. I think that the western media thinks that we are bad. We are not going to have any international inquiries on any issues. The UK hasn’t got. Germany hasn’t got. Why should we poor Sri Lankans and Asians need to have?  You think we are second class?” Gak said, “I don’t but because you have a history of commissions from 2008 at least,” and the President said “If you think we are a third grade country you have got it wrong.” Gak asked about the Save the Children report on hunger in the country and the President immediately responded saying he had read that report. “I am not saying I did not. We may not agree on the figures but there is hunger and I am not saying no to it.” The President said, “To only to accuse us on hunger is not right,” but Gak interrupted saying “There is a difference in times that the State has to solve its problem and the time that a parent needs to feed a child. Do you agree?” President Wickremesinghe responding said, “Can you fulfil that in one when the economy collapses and in not even a year now, that hunger and poverty is down.” The President said, “It is a transition period. We did not say there is no hunger. We say there is hunger and that is why I took over the presidency to finish off the hunger.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Online Safety Bill presented in Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles yesterday (3) presented the Online Safety Bill in Parliament. The Online Safety Bill is to establish the Online Safety Commission; to make provisions to prohibit online communication of certain statements of fact in Sri Lanka and to prevent the use of online accounts and unauthentic online accounts for prohibited purposes, and other related matters. Subject to the provisions of Section 6, the Commission shall consist of five members appointed by the President and the term of office of a member of the Commission shall be three years from the date of appointment. Following Minister Alles presenting the Bill, Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella said the Opposition was against the Bill, claiming that it would lead to Sri Lanka being criticised in international arena. Minister Alles responding said, “This Bill was introduced for the first time in 2016 when you (then government) were in power. We are presenting it today with minor amendments.” At this juncture, Prof G.L. Peiris said the Bill was included in the Order Paper on 27 September. According to the Constitution, the public can challenge a Bill within 14 days since it is published in the Order Paper. But after 27 September, there was a long weekend of four days. As a result, the public only had seven working days to go to Court. I will also go to the Supreme Court. I’m not pointing fingers at anyone here. This is not fair.” Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe intervened and said, “When you (Prof. G.L. Peiris) were the main legal adviser to former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, you brought the 20th Amendment reducing the time public could raise concerns to just seven days. You even approved it. The final decision will be given by the Supreme Court.” Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse then told the House that the 14-day-time-frame would be calculated from yesterday (3). BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: SLFP not inclined to merge with SLPP– Sirisena
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Chairman, former President Maithripala Sirisena yesterday (3) asserted that the SLFP has no intention of merging politically with the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) and it is not possible at the moment. During a media briefing at SLFP Headquarters, Sirisena said, “To be honest, the majority of people in the country are against the government. This is clear from the people’s reactions towards the government.” He added that the unbearable cost of living has left the people of this country disenchanted with the government. He claimed that they (SLFP) are in the Opposition in Parliament and have their own political paths, similar to what the government has. There is no need to associate with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, as their policies are entirely different, he claimed. “Each political party has its own unique policies and agendas that may not align with each other. We have different political ideologies and it is not feasible for us to go on the same path. However, we do not hold any personal animosity towards any other political party or their representatives. Our differences are purely based on our political ideologies,” Sirisena said. “As SLFP members, in accordance with our party’s general policies and objectives, we are ready to work for the country while putting aside our personal political policies and agendas in order to form alliances. The SLFP has formed numerous alliances and collaborated with other political parties, prioritising the advancement of the country over our party’s individual policies,” he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Namal thanks Nishantha but insists he did not receive bill
author: Author not found
Content: After State Minister Sanath Nishantha settled SLPP MP Namal Rajapaksa’s controversial ‘electricity bill’ of Rs 2.6 million on Monday (2), the latter said he is thankful to MP Nishantha for settling the bill, but insisted that neither he nor his father (former PM Mahinda Rajapaksa) had received any such bill from the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to date. Responding to a query raised by the media, Rajapaksa said, neither he nor his father had received any electricity bill. According to Rajapaksa, the bill that was paid by Nishantha, had been forwarded to the President’s Security Division (PSD). “This is now becoming a scandal. However, that chapter is now closed,” said Rajapaksa who further stated that the people who are trying to slander his and his family name can finally rest, given that the bill is finally settled and they should invest their time to find a new topic to talk about. The CEB, in response to a Right to Information (RTI) request of former JVP Provincial Councillor Nalin Hewage, recently revealed that an outstanding electricity bill of Rs 2,682,246.57 was due for the Weeraketiya house, relating to the provision of security lights and generators for an event that took place between 12 and 15 September 2019. The CEB said they had installed security lights and generators for the mentioned function at the Weeraketiya house, on being informed that former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa was to attend a function on the said dates. The CEB further said, despite providing the services and incurring the electricity charges of Rs 2,682,246.57, the payment had not been settled even after four years, although multiple requests had been made for it to be settled. After the CEB’s response to Hewage’s RTI request went viral on social media, Namal Rajapaksa took action and sent a letter to the CEB. In the letter, he requested detailed information regarding the unpaid bill. Specifically, he asked for the recipient’s name to whom the bill was issued, the amount of the bill, the date when the bill was issued and the address to which the bill was sent. BY Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Hema Premadasa asks for mosquito coils from President’s Office – Aluthgamage
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage yesterday (3) alleged that former First Lady Hema Premadasa, mother of Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa has submitted a letter to the Presidential Secretariat, requesting various items, including mosquito coils. Speaking in Parliament, Aluthgamage claimed that he would urge Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa to provide a pack of mosquito coils to his mother before discussing the country’s development. Aluthgamage alleged that Hema Premadasa sent a letter to the Accountant at the President’s Office on 20 September 2023, requesting mosquito coils, two blue pens, bottles of glue, half sheets, and file covers. Aluthgamage said he would table the letter. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Govt informs IMF it cannot accede to tax increases
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has informed the International Monetary Fund (IMF) that it cannot raise tax percentages as per the IMF’s request, revealed Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. Addressing Parliament yesterday (3), Rajapakshe said discussions would be initiated to ask the IMF to reconsider this request. He explained to Parliament that the IMF had advised the Government to increase tax revenue to a certain extent by the end of the first quarter of the following year. Rajapakshe emphasised that increasing tax revenue would necessitate raising tax percentages, but the Government has expressed its concern about imposing additional tax burdens on the people at this time. In response to a question raised by Opposition MPs regarding the delay in the IMF’s second tranche, the Minister said it is not a matter of failing to meet IMF conditions but rather a matter of the Government’s reluctance to further tax the population. The Minister further disclosed that the forthcoming discussions with the IMF will focus on appealing for a reconsideration of their request to increase tax revenue. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Edmund’s Newspaper Revolution’ launched
author: Author not found
Content: The publication titled ‘Edmund’s Newspaper Revolution’, a compilation of Edmund Ranasinghe’s seven decades of dedicated media work, was launched yesterday (3). The event held in honour of a distinguished figure in Sri Lankan journalism, Edmund Ranasinghe, the founding Editor and Editorial Director of the Divaina, newspaper, marked the inauguration of a programme initiated by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to pay tribute to senior journalists, who have made significant contributions to the field of journalism in the country. The event was compered by the Chairman of the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute, Senior Journalist Saman Athaudahetti. Addressing the event, President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that all media outlets, including social media, should engage in a discussion regarding whether to enter into international agreements or adhere to the country’s legal framework. This book was authored by Presidential Senior Adviser Prof. Sunanda Madduma Bandara and edited by Presidential Media Director W.M.K. Wijebandara and Deputy Media Director Deepti Adhikari. The event saw the presence of notable figures, including Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena, State Minister of Mass Media Shanta Bandara, MP Premanath C. Dolowatta, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayaka, President’s Senior Adviser on Climate Change Ruwan Wijewardena, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Secretary of the Ministry of Mass Media Anusha Palpita, Government Information Director General Dinith Chinthaka Karunaratne and distinguished senior journalists, along with a multitude of journalists who gathered to mark this occasion.

title: Nearly 70% unskilled political appointees in NWSDB – Jeevan
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) currently employs an unusually high number of political appointees, resulting in approximately 70 per cent of unskilled workforce within the Ministry, Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development, Jeevan Thondaman disclosed yesterday (3). Addressing Parliament, the Minister said the NWSDB faces understaffing in certain areas while dealing with overstaffing in others. “There is a need to address the excessive political appointments in the ministry. Around 70 per cent of the labour force in the ministry lack the requisite skills and this has caused a staffing imbalance within the NWSDB,” he said. These revelations were in response to a question about the ministry’s ability to hire labourers directly for pipe installations, a concern raised due to issues faced by labourers regarding their wages when employed through contractors. Thondaman said granting permanent appointments in such a context is not feasible, considering the ministry’s current financial commitments. Before the recent water tariff hike, the ministry faced its first-rate increase in a decade. There is a significant monthly expense related to electricity and loan repayments, he pointed out. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: COPF instructs Audit Dept to calculate wheat flour availability
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), Dr. Harsha de Silva, instructed the Auditor General’s Department to calculate the quantity of wheat flour currently available in Sri Lanka’s warehouses and submit an audit report pertaining to wheat flour within two months. The Parliamentarian was of the view that if there is a pricing formula for wheat flour too, it will leave no room for individual parties to decide on the prices according to their wishes. This was discussed when the Committee on Public Finance met recently under the Chairmanship of Dr. de Silva. The Members of the Committee pointed out that wheat flour is being sold at different prices in shops all over Sri Lanka. However, according to the prices given by the Ministry of Finance, one kilo of wheat flour can be sold at Rs 198. The Chair emphasised that two price calculations are being used in setting the price of wheat flour and this should be changed. Although the price has increased due to the increase in the tax imposed on wheat flour, the Chair told the officials that the increased tax has increased the price of the wheat flour that was already in the warehouses of the country. Recalling the efforts made to prepare a price formula for gas and milk powder last season, the chairman pointed out the dire need of a price formula for regulating the price of wheat. The Committee emphasised that a price formula should be prepared immediately in order to work in a more diversified manner. Furthermore, under the Singapore-Sri Lanka Free Trade Agreement, the Committee on Public Finance approved the reduction of taxes on many other goods. It was approved when the Resolution under the Customs Ordinance, published in the Gazette Extraordinary No. 2338/54, was discussed on 30 June. Under that, it was proposed to reduce the tax rate which was 15% to five per cent. Granting approval for that, the Committee questioned the officials regarding the benefits of this trade agreement. However, the officials responding, stated that it was not possible to conduct a feasibility study. Expressing his displeasure, the Chair instructed the chief officer in charge of the Singapore-SriLanka Free Trade Agreement to submit a report to the Committee within six weeks, presenting logical facts about the agreement. Resolutions under the Customs Ordinance, published in the Gazette Extraordinary No. 2336/72 on 16 June 2023 were further reviewed for a second time. However, the Committee decided not to approve the proposal made through this Gazette. Here, the officials presented a proposal to change the HS code related to the import of raw materials required for soap production. The Committee questioned whether there will be an increase in tax rates on the import of the relevant raw materials. Accordingly, the Chair pointed out that it is questionable that one group of the government requests for approval to reduce tax and another group requests increased taxes. In the year 2021, it was revealed to the Committee that no new investment had been made during that period, even though the tax charges had been reduced in the import of raw materials required for soap production. Accordingly, Dr. de Silva instructed the concerned officials to conduct discussions, under the leadership of the Secretary to the Ministry of Finance and formulate a policy on tax revision and submit it to the COPF.

title: WHO recommends new vaccine to prevent malaria in children
author: Author not found
Content: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has recommended a new vaccine, R21/Matrix-M, to prevent malaria in children. The recommendation follows advice from the WHO: Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunisation (SAGE) and the Malaria Policy Advisory Group (MPAG) and has been endorsed by the Director-General of the WHO following its regular biannual meeting held from 25-29 September. The R21 vaccine is the second malaria vaccine recommended by the WHO following the RTS, S/AS01 vaccine, which received a WHO recommendation in 2021. Both vaccines are shown to be safe and effective in preventing malaria in children and when implemented broadly, are expected to have high public health impact. Malaria, a mosquito-borne disease, places a particularly high burden on children in the African Region, where nearly half a million children die from the disease each year. Demand for malaria vaccines is unprecedented; however, available supply of RTS, S is limited.  The addition of R21 to the list of WHO-recommended malaria vaccines is expected to result in sufficient vaccine supply to benefit all children living in areas where malaria is a public health risk.  The updated WHO malaria vaccine recommendation is informed by evidence from an ongoing R21 vaccine clinical trial and other studies, which showed: High efficacy when given just before the high transmission season: In areas with highly seasonal malaria transmission (where malaria transmission is largely limited to four or five months per year), the R21 vaccine was shown to reduce symptomatic cases of malaria by 75% during the 12 months following a 3-dose series. A fourth dose given a year after the third maintained efficacy. This high efficacy is similar to the efficacy demonstrated when RTS,S is given seasonally.  Good efficacy when given in an age-based schedule:  The vaccine showed good efficacy (66%) during the 12 months following the first three doses. A fourth dose a year after the third maintained efficacy. High impact: Mathematical modelling estimates indicate the public health impact of the R21 vaccine is expected to be high in a wide range of malaria transmission settings, including low transmission settings. Similarity of R21 and RTS, S vaccines: The two WHO-recommended vaccines, R21 and RTS, S, have not been tested in a head-to-head trial. There is no evidence to date showing one vaccine performs better than the other. The choice of product to be used in a country should be based on programmatic characteristics, vaccine supply, and vaccine affordability Safety: The R21 vaccine was shown to be safe in clinical trials. As with other new vaccines, safety monitoring will continue. Next steps for the second recommended malaria vaccine, R21/Matrix-M, include completing the ongoing WHO prequalification which would enable international procurement of the vaccine for broader rollout. At least 28 countries in Africa plan to introduce a WHO-recommended malaria vaccine as part of their national immunisation programmes. Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance has approved providing technical and financial support to roll out malaria vaccines to 18 countries. The RTS, S vaccine will be rolled out in some African countries in early 2024, and the R21 malaria vaccine is expected to become available to countries mid-2024.  WHO also issued recommendations on the advice of SAGE for new vaccines for dengue and meningitis. Dengue poses a major public health burden in endemic countries will increase further both in terms of incidence and geographic expansion, due to climate change and urbanisation. The live-attenuated quadrivalent dengue vaccine developed by Takeda (TAK-003) has demonstrated efficacy against all four serotypes of the virus in baseline seropositive children (4-16 years) in endemic countries and against serotypes one and two in baseline seronegative children. SAGE recommended that the vaccine be considered for introduction in settings with high dengue disease burden and high transmission intensity to maximise the public health impact and minimise any potential risk in seronegative persons.  SAGE recommended that the vaccine be introduced to children aged six to 16 years of age. Within this age range, the vaccine should be introduced about 1-2 years prior to the age-specific peak incidence of dengue-related hospitalisations. The vaccine should be administered in two doses schedule with a three-month interval between doses. SAGE recommended that vaccine introduction should be accompanied by a well-designed communication strategy and community engagement.

title: MCPA wants probe into medicinal drug imports bypassing Customs
author: Author not found
Content: A probe should be initiated into how medicinal drugs, procured through tenders and emergency purchasing, reached Sri Lanka after evading the Customs, the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) said.    MCPA President Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (3) said there were serious concerns as to whether some of the pharmaceuticals, especially medicinal drugs that reached State hospitals, were contraband. Facts revealed by the MCPA regarding medicinal drugs of poor quality, resulting in patient deaths and child malnutrition, have now been confirmed. Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella has even pledged to blacklist a pharmaceutical company, which allegedly capitalised on the country’s economic crisis by using politicians and even some Health Ministry officials to conduct a medicinal drug racket, he alleged.  The MCPA Chairman urged the Health Minister to reveal the name of the particular pharmaceutical company to the public. He also cautioned health authorities to be vigilant as those blacklisted medicinal drug companies could recommence importation of pharmaceuticals under different company names as has been done in the past. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Cabinet nod for ‘Sri Lanka University of Education’ Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet has approved the initiation of a Bill aimed at setting up a new educational institution called the ‘Sri Lanka University of Education’. On 4 December 2019, Cabinet appointed an expert committee, led by Professor Gunapala Nanayakkara, to provide recommendations regarding the administrative and legal processes required to elevate the current National Colleges of Education to University status. This transformation aims to ensure that the entire teaching community in Sri Lanka attains graduate-level education. Subsequently, the expert committee proposed the elevation of 19 out of the existing 20 National Colleges of Education to the status of university campuses, and the creation of a new institution known as the ‘Sri Lanka University of Education’. In light of these recommendations, Cabinet has approved a proposal put forth by the Minister of Education for the formulation of a new Bill that will encompass the necessary legal provisions to establish the Sri Lanka University of Education.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  In the run-up to the United Nations Climate Change Conference, COP28 in UAE this year, The European Union (EU) Delegation to Sri Lanka and the Maldives has launched its ‘Let’s Go Green’ campaign, aiming to create awareness and advocate for responsible green behaviour around plastic, waste reduction and energy saving among citizens. The campaign will include a variety of workshops, competitions and activities mainly focused on school and undergraduates encouraging them to come up with their own solutions to existing issues around Sri Lanka’s environmental challenges. According to the EU Delegation, the ‘Let’s Go Green’campaign will also bring stakeholders from the private sector together, not only to raise awareness on the importance of adopting and integrating more comprehensive solutions to reduce industrial waste, but also to discuss and come up with innovative ideas encouraging more sustainable business practices. Carried out in the context of the European Green Deal policy initiatives by the EU, the EU in Sri Lanka and the Maldives have implemented multiple projects in both countries to support sustainable tourism, marine conservation and biodiversity protection to aid in green economic recovery of the two island nations. Launched on 1October, the EU delegation said the campaigns will continue until 10 November 2023, in time for the COP28 Summit which will also be held at the end of November in UAE. By Buwanaka S. Perera Popular

title: Education Department to recover cost of missing cool boxes
author: Author not found
Content: The Education Department has decided to obtain the value of two cool boxes, which went missing after being provided to  Central Province Education Department, from the then Education Director of the Central Province Thilak Ekanayake and M. B. Ekanayake, who had functioned as the Officer-in-Charge of Vehicles. This is following an inquiry conducted into the missing cool boxes, which were in two KDH vans, that had been provided to the Central Province Education Department upon being purchased by the Education Ministry. Following a probe and an audit, it had been revealed that the cool boxes had gone missing in the period from 2015 to 2020. At the time of the purchase of the vehicles the firm which had imported them had handed over the cool boxes as a propaganda exercise. The Education Ministry had launched an inquiry into the missing cool boxes from the vans. After the estimated costs of the cool boxes had been tabulated at Rs 58,500 it had been decided to charge two thirds of the costs from the Officer-in-charge of the Vehicles and the rest from the former Director of Education. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Ratnapriya attacks Sajith, Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: Director General of Trade Unions to the President, Saman Ratnapriya, made assertions on Monday (2) that certain ‘politically marginalised’ leaders, such as Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake are attempting to disrupt the ongoing economic progress by fabricating stories. The Opposition Leader, Ratnapriya claimed, often seemed indecisive and driven by his own agenda, described as ‘Aasai Bayai – Keen but reluctant’. Instances from his political history highlighted this tendency, including his hesitance to take charge when an opportunity arose over the post of President during Aragalaya and when the presidential post became vacant after President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s resignation. Ratnapriya alleged that both Premadasa and Dissanayake were misinterpreting the proposed Online Safety Bill to serve their political ambitions, making baseless statements in public and media and misleading the general public. Furthermore, Ratnapriya criticised Premadasa for using the IMF programme to gain political leverage, implying that his motivations were driven by a desire for power rather than genuine concern for the nation. Ratnapriya criticised Dissanayake over his inconsistent stance on IMF dealings, suggesting a lack of common sense in the latter’s approach. Ratnapriya also mentioned the government’s efforts to upgrade the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) with additional benefits, but criticised politically motivated trade union leaders like Wasantha Samarasinghe for impeding progress through legal action. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane meets German State Secretary Thomas Bagger
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary of Foreign Affairs Aruni Wijewardane met her counterpart, State Secretary Thomas Bagger of the Federal Foreign Office of Germany at the Federal Foreign Office in Berlin on 27 September 2023. Also present at the meeting were Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Germany Varuni Muthukumarana and senior officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  The meeting took place during an important point in Sri Lanka-German bilateral relations where the two countries are celebrating 70 years of diplomatic ties.  At the outset, State Secretary Bagger welcomed the meeting with Foreign Secretary Wijewardane and stressed that this meeting would pave the way for new avenues for future cooperation. Referring to the excellent relations that exist between Sri Lanka and Germany, Foreign Secretary Wijewardane appreciated the German assistance in enabling Sri Lankan businesses, particularly SMEs to gain better access to international markets. She stressed that Sri Lanka is looking for more prospects in the German market for healthcare workers and export of ICT services on a sustainable basis. The two sides also discussed furthering of vocational training education in Sri Lanka. Foreign Secretary Wijewardane expressed appreciation for Germany’s longstanding development cooperation partnership with Sri Lanka, and requested continuation of direct development aid, taking note of the present economic situation in the country. She also appreciated the assistance extended to Sri Lanka in diverse fields by German Foundations, including Frederick Naumann Foundation.

title: Protest draws results: Konwewa – Dembatawewa road to be renovated
author: Author not found
Content: The long-standing problem of the Konwewa road, which remained unresolved for a decade, is finally set to be addressed within a week, following a protest on 1 October. The protest took place at the heart of Konwewa town due to the lack of maintenance on approximately one kilometre of the Konwewa – Dembatawewa main road. Additionally, the ongoing issue of elephants wandering into the village added to the community’s frustrations. The main road serves more than 2,000 residents across 28 villages in Dembatawewa and Konwewa. Unfortunately, a roughly one-kilometre stretch near Yanoya has suffered severe deterioration due to a decade of neglect. During the rainy season, the road becomes inundated, halting all movement, forcing locals to use boats for transportation. In response to this problem, the people of the area and the local monks organised a protest. They demanded a permanent solution, emphasising that the authorities had been informed about this issue for ten years but had not taken any action. Protesters marched from Yanoya to Konwewa town, blocking several major roads in the area, including the Konwewa – Ganewalpola road, Konwewa – Kahatagasdigiliya main road, and Konwewa – Kekirawa Junction main road. They chanted slogans during the demonstration, which lasted for nearly three hours. The protest came to a close when Kahatagasdigiliya Divisional Secretary R. Senthil arrived and assured the protesters that a solution would be provided within a week. BY Gayan – Medawachchiya

title: USAID and SLTA launch social media influencer campaign to boost tourism
author: Author not found
Content: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) Indo Pacific Opportunity Project (IPOP) and Sri Lanka Tourism Alliance (SLTA) recently launched a social media Influencer campaign to support efforts to increase Sri Lanka’s tourist arrivals and boost the tourism industry. The campaign will be conducted by a team of 10 global influencers with followers from top tourism source markets, including: the UK, India, France, Germany, Poland, Scandinavia, Canada and the United States. The team will travel to many exotic locations around the country to showcase a range of sustainable niche tourism products and experiential cultural attractions that Sri Lanka has to offer to attract more visitors to the country. Tourism is critical to Sri Lanka’s economy as it exits the pandemic and deals with its internal economic crisis. Pre-pandemic tourism represented 12 per cent of the country’s GDP, generating USD 4.3 billion in revenue in 2018. Sri Lanka is currently experiencing an encouraging surge in tourist arrivals and on Tuesday 26th September, crossed the crucial landmark of One million tourists for the year 2023 – easily surpassing the total of 720,000 recorded for the whole of 2022. The landmark also coincided with the celebration of World Tourism Day on 27 September. “The increase in tourist arrivals this year in Sri Lanka is very encouraging,” said Chief Guest, Julie Chung, Ambassador of the United States to Sri Lanka, at the special launch event held on Monday 25th September at Cinnamon Grand Hotel.  The Ambassador added, “It shows that Sri Lanka is again ready to realise its full potential as a global tourist destination, following years of downturn due to the Covid pandemic and the economic crisis.  I am particularly pleased that USAID is engaged in this important sector and that we are supporting Sri Lanka’s return to economic stability.  With the United States having worked side-by-side with Sri Lanka for 75 years, this is what a strong partnership looks like.” Using social media influencer campaigns has become a popular strategy for brands and organisations globally to communicate their messages, products, or services to a broader and more engaged audience. USAID has successfully sponsored social media influencer campaigns in Georgia and, most recently, Nepal. Theses campaigns are especially useful to target specific markets (eg. UK, Germany, India, etc.) as well as certain interests (Adventure, Culture, Wellness etc.). USAID launched the Indo Pacific Opportunity Project (IPOP) tourism activity in July 2022 to support economic reforms and promote foreign direct investment in Sri Lanka.  The two-year project is assisting the Sri Lanka Tourism Ministry to streamline and implement new policies and procedures to enable fast-tracking and attraction of foreign direct investment in the tourism sector. The launch of this social media influencer campaign is another step forward in USAID-IPOP’s strategy to boost Sri Lanka’s tourism.

title: SriLankan Incurs USD 6M loss – Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva yesterday (2) said the delays and cancellation of eight SriLankan Airlines flights, in the last few weeks, had caused a loss of USD 6 million to the State coffers and emphasised that due to this situation, no salary increments or other benefits would be accorded to the employees. The SriLankan management, however, maintained that the aviation engineers went on a ‘work-to-rule’ campaign without declaring it to the management. However, President of the Jathika Nidhahas Sevaka Sangamaya (JNSS), Janaka Wijeyapathirana, told Ceylon Today that their trade union had no involvement in disrupting SriLankan eight flights in the last several weeks. He emphasised that SriLankan officials should ensure that those responsible for disrupting the services are identified and appropriate action is taken against them. The Minister, held discussions with the relevant stakeholders, including the trade unions attached to the SriLankan and the management, over the delays of the eight flights during the past few days. According to the Minister, when inquired from the engineers, attached to the national carrier, their representatives from the trade unions had conveyed to the Minister that technical glitches in aircraft had caused the unexpected delays. However, the officials from the management had insisted that the delays had occurred due to the ‘workto rule’ campaign launched by the trade unions. The Ministers had then pointed out that 260 pilots have been deployed for service in 21 aircraft and that for one aircraft at least 12 pilots should be on duty. He had then noted that according to internationally accepted calculations, a pilot should put in at least 100 hours of service per month and that during the past month pilots of the national carrier had only done 60 hours. The Minister had stated that if a pilot had put in at least 80 hours of service then such delays could have been overcome. He had then accepted that there was an issue related to salaries of the national carrier and that SriLankan has been forced to pay a sum of USD 1.2 billion as loans and interest. However, he added that if the national carrier were to return dividends then a performance based-incentive could be given after consideration. He further stated that the fifth freedom right would be given to other airline operators shortly. According to Wijeyapathirana, the aviation engineers who were on duty had effectively implemented a “work-to-rule” agenda without formally declaring it to the management. He expressed disappointment, stating that this action was not planned by them. Furthermore, he alleged that when questioned, the engineers mentioned that they deliberately delayed repairing a technical issue with the aircraft. Wijeyapathirana explained that the JNSS has a significant membership of 70 per cent in SriLankan. He alleged that aviation engineers had “slowed down” their duties, resulting in delays that led to the transfer of passengers from UL (SriLankan Airlines) to other available flights and that also led to cancellations. This situation also led to the necessity of providing food and lodging in hotels due to the delays and cancellation of the flights. Reportedly, approximately 150 aviation engineers had been requesting a productivity allowance for the past six months. It had been granted to cabin crews but not to them. It is worth noting that other service providers within SriLankan might also demand similar allowances, but as a major loss-making entity, SriLankan cannot afford to provide such allowances. The JNSS President clarified that the technical issue in question was related to routing check-ups and did not compromise the safety of the aircraft. On 1 October,  UL181 faced a cancellation situation, causing a commotion at the airport, when passengers had already been seated in the aircraft for three hours. This flight was originally scheduled to depart for Katmandu, Nepal, from the Bandaranaike International Airport at 8:20 a.m. but had to be cancelled due to a mechanical issue. Simultaneously, on the same day, another SriLankan Airlines flight, bound for Mumbai, India, was also called off due to a technical problem affecting the aircraft. These cancellations inconvenienced hundreds of passengers, disrupting their travel plans and causing unexpected delays. SriLankan Airlines then had to take measures to assist affected passengers by offering alternative arrangements. President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in May this year, said SriLankan Airlines has had a total loss of Rs 372 billion by 31 March 2021. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Adverse weather impacts 3,672 families
author: Author not found
Content: The Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said that a total of 3,672 families, comprising 15,496 individuals, across 51 Divisional Secretariat divisions, spanning four districts in the country, have been severely affected by the ongoing adverse weather conditions. According to DMC sources, in the Ratnapura District, 214 families, consisting of 827 members, were affected by falling trees, cutting failures and floods due to the heavy rains. These incidents occurred in Ratnapura, Ayagama, Kiriella, Godakawela, Elapatha, Kahawatte, Pelmadulla, Kolonna, Opanayake, Kuruwita, Weligapola, Kalawana, Eheliyagoda and Nivithigala DS divisions. In the Kalutara District, a total of 501 families, with 1,913 members, faced challenges due to floods, heavy winds and cutting failures in areas including the Bandaragama, Beruwela, Bulathsinhala, Matugama, Millaniya, Agalawatte, Horana, Walallawita, Ingiriya, Kalutara, Dodangoda, Madurawela and Panadura DS divisions. The Gampaha District registered 2,153 families, comprising 9,509 individuals, affected by falling trees and heavy rains in the Kelaniya, Gampaha, Katana, Attanagalla, Dompe, Wattala, Biyagama and Minuwangoda DS divisions. In the Matara District, 804 families, comprising 3,247 members, encountered difficulties due to falling trees and heavy rains in the Akuressa, Thihagoda, Malimbada, Devinuwara, Weligama, Kamburupitiya, Athuraliya, Kirinda, Pasgoda, Hakmana, Matara, Pitabeddara, Mulatiyana, Kotapola, Dickwella and Welipitiya DS divisions. During these incidents, 376 houses suffered partial damage, while five houses were fully damaged. The Millaniya DS division in the Kalutara District reported the highest number of partially damaged houses, with 106. Additionally, five medium-scale enterprises in these districts were also impacted. In the Gampaha District, 37 families, comprising 147 members, have been accommodated in three safety centers. Furthermore, in response to the adverse weather, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) issued level two amber – watch and level one yellow – watch landslide early warning alerts to 30 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and surrounding areas across nine districts. The districts affected include Galle, Kalutara, Kandy, Kegalle, Matara, Ratnapura, Colombo, Kegalle and Hambantota. These alerts are aimed at ensuring public safety and preparedness in areas prone to landslides during heavy rainfall. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Nishantha claims he paid Namal’s out standing Rs 2.6M electricity bill
author: Author not found
Content: The contentious unpaid electricity bill, amounting to Rs 2.6 million, of MP Namal Rajapaksa, was settled yesterday (2) by State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha. Addressing the media later, Nishantha expressed his decision to clear the outstanding bill as a mark of respect for former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, who played a pivotal role in ending the war and as a token of gratitude for their friendship in both politics and business. “I have paid the full electricity bill of Rs. 2.6 million to the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) on behalf of MP Namal Rajapaksa,” he claimed. He further clarified that, after discussing the matter with the CEB chairman, it was confirmed that MP Namal Rajapaksa had not requested additional electricity supply for his wedding, despite rumours suggesting otherwise. The CEB, in response to a Right to Information (RTI) request of former JVP Provincial Councillor Nalin Hewage, recently revealed that an outstanding electricity bill of Rs 2,682,246.57 was due for the Weeraketiya house, relating to the provision of security lights and generators for an event that took place between 12 – 15 September 2019. The CEB said, they had installed security lights and generators for the mentioned function at the Weeraketiya house on being informed that former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa was to attend a function on the said dates. The CEB further said, despite providing the services and incurring the electricity charges of Rs 2,682,246.57, the payment has not been settled even after four years, although multiple requests had been made it to be settled. When Hewage publicly, on a television show, accused Namal Rajapaksa of dodging payment of the said electricity bill Rajapaksa denied receiving any such bill. After the CEB’s response to Hewage’s RTI request went viral on social media, Namal Rajapaksa took action and sent a letter to the CEB. In the letter, he requested detailed information regarding the unpaid bill. Specifically, he asked for the recipient’s name to whom the bill was issued, the amount of the bill, the date when the bill was issued, and the address to which the bill was sent. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: New vehicle revenue licence system eRL 2.0 launch on 7 Oct
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is set to launch its new Motor Vehicle Revenue Licence System, eRL 2.0, on 7 October, State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath said yesterday (2). He made this announcement during a press briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC). Herath added that the eRL 2.0 programme will be rolled out in all provinces except the Western. What sets the eRL 2.0 system apart is its convenience, allowing citizens to obtain motor vehicle revenue licences from the comfort of their homes. This digital transformation initiative is aligned with President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s vision to digitise all government institutions in Sri Lanka, as outlined in the budget 2023 statement. To kickstart the digitisation process, nine pilot projects are currently underway, involving various government institutions, including Divisional Secretariat Divisions, Pradeshiya Sabhas, Municipal Councils and District Secretariat Offices. These efforts aim to enhance efficiency and transparency within the public service, the State minister revealed. Starting on 7 October, the eRL 2.0 system will offer residents the option to acquire vehicle revenue licences online. It is a collaborative effort between the State Ministry of Technology and the Information and Communication Technology Association of Sri Lanka. It will initially cover all provinces, excluding the Western Province, with plans to expand to all government institutions and enable online payments by March of the following year.

title: Nobel Prize goes to scientists behind mRNA Covid vaccines
author: Author not found
Content: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine has been awarded to a pair of scientists, who developed the technology that led to the mRNA Covid vaccines. Professors Katalin Kariko and Drew Weissman will share the prize. The technology was experimental before the pandemic, but has now been given to millions of people around the world to protect them against serious Covid-19. The same mRNA technology is now being researched for other diseases, including cancer. The Nobel Prize committee said: “The laureates contributed to the unprecedented rate of vaccine development during one of the greatest threats to human health in modern times.” Both were told they had won by telephone this morning and were said to be “overwhelmed”. Vaccines train the immune system to recognise and fight threats such as viruses or bacteria. Traditional vaccine technology has been based on dead or weakened versions of the original virus or bacterium – or by using fragments of the infectious agent. In contrast, messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA) vaccines use a completely differently approach. During the Covid pandemic, the Moderna and Pfizer/BioNTech vaccines were both based on mRNA technology. Professor Kariko and Professor Weissman met in the early 1990s when they were working at the University of Pennsylvania, in the United States, when their interest in mRNA was seen as a scientific backwater. An mRNA Covid vaccine contains the genetic instructions for building one component – a protein – from the coronavirus. When this is injected into the body, our cells start producing lots of the viral protein. The immune system recognises these as foreign so it attacks and has learned how to fight the virus, and therefore has a head start when future infections occur. The big idea behind the technology is that you can rapidly develop a vaccine against almost anything – as long as you know the right genetic instructions to use. This makes it far faster and more flexible than traditional approaches to vaccine development. There are even experimental approaches using the technology that are teaching patients’ bodies how to fight their own cancers. Scientists analyse a patient’s tumour, look for abnormal proteins being produced by the cancer that are not in healthy tissue and develop a vaccine to target those and inject that into the patient. Profs Kariko and Weissman made the crucial breakthroughs that made mRNA vaccines happen. The principle taps into normal human biology. RNA’s role in our body is to convert the instructions that are locked away in our genetic code, or DNA, into the proteins that our body is built from. However, there were challenges. But by refining the technology, the researchers were able to produce large amounts of the intended protein without causing dangerous levels of inflammation that had been seen in animal experiments. This paved the way for developing the vaccine technology for use in people. Katalin Kariko is now a professor at Szeged University in Hungary and Drew Weissman is still working as a professor at the University of Pennsylvania. (BBC)

title: Person boards plane without travel documents
author: Author not found
Content: The CID has launched an investigation into how a person had boarded an airplane, scheduled to take off for Japan, from the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) in Katunayake, without any legal travel document. The individual was arrested while seated in the plane. A senior official at the CID said that the security and immigration officials will be questioned and CCTV footage will be analysed.  It is highly questionable as to how the passenger avoided all the security measures and boarded the plane without any legal document for air travel, the CID officials said, adding they are probing to find out whether the passenger bribed any official at the BIA to obtain support. He said another CID team has been deployed for background screening of the suspect.  The suspect was remanded until 6 October by the Negombo Acting Magistrate. BY Keerthi Mendis

title: Two surrender over gruesome murder
author: Author not found
Content: Two individuals, including the prime suspect, in the gruesome murder of a woman, whose decapitated and dismembered body was found on the banks of the Kelani Ganga in Siyamabalape, have voluntarily surrendered to the Police. According to Police, the two suspects arrived at the Sapugaskanda Police Station, accompanied by four lawyers. They had also surrendered the three-wheeler believed to have been used in transporting the victim’s body. The Police are currently questioning both suspects. The main suspect was identified as a 53-year-old businessman from Siyamabalape, while the other is reportedly a 48-year-old individual from the same area, known locally as a ‘Kapuwa’, who allegedly assisted the main suspect in dismembering the woman’s body. The victim, T.G. Pradeepa, a 51-year-old woman, who had been missing since 27 September, was discovered by the Police on 28 September, on the river bank. The incident was reported to the Mulleriyawa Police by Pradeepa’s daughter on 27 September. Investigation findings, including CCTV footage, indicated that the victim had encountered the main suspect outside a restaurant in Kaduwela town before leaving with him in his car. The main suspect, a Siyamabalape resident, was known to have had a close association with the woman for more than two decades. It has been revealed that a dispute over a financial matter led to the tragic event. Furthermore, the suspect’s abandoned house in Siyamabalape was found to contain bloodstains, strands of hair, and shreds of women’s clothing. The victim’s body was discovered approximately one metre away from the suspect’s residence on the river banks. An overseas travel ban had been clamped on the main suspect, prompting the Sri Lanka Police to seek public assistance in locating him in connection with the murder investigation.
