In the Kalutara District, a total of 501 families, with 1,913 members, faced challenges due to floods, heavy winds and cutting failures in areas including the Bandaragama, Beruwela, Bulathsinhala, Matugama, Millaniya, Agalawatte, Horana, Walallawita, Ingiriya, Kalutara, Dodangoda, Madurawela and Panadura DS divisions. The Gampaha District registered 2,153 families, comprising 9,509 individuals, affected by falling trees and heavy rains in the Kelaniya, Gampaha, Katana, Attanagalla, Dompe, Wattala, Biyagama and Minuwangoda DS divisions. In the Matara District, 804 families, comprising 3,247 members, encountered difficulties due to falling trees and heavy rains in the Akuressa, Thihagoda, Malimbada, Devinuwara, Weligama, Kamburupitiya, Athuraliya, Kirinda, Pasgoda, Hakmana, Matara, Pitabeddara, Mulatiyana, Kotapola, Dickwella and Welipitiya DS divisions. During these incidents, 376 houses suffered partial damage, while five houses were fully damaged. The Millaniya DS division in the Kalutara District reported the highest number of partially damaged houses, with 106. Additionally, five medium-scale enterprises in these districts were also impacted. In the Gampaha District, 37 families, comprising 147 members, have been accommodated in three safety centers. Furthermore, in response to the adverse weather, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) issued level two amber – watch and level one yellow – watch landslide early warning alerts to 30 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and surrounding areas across nine districts. The districts affected include Galle, Kalutara, Kandy, Kegalle, Matara, Ratnapura, Colombo, Kegalle and Hambantota. These alerts are aimed at ensuring public safety and preparedness in areas prone to landslides during heavy rainfall. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Nishantha claims he paid Namal’s out standing Rs 2.6M electricity bill
author: Author not found
Content: The contentious unpaid electricity bill, amounting to Rs 2.6 million, of MP Namal Rajapaksa, was settled yesterday (2) by State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha. Addressing the media later, Nishantha expressed his decision to clear the outstanding bill as a mark of respect for former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, who played a pivotal role in ending the war and as a token of gratitude for their friendship in both politics and business. “I have paid the full electricity bill of Rs. 2.6 million to the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) on behalf of MP Namal Rajapaksa,” he claimed. He further clarified that, after discussing the matter with the CEB chairman, it was confirmed that MP Namal Rajapaksa had not requested additional electricity supply for his wedding, despite rumours suggesting otherwise. The CEB, in response to a Right to Information (RTI) request of former JVP Provincial Councillor Nalin Hewage, recently revealed that an outstanding electricity bill of Rs 2,682,246.57 was due for the Weeraketiya house, relating to the provision of security lights and generators for an event that took place between 12 – 15 September 2019. The CEB said, they had installed security lights and generators for the mentioned function at the Weeraketiya house on being informed that former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa was to attend a function on the said dates. The CEB further said, despite providing the services and incurring the electricity charges of Rs 2,682,246.57, the payment has not been settled even after four years, although multiple requests had been made it to be settled. When Hewage publicly, on a television show, accused Namal Rajapaksa of dodging payment of the said electricity bill Rajapaksa denied receiving any such bill. After the CEB’s response to Hewage’s RTI request went viral on social media, Namal Rajapaksa took action and sent a letter to the CEB. In the letter, he requested detailed information regarding the unpaid bill. Specifically, he asked for the recipient’s name to whom the bill was issued, the amount of the bill, the date when the bill was issued, and the address to which the bill was sent. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Police tell Court no suspects arrested yet
author: Author not found
Content: Anuradhapura Police yesterday (2) informed Anuradhapura Chief Magistrate Nalaka Jayasuriya that they were yet to apprehend any suspects, involved in the shooting incident targeting actor turned politician Uddika Premarathna and that further inquiries are underway to identify the suspects and arrest them. Police told Magistrate Jayasuriya that they were seeking the support of their intelligence units and private spies to identify the suspects.  The Chief Magistrate, having considered the submissions made by the Police, through a progress report into the incident, then instructed them to file another progress report shortly.  The alleged incident had occurred during the night of 17 September. Two shots had been fired at the vehicle of the Parliamentarian near his residence, the Police previously informed the Court via their ‘B’ Report. Police added that though the MP concerned escaped unhurt in the shooting his vehicle suffered serious damage as a result and that they are conducting more investigations into it from several angles. According to the Police, they also recorded statements from two of the officers in Premarathna’s security. The Police then pledged to seize the firearm which was used by the suspects. BY Upali Karunadasa – Anuradhapura

title: Anura Kumara claims 33 NLDB farms to be sold
author: Author not found
Content: Plans are afoot to sell off 33 dairy farms, owned by the National Livestock Development Board (NLDB), which includes the well-known brands Milco and Highland, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake alleged. Addressing the gathering at the JJB Mawanella Electoral Convention, Dissanayake asserted that these Sri Lankan dairy farms are slated for sale to India’s Amul Dairy Company. He also alleged that Cabinet approval has already been secured for the sale of Milco, and a finalised Cabinet proposal is in place for the sale of ‘Highland’ to Amul. Additionally, Dissanayake disclosed that among the 21 dairy farms, owned by the NLDB, set to be divested, the Adigama, Ridiyagama, Narammala and Polonnaruwa dairy farms are included in the proposed plan. To facilitate this process, two committees have been established: one responsible for assessing the land, trees, and plantation on the farms and the other, headed by the NLDB Director General, tasked with evaluating the animals and equipment within the farms, he claimed.

title: Wounded jumbo’s owner disappointed
author: Author not found
Content: M. M. Roshan, the caretaker of the female tusker ‘Sita’, has expressed disappointment over the lack of intervention from responsible Government agencies regarding the provision of treatment for the tusker’s gunshot injuries. An expert from the Veterinary Unit, affiliated with the Sri Dalada Maligawa in Kandy, has initiated the treatment for ‘Sita’, who was suffering from gunshot injuries. The tusker is currently undergoing treatment at the Mahiyangana Raja Maha Viharaya. The incident occurred when ‘Sita’ sustained a gunshot injury while chained at the temple premises, following her participation in the Mahiyangana Raja Maha Viharaya Randoli Perahera on 30 September. The tusker was shot during a momentary absence of her mahout. Veterinarians have reported that the tusker’s left foot suffered penetration from four to five bullets. Investigations have revealed that the shots were fired from a Repeater firearm issued to a Civil Defence Officer affiliated to the Department of Wildlife, who was assigned to a security detail. The suspect in the case was apprehended and subsequently produced before the Mahiyangana Magistrate’s Court. The individual was released on a surety of Rs 100,000.

title: SL to negotiate Govt-to-Govt agreements for purchase of medicines
author: Author not found
Content: With the glut of accusations levelled against the Health Ministry over emergency purchasing, steps are being taken to negotiate government to government agreements for the procurement of medicinal drugs, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said yesterday (2). He said that discussions were currently being held with the Governments of Bangladesh and India for a government-to-government venture, to obtain medicinal drugs. “We have completed 90% of the procedures and could hope for a feasible outcome by next month,” he said. The Minister said that he had discussed the matter with the Bangladeshi Premier to obtain 63 medicines, of which 54 would be free of cost. The Health Minister noted that 90% of the medicines that were imported to Sri Lanka were from India and Bangladesh. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 16th GYPF 2023 at BMICH Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: Today with youth voices from over 15 countries, the 16th Global Youth Peace Fest-GYPF 2023, a joint initiative of the National Youth Services Council, Sri Lanka and Yuvsatta (youth for peace), India, started at Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall (BMICH), Colombo. Prominent amongst those who interacted with over 200 participating young people from 15 countries were Maithripala Srisena, Former President of Sri Lanka,  Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, PC, M.P., Minister of Justice, Sri Lanka, senior Gandhian Leader from India Dr. P.V. Rajagopal, American Gandhi Don McAvinchey, Chandrika De Zoysa, Country Coordinator of GYPF2023 and Pramod Sharma, Founder, Yuvsatta (youth for peace). In her welcome address, Chandrika De Zoysa mentioned that in the past two decades GYPF-the annual Global Youth Peace Fest, has now become a breeding ground for inspiring new ideas, beyond forging lasting friendships across cultures. GYPF provides participating delegates with a global platform to meet like-minded people and youth leaders to network and evolve to build a better world. Appreciating the annual Global Youth Peace Fest for the promotion of youth leadership and transformative change, Maithripala Srisena said peace can’t be measured by defence expenditure, government policy or the number of wars waged in the world. Peace is not a lack of weapons or careless citizens. But when hundreds of youth travel miles from their homes for such programmes it’s apparent that our young people are our hope for a better, peaceful and harmonious world. Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe added that every day we watch on social media and television, wars in different parts of the world and we realise the extent of the destruction and devastation that wars leave. The solutions are not easy, but we can begin with ourselves, first be at peace with yourself, strive for peace in your homes with love and harmony among all your family members and from yourself, own self, and your family, it will transcend to society, city, nations and the whole world. Instead of ‘be the Change’, ‘I am the Change’ is the slogan of this year’s Global Youth Peace Fest, introducing the same Dr. PV Rajgopal said youth have to replace the present-day business of wars and violence of powerful countries and big corporates with a strong belief in power of self and mantra of non-violence which Mahatma Gandhi propagated, lived anddied for. American Gandhi Don McAvinchey asked the participating young people to ask themselves, what is there in the world, they’d like to live for and change for a better world. The majority of the population in the world is young people and they have to unite through such endeavours bridging the gaps of religion, race, gender and nationalities. Prominent participating dignitaries also presented 15 promising international young delegates of the Global Youth Peace Fest with the ‘Youth Leadership Awards’. Participating young delegates who came for the programme are from India, Pakistan, Nepal, Bangladesh, the Philippines, Malaysia, Australia, the USA, Egypt, Uganda, Sudan, Nepal, the Maldives, Indonesia and Sri Lanka. ‘Day 1’  of the programme ended with a ‘Bridge the Gap March for Girls and Women’s Rights’, from Town Hall to Independence Square: In which the participants were carrying posters with slogans like ‘Stand for Women’s Rights’, ‘Close the Gap’, ‘Women’s Wave Rising’, ‘Women Rights are Human Rights’ etc. and in the end, lighting candles they pledged to work promoting the rights and dignity of girls and women. Thanking the participating young people who joined the march, Pramod Sharma, Founder, Yuvsatta (youth for peace) informed that in 86 countries, women face some form of job restriction and 95 countries do not guarantee ‘equal pay for equal work’. Women and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)-Gender equality is a right. Fulfilling this right is the best chance we have in meeting some of the most pressing challenges of our time—from economic crisis and lack of health care to climate change, violence against women and escalating conflicts. Tomorrow the second day of the programme will start with an early morning Colombo Beach cleanliness drive at Galleface Beach and later full-day interactive workshops at headquarters of the biggest NGO in Sri Lanka, the Sarvodaya Shramadana Movement.

title: Sri Lanka India Society – strengthening bonds of friendship
author: Author not found
Content: The President of the Sri Lanka India Society Kishore Reddy and the executive committee of the society organised a commemorative dinner for the 77th Independence day of India with Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena as the Chief Guest, Gopal Baglay, High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka as the guest of Honour and Renuka Ekanayake, Director SAARC Cultural Centre as the Key note speaker. Chief Justice of Sri Lanka Jayantha Jayasuriya, Minister Manusha Nanayakkara, Member of Parliament Yadamini Gunawardena, Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman, Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, as well as diplomats, members of the society, officials and many other dignitaries joined to celebrate a night of friendship at Taj Samudra Hotel in Colombo. Prime Minister Gunawardena said India is progressing as an economic power and playing a crucial role in promoting development and humanitarian goals around the world. He added that India has been able to develop economic development during this Asia’s centenary era. The Prime Minister, who remembered that Independence Day, also recounted his connection with India as the son of the parents who participated in India’s freedom struggle and said it was an opportunity to reconnect with history and “an opportunity to assess our present and plan for the journey ahead.” Looking at the present, it shows that India has not only regained its rightful position in the world but also raised its stance in the international programme. The Prime Minister said that India is playing a crucial role in promoting development and humanitarian goals around the world. Guest of honour, High Commissioner Gopal Bagley, emphasised the diversity of centuries-old bonds, deeply rooted among India and Sri Lanka. The initiatives taken by the society strengthens ties between the people of the two countries were also appreciated. As Sri Lanka and India are children of the same ancient culture and both countries have common cultural ties, India will always help when Sri Lanka needs India’s help, the High Commissioner said. SLIS President Kishore Reddy insisted that the relationship and cultural ties between people are one of the key towers of the relationship between India and Sri Lanka. He demonstrated that sharing knowledge nurtures diversity and common prosperity. Reddy, while speaking about the relationship between the nations, said: “Trade and investment have grown and there is cooperation in the fields of development, education, culture, and defence. Both countries share a broad understanding of major issues of international interest. As a friendship society, we are very happy and equally proud of India’s assistance to Sri Lanka when needed. He ended with a toast, saying: “We wish Sri Lanka and India peace and prosperity, today and in the future and for the enduring friendship and partnership between both countries.” Renuka Ekanayake, while speaking on the topic ‘Historical bonding between India and Sri Lanka’ said that the relationship between India and Sri Lanka was age old and the cultural bonding keeps strengthening through time. Established in 1949, the Sri Lanka India Society is one of the oldest and largest friendship societies in Sri Lanka, where two culturally rich nations continue their deep-rooted, centuries-old ties. From sharing similar sentiments on religion and cultural norms, Indo-Lanka relations have been multi-faceted, unwavering, and time-tested. The society which has more than 800 life members comprising both Sri Lankan and Indian nationals have strengthened people to people relationship between the two countries, whilst the benefits of its synergies have touched the lives of many.

title: Iranpharma Expo 2023 in Tehran
author: Author not found
Content: On an invitation extended by the Islamic Republic of Iran, Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Iran G.M.V. Wishwanath Aponsu participated in the  8th International Exhibition on Pharmaceuticals and Related Industries “IRANPHARMA EXPO 2023” held at the Imam Khomeini Grand Campus (Mosala) in Tehran from 27-29 September 2023. More than 427 Iranian companies and 282 foreign exhibitors from 33 countries showcased their products and services in the international exhibition. The IRANPHARMA EXPO is an annual event in the pharmaceutical industries that hosts manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, pharmaceutical equipment and machinery, recombinant drugs, herbal medicines, food and dietary supplements, knowledge-based companies, pharmaceutical distributors, scientific and pharmaceutical research facilities, associations and health-oriented publications. The exhibition is a key business gathering in Iran and West Asia with prominent pharmaceutical related companies and facilitates for creating a new platform for potential business partnerships. During the inauguration of the above exhibition, Ambassador Aponsu met the Minister of Health and Medical Education of Iran Dr. Bahram Einollahi and congratulated him for organising the IRANPHARMA EXPO 2023 in a successful manner. He conveyed Sri Lanka’s interest in establishing effective long-term cooperation with Iran in the fields of health, medical education and pharmaceutical industry. Accepting the Ambassador’s proposal, the minister underscored the need of further discussions on the proposal between the concerned authorities of Sri Lanka and Iran. The Sri Lankan envoy also attended the business discussion of the exhibition, chaired by the Head of the Iran Pharmaceutical Export Association Dr. Sayed Ali Maboudi and briefed on the opportunities available in the Sri Lankan market including investments in medical education sector and pharmaceutical industry. Business representatives of pharmaceutical companies spoke on their company profiles and expressed their interest to hold initial level meetings with Sri Lankan counterparts. Highlighting the present developments in Sri Lanka, the ambassador assured to create a platform with a view to exploring joint cooperation and enhance bilateral trade and investment exchanges in pharmaceutical sector. Iranian-made pharmaceuticals are currently exported to 40 countries across the world. Dr. Sayed Ali Maboudi expressed his appreciation for the ambassador’s participation in the exhibition and pledged his support for establishing new partnerships between Sri Lanka and Iran particularly in the pharmaceutical industry for the benefit of the two countries. Several Ambassadors and representatives based in Tehran including India, Philippines, Nicaragua, Bolivia and Zimbabwe attended the IRANPHARMA EXPO 2023.

title: Outgoing Sri Lankan HC bids farewell to Commerce and Industry Minister of India
author: Author not found
Content: Outgoing Sri Lankan High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda paid a farewell call on the Indian Minister of Commerce and Industry Shri Piyush Goyal on 29 September, at the Ministry of Commerce and Industry in New Delhi. During the call, High Commissioner Moragoda recalled the continuous interactions he has had with the Minister and expressed his appreciation to the latter for the support extended during his tenure in Delhi. The High Commissioner particularly thanked the Minister for his contribution towards the resumption of the negotiations on Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) between India and Sri Lanka. The next (12th) round of negotiations on the ETCA are scheduled to be held in Colombo from 30 October-01 November 2023. In this regard, they welcomed the virtual meeting of the Chief Negotiators of Sri Lanka and India on 19th September to discuss the way forward in resumption of ETCA negotiations, as agreed by the leaders of the two countries in the “India-Sri Lanka Economic Partnership Vision” in July this year, and stressed the importance of completing the negotiations within the agreed timeframe. As a token of appreciation and goodwill, High Commissioner Moragoda presented to Minister Goyal a stone obtained from the stream flowing besides the Seetha Amman Temple in Seetha Eliya (Ashoka Vatika), a significant Ramayana site in Sri Lanka.

title: Accept IMF terms or boost migrant remittances – Prof. Methsila
author: Author not found
Content: The Government can either accept the strict and controlling terms imposed by the IMF, to secure a USD 300 million loan, or they can focus on boosting the money sent home by Sri Lankan migrant workers, which currently amounts to USD 450 million per month, Professor Aminda Methsila of the Wayamba University of Sri Lanka (WUSL) pointed out. He stated that the Government would need to take a decision on these issues sooner than later as it is clear the modus operandi of the IMF is to further strangle Sri Lanka at a time when it is economically embroiled in a tailspin whilst trying to achieve its own targets via it. Prof. Methsila stated that if the Government does decide to fulfil the conditions laid down by the Washington based global money lender it will certainly signal the death knell to most of the long-standing businesses here. He made these comments speaking to the media. The Professor added that if the Government were to implement most of the proposals put forth to them by a group of IMF representatives who were in the country recently prices of all items in this country would spike by 20 per cent rendering survival in Sri Lanka well nigh impossible. BY ShakyaInduwara – Kuliyapitiya

title: AG informs Court no appointment till 13 Oct
author: Author not found
Content: Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam yesterday (2) informed the Court of Appeal that no one will be appointed to the vacant Trustee post of the Seenigama Devalaya in Hikkaduwa, which is currently embroiled in controversy, till 13 October. A writ petition, filed to this effect, was perused before a Court of Appeal Bench, comprising Justices Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepla yesterday. The aforementioned assurance to the Court, was given by the State Counsel, on behalf of the Commissioner General on Buddhist Affairs, when a writ petition filed by Attorney-at-Law Udayanga Munaweera, was taken up. Through his writ petition, the Lawyer has challenged the marks given for prospective candidates, during the interview process, held to select a suitable person, for the said portfolio of the devalaya. The State Counsel then informed the Bench, that a detailed report regarding the marks given to the prospective applicants, including the lawyer concerned, during the interviews held on 16, 17 and 25 August, at the Department of Buddhist Affairs, will be submitted to Court shortly. Later, the Court deferred further hearing of the writ petition, to the said date. The writ petition filed through Sampath Wijewardena, has mentioned that during the interview process, only a solitary mark, had been given to a widely recognised certificate in the country. The petition has stated furthermore, that a sinister plot had been hatched, to appoint an accomplice of a politician, who had been rejected by the people at the previous General Election, as the trustee, while overlooking qualified applicants for the post, at the same time.  BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Snr Journalist Edmund Ranasinghe to be felicitated today
author: Author not found
Content: The felicitation ceremony for senior journalist Edmund Ranasinghe, the founding editor and editorial director of Divaina newspaper and one of Sri Lanka’s most esteemed journalists, is scheduled for today (03) at 3:00 pm at the Presidential Secretariat. President Ranil Wickremesinghe will preside over this event, which marks the initiation of a programme conceptualised by him 9th President) to honour senior journalists who havemade significant contributions to journalism in the country. In appreciation of 93-year-old journalist Ranasinghe’s seven decades of dedicated work in the media, a book titled ‘Edmund’s Newspaper Revolution,’ will be published. The keynote speech at this tribute ceremony will be delivered by Upali Tennakoon, the former Editor-in-Chief of the Island and Rivira newspapers, currently residing in the United States of America. Edmund Ranasinghe embarked on his media career as a journalist at the Lake House, Daily News newspaper in 1952. In 1973, while serving as the News Editor and holding the title of Deputy Editor at Dinamina, he resigned from his position in protest over the government’s takeover of Lake House. In 1977, Ranasinghe was reappointed as the Editor of Dinamina by invitation from Lake House and later he also took on the role of Editor at Silumina. In 1981, he became the founding Editor of the Divaina newspaper, revolutionising journalism in Sri Lanka and elevating it to unprecedented popularity in a short span of time. In 2016, at the age of 86, Ranasinghe once again assumed the role of Editor at Silumina further showcasing his enduring commitment to journalism.

title: Troops distribute school needs, lunch to children’s Home
author: Author not found
Content: Troops from the 241 Infantry Brigade commemorate World Children’s Day on Sunday (1 October) by distributing school supplies, including textbooks, exercise books and lunch, to 43 students and staff at the Amman Mahalirillam Children’s Home in Alayadivembu, Akkaraipattu. This event was held under the guidance of Major General W. Chandrasiri, the General Officer Commanding of the 24 Infantry Division, and on the instruction and coordination of Brigadier LSDN Pathirathna, the Commander of the 241 Infantry Brigade, The officers and personnel of the 241 Infantry Brigade organised the lunch, while the school books were generously donated by Venerable Warakapola Indrasiri  Thera, the Senior Incumbent and Head of  ‘Siri Indrasiri Pirivena’, along with novice monks and students from the Damma School of Ancients at Muhudu Maha Viharaya. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Vehicle owners lament fuel price hike
author: Author not found
Content: Vehicle owners in Hatton stated that the latest fuel price hike at midnight Sunday (1) has become unbearable for them. The consumers, residing in the Estate sector, stated that they too had felt the pinch during the previous fuel price hike and the recent increase it will result in them falling from the frying pan into the fire. They charged that thanks to fuel price hike all essentials would invariably rise in price along with transport fares and living would become well nigh impossible before the year ends. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Edu Dept to recover cost of missing cool boxes
author: Author not found
Content: The Education Department has decided to obtain the value of two cool boxes, which went missing after being provided to  Central Province Education Department, from the then Education Director of the Central Province Thilak Ekanayake and M. B. Ekanayake, who had functioned as the Officer in Charge of Vehicles. This is following an inquiry conducted into the missing cool boxes, which were in two KDH vans, that had been provided to the Central Province Education Department upon being purchased by the Education Ministry. Following a probe and an audit, it had been revealed that the cool boxes had gone missing in the period from 2015 to 2020. At the time of the purchase of the vehicles the firm which had imported them had handed over the cool boxes as a propaganda exercise. The Education Ministry had launched an inquiry into the missing cool boxes from the vans. After the estimated costs of the cool boxes had been tabulated at Rs 58,500 it had been decided to charge two thirds of the costs from the Officer-in-Charge of the Vehicles and the rest from the former Director of Education. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SLPP to reveal presidential candidate at party CONVENTION
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) is set to unveil the identity of the party’s candidate for Presidential Election 2024, who has a name with ‘three letters,’ at the Party Convention in November, MP Ranjith Bandara said. Addressing the media in Kandy yesterday (1), Bandara highlighted the strategic thinking among representatives from various political parties in the country. These representatives are contemplating the optimal chances of securing parliamentary seats in the forthcoming General Election and have been engaging in ‘confidential discussions’ with Basil Rajapaksa, he claimed. Speaking further, Bandara emphasised a fundamental distinction between politics and administration, stressing that these two domains are separate entities. He pointed out that the enduring role of civil servants in government institutions, despite the changing landscape of political leadership. He also noted a significant shift in the dynamics of government administration, as the role of permanent secretaries has evolved over time, which he believes is a primary contributing factor to the decline observed in various sectors.  The Party Convention of Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna will be held in November and the name of the candidate for the presidential election will be revealed. He said representatives of all political parties were thinking about the best opportunity to be elected to  Parliament in the next General Election and people from many parties were meeting Basil Rajapaksa and discussing secretly. He said politics and administration were two separate entities and even though politicians were different, officers working in State institutions remain the same. He emphasised that although there were permanent secretaries during the earlier regimes, that situation does not exist anymore and this was the main reason for deterioration in management and administration in all fields. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Govt assures highest compensation – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera announced that the Government is taking proactive measures to ensure the highest possible compensation for farmlands affected by recent adverse weather conditions. Amaraweera highlighted the significant damage inflicted on paddy fields as a result of both droughts and heavy rainfall. He stressed that while the assessment of crop damage caused by drought is nearing completion, a thorough evaluation of the damage caused by rain and flooding is also underway. Additionally, the minister pointed out that unexpected climate change has led to the destruction of a substantial amount of cultivated land. He noted that despite the Meteorological Department’s earlier predictions of continuous rainfall in October and November, the region experienced unanticipated rainfall throughout September.

title: President congratulates new Maldivian President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe congratulated Mohamed Muizzu, the newly elected President of the Maldives, thus solidifying the bonds of friendship and cooperation between the two countries, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. President Wickremesinghe congratulated President Muizzu through a personal telephone call, demonstrating the importance of the occasion. During their conversation, President Wickremesinghe expressed his strong desire to elevate the existing close andfriendly bilateral relations into a robust and multi-faceted partnership. Both leaders emphasised their commitment to the betterment of the citizens of Sri Lanka and the Maldives, with President Wickremesinghe highlighting the pivotal role of enhanced economic cooperation. This expanded cooperation aims to encompass diverse fields such as education, healthcare, bilateral trade, and investment, promising mutual growth and development, the PMD said. President Wickremesinghe also expressed his anticipation of working closely with President Muizzu to achieve these shared goals, reaffirming the dedication of both countries to a brighterand prosperous future. President Wickremesinghe expressed his sincere hope for the Maldives to thrive under President Muizzu’s leadership, according to the PMD.

title: President returns from Germany
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe returned to Sri Lanka yesterday (1) morning following the conclusion of his official visit to Germany, where he participated in the ‘Berlin Global Dialogue.’ The President left for Germany on Wednesday, 27 September, to attend the dialogue, which took place on 28 and 29 September, in Berlin. The global forum brought together influential decision-makers and leaders from the realms of politics, business, and society, as well as young visionaries. On the opening day President Wickremesinghe delivered the keynote address. He emphasised the imperative of comprehensive international dialogue to address global challenges in 2024. While participating in the ‘Berlin Dialogue’ roundtable, President Wickremesinghe said discussions regarding debt restructuring with China had been productive thus far. He also highlighted the necessity of resuming discussions with the Paris Club and India on this matter. In addition to his participation in the Berlin Global Dialogue, President Wickremesinghe engaged in bilateral discussions with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Kazakhstan President Kassym-JomartTokayev on the sidelines of the event. Accompanying President Wickremesinghe on his trip were Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayaka; President’s Senior Adviser on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samarathunga and Secretary of the Foreign Ministry Aruni Wijewardane. The President also took part in the Leaders Dialogue session focused on ‘The Role of Kazakhstan in the Transition of the Global Economy,’ led by the President of Kazakhstan.

title: Ban on nine single-use plastics takes effect
author: Author not found
Content: The ban on the manufacturing and sale of nine more single-use plastic products came into effect yesterday (1). The banned items include single-use drinking straws and stirrers; single-use plates, cups, spoons, forks, and knives; plastic garlands, and plastic string hopper trays. Further, manufacturing, importing for local use, sale, offering for sale, displaying for sale, offering free of charge, or exhibiting these items within the country are banned from 1 October. Legal action will be instituted against those who violate this ban in terms of the provisions of the National Environmental Act. The use of the above single-use plastics was banned by Gazette Extraordinary No. 2341/30 of 19 July 2023, Central Environmental Authority (CEA) Director General P.B. Hemantha Jayasinghe told the media on 24 August. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: Cabinet approval granted – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha said Cabinet has approved the initiation of vocational training courses for students immediately after the completion of their G.C.E. Ordinary Level and G.C.E. Advanced Level examinations. During an event held in Gintota, the Minister highlighted that these vocational training courses have been strategically planned to be conducted nationwide for students scheduled to sit for the G.C.E. A/L this year, right after the conclusion of their examinations. He pointed out that the corresponding vocational training programmes will be promptly launched for students appearing for the G.C.E. O/L, immediately after the conclusion of their examinations. It is anticipated that over 50 per cent of the students taking these examinations will enrol in these courses.

title: Probe launched into shooting of tame female elephant
author: Author not found
Content: In the early hours of Saturday (30 September) an officer of the Civil Security Department (CSD), attached to the Mapakadawewa Wildlife Regional Office, was arrested for shooting and injuring the 47-year-old female elephant named ‘Sita’ that had taken part in the annual Esala Perehara of Mahiyangana Rajamaha Viharaya. The officer was later released on surety bail in Rs100,000. The incident has occurred at around 3:30a.m. on Saturday. Following the end of the perahera, the mahout had tethered Sita to a tree on the banks of the Mahaweli River, next to the temple complex to have some breakfast. According to a statement made by the Director General of the Department of Wildlife and Conservation (DWC) Chandana Sooriyabandara, the area where the incident took place is prone to wild elephant encounters and the officer had mistaken the elephant as a wild elephant and had shot it to drive it away. According to the mahout, despite the people around, informing the officer that the elephant he was aiming to shoot was a tame elephant, the officer continued to shoot in the belief that it was a wild elephant. The DWC said the elephant was treated by a veterinary surgeon from the department following the incident. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Panchali Panapitiya, founder of the animal rights advocacy organisation, RARE Sri Lanka, said the excuse trotted out for the shooting by the e DWC was unacceptable. “How is it okay to shoot an elephant whether it be from the wild or not?” Highlighting the injuries to Sita, Panapitiya said there were over seven wounds inflicted on Sita following the incident. She also stated that captive elephants must be kept away from wild elephants for their safety. The area in question being prone to constant human and wild elephant conflicts, the DWC must be more aware and careful with how they address a wild elephant encounter. Panapitiya said being tethered to a tree, the elephant couldn’t even flee the area. She also alleged that the DWC isn’t trained enough to handle such a situation and that there should be more security to ensure the safety of captive elephants. According to Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa, the true intent of the CSD officer is yet to be ascertained as he has acted on his own accord and not on any orders to carry out the shooting. SSP Thalduwa told Ceylon Today that due to vehicles being parked in front of the temple, mahouts tether elephants on the river bank. Responding to the question on the legality of shooting an elephant, SSP Thalduwa said the DWC has a  process they implement to de-escalate a human- elephant conflict and that shooting at an elephant was the last resortDWC officers should engage in. Only if the elephant becomes an immediate threat to human lives and property in the immediate vicinity, should the elephant be shot at. The CSD has commenced an internal disciplinary investigation against the officer in question. State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Thenakoon has also called for an impartial inquiry into the matter and that disciplinary action will be taken against the CSD personnel for misconduct, if he is found to have committed any offence while on duty. By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Two more SriLankan flight delays
author: Author not found
Content: Hundreds of passengers faced severe inconvenience yesterday (1) morning when two SriLankan Airlines flights, scheduled to take off for Nepal and India, from the BIA, were cancelled due to technical problems. Flight UL-180 scheduled to depart for Kathmandu, Nepal, at 8:20 a.m. was delayed and over 200 passengers were stranded including State Minister Sisira Jayakody. Passengers boarded the flight at 7:15 a.m., but the plane remained grounded at the BIA until 11:00 a.m. Subsequently, it was announced that another aircraft would be provided due to technical issues in the original plane. However, as the afternoon rolled on, this promise remained unfulfilled, leading to growing frustration among passengers, including Minister Jayakody. The delay was attributed to the challenging topography of Nepal, known for its mountainous terrain and frequent fog, particularly in the evening, which hindered takeoff. Airport sources said due to these conditions, the flight was cancelled. Jayakody expressed his concerns and said the Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva has to bear the responsibility. He said a number of foreign tourists, including himself, were inconvenienced by the delay. Airport authorities, when queried about the delay cited action taken by technical officers and trade unions as contributing factors. He assured passengers that efforts were underway to secure an alternative aircraft for the affected flight. Meanwhile, another flight which was bound for Mumbai, in India in the morning, had also been cancelled due to a technical issue with the aircraft. Following the cancellations passengers for the two flights were directed to hotels, an airline spokesman said. Moreover, it is reported that other flights scheduled to arrive at BIA from destinations such as Trivandrum in India, Male in the Maldives, Chennai in India, Dhaka in Bangladesh, and Narita in Japan also experienced delays. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Amber, yellow landslide warnings issued for seven districts
author: Author not found
Content: Amidst the inclement weather conditions prevailing in the region, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has issued both, level two amber ‘watch landslide early warning alerts’ and level one yellow ‘watch landslide early warning alerts’ to 30 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and their surrounding areas in seven districts across the country. Dr. K.G.P. Wasantha Senadeera, Senior Scientist at the Landslides Early Warning Centre (LSEWC), has provided details of these alerts. Level two amber alerts have been issued for specific regions, including Neluwa DS Division and its surroundings in the Galle District, Ingiriya DS Division and its surroundings in the Kalutara District, Pasgoda Korale DS Division and its surroundings in the Kandy District and Kotapola and Pitabeddara DS divisions along with their surroundings in the Matara District. Additionally, Kalawana, Ayagama, Eheliyagoda, Ratnapura, Kuruwita, Pelmadulla, Nivithigala, Kiriella and Elapatha DS divisions and their surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District are also under the level two alert. Furthermore, level one yellow alerts have been issued for the following areas: Elpitiya DS Division and its surroundings in the Galle District, Walasmulla DS Division and its surroundings in the Hambantota District, Mathugama, Walallawita, Bulathsinhala and Agalawatta DS divisions and their surroundings in the Kalutara District, Yatiyanthota, Ruwanwella, Deraniyagala and Dehiowita DS divisions and their surroundings in the Kegalle District, Mulatiyana and Athuraliya DS Division and their surroundings in the Matara District, Yatawatta DS Division and its surroundings in the Matale District, and Imbulpe and Kolonna DS divisions and their surroundings in the Ratnapura District. Residents in hilly areas, experiencing heavy rainfall, are strongly advised to remain vigilant and exercise caution. In the event that any signs of landslides are detected, such as slanting trees, light and telephone poles, the sudden emergence of muddy water from springs in the Highlands, cracks in the walls and floors of residential buildings and other structures, or cracks in the ground in neighbouring areas, individuals are urged to promptly inform the relevant authorities, including the Police and the Disaster Management Centre (DMC), and evacuate to safe locations as necessary. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sinopac increases fuel prices
author: Author not found
Content: Sinopac Energy Lanka (Pvt) Ltd yesterday (1) announced a fuel price hike that came into effect at 6:00 p.m. on the same day. Accordingly, a litre of Petrol 95 Octane was increased by Rs 6 and Auto Diesal was increased by Rs 10. Super Diesel was increased by a massive Rs 61. The price of a litre of Petrol 92 Octane remained unchanged. New prices would be Petrol 95 Octane Rs 420 per litre, Auto Diesel Rs 348 and Super Diesel Rs 417. Meanwhile, it is expected that both CEYPETCO and Lanka Indian Oil Compay (LIOC) will revise fuel prices today (2), in accordance with the established pricing formula. The Ministry of Power and Energy has indicated that the updated fuel prices will be officially disclosed on the same day. During the previous month’s price adjustment, the CEYPETCO raised fuel prices significantly in adherence to the pricing formula. Simultaneously, the Litro Gas Company has announced that it will reveal the revised prices for domestic gas cylinders on Wednesday (4). It is reported that domestic gas cylinder prices are likely to see an increase in response to the prevailing global market rates during this forthcoming price adjustment.

title: Indian dies after falling into water boiler
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic incident an Indian national lost his life after falling into a water boiler situated within a private factory in the Meegama, Welipenna, according to the Police. The victim, identified as a 34-year-old Indian national J. Rajbhai, was employed at the factory. He accidentally tumbled into the hot water boiler, leading to severe injuries. The incident had occurred on 30 September. Following the accident, Rajbhai was transported to the Colombo National Hospital for urgent medical attention. Despite medical efforts, the 34-year-old succumbed to injuries while undergoing treatment.

title: Inclement weather affects nearly 5,000
author: Author not found
Content: Over 5,000 individuals, from nearly 1,300 families, have been adversely affected and 316 houses have been damaged due to the challenging weather conditions, according to the Disaster Management Centre (DMC). The DMC said a total of 5,051 individuals from 1,275 families have been affected by the adverse weather. The water level in Kuda Ganga, a tributary of the Kalu Ganga, has surpassed the ‘flood level’ in Millakanda. The designated high flood level at the Millakanda gauge was eight metres, at approximately 3.00 a.m. yesterday (1) a measurement of 8.68 metres was recorded. The Department of Irrigation has issued a caution regarding the Kalu Ganga in Putupaula, which is currently at a minor flood level. Similarly, the Gin River has exceeded the minor flood level in Baddegama, and Nilwala River in Panadugama and Thalgahagoda is also at a minor flood level. Furthermore, the Attanagalu Oya has surpassed the minor flood level. S.P.C. Sugeeshwara, Director of Irrigation at the Hydrology and Disaster Management Division of the Irrigation Department, has advised people in these areas to remain vigilant.

title: COYLE delegation strengthens business ties in Indonesia
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation of 16 dynamic entrepreneurs, representing the Chamber of Young Lankan Entrepreneurs, undertook a significant journey to Jakarta, Indonesia from 19 – 24 September 2023. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jakarta facilitated the delegation, which is aiming to foster economic collaboration, allowing them to explore opportunities with the Indonesian business community.  On 21 September 2023, the delegation had the privilege to visit the Permanent Trade Exhibition at the Ministry of Trade of the Republic of Indonesia. This was followed by a fruitful B2B discussion with a prominent pharmaceutical sector company in Indonesia setting the stage for potential partnerships.  On 22 September 2023, a business gathering was organised by the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jakarta at the embassy premises. The event was attended by more than 70 enthusiastic Indonesians from the business community representing key associations such as KADIN (Indonesia Chamber of Commerce and Industry), HIPMI (Indonesian Young Entrepreneurs Association), APINDO (Indonesian Entrepreneurs Association), and GAPMMI (Indonesian Food and Beverage Producers Association). Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Indonesia and ASEAN Admiral Prof. Jayanath Colombage addressed the business gathering giving an in-depth background of business opportunities for both countries. He highlighted that Indonesia is a country of opportunities for those who aspire to link up with the business world with special reference to the growing middle class and the gigantic market. In Indonesia, there are nearly 229.9 million people which is about 88% of the total population, who like to spend money on traveling and shopping.  The Chamber of Young Lankan Entrepreneurs presented a comprehensive overview of business opportunities to their Indonesian counterparts. The event was a resounding success as Indonesian business leaders warmly received the proposals, paving the way for future collaborations and fruitful partnerships. This exchange underscored the potential for mutually beneficial economic ties between Sri Lanka and Indonesia.

title: Safeguard children’s rights in society – Premier
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena expressed the Government’s commitment to create a brighter future for children and ensure their protection and happiness. He said there was a greater need for additional protection and support to strengthen measures to safeguard children’s rights in society. The Prime Minister also spoke of the importance of removing any legal obstacles that hinder children’s enjoyment of their rights. The Ministry of Women and Child Affairs celebrated World Children’s Day, yesterday (1) at Temple Trees. Premier Dinesh Gunawardena and State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe were present. “The private sector has made significant contributions to benefit children, and I am thankful for that,” the Premier said, acknowledging the private sector’s role in supporting children’s welfare. Highlighting the government’s responsibility to make decisions on behalf of approximately five million children, the Prime Minister emphasised the importance of addressing issues such as school dropouts and actively supporting efforts to strengthen child protection laws. He also proposed the construction of a children’s cinema, underscoring the government’s commitment to expanding avenues for children’s satisfaction. State Minister Geetha Kumarasinghe reaffirmed the Government’s dedication to protect and support children every day of the year. She said the need for increased attention to preschool education, indicating positive changes in Sri Lanka’s preschool system. Addressing the challenges faced by schoolgirls, Kumarasinghe called for affordable access to sanitary napkins through the Department of Education and advocated for vocational training opportunities for children in orphanages, ensuring their continued support beyond the age of 18. World Children’s Day celebration featured various activities, including the issuing of a Children’s Day stamp, children’s programmes, evaluations, certificate awards, and gifts. The event was attended by State Minister Shantha Bandara, Parliamentarian Jagath Kumara, Ministry Secretaries, heads of government and non-governmental institutions, local and foreign representatives, as well as a large gathering of children.

title: Embrace innovation, inclusivity – Jeevan
author: Author not found
Content: Minister Jeevan Thondaman, in a landmark address at the International Labour Organization’s (ILO) South Asia Trade Union Symposium, called upon South Asian trade unions to embrace innovation and inclusivity. The Minister’s compelling speech highlighted the pressing challenges and opportunities facing trade unions in the ever-evolving landscape of work. Minister Thondaman acknowledged the historical significance of trade unions in advocating for workers’ rights, fair wages, and safe working conditions. However, he said challenges confronting today’s workforce are unprecedented, driven by automation, artificial intelligence, and the gig economy, necessitating innovative adaptation by trade unions. A key highlight of Minister Thondaman’s speech was his impassioned call for South Asian trade unions to harness the power of technology to empower workers. He emphasised that they “must leverage technology to connect with workers across various sectors, ensuring their voices are heard.” Further, the Minister stressed that achieving diversity and inclusivity within trade unions themselves is essential to represent the diverse workforce of the region effectively. He reiterated that trade unions “should strive for diversity and inclusivity within” to stand up for the rights of all workers, regardless of their background or occupation. Minister Thondaman also recognised the global nature of the economy and emphasised the need for collaboration and solidarity among trade unions across borders. He called for trade unions to work together across borders and industries to “create a stronger, more unified voice for workers’ rights on the global stage.” The Minister’s words resonate as a call to unite and amplify the collective power of workers worldwide. Addressing specific concerns in Sri Lanka, Minister Thondaman touched on issues faced by tea estate workers, many of whom have been impacted by the lack of adequate legal protection. He also acknowledged the lack of protection for South Asian migrant labour, highlighting the pressing need for action and reform. Minister Thondaman stressed the need to address the skills gap among young workers. He asserted the skills shortage among young individuals and the importance of investing in education and training to empower the workforce of the future.

title: Police probe death threat to woman
author: Author not found
Content: The Police recently informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera that they have launched a probe into an incident, where a woman had been threatened with death, by a group of unidentified persons wearing full face helmets, who arrived on motorcycles. The Police told the Court, that they had begun the inquiry into the incident, based on a complaint lodged, by K. Don Wasana Asirini, a resident of Kotikawatta. The Police added that initial inquiries conducted into the incident, had revealed that the unidentified group, had threatened her, saying that if there had not been many around, she would have been killed, then and there. The Police told the Additional Magistrate, that the plaintiff, having separated from her husband, continue to live alone with her daughter and that in her complaint, she had further mentioned that previously too, a group of masked persons had issued death threats to her and her child. According to the Police, the incident, had taken place around 7.10 p.m. on 28 July.   BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Book on ‘Sensitive News Reporting’ launched
author: Author not found
Content: A recent presentation at the Sri Palee Campus of Colombo University saw the launch of the book titled ‘Principles of Sensitive News Reporting in a Competitive Media Practice.’ The book, compiled by media personality Anuradha Nilmini, was presented to Professor Tudor Weerasinghe. ‘Principles of Sensitive News Reporting in a Competitive Media Practice’ is expected to be a valuable resource for a wide audience, including journalists involved in media reporting, university students pursuing Journalism and Mass Communication studies, as well as students engaged in Communication and Media Studies at the school level. The book is available at the International Book Fair at the BMICH. This book is published by Fast Publishing Private Limited.

title: AMS calls for uninterrupted service of SLMC members during five-year term
author: Author not found
Content: In a recent statement, the Association of Medical Specialists (AMS) expressed concern about the independence of the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC), a statutory institution tasked with upholding the standards and ethical practices of registered health professionals. The AMS called for the uninterrupted service of SLMC members during their full five-year term to ensure the council’s independence and efficiency. The AMS highlighted past instances where members of the SLMC, including a President, were removed from their positions prematurely, leading to ongoing legal disputes. While refraining from commenting on the Minister’s power to remove members before their term ends, the AMS emphasised the adverse consequences of such actions. One such removal that drew attention was that of Professor Jayantha Jayawardena, who was terminated within less than a year of his appointment, despite being expected to serve a full five-year term. Prof. Jayawardena, who had a distinguished career as a medical academic, had made significant contributions to the SLMC during his tenure. He held various key positions within the council, including Vice President and Chairman of several committees. The AMS warned that frequent turnover of SLMC members, especially those holding crucial positions, could disrupt its operations, leading to delays in decision-making and potentially compromising its independence. It further stressed that members might withhold their views due to uncertainty about their positions within the council. The AMS also raised concerns about the removal of Prof. Jayawardena, who had recently exposed significant payments made from SLMC funds to certain parties. It called for impartial inquiries into allegations against appointed members rather than abrupt terminations without due process, emphasizing the importance of adhering to principles of natural justice. In a letter to Prof. Jayawardena, it was stated that restructuring of the SLMC was planned. The AMS questioned why he was singled out for termination when other appointees, including the President of the SLMC, remained in their positions. The AMS firmly opposed any attempts to compromise the independence and autonomy of the Sri Lanka Medical Council, especially at a time when the country’s healthcare system is facing challenges such as medication shortages, quality issues with drugs, and a scarcity of healthcare professionals.
