title: Six Jumbos Killed by Trains in 36 Hours
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, six elephants, including four juveniles below the age of five, died in two train accidents which occurred within a period of 36 hours, up to 12:00 midnight on Wednesday (27). The elephants died in Galgamuwa and Habarana after colliding with the Colombo-Kankesanthurai train and the Colombo-Batticaloa train, respectively. The first incident occurred around midnight, where a night mail train travelling from Colombo to Kankesanthurai collided with four elephants near Galgamuwa. Additionally, in a separate incident that took place at approximately 12:30 a.m. yesterday, a female tusker and an elephant calf collided with the ‘Meenagaya’ train on its journey from Batticaloa to Colombo. Regrettably, the elephant calf succumbed to its injuries immediately following the collision, while the injured female tusker passed away later in the day. The local wildlife authorities from the Galgamuwa and Ritigala Wildlife Offices were conducting investigations to gain further insights into these distressing incidents. The Department of Wildlife Conservation (DWC), in response to questions regarding elephant deaths caused by train collisions, explained their collaborative efforts with the Ministry for Wildlife and Forest Reserve Conservation and Sri Lanka Railways. This cooperation was initiated after a similar collision in 2008 resulted in the tragic deaths of four elephants in Galgamuwa. To prevent such accidents, various measures have been proposed, including widening the clearing area on both sides of railway lines, avoiding the use of horns, reducing train speeds in elephant corridors and forested areas, and constructing underground passes. These collisions tend to occur more frequently during times when elephants venture out of the forests in search of harvested crops, particularly in proximity to the paddy harvesting season, a senior official at the department said. Despite some initiatives, such as a text message alert system for train drivers to be notified of elephant movements, being in place under the auspices of Sri Lanka Railways since last year, it has become defunct due to the ongoing economic crisis. Meanwhile, Hemantha Withanage, the Executive Director at the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ), expressed concerns that many of the proposed mitigation plans have either not been implemented or have been abandoned. He suggested that an elevated railway track on pillars, which wouldn’t obstruct train or elephant movements, would be the most effective solution. According to Withanage, the high number of elephant casualties in train collisions is primarily due to reckless conduct by train operators and he criticised the Railways Department for not maintaining consistency in prioritising a solution to this problem, particularly in relation to initiatives like the text alert system. In response to these challenges, Minister for Transport and Highways, Bandula Gunawardena, requested the public to report elephant sightings near railway tracks by calling the hotline 1971. However, when tested by Ceylon Today, the response was unsatisfactory, as the call was redirected to contact the relevant railway station. Ceylon Today also attempted to reach out to both Minister Bandula Gunawardena and Minister Pavithra Wanniarachchi, who is responsible for Wildlife and Forest Reserve Conservation. Unfortunately, both ministers were unavailable for comment on the steps taken to prevent elephant-train collisions, emphasising the urgency of addressing this critical issue. According to the government data, between 2019 and 2022 there have been 1,549 elephant deaths in Sri Lanka, with at least one elephant death recorded on an average during the first quarter of 2023. (Pic by Social media) By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: A/L exam final schedule out on Monday
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education expects to reveal the final date for the G.C.E. Advanced Level (A/L) Examination 2023 in the first week of October. According to Nihal Ranasinghe, the Secretary to the Ministry of Education, the official announcement regarding the examination schedule will be made by 2 October. This decision follows the recent announcement by Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha in Parliament that the originally scheduled A/L examination days would be postponed. The revised examination dates will be communicated by the Commissioner General of Examinations. Initially planned to be held from 27 November to 2 December, the postponement came about in response to requests from both ruling and opposition MPs, who expressed concerns about students having insufficient time to prepare for the examinations.

title: Mullaitivu District Judge Saravanaraja resigns
author: Author not found
Content: Mullaitivu District Judge T. Saravanaraja has resigned from his judicial posts, citing life threats, pressures, and harassment. It is speculated that Judge Saravanaraja’s resignation citing life threats is a part of a concerted effort to claim asylum in a foreign country. In his resignation letter to the Secretary of the Judicial Services Commission on 23 September 2023, the judge has said he would resign from the post of District Judge, post of Magistrate, post of Family Court Judge, post of primary court Judge, post of small claims court Judge and post of juvenile court Judge. He claimed that his decision to resign came following threats to his life and pressure. The Judge did not mention any particular reason for the alleged threats in his resignation letter.

title: SL needs USD 26.5B to ensure climate initiatives succeed – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, speaking at the ‘Berlin Global Dialogue’, emphasised the significant financial requirements Sri Lankafaces in achieving its climate prosperity plan, saying that the country needs USD 26.5 billion by 2030 for the successful implementation of its climate initiatives. In his address, President Wickremesinghe highlighted the dual challenges of climate change mitigation and debt restructuring that the country must navigate, all while having limited funds at its disposal. He drew attention to the tumultuous nature of the global economy over the past two decades, which included crises like the European debt crisis, the Covid-19 pandemic, economic shocks stemming from it and the pressing issue of climate change funding alongside sovereign debt concerns. President Wickremesinghe noted, “I don’t think we have gone through this type of crisis in any other period of modern history. And, in all these instances, it is the developing economies and the Global South that has suffered disproportionately.” The President underscored current economic challenges, such as high inflation in advanced economies, rising oil prices nearing USD 100 per barrel and global Central Banks tightening their monetary policies. He cited the lack of growth in Sri Lanka’s exports to Europe this year as a clear indication of the challenges the country faces during its recovery. He also highlighted the disparity between advanced economies and developing nations in terms of financial buffers and reserves to deal with shocks, emphasising that the latter typically lacks such resources. This disparity often leads to sovereign debt crises, as it did in Sri Lanka. In this context, President Wickremesinghe cautioned that the world may be on the brink of another crisis if immediate corrective measures are not taken. Regarding the debt restructuring efforts, he mentioned that Sri Lanka has been in positive discussions with China and needs to engage with the Paris Club and India once again. President Wickremesinghe concluded by highlighting the importance of international cooperation and financing to address the pressing challenges, particularly for developing countries. He commended Germany for its contributions to the Green Climate Fund and stressed the urgency of addressing climate change and debt restructuring with the limited available resources. He stated, “The funding on the table is woefully inadequate to address the vast challenges at hand. So, we haven’t got any money, but we do have USD 100 billion with the IMF. Let’s start with that money. USD 100 billion is better than nothing. Then let’s see how we can raise the rest of it.” President Wickremesinghe also expressed concern for the greater financing needs of African countries, particularly those with lower incomes, highlighting their unique challenges and requirements.

title: SriLankan flight delays due to insufficient aircraft
author: Author not found
Content: Ongoing delays in SriLankan Airlines flights are primarily due to the insufficient number of aircraft in the possession of SriLankan Airlines, a spokesperson for the airline revealed. The spokesperson further said while the airline requires 24 aircraft for its daily flight operations, only 20 were currently available for active service. Additionally, A330 and A320 aircrafts have been allocated for long-term essential maintenance, and another two A-320 aircrafts of Neo Air Group are temporarily grounded until they receive new engines from Airbus in France. Furthermore, the spokesperson disclosed that approximately 30 employees from the SriLankan engineering department have left their positions to join foreign airlines. Nevertheless, the remaining staff members are committed to covering the essential workload. As a consequence of these challenges, flights scheduled to depart from Katunayake Airport to Lahore in Pakistan, Chennai in India, and Dhaka in Bangladesh experienced delays, he said. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Breast cancer accounts for 26% of all cancer cases – Dr Ishani
author: Author not found
Content: Twenty-six per cent of cancer patients, detected in Sri Lanka, are those with breast cancers, said National Cancer Control Programme Director Dr. Ishani Fernando. She noted that a total 5,329 new patients with breast cancer were detected in 2020. Of them 147 were men. She added that 25% of the cancer patients detected in the world too suffer from breast cancer. She said that a total 37,648 new cancer patients had been detected in 2020 while 15,599 patients had died of cancer in 2019. When 27 new patients were detected with cancer for every 100,000 persons, at least 11 of them succumb to the deadly disease, she said. Comparing  Sri Lanka’s statistics with the United States, she said that if 90% of new cancer cases were detected for every 100,000 persons in that country, only 12 of them died of it. She noted that those within the age group of 65 to 70 years were highly vulnerable to breast cancer. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: DWC opens two off-season routes to Sripada
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Wildlife Conservation (DWC) has officially announced the opening of the Ratnapura and Nallathanni routes for pilgrims who wish to climb Sripada during the off-season. Ticket counters have been established at two designated locations, one at the former Pawanella Police Checkpoint for the Ratnapura Route and another at the Nallathanni Wildlife Security Office for the Nallathanni Route. These ticket counters will operate from 6.00 p.m. until 10.00 a.m. the following morning according to the department. Additionally, the department has issued a warning, alerting pilgrims to the presence of Wildlife Officers who will be monitoring the Sripada Reserve to ensure compliance. In contrast, the Kuruwita, Dehenakanda and Marigoda Routes to the Sri Pada Reserve will remain closed during the off-season. It is strictly prohibited to access the reserve through these routes during this period, emphasised the Wildlife Department. The department also informed the public that, in accordance with the Fauna and Flora Protection Ordinance, legal action will be taken against individuals who enter the Sri Pada Reserve without purchasing tickets.

title: Shooting injures 47-year-old
author: Author not found
Content: A man sustained injuries as a result of a shooting in Meetiyagoda, Ambalangoda, yesterday (28) morning. According to the Police, the victim, a 47-year-old resident of Paniyana, Ambalangoda, was riding a motorcycle, on the Ambalangoda-Meetiyagoda road, when two unidentified assailants on a motorcycle opened fire at him. The victim is the younger brother of Vipula Priyantha known as ‘Palathuru Priyantha’ who was killed some time ago. The injured individual is currently receiving medical treatment at the Balapitiya Base Hospital. The motive behind the shooting remains unknown.  Meetiyagoda Police have launched an investigation to arrest the two assailants. BY S. Deeyagahage – Ahangama

title: Vehicle import ban to be further revised
author: Author not found
Content: Acting Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said the circular, which previously relaxed import restrictions, particularly for buses and lorries used in public transport, will undergo further revisions in the coming days. Speaking to the media following an event held in the Dehiowita on Wednesday (27), Siyambalapitiya explained that the earlier revision had allowed the importation of 10-year-old vehicles by lifting restrictions on buses and trucks used for public transportation services. However, based on insights provided by industry experts, it became evident that despite the lower initial prices of these 10-year-old vehicles, their maintenance, spare parts, and fuel costs are comparatively high as a result, there is a need for a reconsideration of this policy. He clarified that those who have already initiated the process by issuing Letters of Credit (LCs) during the validity period of the previous circular, which was until 14 September, will still be allowed to import vehicles in accordance with the existing regulations. Furthermore, he pointed out that a new circular would be promptly issued to ensure that it comes into effect at an appropriate time for the importation of buses and trucks into Sri Lanka, without incurring unnecessary maintenance, spare parts and fuel costs. Minister of State for Finance Dr. Ranjith Siyambalapitiya says that in the next few days, the circular that was issued relaxing the import restrictions especially for buses and lorries used for public transport will be revised again. The Minister stated this, while speaking to the media after a programme held in Dehiowita area yesterday evening. Speaking there, the minister said, by removing the import restrictions imposed on buses and trucks used for public transport services, the import of 10-year-old vehicles was allowed. But according to the facts presented by the experts in the field, although the prices of 10-year-old vehicles are low, the cost of maintenance, the cost of spare parts and the cost of fuel are relatively high so, the minister said that it had to be reconsidered. However, the minister said, since the previously issued circular was valid until the 14th, those who have issued letters of credit during that period will be allowed to import vehicles according to the existing circular. Also, the Minister emphasised that the new circular will be issued very quickly so, that it will be effective at a suitable time for the import of buses and trucks to Sri Lanka without incurring unnecessary maintenance costs, unnecessary spare parts costs and unnecessary fuel costs. BY Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: Met Dept issues rainfall Amber alert
author: Author not found
Content: Following reports of rainfall exceeding 100mm in specific regions of the island, the Department of Meteorology has issued an Amber Alert for the Western and Sabaragamuwa Provinces, as well as parts of the Galle and Matara Districts. This alert aims to caution residents about potential landslides and flooding. Due to active Southwest Monsoon conditions prevailing over the island, the Department of Meteorology anticipates that the ongoing showery weather in the southwestern part of the island will persist. The Irrigation Department has indicated that the high rainfall in certain areas of the upstream and middle catchment zones of the Nilwala River Basin could lead to a flood risk in the Nilwala River Valley, affecting Kotapola, Pitabeddara, Akuressa, Pasgoda, Athuraliya, Malimbada, Thihagoda, Matara, and Devinuwara DS Divisions. There is also a similar potential for flooding in the low-lying areas of the Kuda Ganga Valley in Palinda Nuwara and Bulathsinhala DS Divisions. The Irrigation Department has urged local residents and commuters in these areas to take extra precautions. The Director of Irrigation (Hydrology and Disaster Management) stated that sluice gates at the Kukule Ganga Dam have been opened due to rising water levels, in the Kukule Ganga Reservoir following heavy rainfall over the past 24 hours. Due to active Southwest Monsoon conditions over the island, the department further stated that the prevailing showery condition in South-Western part of the Island is likely to continue further. The Irrigation Department has stated that due to high rainfall that has been occurring in certain parts of the upstream and middle catchment areas of Nilwala River Basin there is a possibility of a flood situation in the Nilwala River Valley in Kotapola, Pitabeddara, Akuressa, Pasgoda, Athuraliya, Malimbada, Thihagoda, Matara and Devinuwara DS Divisions. With a similar possibility in flooding in the low line areas of Kuda Ganga Valley in Palinda Nuwara and Bulathsinhala DS Divisions, the Irrigation Department has requested local residents and commuters through these areas to take extra precautions. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Director of Irrigation (Hydrology and & Disaster Management) said, sluice gates of the Kukule Ganga Dam has been opened due to the increase of water levels in the Kukule Ganga Reservoir following heavy showers since Wednesday (27). (Pic by Amila Gamage) By Buwanaka S. Perera

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Ischemic heart disease affecting even youths – Medical expert
author: Author not found
Content: Ischemic heart disease (coronary artery disease) accounted for 52 per cent of the deaths that occurred in State hospitals in 2020, while it was the main cause of death in State hospitals from 2010 to 2020, according to Dr. Sherine Balasingham, Consultant Community Physician of the Health Ministry’s Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs) division. Dr. Balasingham yesterday (28) said, cerebrovascular disease had taken fifth place as the cause of death in government hospitals in 2020. In 2021, that had changed as Covid-19 had taken precedence while ischemic heart disease took second place that year. A concerned Consultant Community Physician noted that in 2020 there had been a marked significance in the increase of ischemic heart disease (IHD) amongst teenagers and adults, between the age group of 17 to 49.  Medical statistics shows that in 2021 a considerable number of young persons (both men and women) in the age groups of 18 to 27 and 29 to 39 have been admitted to hospitals and died due to IHD. “It has come to a point where we as parents would have to lament the death of our children due to NCDs like IHD or cerebrovascular disease even before us,” she observed.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Firearms licences renewal begins on 1 Oct
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Defence yesterday (28) made an announcement on the renewal of firearms licences for both individuals and institutions for the year 2024. According to the announcement, the renewal of firearm licences will be accepted from 1 October 2023 to 31 December 2023. Detailed information and application forms can be obtained from the official website of the Defence Ministry (www.defence.lk). The Defence Ministry emphasised that renewals for firearm licences for the year 2024 will not be processed after 31 December 2023. It is crucial to be aware that possessing a firearm without a valid licence is a punishable offence, as specified in Section 22 of the Firearms Ordinance. In addition to firearm licence renewals, private security firms are also required to renew their registrations for the Year 2024/2025. The renewal period for these firms is set from 1 October 2023 to 31 December 2023. Any renewals submitted after the specified deadline may be subject to fines or legal action, the Defence Ministry said.

title: NBRO declares 29 DS Divisions landslide prone
author: Author not found
Content: Along with the prevailing inclement weather conditions, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has declared 29 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and the surrounding areas, across six districts in the country, to be landslide prone areas by issuing them level two amber-watch and level one yellow-watch landslide early warning alerts. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Senior Scientist of Landslide Early Warning Centre of the NBRO Dr. K. G. P. Wasantha Senadeera said, the Galle, Kalutara, Kandy, Matara, Ratnapura, Hambantota and Kegalle Districts are among them. Dr. Senadeera said, level two amber-watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Neluwa DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Galle District, Ingiriya DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Pasgoda Korale DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kandy District, Kotapola and Pitabeddara DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matara District and Ayagama, Pelmadulla, Kuruwita, Kalawana, Eheliyagoda and Kiriella, Elapatha, Ratnapura and Nivithigala DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. Dr. Senadeera added that level one yellow-watch landslide early warnings have been issued to Elpitiya DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Galle District, Walasmulla DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Hambantota District, Walallawita, Agalawatta, Matugama and Bulathsinhala DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Ruwanwella, Kegalle, Dehiowita, Deraniyagala and Yatiyantota DS Divisions and the neighbouring areas in the Kegalle District, Mulatiyana and Athuraliya DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matara District and Imbulpe and Kolonna DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District. The people living in the hilly areas where heavy rainfalls occur have been advised to exercise caution and if they noticed any landslide signs, in particular leaning of trees, light and telephone posts, appearance of sudden muddy water and springs from the highlands and in the close proximity, sudden cracks on the walls and floor of residential buildings and other structures and on the ground in the neighbouring areas have been asked to move towards safe places after informing the relevant authorities including the nearby Police Station and the Disaster Management (DMC) Regional Office, Dr. Senadeera added.   By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Govt obligated toprotect Buddhism
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake said the government is obligated to protect Buddhism in accordance with the Constitution. He also mentioned that, following the instructions of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, steps have already been taken to provide necessary facilities to students studying history, doctors and professors. Additionally, efforts are being made to establish a centre for the study of Sri Lankan history. Ekanayake expressed these thoughts while attending the presentation ceremony of scroll memorandums related to areas declared as ‘Pujabhumi’ by the National Physical Planning Department through the Gazette. This ceremony took place on Wednesday (27) at the Presidential Secretariat. During the event, Ekanayake presented the ‘Pujabhumi’ scroll memorandums for five temples and a Devalaya with archaeological, historical, and sacred significance. He also urged the venerable Maha Sangha to respect the right to practise other religions freely and not to be influenced by efforts to create religious conflicts in the country. The scroll memorandum declaring the Welgama Rajamaha Vihara as a ‘sacred site’ was presented to the Chief Incumbent Ven. Ampitiye Seelawansa Tissa Nayaka Thera. The scroll memorandum for declaring the Meegammana Rajamaha Viharaya, located in the Meegammana village of Pathadumbara valley, as a ‘sacred site’, was presented to the chief incumbent of the temple, Ven. Maninggamuwe Wimala Keerthi Sri Sumanajothi Piyarathana Thera. Furthermore, the scroll memorandum declaring the Gangodawila Sri Vijayarama Rajamaha Viharaya in Kolomthota Gangodawila village as a ‘sacred site’ was presented to Saddharma Keerthi Sri Ven. Amunumulle Jinarathana Thera. The Papiliyana Sunethra Mahadevi Piriwen Rajamaha Viharaya received the scroll memorandum declaring it a ‘sacred site’, which was presented to the Chief Incumbent Venerable Prof. Medagoda Abhayatissa Thera. Lastly, the scroll memorandum declaring the Minneriya Mahasen Rajamaha Viharaya as a ‘sacred site’ was presented to Ven. Matale Udugama Saddhananda Thera, the Chief Incumbent of the temple. The scroll memorandum declaring the Medagoda Sri Siddha Sath Pattini Devlaya in Ruwanwella as a ‘sacred site’ was handed over to the guardian of the Devalaya, Ajith Shanta Bandara. This event was attended by the Maha Sangha, including Former Vice-Chancellor of the Pali and Buddhist University, Vice-Chief Sanghanayaka of the Southern Sri Lankan sector of the Malwathu Chapter Ven. Prof. Ittademaliye Indrasara Nayaka Thera, Ven. Attangane Rathanasara Thera, Chief Registrar of the Sri Lanka Ramagngna Chapter, Chief Prelate to Russia Ven. Prof. Pallekande Rathanasara Thera, Former Chief Registrar of the Amarapura Chapter, and the acting Mahanayaka of the Wajirawansha sector of the Amarapura Chapter. Also present were Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickremenayake, Secretary to the Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs, Somarathna Vidanapathirana, Secretary to the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing, S. Sathyananda, and other government officials.

title: Leadership Development Seminar 11.O concludes successfully
author: Author not found
Content: The Annual Leadership Development Seminar 11.0, organised by AIESEC in Colombo Central, of the University of Colombo took place on 26 and 27 August 2023 at the Berjaya Hotel Colombo with over 120 participants. Being an affiliated member chapter of AIESEC in Sri Lanka, AIESEC in Colombo Central aims to build aspiring leaders who work towards peace and fulfilment of humankind and unleashing true leadership potential through transformative experiences, and the Leadership Development Seminar 11.0 is a dynamic and exceptional milestone in this endeavour. With a focus on dynamic leadership, the seminar featured a range of engagement and outbound sessions designed to strengthen bonds between AIESECers and foster personal growth. Delegates took part in engaging activities that emphasise teamwork, communication and problem solving, – vital skills for any aspiring leader. The seminar’s unique blend of interactive sessions and delegate engagement provided a platform for attendees to learn from experienced mentors, share insights with their peers, and form lasting connections. Participants also had the opportunity to gain valuable insights into leadership styles, effective decision-making, and adaptability – qualities essential in today’s dynamic world. As AIESEC continues to empower young individuals to create positive change in their communities and beyond, the University of Colombo’s leadership development seminar stands as a testament to the organisation’s commitment to nurturing the leaders of tomorrow.

title: Five arrested with gold, jewellery worth over Rs 120M
author: Author not found
Content: The Narcotics Control Unit of Sri Lanka Customs arrested five passengers on their arrival at the BIA on 27 September, while they were attempting to smuggle a significant quantity of gold biscuits and jewellery into the country. The group comprised four women and one man, arriving in Sri Lanka from Dubai on two separate flights. A total of 6 kg of gold biscuits and jewellery, with an estimated value of approximately Rs 123 million, were confiscated by Sri Lanka Customs. Sri Lanka Customs said three of the arrested women and the man arrived in Sri Lanka at around 1:10 a.m. on a flydubai flight. The other woman arrived at the BIA at approximately 5:25 a.m. on a SriLankan Airlines flight. On inspection, Sri Lanka Customs officers found the concealed stock of gold biscuits and jewellery on their person and among the hand luggage they were carrying. All of the suspects are residents of Colombo, engaged in business activities, and frequent air travellers. By T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: World Tourism Day marked at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Marking World Tourism Day on Wednesday (27), Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Limited together with the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau and Ceylon Tea Board welcomed travellers at the BIA. Tourists were welcomed by offering lotus flowers, showcasing Sri Lankan warmth and hospitality.  The Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau offered Sri Lankan traditional sweet packs along with valuable gift packs. Sunshine Holdings, representing the Ceylon Tea Board, made arrangements to serve refreshing iced tea and Ceylon tea gift packs, promoting Ceylon tea brands among tourists too. It was encouraging to see tourists participating in the celebration, and the event helped to create a positive first impression about Sri Lanka. At the same time, on 26 September (Tuesday), Sri Lanka marked the arrival of the one-millionth tourist, and the country witnessed remarkable growth in the Sri Lankan tourism industry compared to last year. (SRM)

title: Early childhood education compulsory for four-year-olds
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha recently announced the mandatory introduction of early childhood education for all four-year-old children. The minister said the Government has pledged to provide support for children who may face financial constraints in accessing early childhood education. “To facilitate this initiative, early childhood development centres may also be set up within primary schools where suitable space is available. This multifaceted approach not only ensures accessibility but also addresses the challenges faced by schools at risk of closure,” he added. Premajayantha stressed the importance of formal early childhood development in the transformative reform of the country’s education system. He recognised that this represents a foundational step towards achieving success in educational reforms. Minister Premajayantha made these remarks while participating in a programme titled ‘Suwa Diviyai Sathutu Sithai’ in Battaramulla, organised as part of School Health Promotion Month.

title: World Tourism Day celebrated in Kalutara
author: Author not found
Content: World Tourism Day was celebrated on Wednesday (27) and a special programme was organised for foreign tourists in Kalutara. Nearly fifty foreign tourists participated in this event, where they were able to learn about and explore local religious shrines, including the Kalutara Bodhiya, Holy Cross Church, and the Kathirvelayudha Swamy Kovil as well as the traditional pottery and textile shops. The programme was successfully organised by the management team of Royal Palm Hotel, Kalutara led by hotel Manager Ravi Kurukulasuriya. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: SL will face new challenges in digitalisation – Chung
author: Author not found
Content: US Ambassador Julie Chung said Sri Lanka will have to face special challenges in digitalisation, using new technology and more attention should be paid to protect the security of data. She added that the United States is working to provide the necessary technology, in the process of modernising Sri Lanka’s Naval and aviation sectors. The Ambassador revealed this when she met Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, at the office of the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation in the afternoon of 27 September.  The Ambassador praised the current government’s programme to expand Sri Lanka’s shipping and aviation sector and said that American investment opportunities will be provided to Sri Lanka. Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva said, “The new policies necessary for the development of Sri Lanka’s shipping and aviation sector, in a manner suitable for the future, have been made under the guidance of President Ranil Wickremesinghe and through this, the sector will be maintained without burdening the government.” Also, the minister said that there are many investment opportunities in Sri Lanka’s shipping and aviation sector and that he would invite American investors for that. The discussion was attended by American Embassy officials, Dustin R. Bickel and Daniel Moon, Thiloma Abeynayake, Additional Secretary of the Ministry Nayana Somaratne, Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority G.  S.  Vithanage, Director General P.A. Jayakantha, Chairman of the Airport and Aviation Services Limited retired Major General G.  Chandrasiri and Chairman of the Ports Authority Keith Barnard participated.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 400 children killed in road accidents in 2022
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMA) representative Prof. Samath Dharmaratne made a shocking revelation yesterday (27) that lives of 400 children were lost in 2022 alone due to road accidents. He lamented that if appropriate measures were not put in place, many more innocent lives will be lost in future in a similar manner. While addressing a media awareness workshop hosted by the National Council for Road Safety at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute (SLFI), titled ‘Rapidly increasing road accidents’, Prof. Dharmaratne said the number of deaths due to road accidents were on the rise and had exceeded the number of lives lost during the 30-year war in Sri Lanka. He said the Government spends a hefty Rs 1.8 billion to treat those injured in road accidents and added that road accidents had claimed 24,786 lives from 2016 to 2018 in Sri Lanka and 20,000 people had been injured during the same period. “Road accidents had claimed many lives on the spot and have left many young men disabled for life. Among them were motorcyclists, pedestrians and cyclists and represent more than 60 per cent of accident victims. Approximately seven to eight people lose their lives on a daily basis in road accidents,” Prof. Dharmaratne added. Setting up a Task Force to prevent road traffic accidents was a prime concern today, he pointed out. He also said there was an absolute need to implement traffic rules to reduce the spate of accidents and the number of people falling victim and some of them being maimed for life. He said if traffic rules were properly implemented accidents, could be reduced at least by 10 per cent.  “Unfortunately, many of the casualties were those in their youth, resulting in the country losing invaluable human resource leading to the country’s development being hindered. On the whole, he said road accidents were preventable but if this did not happen, the number could increase several fold in the future, he said. Road accidents should be dealt with expeditiously otherwise they could cause severe social and economic impact.    While addressing the workshop, State Minister of Transport,  Lasantha Alagiyawanna said  the nearly 25 plans must be put into action to prevent road traffic accidents. It should be effected annually and cannot be implemented at once. “To prevent accidents was a national responsibility and the media should extend its fullest support to reach the desired target. Except for Asian countries, Sri Lanka cannot be compared with other countries with the population and the road network.  We have no safe road network. There are no running tracks, pedestrians have little or no pavements to walk on and the differently-abled cannot use the road network in Sri Lanka. However, he was in praise of the Police, saying that they did their utmost to prevent accidents,” Alagiyawanna said. Meanwhile, he said Police have made arrangements to introduce an e-traffic police app to prevent road accidents getting the support from the public and every arrangement has been put in place to introduce the app soon.   By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Doctors to withdraw from peripheral hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors warned they would take measures to limit the medical resources made available to peripheral hospitals after the next two weeks if the Health Ministry failed to provide them with a feasible solution to the brain-drain amongst the medical fraternity. Secretary of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge yesterday (27) said this was to thwart any bogus action by the Health Ministry to intimidate them into staying in the country. He said countrywide public awareness campaigns would be organised from 2 October. Action would also be taken to educate political leaders. “The Cadre approval was made available only in 2015. But no action has been taken to expand the availability of human resources with the expansion of hospital services and units.”  He noted that action would be taken to collect details of peripheral hospitals starting from Central Dispensaries to assess the number of doctors available. “If only one doctor is manning the post measures would be taken to withdraw and place him or her in one of the major hospitals,” he said. “We would have to close the Central Dispensaries and peripheral hospitals.” The outfit’s Central Committee had unanimously decided to support any trade union action against any decision that is politically motivated, outside the law and tradition and decided to defeat any action to solve this, which is out of tradition and without the agreement of the stakeholders, by resorting to political and legal measures. He urged the medical fraternity to come to Colombo on 11 October if the Health Ministry continues to give false solutions to the issue.  He said this situation was being used to set up private medical colleges (PMCs) without even conducting a feasibility study. The PMCs are going to be set up overlooking the deficiencies in State-run medical education. “It takes six years to produce a fully-fledged medical practitioner. Does the Health Ministry expect the public to wait till such doctors are produced?” he queried. Dr. Aluthge added that there was also a solution that had been presented to recruit foreign doctors. “At present, a specialist doctor receives a basic salary of Rs 88,000. Who is the qualified specialist foreign medical practitioner who would like to come to Sri Lanka and work for that amount?” he questioned. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: IMF leaves without reaching a staff-level agreement
author: Author not found
Content: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) staff that concluded their visit to Sri Lanka yesterday (27) left without reaching a staff-level agreement. They stated their commitment to continue working towards it in the near term, with the goal of sustaining the reform momentum necessary for Sri Lanka to recover from its severe economic crisis. The first tranche of USD 330 million was awarded by the IMF in March following the approval of USD 3 billion rescue package, however, yesterday, the officials of the IMF said there is no fix time for the second tranche for Sri Lanka pointing out Sri Lanka yet to meet the obligations of the IMF recommendations. Despite early signs of stabilisation, full economic recovery is not yet assured, the IMF team said. Growth momentum remains subdued, with real GDP in the second quarter contracting by 3.1 per cent on a year-on-year basis and high-frequency economic indicators continuing to provide mixed signals. Reserve accumulation has slowed in recent months, the IMF team led by   Peter Breuer and Katsiaryna Svirydzenka who were in Colombo between 14 to 27 September said in their official statement. The IMF statement continued thus, “The people of Sri Lanka have shown remarkable resilience in the face of enormous challenges. Sri Lanka has made commendable progress in implementing difficult but much-needed reforms. These efforts are bearing fruit as the economy is showing tentative signs of stabilisation. Inflation is down from a peak of 70 per cent in September 2022 to below 2 per cent in September 2023, gross international reserves increased by USD 1.5 billion during March-June this year, and shortages of essentials have eased. “Sustaining the reform momentum is critical to put the economy on a path towards lasting recovery and stable and inclusive economic growth. The authorities have met the programme’s primary balance targets and remain committed to this important pillar of the program so as to support their efforts to restore debt sustainability. However, revenue mobilisation gains – while improved relative to last year – are expected to fall short of initial projections by nearly 15 percent by year end, in part due to economic factors. The onus of fiscal adjustment would fall on public expenditure if there were no efforts to recoup this shortfall. This could weaken the government’s ability to provide essential public services; and undermine the path to debt sustainability. To increase revenues and signal better governance, it is important to strengthen tax administration, remove tax exemptions, and actively eliminate tax evasion. “Against continued uncertainty, it also remains important to rebuild external buffers by strong reserves accumulation. Building on the Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s success in controlling inflation, refraining from monetary financing will help keep inflation in check. Other challenges include maintaining cost recovery of electricity pricing. “The Government has made steady progress on structural reforms. Key legislations passed in Parliament, including the new Central Bank Act and the Anti-Corruption Act, could improve governance if implemented effectively. The IMF Governance Diagnostic Report would inform future reform measures to strengthen governance when published. A new welfare benefit payment scheme was enacted with new eligibility criteria that aims to improve targeting, adequacy, and coverage of social safety nets. To ensure financial stability, steps were taken on conducting bank diagnostics, developing a roadmap for addressing banking system capital and liquidity shortfalls, and improving the bank resolution framework. “The authorities have also made headway on regaining debt sustainability through the execution of the domestic debt restructuring and advancing discussions with external creditors. As Sri Lanka is restructuring its public debt which is in arrears, Executive Board approval of the first programme review requires the completion of financing assurances reviews. These financing assurances reviews will focus on whether adequate progress has been made with debt restructuring to give confidence that it will be concluded in a timely manner and in line with the program’s debt targets. “Discussions are on-going, and the authorities are continuing to make progress on their plans for revenue mobilisation targets, anti-corruption efforts, and other important structural reforms.  “The IMF team held meetings with President and Finance Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, Central Bank of Sri Lanka Governor Dr. P. Nandalal Weerasinghe, State Minister   Shehan Semasinghe, Chief of Staff to the President   Sagala Ratnayaka, Secretary to the Treasury   K M Mahinda Siriwardana, and other senior government and CBSL officials. The IMF team also met Parliamentarians, representatives from the private sector, civil society organisations, and development partners. “We would like to thank the authorities for the excellent collaboration during the mission. The team will continue its discussions in the context of the First Review with the goal of reaching a staff-level agreement in the near term. We reaffirm our commitment to support Sri Lanka at this difficult time.”  (SRM)

title: SC orders Education Ministry to act promptly
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court ordered the Ministry of Education yesterday (27) to act promptly in aligning the appointments for Grade III positions in the principal service with the previously agreed-upon terms among the concerned parties. This agreement, formalised in the Supreme Court, entails the appointment of 4,718 individuals to the aforementioned positions. The Supreme Court’s decision stems from a series of Fundamental Rights (FR) petitions that were filed in relation to appointments for Grade III positions in the Principal Service.

title: ECT to commence operations on 1 June 2024
author: Author not found
Content: The initial phase of construction of the East Container Terminal (ECT) of the Colombo Port is slated for completion, with operations set to commence on 1 June 2024, the Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation said. This revelation was made during a recent meeting of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Energy and Transport, chaired by Nalaka Bandara Kottegoda, in Parliament. The committee convened to discuss various matters, including the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (Amendment) Bill, the Annual Report of the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Limited for 2022, and the Performance Report of the Ministry of Shipping and Aviation for the same year. The committee approved the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (Amendment) Bill during this session. The Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation presented progress updates during the committee meeting, confirming that construction progress for the East Container Terminal currently stands at 20 per cent. The full completion of this terminal is anticipated in the second quarter of 2025. Further, ministry officials also reported a 20 per cent advancement in the construction of the Western Terminal at Colombo Port, with its expected completion also scheduled for the second quarter of 2025. Meanwhile, Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Limited stated that it will be making profits after June 2022. Accordingly, in the last seven months of this year (2023), the company has recorded a net profit of USD 18 million. The Chairman of Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Limited said that an international conference for aviation related personnel and research groups from all over the world is planned to be held on 10 December this year. Many organisations including heads of the world’s leading airlines will be in attendance, he said. Accordingly, the officials informed the Committee that the draft of the national policy which has been prepared so far will be forwarded to the Committee. Further, the Members of the Committee instructed the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation to look into the possibility of transporting goods by sea during the distribution of goods in Sri Lanka.

title: Over 4,000 vacancies in CEB, CPC – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Presently, there are over 4,000 vacancies within both the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC), Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said. Minister Wijesekera, however, underscored that the existing workforce is sufficiently equipped to manage the operations of these institutions and provide essential services. Specifically, he provided an overview of the staffing situation, stating, “In the Petroleum Corporation, there are 3,292 approved staff positions, with 2,100 individuals presently employed, resulting in 1,192 vacancies. Meanwhile, the Ceylon Electricity Board, which has 24,000 approved staff positions, employs 21,000 individuals. Additionally, 3,000 external hires have been brought in to address specific service requirements, leaving a need for 3,000 more employees to reach the approved staffing levels.” Minister Wijesekera acknowledged that the Government has refrained from exploiting these vacancies for political gains. Instead, it has prioritised unpopular yet necessary decisions to advance the sustainable economic development of the nation. “It’s important to recognise that, while I could potentially offer employment to an additional thousand individuals from the Matara District within the Petroleum Corporation for political advantage, such actions would be inconsistent with the Government’s policy, which places the integrity of these institutions above political interests,” he emphasised. He was speaking during a conference titled ‘Restructuring of Government Institutions for a New Development Approach,’ held at the Ministry of Finance on 26 September.

title: Land reclamation projects in Ja-Ela come under microscope
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Trade, Commerce, and Food Security Nalin Fernando queried on what grounds the approval of land reclamation projects in the Ja-Ela area by the Sri Lanka Land Development Corporation amidst the halting of development projects in the Muthurajawela Wetland Sanctuary, could be justified. Recently, a protest was held against constructing of a hotel within the sanctuary by the area residents. Speaking during the Gampaha District Development Committee, the minister said given the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Conservation and the Central Environmental Authority’s decision to preserve the Muthurajawela Reserve through a gazette, there can be no room for development projects.  In line with a circular issued by the Presidential Secretariat, all development projects within the Muthurajawela Reserve must come to an immediate halt, Fernando added that under no circumstances can approval be granted for land reclamation projects in the dedicated area. If any activities are causing harm to the Muthurajawela ESZ, they will undoubtedly face strong opposition from the public, and those responsible will be held accountable for their actions, he asserted. The Muthurajawela marsh is the largest saline coastal peat bog in the country and was granted the status of a wetland sanctuary under the Flora and Fauna Protection Act in 1996 by the government. This unique ecosystem, home to diverse wildlife, has faced threats in the past, notably during the construction of the Colombo – Katunayake Expressway. The marsh serves as a critical retention area for surface stormwater runoff and supports the livelihoods of a substantial local population. Preserving Muthurajawela is not only essential for the well-being of people and wildlife but also for the overall economy of Sri Lanka, a nation already grappling with the severe consequences of the ongoing climate crisis, the minister pointed out. BY Buwaneka Perera

title: Sanath Nishantha’s Contempt hearing fixed for 27 Oct
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal, yesterday (27), fixed 27 October, for further hearing of the Contempt of Court case, filed against State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha. The SLPP MP has been charged with, making derogatory remarks, concerning the Judiciary, Judges and the Attorney General’s Department, during a media briefing held at his party head office, which has been tantamount to Contempt of Court. The case was taken up before a Court of Appeal Bench, consisting of Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne (President) and Chamath Morais. Deputy Solicitor General Lakmini Girihagama, representing the Attorney General told the Bench, that Contempt of Court charges had been preferred, against the State Minister concerned. Thereafter, the Court fixed further hearing of the case to the said date and instructed Sanath Nishantha, to be present in Court, on that date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Diana unveils plan to attract 1.5M foreign tourists
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage unveiled an ambitious plan to boost tourism in Sri Lanka, aiming to attract 1.5 million foreign tourists to the country by the end of 2023. This plan encompasses various promotional campaigns, the development of cities that never sleep, the establishment of taxi associations, and even the consideration of legalising marijuana, she said and added that Cabinet approval has been granted for the cultivation of marijuana, with the goal of bolstering the country’s foreign reserves. During a media briefing at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (27), Gamage outlined her strategy to achieve this objective. She noted that in the first nine months of the year, Sri Lanka has seen a notable increase in tourist arrivals, with approximately one million foreign visitors already gracing the nation’s shores. The expectation is that this number will further rise to 1.5 million by year-end. Gamage highlighted the anticipation of a substantial influx of European tourists during the final months of the year, coinciding with the onset of winter in Europe. The Ministry is actively targeting European countries, including the UK, despite the economic challenges they may be facing. To enhance the convenience and satisfaction of tourists, plans are in motion to provide essential night-time facilities in popular destinations like Ella, Nuwara Eliya, Galle, and Colombo. These cities are slated for transformation into vibrant 24/7 hubs through regulatory adjustments aimed at facilitating tourist spending. Further, she expressed her support for the legalisation of sex work in Sri Lanka, emphasising its potential positive impact on the country’s economy.

title: SLR incurs 245.45B loss from 2015 to 2022
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Railways (SLR), over the past eight years, has incurred expenditures totalling Rs 297.64 billion while its revenue amounted to only Rs 52.19 billion during the same period, Ceylon Today learns. According to a senior official at SLR, this has resulted in a substantial loss of Rs 245.45 billion between 2015 and 2022. Notably, in 2021, the SLR reported an expenditure of Rs 40.41 billion, which increased to Rs 42.53 billion in 2022—an increase of Rs 2.12 billion in just one year. The data reveals a significant disparity between income and expenses within the SLR over the past eight years. Despite annual revenues not surpassing Rs 8 billion from 2015 to 2021, expenditures consistently exceeded Rs 29 billion each year. In 2022, although the department achieved revenue exceeding Rs 10 billion for the year, its expenses soared to over Rs 42 billion. This marked the third consecutive year with the highest expenditure in the past eight years. Further, it was noted that the SLR generates a daily income ranging from Rs 25 to 27 million through its railway stations. Despite this income, the financial imbalance remains a significant challenge for the department’s sustainability, the official pointed out. By Mithun Jayawardhana
