title: Eight sentenced to death over 2003 murder
author: Author not found
Content: The Kalutara High Court handed down death sentences yesterday (27) to eight individuals who had been charged with murder. This order was issued by Kalutara High Court Judge Pradeep Abeyratne, following their conviction for the fatal stabbing of a resident in the Kalil Place in Kalutara (South) on 24 March 2003. The accused faced these severe consequences after the Attorney General had filed indictments against them in the Kalutara High Court. Consequently, capital punishment was imposed on Mohamed Zain Mohamed Hamsa (46), Abdul Karim Mohamed Rawisdeen (49), Mohamed Mauz Mohamed (59), Mohamed Riazdeen Mohamed (45), Mohamed Jiffry Mohamed Jinnah (47), Mohamed Zahir Mohamed Siam (44), Mohamed Nilabdeen Mohamed Ajeel (45), and Mohomed Jiffry Mohamed Firdhouse.

title: Five fishermen sentenced to death after five years
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle, yesterday (27), imposed the death penalty, on five fishermen, after convicting them on the charges of possession, smuggling and aiding and abetting in the trafficking of 252 kg of heroin. The Judge, announcing the verdict, said he was imposing the death sentence on the five accused, as the prosecution had proved its charges against them, beyond a reasonable doubt. State Counsel Osmin Azwer, prosecuting on behalf of the Attorney General, informed Court, that it had been proved during investigations, that the haul of heroin seized from the possession of the five accused, had not been assembled for personal use, but for the sole purpose of trafficking. He said due to the severe harm, such actions could cause to society at large, the Court should impose the most severe of punishments on the five accused, which is the death sentence. He added that the target group of the accused had been schoolchildren and hence, they should not be let off leniently. The lawyers for the defendants, then urged the Court, to impose lenient penalties on their clients, considering the harsh impact, severe sentences could have on their families and their children. The defendants then maintained from the dock, that they were clueless about the charges that had been preferred against them and that they were innocent of it. The SL Navy, which had inspected a fishing trawler travelling some 115 km away from the Galle seas, in the Southern Province following a tip-off, had seized the said stock of heroin, after which the five accused had been taken into custody, five years ago. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Voluntary program required to prevent drug trafficking – PM
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said steps should be taken to fill vacancies in the province while giving teaching appointments. Addressing a meeting with Provincial Governors on 26.09.2023 at Temple Trees, he stressed that a voluntary program is required to prevent drug trafficking. Speaking on this occasion the Prime Minister further stated; “It is necessary to implement the program in order to improve the economic, political and administrative situation in the country. Attention should be paid to the functioning of local government bodies that do not have public representatives currently. There are no public representatives in the local government institutions for more than a year. The President has made arrangements to continue the work of the provincial councils by appointing district development committee chairmen and the work of the Divisional Secretary’s Divisions by appointing development committees in the divisional secretariats. The President had issued a circular instructing that the governors should work together with the district secretaries. As representatives of the President, Governors enjoy special executive powers. Government officials and governors should pay considerable attention to all aspects of development and governance. More attention should be paid on placing multitasking employees. It should get the support of the provincial councils. This cannot be done by government departments alone. In some districts only a small number of placements have to be completed. These people don’t have O/L qualification. N.V.Q special training has been provided by the government. Take steps to place them in a proper institution that have been recognized for training. There are certain issues regarding teaching appointments. Steps should be taken to give appointments in each province. This will make the teaching appointment program successful. Those teachers who were sent to provinces or districts out of their residence might not remain in those schools. There is a surplus in some regions. Our sole aim is to educate the students and not to grant concessionary transfers. Placement of the government teaching appointments should be taken place in order to fill vacancies in the respective provinces. The Ministry of Local Government has recognized that it is possible to increase the income of all local government bodies. This should be given special attention. Court fines, stamp revenue, other transfer and financial provisions are less directed to local authorities. The development committees should pay attention to this and try to reduce the expenses. Former President and the current President had a policy of increasing solar energy. But the progress is very slow. Priority should be given to provincial councils and district committees to implement projects. Digitization of local government agencies leads to increase revenue. The concerned commissioners have been advised in this regard. At the same time continuous supervision is very important. Some illegal methods of revenue should be looked into. Drug usage and drug trafficking has increased. Pay attention in this regard at the provincial level together with the police. If prompt steps are not taken it is uncertain where the killings due to internecine war between underworld gangs might end. This situation must be controlled. During the war, Public Security Committees were formed. The police were in alert. Such a voluntary program is needed again. Instructions should be given to control this situation through these steps. Children, teachers and young people should possess understanding in this regard and carry forward this drug prevention movement. Discussions should be held with security forces, inter-community organizations, and religious leaders to control this situation immediately. Not every child who leaves school can be admitted to university. They should be directed to vocational education. More attention should be paid, especially in directing them to information technology. Unless attention is paid in this regard at district level, these children tend to join various gangs. Direct the young children to a programme targeting their future. There are thousands of acres of government or government-related unutilized estate lands owned by the Land Reforms Commission which are not being used for a productive purpose.The government decided to allow the youth to cultivate these lands for a short period of time. The programme needs to be carried forward.” State Ministers Janaka Wakkumbura, Ashoka Priyantha, Governors Maheepala Herath, Willy Gamage, Lalith U. Gamage, A. J. Muzammil, Roshan Gunathilake, P. M. S. Charles, Senthil Thondaman, Naveen Dissanayake, Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Provincial Councils, and Local Government Ranjith Ashoka and all Provincial Chief Secretaries participated in this discussion.

title: Transforming Sri Lanka’s Resilience in Climate and Disaster Risk Management
author: Author not found
Content: As a climate-vulnerable developing country, managing climate and disaster risks as well as mobilising risk finance is a critical need for Sri Lanka. SLYCAN Trust’s initiative of developing a Multi-Actor Partnership on Climate and Disaster Risk Management and Finance launched into a new phase on 19 September at the Cinnamon Grand Hotel, Colombo, with the participation of key stakeholders from the agriculture, tourism, fashion, and SME sectors. The key focus of the session was on collaborations, partnerships, and exchanges between different actors and stakeholder groups that could enhance opportunities related to accessing climate and disaster risk finance, strengthen existing mechanisms, harness synergies, and increase mid- and long-term economic resilience. Opening the event, SLYCAN Executive Director, Attorney-at-Law Vositha Wijenayake highlighted the importance of focusing on climate and disaster risk management for building long-term resilience. “Climate change is a key factor that impacts today’s development. It is important that climate risks and impacts are considered and addressed in planning local and national level economic empowerment as well as resilience-building guided by inclusive and participatory processes,” she said. Importance of climate and disaster risk management and multi-actor partnerships Speaking at the event, SLYCAN Trust Director of Research & Knowledge Management Dennis Mombauer explained the work conducted in the first phase of the programme. “We have established this multi-actor partnership with a focus on Sri Lanka’s food systems to identify opportunities for enhancing and building on existing risk management and transfer mechanisms and accessing climate and risk finance.” “Moving into this new phase, we aim to formalise the partnership and expand it to additional sectors – tourism and trade, fashion and apparel – that are climate-vulnerable but also have the potential to empower entrepreneurs, communities, and youth, as well as‌ contribute to building overall resilience and prosperity,” he explained. As an output of the discussion on short- and medium-term goal setting for climate and disaster risk management, the stakeholders from the tourism sector identified the need for better risk mapping and risk transfer processes for the sector, including possible risk pooling through collective funding processes being set up. Additionally, it was further highlighted that it would be important to focus on the climate risks that are threatening the industry, while also identifying solutions through awareness and enhancing information sharing amongst key stakeholders in the industry. Climate resilience and innovation across diverse sectors The stakeholders representing the Small and Medium Enterprises (SME) sector highlighted the need to focus on the sector as a priority in the conversations on climate adaptability and capacity building. The need for innovating the business models used by the SME sector to match global trends on sustainable innovation was identified as a tool to build resilience, while entrepreneurship skills development to adapt to climate change was recognised as a cross-cutting theme for all the sectors from national to local level. Under the discussions on the food systems-related sector, the participants highlighted that research and development was a key aspect in scaling up climate change adaptation action. Among other points highlighted were Public-Private Partnerships; partnerships for knowledge and evidence sharing and scaling-up research related to the sector; and innovative technologies and technology transfer; as well as the importance of urgent measures for addressing climate-induced loss and damage in food systems. The participants also emphasised the need for climate risk management in aquaculture. Diverse stakeholder participation In addition to the tourism and SME sector representatives, the event also saw the participation of representatives from the finance, banking, and insurance sectors, who contributed to the discussion by providing solutions and approaches to be generated in climate and disaster risk finance options for Sri Lanka. This included key stakeholders of agriculture, SME, tourism, and fashion and garment sectors who represented Government ministries and departments, academia, private-owned businesses, and Government and private-owned finance and insurance sector organisations, as well as social entrepreneurs.

title: Book project on Ramayana sites launched
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of Sri Lanka in New Delhi has initiated a book project on Ramayana sites in collaboration with the internationally renowned publisher Dorling Kindersley Publishing Private Limited (DK) India. This is considered the latest of a series of activities to mark the 75th anniversary of the establishment of formal diplomatic relations between India and Sri Lanka this year. The proposed book, with the working title In the Footsteps of Rama; A Cultural Journey through India and Sri Lanka, will feature the Ramayana sites both in India and Sri Lanka giving reference to the historical, archaeological and mythological aspects of these sites. DK, a publisher of high-quality illustrated reference books plans to bring out the final production of the book by July next year. The agreement pertaining to the publication was signed on 25 September at the High Commission of Sri Lanka in New Delhi. DK India’s Managing Director Aparna Sharma, Head Finance & Operations Alka Kumar, Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda, Deputy High Commissioner Niluka Kadurugamuwa, Minister of the High Commission Upul Pushpakumara and Minister Counsellor Gamini Sarath Godakanda were present at the signing.

title: Life And Times of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)
author: Author not found
Content: “And We have sent you (O Muhammad SAW) not but as a mercy for the Aalameen (mankind, jinns and all that exists)” [al-Anbiya’ 21:107]. Thus, Allah epitomises the excellent qualities of mercy our beloved Prophet Muhammad possesses {May Allah’s Peace and Blessings be Upon Him (PBUH)}. Furthermore, the Holy Quran disclaims any superhuman characteristics for Muhammad but describes him as a man having the highest moral excellence (Quran 68:4: “And thou dost, surely, possess sublime moral excellences”). On this day when Muslims all over the world are remembering the birth of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), in this peace, I wish to recall some of the events in the Prophet’s-Sallallahu Alayhi Wa Sallam (SAW)-(May Allah honour him and grant him peace), life where he demonstrated these qualities of ‘sublime moral excellences’ in real life. Incidentally, Islamic historians are unsure about the actual date of Prophet Muhammad’s birth. Still, it is recorded in Musnad–al–Muslim that when the Prophet (PBUH) was asked for his reason for fasting on Mondays each week, he replied that it was the day of his (the Prophet’s) birth as such he was fasting in remembrance of this day. Returning to the subject of the Prophet’s possession of ‘sublime moral and excellence’ and that of being a merciful human being. The Prophet first demonstrated these qualities during his visit to Taif after being persecuted in Mecca. “When Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) called the people to Islam in Makkah, he was opposed by the leaders of the tribes of Quraysh. The Prophet (PBUH) was ridiculed and those who converted to Islam were persecuted and tortured. The people of Quraysh boycotted the Muslims for three years, and the Muslims suffered from sickness, hunger, and poverty. In the same year, Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) lost his two strongest supporters and sources of comfort: his wife, Khadijah, and his uncle, Abu Talib. Without the protection of his uncle, Abu Talib, in Makkah, Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) needed to reach out and seek support beyond the city of Makkah. He (PBUH) wanted to spread the message to the people of Taif, hoping they would believe and accept the message of Islam. He trekked from Makkah to Taif to invite the people to the belief in ‘One God’. Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) met with the Chiefs of the major Tribe in Taif, ‘Thaqeef’. He (PBUH) told them about Islam, worshipping only ‘One God’ and leaving Idol worshipping. They rejected his message and insulted him. Not only did they refuse to listen to his message, but they unleashed the children of their tribe to throw stones at him and drive him out of their town. With people jeering at him as his ankles bled, he ran out, finding shelter in an empty orchard. Alone, bleeding, and rejected, he (PBUH) rests on a rock and prays to Allah. He (PBUH) is so compassionate and merciful; he does not ask Allah to punish the people of Taif or to execute revenge against them; instead, the ever-merciful Prophet ( PBUH) supplicated to Allah as follows”. “To You, my Lord, I complain of my weakness, lack of support, and the humiliation I am made to receive. “Most Compassionate and Merciful, You are the Lord of the weak and my Lord. To whom do You leave me? “To a distant person who receives me with hostility? Or to an enemy You have given power over me? As long as you are not displeased with me, I do not care what I face. “I would, however, be much happier with Your mercy. I seek refuge in the light of Your face by which all darkness is dispelled, and both this life and the life to come are put in their right course against incurring Your wrath or being the subject of Your anger. “To You, I submit until I earn Your pleasure. Everything is powerless without your support.”  At that moment, Angel Jibreel came to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and told him that if he wished, Allah could order an angel to collapse the two mountains surrounding the people of Taif and crush them. How did Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) react to those who had insulted him and threw stones at him? He (PBUH) opted for mercy not violence towards them. He was not overcome with rage or hate. Instead of seeking revenge against the people of Taif, he said to Angel Jibreel, “I rather hope that Allah will raise from among their descendants, people who will worship Allah the One, and will not ascribe partners to Him.” Later, under the same circumstances prevailing in Mecca of persecution of Muslims by the nonbelievers, the Prophet sought refuge in Medina, which was called Yathrib at the time. It is essential to highlight that Muhammad (PBUH) did not enter Medina as a conqueror. He went there seeking refuge from persecution in Mecca. But strangely, the people of Yathrib welcomed the Prophet (PBUH) and accepted him as their leader. Therefore, he (PBUH) sought the confidence of the Yathribite populace by declaring the “Saheefa”, a charter guaranteeing peace and protection to all the people. The Constitution of Medina, also known as the Charter of Medina (Sahifat al-Medina), is believed to have been written in 622-624 CE and is said to have been drawn up on behalf of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) shortly after the Prophet arrived in Yathrib as it was known then, in 622 CE which is the first Hijra Year {(1 AH)-named for the migration of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) from Mecca to Medina more than 1,400 years ago}. Allah has continued to remind us of the Prophet’s (PBUH) qualities in several verses in the Holy Quran as follows: “Indeed, a messenger has come to you from among yourselves. Your difficulties are grievous to him, he is full of concern for you, and he is very kind and companionate with the believers” (Tawba verse 128). “Indeed, there is a good example for you in [the character of] the Messenger; [and] for those who have hope for God, and the Last Day, and remember God much” (Al Ahzab verse 21). Thus the life led by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was a perfect example for all Muslims to follow. He possessed every excellent quality one could ever think of. He was kind, polite, well-mannered, sympathetic, humble, good-tempered, good-natured, and so forth. Anyone who wants to emulate an individual’s character must emulate the character of the Prophet, according to the Holy Quran. This fact is extensively acknowledged by great scholars as follows: George Bernard Shaw –”He must be called the saviour of humanity. I believe that if a man like him were to assume the dictatorship of the modern world, he would succeed in solving its problems in a way that would bring it – much-needed peace and happiness” (The Genuine Islam, Singapore, Vol. 1, No.8, 1936) “But the very idea that Muhammad would have found anything to be optimistic about in the carnage committed in his name on ‘September 11th’ is an obscenity, because, as I try to show in these pages, Muhammad spent most of his life trying to stop that kind of indiscriminate slaughter. The very word Islam, which denotes the existential “surrender” of the whole being to God, which Muslims are required to make, is related to ‘Salam’- ‘Peace’”. And most importantly, Muhammad eventually abjured violence and pursued a daring, inspired policy on non-violence that was the culmination of his prophetic career. In imagining that the holy war was the culmination of his career, the fundamentalists (extremists) have distorted the whole meaning of his life. Far from being the father of Jihad (Exertion or Struggle), Muhammad (PBUH) was a peacemaker who risked his life and nearly lost his closest companions because he was so determined to effect a reconciliation with Mecca. Instead of fighting an intransigent war to the death, Muhammad (PBUH) was prepared to negotiate and compromise. And this apparent humiliation and capitulation proved, in the words of the Holy Qur’an, to be a great victory (Fat-‘h)….If we could view Muhammad as we do any other important historical figure we would surely consider him to be one of the greatest geniuses the world has known”. (A Biography of the Prophet). It is impossible for anyone who studies the life and character of the great Prophet (PBUH) of Arabia, …., to feel anything but reverence for that mighty Prophet (PBUH), one of the great messengers of the Supreme. And although in what I put to you I shall say many things which may be familiar to many, yet I myself feel whenever I re-read them, a new way of admiration, a new sense of reverence for that mighty Arabian teacher. Thus, it can be seen, far from being dictatorial, that the Prophet of Islam – Muhammad (PBUH) adopted a semi-democratic form of administration to unite the peoples of different faiths as one community. An excellent example for nations in conflict to promote peaceful coexistence not only within their own territories but worldwide. May the peace and blessings of God be showered upon Prophet Muhammad. Ameen! By Dr. M. Haris Deen

title: Bible-based website available in over 100 sign languages
author: Author not found
Content: 23 September marked the 5th anniversary of the International Day of Sign Languages, instituted by the United Nations to highlight the diversity of the more than 300 different sign languages used worldwide by 70 million deaf or hard-of-hearing persons. Because of the variations in vocabulary, grammar, and syntax of each sign language, there is no one-size-fits-all approach to translation. Jehovah’s Witnesses have proven up to the challenge. Not only do they hold the distinction of publishing the world’s first complete Bible in American, Brazilian, Mexican, and Russian Sign Language, but they also offer Bible-based content in over 100 different sign languages on their official website, jw.org. “We don’t want anyone to be overlooked,” said spokesperson Naleen Wanigasekara. “So jw.org offers sign-language videos that share practical advice from the Bible on how to cope with discouragement, how to have a happy family life, how to use your time wisely and so much more.” The Witnesses’ efforts to reach the deaf with their positive message does not stop with the translation of their website. They also try to meet and speak with deaf people in their community. Luxmikaanth Nimalamoorthy, who is deaf, was contacted by Jehovah’s Witnesses at his home. “I was impressed by the great lengths that hearing ones went through to learn sign language and help the deaf community. The talks that were translated into sign language at their meetings touched my heart.” Deaf persons are warmly invited to view the content available in their preferred sign language on jw.org, the official website of Jehovah’s Witnesses. Times and locations of local meetings held in sign language can also be found on the website. Admission is free and no registration is required.

title: Expanded LKI Board of Management Meets
author: Author not found
Content: The expanded Board of Management of the Lakshman Kadirgamar Institute of International Relations and Strategic Studies (LKI) met recently presided over by Foreign Minister M.U.M. Ali Sabry, in his capacity as the ex officio Chairman of LKI. The Foreign Minister recently appointed four new members to the LKI Board of Management, to fill the vacancies that prevailed. They were: Ruwantha Cooray – Attorney-at-Law, Kimarli Fernando – Banker and Attorney-at-Law, Ahmed Talal Rafi – Economist and Management Consultant, and Dr. Harinda Vidanage – Strategic Studies Expert.

title: Edith Cowan University confers Dr. Jalagge with Honorary Doctorate
author: Author not found
Content: Edith Cowan University proudly conferred an Honorary Doctorate on Dr. Rosh Jalagge on 3 September, in recognition of his outstanding service-based entrepreneurial achievements and remarkable philanthropic contributions as the CEO/Founder of the Roshana Care Group. Dr. Jalagge, a visionary leader and dedicated advocate, migrated to Perth, Western Australia, in the late 1990s. It was during this time that he identified a pressing need in the Perth community for comprehensive support services tailored to individuals grappling with mental illnesses and psychosocial disabilities. He observed that many of these individuals, already marginalised by their conditions, were further burdened by poverty and the lack of affordable community support. Motivated by a deep sense of compassion and a commitment to make a meaningful difference, Rosh embarked on a journey to provide holistic and affordable care solutions. He collaborated with psychiatric hospitals and other healthcare providers, establishing a foundation for comprehensive mental health care in Western Australia. As his commitment to community service grew, Dr. Jalagge extended his focus to another vulnerable demographic – the elderly. Inspired by Sri Lankan values that emphasise caring for one’s parents and the elderly with love and compassion within one’s own home, he aimed to instil these values within the Western Australian community. Thus, his aged care services were born, which have since expanded across Australia, offering compassionate, community-oriented care for the elderly. Rosh’s efforts not only transformed the landscape of mental health and aged care in Australia but also created numerous employment opportunities for Australians and immigrants alike. His approach, rooted in compassion and collectivism, has not only improved the quality of life for those in need but has also strengthened the fabric of Australian society. Dr Jalagge, along with his wife Priyanka Gamage, also founded the philanthropical foundation ‘Rosh and Priyanka Foundation’. Through this, Rosh has been a consistent and significant donor to people in need in Sri Lanka throughout the years; mainly focusing on education, medical and disaster relief. Rosh is also a renowned donor to the Sri Lankan society in Australia donating hundreds of thousands of dollars each year, and providing employment opportunities and assistance to new migrants to Australia. His philanthropic activities are further extended to the indigenous society in Western Australia as well. Remarkably, Dr. Jalagge’s recognition with an Honorary Doctorate from Edith Cowan University makes him one of only two Asians to receive this esteemed honour. The first recipient was the King of Thailand, underscoring the exceptional nature of his contributions to society. Edith Cowan University celebrated the extraordinary achievements of Dr. Rosh Jalagge and his unwavering commitment to the welfare of vulnerable populations in Australia. This Honorary Doctorate reflects the deep appreciation and admiration for his service-based entrepreneurship and philanthropic endeavours and serves as an inspiration to all.

title: President leaves for Germany
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who commenced an official visit to Germany yesterday (27) morning, designated five acting ministers to oversee the responsibilities of the ministries under his purview in his absence, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. Accordingly, State Minister Premitha Bandara Tennakoon will assume the role of Acting Minister of Defence, State Minister Shehan Semasinghe will take on the responsibilities of Acting Minister of Finance, State Minister Kanaka Herath will function as the Acting Minister of Technology, State Minister Anupa Pasqual will serve as the Acting Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment, and State Minister Ranjith Siyambalapitiya will function as the Acting Minister for Investment Promotion. The President embarked on his trip to Germany to deliver the opening remarks at the Leaders’ Dialogue session during the ‘Berlin Global Dialogue’ scheduled for 28-29 September. Following this, he will participate in a bilateral session with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and officials from the Federal Republic of Germany, the PMD added.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Garbage on road hinders vehicular movement
author: Author not found
Content: Residents living near the Puttalam-Old Mannar road said transport along the road has been severely hampered of late due to the haphazard release and dumping of garbage. They said that garbage had been dumped in large quantities on the Old Mannar road and on the stretch which runs from Puttalam town to Eluwankulama. They added that similar refuse matter has also been released in places such as Puttalam first, second, third and fourth mile posts resulting in residents being severely affected by the stench emanating from rotting garbage piles and the damage caused to the environment as a result. BY Priyankara Kalupahana – Puttalam

title: Heroin trafficker sentenced to life imprisonment
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Manjula Thillakaratne, on Tuesday (26), imposed a life sentence on a 30-year-old youth, after convicting him on the charges, of possession and trafficking of 78.57 g of heroin. Announcing the verdict, the Judge said he was imposing the sentence on the accused, as the prosecution had proved its charges against him, beyond a reasonable doubt. The suspect is Mohammad Islam, a resident of Hunupitiya, Wattala. The suspect had been arrested by a Police team, from the Wellawatte Anti-Vice Squad, at Crow Island in Colombo 15, on 26 March, five years ago and the Attorney General had subsequently indicted him, in the High Court. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: EP to get 700 more teachers
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman announced on 25 September that arrangements have been made to appoint an additional 700 new graduates to fill the existing vacancies in schools in the province. Considering the current shortage of teachers in Eastern Province schools, Thondaman has submitted a letter to the Public Service Commission of the Eastern Province, requesting them to make the required arrangements for these graduate appointments. Thondaman also said 630 graduate appointments have already been made to schools in the province, and efforts were underway to appoint these graduate teachers to schools in the province. He said the decision comes in the light of the province’s educational advancement. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Protective barrier being constructed to halt beach erosion
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the extensive beach erosion that has impacted Kattankudy, the Ministry of Urban development has initiated an urgent programme to address the issue. Murugesan Tulsidasan, Divisional Engineer of the Batticaloa District Coastal Resource Management Department, confirmed that the project has commenced. A protective barrier, consisting of massive stones, is currently being constructed along the beach. This barrier is approximately 80 metres in length and has a depth of about three metres. Additionally, it has been disclosed that the State Ministry of Coastal Protection and Low Land Development has allocated Rs 1.5 million for essential activities related to this project. The erosion problem has resulted in damage to numerous coastal structures, and local fishermen have also suffered losses to their livelihoods as a result of this issue. BY T.I. Jawferkhan- Batticaloa

title: Mandarina Colombo marks World Tourism Day
author: Author not found
Content: Mandarina Colombo celebrated World Tourism Day on 27 September with a series of events. As a subsidiary of Macksons Holdings, Mandarina Colombo has gained significant popularity since its opening in January 2017. Known for its exceptional hospitality services catering to both the business community and tourists, Mandarina Colombo organised various social initiatives to mark the occasion. One noteworthy event was a community care project focused on cleaning the historic Gangarama Temple in Hunupitiya. The temple holds immense religious and cultural significance, attracting tourists from both local and international destinations. The dedicated staff of Mandarina Colombo actively participated in this initiative, showcasing their commitment to the community. In addition to the temple cleaning project, Mandarina Colombo also extended its support to the Gangodawila Girls’ Orphanage in Nugegoda. As part of World Tourism Day, the hotel organised a special dinner for the girls, providing them with a memorable experience and fostering a sense of belonging and care. Through these initiatives, Mandarina Colombo demonstrated its dedication to promoting and celebrating the tourism industry while making a positive impact on the local community.

title: Railway worker arrested for stealing diesel
author: Author not found
Content: Officials from the Galle Railway Station said they had detained a worker who had stolen 30 litres of diesel from the pumping storage at dawn on Tuesday (26). The suspect was handed over to the Galle Police. Security officers, on duty at the railway station, having spotted the suspect inside a railway carriage inspected the carriage and found the stolen diesel in three 10 litre cans. The suspect was handed over to the Galle Police. BY S. Diyagahage – Ahangama

title: CEB, CPC restructuring plan to Cabinet in two weeks
author: Author not found
Content: Legislation to restructure the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) will be presented to Cabinet within the next two weeks, revealed Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara yesterday (26). The Minister addressing a seminar on restructuring loss-making State enterprises at the Ministry of Finance said the draft Bill of the new legislation was sent to the Attorney General for changes to be made to the Bill. After amendments were made, the draft was re-sent to the Attorney General and will be presented to Cabinet within the next two weeks, he added. Wijesekara said restructuring proposals have been given to trade unions and the upper management of the institutions as well. He said following Cabinet approval, the public and other concerned parties could go to the Supreme Court, if they feel the legislation violates the Constitution. “This decision was taken to make the CEB and the CPC more efficient, accountable, profitable and transparent. These are not popular decisions and we do not take them aiming at an Election. But these things should be done by someone. On the other hand, the staff level discussion with the International Monetary Fund has been scheduled for next month. We need to show them that we are committed to resolve the financial crisis in the country,” he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: New law soon to transform Port City into ‘Colombo Financial Zone’ – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (26) said a new law to transform the Port City into a Financial Zone will be introduced soon. According to the President’s Media Division (PMD), the President said the new law will transform the Port City into ‘Colombo Financial Zone’, granting it jurisdiction over offshore activities. The President emphasised that the success of dispute resolution mechanisms was not just essential for the country’s economic growth, but also vital for Sri Lanka’s aspirations to become an outward-looking economy. He highlighted forthcoming legislation aimed at transforming the Port City into the Colombo Financial Zone and the transition from the Board of Investment (BOI) to the Economic Commission, both of which are designed to facilitate more efficient dispute resolution. The President, while speaking at the 2023 Commercial Mediation Symposium, held at the Hilton Hotel in Colombo,underscored the imperative need for a cultural shift towards more efficient dispute resolution mechanisms in Sri Lanka. In his speech, the President acknowledged the country’s long-standing reliance on trial courts and emphasised the importance of embracing alternative dispute resolution methods. Highlighting the government’s commitment to this cause, President Wickremesinghe made reference to the establishment of the Alternate Dispute Resolution Centre in 2018 and expressed his unwavering support for its continued growth. He urged the Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of Investments to collaborate closely in advancing these initiatives. During his address, President Wickremesinghe emphasised the significance of change, stating, “Alternate dispute resolution, arbitration, both have a long way to travel in Sri Lanka and that’s our problem. We have to first find ways of how we can adjust to this process. You need a change of culture. Change of culture where disputes can be resolved in the shortest possible time.” He acknowledged the prevailing tendency to adhere to traditional Trial Court procedures, emphasising the need for change in this regard. Furthermore, President Wickremesinghe stressed the importance of international trade agreements and urged Sri Lanka to establish itself as a prominent centre for alternate dispute resolution. He called upon legal professionals to broaden their horizons beyond national borders and specialise in emerging fields such as AI, Blockchain, and green energy, underlining the importance of securing the nation’s competitive future in a rapidly evolving global landscape. President Wickremesinghe emphasised that Sri Lanka must position itself as the central player in the region. When examining Singapore as a benchmark, Sri Lanka should strive to match or surpass Singapore in various aspects, except for cost, where it should maintain a competitive advantage. This approach is crucial because there exists a noticeable void in this region, which Sri Lanka can effectively fill if it acts swiftly. “This is the key lesson to be derived. Furthermore, it is essential for all lawyers and individuals involved in legal services to broaden their perspectives and explore opportunities beyond their current scope,” the President added.

title: One millionth tourist for 2023 comes from Russia
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka yesterday (26) celebrated the arrival of its one millionth tourist in 2023. This is the first time since 2019 that the country has topped a million tourist arrivals. Russian nationals, Alex Mazkov and his family, became the symbolic millionth tourists of the year, arriving on an Oman Airlines flight (WY-373). Their journey took them from Russia to Muscat in Oman and then to the BIA. On arrival at BIA, the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) extended a warm welcome to the family. Dr. Prasad Jayasekera, Director of SLTPB, highlighted the significance of this achievement, noting that it had been three years since Sri Lanka had reached the milestone of welcoming one million tourists in a single year, with the last being in 2019. In the first 24 days of September alone, Sri Lanka recorded over 88,000 tourist arrivals, contributing to the year-to-date figure. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Injunction over Sirisena’s letter to Dayasiri dissolved
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Sandun Vithana, yesterday (26), dissolved the injunction imposed on SLFP Chairman, former President Maithripala Sirisena, and the Deputy General Secretary of the party, which prevented the activation of the letter, calling for ousted General Secretary of the party MP Dayasiri Jayasekera, to submit his explanation within four days, on flouting of the party disciplinary code. The District Court Judge dissolved the injunction after having perused submissions produced on behalf of the SLFP Chairman, by President’s Counsel Faiszer Musthapha. Musthapha informed Judge Vithana, that the letter had been sent to MP Jayasekera with the approval of the Central Committee of the SLFP and charged that the Parliamentarian, concerned, had concealed the truth from the Court, when seeking his injunction. He further alleged that MP Jayasekera had resorted to his actions sans clean hands. President’s Counsel Ikram Mohammad, representing the plaintiff, had told the Court previously, that the letter issued to his client had was invalid before the law and hence taking any action, based on it, would be unlawful. However, the injunction which was imposed on the SLFP Chairman and on Deputy General Secretary was due to last until 5 October. The letter issued to the ousted General Secretary, had contained charges, such as placing of bond when submitting of nominations to contest the 2023 LG Poll, without the approval of the CC of the party, allowing the People’s Freedom Alliance to use the address of the party head office, without seeking due consent, berating SLFP Organisers in choice words, failure to carry out his duties as the party General Secretary and constant criticism of the party leadership, in the eyes of the public. President’s Counsel Jagath Wickremanayake and Attorney-at-Law Vinura Jayawardene appeared for the plaintiff MP. BY Hansi Nanayakkara
