title: Permission not given by SL for Shi Yan 6 to dock – Ali Sabry
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Minister Ali Sabry on Monday said Sri Lanka has not given permission to a Chinese vessel to dock, adding that Indian security concerns are “important” for Sri Lanka. Asked about reports regarding a Chinese research vessel named Shi Yan 6 scheduled to dock in Sri Lanka in October and India’s concerns regarding it, he said they have a standard operating procedure (SOP) and they have consulted many friends, including India. “That’s a conversation going on for some period of time. India has expressed its concerns over a long time, but we have come out with the SOP (standard operating procedure). When we were making that, we consulted many of our friends, including India. So, as long as it complies with the SOP, we have no problem. But if it doesn’t comply with the SOP, we have a problem,” Ali Sabry told ANI. He said that Sri Lanka has not given permission for the Chinese vessel Shi Yan 6 to dock in October, adding that negotiations are ongoing. “So, therefore, as far as I know, we have not given permission to come to Sri Lanka in October. Negotiations are going on. Indian security concerns, which are legitimate, are very, very important for us. We have always said that because we want to keep our region a zone of peace,” said Ali Sabry. Sri Lankan President Ranil Wickremesinghe too had said that an SOP had been worked out for foreign vessels. The Chinese research vessel was expected in Sri Lanka in October to conduct research along with the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA). US Under Secretary Victoria Nuland, during her meeting with Sri Lankan Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, had raised concerns regarding Shi Yan 6’s visit. Taking to X, formerly Twitter, Victoria Nuland stated, “The US supports a strong and prosperous Sri Lanka. Our work together continues at #UNGA. I met with @MFA_SriLanka, Minister Ali Sabry to discuss US economic assistance, human rights, and our shared vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific.” India had expressed its security concerns over the docking of the vessel at the Sri Lankan port as it was shown as a research vessel with the capability of mapping the ocean bed, which is critical to anti-submarine operations of the Chinese Navy. The Chinese research ship had docked at Sri Lanka’s Hambantota Port. (ANI)

title: One millionth tourist for 2023 comes from Russia
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka yesterday (26) celebrated the arrival of its one millionth tourist in 2023. This is the first time since 2019 that the country has topped a million tourist arrivals. Russian nationals, Alex Mazkov and his family, became the symbolic millionth tourists of the year, arriving on an Oman Airlines flight (WY-373). Their journey took them from Russia to Muscat in Oman and then to the BIA. On arrival at BIA, the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) extended a warm welcome to the family. Dr. Prasad Jayasekera, Director of SLTPB, highlighted the significance of this achievement, noting that it had been three years since Sri Lanka had reached the milestone of welcoming one million tourists in a single year, with the last being in 2019. In the first 24 days of September alone, Sri Lanka recorded over 88,000 tourist arrivals, contributing to the year-to-date figure. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Office for National Unity, Reconciliation Bill published
author: Author not found
Content: The Bill establishing the Office for National Unity and Reconciliation has been published in the Gazette. As per the directive of the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms, this Bill was gazetted on 22 September. This legislation is driven by the need for national unity and reconciliation in Sri Lanka. Its primary aim is to create a reconciliation office that fosters a society where all communities coexist harmoniously. The composition of this office includes one member, nominated by the Minister and appointed by the President, along with 10 other members appointed by the President based on the Minister’s recommendations. Their terms in office will last three years. The appointment of the chairman will be made by the President, with recommendations from the Minister. One of the crucial responsibilities of the Office of Reconciliation is to advise the government on measures to address issues that negatively impact national unity and to resolve tensions and conflicts between different communities. Furthermore, the Office of Reconciliation is tasked with finding solutions to post-conflict challenges such as the resettlement of internally displaced persons, as well as the rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-combatants. To oversee the affairs of the Office of Reconciliation, a Secretariat will be established, and a Director General will be appointed as its Chief Executive Officer. Additionally, this Bill empowers the filing of cases in the Court of Appeal against individuals who provide false information to the office and obstruct the execution of its functions.

title: Retired military officer jailed for abusing minor
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige, yesterday (26), sentenced a retired senior military officer to 15 years RI on finding him guilty of sexually abusing his 15-year-old niece. The Judge also ordered the convict, to pay compensation of Rs 250, 000 to the aggrieved party and also ordered him to pay a fine of Rs 25,000. Judge Patabendige in his judgment said that he was sentencing the accused, as the prosecution had proved its charges against him, beyond all reasonable doubt. Attorney-at-Law Asitha Vipulanayake, appearing on behalf of the accused, urged the Judge to pass a lenient penalty on his client, considering his age. The Attorney General had indicted the retired officer over the incident, which had taken place 14 years ago. BY Hannsi Nanayakkara

title: Gem mining on Mahaweli lands post-harvest discussed
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministerial Consultative Committee on Plantation Industries is reviewing the possibility of granting permission for gem mining on Mahaweli lands during the post-harvest period. During a recent meeting held in Parliament and chaired by Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, Minister of Industry, the Committee discussed this matter in consultation with the National Gems and Jewellery Commission. Additionally, the Committee addressed concerns about the equitable distribution of profits from gemstone mining among the workers involved in these activities. The Minister instructed the authorities to ensure that employees receive their rightful share. The Committee also deliberated on the steps taken and progress achieved in addressing credit issues faced by small and medium enterprises affected by Covid-19. Officials provided information about the SMILE loan scheme implemented under the Ministry of Industry to support small and medium enterprises. Furthermore, the Committee approved the Regulations published in the Gazette under the Companies Act No. 07 of 2007.

title: Four excise officers suspended
author: Author not found
Content: Several excise officers, of the Tangalle Station, were suspended due to their alleged involvement in the abduction and assault of a ‘Beedi’ manufacturer in Walasmulla, as well as their attempt to extort a bribe. The Commissioner General of Excise, following the directives of the State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya has suspended the officers. Siyambalapitiya has also instructed that legal action to be taken against these officers, regardless of their ranks. The ‘beedi’ manufacturer’s licence expired on 26 June.  Meanwhile, a group of excise officers, including the Officer-in-Charge (OIC) of the Tangalle Excise Station, visited his residence on 18 September. Initially, they threatened to file a case against the manufacturer for not renewing his licence. However, they later demanded a bribe of Rs 1.4 million to settle the matter without pursuing legal action. When the ‘Beedi’ manufacturer refused to pay the bribe, the excise officers forcibly abducted him using a three-wheeler, assaulted him and allegedly stole Rs 1 million from him. The assault was captured on nearby CCTV cameras. Following a complaint filed at the Walasmulla Police station, the Tangalle crimes investigation unit launched an inquiry into the incident. On Monday (25), five individuals, including the OIC, two officers, and the driver from the Tangalle Excise Station were arrested, along with an Army sergeant. After being produced before the Walasmulla Magistrate, the suspects were remanded until 5 October. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: GRTA repeats call to repair cooling system
author: Author not found
Content: Radiological Technologists reiterated their call to the Health Ministry and the authorities to take action to attend to repairs of the linear accelerator machine at the Teaching Hospital Batticaloa, which also catered to patients in the South. It has been out of order since 22 August 2023. President of the Government Radiological Technologists’ Association (GRTA), Chanaka Dharmawickrema yesterday (26) said according to the service provider, the breakdown was due to a fault in the air conditioning system of the unit where the machine is installed. Failure to control temperature and humidity has been cited as the cause of machine breakdown. Dharmawickrema said the two linear accelerator machines in the National Hospital Kandy have been out of action since November last year, owing to the faulty in cooling system of the building where the machines are kept. He said at least 40 to 50 patients were being treated daily by these machines at the Teaching Hospital, Batticaloa. The Hospital caters to patients from Hambantota, Moneragala, Ampara, Batticaloa, Trincomalee, Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa and Kandy, the President of the GRTA pointed out. Radiation therapy using linear accelerator machines can be identified as the most modern treatment method for patients with cancer. Through this treatment, the cancerous cells can be destroyed successfully without harming the healthy cells adjacent to them. Currently, He noted that there were only ten such machines in State hospitals, namely Apeksha Hospital (05), National Hospital Kandy(02), Teaching Hospitals, Jaffna and Karapitiya had one linear accelerator machine each. He said steps had been taken to inform all relevant parties of the breakdown but till now the necessary work to restore the machine has not been done. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SOC to summon IRD officials soon
author: Author not found
Content: The officials at Inland Revenue Department (IRD), who have allegations of corruption, will be summoned, by the Sectoral Oversight Committee (SOC) on National Economic and Physical Plans, soon, Chair of the Committee Mahindananda Aluthgamage said yesterday (26). Speaking at a media briefing held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Aluthgamage pointed out the urgent need for the establishment of a dedicated unit tasked with overseeing institutions responsible for tax revenue generation, including the Inland Revenue Department. The government has set ambitious revenue targets, including Rs 3,101 billion from the Inland Revenue Department, Rs 1,217 billion from Sri Lanka Customs and Rs 217 billion from the Excise Department. Unfortunately, current figures fall short of these expectations, with the Inland Revenue Department collecting Rs 956 billion, Sri Lanka Customs contributing Rs 578 billion, and the Excise Department generating Rs 109 billion, totalling only Rs 1,643 billion. The government is now facing the task of bridging this revenue shortfall, he said. He also stressed that the government’s imperative role in taking decisive actions against officials who are not actively contributing to the growth of the State’s tax revenue. Aluthgamage asserted, “A pivotal meeting took place with President Ranil Wickremesinghe and representatives from the International Monetary Fund. These discussions yielded remarkable results. Today, they are scheduled to update the nation on the progress made in line with the government’s agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF).” The IMF has pinpointed three critical areas of focus during these discussions. As a result, the government has pledged to reduce inflation to a single digit, fortify foreign reserves and augment government tax revenue. “Of particular note, food inflation, previously at an alarming 95%, has significantly dropped to -5%. Overall inflation has decreased from 70% to a mere 2.6%, while foreign reserves have seen substantial growth, increasing from USD 20 million to USD 4 billion. However, the primary emphasis of the IMF remains centered on boosting government revenue, primarily due to the fact that 90% of government income is derived from taxes,” he elaborated. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Cabinet nod for USD 200M ADB loan
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet has approved the proposal to enter into a loan agreement with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for a sum of USD 200 million. The loan carries an annual interest rate of two per cent and has a repayment period of 25 years, including a grace period of five years. The Government has engaged in preliminary discussions with the ADB to secure two separate loan facilities, each totaling USD 200 million. These loans are intended to support the implementation of two sub-programmes under the economic stabilisation and reformation programme. The first sub-programme aims to expedite reforms that will strengthen the conflict management framework and enhance stability in the finance sector. Meanwhile, the second sub-programme seeks to establish a comprehensive and resilient financial system.  In light of these objectives, Cabinet approval has been granted for the proposal submitted by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who also serves as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies, to proceed with the loan agreement with the ADB.

title: Appropriation Bill for 2024 to be presented on 13 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: The Government will present the Appropriation Bill for the fiscal year 2024 to Parliament on 13 November, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. Accordingly, the debate on the 2nd Reading of the Appropriation Bill will take place from 14 – 21 November, with the vote on the 2nd Reading scheduled for 21 November. Siyambalapitiya added that the debate on the third reading will be from 22 November to 13 December. Cabinet yesterday (26) approved the submission of the Appropriation Bill for the year 2024 to Parliament. In July 2023, the Cabinet had previously approved the drafting of the Appropriation Bill for the fiscal year 2024. Subsequently, clearance from the Attorney General was obtained for the draft Appropriation Bill for the same fiscal year, prepared by the Legal Draftsman. President Ranil Wickremesinghe, acting in his capacity as the Minister of Finance proposed to Cabinet that the Draft bill be published in the government gazette and subsequently presented to Parliament for approval. The Cabinet, in response to the President’s proposal, approved the submission of the 2024 appropriation bill to Parliament for its consideration and approval.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President calls for re-examination of King Sitawaka Rajasingha’s legacy
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, speaking at the ‘Sitawaka – Sisu Arunalu’ programme, held at Rajasingha Central College Hanwella on Monday (25), called for a fresh analysis of the life and character of King Sitawaka Rajasingha, a courageous and patriotic king of historical significance. The event, where school equipment and uniforms were distributed to 12,000 schoolchildren, was made possible through the support of the Chinese Government. The President emphasised that King Rajasingha, has been overshadowed by history due to a reference in Chulavansa made two centuries after his reign. President Wickremesinghe urged a reconsideration of the historical approach that has favoured victorious figures while neglecting those who faced defeat. Symbolising the distribution of school equipment and uniforms, the President presented school equipment to several students during the event. It is worth mentioning that this assistance is a direct outcome of the Prime Minister’s visit to China. Hanwella, Avissawella, situated in the Western Province, boasts an advanced education system. The Prime Minister is making a substantial commitment towards its further development. Highlighting the significance of preserving historical and cultural heritage, President Wickremesinghe revealed that he has instructed the Department of Archaeology to explore the archaeological treasures of the Sitawaka Kingdom. This effort aims to shed light on the historical significance of the region and pave the way for the construction of a museum dedicated to Sitawaka’s history. President Wickremesinghe emphasised the need for the country’s children to receive both modern education and knowledge about Sri Lanka’s rich cultural history. He expressed his commitment to ensuring that Sri Lankan youth are equipped with the skills and knowledge necessary to shape the nation’s future. Furthermore, President Wickremesinghe called for a re-evaluation of the character and history of King Sitawaka Rajasingha, suggesting that the narrative surrounding those who lost battles in history should be reconsidered. In an effort to encourage knowledge-sharing, President Wickremesinghe invited local school students to submit facts about the Kingdom of Sitawaka and King Sitawaka Rajasingha. He pledged to reward the school that submits the most compelling information. Despite recent economic challenges, President Wickremesinghe assured that the Government remains committed to allocating more resources for free education and healthcare. He expressed his dissatisfaction with the current education system and his determination to transform Sri Lanka into a vocational training centre while providing children with an education system that empowers them for the future. During the event, a poem was recited in honour of King Rajasingha, highlighting his historic significance. King Rajasingha’s actions are recognised for preventing Sri Lanka from facing a fate similar to Mozambique or Angola and for being the only South Asian king to successfully defeat the Portuguese. President Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed the importance of preserving the historical legacy of Kingdom of Sitawaka, emphasising its role in safeguarding Sri Lanka’s independence. To ensure this heritage is passed down to future generations, he announced plans to establish a museum in the Sitawaka area. Furthermore, the President instructed Chief of Defence Staff Shavendra Silva to oversee the construction of memorials at key historical battle sites, such as Mulleriyawa and Danthurei. These efforts aim to commemorate the bravery and sacrifices of those who contributed to Sri Lanka’s history. President Wickremesinghe emphasised the need to revisit the legacy of King Sitawaka Rajasingha, a courageous and patriotic leader who has been overlooked by history. He pointed out that historical accounts, like Chulavansa, have often favoured winners over losers, neglecting those who lost battles. As a result, he called for a re-evaluation of King Sitawaka Rajasingha’s character and contributions. In addition, President Wickremesinghe instructed the Department of Archaeology to commence work on preserving the archaeological significance of the Sitawaka region, which is expected to undergo rapid urbanisation in the coming years. This proactive approach aims to safeguard the historical heritage of Sitawaka from potential loss, similar to what occurred in the city of Kotte. President Wickremesinghe stressed the importance of understanding the past while building the future. To encourage this, he invited students from Sitawaka schools to submit essays detailing the history of Kingdom of Sitawaka. A prize will be awarded to the school with the most outstanding submission, promoting a deeper appreciation of Sri Lanka’s historical heritage among the youth. The event was attended by Justice Minister Dr. Wijayadasa Rajapakshe, Public Security Minister Tiran Alles, Members of Parliament Jagath Kumara and Yadamini Gunawardena, Western Province Governor Marshal of the Air Force Roshan Gunathilake, Jagath Surasena, Principal Rajasingha Central College as well as teachers, parents, students and other dignitaries.

title: ‘Annual Pirith Chanting Ceremony’ of J’Pura Medical Faculty
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘Annual Pirith Chanting Ceremony 2023’ is organised by the Buddhist Society of the Faculty of Medical Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura to honour the invaluable cadaver donations made by the respected late donors and their family members. These selfless donations have made it possible for countless young, aspiring medical students to learn the necessary skills to be moulded into being capable and proficient medical officers for the country. The Piritha as it’s commonly known, is put together each year with the tireless efforts of the junior most batch, under the careful guidance of the senior most para clinical batch present at the faculty at that time. This makes it possible to pass on virtues that are truly admirable and valuable, for generations to come. Also, it helps in forming a bond of fellowship within and among the students. As such, it is our hope to inculcate better values and attitudes in our medical undergraduates by upholding the tradition of our annual meritorious act. Additionally, the Buddhist Society conducts several other donation programmes that are beneficial to society. Among these are, the annual stethoscope scholarship given to the batch of undergraduates that will be commencing their clinical education and the project of donating essentials to people living in rural areas and those who are impoverished are noteworthy. The ceremony is scheduled to be held on 13 October at the faculty premises followed by an almsgiving the following morning for25 venerable monks. We invite all faculty undergraduates, medical professionals, and well-wishers to join us in this noble cause. For further information, contact Adithya on +9471 869 6889.

title: ‘Saviya’ Community-Based Rehabilitation
author: Author not found
Content: The Western Province Community Police Division conducted the inaugural ‘Saviya’ community-based rehabilitation programme for the Colombo South Police Division, on Saturday, 23 September, at Sanghamitta Vidyalaya, Borella. SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon was the Chief Guest. The programme included a medical clinic and a counselling centre for those addicted to narcotics. (Pix by Amila Gamage)

title: S&P upgrades local currency sovereign credit rating
author: Author not found
Content: S&P Global Ratings raised Sri Lanka’s ratings from ‘SD/SD’ (selective default) to ‘CCC+/C’, reflecting a forward-looking opinion on the country’s creditworthiness in local currency obligations. This upgrade comes after the completion of the government’s domestic debt exchange program with superannuation funds, which S&P Global Ratings viewed as a distressed restructuring. In addition to the overall upgrade, the issue rating on Sri Lanka’s local currency bond maturing in October 2023 has been raised to ‘CCC+’ from ‘D’. However, the long-term foreign currency rating remains at ‘SD’, and no outlooks are assigned to ‘SD’ ratings as they represent a condition and not a forward-looking default probability opinion. The stable outlook on the long-term local currency rating reflects improvements in the government’s debt profile through domestic restructuring, despite ongoing economic, external, and fiscal pressures. S&P Global Ratings stated that the ratings could be lowered if further indications of restructuring of obligations denominated in Sri Lankan rupees (LKR) to commercial creditors arise, such as rapid inflation, increased government interest burdens, or worsening fiscal performance leading to funding pressures in local currency. Conversely, an improvement in the sustainability of the government’s local currency debt stock could lead to a further upgrade. This might occur if the government’s fiscal metrics and the overall performance of the Sri Lankan economy improve more rapidly than expected. S&P Global Ratings also mentioned that the post-restructuring ratings tend to be in the ‘CCC’ or low ‘B’ categories, depending on the new debt structure and the sovereign’s capacity to support it. The successful completion of the domestic debt exchange programme and a separate restructuring exercise on debt owed to the Central Bank of Sri Lanka is viewed as supportive of Sri Lanka’s near-term creditworthiness on its local currency obligations. These actions will reduce refinancing needs and the government’s interest bill. However, Sri Lanka’s ability to meet its financial commitments in the long term remains dependent on favourable economic developments. As of May 2023, local currency-denominated Treasury Bills and Bonds outstanding were approximately LKR 14.1 trillion, equivalent to about 60% of GDP. Despite ongoing restructuring efforts, Sri Lanka’s net general government indebtedness is expected to remain at more than 100% of GDP through at least 2026, with the government’s interest burden remaining above 50% in 2026. These figures will depend on several economic variables and the outcomes of future restructuring efforts.

title: Miriyagalle to become vegetable hub for Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: Miriyagalle village, in Padukka, is poised to become a dedicated vegetable-growing hub, to supply the much-needed vegetables for Colombo. This is being done in order to assist consumers in Colombo, who are forced to purchase vegetables and fruits from far-flung regions of the island, resulting in their having to pay significantly higher prices. Notably, prices of upcountry and low-country vegetables are exorbitant in Colombo and other Western Province Districts. In response to this issue, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera has directed officials to initiate a project aimed at cultivating vegetables required by Colombo, within the district itself. Consequently, Miriyagalle has been chosen for this endeavour, with an initial group of thirty farmers from the village gearing up for vegetable cultivation across 250 acres. The Ministry of Agriculture is providing comprehensive support and facilities to the farmers in Miriyagalle, including financial subsidies of Rs 500,000 per farmer for poly tunnel cultivation. The inflated prices of vegetables can be largely attributed to losses during transportation from economic centres like Dambulla and Tambuttegama to Colombo, increased transportation costs, and the influence of intermediaries. These intermediaries buy produce from farmers and sell them to Colombo consumers at marked-up prices. A recent discussion at the Ministry of Agriculture resulted in the Minister’s instruction to develop Miriyagalle as a dedicated vegetable-growing hub for Colombo. The Minister emphasised the need for this initiative saying, “In Anuradhapura and Moneragala, pumpkins that cannot be sold for even Rs 10 go up to Rs 80 in Colombo. This price will never decrease. It had been reported in the media that 10 kg of kekiri had to be sold to pay the fee to use the toilets once at the Dambulla Economic Centre. Yet, in Colombo, a kg of kekiri costs about Rs 50.” The minister further said, growing the vegetables Colombo needs within the district itself will help curb the influence of middlemen and prevent consumers from being exploited. The vegetables cultivated in Miriyagalle will be directly supplied to Colombo, bypassing intermediaries. The minister assured that all necessary support and facilities would be provided to the farmers involved in this project. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Dehiwala-Mt. Lavinia MC to clean-up beach
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Commissioner of the Dehiwala-Mount Lavinia Municipal Council Anusha Kumara said, a programme to clean a 6.5-kilometre stretch of the Dehiwala-Mount Lavinia Beach front has been undertaken. He said, the beach front had been polluted beyond measure due to the irregular release of garbage and refuse and observed that the MC has decided to initiate a cleaning programme to enhance the beauty of the beach front for both locals and foreigners. According to Kumara, the ad-hoc dumping of garbage and other materials to the beach had resulted in sea pollution increasing and  due to the present rainy weather plastics, polythene and glass bottles had washed ashore. BY Shehan Jayawardene – Ratmalana

title: Farmers happy with prices for rice, maize
author: Author not found
Content: J.M. Nimal Bandara, Chairman of the Joint Farmers’ Organisation of Minipe, expressed satisfaction with the prices received by rice and maize farmers in Minipe this year. He said, Minipe farmers received favourable prices, with wheat fetching between 110 and 120 rupees per kg and maize prices ranging from Rs 140 to 170 per kg. He further remarked that these prices brought happiness when compared to the previous season’s rates. The farmers’ organisation’s attention is now directed towards cultivating an additional season next year. Bandara conveyed these sentiments during the District Agriculture Committee meeting held at the Kandy District Secretariat Auditorium on Monday (25). Expanding on their agricultural efforts, Bandara mentioned that approximately 250 acres of rice and 150 acres of maize were cultivated. He emphasised that providing a fertiliser subsidy for maize cultivation could facilitate its growth and potentially contribute to controlling the prices of chicken feed. Kandy District Secretary Chandana Tennakoon, presented the facts and informed the committee that he had already made requests to the relevant authorities, including the Ministry of Agriculture, regarding the provision of fertiliser subsidies for maize cultivation. He expressed optimism that there would be a positive response to these requests. The meeting also saw the participation of Additional District Secretary Lalith Atampawala, District Director of Agriculture R.P. Kasturiarachchi and several other committee members. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Rangebandara slams Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara criticised Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, for what he considers to be imprudent claims and allegations, likening him to a ‘political joker’. Rangebandara suggested that Premadasa is skilled at entertaining people with fictitious stories that make them laugh. Rangebandara further said Premadasa’s reliance on such tactics stems from his  inability to politically survive without them, which is why he resorts to making baseless allegations in public and taking up issues related to social media. Premadasa, according to Rangebandara, is attempting to turn the issue into a new controversy and is even threatening to resort to extreme measures if social media is suppressed. Speaking at Sirikotha, Rangebandara said, while the Constitution guarantees freedom of expression, it also imposes limits to protect the rights and privileges of everyone in the country. Rangebandara said, significant progress has been made in various aspects of the country under the administration of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. He said, solutions have been found for many pressing issues and the country is on a path to recovery. He also said, President Wickremesinghe’s recent participation in the G-77 Summit in Cuba was testament to his global leadership recognition. He said, that President Wickremesinghe had held constructive discussions with Samantha Power, South Korean Prime Minister and the King of Malaysia with regard to the current crisis situation the necessity of assistance from them to rescue the country from the bankruptcy it has been plunged into today. President Wickremesinghe has been invited to take part in the Youth Conference to be held in Germany and is expected to deliver an oration under the title ‘Climate Changes and Restructuring Debts’.  Very soon Cuba’s President is expected to visit Sri Lanka on an invitation extended by President Wickremesinghe. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: FORMER SDIG gets five-year jail term
author: Author not found
Content: Ratnapura High Court Judge Lanka Jayaratne, yesterday (25) sentenced former SDIG of the Sabaragamuwa Province, Lalith Jayasinghe, to five years in jail. The Judge, in her verdict deemed that the prosecution had proved its charges, against the accused former SDIG, beyond a reasonable doubt and thus imposed the said sentence on him and instructed him to pay a fine of Rs 25,000 as well.  The sentence was imposed by Judge Jayaratne, over the case filed against the convict for influencing the Kahawatte Police OIC Lalith Rajamanthri, not to apprehend State Minister Premalal Jayasekera, in connection with a shooting incident targeting a group of people, who were assembling a platform for a political event in Ratnapura, in the lead-up to the Presidential Election, eight years ago. The Attorney General had indicted the accused former SDIG, before the said High Court and for having flouted Provisions contained in Section 209 of the Penal Code. Deputy Solicitor General Janaka Bandara, prosecuting on behalf of the Attorney General, addressing the Court, before the passing of the sentence, stated that influencing a subordinate of whatever rank in a State institution, is a punishable offence under the law and that such actions, cannot be condoned under any circumstance. Hence, he requested the Court, to mete out suitable punishment to the accused former SDIG, in order to deter others, from the public service, committing such offences in the future. On 5 January 2015, the Pelmadulla Chief Magistrate issued an arrest warrant on the lawmaker and several local politicians, over their alleged involvement in the shooting incident, at a venue of an election rally of former President Maithripala Sirisena, who was the Common Opposition Candidate at the time.  A political supporter, who was engaged in decorating an election stage, was wounded in the shooting and succumbed to injuries in hospital on 8 January of that year. MP Premalal Jayasekara, former Sabaragamuwa Provincial Council Member Nilantha Jayakody and former Kahawatta Pradeshiya Sabha chairman Vajira Darshana were arrested in January 2015, over the incident, whereas MP Jayasekara was later enlarged on bail in December that year. In July, 2020, Jayasekara and the other two accused were sentenced to death, over the fatal shooting incident. The verdict in the case had been delivered by the Ratnapura High Court. However, later in March last year, the Court of Appeal acquitted MP Premalal Jayasekara and two others, of charges pertaining to the relevant shooting incident, since, there was no evidence of the three accused being in possession of firearms, at the time of the incident and them firing shots. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Pigs to be tested for Nipah virus
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) is scheduled to conduct random sample testing in piggeries to check for the Nipah virus. DAPH Director General, K.A.C.H.A. Kothalawala yesterday (25) said that measures would be taken to test for the virus despite Sri Lanka not being at risk of contracting the zoonotic disease transmitted by bats. Currently the disease is present in the South Indian State of Kerala. However, she noted,  the country’s location has helped as bats cannot fly over the sea. “Also, we do not import animal products which slim down possibilities of the Nipah spread in Sri Lanka,” she noted adding however that the Department had testing kits which it would anyway use to test the local swine for the bat borne disease. Fielding questions Dr. Kothalawala noted that the Western and North Western Provinces had the highest number of piggeries in the country.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Probation officers to be made JPs
author: Author not found
Content: To alleviate the challenges faced by children involved in legal matters, especially when obtaining affidavits, a Gazette Notification has been released to address the appointment of probation officers as Justices of the Peace. In accordance with the Judicature Act No. 02 of 1978, Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe has issued Gazette Notification No. 2347/10-2023 to enact this change. The notification stipulates that every Probation Officer, from the Department of Probation and Child Care Services, currently in active permanent service, will hold the ex-officio position of Justice of the Peace for the respective administrative district within their province of appointment. Additionally, the Gazette Notification specifies that every National Integration Coordinating Officer attached to the Divisional Secretariats, also in active permanent service, will automatically assume the role of Justice of the Peace for the administrative district corresponding to their Divisional Secretariat Division. This significant step has been taken by the Minister of Justice in response to the advocacy efforts of the Parliamentary Caucus for Children. The aim is to streamline legal procedures and alleviate the burden on children involved in legal proceedings by facilitating the availability of justices of the peace through probation officers. During the recent session of the Parliamentary Caucus for Children, chaired by MP Rohini Kumari Wijerathna and attended by Provincial Commissioners, including the Commissioner from the Department of Probation and Child Care Services, an extensive discussion took place. The participants, while expressing their concerns and offering suggestions, highlighted a pressing issue in the judicial process. They pointed out that children under probation faced inconvenience when required to seek third-party assistance in obtaining affidavits. Recognising the significance of addressing this challenge, the Parliamentary Caucus for Children proposed the appointment of Justices of the Peace, subsequently presenting this proposal to the attention of Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. Wijerathna expressed her heartfelt appreciation and gratitude to Minister Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. She acknowledged this achievement as a remarkable milestone for the Caucus and extended her thanks to all dedicated participants at the Caucus meeting held on 22 September 2023.

title: Ranawaka’s, Asmadala’s bail conditions eased
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta, yesterday (25) eased the bail conditions imposed on first accused MP Patali Champika Ranawaka and third accused, former OIC of the Welikada Police ASP Sudath Asmadala, in the hit-and-run case, filed against them, where Ranawaka has been charged with causing grievous injury to youth Sandeep Sampath, at Rajagiriya seven years ago. Accordingly, the Judge lifted the bail conditions imposed on them, where they were ordered to report to the Colombo Crimes Division (CCD), on each first and last Sunday of the month. The Court did so having considered requests made on behalf of the two accused, by their Counsel, who urged to lift the bail conditions, as they had not violated those conditions to date and had been behaving in a responsible manner. The State Counsel appearing on behalf of the Attorney General, then informed the Court, that the latter too, was not opposed to lifting bail conditions imposed on the two defendants. Afterwards Judge Thotawatta, temporarily lifted the overseas travel ban imposed on the Parliamentarian, from today(26) until 1 March next year. The State Counsel then told the Court, that the Supreme Court which had previously slapped an interim injunction preventing the hearing of the case, had further extended it, till 31 January 2024. The High Court Judge then deferred further proceedings of the trial, to 4 March next year. The Attorney General has indicted Ranawaka, Dilum Thusitha Kumara, who had posed as the driver of the vehicle, which had been involved in the accident and the former OIC of the Welikada Police, before the High Court on the charges off compiling fake evidence, fleeing after causing a traffic accident, failing to bring the incident to the notice of the Police and reckless driving etc. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: MCPA wants probe into shady deal involving antibiotic
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), urged the Ministry of Finance to probe an alleged corruption taking place in the purchase of a strong antibiotic, causing heavy financial losses to the country.    MCPA President, Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa, yesterday (25) urged the Ministry of Finance to look into what appeared an allegedly shady deal, in purchasing the antibiotic ‘Meropenem’, in which the Health Ministry had purchased the medicine at nearly Rs 900 per vial last year, at a time when the rupee had depreciated against the dollar. However now, after the rupee has strengthened, the Ministry was purchasing it at Rs 2,000 per vial. Sri Lanka was regularly purchasing the same antibiaotic through emergency purchasing when it was revealed that there was an adequate quantity of the Meropenem group of antibiotics in the country, according to the Health Ministry’s ‘Swastha,’ data system, he alleged. The country was incurring a loss of over Rs 80 million as a result, he lamented urging the President to initiate a probe into the alleged fraud. Dr. Sanjeewas noted that the particular antibiotic, was often used only in special cases and in the main National Hospitals and teaching hospitals in the island. It was not used as an antibiotic in peripheral or regional hospitals. The MCPA President asserted that going by the manner in which the Health Ministry was purchasing Meropenem it would prove strongly that Sri Lanka was violating the National Policy on the Use of Antibiotics. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Kenyan youth nabbed with Rs 300M worth cocaine at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: A Kenyan national was arrested at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) with approximately 4 kilograms of cocaine, valued at approximately Rs 300 million, on Sunday (24) evening. The 26-year-old passenger, who had recently arrived from Ethiopia, was detained at the airport’s arrival terminal by the Sri Lanka Customs narcotics control unit. Reportedly, the suspect, identified as a Kenyan car dealer, had embarked on a journey from Ethiopia’s capital, Addis Ababa, to Doha, Qatar, and subsequently boarded a Qatar Airways flight (QR 654) to Sri Lanka. Customs officers made the discovery of 180 capsules of cocaine, totalling 4 kg in weight, concealed inside three metal cookie tins located within his hand luggage. The arrest was made based on foreign intelligence received by the Sri Lanka Customs narcotics control unit, as the suspect attempted to pass through the ‘Green Channel’ at the airport. Subsequently, the Kenyan passenger, who had arrived in Sri Lanka for the first time, was handed over to officers from the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) at BIA, along with the confiscated drugs, for further investigation. BY T.K.G. Kapila

title: CID ordered to hand over Schaffter’s body to family
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Additional Magistrate yesterday (25) issued an order for the CID to release the late businessman Dinesh Schaffter’s remains to his family following the completion of the post-mortem. The specialised medical committee, tasked with investigating Schaffter’s death, informed the Court that their inquiry had concluded, paving the way for the release of the deceased businessman’s remains. Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya noted that the five-member expert committee, led by Prof. Asela Mendis, appointed by the Court for this purpose, had completed its judicial investigations. In response to the expert committee’s request, the Additional Magistrate ordered the CID to hand over the body to Schaffter’s family, with Prof. Clifford Perera and Judicial Medical Officer P.R. Ruwanpura overseeing the handing over. Furthermore, a recall of the case has been scheduled for 9 October 2023. Schaffter’s death, which has remained largely unresolved, led to the exhumation of his remains on 25 May 2023, under judicial supervision and armed security, as per the orders of the Colombo Magistrate’s Court. The former Director of Janashakthi Group of Companies was discovered bound in his car at the General Cemetery Borella, on 15 December 2022, and succumbed to his injuries a day later while undergoing treatment in the National Hospital’s ICU in Colombo. On 19 May, the five-member committee comprising judicial and forensic medical experts, tasked with determining the true cause of the businessman’s death, formally petitioned the Colombo Magistrate’s Court to grant permission for the exhumation of the deceased’s body. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Committee appointed to probe death of new born twins
author: Author not found
Content: The Director General of Health Services (DGHS) has appointed a team to probe the controversial death of twins born on 9 September. Acting Deputy Director General (Medical Services-II) Dr. G. Wijesuriya yesterday (25) confirmed that a two-member committee had been appointed to probe the controversial deaths of twins at the Kalubowila Teaching Hospital almost ten days after they were born. A pregnant mother from Honnanthara, Kesbewa had been admitted on 8 September 2023 and had delivered twins (a girl and a boy) on 9 September 2023. But since the infants had a low birth weight, they had been admitted to the Hospital’s Neonatal Unit. However, ten days later, the boy had died, while doctors claimed that the infant had died due to a germ entering his body. Subsequently, it was revealed that he had die due to a difficulty in breathing. On 23, September 2023 the baby girl too had died. The parents and relatives had lodged a complaint with the Hospital Administration and the Kohuwala Police alleging that the negligence on the part of the hospital staff had led to the deaths of the twins.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Bullets parts from Galle businessman’s body sent to GA
author: Author not found
Content: The Judicial Medical Officer’s (JMO) Office, at the Teaching Hospital Karapitiya, said that parts of bullets removed from the body of slain millionaire businessman of Galle, Lalith Mendis, were sent to the Government Analyst (GA) for the requisite tests. Accordingly, four bullet parts were located in the body of the murdered businessman during the post-mortem and were sent to the GA for the necessary tests. It is also said that some 10-odd bullets were sprayed into the body of the late businessman and that he had succumbed to injuries caused to his head and brain, the postmortem revealed. BY Lalith Chaminda

title: Head-on collision kills two
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons died and three others were injured when a three-wheeler collided with a private passenger bus in the Beligamuwa area of Galewela on the Dambulla-Kurunegala main road yesterday (24) morning. The injured were a male, female and a child. They are said to be in critical condition and have been referred to the Dambulla Base Hospital after initially being admitted to the Galewela Hospital. The dead were males, aged 31 and 34, who have been identified as residents of the Arachchikattuwa area. Police suspect that the head-on collision could have occurred as a result of the driver of the three-wheeler falling asleep at the wheel.

title: Abducted bus driver escapes
author: Author not found
Content: The individual who was abducted while travelling by bus in Gampola had managed to escape from his abductors at Orugodawatta, in the night of 24 September. He had gone to the Gampola Police Station and had been admitted to the Teaching Hospital Gampola. The individual, identified as Hemantha Rajapaksa, a bus driver attached to the Gampola SLTB Depot and resident of Kothmale, was abducted when he was on his way to report for duty at dawn on 24 September in an SLTB bus plying from Mawela to Kandy. Four people who entered the bus, after blocking it with a van at Jayamalapura, in Gampola, began assaulting him and inquiring about a sword. They had then bundled him into the van and driven away. He told the Police that his abducters inquired about a sword, that he sold to a person in Orugodawatta around six months ago and that he was taken to the said area. He stated that after grappling with his abductors he managed to escape from them and having run through a coconut plantation in Orugodawatta he boarded a bus from Nittambuwa to escape from his captors. Police said six males and a female arrived in the van to abduct the bus driver while it has also come to light that the bus driver previously served as a driver of a powerful former Minister from Kelaniya, whose ancestral heritage dated back to the reign of King Dutugemunu. Upon his arrival at the Police, after recording his statement he was admitted to hospital. BY Suranga Dilshan – Gampola

title: Vehicle revenue licence issuance suspended
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Transport has declared a temporary suspension of vehicle revenue licence issuance in the Western Province, due to a computer system upgrade. In an official statement, the Secretary of the Ministry of Transport announced that this suspension will be in effect from 27 September to 2 October 2023. During this period, vehicle revenue licences set to expire from 26 September onward can be renewed without incurring late penalties until 10 October. Furthermore, the option to obtain vehicle revenue licences online via www.motortraffic.wp.gov.lk, the official website of the Department of Motor Traffic, has also been temporarily halted from midnight on 24 September until 6 October 2023.

title: Protest against Hotel project encroaching Muthurajawela
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Dandugama, Ja -Ela staged a passionate protest against the commencement of a hotel project that involved encroaching upon the pristine Muthurajawela Wetland Sanctuary. Waving black flags and holding placards, the demonstrators marched through Dandugama to voice their fervent opposition. A. Tharanga, a local activist, actively engaged in the protest, expressed his concerns to the media, stating, “The reclamation of the Muthurajawela Wetland Sanctuary would have a detrimental impact not only on Ja-Ela but also on the entire Gampaha District. Muthurajawela is a world heritage site, with a fragile ecosystem, that houses a diverse range of bird species and a unique community of flora and fauna exclusive to Sri Lanka. Moreover, the sanctuary plays a crucial role in the local tidal process. If Muthurajawela is reclaimed for hotel construction, our future generations will undoubtedly condemn us for permitting such an environmental travesty.” Joining the protest, Kanchana Perera expressed her concerns, saying, “The reclamation of Muthurajawela spells doom for our villages and would lead to our having to face floods. Today, they are attempting to reclaim Muthurajawela by distributing bags of goods to some villagers and offering money to a few who are willing to compromise their principles.” Namal Suranga, the chief organiser of Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) in the Ja – Ela electorate, emphasised the significance of Muthurajawela’s ecosystem, saying, “Even former President Maithripala Sirisena recognised its importance by issuing a special gazette to prohibit its reclamation. Its value is apparent, but it has been threatened for personal gain. Today, the people have awakened to oppose these landfills.” When queried, Ajith Panditaratne, the Chairman of Malwatta Company, which is planning to construct a hotel complex on a portion of Muthurajawela said, “We are proceeding with this project after securing all the necessary permissions from relevant government authorities. This hotel project, spanning 52 acres, has received permission from the Attorney General’s office and the Court. We are following the prescribed guidelines and cannot execute it as we see fit. Furthermore, 20 acres will be allocated for the construction of tanks and reservoirs, benefiting the local community.” BY Prasanga Pawuluhewa – Ja Ela

title: Ashu claims President rebuilding int’l relations
author: Author not found
Content: Former MP Ashu Marasinghe yesterday (25) claimed that President Ranil Wickremesinghe is actively rebuilding international relations, particularly with the developed Western world, which had been disrupted due to the implementation of erroneous foreign policies by previous governing factions in the country. Marasinghe stated that the President has effectively dispelled any misconceptions held by the rest of the world, especially the developed Western nations, about Sri Lanka. He added that this positive situation has arisen due to the international community’s recognition of the foreign policies and goodwill that President Wickremesinghe has fostered, especially with donor countries such as Japan, the USA, India, China, Germany, and countries under the European Union’s jurisdiction. He noted that President Wickremesinghe’s vision has been embraced by both capitalist and socialist nations simultaneously, leading to tangible benefits for Sri Lanka. Marasinghe cited the President’s recent keynote address at a summit in Cuba, hosted by China, as a prime example of this. During a media briefing at Sirikotha, Marasinghe emphasised that President Wickremesinghe advocates for a foreign policy that doesn’t favour any specific political ideology or entity. In addition to addressing criticisms, President Wickremesinghe seized the opportunity during his recent tour to engage in discussions with leaders and high-ranking officials, particularly from Malaysia, South Korea, Germany and the USA, while in Cuba. As a result of these discussions, the South Korean leader promised President Wickremesinghe that they would consider providing more employment opportunities to Sri Lankans and prioritise Sri Lanka in their foreign employment programmes. Marasinghe further claimed that President Wickremesinghe’s statements to the American media, where he asserted that he is not beholden to any specific country like the USA, China, or India, clearly demonstrate his commitment to not being subservient to any global superpower, regardless of their economic and political stature. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Rajeev Amarasuriya appointed Country Representative
author: Author not found
Content: Attorney-at-Law Rajeev Amarasuriya has been appointed as the Sri Lanka Country Representative of the Commonwealth Legal Education Association (CLEA). Founded in 1971, the CLEA is a Commonwealth-wide body with regional Chapters and Committees in South Asia, Southern Africa, West Africa, the Caribbean and the United Kingdom, and fosters and promotes high standards of Legal Education in the Commonwealth. The goal of the Commonwealth Legal Education Association is to make Legal Education socially relevant and professionally useful, through Conferences, Moots, Newsletters, Lecture Series, Curriculum Development and activities for students. Amarasuriya is the Immediate Past Secretary of the Bar Association of Sri Lanka and is credited for introducing many innovative and highly successful Continuous Legal Education and Professional Development Programmes during the period of the Pandemic, including 175 publicly accessible Webinars, the introduction of the BASL Online Certificate Courses and many other such initiatives which to-date support the legal fraternity and law students. He is a sitting Member of the Council of the University of Colombo, a Board Member of the Sri Lanka Accounting and Auditing Standards Board, an Executive Committee Member of the Law Association for the Asia and Pacific [LAWASIA], a Member of the Standing Committee on Legal Studies of the UGC, among several other offices and positions held. He has also been a Member of the Council of Legal Education of Sri Lanka, a Commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission of Sri Lanka, a Member of the Advisory Board of the Faculty of Law, Sri Lanka Institute of Information Technology, a Member, Board of Governors, Sri Lanka National Arbitration Centre and the President, Alumni Association of the University of Colombo. He is also the Founder Editor of the Junior Bar Law Journal launched in 2004 and the Bar Association of Sri Lanka Sinhala Law Journal launched last year. He holds a Bachelor of Laws Degree with Honours from the University of Colombo, is the Gold Medal Winner of the Sri Lanka Law College, is a Fellow Member of CIMA (UK) and CMA Sri Lanka, an AFGG-Raisina Fellow and is reading for his PhD at the University of Colombo and has presented many papers at Conferences both Internationally and Nationally. The Executive Committee of the CLEA comprises; President – Senior Professor (Dr.) S.Sivakumar of the Indian Law Institute;Emeritus President / Immediate Past President – Prof. David Mac Quoid-Mason of the Centre for Socio-Legal Studies, South Africa; Vice Presidents Dr. Peter Slinn of the University of Notre Dame (London Law Centre), Dr. Joe Silva, former Principal Sri Lanka Law College and Prof. John Hatchard Emeritus Professor, University of Buckingham and Professor, UN Anti-Corruption Academy; General-Secretary Prof. Meera Furtado, Head of Law, Sussex University Studies and the Executive Committee Members and Regional Representatives; Australasia –  Prof (Dr.) Neil Boister, Professor, Faculty of Law, University of Canterbury, New Zealand; Europe – Prof.  Stéphanie Laulhé Shaelou, Professor of European Law and Reform,Director, Jean Monnet Centre of Excellence on the Rule of Law and European Values (CRoLEV); United Kingdom – Prof. Patricia Mc Kella, Associate Director, Undergraduate Laws Programme, University of London; South Africa – Dr.  Franaaz Khan, Department of Private Law, University of Johannesburg, South Africa, Asia -Prof. (Dr.) S. Sivakumar, Senior Professor, Indian Law Institute; Bangladesh – Barrister Prashanta Barua and Sri Lanka – Attorney Rajeev Amarasuriya.

title: London Venmai to be launched
author: Author not found
Content: The Tamil translation of Rodney Widanapathirana’s new novel, London Unusuma (London Heat) London Venmai will be launched on 27 September at the Colombo International Book Fair at BMICH, Colombo. The book was translated by Su Muralitharan and Published by London Tamil Literary Association

title: Feast of St. Mary’s Church
author: Author not found
Content: The 171st annual feast of the St. Mary’s Church, Kegalle was held on Sunday, 24 September 2023.

title: Coast conservation a vital income generator – Arundika
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s stunning beaches have earned global recognition, and as part of long-term investments, the Government has decided to extend investment prospects along its coastline. Close collaboration with agencies such as the Investment Promotion Board and the Ministry of Lands has been initiated, leading to a dedicated programme  aimed at revitalising and advancing the tourism sector, said Arundika Fernando, State Minister of Urban Development and Housing, at a  media briefing held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) recently. He added “Given our nation’s rich mineral resources, we have devised plans to expand investment opportunities while remaining committed to land conservation. Additionally, the Department of Coast Conservation actively participates in initiatives to enhance the value of our mineral resources. These resources have the potential to yield significant value through the production of value-added goods.” Fernando reiterated the country’s commitment to strengthen the economy through the proper use of mineral resources. He said the potential to create high-value-added products from these resources while underscoring the paramount importance of safeguarding the country’s land. “Furthermore, we are committed to introducing a new environmental and ocean protection Bill in our country. This legislation will play a vital role in safeguarding our natural resources. Our primary focus must centre on pioneering innovative programmes that contribute to our country’s economic recovery. Timely and effective resource management is crucial for initiating income-generating initiatives. Moreover, we aspire to establish a specialised Bank dedicated to the advancement of our domestic industries. Recognising that some financial institutions have constrained their support for the construction industry, we are actively addressing the challenges that have emerged within this sector,” he pointed out. Fernando highlighted the significance of Sri Lanka’s strategic geographical location and its vast wealth of valuable mineral resources. He also said the country’s enchanting coastline, one of the world’s most beautiful, faces challenges from periodic sea erosion. To address these issues, the Government has initiated proactive measures and allocated funds for mitigation efforts. The Department of Coast Conservation has undergone expansion to tackle coast conservation while playing a crucial role in boosting the tourism sector. Addressing ongoing challenges involving hotels, investors, and the Department of Coast Conservation, State Minister Fernando said the Government was committed to adopt a flexible approach to resolve these issues. Efforts are ongoing to facilitate construction projects in the tourism industry to attract investors. The goal is to foster development and create opportunities along Sri Lanka’s coastlines while preserving the uniqueness of the coastal regions. This approach not only safeguards the country’s heritage but also generates revenue for the Government, he said.

title: Four cattle rustlers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The Police have arrested four cattle rustlers who were in possession of cow which had earlier been saved from slaughter. The foursome had been involved in rustling cattle, keeping the tethered in a forest without food and later selling them to be slaughtered for meat. The arrested suspects, all residents of Padduka, were between 20 and 30 years old.  Acting on a tip-off, the Ingiriya Police conducted a raid in the Aduragala rubber forest in Ingiriya and arrested the group. According to the Police, they were in the process of loading the cow, which had been saved from slaughter, onto a lorry. This particular cow, which had been liberated as part of a ceremony of a temple in Ingiriya, was estimated to be valued at nearly Rs 400,000. Investigations have uncovered that the suspects had ordered the cow’s owner to claim that the cow was sold to them voluntarily. BY N.P. Kahawala – Ingiriya

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Four arrested for illegal hunting
author: Author not found
Content: Four individuals, involved in illegal hunting of four sambhur and a mouse deer for meat, within the confines of Rantambe sanctuary, were arrested, the Department of Wildlife Conservation said. According to the department, the combined weight of the four sambhur carcasses totalled 304 kg, while the mouse deer weighed 1.5 kg. In their possession, the poachers had three 12-bore shotguns, two three-wheelers, two live cartridges and an electric torch. All these confiscated items will be produced as evidence when the suspects are taken before the Walapane Magistrate. The unlawful practice of poaching wild animals for bush meat remains a significant issue in certain regions.

title: Coast conservation a vital income generator – Arundika
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s stunning beaches have earned global recognition, and as part of long-term investments, the Government has decided to extend investment prospects along its coastline. Close collaboration with agencies such as the Investment Promotion Board and the Ministry of Lands has been initiated, leading to a dedicated programme  aimed at revitalising and advancing the tourism sector, said Arundika Fernando, State Minister of Urban Development and Housing, at a  media briefing held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) recently. He added “Given our nation’s rich mineral resources, we have devised plans to expand investment opportunities while remaining committed to land conservation. Additionally, the Department of Coast Conservation actively participates in initiatives to enhance the value of our mineral resources. These resources have the potential to yield significant value through the production of value-added goods.” Fernando reiterated the country’s commitment to strengthen the economy through the proper use of mineral resources. He said the potential to create high-value-added products from these resources while underscoring the paramount importance of safeguarding the country’s land. “Furthermore, we are committed to introducing a new environmental and ocean protection Bill in our country. This legislation will play a vital role in safeguarding our natural resources. Our primary focus must centre on pioneering innovative programmes that contribute to our country’s economic recovery. Timely and effective resource management is crucial for initiating income-generating initiatives. Moreover, we aspire to establish a specialised Bank dedicated to the advancement of our domestic industries. Recognising that some financial institutions have constrained their support for the construction industry, we are actively addressing the challenges that have emerged within this sector,” he pointed out. Fernando highlighted the significance of Sri Lanka’s strategic geographical location and its vast wealth of valuable mineral resources. He also said the country’s enchanting coastline, one of the world’s most beautiful, faces challenges from periodic sea erosion. To address these issues, the Government has initiated proactive measures and allocated funds for mitigation efforts. The Department of Coast Conservation has undergone expansion to tackle coast conservation while playing a crucial role in boosting the tourism sector. Addressing ongoing challenges involving hotels, investors, and the Department of Coast Conservation, State Minister Fernando said the Government was committed to adopt a flexible approach to resolve these issues. Efforts are ongoing to facilitate construction projects in the tourism industry to attract investors. The goal is to foster development and create opportunities along Sri Lanka’s coastlines while preserving the uniqueness of the coastal regions. This approach not only safeguards the country’s heritage but also generates revenue for the Government, he said.
