title: GALLE TEXTILE BUSINESSMAN SHOT DEAD
author: BY Keerthi Mendis, S. Deeyagahage – Ahangama, Kamal Wijehewa – Galle, T. Withanawasam – Imaduwa, Siri Nihal Gamage – Wanduramba
Content: Lalith Wasantha Mendis, a 61-year-old textile businessman based in Galle and father-in-law of State Minister D.V. Chanaka, was shot and killed in the night of 23 September by unidentified gunmen who arrived on a motorbike. The assailants opened fire at Mendis while he was travelling in his car along Dickson Road in Galle. Despite being rushed to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, he succumbed to his injuries. The attackers discharged multiple rounds of bullets targeting the victim, while he was in the driver’s seat of his vehicle. Reports indicate that the weapon used in the killing was a T-56 firearm. The Magisterial Inquiry into the killing was conducted by Galle Additional Magistrate Lakmini Vidanagamage. Law enforcement authorities are currently investigating whether this murder is linked to a longstanding feud between two underworld gangs operating in Dubai. Police suspect that previous shootings and killings involving ‘Ratgama Vidura’ and ‘Kosgoda Sujee’ in recent months may also be connected to this incident. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa confirmed the deployment of multiple Police teams to track down the individuals responsible for the crime. CCTV footages in the area are under scrutiny and Police believe that the assailants can be identified from the footages. Galle Police are leading the investigation into the killing. (Pic by Farhan Nizamdeen)

title: FUTA to protest today against ‘neglect of free education’
author: Author not found
Content: The Federation of the University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA)  announced that a protest will be held at 12 noon today (25) opposite the University Grants Commission (UGC), against the increasing neglect of State universities by the Government and its covert efforts to transform them into self-financing institutions, which threatens the accessibility of free education for disadvantaged students. In a statement, FUTA said this protest will bring together academics from 17 universities and approximately 46 academic trade unions, alongside leaders from 26 non-academic and executive unions within the university system who are pledging their support. The protest will address several key issues. Firstly, the academic and university community is very dissatisfied with the Government’s neglect of state universities, particularly in terms of funding and human resources. Universities have been grappling with a severe crisis since they are unable to recruit permanent staff. Despite a significant increase in student enrolment from 30,000 to 45,000, the number of academic staff has remained stagnant and is rapidly declining due to retirements and emigration. Currently, the academic staff requirement for all seven universities stands at more than 15,000, but the existing number is less than 6,500. This shortage has led to overburdened academics and an inadequate student-teacher ratio. Secondly, the Government’s university restructuring policies pose a serious threat to the existence of a free education system. These policies signal a shift towards self-financing institutions, raising concerns about the future of accessible higher education. FUTA and the joint front of non-academic unions are determined to protect state universities and uphold the principles of free higher education. Lastly, the protest also calls for the reversal of unfair taxation policies and advocates for a fair tax system to address tax evasion. Additionally, FUTA opposes the Government’s proposal to cut superannuation funds and impose heavy interest on them, which could significantly impact workers’ retirement savings. “FUTA is inviting the public to join their struggle to protect the country’s free higher education system, as they believe that the government’s current policies threaten to deprive future generations of this valuable resource. The protest is expected to draw widespread attention, with FUTA calling on media organizations and social media activists to provide extensive coverage of this crucial event,” the statement added.

title: SLTB bus driver abducted in Gampola
author: Author not found
Content: A group who arrived in a van, intercepted a Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) bus en route from Mawela to Kandy and abducted a  46-year-old bus driver  in Gampola last (24) morning, Police said. Four people forcibly boarded the bus and assaulted one of the passengers with a sharp weapon. They subsequently abducted the victim, forcing him into their waiting van. The victim has been identified as 46-year-old Hemantha Rajapaksa, employed as a bus driver at the Gampola SLTB Bus Depot. He resides in the Wattegama area and was en route to his workplace when the abduction transpired. The motive behind the abduction remains undisclosed at the time of going to press. Gampola Police have initiated an investigation into the incident. Gampola Police have deployed four police teams to locate and identify the van used in the abduction. BY S. Yoga – Galaha

title: 13 food crops to be cultivated in upcoming Maha season
author: Author not found
Content: Relevant authorities in the agriculture sector have come together to cultivate 13 essential food crops in the upcoming Maha season, the Ministry of Agriculture announced. This collective effort involves coordination between the Ministry of Agriculture, Agriculture Department,  Agrarian Development Department and  Provincial Agriculture Authorities. They have agreed to carry out the initiative. The Agriculture Department has appointed crop leaders for each of the 13 food crops, which include paddy, maize, chillies, potatoes, red onions, big onions, green beans, cowpea, soybeans, Gingelly, Kurakkan, black gram and groundnuts. A meeting took place on 23 September at the Gannoruwa Agriculture Service Training Institute bringing together leaders responsible for these food crops and Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera. Many officials, researchers, scientists, and provincial agriculture secretaries attended the meeting. Minister Amaraweera spoke about self-sufficiency in paddy and rice production, noting an ample stock of rice and paddy reserves that could meet the country’s requirements until the next Maha season paddy harvest. “Consequently, there is no immediate requirement for rice imports, given the surplus stocks available in the country, based on available data and information,” he added.

title: LG Polls nominations cancellation to cost State Rs 1B – PAFFREL
author: Author not found
Content: Cancellation of nominations for the Local Government (LG) elections, as recently decided is anticipated to result in a financial loss exceeding Rs 1 billion for the State, according to the People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) organisation. Rohana Hettiarachchi, Executive Director of PAFFREL, expressed grave concerns over this decision, particularly in light of the ongoing economic crisis, deeming it unwise and not in the country’s best interest. Hettiarachchi also pointed out that the Election Commission of Sri Lanka had already allocated substantial funds for the 2023 LG Polls, which encompassed expenses such as the printing of ballot papers. The Ministerial Consultative Committee on Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government unanimously consented to cancel the nominations submitted for the Local Government Election 2023. This decision was taken considering the significant difficulties faced by those who had submitted nominations, due to the postponement of the elections. The Local Government Election 2023, which was originally scheduled to be held on 9 March, had to be postponed indefinitely due to lack of funds. The unanimous consent was reached at the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government meeting held on 20 September in Parliament. The meeting was chaired by Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena who is also the Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government.

title: Police Sergeant remanded for embezzlement
author: Author not found
Content: Galle Chief Magistrate Isuru Netthikumara on Friday (22) remanded a Sergeant of the Galle Police Administration Division, who was charged with embezzling Rs 727,000 in reward money belonging to Police officers. The 58-year-old sergeant has been serving at the Administration Division of Galle Police for a significant period. In April last year, a sum of Rs. 727,150 was credited to the Galle Police account from the Police rewards fund, designated as reward money for the officers of the Galle Police. Subsequently, the accountant issued a check for the specified sum and handed it over to the accused sergeant, acting on the recommendation of the IP of Galle Headquarters Police, who then cashed the cheque at a State bank. However, concerns arose when vouchers confirming the payment of the reward money to the Police officers were not received. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the suspect had cashed the cheque but failed to distribute the money to the deserving Police officers. The accountant promptly reported this discovery to the higher officials. Subsequent investigations revealed that the sergeant had engaged in fraudulent activities by withholding the reward money from the Police officers. BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle and S. Deeyagahage – Ahangama

title: PHIs to oversee, regulate school canteens
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Health Inspectors’ Association has announced its intention to launch a programme aimed at overseeing and regulating school canteens across the entire island. During a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday (24), President of the Association Upul Rohana revealed that PHIs are planning to conduct comprehensive inspections of all school canteens in the near future. “We are committed to closely monitoring school canteens,” he stated. Rohana emphasised that while the school canteen policy may not be a fully enforceable legal document, it has been observed that issues arise due to the provision of inappropriate food to schoolchildren through these canteens. “We have issued a circular with guidelines outlining which foods are safe for schoolchildren and which foods are permissible for sale in school canteens,” he explained. “Both school authorities and those responsible for maintaining the canteens have been duly informed of these guidelines,” he added. Furthermore, Rohana pointed out that although there may be certain legal challenges in pursuing action against those who violate these guidelines under the Food Act, it is entirely feasible to take legal measures in cases that jeopardise the health of schoolchildren. “We are committed to implementing stringent oversight of school canteens in the future,” he affirmed.

title: Ali Sabry defends son’s presence at UNGA
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Sabry issued a statement, on ‘X’ social media platform, addressing concerns surrounding his son’s participation in several official meetings held on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York. A photograph depicting Foreign Minister Ali Sabry alongside his son during an event at the UNGA recently gained significant attention on social media. The image prompted questions about the reasons for Sabry’s son being part of the official delegation, leading to allegations of nepotism against the Foreign Minister. In response to these concerns, Minister Sabry provided a clarification, “In light of the concerns expressed on social media regarding my son’s presence at a few bilateral meetings held during the UNGA, I wish to provide the following context: “In addition to my responsibilities in supporting the President with his high-level engagements, my role as the Foreign Minister involves maintaining a demanding schedule during my visits to the UNGA and Washington D.C. This itinerary encompasses delivering ten speeches and interventions, participating in three public events, and engaging in numerous bilateral and multilateral meetings. The extensive workload requires extensive research, speechwriting, and meticulous preparations. “To aid Ministers in fulfilling their respective duties, each of us benefits from a Minister’s bureau, consisting of both paid and voluntary contributors. My son has served as a research assistant and speechwriter on an ad hoc, voluntary basis at my request for a period of time. During the UNGA sessions, he volunteered to offer his time and expertise for a few days, as he is currently pursuing his studies in the United States. “I would like to acknowledge that his contributions significantly assisted me in preparing for these critical engagements. Importantly, neither the Foreign Ministry nor the Government of Sri Lanka has incurred any expenses on his behalf, whether related to his involvement in these engagements or at any other time. His contribution has been entirely voluntary and incurred no cost to the taxpayer. “I firmly believe in the public’s right to demand accountability from their representatives, and I remain committed to providing the facts to enable informed judgment,” Ali Sabry said.

title: ‘Vaishali Festival of Democracy’ at Nalanda University in Bihar
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda said the Satara Sampada or the four accomplishments preached by the Buddha could form a firm basis for a culture of democracy. He made these remarks while speaking at a panel discussion titled ‘Culture of Democracy’ at the first edition of the ‘Vaishali Festival of Democracy’ which was held at the Nalanda University in Rajgir, Bihar last week. Named after Vaishali, the city that had the first known democratic republic in ancient India, the Festival of Democracy was jointly organised by the Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR) and the Nalanda University in Rajgir. India’s former President Ram Nath Kovind, Bihar Governor Rajendra Arlekar, Minister of State of External Affairs of India Meenakshi Lekhi and the Chief Minister of Assam Himanta Biswa Sarma were among the dignitaries who attended the inaugural session of the Festival. In addition to Sri Lanka, Heads of Mission of Argentina, Chile, Egypt and Nepal also attended this first edition of the Vaishali Festival of Democracy.  High Commissioner Moragoda spoke at one of the two panel discussions of the Festival, which was moderated by Prof. Shantishree Pandit, Vice Chancellor of the Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi. Speaking on the culture of democracy, High Commissioner Moragoda observed that the Festival is aptly named, reviving India’s democratic heritage, and stated that both Buddhism and Hinduism, which originated in India provide a sound basis for a culture of democracy. In particular, he referred to the Satara Sampada or four accomplishments preached by the Buddha; Saddha (faith or trust), Sila (virtuous behaviour), Tyaga (sacrifice) and Panna (full realisation and thorough understanding) as key pillars of a democratic society. During his visit to Nalanda University, High Commissioner Moragoda also met its Vice Chancellor Prof. Abhay Kumar Singh and discussed opportunities available for Sri Lankan students at Nalanda University and the ways and means to cooperate in the higher education sector. Marking the visit, High Commissioner Moragoda presented to the University, reproductions of two murals painted by the eminent Sri Lankan painter Solias Mendis in the Kelaniya Rajamaha Vihara depicting the gift of Buddhism to Sri Lanka from India, which were unveiled at the office of the Vice Chancellor.

title: Distribution of textbooks for the 2024 school year begins
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education, Dr. Susil Premajayantha, said arrangements have been made to ensure that school textbooks for next year will be distributed among the students, before the commencement of the 2024 school year. He said this while observing the distribution of textbooks, from the main warehouse of the Educational Publications Department in Pitipana, Homagama to the regional centres islandwide. The Minister also rejected baseless speculations and false propaganda spread by various interested parties who claim that school uniform material will only be given to a limited number of students. Minister Premajayantha guaranteed that both uniform material, as well as school lunches, would be provided as usual without any delay. He added that the expectation of providing all these physical facilities is to cover the syllabus on time by the end of 2024 and restore all the academic activities that were disrupted during the Covid-19 pandemic. Also, Minister Premajayantha said when compared to last year, this year the school textbook printing could be done in a cost-effective and timely manner, where a saving of Rs 4,000 million could be made to the State. He added the State Printing Corporation has even started making profits, and that in the future, printing of all school textbooks, exercise books as well as other Government documents will be given to the SPC. He emphasised the support and dedication of all these institutions and staff is imperative to ensure transformative education reforms in this country.

title: Curtain Raiser – Global Maritime India Summit
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of India organised a Curtain Raiser in Colombo on 22 September for the Global Maritime India Summit (GMIS) to be held in India from 17-19 October in Mumbai. Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva was the Chief Guest. From the Indian side, Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways, Government of India, T.K. Ramachandran and senior officials from the Ministry of External Affairs and the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways attended the event virtually. The High Commissioner of India in Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay, senior officials from the Government of Sri Lanka and captains of business and industry, were also present at the event. In his welcome remarks, the High Commissioner stressed the importance of cooperation between India and Sri Lanka in the maritime sector. He highlighted that both Governments are working on enhancing maritime connectivity, as mentioned in the vision document launched by the leaders during the recent visit of the President of Sri Lanka to India. The High Commissioner thanked the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation for confirming participation at the forthcoming summit in India in October and announced that Sri Lanka has been accorded the status of ‘Partner Country’ at the summit. The Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways, Government of India, informed that the Global Maritime India Summit is a flagship event aimed at propelling the Indian maritime economy by promoting global and regional partnerships and facilitating investment. He welcomed the participation of the delegation from Sri Lanka, led by the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation at the 3-day summit in India, which will bring together global maritime players, policymakers and regulators, key opinion leaders and industry leaders through a series of engaging dialogues, forums and knowledge exchange platforms. He further mentioned that the event will give an opportunity for the Government of Sri Lanka to attract greater investment from India in the development of its maritime infrastructure. It will also facilitate greater business-to-business interactions. Thanking the Government of India for inviting him to the Global Maritime India Summit, the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation emphasised the importance of close collaboration, exchange of knowledge and adaptation of new technology for the growth of the maritime sector. He appreciated Indian investment in port development in Sri Lanka and highlighted the desire of both Governments to work closely to develop the industrial zone at Trincomalee. The minister recalled India’s support in establishing air connectivity between Jaffna and Chennai and announced the early commencement of ferry services between the two countries. Romesh David, CEO of South Asia Gateway Terminals, Port of Colombo, who also addressed the event, highlighted the potential of India-Sri Lanka collaboration in the maritime sector in catalysing the economic development of the entire region. Senior officials from prominent Associations like the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, Indo-Lanka Chamber of Commerce, Ceylon Association of Shipping Agents, Association of Container Transporters, Sri Lanka Logistics and Freight Forwarders Association, Hub Operators Association of Sri Lanka, Sri Lanka Logistics Providers Association, Sri Lanka Shipper’s Council and International Chamber of Commerce, attended the event.

title: Gaminipura residents cry foul over omission
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Gaminipura in Hatton, who are predominantly low-income families, have voiced their discontent over the name list prepared for distribution of food bags sponsored by the World Food Programme (WFP), in the estate sector. They alleged the said name list is unjust. The WFP recently carried out food distribution, providing 50 kg of rice, 20 kg of lentils, and 5 litres of cooking oil to low-income families, disabled individuals and those in need on a bi-monthly basis. The distribution list was created based on information provided by the Grama Niladhari responsible for the area and the Development Officer of the area. However, residents of Gaminipura alleged that the names of their family members were omitted from the list. They allege that the Grama Niladhari and the Development Officer, overseeing the area, had allocated food bags to individuals who did not meet the low-income criteria. Despite being informed by the Grama Niladhari to attend a meeting at Sarvodaya Hall, Gaminipura on 23 September to file appeals, neither the Grama Niladhari nor the Development Officer was present on that day. Frustrated by this situation, the residents have lodged complaints with the Ginigathhena Divisional Secretariat regarding their exclusion from the food distribution. In response to inquiries, the Grama Niladhari, overseeing the area, stated that he had distributed the food items according to the list provided by the Development Officer responsible for the domain. These food distributions are intended to continue on a bi-monthly basis for a total of six months, with the aim of assisting low-income families and those in need. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: India ready to help local fishers
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda yesterday (24) said that the Indian Government is prepared to assist in the development of the fisheries industry in our country by providing the necessary technical and financial support. Minister Devananda said he had a meeting with Dr. Satyanjal Pandey, Deputy High Commissioner for India in Sri Lanka at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta, Colombo, on 23 September. Devananda said the Deputy High Commissioner emphasised that in the past, the Indian Government had provided financial and technical assistance to support the local fisheries industry, as a symbol of the enduring bilateral relations between the two countries. Devananda also said the latter assured him that a team of Indian scientists with expertise in fisheries would arrive in Sri Lanka soon to conduct research. Further, the Indian Government was prepared to offer assistance in various areas, including sea-cucumber, crab, shrimp, and ornamental fish breeding and to set up centres in Sri Lanka and offer assistance to identify fish breeding locations in the North and East. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Distribution of textbooks for the 2024 school year begins
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education, Dr. Susil Premajayantha, said arrangements have been made to ensure that school textbooks for next year will be distributed among the students, before the commencement of the 2024 school year. He said this while observing the distribution of textbooks, from the main warehouse of the Educational Publications Department in Pitipana, Homagama to the regional centres islandwide. The Minister also rejected baseless speculations and false propaganda spread by various interested parties who claim that school uniform material will only be given to a limited number of students. Minister Premajayantha guaranteed that both uniform material, as well as school lunches, would be provided as usual without any delay. He added that the expectation of providing all these physical facilities is to cover the syllabus on time by the end of 2024 and restore all the academic activities that were disrupted during the Covid-19 pandemic. Also, Minister Premajayantha said when compared to last year, this year the school textbook printing could be done in a cost-effective and timely manner, where a saving of Rs 4,000 million could be made to the State. He added the State Printing Corporation has even started making profits, and that in the future, printing of all school textbooks, exercise books as well as other Government documents will be given to the SPC. He emphasised the support and dedication of all these institutions and staff is imperative to ensure transformative education reforms in this country.

title: Curtain Raiser – Global Maritime India Summit
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of India organised a Curtain Raiser in Colombo on 22 September for the Global Maritime India Summit (GMIS) to be held in India from 17-19 October in Mumbai. Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva was the Chief Guest. From the Indian side, Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways, Government of India, T.K. Ramachandran and senior officials from the Ministry of External Affairs and the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways attended the event virtually. The High Commissioner of India in Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay, senior officials from the Government of Sri Lanka and captains of business and industry, were also present at the event. In his welcome remarks, the High Commissioner stressed the importance of cooperation between India and Sri Lanka in the maritime sector. He highlighted that both Governments are working on enhancing maritime connectivity, as mentioned in the vision document launched by the leaders during the recent visit of the President of Sri Lanka to India. The High Commissioner thanked the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation for confirming participation at the forthcoming summit in India in October and announced that Sri Lanka has been accorded the status of ‘Partner Country’ at the summit. The Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways, Government of India, informed that the Global Maritime India Summit is a flagship event aimed at propelling the Indian maritime economy by promoting global and regional partnerships and facilitating investment. He welcomed the participation of the delegation from Sri Lanka, led by the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation at the 3-day summit in India, which will bring together global maritime players, policymakers and regulators, key opinion leaders and industry leaders through a series of engaging dialogues, forums and knowledge exchange platforms. He further mentioned that the event will give an opportunity for the Government of Sri Lanka to attract greater investment from India in the development of its maritime infrastructure. It will also facilitate greater business-to-business interactions. Thanking the Government of India for inviting him to the Global Maritime India Summit, the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation emphasised the importance of close collaboration, exchange of knowledge and adaptation of new technology for the growth of the maritime sector. He appreciated Indian investment in port development in Sri Lanka and highlighted the desire of both Governments to work closely to develop the industrial zone at Trincomalee. The minister recalled India’s support in establishing air connectivity between Jaffna and Chennai and announced the early commencement of ferry services between the two countries. Romesh David, CEO of South Asia Gateway Terminals, Port of Colombo, who also addressed the event, highlighted the potential of India-Sri Lanka collaboration in the maritime sector in catalysing the economic development of the entire region. Senior officials from prominent Associations like the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, Indo-Lanka Chamber of Commerce, Ceylon Association of Shipping Agents, Association of Container Transporters, Sri Lanka Logistics and Freight Forwarders Association, Hub Operators Association of Sri Lanka, Sri Lanka Logistics Providers Association, Sri Lanka Shipper’s Council and International Chamber of Commerce, attended the event.

title: LG polls nominations to be cancelled
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministerial Consultative Committee on Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government unanimously consented to cancel the nominations submitted for the Local Government Election 2023. This decision was taken considering the significant difficulties faced by those who had submitted nominations, due to the postponement of the elections. The Local Government Election 2023, which was originally scheduled to be held on 9 March, had to be postponed indefinitely due to lack of funds. The unanimous consent was reached at the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government meeting held yesterday (20) in Parliament. The meeting was chaired by Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena who is also the Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government. During the meeting, a discussion was held regarding the obstacles faced by field officials when running for elections in their respective electorates. The current status of the amendment to the relevant Act aimed at removing these obstacles was also discussed. Officials present at the meeting stated that, according to instructions received from the Attorney General, if an amendment is required to revert a legislation to its former state, a 2/3 majority and a referendum are necessary for the said purpose. Furthermore, a progress review concerning the systematisation of the transfer of Secretaries to the Provincial Councils and the transfer of Divisional Secretaries, as mentioned in the Service Minutes, was discussed during the Ministerial Consultative Committee meeting. Attention was also drawn to the fact that provincial council government officials have not been placed with due diligence. In light of this, the Prime Minister emphasised that the transfers of all administrative officers, including divisional secretaries, should be conducted properly. Given that there is currently no decision regarding new recruitments to the public service, and since there are existing vacancies in the provincial and overall public service, the Committee also discussed the possibility of considering those employees who have passed the Management Service Officer Grade III limited competitive examination to fill these vacancies.

title: 12-hour water cut
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) announced yesterday (21), that there will be a scheduled disruption of water supply in several areas of Colombo on Saturday (23) and Sunday (24) for a duration of 12 hours. During this time, water supply will be temporarily disconnected in Colombo areas 11, 12, 13, 14 and 15, starting from 6:00 p.m. on 23 September and lasting until 6:00 a.m. on 24 September. The NWSDB explained that this interruption is necessary due to essential development work.

title: GCE A/L 2023 Exam schedule out next week – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha yesterday (21) announced in Parliament that the Commissioner General of the Department of Examinations will unveil the revised schedule for the G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination 2023 next week. In a statement, Premajayantha said, a significant number of students and MPs representing both the ruling party and the Opposition, have called for a postponement of the A/L examination, citing various concerns. The minister acknowledged that when considering this request, it is essential to weigh the consequences of postponing the A/L Examination 2023 to next year. He mentioned that the ongoing postponement of school Examinations and result releases has been due to a variety of challenges, including the Covid-19 pandemic, trade union actions, and economic crises. “These issues have adversely affected schoolchildren and parents alike. Additionally, delays in university admissions, higher education course enrollments, and foreign university applications over the past few years have hindered students from pursuing further education at the appropriate age,” he pointed out. However, the Education Ministry is doing its best to prevent the exam from being continually delayed, he pledged. He also pointed out that if the A/L Examination 2023 is rescheduled to January 2024, the G.C.E. Ordinary Level Examination 2023, originally planned for March and April 2024, would have to be postponed to May or June, leading to repeated delays.” “Such disruptions would affect the school term calendar and, consequently, the admission of students to Grade 1, potentially hindering their chances to apply for foreign universities and scholarships. Moreover, State job recruitments would face delays due to postponed examination result releases,” he added. Speaking further, the minister said the decision to revise the A/L Examination 2023 dates was made in consideration of the considerable number of students who applied for the exam after the release of the A/L 2022 results, noting that there were 18,473 more applications compared to previous years following the release of results’. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: National Hospital has highest number of post-op infections
author: Author not found
Content: Concerned Medical Specialists accused the National Hospital Colombo of allegedly having the highest number of post-operative infections (septicaemia), mainly as a result of it violating the Infection Control Manual guidelines endorsed by the World Health Organisation (WHO).  Specialist doctors of the NHSL lamented yesterday (21), despite having a Deputy Director General, three Deputy Directors, close to 200 medical specialists, and a large number of Senior Medical Officers, there was a gross negligence of public and patient health safety in ensuring that proper guidelines were met in order to ensure that patients who went in for surgery did not contract infections following it. They noted that the Health Secretary had appointed a three-member Committee, Chaired by Dr. Lakshmi Somathunga, with Senior Microbiologist, Dr. Geethika Patabendige and Additional Secretary (Procurement) and Y.L.M. Navavi as its members last month. The Committee’s report was handed over to the Health Secretary last week, but no action has been taken on it till date. They noted that according to information, strong recommendations had been made with regard to the situation. The Hospital Specialists expressed concern alleging that outsourced private sector janitorial staff were unofficially utilised in cleaning even the interiors of the hospital’s theatres and the Intensive Care Units (ICUs) of the largest teaching hospital in Sri Lanka. The janitorial workers are tasked with cleaning the sanitation facilities of patients and the public, the environment, the sewage and drainage systems. They have not undergone a screening for their health condition and thereby they could be carriers of infections.  They noted that cleaning up of theatres and ICUs, where a high level of sterility was expected, were supposed to be carried out by the NHSL’s health assistants (minor employees). The Committee appointed had submitted its report to the Health Secretary, Janaka Sri Chandragupta last week. However, it appears that there is an effort to sweep the whole issue under the carpet and continue as before. They noted that strong recommendations had been made while it had been pointed out that there was no need to even appoint a committee in this regard. It was the Deputy Director General of the NHSL Colombo who should be responsible for implementing the infection control manual guidelines. President of the College of Medical Laboratory Science Sri Lanka (CMLSSL) Ravi Kumudesh claimed that there had been incidences of infections triggered amongst laboratory staff by samples of live unsterilized bacterial cultures being taken for disposal with the hospital’s general waste, whereas it should be placed in an autoclave and sterilised prior to disposal. Under the circumstances janitorial staff had been compelled to handle such waste despite being without appropriate protection.       However, several attempts to contact the Committee’s Chiarman, Dr. Somathunga for comment failed as she was allegedly at a meeting and later was unavailable for comment. Senior Microbiologist Dr. Patabandige refusing to comment said, “I was not the Chairman of this Committee,” she said noting that the Committee’s report had been handed over to the Health Secretary, while any question in this regard should be put to him.  Several attempts to contact the Health Secretary also failed.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Former UK PM David Cameron to promote Port City
author: Author not found
Content: Former UK Prime Minister David Cameron will address an exclusive, closed-door forum on 26 September, focusing on the strengthening ties between the UAE, the Indo-Pacific region and the evolving role ofSri Lanka in this emerging trend that is rapidly gaining momentum. The discussion will highlight the UAE’s significant role as an international player capable of concurrently engaging with multiple partners, including those in the Indo-Pacific Region, the Port City Developers, the CHEC Port City Colombo (Pvt) Ltd, a subsidiary of China Communications Construction Company Limited (CCCC), announced yesterday (21). The Developers said, in this context of having the close-door forum, the UAE aims to strengthen its connections with the Indo-Pacific Region and Sri Lanka will play a crucial role in this partnership, with its trade and investment offerings, mainly through the upcoming multi-billion-dollar Port City Colombo development Project. Designated as a Special Economic Zone (SEZ), it provides attractive incentives for international businesses, making it an ideal destination in the Indian Ocean. What sets it apart is the independent governance framework led by the Colombo Port City Economic Commission, that aligns with global standards and ensures a business-friendly environment, further solidifying Sri Lanka’s status as a significant player in the regional economic landscape. Port City stands as a meticulously planned man-made island city, designed to attract international businesses. The promotional efforts have been executed according to plan, and this sprawling development spans 269 hectares of land reclaimed from the sea. It is set to encompass five distinct precincts, namely the Financial District, Central Park Living, Island Living, The Marina, and the International Island. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Full PCoI Report on Easter Attacks cannot be made public – Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena yesterday (21) said the full report of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) on the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attack cannot be disclosed to the public. In an announcement, at the beginning of yesterday’s Parliamentary Sittings, the Speaker addressed recent concerns regarding the disclosure of specific information contained in the PCoI report. He informed the House that certain details and documents within the PCoI report, such as confidential witness statements, cannot be made public. This decision aligns with the directive issued by the Secretary to the President. Abeywardena elaborated that, based on communication he received, from the Secretary to the President on 3 March and 14 March 2022, it was stressed that the aforementioned information must remain confidential to protect the anonymity of the relevant witnesses. These details should only be accessible to Members of Parliament under the supervision of the Secretary General of Parliament. “In addition,” Abeywardena added, “I would like to apprise the House that this directive was reconfirmed in a letter dated 12 September 2023 to underscore the factual status of this matter.” BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sirisena barred from acting against Dayasiri
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Sandun Vithana, yesterday (21) issued an injunction on the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), preventing the Party from instituting any disciplinary action, against its ousted General Secretary MP Dayasiri Jayasekera, or finding him guilty of such actions, till 5 October. The Judge issued the injunction on the Party Leader former President Maithripala Sirisena and on Sarath Ekanayake, who had functioned as the Party’s Acting General Secretary since ousting of Jayasekara. Jagath Ekanayake PC and Attorney-at-Law Wickrema Mohotti appeared on behalf of MP Jayasekera. The Court also notified both Sirisena and Ekanayake to produce their submissions, in this regard on the said date. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Sri Lanka accedes to TPNW
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka became the 69th State party to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW) on 19 September 2023. Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry deposited the Instrument of Accession to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons at a high-level ceremony held at the UN Headquarters in New York, on the sidelines of the 78th Session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA).   Upon receiving 50 ratifications it entered into force on 22 January 2021. The Treaty prohibits State Parties from developing, testing, producing, manufacturing, acquiring, possessing or stockpiling nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. Sri Lanka participated in the negotiations of the PNW Treaty at the United Nations in New York, which was adopted on 7 July 2017 and was among the 122 States that voted in favour of its adoption. Sri Lanka also contributed through active participation in the Open–Ended Working Group (OEWG) process of 2016 in Geneva which led to the treaty negotiation process. Sri Lanka has promoted universal adherence to the treaty by consistently voting in favour of an annual UN General Assembly resolution that calls upon all States to join the treaty “at the earliest possible date”.  Sri Lanka’s ratification of the PNW Treaty reaffirms its long-standing commitment towards nuclear disarmament in favour of international peace and security. In this context, Sri Lanka also ratified the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban (CNTB) Treaty on 25 July 2023, the government said.  UN Under-Secretary-General and High Representative for Disarmament Affairs Izumi Nakamitsu, Secretary of Foreign Affairs Aruni Wijewardane, Permanent Representative of Sri Lanka to the UN in New York Mohan Pieris and senior officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka, the Permanent Mission of Sri Lanka in New York and the UN Office of Legal Affairs participated in the ceremony. (SRM)

title: Digital security sticker mooted for liquor
author: Author not found
Content: A digital security sticker should be introduced, to all liquor manufacturers, in order to tackle all acts of fraud and corruption connected with the counterfeit sticker racket on bottles of liquor, the Parliament Committee on Ways and Means observed. Its Chair Patali Champika Ranawaka said the consumers will be able to decipher whether the sticker is genuine or not via the QR code once this particular sticker was introduced. He stated that furthermore the introduction of such a sticker will also enable the Excise Department to identify the exact amount of tax it could obtain and the exact amount of tax that could be levied from each product etc. He made these observations whilst addressing the said Committee in the House yesterday. Among others who participated in the sessions were MPs Dr. Harsha de Silva, Vasudeva Nanayakkara, Lasantha Alagiyawanna, and Ashok Abeysinghe, along with officers from the Excise Department, IRD and the Finance Ministry. Responding to questions posed by the Committee, the officers from the Excise Department stated that raids were continuing to apprehend those behind the counterfeit sticker racket. They mentioned that following those raids, it had come to light, that 90 per cent of the stickers placed on bottles of liquor were fake. They remarked that they had also brought the matter to the notice of the CID too, but were of the view that the CID were yet to identify those behind the racket and the precise location from where the racket had been set in motion. The committee also insisted on finding out whether retail outlets, involved in the liquor trade, were engaged in this counterfeit racket. They instructed the Excise Department to continue with their raids and warned that licences of firms involved in the racket would be cancelled henceforth. The Committee also urged the Excise Department to impose fines on those found guilty of being involved in the racket. The Excise Department was also instructed to submit a report to the Committee stipulating the precise amount in fines they had imposed on firms engaged in this racket since 7 September this year. The detailed report should be submitted to the committee on the precise loss incurred by the Excise Department, due the racket. During the sessions it was revealed that there were around seven liquor manufacturing firms, which had to date refrained from paying the requisite taxes to the Excise Department and that two firms  in particular namely Globe Blender and the Wayamba Spirits Stores had abstained from paying taxes to the tune of Rs 1.5 billion. It was then decided to inform all of the liquor manufacturing firms that were in arrears to pay their taxes on or before 15 October and cancel the licences of such firms if they still continue to act unheeding these instructions by 30 October.

title: India’s IRCON to enhance railway signalling system
author: Author not found
Content: In a development aimed at enhancing the transportation infrastructure in Sri Lanka, the Ministry of Transport and Highways of Sri Lanka and India’s IRCON Ltd. signed a contract yesterday (21), for the design, installation, testing, and commissioning of a Signalling system for Sri Lanka Railways, from Maho to Anuradhapura, covering a distance of 66 km. This momentous agreement, signed yesterday (21), in Colombo, was attended by dignitaries, including Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena, and High Commissioner of India in Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay. The signing ceremony also saw the presence of the Governor of the Eastern Province Senthil Thondaman, State Minister of Highways Siripala Gamalath and senior officials from the Ministry of Transport and Highways, Sri Lanka Railways and IRCON Ltd. This vital project, which is being executed under an Indian Line of Credit (LOC) of USD 318 million, comes at a total cost of USD 14.90 million. High Commissioner Gopal Baglay highlighted the strategic importance of the Signalling Project, emphasising its role in improving the mobility of the people of Sri Lanka, fostering economic recovery, and further strengthening the cooperation between the two nations. He noted that the LOC extended for this project underscores India’s steadfast commitment to supporting Sri Lanka during challenging times. In response, Minister Gunawardena expressed his gratitude to Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi and the Government of India for their unwavering support to Sri Lanka, particularly during the economic crisis last year. He acknowledged that India has been a vital partner in Sri Lanka’s railway projects, offering significant support in the form of LOCs. The signing of this agreement adds to a series of successful railway projects in Sri Lanka executed under Indian LOCs, totaling over one billion USD. IRCON Ltd, with its operations commencing in Sri Lanka in March 2009, has played a crucial role in the rehabilitation and modernisation of Sri Lanka Railways, as well as capacity building and employment generation. Currently, IRCON Ltd. is engaged in another essential project involving the upgrade of the Railway Line, including track rehabilitation and ancillary works from Maho to Omanthai, covering a distance of 128 kilometres, at a cost of USD 91.27 million.  The track rehabilitation work from Anuradhapura to Omanthai has already been completed with work on the section from Anuradhapura to Maho scheduled to commence in January 2024.

title: New PCoI will work for two months – Prasanna
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Government Whip Minister Prasanna Ranatunga yesterday (21) said that the newly appointed Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) would continue its work for two months and a report will be submitted to the House after that. During the Adjournment Debate on the controversial Channel 4 documentary, Ranatunga alleged that the Opposition has been engaged in an exercise to spread a canard that President Ranil Wickremesinghe is out to protect those behind the 2019 Easter Sunday terror blasts. He stated that the Opposition should not use nationalism and religious extremism to obtain cheap political mileage.  Speaking further he said “I have spoken about this (Easter Sunday attacks) more than a few times in this House. In May of 2019 we in fact debated this topic for three successive days. In March of 2021, again we did the same. In April of that year too, we debated it for three days. Why do we debate it again today? This whole issue emerged again thanks to the controversial video screened on Channel 4 related to the Easter Sunday blasts. I do not believe that the video in question aired by this TV Station focused on the Easter Sunday carnage. They only focused on one-fifth of its content.” They devoted most of the duration to touch on the civil war here and the Tamil Diaspora was clearly behind it. They screened it just in time ahead of the annual UN Sessions in New York. These people thus used the Easter Sunday blasts to sling mud at Sri Lanka as they have an unfinished score to settle with us, he alleged.

title: What Laws Govern the Colombo Port City Development?
author: Author not found
Content: Following up on two interesting articles which appeared in this Newspaper (Ceylon Today) on 15 and 17 September 2023, I really do wonder what actual laws govern the Port City of Colombo. There are plans to remove the food stalls within the Port City by 2027. But during those 4 years what laws do they adhere to? The well composed article says that “the Port City will be a smart city with renewable energy and effective sewerage systems to be incorporated.” But what happens until then? What is happening now? concerns about public health standards have arisen following reports of food poisoning among a group of foreigners, including diplomats, at a Port City restaurant. While Public Health Inspectors routinely monitor hotels, restaurants, and small eateries across Colombo, there remains uncertainty about whether they extend their oversight to the Port City. Questions regarding sewage and waste management also linger, particularly regarding the collection and treatment of garbage and wastewater within the Port City. The Solution surely cannot wait until 2027? What about Law & Order? In March of this year, a tragic incident unfolded within the Port City, where a 24-year-old man lost his life during an altercation. Surprisingly, the official response mentioned the “Harbour Police” investigating the matter. This begs the question: What role does the Harbour Police play in handling such criminal cases within a distinct part of Colombo? We are aware of the Port City having its own Flag, Its own ID’s. Will they also have their own Police Force? As for utilities, there is no direct connection to the main power grid, leaving many to wonder about the supply during the project’s full-scale operation. If generators are in use, it raises questions about the source of fuel and whether it impacts Sri Lanka’s currency reserves. Eventually people will need this to enter the Colombo Port City As the Colombo Port City project progresses, it is crucial to address these pressing concerns. Ultimately, clarity is needed on the legal framework, security, public health, and utilities within the Port City to ensure the well-being of both Sri Lankan citizens and visitors. As the project unfolds, we have to ensure greater scrutiny and accountability in these areas to maintain safety, transparency, and sustainable development. By Game Changer

title: Spotted deer at risk in Seruwila
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the severe drought being experienced in the Seruwila area, not only humans, but also animals have been affected. Residents of the Koneswaram Sacred Site in Trincomalee have reported that the dry conditions have led to a severe shortage of food for wildlife, particularly spotted deer that roam in the nearby jungles. They pointed out that the spotted deer have been adversely affected by the scarcity of grass, which constitutes their staple diet. Residents observed that as a result of this food shortage, the spotted deer have been forced to venture into the town in search of food. This situation has led to these animals consuming garbage and other waste materials, putting their lives at risk. BY Manushanka – Seruwila

title: Dialog’s Innovation Challenge invites all innovators to create SL’s Digital Future
author: Author not found
Content: Dialog Axiata PLC, Sri Lanka’s premier connectivity provider, is extending an invitation to all Sri Lankans to join the Dialog Innovation Challenge, a national endeavour to propel the country through digital transformation and create the digital future of the nation. This national initiative invites the nation’s finest minds and visionaries to channel their innovation and creativity towards a common goal: enriching the lives of Sri Lankan individuals, businesses, and communities through technology-driven solutions. The proposed solutions must be a beacon of innovation, capable of reshaping a market or elevating existing processes. Participants can submit solutions that are at any stage of completion, be it a prototype, a Minimum Viable Product, or a fully developed solution. No limitations bind the scope of these solutions, as participants can harness the transformative power of digital technologies such as AI, machine learning, IoT, computer vision, blockchain, data analytics, robotics, and cloud computing as catalysts for change. All Sri Lankans above the age of 16 can participate either as individuals or dynamic teams by visiting dialog.lk/ic Extraordinary rewards await the champions of this national initiative, where a prize pool ofRs 5 million will be awarded to the winners, accompanied by invaluable mentorship and access to Dialog’s expansive innovation ecosystem and resources. Further, fuelling the fire of ingenuity, participants will get the opportunity to be mentored by tech luminaries, industry trailblazers, and visionary innovators from the programme’s partners, the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka (ICTA), Institution of Engineers Sri Lanka (IESL), National Innovation Agency (NIA),  Sri Lanka Inventors Commission (SLIC), Sri Lanka Institute of Marketing (SLIM), Digital Marketing Association of Sri Lanka (DMASL), Dialog Innovation Fund, Innovation Foundry and Ideamart. Together, they will navigate a transformational journey, propelling their solutions into the spotlight and connecting with vital stakeholders, potential investors, and strategic partners. Speaking about the initiative, State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath said, “As the Minister of Technology, I believe the Dialog Innovation Challenge will enable a digitally empowered Sri Lanka, where innovation drives progress and transforms lives. I applaud Dialog Axiata PLC for its unwavering commitment to fostering creativity and ushering in a new era of technological advancement. As the country moves forward with the national digital economy acceleration initiative DigiEcon Sri Lanka 2023 – 2030, I encourage all Sri Lankans to seize the opportunity and apply for the Dialog Innovation Challenge.” Commenting on the initiative, Supun Weerasinghe, Group Chief Executive of Dialog Axiata PLC said, “At Dialog, we envision a Sri Lanka that stands tall as a digital nation of innovation, a beacon of technological brilliance. The Dialog Innovation Challenge is a national endeavour that calls upon every Sri Lankan to unite and shape the future of our nation through transformative digital solutions. Together, we aim to empower and enrich Sri Lankan lives, revolutionise industries, and pave the way for unprecedented progress – propelling Sri Lanka into an era of boundless possibilities, fostering a vibrant ecosystem of innovation and prosperity.” For more information about the Dialog Innovation Challenge, visit www.dialog.lk/ic

title: Ananda College emerges National Champions in English Debating
author: Author not found
Content: The English debating team of Ananda College emerged as National Champions at the 18th Sri Lanka Schools’ National Debating Championship organised by the Debating Society and Moot Court of the Faculty of Law, University of Colombo in association with the Sri Lanka Debaters’ Council. The tournament is considered as the high point of the local English debating circles and featured 54 teams from all over the island including government and international schools. The champion Ananda College English Debating Team comprised Thishya Mendis (Captain) Cheka Mendis (Vice-Captain), Mevindu Asuramanna and Yasindu Edussuriya.   In the first two days of the tournament, the Ananda team won against Colombo International School, Gateway College Rajagiriya, Methodist College, Gateway College Dehiwala and Jaffna Hindu College in the preliminary rounds. Then they beat Visakha Vidyalaya Colombo in the Octofinals, Trinity College Kandy in the Quarterfinals and Royal College Colombo in the Semi-finals and finally Wesley College Colombo in a thrilling final in the Faculty Auditorium to emerge as National Champions. At the same time, Royal College Colombo became the National Champions in Sinhala medium and S. Thomas’ College Mount Lavinia were the Tamil Medium National Champions for 2023.

title: Ingiriya mobile library worth over Rs 6M lies idle
author: Author not found
Content: Ingiriya Public Library users have expressed displeasure over the failure of the authorities to utilise a mobile library worth over six million rupees which has been parked in a corner of the library premises over the past six months. Those who visited the Ingiriya Public Library said the mobile library contains material which no other library in the Kalutara District has and criticised officials over their inability to put the mobile library to use and cater to the public, without allowing it to idle in a corner of the library premises. The air-conditioned mobile library (bus) had been handed over to the Ingiriya Public Library by former Chairman of the Horana Pradeshiya Sabha, Ashoka Ranatunga with the intervention of a private company. When contacted, the Secretary of the Horana PS Prasanna Sirisena said the bus could not be used due to the registration book being misplaced and added that as the issue has been sorted out it will be put into service shortly. BY N.P.Kahawala – Ingiriya

title: Italian Envoymeets Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: Italian Ambassador to Sri Lanka Damiano Francovigh visited the Ministry of Public Security on Wednesday (20) and held a meeting with Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. During their discussions, they addressed the bilateral diplomatic relationship between Sri Lanka and Italy. Additionally, they engaged in a dialogue about the current political situation in Sri Lanka. The meeting also involved considerations of potential measures that could be implemented by the Ministry of Public Security and the Ministry of Interior in Italy to combat illegal immigration and drug trafficking between the two countries. Furthermore, Minister Alles and Ambassador Francovigh took into account the well-being and needs of Sri Lankans residing in Italy.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
