title: Nagapattinam Port gearing up– TN Minister Velu
author: Author not found
Content: The Tamil Nadu Government is actively preparing to upgrade the Nagapattinam to Kankesanthurai (KKS) ferry route, located in the Northern Province of Sri Lanka. Speculations have arisen that the ferry service could commence as early as October 2023, even though the interior work for the ferry terminal is still in the process of being tendered and calling for bidders. Tamil Nadu Minister for Public Works, Highways and Minor Ports, A. Velu visited the Port of Nagapattinam for an inspection of trade sector activities on 20 September. Plans are in motion to swiftly introduce a High-Speed Passenger Ferry service from the small Port of Nagapattinam, situated approximately 60 nautical miles from Kankesanthurai in Sri Lanka. This mission is coordinated by the Tamil Nadu Maritime Board, a department, within the Tamil Nadu Government, responsible for maritime and port affairs, the Tamil Nadu Minister has said. The Nagapattinam Port, originally a small fishing harbour, has already undergone dredging operations to clear the mouth of the harbour for ferry operations. However, there are additional processes that need to be completed, according to reliable sources. The operation of the ferry, under the ownership of a Singaporean resident of Sri Lankan origin, has already made an investment in a Singaporean ferry ship. It is currently awaiting clearance from Indian authorities. Initially, plans were in place to launch the ferry service between Karaikkal Port in Puducherry and KKS. However, the port, which was running at a loss, was taken over by the Adani Group after the agreement was signed between India and Sri Lanka. The now Adani-run Karaikkal Port had declined to support passenger services at the port as it is a bulk cargo operation and they cannot upgrade for passenger service with safety measures. Consequently, the ferry service was redirected to the Nagapattinam fishing harbour, which had not previously been used for passenger services. According to inside sources, the Tamil Nadu authorities are currently in the process of inviting tenders and selecting bids, which may take longer than initially anticipated and as a result, it is now expected that the ferry service may commence after the Thai Pongal festival in 2024, as the tender process has not yet been initiated. The Indian Shipping Corporation, as part of the Indian Government’s initiatives, is overseeing the launch of the high-speed passenger ferry service from Nagapattinam. Given that this service involves international travel to Sri Lanka, the Indian Government has entrusted the Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) with ensuring security. In Nagapattinam’s trade sector, all necessary facilities have been prepared for the commencement of the passenger ferry service, expected to begin in October. The Tamil Nadu Government has collaborated with the Sri Lankan Government to initiate this historic passenger ferry service. This initiative, which is of great significance to both the people of Sri Lanka and Tamil Nadu, is expected to substantially contribute to the development of the Tanjavur District, strengthening its ties with Sri Lanka through the Delta regions, boosting tourism, and fostering economic prosperity, the Tamil Nadu Government said. The Customs Department, External Affairs Department, Immigration Department, Directorate General of Shipping, and Shipping Corporation of India, all under the Indian Government’s administration, have played pivotal roles in facilitating this remarkable development, the Minister had said. This initiative holds particular importance for the Tamil community residing in North Sri Lanka, as it facilitates travel to the trade hub of Kankesanthurai.   By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Nearly 40% of deaths at Badulla Hospital due to heart failure – GMOA
author: Author not found
Content: In a shocking revelation, Assistant Secretary of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Palitha Rajapaksa said last year alone nearly 40 per cent of deaths at the Badulla Teaching Hospital were due to heart attacks and still, the hospital lacks an angiogram machine, placing lives of possible cases of heart disease in the Uva Province at risk as some of them succumbed to their ailment without even a diagnosis.  Dr. Rajapaksa said last year, of the 1,883 post-mortems conducted at TH Badulla, 770 deaths were determined to be due to heart attacks. When contacted yesterday (20), he said in 2022 alone the Cardiology Unit of Teaching Hospital Badulla had treated 2,500 patients suffering from heart disease. Of them, only some had undergone an angiogram. Both the Uva and Sabaragamuwa provinces are short of angiogram machines resulting in some of the patients going undiagnosed. It is only after their death it is found that those patients had been admitted due to a heart ailment.“If we know that the patient is suffering from heart disease then we could treat them accordingly, but in some instances the patient either dies on admission or within 24 hours after admission or is admitted to the hospital and remains undiagnosed.” The 1.5 million population in Uva Province have to travel to National Hospital, Colombo or Kandy or District General Hospital Kalutara Nagoda, Teaching Hospitals Karapitiya and Anuradhapura and District General Hospital, Polonnaruwa to get an angiogram (a scan that shows blood flow through arteries or veins, or through the heart, using X-rays, computed tomography angiography (CTA) or magnetic resonance angiography) done. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Today is World Peace Day
author: Author not found
Content: The International Day of Peace, also officially known as World Peace Day, is a United Nations-sanctioned holiday observed annually on 21 September. On this internationally observed Day of Peace, comes a book to remind us that the peace inside us is always available.  We all know modern life can be so busy it can make us feel frazzled and overwhelmed. Sometimes we look for a way to dim the noise and find some calm moments of peace. In this book full of modern anecdotes and ancient wisdom, renowned global teacher and author Prem Rawat reveals that we all carry within us a hidden resource for doing just that – finding peace – but we have not been taught how to use it. He describes how to turn down the noise and ‘hear ourselves’ – listening to the subtle but strong song of peace that sings inside each of us. Once we learn to listen to the authentic voice within, we can maintain that peace as we face the busy world.  Rawat describes himself as a realist, and writes that the book is not a message to “just think positive”. Prem Rawat will be one of the distinguished guests speaking at the third Annual Global Peace Education Network Conference webinar taking place online on Wed. Sept 20, at 8 a.m. PST. New York Times best seller. eBook and audible. In libraries, bookstores and Amazon.

title: Govt implementing PCoI recommendations – Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: Disciplinary measures have been initiated against certain State officers who were found to have neglected their duty in preventing the 21 April 2019, Easter Sunday terror attacks, in line with the recommendations made by the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI), which extensively investigated the tragic events, Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles informed Parliament yesterday (20). In response to a query posed by SJB MP Hector Appuhamy, Minister Alles also pledged to investigate the unauthorised release of video clips featuring Zahran, the ringleader of the suicide bombers. He acknowledged that the source of these leaks was unclear but assured the House that he would delve into the matter and provide an update. Further, Minister Alles clarified that the PCoI report did not hold SDIG Nilantha Jayawardena responsible for the attacks. Instead, he mentioned that SDIG Jayawardena had been found liable by the Supreme Court and had been ordered to pay compensation.  At this juncture, a dispute arose when Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella insisted that SDIG Jayawardena had indeed been held accountable for the destruction caused by the Easter Sunday bomb attacks.  MP Appuhamy supported this claim by referring page 320 of the Presidential Commission’s report. In response, Minister Alles assured the assembly that he would provide additional information regarding the Easter Sunday bomb attacks within two days. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: CEB ordered to pay Vavuniya Power Corporation Rs 1M
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court, yesterday (20), ordered the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to compensate Vavuniya (Lanka) Power Corporation with Rs 1 million. This compensation is in response to a violation of the fundamental rights of the company due to the denial of permission to initiate a project. The Supreme Court Bench, comprising Justices Gamini Amarasekara, Yasantha Kodagoda, and A.M.A. Nawaz also directed the Ministry of Power and Energy to promptly notify the Court about the initiation of legal action against the officials responsible for neglecting the company’s request. This order was issued in response to a petition to the Supreme Court by Vavuniya (Lanka) Power Corporation, asserting that their fundamental rights were infringed upon by the denial of permission to commence their project. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: President meets Meta’s Sir Nick Clegg
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe met Sir Nick Clegg, the former UK Deputy Prime Minister and present President for Global Affairs at Meta, during the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. During their discussions, President Wickremesinghe highlighted the Government’s new initiatives to combat online hate speech and the dissemination of fake news, as reported by the President’s Media Division. He underscored that the proposed bill would enable concerned parties to challenge specific aspects through the Supreme Court, and further revisions could be considered during the Parliamentary Committee review. The President was briefed on Meta’s advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI), with a particular emphasis on open-source technologies. Both parties explored potential collaborations between the Sri Lankan Government and Meta in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). One of the proposals discussed involved the development of a cooperative programme between Meta and Sri Lankan universities aimed at advancing AI technology. President Wickremesinghe reiterated his two primary areas of focus: nurturing the growth of the AI sector in the country, particularly in the field of education, and utilising AI to support data-driven initiatives aimed at addressing climate change. Accompanying the President were Senior Advisor for Climate Change, Ruwan Wijewardene; President’s Secretary, Saman Ekanayake; Chairman of the BOI, Dinesh Weerakkody; and Director of International Affairs, Dinouk Colombage.

title: Bangladeshi PM impressed with quick loan repayment
author: Author not found
Content: Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina expressed her satisfaction with Sri Lanka’s swift recovery from the economic crisis, remarking that she had not anticipated such a rapid loan repayment from Sri Lanka, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. She said this when she met President Ranil Wickremesinghe in New York on Tuesday (19). The meeting focused on various facets of bilateral relations and cooperation between the two South Asian nations. During their discussions, President Wickremesinghe conveyed his sincere appreciation to Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and the people of Bangladesh for their steadfast support and assistance during challenging periods. He acknowledged the aid extended to Sri Lanka and expressed deep gratitude for Bangladesh’s generosity. President Wickremesinghe also apologised for not being able to visit Bangladesh in the past due to various commitments and circumstances. He affirmed his commitment to strengthening the ties between the two countries and proposed the possibility of visiting Bangladesh in November or December, aligning with the Bangladeshi Government’s convenience. Bangladeshi Prime Minister Hasina shared the tragic history of her family, recounting the devastating assassinations that had affected her loved ones. The cordial conversation between the two leaders fostered a deeper understanding of each other’s experiences and aspirations, the PMD added.

title: Human trafficking suspect arrested in Thambuttegama
author: Author not found
Content: A woman was recently arrested in Thambuttegama on suspicion of her involvement in a human trafficking network that operates between Sri Lanka and Dubai, the Police said. The arrest was carried out by the Human Trafficking, Smuggling and Maritime Crime Investigation Division of the CID. The accused had arranged for a retired female Army soldier to travel to Dubai on a tourist visa in June 2022. Subsequently, she attempted to coerce the former soldier into the prostitution trade in Dubai. The retired Army soldier, hailing from Anuradhapura, had been compelled to visit a brothel in Dubai twice during her stay, from where she managed to escape. She then demanded that the responsible ‘employment’ agency facilitate her return to Sri Lanka. On her arrival in Sri Lanka, having paid an additional sum of Rs 400,000, in addition to the initial Rs 500,000 spent for her journey to Dubai, the victim reported the incident to the Inspector General of Police (IGP) through the Army Commander. Consequently, an investigation into the matter was launched. While the female suspect has been detained in Thambuttegama, ongoing efforts are being made to arrest her accomplice in Dubai, the Police added.

title: Wajira denies social media claims
author: Author not found
Content: UNP MP Wajira Abeywardena expressed concern yesterday (20) regarding the dissemination of contradictory and truth-distorting statements on social media related to remarks made by him concerning the recent Parliamentary Select Committee appointed to probe the reasons behind the economic crisis in the country. During the committee meeting, Abeywardena claimed the country failed when the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) declared bankruptcy. He claimed the CBSL’s step was wrong because the power of State finance lies with Parliament. Therefore, a large number of CBSL officials are responsible for the plight of the country, he added. Following the controversy that erupted on social media due to his statement, Abeywardena emphasised that such unfounded and fabricated statements on social media constituted an insult to the Finance Secretary and government officials. Speaking to the media at Sirikotha, MP Abeywardena clarified that his 2022 parliamentary statements had consistently focused on the country’s prevailing circumstances, particularly highlighting potential threats to Articles 27, 28, and 29 of the Constitution. He underscored that these parliamentary speeches did not pertain to Finance Ministry officials or other individuals. Abeywardena strongly condemned the irresponsible statements made on Facebook with the sole intention of gaining political mileage. He stressed the importance of rectifying historical errors and preventing their recurrence as the nation moves forward. Additionally, Abeywardena emphasised that all statements circulated on various social media platforms, including mentions of the Finance Secretary and other individuals, were distorted expressions driven by hatred and anger. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Borella OIC ordered to obtain witness testimony
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, yesterday (20), ordered the OIC of Borella Police to appear in Court on 11 October and examine the witnesses, if the Police Sub-Inspector, who carried out the task so far, is unable to appear for the next hearing of the case involving the tragic death of a three-year-old child at Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH) due to a kidney disease. The Additional Magistrate issued this order in response to the absence of the SI who carried out the examination of witnesses yesterday (20), as he was attending a training session. Thus, there was no suitable officer yesterday (20) to obtain the testimony of Prof. Randula Dias, a specialist at LRH. Due to the unavailability of the SI, another Police Officer was assigned to handle the proceedings. The Magistrate pointed out these procedural shortcomings and stressed the importance of conducting evidence-taking responsibly, as any lapses could potentially prejudice any party involved. Considering the difficulties encountered during the hearing, the Magistrate decided to halt the expert doctor’s testimony midway and scheduled a new hearing date for 11 October. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Batticaloa Campus returned to Hizbullah
author: Author not found
Content: After nearly four years, control of the Batticaloa Campus which is known as the ‘Sharia University’ in Punani, Batticaloa has been reverted to its former owner, M.L.A.M. Hizbullah, who previously served as the Eastern Province Governor. Following the Easter Attacks in 2019, the university, which had been taken over by the Government, continued its operations as both a medical treatment centre and as a facility to treat Covid patients. The university had been the subject of controversy islandwide. It was reported that about Rs 8 billion had been spent to construct the university. By T.I. Jawferkhan – Batticaloa

title: Will not allow social discord in East – Senthil
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman affirmed his commitment to thwarting any attempts to foment social discord among the three communities in the Eastern Province. He pointed out that the procession commemorating Thileepan in Trincomalee was deemed unnecessary and cited the suspension of a new Buddhist temple’s construction was due to lack of clearance from the predominantly Hindu community and it was rejected by the Grama Niladhari of that area. Governor Thondaman, underlining his resolve to take resolute measures in safeguarding peace said, on the issue involving the construction of a Buddhist temple at Periyakulam on Nilaveli Road in Trincomalee, as requested by Ven. Viharadhikari Sukhitha Wansatissa Thera was rejected based on the fact that 99.9 per cent of the population adheres to Hinduism, and they had expressed opposition to the construction of a Buddhist temple. He emphasised the importance of adhering to the country’s legal procedures for any construction project, stating that while anyone can offer land to someone, there are procedures that must be followed. He noted that Tamils were involved in the protests and as a Governor, his obligation was to promptly address their concerns, especially when they were protesting against the Government. He highlighted that any construction project requires approval from authorities such as the Urban Development Authority (UDA) and Pradeshiya Sabha. “When the Thera visited the UDA and the PS, they were inquired about the presence of public objections and as there were it was rejected. If they can seek a resolution with that community then it’s fine. It is within their purview to either abandon the idea or persuade the community to proceed with the construction. I want to clarify that the decision is not mine to make; my stance is to ensure adherence to legal processes in any endeavour.” Yesterday (20), the Buddhist clergy involved in the construction of the temple were seen gathering signatures from the public to petition against the Governor, who was opposing the temple’s construction. “In a democratic country, individuals are entitled to express their views and take action as they see fit. I wholeheartedly encourage any democratic engagement. I have extensive experience running the largest trade union, the Ceylon Workers’ Congress of Sri Lanka, which boasts over 200,000 members and operates as both a political and trade union party. We engage in daily protests on various issues in different estates, and I will consistently support any democratic actions taken.” According to the Governor, in the incident where the Thera and his associates forcefully entered the GS office during a DCC meeting recently regarding the temple construction, the Governor had told him that their actions were setting a bad precedent for other communities in the country. He explained that he had pointed out to them that if similar actions were taken by different religious leaders, it could lead to chaos.For instance, he mentioned that in Kattankudy, Muslim moulavis might barge into meetings, in Batticaloa Tamil priests might do the same, and in Mannar, Christian priests could follow suit. He said the Governor had refused to engage in further discussions during the DCC meeting. Instead, he directed them to the GS room, where the GS issued a letter permitting access to the land but prohibiting the construction of the Buddhist temple. The residents of the area have consistently requested a plot of land to build a Hindu temple, and their plea has not received approval. Consequently, they questioned how permission could be granted for the construction of a Buddhist temple, as emphasised by the Governor. Further, Governor Thondaman stressed his commitment to preventing any Tamil war hero remembrance processions that could disturb the Sinhala community in the Trincomalee District. He pointed out that the routing of Thileepan’s commemorative procession through a Sinhala village had provoked anger among the Sinhalese. He made it clear that such practices would not be tolerated in the future, and he has issued strict directives to this effect. He also noted that such activities have the potential to undermine national reconciliation and unity.The Governor highlighted that, first and foremost, organisers of events like these should seek permission from the Police, which they failed to do. Secondly, they must recognise that existing tensions between communities can be exacerbated by such actions.Thileepan had advocated for a separate homeland, which the Sinhala community did not support, and conducting his commemorative procession through a Sinhala village can incite resentment and even violence.Governor Thondaman characterised the actions of MP Gajendrakumar as irresponsible.“Maintaining peace and order in the Eastern Province, ensuring that unnecessary disturbances and unethical matters do not occur is vital.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: CEB ordered to pay Vavuniya Power Corporation Rs 1M
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court, yesterday (20), ordered the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to compensate Vavuniya (Lanka) Power Corporation with Rs 1 million. This compensation is in response to a violation of the fundamental rights of the company due to the denial of permission to initiate a project. The Supreme Court Bench, comprising Justices Gamini Amarasekara, Yasantha Kodagoda, and A.M.A. Nawaz also directed the Ministry of Power and Energy to promptly notify the Court about the initiation of legal action against the officials responsible for neglecting the company’s request. This order was issued in response to a petition to the Supreme Court by Vavuniya (Lanka) Power Corporation, asserting that their fundamental rights were infringed upon by the denial of permission to commence their project. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: President meets Meta’s Sir Nick Clegg
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe met Sir Nick Clegg, the former UK Deputy Prime Minister and present President for Global Affairs at Meta, during the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. During their discussions, President Wickremesinghe highlighted the Government’s new initiatives to combat online hate speech and the dissemination of fake news, as reported by the President’s Media Division. He underscored that the proposed bill would enable concerned parties to challenge specific aspects through the Supreme Court, and further revisions could be considered during the Parliamentary Committee review. The President was briefed on Meta’s advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI), with a particular emphasis on open-source technologies. Both parties explored potential collaborations between the Sri Lankan Government and Meta in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). One of the proposals discussed involved the development of a cooperative programme between Meta and Sri Lankan universities aimed at advancing AI technology. President Wickremesinghe reiterated his two primary areas of focus: nurturing the growth of the AI sector in the country, particularly in the field of education, and utilising AI to support data-driven initiatives aimed at addressing climate change. Accompanying the President were Senior Advisor for Climate Change, Ruwan Wijewardene; President’s Secretary, Saman Ekanayake; Chairman of the BOI, Dinesh Weerakkody; and Director of International Affairs, Dinouk Colombage.

title: Bangladeshi PM impressed with quick loan repayment
author: Author not found
Content: Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina expressed her satisfaction with Sri Lanka’s swift recovery from the economic crisis, remarking that she had not anticipated such a rapid loan repayment from Sri Lanka, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. She said this when she met President Ranil Wickremesinghe in New York on Tuesday (19). The meeting focused on various facets of bilateral relations and cooperation between the two South Asian nations. During their discussions, President Wickremesinghe conveyed his sincere appreciation to Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and the people of Bangladesh for their steadfast support and assistance during challenging periods. He acknowledged the aid extended to Sri Lanka and expressed deep gratitude for Bangladesh’s generosity. President Wickremesinghe also apologised for not being able to visit Bangladesh in the past due to various commitments and circumstances. He affirmed his commitment to strengthening the ties between the two countries and proposed the possibility of visiting Bangladesh in November or December, aligning with the Bangladeshi Government’s convenience. Bangladeshi Prime Minister Hasina shared the tragic history of her family, recounting the devastating assassinations that had affected her loved ones. The cordial conversation between the two leaders fostered a deeper understanding of each other’s experiences and aspirations, the PMD added.

title: Human trafficking suspect arrested in Thambuttegama
author: Author not found
Content: A woman was recently arrested in Thambuttegama on suspicion of her involvement in a human trafficking network that operates between Sri Lanka and Dubai, the Police said. The arrest was carried out by the Human Trafficking, Smuggling and Maritime Crime Investigation Division of the CID. The accused had arranged for a retired female Army soldier to travel to Dubai on a tourist visa in June 2022. Subsequently, she attempted to coerce the former soldier into the prostitution trade in Dubai. The retired Army soldier, hailing from Anuradhapura, had been compelled to visit a brothel in Dubai twice during her stay, from where she managed to escape. She then demanded that the responsible ‘employment’ agency facilitate her return to Sri Lanka. On her arrival in Sri Lanka, having paid an additional sum of Rs 400,000, in addition to the initial Rs 500,000 spent for her journey to Dubai, the victim reported the incident to the Inspector General of Police (IGP) through the Army Commander. Consequently, an investigation into the matter was launched. While the female suspect has been detained in Thambuttegama, ongoing efforts are being made to arrest her accomplice in Dubai, the Police added.

title: Use of Turmeric for indigestion
author: Author not found
Content: Turmeric is a well-known culinary spice and is listed as a component of curry powder. It is derived from the root of a rhizomatous, herbaceous, perennial plant, Curcuma longa. As many as 133 species of Curcuma has been identified worldwide. India is the largest producer of Turmeric and is also its biggest consumer. It is used extensively in South Asian and South East Asian cooking. It has also been used in traditional medicine for centuries. It is rich in phytonutrients and anti-oxidants. More than one hundred components have been isolated from turmeric. The main components are a volatile oil, containing turmerone, and colouring agents called curcuminoids. The components responsible for the aroma of turmeric are turmerone, arturmerone and zingiberene. Marco Polo refers to turmeric as ‘Indian saffron’ used for dyeing cloth.     Although it has long been used as a medicinal remedy in South East Asia, in recent years, it has also become a widely available supplement (as either a capsule or powder formulation). Currently, the actual health effects of Turmeric supplementation, on a variety of medical conditions remain uncertain. Some of the conditions in which it is purported to be of benefit include: arthritis, cancer, heart disease and gastrointestinal disease. However, in many of these conditions, good and robust clinical research data are still lacking, for allowing one to effectively evaluate any of the purported health benefits. Curcumin The naturally active compound in Turmeric is called curcumin. It gives turmeric its bright yellow colour and is thought to have anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidant, anti-mitotic and anti-microbial properties. Curcumin is poorly water soluble and has low bioavailability. When curcumin is taken orally, only a small amount is absorbed. To overcome this issue, it has been formulated as miscellar, liposomal or microgel formulations, so as to increase its solubility and bioavailability, when used as a supplement. Some agents are known to block the metabolic pathways of curcumin and thus increase its bioavailability. For instance, piperine, a major active component of black pepper, is known to markedly increase the bioavailability of curcumin. Curcumin has been shown to target multiple cell signalling pathways and molecules within a cell. It is available in several formulations including tablets, capsules, ointments, cosmetics, soaps and drinks. One needs to remember that between 2018 and 2023, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the United States of America (USA) issued 29 warning letters to USA manufacturers of dietary supplements, for making incorrect claims of anti-disease effects, from using products containing curcumin. Indigestion and Omeprazole Functional dyspepsia (indigestion), causes a range of symptoms including: feeling excessively full after food, feeling full after eating only a little food (early satiety), and pain and/or burning sensation in the stomach and/or the oesophagus (epigastric pain). Omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is a well-known drug that is used to treat functional dyspepsia. Omeprazole was approved for medical use around 35 years ago and is on the WHO’s (World Health Organisation) list of essential medicines. The long term use of PPIs has been linked to increased fracture risk, micronutrient deficiencies, and a heightened risk of infections. It has a drug interaction with a medicine called clopidrogrel. Tumeric has been used as an antacid in South East Asia for many decades. However, its effectiveness in treating indigestion, when compared to standard drugs has been uncertain. Recent research study In a recent multicentre randomised research study, 206 patients with recurrent functional dyspepsia of unknown cause were randomly assigned to take curcumin alone (69 patients), omeprazole alone (68 patients) or curcumin plus omeprazole (69 patients) for 28 days. The patients for this study were selected from those seen at hospitals in Thailand, between 2019 and 2021. They were aged between 18 and 70 years. The curcumin group received two large 250 mg capsules of curcumin 4 times a day and one small dummy capsule. The omeprazole group received one small 20 mg Omeprazole capsule daily and two large dummy capsules 4 times a day. The dropout rate during the study was between 23 and 29 percent. At the start of the trial, patients in all three groups had similar clinical characteristics. Follow-up assessments were done at one and two months. The indigestion score showed a significant reduction in symptom severity by one month, in all three groups. The improvements were higher after two months. There was no significant additional benefit in the group taking both agents. No serious side effects were noted during the study. However, there was a degree of deterioration of liver function tests in over-weight individuals receiving curcumin. This study showed that curcumin could be as effective as a proton pump inhibitor for treating symptoms of indigestion. This is an important initial research study finding, particularly in an area where good research evidence is badly needed. However, we need to remember that this was a small study and follow-up clinical data were available only for a short period. Potential issues with excessive intake of Turmeric Excessive amounts or turmeric or curcumin may cause diarrhoea, nausea and headache. It has anticoagulant properties and would slow down blood clotting. Turmeric supplements should be stopped for at least two weeks prior to a surgical procedure. It may also interact with other medicines when taken concurrently. The WHO has determined 0.3mg Turmeric per kilogram body weight, as an acceptable daily intake. Individuals with gall stones or diabetes need to take special care when using turmeric supplements. Pregnant and breast feeding women should not take turmeric supplements. In general, the amounts included in supplements are between 500 and 2000 milligrams. In all instances, it is important that a person checks with their healthcare professional before commencing any supplements. Conclusion Further large scale clinical studies should shed light on the use of turmeric in the management of indigestion (a common medical condition). Currently, several clinical and laboratory studies are ongoing, investigating the effects of turmeric and curcumin, on a range of inflammatory and other medical disorders. By Prof. Suranjith L Seneviratne

title: Chad Envoy calls on HC Moragoda
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Chad to India Dillah Lucienne called on Sri Lankan High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda at the Sri Lankan High Commission in New Delhi. Chad and Sri Lanka are to sign an agreement, establishing formal diplomatic relations shortly, and the arrangements in this regard are ongoing. Once formal diplomatic ties are established, the Ambassador of Chad in New Delhi will be concurrently accredited to Sri Lanka, making Chad the 100th Diplomatic Mission concurrently accredited to Colombo from New Delhi.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Linac machine out of commission at Batti hospital
author: Author not found
Content: Government Radiology Technologists lamented that cancer patients in the Eastern Province were left in the lurch, due to the  Linear Accelerator (Linac) machine being constantly out of order, due to poor maintenance issues. President of the Government Radiological Technologists’ Association (GRTA) Chanaka Dharmawickrema yesterday (19) said, multiple breakdowns of the Linear Accelerator, installed at the Batticaloa Teaching Hospital (TH), during the past few months was an issue not only for patients but also to hospital staff. He said the latest break down was allegedly due to a technical fault in the air conditioning system. According to the company from which the Linac was purchased, it should be kept in the correct humidity provided by the air conditioning system.  Dharmawickrema said the hospital has been unable to operate the machine for the past one week, raising concerns about the continuity of vital cancer treatment services in the region. “The machine is the only one in the region and plays a key role in providing radiation therapy to cancer patients,” he added. With only ten such machines in the island, the breakdown of Linac at the Batticaloa Teaching Hospital highlights the precarious state of cancer treatment infrastructure in the country, the GRTA President pointed out. Dharmawickrema said that  Linac was an essential tool in medical technology used in radiation therapy to treat various forms of cancer. It delivers precisely targeted radiation doses to cancerous tumours, minimising damage to surrounding healthy tissue. The recent breakdown has not only caused disruptions to ongoing cancer treatment, but has also led to a backlog of patients due to the disruption of treatment schedules. “One can only imagine the uncertainty and mental strain faced by patients whose treatment has been postponed owing to the criticalness of their illness,” he observed. He said that it left questions about quality of the healthcare system’s infrastructure, particularly in rural areas. Approximately 40 patients receive radiotherapy treatment daily at Batticaloa Teaching Hospital, making the uninterrupted operation of the Linac machine imperative. The situation in the Teaching Hospital underscores the urgent need for investment in healthcare infrastructure and Linac maintenance across the country. With just ten Linac machines serving a population of over 21 million, Sri Lanka is grappling with a severe shortage of these critical devices. It is imperative that the government and healthcare authorities take immediate action to address these issues, he stressed. Fielding questions, he said the Bio Medical Unit of the Health Ministry also had the responsibility to inquire as to why the Linac was constantly breaking down at the Batticaloa Teaching Hospital and ensure that the hospital continued to provide uninterrupted care and services to cancer patients.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 4th International Conference on Intangible Cultural Heritage at USJ
author: Author not found
Content: The 4th International Conference on Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICICH), organised by the Department of Anthropology, Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences of the University of Sri Jayewardenepura is taking place today (21) and tomorrow (22) at the university, creating a platform for academics and researchers to come together and share their knowledge in the sphere of their cultural heritages. The inaugural session will be held on 21 September at 9.00 a.m. to 11.00 a.m. The conference, this year, is hosted for the fourth time by the Department of Anthropology in collaboration with the UNESCO – Sri Lanka National Commission. Abstracts were called under the theme of ‘Preserving and Safeguarding Cultural Heritage through Traditional Insights’. Special addition to the current conference proposed by the Secretary General of Sri Lanka National Commission of UNESCO is the inclusion of the English translation of the Sinhala and Tamil abstracts to disseminate the invaluable traditional insights of Sri Lanka to the world. Chief Guest of the conference is Snr. Prof. Pathmalal Manage, Vice Chancellor of the University of Sri Jayewardenepura and Dr. Tim Curtis, Chief of the Intangible Cultural Heritage Section of UNESCO is the guest of honour. The keynote address will be delivered by Dr. Gamini Wijesuriya, UNESCO Facilitator for Intangible Heritage Convention while the plenary address will be delivered by Prof. Shihan De Silva Jayasuriya, Chair, National Scientific Committee on Intangible Cultural Heritage, ICOMOS Sri Lanka.

title: Minister Alles chairs spl discourse on Easter Report
author: Author not found
Content: A special discussion took place in Parliament on Tuesday (19), chaired by Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, to brief MPs on the investigation report regarding the Easter Sunday terror attacks. In attendance were Viyani Gunathilaka, Secretary of the Public Security Ministry, IGP C.D. Wickramaratne  as well as senior officials representing the CID and the TID. Members from various political parties and the Opposition MPs participated in this meeting, during which the investigation officers addressed the questions raised by the MPs concerning the investigation report. MPs expressed their gratitude to Minister Alles for his efforts in providing information about the investigation report.

title: ‘We do not align with either India or China’– President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe highlighted the reluctance of island nations in the Indian Ocean and South Pacific to become embroiled in the rivalry between major world powers. The President emphasised that these nations are focused on their own priorities, including social, economic, and ecological development, and seek to maintain their sovereignty and independence. He made this statement, participating in the ‘Ocean Nations: The 3rd Annual Indo-Pacific Islands Dialogue’, moderated by Dan Baer, Senior Vice President for Policy Research at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and hosted by the Carnegie Endowment and Sasakawa Foundation. President Wickremesinghe asserted that the Sri Lankan Government does not align itself with either India or China and firmly stands for Sri Lanka’s interests above all else. This commitment to sovereignty extends to other island nations in the region. Island nations in the Indian Ocean and South Pacific have distinct priorities, unrelated to the Quad (comprising the US, India, Japan, and Australia) or China’s objectives, he said, adding that Sri Lanka is open to collaboration with any partners willing to respect its autonomy. Regarding regional frameworks, President Wickremesinghe noted that China’s rise occurred within existing regional frameworks such as APEC and ASEAN, which many nations prefer to maintain. The recent expansion of great power rivalry beyond these frameworks has raised concerns among member nations. He said the South Pacific and the Indian Ocean hold immense strategic value. The South Pacific is a vital hub for the US Navy, and the Indian Ocean played a crucial role in World War II. President Wickremesinghe said, “The South Pacific, which includes Hawaii, is where the US dominance of the Pacific was established in WW II, including the Battle of the Coral Sea and Midway, as well as the shooting down of Admiral Yamamoto’s plane. The importance of the Indian Ocean was best described by Winston Churchill, who said the most dangerous moment of the war was the capture of Ceylon and consequently the loss of the Indian Ocean.” The Indo-Pacific concept has gained recognition, primarily due to mounting challenges from China, the President said, adding that it has prompted a re-evaluation of regional dynamics and cooperation, such as the Jakarta Concord within the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA). The G7’s attempt to involve European powers and NATO in the Indo-Pacific was met with opposition, with only France expressing interest. This move was seen as violating IORA’s rules-based order, the President pointed out. The President also noted that the Quad has shifted its focus from security and dialogue to applying coordinated pressure in the region. While surface warfare threats are minimal in the Indian Ocean, addressing the issue of submarine warfare within IORA is necessary. Regarding Security Dialogues, the President pointed out that island nations find security dialogues acceptable but emphasise non-interference in their internal affairs. Many island nations, including Sri Lanka, have not engaged in high-level discussions regarding the Indo-Pacific. Recent developments, such as the US opening an embassy in the Maldives, were also noted. The power balance in the Indian Ocean is evolving, influenced by ASEAN, the Russia-Ukraine war, and the emergence of BRICS+. This changing landscape favors the independence of island nations and calls for strengthened cooperation between IORA, ASEAN, and BRICS+. In response to a question about the Hambantota port, President Wickremesinghe said Sri Lanka expressed concerns about the labeling of the Hambantota commercial port as a Chinese military base. The country is developing the Trincomalee harbour in cooperation with India and intends to raise this matter at international forums. He also emphasised the need for IORA to accommodate the Indo-Pacific concept, recognising the interconnectedness of the Indian and Pacific Oceans and enabling cooperation among small island states in both regions. The island nations of the Indian Ocean and South Pacific remain steadfast in their pursuit of independence, non-interference, and the protection of their unique priorities amidst the evolving dynamics of great power rivalry in the Indo-Pacific region, the President added.

title: Final decision on 2023 A/L exam soon – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha informed Parliament yesterday (19) that the Commissioner General of Examinations would soon provide an update regarding the proposed postponement of G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination this year. Premajayantha was responding to Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Rohini Kumari Wijeratne, who recommended delaying the A/L examinations until January next year. She suggested rescheduling the A/L Examinations to take place from 22 January to 17 February 2024, with corresponding adjustments to the third and first school terms to October of this year and February 2024 for the first term.  She also noted that the A/L results could be expected by May of the following year, allowing for the normal scheduling of A/L examinations in October. Minister Premajayantha revealed that this proposal had been submitted to the Commissioner General of Examinations for consideration and an official announcement would be forthcoming shortly. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sunday’s Shooting : Uddika blames ‘existing system
author: Author not found
Content: MP Uddika Premarathna, who was shot at on Sunday (17) night, in front of his home in Anuradhapura, told Parliament yesterday (19) that the attack was due to the ‘prevailing political system’ in the country. Premarathna expressed his belief that the system was not only responsible for the attack on his residence but also for the current state of the nation. He emphasised that rather than focusing solely on identifying the perpetrator of the shooting, it is imperative to recognise that the existing system is at the root of such incidents. He further highlighted that this system is widely acknowledged as flawed, both by the citizens of the country and within the realm of politics. It is this systemic flaw, according to MP Premaratne, that has contributed to the challenging circumstances the nation finds itself in today. Meanwhile, several MPs raised their voice in Parliament against the shooting.  Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said it is a responsibility of the government to ensure the security of MPs. He requested to increase the security provided to Premarathna. MP Vasudeva Nanayakkasa said the ‘conspiracy’ behind the shooting should be discovered. MP Dayasiri Jayasekara said the shooting should be considered as an attack against all the MPs. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Payment made to MEPA for beach cleaning, not compensation
author: Author not found
Content: The former operators of the ill-fated ‘MV X-Press Pearl’, which caught fire and ultimately sank off the northern coast of Colombo on 2 June 2021, officially announced that they made two payments totalling USD 878,650.53 through the vessel owner’s P&I insurers. Additionally, they have made another payment of Rs 16,315,451.05. These payments specifically pertain to claims filed by the Marine Environment Protection Authority of Sri Lanka (MEPA) for beach cleaning and rehabilitation efforts. Ceylon Today recently reported that the USD payment made by the MV X-Press Pearl to Sri Lanka, which was portrayed by the Government as compensation, was actually intended for beach cleaning. Also, in accordance to the proposal put forth in 2022 to the Cabinet, it had been communicated to P&I insurers that the compensation for beach cleaning payment needed to be made in US dollars, despite themsaying  that they would settle the amount in Sri Lankan rupees and surprisingly the Sri Lankan delegate had expressed agreement. The shipping company or the P & I Club can’t make payments in Sri Lankan rupees as per the Cabinet approval. However, the Government has accepted the rupee payment noted former MEPA Chairman Dharshani Lahandapura. Resolution of these claims was discussed at recent meetings between a Sri Lankan Government delegation and representatives of the ship owners and their insurers in Singapore on 18 and 19 July 2023, the MV – Xpress Pearl owners noted amidst controversies over the claims by Sri Lankans. Assessments on the payment of further claims are ongoing, with all legitimate claims being considered, they told the local media. Meanwhile, a caretaker tug remains at the site monitoring the situation until the conclusion of the southwest monsoon season, when work will recommence to lift the remaining fore section of the wreck and transport it to a certified decommissioning facility for dismantling, recycling, and disposal. In February 2023, the aft section of the wreck left Sri Lankan waters aboard the semi-submersible FAN ZHOU 10 en route to a certified decommissioning facility for dismantling, recycling, and disposal. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Court orders detailed probe
author: Author not found
Content: Anuradhapura Chief Magistrate Nalaka Jayasuriya yesterday (19) ordered the Anuradhapura Police to conduct a detailed probe into the shooting incident targeting MP Uddika Premarathna, arrest all suspects involved and produce them in Court. The Chief Magistrate also instructed the Anuradhapura Police to submit a progress report to him on the ongoing probe into the incident. The Court issued these Orders following a ‘B’ report submitted by the Anuradhapura Police. In their report the Police stated that that an unidentified group had opened fire targeting the lawmaker near his residence during the night of 17 September. They told the Court that though the MP concerned had escaped unhurt the incident had resulted in his vehicle being damaged and said that investigations were being conducted from several angles. The Police told Chief Magistrate Jayasuriya that statements had also been recorded by them from the MP and two security officers who had been deployed to provide protection to the MP. They stated that so far, they were yet to identify any suspects behind the incident. BY Upali Ananda – Anuradhapura

title: Court bans ‘Thileepan’ commemoration
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage, yesterday (19) issued an Order prohibiting the commemoration of ‘Thileepan’, a member of a proscribed organization, in several areas within Colombo, on account of the severe inconvenience likely to be caused to the public. Accordingly, he issued the Order, prohibiting commemorations in the Kollupitiya (Colombo 3), Colombo Fort and Slave Island jurisdictions. The Fort Police had produced submissions to Magistrate Gamage, that they had received information that certain individuals were planning to conduct events in Colombo commemorating ‘Thileepan’. Having perused the submission, the Court issued the requisite order. The relevant order was issued against all persons, expected to participate in the celebrations, including the Christian Solidarity Movement (CSM) and Rev. Fr. Marimuttu Satyavel, on the request of the Fort Police. Rasaiah Parthipan, better known as ‘Thileepan’, was a member of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) and died while on hunger strike in 1987, during which he had articulated five requests to the Indian Government, aiming to encourage them to apply pressure on the Sri Lankan Government, to fulfil those requests. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Severe gynae, anaesthetists shortage
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella accepted in Parliament yesterday (19) that there is a severe shortage of Gynaecologists and Anaesthetists in the country at the moment. In response to a question raised by the Opposition, Rambukwella said the Health Ministry is trying to provide solutions for this issue as soon as possible. Speaking about the recent reports on the shortage of Yellow Fever vaccines for those who expect to travel abroad, specially to African countries, Rambukwella said 2,000 vaccines were brought on the same day with the assistance of UNICEF. “We had called tenders to bring Yellow Fever vaccines. However, we did not receive any tenders. That was the reason behind the shortage of vaccines,” he explained. He said it is being considered to bring the vaccines in collaboration with the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC). BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: MCPA goes to SC urging end to misuse of tax payers’ money
author: Author not found
Content: Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) President Chamal Sanjeewa filed a petition, in the Supreme Court, urging the Chief Justice to put an immediate end to the misuse of public funds for emergency purchasing of medicines, violating a person’s right to life and causing heavy losses of public taxes. Dr. Sanjeeva, filing the petition prayed the Chief Justice to move legal procedures against the Ministry of Health for the unacceptable waste of public property for procurement activities, in the emergency purchasing of pharmaceuticals, at a time when the country was going through a severe economic downturn. The country’s State health service was in a serious crisis while health administrators’ cite this as a main reason for the situation. However, for the past one year it had been possible to buy high quality medicinal drugs at a cost-effective price through correct procurement procedures. Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, Health Secretary, Janaka Sri Chandragupta and the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC) have failed to follow proper procurement procedures and made purchases at higher prices, through emergency purchasing, without even the registration and standard certification from the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA).  Dr. Sanjeeva in his petition alleged that the best examples for the situation were the questionable lenses and a particular antibiotic used to control and prevent bacterial infection. The country has incurred heavy losses of tax money as a result of these questionable emergency drug purchases in addition to the loss of life due to the importation of drugs without observing proper procurement methods and registration, he said.  The MCPA President accused the Health Minister and Health officials of violating the people’s right to life by using their own discretion instead of following proper accepted methodology to import medicinal drugs and procure them. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Six arrested over body found in bag
author: Author not found
Content: Six individuals have been arrested in connection with the recent discovery of a body inside a travelling bag left on the banks of the Dandugam Oya in Seeduwa. The suspects, all residents of Katana, were detained by Seeduwa Police. Among those taken into custody are believed to be a father and his two sons. The deceased was a 36-year-old individual and resident of Mahawewa. The Police have disclosed that the elder son, of the main suspect, had fallen victim to a foreign job racket allegedly operated by the deceased. On 15 September, the body of a man was found inside a travelling bag that had been abandoned on the banks of the Dandugam Oya in Seeduwa. According to the Police, the victim is suspected to have died a few days earlier and his body subsequently placed inside the blue travelling bag. Following a Magisterial inquest, the remains of the deceased were transported to the Negombo District General Hospital.

title: Dialog Enables 5G for Apple iPhone Users
author: Author not found
Content: Dialog Axiata PLC, the first telecommunications service provider in the South Asian region to demonstrate 5G capabilities in 2018, has once again achieved a 5G milestone in the country by becoming the first to extend 5G connectivity to Apple iPhone users through its 5G Trial Network. Users with Apple iPhone models 12 and above and the latest version of iOS (version 17) can now experience the power of 5G and the lightning-fast download and upload speeds of up to 1Gbps on Dialog – Sri Lanka’s largest 5G trial network with over 70 locations island-wide. This service is available in Colombo and select cities nationwide, with locations listed on – www.dialog.lk/5g. To celebrate this momentous occasion, Dialog is offering monthly 5GB free data for its Apple iPhone customers to explore the capabilities of 5G on Dialog’s 5G Trial Network. This announcement follows a range of 5G milestones and firsts in South Asia and Sri Lanka, including the deployment of the region’s first 5G trial network, the first 5G Standalone (5G SA) network trial, and the first standards-based 5G fixed-wireless pilot transmission in December 2018. Dialog remains committed to pioneering technological advancements in the nation and the region in line with its brand promise of delivering ‘The Future. Today.’ Customers can visit www.dialog.lk/5g to stay updated as Dialog expands its 5G trial network to more locations.

title: Seven Lankans deported from Réunion Island
author: Author not found
Content: Seven Sri Lankans, who had sought refuge on Réunion Island in France, were deported to Colombo and they landed at the BIA Katunayake on 18 September. The group are said to be residents of Batticaloa and Puttalam. Of them, four had paid a sum of Rs 300,000 to the human smugglers behind the racket and they had been transported via boat to France. The rest had paid Rs 400,000 to the smugglers and they had been flown from Katunayake to Indonesia after which they had been transported via boat to Réunion, Island.  After the group had been taken into custody by officers from the Department of Immigration and Emigration, they have been handed over to CID sleuths at the BIA for further investigations. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Court orders detailed probe
author: Author not found
Content: Anuradhapura Chief Magistrate Nalaka Jayasuriya yesterday (19) ordered the Anuradhapura Police to conduct a detailed probe into the shooting incident targeting MP Uddika Premarathna, arrest all suspects involved and produce them in Court. The Chief Magistrate also instructed the Anuradhapura Police to submit a progress report to him on the ongoing probe into the incident. The Court issued these Orders following a ‘B’ report submitted by the Anuradhapura Police. In their report the Police stated that that an unidentified group had opened fire targeting the lawmaker near his residence during the night of 17 September. They told the Court that though the MP concerned had escaped unhurt the incident had resulted in his vehicle being damaged and said that investigations were being conducted from several angles. The Police told Chief Magistrate Jayasuriya that statements had also been recorded by them from the MP and two security officers who had been deployed to provide protection to the MP. They stated that so far, they were yet to identify any suspects behind the incident. BY Upali Ananda – Anuradhapura

title: Court bans ‘Thileepan’ commemoration
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage, yesterday (19) issued an Order prohibiting the commemoration of ‘Thileepan’, a member of a proscribed organization, in several areas within Colombo, on account of the severe inconvenience likely to be caused to the public. Accordingly, he issued the Order, prohibiting commemorations in the Kollupitiya (Colombo 3), Colombo Fort and Slave Island jurisdictions. The Fort Police had produced submissions to Magistrate Gamage, that they had received information that certain individuals were planning to conduct events in Colombo commemorating ‘Thileepan’. Having perused the submission, the Court issued the requisite order. The relevant order was issued against all persons, expected to participate in the celebrations, including the Christian Solidarity Movement (CSM) and Rev. Fr. Marimuttu Satyavel, on the request of the Fort Police. Rasaiah Parthipan, better known as ‘Thileepan’, was a member of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) and died while on hunger strike in 1987, during which he had articulated five requests to the Indian Government, aiming to encourage them to apply pressure on the Sri Lankan Government, to fulfil those requests. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Elephants run amok in Galenbindunuwewa
author: Author not found
Content: A herd of around 40 elephants attacked the Maradankalla village in the Galenbindunuwewa DS Division in the Anuradhapura District on 18 September night and destroyed many permanent crops including coconut, mango, guava, as well as cash crops such as pumpkin and kekiri. Residents point out that these wild elephants, which have been coming to the village from areas such as Palugollagama, Huruluwewa and Manankattia Lake reserves for nearly four years, are constantly destroying the crops in this area and villagers point out that wild elephants can be seen in the cultivated fields of this village day and night. The rampaging wild elephants had destroyed nearly five acres of pumpkin and kekiri fields. Area residents, whose livelihood is based on farming, have informed the Galenbindunuwewa Divisional Secretary and the Moragoda Wildlife Officers about the wild elephant issue, to no avail. Residents appealed to responsible authorities to drive away the wild elephants and build an electric fence to protect the village. By Chinthaka Krishantha Balasuriya – Galenbindunuwewa

title: Cleaning the country’s beaches
author: Author not found
Content: On World Cleanup Day, which took place on 16 September, the ZeroPlastic Movement joined forces with the Central Environmental Authority and successfully executed over 680 cleanups across our beloved country. This ambitious project was made possible through the generous sponsorship of the Star Garments Group.

title: Outgoing Iranian Envoy meets PM
author: Author not found
Content: Outgoing Ambassador of Iran Hashem Ashjazadeh thanked Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena for continuously extending support to him during his diplomatic tenure to promote bilateral friendship and development cooperation. The Ambassador, who paid a farewell call on the Prime Minister at Temple Trees on Monday (18 September), recalled that during the challenging period of the Covid-19 pandemic and the global economic crisis he could count on the Prime Minister’s support. The Prime Minister thanked Ambassador Ashjazadeh for his efforts to promote friendship and cooperation between Iran andSri Lanka during a difficult and challenging period. He praised the ambassador for his special efforts to assist Sri Lanka and for working tirelessly to ensure the completion of important joint ventures undertaken by Iran for the benefit of Sri Lanka. Minister Naseer Ahamed, MP Shasheendra Rajapaksa and MP Sudarshana Denipitiya, Secretary to the Prime Minister Anura Dissanayake and Economic and Consular Section Chief of the Iran Embassy K. Soheil were also present during the meeting.

title: Surgeries at standstill at H’tota General HospitaL
author: Author not found
Content: Surgeries at the Hambantota General Hospital, which caters to  around 900 patients per day, have come to a standstill for want of anaesthetist, Ceylon Today learns. Hospital sources said the sole anaesthetist, attached to the hospital, had gone overseas around two months ago and a replacement has still not been made, further complicating matters. He added that though two anaesthetists had been assigned for duty at the hospital, to date they had not reported for duty. It is revealed that due to this situation, patients in need of surgeries have been transferred to hospitals in Matara, Mahamodara and Karapitiya further inconveniencing them. Hospital sources further mentioned that most of the doctors, who have been assigned for duty at this hospital, had reportedly declined to serve there. They warned that if the situation is not addressed urgently the activities at this hospital could collapse shortly. BY Amila Sampath – Tissamaharama

title: World Patient Safety Day marked at Akkaraipattu Base Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: ‘World Patient Safety Day’ was marked at Akkaraipattu Base Hospital, where an event was held at the Hospital’s Open Air premises on Monday (18). Medical professionals and hospital employees participated in the event. Dr. T.S.R.T.R. Rajab, Medical Superintendent, addressed the gathering emphasising the responsibility of the staff to carry out their duties with utmost commitment to patient safety. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Indian ship, Sri Lanka Navy in rescue of distressed fishers
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy has successfully rescued three distressed fishermen from a local fishing trawler, that had capsised while drifting into Indian waters, north of Sri Lanka. These fishermen, who had encountered peril at sea, were initially rescued by a Merchant Vessel. Following their rescue, the Sri Lanka Navy played a pivotal role in bringing them safely ashore. This coordinated effort was orchestrated by the Maritime Rescue Coordinating Centre (MRCC) Colombo on 17 September. The ill-fated trawler, identified as OFRP-A-1604 TLE, had embarked on a routine fishing expedition from Hambantota on 2 September but encountered mechanical failure, ultimately drifting into Indian waters, where it capsised. During this critical time, the MV INTERSEA VOYAGER, transiting through the region, spotted the distressed situation and promptly reported it to MRCC Chennai. MRCC Chennai, in turn, directed the Merchant Vessel to assist and rescue the fishermen from the distressed fishing vessel. Subsequently, MRCC Colombo was alerted to the incident. Under the coordination of MRCC Colombo, MV INTERSEA VOYAGER safely retrieved the fishermen off Hambantota Harbour. To facilitate their return to shore, the Sri Lanka Navy dispatched the Fast Attack Craft P 421 from the 4th Fast Attack Flotilla. Once ashore, the rescued fishermen were swiftly transported to the District General Hospital in Hambantota for necessary medical attention.
