title: SLPP proposes extending Samurdhi
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) and other alliance members are working together to develop a joint proposal for the 2024 budget, SLPP MP Namal Rajapaksa said. “One of the proposals under consideration is the extension of the Samurdhi programme for another year. We are suggesting this extension due to certain challenges in the swift implementation of Aswesuma,” Rajapaksa explained. “We are also exploring strategies to enhance the rural economy’s performance, with the aim of making a more significant contribution to the national economy,” he added.

title: Body found with limbs bound in Ratgama canal
author: Author not found
Content: Ratgama Police said they had found the body of a person whose hands and legs tied and floating in a canal behind the Ratgama crematorium on 18 September. Police said the victim would have been killed and has been identified as 28-year-old G. Shehan Thilanga a resident of Gammaddegoda, Ratgama. Following initial investigations it had come to light that the victim was without a permanent job and that he had returned to the country around a year ago after being employed abroad. The body was taken to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital for the post-mortem. Ratgama Police are carrying out further investigations to apprehend the suspects behind the killing. BY S. Diyagahage – Ratgama

title: SriLankan needs 30 pilots in the coming months – Nuttlal
author: Author not found
Content: National carrier SriLankan Airlines is in the process of recruiting approximately 30 foreign pilots to manage airline operations and has currently recruited five foreign pilots, while the Government actively seeks investors to take over the ground handling and catering services of the airline. CEO of SriLankan Airlines, Richard Nuttal, told Ceylon Today, “We received permission to hire foreign pilots a couple of months ago. This is not a new practice; we had foreign pilots before the Covid-19 pandemic. However, our priority is to employ Sri Lankan pilots when available, and currently, we have hired five foreign pilots. Depending on fleet requirements and retaining our current crew, we anticipate the need for around 30 pilots in the upcoming months.” Nuttal, in an interview with Channel NewsAsia (CNA) in July 2023, said that SriLankan Airlines is projecting a USD 50 million profit for the next year (2024), emphasising that tourism has rebounded to pre-pandemic levels. He added that the airline is largely shielded from currency fluctuations, as 80 per cent of its revenue comes from international sources and ticket fares are set in dollars. Regarding servicing Sri Lanka’s debt, Nuttal explained to the TV channel that the Sri Lankan Government is exploring ways to handle State-owned enterprises. There is an initiative, partly through the IMF, to stop government’s liability for inefficient State-owned enterprises, possibly through privatisation. Nuttal also mentioned that 10% of the airline’s revenue in 2023 was spent on interest payments for past debts, which had nothing to do with SriLankan Airlines. These debts were incurred in dollars, with interest rates ranging from 12% to 15%, which may not be sustainable in the long term if passenger yields decline. As for investor interest, Nuttal explained that in Sri Lanka, all potential partnerships go through a process managed by the State-Owned Enterprises (SOE) unit under the finance ministry. While the government is currently overseeing this process, it is expected that, at some point, they will seek expressions of interest (EoI) from potential partners to work with, although the exact timing remains uncertain. “’We will have wait to see for a good partner to work with and maybe we will get one or maybe not,” he added. Given the absence of investors and the continued growth in international passenger traffic, the government has hired around 96 new air hostesses and is actively pursuing the recruitment of an additional 30 pilots to handle the increasing international passenger demand. Currently, SriLankan Airlines operates 19 out of its 24 aircraft, but faces a significant shortage of ground handling and cargo handling staff. President of the Jathika Nidhahas Sevaka Sangamaya, Janaka Wijeyapathirana, told Ceylon Today that it is a critical understaffing issue at SriLankan Airlines, with a deficit of approximately 400 staff members. He also noted that the government has approved the recruitment of 30 pilots. Additionally, Wijeyapathirana mentioned that locally trained cadet pilots will be hired as First Officers to serve SriLankan Airlines. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SL, US reaffirm dedication to strengthening trade, investment ties
author: Author not found
Content: The United States and Sri Lanka convened the fourteenth Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) Council Meeting in Colombo yesterday (18), reaffirming their dedication to strengthening trade and investment ties. The technical-level meeting, co-chaired by K.J. Weerasinghe from the Government of Sri Lanka and Brendan Lynch, Acting Assistant United States Trade Representative for South and Central Asia, featured constructive discussions on a range of significant topics. Julie Chung, US Ambassador to Sri Lanka and Chandanie Wijayawardhana, Acting Secretary to the President, opened the meeting, acknowledging the 75th anniversary of bilateral relations between the two countries. During the TIFA Council meeting, both delegations tackled policies affecting the investment climate, recent labour reforms, intellectual property protection and enforcement, customs and trade facilitation, technical trade barriers, and market access for apparel, gemstones, jewellery, and agricultural products. The discussions also extended to cooperation and technical assistance in areas such as the digital economy, gem and jewellery industry, floriculture, boat-building sectors, and technology transfer and research commercialisation at the Coconut Research Institute. Transparency and efficiency in approving foreign direct investment (FDI) were highlighted as critical factors for domestic economic growth and attracting foreign investments. The United States emphasised the importance of implementing robust anti-corruption measures and Sri Lanka provided updates on its proposed anti-corruption legislation, seeking technical assistance and training from the US Government. The Biden-Harris Administration’s commitment to workers’ rights was emphasised and Sri Lanka outlined its ongoing labour law reform efforts. The United States stressed the significance of consulting relevant stakeholders and ensuring public review and comment throughout the process. Sri Lanka detailed its procedures for labour law reforms, with the United States expressing its readiness to support these endeavours. Both nations discussed reducing agricultural trade barriers to enhance food security in Sri Lanka. The United States advocated for increased market access for US agricultural product exports, including animal feed. The role of biotechnology in sustainable agriculture and food security was also explored. Intellectual property (IP) protection and enforcement were recognised as crucial for bilateral trade and innovation. Sri Lanka shared updates on its IP legislative reforms, and the United States offered capacity-building support.

title: SC overturns Appeal Court Order
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court issued an interim injunction, overturning a previous Stay Order issued by the Court of Appeal that had prevented the execution of arrest warrants for five individuals, including the former Mayor of Kurunegala, Thushara Sanjeeva Witharana. These individuals are facing charges related to the demolition of the ‘Buwanekaba Rajasabha Mandapa’ in Kurunegala town. The Supreme Court issued this order during the hearing of an appeal filed against the Court of Appeal’s previous order, yesterday (18). This interim injunction will remain in effect until the relevant petition is heard and concluded, as per the Supreme Court’s directives.

title: Harin to withdraw Petition in SC
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Tourism and Lands Harin Fernando yesterday (18) told Supreme Court that he would withdraw the Petition he had previously filed, which sought to prevent law enforcement authorities from arresting him in connection with investigations into the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attack. This decision was conveyed by the minister’s legal representative during a hearing before a Supreme Court panel comprising Justices Gamini Amarasekara, Mahinda Samayawardana and Arjuna Obeysekara. Minister Fernando had submitted this petition some time ago, seeking a Supreme Court order to prevent his arrest in connection with the investigations into the Easter Sunday terror attacks. During a court session on 13 September, Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris informed the Court that the Attorney General had instructed the Police on 20 June to complete their investigations into Fernando after reviewing the files compiled by the Police Special Investigation Unit. In yesterday’s Court proceedings, Minister Fernando’s lawyer conveyed his client’s decision to no longer pursue the petition and requested permission to withdraw it. Consequently, the petition was officially withdrawn, and the Supreme Court panel issued an order to revoke it.

title: Govt cannot hide issues using new laws – Kumudesh
author: Author not found
Content: The Government should not think it could conceal issues, especially those in the State health service, by bringing in laws to suppress the increasing tension amongst the trade unions, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) said.   An Extraordinary Gazette has been released, by the Acting Secretary to the President, officially designating electricity, petroleum, and health services as essential services. As per the Gazette Notification, all activities related to the provision of electricity, the distribution of petroleum products and fuels, as well as all tasks, jobs or labour of any kind essential for the maintenance and the care, feeding, and treatment of patients in hospitals, nursing homes, dispensaries, and similar healthcare facilities are now classified as essential services. AHP President, Ravi Kumudesh yesterday alleged that a Special Gazette Notice had been issued with the signature of the Acting Presidential Secretary, Chandani Wijayawardena, identifying several services as ‘essential services’. The Gazette is allegedly aimed at preventing blockage or obstruction of services required in order to maintaining the daily life of people. Accordingly, all services, work or labour of any description necessary or to be performed in connection with the maintenance and reception, care, feeding and treatment of patients in hospitals, nursing homes, dispensaries and other general institutions, as well as all services in connection with the supply of electricity, supply or distribution of petroleum products and fuel have been declared essential services as a result, he noted. Kumudesh said that although the crisis in the health service has been subsumed as a political issue due to the no-confidence motion it seems that the government has somehow calculated that this crisis may turn into a major unrest due to the lack of any visible solution and thereby had taken measures to preparation for it. But the government’s ambition was clear by its move to through bringing laws to suppress, he added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Three Cops identified in maid’s custodial death
author: Author not found
Content: Three Police officers, allegedly linked to the killing of Rajakumari, a domestic aid, who was in custody at the Welikada Police, were identified by the witnesses yesterday (18). Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawala presided over the proceedings and issued an order for the continued remand of the four Police officers implicated in the case, including the three officers who were identified. They are to remain in custody until 2 October. The identification parade, during the Court session, led to the positive recognition of two sergeants and a constable who were allegedly involved in the incident. R. Rajakumari, a 41-year-old resident of Badulla, was arrested on 11 May, following a complaint by her former employer, Sudharma Nethicumara, who alleged that Rajakumari had stolen her gold jewellery. Tragically, Rajakumari died while in the custody of the Welikada Police, leading her relatives to raise suspicions of assault. On 25 August, Magistrate Kekunawala directed the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) to arrest the suspects involved in the housemaid’s death. This decision followed a meticulous review of evidence and the findings in the post-mortem report submitted by the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO). The cause of death was determined to be hemorrhagic shock resulting from damage to the deceased’s muscles, likely inflicted by a blunt weapon or similar force. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Six arrested over attack on Selvarasa
author: Author not found
Content: China Bay Police have apprehended six individuals, on suspicion of assaulting Jaffna District MP Selvarasa Kajendiran, during the Thileepan memorial car procession in Trincomalee, on Sunday (17). The arrests were made based on photographic and video evidence gathered at the scene of the incident. Following the assault, the procession altered its route and proceeded towards Tambalagamuwa. MP Kajendiran subsequently lodged a complaint with IGP C.D. Wickramaratne via telephone. In response, a Police team, led by Trincomalee ASP Namal Perera, arrived in Tambalagamuwa to record the complaint. Among the six individuals apprehended, three are residents of Trincomalee, one hails from Manayaveli, another from Sumedhankarapura, and the remaining individual is a resident of Sardapura. By Lakmal K. Baduge – Trincomalee and Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Govt settles Rs 151B of 180B due to road contractors
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has settled Rs 151 billion in arrears to the road contractors up to now, leaving only Rs 29 billion to be settled, State Minister of Highways Siripala Gamlath said yesterday (18). Addressing a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Gamlath said, “When I assumed the role of State Minister, numerous highway projects across the country had grounded to a halt, with substantial outstanding payments to contractors amounting to approximately Rs 180 billion. This sum was equivalent to less than one year’s road project budget. We have already disbursed Rs 151 billion, leaving Rs 29 billion to be settled, which has encouraged some contractors to recommence their projects. Additionally, we have successfully cleared a significant backlog of unpaid arrears that had accumulated over several years.” The State Minister said plans are afoot to recommence construction on Sri Lanka’s dormant road infrastructure projects. Funding for these projects is set to be allocated in the forthcoming budget, assuring swift progress and timely delivery to the public. He highlighted that the focus of road development is centered on projects managed by the Road Development Authority, encompassing 12,225 km of roads, 312 km of highways, 5,432 bridges, 12 flyovers, boats, and 9 bridge ferries annually. A robust road network is considered crucial for a thriving manufacturing economy and for enhancing the overall quality of life. Therefore, strategic road widening initiatives are being prioritsed without relying on foreign funding. Substantial annual investments are also directed towards maintaining small bridges and highways. He emphasised the importance of highways for the country, noting that the construction of the Central Expressway had been impacted by currency exchange issues. Nevertheless, he highlighted recent achievements, including the completion of the Mirigama-Kurunegala road and the ongoing progress on the initial 13 kilometres of the Potuhera-Galagedara road, which spans 31 km. He also mentioned the critical port access route project, funded by the Asian Development Bank, which aims to ease traffic congestion in key areas like Colombo Fort and the Harbour. Plans are in place to transfer the port entrance flyover into public ownership by 2024. As the national road system construction continues, significant milestones have already been achieved, with 85% completion of the Kohuwala flyover and 35% progress on the Peradeniya flyover, supported by a Hungarian loan. Out of the targeted 13,160 roads for construction, 5,201 have already been completed. The comprehensive project envisions the construction of approximately 17,850 kilometres of roads, with an estimated budget of Rs 231 billion. Of this amount, Rs 160 billion has already been disbursed for completed projects, leaving Rs 70 billion pending. The upcoming budget will include allocations for maintaining existing roads and restarting stalled projects, promising a positive outlook for on-time completion, he said.

title: CID takes over probe into shooting at MP’s car
author: Author not found
Content: The CID has taken over wthe investigation into the shooting incident involving MP Uddika Premarathna in Anuradhapura in the night of Sunday (17). In an official statement, the Police Media Unit announced that the directive to transfer the investigation to the CID came from the Inspector General of Police (IGP). According to the Police, an unidentified group arrived in a car and opened fire at the private vehicle of the Parliamentarian, which was parked near his residence. The shooting occurred after the MP had parked the vehicle outside his home and was walking towards his private residence. It is reported that the CCTV cameras set up to cover the view of front gates of Premaratne’s home had been disconnected for some time. Fortunately, Premarathna emerged unharmed as the armed individuals targeted his vehicle, causing damage to the rear window. The Police have not yet identified the suspects, but it has been determined that they used a pistol in the attack. MP Premarathna, a well-known Sri Lankan actor, entered Parliament as a member of the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) in 2020. However, earlier this month, in September 2023, he made the decision to become an independent MP. BY Thisara Samal and Percy Kuruneru

title: NHSL PET scanner operator shortage causes dilemma for patients
author: Author not found
Content: Radiology Technologists warned that the severe shortage of personnel to function the Positron Emission Tomography (PET) Scanner at the National Hospital, Colombo had allegedly created a dilemma for patients and the hospital staff. President of the Association of Government Radiologic Technologists (AGRT), Chanaka Dharmawikrama yesterday (18) lamented that 13 September 2023 was the last time the PET scanner at the NHSL had been operated. Of the three personnel, who were trained to operate the piece of technology, one had retired earlier this month while the other had gone overseas. He lamented that the only remaining personnel was on the verge of leaving the service in the near future in frustration. He explained that currently the State health service had two PET scanner machines which have been installed at ‘Apeksha’ Hospital, Maharagama and the National Hospital of Sri Lanka (NHSL), Colombo. The Scanner uses a radioactive substance to look for disease in the body. A PET scan shows how organs and tissues are working. A PET scan is largely used to detect the growth and spread of a cancer in the human body, he noted. The AGRT President noted that the test would cost over Rs 300,000 in the private sector. Dharmawickrema lamented that patients in the free health service were at a great disadvantage as a result. He urged the Health Ministry to take urgent measures to either recruit Radiology Technologists from amongst the 150-degree holders whom the Health Ministry has kept idling for the past several months, without taking the necessary measures to enrol them in the State healthcare, to fill the shortage. The AGRT President said the Health Ministry could also give a two-year extension of service to Radiology Technologists who had retired or were due to retirefrom service. He noted that it took at least six months to train a new recruit to handle the PET technology. Meanwhile, informed medical sources noted that there was a gross shortage in trained staff to function the PET scanner at NHSL. At the same time there are those personnel who want to cite this as a reason to force the Health Ministry to give them service extensions where as the Director General Health Services (DGHS) had allegedly issued instructions to stop the NHSL PET scanner for a period of one week till such time that the issue was resolved. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Korea pledges more jobs for Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting between a delegation headed by Minister of Employment and Labour of the Republic of Korea, Lee Jung-sik and Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, was held in Parliament recently. Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera and the Korean Ambassador to Sri Lanka Miyon Lee were also present. Korean Minister Lee Jung-sik, stated that according to the current economic and social changes, the Korean Employment Permit System will be restructured and thus it is expected to increase the employment quota given to Sri Lankan workers. He further stated that through this restructuring, he hopes to expand the opportunities available to Sri Lanka, especially in various industrial sectors and specialised service sectors. Furthermore, the Korean Minister expressed his appreciation for the measures taken by the Sri Lankan Government to teach Korean language to Sri Lankans and stated that he hopes to continue the Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA) and other cooperation programmes. Speaker Abeywardana had requested that more opportunities be given to Sri Lankan workers for employment through various employment sectors as the economy of Sri Lanka will benefit greatly if Sri Lankan workers are engaged in Korean jobs. The Speaker also expressed his gratitude for the support provided by KOICA to Sri Lanka.

title: Constable’s mother, in-law detained
author: Author not found
Content: The mother and the brother-in-law of the Police Constable, who helped drug trafficker and underworld figure Nadun Chinthaka alias ‘Harak Kata’ in his unsuccessful bid to escape have been arrested. According to the Police, they were arrested after investigations revealed that they too had aided the Police constable to help ‘Harak Kata’ escape.  Police obtained a detention order to hold them for 90 days for questioning under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Meanwhile, the Police recovered the car, suspected to belong to the constable, in the Matara area. Nadun Chinthaka had attempted to escape custody by snatching a firearm from a Sub-Inspector during questioning by the CID.  However, the Sub-Inspector had managed to prevent the escape, and the Police had launched an investigation. The incident occurred on 10 September when Nadun Chinthaka was taken to the CID for interrogation. Following the failed attempt by ‘Harak Kata’, the Police constable, who had assisted him had gone missing. As a result, multiple Police teams have been deployed on a search operation to locate him. Nadun Chinthaka Wickramaratne, who had been involved in drug trafficking from Dubai, was arrested in Madagascar earlier this year and extradited to Sri Lanka. Initially detained by the CID for a 90-day period, his detention was extended after the expiration of the initial period.

title: Susil seeks blessings in USA
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premjayantha, who was in the USA recently visited and sought blessings of Ven Katugastota Uparathana Thera, the Chief Judicial Sanghanayake of North America and the Chief Prelate of the Maryland International Buddhist Temple

title: ‘LOLC Divi Saviya’ Surpasses 2000 Schools and Counting
author: Author not found
Content: LOLC Group, a true Sri Lankan multinational conglomerate renowned for its longstanding dedication to the nation spanning over four decades, has reaffirmed its commitment to corporate social responsibility through the successful achievement of a pivotal milestone in its ‘LOLC Divi Saviya’ initiative. ‘LOLC DiviSaviya’ launched in February 2023, has been a beacon of hope for the most deserving children across Sri Lanka. This ambitious project has now successfully reached out to 2,000 schools to date, transforming the educational journey of countless children. To commemorate this momentous occasion, a special event was organised at the Punkudathivu Roman Catholic Tamil Mixed School on 15 September, where the essential school supplies were distributed to the students in the presence of several well-wishers. Sakunthala, representing the parents of Hettiyawa Primary School in Anuradhapura, spoke about the profound impact of the ‘LOLC Divi Saviya’ Project. Her emotional words resonated deeply, “It is a day when hope rained down upon us, just like the much-needed rain during a drought. When our villagers whose livelihood is agriculture were struggling with helplessness, wondering how to provide for our children’s education, LOLC emerged as our guide. I am overwhelmed with gratitude for the joy and care you have brought into our hearts. While we struggled to afford the essential school equipment that our children need for unhindered learning, LOLC’s ‘Divi Saviya’ has come forward to support the children of our nation”. With heartfelt gratitude, Rupika Prashanthi, a parent at Thannabodhiya Vidyalaya, expressed her emotions, “Speaking on behalf of our school, I want to extend our deepest thanks to LOLC for selecting our school in the rural Walapane region for this initiative. This contribution has a thoughtful impact on the education of our precious children, and we are truly touched by your generosity.” Dhammika Priyangani, speaking on behalf of the parents of Arugammana Maha Vidyalaya, Kegalle, shared her heartfelt sentiments, “Divi Saviya programme has been a lifeline for the children who face financial hardships in pursuit of their education. Our gratitude to LOLC knows no bounds for this priceless support, and we gratefully wish that your institution continues to champion such profoundly impactful social initiatives.” The ‘Divi Saviya’ initiative, which commenced in February 2023, began with 1,390 schools and expanded its reach across the entire island. Under the second phase, initiated in August, the Project is set to extend its assistance to 1,512 schools further, catering to the students’ needs. Operating under the theme ‘For the Future of the Children,’ this programme provides school requirement kits comprising School Bags, Exercise Books, Pens, Pencils, Colour Boxes, and Mathematical Toolboxes to schoolchildren. LOLC Group has made a substantial investment of Rs 1.5 billion in this endeavour.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: TN Chief Minister Stalin inaugurates handing over of houses to refugees
author: Author not found
Content: Tamil Nadu Chief Minister M.K. Stalin on Sunday (17), through video conference, inaugurated the handing over of 1,591 houses to Sri Lankan Tamil refugees across 13 districts in India. The houses have been constructed at a cost of INR 797 million. The official opening of the houses in Vellore was held at the Melmonavur Sri Lankan Tamil refugee camp.  Stalin handed over keys of 220 houses to refugees within the camp. According to sources, the construction cost of this phase in Vellore amounts to INR 110 million. Stalin interacted with the Sri Lankan Tamil community during his visit and encouraged them to maintain their new houses in the camp. In an announcement, in the Assembly last year, Stalin had said that 7,469 dilpidated houses across 104 Sri Lankan Tamil rehabilitation camps, spread throughout 29 districts, would be rebuilt. Following the announcement, construction of 3,510 houses began, out of which 1,591 have been completed as part of the first phase of the project. Stalin also declared open new houses in 12 other districts, including Tiruvannamalai, Tiruchy, Coimbatore, Erode, Salem, Virudhunagar and Sivaganga through video conference and spoke to the beneficiaries of the housing scheme. (The New Indian Express)

title: Thondaman looks into EP Pvt Hospital operators’ woes
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman, yesterday (18), said he had extensive discussions with operators of private hospitals in the Eastern Province, to find out the challenges they face in the field of healthcare. A delegation representing private hospitals in the province recently met the Governor to discuss the difficulties they are facing in delivering paid healthcare services, primarily due to the economic crisis that has brought several sectors, including healthcare, to a standstill. Governor Thondaman mentioned that they also requested his assistance in addressing these issues and revitalising the industry. They urged him to bring these challenges to the attention of the Central Government, particularly the Ministry of Health. Furthermore, measures have been initiated to provide additional support to the representatives of private hospitals through the Provincial Health Services Department, added Governor Thondaman. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Hospital staff warn of protest
author: Author not found
Content: Staff of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital distributed leaflets yesterday (18), starting from the Hospital Complex and extending into the Galle City, informing the public of their upcoming protest. The protest will be held on 22 September. The healthcare workers have seven demands, including solutions for shortage of medicine and staff.  They also they demand the necessary equipment for the hospital. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Waterfalls, rivers take eight lives
author: Author not found
Content: Head of the Yowun Mithuro Waterfall Association U. Asitha Indika said, a total of eight deaths, connected to waterfalls and rivers, had occurred in the country from the beginning of this year up to date. He noted that the number of deaths had decreased compared to previous years and mentioned that constant awareness programmes conducted by them had helped in the reduction. Indika added that majority of those who had fallen victim to waterfalls and rivers had been University students who were much more knowledgeable than the rest in society. He was of the view that those who are not skilled in swimming should refrain from venturing to bathe at waterfalls and rivers whilst being intoxicated as well as going into deep areas in rivers and waterfalls and attempting to take photos etc. BY K.A.S. Piyathilake – Kuruwita

title: Detailed assessment of all water bodies called for
author: Author not found
Content: The President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka, has instructed relevant officials to prepare a comprehensive report within two weeks, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said yesterday (18). This report should provide a detailed assessment of the current safety conditions of all reservoirs, lakes, dams and water-carrying tunnels throughout the island. Furthermore, it should outline the necessary repair work needed and estimate the associated costs. Ratnayaka stressed the urgency of this report, emphasising the need for swift action to address any potential safety concerns. The primary goal of this report is to support well-informed decision-making at the highest levels of government. This directive was issued during a high-level meeting, held at the Presidential Secretariat on Monday (18). Officials from relevant government institutions, including the Irrigation Department, the Sri Lanka Mahaweli Authority, and the Electricity Board, participated in the discussions. During the meeting, a thorough discussion took place regarding the technical safety aspects of reservoirs, dams and tunnels, particularly those under the purview of the Irrigation Department, the Sri Lanka Mahaweli Development Authority, and the Ceylon Electricity Board. Special attention was given to the challenges posed by blockages in water-carrying tunnels, necessitating their restoration by removing sedimentary deposits such as sand and mud. Additionally, the potential impacts of recent seismic activity on the structural integrity of reservoirs and tunnels in various regions were assessed, along with the recurring annual impacts under normal operating conditions. Engineers and senior officials representing the Irrigation Department, Sri Lanka Mahaweli Authority, and Electricity Board actively participated in the extensive deliberations, reaffirming the government’s commitment to ensuring the safety and reliability of critical water infrastructure. The report is expected to be submitted to President Ranil Wickremesinghe and will serve as a crucial reference point for future policy decisions aimed at enhancing the resilience and functionality of Sri Lanka’s water infrastructure.

title: Two Policemen attacked
author: Author not found
Content: Two Police officers, attached to the Thalathuoya Police Station, were attacked by an unidentified group at around 11p.m. on 17 September near the Rajapaksa Bend, on the Gurudeniya Road. They had been admitted to the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital after they had been assaulted by an unidentified group The two officers were a Constable and a Sergeant, who had concluded their day’s duty and were on their way to their quarters. They were admitted to the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital with injuries sustained in the attack. The reason behind the assault had not been established at the time of going to press and inquiries were being conducted by Thalathuoya Police. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: National anti-ragging committee to be formed
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Higher Education, Suren Raghavan, has announced the establishment of a national anti-ragging committee. During a press conference held at the Department of Government Information (DGI) yesterday (18), the State Minister highlighted that 36 incidents of ragging have been reported in the past 12 months, resulting in the suspension of 57 students. “We engaged in discussions for approximately eight months, considering various aspects such as social, structural, political, and managerial, to establish the new National Anti-Ragging Committee,” Raghavan stated. He emphasised that while the government can enact laws and create structural institutions, using all available resources, the ultimate responsibility falls upon university lecturers and vice-chancellors. Furthermore, Raghavan revealed that “there is substantial evidence indicating that political parties and their supporters, who have adopted acts of violence as their guiding principle and ideology, continue to engage in acts of ragging within universities.” Raghavan also expressed the commitment of the President, Prime Minister, and Minister of Education to ending this “uncivilized system.” BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Country needs a leader like JRJ – Jagoda
author: Author not found
Content: Deceptive promises will no longer fool the people of this country, asserted former UNP MP Achala Jagoda. Addressing the media at Sirikotha yesterday (18), Jagoda also emphasised that Sri Lanka currently requires a leader with political acumen and the ability to establish and maintain diplomatic relations with the international community, akin to the late President J. R. Jayewardene. Furthermore, Jagoda stated that President Ranil Wickremesinghe can be considered a leader possessing skills comparable to President Jayewardene. He believes President Wickremesinghe has a clear vision and mission to rescue the country from its current economic crisis, similar to President Jayewardene’s efforts in the 1980s, after coming to power in 1977. Jagoda suggested that if a leader with qualities akin to Jayewardene emerges in Sri Lanka, there would be no one better suited for the role than President Wickremesinghe. Addressing the media at Sirikotha, Jagoda highlighted President Wickremesinghe’s proactive efforts to strengthen bilateral cooperation with Cuba in the fields of health and sport and fostering the exchange of technical knowledge between the two nations. He also pointed out that the tourism industry had significantly deteriorated due to the stringent measures implemented by the former President and the Easter Sunday bombings. Jagoda criticised the appointment of a Prime Minister for a mere 52 days, which, he believed, exacerbated the situation further. He added, “At that time, politicians like Dullas Alahapperuma, who supported that decision, are now shedding crocodile tears, claiming that the country cannot be effectively governed. Thanks to the prudent actions taken by President Wickremesinghe in a timely manner, every sector is gradually returning to normalcy.” BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Child killed in shooting
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, a seven-year-old girl was killed following a shooting carried out by two ‘motorcycle gunmen’, near the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court yesterday (17) evening. The girl’s father who was also present at the scene, remains in critical condition at the National Hospital, Colombo. The shooting took place as they were leaving the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court premises around 4.00 p.m. following Court proceedings had concluded in connection with a separate case. At the time of the incident, the injured man, his daughter, and his wife were travelling together in a three-wheeler. Police suspect that the father of the child may have been the intended target of the killers. Further, it has been revealed that he is the primary suspect in a previous case involving a fatal attack with a sharp weapon in Kotahena back in November last year. In a media briefing held on 6 September, Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon revealed that 42 crimes have occurred with using of firearms within last three months and 22 of them were murders. BY Keerthi Mendis and Mithun Jayawardhana

title: New building for Polpithigama Police
author: Author not found
Content: The opening of the new building of the Polpithigama Police Station was held on Saturday (16), under the aegis of Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles. Minister Alles, after participating in religious ceremonies, unveiled the plaque of the building. Thereafter, the Minister inspected the building and participated in a tree-planting programme and a public meeting organised by the Polpithigama Police. Addressing the gathering, Minister Alles said he was happy to be able to complete and deliver the building, which had been a need for many years. He also said when he took over the portfolio in May last year, the country was in the middle of a crisis, and the respect and dignity of Police Officers had deteriorated. However, due to the tireless efforts taken over the past year, the Police Officers have been able to regain their pride and dignity. Further, the Minister said the welfare of the Police Officers could be increased due to the provision of the Batta allowance. He added that 500 new jeeps will be provided to the Police, to aid in the fight against drugs and organised crime. The Minister also pointed out, although many deride the Police, they are compelled to turn to them for assistance in times of need. On this occasion, Minister Alles presented a special felicitation prize to M. Savindi Poornima Jayawardena of Kurunegala Holy Family Girls’ College, who is the daughter of a Police Officer, who came first in the Kurunegala District as well as was placed 12th in the island, in the Commerce Stream in the 2022 G.C.E. Advanced Level examination. Public Security Ministry Secretary Viyani Gunathilaka, Western Province Senior DIG Deshabandu Tennakoon, North Western Province Senior DIG Kithsiri Jayalath and Senior Police Officers participated in this event.

title: President to address 78th UNGA Session on 21 Sept
author: Author not found
Content: Following his participation at ‘the G77 and China’ Summit in Cuba, President Ranil Wickremesinghe arrived in New York earlier yesterday (17) to attend the 78th Session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA), in the United States of America. This Session, themed ‘Rebuilding trust and reigniting global solidarity: Accelerating action on the 2030 Agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals towards peace, prosperity, progress and sustainability for all’ is scheduled to take place from 18-21 September. President Wickremesinghe is expected to address the session on 21 September, where he will deliver a special speech. Furthermore, the President will actively participate in the 2023 Sustainable Development Goals Summit, where global leaders will outline strategies for transformative and accelerated actions towards 2030. Additionally, the President has been invited to deliver the keynote speech at the Indo-Pacific Island Dialogue for Maritime Nations. In parallel, he has scheduled bilateral discussions with several State leaders participating in the conference.

title: USD 50,000 bonus for curators, ground staff
author: Author not found
Content: In a token of appreciation, the Asian Cricket Council (ACC) and Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) announced a special payment of USD 50,000 to thank the curators and the ground staff, in Colombo and Kandy, for carrying out a fantastic job during the Asia Cup 2023, making it a remarkable event despite the rain. The ACC in a statement said, “The Asian Cricket Council (ACC) and Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) are proud to announce a well-deserved prize money of USD 50,000 for the dedicated curators and ground staff at Colombo and Kandy. Their unwavering commitment and hard work made the Asia Cup 2023 an unforgettable spectacle. From pitch perfection to lush outfields, they ensured the stage was set for thrilling cricket action. This recognition highlights the critical role these individuals play in cricket’s success.”

title: Timely examinations, results and access to higher education vital – Premier
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said negotiations were in progress to reduce the duration of the graduate courses by one year enabling children to pass out one year earlier. Addressing the prize-giving ceremony of Visakha Vidyalaya, Colombo, the Premier highlighted the transition from college to university, emphasising that universities serve as hubs to access global knowledge and enhance a nation’s educational value. The Premier acknowledged the challenges they faced, especially during the recent issues that affected the country. He also pointed out the Government’s commitment to expand educational opportunities and said the emergence of new fields of study that provide diverse avenues for individuals to contribute to the country. Gunawardena expressed the collective desire of parents and students for timely examinations, results, and access to higher education. He assured that the Government is committed to implement and adhering to this schedule, emphasising its significance.

title: Serve the public with integrity – Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles said his Ministry was committed to addressing the challenges faced by Police officers and emphasised the importance of honest public service by the Police force. During his address to Police officers on the occasion of the opening of the new Polpithigama Police Station premises on 16 September, Minister Alles said, “The foundation stone for this facility was laid back in 2007, and I regret the lengthy construction process. Nonetheless, I’m pleased to have the opportunity to inaugurate it.” Minister Alles said merely having modern facilities did not automatically make the police force effective. He underscored that the key to success lies in the police serving the public with integrity. Reflecting on the situation when he assumed the portfolio last year amidst the chaos in the country, he highlighted the positive changes that have since been achieved. He acknowledged the Ministry’s efforts to provide necessary facilities and pledged to continue these efforts. Minister Alles further urged police officers to carry out their duties diligently and take appropriate action to combat crime within the country. BY Nandana Kelegama – Polpithigama

title: Govt agencies with environmental responsibilities to be restructured
author: Author not found
Content: State institutions such as the Marine Environment Protection Authority, Coastal Conservation Department that are addressing environmental concerns would be restructured, President’s Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake said. Ratnayake said this while participating in a beach clean-up at the Beach Plaza in the Port City, coinciding with International Coastal Cleanup Day (ICCD) and the commencement of Marine Resources Conservation Week. President Ranil Wickremesinghe is taking proactive steps to set up a specialised task force with a primary focus on preventing environmental pollution and ensuring the protection of our environment, according to Ratnayake. This dedicated task force will assume responsibility for devising, executing, and overseeing initiatives aimed at safeguarding our environment. Ratnayake also highlighted the Government’s commitment to comprehensively restructure the institutions entrusted with environmental responsibilities. The President’s Media Division (PMD) said a committee will be formed to reinforce environmental protection laws and facilitate the restructuring process. He emphasised the involvement of various institutions, including the Marine Environment Protection Authority, Coastal Conservation Department, local government bodies, and the Sri Lanka Tourism Board in managing environmental concerns. Notably, the Navy provides valuable support, even though it is not the primary authority responsible for environmental matters. Recognising the need for more effective environmental governance, Ratnayake expressed the Government’s commitment to restructuring these agencies with environmental responsibilities. To oversee this restructuring, a dedicated committee will be set up. The overarching goal is to strengthen existing environmental laws following this organisational overhaul. President Wickremesinghe’s vision includes the formation of a task force, which will play a pivotal role in planning, implementing, and supervising activities aimed at addressing environmental challenges. These comprehensive initiatives aim to raise public awareness and implement sustainable measures to combat environmental pollution. Ratnayake stressed the vital importance of preserving our environment for present and future generations. He also underscored that the responsibility for environmental preservation cannot be shouldered by the Government alone, emphasising the collective role that individuals and society must play in protecting our environment.

title: 8th South China Sea Buddhist Shenzhen Roundtable in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The 8th South China Sea Buddhist Shenzhen Roundtable is scheduled to take place in Sri Lanka from 24-26 October, the President’s Media Division (PMD) announced. This event will be hosted by the Hunupitiya Gangaramaya Temple in Colombo. The opening ceremony, to be chaired by President Ranil Wickremesinghe will be on 24 October at the Bandaranaike International Conference Hall (BMICH) in Colombo. A preliminary discussion regarding the organisational aspects of this Buddhist Roundtable was conducted at the President’s Office. Sagala Ratnayaka, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of the Presidential Staff, presided over this session. The Buddhist Shenzhen Roundtable in the South China Sea region has been organized by the Hongfa Temple in Shenzhen, China, since 2016. It serves as an annual international platform for discourse, with a focus on the theme of ‘Walking Together in Harmony and Gathering the Wisdom of the Silk Road’. Notably, this year’s event will be hosted in Sri Lanka, with the participation of representatives from 22 countries centred around the Silk Road theme. During the discussion, potential roles of relevant government institutions in ensuring the success of this conference were also deliberated upon. Participants included Vidura Wickramanayake, Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs,  Saman Ekanayake, President’s Secretary and the Secretary of the Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs, as well as officials from relevant State departments and organisations.

title: Two arrested over sexual assault on Irish national
author: Author not found
Content: The proprietor and an employee of a massage establishment located in Yaddehimulla, Unawatuna were arrested by Habaraduwa Police in connection with the sexual assault of a 38-year-old Irish national. The incident occurred at a massage parlour catering to tourists. According to Police, both the owner and the employee are facing charges not only related to the sexual assault against the victim but also for aiding and abetting. The Irish woman had visited the massage centre on 16 September to avail herself of their services. During her massage session, she experienced unwanted advances from the suspect. Following the incident, the victim lodged a complaint with the Habaraduwa Police, who took swift action to arrest the suspects. By S. Deeyagahage – Ahangama

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Selvarasa attacked while proceeding to Thileepan’s memorial service
author: Author not found
Content: MP Selvarasa Kajendiran came under attack when the motorcade carrying a portrait of slain LTTE cadre Thileepan was attacked, while it was proceeding from the East to the North to participate in a memorial service for Thileepan. The vehicle carrying the portrait and those in the vehicle were attacked by a group who protested against the commemoration. As the motorcade was en route from Tambalagamuwa, a group of protesters carrying placards and lion flags obstructed the road, and demanded the commemoration be held only in Jaffna. Subsequently, the vehicle transporting the portrait was attacked prompting it to turn back to Tambalagamuwa. During the attack a window of the vehicle  was shattered and Kajendiran who was travelling on a motorbike was assaulted. Following the incident, the Riot Police arrived at the scene. An investigation has been initiated into the incident. In conjunction with the 36th anniversary of Thileepan, the car procession travelling from east to north was attacked in Sardhapura, Trincomalee yesterday (17) evening. The car carrying Thilipan’s picture and the people who came there were attacked and the TNP Member of Parliament Selvarasa Gajendran who came there was attacked by the protestors. When the convoy was coming from Tambalagamuwa, the people carrying protest placards and lion flags were crossing the road and shouting to keep the Tiger celebrations in Jaffna. Then the vehicle with the Thilipan memorial was attacked and the vehicle returned towards Tambalagamuwa. Due to the attack, one of the windows of the vehicle was broken. After the attack, the anti-riot unit and the police arrived at the scene. The police have started investigations into the incident. BY Lakmal K. Baduge – Trincomalee

title: Over 66,234 acres of paddy suffer damage due to drought
author: Author not found
Content: This year’s Yala season witnessed significant agricultural losses due to drought, with over 66,234 acres of paddy and other crops suffering damage. The Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board has reported that 67,408 farmers have been adversely affected. The district with the highest crop damage is Kurunegala where more than 16,992 acres have been affected by the drought. In addition, the Udawalawa region has seen over 14,810 acres of crops destroyed due to the persistent dry conditions. Meanwhile, W.M. M. B. Weerasekera, Chairman of the Agriculture and Agrarian Insurance Board, has indicated that the assessment of crop damage resulting from drought, rain, and caterpillar infestations is in its final stages. He has informed Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera that the evaluation of damage caused by drought has been completed, and the assessment for damage caused by rain is currently in progress. The Chairman further said once the assessments are concluded, a comprehensive report on crop damage will be submitted to Minister Amaraweera.

title: Central Bank Act has ushered in increased independence – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Bank Act, which came into effect on 15 September, has ushered in increased independence for the bank and its operations, according to Acting Finance Minister Ranjith Siyambalapitiya. Under the provisions of the new Act, the Central Bank’s authority to print money is now restricted to exceptional circumstances, including special security or health-related issues, with an upper limit of 5 per cent of the value of issued Treasury Bills. Additionally, the Central Bank is mandated to work toward an inflation target and provide justifications in cases where it falls short of meeting this target. An important change outlined in the Act is the exclusion of the Treasury Secretary from participating in the General Board of Governors and the Monetary Policy Board of the Central Bank. Further, the qualifications of board members are now explicitly defined in the Act and necessitate approval from the Constituent Assembly. Acting Minister Siyambalapitiya also noted, “Those appointments have to be approved by the Constituent Assembly. In addition to this, the Minister further mentioned that Parliament will have the power to summon the Governor of the Central Bank.”

title: Family of five injured in petrol bomb attack
author: Author not found
Content: In a disturbing incident in Thavady, Chunnakam, a group of individuals forcibly entered a residence and allegedly threw a petrol bomb, resulting in injuries to five persons who were in the house. The victims, comprising the mother, father, two daughters and son from the same family, were subsequently admitted to the Jaffna Teaching Hospital for burn injuries sustained in the incident, which took place on 16 September. Investigations revealed that one of the suspects, a resident of Urumpirai, Jaffna with his friends had carried out the attack following a dispute with a daughter of family, who is said to be his girlfriend. The attackers not only set fire to the house but also vandalised a three-wheeler parked in front of the residence and caused damage to the doors and windows of the house. Chunnakam Police arrested three suspects in connection with the attack. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Grilling of ‘Ganemulla Sanjeewa’ leads to T-56 rifle used in killings
author: Author not found
Content: Police retrieved a T-56 assault rifle, reportedly used in a number of killings, through information elicited from ‘Ganemulla Sanjeewa’, during interrogation. Subsequent investigations revealed that this firearm was used in multiple criminal incidents in Gampaha. Further inquiries regarding the suspect are currently underway under the supervision of DIG, Rohan Premaratne, who is in charge of the Western Province. Most of the crimes, the suspect is said to have committed, were reported from the Gampaha District. ‘Ganemulla Sanjeewa,’ was apprehended by officers from the Department of Immigration and Emigration at the BIA on his return from Nepal on Wednesday, 13 September. To facilitate interrogations, Police were given a 90-day detention order under the Prevention of Terrorism Act. At the time of his arrest, the suspect was found in possession of a forged passport, accompanied by personal details belonging to a female believed to be a resident of Dematagoda Police said.

title: Appointment of new Customer Service Assistants of People’s Bank
author: Author not found
Content: Letters of Appointment were awarded recently to 500 newly recruited Customer Service Assistants of People’s Bank at an event which was attended by State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe, People’s Bank Chairman Sujeewa Rajapakse, Board Member Manjula Wellalage and CEO/ General Manager Clive Fonseka together with the corporate and executive management.

title: ‘Members with Families Day’ by SLFUW
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Federation of University Women (SLFUW) held its ‘Members with Families Day’ on Sunday, 10 September, in the Auditorium at its Headquarters in Colombo. SLFUW President, Col. Dr. Udula Krishnaratne warmly welcomed those present. Commenting on the long history of the SLFUW, Dr. Krishnaratne paid tribute to Clara Motwani, an American-born educationist, who set it up nearly 83 years back. She thanked all members, non-members and well-wishers who helped in numerous ways. The day’s programme included the presentation of scholarships to three needy female undergraduates, one each from the Faculties of Law and Indigenous Medicine of the University of Colombo, and one from Faculty of Medicine, University of Ruhuna. Awards were also presented to felicitate three members for their outstanding contributions to SLFUW; Anandi Balasingham, Retired Senior Journalist (Lake House) and Consultant Tamil ‘Mirror’ newspaper of Wijeya Newspapers, awarded by Dr. Udula Krishnaratne; Chintha Munasinghe, Retired Commissioner of Inland Revenue, and former President of SLFUW, (in her absence accepted by Rohini Mediwake) presented by Seela Ebert, a former president of SLFUW and Neelia Fernando – specialist in the development and maintenance of information systems in the National Science Council. The award was given by Jayanthi Liyanage, a former SLFUW President. A cash donation was also handed over to the Visually Impaired Foundation by Dr. Krishnaratne. Apart from these items of appreciation and goodwill, it was a fun-filled day with games and competitions as well as music, singing and dancing with prizes and surprises, galore and gifts for everybody. A joyous atmosphere prevailed throughout.

title: Chaminda Kularatne appointed DSG and CoS of Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Attorney-at-Law Chaminda Kularatne has been appointed as Deputy Secretary-General (DSG) and Chief of Staff (CoS) of Parliament. This position, which was held by Tikiri Jayatilake, became vacant due to his appointment as a High Court Judge. Accordingly, with the approval of the Parliamentary Business Committee comprising Party Leaders of Parliament, applications were called by the Parliamentary Staff Advisory Committee for this position. Kularatne was selected for the position after the applicants were interviewed by a high-level panel, chaired by the Speaker and comprising the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the House, the Chief Opposition Whip and the Secretary-General of Parliament. The selection of such a high-level position in the Parliament of Sri Lanka was previously made by a high-level interview panel in 1963. Berty Koswatte, who worked as the Deputy Secretary-General (Clerk Assistant) of the Parliament at that time, vacated the post due to his appointment as Secretary of the Senate. Therefore, open applications had been called for an interview. Accordingly, an interview was held by a panel comprising R.S. Pelpola (the then Speaker), Dudley Senanayake (Opposition Leader), C. P. de Silva (Leader of the House) and Ralph Deraniyagala (Secretary-General). From amongst the applicants, Sam Wijesinghe was selected as the Deputy Secretary-General of the Parliament. Chaminda Kularatne has held many executive level administrative positions, including Secretary to the Chief Government Whip of Parliament, Additional Secretary to the President, Additional Secretary to the Prime Minister, Additional Secretary to the Leader of the Opposition, Minister Counsellor at the Sri Lanka High Commission in London, Senior Assistant Secretary to the President and Assistant Secretary to the President. He is a senior public servant with nearly 20 years of national and international experience in constitutional law, parliamentary affairs and proceedings, international relations, public administration and financial regulations. He has represented Sri Lanka at many international conferences and training courses in many countries including the United Kingdom, United States of America, Australia, China, Indonesia and Japan. Further, he is a Bachelor of Law (LLB Sri Lanka), a Senior Lawyer and a Post Graduate Diploma holder in Business Management from the University of Colombo and the University of Buckinghamshire, United Kingdom. He is also a life member of the Sri Lanka Bar Association since 2005 and a member of the Bar Council since 2016. He has held the directorship of the Board of Directors of Bank of Ceylon, Merchant Bank, MBSL Insurance Limited, Grand Oriental Hotel (GOH), Maganeguma Emulsion Private Limited and Colombo Financial City Founding Ltd. and many government institutions. Furthermore, he was the first South Asian diplomat to represent the Executive Council of the Consular Officers Association which is the oldest association of Diplomats, when he served as a Minister Counsellor at the High Commission of Sri Lanka in London. During that time, he maintained good relations with the United Kingdom Parliament (House of Commons), and the Commonwealth Secretariat. When Kularatne completed his tenure as the Minister Counsellor at the High Commission of Sri Lanka in London, he was honoured to be invited for a gathering to bid farewell, in a committee room of the Parliament of Great Britain, hosted by the UK Parliamentarians. He was the first Sri Lankan diplomat to receive that honour.
