title: Navy launches beach cleaning programme to coincide with International Coastal Cleanup Day
author: Author not found
Content: Under the esteemed patronage of the Chief of Staff to the President and National Security Adviser Sagala Ratnayaka, a beach cleaning programme unfolded at Port City Beach on 16 September 2023. This initiative which was conducted on the sidelines of the International Coastal Cleanup Day and the National Marine Resources Conservation Week was also participated by Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera. In a concerted effort to combat coastal pollution and preserve the natural beauty of shores, the Sri Lanka Navy orchestrated a series of beach cleaning programmes across all Naval Commands. Expanding their efforts, the Sri Lanka Navy extended similar programmes to encompass all Naval Commands. The Western Naval Command diligently cleaned Crow Island and Galle Face beaches, while the Eastern Naval Command focused on the rejuvenation of Dutch Bay beach. Simultaneously, the North Central Naval Command took on the task of cleaning Urumale beach, and the Northwestern Naval Command turned its attention to the Hunesh Nagar to Karadakkuliya beach patch. These commendable endeavours saw the active involvement of not only top brass including the Commander of the Navy and Area Commanders, but also a dedicated group of naval personnel. Together, they worked tirelessly to rid the shores of copious amounts of plastic, polytene, and various other solid waste materials, safeguarding the allure of these coastal areas. In concert with the National Marine Resources Conservation Week, the Sri Lanka Navy launched an extensive mangrove planting campaign spanning across all Naval Commands. Furthermore, the Navy has scheduled awareness programmes targeting the fishing communities. These initiatives aim to educate and advocate against the irresponsible disposal of plastic and polythene materials into beach environments.

title: Steps taken to deport all four Lankan convicts
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Government of India has informed the Madras High Court that it has taken steps to deport all four Sri Lankans, convicted in the Rajiv Gandhi assassination case, to Sri Lanka. Foreigners Regional Registration Officer P Ve Arunshakthikumar, Bureau of Immigration, Ministry of Home Affairs of India stated this in his counter affidavit filed on Thursday, in response to a petition filed by S. Nalini, one of the seven convicts ordered to be released by the Supreme Court last year. She had sought a direction to the authorities to release her husband Sriharan alias Murugan from the Special Camp (Foreigners Detention Centre), Tiruchirappalli, to enable him to live with her in the city. In her petition, Nalini said when she was arrested she was pregnant, and her daughter was born on 19 December 1992 while she was detained in the Chengalpattu sub-jail. Her daughter was now married and living with her husband and child in London. Nalini submitted her daughter is a citizen of the United Kingdom and that Murugan would like to settle with her there. Moreover, he has to contact the Sri Lankan Embassy in connection with his passport. Since he was detained in the Special Camp, he was unable to move out. She made a representation dated 20 May 2023 to the Foreigners Regional Registration Officer in Chennai, requesting that her husband be released from the Special Camp to enable him to live with her in Chennai. However, there was no response from the authorities, she added. In his counter, the officer said since all four Sri Lankan nationals arrived in India illegally by boat and did not possess valid Sri Lankan travel documents/passports and as per the extant guidelines of MHA circular, dated 24 April 2014, a movement restriction order was issued by FRRO, Chennai, against them to lodge them in the Trichy special camp till their deportation to their native country (Sri Lanka). He further stated that meanwhile in this regard, a communication had been sent to MEA (Consular Division) by a letter dated 12 November 2022 along with Biographic details requesting for issuance of travel documents/passports in favour of all four Sri Lankans from the Sri Lankan High Commission, India for further deportation to their native country. In May, a representation was received from Nalini requesting this office to release her husband from the foreigners detention camps so that they can live together. Since the communication from MEA was awaited, her representation was kept pending at our end, he added. Besides Murugan, the other Sri Lankans convicted in Gandhi’s assassination are – Santhan, Robert Payas and Jayakumar. They were all ordered to be released last year by the Supreme Court. Three others – Perarivalan, Nalini and Ravichandran – all Indians, were also released following Apex Court orders. Gandhi was assassinated by a woman suicide bomber of the banned LTTE in 1991 at nearby Sriperumbudur. (PTI)

title: PSC on eradicating drug menace calls for views
author: Author not found
Content: The Parliamentary Select Committee (PSC), to immediately control and eradicate the rapidly spreading drug menace in the country, has called for public proposals and views. The Committee, appointed by a motion passed by the Parliament on 8 June 2023, is tasked with identifying the mechanisms to be implemented in order to immediately control and eradicate the rapidly spreading drug menace and to submit observations and recommendations to Parliament in that connection.  This Select Committee, appointed by the Speaker, is under the Chairmanship of Minister of Public Security Tiran Allas, with 11 MPs. The Assistant Secretary General of Parliament Hansa Abeyratne is the Secretary to the said Select Committee. Organisations who are desirous to submit their proposals and views on the mechanisms to be implemented in order to Immediately Control and Eradicate the Rapidly Spreading Drug Menace in the Country, may submit their proposals and views to reach: The Secretary, The Select Committee of Parliament, Parliament of Sri Lanka, Sri Jayewardenepura Kotte or via e-mail: [email protected] on or before12 October 2023. If the Committee is desirous of taking oral evidence from those who make representations, the relevant parties along with documents will be called to appear before the Committees in due course.

title: Gotabaya’s re-entry to politics a joke
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) senior member and former Minister S. M. Chandrasena made a statement yesterday (17), claiming that the attempt by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa to return to politics after fleeing the country and resigning from his position was joke. When asked about the current political situation in the country,  Chandrasena said while Gotabaya Rajapaksa, as the former Defence Ministry Secretary, made significant contributions to liberating the country from the LTTE, they supported him in the Presidential Election 2019, where he secured a landslide victory with an expected total of 6.9 million votes. However, Chandrasena expressed his disappointment, stating that Gotabaya did not possess the qualities required for the role of a President. He alleged that by aligning himself with certain political factions and prioritising their interests, Gotabaya led the country into a state of tragedy, causing widespread discontent and anti-government sentiments among the people. Chandrasena claimed to have received information, from certain sources, indicating that Gotabaya was making an attempt at returning to politics, but he expressed doubts about any positive outcome, suggesting that Rajapaksa’s involvement would likely worsen the situation and be met with resistance from the majority of the people. He also expressed regret that the former President had let down the 6.9 million people who had cast their valuable votes to elect him as President of the country. Further, Chandrasena said the SLPP had no intention of fielding Gotabaya Rajapakse in any future elections, including the upcoming Presidential Election. He asserted that as a national political party, they would move forward by addressing and rectifying mistakes made during the latter’s tenure. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Illegal sandmining in Iranamadu under control
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda yesterday (17) said, illegal sand mining in Iranamadu has been brought under control. Devananda also issued a warning, stating that legal action will be taken against those responsible for environmental destruction. He expressed concern over the irresponsible actions of certain factions who should safeguard the environment. Further, he asserted that illegal sand mining activities occurring in other areas of the Northern Province will be curtailed to prevent further environmental degradation. The Fisheries Minister said he has been authorised to take action and pursue legal action against violators. He said a special meeting was convened at the Kilinochchi District Secretariat to address this issue and collaborate with officials on legal measures to be taken. Following this meeting, Devananda, accompanied by local Police and relevant officials from DS Kilinochchi visited Iranamadu and confirmed the successful reduction of illegal sand mining. He expressed confidence that this matter would be discussed during the upcoming Kilinochchi District Development Committee meetings scheduled for tomorrow (19). By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SLWJA holds talks with IFJ Regional Director
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting between the Sri Lanka Working Journalists’ Association (SLWJA) and Jane Worthington, Regional Director of the International Federation of Journalists (IFJ), Asia Pacific, took place on 14 September at the SLWJA office in Colombo. The discussions revolved around potential collaborations between the two entities, focusing on training sessions, workshops, and programmes aimed at enhancing journalistic skills and knowledge.

title: Rameswaram fishers demand release of eight colleagues
author: Author not found
Content: Fishermen in Rameswaram went on strike on Saturday (16) demanding the release of eight Rameswaram fishers arrested by the Sri Lankan authorities. All the 800 odd fishing vessels were moored at the fishing jetty and fishermen did not collect the fishing tokens. The Sri Lanka Navy, on Wednesday night (13), detained 17 fishermen – eight Rameswaram fishermen and nine fishers from Pudukkottai District – on charges of poaching in the territorial waters of the island nation. The Sri Lanka Navy seized the three fishing boats from them. The fishermen were produced in a Jaffna Court and remanded till 27 September. Condemning the repeated arrests of fishermen by the Sri Lanka Navy, the fishermen’s associations called for a strike on Saturday. “The State government and the Centre should expedite diplomatic measures to release our fishermen and the fishing vessels confiscated by Sri Lanka,” said fishermen leader P. Jesuraja from Rameswaram. The Sri Lanka Navy has seized 17 trawlers and arrested 110 Indian fishermen so far in 2023. While the Lankan Courts usually release the fishermen on conditional bail that they should never return to Sri Lanka for fishing, the fishing crafts are not returned to the boat owners.  (Times of India)

title: Japanese comedians to hold fundraiser
author: Author not found
Content: A team of Japanese comedians is set to entertain guests at a fundraising event hosted by the Lanka-Japan Friendship Society. The event will take place at the Grand Oriental Hotel on 23 September, commencing at 7:00 p.m. Japanese Ambassador Mizukoshi Hideaki will be the Chief Guest at this musical night and sing-along, which has been organised with the noble purpose of combating malnutrition among schoolchildren.

title: Akkaraipattu Base Hospital bags Certificate of Excellence for patient care
author: Author not found
Content: The Akkaraipattu Base Hospital was awarded the Certificate of Excellence in recognition of its outstanding practices at the ‘Relaunch of the Patient Safety Oriented Intensive Care Unit’ project. Additionally, the hospital was honoured for its exceptional performance in the National Maternal and Newborn Care Quality Assessments at the World Patient Safety Day 2023 celebrations. This event took place at the BMICH recently. It was organised by the Directorate of Healthcare Quality and Safety under the Ministry of Health. Dr. Chitramalee de Silva, Director of the Family Health Bureau presented a memento to Dr. T.S.R.T.R. Rajab, Medical Superintendent of the Akkaraipattu Base Hospital in recognition of the hospital’s outstanding performance in the National Maternal and Newborn Care Quality Assessments. Dr. Asela Gunawardena, Director General of Health Services; Dr. Lal Panapitiya, Deputy Director General; Dr. Dewanee Ranaweera, Director of Healthcare Quality and Safety; Dr. Wimal Karandagoda, Healthcare Management Consultant; Dr. M.H.M. Sanoofer, Quality Management and Healthcare Management expert; as well as Base Hospital Medical Officers were present at the event. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Branch kills 17 year-old
author: Author not found
Content: A 17-year-old girl travelling on a motorbike with her father suffered critical injuries when a large branch fell on her head. She succumbed to injuries soon after admission to hospital. However, her father miraculously escaped with minor scratches. According to the Punduloya Police, this incident occurred on the evening of 16 September along the Talawakelle – Tawalantenna road. The victim, identified as Vijayaraj Divwarani and a resident of Pambarakele, was rushed to the Lindula Divisional Hospital where she succumbed to injuries while receiving medical attention Police said. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Man run over by train
author: Author not found
Content: A 26-year-old man who was sleeping on the rail track in Madapokuna in Maho was run over by a train The deceased has been identified as a resident of the Madapokuna. His body was sent to the Maho Hospital for a post mortem. Police are currently conducting further investigations regarding the incident.

title: Steps taken to deport all four Lankan convicts
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Government of India has informed the Madras High Court that it has taken steps to deport all four Sri Lankans, convicted in the Rajiv Gandhi assassination case, to Sri Lanka. Foreigners Regional Registration Officer P Ve Arunshakthikumar, Bureau of Immigration, Ministry of Home Affairs of India stated this in his counter affidavit filed on Thursday, in response to a petition filed by S. Nalini, one of the seven convicts ordered to be released by the Supreme Court last year. She had sought a direction to the authorities to release her husband Sriharan alias Murugan from the Special Camp (Foreigners Detention Centre), Tiruchirappalli, to enable him to live with her in the city. In her petition, Nalini said when she was arrested she was pregnant, and her daughter was born on 19 December 1992 while she was detained in the Chengalpattu sub-jail. Her daughter was now married and living with her husband and child in London. Nalini submitted her daughter is a citizen of the United Kingdom and that Murugan would like to settle with her there. Moreover, he has to contact the Sri Lankan Embassy in connection with his passport. Since he was detained in the Special Camp, he was unable to move out. She made a representation dated 20 May 2023 to the Foreigners Regional Registration Officer in Chennai, requesting that her husband be released from the Special Camp to enable him to live with her in Chennai. However, there was no response from the authorities, she added. In his counter, the officer said since all four Sri Lankan nationals arrived in India illegally by boat and did not possess valid Sri Lankan travel documents/passports and as per the extant guidelines of MHA circular, dated 24 April 2014, a movement restriction order was issued by FRRO, Chennai, against them to lodge them in the Trichy special camp till their deportation to their native country (Sri Lanka). He further stated that meanwhile in this regard, a communication had been sent to MEA (Consular Division) by a letter dated 12 November 2022 along with Biographic details requesting for issuance of travel documents/passports in favour of all four Sri Lankans from the Sri Lankan High Commission, India for further deportation to their native country. In May, a representation was received from Nalini requesting this office to release her husband from the foreigners detention camps so that they can live together. Since the communication from MEA was awaited, her representation was kept pending at our end, he added. Besides Murugan, the other Sri Lankans convicted in Gandhi’s assassination are – Santhan, Robert Payas and Jayakumar. They were all ordered to be released last year by the Supreme Court. Three others – Perarivalan, Nalini and Ravichandran – all Indians, were also released following Apex Court orders. Gandhi was assassinated by a woman suicide bomber of the banned LTTE in 1991 at nearby Sriperumbudur. (PTI)

title: CPCEC Plans to Remove Food Stalls From Port City
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Port City Economic Commission (CPCEC) announced plans to remove the food stalls situated within the Colombo Port City, by March 2027. The announcement was made at a recent meeting of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), after the committee argued that these food stalls, categorised as leisure activities, are not in alignment with the primary objective of attracting foreign investments to the Colombo Port City. This discussion unfolded during a meeting held in Parliament on Tuesday (12), presided over by Dr. Harsha de Silva. The Committee, during this session, scrutinised the regulations established under the Colombo Port City Economic Commission Act, No. 11 of 2021, which are to be presented in Parliament next Tuesday, 19 September. Inquiries from the Committee extended to the legal basis behind permitting these food stalls and the reasons behind their removal by 2027. The Committee also probed whether the Attorney General’s office had been consulted regarding this matter. The Committee subsequently instructed both the Colombo Port City Economic Commission and the Attorney General’s Department to promptly provide detailed information on this matter for further examination. The Committee went on to inquire about the revenue generated by the ongoing activities within the Port City. Officials were directed to submit comprehensive details on this matter to facilitate a more informed decision before granting approval for the regulations. Moreover, given that the Port City is being developed as a distinct landmass under the Smart City concept, the Committee raised questions regarding the incorporation of smart city elements such as wastewater management, renewable energy solutions and effective sewerage mechanisms. The Committee stressed the importance of avoiding the issues seen in other parts of the country concerning inadequate sewerage and wastewater management when planning and constructing the Port City. Furthermore, it has come to light that various State institutions, including the Road Development Authority, Urban Development Authority, and the Water Board, have invested a substantial amount of taxpayer money in supporting the construction and development of the Port City. Given that these funds are derived from the taxes paid by citizens, the Committee on Public Finance raised pertinent questions regarding the benefits that the citizens of the country could expect to receive in return for these investments. In response to this concern, the COPF has directed the Members of the Port City Commission to furnish a comprehensive breakdown of government expenditures related to the Port City and its associated infrastructure. Additionally, the COPF has requested detailed information regarding the revenue streams generated by the Port City Project.

title: President to address UNGA 78th Session on 21 Sept
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe is scheduled to participate in the 78th session of the United Nations General Assembly, in New York and deliver his speech on 21 September, focusing on the theme ‘Rebuilding trust and reigniting global solidarity: Accelerating action on the 2030 Agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals towards peace, prosperity, progress, and sustainability for all’. During his visit, President Wickremesinghe will engage in several important events. He is slated to participate in a Heads of State/Government Leaders Dialogue during the 2023 SDG Summit, where world leaders will come together to provide essential guidance on transformative and accelerated actions leading up to 2030. Additionally, he will address the Climate Ambition Summit convened by the UN Secretary-General, emphasising the global commitment to accelerating the transition to an equitable, renewable energy-based, and climate-resilient global economy. The President is also expected to deliver a keynote address at the High-Level Meeting on Financing for Development, underlining the importance of fostering debt sustainability and strengthening the global financial safety net. Furthermore, President Wickremesinghe will hold discussions with António Guterres, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, and engage in dialogues with leaders of member countries. Beyond diplomatic engagements, the President’s visit will encompass participation in a Roundtable Discussion on Economic Opportunities in Sri Lanka, where he will interact with over 40 prominent private companies from the United States. Additionally, he will take part in the Ocean Nations: The third Annual Indo-Pacific Islands Dialogue, an event organised by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Sasakawa Foundation in New York. Accompanying President Wickremesinghe will be Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, who also attended the UNGA 2022 and addressed climate change challenges and their impacts on Sri Lanka. Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane, and other senior officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs are also set to attend the UNGA 78. (SRM)

title: President marks Prisoners’ Day by freeing 933 inmates
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe marked the 25th National Prisoners’ Day, observed on 12 September, by announcing a special State pardon for a total of 933 inmates. Thus, 926 male and seven female prisoners are to be released under the authority vested by Article 34 of the Constitution of Sri Lanka, confirmed Prisons Media Spokesman Chandana Ekanayake. The criteria for the release of these inmates encompass a variety of circumstances. First, those who have been serving sentences are granted a one-month pardon for each year of their term served. Additionally, individuals who found themselves in prison as of September 12 due to unpaid fines will also benefit from this pardon. Furthermore, the special State pardon, includes inmates over the age of 65 who have already completed half or more of their sentence as of 12 September. Similarly, those who had been sentenced to 40 years of imprisonment and have already served 20 years by 12 September will be released. In a bid to address drug-related offences, the pardon extends to individuals who were sentenced to rehabilitation programmes. Those who have completed half or more of their relevant sentences related to drug offences by 12 September will also be set free as part of this initiative.

title: EPF offers to exchange its Treasury Bonds
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) announced that the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) has made an offer to exchange its portfolio of Treasury Bonds as part of the Domestic Debt Structuring (DDS) programme. The EPF, as an eligible participant and with the approval of the Monetary Board of the CBSL, submitted an offer to exchange its Treasury Bonds portfolio under the DDS programme. This action aligns with the invitation extended by the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation, and National Policies, following a resolution adopted by Parliament on this matter. The Monetary Board of the CBSL, serving as the custodian of the EPF, carefully considered two options: Debt Exchange and Non-Exchange, and ultimately decided in favour of the Debt Exchange offer. This decision was taken with a long-term perspective and was deemed to be in the best interest of the Fund’s members. The EPF submitted Treasury Bonds with a face value of Rs. 2,667,512,169,237 for Debt Exchange, which includes an additionalRs 149,890,740,000, surpassing the minimum participation requirement due to the comparative benefits it offers to the Fund. The Government has accepted this offer and issued new Treasury Bonds to the EPF with an equivalent face value.

title: Revised ATB would allow PTA detainees to seek bail after one year – Ali Sabry
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry stated that the proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill (ATB), which was gazetted in March 2023, has been amended to align with established international standards, including ensuring that individuals arrested must be brought before a Magistrate within 48 hours. Prosecution cannot be solely based on confessions obtained from the detained individuals and individuals arrested under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) have the opportunity to seek bail after one year of detention providing them with a legal recourse to challenge their continued detention. The Bill will ensure that it does not compromise the national security of the nation, he added. The Minister said, the Bill will be presented to Parliament for its initial reading. “Within this framework, our citizens will maintain the right to thoroughly examine the Act and voice any concerns they may have. They will also have the opportunity to challenge its provisions and, if necessary, seek legal remedies by approaching the Supreme Court within one week from its publication.” He added that under the provisions of the new Bill, there are several key safeguards and procedural requirements in place to protect the rights of individuals detained under suspicion of terrorism: Individuals can be detained and interrogated for a maximum period of 60 days without requiring prior approval from a Magistrate. However, they can only be held in authorised detention centres. After the arrest of an individual, they must be brought before a Magistrate within 48 hours. Prosecution cannot be solely based on confessions obtained from the detained individuals. Any confession used for prosecution must adhere to the common law requirement, which typically means that it should be made before a Magistrate in accordance with established legal procedures. Individuals arrested under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) have the opportunity to seek bail after one year of detention, providing them with a legal recourse to challenge their continued detention. In cases where individuals are detained for more than one year, such extended detention must be authorised by a Magistrate, adding an additional layer of judicial oversight. “These provisions collectively reflect an effort to strike a balance between addressing security concerns and safeguarding the rights and due process of individuals detained under suspicion of involvement in terrorism. It is important to ensure that these legal safeguards are effectively implemented to protect the rights of those affected by these laws.” Ali Sabry underscored that the existing Prevention of Terrorism Act has undergone substantial amendments with the primary objective of disseminating a balanced legal framework. This framework has been designed to safeguard and uphold the fundamental human rights of our country’s citizens. The Minister, addressing the media at the Presidential Media Centre on Wednesday (13), further noted that in accordance with globally acknowledged standards, comprehensive measures have been undertaken to revise the current PTA, aiming to establish a harmonious legal framework that safeguards both the national security of the country and the fundamental human rights of its citizens. The objective of these revisions is to formulate a law that strikes a judicious balance. “In this context, under the guidance and leadership of the Minister of Justice, extensive deliberations and consultations have been conducted with relevant authorities. These collaborative endeavours have resulted in substantial improvements to the proposed new legislation, elevating it to a commendable standard.” It is important to note that our country possesses a well-established system for enacting and promulgating new laws and statutes. Following the publication of the new Act in the Gazette, it will be made accessible to the entire populace, allowing for a comprehensive understanding of its provisions and implications by the citizens of the nation, he said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Doctors can extend service by two years after retirement age
author: Author not found
Content: Amidst a concerning trend of significant attrition among doctors, which poses a potential threat to the stability of the entire medical sector, the Health Ministry announced that in addition to the existing retirement age of 63 years, doctors will now have the option to extend their service by an additional two years on a contractual basis, based on their personal preferences and choices. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry yesterday (15), quoting Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, said that as an alternative solution to the large-scale brain drain taking place amongst doctors, the government has decided to recall retired doctors and specialists for service on contract basis. “The move aims to address the prevailing doctor shortage at hospitals due to brain drain prompted by the economic crisis,” he said. The spokesman said, a Cabinet Paper proposing this alternative solution would be submitted to the Cabinet of Ministers. He said, a substantial number of medical practitioners, both MBBS qualified doctors and medical specialists had recently migrated to foreign countries, in search of better remuneration and quality of life. He pointed out that it had resulted in the collapse of health services in a number of State Hospitals. Meanwhile, senior medical specialists warned that they would be at a serious disadvantage in agreeing to continue in service unless the age of retirement was extended from the stipulated 60 years. Most of the specialists who are of a retirement age are stationed at their end posts in Colombo, Galle, Matara, Negombo, Gampaha, Ratnapura and Jaffna where they are closer to home. In addition, their immediate juniors would be prepared to step into the positions on their retirement. They noted that the brain drain was severely affecting the hospitals in the peripheries. But having past those postings none of the specialist doctors would like to reverse their steps and go back to the peripheries after retirement. Therefore, the government and the Health Ministry would have to have a clear idea as to how they were going to resolve the issue by recalling and extending the service of doctors on retirement even if it is on contract basis, a spokesperson for the senior medical specialists added.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: IMF review of Sri Lanka begins
author: Author not found
Content: The inaugural meeting to assess Sri Lanka’s progress regarding the implementation of the new economic reforms, proposed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), was held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (14). These discussions will be held over a period of two weeks from today and the final discussion of the review will be held on 26 September under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Representing the Sri Lankan Government in this deliberation were Minister of State for Finance Shehan Semasinghe, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Adviser to the President on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, Finance Ministry Secretary Mahinda Siriwardena and Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe. The IMF delegation featured prominent figures such as Peter Breuer (Senior Mission Chief), Katya Svirydzenka (Deputy Mission Chief), Mike Li, Sophia Zhang, Dmitriy Rozhkov, Noda Selim, Sandesh Dhungana, Nui Miao, Mark Adams (virtual), Joei Turkewitz, Nuong Lan Vu.

title: SL says debt restructuring vital for strategic repositioning
author: Author not found
Content: As the 23rd Council of Ministers meeting, of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA), is scheduled to be convened in Colombo in October, the Sri Lankan Government said Sri Lanka’s policy in the Indian Ocean region is centred on promoting a free and open Indo-Pacific, with a primary emphasis on ensuring maritime safety and security while strategically repositioning the country and to this end, the restructuring of the debts of Sri Lanka is vital. Elaborating on the significance of the IORA (Indian Ocean Rim Association), National Security Adviser Sagala Ratnayake yesterday (14), at an event held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, where President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Karu Jayasuriya, and members of the diplomatic circle were present, stated that the Indian Ocean region has evolved beyond being a mere passageway for maritime trade. It has now emerged as a vital global nexus where security, economics, environmental concerns, and social issues intersect, making it an immensely important strategic arena. The national interests of States drive the international system. Commonly held interests thus can come under threats depending on the various national interests, he added. In light of Sri Lanka’s recovery from an economic crisis exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic and certain policy decisions, he said the country  has embarked on a robust revival programme. “This endeavour has positioned us to assume a crucial role in fostering the harmony essential within the Indian Ocean region”. He said government’s key policy in the Indian Ocean revolves around the commitment in safeguarding undersea cables, combating illicit fishing, addressing human trafficking and smuggling, and confronting climate-related disasters and maritime pollution.  Nobody would pay attention to us. It is the strong commitment to our reform process, the subsequent stabilisation, and the ensuing growth that have carved out our unique position,” Ratnayake emphasised. “The domestic debt restructuring (DDR) is on the verge of completion, and our next steps involve enacting the Central Bank Act, finalising the DDR process, and converting Treasury Bills into Bonds. Additionally, we are committed to achieving bilateral debt restructuring. During the initial round, we sought assurances from the Paris Club, India, and China, and they swiftly stepped forward to assist us. We remain hopeful of their continued support in the next round as well,” he added. The Japanese Ambassador highlighted that this occasion presents an excellent opportunity for the President to engage in discussions with the Japanese Prime Minister regarding his reforms in finance and governance methods. These reforms hold significant importance in rebuilding trust within the Japanese Government and the business community towards Sri Lanka. Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Bagley, emphasised that the most significant achievement in India’s relationship with Sri Lanka is the connectivity document between the two nations, which encapsulates their shared vision. He noted, “Connectivity is the cornerstone of this vision, with its multi-dimensional implications. The dynamics of the India-Sri Lanka bilateral relationship, in many ways, embody our vision and collaborative efforts for the entire Indian Ocean region and the Indo-Pacific.” The French Ambassador said, the visit of their President Marcon was also to express to commitment to stand alongside Sri Lanka in this economic situation of the country.   The Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka said, China has been the country with high level partnership with Sri Lanka. He said, the Sri Lankan Prime Minister and the Speaker visited China to prepare for next month’s forum on international cooperation where Sri Lanka would participate. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
