Content: The inaugural meeting to assess Sri Lanka’s progress regarding the implementation of the new economic reforms, proposed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), was held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (14). These discussions will be held over a period of two weeks from today and the final discussion of the review will be held on 26 September under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Representing the Sri Lankan Government in this deliberation were Minister of State for Finance Shehan Semasinghe, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Adviser to the President on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, Finance Ministry Secretary Mahinda Siriwardena and Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe. The IMF delegation featured prominent figures such as Peter Breuer (Senior Mission Chief), Katya Svirydzenka (Deputy Mission Chief), Mike Li, Sophia Zhang, Dmitriy Rozhkov, Noda Selim, Sandesh Dhungana, Nui Miao, Mark Adams (virtual), Joei Turkewitz, Nuong Lan Vu.

title: SL says debt restructuring vital for strategic repositioning
author: Author not found
Content: As the 23rd Council of Ministers meeting, of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA), is scheduled to be convened in Colombo in October, the Sri Lankan Government said Sri Lanka’s policy in the Indian Ocean region is centred on promoting a free and open Indo-Pacific, with a primary emphasis on ensuring maritime safety and security while strategically repositioning the country and to this end, the restructuring of the debts of Sri Lanka is vital. Elaborating on the significance of the IORA (Indian Ocean Rim Association), National Security Adviser Sagala Ratnayake yesterday (14), at an event held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, where President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Karu Jayasuriya, and members of the diplomatic circle were present, stated that the Indian Ocean region has evolved beyond being a mere passageway for maritime trade. It has now emerged as a vital global nexus where security, economics, environmental concerns, and social issues intersect, making it an immensely important strategic arena. The national interests of States drive the international system. Commonly held interests thus can come under threats depending on the various national interests, he added. In light of Sri Lanka’s recovery from an economic crisis exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic and certain policy decisions, he said the country  has embarked on a robust revival programme. “This endeavour has positioned us to assume a crucial role in fostering the harmony essential within the Indian Ocean region”. He said government’s key policy in the Indian Ocean revolves around the commitment in safeguarding undersea cables, combating illicit fishing, addressing human trafficking and smuggling, and confronting climate-related disasters and maritime pollution.  Nobody would pay attention to us. It is the strong commitment to our reform process, the subsequent stabilisation, and the ensuing growth that have carved out our unique position,” Ratnayake emphasised. “The domestic debt restructuring (DDR) is on the verge of completion, and our next steps involve enacting the Central Bank Act, finalising the DDR process, and converting Treasury Bills into Bonds. Additionally, we are committed to achieving bilateral debt restructuring. During the initial round, we sought assurances from the Paris Club, India, and China, and they swiftly stepped forward to assist us. We remain hopeful of their continued support in the next round as well,” he added. The Japanese Ambassador highlighted that this occasion presents an excellent opportunity for the President to engage in discussions with the Japanese Prime Minister regarding his reforms in finance and governance methods. These reforms hold significant importance in rebuilding trust within the Japanese Government and the business community towards Sri Lanka. Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Bagley, emphasised that the most significant achievement in India’s relationship with Sri Lanka is the connectivity document between the two nations, which encapsulates their shared vision. He noted, “Connectivity is the cornerstone of this vision, with its multi-dimensional implications. The dynamics of the India-Sri Lanka bilateral relationship, in many ways, embody our vision and collaborative efforts for the entire Indian Ocean region and the Indo-Pacific.” The French Ambassador said, the visit of their President Marcon was also to express to commitment to stand alongside Sri Lanka in this economic situation of the country.   The Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka said, China has been the country with high level partnership with Sri Lanka. He said, the Sri Lankan Prime Minister and the Speaker visited China to prepare for next month’s forum on international cooperation where Sri Lanka would participate. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Bandula to seek CID probe into Dodangoda’s claim
author: Author not found
Content: A significant development arose in the ongoing dispute between the railway trade unions and Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardena, when he announced his intention to involve the CID and the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), in response to allegations made by Indika Dodangoda, the Convener of a collective of railway unions. Dodangoda, during a media briefing had accused the minister of awarding the Meerigama-Mahawa route train signal project to an Indian company without following the required tender process, intensifying the conflict between the minister and trade unions. Gunawardena who vehemently refuted the allegation said Dodangoda is deliberately trying to damage his goodwill by uttering such false statements. “This person (Dodangoda) is not even a member of any trade union. I have not awarded a single project of the Department of Railways to an Indian company. All the projects initiated by the department have commenced under the Indian Credit Line and the Ministry of Finance oversees those projects. So, Dodangoda is uttering blatant lies and if he has any proof for his allegations, he has to come forward and present it,” Gunawardena said. The minister stressed that he also informed the General Manager of Railways and Transport Ministry Secretary to initiate an investigation into Dodangoda’s statement. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Lohan granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: Anuradhapura Chief Magistrate Nalaka Jayasuriya granted bail for State Minister of Plantation Industries, Lohan Ratwatte, in the case where the latter is charged with illegally entering the Anuradhapura Prison premises and threatening an inmate with a firearm two years ago. Bail was set at two sureties of Rs 200,000 each and the case was fixed for 4 January next year. The Chief Magistrate instructed the State Minister to appear before him on that date. He also instructed the first witness P. Sooriyapalan and the second witness M. Pulaxan, to be present in Court to testify on the said date. Ratwatte has been charged before the Court, for having unlawfully entered the Anuradhapura Prison, on or before 12 September 2021, while functioning as the State Minister of Prison Reforms. It is alleged that he then threatened and intimidated an inmate named P. Sooriyapalan, with a firearm. When the case was called up, the charges filed against the suspect State Minister, were read out in Court. Defence Lawyer President’s Counsel Sampath Mendis maintained that his client, was innocent of the charges filed against him. The Colombo Crimes Division (CCD), has filed the case before the Anuradhapura Chief Magistrate’s Court and yesterday (14), was the first time the suspect, was present in the Court. BY Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: The Key to Sustainable Food Systems
author: Author not found
Content: The fabric of our global food system is fraying under the strain of climate change and an ever-expanding population. To prevent it from unravelling, we must embrace distributed renewable-energy solutions, which are critical for reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, boosting resilience and productivity, and cutting costs. Failure to do so would jeopardise efforts to achieve the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and threaten our very survival. Halfway to the 2030 deadline, progress towards the SDGs – conceived as a “shared blueprint for peace and prosperity for people and the planet” – is lagging significantly. In July, the UN High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development in New York and the UN Food Systems Summit +2 Stocktaking Moment in Rome underscored the importance of ensuring access to modern energy (SDG 7) and achieving zero hunger (SDG 2), respectively. When it comes to strengthening the long-term resilience and adaptability of the global food system, these two objectives are interlinked. Translating this into public policies has taken on new urgency, given that rapid global warming, population growth, public health crises, volatile energy markets, and conflict have exposed the food system’s unique vulnerabilities and shortcomings. Past solutions and approaches will no longer work; on the contrary, they contributed to the current problems. Previously, concerns about food supply – including high prices during the 2008 global financial crisis – invariably led to agricultural intensification and mechanisation, as well as an increase in land use. As a result, agribusiness (including the production, transport, and storage of food) today accounts for roughly one-third of all GHG emissions, which in turn threaten the future of agriculture. While the effects of climate change are felt throughout the global food system, they are disproportionately borne by those least responsible for the problem: smallholder farmers in the Global South. For example, Sub-Saharan Africa, which relies on rainfed agriculture, already experiences one-third of the world’s droughts and is vulnerable to higher temperatures and other extreme weather. The IMF has found that a single drought can lower an African country’s medium-term economic growth potential by one percentage point. That conclusion reflects agriculture’s central role in the developing world: in some of the least-developed countries, it accounts for more than 25% of GDP, while 52% of employed people in Sub-Saharan Africa are active in the sector. Given this, achieving sustainable and climate-friendly food production in the Global South could lead to significant welfare improvements. This will require a shift to distributed renewable energy, which can be used in primary production, post-harvest processing, storage, and cooking – the agricultural activities that tend to consume the most energy in developing countries. To be sure, decentralised renewable energy is not a panacea. But it could contribute significantly to stabilising the global food system by lowering energy costs, a crucial factor for boosting productivity; by facilitating financing for productive applications, which could democratise access to yield-enhancing technologies; and by reducing GHG emissions and promoting climate-change adaptation. Last but not least, reducing reliance on fossil fuels and decentralising energy production can help shift global power dynamics within the food system. Solar-powered irrigation, for example, has significantly improved water access and enabled multiple cropping cycles, increasing productivity and reducing GHG emissions. Solar-powered pumps have boosted farmers’ incomes by more than 50% in India and led to significant increases in yields in Rwanda. The Ethiopian Ministry of Irrigation and Lowlands – which one of us heads – recently banned the import of diesel irrigation pumps to support the rapid transition to renewable energy solutions. In Sub-Saharan Africa, solar milling machines could make grinding grain into flour more efficient, affordable, and sustainable. Additionally, the expansion of mini-grids to power post-harvest processes can bring more economic and environmental benefits by enabling communities to preserve their produce locally. Cold storage and refrigeration are crucial for extending shelflife, reducing food loss, and maintaining product quality. Decentralised cold-storage solutions that are powered by renewable energy could improve market access and reduce spoilage for smallholder farmers and remote communities. By converting existing infrastructure to renewable energy sources, we can cut GHG emissions and make cold chains more environmentally friendly and affordable. All the above examples demonstrate the diverse applications of distributed renewable energy, and each solution contributes to a more resilient, sustainable, and climate-friendly food system. By scaling up these innovations, we can address the energy challenges faced by smallholder farmers, processors, and consumers while reducing our carbon footprint. Reinforcing the fabric of our global food system requires a new framework designed to reduce land use, enhance productivity, minimise food loss, and cut GHG emissions. Renewable energy must be its foundation. Otherwise, developing countries will be unable to raise agricultural yields and end hunger, stop and reverse environmental degradation, or democratise energy access. Kristina Skierka is CEO of Power for All and Aisha Mohammed Mussa is Minister of Irrigation and Lowlands of Ethiopia (Project Syndicate) By KRISTINA SKIERKA and AISHA MOHAMMED MUSSA

title: Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report on SL launched
author: Author not found
Content: The Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report on the Anti-Corruption Landscape of Sri Lanka introduces a comprehensive set of governance reform recommendations designed to address the root causes of the current crisis in the nation. This report, the result of an in-depth study, identifies and prioritises key aspects of governance that require systematic attention from both a public opinion and economic governance perspective. This collaborative effort, reflecting the crucial socio-political moment of reform in Sri Lanka, was led by Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) in partnership with a core group consisting of Verité Research, the Centre for Policy Alternatives (CPA), Sarvodaya, People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) and the National Peace Council (NPC). Together, they formed the “Civil Society Initiative on Anti-Corruption Reform for Economic Recovery”, with the shared understanding that the country is in a governance crisis embedded in deep-rooted corruption, which must be addressed, if we are to strive towards actual, sustainable and equitable economic recovery. The report benefited from input provided by over 250 participants, representing diverse sectors, geographical locations, and ethnic, religious, and cultural groups. Prof. Arjuna Parakrama, an esteemed Researcher, conducted the research for the Civil Society Initiative. The High-Level Launch of the ‘Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report on Sri Lanka’ took place on Wednesday, 13 September at the BMICH in Colombo. The event saw the participation of policymakers, representatives from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), diplomatic missions, international funding institutions, civil society organisations, academics, and distinguished guests from various other sectors. A quote from the Report underscores its urgency: “The current growing sense of economic injustice has been exacerbated by the fact that the architects of the economic crisis do not bear any part of the burden of its proposed reform, which has been, again, firmly thrust, without any public dialogue, on the victims of this very crisis.” Furthermore, it highlights, “Corruption is the core issue that determines the nature of the Sri Lankan polity. In fact, corruption has spread so far and wide that the country is currently facing imminent State Capture, which prevents public institutions from fulfilling their roles.” The report also reveals that among the high-probability and high-risk tactics used in Sri Lanka are the structural weakening of the country’s accountability framework, influence and interference with public officials, abuse of State-owned enterprises, manipulation of public procurement procedures, suppression of civil society, and the use of illicit financial transactions. Recommendations The Civil Society Governance Diagnostic Report on Sri Lanka presents a total of 34 main governance benchmark recommendations. These recommendations are categorised into three timeframes for implementation: immediate (0 – 6 months), short-term (up to 12 months), and medium-term (up to 24 months). They encompass measures aimed at enhancing transparency and accountability, improving macro-political-economic stability and sustainability, and fostering structural changes within the country. Below is a comprehensive list of these recommendations: Immediate (0 – 6 months): Measures to enhance transparency and accountability of existing systems Maintain a fiscal transparency platform that displays all information related to tax exemptions. Publish an annual report by 31 March each year, setting out the previous year’s expenditure variations against the approved budget, and explanations for the same. Quarterly publication of a revenue report detailing changes to revenue measures that might result in an annual revenue loss of 0.1% of GDP. Publish follow-up on actions taken to regularise qualified opinions of the Auditor General. Implement all the provisions of the Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act (FMRA), revised as appropriate, and ensure that non-compliance is penalised. Limit budget allocations under the development activities of the Department of National Budget (discretionary spending) to 3% of total expenditure. Reduce corruption and waste in relation to the benefits provided to political leaders and senior bureaucrats through enforcing systems of transparency and accountability.   Address the politicisation of the public service. Publish data related to all secondary market transactions of the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF), with adequate detail to assess off-market rates of sale and purchase (as analysed by the forensic audits of the EPF published in 2019). Proactively disclose information relating to the project three months before commencement as outlined in the Right to Information Act. Quarterly publication of a complete set of updated information on public debt. Maintain an online platform that publishes all significant public procurement contracts when cumulatively above LKR 100 million to any set of connected suppliers. Ensure impartial implementation of the legal framework in the Anti-Corruption Act (ACA) for public access to asset declarations.  Hold national elections in accordance with the constitutionally mandated timeframe. Ensure enforcement of election campaign expenditure monitoring offences through by setting up an electronic system. Ensure the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption’s (CIABOC) readiness to investigate and apply the law effectively and equally. Publish all documents related to Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) for all large-scale infrastructure projects in an online portal to ensure transparency. Protect and uphold civic space for citizen participation in all appropriate aspects of governance, including democratic dissent and protest.  Short-term (Up to 12 months): Measures to improve macro-political-economic stability and sustainability Amend all tax-related legislation to remove the excessive use of discretion for taxation changes without approved schemes. Fully implement the price and tax measures anticipated in the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (Article 6), to which Sri Lanka is a signatory. Achieve an annual reduction of 10% in the five-year average of tax exemptions (connected to Recommendation 1). Set up a Public Debt Management office external to the Central Bank.    Strengthen the National Procurement Commission for better oversight of public procurement and pass the Procurement Guidelines of 2019 with public consultation.  Conduct special audits on the ten State ministries/agencies with the lowest proportion (in value) of competitive bidding, and over LKR 10 billion in procurement. Establish a publicly accessible, online conflict-of-interest register.    Enact regulations for the transparent and accountable management of State enterprises.  Amend Parliamentary Standing Orders to better reflect continuity and accountability, especially to prevent disruption of the work of the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA), the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) and the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) each time Parliament is prorogued. Reduce unnecessary military expenditure by demilitarising the North and East of Sri Lanka, re-skilling military cadre prior to release, including handing back private and common State lands. Increase transparency and accountability of new social safety net cash transfers.  Ensure proper oversight and enforcement related to illicit financial flows (IFFs). Medium-term (Up to 24 months): Measures towards structural changes that are necessary to significantly reduce corruption risk and impunity Pass legislation on asset recovery in compliance with the United Nations Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC) with wide consultation, and ensure progress on key corruption cases, including those already commenced, with technical assistance from StAR (Stolen Asset Recovery Initiative). Establish a specialised independent corruption prosecution office with IMF technical guidance based on advising offices established in other countries. Alienate land for user-owned housing in the Malaiyaha Tamil areas, and provide living minimum wage for plantation sector workers (right to housing and livelihood). Change the composition and structure of the Constitutional Council so that there is a higher ratio of non-political representatives. For detailed information on the 34 Recommendations of the Report, please refer to the full report on www.tisrilanka.org. At the High-Level Launch, the Civil Society Initiative emphatically called upon the Government to prioritise these key recommendations in good faith, with support from development partners such as the IMF, World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.

title: BoC partners with OUSL to kick off ‘Less Plastic Movement’
author: Author not found
Content: In recent years, increasing consumption of macro and micro plastics has emerged as one of the largest threats to the future of our oceans, seas and marine life. The United Nations has declared the conservation and sustainable use of the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development as the 14th Sustainable Development Goal. In fulfilling its commitment as a corporate sustainability citizen towards advancing the sustainable development agenda, Sri Lanka’s No. 01 Bank, Bank of Ceylon (BOC) partnered with the Open University of Sri Lanka to commence the national campaign ‘Less Plastic Movement’. This National Campaign was kicked off and a collective effort was organised to collect plastic and polythene waste, from 50 selected locations across the island to prevent further harm to our ecosystems. These locations include reef sites, inland areas, coastal belts and other ecologically sensitive regions. Bank of Ceylon has stepped forward to sponsor such clean-up activities in six locations islandwide including Trincomalee Uppuveli, Venparei white rock, Casuarina Beach Jaffna, Trinco-Dutch Bay, Kayankerni, Batticaloa and Boiler Wreck – Batticaloa to clean the reefs in partnership with the Centre for Environmental Studies and Sustainable Development of the Open University of Sri Lanka, Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA), Central Environment Authority, Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Public Administration and Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, Local Government Authorities and other stakeholders. The total amount of waste collected from the BOC-sponsored sites in the clean-up is 438.65 kg which includes 220.8 kg recyclable waste and 217.85 kg non-recyclable waste. Masks and PET Bottles are the biggest source of waste found in the collection followed by food wrapping and shopping bags. Collected waste was sorted and sent for recycling with the support of registered plastic recyclers in adopting the latest sustainable practices hence resulting in a reduction of plastic waste that ends up in landfills or in the environment. Simultaneously, the non-recyclable plastic collections are disposed of in the dumping sites with the assistance of relevant Local Government Authorities. As part of the campaign, the OUSL has carried out an extensive education and awareness campaign regarding the health and environmental impact of plastics. Over the past year, BOC invested in CSR activities towards advancing climate actions under SDGs. In 2022, the Bank was able to save Rs 56.7 million worth of paper and toner through process automation while recycling 21.9 MT of paper under SDG number 12. As a leader in green and sustainable financing, BOC grants green financing loans while disbursing loans in accordance with the Central Bank’s taxonomy and nearly Rs 1 billion in funding for sustainable manufacturing in 2022. The Bank has introduced various loan products including loans for Solar, electric bikes, and biogas plants to advance the national sustainable agenda during the past year. Similarly, the Bank has introduced new green deposit products, Haritha Kekulu and BOC E-Thuru, and continues to promote among the Bank’s customer base.

title: Dialog’s Sayuru partners MEPA for Ocean Conservation and Waste Management Awareness
author: Author not found
Content: Sayuru, powered by Dialog Axiata PLC, partnered with the Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) on World Ocean Day in a shared mission to advance sustainable development initiatives for ocean conservation and waste management, which is also aligned with the 2023 Environment Day theme of Beating Plastic Pollution. As part of this collaboration, Sayuru will actively engage in projects and initiatives that address social and environmental challenges in an effort to make a positive difference in the lives of the coastal community. This partnership aims to contribute to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, specifically Goal 1 (No Poverty), Goal 13 (Climate Action), and Goal 14 (Life Below Water). Further, this initiative will conduct a range of awareness programmes addressing crucial environmental issues such as the reduction of pollution in mangroves, coral reefs, turtles, coastal protection, and pollution in coastal ports to emphasise the importance of environmental preservation. In addition, Dialog plans to launch the feature-rich Sayuru smartphone app, which will support the fisheries industry and provide location services even without an Internet connection, where Dialog users can enjoy free data usage when accessing the app. Launched in 2020, Sayuru is a free and trilingual Interactive Voice Response (IVR) weather advisory service developed in collaboration with the Department of Meteorology and the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources to provide daily forecasts tailored to their locations along the coast of the island. In emergency situations, voice messages in the fisherman’s preferred language are dispatched by Sayuru using Outbound Dialing (OBD) technology, to help ensure their safety. The partnership between Sayuru and MEPA reinforces Dialog’s commitment to sustainable development and its dedication to making a meaningful difference in the lives of coastal communities. Together, they aim to foster a cleaner and healthier marine environment for future generations.

title: Giving Leadership to Lions Int’l 306 A2 as District Governor
author: Author not found
Content: District Governor 2023/2024, Lion Nuwan I Ballantudawa, MJF, MAF graduated with Bachelor of Arts (Hons) specialized in Political Science from University of Colombo.  His wife, Lion Piumi also graduated in Bachelor of Law from the same University.  They are blessed with a little daughter ‘Dahamdhi Yashodara’. District 306 A2 has a membership of 2550 with 107 Lions Clubs covering Colombo to Moneragala. District Governor Lion Nuwan leads the district with his theme ‘Service Empowered with Leadership’” with his vision on lionism based on five principles. Administration is equally important as service, All decisions and appreciations should be made objectively with no bias to other factors, Service should be aimed at empowering people, Lionism should be a brand name for leadership empowerment, Transparent, accountable and responsible leadership based on trusteeship are the five principles. We conduct numerous service projects, namely Medical Camps, Distribution of spectacles and wheelchairs, Assisting Cataract Surgeries, Diabetes Screening and Conducting Awareness Programs and Providing Scholarships especially for the underprivileged students in the society. Lions Club of Colombo Pride invites all friends to join hands with Lions International.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Pakistan Embassy organises seminar on Gandhara Heritage
author: Author not found
Content: Pakistan High Commission, Colombo organised a Seminar on the Gandhara Heritage of Pakistan on 13 September. The event, held at the prestigious Nāgānanda International Institute for Buddhist Studies (NIIBS), was inter alia attended by former President Mathripala Sirisena, former Speaker Karu Jayasuriya, Imtiaz Bakeer Markar MP, Diplomatic Corps, prominent Monks, members of All Ceylon Buddhist Council, and a large number of students. Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickremanayake was the Chief Guest. High Commissioner of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan to Sri Lanka Maj. Gen. Umar Farooq Burki (HI) (M) in his welcome address gave an overview of the excellent friendly ties between Pakistan and Sri Lanka. While stressing the need for frequent people-to-people contacts between the two countries, the High Commissioner highlighted the immense potential Pakistan possesses in religious and cultural tourism. In this regard, he stressed the need for institutional linkages between the two countries. The Chief Guest, in his remarks, appreciated the efforts of the High Commission for apprising the Sri Lankan public of the huge cultural and religious tourism potential of Pakistan, especially its rich Gandhara Heritage. The Minister proposed that the two countries should create a Heritage Forum for a bilateral exchange of views and experience. Presentations and speeches were made by prominent Sri Lankan scholars as well as two eminent Speakers from Pakistan viz. Dr Abdul Sammad, Director General, Archaeology Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province of Pakistan and Iqbal Khan, Director, Taxila Museum. Some of the other highlights of the seminar included the display of books and pamphlets related to Pakistan’s Gandhara Heritage and the launch of a documentary on the Gandhara Heritage of Pakistan. In the spirit of close brotherly relations and to further build upon the cultural linkages, an MoU between Pakistan and Sri Lanka on the promotion of religious tourism and collaboration in the preservation and projection of Gandhara Heritage is also at an advanced stage.

title: Speaker endorses Central Bank Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana endorsed the certificate on the Central Bank of Sri Lanka Bill and the Banking (Special Provisions) Bill yesterday (14). The Central Bank of Sri Lanka Bill was passed in Parliament by a majority on 20 July with amendments. The Banking (Special Provisions) Bill was passed without a vote on 21 July. Accordingly, the said Bills will come into effect as the Central Bank of Sri Lanka Act No. 16 of 2023 and the Banking (Special Provisions) Act No. 17 of 2023. Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera, Assistant Secretary-General Hansa Abeyratne and Director Legislative Services and Director Communications (Acting) Janakantha Silva were also in attendance.

title: Large crowds pay homage to Deegawapiya Relics
author: Author not found
Content: Large crowds paid homage to the sacred Omniscient Relics of Deegawapiya Stupa at the Pepiliyana Sunethra Devi Piriven Maha Viharaya, on 12 September. Chief Incumbent, Sri Sunethra Devi Raja Maha Viharaya, Prof. Medagoda Abhayatissa Thera who facilitated the exposition of revered articles at the temple premises was also present during the session. The charming religious evening saw an influx of a large gathering of devotees and Maha Sangha at the venue paying their homage during this rare occasion. The Relics unearthed from the Deegawapiya site during the excavations as well as the Crest Gem embedded with 2,800 precious stones will be taken to Ratmalana Parama Dhamma Chethiya Pirivena. Thereafter the revered articles will be taken on a religious procession to Maharagama Siri Vajiragnana Dharmayathanaya, for ‘public veneration’. They will be on exposition at Kotte Rajamaha Viharaya on 15 September, Pannipitiya Siri Damminda Viharaya on 16 September and Piliyandala Mampe Viharaya on 17 September respectively.

title: INS ‘Nireekshak’ arrives in Trincomalee
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian Naval Ship (INS) ‘Nireekshak’ arrived at the Trincomalee harbour on a formal visit yesterday (14). The visiting ship was welcomed by the Sri Lanka Navy in compliance with Naval tradition.  INS ‘Nireekshak’ is a 70.5m long Diving Support Vessel manned by a crew of 137 and the ship is commanded by Commander Jeetu Singh Chauhan. Meanwhile, the Commanding Officer of the ship called on Commander Eastern Naval Area, Rear Admiral Suresh de Silva at the Eastern Naval Command Headquarters this morning.  During the ship’s stay, the crew will take part in several programmes, with a view to promoting cooperation and goodwill between two navies. In addition, diving training exercises with the Sri Lanka Navy Diving Unit, a health camp for the community in Trincomalee, and visiting some of the tourist attractions in the country are part of the itinerary.  The ship is expected to leave the island on 21 September.

title: Kerala Chief Minister to visit SL shortly – Thondaman
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman said Chief Minister of Kerala Pinarayi Vijayan expressed his willingness to visit Sri Lanka in the near future. Thondaman said the Kerala Chief Minister communicated this during their recent meeting in Kerala. The meeting between the Eastern Province Governor and Kerala Chief Minister took place on 11 September, at Vijayan’s office in Kerala. They discussed various matters, including collaborative efforts to promote tourism in the Eastern Province with the support of the Kerala Government. Additionally, they addressed the concerns of the Central Hill Country residents who had resettled in Kerala in the 1970s. Thondaman said 1,480 families had relocated to Kerala during that year, with many of them presently employed in Rehabilitation Plantation Limited and other corporations in Kerala. Attention was also paid to resolving issues presently faced by these individuals. The Eastern Province Governor added that the Kerala Chief Minister praised the timely action taken by the President to resolve the country’s economic crisis. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Sri Lanka gearsfor World Tourism Day
author: Author not found
Content: The tourism industry in Sri Lanka is gearing up for an exciting series of events to celebrate World Tourism Day 2023 which falls on 27 September. Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) has planned several events from 25 to 27 September, with a special focus on green investments and Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in the tourism sector. The global theme of this year’s World Tourism Day commemoration centres around tourism and green investments. Sri Lanka is currently experiencing an encouraging surge in tourist arrivals and crossed the 900,000 mark in early August, easily surpassing the total of 719,978 recorded for the whole of 2022. Anticipation is building as we approach the last week of September when the one-millionth tourist is expected to arrive. This holds special significance for the upcoming World Tourism Day celebration. These celebrations align with global efforts to rethink and reshape the tourism sector to be more sustainable, responsible, and community-oriented. By focusing on green investments and sustainable practices, Sri Lanka aims to position itself as a leading destination that balances tourism’s benefits with environmental and social considerations, thus ensuring long-term prosperity and well-being for all stakeholders involved. Sustainable Niche Tourism Learning Expo – 25 September Heralding the week’s activities is the Sustainable Niche Tourism Learning Expo on 25 September, hosted at Cinnamon Grand Hotel in Colombo. The event is organised by SLTDA in collaboration with the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) Indo-Pacific Opportunity Project (IPOP) for sustainable tourism. The primary objectives of this outreach event are: Enhancing the competitiveness of MSMEs through learning opportunities, access to mentoring sessions with industry trailblazers, and the dissemination of toolkits focused on product development, marketing, promotions, and sustainability. Encouraging MSMEs to embark on their sustainability journey. Promoting business-to-business networking to connect MSMEs with larger operators and local suppliers. Creating awareness of the business registration criteria and providing on-location registration opportunities. Promoting the ongoing sustainability certification programme among businesses engaged in tourism. Official World Tourism Day Celebration – 27 September The official celebration of World Tourism Day will take place on 27 September at Marino Beach Hotel, Colombo. This global event, celebrated worldwide, highlights the role of tourism in fostering socio-cultural exchange, economic growth, and sustainable development. This year’s theme, “Tourism and Green Investments” underscores the importance of investing in people, the planet, and prosperity within the tourism industry. The event will: Raise awareness about the significance of green investments in tourism. Showcase successful examples of sustainable tourism practices and green investments. Encourage collaboration among stakeholders for sustainable initiatives. Provide a platform for knowledge sharing, networking, and best practice exchange. Inspire industry professionals to adopt sustainable strategies. Embracing a Million Dreams: Sri Lanka’s Tourist Triumph in 2023 In addition to these events, Sri Lanka anticipates receiving One million tourist arrivals around 27 September marking a significant milestone after the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. The SLTDA together with the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) has organised a special reception to greet the one millionth tourist. This accomplishment comes after several years of striving to rebuild the industry following many challenges. The SLTPB intends to greet tourists by offering them gift packs that feature local sweets and a keepsake. Additionally, they are planning to set up a designated area for tourists to take selfies and create lasting memories during their visit. The revival of Sri Lanka’s tourism industry is a testament to the resilience and efforts of the country’s tourism sector, despite the challenges it has faced. It signifies a positive outlook for the recovery and growth of tourism in Sri Lanka.

title: Prosecution to conclude seeking evidence soon
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Solicitor General (DSG) Janaka Bandara yesterday (14) informed Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja that seeking of evidence for the Prosecution, in the abduction case filed against former MP Hirunika Premachandra, will be concluded at the earliest. The former lawmaker and seven of her supporters have been indicted before the High Court with abduction and intimidation of a youth, employed at a textile shop in Colombo 9, on 21 December, eight years ago. However, seven of Premachandra’s supporters, pleaded guilty to the charges filed against them, on Christmas Eve, 2017 and the High Court, imposed a two-year Rigorous Imprisonment, suspended for 12 years on them. But, as the former MP refused to plead guilty to the charges, the High Court ordered to sustain the lawsuit against her. When the said case was called, Deputy News Editor of Sri Lanka Rupavahini Corporation (SLRC) Vimukthi Kariyawasam, who had been named as a witness for the Prosecution, gave evidence. DSG Bandara, told Judge Ranaraja, that the Prosecution would look to conclude the process of seeking evidence shortly, after the Defence, had considered the documents handed over to them by the Prosecution, as being acceptable. The Court then deferred further proceedings of the trial, to 4 October. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Rajitha permitted to go abroad
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta temporarily lifted the overseas travel ban, imposed on former Minister Dr. Rajitha Senaratne, till 1 December, when the Gotabaya Rajapaksa defamation case was called for hearing yesterday (14). The Court lifted the ban, having considered a request made by the Counsel for the SJB MP, who urged for a temporary removal of the foreign travel ban, due to his client needing to be away from these shores for personal reasons. The Attorney General has indicted the ex-minister and former head of the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC) Mohammad Rumy, before the High Court on 14 counts, for having cast aspersions on the character of former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, in the lead up to the 2019 Presidential Poll, via a media briefing held on 10 November of that year and for having flouted Provisions contained in the Sections 190 and 169 of the Penal Code and Provisions in Section 80 of the Presidential Election Act No. 16 of 1981. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: ‘Reportto Work or Get Fired’
author: Author not found
Content: The government and railway trade unions locked horns yesterday with latter threatening to resort to tougher actions after Railways Department threatening to terminate all locomotive drivers on strike. Despite issuing Gazette Notifications declaring the Railway as an essential service on Tuesday (11), the strike initiated by the Sri Lanka Locomotive Operating Engineers’ Union continued for the second consecutive day yesterday (13). With railway unions threatening to resort to a fully-fledged TU action, the government appeared to have taken a step back and gone into defensive mode by last evening, just hours after the Department of Railways threatened 84 striking drivers to report to work immediately or face consequences as they would be ruled as vacated post. This was after the government  deciding to pass the ball to the Public Services Commission to resolve the matter. Minister of Transport Bandula Gunawardena, following a meeting of the Cabinet Sub-Committee on State Expenditure, chaired by Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, informed the media that it was decided during the meeting that resolving this issue was beyond the capacity of the Cabinet. The Public Services Commission has been tasked with finding a possible solution. When asked whether it was difficult to solve the issue by declaring the Railways as an essential service and deploying military at railway stations, Gunawardena replied, “Yes, it is.” “We can’t act as village thugs when it comes to matters like this. That is why we decided to ask the State Services Commission to come up with a possible solution. Until then, I request drivers to report to work, as railways has been declared an essential service,” he said. Indika Dodangoda, convener of a coalition of railway unions, said yesterday that their decision to take action was a response to the Government’s disregard for their demands. Dodangoda said, “We noticed that the railway service was designated as an essential service. There are serious concerns regarding the legality of this decision. It is evident that the Government is attempting to curb trade unions through this measure,” and cautioned the Government that further attempts to suppress unions without addressing their grievances would inconvenience the public even more. Minister Guanwardena said sending termination letters to drivers would be considered, if they do not report to work today (14) as well. As a result of the strike, 128 train journeys were cancelled yesterday (13), severely inconveniencing the public. However, the Station Masters’ Union of Sri Lanka Railways said 139 train journeys were carried out as usual despite the strike. Following the death of a youth who travelled on the roof of an overcrowded train due to the strike on Tuesday (12), President Ranil Wickremesinghe issued a gazette extraordinary, declaring the Railways as an essential service. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Railway Dept to pay Rs 500,000 compensation
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Railways Department will provide a compensation of Rs 500,000 to the family of the youth who tragically lost his life when he fell off the roof of a train on Tuesday (12). Minister of Transport, Bandula Gunawardena, confirmed this announcement on Wednesday (13). The tragedy occurred when an 18-year-old youth travelling on the overcrowded roof of a train from Kandy to Colombo on Tuesday (12), when locomotive drivers went on strike. Tragically, he fell off the train roof when it hit the roof of the Horape railway station resulting in instant death. On the same day, another passenger in a crowded train travelling from Colombo to Rambukkana also fell from a compartment in Bulugahagoda. He sustained injuries and was transported to hospital for medical attention.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CPC planning daily automated price adjustment system
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) is currently developing a daily automated price adjustment system for the upcoming year, Minister of Power and Energy, Kanchana Wijesekara said yesterday (13). The Minister said the proposal was a key topic of discussion during a recent meeting involving the Minister, representatives from the CPC dealers’ association, and other CPC officials. Posting on ‘X’ social media platform, Wijesekara, said the CPC dealers were briefed on the corporation’s plans to introduce a daily automated price adjustment system starting in 2024. Additionally, there are intentions to modernise all fuel dispensing and inventory management facilities through the incorporation of new equipment. During the meeting, various other important subjects were addressed, including matters related to dealer margins, fuel distribution, future developments and the setting up of new fuel stations, he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: HRCSL asks President for revised copy of Anti-Terrorism Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has formally requested President Ranil Wickremesinghe to provide them with a revised copy of the ‘Anti-Terrorism’ Bill that was recently approved by Cabinet.  The Commission specifically seeks the revised version of the Bill initially gazetted on 17 March 2023, the HRCSL noted. President Wickremesinghe has been asked to provide his observations and recommendations concerning the Bill that was gazetted in March 2023. The Commission said they anticipate offering additional observations and recommendations once they receive a copy of the revised Bill. The Cabinet granted approval for the publication of the Anti-Terrorism Bill, which underwent revisions based on suggestions and opinions from various government parties. The intention is to present this Bill in Parliament for approval. This initiative is part of the Cabinet’s earlier approval to introduce a new Act to replace the existing Prevention of Terrorism (Temporary Provisions) Act No.48 of 1979. The Attorney General has already cleared the Bill prepared by the Legal Draftsman. Subsequently, on 27 February 2023, Cabinet approved the proposal put forth by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms to publish the Bill in the Government Gazette and submit it to Parliament for approval. In September 2022, the Cabinet had given its approval to submit a new Anti-Terrorism Bill, prepared by the Legal Draftsman, as a replacement to the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Consequently, the relevant Bill was published in the Gazette on March 22, 2023. Following its publication, various interested parties, both locally and internationally, provided their opinions on the Bill. Subsequently, the Ministry of Justice formally solicited suggestions and opinions on the matter. In response, necessary steps have been taken to revise the original draft Bill published in the Gazette, considering the opinions and suggestions received by the Ministry. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Will consider releasing Udayanga’s funds – AG
author: Author not found
Content: Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, yesterday (13), informed Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta that he will consider the possibility of releasing money contained in the bank account of former Sri Lankan Envoy to Russia Udayanga Weeratunga, deposited on or before 1 June 2006 and before the emergence of the MiG aircraft scandal. However, Senior State Counsel Udara Karunathilake, appearing for the Attorney General, told Judge Thotawatta that the Attorney General’s Department is vehemently opposed to releasing money, which had been deposited in the bank accounts of the accused, at the time of the MiG aircraft scandal and a sum of USD 400,000. The Attorney General made this remark, when a motion filed by Weeratunga, seeking an order to release cash contained in two of his frozen bank accounts, was taken up for hearing. This sum had been received by the accused, during the time the latter had served as the Sri Lankan Ambassador to Moscow. Through his motion, the former Sri Lankan Ambassador had stated that money contained in two of his bank accounts had been frozen after he was accused of illegally accruing it, while unlawfully intervening in the controversial MiG aircraft deal for the Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF). He has also been accused of alleged embezzlement of public funds, with regard to the procurement of MiG aircraft and money laundering. Weeratunga, in an affidavit, had previously mentioned to the Court, that the money that had been deposited in his accounts, had been the salary that he received, while functioning as the Envoy to Russia, over a period of nine years and the money which he saved, before the MiG aircraft scandal emerged. Anil Silva, PC, appearing for the petitioner, informed the Judge, that his client’s bank accounts had been suspended unilaterally over the past 24 months and that due to this situation; his client had been forced to undergo serious economic strain, even being unable to spend for his children’s education. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ganemulla Sanjeewa arrested at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Sanjeewa Kumara Samararatne, also known as Ganemulla Sanjeewa, a notorious criminal with a history of drug trafficking and other illegal activities, was arrested yesterday (13) by Immigration officers at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) in Katunayake. Airport sources reported that he had entered the country from Kathmandu, Nepal, using a forged passport. He had arrived in Sri Lanka from Kathmandu under the false identity of Senadhira Karunaratne. CID officers at the airport have taken his fingerprints to confirm his true identity. Ganemulla Sanjeewa, previously accused of masterminding the largest bank robbery in Sri Lanka in 2009, is believed to have been involved in numerous criminal activities. The details of how he managed to travel from Nepal to Sri Lanka remain undisclosed, and the CID will conduct an interrogation to uncover more information. BY Keerthi Mendis

title: Hearing of Petition concludes following Govt’s pledge
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal has opted to conclude the hearing of a petition following the Government pledge not to export toque macaques from Sri Lanka to China. This decision came during the consideration of a petition filed by a group of environmentalists who sought to halt the Government plan toexport these monkeys  to China. The hearing was presided over by President of the Court of Appeal Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and Justice Chamath Morais. During a prior hearing of the petition, the Attorney General had assured the Court that the Government had no intentions or arrangements in place for exporting monkeys. The legal representatives for the petitioners expressed satisfaction with the Government’s assurance and conveyed that there was no need to continue with the petition. Consequently, the Court of Appeal has concluded the hearing of the petition in light of the Government’s commitment.

title: Govt still behind on revenue targets – Finance Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: Despite introducing Advanced Personal Income Tax (APIT), the Government is still behind on the expected revenue targets this year, the Finance Ministry officials told the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Alleviating the Impact of the Economic Crisis. However, even at present, efforts are being made to provide relief to the affected professionals due to the tax revision, said the officials. The officials of the Inland Revenue Department stated that a special programme has been started to add persons who are not involved in the tax process. Accordingly, a new taxpayer group registration programme (Bulk Registration) has been planned for this week. The committee meeting was held last week to discuss the concerns of the professionals who are affected by the APIT Tax and provide potential solutions. During the discussion, Committee Chairman MP Gamini Waleboda, said he will intervene to take the necessary measures to present amendments to the APIT Tax in the upcoming Budget. The trade union representatives expressed their opinions at length about what was expected from the tax amendments and whether the objectives have been achieved. The representatives said many professionals have been affected by the amendments made to the APIT Tax. The committee acknowledged the seriousness of the problem given that professionals left the country due to the tax issue. The Committee, therefore, assured the trade union representatives that the Government and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) are urged to resolve this issue. The Chairman pointed out the importance of preparing a policy on how taxes should be imposed for each profession and legislating it through Parliament in the future or when tax revisions take place. Thus, the Chairman instructed trade union representatives to prepare a report on the revisions to be made to the PAYE Tax within two weeks and submit it to the committee.

title: German Tech to train SLTB technicians
author: Author not found
Content: Recruiting students through the Ceylon-German Technical Training Institute (CGTTI) to address the shortage of technicians in the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) has been given priority. A special discussion was held recently by the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Energy and Transport with regard to the matter in Parliament. Officials representing the Ministry of Transport, Sri Lanka Transport Board, Ministry of Education and the Ceylon-German Technical Training Institute were present before the committee Chaired by MP Nalaka Bandara Kottegoda. As a result, it was decided to provide a special training to a group of 50 technical students. It was discussed at length that although the Ceylon-German Technical Training Institute was established with the objective of providing training to employees of the SLTB, the requirement is not being met properly. In this context, the SLTB has requested that 50 students recruited annually to the German Technical Training Institute to be trained in the Transport Board to fill the shortage of technicians in the SLTB. It was discussed that although 600 students were recruited for the full-time course as the Ceylon-German Technical Training Institute Is held in high esteem, it is envisaged that these trainees may opt for other lucrative job opportunities. Further, concerns were raised over the shortage of trainers and lack of facilities in providing training to students. However, the Committee Chair instructed to act fast in consultation with the relevant ministries and institutions to provide the necessary training to meet the needs of technicians of the SLTB. Further, the Committee Chair instructed that the proposal to start a training centre in Kandy in conjunction with the Sri Lanka Transport Board and the Ceylon-German Technical Training Institute to be considered immediately.

title: Private medical colleges threat to health sector – MCPA
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) warned that setting up private medical colleges for profit will lead to the collapse of health services in both the State and private sectors. MCPA President, Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa, yesterday (13), accused the Government and the Health Minister of taking such decisions without proper consideration of the number of doctors required by the country, the number of medical practitioners leaving the country or the number of doctors required to run State and private sector health services. He pointed out that such a situation would only result in the collapse of the services and cast a shadow over the future of doctors emerging from these faculties. Several civil organisations staged a continuous sit-down protest (Satyagraha) outside the Health Ministry demanding the removal of Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, Health Secretary Janaka Sri Chandraguptha and several senior officials accused of corruption while calling for President Ranil Wickremesinghe to reveal the relevant agreements before setting up private medical colleges (PMCs). The MCPA President pointed out that the incumbent President had faced a severe defeat as the Prime Minister of the Government of Good Governance during the problems revolving around the South Asian Institute of Technology and Medicine (SAITM). “It is unfortunate that now as the President he was once more attempting to set up PMCs without learning from past mistakes,” he said. He alleged this was an attempt to create another crisis in the country. Dr. Sanjeewa lamented that no attempt had been made to resolve the crises in the State health service, observing that while none of the developed countries had started private medical schools, developing countries such as India, Bangladesh and Nepal had set them up to make money. “It has resulted in the question of the quality of medical services provided in those countries.” He noted that opening PMCs sans a proper knowledge of the situation would only result in the decline of the quality of the medical service provided. Dr. Sanjeewa lamented that doctors passing out from these medical schools would have to face further issues owing to the lack of postings in the private and State sector hospitals and would have to treat patients within kiosk-like spaces (petti kada). He noted that the private sector hospitals also needed only about 200 doctors. But since medical practitioners serving in the State sector also cater to private hospitals on an interim basis, the private sector hospitals don’t recruit enough permanent medical staff. The MCPA President said by producing a large number of doctors at the same time through private medical schools, exceeding the required numbers would reduce the job security of medical practitioners presently working in the State service. It would only result in more doctors leaving the country. He also urged the Health Minister to reveal to the public the nature of agreements made  with the PMCs, pointing out that the country’s entire health education system would be jeopardised should it turn out to be like the agreement that had been drawn up with SAITM. Such secrecy would only leave the students enrolled in those colleges and their parents in a dilemma, Dr. Sanjeewa warned.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Decision on acquittal request on 2 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court (CHC) Judge Navaratne Marasinghe said yesterday (13) that his decision on whether to acquit SLPP MP Namal Rajapaksa and four others, accused in a case filed against them, sans calling for submissions from the Defence, will be delivered on 2 November. The former minister and four others have been charged in the HC, with the depositing of an unlawfully accrued sum of Rs 30 million, in Gowers Corporate, while Rajapaksa had been functioning as a lawmaker. When the case was taken up, the five accused were present in Court. A leading witness for the Prosecution, Rohan Irugala, giving evidence in Court, had mentioned previously that the initial statements that he had given in the Kaduwela Chief Magistrate’s Court and to the Financial Crimes Investigation Division (FCID) were false. However, he had stated that following advice received from his mother and wife, he had proceeded to give genuine statements before the Kaduwela Chief Magistrate and the FCID. These details were revealed to Court by Defence Counsel Sampath Mendis, PC. Mendis PC stated that the probe into the case had commenced on 27 July 2015 and that the statements from the witness had been recorded for the first time, only on 8 September of that year. Mendis PC told the Court, that as it had come to light that the mother of the witness concerned had died on 9 May 2015, it was clear, that all statements recorded from the witness, had been fabrications. He informed Judge Marasinghe, that the witness concerned had also provided questionable and confusing statements, regards the cheques related to the case in question. Nalin Marapana, PC, representing the other accused persons, told the Court that the Government that had assumed power at the time, had intentionally filed the case against its political opponents, based on false evidence and to victimise its political rivals. He added that to that end, the Government at the time, had even formed the FCID and set up Special Courts, to prosecute those harbouring political views in direct opposition to it. Hence, he urged the Court to issue an order for the acquittal of his clients, from the charges filed against them, without calling for submissions from the Defence. Thereafter, Senior Deputy Solicitor General (SDSG) Dilan Ratnayake appeared in Court on behalf of the Attorney General. He said the Court has been empowered by law, to arrive at a suitable decision, regards the veracity of statements provided by the witnesses to the Prosecution and that they anticipate a just and fair decision in this regard. SDSG Ratnayake, however, added that he would not oppose the submissions produced by the lawyers for the Defence. The Judge mentioned that whether the defendants will be released from the case or not without calling for submissions, will be announced on the said date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Trusted my preparation in last 3-4 months – KL Rahul
author: Author not found
Content: Two games into the Super Four stage of the 2023 Asia Cup, India have already made significant strides. After a dominant victory over Pakistan, they faced a challenging encounter against Sri Lanka on a sluggish wicket where runs were hard to come by. For KL Rahul, it was an opportunity to scale up after a four-month-long hiatus that briefly made many believe he would be better off on the bench.  An 11th-hour injury to Shreyas Iyer opened the door for his inclusion in the Pakistan game, and Rahul proved why he is India’s best bet in the middle overs. In contrast to the Pakistan match, Rahul had to toil for his runs against Sri Lanka, facing a spin duo of Dunith Wellalage and Charith Asalanka, paying homage to Sri Lanka’s rich spin tradition. The ball spun consistently, but Rahul persevered, constructing a solid innings for himself until a moment of misjudgment led to his dismissal. “I didn’t get so much time to think about anything because it was so last moment,” Rahul said in the post-match press conference. “But I trusted my preparation in the last three or four months. I came to Sri Lanka thinking I would start in the playing XI, and that’s how I was preparing for it.  “When I played the first few balls, I tried to figure out the shots I could play on this pitch and accordingly diffuse the pressure. It was different against Pakistan because the ground allowed us to play more shots. But in this match, I am happy the shots I chose to play till I got out were good.” With India’s combination needing Rahul to bat at No.5 and keep wickets in the upcoming ICC World Cup in India, it was crucial to see how he was holding up against the likes of Ravindra Jadeja and Kuldeep Yadav. Fair to say, with the ball turning heavily, Rahul did a good job of judging the pace and getting an extremely important validation on his fitness level. The work that he has put in during the rehab process at the National Cricket Academy (NCA) helped him better himself.
