title: Santosh Jha appointed Indian HC to Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Santosh Jha has been appointed as the High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka, succeeding Gopal Bagley. Jha, who was serving as the Ambassador of India to Belgium, was officially announced as the High Commissioner to Sri Lanka yesterday. Meanwhile, High Commissioner Bagley has been appointed as the High Commissioner of India to Australia. Bagley played a crucial role in supporting Sri Lanka during the crisis it faced last year. India provided significant funding of USD 4 billion in 2022, and Bagley’s service during that time was highly appreciated. (SRM)

title: Narco control funds in developing countries underutilised
author: Author not found
Content: Funds for narcotics control provided for developing countries by donors, with prominent roles played by the United States, European Union, Japan and the United Kingdom, spent on projects in developing countries, were unspecified, an international report titled ‘Aid For The War on Drugs’, published by Harm Reduction International (HRI), a non-governmental organisation revealed. The organisation is committed to leveraging data and advocacy to advance harm reduction and promote reforms in drug policy. The report was launched in Colombo on 12 September. In 2021, more aid money for narcotics control overall was spent on projects in developing countries was unspecified. This is but one major example of many significant gaps in the data examined. The report says many records have only very brief entries in project description fields; some have no detail at all, or only code words used for the narcotics control projects in developing countries.  “One UK aid record, for example, says ‘Romeo / Delta / Foxtrot’ in its description, with no explanation. In 2021, when the US significantly increased the amount of its aid spent on narcotics control, most of its records were redacted (edited),” the report said. In total, aid funding for narcotics control has been channeled to 92 developing countries worldwide. For more detailed information on the top 20 recipient countries, it’s worth noting that some funds were also allocated to regional programmes, as indicated by the available data. The report continues to say at least 115 countries around the world criminalise even limited amounts of drugs for personal possession.  Wealthy and powerful countries, such as the US, China, and Russia continue to exert influence over drug policy globally. They do this through funding flows as well as the provision of material resources and technical assistance for counter-narcotics initiatives, and the ongoing promotion of a prohibitionist moral consensus. Some have described these power dynamics and imbalances affecting countries such as Colombia as narco-colonialism. This substantial financial support was contributed by numerous donors, with prominent roles played by the United States, European Union, Japan and the United Kingdom. Over the course of a decade, from 2012 to 2021, more than USD 974 million in aid funding was allocated for narcotics control projects in various countries across the globe. Civil society and journalists ought to advocate for increased transparency in the allocation and utilisation of aid funds and hold more extensive and comprehensive investigations into the allocation of funds for “narcotics control” in various countries noted the report. The US has not only assisted in the development of stringent drug laws but has also supported initiatives related to anti-drug awareness and education campaigns. Significantly, a portion of these funds, amounting to at least USD 70 million throughout the studied period, was directed towards countries that enforce the death penalty for drug-related offenses, the report says. This situation raises grave concerns regarding whether aid budgets have inadvertently supported regimes that carry out executions. In 2021, the largest individual recipient of such aid was Colombia, receiving USD 109 million, followed by Afghanistan with USD 37 million, Peru with USD 27 million, Mexico with USD 21 million, and both Guatemala and Panama, each receiving approximately USD 10 million.   Though data availability and transparency vary across projects and donors, this analysis reveals how aid money has supported approaches that undermine global development goals and “do no harm” principles. Analysis of this data reveals that aid donors have spent almost a billion dollars of this money on “narcotics control” efforts around the world. Specifically: at least USD 974 million was spent this way over the ten years between 2012- 2021. In Myanmar, the State Department’s Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement (INL) says it has not only helped to establish the country’s first national drug control policy, and build the capacity of the country’s Drug Enforcement Division (in partnership with the DEA), but it has also funded ‘the development of creative drug awareness campaigns in Burma’ (without further details disclosed).    UK aid for narcotics control declined over the 10-year period examined, from more than USD 10 million in 2012 to USD 2 million by 2019 and then to nothing by 2021. It is unclear what drove these changes – or for how long they will last. It is also not clear how UK aid spent on narcotics control aligned with the priorities of poverty reduction and gender equality enshrined in UK law. EU Institutions spent the second largest amount of aid on narcotics control between 2012- 2021. In several specific years, however, EU Institutions actually spent more aid like this than the US (for example, in 2016, they recorded USD 55 million in aid for narcotics control, versus USD 16 million from the US).   By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: 118 train journeys cancelled
author: Author not found
Content: The strike launched by the Railway Locomotive Operating Engineers’ Union yesterday (12) turned into a tragedy, leaving an 18-year-old youth dead and another youth hospitalised with serious injuries, when they were on board overcrowded trains. Several morning and evening office trains were cancelled, severely inconveniencing passengers, who were already at railway stations, especially in the morning. In a tragic turn of events, a student of the Moratuwa University lost his life, when he fell from the roof of a train at Horape, on the Kandy-Colombo run. The Police identified the deceased as W.W.I.D. Perera (18), hailing from the Moragoda in Gampaha. A senior official from the Railway Department announced that an investigation will be launched to determine the circumstances of this tragic incident. It is suspected that the young man may have fallen from the train’s roof after coming into contact with either a tree or a cable. In the evening, another passenger fell from a train, running on the main line, at the Bulagahagoda Substation and was subsequently admitted to Teaching Hospital Ragama. During this incident, a slow train bound for Gampaha was halted at the second platform. Simultaneously, a train moving in the same direction from the first platform struck a bag hanging on the back of a passenger, causing the passenger to fall. The injured individual is a young man estimated to be between the ages of 20 and 25. Sources have reported that he sustained injuries to his arm and spine as a result of the accident. As a result of trade union actions, a total of 118 scheduled train services had to be cancelled, causing significant inconvenience to the general public, as reported by the Sri Lanka Railways Station Masters’ Union (SLRSMU). The SLRSMU indicated that on the previous day (11), eleven scheduled train services had to be cancelled due to a lengthy trade union strike organised by the Railway Locomotive Operating Engineers’ Union. However, in response to the strike, the Department of Railways took measures to provide some relief by running several train services on the following day. Specifically, four trains operated on the Kelani Valley line, while 12 trains were in service on the mainline. Additionally, six train services were available on the Puttalam line, and 12 on the coastal line. Furthermore, the Railways Department assured the public that all necessary arrangements had been put in place to ensure the operation of all night mail trains on that day. President Ranil Wickremesinghe on the same day issued a gazette extraordinary making the train service an essential service with immediate effect. The gazette was issued by the President under the Compulsory Public Service Act. Meanwhile, in an unprecedented act, Cabinet Spokesperson and Minister of Transport Bandula Gunawardena led a moment of silence during the Cabinet media briefing held at the Department of Government Information to address the decisions taken by the Cabinet of Ministers. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: AG’s stand on Udayanga’s Motion today
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta, yesterday (12) instructed Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, to inform Court today (13), about his stand on a motion, filed by former Sri Lankan Envoy to Russia Udayanga Weeratunga, seeking an order to release cash contained in two of his frozen bank accounts. Through his motion, the former Sri Lankan Ambassador, has stated that money contained in two of his bank accounts, has been frozen, after he was accused of illegally accruing it, while unlawfully intervening in the controversial MIG aircraft deal for the Sri Lanka Air Force. He has also been accused of alleged embezzlement of public funds, with regard to procurement of MIG aircraft and money laundering. Weeratunga, in an affidavit had previously mentioned to Court, that the money that has been deposited in his accounts, had been the salary that he had received while serving as the Lankan Envoy to Moscow, over a period of nine years and the money which he had saved, before the MIG aircraft scandal emerged. President’s Counsel Anil Silva, representing the petitioner, informed Judge Thotawatta, that his client’s bank accounts had been suspended unilaterally over the past 24 months and that due to this situation, his client had been forced to undergo severe economic strain, even being unable to spend for his children’s education etc. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: CG of Immigration to testify on 31 Oct
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, yesterday (12) notified a group of persons, including former Controller General of the Department of Immigration and Emigration, Chulananda Perera to testify on behalf of the prosecution, in the case filed against Sashi Weerawansa, (wife of MP Wimal Weerawansa), on 31 October. Sashi Weerawansa is charged with the use of a forged NIC. The case in question was previously heard before Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis. Following an Order issued by him the case was transferred to the Colombo Additional Magistrate’s Court. Accordingly, the case was called before Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya yesterday. A request made to Court, by President’s Counsel Nalin Ladduwahetty, on behalf of Weerawansa, to obtain documents and evidence currently in possession of the High Court, which is perusing an appeal in this connection, to be used in the ongoing case, was granted. Court approved the Defence filing initial objections pertaining to the case and deferred further hearing to the said date. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Murali biopic ‘800’ faces backlash
author: Author not found
Content: Minister Jeevan Thondaman has written to the director of the Murali biopic ‘800’ which features the life of Sri Lankan cricketing hero, Muttiah Muralitharan, expressing deep concern about the use of a derogatory term directed at the Upcountry Tamils of Indian origin in the movie. According to the film director, he has taken prompt action to remove the offensive term. The biopic’s official trailer was launched on 5 September. The derogatory remark in the film sparked a significant reaction on social media, leading to calls for a boycott of the movie ‘800’ directed by M.S. Sripathy. Even MP Mano Ganesan expressed criticism, on social media, concerning the film’s introduction by actor Nassar, where he used the derogatory term to depict the story of Muralitharan, resulting in strong objections within the Tamil-speaking community. Given the current situation, the film director has assured that the derogatory term has been promptly removed from ‘800’ to address the concerns of the public. Minister Thondaman has been formally informed of this action through a letter. Initially, South Indian actor Vijay Sethupathi was chosen to portray the role of Muralitharan, but he faced strong backlash from fans, who believed that the cricketer had been politically involved in Sri Lanka and had denied certain aspects of the 30-year war. He was warned against portraying his character. In response to the agitation the controversy surrounding his casting, actor Sethupathi decided to reject the offer. Subsequently, a North Indian actor Madhur Mittal who acted in the movie ‘Slumdog Millionaire’ was cast as Muralitharan in ‘800’. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Catholic Church rejects new PSC into Easter attacks
author: Author not found
Content: The Catholic Church of Sri Lanka said it was not prepared to accept any more committees, whether it is a Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PcoI) or Parliamentary Select Committee (PSC), to probe the Channel 4 documentary on the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. Addressing the media at the Colombo Archbishop’s House, Spokesman for the Colombo Archdiocese, Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando yesterday (12), said the nation at large was aware that three commissions of inquiry and a parliamentary committee were appointed since the Easter Sunday attacks. Though they submitted reports and recommendations, none of them yielded the expected results, he charged, noting that only millions in public funds and precious time had been wasted.  Fr. Cyril Gamini said at the time the carnage took place President Ranil Wickremesinghe was the Prime Minister in the government of good governance and PSCs were appointed by him at that time. “Therefore, Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith and the Catholic Church of Sri Lanka have serious doubts as to whether another Parliamentary Select Committee would conduct an impartial and honest investigation. “Such a committee only aimed at misleading the public while incurring further wastage of time and money. Therefore, the Catholic Church of the country is unwilling to accept such a proposal,” he said. The Spokesman for the Colombo Archdiocese said urgent steps should be taken to initiate an unbiased, fair and transparent investigation of unexamined details surrounding the Easter Sunday attacks. He said the probe should be conducted under the extensive monitoring and supervision of an independent international investigation team. He stressed that the investigation team, appointed to conduct the independent probe, should include all investigators who have been transferred to different areas from the Criminal Investigation Department (CID), which conducted the initial investigation into the Easter Sunday attacks. Fr. Fernando said that all officers who were found guilty of having failed to prevent the attack by the Supreme Court but continued to serve in the Police Force should be suspended till the investigations were completed. President Ranil Wickremesinghe decided to form a PCoI, headed by a Supreme Court Justice to carry out an investigation related to the Channel 4 documentary on the 21 April 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. It was also reported that a PSC too would be appointed to probe the controversial statement of former Attorney General Dappula de Livera, that there was a ‘mastermind’ behind the terror attack. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: ‘I gave interview to ITN, not Channel 4’
author: Author not found
Content: Former MP and Sri Lankan Ambassador to Switzerland Sarrath Kongahage, clarifying his statements on the Easter Sunday attacks featured in the recent Channel 4 documentary alleged that he gave the interview to the London ITN channel and not to Channel 4. Kongahage made this clarification during a press conference held at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute (SLFI) yesterday (12). He explained that two representatives from the ITN channel had visited his home during the controversy and conducted a two-hour interview. During the media briefing, Kongahage condemned the Channel 4 documentary on the Easter Sunday attacks, calling it “fictitious” and “controversial”. He has also accused the Tamil Diaspora of funding the channel in order to create problems in Sri Lanka. “It is important to remember that the Easter Sunday attacks were a tragedy that claimed the lives of over 250 people. It is also important to remember that the perpetrators of these attacks were Muslim extremists, not the Tamil Diaspora. The best way to move forward is to work together to promote peace and reconciliation in Sri Lanka. This can only be achieved if we are willing to listen to each other and to learn from the past,” he said. Speaking further, Kongahage said he hopes that the Channel 4 documentary will spark a much-needed conversation about the Easter Sunday attacks and the challenges facing Sri Lanka today. “However, it is important to remember that this is a complex issue and that there is no easy solution. We must all work together to find a way to heal the wounds of the past and to build a better future for all Sri Lankans,” he said. He accused Channel 4 of attempting to blame the Easter Sunday terror attack on former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa. Kongahage argued that the attack was carried out by Muslim extremists who were motivated by their extremist beliefs and targeted innocent people. Kongahage expressed his disappointment with two individuals from Channel 4, who, along with Farasz Shaukath Ali (who currently resides in the United Kingdom), alleging that they deceived him by pretending to be from UK’s ITN. “They subsequently aired the interview on their own channel, distorting the truth,” he said. He added that a local channel had provided video footage related to the Easter Sunday terror attack. Kongahage accused the Diaspora of attempting to create tension between Sri Lanka and India. He believed that reconciliation in Sri Lanka could only be achieved if all citizens come together regardless of religious, communal, caste, or other divisive factors. He criticised Channel 4 for not being neutral and suggested that they catered to the Diaspora and LTTE loyalists, often placing blame solely on the Sinhala community. He claimed that there was evidence pointing to Muslim extremists as responsible for the Easter Sunday attack, citing discussions with former MP Ranjan Ramanayake and former CID Director Shani Abeysekara. Kongahage expressed support for an international investigation but insisted that they must be conducted impartially and fairly. He urged Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa to seek the truth, especially considering that his father was also a victim of the LTTE. Kongahage called for inquiries into LTTE-related murders, citing internationally recognised reports such as the Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission (LLRC) and those by Udulagama, Paranagama, among others. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: DMT to operate online by year end
author: Author not found
Content: The Government will introduce the proposed e-motoring system by the year’s end, following the resolution of various challenges, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said. Ceylon Today, in yesterday’s edition, revealed that despite the pledges, the Government has failed to implement the proposed system, which will enable the Department of Motor Traffic to conduct its operations o online. During the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (12), Gunawardena confirmed that the final decision to implement the e-motoring system had been taken. While Cabinet approval has already been obtained, the system’s launch will require additional time due to the necessity of receiving reports from several professional committees. “We have secured a building near Gangaramaya, in Colombo, for this purpose. This building must undergo evaluation by Government assessors, and we deem it essential to establish the necessary administrative infrastructure for the system,” he explained. Minister Gunawardana acknowledged that despite strenuous efforts, the current procurement and other procedural requirements are time-consuming. Attempting to bypass these processes could lead to accusations of programme mismanagement. Nevertheless, as a solution aimed at simplifying vehicle registrations, reducing corruption, and curbing fraudulent activities, the e-motoring system is expected to be operational by the end of this year, Gunawardena assured. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Lanka rejects resolutions, recommendations
author: Author not found
Content: At the 54th Session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, Sri Lanka said  the Government has consistently rejected Resolutions 46/1 and 51/1 that led to the setting up of the so-called ‘Accountability Project’ and also reject the written update, its conclusions and recommendations. However, the Sri Lankan President has outlined the Government’s vision and the progress made in reconciliation efforts undertaken, inter alia, in legislative reforms, institutional activities, addressing land issues, resettlement of IDPs, North- East Development Plan, and 13th Amendment. “All Party Conferences have been convened to consolidate political support for these reconciliation efforts,” Himalee Arunatilaka, Permanent Representative of Sri Lanka to the United Nations in Geneva, said. She added, “Human Rights pursuant to HRC Resolution 51/1, 11 September 2023, are intrusive and polarising and it is upheld only by a handful of countries for reasons unrelated to human rights, and based on their vote bank domestic politics. “We recall that the majority of the Member States either opposed or abstained from voting on these Resolutions, in fundamental disagreement with its unacceptable content in particular the so-called evidence gathering mechanism, the establishment of which is unprecedented. We reiterate that it goes beyond the mandate that Member States conferred on the Council by UNGA Resolution 60/251.” “However, Sri Lanka remains firmly committed to pursuing tangible progress on human rights through our domestic institutions and have made significant progress” Himalee added and said the Anti-Corruption Act No. 09 of 2023 passed by the Parliament has strengthened the financial and functional independence of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery and Corruption. “Deliberations continue on the draft Anti-Terrorism Bill, while remaining committed to having the draft law in line with international standards.Tangible progress has been made by independent domestic mechanisms inter alia, the Office on Missing Persons (OMP), Office for Reparations (OR), and Office for National Unity and Reconciliation (ONUR), details of which have been provided in our written observations to the Report. “The Interim Secretariat of the Truth and Reconciliation Mechanism is established. The proposed truth-seeking mechanism has been identified as a meaningful way to secure the peace achieved after three decades of brutal conflict. Consultations are ongoing with stakeholders including the civil society on the proposed mechanism, she added. Himalee reiterated that the Government has provided our observations in detail with regard to this written update, which intends to cover grave distortions in the written update of the OHCHR and its misrepresentation of the current ground situation in Sri Lanka.  “We request that this response be given equal visibility as the OHCHR report. “Notwithstanding our position on the HRC Resolution, as a responsible member of the international community, Sri Lanka will continue to engage constructively with the UN and its agencies, in keeping with domestic priorities and policies as well as the international obligations voluntarily undertaken. Many countries have already raised serious concerns on the budgetary implications of this Resolution given its dubious mandate. Sri Lanka has repeatedly pointed out that this is an unproductive and unhelpful drain on the resources of the Council and its Members. For all the reasons stated above, Sri Lanka will not cooperate with it. However, as an active participant of the multilateral framework and in keeping with our close engagement with the international community and the Council in other areas of its work, Sri Lanka will continue to engage constructively with other mechanisms of the Council that have been productive and beneficial to our people such as the UPR process,” she further added. (SRM)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CID records statement from Nagamuwa
author: Author not found
Content: Politburo member of the Frontline Socialist Party (FSP), Duminda Nagamuwa, arrived at the Criminal Investigation Department yesterday (12) morning to provide a statement with regard to his allegation against Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage had issued an Order for Duminda Nagamuwa to appear at the Digital Forensic Division of the Criminal Investigation Department yesterday (12) at 9.00 a.m. This summons was issued in connection with statements made on Facebook and YouTube channels that were deemed offensive to the Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles. Minister Alles had previously stated at a press conference that although Police officers had attempted to contact Duminda Nagamuwa for questioning, they were unable to locate him. BY Tharaka Samman

title: Cabinet nod to import new rechargeable electric vehicles
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the import of new rechargeable electric vehicles, exempt from Customs tariff, not exceeding USD 30,000, including insurance and shipping charges, for certain investment projects under BOI programmes. The Government said it has been decided to import new rechargeable electric vehicles without Customs tariff in a bid to attract investments. Cabinet approved the import of electric vehicles subject to an exemption of custom tariffs to an amount not exceeding USD 30,000. Insurance and shipping charges related to projects that fulfil the required criteria will also be included in the exemption to attract various investments under the programmes ‘Retaining and extending investors for re-investment of existing board of investment approved companies’ and ‘The 100 service companies programme that are Board of Investment’s information technology and companies empowered by information technology’. Meanwhile, Cabinet approved a second proposal related to the matter pertaining to the local assembly of electric vehicles. A zero (0%) customs tariff was decided on the CIF value when importing electric vehicles, electric two-wheelers with a power grade up to 500 kW and modern partially assembled Semi-Knocked Down (SKD) sets with an engine capacity up to 3000 CC for assembling plug-in hybrid electric vehicles for  investors that engage them for electric vehicles and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles for a minimum investment of USD 50 million by companies already approved by the Board of Investment (BOI) or new companies entering into agreements. The proposal was approved by Cabinet to encourage the manufacture of electric vehicles locally.

title: France funds satellite-based oil spill detection mission for MEPA
author: Author not found
Content: The Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU), yesterday (12) in Colombo, with the French company CLS, a subsidiary of the French Space Agency (CNES) and CNP, a pioneer provider of monitoring and surveillance solutions for the Earth since 1986, to detect oil leaks from ships in Sri Lankan waters, using satellite images. It has become important to monitor, as on average, 350 ships sail through Sri Lanka’s Economic Exclusion Zone (EEZ) every day, increasing the risk of pollution from both accidental spills and illegal discharges. The French company is said to provide images when Sri Lanka wanted and they will be continuously monitoring the seas, MEPA Chairman Asela Rakeva said. He said the images will also look around ships and boats in the Sri Lankan waters and monitor the movements to track oil spills. The support from France was initiated two years ago when the Xpress Pearl disaster occurred in Sri Lankan waters. “The agreements were initiated and finalised during my tenure,” said former MEPA Chairman Dharshani Lahandapura and she added they had lengthy discussions with French delegates including French ambassador and CLS representatives. The French company developing satellite-based solutions for a sustainable planet and a leading player in maritime safety, is stepping up to help protect Sri Lanka’s waters with a pilot project, to detect and monitor marine oil spills for MEPA   Chairman Rakeva said. He said that Sri Lanka, nestled in the heart of the Indian Ocean with a strategic position along major shipping routes and boasting several commercial harbours managing over 5,000 ships annually, faces an elevated risk of oil pollution in its waters. Recent maritime incidents underscore this risk and emphasise the urgent need for a robust maritime disaster response mechanism. Recognising the importance to swiftly identify and address oil pollution occurrences  in Sri Lankan waters, as well as hold accountable those responsible, the collaborative endeavour, ‘Pioneering Project for Marine Oil Spill Detection and Monitoring in Sri Lanka’, generously funded by the French Government, marks a significant milestone. CLS Head of International Development, Sophie Besnard, added that CLS is proud to be involved in this initiative crucial to preserving Sri Lanka’s waters and maritime safety. “Working with dedicated partners and using state-of-the-art technologies, we are resolutely committed to preserving the environment and ensuring a sustainable future for Sri Lanka. We thank the Sri Lankan authorities and MEPA for putting their faith in us.” The project is financed by a grant from the French Ministry of the Economy, Finance and Industrial and Digital Sovereignty of France and supported by the French Embassy in Sri Lanka, with the close collaboration of its Department of Treasury and Economic Affairs. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SL participates at the WorldFood Istanbul Trade Fair 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Türkiye coordinated Sri Lanka’s participation at the WorldFood Istanbul Trade Fair at the TÜYAP Fair and Congress Centre in Istanbul from 6 to 9 September. Ceylon Tea Land Pvt. Ltd, Uniworld Teas Pvt. Ltd., Heritage Teas Pvt. Ltd. and Vintage Teas Ceylon Pvt. Ltd. had their products showcased in the ‘Ceylon Tea’ Pavilion organised by the Sri Lanka Tea Board in conjunction with the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Türkiye. In addition, MJF Exports Pvt. Ltd, Imperial Teas Group of Companies and McCoy Ceylon Commodities Pvt. Ltd. also represented the Tea sector. Further, NDC Exports Pvt. Ltd. and Manchee De Coco Products Pvt. Ltd. exhibited coconut-based food products at the Fair. This is the largest F&B  sector Exhibition in Eurasia and is on its way to becoming one of the largest F&B sector Exhibitions globally. For 30 years, WorldFood Istanbul has been the meeting point for International F&B Producers and Türkiye’s key buyers. It’s the ideal place for foreign firms to explore the Turkish food sector, network with important industry figures and buyers, and promote their products in an exciting new market. As a B2B event, WorldFood Istanbul is the perfect platform for growing sales and attracting new clients in the USD One Billion food import sector of Türkiye. WorldFood Istanbul is a platform where many Local and Foreign Brands are showcased and where the F&B sector is represented by all stakeholders, from Producers to Entrepreneurs. In 2022, 835 exhibitors from 25 countries and 38,358 visitors from 163 countries were at the WorldFood Istanbul. Figures for this year’s Fair are yet to be announced. In parallel to attending the WorldFood Istanbul to facilitate Sri Lanka’s participation, the Minister (Commercial) of the Sri Lanka Embassy in Türkiye Thavishya Mullegamgoda had mutually beneficial meetings with the Foreign Economic Relations Board (DEIK), Istanbul Chamber of Commerce, Independent Industrialists and Businessmen’s Association (MÜSİAD), Association of Turkish Travel Agencies (TÜRSAB), Turkish Industry and Business Association (TÜSİAD) and the Türkiye Exporters Assembly (TİM), all offices of which are located in Istanbul.

title: PM discusses early implementation of Lower Malwathu Oya hydro-solar-irrigation project as a PPP
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena discussed the possibility of early resumption of the Lower Malwathu Oya hydro-solar-electricity-irrigation project, as a Public-Private Partnership Project with foreign investments. The Chinese investors who built the Yan Oya Dam called on the Prime Minister at the Temple Trees on Monday (11) to discuss the Prime Minister’s proposal to install solar panels on Yan Oya reservoir as well as the proposed Malwathu Oya reservoir to generate 100 megawatt electricity and irrigate 22,000 hectares of land in Anuradhapura and Trincomalee districts. The Chinese investment team headed by Senior Business Manager Andrew Yang said Yan Oya reservoir could be used as a mega solar power generation platform by installing floating solar panels. Such a project could generate electricity for the national grid and also earn funds for completion of the Lower Malwathu Oya Project. The proposed project cost will be USD 160 million and in the first phase, floating solar panels will be placed on Yan Oya reservoir and generate 50 megawatt electricity that could be sold to the national grid. Once the MalwathuOya reservoir is completed in two years solar panels could be installed to adder another 50 megawatts. In addition to that MalawathuOya mini hydro system will generate 1,6 megawatts. Former Minister S. M. Chandrasena said the first survey and feasibility study for Lower MalwathuOya Project was done more than a decade ago when he was Deputy Minister of Irrigation. He thanked the Premier for the steps taken to resume the project that would irrigate land in Anuradhapura and Trincomalee districts to boost rice and cash crop production. The Chinese investors would assist the farmers to grow rice and cash crops and export part of the production to China. Additional Secretary Mahinda Gunaratne, senior officials and project evaluators took part in the discussion.

title: BASL President, members meet Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: A group of members of the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) including its President Attorney at Law Kaushalya Navaratne met the Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena in Parliament yesterday (11). Deputy President of BASL, Attorney at Law Nalinda Indratissa, Secretary, Attorney at Law  Isuru Balapatabedi, Treasurer Attorney at Law   Chamath Jayasekara, Assistant Secretary Attorney at Law Mehran Karim were also present at the meeting.

title: COPE praises Kalubovitiyana Tea Factory
author: Author not found
Content: The Kalubovitiyana Tea Factory Limited was praised by the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) for the progress it has made in 2021 and 2022. During the meeting, the Auditor General pointed out that the recommendations given by COPE in 2013 have been followed to an extent of ninety-five per cent and great progress has been achieved through high management skills. The company was summoned to the COPEwhich met last week chaired by Prof. Ranjith Bandara The Auditor General’s 2021, 2022 reports and current performance of that institution were examined at this Committee meeting held. A group of officials including Janaka Dharmakirthi, Secretary to the Ministry of Plantation Industry, Aminda Rodrigo, Chairman of the Kalubovitiyana Tea Factory Limited, were also present at this Committee. Addressing the committee, the Chairman of Kalubovitiyana Tea Factory Limited said that in 2022,the highest income of the company was two billion rupees and a profit of Rs 214 million following the payment of tax was also recorded. He pointed out that there are four tea factories in Matara, Galle and Kandy districts and they have successfully overcome many challenges including obtaining tea leaves. The Chairman of the company also stated that the company has shown success by adhering to the existing rules of the Government as a public institution. Although the company is small, the Auditor General said that this State-owned company has shown great progress in terms of accounts and financial statements. He appreciated the company and mentioned that it has been a long time since he met such a progressive institution. Attention was directed on recovering the amount of Rs 1.4 million which is the deposit amount paid when acquiring the building where the Head Office was maintained by the company on amonthly rental basis. The officials stated that a case is being filed. In 2003, even though the loan amount given to a State-owned company at the interest rate of 22% was recovered, the interest was not charged. The officials also said that the company has assured that it will pay the interest amount of Rs 51 million in instalment.

title: Rear Admiral Dammika Kumara pays a courtesy call on Premitha Bandara Tennakoon
author: Author not found
Content: Newly appointed Vice-Chancellor (VC) of General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University (KDU) Rear Admiral Dammika Kumara made his maiden call on the State Minister of Defence, Premitha Bandara Tennakoon at the State Ministry of Defence on Monday (11). Minister Tennakoon warmly received the VC at the Ministry and had a cordial discussion with him. During the meeting, the Minister also extended his compliments to the VC in his new role while expressing his expectation that the KDU would further soar to greater heights. Following the discussion, Rear Admiral Kumara presented a Souvenir to the State Minister to mark the occasion. Rear Admiral Dammika Kumara assumed duties as the VC-KDU on 1 September.

title: SL Has Completed 19.4% of 2015 UNHRC Resolution Commitments
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka has completed 19.4% of the measures it committed to implement under the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) Resolution 30/1 as of August 2023, according to the UNHRC Monitor published by Verité Research. However, 61.1% of the commitments in the resolution – which was co-sponsored by Sri Lanka – have seen ‘poor’ or ‘no’ progress, eight years since it was adopted in October 2015. The ‘UNHRC Monitor’ of Verité Research is the first and only monitor of its kind which objectively tracks the implementation of Resolution 30/1. A written update on Sri Lanka is scheduled to be delivered at the 54th Regular Session of the UNHRC on 11 September. Resolution 30/1 contained 36 distinct actionable commitments. Of these commitments, 7 (19.4%) are classified in the UNHRC Monitor as ‘complete’, 7 as ‘partial progress’ (19.4%), 18 as ‘poor progress’ (50%), and 4 as ‘no progress’ (11.1%). These commitments fall into five broad thematic categories: Rights and Rule of Law (15 commitments), Transitional Justice and Reconciliation (9), Security and Demilitarisation (7), International Engagement (3) and Power Sharing (2). The seven completed commitments are: (1) engage in broad transitional justice processes; (2) establish the Office on Missing Persons; (3) establish the Office for Reparations; (4) sign and ratify the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearances; (5) criminalise enforced disappearances; (6) continue engagement between the Government of Sri Lanka and the OHCHR; and (7) cooperate with special procedure mandate holders. There are seven commitments that remain partially fulfilled, including: (1) publishing previous presidential commission reports and (2) issuing Certificates of Absence to families of missing persons. Some of the key commitments which remain at ‘poor progress’ since 2015 are: (1) restore normality to civilian life; (2) investigate attacks on journalists, human rights defenders, religious minorities, and civil society; (3) hold perpetrators of these attacks to account; and (4) prevent such attacks in the future. The commitment to set up a judicial mechanism with a special counsel and foreign participation, to investigate violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, has remained at ‘no progress’ since February 2018. Since 2015, successive governments have also not made any progress on the commitment to review the Public Security Ordinance. At the 34th UNHRC session held in March 2017, the Sri Lankan government co-sponsored Resolution 34/1 – which reaffirmed the Resolution 30/1 commitments. At the 40th session in March 2019, the government co-sponsored Resolution 40/1, which also reaffirmed its commitments to reconciliation envisaged in Resolution 30/1. However, in February 2020, the Sri Lankan government informed the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) of its decision to withdraw from co-sponsorship of Resolution 40/1 of 2019, and its preceding resolutions 34/1 of March 2017, and 30/1 of October 2015. Verité Research has released analyses of progress in fulfilling the commitments in Resolution 30/1 in June 2016, March 2017, February 2018, March 2019, February 2020, February 2021, March 2022, February 2023 and August 2023.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CEJ informs Court it is preparing programme
author: Author not found
Content: The Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) yesterday (12) informed the Court of Appeal, that it is preparing a sustainable programme to reduce the Human-Elephant Conflict (HEC). The case was heard before the Appellate Court Bench comprising Justices Sampath K. B. Wijeratne and M. A. R. Marikkar. The lawyers for the CEJ informed the Court that their client was already in the process of obtaining the views of the public and scholars towards formulating a sustainable mechanism to minimise the human-elephant conflict nationwide. They stated that already a series of meetings had also been held with the input of relevant stakeholders as well. The lawyers added that all suggestions and proposals received in this connection will be submitted to Court, in the form of a dossier, in due course. Additional Solicitor General Parinda Ranasinghe appearing for the respondents said that already a programme aimed at reducing the human-elephant conflict had been compiled three years ago and that it should also be considered by the petitioners. The petitioners informed the Court that they will be considering it as well as new ideas and opinions put forth by the public and scholars in formulating the latest programme. The Court later fixed the next hearing for 22 November.

title: Judicial independence under threat – BASL
author: Author not found
Content: The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL), while noting that the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary are being affected by statements made by certain MPs, expressed its concerns and displeasure on the same when a group including its President, Attorney-at-Law Kaushalya Navaratne met Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana in Parliament on Monday (11). Therefore, the President of the Bar Association requested the Speaker to pay attention to this matter and handed over a written request to this end. During the meeting, Navaratne said the Bar Association has observed that the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary are being affected by statements made by certain MPs, inside and outside the chamber regarding Court cases and judges, in the recent past. He said the Bar Association expresses its regret over this situation as it was also observed that statements were issued mentioning the names of serving judges. The Speaker assured that he will always stand to protect the honour of the judiciary including judges and draw the attention of MPs in this regard. Deputy President of BASL, Attorney-at-Law Nalinda Indatissa, Secretary, Attorney-at-Law Isuru Balapatabendi, Treasurer, Attorney-at-Law Chamath Jayasekara, and Assistant Secretary, Attorney-at-Law Mehran Karim were also in attendance.

title: Probe on to find buses plying sans permits
author: Author not found
Content: Following the finding of two buses, engaging in passenger transportation, without proper route permits, the Central Provincial Road Passenger Transport Authority has initiated an investigation to determine whether there are more buses operating without permits. One of the buses operates between Kandy and Nuwara Eliya, while the other serves the Hatton – Nuwara Eliya route. Meanwhile it was also found that a luxury bus, running between Hatton and Nuwara Eliya, had plied the route for approximately six years without obtaining a passenger transport licence. The investigating committee, appointed to address this issue, has taken action against several individuals. They have ordered the transfer of the manager of the Nuwara Eliya District Transport Service Authority, officials responsible for overseeing the matter and officers-in-charge of the Hatton and Nuwara Eliya bus stations. Moreover, the committee has recommended further disciplinary and legal measures be taken against those involved. Central Province Governor Lalith U. Gamage appointed a committee, headed by Central Province Cooperative Development Commissioner Amila Navaratne, about a month ago to conduct this investigation. Provincial Sports Director S.M.C. Samarakoon also serves as a committee member. The committee has found fault with the officers responsible for the Hatton and Nuwara Eliya bus stations and the road inspectors for their failure to monitor and report the bus in question, on the Nuwara Eliya – Hatton route, over the course of several years. Additionally, the committee holds the Acting Deputy General Manager (Running) of the Transport Service Authority’s main office, the Officer-in-Charge of Nuwara Eliya District Management M. Basnayake, and other officials from the Nuwara Eliya District Office accountable for not providing accurate reports and monitoring. The committee recommended that the financial losses incurred by the transport authority, due to the operation of a bus without a passenger transport licence for nearly six years, as well as the failure to maintain proper log sheets, should be calculated and charged from the officials who were responsible to oversee the route. Furthermore, the Central Provincial Road Passenger Transport Authority has lodged a complaint with the Police and initiated an investigation into another bus that has operated illegally between Kandy and Nuwara Eliya for an extended period. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Career guidance seminar fostering informed career choices
author: Author not found
Content: A career guidance seminar organised by the Batch of ‘99 of St. Joseph’s College, Maradana, took place at the Bonjean Hall of the College on 12 September. Nearly 355 students participated. The seminar was to raise awareness among students and assist them in understanding and choosing a suitable profession from the diverse range of opportunities available, moving beyond traditional career paths. Shenal Kolonne, Vice President of Virtusa and Chairman of the sCommittee of the seminar, explained that the programme was designed to provide guidance to G.C.E. A/L students to select a suitable profession or higher education path while still in school or following graduation. He emphasised the importance of empowering students to make independent decisions about their future careers, free from pressure from parents or others.” Sri Lanka offers a wide array of professions, many of which can be lucrative, but due to a lack of awareness, many educated young individuals miss out on these opportunities. The goal is to nurture more professionals from this college who can contribute to the economic advancement of the country”, he further said. Kolonne pointed out that, unfortunately, many parents impose their own desires on their sons and daughters when it comes to selecting a G.C.E. A/L stream, often overlooking their children’s aptitude for specific subjects. This approach, he said does not benefit the students and can lead to compromising their future endeavours. Kolonne expressed confidence that St. Joseph’s College will produce a greater number of professionals capable of serving the nation and contributing positively to the country’s development. This initiative reflects a commitment to fostering informed and purposeful career choices among young students, ultimately benefitting both the individuals and the nation as a whole. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: President has called for impartial probe
author: Author not found
Content: In light of the controversial documentary broadcasted by the London-based Channel 4 TV channel regarding the 21 April 2019, Easter Sunday terror attacks, the political landscape of our country has become increasingly complex and President Ranil Wickremesinghe has been actively addressing this matter, prioritising the need for transparent and impartial investigations, former UNP MP Ashu Marasinghe said yesterday (12). He also highlighted that President Wickremesinghe has taken steps to appoint a parliamentary select committee to investigate this issue. Additionally, then President Maithripala Sirisena had formed a committee to inquire into the Easter Sunday terror attacks. During a media briefing held at Sirikotha, Marasinghe said a committee, led by a former Supreme Court Judge, has been appointed to investigate allegations made in the Channel 4 video. Prof. Marasinghe emphasised that, as per former Attorney General Dappula de Livera’s statement, “any citizen can submit complaints or provide information regarding the individuals behind the Easter Sunday terror attacks. This is a right afforded to every citizen in Sri Lanka. Even the Cardinal, a revered religious figure, has the authority to share his concerns and information with the select committee regarding the attacks.” Marasinghe also pointed out that the Easter Sunday terror attacks led to the downfall of the UNP. “Recently, SLPP MP Dullas Alahapperuma announced his support for Opposition Leader Premadasa in the upcoming Presidential Election. This matter did not raise concerns previously, but the SJB’s decision to bring it up now seems indicative of the party’s struggles,” he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Watermelon prices dip, farmers lament absence of fair pricing
author: Author not found
Content: Large-scale watermelon farmers, in the Rajarata area, are grappling with a severe economic crisis due to the absence of fair pricing for their crops. The prolonged drought in the Rajarata region has left farmers frustrated, as they struggle to secure reasonable prices for their watermelon harvests. Currently, a kilo of watermelon is only fetching a meagre Rs 15 to Rs 20 at the Dambulla Economic Centre. Farmers say the journey to the Dambulla Economic Centre to sell their harvest is both costly and burdensome.  Sumit Kumara, a farmer from Megodawewa, shared his plight, “When a drought strikes, we cultivate watermelons with the limited water available in our wells. Cultivating half an acre cost us approximately Rs 70,000. Regrettably, we are unable to secure a fair price for our harvest. It’s disheartening to sell our hard-earned produce for a mere Rs 15 to Rs 20. This problem has plagued us for nearly two decades and our survival is at stake. We struggle to access essential resources like oil and fertiliser and the drought adds to our woes. We are left with no option but to contemplate drastic measures. We earnestly appeal for watermelons to be purchased at a minimum of Rs 70-Rs 80 per kg. When we go to the Dambulla market, we have to sell five kg of watermelons just to cover restroom expenses.” Sudarshani Lanka, another farmer said, “We have invested our savings, including our gold and land, into farming. Unfortunately, we are now in a situation where we can’t even afford to safeguard those assets. We have devoted nearly everything to farming and yet, we are not generating any income. If this situation persists, we may have no choice but to resort to extreme measures. We demand fair pricing of at least Rs 70-Rs 80 per kg for watermelons.” BY Krishnan Sachin – Maradankadawala

title: Gangster Harak Kata’s Escape Bid Fails
author: Author not found
Content: According to a recent revelation, detained gangster, Nadun Chinthaka Wickremaratne, aka ‘Harak Kata’ had attempted to wrestle a firearm from a Sub-Inspector (SI) of the CID within the CID premises. Reliable sources indicated that Harak Kata had received assistance from a Police Constable (PC) in his unsuccessful attempt to steal the firearm. Following the thwarted effort, the PC had fled the scene. According to these sources, Harak Kata, a notorious illegal drug trafficker and leader of an organised crime ring, was summoned to the CID for questioning on 10 September. Subsequently, the PC, who had aided the suspect drug kingpin, offered a parcel of homemade milk toffees to the officers present. Alarmingly, two of the officers who consumed the toffees subsequently lost consciousness. During the interrogation, Harak Kata requested a visit to the washroom and the handcuffs restraining him were reportedly loosened by the PC in question. Upon his return to the interrogation room, Harak Kata made a desperate attempt to forcibly seize the firearm of a Special Task Force (STF) SI. Fortunately, the SI managed to wrestle with Harak Kata, thwarting his bid to steal the weapon and bringing the situation under control. However, the PC, who had assisted Harak Kata’s efforts to steal the SI’s firearm, had vanished from the scene. Law enforcement authorities have deployed several Police teams to locate and arrest the PC. Harak Kata, who was deported to the country, is currently held under detention orders by the CID for further interrogation and investigation into this incident. BY Keerthi Mendis

title: Two railway unions call off strike
author: Author not found
Content: Two railway trade union actions, including the one planned for today (12), have been cancelled following discussions with the General Manager of Railways (GMR). As a result, the railway yard workers have decided to call off their trade union action, announced by the Sri Lanka Railways Station Masters’ Union. Additionally, the Locomotive Operating Engineers’ Association and railway yard workers went on strike in the morning of 11 September, due to the non-payment of incentives to railway employees working in railway yards for several months. This strike resulted in the cancellation of six train services scheduled for operation this morning, and one long-distance train bound for Kandy at 10.40 a.m. from Colombo Fort was also cancelled. The strike was called off after the GMR provided assurances on 11 September. The GMR promised to settle their incentive payments by 25 August. The association confirmed that there were no impacts on train services scheduled for the evening. Train operations were disrupted throughout the day on 11 September after railway yard workers in the Colombo District initiated their trade union action. Trains departing from the affected railway yards did not operate until the GMR’s pledge. Meanwhile, the Locomotive Engineers’ Union had also scheduled a strike for today (12). They cited several key demands for their decision, including amendments to the recruitment process and promotions, which have been delayed for nearly five years despite their persistent requests in this regard. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cabinet nod for three Private Medical Colleges
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said the Cabinet has granted approval for the establishment of three private medical colleges within Sri Lanka. He emphasised that these forthcoming medical institutions will adhere to the high standards set by the existing medical schools in the country. Speaking at a media briefing, held at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (11), Rambukwella provided insights into this initiative. He said, “The Cabinet has already given its approval to launch three new medical colleges. These institutions must maintain the same high standards as our existing medical schools. We must consider the number of our youth who choose to study in private institutions or abroad. It is our moral duty to provide adequate facilities and opportunities for our country’s children.” Furthermore, the Minister emphasised, “Professors who have worked as consultants in the medical colleges of our country have outlined minimum qualifications. There is a law that mandates other recognised medical schools in this country to meet or exceed these standards. Additionally, three hospitals have been integrated into these universities.” Rambukwella noted that these universities have been encouraged to allocate scholarships to 10% of their student population, recognising that there are qualified students who may face financial barriers to pursuing a medical education. Addressing concerns about the emigration of medical professionals, the Minister attributed this trend to economic challenges faced by the country in 2019. He reassured that the government is dedicated to addressing these issues, especially those related to doctors’ remuneration. He also stressed the importance of developing comprehensive short, medium, and long-term plans to tackle these challenges, highlighting that countries like England offer significantly higher salaries to medical professionals educated in Sri Lanka’s free education system. In furtherance of their commitment to address critical healthcare challenges, the government aims to augment the intake capacity in specific domains. While there are currently stipulated minimum qualifications and approximately 13 medical faculties throughout the country, only around 2,000 individuals are admitted to these institutions. Rambukwella emphasised the need to expand these numbers to provide opportunities to aspiring medical professionals with foundational qualifications.

title: Mano, Jeevan condemn Plantation management
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of Tamil Progressive Alliance Mano Ganesan and Secretary General of the Ceylon Worker’s Congress, Minister of Water Supply and Plantation Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman condemned Velanturai Plantation Manager, Kahawatte for allegedly attacking another family that tried to construct a makeshift house to live in, as the line room was congested. The temporary house erected there was demolished due to an alleged attack by the Velanturai Plantation Management of the Kahawatte Plantation PLC. MP Ganesan said he has called Minister of Plantation Dr. Ramesh Pathirana over the incident and urged him to stop such incidents. He told the Minister when he raises such issue the minister sends other government minister there and hides behind it and nothing happens thereafter. He said that Dr. Pathirana said he is tired of the plantation companies and told Ganesan to speak to the President of the country.  “I called the President and the President’s Office said they will call me again and I am waiting for the call.” Meanwhile, Minister Thondaman, who went to the scene, warned the Kahawatte Plantation Company to halt such practices of destroying those makeshift houses and brought it to the attention of the minister of plantation. Strongly condemning this inhuman plantation management, he immediately ordered them to get a house, a full scholarship to a university student whose makeshift house was broken by thugs, and one of their family members to be appointed as an officer in Kahawatte plantation company. Further, after this year’s budget, he has advised the Manpower Development Fund to take necessary steps to construct more houses in the Ratnapura District and also further advised the said fund to take steps to create a model village for the said plantation. The Minister said that wherever injustice is done to the people of the plantation, he will stand by them. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: DMT still to adopt online system
author: Author not found
Content: Although three months and 11 days have passed since Minister of Transport Bandula Gunawardena’s 29 May announcement that the Department of Motor Traffic (DMT) would change to an online system within three months, using the ‘e-Motoring system,’ no action has been taken to fulfil this commitment. This was revealed in a report from the National Audit Office. The National Audit Office report also disclosed that Rs 20 million was allocated in 2022 to strengthen the data system, addressing weaknesses and preventing irregularities. Furthermore, the report highlights that the Department of Motor Traffic has not taken any concrete steps to implement the ‘e-Motoring’ project. Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardena stated on 29 May that despite the Government’s attempts to launch the ‘e-Motoring’ project since 2017, certain bureaucrats obstructed its progress. He further committed to completing these tasks within the next three months and implementing the motor vehicle department’s services through the ‘e-Motoring’ system on the road. BY Mithun Jayawardhana
