title: Four cops further remanded over custodial death
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawala yesterday (11) further remanded, till 18 September, the four Police personnel, allegedly involved in the custodial death of R. Rajakumari, a domestic worker. Three of the four suspects, comprising two Police Sergeants and a Constable, were initially scheduled to participate in an identification parade yesterday (11). However, the identification parade was postponed by a week following objections raised by the accused. Additionally, Attorney-at-Law Senaka Perera, representing the aggrieved party, informed the Court that he had received information suggesting that the Officer-in-Charge (OIC) of the Welikada Police Station, who was previously transferred following Rajakumari’s death, had been reinstated in the same position. He expressed concerns that this development could potentially impede the ongoing investigations into the housemaid’s tragic demise. However, no specific order pertaining to this matter was issued by the Magistrate. R. Rajakumari, a 41-year-old resident of Badulla, was arrested on 11 May  following a complaint by her former employer, Sudharma Nethicumara, who alleged that Rajakumari had stolen her gold jewellery. Tragically, Rajakumari died while in the custody of the Welikada Police, leading her relatives to raise suspicions of assault. On 25 August, Magistrate Kekunawala directed the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) to arrest the suspects involved in the housemaid’s death. This decision followed a meticulous review of evidence and the findings in the post-mortem report submitted by the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO). The cause of death was determined to be hemorrhagic shock resulting from damage to the deceased’s muscles, likely inflicted by a blunt weapon or similar force. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: ‘Hands off medical education!’
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors urged Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella to concentrate on resolving issues in the State health service instead of getting involved in matters concerning medical education which comes under the purview of the Ministry of Education.  Fielding questions, when contacted for comment regarding the alleged setting up of three private medical colleges, Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe noted that the Health Minister and the Government should be more concerned about how to solve the issues facing the State-run health service as there were issues regarding pharmaceuticals and their shortages and the fast-depleting human resource in hospitals. The government is sadly under a misconception if it thinks that the current brain drain issue could be resolved by setting up private medical faculties. It takes approximately seven years for an MBBS qualified medical practitioner to pass out. It takes about 15 years to produce a board-certified consultant. Therefore, how does the government expect to find solutions to the current issue by setting up private medical colleges, he queried. Also, priority should be given to settling the issues faced by State-run medical faculties. Some of them are in the process of being accredited whereas the Medical Faculty in Moratuwa University does not have proper building and has to currently use the General Hospital Nagoda for clinical training purposes. Sabaragamuwa Medical Faculty does not have a proper professorial unit while the Rajarata Medical Faculty has issues regarding staff to function its professorial units. He warned that if proper attention is not paid the international accreditation given to State run medical faculties would suffer a serious setback.   President Wickremasinghe recently said that plans have been made to establish the first non-government medical faculty in Sri Lanka, in a move to expand medical education opportunities and find solutions to the challenges posed by the shortage of doctors. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Cloths and buttons turned into cigarettes
author: Author not found
Content: A large stock of 4.5 million foreign-manufactured cigarettes, valued at approximately Rs 110 million, had been illegally imported, into Colombo from India, inside a container, without proper declaration to the Sri Lanka Customs. The illegal importers were apprehended by a group of officers from the Central Intelligence Directorate of Sri Lanka Customs yesterday (11) afternoon at the Gray Line container section, in Grandpass, Colombo. Customs Media Spokesperson Seevali Arukgoda stated that this arrest was effected based on information provided by the Customs Intelligence Division of India to their Sri Lankan counterparts. The container had arrived at the Port of Colombo from the Port of Kattupalli in India on 7 September. Arukoda mentioned that the container, declared by an importer in the Wattala area as containing “100% cotton cloth and plastic buttons,” did not contain the declared items. The Customs estimates that Sri Lanka stands to lose duty income exceeding Rs 310 million if this stock of cigarettes is released from the Port of Colombo. Two suspects, attempting to release the container, have been apprehended by customs officials. Customs intelligence officers are currently conducting further investigations into this matter. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Appeal Court transfers Sashi’s case
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday instructed Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, to forthwith take requisite measures to hear the case against Sashi Weerawansa (wife of MP Wimal Weerawansa), before the Colombo No. 2 Additional Magistrate’s Court. The case related to flouting of Immigration and emigration laws by Sashi Weerawansa, had been taken up for hearing before the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court hitherto, but, the Appellate Court Judge Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne (President), having perused a petition filed before him by the lawmaker’s wife, instructed Chief Magistrate Alwis, to transfer the case from his Court, to the Additional Magistrate’s Court with immediate effect. Through her petition Sashi Weerawansa, had challenged an order issued by Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, who rejected a request made to him by a junior lawyer, to defer the hearing of the case at the previous hearing, due to Nalin Ladduwahetty PC being indisposed. Representing the Attorney General, Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris informed the Court of Appeal, that the intention of the Chief Magistratehad been to expedite the case hearings. He added that if the petitioner has no trust in the Chief Magistrate in question, then his department would have no issue, with the case being transferred to a different Court. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Decision on ETI future on 6 October
author: Author not found
Content: A set of Directors and a group of depositors of the Edirisinghe Trust Investment Finance Ltd, yesterday opposed the request made to the Colombo Commercial High Court, by the Central Bank Sri Lanka (CBSL), to issue an order for the financial institution in question, to settle its financial arrears and close down, while another set of its depositors moved Court, to issue an order to ETI, to settle their financial arrears and shut down. Additional Solicitor General Viraj Dayaratne told the Court, that a press advertisement to liquidate the assets of ETI, had been published on 27 July and that already a sum of close to Rs 6 billion, had been repaid to the depositors and that a further sum of Rs 8 billion, has still to be paid. The lawyer appearing on behalf of the depositors, informed the High Court, that his Association was opposed to it, while the lawyers, appearing on behalf of the Directors of the ETI and the lawyers appearing for a few other parties, also objected. When the case was called, Additional Solicitor General Dayaratne produced submissions on behalf of the CBSL. The petition had been filed by the Directress of the Non-Financial Institution Inspection Department, attached to the CBSL. Taking the submissions into consideration, the High Court Judge instructed parties concerned to file their objections before 25 September and stated that his decision, on whether the said financial institution will be liquidated or not, will be delivered on 6 October. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SJB Petition in Diana case dismissed
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (11) dismissed a petition, filed by SJB General Secretary MP Ranjith Madduma Bandara and civil society activist Oshala Herath, praying to form a five- Judge Bench, to determine the suitability of State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage, functioning as a lawmaker in the current Parliament, due to being a dual citizen. The said petition was perused before a Bench of the Appellate Court, comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne (President) and Chamath Moraes. The Court stated that as there is already a three-Judge Bench, formed to hear the petition, there was no necessity to appoint a five-Judge Bench. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SLPA enquiry centre opens
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva, declared open the Enquiry Centre of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) yesterday (11), enhancing the capabilities of the Port of Colombo, which plays a pivotal role asa hub port and international trade and shipping center with continuous operational activities. Accordingly, the SLPA Enquiry Centre has been established with the aim of providing information about the port services in a more expedited and convenient manner for local and foreign customers connected with the Port of Colombo and to educate the public about the port operations. The centre will be open daily from 8.30 a.m. to 5.00 p.m., offering port service information through the hotline 1984. This hotline will prove to be exceptionally convenient, particularly for individuals engaged in import, export, and shipping activities. Moreover, anyone with an interest in the maritime, shipping, and port sectors, or those seeking information related to these fields, can also access the pertinent information viathe hotline. Anyone, inquiring for additional information, can visit the SLPA Enquiry Centre, situatedat No. 15, Lotus Road, Canal Yard, Colombo 01. Alternatively, inquiries for informationcan also be submitted via email at i[email protected]. At the inauguration of the centre, the Minister placed the first call to the hotline. Addressing the event, he under scoredth at the hotline service, being linked to international ports, offers the opportunity to promptly access up-to-date information in the realms of trade, shipping, and ports. Speaking further at the event, the minister said, “The efficiency of the SLPA’s services is expected to significantly improve with the introduction of the new Enquiry Centre. This initiative aims to reduce the frequency of one-on-one meetings between officials and customers or service recipients, thereby eliminating the necessity for in-person discussions with officials.This proactive measure would mitigate certain irregularities as well.” SLPA Chairman Keith Bernard, Managing Director Prabath Malavige, and a large number of high officials also participated.

title: Health Ministry data system wasting funds
author: Author not found
Content: Action should be taken against those who proposed setting up the Health Ministry’s database, which had caused a large sum of public funds to go waste, the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) stressed. The MCPA alleged that the Health Minister, Director General Health Services (DGHS) and the Health Ministry Spokesperson, all make contradictory statements on the said database. President of the MCPA, Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa yesterday (11) alleged that the faulty data system of the Health Ministry had even led to discrepancies with regard to information of the availability of pharmaceuticals. He noted that a press release issued by the Director General of Health Services and the Media Spokesman of the Health Ministry revealed that there were lenses available only for six months. But on Sunday (10), Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said there were lenses available only for another month. According to the Health Ministry’s data system however currently there were no lenses available in the country, he alleged. He alleged that the Health Ministry was not even able to give an accurate statement regarding an issue instead of creating a mess. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Ceylon Theatres and British Council join hands
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Theatres, a company associated with the National Cinema Industry for over 90 years, is partnering with the British Council to bring the UK’s National Theatre Live (NT Live) to Sri Lankan audiences. The British Council said it is pleased to support the NT Live screenings, in 2023/24, as part of the 75th anniversary celebrations of the UK-Sri Lanka diplomatic ties. This will allow a wider audience to enjoy and experience world class UK Arts. This cinematic experience is not only of interest to theatre enthusiasts, but will also appeal to students who enjoy literature and have a passion for arts and culture. National Theatre Live is an initiative operated by the Royal National Theatre in London. It broadcasts live, by satellite, performances of their productions to cinemas and arts centres around the world. Ceylon Theatres operates the Regal cinemas and the Majestic cinema in Sri Lanka, which collectively has 18 screens across the country in 7 locations.   Ceylon Theatres have made arrangements to screen two iconic productions for a limited time period – Yann Martel’s ‘Life of Pi’ and William Shakespeare’s ‘Othello’. The screenings are scheduled to take place at the Majestic Cinema Colombo and Regal Cinema Jaffna. ‘Life of Pi’ will be screened on 9, 10, 16 and 17 September at the Majestic Cinema, and on 9 September at the Regal Cinema Jaffna. Shakespeare’s ‘Othello’ will be screened on 23, 24, 30 September and 1 October at the Majestic Cinema, and October 7 at the Regal Cinema Jaffna. Tickets can be booked online at https://ceylontheatres.com/get-tickets/ or will be available at the ticket counter at the respective venues. For any further information or clarifications contact Majestic Cinema on 0112 591 585, Regal Cinema (Jaffna) on 0212 227 712.

title: Pathfinder Foundation participates at 8th RIIO Int’l Conference
author: Author not found
Content: The Eighth Research Institute for Indian Ocean (RIIO) International Conference, which focused on the Challenges and Prospectus for Blue Economy Cooperation in the Indian Ocean, was held in Kunming, China. The event, held from the perspective of security and development, was attended by policymakers and academia representing think tanks in South Asia and Southeast Asia, including Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Maldives, Malaysia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Thailand etc. The discussions were held under four main themes, namely Strategic Competition and Cooperation among Great Powers in the IOR, Geopolitical Changes and Challenges for Maritime Security in the IOR, Cooperative Mechanism and Building Blue Economy Partnership in the IOR, and the Problems, Challenges, and Prospects for Cooperation in the IOR. The deliberations on the above themes are important to Sri Lanka to enable the country to exploit numerous blue economic development opportunities. In particular, building blue economic partnerships within the region will be a key subject area of discussion, as Sri Lanka assumes Chairmanship of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) in the latter half of this year and develops a deeper understanding of geopolitical sensitivities in developing national policies for the country. During the discussion on ‘Strategic Competition and Cooperation among Great Powers in the IOR’, Bernard Goonetilleke, Chairman Pathfinder Foundation, addressed the conference on the topic of ‘Indian Ocean power rivalry and the dilemma of small States’. In his presentation, he focused on the resurgence of great power rivalry in the 21st century and the plight of the small States, which are forced to take sides or face consequences. Bernard Goonetilleke, Chairman, and Dr. Dayaratna Silva, Executive Director of Pathfinder Foundation, participated at the Eighth RIIO International Conference on Common Development of China and Indian Ocean region’.

title: Promoting women empowerment and skill development
author: Author not found
Content: As an esteemed and leading partner in the modern business community, G&G Group is deepening its roots towards a variety of industries capitalising strategic goals for long-term socio-economic mutuality. Being one of the leading suppliers of Power, Tea and Agricultural commodities, G&G Group forays into the trading of agricultural commodities across the range of products from Soybean, Wheat, Barley, Copra and many other products. The G&G Group which always strives for excellence, has a team of highly-experienced and qualified-professionals to manage its businesses and investments across the business contours. The conglomerate has also heavily invested in the Renewable Energy, Tea Plantation, Food Processing, Agro commodity business across Asia.  Demerged from the Watawala Plantations PLC and coming under the wings and becoming a part of the G&G Group in 2017, with a strong focus on innovation and value addition, Hatton Plantations consolidated its position as one of the largest tea producing plantation companies in Sri Lanka. Over the years, Hatton Plantations continues to build upon the established and proud reputation of being a prime producer of pure Ceylon tea and continues to set new standards in ensuring the people around the globe to enjoy a quality cup of tea. Sri Lanka is an Island Nation with a rich biodiversity located in the Indian Ocean. The country’s economy is highly-based on textiles, tourism, tea exports, rice, and other agricultural products. Sri Lankan tea production is well known around the world as ‘Ceylon Tea’. According to the statistics of the Sri Lanka Exports Development Board, tea exports account for about 11% of the total exports, and about 62% contribute to the total agriculture exports in the country.When looking at the tea industry in Sri Lanka, the Government and private plantations are the key components of gaining this huge amount of foreign income to the country. In the complex process of manufacturing tea, plantation employees play a vital role to have a production of best quality under the guidance and supervision of the management.  Tea harvesters in Sri Lanka can be defined as one of the main contributors to a better output in the tea industry. ‘Tea plucking’ is a skill that women have assimilated, picking tender tea shoots with their nimble fingers. As one of the pioneer Ceylon tea producers in Sri Lanka’s G&G Groups, Hatton Plantation PLC recently declared a new chapter of utilising female cadres, other than as the tea pickers, in the history of Sri Lankan tea plantations. The company introduced female harvesting team leaders for 14 tea estatesof Hatton Plantations located in the Central Highlands as an innovative strategy. ‘Kankani’ are the personnel, who are in charge of supervising female tea pickers and in the long-standing history of the tea industry this was designated to male cadre. With introducing of the new strategy, these new female harvesting team leaders are streamlined as supervisors of female tea pickers by the Hatton Plantation PLC, recognising the need for psychosocial factors in the long run towards a better industry. The specialty of this programme is that, these harvesting team leaders have been selected from the same community of estate harvesters, considering their educational qualifications, personalities, communication skills and also subsequent to a proper interview procedure. Most of them are from the families of tea harvesters who had been retired after rendering a valuable contribution to the national economy of Sri Lanka. The aim of this new strategy is to have a close communication whilst ensuring the mental stability of women and as a motivational drive to go through any condition by avoiding negative feelings like insecurity, helplessness, and having no voice for them. After primary selections from interviews, these young female individuals had to go through a 3-week-long training programme that included modules on tea harvesting and plowing, techniques and skills, and cost-effectiveness. Further, they will learn agricultural practices to understand the challenges and opportunities related to the tea industry. They were specially trained on the role of supervisor, to ensure their work’s competency, efficiency and effectiveness. Similarly, prior to getting into the field, they will sharpen more by undergoing the leadership module, the effective communication module, resolving conflicts under the four steps of communication, active listening, reviewing opinions which ends with win-win solutions.  Finally, by managing the performance goals of the team members, leading and working together with the team, leading and managing unforeseen situations and also safety and security, will make them competent in carrying out their duties in an organised manner. Hatton Plantations PLC recently conducted two training programmes for female harvesting team leaders (1st programme for eight personnel and 2nd programme for 12 personnel). The Human Resources Management Department of the Company streamlined the process under the direction of the Chairman, Hatton Plantation PLC, Gary Seaton, the executive director and other directors of the company. The certificates awarding ceremony for the 12 female plucking supervisors was held at the headquarters of Hatton Plantation PLC on 31 August 2023. Menaka Athukorala, Executive Director, Hatton Plantations PLC, K. Gowri Shankar, Group Director, Corporate Strategies & Investments, G&G Group of Companies, Singapore, and a few senior head office staff members attended the ceremony. Gowri Shankar speaking during the day’s ceremony, after awarding certificates and offer letters to graduates said, “I am highly impressed with this new strategy, which can provide suitable employment and sustainable opportunities to the families of our existing workers. We want them to excel and climb up the ranks within the organisation. It was their ancestors who took care of the estates and we believe the legacy and  tradition should continue but with modern methods and means, that’s guided by deep commitment towards sustainability . I am confident they will succeed and bring more efficiency and innovation to the industry as they are well-educated and trained.” Menaka Athukorala said, “This will motivate and enhance female tea pluckers, their communities, and those who are employed as new young harvesting team leaders to climb the ladder with career prospects to be experts in the sector, foundation we laid today.” Thamilini Shramiladevi, one of the newly-appointed harvesting team leaders, expressed her gratitude to the G&G Groups, Hatton Plantations, and all the officials for empowering and giving them a platform to excel. “We are ready to take any challenge and confident to carry out the responsibilities entrusted to us.” With this new chapter, we can enhance sociocultural enrichments by filling communication gaps. Similarly, each of the 14 estates of G&G Groups, Hatton Plantation are conducting a series of charity events for the betterment of community of estate sector. Specially, nutrition programmes for the pregnant and mothers with infants, educational assistance for schooling kids, medical camps, housing projects, infrastructure development, fulfilment facilities for sanitary needs are just a glimpse . Every industry needs new strategies and innovation aligned with best practices. Such allocations have a huge value in the short and long run. In today’s context such innovative strategies will empower women and give them equal opportunity to remove the gender inequality.

title: Wastewater management in shrimp farms below par – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda directed officials to take legal action against shrimp farms, in the Mannar and Negombo areas, that have failed to  manage wastewater in their businesses. Devananda said he received complaints regarding the improper disposal of wastewater from shrimp farms in Negombo and Mannar. At a meeting held on 8 September, the Fisheries Minister met officials from the National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA) and the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) to discuss and initiate action against such irresponsible practices. Minister Devananda specifically said he had received reports from MPs representing these regions about the a particular shrimp farm in the Mannar District, which was discharging wastewater in an environmentally harmful manner. He instructed them to provide him with a detailed report. Devananda highlighted the responsibility of NARA and NAQDA to conduct a comprehensive study on wastewater management in these farms and recommend measures to address the issue. The Fisheries Minister said there were approximately 670 shrimp farms in the Negombo and Puttalam areas, with 237 of them located in the Negombo zone. During his recent inspection tour of the Negombo area, he observed that wastewater management in these farms was below par. To address this issue, Devananda appointed a committee comprising officials from NARA, NAQDA, respective Divisional Secretaries, and regional officials from the Fisheries Ministry for the North-western Province. This committee has inspected a total of 176 shrimp farms in the region so far. During discussions with NARA and NAQDA officials, Devananda also inquired about the wastewater disposal practices of shrimp farms at Erukkalampiddy in the Mannar District, expressing concern about their potential environmental impact. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: UNP Convention on 21 October
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Range Bandara announced on Sunday (10) that the UNP’s 77th annual convention, originally postponed due to the ongoing intermittent weather across the country, has now been rescheduled for 21 October, commencing at 2.00 p.m. The Convention will be chaired by UNP Leader, President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Range Bandara said the decision to reschedule the convention was unanimously agreed on during a meeting of the UNP Working Committee (WC), which was presided over by Party Leader President Wickremesinghe. He also said arrangements have been made in preparation for the event. The meeting was attended by UNP Chairman Wajira Abeywardena, Executive Director Chamal Senarath, and a significant number of party activists. Range Bandara said the Convention is expected to draw a large number of foreign diplomats, guests, political party leaders, party activists and numerous supporters. He said the UNP in its efforts to modernise activities has shifted all party activities to a digital platform. The General Secretary expressed confidence in the UNP’s resurgence and predicted that it would achieve victory soon, with the potential for a landslide win in the upcoming Presidential election, expected to be held by November next year. During President Wickremesinghe’s visit to Sirikotha on 8 September, the party’s ongoing modernisation programmes, including digitalisation, were discussed, Range Bandara said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SL man arrested over wife’s death
author: Author not found
Content: A man was charged on Monday (11) with the murder of his wife, after her body was found at a hotel in Katong.  Eshan Tharaka Koottage, 30, is accused of murdering his wife Diyawinnage Sewwandi Maduka Kumari sometime between 10.45 a.m. and 4.42p.m. on 9 September at Holiday Inn Express Katong Square, located at 88 East Coast Road. The charge sheet did not state how the alleged act was committed.  The Sri Lankan man, dressed in a white long-sleeved shirt, was handed the charge via videolink in the State Courts. The prosecution applied for him to be remanded for one week with permission to take him out for investigations, scene revisitation and recovery of exhibits.  The accused requested through an interpreter to speak to the Sri Lankan High Commission to engage a lawyer and asked for the State to provide him a lawyer, but was told he could not communicate with anyone at this juncture.  He will return to court on 18 September. According to the Police, the accused went to Marine Parade Neighbourhood Police Centre on Saturday at about 5.05p.m. to inform Police that he had killed his wife at the hotel, which is beside i12 Katong shopping mall. He was then arrested. The 32-year-old woman was found lying motionless with a slash wound in a hotel room when the Police arrived. She was pronounced dead at the scene.  A knife, believed to have been used in the incident, was recovered in the hotel room. If convicted, he faces the death penalty. (CNA)

title: RE electricity leads after six days
author: Author not found
Content: Electricity generated by cheap and clean renewable energy (RE), aided by monsoonal rains, met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs for two consecutive calendar days to Sunday (10) after six days, data furnished by CEB yesterday (11) showed. On Sunday (10), RE met 50.33 per cent (18.29 Giga Watt hours (GWh) of the country’s electricity needs, while the balance 49.67 per cent (18.05 Gwh) was met by the  environmentally-pollutive imported fossil fuels (FF) and on the previous day Saturday, RE provided 50.04 per cent (19.72 GWh) of the country’s electricity needs, while FF provided the rest (49.96 per cent/19.69 GWh). On Sunday Sri Lanka consumed a total of 36.34 GWh of electricity, while on the previous day Saturday, that figure was 39.41 GWh Prior to the weekend (9 and 10), the last time RE met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs for two consecutive calendar days was on last Sunday and Monday (3 and4), while in the interim period leading to Saturday, over 50 per cent of the island’s electricity needs was met by FF. Meanwhile, Sunday’s total electricity split, though not in any particular order was coal 10.82 GWh (equivalent to 29.77 per cent of total electricity consumption on that day), CEB hydroelectricity 7.04 GWh (19.37 per cent), other forms of RE including private sector (PS) biomass, wind, mini hydroelectricity and CEB wind-11.25 GWh (30.96 per cent), CEB thermal oil, another form of FF, 5.94 GWh (16.35 per cent) and PS/independent power producers’ thermal oil-1.29 GWh (3.55 per cent), respectively. According to the recently released Central Bank of Sri Lanka 2022 Annual Report, the most cost effective form of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB hydroelectricity costing Rs 1.80 a unit or per one kilo Watt hour (KWh), followed by non conventional RE such as PS mini hydroelectricity Rs 14.98, coal (Rs 27.32),CEB fuel oil (Rs 67.69) and PS fuel oil (Rs 69.65). CBSL’s 2022 Annual Report further said that CEB’s average electricity tariff last year was Rs 21.25 a unit.  Meanwhile, CBSL in their tariff calculations have not taken into account the 66 per cent electricity tariff increase effected by the Government which came into effect in February of this year (2023). By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Quake recorded in seas off Batticaloa
author: Author not found
Content: A tremor measuring 4.65 on the Richter scale occurred in the seas off the north-eastern coast of Sri Lanka in the wee hours of yesterday (11). This seismic event was documented by the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau. The quake’s epicenter was located approximately 310 km north-east of Batticaloa and occurred at a depth of 24 km, at around 1.30 a.m. The Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) assured that this earthquake does not pose any tsunami threat to Sri Lanka.

title: SL Embassy in Bahrain organises ‘Sri Lanka Fest’
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in the Kingdom of Bahrain, in coordination with Lulu Hypermarket, organised a week-long Sri Lanka Produce and Food Mart, from 07-13 September 2023, titled ‘Sri Lanka Fest’, with a view to promote trade, tourism and culture of Sri Lanka, as well as to augment the image of the country, amongst the nationals of Bahrain and foreign expatriates, residing in Bahrain. The event was expected to attract over 2,000 visitors and shoppers, including Sri Lankan nationals domiciled in Bahrain.  Sri Lankan Ambassador to Bahrain H.M.G.R.R.K. Wijeratne Mendis inaugurated the colourful event on 7 September, along with Acting Undersecretary for Consular & Administrative Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Kingdom of Bahrain Dr. Mohamed Ali Bahzad, Chief Executive Officer of Bahrain Chamber of Commerce and Industry (BCCI) Mohamed Atef Al Khaja, Chief Executive Officer of Labour Market Regulatory Authority (LMRA) Nibras Mohammed Talib and Lulu Group Regional Director  Mohamed Kaleem. The Ambassadors of China, Nepal, the Philippines to Bahrain, and the members of the Diplomatic Community in Bahrain graced the opening ceremony.   This year’s event displayed and marketed a number of new products and goods such as cinnamon, seafood including tuna, kingfish and prawns, pepper, authentic spices, various kinds of biscuits, and confectionary products. A variety of healthy organic coconut products such as coconut cream, coconut milk, and cold-pressed coconut oil, were available at attractive prices. Ceylon Tea and tea-based herbal infusions with turmeric, chamomile and other herbs from well-known plantations around Sri Lanka, were also promoted.   Other attractions at the Sri Lanka Fest included the stalls set up by Sri Lankan-origin entrepreneurs displaying Kithul jaggery, confectionary items, spices, palmyra products, handicrafts, handloom, batik products as well as various eco-friendly products. The Ceylon Tea stall organised by Dilmah provided the visitors a unique opportunity for tea tasting, while attractive Sri Lanka Tourism packages were offered by Akbar Holidays. Large television screens displayed videos on touristic attractions of Sri Lanka, Ceylon Tea, export products of Sri Lanka, and the many investment opportunities such as Colombo Port City project.  Using the event as a platform, the Sri Lanka Embassy with the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment organised a stall to promote foreign employment and encourage skills recognition through NVQ certification. The aim of the Embassy’s initiative is to collect data and information regarding skills and qualifications of Sri Lankan migrant workers and expatriates in Bahrain, enabling them to register for the ‘Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL)’ which is being organised by the Embassy.    Highlighting Sri Lanka’s vibrant culture, the dance performance was showcased by members of the Sri Lanka Club Dancing Group and ‘Thiranga Kala – Bahrain’, which drew wide applause and appreciation from the audience. The cultural performances were also showcased on 8 and 9 September.  Adding flavour to the event, Chef Udaya Kumara from the Bahrain-based Sri Lankan Restaurant ‘Zaynah’ demonstrated the preparation of authentic Sri Lankan cuisine.  The ‘Sri Lankan Fest’ is part of a series of events organised by the Embassy of Sri Lanka under the Economic Diplomacy initiative in coordination with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Export Development Board, Sri Lanka Tourism, Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment and other relevant Sri Lankan authorities to promote trade, tourism, culture and investment in Bahrain.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Two more committees to probe Easter carnage
author: Author not found
Content: Following Britain’s Channel 4’s controversial documentary, another two committees are to be appointed, by President Ranil Wickremesinghe and the Government, to probe the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said yesterday (10). If these proposed committees are appointed, they will be the third and fourth appointed to probe the carnage, in which a total of 269 people were killed, including at least 45 foreign nationals, three Police officers and eight suicide bombers. An additional 500 were injured in the terror attack. According to the PMD, President Ranil Wickremesinghe would appoint a committee led by a retired Supreme Court Judge, with the primary mission of investigating serious allegations recently brought to light by Channel 4 in a broadcast video. These allegations have ignited public concern, especially as former Attorney General Dappula de Livera has made similar claims, suggesting the presence of a mastermind behind the devastating Easter bomb attack. In response, the Government is preparing to establish a Parliamentary Select Committee specifically tasked with probing these disturbing assertions, the PMD said. “Recognising the gravity of the situation, the President is committed to conducting a comprehensive review of all available information. As part of this effort, the reports will be presented to the Parliament, along with the existing Parliamentary Select Committee report on the Easter bomb attack and the Presidential Commission report on the same tragic event,” the PMD said. On 21 April 2019, Easter Sunday, three churches in Sri Lanka and three luxury hotels in the commercial capital, Colombo, were targeted in a series of coordinated IS-related terrorist suicide bombings. Later that day, two smaller explosions occurred at a housing complex in Dematagoda and a guest house in Dehiwala. Security lapses leading to the attack and the Sri Lankan Government’s failure to act on intelligence were highlighted during inquiries into the attacks. On 12 January 2023, The Supreme Court of Sri Lanka ruled that the then-incumbent President Maithripala Sirisena and several other State authorities at the time failed to act on intelligence and they were ordered to pay compensation to victims. In 2019, just a day after the terror attacks, then President Maithripala Sirisena appointed a PCoI, headed by Supreme Court Justice Vijith Malalgoda. The PCoI handed over its report to Sirisena on 10 June 2019. In May 2019, a PSC was appointed to probe the attacks and incidents in its aftermath by then Speaker Karu Jayasuriya. The Select committee was headed by then Deputy Speaker Ananda Kumarasiri and included seven MPs. The PSC report was presented to Parliament on 23 October 2019. Sirisena appointed another PCoI on 20 September 2019, headed by Supreme Court Justice Janak de Silva. The final report of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) into the Easter Sunday attacks was handed over to then President Gotabaya Rajapaksa by Justice Janak de Silva on 1 February 2021. The first and second interim reports were handed over to the then President on 20 December 2019 and on 2 March 2020. The full PCoI report was not disclosed to the public, by the authorities, citing national security reasons. However, it was reported that the full report was handed over to Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena by the Presidential Secretariat on 22 February 2022, on the instructions of President Gotabaya  Rajapaksa. Meanwhile, Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles Minister handed over the full report to the Catholic Church on 25 April. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Poppy Day unveiled
author: Author not found
Content: To mark Poppy Day, the first poppy flower was pinned onto President Ranil Wickremesinghe last (10) morning at the Presidential Secretariat. Major General Upul Perera, Chairman of the Sri Lanka Ex-Servicemen’s Association facilitated the occasion. Each year, the Sri Lanka Ex-Servicemen’s Association organizes Poppy Day in memory of war heroes who sacrificed their lives during the world wars and Sri Lanka’s thirty-year-long internal conflict. The funds raised during this commemoration support the welfare of the families of fallen heroes and disabled veterans. In a symbolic gesture a poppy flower was also pinned onto Sagala Ratnayaka, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff. Lt. Col. Ajith Siambalapitiya, General Secretary of the Sri Lanka Ex-Servicemen’s Association, Major P.K.C. Shantilal Kankanam, Treasurer, Brigadier Hemantha Liyanage, Chairman of the Poppy Celebration Committee, and committee members Major P.H. W. de Silva, Captain T.M.H. Madugalla, K.H.N. Chandi Hettiarachchi, and Mr. I.K.A. Rohani, among others were present.

title: SCL on imported potatoes extended – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya announced that the Special Commodity Levy imposed on imported potatoes will be extended for an additional four months, commencing 8 September. On 8 March 2023, the Ministry of Finance decided to increase the Special Commodity Levy on imported potatoes by Rs 30 per kg for six months, resulting in a revised levy of Rs 50 per kg. The relevant levy was initially imposed for six months, due to end in September 2023. However, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies, has issued a new Gazette that extends the validity of this levy for an additional four months.

title: Two arrested over Ambalantota bus shooting
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons were arrested, on Saturday (9) evening, in connection with the recent shooting inside a bus at Ambalantota. The arrests were made by the Matara Police Crimes Division on Saturday evening in Thalawilla. The suspects were aged 21 and 31. The incident took place last Thursday (7) when an assailant shot and injured a woman in a bus. CCTV camera footage shows two unidentified persons arriving on a motorcycle, forcibly entering the bus and obstructing its movement.  Subsequently, they fled the scene after shooting the woman, who was immediately rushed to the Ambalantota Hospital.

title: Woman dies under mysterious circumstances
author: Author not found
Content: A 27-year-old woman, a UK citizen of Sri Lankan origin, has tragically lost her life in Sri Lanka under mysterious circumstances and Mount Lavinia Police are investigating. The incident occurred at an apartment on Alwis Avenue in Mount Lavinia. She had fallen from the 13th floor. Police are investigating to ascertain whether it was a case of suicide, accident, or a criminal act. According to Police, she had arrived in Sri Lanka on 8 March to visit a 29-year-old individual, a law student residing in Wellawatte, with whom she had developed a close connection through social media. Subsequently, the two had been residing together in the same apartment complex. It was revealed that the Sri Lankan man, who was pursuing his studies in Switzerland, had also returned to Sri Lanka the previous year. The woman had plans to return to England early Sunday (10) morning.The man is currently in Police custody. The post-mortem was scheduled for yesterday (10) and the British High Commission has been notified of the death.

title: Excise Act tobe overhauled– Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: Immediate action is to be taken to revise the Excise Act, as the current legislation is outdated, riddled with discrepancies and in need of swift amendments, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. “The Excise Act is among the oldest in our country, dating back over a century. It has seen countless updates, with more than 1,000 modifications made to adapt to changing times. It’s akin to a patient with numerous bandages,” he pointed out, adding that the Act does not cover crucial areas due to numerous gaps in its provisions. To rectify existing loopholes and enhancing State revenue, Siyamabalapitiya affirmed that efforts are in progress to introduce revisions and overhaul the current Excise Act.

title: Significant data loss due to cyber attack on ‘gov.lk’
author: Author not found
Content: A significant data loss has impacted all State offices using the ‘gov.lk’ email domain, due to a large-scale ransomware attack, that occurred between 17 May and 26 August, the Information and Communication Technology Agency (ICTA) revealed. In a statement, the Director for Strategic Communications at ICTA verified that numerous government offices, including the Cabinet Office, using the ‘gov.lk’ email domain, were affected by this data loss. The incident is believed to have been triggered by a large-scale ransomware attack that occurred between 17 May and 26 August. This ransomware attack had a profound impact, affecting approximately 5,000 email addresses. ICTA reported that due to the absence of both offline and online backup systems during a critical two-month period, several emails lost in the attack are now irretrievable. In response to this alarming incident, ICTA has taken immediate measures to implement a daily offline backup process. Additionally, they will upgrade the relevant application process to the latest version, bolstering its defenses against virus attacks. Efforts to recover the lost data are currently underway, with both ICTA and the Sri Lanka Computer Emergency Readiness Team (SLCERT) actively engaged in the recovery process. Furthermore, SLCERT has issued a public warning about a phishing scam that specifically targets Sri Lankan nationals. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Suwa Seriya faces driver shortfall
author: Author not found
Content: There is a shortage of over 600 personnel at the 1990 Suwa Seriya Foundation, with 321 vacancies specifically for drivers, a senior official from the State Ministry of Primary Health Services told Ceylon Today. Despite the approved total staff count being 1,992, the actual number of employees stands at 1,390. This shortfall could pose a challenge to the continuity of services provided by the SuwaSeriya Foundation. Additionally, it was noted that 25 ambulances, obtained through a finance lease system in 1990, remained parked in the supplier’s lot for over a year-and- a- half without being used. The reason attributed is incomplete infrastructure improvements required to align the services with those offered by the SuwaSeriya Foundation. The official also pointed out that the procurement of the ambulances, conducted by the National Budget Department, was done without necessary specifications for a hospital care ambulance and without appointing any representative from the 1990 SuwaSeriya Foundation to the Technical Evaluation Committee. Further, there is insufficient information regarding the value of these ambulances, with some individuals treating such details as confidential documents. Established in 2016, the SuwaSeriya Foundation’s mission is to prevent accidents, diseases and emergencies, rapidly and effectively respond to emergency situations and aid in the rehabilitation of individuals following illness and injury. The 1990 ambulance service was inaugurated in Hambantota on July 27, 2016, with generous support from the Government of the Republic of India. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: COPA displeased with officials ’lack of preparation
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) expressed its strong displeasure at the Ministry of Sports and Youth Affairs and the Department of Sports Development coming before the committee without preparation. This displeasure was expressed when the COPA, chaired by State Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna, met last week in Parliament to discuss the Auditor General’s reports for the years 2020 and 2021 and the current performance of the Ministry of Sports and Youth Affairs and the Department of Sports Development. When the officers who were who summoned were asked about the matters mentioned in the Auditor General’s report, they failed to answer them. The Committee pointed out that these institutions were summoned to inquire about the sports in the country and the officials had not made any preparation for that. Because of this, the COPA decided to summon these two institutions again on 20 October 2023. The Committee mentioned that such an incident has not happened in the recent past of COPA. According to the answers given by these officials, it was clear that there was no national plan regarding sports and no follow-up had been done regarding the spending of government funds. Also, the committee asked the officials about the number of games in the Olympics and the officials failed to give a correct answer. Thus, the committee expressed its regret in this regard as well. Also, the committee asked about the games in the Olympics, Commonwealth Games, Asian Games and South Asian Games and the position of Sri Lanka in these tournaments and the games played, but the officials ould not give a clear answers. Also, the committee inquired about the number of sports currently in Sri Lanka and the officials said that there are four registered A-grade sports, 12 B-grade sports and 73 C-grade sports. The committee asked how many sports have established national records in this country and the officials said that they cannot give a definite answer in this connection.  The committee also inquired about the sports being run in Sri Lanka and the records set in those sports in the last five years, but the officials failed to give specific answers for those too. The committee inquired about the criteria followed in the transition of Sri Lanka’s national sport from Elle to volleyball, and no clear answer was received from the officials in this regard. Also, according to the reports of the Auditor General, the committee inquired about the non-effective completion of the projects on which about Rs 1,500 million had been spent. Since no satisfactory answer was received in this regard, the committee recommended to submit a report onthis within a month. Due to the lack of coordination between the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Sports, it wasrevealed that there is no clear plan to bring the players from school level to the national level. Also, the Committee was displeased with the lack of follow-up on the establishment of district sports committees, despite the fact that the circular was sent to establish the respectivecommittees. It was also discussed that the hockey ground built in Torrington was not in compliance with international standards. Also, it was revealed that the officers have no understanding of the tasks performed by theNational Sports Council, which has been established to advise the Minister. The committee recommended that a report be produced about international level sports tournaments and the places where Sri Lanka is represented. TheCOPA also recommended that the report should highlight the relationship between the Ministry of Sports and the Ministry of Education.

title: Suspect arrested in foreign employment scam
author: Author not found
Content: A resident of Eliyadiwulwewa in Eppawela was arrested in connection with a fraudulent foreign employment scheme. The suspect was arrested for deceiving several people by promising them employment opportunities in Doha, Qatar, and extracting money from them. The Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) carried out the arrest on Saturday (9) following six separate complaints received about the suspect. These complaints alleged that he had swindled a total of Rs 1.6 million from victims under the false pretense of securing employment in Qatar. Initial investigations have uncovered that the suspect had targeted retired Tri-forces and police personnel, falsely guaranteeing them positions in the security sector in Doha, Qatar. In addition to the complaints filed with the SLBFE, the Eppawela Police have also received numerous complaints concerning the suspect’s aggressive behaviour towards individuals who inquired about their money. Police saidon interrogation, the suspect disclosed that he acted as an intermediary and claimed to have fallen victim to a third party. He had already handed over the collected money to the third party. The suspect was handed over to the Eppawela Police for further investigations.
