title: Global Biofuels Alliance’s launch marks watershed moment
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, on Saturday (9), said the launch of the Global Biofuels Alliance marks a watershed moment in India’s quest towards sustainability and clean energy. “The launch of the Global Biofuels Alliance marks a watershed moment in our quest towards sustainability and clean energy. I thank the member nations who have joined this Alliance,” PM Modi wrote on ‘X’ formerly Twitter on Saturday. PM Modi, on Saturday, launched the Global Biofuels Alliance in the presence of US President Joe Biden, President of Brazil Luiz Inacio, President of Argentina, Alberto Fernández and Prime Minister of Italy Giorgia Meloni. The Global Biofuels Alliance is one of the priorities under India’s G20 Presidency. Brazil, India, and the United States, as leading biofuel producers and consumers, will work together during the next few months towards the development of a Global Biofuels Alliance along with other interested countries. This Alliance will be aimed at facilitating cooperation and intensifying the use of sustainable biofuels, including in the transportation sector. It will emphasise strengthening markets, facilitating global biofuels trade, developing concrete policy lesson-sharing and providing technical support for national biofuels programmes worldwide. It will also emphasise the already implemented best practices and success cases. The Alliance shall work in collaboration with and complement the relevant existing regional and international agencies as well as initiatives in the bioenergy, bioeconomy, and energy transition fields more broadly, including the Clean Energy Ministerial Biofuture Platform, the Mission Innovation Bioenergy initiatives, and the Global Bioenergy Partnership (GBEP). GBA will be a competent organisation that will set technical standards for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) business in collaboration with relevant industry bodies. The alliance will have a three-category membership structure bringing together member countries, partner organisations and industries. The alliance will work towards enhancing global collaboration and cooperation for the accelerated adoption of biofuels by identifying global best practices for the development and deployment of sustainable biofuels and bioproducts. Nineteen countries agreed to stand with India as initiating members of the Global Biofuels Alliance. (ANI)

title: Vibrant Onam Celebration by Indian Cultural Association in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: Onam, the annual harvest festival of Kerala, South India, is a vibrant and culturally rich celebration that transcends borders. Even in the heart of Colombo, the Indian Cultural Association organised a Grand Onam celebration that brought the spirit of this cherished festival to the Indian Diaspora and the local community. The Grand Onam celebration was presided over by Eldos Mathew Punnoose, Counsellor (Development Cooperation and Press Information of Indian High Commission). Ankuran Dutta, Director of ICCR (Indian High Commission) was also present during the grand occasion. The President of ICA, Captain Anirban Banerjee, the advisory board comprising of Ranjan Chakrawarthy, Sanjay Baid, Veena Durgabakshi, General Secretary, Jayadratha Das, the Executive Members, Aseem Bhargava, Biswas Janardhanan, Sanjeev Mishra, Elvis Peter, Swapan Haldar, Poornima Das, Prasanna Suresh were some of the other important dignitaries of the event. The Indian Cultural Association in Colombo has been playing a vital role in preserving and promoting Indian traditions and festivals in Sri Lanka. The Onam celebration organised by this association is a testament to their commitment to fostering cultural ties and spreading happiness among the community. It not only preserves Indian culture but also fosters goodwill and understanding among communities in Colombo, making it an event worth experiencing for anyone interested in the diverse tapestry of Indian traditions. Some of the key highlights of the Onam Celebration were: • Grand Floral Decorations: The ladies of the Indian Cultural Association decorated the venue with intricate flower carpets called “Pookalam.” Various flower petals were used, showcasing artistic creativity. • Traditional Attire: Participants and attendees wore traditional Kerala attire. • Onam Sadhya: The highlight of the celebration was the sumptuous Onam Sadhya, a traditional feast served on banana leaves which included an array of vegetarian dishes, such as Avial, Thoran, Parippu Curry, and Payasam, prepared with aromatic spices and coconut. • Cultural Performances: The event was enlivened with captivating cultural performances. The ladies of ICA performed the traditional Thiruvathirakali, followed by traditional songs and folk dances creating an atmosphere of cultural immersion.

title: HC Sirisena appointed as first SL Permanent Rep to IMO
author: Author not found
Content: High Commissioner Saroja Sirisena presented credentials to Kitack Lim, Secretary General of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) as Sri Lanka’s first Permanent Representative to the IMO. Sri Lanka’s accreditation to IMO comes at a time when the country is due to assume chairmanship of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) in October this year. Being in the centre of one of the most vital shipping lanes, Sri Lanka is positioned to be a major maritime hub in the Indian Ocean.  Sri Lanka’s geographic location and its access to regional markets add immensely to its economic and commercial interests and the country remains committed to the safe, secure Indian Ocean and sustainable use of its maritime resources. Established in 1948, IMO, which is headquartered in the United Kingdom, is the United Nations specialized agency with responsibility for the safety and security of shipping and the prevention of marine and atmospheric pollution by ships. IMO currently has 175 Member States and three Associate Members. Sri Lanka obtained membership of IMO in 1972.

title: Dengue prevention, control compromised
author: Author not found
Content: With the Health Ministry owing over Rs 100 million (Rs 10 billion) in arrears, the provision of reagents – especially to conduct full blood count tests on possible dengue cases has been hard hit. President of the College of Medical Laboratory Science Sri Lanka (CMLSSL), Ravi Kumudesh lamented on Friday (8), that this situation posed a severe threat to the FBC tests conducted by State Hospitals as the four companies which sold machine-specific reagents to conduct the test were on the verge of stopping the provision of their reagent. There are State-run Hospitals that have two to three such testing machines, but unfortunately with the Health Ministry’s failure to pay its dues for the reagents purchased, some of the companies have stopped selling the reagent for the FBC test. Therefore, that particular machine cannot be used to conduct the test. Risk Kumudesh noted that this situation posed a severe risk to dengue patients as it was most important to conduct the FBC test and issue the test result in at least half-an-hour which would enable the initiation of treatment and management of dengue at the earliest. However, the present situation may result in the Hospital laboratory staff being unable to conduct the test at all. State hospitals that have two to three FBC testing technologies would also be unable to use them to cater to the need, especially if the number of cases being tested were high. Solution  The CMLSSL President said, his outfit had researched and proposed possible solutions to this issue. The situation itself created a monopoly with the Health Ministry being dependent on those particular companies to provide the reagent for their equipment. However, this situation can be ‘tweaked’ if the Health Ministry is willing to call for tenders on the basis that the company that bided the lowest amount would have the machine that had been sold by it functioning. If the Health Ministry wished it could follow the example of India and invite outside companies to also bid for the reagent tender, he said. However, with the mindset of some of the Health Ministry’s officials bent on corruption the proposal made by the College to the Ministry over 1-1/2 years ago has met with a deafening silence from the Health Ministry’s side.     Situation report While several efforts to contact the Director of the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) failed, a situation update sent by the Unit noted that by 8 September a total of 62,601 dengue cases had been recorded.   A total of 13 high-risk Medical Officer of Health areas had been recorded by the 34th week of this year according to the Dengue Sentinel Site Surveillance System (DenSys). 48.7 per cent of the dengue cases were from the Western Province. It should be noted that by this time Colombo has overtaken the Gampaha District by recording 116 more cases. The Colombo District from January till date has recorded 13,265 cases, while Gampaha has recorded 13,139 cases. The Central Province has 10.5 per cent dengue cases (Kandy – 5,237), the North Western Province 8.4 per cent (Puttalam – 3,005, Kurunegala – 2,237) and Sabaragamuwa has 8.3 per cent (Ratnapura – 2,587, Kegalle – 2,600) of dengue cases. A total of 38 dengue deaths have been recorded in the country to date. ‘Our lives are our responsibility’ Fielding questions, an NDCU Spokesperson said, although there wasn’t a steep rise in the number of dengue cases being recorded in the country at present, the heavy and intermittent showers in South West monsoons would give way to a rise in numbers towards the latter part of this year. However, it would be helpful if the public changed their attitude towards the dengue control work being carried out. “They should keep in mind that their environs should be kept clean at all times of possible mosquito breeding places and not just to avoid being issued with a red notice or having a fine slapped on them for having mosquito breeding grounds. But this is what happens most often. People want to temporarily avoid the unpleasantness and carry out frenzied cleaning programmes.”     Civic duty People of this country bear a responsibility to the community to ensure that their behaviour does not pose a threat or hinder another’s life. “Cleaning up their environs should be everyone’s sincere motto as that is possibly the only way in which communities in all parts of the country would be able to battle and overcome dengue for their own sake and the sake of their children.” By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Rs 2.23B spent on electric fences
author: Author not found
Content: Despite the Department of Wildlife Conservation spending Rs 1.2 billion on the construction of electric fences and Rs 1.03 billion for their maintenance in 2021 and 2022, there has been no reduction in the human-elephant conflict, a report prepared by the National Audit Office revealed. According to the report presented to Parliament, by 31 December 2022, a total of 4,756 km of electric fences was erected in an effort to mitigate Human-Elephant Conflict (HEC). Regrettably, there has been an alarming increase in elephant fatalities, human casualties, property damage and physical harm over the past five years, the report revealed. According to the National Audit Office, a disturbing total of 1,867 elephant fatalities and 618 human casualties occurred between 2018 and 2022, with a noticeable spike in 2022 compared to previous years. The issue of wild elephant deaths has become increasingly prevalent in recent times. Meanwhile, the Centre for Environment and Nature Studies (CENS) has reported that 3,765 wild elephants have perished over the past 12 years, from 2010 to 2022, based on information obtained through the Right to Information (RTI) Act. Also, data from the Department of Wildlife Conservation indicates that 276 elephant fatalities have been recorded in the first nine months of this year alone. Former Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera recently announced plans to conduct an elephant census in Sri Lanka in 2023. He stressed the importance of acquiring accurate data on the current wild elephant population in Sri Lanka to effectively address the HEC. The last official wild elephant census took place in 2011, during which the wild elephant population was estimated to exceed 5,000. Unofficial sources suggest that the current wild elephant population may approach 7,000. Moreover, a high-ranking official from the Wildlife Department also revealed that over Rs 2.2 billion was spent in 2021 – 2022 to establish and maintain electric fences aimed at mitigating the HEC. Despite these efforts, 439 elephants lost their lives, 145 human lives were tragically lost and more than 2,660 instances of property damage, as well as nearly 200 cases of physical harm, were reported during the same year. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Gotabaya vehemently refutes Channel 4 allegations
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa vehemently refuted the allegations made against him, in the recent ‘Dispatches’ documentary by British television network Channel 4, concerning the 2019 Easter Sunday bombings in Sri Lanka. In a statement, Rajapaksa characterised the video as “largely an anti-Rajapaksa diatribe aimed at tarnishing the Rajapaksa legacy from 2005 onwards and is a collection of falsehoods, much like the previous films broadcast by the same Channel.” This statement comes on the heels of the broadcast of Channel 4’s investigative film titled ‘Sri Lanka’s Easter Bombings,’ which delved into the 2019 terror attacks that targeted several churches and luxury hotels in Sri Lanka, resulting in the tragic deaths of more than 260 people and leaving hundreds wounded. The Channel 4 exposé levelled serious allegations against senior State officials, suggesting that they were involved in a plot to instigate insecurity in the country to facilitate Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s victory at the 2019 Presidential Election. The former Head of State dismissed as ‘absurd’ the notion that a group of Islamic extremists carried out suicide attacks with the aim of ensuring his presidency. “Major General Sallay had informed Channel 4 that he had been removed from the position of Director of Military Intelligence and was serving in Malaysia as Minister-Counsellor from 2016 to December 2018 and that he had not been in Sri Lanka at the time this meeting is said to have taken place. Furthermore, from January to November 2019 he was in India following the National Defence College course and during this entire period from 2016 to 2019, he was not operative within the defence or security structure of Sri Lanka. After Maj. Gen. Sallay was removed from Military Intelligence in 2016, he never served in that organisation again. It was only after I became President that he rejoined the intelligence apparatus as the Head of the State Intelligence Service from December 2019 onwards. Hence, this story about Maj Gen Sallay meeting the suicide bombers in February 2018 is clearly a fabrication.  In order to bolster their claim that Military Intelligence was in league with the suicide bombers, the film alleges that when the Police started investigating the Vavunativu incident of 30 November 2018, where two Policemen were killed and their weapons stolen and the discovery of explosives at the Wanathawilluwa safe house on 16 January 2019, the Military Intelligence had sabotaged the Police investigations. All Sri Lankans are aware that the Government of 2015-2019 persecuted the intelligence services and particularly the Military Intelligence and that that quite a few of its members spent months and years in remand and in Police custody during that period. Hence, any claim that the Military Intelligence could sabotage Police work during the 2015 – 2019 Government, is plain nonsense,” Rajapaksa said. “One of the allegations made against me and my government in this latest film is that after becoming President, I ‘sabotaged’ the investigation by transferring officers carrying out the investigation. I assume that this is a reference to the former Director of the CID Shani Abeysekera. Leaked telephone recordings had revealed that he had conspired with a politician to influence the outcome of an ongoing criminal case in the High Court, and he could not be kept in a position of responsibility in the CID under any circumstances by any government. The Police Officers attached to the Presidential Commission to investigate the Easter Sunday attacks were not transferred after I came into power. In any case, there was a gap of nearly seven months between the Easter Sunday attacks and my coming into power, and investigations should have been carried out during that period. SSP Abeysekera was also one of those responsible for the negligence between 2016 and 2019 mentioned in the Presidential Commission’s report,” he claimed. Rajapaksa categorically denied the allegations made by one of the high-ranking whistleblowers interviewed by Channel 4. “This whistleblower claimed to have facilitated a meeting between members of the Islamic extremist group led by Zahran Hashim and the then Army Intelligence Chief, Major General Suresh Sallay, in January 2018, prior to the tragic events. “The whistleblower, Hanzeer Azad Maulana, had previously served as a spokesman for the LTTE’s breakaway group, Tamil Makkal Viduthalai Pullikal (TMVP), led by the current State Minister of Rural Road Development, Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan, also known as Pillaiyan. Maulana, who is currently seeking political asylum in Switzerland, reportedly provided testimony to the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) and was interviewed by European intelligence agencies. Maulana claimed to Channel 4 that he witnessed the alleged meeting between the suicide bombers and a senior Sri Lankan intelligence officer before the Easter Sunday attacks. However, Sallay informed Channel 4 that he had been removed from his position as Director of Military Intelligence and had been serving as Minister-Counsellor in Malaysia from 2016 to December 2018. He stated that he had not been in Sri Lanka at the time of the alleged covert meeting.” Rajapaksa, in his press release, emphasised that he had no contact with Sallay until he was elected president in 2019, after leaving his role as Defence Secretary in 2015. Despite Channel 4 describing Sallay as one of his close associates, Rajapaksa categorically denied this claim. “Despite the politically motivated accusations being made against me by certain individuals, I have personally done everything possible to help the Roman Catholic community when I held government office. After the war ended, I helped in the restoration and reconstruction of the Madhu Church and the Church in Mullikulam. I also helped facilitate the arrangements to invite His Holiness the Pope to Sri Lanka and I headed the committee formed by the then government to organise the visit. I also played a key role in the construction of the Benedict XVI Catholic Institution of Higher Education in Bolawalana. I worked very closely with His Eminence the Cardinal during that period,” the former President concluded.

title: President to leave for Cuba
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe is set to leave for Cuba to address the G77 + China Leaders’ Summit next week, the President’s Media Division (PMD) announced yesterday (7). This summit, themed ‘Current Development Challenges: Role of Science, Technology and Innovation’ is scheduled for 15 and 16 September, in Havana, Cuba. President Wickremesinghe’s participation in the summit comes as a result of an official invitation from Cuban President Miguel Diaz-Canel. Alongside the summit, there are plans for bilateral discussions between President Wickremesinghe and the Cuban President to further strengthen the cooperation between Sri Lanka and Cuba. The G77 + China Leaders’ Summit represents the largest intergovernmental coalition of 134 developing nations, as recognised by the United Nations. It serves as a platform for Southern countries to voice and promote their shared economic interests, while enhancing their collaborative negotiating capabilities. This conference offers an opportunity to address contemporary challenges in the realms of science, technology and innovation, exploring cooperative solutions, particularly through inter-Southern collaboration. The leaders of these nations are expected to adopt the ‘Havana Declaration’ during the summit, which will outline guidelines for reforms and new approaches to enhance cooperation among Southern countries in the fields of science, technology and innovation. Aruni Wijewardane, Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, along with a delegation of senior officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, will accompany the President to the conference.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Inland Revenue Bill passed in Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: The Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill was passed with a majority of 45 votes in Parliament yesterday (7). A total of 103 MPs voted in favour of the Bill while 58 MPs voted against it. The Bill was taken into debate after the Supreme Court determined that it could be passed with a simple majority in Parliament. Meanwhile, the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva, approved the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill by a majority, at the Committee meeting held on the same day in Parliament. The majority approval for the said Bill was preceded by discussions at length pertaining to the particulars of the Bill. Committee Chair Dr. de Silva and MP Patali Champika Ranawaka abstained from casting their votes. The Central Bank (CBSL) officials clarified that the 30 per cent tax increase, as stipulated by the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill, applies only to the interest income on the bond portfolio. Furthermore, it was highlighted that in the event that superannuation funds do participate in the Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR), this will be reversed to 14 per cent. The Committee also questioned the ability of the CBSL to guarantee the proposed rate of a 12 per cent return until 2025 and nine per cent thereafter to the superannuation funds participating in the DDR. In response, the CBSL Governor stated that it is not possible to guarantee the return to each member; however, he assured them that they will strive to achieve the proposed return. He further mentioned that in the event that this rate cannot be maintained, there is an ongoing discussion for the treasury to step in to ensure the proposed return until 2025. The committee expressed the opinion that a forthcoming amendment should consider an inflation-adjusted interest rate to guarantee a positive return for EPF members. The CBSL Governor also revealed that if the EPF participates in the DDR, the opportunity loss to the EPF bond portfolio is four per cent. However, should the EPF choose not to participate, the opportunity loss to the bond portfolio increases to 21 per cent due to the higher tax rate of 30 per cent as per the latest amendment to the Inland Revenue Bill. Additionally, it was observed that all superannuation funds not eligible for the DDR will be subjected to a 30 per cent tax increase, potentially discouraging the formation of new superannuation funds in the future. Furthermore, the committee, whilst congratulating CBSL Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe, for being named among the 21 Bank Governors, listed in the Global Finance Magazine’s Central Banker Report for 2023, also commended the efforts of the officials present. State Ministers Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, Dr. Suren Raghavan, Dr. Seetha Arambepola, Anupa Pasqual, MPs Wajira Abeywardana, Johnston Fernando, Mahindananda Aluthgamage, Patali Champika Ranawaka, Chandima Weerakkody, Nimal Lanza, U. K. Sumith Udukumbura, Major Pradeep Undugoda, Premnath C. Dolawatte, M. W. D. Sahan Pradeep Withana, Madhura Withanage were present at the Committee Meeting.

title: Nurses seek Police protection
author: Author not found
Content: The Government Nursing Officers’ Association (GNOA) urged the Jaffna Police to provide security for the nursing staff of a ward at the Jaffna Teaching Hospital, where an alleged case of medical negligence occurred, in which the lower part (below the wrist) of an eight-year-old’s right hand was amputated. GNOA Secretary, Ajith Ratnayake alleged the nurses of the ward, in which the eight-year-old was being treated, had received death threats while a few people had even protested outside the Teaching Hospital Jaffna yesterday (7), demanding that the nurses in connection with the incident be taken into custody. “While respecting their right to protest, we emphasise that such influence is justified after reasonable investigation into the said incident,” he said. Ratnayake urged the Health Ministry to initiate a probe parallel to the internal investigation being carried out by the Teaching Hospital. It is also the duty of health authorities to take appropriate measures if an unfair situation was reported.  Explaining the incident, the GNOA Secretary said, the eight-year-old, who had been suffering from fever, was brought to the Jaffna Teaching Hospital on Sunday night (3), after initially being treated for fever in the private sector as her condition did not improve. Ratnayake said, the ward staff on duty at the time had suspected that the girl must have been administered treatment through a vein on her hand as her hand had been swollen even at the time of admission. A cannula had been inserted to the same hand in order to administer a drug upon admission with medical advice. The child’s family members had informed the ward’s nursing staff of the girl’s discomfort, while they in turn had informed the relevant doctors, he said.  Several doses of the drug were administered to the eight-year-old under medical supervision which led to the unfortunate situation in which the child’s hand had become numb. Acting Deputy Director General (Medical Services) Dr. G. Wijesuriya said, a committee, comprising specialists and senior nurses, has been appointed to investigate whether the cannula was at fault or if there were other factors involved. He noted that the committee’s findings would shed light on the incident. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Authority under increased scrutiny
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) is facing increased scrutiny following revelations, of multiple administrative weaknesses and irregularities, during a recent investigation conducted by the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE). One of the key outcomes of the COPE inquiry is the recommendation for the SLPA to submit a proposal within the next three months. This proposal should outline strategies for enhancing revenue, improving cost management, and increasing overall operational efficiency within the organisation. Another significant area of concern is the non-payment of funds to the Consolidated Fund, spanning the period of 2016 to 2021. COPE has initiated an investigation to address this issue and ensure accountability. Additionally, the committee has raised questions about the failure to amend a contract worth USD 282.56 million. This contract was intended for the purchase of 12 oversize cranes and 40 automatic gantry cranes, with the goal of maximising the operational capacity of the east terminal. A startling discovery was the reduction in container handling capacity at the Colombo Port, which has declined from 81% in 2001 to a mere 28% by 2022. This decline raises concerns about the efficiency of port operations. Further investigations have revealed a decrease in the number of ships arriving at the Ports of Colombo, Galle, and Trincomalee from 2018 to 2022, prompting the committee’s attention. The delay in obtaining UNESCO approval for the construction of a multi-purpose terminal at the Galle Port has also raised eyebrows. The project has been suspended for three years due to this delay. Other issues under scrutiny include the payment of overtime allowances to specific employees despite an excess of 914 employees within the authority. The absence of CCTV cameras covering all gates and bonded warehouses within the SLPA has also come to light. Moreover, the Night Navigation system at the Trincomalee Port is reported to be operating below its optimal capacity, which has drawn the committee’s attention. The expenditure on food for the Year 2022 amounted to a significant Rs 1.2 billion, further necessitating a comprehensive review of spending practices. Given the gravity of these findings, the Sri Lanka Ports Authority is expected to be summoned once again before COPE on 8 December 2023. This additional session will provide an opportunity for the SLPA to address the issues raised during the inquiry and take necessary corrective actions. The COPE investigations underscore the imperative of addressing irregularities and weaknesses within the SLPA to ensure transparency, efficiency, and the continued success of Sri Lanka’s vital port operations. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: CEJ files case against Wildlife Dept
author: Author not found
Content: Although a 1,285-hectare piece of land, belonging to the Muthurajawela Wetland Conservation Area and Sanctuary, had been gazetted as a sanctuary through Gazette No. 947/13 of 1996, the Wildlife Conservation Department had failed to physically demarcate the boundary, the National Audit Office revealed. A case has been filed, by Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) at the Court of Appeal, regarding the failure of the authorities to act in accordance with the 4 April 2020 Appellate Court Order to mark the relevant boundaries and take steps to protect the sanctuary. The said case, highlighting illegal activities taking place at the Muthurajawela Wetlands and to prevent such unlawful activities taking place, had been considered before the Court of Appeal on 5 September. The case had been called before a Bench comprising Justices M. T. Mohammad Lafal and Vikum Kaluarachchi. At the hearing the petitioners had pointed out that the order issued to respondents by the Court in April last year to physically demarcate the boundaries of the said wetlands, has not been followed to date. They thus produced submissions to the Bench over the failure of the respondents to abide by the order issued to them which has now exceeded 12-months. The petitioners then mentioned that the Court had issued its directive to the respondents to implement its order within a 90-day period. However, the Attorney General’s Department, appearing on behalf of the respondents, informed the Court that the process of physically demarcating the boundaries of the Muthurajawela Wetlands has commenced. The Court of Appeal Bench having perused the submissions of the petitioners and the Attorney General’s Department, instructed the latter and the respondents to produce a progress report on the physically demarcating of boundaries to Court on or before 8 November and deferred further hearing of the case to the same date. Senior Counsel Ravindranath Dabare on the instructions of Attorney Samadi Hansani appeared for the petitioners. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Mithun Jayawardhana

title: SC orders AVM Thuyacontha’s retirement privileges be restored
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court (SC) yesterday (7) instructed Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam and the respondent parties, to forthwith grant the retirement privileges that retired Air Vice Marshal (AVM) Sampath Thuyacontha had been deprived of. The retired Air Force official’s due retirement privileges, as per his position, had been withdrawn due to him having attended a few political rallies of Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB). The Supreme Court Bench comprising Justices Yasantha Kodagoda and Arjuna Obeysekera, ordered the respondents to promptly hand over a letter to the retired Air Force officer and to his Counsel, stating that the withdrawn retirement privileges would be duly restored. The Apex Court gave this instruction to the respondents, following submissions made by Attorney General Rajaratnam, who assured the Court, that Thuyacontha’s suspended privileges for, will be duly restored. The retired Air Force officer had filed a FR petition before the Supreme Court, praying for an order to the Air Force Commander, to restore his retirement privileges, which had been suspended due to his having attended a few political meetings of the JJB. The petitioner had also moved the Court, to order the respondents to pay him compensation amounting to Rs 5 million and to deem that the actions of the Air Force Commander, had infringed his Fundamental Rights. The petitioner had also named the Administrative Director of the Sri Lanka Air Force, State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon and the Attorney General, as the respondents. He had further informed the Court, via his petition, that he had come to know of the suspension of his retirement privileges and his blacklisting by the Sri Lanka Air Force, via the media last March. But, Thuyacontha a had stated in his petition, that to date his former employer (Air Force), had failed to officially convey to him, about the withdrawal of his retirement privileges and perks. He had stated that he had diligently served the Air Force, for a period in excess of three decades, while doing his utmost towards the war and that during his long service he had also been feted with numerous honours and accolades as well. He had also emphasised that either during his active service or even in his retirement, he had never been engaged in any illegal activity. The petitioner had mentioned that in such a scenario, depriving him of his retirement privileges and proceeding to blacklist him had been questionable tactics adopted by the Sri Lanka Airforce. He had further explained to the Court, that without following the requite law concerning retired officials, the Air Force Commander, has no legal right to blacklist him, under any circumstance. Hence, the former Air Force officer, has pointed out that the Supreme Court, should deem that his Fundamental Rights have been blatantly violated by the Air Force Commander, who had blacklisted him without even seeking a response from him and to deem the actions of the Commander as null and void and to instruct him to pay him compensation of Rs 5 million over the violation of his FR. Attorneys Sunil Watagala and J. M. Wijeyabanndara, looked into the interests of the petitioner. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Printing fake liquor stickers a criminal tax offence – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Saying that fixing of counterfeit stickers on liquor bottles should be considered an offence similar to compilation of forged documents, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa added that offenders committing such acts ought to be prosecuted according to the country’s criminal law. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (7), he stated that printing of counterfeit security stickers is a criminal tax offence.  He charged that instead of striving to prosecute those behind the racket, the Excise Department action, of only subjecting offenders to a minor fine and allowing them to go scot free, cannot be condoned especially in a country which has been rendered bankrupt economically. Speaking further, the Opposition Leader said, “There are ample stocks of liquor bottles with counterfeit stickers at the first floor of the Excise Department, situated inRajagiriya. We have proof that certain corrupt officers of this Department are presently in the process of removing the counterfeit stickers and replacing them with genuine stickers in a bid to sweep this conspiracy under the carpet. The Excise Commissioner General, during a recent radio programme, had mentioned publicly that as they have issued an invoice for illegal liquor bottles the offenders would be released after subjecting them to a settlement fine. However, we have to ask how such offenders could be freed after only imposing a settlement fine on them. Is this so simple and is this a mere minor offence. This regime, due to dwindling State coffers, is continuing to impose taxes on masses. But, they are least concerned about recouping losses, via this racket, by imposing far more stringent punishment on the offenders.” Responding to the views expressed by the Opposition Leader, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya stated that thus far those found guilty of being involved in the racket have not been freed. He added that at the same time stocks of liquor containing counterfeit stickers, seized by the Excise Department have also not been released to the domestic market thus far. The State Minister added that in the recent past the Excise Department had seized around 100,000 bottles of liquor with counterfeit stickers and of that number 43,776 had been 180 mm bottles.  Siyambalapitiya was also said that fines exceeding Rs 52 million had been imposed on offenders. Meanwhile, SJB MP Buddika Pathirana, joining the conversation, pointed out that State Minister Siyambalapitiya, on a previous occasion, had stated that the counterfeit sticker issue had been referred to the CID. He thus asked the Minister to enlighten the House on the progress of the CID investigation, but State Minister Siyambalapitiya did not respond. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Aswesuma’ second stage commences
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe announced the commencement of the second phase of the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefits programme, with a total payment of Rs 1.55 billion allocated to benefit 257,170 recipients for the month of July. In a post on the platform X, the State Minister highlighted that the funds have been transferred to State banks, with the expectation that these banks will credit the payments to the beneficiary accounts by today (8). Additionally, Semasinghe clarified that the Welfare Benefits Board would proceed to disburse payments to the remaining beneficiaries once the verification of accounts is complete. He also mentioned the possibility of consolidating the August payments for all beneficiaries after the July disbursements are finalised. In the initial phase of the welfare benefits programme, a total of Rs 5,016 million was distributed to 791,000 beneficiaries. In the ongoing second phase, the Government has already disbursed Rs 6,566 million to a total of 1,048,170 families, Semasinghe said. Furthermore, Semasinghe said after completing surveys related to appeals and objections, payments would be made to all eligible beneficiaries. (MD)

title: All import restrictions, except private vehicles to be lifted
author: Author not found
Content: The officials representing the Ministry of Finance disclosed that they intend to lift all restrictions on imports, except for private vehicles, by the end of 2023. The officials stated the aforesaid when the Committee requested for a time frame as to how long such restrictions will be in place, post advertently considering the duopolies such restrictions have caused, especially governing wheat flour and tile. The discussion was held at the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) Tuesday (5) in Parliament, chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva. Accordingly, the Committee took into consideration the Regulation under the Imports and Exports (Controls) Act, No. 1 of 1969 published in the Gazette Extraordinary 2341 / 38 of 20.07.2023 and was approved by the Committee. The Order under the Foreign Exchange Act, No. 12 of 2017 was also considered during the Committee on Public Finance chaired by Dr. de Silva and approved. Accordingly, the eligible migration allowance for the emigrants, who are claiming the migration allowance for the first time, was increased from USD 30,000 up to a maximum of USD 50,000 or the equivalent in any other designated foreign currency. The Committee questioned the position of equity for those who migrated the year prior to such order. The officials stated that emigrants who have already claimed migration allowance could claim the remainder up to a maximum of USD 20,000. Moreover, the Social Security Contribution Levy (Amendment) Bill was also considered by the COPF and was approved. Accordingly, the said Bill intends to amend the said Act to exempt any motor vehicle liable to the excise duty under the Excise (Special Provisions) Act, No. 13 of 1989 on the importation in considering excise duty is a composite tax introduced to simplify the tax structure, previously included in the Act. Furthermore, it also intends to exempt equipment used by persons with disabilities, to lower the tax burden on such persons, rough unprocessed gem stones imported for re-exporting after cutting and polishing to maintain the competitiveness of such Sri Lankan business in the global market, by lowering the tax burden and any items sold at duty free shops, similar to other import taxes. However, the Committee questioned the officials present regarding the motive, effectiveness and the impact of exempting equipment used by persons with disabilities to lower the tax burden when access for persons with disability is not being facilitated. State Minister Dr. Suren Raghavan, MPs Chandima Weerakkodi, Wajira Abeywardana, Patali Champika Ranawaka, Nimal Lanza, Isuru Dodangoda, Major Pradeep Undugoda, Dr. Nalaka Godahewa, Mahindananda Aluthgamage and Madhura Withanage were also present at this Committee meeting.

title: A Glowing Tribute to A Great Institution Builder
author: Author not found
Content: Let me pay a tribute to Major General Milinda Peiris, the greatest of all Sri Lankan Vice Chancellors in recent times! The late General Sir John Kotelawala would have been proud of General Peiris, who groomed his students to dress impeccably, converse in English, dine comfortably with the fork and knife, and learn to dance Cuban rumba, Afro-Brazilian samba, Argentinian Brazilian tango and cha cha cha. More than that, he trained them to think wisely and serve unambiguously Sri Lanka and humanity. Anyone walking into General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University (KDU) or University Hospital KDU will witness General Peiris’s outstanding contribution to both military service and higher education in Sri Lanka. Sri Lankan leaders recognised him as a leader with an indomitable spirit and a far-reaching vision. An all-rounder, General Peiris excelled wherever he served and whatever he did! He served in many battlefield appointments including as the General Officer Commanding (GOC) 22 Division in charge of Trincomalee District at the height of the war. Severely injured in battle to liberate Kilinochchi (Sathjaya 3), he never gave up. Committed to human rights, he understood the importance of adhering to international norms and the value of international engagement. Although he reached the appointment of Chief of Army Staff, I wish he became the Army Commander. Unlike many, he was well-read and understood the need to transform the Army into a modern military. With the physical battlespace shifting to the information space, he had the understanding to raise cyber warriors to monitor and rebut online falsehoods and manipulations. However, as Vice Chancellor, Gen. Peiris mentored a generation of scholar-warriors to create that Revolution in Military Affairs that others still lack the understanding to raise to secure Sri Lanka. A man of the calibre of Gen. Peiris was not built overnight. He served in several appointments including as Defence Attache of the Sri Lankan Embassy in the US when the FBI dismantled the LTTE international network on US soil subsequently led to the crucial intelligence needed to sink the LTTE fleet of ships plying between North Korea and Sri Lanka. His steadfast service to Sri Lanka especially his contribution to ending the campaign of terror in Sri Lanka did not end in May 2009. He built an institution that will raise the men and women who will serve the branches of government to protect the nation. I had the pleasure of working with Gen. Peiris when he was a member of the Advisory Council of the Institute of National Security Studies and also as a member of the Board of Management of the Lakshman Kadirgamar Institute of International Relations and Strategic Studies. I also supervised KDU’s first ‘PhD student’ Admiral Jayanath Colombage, a former Navy Commander, who later became Foreign Secretary. Of all the Vice Chancellors I met in Sri Lanka, Gen. Peiris stood out as the Best Vice Chancellor in the contemporary history of Sri Lanka. He did not permit ragging, strikes, or defacing the walls with posters or buildings with graffiti. He maintained discipline, inculcated the spirit of collective leadership, and trained university students to maintain the highest standards that the State Universities were unable to achieve. He took over KDU two years after KDA became a University but it was his vision that transformed the Academy into a fully-fledged University. As Vice Chancellor of General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University from December 2008 to February 2016 and once again from 16 January 2020 until 1 September 2023, he established the foundation that will build the next generation of national security leaders of Sri Lanka. As we need to staff the national security establishments with the nation’s best and the brightest, I admire his commitment and dedication.  He opened up new horizons to the students of KDU by establishing two new facilities; the Faculty of Criminal Justice and the Faculty of Technology. During his tenure, KDU ranked 4th among the 10 Most Prestigious Academies in the World. The other top academies are the United States Military Academy at West Point, PLA National Defence University, China and the Royal Air Force College, USA. As the former Director General of the Institute of National Security Studies of Sri Lanka, may I express my gratitude to this great son of Sri Lanka for raising a generation of warfighters and peacemakers in Sri Lanka and beyond. With such expertise and experience, Gen. Peiris has much more to offer to Sri Lanka and the rest of the world.  In recognition of his steadfast contribution to higher education, may I propose General Peiris be appointed as Vice Chancellor Emeritus of KDU. About the Author: (Dr. Rohan Gunaratna PhD International Relations (St Andrew’s) is an Honorary Professor at General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University and Senior Adviser to its Department of Defence and Strategic Studies. He was a Senior Fellow of the United States Military Academy at West Point). By Prof. Rohan Gunaratna

title: Advancing physiotherapy education globally
author: Author not found
Content: Advancing physiotherapy education globally is essential to ensure that individuals receive high-quality care from well-trained professionals. The case study of Sri Lanka highlights both the challenges and triumphs in this endeavour. Here are some key takeaways: Challenges in physiotherapy education in Sri Lanka: 1. Proliferation of substandard Institutes: One of the significant challenges in Sri Lanka is the presence of unaccredited institutes offering physiotherapy diplomas. These institutes often provide substandard education and can potentially compromise patient care. 2. Regulatory and Accreditation Issues: To maintain high standards in physiotherapy education, Sri Lanka needs to strengthen its regulatory mechanisms and accreditation processes. This includes partnering with international organisations to ensure that educational programmes align with global standards. 3. Risk to Patient Safety: Graduates from these unaccredited institutes may lack the necessary skills and knowledge to provide safe and effective physiotherapy treatments. This poses a risk to the health and well-being of patients in Sri Lanka. 4. Falling Behind International Benchmarks: Without addressing the issue of substandard education, physiotherapy in Sri Lanka may lag behind international benchmarks, hindering the country’s ability to meet the healthcare needs of its population effectively. Triumphs in Physiotherapy Education: 1. Recognition of Significance: Sri Lanka has recognised the importance of physiotherapy in healthcare and has established degree programs in the field at three national universities. This acknowledgment is a positive step towards expanding access to quality education. 2. Global Standards: Many countries, including Sri Lanka, have recognised the importance of adhering to global standards in physiotherapy education. This commitment ensures that students receive a comprehensive education that prepares them for diverse clinical scenarios. 3. World Physiotherapy Day: Celebrating World Physiotherapy Day is an opportunity to raise awareness about the importance of the profession and the need for high-quality education. It serves as a reminder of the tireless efforts of physiotherapists in improving health and well-being worldwide. Conclusion: Physiotherapy education plays a critical role in producing competent professionals who can provide effective care to patients. While challenges exist, such as the presence of substandard institutes, Sri Lanka’s recognition of the importance of physiotherapy and its commitment to global standards are positive steps. Addressing these challenges and continuously improving physiotherapy education is essential to safeguard patient safety and ensure that physiotherapists can meet the healthcare needs of the population. On World Physiotherapy Day, it’s important to pledge support for the ongoing enhancement of physiotherapy education, which remains a cornerstone of quality healthcare delivery worldwide. By Rasika L. Jayakody Secretary Sri Lanka Society of Physiotherapy

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Programme to halt women and children begging
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe said measures will be implemented to address the widespread exploitation of children and women in begging activities. She indicated that she intends to initiate preliminary discussions with various relevant institutions, including the Police, local authorities and the National Child Protection Authority, to combat this issue effectively. This topic was extensively deliberated upon during a recent meeting of the Ministerial Consultative Committee (MCC) on Women’s, Children’s Affairs and Social Empowerment, which was chaired by Kumarasinghe along with MP Anupa Pasqual. During the discussions, it was revealed that the exploitation of children and women for begging has evolved into a profitable business. It has become common practice to hire children for begging purposes, with some being coerced into drug use, while women feign pregnancy to elicit sympathy and contributions. Despite the existence of legal provisions addressing this matter, concerns were raised about the lack of effective implementation at the practical level. Kumarasinghe instructed officials to take immediate action to gather pertinent data regarding beggars in the country, which will be obtained through a survey conducted by the Department of Social Services in September. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Dialog Launches Treasure Hunt in the Futureverse
author: Author not found
Content: Dialog Axiata PLC launched the first phase of the Futureverse mobile app with a thrilling treasure hunt event. This event marked a significant milestone for Dialog Axiata PLC, as it unfolded on Sri Lanka’s first Metaverse mobile app, which also holds the distinction of being the second most downloaded Android mobile app in the country during the launch period. This immersive treasure hunt adventure transported participants into a captivating 3D environment, creating an unforgettable experience. Over 5,000 participants embarked on an interactive treasure hunt by completing three engaging quests within the app. As quests were accomplished, hidden coins and items were presented, upon which participants were able to uncover and collect valuable prizes. Commenting, Anthony Rodrigo, Chief Innovation Officer and Chief Architect of Dialog Axiata PLC said, “Dialog’s Futureverse Metaverse app is redefining how users interact and explore digital spaces. Our treasure hunt event showcased the app’s dynamic capabilities, seamlessly blending the thrill of discovery with technological innovation, further solidifying Dialog’s commitment to providing innovative and immersive experiences for our users.” Dialog Futureverse, the country’s first fully immersive, interactive and experiential Metaverse is a virtual world where users can create their own custom avatars and access all Dialog products and services, socialise with friends, attend events, play games and much more. Powered by immersive technologies like VR and XR, Futureverse extends a seemingly borderless digital realm that delivers endless experiences and possibilities. An exhilarating digital realm is just a download away. Simply head to the Apple App Store or Google Play Store and download the Futureverse app today. Stay tuned for more exciting events coming your way soon.

title: UNP launches digital platform
author: Author not found
Content: Starting this week, every aspect of the UNP has undergone digitalisation, marking a significant step towards rejuvenating the party. The UNP proudly claims the distinction of being the first political party in Sri Lanka to embrace the digital platform in today’s rapidly evolving technological and geopolitical landscape. The launch of the UNP’s digital platform coincided with religious ceremonies held at Sirikotha. These ceremonies were originally planned in conjunction with the UNP’s 77th Convention but had to be postponed due to adverse weather. UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara said, “This new addition to the party aims to streamline our day-to-day operations and position us as a key contributor to Sri Lanka’s journey towards becoming a developed nation by the time we celebrate our 100th Independence Day in 2048. Following the recommendations of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, this goal is certainly attainable.” Rangebandara expressed confidence that this new digital mechanism would enable effective coordination with party members, facilitate consultation with leaders of other political parties, and enhance communication within the UNP members’ network. During the event, UNP Chairman Wajira Abeywardena, General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara, National Organiser Sagala Ratnayake, Assistant Leader Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, and prominent UNP members paid tribute to the late leaders of the party, who made significant contributions to the nation and elevated the party’s stature as a political force, by garlanding their statues. Rangebandara emphasised the close connection between the UNP and the country’s development, highlighting the party’s longstanding commitment to the progress of Sri Lanka. He pointed to a wealth of historical evidence and the party’s consistent positions in the past as a testament to their dedication to the nation’s advancement. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Hi-Expo on 8, 9 Sept a tSt. Thomas’ College, Matale
author: Author not found
Content: The Hi-Expo Higher Education and Career Guidance Exhibition will be held on 8 September (today) and 9 September (tomorrow) from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The event is approved by the Ministry of Education and organised by the Colombo Branch of Matale Old Thomians’ Association (MOTA Colombo) with the support of Mother OBA and other OBA Branches and the School. This event allows students to explore diverse educational paths and career opportunities. Leading higher education institutions nationwide will converge, offering students insights into various academic programmes. The event also features the Skill Development and Vocational Education Department of the Matale District and the region, emphasising holistic career options. The exhibition will showcase the school’s Advanced Level students’ Technical Exhibition, demonstrating innovation and hands-on skills. Notably, distinguished county professionals will guide students in the career guidance programme, aiding them in making informed decisions about their future. Students who have sat for the G.C.E. A/L exam and are awaiting results can also participate in the event. St. Thomas’ College Matale celebrated its 150th Anniversary this month with a range of activities, and this event is another initiation by MOTA Colombo. For more information about the event, contact Dhammika Hewawasam, Principal – St. Thomas’ College, Matale on 078 954 7978.

title: Insights of Student Parliaments vital
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said to initiate the groundwork for an education system fit for the 21st century, insights of Student Parliaments would be also sought. The President said this during a recent meeting with Sivali Central College’s Student Parliament in Ratnapura. Around 140 student representatives visited the Presidential Secretariat and engaged in a friendly discussion. During the interaction, the President explained the role of the Presidential Secretariat in Sri Lanka’s government decision-making process, its history and structure. He shared plans to set up 10 new universities in the country and facilitate higher education opportunities in the UK and the US through student loans. Students will have the freedom to choose their desired subjects and educational reforms, including new technology colleges, are under consideration. President Wickremesinghe encouraged the students to actively participate in college Student Parliament activities and even invited them to hold meetings in the main auditorium of the Presidential Secretariat, where Sri Lanka’s First Parliament convened. He also acknowledged the presence of students from the previous group, expressing gratitude for the opportunities provided by his administration. Principal of the Ratnapura Sivali Central College Neil Wathukarawatta and several teachers were also in attendance.

title: All import restrictions, except private vehicles to be lifted
author: Author not found
Content: The officials representing the Ministry of Finance disclosed that they intend to lift all restrictions on imports, except for private vehicles, by the end of 2023. The officials stated the aforesaid when the Committee requested for a time frame as to how long such restrictions will be in place, post advertently considering the duopolies such restrictions have caused, especially governing wheat flour and tile. The discussion was held at the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) Tuesday (5) in Parliament, chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva. Accordingly, the Committee took into consideration the Regulation under the Imports and Exports (Controls) Act, No. 1 of 1969 published in the Gazette Extraordinary 2341 / 38 of 20.07.2023 and was approved by the Committee. The Order under the Foreign Exchange Act, No. 12 of 2017 was also considered during the Committee on Public Finance chaired by Dr. de Silva and approved. Accordingly, the eligible migration allowance for the emigrants, who are claiming the migration allowance for the first time, was increased from USD 30,000 up to a maximum of USD 50,000 or the equivalent in any other designated foreign currency. The Committee questioned the position of equity for those who migrated the year prior to such order. The officials stated that emigrants who have already claimed migration allowance could claim the remainder up to a maximum of USD 20,000. Moreover, the Social Security Contribution Levy (Amendment) Bill was also considered by the COPF and was approved. Accordingly, the said Bill intends to amend the said Act to exempt any motor vehicle liable to the excise duty under the Excise (Special Provisions) Act, No. 13 of 1989 on the importation in considering excise duty is a composite tax introduced to simplify the tax structure, previously included in the Act. Furthermore, it also intends to exempt equipment used by persons with disabilities, to lower the tax burden on such persons, rough unprocessed gem stones imported for re-exporting after cutting and polishing to maintain the competitiveness of such Sri Lankan business in the global market, by lowering the tax burden and any items sold at duty free shops, similar to other import taxes. However, the Committee questioned the officials present regarding the motive, effectiveness and the impact of exempting equipment used by persons with disabilities to lower the tax burden when access for persons with disability is not being facilitated. State Minister Dr. Suren Raghavan, MPs Chandima Weerakkodi, Wajira Abeywardana, Patali Champika Ranawaka, Nimal Lanza, Isuru Dodangoda, Major Pradeep Undugoda, Dr. Nalaka Godahewa, Mahindananda Aluthgamage and Madhura Withanage were also present at this Committee meeting.

title: Loopholes in Excise Law allow sticker racketeers go free
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Buddhika Pathirana says that racketeers, who have released bottles of liquor to the market containing counterfeit stickers, are able to go scot free after only being subjected to a modest fine due primarily to loopholes in the Excise law. Addressing a media conference held at the Opposition Leader’s Office recently, the MP stated that the entire racket of printing counterfeit stickers and placing them on liquor bottles and then releasing such stocks to the local market is done intentionally and with the blessings of big wigs of the Excise Department. He termed it as a deliberate crime. He therefore pointed out that instead of taking stringent action to prosecute offenders, as per the Provisions of the Penal Code, subjecting offenders to only ordinary fines as per the Excise Act, could best be described as measures adopted by the Excise Commissioner General to protect wrongdoers. Speaking further, the MP stated, “This racket is akin to printing of forged currency. Printing counterfeit stickers also falls under the crime of compilation of forged documents. In such an event if such offences are only described as technical offences, we feel the Excise Commissioner General is safeguarding a set of corrupt officials and he is striving to sweep this racket under the carpet. We also suspect that the Commissioner General could also be receiving kickbacks in return from liquor firms involved in this racket. If the Commissioner General is failing to prosecute corrupt officers who are in the Department, then it has to be said clearly that he too is a part of this corrupt and sinister system.” The MP added that the attention drawn towards the said racket by the Parliament Committee on Ways and Means (PCWM), helmed by MP Patali Ranawaka has also been timely. The lawmaker noted that following him having shed light on the sordid racket for years the PCWM taking action to address the issue has been commendable and would go a long way towards rooting out such malpractices for once and for all.

title: Budget 2024: President Promises ‘Many Surprises’
author: Author not found
Content: “The Budget 2024 will contain many surprises,” President Ranil Wickremesinghe said yesterday (6) in Parliament, one of which will be a proposal to tax primary bond dealers. He made this statement in response to Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa’s allegation that the Government plans to impose a 30 per cent tax on EPF holders who choose not to participate in the debt optimisation process. President Wickremesinghe said, “We will tax the primary bond dealers through the next budget, and you will find surprises in the budget.” He also expressed his disapproval of Opposition Leader Premadasa’s criticism of companies that invest in bonds, suggesting that seeking funds from these companies for various purposes is inconsistent with his stance. Additionally, President Wickremesinghe clarified that the proposal to impose a 30 per cent tax on EPF was initially put forward by the SLPP even before he became Prime Minister. He referenced the Supreme Court’s verdict on the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill, highlighting that the Court found no issues with it. Further, he pointed out that the banks’ inability to participate in the domestic debt optimisation process was emphasised in the Supreme Court’s determination due to their limited capital reserves. In response to Chairman of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), Harsha de Silva’s request to debate the Inland Revenue Amendment Bill, which includes provisions for the 30 per cent tax on EPF, President Wickremesinghe made these statements. A tense situation arose in Parliament when Opposition MPs protested the decision to debate the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill before it had been examined by the Parliamentary Committee on Public Finance. Dr. de Silva addressed the issue, stating that the COPF had not yet discussed the Inland Revenue Amendment Bill. He emphasised that the Finance Committee had not conducted any analysis of the Bill and raised concerns that this move might sideline the State Finance Committee within Parliament. The COPF Chair disclosed that he had requested information about the bill from the Finance Secretary, but as of yesterday (6), he had not received the necessary data. He questioned how a thorough analysis of the bill could be conducted without access to this essential information. By Methmalie Dissanayake
