title: Only an independent probe will clear Channel 4 findings – Cardinal
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith said the Catholic Church of Sri Lanka was prepared to accept the facts that were revealed in the documentary aired on Britain’s Channel 4 on the Easter Sunday terror attacks in 2019, and would reject the findings only following a transparent, independent and honest investigation into them. Fielding questions during a media briefing at the Archbishops House, Colombo, Cardinal Ranjith yesterday (6) said the probe should be in accordance with international laws and standards to ensure that it is carried out in a transparent, independent manner sans political interference. “We wish to urge our fellow citizens to focus their attention on the facts that have been presented through the programme as our concern is not to find fault with the Channel on or its past relations with the country,” he said noting that it was the Channel’s findings that were important to Sri Lanka’s Catholic Church. Cardinal Ranjith said Minister Manusha Nanayakkara said a Parliamentary Select Committee would be appointed to look into matters that had been revealed in the programme on the Easter Sunday attacks. “We wish to note that even though Parliamentary Select Committees and a Presidential Committee of Inquiry as well as other committees were appointed in the past to investigate these sad events and many recommendations were made by those commissions, no credible and positive action was taken by political authorities on the recommendations. He accused the present and the previous government of only paying lip service to the recommendations. Even the recommendations which were implemented such as the banning of several extremist organisations such as the National Thowheeth Jama’ath had been lifted recently,” he said.   The Head of Sri Lanka’s Catholic Church said therefore no tangible and credible results would emerge from yet another Parliamentary Select Committee. Instead, it would be a waste of public funds and time. According to the Catholic Church of Sri Lanka, investigations should be carried out on the findings outlined in the various commission reports already presented. And recommendations stated there need to be implemented, he said. Cardinal Ranjith said investigations should be made by an independent international investigation team assisted by Sri Lankan officials of the CID whose services were originally sought by the Government and transferred to other areas and posts by biased political authorities. He said to ensure that the fresh investigation will be independent of officials in the Police and the intelligence being investigated following the Easter Attacks and hold positions at present should be suspended or moved out of their present high posts to ensure the independence of the investigation. Cardinal Ranjith urged President Ranil Wickremesinghe and the Government to carry out these requests. “We do not feel that truth and justice will be meted to the innocent victims of the 2019 Easter Attacks, unless an absolutely independent, transparent and sincere internationally monitored investigation probe was carried out,” Cardinal Ranjith stressed noting that the Catholic Church did not believe in mere promises but in action. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Govt lacks resolve to uncover truth – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, who alleged the Government does not care about delivering justice to the victims of the Easter Sunday terror attacks in 2019, questioned whether it is because the masterminds of the attack were now with the Government. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (6), Premadasa said the Government decision to appoint another Select Committee to investigate the Easter attacks appears to be an insincere gesture. Premadasa alleged that the Government came to power by exploiting racial tensions and undermining national unity while promising justice for the Easter attack victims. He said the Government has failed to reveal the complete truth about the Easter attacks and has not conducted a fair, impartial, and transparent investigation. He said the international community has also expressed doubts about the investigation. When Cardinal Ranjith raised concerns, the Opposition leader pointed out that the response was inadequate, suggesting the need for a transparent investigation and the possibility of appointing a Select Committee, which he saw as an evasive tactic. Premadasa said the need for an impartial and fair investigation within the country, especially considering the loss of many lives in the barbaric Easter attack. He said the majority believe that there has not been a fair local investigation into this terrorist attack. He stressed the importance of justice for the victims and their families. Premadasa lamented the racist attacks that followed the Easter attack, targeting the Muslim community. He criticised individuals who promoted racism and division and gained ministerial positions by exploiting national unity. He claimed that these individuals have failed to identify the masterminds behind the attack and suggested that the Government lacks the resolve to uncover the truth. Furthermore, he called for an international investigation and proposed that fair investigations could be conducted with both local and international cooperation under a united government committed to justice and transparency. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Channel 4 has history of rivalry with Rajapaksas – Namal
author: Author not found
Content: Refuting the allegations levelled in the controversial Channel 4 documentary on Easter Sunday terror attacks in 2019 that the terror attacks were used as a ploy to elect Gotabaya Rajapaksa as the President, Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa claimed that before 2019 all members of the Rajapaksa family were at the Financial Crimes Investigation Division (FCID) and prison most of the time, and as a result, none of them had time to carry out such a conspiracy. Apart from Namal Rajapaksa, none of his family members has spoken about the controversy so far. Speaking in Parliament, Rajapaksa stressed that Channel 4 has harboured a long-standing rivalry with the Rajapaksas, dating back to the conclusion of the war in 2009. He questioned the credibility of the video, pointing out that it was subsequently deleted from the channel’s website. Rajapaksa expressed his concerns that the latest video from Channel 4 may be another attempt to settle scores with the Rajapaksas for their role in eliminating terrorism from Sri Lanka or to serve certain political agendas. He stressed, “Channel 4 has a historical animosity towards my family, my father, and the Rajapaksa name, particularly following the conclusion of the war in 2009. They have consistently released videos targeting the Rajapaksas. In my view, Channel 4 appears to function more as a video production entity than a genuine media institution.” Speaking further, Rajapaksa said it is important not to exploit the tragic events of the Easter Sunday attacks for political purposes. “Investigations are still underway into the tragedy. These things could hinder those investigations,” he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Minister Chandrakanthan rubbishes Channel 4 documentary
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan (Pillaiyan), while rubbishing the controversial Channel 4 report on the 21 April 2019, Easter bombings in Sri Lanka as false news, yesterday (6) said it is disturbing that a media outlet operating in Europe published such untrue news to confuse and mislead people without investigating the truth properly. “I saw Hanzeer Azad Maulana’s untruthful statement linking us to the Easter bombings in support of foreign powers, which were waiting to bring us down, for his personal political asylum claim. It is really disturbing that such a media outlet operating in Europe has published such untrue news to confuse and mislead people without investigating the truth properly.” Azad Maulana, who had been engaged in office-related activities with us during my tenure as Chief Minister, left the country approximately a year and a half ago due to significant conflicts in his personal life, the State Minister insisted. He also said it is usual for people who make asylum claims in foreign countries to criticise us (MPs/rulers) and political parties to confirm their asylum claims. However, due to his (Maulana’s) association with me, he went a few miles ahead and got his asylum claim confirmed by portraying himself in the news, he added. “I have personally witnessed on numerous occasions the presence of deceit and treachery in the paths I have traversed. The central theme of the video falsely portrays the Easter bombings as a strategy for regime change. This is entirely untrue, and even individuals with a basic understanding of politics can readily discern the facts.” “The Easter bombings occurred on 21 April 2019. However, it is important to note that the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) had already secured a resounding victory in the Local Government Elections in early 2018, maintaining a strong majority. It is evident, even to the layperson, that there would have been no reason to launch such an attack under such circumstances, because the party was in a very strong position when they faced the Presidential Election.” Also, the Easter bombings carried out in Sri Lanka are very cruel, so we are sure that all those involved should be given the maximum punishment of death. Therefore, it can be observed that Hanzeer Azad Maulana himself has expressed his views as if he was directly connected with the incident. Therefore, he should also be investigated and the culprits, whoever they may be, should be severely punished in accordance with the law, he asserted. He stressed that there is no doubt that the Easter bombings will be shocking to those who are not aware of the brutal global attacks carried out by Islamist fundamentalist terrorists. “We also have strong suspicions that this is an attempt to get the real criminals to escape under the organised agenda of Islamist extremists ISIS, which is run by more intellectuals and the wealthy.” In addition, Channel 4 has been informed that the military intelligence officer Suresh Sallay, who is mainly associated with this story, was not in Sri Lanka during the timeframe mentioned by Maulana. He was abroad, and he was not working on military duty of Sri Lanka since January 2018 until the attack took place, he added.

title: One should be cautious about close acquaintances – Sirisena
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Chairman, former President Maithripala Sirisena, who spoke about suspending the Party membership ofMP Dayasiri Jayasekara, said one should exercise caution and be vigilant regarding the actions of close acquaintances. In a surprising move, the SLFP removed MP Jayasekara, who was the party’s General Secretary and replaced him with Sarath Ekanayake as the Acting General Secretary. In a letter dated 5 September sent by the SLFP Chairman, it was stated that Jayasekera’s party membership has been suspended, and a disciplinary inquiry will be conducted in accordance with the party’s constitution. Additionally, a charge sheet will be issued within the next 14 days. This decision was made during a meeting held at Sirisena’s residence. Responding to the media about Jayasekara’s suspension, Sirisena, who was seemingly in a light mood, said, “We did not kick Jayasekara out of the Party. This is only a temporary move. I have a Court case with regard to my party chairmanship. So, I do not wish to reveal more details at this moment.” Sirisena said there is no issue with Jayasekara continuing his party membership. However, Jayasekara won’t be given the General Secretary post. “He can have any other post, but not the General Secretary post,” Sirisena added. “The decision to suspend Jayasekara’s party membership was taken because of certain actions of him. If he likes to compromise and reach an agreement, then there would be no problems with having Jayasekara in the party,” he said. When reminded that Jayasekara was the right hand of Sirisena in the Party, the latter said in politics anything could happen. “This is politics. All the members of Bandaranaike family were removed from the Party as well. These things happen,” he further said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘I never bite the hand that feeds me’– Dayasiri
author: Author not found
Content: MP Dayasiri Jayasekara who was removed from the post of Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) General Secretary and suspended from Party membership said he was suspended because some people, particularly the Party Chairman were afraid he would take over the leadership of the Party. Addressing the media at a press conference, Jayasekara said he did his best to put the Party back on its feet since he was given the General Secretary post in 2019. Jayasekara said the Party’s decision was not the sentiment felt at the grassroots. “Most of the membership do not want to be a part of the Government. It is a handful people at the top who want to remove me because they want to plug this party to the UNP”, he added. The ousted General Secretary said he was taken aback when he received the email regarding his ouster on 5 September night. Speaking further, Jayasekara said there was a spilt within the party about being a part of the Government. Several MPs joined the Government and received ministerial portfolios. I always acted against it. “If the party wants to act according to their wishes and kick me out, I have nothing to say about it” he said. Dayasiri said the move made by party Chairman Maithripala Sirisena was not a surprise because the latter has taken similar courses of action in the past as well. “This is a completely wrong decision because many Central Committee members including myself were not invited to the meeting on the night of 5 September. I will take necessary action about it,” he added. Moreover, Jayasekara said Sirisena should not entertain fears about the leadership because he said, “I never bite the hand that fed me”. However, Sirisena must realise about those who really intend to harm him, he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: JJB wants inquiry initiated into Channel 4 claims
author: Author not found
Content: Following the controversial documentary of Britain’s Channel 4 on the Easter Sunday terror attacks 2019, the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) called on the Government to take immediate action to remove Major General Suresh Salley, the Director of the State Intelligence Service (SIS) and initiate an impartial inquiry into his actions and Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan, also known as Pillaiyan, regarding their alleged involvement in the carnage. Addressing a media briefing, JJB MP Vijitha Herath emphasised the absurdity of conducting an inquiry while Suresh Salley, who faces allegations, continues to hold the position of SIS Director. “As claimed by Azad Maulana in the Channel 4 video, it is evident that former Eastern Province Chief Minister P Chandrakanthan and Suresh Salley had direct connections with the perpetrators of the Easter Sunday bombings. Incriminating photographs featuring Gotabaya Rajapaksa, Maulana, and Pillaiyan have surfaced. Maulana himself has disclosed his association with Pillaiyan. The actual culprits behind the attacks remain at large due to the misdirection of investigations. These revelations unveil the masterminds and true motives behind the attacks,” Herath alleged. The MP further pointed out that Salley, who faced accusations related to the attacks, was appointed as the Director of the SIS by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa shortly after assuming office. This raises questions about potential connections between Salley’s appointment and the Easter attacks. Herath also stressed the need to resume investigations against Gotabaya Rajapaksa now that he is no longer the President, as he no longer enjoys immunity from legal proceedings. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: PTC case against Fowzie deferred to 7 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (6) deferred further proceedings of the Pre-Trial Conference (PTC) of the case filed against former Minister A.H.M. Fowzie to 7 November. The former Minister has been accused before the High Court, by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) of the misuse of a luxury jeep worth Rs 2.5 billion provided to the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) by the Dutch Government, while serving as the Minister of Disaster Management and thereby causing a loss of profit to the State by his actions and for violating Provisions of the Bribery Act. When the PTC was called for hearing yesterday, defendant was not present in Court and his lawyer submitted a letter to Judge Marasinghe to confirm his client’s inability to appear, due to official work in Parliament. Accordingly, the Court fixed further the hearing of the PTC to the aforementioned date.    BY Hansi Nanayakkarra

title: Police initiate building database on criminals
author: Author not found
Content: Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon yesterday (6) revealed that due to the absence of a proper database at the Police Department about accurate information on criminals in the past decade, a rise in crimes is being witnessed in the country.  “We have started establishing such a database and about 75 per cent of the work has been completed,” he said. Addressing the media at the Department of Government Information, SDIG Tennakoon said there was a necessity to have a comprehensive database that contains information about those involved in organised crimes in the past decade. SDIG Tennakoon said it has been decided to commence fresh investigations into the unsolved organised crimes that happened in the last five years. “Within the last three months, 42 organised crimes using firearms have occurred and 22 of them were murders. “Some persons involved in various crimes have gone abroad and steps have been taken to repatriate them with the support of INTERPOL,” he added. He also said that Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles and IGP C.D. Wickramaratne have instructed to initiate a special programme to eradicate crime within the next three months. He also said Police have identified the masterminds behind crimes while being in prison. “A special programme will be carried to prevent such occurrences,” he said. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Bishops’ Conference still reviewing PCoI report
author: Author not found
Content: The Lawyers of the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of Sri Lanka are allegedly still going through the report of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) into the 21 April 2019, Easter Sunday terror attacks, handed over to it by the Minister of Public Security in April this year. Fielding questions during a media briefing, Archbishop of Colombo, Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith said they were still going through the report which had over 70,000 pages with a fine-tooth comb. He noted that the Bishops’ Conference could not publicise the document according to government instructions when handing it over to the Bishop’s Conference. “Those who wish to go through it would have to obtain it by submitting a Right to Information (RTI) request to Government authorities,” he said.  Spokesman for the Colombo Archdiocese, Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando noted that there were areas in the copy of the report handed to the Catholic Bishops’ Conference that they felt needed to be investigated further instead of being merely glanced over. “We are listing those sections which need to be probed further and will bring it to the attention of the relevant authorities,” he noted. Meanwhile, Cardinal Ranjith, lashing out, said despite claims by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa that he (Cardinal Ranjith) had not issued any instructions urging the Catholic community of Sri Lanka to refrain from voting for Premadasa at the 2019 Presidential Election, “There are rumours that I had urged the people to vote for ousted President Gotabaya Rajapaksa instead. But the fact is that I refused to meet any of the Presidential candidates after they handed in nominations.”  Cardinal Ranjith lamented that the claims that he had urged the Catholics to vote for President Rajapaksa at the elections had been started by another Catholic Minister who went around publicising the false information. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Forger given suspended sentence
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (6) sentenced a State Bank employee, charged with forgery, to one year’s Rigorous Imprisonment (RI), suspended for five-years. The suspect pleaded guilty to the charge of forging the signature of former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa. The Magistrate afterwards, sternly warned the suspect bank official on his future conduct and also fined him Rs 1,500. The suspect, who had been interdicted from his bank, had been arrested and produced in Court, by the CID, on 28 March last year on the charge of forging the former President’s signature on a fake letterhead, aimed at reinstating him in his former post. The suspect was then remanded by the Court and later enlarged on bail. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Nagamuwa ordered to appear before CID Digital Forensics Div
author: Author not found
Content: Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) politburo member Duminda Nagamuwa was ordered by the Colombo Fort Magistrate to present himself before the Digital Forensics Division of the CID. Nagamuwa made a court appearance yesterday (6) regarding allegations that he had disseminated defamatory statements on social media platforms, including Facebook and YouTube, targeting Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage ordered Nagamuwa to appear before the Digital Forensics Division of the CID at 9:00 a.m. on 12 September. Previously, on 31 August, the Colombo Fort Magistrate had issued summons to the FSP member, requiring his presence in court yesterday (6).

title: Xi Jinping to skip G20 Summit in New Delhi
author: Author not found
Content: Chinese President Xi Jinping will skip the coming weekend’s annual G20 Summit in New Delhi, India and will be sending Chinese Premier Li Qiang in his place. Since Xi became China’s Leader, he has attended every other G20 Summit. Some commentators see the move as a deliberate snub; Beijing has long-standing border tensions with New Delhi that escalated into a brief but deadly clash in 2020. India’s membership in the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue alongside Australia, Japan, and the United States has also angered China. Yet these issues aren’t new, which makes Xi’s absence a little more puzzling. At the BRICS Summit in Johannesburg, South Africa, last month, Xi and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi seemed to get along relatively well. In a private meeting, the two leaders nominally agreed to reduce border tensions. Xi may be irritated with India for lobbying against China’s influence within BRICS as it plans to add six new members. Foreign Policy’s China Brief said the tensions may also be related to cartography. After the summit, China’s Ministry of Natural Resources released a new official map that—as usual—included other countries’ territory as part of China, including the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh, which China briefly invaded in 1962 and claims as part of southern Tibet. India protested vehemently, suggesting that New Delhi may perceive the timing of the map’s release as a provocation. Xi’s supposed G20 snub could be a response to this anger, the website noted. (SRM)

title: Launch of ‘SLIC Jeewana Shakthi’ for Tea Plantation Sector
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation (SLIC), one of the largest and robust insurance companies in the country introduces ‘SLIC Jeewana Shakthi’, a special Life and Health Insurance cover for the Estate and Plantation Workers of Sri Lanka. This special cover was developed in collaboration with the Plantation Human Development Trust (PHDT) and the Ministry of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development. Sri Lanka is known across the world for its tea: Famously known as Ceylon Tea. The country’s tea industry is one of the prominent economic sectors and the estate employees and tea plantation workers are the backbone of this industry. Tea Estate employees encompass a wide range of roles, from managerial positions to skilled artisans whilst the tea plantation workers engage in physically demanding tasks. At present, there are over 150,000 tea estate employees and tea plantation workers. It is the responsibility of the stakeholders involved in this industry to ensure the well-being of this community which plays a pivotal role in sustaining the tea industry of Sri Lanka. SLIC, as a responsible insurance solutions provider taps into new markets with new products to uplift the lifestyles of the people of the country. This stems from their mandate of providing ‘insurance for All’ Sri Lankans.  Understanding the importance of this community and their unique needs SLIC came forward to provide a suitable insurance solution for their well-being. As a result, the State-owned insurer has introduced ‘Sri Lanka Insurance Jeewana Shakthi’, a special life and health cover for this unique segment of customers. ‘SLIC Jeewana Shakthi’ is a life cover offered exclusively to the Estate employees and Plantation workers of the tea industry as a special insurance solution. It is offered as a family cover and is open for employees between 18- 70 years of age and includes critical illness benefits, ‘hospital cash benefits’, Life covers etc. The Policy covers the policy holders’ spouse and children as well. Commenting on the launch of ‘SLIC Jeewana Shakthi’ insurance cover, Chandana L. Aluthgama, CEO, SLIC said: “SLIC continues to demonstrate its commitment to providing innovative and tailor-made insurance solutions that cater to the evolving needs of the people of Sri Lanka by offering unparalleled value and comprehensive protection to its valued customers at an affordable price.” President’s Counsel Ronald C. Perera, Chairman, SLIC, said: “Sri Lanka Insurance as the pioneer insurance provider of the country has always been at the forefront in understanding the pulse of the people and supporting them in improving their quality of life.  The tea industry plays a pivotal role in the country’s economy and as responsible corporate citizens, it is every the organisation’s responsibility to facilitate such requirements to strengthen the economy of the country. Barath Arullsamy, Chairman, PHDT commented: “We stand on the threshold of a transformative moment with the introduction of ‘SLIC Jeevana Shakthi,’ a ground-breaking insurance scheme born from the collaboration between the Plantation Human Development Trust (PHDT), the Ministry of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development, and Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation.  “The plantation sector workers, with their dedication and sweat, are the lifeblood of our nation’s plantation industry. ‘SLIC Jeevana Shakthi’ encapsulates our unwavering commitment to their well-being, providing life and critical illness coverage up to Rs 300,000, coupled with a daily hospital cash benefit of Rs 500. This Scheme extends not just protection, but a lifeline, especially during times of adversity”. He further said: “We are immensely grateful to SLIC and the Ministry for their visionary partnership in shaping this unique offering, tailored to uplift the lives of the very individuals who cultivate our nation’s prosperity. I extend a heartfelt invitation to all Regional Plantation Companies to join us in fortifying this endeavour. Together with your support towards the ‘SLIC Jeevana Shakthi’ Insurance Scheme, we can demonstrate our collective dedication to safeguarding the rights, dignity, and prosperity of the Plantation sector workforce and their family, a community whose contributions stand at the core of Sri Lanka’s growth story.” Jeevan Thondaman, Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development commented: “Today marks a profound step forward as we unveil ‘SLIC Jeewana Shakthi’ – an exceptional insurance scheme co-crafted by the Ministry of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development, the Plantation Human Development Trust (PHDT) and Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation (SLIC). This initiative stands as a testament to our unwavering commitment to the welfare of tea estate workers, underpinned by the distinctiveness of this Scheme. “Tea estate workers form the backbone of our economy, yet their hard work can expose them to unforeseen risks. ‘SLIC Jeewana Shakthi’ provides up to Rs 300,000 in life and critical illness coverage, along with Rs 500 daily hospital cash benefit. It will provide financial security and a safety cushion during times of hardship. With a monthly premium starting at just Rs 99 for a family of four, it is also the most cost-effective insurance solution available for anyone. “I would like to thank the Chairman, Board of Directors and the Team at SLIC for coming forward and creating this unique product together with the Ministry and the PHDT. “I take this opportunity to invite Regional Plantation Companies to join us in this endeavour, showcasing their commitment to workers’ protection and well-being. Your support will provide more than financial security to tea estate workers; it will be your gratitude in action: Together, let’s ensure a future of security and progress for the true heroes of our tea industry.”

title: USFDA lauds Yaden Labs’ state-of-the-art facility
author: Author not found
Content: United States Food and Drug Administration (USFDA) officials visited Yaden Laboratories Pvt. Ltd., a modern, state-of-the-art sterile formulation finished dosage manufacturing facility inside the Katunayake Export Processing Zone, as part of their programme in Sri Lanka along with the National Medicine Regulatory Authority (NMRA) aimed to support and improve Sri Lanka’s pharmaceutical regulatory system and Quality Control. USFDA authorities commended Yaden Laboratories Pvt. Ltd., for its well-maintained sterile manufacturing facility. The current challenges faced by local pharmaceutical manufacturers and improvements to supply chains were discussed during this visit.

title: SL-China Investment Promotion Forum 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka-China Investment Promotion Forum 2023 was held in Shanghai on 5 September. State Minister of Investment Promotion Dilum Amunugama represented Sri Lanka. At the forum, enterprises from various industries in China enthusiastically reached investment intentions in related fields, including medicine, solar power generation, wind energy, fisheries, infrastructure and so on, with a signed amount of USD 100 million. The China Representative Office of the Ministry of Investment Promotion of Sri Lanka was inaugurated on the same day. According to reports, Sri Lanka’s key investment areas involve pharmaceuticals, clothing, textiles and accessories, electrical and electronics, rubber, automobile components, medical equipment, machinery and electrical appliances, mineral processing and other manufacturing industries; renewable energy, comprehensive hazardous waste, logistics centres, hospitals and other infrastructure; information technology, hotels and tourism, education services such as breeding; there are also agricultural projects such as processed food, fish and seafood, spices and concentrates, fruits and vegetables. The minimum entry threshold for foreign investment is USD 250,000, which provides incentives for financial measures such as corporate income tax and tariff exemption. It is reported that Sri Lanka has taken multiple measures to establish regional logistics centres and promote the development of tourism. In the next few years, Sri Lanka will accelerate the development of the digital economy.

title: Increased risk of human-elephant conflicts
author: Author not found
Content: Wildlife officers in Polonnaruwa, Welikanda, Maduru Oya, Weheragala and Manampitiya said due to forest reserves situated in Thoppigala, Wadamune, Maduru Oya, and Thrikonamaduwa being cleared by timber racketeers, such areas could witness human-elephant conflicts before long. They further said in Welikanda, nine wild elephants had perished due to human-elephant conflicts this year alone. They said due to large-scale deforestation by these racketeers, the habitats of wild elephants have been destroyed, resulting in them encroaching on towns and villages leading to conflicts with residents. The officers also added that due to deforestation by timber racketeers and hunting of wild animals by poachers, the animals tend to encroach on towns seeking food and water leading to human-elephant conflicts and they warned if the situation is not resolved by the Government urgently, it would be disastrous. By Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: Woman soldier gets new house
author: Author not found
Content: At a ceremony held in the Alayadivembu DS Division recently, a house, complete with all amenities, was handed over to a woman soldier whose home was destroyed in a sudden fire. The woman soldier, Thavaseelan Dirona, is a member of the 3rd Battalion, Sri Lanka Army Women’s Corps. Her house was completely gutted by fire. This tragic event left Dirona, along with her grandparents, in dire straits. Recognising the predicament of this soldier, Major General W. Chandrasiri, General Officer Commanding, 24 Infantry Division, took immediate steps to construct a new house for her. Under the guidance of Major General Chandrasiri and the coordination and supervision of Colonel L.S.D.N. Pathirathna, Commander of the 241 Infantry Division, along with generous support from the trade communities in Akkaraipattu, the house was rebuilt. The collective efforts of the 11th Battalion Sri Lanka National Guard, coupled with financial and material contributions from well-wishers proved invaluable. The house was handed over to the soldier and her family by the Major General. The event was attended by Alayadivembu Divisional Secretary along with several local businessmen and residents. Lunch parcels were distributed to residents who were in attendance. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Sri Lanka to assume Chairmanship of IORA
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka will assume the Chairmanship of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) from 2023 to 2025 at the forthcoming23rd Council of Ministers’ Meeting hosted by Sri Lanka on 11 October 2023 in Colombo. Sri Lanka has chosen ‘Strengthening Regional Architecture: Reinforcing Indian Ocean Identity’ as the theme for its Chairmanship of IORA. Ministers of Foreign Affairs of the 23 Member States and the 11 Dialogue Partners or their representatives and Senior Officials are expected to attend the Indian Ocean Rim Association Council of Ministers and Committee of Senior Officials meetings in Colombo in October 2023. The Member States of the Indian Ocean Rim Association are Australia, Bangladesh, Comoros, France, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kenya, Madagascar, Malaysia, Maldives, Mauritius, Mozambique, Oman, Seychelles, Singapore, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Tanzania, Thailand, United Arab Emirates and Yemen. The Dialogue Partners are China, Egypt, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the Russian Federation, Saudi Arabia, Türkiye, the UK and the USA. The 25th Meeting of the Committee of Senior Officials will precede the Council of Ministers’ Meeting. This is the second time that Sri Lanka will assume the IORA Chairmanship, having previously served as the Chair from 2003 to 2004. The Indian Ocean Rim Association is the only intergovernmental regional forum that brings together 23 littoral States of the Indian Ocean. There are also 11 Dialogue Partners in the Association. Sri Lanka is a founding member of the Association. The Indian Ocean Rim Association marked its 25th anniversary in 2022. The Council of Ministers is the highest decision-making body of the IORA, and Foreign Minister Ali Sabry will be the Chair of the Council of Ministers during Sri Lanka’s Chairmanship. Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane will chair the IORA Senior Officials Meeting preceding the Council of Ministers. The primary objectives of the IORA are to promote regional economic integration, enhance trade and investment, facilitate sustainable development, and strengthen maritime safety and security and it focuses on several priority areas, including maritime safety and security, trade and investment facilitation, fisheries management, disaster risk reduction, academic and scientific cooperation, tourism and cultural exchanges, and women’s economic empowerment. The Secretariat for Sri Lanka’s Chairmanship of IORA will function under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs headed by Executive Director General Prof. Sudharshan Seneviratne, former High Commissioner of Sri Lanka to Bangladesh. Officials of the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) and Sri Lanka Navy will be attached to the Secretariat, along with senior officials of the Foreign Ministry.

title: Protest against improper waste disposal in Mathugama PS
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was staged against the alleged improper disposal of waste by the Mathugama Pradeshiya Sabha (PS) in a densely populated area near a prominent school in Mathugama. Several years ago, the Mathugama PS collected electronic waste, including mobile phone batteries, tube lights, television tubes, and other electronic items, from its suburbs for recycling. However, instead of proper recycling, these hazardous materials, which should not be released into the environment, were illegally dumped at the old Horawala school site, the residents alleged. It is reported that on the request of the Mathugama Divisional Secretary, the sacks containing electronic waste were buried in the Welipenna Holinbone Colony Cemetery. Subsequently, when residents protested against the dumping of waste in the cemetery, citing health concerns, the electronic waste was moved to the Athulathmudaligama waste yard. Recently, due to objections raised by PS Councillor Athula Maddumage, this waste was transferred to the local council’s solid waste collection facility, situated in a densely populated area near C.W.W. Kannangara College, Mathugama. Former PS member Maddumage commented on this incident, expressing concern that the waste contains hazardous materials such as mercury, cyanide, heavy metals, and carcinogenic substances that pose both short-term and long-term health risks to the community. He urged the PS authorities to responsibly recycle this waste. The protesters strongly criticised the Mathugama Local Council for dumping toxic waste in an area where schoolchildren and residents rely on the same water sources for drinking. He called on the local council authorities, as well as government health and environmental agencies, to promptly recycle or dispose of this toxic electronic waste stock safely and responsibly. By Kumara Gammedda – Ittapana

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Unclaimed Narcotics Parcels Worth Rs 86M Seized
author: Author not found
Content: In the year 2023 alone, officers at Sri Lanka Customs’ Central Valuation Division (CVD) in Colombo have seized parcels of narcotics worth over Rs 86 million, which had not been collected by the intended recipients. The Central Valuation Division is responsible for the valuation of imported goods when ad valorem duties are applicable. Valuation of abandoned and seized goods put up for tender sales also comes under this Division. During an inspection conducted by Customs officers from the Colombo Postal Appraisal Branch recently, a collection of parcels, that had arrived by post in Sri Lanka and had been left unclaimed by their respective recipients for an extended period, were discovered to contain both marijuana and artificially produced drugs. This inspection was conducted in the presence of officials from the Postal Department, Customs Narcotics Prevention Division and the Police Narcotics Bureau. The total quantity of drugs found within these parcels amounted to 1.406 kg, with an estimated value of Rs 14 million. These parcels had been dispatched to various addresses across different provinces of Sri Lanka and originated from countries including the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Inland Revenue Bill debate begins today
author: Author not found
Content: The Parliamentary debate on the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill and Social Security Contribution Levy (Amendment) Bill will be held today (6) and tomorrow (7). The debate will take place from 4.30 p.m. to 7.00 p.m. on both days and the vote on the Second Reading will take place tomorrow (7) at 7.00 p.m. The committee stage debate will be held tomorrow (7) until 7.30 p.m. Meanwhile, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena announced that the Supreme Court has determined that the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill can be passed by a simple majority in Parliament. The Speaker said the Supreme Court has held that neither the Bill, which was challenged in Court nor any of its provisions, was inconsistent with Article 12 of any provisions of the Constitution. Last week, the Supreme Court concluded the deliberations of the petitions filed challenging the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Draft Bill, filed by two persons including Chaturanga Abeysinghe, an activist of the National People’s Power (NPP). The petitioners alleged that if passed in Parliament, the proposed Bill will revise a number of levies and will also further empower the Inland Revenue Department as the primary agent to collect taxes and deal with issues arising from taxes on behalf of the Government. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: HC decision on defence objections on 27 Sept
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday (5) said his decision on the initial objections raised by the defence, in the case against former Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) Bashwara Senanayake and former Managing Director Rumy Jawffer, will be delivered on 27 September. The aforementioned duo has been indicted, on five counts, before the High Court, by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), with costing a loss of Rs 4.2 million to the SLTPB, through the placing of press advertisements in support of candidates, who contested the 2014 election and thereby flouting Provisions contained in the Bribery Act. President’s Counsel Rienzie Arsecularatne and Kalinga Indatissa, representing the two accused, stated that CIABOC had filed spurious charges against their clients. However, Senior Deputy Solicitor General Dilan Ratnayake mentioned that the High Court has no authority to peruse initial objections in this regard and observed that power has only been vested in the Court of Appeal. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: national policy for agriculture proposed
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Sectoral Oversight Committee (SOC) on Food Security and Agriculture MP D. Weerasinghe said that they have already proposed a national policy for agriculture, to regulate the use, quality and price of chemical fertiliser and seeds imported to the country, based on experimental data carried out over several decades. He also mentioned that it has been confirmed that the highest rice yield per hectare can be obtained by using 70% chemical fertiliser and 30% organic fertiliser in proportion, based on research conducted since 2003 and the proposed national policy will also include those findings. Weerasinghe conveyed these updates during a media briefing held yesterday (5) at the Presidential Media Centre. “Even though governments have changed, every sector needs to have a national policy that does not change. The agriculture sector has been waiting for a national policy for the last 25 years. If we lose the quality of the agricultural sector, the country’s agriculture will fail. Therefore, this country needs a national policy regarding imported chemical fertiliser and seeds together with their price regulation,” he said. In the next sectoral oversight committee meeting, a report will be submitted to investigate the quality of chemical fertiliser and seeds and to regulate their prices. “Under the direct advice of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, we are in the process of introducing modern technology to traditional agriculture. Also, measures are being taken to provide training to agriculture-related government officials regarding the use of fertiliser.” The MP said that due to the overuse of chemical fertiliser for many decades, the quality of the soil has now decreased. It has been recommended to apply 70% chemical fertiliser and 30% organic fertiliser for crops in proportion. However, there is a problem regarding the quality of these applied fertilisers. Some companies produce high-quality fertiliser in the country. However, due to the recent issues related to fertiliser, their image has suffered some damage. It should be rectified again. Programmes should be prepared to protect such entrepreneurs and promote agriculturearound the country. Entrepreneurs who produce organic bio-fertiliser and liquid fertiliser should be gathered and this programme should be carried forward. This cannot be done overnight. It is necessary to provide organic fertiliser to the farmers for at least five seasons to make this programme successful, he said. Through the Colombo Declaration, signed under the United Nations Global Environment Programme in 2016, we have agreed that the nitrogen waste released into the environment should be reduced by 50% by 2030. Therefore, the implementation of this programme is mandatory. “Also, the European Union has decided to make their purchases of completely organic fruits and vegetables when exporting to their countries by 2030. So, if we hope to export fruits and vegetables to EU countries in the future, we should tend to use organic fertiliser. That is why it was decided, as a committee, to continue the agricultural production process with organic fertiliser. In 2013, the Ministry of Agriculture recommended the use of organic fertiliser. They have asked to apply 10 metric tons per hectare. However, the farmers are facing practical problems. Ten thousand kilos cannot be applied per hectare of land. But today, government and private institutions have researched together and produced bio and liquid fertiliser,” he said. It is possible to increase the yield by 40% through the use of nano-fertiliser, compared to100% chemical fertiliser. Also, 70% organic fertiliser and 30% chemical fertiliser can increase the yield of this country from 13% to 25%, he added Speaking further, Weerasinghe said that there is a very wrong attitude among farmers regarding organic fertiliser. Therefore, there should be a change in the attitude of the farmers as well. Chemical fertiliser companies are ahead of us and they have drawn it. Therefore, the time has come to create a new attitude change among the farmers, he added. “The agriculture modernisation programme is essential for this country. Organic fertiliser should be used for the safety of seeds, health and soil. If not, the degradation of our soil is inevitable. People’s health, seeds and the whole agriculture sector would be destroyed. Before the use of chemical fertiliser in 1960, this country was self-sufficient in agriculture. Everyone has to think again about what happened to this Eastern Granary. Also, the government spends a lot of money to import chemical fertiliser. Many people are still protesting against this programme. As a young MP who came to theParliament through the vote of the farmers, I will fulfil my responsibility to the country even if I lose my political career,” he asserted.

title: Bandula refutes Manusha’s statement
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena refuted the statement made by Labour and Foreign Affairs Minister Manusha Nanayakkara that another Parliamentary Select Committee would be appointed to investigate the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. Gunawardena yesterday (5) said there was no discussion at the recent Cabinet meeting regarding the documentary produced by Britain’s Channel 4 concerning the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. He said that no attention has been paid to the contents of the controversial documentary aired by Britain’s Channel 4 the previous night. Responding to a question, the Cabinet spokesman clarified that such discussions had not taken place. However, he said that during the parliamentary debate on the second reading of the Ayurveda (Amendment) Bill, Labour and Foreign Employment Minister Manusha Nanayakkara had raised a differing opinion. Nanayakkara said the Government intended to launch an investigation into the revelations made by Channel 4 concerning the Easter Sunday attacks. He informed Parliament that Cabinet had taken a decision to set up a Parliamentary Select Committee to investigate the Channel 4 disclosures. Additionally, the Government is open to conducting international-level investigations if deemed necessary to uncover the truth surrounding the Easter Sunday attacks, he said. However, Gunawardena added that although Minister Nanayakkara had spoken about this in Parliament, it was not included in the Cabinet’s official agenda. He explained that Cabinet discussions follow a specific schedule, and any matter of exceptional importance would be addressed separately from the standard agenda. He clarified that no special cases, separate issues, or matters that were not on the agenda was discussed during the Cabinet meeting. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Drug Destruction Centre in Kalpitiya soon
author: Author not found
Content: The Delay in submitting Government Analyst reports to Court has been mainly due to the lack of staff at the Department. This was revealed at the Parliament ary Select Committee, which looks into measures taken to control the drug menace in the country. This was taken up for discussion when the Committee met in Parliament under the Chairmanship of Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles. It was also revealed that a drug destruction centre will be constructed in Kalpitiya. Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, Chairman of the Presidential Task Force, appointed to control narcotics, stated that a drug destruction centre will be built in Kalpitiya and if the committee intervenes to get water, electricity and road facilities for this purpose, the Centre could be ready by the end of this year. Responding, Minister Alles said necessary interventions will be made to resolve the issues. MPs who were present inquired about the delay in Government Analyst’s reports and the officials present said in the past it took about nine months for this and now it took only about three months. They said the lack of officers at the Department was the reason for the delay and steps will be taken to recruit the necessary officers. Drugs being sold through cash transactions, through ez-cash and the measures that can be taken by the Telecommunication Regulatory Commission regarding this was also discussed. The Ministry of Health, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, Ministry of Fisheries, Sri Lanka Coast Guard, Sri Lanka Navy, Sri Lanka Customs, Telecommunications Regulatory Commission of Sri Lanka, Postal Department and Prison Department were called before the Committee, where measures taken by these departments to control the drug menace in the country, were discussed. State Minister Sisira Jayakody, suggested that Ministry of Health seek the support of the Ministry of Indigenous Medicine to control drugs. Measures taken to prevent drugs coming in the mail, measures taken to reduce the spread of drugs related to schools and prevent drugs from entering through the sea route were also discussed. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa also joined this Committee and said  controlling the drug menace was directly related to national security and necessary steps should be taken in this regard.

title: Dhammika Perera, two others resign from SOC
author: Author not found
Content: Three MPs, including Dhammika Perera, stepped down from their roles as members of the Sectoral Oversight Committee (SOC) on Alleviating the Impact of the Economic Crisis, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena informed Parliament yesterday (5). The other MPs were Prof. Ranjith Bandara and S.B. Dissanayake. The Speaker also informed the House that to fill the vacancies resulting from these resignations, Nimal Lanza, Nalaka Bandara Kottegoda and Manjula Dissanayake have been appointed to the committee. In addition to these changes, the Speaker announced that MP Sanjeewa Edirimanna has been appointed to replace Major Pradeep Undugoda, who resigned as a member of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Open and Responsible Government. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: AG gives clearance for Cyber Security Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General has given his clearance for the draft Bill on the security of online methods, drafted by the Legal Draftsman, with the objective of safeguarding the general society from the damages caused by publicising false information and discriminating through the internet. As appeared in section III of the said draft Bill, several actions have been misinterpreted in the provisions of this act. They are communication of false statements on the incidents within Sri Lanka, false statements causing defame, paving way for riots by provocation without reason, disturbing a religious assembly through false statements, communication of false statements with the sole intention of hurting religious emotions and communication of false statements with the sole intention of abominating religious emotions, fraud, cheating by appearing as some other person, defaming intentionally by a false statement with the objective of arousing violation of peace, circulation of false statements with the intention of causing a riot or an offense against the Government, communication of statements on incidents to cause harassment, child abuse and production of bots or modifying them to cause an offense.  Accordingly, the Cabinet approved the resolution furnished by the Ministry of Public Security to publish the above draft Bill in the Government Gazette and subsequently submit the same to the Parliament for its concurrence.

title: ‘Problematic’ antibiotic still not sent to WHO lab
author: Author not found
Content: The Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) accused the Health Ministry of having failed to submit the antibiotic, which allegedly caused several deaths due to allergy, to a World Health Organisation (WHO) approved laboratory for testing. President of the AHP, Ravi Kumudesh yesterday (5) alleged that a month had lapsed since the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) had pledged to send the locally produced medicinal drug to a WHO approved lab facility. He accused the NMRA of not sending even a sample for testing as pledged. He said the Committee on Risk and Safety of Medicines had recommended  the drug to be sent for testing to a WHO approved lab facility at the beginning of August, when the issue regarding the particular antibiotic came up. Kumudesh accused health authorities of having failed to take action even after suspicions regarding the antibiotic were further heightened when a 50-year-old patient, being treated at the National Hospital, Colombo died after being administered the particular antibiotic. It cannot be claimed that the deaths were caused by the drug itself as a fair laboratory test was not conducted due to the lack of equipment in the National Drug Quality Control Laboratory (NDQCL). But it is a serious situation for the NMRA to deliberately delay conducting tests, at the WHO approved lab facility, owing to the seriousness of the issue regarding the quality of medicinal drugs- especially since the relevant pharmaceutical company was willing to fund and support any laboratory test that was conducted with regard to the said medicinal drug, he said.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Sajith calls for int’l probe on Easter attacks
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said he does not hold any grudge against Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith for telling people not to vote for him during the last Presidential Election. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (5), the Opposition Leader said he could understand the Cardinal’s stance, rooted in the pain caused by the Easter Sunday terror attacks of 2019, which still lingers within the Catholic community in the country. Premadasa alleged that the Easter attack had been utilised as a political tool to gain power. He pointed out that during election campaigns in 2019 and 2020, this tragic event was discussed. However, he lamented that justice has not yet been fully served and as such, it is inappropriate to insult Cardinal Ranjith and the Catholic community without conducting a formal investigation. Premadasa stressed the necessity for an international-level probe into the Channel 4 disclosure regarding the Easter Sunday attacks. He criticised the Government for not providing its own disclosure on the matter and called for an impartial international investigation to ascertain the truth. He also mentioned that a Minister had made an insulting statement suggesting that Cardinal Ranjith could have been involved in the attacks. Premadasa condemned this statement and highlighted that the Minister’s remarks, regarding the Cardinal, were offensive. Premadasa further said that during the presidential election, Gotabaya Rajapaksa was elected in the belief that the majority, including the Cardinal at that time, would ensure national security. However, he underscored that now, through foreign efforts, a significant revelation has emerged concerning the masterminds behind the Easter attacks. Consequently, Premadasa expressed disappointment that the search for these individuals within the country seems futile, necessitating an international investigation. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Two years RI suspended for five years
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday (5) sentenced a father, who pleaded guilty to a charge of sexually abusing his seven-year-old daughter, to two years’ Rigorous Imprisonment (RI) suspended for five years. Court also ordered the accused to pay compensation in a sum of Rs 50,000 to the victim and slapped a fine of Rs 25,000. Senior Counsel Ashoka Wijeyawardene, appearing for the defendant told Court, that at the time of the incident, his client was 31 years old and as he has expressed his deep remorse over his actions, to impose a lenient penalty. Senior State Counsel Sanka Weerasuriya, having considered the request made by Defence Counsel, had amended the charge sheet against the accused previously, on the advice of the Attorney General. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: CEB Bill to be presented to the House
author: Author not found
Content: The proposed Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) Bill will be presented to Parliament next month, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said yesterday (5). In response to a question raised by MP Kins Nelson in Parliament, Wijesekara said the Bill will be submitted to the Cabinet for consideration next week. Additionally, the Minister spoke of the government’s policy decision to refrain from constructing coal power plants in Sri Lanka. Instead, the Government, intends to set up a solar power plant in place of the previously planned coal power plant in Sampur, he added. Meanwhile, the Minister said there were serious problems with the efficiency of the CEB workforce which is 24,000. As a result, there could be reductions in the number of employees in certain sections. Further, outsourcing employee services was an additional burden to the CEB as well, Wijesekara said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: FUTA warns of imminent collapse in University education
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Federation of University Teachers’ Association (FUTA) Prof. Barana Jayawardena warned that if the Government fails to implement an expeditious plan to prevent university lecturers from leaving the shores for greener pastures, it will pave the way for the university system to collapse sooner than later. He said in such a scenario, the status garnered by Universities globally will also be tainted and it will be difficult to regain its image in the eyes of the world. Prof. Jayawardene explained that according to data collated, by the University Grants Commission (UGC), though 12,000 lecturers ought to serve in the country’s university sector, currently only about 6,000 to 7,000 lecturers were serving. The FUTA head added that this situation has arisen due to University lecturers leaving the sector in droves as well as due to the failure of the Government to absorb new recruits to the cadre. He made these observations at a media conference at the University of Peradeniya yesterday (5). BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: BA in Applied Police Studies launched
author: Author not found
Content: The opening ceremony for the ‘BA in Applied Police Studies’, a joint initiative by the Sri Lanka Police Academy and the University of Sri Jayewardenepura, aimed at enhancing the professional knowledge and skills of Sri Lanka’s Police officers, took place on 4 September. The ceremony was held in the auditorium of the Police Criminal Records Division and was attended by Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. Also in attendance were Secretary of Public Security Ministry Viani Gunathilaka, UGC Chairman Senior Professor Sampath Amaratunga, the Vice Chancellor of Sri Jayewardenepura University and several lecturers. During the ceremony, the first batch comprising 150 Police officers, for this degree programme, were officially registered. The event also saw the participation of several senior Police officers, emphasising the importance of this programme in enhancing the capabilities of the entire Police Department.

title: IESL Induction, Graduation Ceremony 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Induction and Graduation Ceremony 2023 of the Institution of Engineers, Sri Lanka (IESL) was held on 31 August at the BMICH Main Hall. Professor Ranjith Senaratne, Chairman of the National Science Foundation, was the Chief Guest. Associate Members of the Institute who successfully completed the Professional Review procedure were elevated to the status of Chartered Engineers, a prestigious position recognised throughout the country. 201 new Chartered Engineers were inducted this year. In addition, students who passed the IESL exams received their graduation certificates. Following the induction and graduation ceremony, schoolchildren who competed in the IESL’s Junior Inventor of the Year (JIY) Competition for the school year 2022/23 (category winners) were awarded. Winners of the IESL competitions for Engineering Undergraduates (Migara Rathnatunga Trust Awards and Eng. E.W. Karunaratna Awards) were also recognised.

title: Presidential Adviser on Climate Change meets Egyptian PM
author: Author not found
Content: During the Africa Climate Summit (ACS) 2023 in Nairobi, Kenya, President’s Senior Adviser on Climate Change, Ruwan Wijewardene, met Egyptian Prime Minister, Dr. Mostafa Kamal Madbouly. During the discussion, Dr. Madbouly addressed various climate issues globally, including adaptation, the perspective on climate finance, and the global climate agenda. Wijewardene spoke on how the two countries can work together on climate-related issues and trade to strengthen ties. He also outlined the future plans leading up to the upcoming COP28 Climate Change Conference. Sri Lankan High Commissioner to Kenya, Kana Kananathan and other dignitaries were also in attendance.

title: Beware of scammers masquerading as UN staff
author: Author not found
Content: United Nations (UN) Sri Lanka has issued a statement raising concerns over certain scams carried out by persons pretending to be UN correspondents and seeking money or personal details on behalf of the organisation. The statement said UN Sri Lanka has taken notice of an alarming surge in fraudulent activities, falsely claiming association with the UN and its officials. These scams, which have been detected in various forms such as email, Internet websites, text messages, regular mail, or facsimile, aim to deceive recipients into providing financial support or personal information. The UN unequivocally states that these activities are fraudulent and should be treated with the utmost scepticism. The UN is particularly concerned about the prevalence of these scams in Sri Lanka and wishes to alert the Sri Lankan public about these fraudulent activities, which are being perpetrated in the name of the organisation or its officials through various fraudulent schemes. “The UN reiterates that it does not charge any fees at any stage of its recruitment process, including application, interviews, processing, and training. Job seekers are encouraged to visit the official UN careers website at careers.un.org (https://careers.un.org) to apply for positions. Any request for money or personal banking information in the recruitment process is fraudulent. The UN also emphasises that it does not charge any fees during its procurement process, including supplier registration and bid submissions. Businesses looking to engage with the UN can find information on opportunities through the UN Procurement Division (https://www.ungm.org/Public/Notice). The UN categorically states that it does not request any information related to bank accounts or other private details. Any such request should be considered a scam. The UN does not offer prizes, awards, funds, certificates, ATM cards, compensation for internet fraud, scholarships, or conduct lotteries. Claims of such offers should be treated as fraudulent. The UN does not approve military vacations or pensions or release packages in exchange for a fee. Any request for payments related to these services is not legitimate,” the statement said. Therefore, UN Sri Lanka urged the public to remain vigilant and report any suspicious correspondence or activities claiming association with the organisation. To report scams or seek clarification, individuals are encouraged to contact their local authorities and visit the official United Nations website for accurate information and updates. “Anyone with doubts about the authenticity of a message purportedly from, for, or on behalf of the United Nations Sri Lanka or its officials, is encouraged to send an e-mail to [email protected],” the statement added.

title: SLPP MP Asanka Navaratne joins SJB
author: Author not found
Content: General Secretary of the Sri Lanka People’s Party, MP Asanka Navaratne joined the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), expressing his support towards the political party led by Sajith Premadasa. Following a meeting with Opposition Leader Premadasa on 4 September, Navaratne said he will be joining hands with the Opposition, to work towards the common goal of a shared democracy. Navaratne entered Parliament on the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) ticket following the last General Election and represents the Kurunegala District. According to a statement by SJB General Secretary Ranjith Maddumabandara, the SJB held a series of discussions with the political parties of the Opposition to obtain support for the broad political alliance chaired by Premadasa. Navaratne also participated in the discussion, and the present political situation and the challenges faced by the country were discussed at length. The need to build a broad political alliance with the Opposition in the future was emphasised. Further, Navaratne highlighted the need for the Opposition to hold discussions with all political parties in the future. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Procession Carrying Deegawapi Relics Arrives at Gangarama Temple
author: Author not found
Content: The procession carrying the sacred Omniscient Relics of Deegawapi Stupa and the Crest-Gem arrived at the Gangarama Temple on 3 September evening. This provided a rare opportunity to devotees to pay homage to the Deegawapi sacred relics and extend their contribution to the restoration work of the Deegawapi premises. The sacred relics were placed on 3 and 4 September at the Gangarama Temple for public veneration. Thereafter, they were placed at Ananda College on 5 September and students as well as devotees were facilitated to pay homage at the College premises.  Subsequently, arrangements were made for the exposition of these relics at Sri Sambodhi Temple on 6 and 7 September, Kaduwela Sangha Pitti Ancient Temple on 8 September and Panagoda Bodhirajaramaya on 9 September. They will be taken to Bellanwila Rajamaha Viharaya for veneration on 10 and 11 September.
