title: Presidential Adviser on Climate Change meets Egyptian PM
author: Author not found
Content: During the Africa Climate Summit (ACS) 2023 in Nairobi, Kenya, President’s Senior Adviser on Climate Change, Ruwan Wijewardene, met Egyptian Prime Minister, Dr. Mostafa Kamal Madbouly. During the discussion, Dr. Madbouly addressed various climate issues globally, including adaptation, the perspective on climate finance, and the global climate agenda. Wijewardene spoke on how the two countries can work together on climate-related issues and trade to strengthen ties. He also outlined the future plans leading up to the upcoming COP28 Climate Change Conference. Sri Lankan High Commissioner to Kenya, Kana Kananathan and other dignitaries were also in attendance.

title: Doctors question quality of surgical devices
author: Author not found
Content: Not only medicinal drugs, doctors are now questioning the quality of surgical devices, sources at the National Hospital, Colombo (NHSL) said, following an incident in which a carotid vein pressure (CVP) line, used on a patient, breaking inside her carotid vein during removal. Highly placed medical sources yesterday (04) lamented that the patient had to be taken in for an emergency surgery following the incident. Explaining, they said that the patient had been admitted to the NHSL, Colombo for a scheduled hip surgery over a week ago.  But since her blood pressure had dropped following the surgical intervention, she had been transferred to Surgical Intensive Care Unit (ICU)-01 where a CVP line had been inserted to her carotid vein for the purpose of monitoring and injecting medicines. After about a week, since the patient’s pressure has stabilised, the CVP line was removed yesterday (4). However, during its removal, the line had broken so that a part remained inside the patient’s carotid vein while the other part was in the nurse’s hand. The patient had been taken for emergency surgery to remove the remaining piece. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: ‘1333 Bikeathon Out of the Shadows’ reaches Trincomalee
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘1333 Bikeathon Out of the Shadows’, a bike ride aimed at raising awareness about suicide prevention, arrived in Trincomalee on Sunday (3). The Rotary Club of Trincomalee warmly welcomed the cyclists participating in this event, which is organised by the CCC Foundation in collaboration with Rotary Clubs. The primary objective of this island-wide bike ride is to promote the importance of the Telephone Line ‘1333’, a lifeline for individuals struggling with suicidal thoughts. It is a sobering fact that, on average, eleven people in Sri Lanka lose their lives to suicide every day, and for every one person who tragically succeeds, there are ten others who survive the attempt.  The mission of CCC Line 1333 is to combat this alarming trend by focusing on education, engagement, and empowerment. Through these efforts, they hope to eliminate the stigma surrounding mental health issues and other contributing social factors that can lead to suicide. CCC Line 1333 operates as a confidential and toll-free telephone counselling service, encouraging individuals to open up about their personal challenges, whether related to relationships, family, school, work, mental health, or suicidal thoughts. Currently, this service handles an average of 2,000 calls each month, offering support to people across Sri Lanka. The central aim of the ‘1333 Bikeathon Out of the Shadows’ is to spread awareness about the toll-free 1333 hotline within communities throughout Sri Lanka. In the evening, participants engaged with the public at Trinco Beach, distributing informative leaflets on suicide prevention. BY Hasfar A. Haleem

title: Youth remanded over threat to assassinate President
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, yesterday (4) remanded, till 8 September, a suspect who was charged by the CID with over comments made on social media sites, seeking a sniper type firearm, to assassinate the President. The accused was 17-year-old youth from Eppawela. The CID told Court the suspect had known beforehand that the President was due in Eppawela on 7 September. They said that Eppawela Police, had received details regarding a request placed on social media platforms by the suspect, requesting for a sniper type firearm, to assassinate the President and they arrested him. They stated that following information conveyed to the CID by the Eppawela Police, they had taken the suspect into their custody. The CID informed Chief Magistrate Alwis, that upon interrogation, the suspect had accepted that he had placed a statement on social media, regarding an attempt on the life of the President and they insisted that the actions of the suspect, had flouted Provisions in the PTA. The CID further mentioned that on the sidelines of this incident, a member of the Kilinochchi Army Camp had fled the camp with a T-56 Rifle and a Magazine containing 120 cartridges and that it has been identified, that he is also a resident of Eppawela. They added that as both these individuals are residents of Eppawela, they are conducting further investigations to ascertain whether they have conspired and colluded, to make an attempt on the President’s life. The lawyer representing the suspect youth, stated that his client is making a living while selling bread and similar items to the public while being engaged in farming with his father. He added that though it is true, that his client had publicised a note on social media sites, regards an attempt on the President’s life, he has never had such a notion in his entire life. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court remanded the suspect youth, till the aforementioned date. The CID in its submissions stated that the note placed by the suspect had read. “The culprits who made this country bankrupt are coming to our area. Can’t I get hold of a sniper to shoot them?” By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: SIS Director Salley decries Fr Gamini’s remarks on him
author: Author not found
Content: State Intelligence Service (SIS) Director, Major General Suresh Salley, giving evidence before Colombo District Court Judge Sandun Vithana, yesterday (4), stated that releasing of derogatory statements via the Internet, when a case pertaining to the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks is yet being heard in Court, has dealt a severe blow to his public image and placed his professional life in danger. The SIS Chief made this remark, when a case filed by him against Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini, in connection with comments made by Sallley, related to views expressed by the Priest concerned, at a zoom discussion with the International Justice Collective, on 23 October 2021, on behalf of the victims of the Easter Sunday carnage, was taken up for hearing. Salley giving evidence stated that Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini of St. Anthony’s Church, in Negombo, during that zoom discussion, had made remarks critical and harmful to him.  He insisted that he had received unwarranted publicity both locally and overseas, due to the conduct of the Priest concerned. The SIS Chief giving evidence, also maintained that the actions of Rev. Fr. Gamini, had ruined his public image and it had also embarrassed and humiliated him and his family too. Salley further informed Judge Vithana, that he has thus far put in a service exceeding three and a half decades and stressed that the Priest’s remarks, had placed both his and family’s life in serious danger while dealing a serious blow to his professional life. He then noted that making of such controversial comments, when a case is being heard in Court, in this regard, could also provide a warped image of the incident in question, to the society. The witness added that out of four members of his family, three of them had served with the Sri Lanka Army and that some of them had even been disabled, while serving this country. He also emphasised that the comments reportedly made by Rev. Fr. Gamini, mentioning his name, had been so vicious, vituperative and virulent, that he had been forceds to withdraw his child from school. Attorney Sahan Weerasinghe appeared for the Salley, while Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini was represented by PC Shamil Perera and Attorney-at-Law Wimal Ratwatta. Later, plaintiff Suresh Salley submitted an affidavit to the Court, to substantiate his evidence. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Judge, fixed further hearing of evidence to 25 January next year. The plaintiff has also prayed the said Court, to issue an order to the Priest concerned, to pay him compensation amounting to Rs 50 million, over the loss of reputation caused to him, by the resultant actions of Rev. Fr. Gamini. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Over 100,000 bottles of liquor with fake stickers seized
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said over 100,000 bottles of liquor, with counterfeit stickers placed on them, had been seized by officers from the Excise Department, during raids conducted in the recent past. He mentioned that a new sticker system had been introduced, by the Excise Department, as a way to counter the dwindling revenue from the liquor trade, but he observed that certain people involved in the counterfeit sticker racket had managed to make a killing off the illegal business.  Siyambalapitiya made these observations addressing the media, following an event held at Ruwanwella yesterday. The State Minister was of the view that in comparison to the previous time, the bottles of liquor carrying counterfeit stickers, that had been seized during this week, had decreased. He added that therefore the raids currently being conducted by Excise officers in this regard had been successful. Siyambalapitiya added that with the introduction of the new sticker system the domestic liquor production had spiked by 11 per cent while the profits had increased by 20 to 21 per cent. However, he was quick to point out that the counterfeit sticker racket had contributed to profit decreasing. He noted that the raids to seize bottles of liquor containing counterfeit stickers will be expedited further throughout the country and assured that no leeway will be left for racketeers to continue with their rackets. The State Minister warned that those found guilty being involved in the said racket will be fined Rs 500,000 and that all efforts will be made to recoup the losses incurred via the racket. He added that those engaged in the racket will also be prosecuted and their licenses cancelled.  By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: SC displeased with AG’s Dept over delay
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court (SC) yesterday expressed its strong displeasure over the failure of the Attorney General’s Department to submit video evidence to Court, for months, after having assured that it would produce the evidence within four weeks. The Supreme Court, Bench, comprising Justices S. Thurairaja, A.H.M.D. Nawaz and Shiran Guneratne, expressed their displeasure, to the Senior State Counsel, appearing on behalf of Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, when a Fundamental Rights case filed by two lawyers was perused. The FR petition has charged that a protest banners, displayed by Attorneys-at-Law Ajith Kumara and P. Amaradivakara, stating that the direct and indirect intervention of the tri-forces, particularly the Sri Lanka Army, to suppress and crush protests, staged by the masses countrywide, had violated the FR of its citizens, were torn by officers from the Galle Army Camp, who had then intimidated the two lawyers and evicted them from the site.  Senior State Counsel Induni Punchihewa then sought time to file objections pertaining to the petition. The request was granted by the Court and the Bench instructed the prosecution, to file re-objections within six weeks. Later, the Bench deferred further hearing of the petition to 5 March next year. President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris appeared for the petitioner on the instructions of Attorney-at-Law Manjula Balasuriya. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: UNP Convention postponed
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara announced yesterday (4) the UNP’s Party Convention that was originally scheduled for 10 September in Colombo, is indefinitely postponed, due to ongoing adverse weather conditions across the country. The decision to postpone the Convention was unanimously agreed upon during a meeting of the UNP’s Working Committee, chaired by Party Leader and President, Ranil Wickremesinghe, at Sirikotha. Rangebandara explained that the new date for the UNP’s working committee meeting, chaired by President Wickremesinghe, will be determined in October. He emphasised that this decision was made to avoid inconveniencing the participants. He further stated that although every effort had been made to prepare for the convention on the originally scheduled date, the persistent inclement weather conditions made it necessary to postpone it indefinitely. According to Rangebandara, President Wickremesinghe had directed them to hold a minimum of 70 regional-level working committee meetings before the convention. To date, a total of 153 such meetings have been successfully conducted. Regarding the stance of Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, Rangebandara noted that it is evident that he will not be running in the upcoming Presidential Election. He also mentioned previous instances where the Opposition Leader stepped aside, causing divisions within the party when selecting its leader. Such incidents have occurred throughout the political history of the Premier, according to Rangebandara. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: No intention of postponing 2023 A/L exam – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha, firmly holding his grounds, said there is no intention to postpone G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination 2023. The A/L examination will be held from 27 November to 21 December as scheduled, Premajayantha said. According to a statement issued by the Ministry of Education, a total of 323,913 applications have already been received for the examination. The Education Ministry provided an explanation for the November schedule, citing a significant delay in the past, due to teachers and lecturers not completing paper marking in a timely manner, resulting in delayed exam results. It was emphasised that altering the proposed exam schedule again would be unfair to the majority of students. The Ministry further noted that, based on collected statistics, the majority of schools have successfully covered the Advanced Level syllabus. Additionally, the Ministry announced that students who wish to re-sit the exams for the second or third time, following the release of A/L examination results, will be allowed to do so by following the prescribed procedure at the Department of Examinations. Meanwhile, the results of A/L Examination 2022 were released yesterday (4). The Education Ministry has made these results available on websites such as www.doenets.lk/exam or www.results.exams.gov.lk. A total of 232,797 school candidates and 31,136 private candidates appeared for the examination, bringing the total number of candidates to 263,933. Moreover, 166,938 candidates, accounting for 63.3% of the total, which includes 149,487 school candidates and 17,451 private candidates, have qualified for university admissions. Results for 57 school candidates and 25 private candidates have been withheld for undisclosed reasons. Lastly, the Commissioner General of Examinations announced that an online facility will be provided to all school principals for downloading the examination results from the department’s official website. (NV)

title: JJB’s power is in the people – Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake emphasised that the JJB relies on the power and support of ordinary people, as its primary source of strength. Dissanayake, while addressing a gathering in Kotte, highlighted the critical importance of grassroots support for the JJB’s success. He pointed out, “Throughout our country’s history, there have been many divisions, but now, a new division has emerged in society. It’s a division between those who agree with us and those who do not. People who support both, the Rajapaksas and Wickremesinghe are now in the same camp. There is a growing people’s movement against the corruption of the elite class in this country.” Dissanayake further stated that with the rise of this common people’s movement, certain groups have initiated smear campaigns against it. He remarked, “They can continue with these campaigns, but they must also remember that the power of the people surpasses them. People like Mahinda Rajapaksa and Gotabaya Rajapaksa lived with great authority, but eventually, they had to yield to the power of the people. The people are the sole source of power for the JJB.” BY Anuradha Herath

title: No one wants to kill Sajith – Rangebandara
author: Author not found
Content: In response to Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa’s claim that his life is in danger, UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara stressed that no one is interested in killing Premadasa. Addressing the media, during a press conference at Sirikotha, Rangebandara said, “It was a particular SJB member who informed us that Premadasa would not be participating in the upcoming Presidential Election, if the President contests. This MP told me that Premadasa is publicly lying when he says he will contest the Presidential election. Now Premadasa is saying that his life is in danger. I would like to say no one is interested in killing Premadasa. We do not consume beef,” he said. He added that they have experienced how Premadasa had behaved in the past. He made Karu Jayasuriya contest the UNP leadership once, then he made Dullas Alahapperuma to contest for the presidency, when a vote was taken to elect a new President, when former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa resigned from his post in 2022, Rangebandara alleged. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Woman found dead in hotel room
author: Author not found
Content: In a grim discovery, the body of a 43-year-old woman was found in a hotel room, situated in Neralu Uyana, Thalangama on Sunday (3) night. Thalangama Police said the woman was identified as a counsellor and an external lecturer. The body was discovered by the hotel employees. The employees who knocked on the door of the room, where she was staying, as there was no sign of her for a long time, then opened the door and found her body. The hotel employees told the Police that she booked the room on 26 August and on Saturday (2) a person visited her at the hotel. The Police are currently trying to locate that person and her call records are being analysed as well. Thalangama Police are conducting further investigations. BY Keerthi Mendis

title: President fulfilling requests made by public – Sagara
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) General Secretary Sagara Kariyawasam said that President Ranil Wickremesinghe is fulfilling the requests made by the public, although the SLPP has some disagreements with that. Addressing a media briefing, Kariyawasam explained, “The public didn’t seek concessions; they requested that the President increase taxation rather than reducing tax collection. Consequently, the President is acting in accordance with these requests.” Speaking further, he acknowledged that there were individuals who had taken to the streets to demand these changes and expressed that as a political party, they did not necessarily align with these ongoing activities. However, Kariyawasam said the SLPP has opted to present an alternative proposal to the people, “The people will vote according to their preference. If the people want to continue today’s situation, then they will vote for the President. We respect that because this is a democratic country. It should be said that the progress of a country is a responsibility of its people,” he pointed out. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: UN’s Resident Coordinator meets Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting between Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena and newly appointed United Nations Resident Coordinator in Sri Lanka, Marc-André Franche, took place in Parliament recently. Kushani Rohanadeera, Secretary General of the Parliament was also in attendance. Marc-André Franche congratulated Sri Lanka on the adoption of the Anti-Corruption Act and the establishment of the Parliamentary Budget Office. He also mentioned that the United Nations expects to provide more than 300 million dollars through the new co-operation framework for the development programmes in the next five years. Speaker Abeywardena expressed his gratitude for the continuous support of the United Nations Development Programme, as a development partner of the Parliament of SriLanka. Furthermore, views were also exchanged on Sri Lanka’s legislative process, electoral system, peacebuilding activities and women’s representation in politics. Kushani Rohanadeera, Secretary General of Parliament explained the programmes by the Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus to strengthen the representation of women in politics and the inclusion of youth representatives in the Sectoral Oversight Committees.

title: Parliamentary Caucus for Children meets
author: Author not found
Content: The Parliamentary Caucus for Children, chaired by MP Rohini Kumari Wijerathna, which met recently in Parliament, directed its attention towards the Reproductive Health and Sexual Education of Schoolchildren and Cyber Violence Against Children in Sri Lanka The officials present stated that educating schoolchildren of Sri Lanka regarding Reproductive Health and Sex is initially aimed at being conducted online through modes of newmedia. The Chair of the Caucus, Rohini Kumari Wijerathna, commending officials for their efforts stated that the Caucus wishes to officially launch this initiative by October. They also discussed the need to create content pertaining to Reproductive Health and Sex Education for the purpose of catering to different categories and groups in the society for better understanding. The Caucus also looked into the spread of drugs among children and the rights of children. They also looked into re-introducing the complaint box kept in all schools where children can submit their concerns incognito. The Caucus further discussed to make children aware of 1929 hotline service. They also looked into the current context and the application of laws pertaining to Cyber Violence Against Children in Sri Lanka. The Caucus expressed that the Cyber Security Bill is in the draft stage and for the officials to submit their recommendations and observations accordingly. The Caucus also looked into the harassment against children online and the existing measures to take action against such harassment. It was also disclosed that there are many child pornography sites, Facebook pages including other social media platforms with harassing comments against children which is concerning. Moreover, the need for a proper Media policy in place was highlighted as many media reports on cases pertaining to children are been reported in a very unethical and an insensitive manner. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, Deputy Co-Chair of the Caucus MP Velu Kumar, MPs V. Radhakrishnan, Eran Wickramaratne and Thalatha Atukorale were present at the meeting.

title: Journalist’s backpack with laptop stolen
author: Author not found
Content: A journalist from the ‘Mawbima’ website had his backpack stolen on 3 September, at about 3.35 p.m., while travelling by train from Galle to Colombo The theft is believed to have occurred in Moratuwa and a formal complaint has been filed with the Moratuwa Police Crime Division. Inside the stolen backpack, there was an Apple laptop along with its charger, a USB hub, a router, a smartphone, a hard disk, a charger for the smartphone, two cables designed for an Apple laptop and a phone, as well as personal documents. If anyone possesses information related to this incident, the journalist requests that they contact the following numbers: 077 5 804670, 077 7 716902, or 011 7 566566.

title: Over half of Lankan population : ‘multidimensionally vulnerable’
author: Author not found
Content: The crushing economic crisis in Sri Lanka last year has left more than half of the island’s population “multidimensionally vulnerable”, according to a ‘national citizen’ survey led by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). The study spanning the years 2022 and 2023 and covering 25,000 households across the country, found 55.7 per cent of the population to be vulnerable across three dimensions — education, health and disaster, living standards — and 12 indicators, including school attendance, physical condition [of health], unemployment and indebtedness. In effect, the survey showed that 12.34 million people out of Sri Lanka’s 22.16 million-strong population have been badly affected by the crisis and remain vulnerable amid claims of a “recovering” economy. The findings are in line with earlier research by UN agencies on food insecurity levels and reaffirm anecdotal accounts of poor families cutting down their food intake and pulling their children out of school to cope with the high living costs. The findings of UNDP’s study carried out in partnership with the ‘Citra Social Innovation Lab’ anchored at the Prime Minister’s Office, assume significance, especially after the Government rejected a UNICEF report that pointed to high malnutrition levels among Sri Lankan children last year. Notably, the recently launched UNDP report said a majority, or 82 per cent, of those found to be “multidimensionally vulnerable” lived in rural Sri Lanka. It underscored the need for “more policy focus” in those areas. Further, the study found a third of the country’s population gets into debt for essential needs like food, medical care, education, and pawning jewellery or selling items.  “Several districts, including Ampara, Batticaloa, Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu, Nuwara Eliya, Puttalam, and Vavuniya, exhibit notable multidimensional vulnerability values, with over 65 per cent of their populations identified as vulnerable,” the report said, indicating that people living in the island’s Tamil-majority North and East, impacted by the war, and the economically-marginalised Malaiyaha Tamil community, are among those facing the highest levels of economic deprivation. Capital Colombo and the neighbouring Gampaha districts emerged as regions with the highest concentration of vulnerable individuals, a trend that the study attributed to their substantial population sizes. Last year’s financial meltdown pushed Sri Lanka to bankruptcy and brought its citizens to the streets as they contended with acute shortages, long power cuts, and a dramatic increase in prices. A year after defaulting on its foreign debt in the wake of a stifling balance of payments problem, the Government obtained International Monetary Fund (IMF) support in March 2023 by way of a USD 3 billion package to be disbursed over four years. While President Ranil Wickremesinghe has pledged to set the country’s economy on a path of recovery, his Government is struggling to reach an agreement with its external creditors. Colombo must finalise a debt treatment plan before the IMF’s scheduled review this month, as the second tranche of the IMF loan is contingent on it. Further, the Government recently announced its decision to restructure its domestic debt, mainly by recasting the outgo on the country’s pension funds. Worker unions have been fiercely opposing the move. In a recent letter to the IMF, more than 80 Sri Lankan organisations and trade unions said subjecting workers’ pension funds to domestic debt restructuring “will diminish the returns to wage-earners and deplete the fund to half its current value.” “Your debt restructuring programme is crippling working people in Sri Lanka who run our economy and create value in our society. The economic reforms you have imposed on us, without reflecting on the negative consequences of the previous reforms enacted over 16 IMF interventions, are crushing our economy,” they told the Fund. Meanwhile, Central Bank data showed a further slowdown in headline inflation in August, dropping to 4 per cent from 6.3 per cent recorded last month. Still, the numbers are yet to translate to relief for most citizens, especially because of last year’s exceptionally high base effect, even as incomes have remained stagnant.   The Government — in adherence to the IMF programme — recently began making cash transfers to 1.5 million families out of the 2 million it has identified as poor and eligible. Many more families are protesting, asking to be included on the list. However, women’s groups and Government critics argue that a targeted social security programme, amounting to 0.6 per cent of the GDP, will prove grossly inadequate to combat the severe economic strain many face.  (The Hindu)

title: Landslide alerts issued for 14 DS Divisions
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the ongoing inclement weather, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has issued Level One ‘Yellow Watch’ landslide early warning alerts for 14 Division Secretariat (DS) Divisions and the surrounding areas across four districts. Senior Scientist of the Landslides Early Warning Centre, Dr. Wasantha Senadeera, said Galle, Kalutara, Ratnapura, and Kegalle are among the affected districts. He further said Level One ‘Yellow Watch’ landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Baddegama, Elpitiya, and Nagoda DS divisions, along with the surrounding areas in the Galle District. In the Kalutara District, alerts have been issued for Bulathsinhala, Ingiriya, Mathugama, and Walallawita DS divisions and their surrounding areas. In the Kegalle District, the warnings cover Ruwanwella, Yatiyanthota, Deraniyagala, Bulathkohupitiya, and Dehiowita DS divisions. Lastly, in the Ratnapura District, alerts have been issued for Eheliyagoda, Kuruwita, and Ratnapura DS divisions. Dr. Senadeera added that residents in hilly areas experiencing heavy rainfall have been advised to remain vigilant. They should be alert to signs such as slanting trees, leaning light and telephone posts, sudden muddy water emerging from highland springs, cracks in walls and floors of buildings. In such cases, they have been urged to move promptly to safe locations after informing the Police and Disaster Management Centre (DMC) officials. The inclement weather has caused flooding on many main roads and low-lying areas of the Colombo metropolitan city. In several locations, branches have fallen onto the roads, causing traffic congestion. The water levels of the Gin Ganga, Kalu Ganga, and Nilwala Ganga rivers continue to rise. Residents in low-lying areas near these rivers have been cautioned to relocate to safer areas if water levels continue to increase. The water level of the Nilwala Ganga had reached 5.8 metres by noon yesterday (3). The Meteorological Department has predicted the possibility of showers or thundershowers in the Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central, and North-Western Provinces today (4). Regarding the current atmospheric conditions, the Duty Meteorologist forecast fairly heavy showers exceeding 50 mm in some places in the Western and Sabaragamuwa Provinces, as well as in the Galle, Matara, and Nuwara Eliya Districts during the daytime. Strong gusty winds ranging from 40 to 50 kmph could occur intermittently in the Western slopes of the Central Hill, as well as in the Western, North-Western, Northern, and Eastern provinces. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Celebrating 157th Police Day
author: Author not found
Content: Several religious programmes were organised yesterday (3) to mark the 157th Police Day celebration. Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, Secretary of the Ministry of Public Security Viyani Gunathilaka, Western Province SDIG Deshbandhu Tennakoon, a number of other SDIGs and Police officials participated in these events. The Dhamma Sermon was held on Saturday (2) at 7.30 p.m. and an alms giving took place yesterday (3) at the conference hall of the Colombo DIG’s  office. A Hindu religious ceremony was conducted yesterday (3) at 8.30 a.m. at the New Kadiresan Hindu Temple in Bambalapitiya, followed by a Catholic service at 9.30 a.m. at St. James Catholic Church in Modara. Additionally, Islamic religious services were held at the Dawatagaha Mosque, Cinnamon Garndens.

title: SL not a threat to India – Moragoda
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India, Milinda Moragoda, emphasised in a podcast with TRS on 29 August, that regardless of what is happening in Sri Lanka, nobody in India should perceive Sri Lanka as a threat to India. He noted that even though Sri Lanka is a divided country, with politicians who often hold strong differences, similar to India, no leader in Sri Lanka, while in Office, would intentionally take actions that pose a threat to India “knowingly”. He said the surveillance ship Yuan Wang 5 that came last year was a missile tracking vessel and not a warship. But, with today’s technology, it can be a missile tracking vessel as well as track a weather satellite. Indians’ perspective was this ship could be used for either purpose, he asserted. He said, last year, Sri Lanka approved it as a research vessel. “They thought it is a tracking vessel that is used for more benign purposes. But others thought it could be used for military purposes. We had a conversation on that and will have a conversation in the future as well. China is in power and present in the Indian Ocean sending their ships across. So we will have to have a conversation to ensure India what is a threat and talk on those lines,” he underlined. “Our position is what is a threat to India is a threat to us,” he pointed out. Touching on the debt issue, he said, “I don’t think we are caught in a Chinese debt trap.” He added that Sri Lanka’s location in the Indian Ocean has been the biggest opportunity and the biggest challenge. “Opportune means we could have become a very fast-growing country and be the gateway to the Indian sub-continent like Hong Kong to China and Netherlands to Europe.” He also pointed out that the Trincomalee Port is the strategic port and not Hambantota. With its natural harbour, second best in the world, any ship can come to Trincomalee Port as it is deepwater port. We have a natural blessing, he added. On the outer harbour, a massive British ship sank during World War II. Despite this, any ship could enter the port. “It is that deep.” Someone taking over the Trincomalee Harbour has been speculated to be a threat to the region and the world, he added. Today, geopolitics has changed and it keeps changing and Sri Lanka cannot control geopolitics, he stressed. India is a superpower like the US and China and Sri Lanka cannot control that, but accept it. We are not seen as a threat in any way to India because we are connected through civilisation and geography. Regardless of what politicians say and even though we are divided politically, whoever is in Office, we will not do anything that is a threat to India, he emphasised. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Gas price to be hiked
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas Lanka Chairman Muditha Peiris will unveil the latest adjustments to the domestic gas prices today (4). According to the company, the price revision has to be done as it grapples with the highest recorded gas price per metric ton in the global market. Peiris said that there is a sharp increase of over USD 103 per MT of gas in the international gas market. He said, “Given these substantial global price hikes, there will be a revision in domestic gas prices. Due to the rising global prices, we will be implementing an increase in gas prices starting on Monday (4).” Back in July, Litro Gas announced a reduction in the retail price of various gas cylinder sizes, with the 12.5kg domestic cylinder reduced to Rs. 2,982, the 5kg cylinder to Rs. 1,198, and the 2.3kg cylinder to Rs. 561. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ranjith Siyambalapitiya hospitalised
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya was admitted to a private medical facility in Colombo on Saturday (2) due to a sudden illness. The Police suspect the Minister came down with food poisoning after attending a banquet. However, hospital sources said he is in stable condition. It is believed Siyambalapitiya consumed the suspect food during a banquet in Kegalle following a festival. A sample of the food consumed by the State Minister will be sent to the Government Analyst. Police are conducting investigations.

title: Nearly 250 tons of garbage collected during Perahera season
author: Author not found
Content: Approximately 250 tonnes of garbage had been collected within the Kandy city limits, during the Esala Perahera season, Namal Dissanayake, the chief engineer of the Kandy Municipal Council Waste Management Unit, revealed. He said that spectators attending the Perahara contributed with around 10 tonnes of plastic bottles, polythene, and leftover food items daily, while an additional 15 tonnes, included elephant dung and litter from the elephant stables, was also collected daily. Dissanayake highlighted that nearly five tonnes of solid waste, including items such as plastic bottles, polythene, toys, and lunch boxes, as well as over five tons of discarded food items, were gathered each day. He emphasised that despite efforts to raise awareness, a substantial volume of items like plastic bottles, polythene, and wax cloth continue to be brought into the city in large quantities. Additionally, he mentioned that these waste materials are being categorised for recycling at the Gohagoda dumpsite. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Jaffna, Mullaitivu, Mannar incorporated
author: Author not found
Content: Jaffna, Mullaitivu and Mannar have been incorporated into Sri Lanka’s newly -established second Coconut Triangle, which was officially inaugurated in the Northern Province on Saturday (2) in celebration of World Coconut Day. The launch event took place at the Palai Coconut Model Garden in Jaffna, marking the inclusion of the Jaffna, Mannar, and Mullaitivu districts into this significant agricultural region. Sri Lanka has witnessed a substantial increase in its coconut export revenue in recent years. This growth can be attributed to the numerous benefits associated with Sri Lankan coconuts, resulting in a surge in demand. This year, it is expected that exports of coconut-based products will contribute a substantial USD 700 million to the country’s revenue. Further, there are projections that exports of coconut-related products will generate an impressive USD 2 billion in revenue over the next decade. The decision to establish a second Coconut Triangle was driven by the fact that a majority of coconut production is consumed locally, with only a third being designated for export.

title: Suspect remanded over torching Army bus in Mirihana
author: Author not found
Content: Nugegoda Additional Magistrate Nadeera Bogahadeniya remanded, until 11 September, a suspect, who was arrested by the Criminal Investigation Department (CID), in connection with the torching of an Army bus, during a protest held in front of former President Gotabaya Rajapakse’s residence in Pengiriwatte, Mirihana on 31 March 2022. The suspect was arrested in the night of 1 September in Mahiyangana  following a tip-off. The suspect was charged under the Offences Against Public Property Act. According to Police, the 33-year-old suspect confessed to setting the bus on fire and had later disposed all incriminating evidence, including the clothing he had worn during the incident, after the dissemination of photographs and Police sketches on media channels. Police arrested a resident of Deraniyagala, on suspicion of setting the bus on fire, a few days after the Mirihana protest. However, he was released on bail after a few weeks. When granting bail, the Magistrate told Police that the manner in which the suspect was apprehended was unsatisfactory and that they should not arrest people based solely on photographs. The Magistrate said a suspect should only be arrested after a thorough investigation. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: GCE A/L 2022 results out in two or three days
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha, yesterday (3) revealed that the GCE Advanced Level (A/L) Examination 2022 results will be released within the next two to three days. The Commissioner General of Examinations has indicated that the results will be accessible on the following websites upon release: www.doenets.lk | www.results.exams.gov.lk. Although, it was planned to release the results in mid-August, it had to be delayed owing to the issues connected with answer script evaluation. Premajayantha, addressing the media at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) recently, said if the evaluation of Advanced Level answer scripts were not delayed, the results would have been released earlier. The Minister also said that the total number of answer scripts that should be evaluated was 3.4 million. He also said that the A/L Examination 2023 will be held in December, before Christmas and the GCE Ordinary Level examination 2023 will be held in the months of March and April next year. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sinopec to begin islandwide operations by September end
author: Author not found
Content: Chinese fuel company Sinopec, which recently opened its first fuel station in Mattegoda, is set to commence its nationwide operations by the end of September, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said. The minister said discussions were held with Sinopec Fuel and Refinery Operations officials at the Ministry of Power and Energy. These discussions revolved around the progress of their retail operations, the signing of agreements with dealerships, branding strategies, and the upcoming launch of operations islandwide. In a tweet, Wijesekera also highlighted that Sinopec Refinery officials have expressed their commitment to setting up a new refinery in Hambantota. He further mentioned that they will submit the request for proposal (RFP) before the upcoming deadline next week. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Far Shipping’ willing to hire Lankan seafarers
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Far Shipping,’ one of the world’s largest shipping companies, has agreed to create employment opportunities for Sri Lankan seafarers who have received training, according to Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. The announcement came during a meeting at the minister’s office with a delegation from ‘Far Shipping,’ which included Managing Director Yong Jun Yu. Yu expressed his company’s interest in providing job opportunities for young Sri Lankan sailors who have undergone training. He emphasised the potential for many Sri Lankan-trained seafarers to find employment with their company based in China. As a result, discussions will be held with stakeholders in Sri Lanka’s maritime sector to conduct recruitment. Yu also mentioned that his company is open to hiring young individuals who have graduated from naval training institutes in Sri Lanka for on-the-job training and eventual permanent positions. The minister highlighted that entities like Mahapola Maritime Company under the Sri Lanka Ports Authority, private sector institutions, and the University of Moratuwa annually train skilled maritime professionals. He suggested that, if necessary, training programmes could include proficiency in the Chinese language. He expressed his gratitude to China for its longstanding friendship and assistance to Sri Lanka. He welcomed the prospect of providing employment opportunities to Sri Lankan youth in naval and various other fields as the government official responsible for such matters.

title: Peradeniya Alumni stages ‘Garu Katanayakathumani’
author: Author not found
Content: The Alumni Association of the University of Peradeniya, Colombo Chapter, will be staging the popular Drama, Garu Katanayakathumani at 3:30 p.m. on Saturday, 16 September at the New Town Hall, Colombo 7. This drama directed by Udayasiri Wickramarathne, features Nayanathara de Silva, Ishara Wickramasinghe, Thilan Warnajith, Kusal Maduranga, Mihiri Priyangani Yapa, Sanjeewa Dissanayake, Shashika Diyamantha, Malith Peiris, Susanga Kahadawalaarachchi, Sudarshana Bandara and Prabodha Buddapriya. Tickets are available at Sarasavi Bookshop Nugegoda, Sadeepa and Samudra Bookshops Borella. “The main objective of this event is to raise funds for the various projects initiated by the Association to conduct welfare activities for the benefit of undergraduates, Alumni and the public,” the Association’s President, Priyath Cabral said.

title: HC Moragoda Pays Farewell Calls on Top Indian bureaucrats
author: Author not found
Content: Continuing his farewell calls, Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda paid farewell calls on Principal Secretary to the Prime Minister of India Dr. Pramod Kumar Mishra and the Union Home Secretary of India Shri Ajay Kumar Bhalla recently.  The meetings took place at the Prime Minister’s Office and the Ministry of Home Affairs. At both meetings, High Commissioner Moragoda recalled the close interactions he had with these two top bureaucrats and thanked them for the assistance that they had extended to him personally as well as to Sri Lanka during his tenure in Delhi. As tokens of appreciation and goodwill, High Commissioner Moragoda presented to the Principal Secretary to the Prime Minister and the Union Home Secretary stones obtained from the stream flowing besides the Seetha Amman Temple in Seetha Eliya (Ashoka Vatika) in Sri Lanka, which is believed to be the site where Seetha was held captive according to the Ramayana. A Cabinet rank official, Dr. Pramod Kumar Mishra has been serving as the Principal Secretary to Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi since September 2019. Shri Ajay Kumar Bhalla is an officer from the 1984 batch of the Indian Administrative Service. He has been serving as the Union Home Secretary since August 2019.

title: Telecommunications Veteran Christie Alwis no more
author: Author not found
Content: It is with deep sorrow and a heavy heart that we announce the passing of Christie Alwis, a true luminary in the field of telecommunications. Alwis, a Professional Engineer with over 30 years of dedicated service in the industry, breathed his last on 1 September. He leaves behind a legacy of innovation, leadership, and a profound impact on the telecom landscape in Sri Lanka and beyond. Alwis began his illustrious career in telecommunications in 1977 when he joined Sri Lanka Telecom (SLT). Over the years, he ascended through the ranks and held several key positions within the organisation, demonstrating unwavering commitment and expertise in his field. Notably, he served as an Engineer, overseeing crucial aspects of switching and transmission in both the Telecommunication Department (Government) and Sri Lanka Telecom (Corporation). In 1997, Alwis took on the role of Director Customer Services and Executive Assistant to the CEO under the Japanese management of SLT, showcasing his versatile leadership abilities. He continued to excel in his career as he transitioned to the role of Chief Network Officer – Network Planning and Engineering Group from 2002 to 2007, contributing significantly to the development and expansion of Sri Lanka’s telecommunications infrastructure. In 2007, Alwis took on the role of Senior Officer – Corporate Strategic Planning at SLT, once again demonstrating his versatility and adaptability in the ever-evolving telecommunications industry. Beyond his impressive career, Alwis was a passionate educator. He served as a Visiting Lecturer for Communication Engineering and Computer Science at the University of Moratuwa and the University of Sabaragamuwa, enriching the minds of countless students over his 25 years of service as a lecturer. Alwis’ contributions to the telecommunications industry are immeasurable, and he will be remembered not only for his technical prowess but also for his leadership, mentorship, and dedication to the development of the next generation of telecom professionals. As we mourn the loss of this telecommunications veteran, our thoughts and condolences go out to his family, friends, colleagues, and all those whose lives he touched. Christie Alwis’ legacy will continue to shine brightly in the annals of Sri Lanka’s telecommunications history.

title: Sudath Perera assumes duties as Surveyor General
author: Author not found
Content: Additional Surveyor General W. Sudath L.C. Perera assumed duties as the Surveyor General with effect from 30 August. He completed his primary education at Dharmapala Primary School, Gampaha and his secondary education at St. Mary’s College, Negombo and he is a Physical Science (Honours) Graduate from the University of Colombo. He joined the Teaching Service as a Mathematics Teacher for G.C.E. Advanced Level students at St. Peter’s College, Colombo 4 before joining the Survey Department as an Assistant Superintendent of Surveys in 1988 and completed his Higher Diploma in Surveying from the Institute of Surveying and Mapping in Diyatalawa. He obtained a Professional Master’s Degree in Geoinformatics (Spatial Information Systems) from ITC Netherlands, in 1998. He worked as a Lecturer and a Senior Lecturer at the Institute of Surveying and Mapping Diyatalawa and moulded many survey professionals for the nation.  He has been instrumental in pioneering and supervising various development schemes of land surveys such as densification of the control network in Sri Lanka, surveys for the development of airports, expressway surveys in Sri Lanka, acquisition surveys for various development projects, engineering surveys for development and settlements in Mahaweli areas and he has made a great contribution to improving land title registration and management of Sri Lanka, and greatly contributed to develop the Bim Saviya programme. He has played a major role in making mapping work more efficient and bringing maps closer to the public and has been instrumental in empowering the Land Information System in Sri Lanka. He is presently working as a member of the National Steering Committee appointed to establish a National Spatial Data Infrastructure allowing better and more efficient use and sharing of Geospatial Information which will have a great impact on development activities.

title: Ahmed Faris Maumoon – The Maldives’ New Rising Sun
author: Author not found
Content: As the sun sets over the picturesque islands of the Maldives, a new dawn is emerging over its political landscape, in the form of the Maldives’ new rising sun, Ahmed Faris Maumoon, as he officially commences his run for the Maldivian Presidency. A new dawn that promises to steer the island nation toward a future marked by economic stability, warm diplomatic relations, and strong democratic values. As he stands on the cusp of this transformative journey, Maumoon is a name synonymous with proven commitment, vision, and dedication. His story is not just that of a statesman, but a tale of perseverance and impactful leadership. Born into a legacy of statesmanship, Faris has carved his path with distinction. His journey from education to politics showcases a relentless pursuit of knowledge, underscoring his commitment to the betterment of the Maldives. Reflecting on his journey, Faris attributes his unwavering dedication to the values instilled in him by his parents. He fondly recalls his father, former President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, and his mother, Madam Nasreena Ibrahim, as his guiding lights. “Their commitment to the betterment of the Maldives has been a constant source of inspiration to me,” he says, discussing their legacy with a profound sense of respect, emphasising how his parents’ tireless work in shaping the island nation’s trajectory ignited his own passion for serving the Maldivian people. Having completed his higher studies in England and Australia, Faris returned to his homeland armed with a Bachelor’s Degree in Combined Social Sciences and a Master’s Degree in International Relations. This academic foundation would later become the bedrock upon which he would build his political and economic initiatives. In 2005, Faris embarked on his political career, being among the initial 50 signatories to the formation of the “Dhivehi Rayyithunge Party” (DRP) and playing a pivotal role in establishing multiparty democracy in the Maldives. His leadership acumen was demonstrated when he spearheaded the campaign for the historic 2008 multiparty Presidential Election. The subsequent founding of the Progressive Party of the Maldives (PPM) in 2011 further showcased his ability to navigate complex political landscapes. Under his strategic guidance, the PPM achieved a remarkable series of victories within just three years, winning the Presidential Election in 2013, a parliamentary majority in 2014, and the Local Council Elections in 2017. Faris’ achievements within this short time frame testify to his visionary leadership and dedication to rapid progress. Beyond party leadership, Faris served as the Minister of State for Economic Development from 2013 to 2015, introducing transformative economic policies that catalysed inclusive growth. His initiatives, such as microfinance schemes and the “GetSet Loan” programme aimed at youth empowerment, showcased his commitment to creating an enabling environment for small and medium-sized enterprises. Notably, Faris’ advocacy extended to the legislative sphere, where his commitment to democratic values shone through. His opposition to amendments with potentially negative implications for the freedoms and governance of the Maldivian People demonstrated his unwavering dedication to the preservation of democratic principles. His courage was particularly evident when he challenged amendments targeting the national law on assemblies, a move that led to his unjust detention. During this time, he was recognised as a prisoner of conscience by Amnesty International. Maumoon’s vision for the Maldives is not just about a relentless push towards modernity though; it is a delicate blend of embracing progress while preserving tradition. He envisions a Maldives where economic sustainability and diplomatic relations go hand in hand, creating a prosperous nation with a global presence. His belief in transparent governance and inclusive growth echoes through his initiatives that aim to uplift every corner of the Maldives. In his own words, Faris envisions “a thriving modern society that never loses its connection to its traditional roots, and one ready to embrace the world, and one which the world looks forward to embracing in turn”. This sentiment encapsulates his vision for the Maldives – a nation that moves forward with the world while preserving its unique cultural identity. As he sets his sights on the Presidency of the Republic of the Maldives, Faris embodies hope, progress, and a dedication to a brighter future. His commitment to economic stability, sustainable development, warm diplomatic relations, and democratic values makes him a candidate whose vision resonates with the aspirations of the Maldivian people. Moving purposefully toward a prosperous tomorrow, Ahmed Faris Maumoon symbolises the shared Maldivian hope for change and the courage needed to endure through the challenges, and deliver it. He stands as the Maldives new rising sun, ready to steer the nation towards a bright new dawn, while remaining faithful to its rich culture, history and legacy.

title: Govt launches ‘Pledge Loan Scheme’
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Finance announced the initiation of a ‘Pledge Loan Scheme,’ effective 1 September, to assist small and medium-sized paddy mill owners in procuring paddy for the Yala season. This loan scheme will be introduced with favourable interest rates, aiming to ensure reasonable prices for farmers and bolster the small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) paddy millers, the Finance Ministry said. Under this scheme, SME paddy millers with valid business registration, with a maximum daily milling capacity of 25 MT of paddy, will be eligible to access these loans. Further, the ministry outlined that each miller can avail of a loan with an effective interest rate of 16 per cent per annum, capped at Rs 50 million. Of this interest rate, SME paddy millers will bear 12 per cent, while an interest subsidy of 4 per cent will be provided. Repayment of the loan should be completed within 180 days. The total value of loans to be disbursed by the People’s Bank and Bank of Ceylon is Rs 4 billion, according to the ministry’s statement. This concessional loan scheme, approved through a Cabinet Decision dated 14 August, is scheduled to run from 1 September to 30 November of this year, the ministry added.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: The Indian Naval Ship (INS) ‘Delhi’ arrived at the Port of Colombo on a formal visit on Friday morning (1). The visiting ship was welcomed by the Sri Lanka Navy in accordance with naval traditions. INS ‘Delhi’ is a 163.2 m Destroyer manned by a crew of 450 and the ship is commanded by Captain Abhishek Kumar. Meanwhile, the Commanding Officer of the ship called on Commander Western Naval Area, Rear Admiral Suresh De Silva at the Western Naval Command Headquarters on Friday morning. During the ship’s stay, the crew was scheduled to take part in several programmes organised by the Sri Lanka Navy, to promote cooperation and goodwill between the two navies. They are also expected to visit some of the tourist attractions in the country. In addition, INS ‘Delhi’ has made arrangements to open the ship for the visit of schoolchildren. Further, training exchanges are scheduled to be held aboard, involving personnel from both navies. The ship is expected to depart the island today (3) and she will conduct a Passage Exercise (PASSEX) with a ship of the Sri Lanka Navy, off Colombo. Popular

title: 886 MPDTF staff granted permanent positions
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 886 Multi-Purpose Development Task Force (MPDTF) employees, who had been working on a temporary basis in the Eastern Province, have been granted permanent positions. These MPDTF employees were initially appointed on a temporary basis two years ago as part of the Government’s initiative to create 100,000 job opportunities and address unemployment in the country, Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman said. Governor Thondaman mentioned that all other employees hired under this programme have already been granted permanent status. At a ceremony held on Saturday (2) in Trincomalee, Thondaman handed over the permanent appointment letters to these employees. Eastern Province MPs were in attendance as well. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SL secures medal at IOI after 16 years
author: Author not found
Content: Sithija Abhishek Kotuwewatta, a student of Gateway College, Colombo, secured a Bronze medal at the prestigious International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI) Competition 2023. It is after a lapse of 16 years that a Sri Lankan participant has won a medal at this competition. The Sri Lankan IOI team included six members, including Kotuwewatta, Team Leader Adithya Narasinghe, Deputy Leader, Venudi Dayaratne and contestants, Minindu Jayasekara, Shithila Mahabaduge and Mindiya Karunasinghe. The International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI) is renowned as the foremost competition in informatics for high school students worldwide. IOI 2023 was hosted by Hungary in Szeged from 28 August to 4 September, marking the 35th edition. Contestants have to face two intense days, each with five hours of coding challenges, solving three problems a day. Sri Lanka has been continuously taking part in IOI since 1992, and from 1994 to 2007, has consistently clinched at least one medal each year—ranging from Gold, Silver, to Bronze-accounting for 3 Golds, 7 Silvers, and 16 Bronzes. However, the Government ceased funding for the programme in 2005, and it is with the dedication of volunteers from the University of Colombo School of Computing and IOI Alumni, that it is sustained up to now. ACM Student Chapter of the University of Colombo School of Computing along with IOI Alumni took over the management of the programme in 2019. Lakshith Nishshanke, Apiram Rajamohan and Ashan Hansaka were the trainers of the 2023 team. By Induwara Athapattu

title: Collapsing earth mound kills 62-year-old
author: Author not found
Content: A 62-year-old father of three lost his life yesterday (3) morning, when a mound of earth collapsed on him while he was excavating to construct a parapet wall for his house, Nawalapitiya Police said. Initial findings from the Police investigation indicate that the deceased worked as a daily wage labourer. Due to the adverse weather conditions prevailing at the time, with excessive water saturating the highlands, the soil had become unstable, leading to the earth mound falling on him. Rescue efforts were made, and the victim was rushed to the District General Hospital in Nawalapitiya. However, medical professionals confirmed that he had succumbed to his injuries before reaching the hospital, Police said. Following investigations, the body was placed in the mortuary of Nawalapitiya Hospital and later handed over to the deceased’s relatives. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Keheliya instructs to increase medicinal drug suppliers
author: Author not found
Content: After a lapse of several months of the medicinal drug shortage, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella has finally instructed the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) to take necessary steps to increase the number of qualified registered suppliers for each drug to speed up medicinal drug supply. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry said on Friday (1) that this would help create competition rather than the existing monopoly in the supply of certain medicinal drugs. He said this would help control the present shortages of pharmaceuticals and increase in prices. During a discussion held between the Health Minister, the NMRA, State Pharmaceuticals Manufacturing Corporation (SPMC), the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and senior officials of the Health Ministry, the minister said problems arose from having only one supplier for certain medicines. These problems can be avoided if there are several suppliers. He said Minister Rambukwella advised the NMRA to speed up the process by following the necessary rules and procedures, especially towards suppliers who meet the proper qualifications. The spokesman said the Minister had also instructed his officials to maintain stocks of life-saving and essential medicinal drugs in the MSD so there would be sufficient medicines for one year. He said Rambukwella had informed his officials to pay more attention to essential medicines such as those required by cancer and kidney patients to maintain them in the country without any shortage. (DJ)

title: Revamping of SLPP underway – Namal
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) is undergoing a reorganisation effort, including the establishment of party branches islandwide, MP Namal Rajapaksa said. He announced, “We initiated this programme on Saturday (2), with the primary goal of nurturing grassroots level leaders. The SLPP aims to be actively engaged at the local level and serve as a catalyst to provide various forms of support to the people.” Rajapaksa expressed his gratitude to party members who have been instrumental in setting up party offices in recent times. He also asserted, “The SLPP is prepared to participate in any election at any time.”

title: Two patients gone completely blind – GMOA
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the use of ‘Prednisolone’ eye drops in surgeries at Nuwara Eliya District Hospital in April, two patients have gone completely blind, while 17 others developed complications post-surgery, the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) alleged, during a media briefing at the hospital yesterday (31 August). Eye specialist Dr. Kanishka addressing the media briefing, said that despite various information circulating on social media, this disclosure is being made to the public due to the reluctance of many individuals to reveal the true situation. “We cannot accept responsibility for this situation. The public often blames the doctors for prescribing the wrong medicine. However, the primary responsibility for this catastrophe lies with the current government. The Government brings in various inferior medicines for its own benefit. Most of the drugs acquired through emergency purchases are inexpensive, such as the eye medicine Prednisolone,” he said. The doctors said that strict measures should be implemented to prevent the procurement of substandard medicines like this in the future. “While we are called doctors, in certain instances we feel like patients ourselves, as the Government’s actions have pushed us into such a predicament. A number of doctors are leaving the country due to the Government’s inadequate treatment and lack of provision of necessary facilities. As a result, the doctors who remain are forced to handle the workload equivalent to that of two or three doctors per day,” Dr. Kanishka said. “This situation places immense pressure on us as doctors. If it persists, our ability to work effectively and attentively with patients will be compromised. Continuation of this trend will lead to the collapse of the healthcare sector, eroding public confidence in the country’s healthcare system,” he stressed. The government has not offered any compensation or relief to those affected following the eye surgeries. Even if compensation were provided, its duration would be limited if sight is not restored, Dr. Kanishka emphasised adding  that the need was to offer more than just compensation to these innocent patients. BY Neeta Pathmakumari – Norwood

title: President receives Esala Perahera Sannasa
author: Author not found
Content: Diyawadana Nilame of Sri Dalada Maligawa, Pradeep Nilanga Dela, handed over the Esala Perahera Sannasa (scroll) to President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday afternoon (31 August), to officially inform the Head of State that Kandy Esala Perahera was concluded.  The Nilames of the Sathara Maha Dewala and the Pitisara Dewala, accompanied the Diyawadana Nilame of Sri Dalada Maligawa, Pradeep Nilanga Dela, in the procession that made its way to the President’s House in Kandy. The President warmly welcomed them at the main gate. In accordance with custom, the Diyawadana Nilame formally presented the Sannasa to the President. As a symbolic gesture, the President offered a fruit treat to the baby elephant ‘Sindu’, reminiscent of the elephants that graced the procession. Continuing the tradition, a group photo was taken with the Nilames and the President. President Wickremesinghe took the opportunity to honour the artists who participated in the Perahera by presenting them with traditional gifts and awards. Additionally, he extended financial support to the ‘Pitisara Devala’ through the ‘Esala Perahera Trust’ and shared the book ‘Sacred Dalada Culture’ a compilation by the Central Provincial Ministry of Culture. The President, expressing his deep gratitude to all those who supported the Perahera, including the Diyawadana Nilame and led by the Nilames of the Sathara Devala, emphasised the significance of safeguarding the historical Kandy Esala Perahera. He highlighted that this event was not only a religious and national celebration, but also a grand cultural festival that showcased Sri Lankan heritage to the global stage. President Wickremesinghe stressed the importance of carrying this legacy forward. Acknowledging the importance of elephant protection, the President also underscored the need to preserve and uphold the ancient customs. He called for the resolution of challenges such as acquiring tame elephants for the Perahera through constructive negotiations. Additionally, President Wickremesinghe noted that Kandy Esala Perahera would hold a special place in a programme designed to enhance progress in Sri Lanka’s tourism sector in the upcoming year. The event saw the participation of several notable figures, including Central Province Governor Lalith U. Gamage, Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, State Minister Lohan Ratwatte, State Minister Dilum Amunugama, Member of Parliament Gunathilaka Rajapakse, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Secretary of the Ministry of Buddhasasana Religious and Cultural Affairs Somaratne Vidanapathirana, as well as various government officials and the chiefs of the three armed forces.

title: Sinopec commences fuel operations
author: Author not found
Content: Beijing-based international petroleum leader, Sinopec, has officially initiated its presence in Sri Lanka’s fuel industry with the opening of its first filling station in Mattegoda, Colombo. The local subsidiary of the Chinese petroleum giant, Sinopec Fuel Oil Lanka, commenced its retail operations on 30 August, offering discounted petrol and diesel rates with a Rs. 3.00 per litre reduction. Last year’s decision by the Sri Lankan Government to open the fuel import and retail sales market to oil-producing nations, led to the Petroleum Products (Special Provisions) Bill’s approval. This paved the way for global companies like Sinopec to enter as importers, distributors, and retail operators for petroleum products. Following negotiations and a contract agreement signed in May 2023, Sinopec has been granted a 20-year licence to operate 150 filling stations in Sri Lanka, alongside the opportunity to invest in 50 new stations.

title: Pastor Jerome’s Petition fixed for 21 Sept
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (31 August) decided to hear the writ petition, filed by self-proclaimed prophet Jerome Fernando, praying the Court to issue an order preventing his arrest, on 21 September. The petition filed by the Pastor concerned, was perused before a Bench comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne (President) and M.A.R. Marikkar. The petitioner has stated that the CID was planning to arrest him upon him returning to the country from overseas, charging that certain remarks uttered by him had denigrated tenets of Buddhism and therefore he has moved the Court, to issue a writ Order, preventing his arrest. The State Counsel appearing on behalf of the Attorney General informed the Court, that the Attorney General’s Department had already filed limited objections, pertaining to the writ petition filed by the petitioner. BY Hansi Nanayakkara
