title: Court issues Noticeon Nagamuwa
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (31 August) issued Notice on Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) activist Duminda Nagamuwa to appear in Court. This Notice has been prompted by allegations of defamatory statements attributed to Nagamuwa, targeting Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles. In light of this, Nagamuwa has been directed to present himself in Court on 6 September 2023. During a press conference held on 12 August, Duminda alleged that Tiran Alles had invested money in a European island alongside the JVP. Minister Alles filed a complaint with the CID on 15 August over the statement made by Nagamuwa. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Labour Ministry Secy noticed to surrender
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (31 August), noticed Secretary to the Ministry of Labour, R.P.A. Wimalaweera, to surrender to the Horana Chief Magistrate’s Court, after the latter had issued a warrant for his arrest. As per the Notice issued by the Appellate Court, the Secretary to the said Ministry should surrender himself to the Magistrate’s Court within 10 days. Labour Ministry Secretary Wimalaweera, has filed a petition before the Court of Appeal, praying for order invalidating a warrant issued for his arrest, by the Horana Chief Magistrate’s Court, stating that had the warrant had been issued on 24 August over charges of forcing officials from the Director Board of a Rubber Factory in Horana, to provide fake evidence over a fire that had broken out five years ago. The petition was considered before a Court of Appeal Bench, comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne (President) and M.A.R. Marikkar. The suspect was also noticed, to fully support the ongoing case filed against him before the Horana Chief Magistrate’s Court.  The petitioner has also prayed the Court of Appeal, to invalidate a similar order issued on him by the Panadura High Court. Later, the Appellate Court Bench instructed the Horana Chief Magistrate, to enlarge the suspect on suitable bail conditions, upon him surrendering to the said Court. The Court of Appeal also noticed the respondents named in the petition, to be present in Court, to make submissions in this regard, on 14 September. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Talangama killing suspect arrested after fleeing country
author: Author not found
Content: A suspect in the daylight shooting at Talangama on 25 August was arrested at Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake yesterday (31 August), when he was deported from Singapore. A moneylender, 44, was shot in Korawa, South Talangama by a gunman who arrived on a motorcycle with an accomplice. He succumbed to injuries after being admitted to the Colombo National Hospital. The killer had fled the scene. Police said that during inquiries, it had come to light that the suspect had fled the country to Singapore and that following information conveyed to that country to deport the suspect to Colombo, he had been deported. Following inquiries conducted, it had come to light that internecine gang rivalry, between illegal drug smugglers, had led to the incident which was directed by illegal drug peddlers based overseas. BY Niduwara Abeysinghe – Boralesgamuwa

title: Pattern of non-compliance with RTI Act has emerged – Verite
author: Author not found
Content: A concerning pattern of non-compliance with the Right to Information (RTI) Act has emerged within Sri Lanka’s governance landscape, particularly concerning infrastructure projects, alleged Verité Research, a private think-tank. Issuing a statement, Verité Research claimed that in 2022 and 2023, a mere 18% and 25% of the required information for these projects was proactively disclosed online, respectively. Adding to this breach, the available information was predominantly presented in English, disregarding the RTI Act’s mandate of disclosure in Sinhala and Tamil, with English being the secondary option. In 2022, only 18% of the information was accessible in English, while a mere 5% and 4% were offered in Sinhala and Tamil, respectively. These alarming figures persisted in 2023, where 25% was available in English, and only 8% in both Sinhala and Tamil, the statement said. Verité Research’s Infrastructure Watch, hosted on the publicfinance.lk platform, which tracked government adherence to the RTI Act’s proactive disclosure obligations for 60 projects valued at Rs 1.08 trillion in 2022, and 60 projects worth Rs 2.54 trillion in 2023. The 2023 assessment included 37 ongoing projects from the previous year, alongside 23 new ones. “Assessment timelines for the 2022 and 2023 projects spanned from January to April of the respective years. The evaluation solely considered the proactive release of information on the official websites of the responsible Ministries and line-agencies. Mandated by Section 9 of the RTI Act No. 12 of 2016, the responsible Minister for an infrastructure project is obligated to divulge project details. These disclosures are mandatory for both foreign and locally funded projects exceeding USD 100,000 and LKR 500,000 respectively, at least three months before initiation. The information should span five key categories: project specifics, rationale and beneficiaries, budget and financial particulars, approvals and authorisations, and procurement details,” the statement said. Sri Lanka’s large-scale infrastructure initiatives have faced allegations ranging from corruption to procurement misconduct, exorbitant costs, and disregard for environmental impacts. Loans procured over the past two decades to support these endeavors have exacerbated the nation’s debt burden. Transparency serves as a crucial antidote to the issues shadowing infrastructure ventures in Sri Lanka. Introduced in 2016, the RTI Act aimed to achieve this by granting public access to essential government data, empowering citizens to hold the government accountable. “Moreover, publicising procurement contracts through an online fiscal transparency platform to curb corruption aligns with commitments made to the IMF. Yet, the assessment has unveiled a concerning reality: vital information critical for improving infrastructure governance, such as project approvals, clearances, and procurement details, remains obscured from public view,” Verité Research.

title: No. 2 Heavy Transport Squadron Celebrates 66th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Heavy Lifters’, No. 2 Heavy Transport Squadron, steps into its 66th year of proud service to the motherland today (1 September 2023). At the inception, the Royal Ceylon Air Force had only a few aircraft housed in the No. 1 Squadron. Later, with the development of the Royal Ceylon Air Force to its capacity during the leadership of Air Vice Marshal JL Barker, the requirement arose for a separate Training Squadron and an Operational Squadron. As a result, on 1 September 1957, the No. 1 Squadron was split into two, setting up the No. 2 Squadron. Initially, the No. 2 squadron comprised Oxford Airspeed, Prestwick Pioneer, De-Havilland Dove aircraft and also the S-51 Dragonfly helicopter, which was the first helicopter of the Royal Ceylon Air Force. Initially, the squadron was located at SLAF Base Katunayake carrying out Transport and Patrol duties. In September 1959, two De Havilland Herons were purchased directly from England and ferried to the squadron to enhance its operational capability. These were ferried all the way from south London by a local aircrew. The arrival of Herons opened the door to the Royal Ceylon Air Force’s global operations, which extended as far as Indonesia to the east and Cairo to the west. These international flights provided enough experience to the pilots as well as navigators of the fast-developing Royal Ceylon Air Force. In 1973, the squadron received the Convair 440 aircraft into service from Eastern Airlines, USA, to boost operations of HELITOURS between Ceylon and the Maldives. In 1975, the DC 3 Dacotas came into operation, and towards the end of 1979, an HS 748 Avro was absorbed into the No. 2 Squadron fleet. From the period of 1983 to 1985, the squadron acquired three Siai Marchetti SF 260TPs, oneAvro and one Beech King aircraft. With the inception of the SF 260 TPs, the squadron was capable of carrying out a combat role in support of Eelam War I. In 1985, with the expansion of Katunayake International Airport, No. 2 Squadron was shifted to Ratmalana. In 1986, another HS 748 (Avro), five (05) SF 260 TPs and two (02) Y-12 aircraft were added to the squadron inventory. With new aircraft, the squadron expanded its role to Commercial Flights and Aerial Survey missions other than transporting troops, VIPs and cargo. In the late 1980s, DC 3, Doves and Herons were ceased from operation. On 15 September 1992, a significant bit of restructuring of the No. 2 Transport Wing took place, dividing it into No. 201 Heavy Transport Squadron and No. 202 Light Transport Squadron. The No. 201 Squadron operated HS 748 Avro, Y-8 and Cessna 421 aircraft and the No. 202 Squadron operated Y-12 and Beech King Aircraft and both squadrons were under the command of the No. 2 Transport Wing. All technical data for the No. 201 Squadron was computerized in 1992. As a commercial venture, the SLAF Wet-leased two of its Avro aircraft to Air Lanka for a period of two months, from January to March 1992. On 08 November 1995 the No. 201 Squadron was re-designated as the No. 2 Heavy Transport Squadron and the No. 202 Squadron as the No. 8 Light Transport Squadron, which operated under separate commands. Three Antonov 32B aircraft joined the fleet of No. 2 Squadron in the same year. But this period became the darkest period of the No. 2 Squadron’s history, during which two HS 748 aircraft, two AN 32 aircraft and a Y-8 aircraft were shot down by the enemy during operational flights carried out to SLAF Palaly. In 1996, four AN 32 aircraft were acquired by the squadron to cater to the increased demand for transport in support of the ongoing operations and also to replace the two AN 32s lost in 1995. To extensively increase the lift capability, the squadron took delivery of two C-130 Hercules aircraft in late 2000. Other three (03) AN 32s were also added to the fleet in the same year. The present Commander of the Sri Lanka Air Force, Air Marshal RAUP Rajapaksa, served as a Commanding Officer during the period of 1 January 2010 to 28 March 2011 and was a pillar of knowledge and strength to many pilots of the Air Force. The first Commanding Officer of the wing was Flight Lieutenant P.H. Mendis and presently Wing Commander H.M.M. Samarakoon commands the No. 2 Squadron as the acting Commanding Officer. As the No. 2 Squadron spans its commitment over 66 years of distinguished service in the Combat Support Operations in the role of air transportation in the SLAF, the contributions that has made to the country in terms of military and civil requirement are colossal and intangible notably, the assistance provided throughout the humanitarian operations and establishing air diplomacy in the events of regional disasters. Currently, the No. 2 Squadron shelters classic Lockheed C-130 Hercules and AN-32B aircraft together with a dynamic and professional team of aircrew and engineers who are tirelessly work hard to keep the flag flying throughout. In many of the past years, it has been considerably accepted that the largest percentage of flying has been carried out by the No. 2 Squadron and the commitment of the squadron was above 50% of the total air operation hours done by the Air Force from 1996 to 2005. During this period, many pilots of the squadron made the supreme sacrifice in the face of the enemy. However, the squadron continued to discharge the responsibility in the challenging environment, willingly with its remaining pilots and kept the lifeline intact in the northern peninsular. Although the designated role of the squadron may sound limited in its area of responsibility, throughout its life span, No. 2 Squadron has flown into many divested fields of air operations to keep with the slogan of the SLAF.

title: Final Randoli Perahera parades streets of Kandy
author: Author not found
Content: In a profound display of Sri Lanka’s rich cultural heritage, the concluding Randoli Perahera of the esteemed Esala Perahera Festival, paraded the streets of the historic city of Kandy on Wednesday (30) night. Centred on the iconic Sri Dalada Maligawa, the auspicious occasion witnessed the participation of many distinguished guests, including President Ranil Wickremesinghe, visiting US Senator Chris Van Hollen, and US Ambassador Julie Chung.  At the stroke of 7:03 p.m., the enchanting Esala Perahera commenced its majestic journey, traversing through the heart of Kandy’s historic streets. The procession followed a route along Dalada Widiya, Yatinuvara Widiya, Kande Widiya, D.S. Senanayake Widiya, and culminated by passing through Raja Widiya. An immense gathering assembled along both sides of the Perahera route, eagerly awaiting the spectacle of the culminating Randoli Perahera, a pivotal event within the storied Esala Perahera Festival’s rich history.

title: AMS accuses Dy DG, TCU Director of administrative blunders
author: Author not found
Content: The Association of Medical Specialists (AMS) accused the Deputy Director General (Medical Services-1) and the Director Tertiary Care Unit (TCU) of being responsible for administrative blunders which would have “far-reaching medical and legal consequences.” In a letter to Health Secretary, Janaka Sri Chandragupta, AMS President and Secretary Drs. A.D.K.S.N. Yasawardene and R. Gnanasekeram accused the Deputy Director General (Medical Services-1) of transferring a Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) working at the Colombo JMO office to th Homagama Base Hospital, based merely on a complaint, without conducting an inquiry. The duo alleged that the transfer letter had included, a false reason mentioned (“service need”). There are several, similar, ad hoc decisions taken by senior medical administrators in the recent past, which led to total chaos in the well organised specialist medical care of this country. The AMS President and Secretary accused the Ministry of Health and the Director of Tertiary Care of having been unable to even implement a ruling of Professional misconduct given against JMO Ruhul Haq. “The SLMC is the highest body in this country to deliver a ruling on Professional Misconduct of a medical practitioner and that ruling is communicated to the relevant practitioner and his employer – the Health Ministry,” they noted.   Drs Yasawardene and Gnanasekeram pointed out that it was the duty of the Health Ministry to implement this ruling to the letter without looking for any lame excuses. The duo lamented that medical specialists had to face numerous challenges when they worked in the present environment.  They include lack of infrastructure, administrative pro-activity and facilities. “Medical specialists who return from abroad with focused and intense training in overseas centres of excellence, get disheartened under such circumstances, although they have the keen desire and motivation to serve Sri Lanka with dedication,” The President and Secretary of the AMS observed noting that the arrogant and unprofessional behaviour of some of the medical administrators in the present setup only precipitated the exodus of medical practitioners.  (DJ)

title: Centralised camera system to combat fake sticker racket
author: Author not found
Content: Excise Commissioner General Saman Jayasinghe, who admitted there were liquor bottles containing counterfeit stickers or labels in the market, revealed that a centralised monitoring camera system will be in place soon to combat all irregularities taking place with regard to placing of counterfeit stickers. This camera system would be introduced before 30 September. He made this revelation during a discussion held with reps of firms engaged in liquor production, at the Head Office of the Excise Department recently. During this discussion the Excise Commissioner General maintained that the market had been proliferated with liquor bottles containing counterfeit stickers. Jayasinghe also stated during this meeting that President had personally instructed him to bring to book all those found guilty of the said racket and the firms involved in it. He said, those engaged in the racket of placing counterfeit stickers on liquor bottles will be prosecuted to the sternest letter of the law. Jayasinghe, therefore, warned that those firms which are guilty of placing counterfeit stickers on liquor bottles could face the danger of their licences being revoked by the Government. He explained that the said racket could not have taken place without the blessings of the firms involved in the production of liquor and those involved in retail sales. He opined that if the racket is not rooted out it will also deal a severe blow to the income accrued by the State via the industry. Jayasinghe also said, a centralised monitoring camera system will be shortly initiated to combat all irregularities taking place with regard to placing of counterfeit stickers and overcoming such incidents. He also instructed liquor firm reps to install such camera systems within their respective institutions before 30 September. The officials from the Excise Department who had taken part in the discussion had stated that such incidents taking place when their work is being monitored by a few Parliament Select Committees (PSCs) will not augur well for their image in the eyes of the public and they have urged the Excise Commissioner General to move in the matter promptly and eradicate the rackets as it could deal a massive blow to State coffers if allowed to operate as of now. Meanwhile, the Excise Trade Union Collective (ETUC) issuing a media release states that all officers of the Excise Department should not be held responsible for the racket of placing counterfeit stickers on liquor bottles. Its Co-Secretary Nirosh Jayakody said, a set of officers from the Department who are protecting those from the Indian firm involved in supplying these security stickers and the said Indian firm known as Madras Security Printers (MSP) should be held accountable for it. The ETUC states that raids to seize liquor bottles with counterfeit stickers had been conducted since the start of August, but had noted that reviews being carried out into those raids had not been satisfactory. The ETUC has added that due to this situation they had requested the Excise Commissioner General in writing to look into this matter urgently. They have also mentioned that due to several shortcomings, on the part of the MSP, the ongoing racket had continued unabated and they have urged the Excise Commissioner General to investigate it promptly. They have lastly pointed out that the Indian firm which had been selected via a tender process to supply the security stickers had been blacklisted in a few countries after being guilty of committing several irregularities and the ETUC has observed that concerns raised by them in this regard had not been heeded either by the Excise Commissioner General or any of his officers. They have stressed that an unknown and a mysterious force is operating from behind the scenes in conjunction with the Indian firm in question and that they would reveal further details shortly.

title: No outsider allowed to enter site – President
author: Author not found
Content: As a step to address the controversy that erupted with regard to the Kurunthamalai Temple, no outsider will be permitted to enter the site going forward, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said. The President made this remark when he visited Kandy to observe the Kandy Sri Dalada Perahera and met Mahanayake Theras and Anunayake Theras of Malwathu and Asgiriya Chapters. The President said, “Encouragingly, the Sinhalese, Muslim and Tamil communities of that area have united in agreement, pledging not to involve external entities. In times past, this region was characterised by harmonious coexistence among its inhabitants. Regrettably, the introduction of external groups has given rise to these recent complications. I have also communicated this matter to the Nayake Thera of Vavuniya region.” In light of these circumstances, it is imperative that access to this area is restricted exclusively to those within our sphere of influence. To ensure the integrity of our actions, the Department of Archaeology has been directed to conduct a thorough investigation. These actions align with the mandates of the Antiquities Act, underscoring our commitment to preserving our cultural heritage. Moreover, we are poised to undertake an excavation initiative at the esteemed Maha Viharaya. The ongoing excavation efforts in the Northern regions continue to yield valuable insights, and these undertakings remain in active progress. I wish to clarify that the preceding government took prompt action by deploying the armed forces to expedite the excavation process. However, a definitive course of action is still pending, awaiting the decision of the Department of Archaeology. Rest assured, our future steps will be in alignment with the verdict provided by this authoritative body. It is imperative to underscore our unwavering commitment to safeguarding these sacred regions, he said. The President also said the Government’s efforts extend to the safeguarding of all Buddhist shrines. Our approach begins with the identification of archaeological sites of significance. Following this crucial step, a comprehensive investigation ensues. Further, it is crucial to highlight our dedication to addressing any challenges faced by other religious communities in this context, he added. “I must emphatically state that we remain resolute in preventing external entities from instigating disturbances. To foster harmony and prevent potential conflicts, we are actively working towards appointing a committee comprising esteemed religious leaders from the respective provinces. The collective efforts of these leaders are poised to avert any arising conflicts,” the President pointed out. Addressing the country’s economic landscape, the President said the Government is presently transitioning out of financial turmoil. This revival is being facilitated through the implementation of a foreign debt optimisation programme and a series of substantial economic reforms. Presently, local banks are grappling with challenges, leading to restricted access to funds. A significant number of domestic banks find themselves burdened with debt, he said. “Should the banking system falter, it could precipitate severe financial repercussions. Moreover, the Central Bank has received liabilities from the Employees’ Provident Fund. Endeavours are underway to convert these liabilities into long-term bonds. While a marginal disparity in interest rates exists, it bears no detrimental impact on depositors. Notably, an agreement was reached last year to grant a 9 per cent interest to Employees’ Provident Fund depositors and I am steadfast in my commitment to enshrine this minimum interest rate into law.” Additionally, our efforts encompass the formulation of a new Central Bank Act. This step will pave the way for subsequent negotiations with our creditor nations. Concurrently, we will address personal loans, aspiring to either substantially reduce our debt burden or devise a sustainable repayment plan over the long term, the President noted. Speaking further, the President said it is the Government’s aspiration to convene discussions and finalise agreements with the International Monetary Fund by the conclusion of September or the onset of October. This accomplishment would signify our emergence from the shackles of bankruptcy, enabling us to engage in economic transactions with renewed ease. “Acknowledging the trade imbalance where imports surpass our exports, we are resolutely charting a course towards cultivating a competitive economic landscape. Central to this endeavour is the establishment of an export-oriented economy.” Meanwhile, Most Venerable Anamaduwe Dhammadassi Thera, the Anunayake of the Asgiriya Chapter, has expressed his appreciation for President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s significant contributions to the nation’s progress amidst challenging circumstances. During the President’s recent visit to the historic city of Kandy, the Venerable Thera highlighted the importance of understanding and endorsing the President’s endeavours. The Anunayake Thera noted that President Wickremesinghe’s efforts to rejuvenate Sri Lanka following adverse situations have been instrumental in moving the country forward. He lamented that some individuals fail to grasp the depth of these endeavours and urged the public to acknowledge the President’s commitment. Further, the Most Venerable Dhammadassi Thera expressed his confidence that the programmes initiated by President Wickremesinghe for the nation’s betterment will undoubtedly receive the blessings of the Maha Sangha, the community of Buddhist monks. President Wickremesinghe’s itinerary also included visits to other revered Buddhist leaders, including the Anunayake Thera of the Malwathu Chapter, the Most Venerable Dimbulkumbure Sri Vimaladhamma Thera, with whom he exchanged views. At the Asgiri Maha Viharaya, President Wickremesinghe received blessings from the Most Venerable Warakagoda Sri Gnanarathana Thera, the Chief Prelate of the Asgiriya Chapter. The President participated in religious ceremonies at the Asgiriya Gedige Raja Maha Viharaya, underscoring his commitment to Buddhism and its values. The Anunayake Thera said, “Your role during this difficult period is paramount for the nation. The country once faced a significant economic downturn, and your efforts in leading its recovery are commendable. You’ve even personally endured losses, including property and your home. Your aptitude to offer solutions to the prevailing issues is noteworthy. We earnestly pray for divine support, safeguarded by the blessings of the Gods, Goddesses and the protection of the Sacred Tooth Relic.” The actions of the former President in safeguarding Buddhist shrines in the Eastern Province via the Defence Secretary were acknowledged. A programme was initiated to ensure their protection. Also, photo reports were submitted, however, concerns were raised about the present status of this endeavour. Additionally, the issue of external interference creating conflicts in the vicinity of the Kurundi Viharaya was highlighted, urging action.

title: US delegation meets Navy Chief
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation headed by United States Senator Chris Van Hollen met Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera on board SLNS Gajabahu in Colombo yesterday (30). The visit is part of the United States assistance programmes in the region and to discuss opportunities to enhance cooperation. US Ambassador in Colombo Julie Chung was also present on this occasion. On their arrival, the US delegation received a cordial welcome on board SLNS Gajabahu. The subsequent conversation between the delegates and the Navy Commander centred on various topics of bilateral interest. The formal discussion ended with an exchange of mementoes, highlighting the significance of this occasion. Deputy Chief of Staff and Director General Operations, Rear Admiral Pradeep Rathnayake, Commander Western Naval Area, Rear Admiral Suresh De Silva, Naval Assistant to the Navy Commander and Chief Hydrographer of the Sri Lanka Navy, Commodore Kosala Warnakulasooriya and Naval Attaché at the US Embassy in Colombo, Lieutenant Commander Jessica De Mont were present on this occasion.

title: UN Resident Representative meets Opposition Leader
author: Author not found
Content: Marc-André Franche, the recently appointed Permanent Resident Representative of the United Nations, engaged in discussions with Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, at the Opposition Leader’s Office yesterday (30). According to the Opposition Leader’s Office, this meeting took place shortly after Marc-André Franche assumed his duties in the country. The meeting involved a comprehensive exchange of ideas and factual information concerning various socio-economic and political aspects of Sri Lanka. During the conversation, Premadasa offered insights to the new Permanent Resident Representative of the United Nations regarding the present political landscape in the country. Further, the discussions highlighted instances of democratic rights being compromised, the postponement of elections, and violations of fundamental rights. The UN was represented by a delegation led by Azam Bakeer Markar (Development Coordination Officer) and Tharaka Hettiarachchi (Peace Window Coordinator) during this interaction.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Lottery ticket sales dip in Ratnapura
author: Author not found
Content: Following the increase in the price of a lottery ticket from Rs 20 to Rs 40, the sale of lottery tickets in Ratnapura has experienced a drastic 50 per cent decline, Lottery Agent in Ratnapura, Tikiribandara claimed. He said this downturn has put lottery sellers, sales agents, and numerous individuals who rely on this industry in great difficulty. According to Tikiribandara, this decline in sales can be attributed to the economic crisis and that many individuals are unable to allocate Rs 40 for a lottery ticket amidst the rising cost of living. As a result, those who used to purchase four or five tickets have now scaled down to buying only one or two tickets. “The National Lotteries Board must immediately address this situation,” he said. Speaking further, he stressed that the National Lotteries Board must consider the implications of the price increase on the purchasing power of the public and the subsequent impact on the livelihoods of individuals linked to the lottery industry. By K.A.S. Piyathilaka – Kuruwita

title: Man flees country despite travel ban
author: Author not found
Content: A person who had managed to flee the country despite travel bans imposed by two Magistrate Courts was arrested while on board a flight and deported on arrival in Mumbai yesterday (30). The 45-year-old, originally from Jaffna, was banned from leaving the country by both the Point Pedro and Mallakam Magistrates. However, on Tuesday (29) night, he was able to pass through the departure terminal and board a SriLankan Airlines flight bound for Mumbai. A vigilant Australian woman, who was awaiting immigration clearance, noticed the individual discreetly passing through the counter and promptly alerted the authorities. Despite the best efforts of the officers, along with assistance from the concerned Australian passenger, they were unable to locate him. Later, after reviewing CCTV footage, they identified the passenger and cross-referenced his passport and boarding pass details. It came to light that he was on a no-fly list. Given that the flight had already entered Indian airspace, the Immigration and Emigration officers communicated with the Captain and Operations Manager at the Mumbai Airport, apprising them of the situation. On landing in Mumbai, the individual was arrested and subsequently deported to Sri Lanka. He was then handed over to Immigration and Emigration officers at the BIA.  By T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Bid to smuggle Rs 290M worth gems thwarted
author: Author not found
Content: A woman was arrested at the Departure Terminal of BIA yesterday (30) morning while attempting to smuggle a collection of gems valued at Rs 290 million to India, Customs Media Spokesman Seevali Arukgoda said. The suspect is a 30-year-old businesswoman residing in Orugodawatta. She had arrived at the BIA yesterday (30) at about 3:15 a.m., to board AI 274 operated by Air India, bound for Chennai. The Customs Spokesman said the seized gems weighed a total of 2.3 kg and had been concealed on person. By T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: SIS Chief Sallay sends LoD to Rev. Fr. Rohan Silva
author: Author not found
Content: Director of State Intelligence Service (SIS) Major General Suresh Sallay sent a Letter of Demand (LoD) to Rev. Fr. Rohan Silva on 25 August, with regard to a press conference held in Colombo on 21 August 2022, seeking Rs 500 million for alleged damages.   Attorney-at-Law Lakshika Bakmiwewa sent the LOD on behalf of Major General Sallay. The LOD said, “I am instructed that the said press conference was streamed live on digital platforms, and I’m further instructed that the same was open to the public, both local and global alike. I’m also instructed that a degree of publicity for the same was given via live Television News Bulletins of the day and was published in several online news websites and newspapers to the Sri Lankan public and to the world at large. I am instructed to vehemently deny your allegation that my client has in any capacity communicated or met the individual named Mohamed Cassim Mohamed Zahran at any given point in time. I am instructed to vehemently deny your allegation that my client has at some point, provided financial aid or any other form of support to the individual named Mohamed Cassim Mohamed Zahran and/or any one of his followers and/or any such organisation he was involved in.” The LOD further stated that Major General Sallay appeared duly before various commissions of inquiry that were held with regard to the Easter Sunday Attacks and has given testimony and further, has duly appeared before Court(s) of Law in the capacity of a witness. “Moreover, these allegations levelled against my client are nothing but unsubstantiated, distorted and manipulated facts. Further, your statements in this press conference have attempted to create an impression based on false and wilfully fabricated facts to link my client to certain individuals with whom he has no associations and to incidents that had taken place in the country at a time when my client was either based Overseas or employed elsewhere,” the LOD said.

title: Two buses collide head-on in Kajugama
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, in the Kajugama area along the Colombo-Kandy main road, two buses collided head-on, resulting in the loss of one life and injuries to nine individuals. The collision involved a private bus transporting a group of employees and a Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) bus. The private bus, attempting to overtake another vehicle, collided head-on with the SLTB bus which was en route from Kattankudy to Colombo. The 44-year-old driver of the private bus lost his life in the collision, while four women and five other passengers from both buses sustained injuries. The driver’s body was transferred to Warakapola Hospital. The SLTB bus driver was arrested. Nittambuwa Police are conducting investigations.

title: Two cops injured in scuffle with ‘ice’ peddler
author: Author not found
Content: Ella Police said two Police Officers sustained injuries and were hospitalised while attempting to arrest an individual suspected of possessing crystal methamphetamine, commonly known as ‘ice,’ at the Bandarawela-Gotuwela intersection yesterday morning (30). The suspect, a 35-year-old Navy deserter residing in Gotuwela, was arrested eventually. The injured officers, both from the Country Vehicle Division of the Ella Police, were rushed to the Demodara Hospital.  Ella Police are conducting investigations. By Saman Palitha Nanayakkara – Haldummulla

title: Keheliya instructs to recruit 3,000 nurses
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella instructed to recruit 3,000 nurses to bolster Sri Lanka’s healthcare system. He additionally directed the Ministry Secretary to draft a Cabinet proposal if any recruitment-related challenges arise. This directive was conveyed to officials within the Health Ministry’s nursing service during a meeting held at the Ministry on 29 August. In 2018, approximately 2,500 persons were enrolled as student nurses, and an additional 500 nursing graduates are set to join the nursing service. The Ministry of Health has outlined plans to release a gazette for the 2019/2020 Advanced Level category nursing training application by mid-September. Successful applicants will undergo a three-year nursing training programme. Last July, a total of 3,315 individuals were recruited as nursing students based on the Advanced Level results of 2018/2019. Thus, the total number of student nurses in Sri Lanka stands at around 6,700.

title: Dutch delegation visits Galle Fort
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation consisting of Netherlands Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Bonnie Horbach, Secretary of State for Cultural Affairs of Netherlands Gunay Uslu, and Director General of the Ministry of Culture, Education, and Media of Netherlands Barbera Wolfensberger, visited Galle Fort yesterday (30). During their visit, the delegation opened the Museum of Ceylon Forts, located at Galle Fort. Dr. Nilan Cooray, Chairman of Galle Heritage Foundation, and Tharanga Liyanarachchi, the Project Officer, warmly welcomed the delegation. Following the museum’s opening ceremony, the delegation embarked on an observation tour of the Fort Wall. By Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle

title: China should not cut a better deal for itself – Van Hollen
author: Author not found
Content: US Senator Chris Van Hollen, who is in Sri Lanka, underscored that China, the largest creditor of Sri Lanka, should not cut a better deal for itself but be on par with the rest of the creditors in debt restructuring as a condition applied by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The Senator, who is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Appropriations Subcommittee on State and Foreign Operations, expressed concern that a situation where China negotiates a more favourable deal at the expense of Sri Lanka’s people and economy would not be appropriate. Emphasising the significance of support from the IMF for Sri Lanka, the Senator of Maryland said, “The Paris Club and India said to take steps to ensure that their creditor arrangements are on par with the terms offered. These creditors made sure that they have the same arrangement as China. It’s inappropriate for China to pursue more favourable conditions at the cost of Sri Lanka’s populace, given the current timing and urgency of the issue. It is of utmost significance that the country’s primary creditor refrains from exploiting its leverage to the detriment of a comprehensive agreement. Such an agreement holds immense importance for both the people of Sri Lanka and its economy,” he said. The US Senator is in Sri Lanka as a part of a three-nation (Sri Lanka, Nepal and the Maldives) tour and to focus on ways the US can further assist efforts to overcome Sri Lanka’s economic crisis and discuss the way forward on human rights and reconciliation. Senator Van Hollen emphasised the significance of support from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for Sri Lanka. He noted that the IMF’s USD 3 billion assistance is crucial to help stabilise Sri Lanka’s economy. Without this agreement with the IMF, Sri Lanka’s economic situation would spiral downward. On the Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR) programme where people are agitated about using deposits from sources like the Employees’ Provident Fund to address domestic debt, the Senator acknowledged that these decisions are by the Sri Lankan Government, and he highlighted the importance of considering social safety net issues as discussions on this matter continue. Senator Van Hollen said he believed that the IMF’s assistance, combined with effective debt restructuring decisions by the Sri Lankan Government, is crucial for turning around Sri Lanka’s economy. He stressed the need to consider the vulnerabilities of the population while making these decisions. Apart from economic matters, the Senator’s visit also aimed to discuss human rights and reconciliation efforts in Sri Lanka and to meet the civil society as well. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Expert Consultation held to review LKI’s research programme
author: Author not found
Content: The Lakshman Kadirgamar Institute of International Relations and Strategic Studies (LKI) conducted an expert consultation on 24 August 2023, to review the proposed ‘LKI Research Programme’. Senior academics and practitioners, covering areas of research that fall within the scope of the ‘LKI Research Programme’, were invited to provide observations in person during a collective session, and also through written inputs. Opening the discussion, Ambassador Ravinatha Aryasinha, Executive Director of LKI, stated that in addition to the LKI flagship events, such as ‘the LKI Foreign Policy Forum’ inaugurated earlier this month, a structured ‘Research Programme’ is being developed to establish a strong framework at LKI for research on contemporary issues of relevance to Sri Lanka’s Foreign Policy. Highlighting the need for a multi-disciplinary approach to address some of these issues, he said that LKI was keen to engage with Foreign Policy scholars and practitioners, as well as to draw within its expert network those with relevant knowledge in the legal, socio-economic, sustainable development, science and innovation, communication, and cultural dimensions of modern diplomacy. The attendees highlighted the need for LKI to produce independent, timely and evidence-based research that aims primarily to address contemporary issues relevant in shaping Sri Lanka’s Foreign Policy postures. Noting that identifying clear research areas with focus topics will enable LKI to continuously contribute to Foreign Policy discussions. They encouraged LKI to find a balance between depth and breadth in its research. They also noted that LKI should bring together experts that could create an inter-disciplinary network and that it must serve as a bridge connecting academics, practitioners and civil society as well as providing a forum for an open discussion and pre-stage research. Among those who contributed to the consultation were  H. M. G. S. Palihakkara, former Foreign Secretary, Professor Emeritus AmalJayewardena, Prof. Ajith de Alwis, Project Director, Coordinating Secretariat for Science, Technology and Innovation, Dr. Harinda Vidanage, Director, International Relations, KDU, Prof. Maneesha S. Wanasinghe Pasqual, Dr. Pavithra Jayawardena, Dr. Menik Wakkumbura, and Dr. George Cooke from the University of Colombo, Dr. Nishara Mendis, Anushka Wijesinha, Founder, Center for Smart Future, and Kishani Jayasinghe-Wijayasekara, former Deputy Director, SAARC Cultural Centre,  O. L. Ameer Ajwad, Director General/Performance Review and Implementation and  E. A. S. Wijayanthi Edirisinghe, Director General (Actg.)/Human Resources Development, Research & Training, LKI Research. Fellows, Research Assistants, Research Interns and Director/Administration of LKI were also associated in the discussion.

title: Dutugemunu School Launches Innovative Programme
author: Author not found
Content: Amid the prevailing extreme heat conditions, health authorities have highlighted the need for adequate drinking water supply to schoolchildren. In response, Principal of Dutugemunu Model School in Buttala, Sampath Dissanayake, has launched an innovative programme aimed at encouraging proper hydration among students. Under this initiative, after each class period, a designated student takes the floor and addresses the class in English, saying, “Attention, let’s drink water.” Thereafter, all the students promptly reach for their bottles of water and quench their thirst. This practice is embraced not only by the students but also by the teachers. Dissanayake, explaining the rationale behind this approach, said, “Given the ongoing dry spell, we recognised the importance of tackling student fatigue and dehydration. Thus, we formulated this programme, which involves assigning a student leader within the class to prompt their peers to drink water. We decided to convey this reminder in English, using just two simple sentences. This innovative approach comprises various segments designed to facilitate seamless classroom management for our teachers. Beyond hydration, the programme instils an understanding among the children about the significance of water for maintaining a healthy body. Further, it provides a platform to enhance their English speaking skills and fosters leadership abilities, including among students who may need additional support.” By G.I. Roshan – Wellawaya

title: Navy seizes 441 kg of smuggled Kendu leaves
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy seized 441 kg of smuggled Kendu leaves and a dinghy during a special operation conducted in the Pitipana Lagoon area in Negombo on Tuesday (29). The special operation was mounted by SLNS Kelani in the Western Naval Command in Pitipana Lagoon on 29 August. The search operation led to the seizure of about 440.9 kg of Kendu leaves in 15 packages in a dinghy which was searched by the Navy on suspicion. Meanwhile, the consignment of Kendu leaves and the dinghy held by the Navy in this operation will be handed over to the Customs Preventive Office, Katunayake for onward legal action.

title: Commemoration of 50 Years of Association
author: Author not found
Content: High Commission of India, Colombo commemorated 50 years of association between the National Defence College (NDC), India and Sri Lankan Armed Forces on 28 August. The event celebrated the enduring bonds of cooperation, camaraderie and friendship among the militaries of the two countries. Defence Secretary, Gen (Retd) Kamal Gunaratne was the Chief Guest. Chief of Defence Staff Lt. Gen. Shavendra Silva, Commanders of the Sri Lanka Army, Navy and Air Force along with officers from NDC, India and dignitaries from the Ministry of Defence attended the event. Gen (Retd) Gunaratne along with High Commissioner of India Gopal Baglay felicitated the Guest of Honour, Admiral (Retd) D.B. Goonesekara on the special occasion. Admiral Goonesekara has the distinction of being the first NDC India alumni in Sri Lanka. He shared his cherished experiences from the times he spent at NDC, India in 1972, more than 50 years ago. High Commissioner Baglay highlighted at the event that India stands committed to Sri Lanka’s capacity-building endeavours in line with India’s ‘Neighbourhood First Policy’. He emphasised that training engagements between the Armed Forces have instilled a spirit of brotherhood and interoperability amongst the services and form the foundation of their strong bonds. Addressing the gathering, the Defence Secretary commended the efforts of the Indian High Commissioner to bridge the bonds between the two nations across various dimensions. He underlined that India has always been a pillar of strength in the training of Sri Lankan Armed Forces personnel and shares strong cultural, demographical and behavioural similarities as a friendly neighbour. He further expressed his gratitude for the fully funded and comprehensive training opportunities being provided to Sri Lankan Armed Forces. The event was attended by close to 50 NDC India alumni in Sri Lanka. Sri Lanka Armed Forces officers constitute around 10 per cent of the total capacity-building vacancies allocated to officers from foreign countries, making such allocation the largest.

title: ‘Brewing Ambition: Celebrating 75 Years of Friendship and Skills’
author: Author not found
Content: Australian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Paul Stephens, in partnership with Dilmah, hosted an event themed ‘Brewing Ambition: Celebrating 75 years of friendship and skills’ on Thursday, 24 August. The dinner was curated by the renowned Australian-Sri Lankan chef, restaurateur and author Peter Kuruvita with the students of Dilmah’s Empower Culinary and Hospitality School (ECHS) and past winners and contestants of the ‘Supreme Chef’ competition, an initiative of the Australian Aid-funded Skills for Inclusive Growth (S4IG) programme. S4IG works towards implementing an integrated approach to skills development and supports sustainable and inclusive job creation in Sri Lanka. The event was attended by representatives from the education, hospitality, tourism, business and government sectors. The range of guests and fusion menu, highlighting Sri Lanka’s unique culinary offerings, demonstrated the cultural and people-to-people ties that underpin Australia and Sri Lanka’s more than 75-year bilateral partnership. Australian High Commissioner Stephens said, “Australia has been a longstanding supporter of skills development in Sri Lanka, recognising that this is key to sustainable and inclusive economic growth. Australia’s engagement has helped bridge the gaps in Sri Lanka’s tourism and hospitality market and support Sri Lanka in its path to become a tourist-ready destination.” Chairman of Dilmah, Dilhan Fernando, added: “My father first launched Dilmah Tea in Australia and the enduring connection we have with Australians is linked to the opportunity they gave a small but passionate Sri Lankan business to grow. We celebrate this anniversary of our friendship as two nations united by a love for Ceylon Tea.” Peter Kuruvita, sharing his thoughts, said: “It is a great honour to be cooking this dinner, and amazing that we can support the youth in Sri Lanka with initiatives from both the Australian Government and Dilmah Tea. The Dilmah culinary school and the Supreme Chef competition have given these underprivileged kids the opportunity to become chefs and help improve their lives.”

title: President receives blessings from Malwathu, Asgiri Mahanayake Theras
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe called on the Chief Prelates of the Malwathu and Asgiri Chapters on Tuesday (29).  The President first visited the Malwathu Maha Vihara to meet Most Venerable Sri Sumangala Mahanayake Thera, engaging in a brief yet impactful conversation. President Wickremesinghe received blessings and the Theras chanted Seth Pirith and extended their blessings. The President also paid a visit to the Anunayake of the Malwathu Chapter, Most Venerable Dimbulkumbure Sri Vimaladhamma Thera, engaging in a concise and meaningful discussion. Subsequently, President Wickremesinghe proceeded to the Asgiri Maha Vihara, where he received blessings from the Asgiri Mahanayake Most Venerable Warakagoda Sri Gnanarathana Thera. Present at the occasion was also the custodian of the historical Muthiyangana Raja Maha Vihara, Dr. Venerable Muruddeniye Dhammaratana Thera Continuing his interactions, the President visited the Anunayake Theras of the Asgiri Chapter, Venerable Anamaduwe Dhammadassi Thera and Venerable Vedaruve Upali Anunayake Thera, engaging in insightful discussions. Former Minister Malik Samarawickrama and Additional Secretary to the President Kamal Pushpakumara were also in attendance.

title: President’s untiring efforts yielding results – Rangebandara
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara, on 29 August, said President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s untiring efforts have begun yielding results. “Countries that previously viewed Sri Lanka with scepticism have now shown a willingness to assist in addressing the ongoing economic crisis,” he said. He expressed confidence that President Wickremesinghe will get Sri Lanka’s economy back on track, drawing parallels with President J.R. Jayewardene’s efforts in revitalising the country during the 1980s after it faced financial challenges during the regime of Sirimavo Bandaranaike. He added that the President’s tenure can be considered a remarkable era of economic progress for the country, second only to President Jayewardene’s era. Rangebandara predicted that the country would experience significant development in various sectors, including agriculture, education, industry, irrigation, and foreign affairs. The UNP General Secretary said President Jayewardene’s transformative leadership and adept problem-solving skills were instrumental in changing course, addressing both political and economic issues. Rangebandara shared these views during a media briefing at Sirikotha. Further, he highlighted President Wickremesinghe’s successful negotiations of several bilateral agreements during his recent visit to Singapore. He attributed these achievements to effective foreign policies. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Four burglars arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The Crime Prevention Division of the Jaffna Police Division arrested a group of four individuals, who were involved in a series of burglaries targeting valuable items, such as gold jewellery over the past two weeks in Jaffna. As part of their preliminary inquiries, the Police recovered 30 sovereigns of gold jewellery that were in the possession of the suspects. According to the Police, these suspects primarily targeted residences around the midnight hours. The victims, who were asleep at the time, were also threatened with sharp weapons if they came awake. Over the course of the past two weeks, several complaints had been lodged at five Police stations in the Jaffna District. Consequently, a comprehensive manhunt was initiated by the Crime Prevention Division to locate and apprehend the suspects. Upon receiving a tip-off regarding the whereabouts of the suspects, Jaffna District Deputy Inspector General (DIG) Manjula Senarath directed a Police team from the Jaffna Police, led by Crime Branch Officer-in-Charge T. Menon, to conduct a raid. The charges the suspects face include, threatening individuals with sharp weapons and burglary. The police also seized a motorcycle, a sword, and four mobile phones that were in the possession of the suspects. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: No link to Colombo Port City – Commission
author: Author not found
Content: In response to recent media reports surrounding a robbery involving a Chinese national at a residence in Lake Drive, Borella, the Colombo Port City Economic Commission has issued a statement to address any misconceptions. The Commission vehemently denies any connections between the individuals involved in the incident and any affiliations, employment, or investments within the Colombo Port City. Any attempt to link this incident with activities within the Colombo Port City is entirely baseless and lacks substantiation, the Commission said in the statement, adding that the dissemination of unverified information can lead to unnecessary misrepresentation, which in turn could harm the reputation and credibility of the Colombo Port City project. “The Colombo Port City Economic Commission is proactively collaborating with relevant authorities to address any concerns and ensure the safety and security of all individuals associated with the Colombo Port City project. The Commission is committed to upholding the highest standards of safety and security within the project area. To obtain accurate and official information about the Colombo Port City project, the Commission encourages individuals to refer to its official communication channels and authorised representatives. This approach ensures that accurate details are conveyed and that any potential misinformation is minimised,” the Commission said.

title: Doctors warn of jaundice risk
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) warned that there were strong possibilities of Sri Lankan nationals contracting jaundice (yellow fever) while travelling abroad, due to the shortage of the yellow fever vaccine at the International Health Unit of the Health Ministry. MCPA President, Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa yesterday (29) said that according to international health regulations, locals travelling abroad – especially to countries where yellow fever was endemic– should take the vaccine. It was not long ago that the MCPA warned that the shortage of the meningococcal vaccines against meningitis could lead to an epidemic of the disease. He lamented that the health authorities had not paid much attention to the situation at the time when cases with brain fever had been detected from the Galle area. According to the international health regulations of the World Health Organisation (WHO), preventing yellow fever was an essential responsibility of every health system. An international project known as ‘Eliminating Yellow Fever Epidemic’ or EYE- 2026 was implemented. He noted that member countries of the WHO should abide by the project. According to EYE-2026 guidelines, three-pronged measures were to be taken in order to control the disease. They included identifying the risk groups of yellow fever, providing advice and treatment to prevent it for people who go out of the country and the immediate implementation of the health system to control the situation in cases of a yellow fever epidemic, the MCPA President noted. The Audit Report issued recently by the National Audit Office has pointed out the weaknesses of International Health Regulations and strategies followed by the Health Ministry. The report noted that efforts should be made to improve the international health system of the country according to latest trends Dr. Sanjeeva explained. He said a country’s health system was responsible to act according to international health regulations in order to prevent a spread of disease. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: USD 878,000 offered was not compensation– Lahandapura
author: Author not found
Content: Former Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) Chairperson, Dharshani Lahandapura alleged the USD 878,000 offered to Sri Lanka recently, over the MV X-Press Pearl disaster, was not compensation as claimed by Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. Rather, it was a reimbursement for the expenses incurred for beach cleaning by the MEPA, she claimed. She countered assertions that the funds were obtained during a trip to Singapore by a team led by the Attorney General, clarifying that this was simply a reimbursement from the Singaporean company for beach cleaning. Lahandapura told Ceylon Today that in accordance to the proposal put forth in 2022 to the Cabinet, she had communicated to P&I insurers that the compensation for beach cleaning payments should be made in USD, despite them saying they would settle the amount in LKR.  She also refuted claims that the funds were destined for the fishing community, clarifying that they were, in fact, intended to cover the costs that the MEPA had borne for the beach cleaning efforts. The owners of the X-press Pearl ship had committed to making these payments in installments and the installments are ongoing. Lahandapura emphasised that beach cleaning is an ongoing activity and highlighted that one payment covered the period from February 2022 to August, while the subsequent payment pertained to the period from August 2022 to February 2023. “There are instalments for the beach cleaning expenses, and this payment represents the third instalment, that had to reach MEPA but by then I left office,” she said. She revealed that the ship owners initially proposed compensating all dues in LKR, equivalent to USD, but she declined this arrangement. Instead, she pursued and secured a dollar settlement through a Cabinet paper. She also raised a question as to how did the P&I club settle Rs 16 million when the Cabinet paper clearly stipulated USD payments for all compensation and reimbursement from the vessel owners. She highlighted a delay in this payment of USD 878,000 as Sri Lanka Customs  prevented the ship owners from removing parts of the ship debris from Sri Lankan waters. In response, the ship owners had  refused to settle the beach cleaning payment. Subsequently, after being granted permission to tow away parts of the debris, the payment was eventually processed. The Justice Ministry said last week that this payment was designed to serve as compensation for the fishing community affected by the X-Pearl marine disaster. Minister Rajapakshe informed Parliament last week that the insurance company has agreed to extend this compensation despite the ongoing litigation in a Singapore Court, with no adverse impact on the legal proceedings. The insurers have decided to provide compensation within the framework of the case filed in the Commercial High Court in London, under the Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims. Minister Rajapakshe was unavailable for comment with regard to Lahandapura’s claim. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Disbursement of Aswesuma money begins
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe said disbursement of monies to the Aswesuma welfare beneficiaries, for the month of July, has commenced under a few phases. Many Aswesuma beneficiaries, who went to banks to withdraw their money had to go back empty handed yesterday (29), as the money had not been credited to their accounts. Addressing a media briefing, at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Semasinghe said disbursing Aswesuma installments for the month of July, has started for 1.5 million families out of two million, under several phases. Accordingly, under the first phase, nearly Rs 4.4 billion has already been credited to the bank accounts of 689,803 beneficiaries, the State Minister said. Payments for the rest of the beneficiaries will be disbursed from next week. He added warned that if anyone is found providing false information to obtain Aswesuma welfare, the Government will not hesitate to terminate those benefits. The State Minister said queries concerning fund matters can be directed to the hotline number 1924 on weekdays from 10 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Moreover, allowances for disabled individuals, the elderly and kidney patients have already been disbursed. By Mithun Jayawardhana

title: SL to import 92.1M eggs from India
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka will import 92.1 million eggs from India to control fluctuation in price and orders have been called from three Indian companies for three months, said Cabinet Spokesperson Bandula Gunawardena yesterday (29). Addressing the weekly Cabinet media briefing, Gunawardena said the State Trading Corporation had requested the Government to allow the import of eggs from India amid concerns over shortages and market fluctuations. “So, this move is a strategic measure to stabilise domestic egg prices,” he added. Gunawardena said quotations have been called from three Indian companies recommended by the Department of Animal Products and Health. Sri Lanka has been relying on eggs from India since March when the country faced significant egg shortages due to the forex crisis affecting the import of animal feed. In response to the crisis, a decision was made to import Indian eggs. In March, Sri Lanka imported two million eggs from India to ensure food security. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: State losing revenue due to unpaid taxes for 39 towers
author: Author not found
Content: A significant loss of revenue has been caused to the State due to unpaid taxes by companies for 39 telecommunication towers located in the Galle District, P.G. Anura, Land Commissioner for the Southern Province, revealed. The Land Commissioner made this revelation during the Galle District Coordinating Committee meeting held yesterday (29). This disclosure was made as Anura addressed a specific problem, related to a telecommunication tower in Niyagama that was presented to the Galle District Coordination Committee for resolution. The meeting took place at 9.00 a.m. in the Galle District Secretariat Auditorium, under the chairmanship of MP Sampath Athukorala. Anura highlighted that the Land Commissioner General is actively working to recover a significant amount of taxes that are owed to the State. These towers have been leased for 30 years. Committee Chairman Athukorala directed Galle District Secretary Shantha Weerasinghe to promptly request urgent intervention from the Land Commissioner General to address this issue. When queried, Committee Chairman Athukorala said that there are over two hundred telecommunication towers, subject to taxation, within the province. Through the involvement of the Land Commissioner, concerted efforts will be taken to recover the substantial tax revenue that has been lost, he added. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Appeal Court to consider Tharindu’s Revision Petition
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (29) decided to consider the Revision Petition filed by journalist Tharindu Jayawardhana, after he prayed the Court to invalidate an Order issued by the Colombo High Court, to reject his initial Petition to invalidate an Order issued to the CID, by the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court, to probe an alleged Contempt of Court charge, against him and a few others. The Court of Appeal Bench, comprising Justices Sampath B. Abeykoon and G. Kumararatnam, thus noticed the respondents concerned, to produce submissions in this regard, on 16 October. The petitioner has named the Director of the CID, The Director of the Computer Crimes Division of the CID, the OIC of the Cyber Crimes Intelligence Unit of the CID, Sub Inspector S. S. U. Subasinghe and AG Sanjay Rajaratnam, as respondents, while he has named Nathasha Edirisuriya and Bruno Divakara, as suspect respondents. PC Saliya Peiris represented the petitioner. Journalist Tharindu Jayawardene had filed an appeal before the Colombo High Court, praying for an order to invalidate the order issued to the Director of the CID and its Director of the Computer Crimes Division, by Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage, to probe whether Contempt of Court, had taken place via the issuance of certain remarks at a media conference. The petitioner, in his revision application, had informed the Court of Appeal, that Colombo High Court Judge W. P. S. Nissanka, had on 6 July deemed, his petition null and void, without noticing the respondents concerned. Accordingly, the petitioner, based on instructions from Attorney-at-Law Suren D. Perera and via his Counsel Manushika Cooray, had filed the revision petition before the Appellate Court, praying the latter to invalidate the twin orders issued by the High Court Judge and the Colombo Fort Magistrate, as they were replete with shortcomings and errors. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court of Appeal decided to consider the revision petition filed by the journalist concerned and thus noticed the respondents as well. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Compensation for crop damage limited to six types– Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Compensation for crop damage, arising from the ongoing drought, will be limited to only six types of crops, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. The Minister specified that damage to paddy, maize, chilli, potato, big onion and soybean crops are eligible for compensation at present. Amaraweera also expressed his willingness to explore the possibility of extending relief for damages to other types of crops if feasible. According to the Ministry of Agriculture, the amount of cultivated paddy lands, where crop damage has occurred due to the prevailing drought, has increased up to 58,000 acres as of last week. Also, the Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board has mentioned that the amount of crop damage of other crops is 424.70 acres and that of crop damage of paddy and other crops is 51,479.89 acres. The number of paddy farmers affected by crop damage is 45,678 and the number of farmers related to other crop damage was 394. The total number of farmers affected by damage to paddy and other crops is 46,072, the ministry said.

title: Domestic worker remanded over theft at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: A domestic worker, who allegedly stole a passenger’s luggage, with items worth Rs 581,000, including gold jewellery, from a flight arriving from Doha, Qatar, was apprehended by the Katunayake Airport Police and produced in Court. Both individuals had disembarked from Qatar Airways flight KR-664, which arrived at Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake on 16 August at 9.30 a.m. The complainant, a 38-year-old resident of Moratuwa, was returning to Sri Lanka from Qatar. He had come to the baggage clearance area of the arrival terminal to retrieve his luggage containing jewellery valued at around Rs 581,000 and other valuable items. Simultaneously, a 34-year-old domestic worker from Seruvavila, who had also arrived on the same flight, had allegedly taken the complainant’s luggage and fled the scene. This suspect had previously been prohibited from visiting five Gulf countries. Nonetheless, she had left for work in Qatar on 14 August. However, due to her deportation from Qatar, she arrived at Katunayake Airport on 16 August. Upon realising his luggage was missing, the passenger reported the incident to Katunayake Airport Police. After reviewing the airport’s security camera footage, the authorities identified the woman responsible for the theft. Subsequently, the woman was arrested on Monday (28), and the Police managed to recover the stolen luggage, but the jewellery was missing. Following extensive questioning, she surrendered pawn receipts for the jewellery to the Police. The woman was produced before the Negombo Magistrate’s Court on the same day and was remanded until 1 September. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Shared past will help us to build a common future – Dutch Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Dutch State Secretary for Culture and Media Gunay Uslu said Sri Lanka and the Netherlands have a shared past and it will help to build together a common future with close cooperation in the fields of museums, collection management, research and exchange of knowledge and expertise. She said this when she called on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the Temple Trees yesterday (29). On 28 August, the visiting Dutch Minister and Cultural Minister Vidura Wickramanayake signed a Transfer Acknowledge Agreement to transfer valuable artefacts taken from Sri Lanka during the Dutch rule 250 years ago. The objects include the famous cannon of freedom fighter Lewke Disawe, two gold kastanes (ceremonial sword), Sinhalese knives, silver kastane, and two guns. The Prime Minister thanked the visiting Minister Gunay Uslu for the transfer of artefacts and said the two countries should undertake collaboration on research on Dutch architecture, canal system, forts and other monuments for prosperity. Referring to the cannon of Lewke Disawe, the Prime Minister said that he was happy that Sri Lanka will get back this valuable treasure and told the Dutch delegation that Lewke was a place close to his home town Sithawaka and the entire country pay homage to the National Hero Lewke Disawa. Minister Gunay Uslu said a grant will be extended by the Netherlands to facilitate the work undertaken by the Ministry of Culture and the Department of National Museums to preserve the artefacts in a newly renovated chamber at the National Museum. She presented an ancient map of Ceylon by Baltus Jaquaez Van Lier drawn in 1751 to Prime Minister Gunawardena. Ambassador of Netherlands Bonnie Horbach, Director General, Culture and Media in the Netherlands Barbera Wolfensberger, Chairperson, Dutch Colonial Collections Committee Lilian Gonçalves-Ho Kang You and Committee Member Dr. Alicia Schrikker, MP Yadamini Gunawardena and Secretary to the Prime Minister Anura Dissanayake were also present on this occasion.
