title: S Koreans keen to invest in fisheries sector
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda met a group of South Korean investors yesterday (29) to discuss potential investments in Sri Lanka’s fisheries sector. The investors, led by South Korean businessman Kang, expressed their willingness to make ‘colossal ‘ investments in Sri Lanka’s fisheries sector. Minister Devananda said that he was confident that these investments would help to address the many challenges facing the local fisheries industry.  The investors and Minister Devananda discussed the possibility of investing in boat manufacturing, fish feed production and other fisheries-related businesses in Sri Lanka. Devananda also urged the investors to consider setting up a factory in the Eastern Province, near the Oluvil Fishery Harbour. Devananda said that the government is committed to supporting foreign investment in Sri Lanka’s fisheries sector. He said that the government is currently developing a programme to develop the Oluvil Fishery Harbour and that he has instructed officials to take necessary action to set up a factory in the vicinity of the harbour.  The South Korean investors expressed their enthusiasm to invest in Sri Lanka’s fisheries sector. They said that they are eager to start the project and that they are waiting for the approval and permission of Minister Devananda. Secretary to the Fisheries Ministry Indu Ratnayake and frontline officials from the Ministry and the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources were also present during the meeting. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SI involved in custodial death remanded
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court yesterday (29) remanded, until 11 September, a Sub-Inspector of the Welikada Police, who was involved in the custodial death of a housemaid named R. Rajakumari. The Sub-Inspector was arrested by the CID and produced before Court yesterday (29). Rajakumari, aged 41, a resident of Badulla, was arrested on 11 May, following a complaint lodged by her former employer Sudharma Nethicumara. Nethicumara had accused Rajakumari of theft, particularly of gold jewellery. Rajakumari passed away while in the custody of the Welikada Police and her relatives alleged that she had been assaulted in custody. On 25 August, Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawala instructed the CID to arrest the suspects involved in the housemaid’s untimely death. According to the post-mortem report, the cause of Rajkumari’s death was haemorrhagic shock resulting from damage to the deceased’s muscles, likely due to an attack involving a blunt weapon or similar force. The CID is conducting further investigations under the supervision of ASP Meryl Ranjan Lamahewa. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Cabinet nod to streamline visa procedure
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet has given its nod to streamline the current visa procedures of the Immigration and Emigration Department. Under the Immigration and Emigration Act No. 20 of 1948, along with the associated regulations, the Department of Immigration and Emigration currently issues three categories of visas – visit visa, resident visa, and transit visa. Recognising the intricacies involved in processing visas, particularly in the visit and resident visa categories, steps have been initiated to evaluate and enhance the existing visa methodology.  This evaluation takes into account the approaches to visas adopted by countries that have effectively attracted a substantial number of foreign visitors. As a result of this review, the Cabinet of Ministers has approved a proposal put forward by the Minister of Public Security, to simplify and improve the visa procedures currently in place within the country.

title: Illicit gem miningon Norwood Estate wreaks havoc
author: Author not found
Content: Plantation workers at Norwood Estate staged a strike yesterday (29) citing safety concerns over the large pits, dug to mine gems, that have been found amidst tea bushes in certain sections of the estate. The estate workers alleged that a group of individuals involved in illicit gem mining, had dug large pits beneath the tea bushes on both sides of the road leading to the Norwood Public Cemetery and crematorium. They extracted soil rich in gems from the area. The workers stressed that unauthorised miners had encroached upon the fertile tea land, resulting in some tea bushes being uprooted. Plantation workers raised concerns and said that if the Norwood Police did not take appropriate action to curtail illicit gem mining within the estate, they would continue with their strike. In response, the estate authorities filed several complaints with the Norwood Police regarding illicit gem mining taking place in the lower NC section of  Norwood Estate. Inspector S.B. Koholdeniya of the Norwood Police along with a team of officers engaged in discussions with the plantation workers who were on strike. During the discussion, Police assured that measures would be taken to put an end to illicit gem mining and to apprehend those involved. Following the discussions,  workers ended the strike. BY Neeta Pathmakumari – Norwood

title: Pathirana exposes bogus liquor security sticker racket
author: Author not found
Content: SJB Parliamentarian Buddhika Pathirana revealed a racket involving counterfeit stickers on numerous liquor bottles across various districts in the country. These fraudulent security labels were uncovered in over 100 wine stores in districts including Jaffna, Galle, Nuwara Eliya and Ratnapura during raids that were conducted. Pathirana brought these findings to light in Parliament last week, while posing oral inquiries to State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya. The parliamentarian also raised concerns about the involvement of certain high-ranking officials from the Excise Department in the operation of affixing fake security stickers to liquor bottles. He said there was a need to hold an impartial investigation to expose the individuals responsible for this activity and put an end to the scandal. He pointed out that the source of these bogus stickers was traced to a residence in Kochchikade, which is owned by a current Director of the Excise Department. Additionally, he highlighted previous incidents involving bribery allegations against two officials implicated in this case, which took place 19 years ago. In response to these revelations, Siyambalapitiya assured that the Government would initiate an independent investigation into the reported incidents. He underscored that anyone found guilty, regardless of their political stature, would face appropriate legal action. Siyambalapitiya further said that fixing security labels on liquor bottles had contributed to a considerable increase of Rs 19 billion in annual excise revenue, as proposed in the 2016 Budget. This initiative had also led to an 11 per cent rise in alcohol production. Despite these gains, the Government acknowledges the existence of such fraudulent schemes and is taking measures to address them. The plan involves conducting sample tests with the assistance of the Government Analyst and conducting investigations with assistance of the CID. In the light of these developments, he has instructed the Excise Commissioner General to intensify efforts to identify and curb the practice of placing counterfeit security labels on liquor bottles. Subsequent raids have led to the closure of numerous wine stores involved in the illegal operation with liquor stocks being confiscated. Meanwhile, a recent crackdown on liquor bottles bearing counterfeit security stickers comes in response to a directive from Parliament’s Ways and Means Committee. The committee had previously noted that despite being equipped with 200 machines capable of verifying the authenticity of security stickers, the Excise Department had not conducted any raids to confiscate liquor bottles suspected of carrying fake stickers since March. The initiative to implement security stickers on liquor bottles was initially proposed in the 2016 Budget. Subsequently, in 2017, tenders were solicited, and the contract to produce stickers was awarded to Madras Security Printers in 2018.

title: HC Moragoda visits Bhubaneswar MBSI
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda, who was on a three-day official visit to the State of Odisha last week, visited the Bhubaneswar Centre of the Maha Bodhi Society of India (MBSI). At the Maha Bodhi Centre, Moragoda, his wife Jennifer and the delegation were ceremonially welcomed by the boy scouts and girl guides of the MBSI school, which is managed by the Maha Bodhi Society of India. Following the ceremonial welcome, the High Commissioner paid obeisance at the shrine room and the Bodhi tree at the Centre. Three Sri Lankan Buddhist monks, who are resident at the Centre, chanted seth pirith and blessed the High Commissioner and his delegation. After the religious rites, Moragoda met the management and the teachers of the MBSI School. The meeting was presided over by the President of the MBSI Bhubaneswar Committee, Narendra Mishra. Committee’s Vice President and MBSI Governing Board member Namrata Chadha also spoke. The MBSI school has more than 1,800 students and education is free of charge for half of them. The rest pay a nominal fee. The Maha Bodhi Society of India is running the school targeting the students from economically weaker and underprivileged sections of the society. Founded in 1891 in Colombo, by Bodhisattva Anagarika Dharmapala, with the objective of restoring the holy Buddhist sites in India, the Maha Bodhi Society, from its inception, has acted as a representative of the worldwide Buddhist community and provided a platform for the Buddhist World to voice its opinions. The Maha Bodhi Society of India is widely engaged in charitable and social welfare activities alongside spiritual services through its various centres across India. High Commissioner Moragoda was accompanied by Minister of the High Commission of Sri Lanka in New Delhi Upul Pushpakumara and Minister Counsellor Gamini Sarath Godakanda.

title: Renowned Agriculturist Dr. C.R. Panabokke passes away
author: Author not found
Content: Vidya Jyothi Deshamanya Dr. C.R. Panabokke, a distinguished figure in the field of agriculture and a former Chancellor of the Sabaragamuwa University, has passed away. Dr. Panabokke, known for his exceptional dedication to the agricultural sector, breathed his last, leaving behind a trail of achievements that have enriched the nation’s agricultural landscape. As a former Director of Agriculture and an influential academic leader, he played a vital role in shaping the educational and developmental aspects of agriculture in the country. He was also a loving family man and the husband of the late Seemanthani and father of the late Aruni, Renuka and Himadri. His remains will be placed at his residence, located at No. 439/8 Sudharshana Mawatha, Nawala, on Wednesday, 30 August. On Thursday, 31 August, his remains will be transferred to ‘The Respect’, Jayaratne Funeral Parlour, Bauddhaloka Mawatha,​ Colombo 08, for the public to pay their respects. The final rites, a cremation, will take place on Thursday at 5:00 p.m. at the General Cemetery, Borella.

title: CBCSL concerned over socio-economic situ in the country
author: Author not found
Content: The Catholic Bishops’ Conference of Sri Lanka (CBCSL) has expressed its deep concern regarding the socio-economic and political situation of Sri Lanka and its impact on the lives of the people. A letter signed by the President and the General Secretary of the CBCSL, Rev. Dr. Harold Anthony Perera (Bishop of Kurunegala) and Rev. Dr. D. Anthony Jayakody (Auxiliary Bishop of Colombo) stated yesterday (29) that many parents find it difficult to provide their children with meals.  Many families with difficulty have only one meal a day. There is no control of prices of essential goods while many people were on the brink of starvation, they lamented. “The immediate need should be to promote agriculture and other local production to sustain the people,” the Rev. Doctors said. They observed that it is shocking to hear that many food items, including rice, eggs, palm oil were still being imported to the country. These are products which could be produced locally, if incentives were given to local farmers, they observed. Many hospitals are not in a position to care for people’s health needs while there is a severe shortage of medicines, Rev. Drs. Anthony and Jayakody noted. “We are troubled by the increasing number of qualified medical practitioners leaving the country while government hospitals are inadequately supplied with medicines and other medical equipment,” they said adding that many people- particularly the poor, could not attend to their medical needs, as often as a result. The Kurunegala Bishop and the Auxiliary Bishop of Colombo lamented that education too had also been jeopardised by children attending school without proper nourishment, clothing and the stationery as required.  Parents too were not in a position to attend to these basic needs. There is a serious break-down of law and order, they alleged noting that this was seen in the increasing violence in the country. “Murders take place almost on a daily basis while the number of fatal road accidents due to drunken and reckless driving was also on the rise,” they observed. Besides, there seems to be no clear vision to resolve the immediate basic needs of the people, the CBCSL President and General Secretary noted. “In this dire situation, we, the members of the CBCSL earnestly appeal to those in authority to consider the plight of the people seriously before their rhetoric and enactment of political drama, so that the poor and the marginalised could at least sustain their lives whilst providing their basic needs. “Sri Lanka is a blessed country and its citizenry talented, and its youth, educated and keen to be participants in its progress. Therefore, we need to create a society where each one’s dignity is valued and appreciated, and peace, harmony and the true manifestation of democracy such as the independence of the Judiciary and the participation of people in the political life of the nation is safeguarded through the holding of free and fair elections. We appeal to our political leadership to be the instruments of such a political and social renewal and the safeguarding of the dignity and rights of all components of our society. We call upon all our Catholic faithful to pray and work actively for a social transformation of our society in this manner,” CBCSL said.

title: Oman repatriates 32 stranded Lankan workers
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Muscat, Oman, in collaboration with the Omani Foreign Ministry and the Department of Immigration of the Royal Oman Police, successfully facilitated the repatriation of 32 stranded migrant workers on 17 August 2023.  These migrants had entered Oman on visit/tourist visas with the anticipation of finding jobs and subsequently overstayed their visas without securing proper employment.  The issue of migrant workers arriving on visit/tourist visas and then overstaying due to lack of viable employment has been a challenge faced by many potential workers. From November 2022 to date the Sri Lanka Embassy in Oman has facilitated repatriation of more than 400 stranded migrants with support extended by the Omani authorities. The Sri Lanka Embassy in Oman identified the group of 32 stranded illegal migrants and their situation was individually assessed to understand their circumstances and requirements.  The Embassy engaged with the respective Government stakeholders in Oman to obtain visa overstay penalty waiver for the said group along with the necessary documentation and travel arrangements for repatriation. Throughout the repatriation process, the stranded workers were provided with essential humanitarian support, including medical assistance, accommodation, and access to basic necessities by the Sri Lanka Embassy in Oman.  The Oman Sri Lanka Social Club and many well-wishers supported the Embassy during this process. The Embassy said it strongly advises Sri Lankans not to arrive on visit/tourist visa without confirmed jobs, since many male and female workers are continuing to fall victim to human traffickers and end up in the streets under harsh weather conditions.  Hence, the Embassy requested all Sri Lankans to seek jobs only through licensed agencies and register with the SLBFE before arriving in Oman.

title: SOCH queries Health Ministry’s failure
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee on Health (SOCH) has called for an explanation, from the Health Ministry, as to why it had been unable to implement the eight-month suspension, given to Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) Dr. Ruhul Haq. Ceylon Today learns that the Committee, Chaired by former Health Minister Dr. Rajitha Senaratne, had met on Monday (28) afternoon during which the issue, with regard to the sluggish manner in which the Health Ministry had worked towards implementing an eight-month suspension, given to a Medical Practitioner serving at the Colombo Chief JMO’s office, starting from 20 December 2022, had been taken up. Accordingly, Health Ministry Representative, Director Tertiary Care Unit, Dr. Priyantha Atapattu had been unable to provide any plausible explanation as to why the Health Ministry had been unable to take active measures to enforce the SLMC suspension, informed sources alleged. “Dr. Atapattu had been beating around the bush, instead of providing the required details as to why the Health Ministry had failed to implement the temporary suspension,” they claimed. According to sources, the suspension had been implemented only a week prior to the date it was to end (20 August 2023). By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Re-issuance of bonds under DDO rescheduled
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe announced yesterday (28) the re-issuance of bonds under the domestic debt optimisation (DDO) programme, initially planned for yesterday, has been rescheduled to 11 September. This change in the timeline is a result of an ongoing Court procedure relating to the Amendment of the Inland Revenue Act. Originally, there was a plan to re-issue Government Bonds at an interest rate of 9 per cent under the domestic debt optimisation programme, with the process intended to commence today. Concurrently, concerns have emerged regarding the potential impact of this decision on the Employee’s Provident Fund (EPF). Meanwhile, the Supreme Court has concluded the hearing of Petitions, filed against the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Draft Bill. As a result, the Supreme Court has communicated that its decision will be relayed to the Speaker of Parliament. The Petitions were filed by several including Chaturanga Abeysinghe, a Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) member. This Bill, which is aimed at amending the Inland Revenue Act, No. 24 of 2017, was ordered to be published in the Government Gazette by the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies. The Bill was drafted based on the Cabinet’s approval to facilitate the local debt restructuring process. The effective date is 1 April 2023 (subject to the enactment of the Bill). When the fund prepares accounts, based on an alternative period of 12 months, for the computation of income tax payable for the year of assessment, commencing on 1 April 2023, the income tax rate would be applied considering such alternate period of 12 months.

title: Catholic Church still to respond to invitations – Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: Although several invitations have been extended to the Catholic Church, for discussions, as they have stated that they were not satisfied with the investigations into the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, the Catholic Church has not responded to those invitations up to now, Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles said yesterday (28). Addressing a media briefing, at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Minister Alles said the CID has concluded about 99 per cent of the investigations into the terror attack. “But, the Catholic Church and the Catholic community have always been holding press conferences and saying that this has not been done properly. The other thing is that the reports were given to the Catholic Church because they had not given the report prepared by the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) into the attack for several years. I spoke to the President about it and provided the report to the Catholic Church,” he said.  Speaking further, the minister said, during the process of submitting these reports and even prior to that, he communicated to the Catholic Church that it was his intention to offer an opportunity for them to provide an explanation regarding the ongoing Police investigation. Despite the request for an opportunity to present their views, the Catholic Church has not conveyed its stance on this matter. “I urged them to thoroughly review all the facts presented to the bishops and other members of the Catholic Church. If they find any gaps or omissions in these facts, I encouraged them to bring it to light. I proposed a collaborative effort to address this. Unfortunately, the Catholic Church hasn’t taken the chance to engage in this discussion up to this point. Instead, different parties with varied agendas continue to perpetuate this issue.  I have consistently maintained that if the Catholic Church and its community genuinely seek to uncover the perpetrators and the sequence of events, they should join hands with us to comprehensively analyse this investigation,” Minister Alles said.  It’s important to acknowledge that there might be shortcomings in certain areas. Identifying these gaps is crucial. However, I am uncertain if the Catholic community possesses such a desire. To date, the Catholic Church hasn’t afforded us the opportunity to discuss this matter. The reason behind this remains unclear, he added. Moreover, the minister said that the Cardinal was the first to mention the mastermind behind these attacks. “Following that, the former Attorney General, on the day before his retirement, said that there was a mastermind. Upon being called to inquire further, he evaded. Subsequently, he pursued legal action and obtained a restraining order. If he had knowledge about the mastermind in question, he could have shared pertinent information. After the former AG avoided discussing this matter, the Cardinal’s statements regarding the mastermind also ceased.  My point is that there is a need for a comprehensive investigation, as the narratives being circulated are not necessarily accurate. That’s why I’ve extended an open invitation to delve into this matter,” he said.  He said that it should be found who was behind the attacks. However, it seems to me that most of the people are questioning the Police officers, asking where certain Police officers were and what they did,” he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Protest against Govt decision on EPF, ETF
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held yesterday (28) in front of the Fort Railway Station, Colombo, to voice objection against the actions of the Government. The protest was held to object to the Government’s decision to recast the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) and Employees’ Trust Fund (ETF) as part of its Domestic Debt Restructuring process for economic recovery. Earlier yesterday (28), the Fort Magistrate’s Court issued an order preventing the protesters, including trade unionists and politicians, from entering several parts of Colombo during the protest.  Accordingly, representatives including Duminda Nagamuwa, Mujibur Rahuman, Prof. Charitha Herath and others were barred from entering several areas in Colombo such as premises of the Presidential Secretariat, President’s House, Finance Ministry and the Central Bank (CBSL).

title: Dasa sil matha remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Minuwangoda Chief Magistrate T. Thenabadu, yesterday (28) remanded, till 11 September, the Chief Dasa Sil Matha of the Sri Sambuddha Jayanthi Pirivena in Boragodawatta, Minuwangoda when she had been produced in Court, charged with threatening, intimidation and assault of three young girls and a woman, who had been staying at the Pirivena with the hope of becoming Dasa Sil Mathas. The three girls are aged 12, 15 and 18, while the woman who was allegedly assaulted is aged 34. The Chief Dasa Sil Matha of the Pirivena was identified as Palapathwela Padma Sil Meniyo. It was revealed in Court that the three young girls and the woman, who had resided at the said Pirivena, had fled the place being unable to put up with the alleged inhuman treatment by the Chief Dasa Sil Matha and upon them being located by Nuwara Eliya Police, they been handed over to the Minuwangoda Police. The four had then provided statements before the Minuwangoda Chief Magistrate, regarding the ordeal they had experienced at the hands of their tormentor. The Court then instructed the Minuwangoda Police, to produce the complainants before the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) of the Gampaha District Hospital and furnish his report at the next hearing. BY Tony K. Athukorala – Minuwangoda

title: Gangsters involved in shootings swiftly arrested – Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: The recent shootings involved clashes between underworld gangs, and Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles stated yesterday (28) that the Police managed to apprehend most of the individuals responsible for these incidents. During a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Minister Alles highlighted that the swift arrests of the gang members, involved in the shootings, in Kudawella and Keselwatte, within a few days serve as the best evidence of this. The minister underscored that if underworld figures believe they can commit a shooting and evade capture, they must recognise that they will be apprehended regardless of their location in the country. He stressed, “Presently, there have been several reports of clashes among different underworld gangs, resulting in fatal shootings.  These gangs engage in inter-group violence. Preventive measures have already been implemented to quell these activities by underworld factions. The security forces have also been given directives to use force if necessary. As a responsible government, any actions that endangers the lives of citizens will not be tolerated.” “At present, the Police is operating with a non-political agenda, providing all necessary resources. Considering it has been around a year since the current government assumed office, not all goals can be achieved within such a short time frame. Nevertheless, the Police Department has accomplished a substantial amount of work.  The force currently comprises approximately 85,000 officers. “Furthermore, the ministry has designed a specialiSed programme to combat the drug issue prevalent in the country. The southern region has witnessed a consistent increase in underworld activities. In response, the STF, the Police and other security units have collaboratively initiated targeted operations in these areas. This concerted effort has managed to curb underworld activities to a certain extent in the Southern province,” he concluded. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Nagamuwa dodging CID’s call to give statement
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles, stated yesterday (28) that Duminda Nagamuwa, of the Frontline Socialist Party, is untraceable, despite repeated requests from the CID for him to provide a statement regarding his claim about a joint ‘investment done by Minister Alles and the JVP’. Speaking at a media briefing, held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Minister Alles said, “Nagamuwa alleged that the JVP and I invested money together. In response to this allegation, I took the necessary steps. I filed a complaint with the CID and provided a statement. However, now that Nagamuwa has been asked to give a statement, he is nowhere to be found. It appears he is avoiding this. If the FSP possesses any evidence, they are welcome to present it to the CID.” Speaking further, the minister said FSP Education Secretary Pubudu Jagoda said in a television talk show that what FSP meant was they had suspicions about a possible political deal between him and the JVP.  “We had a political deal together since 2010. It was in 2010 that I, JVP, General Sarath Fonseka, Arjuna Ranatunga, formed a party and were elected to parliament together. At that time Jagoda and Nagamuwa too were with the JVP. They were at my office during the whole election time because we worked together for the election in 2010,” the minister said.  (MD)

title: Amaraweera orders probe into hazardous pesticides
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera has directed Ministry Secretary Gunadasa Samarasinghe, to investigate the use of internationally prohibited Highly Hazardous Pesticides (HHP) in Sri Lanka and provide a report. The Minister’s decision came in response to the statement from the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ), which revealed that around 40 HHPs, including insecticides and herbicides banned internationally, are being utilised within the country. The Ministry of Agriculture emphasises that the sale, distribution, or usage of pesticides, prohibited by the government is strictly forbidden. Any individual found in violation of this regulation will face action from the Pesticides Registrar Secretariat, the ministry said. Forty (40) out of 139 permitted pesticides in Sri Lanka, under the Gazette Extraordinary No. 1994/71 on 24 November 2016, have been found as Highly Hazardous Pesticides (HHPs), a report released by the CEJ revealed recently. This is with reference to the Pesticide Action Network (PAN) International consolidated list of banned pesticides, 6th Edition in May 2022. Accordingly, 14 out of those 40 HHPs, have been recommended for domestic use in Sri Lanka. Speaking at a media briefing on 23 August, CEJ Senior Adviser Hemantha Withanage said according to global research the HHPs are linked to cancers, tumours, nervous system disorders, reproductive problems, immune system effects as well as endocrine system disruption. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Travel ban on three directors lifted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya temporarily lifted the overseas travel ban clamped on three Directors of the Western Hospital, Borella, till 9 January next year. Their passports had earlier been impounded by Court, in connection with an alleged kidney racket. Court had previously impounded the passports of six Directors of the said Hospital, in connection with the case, while the passports of three of the Directors namely Mohammad Rezvi Sheriff, Fathima Sheriff and Ameena Sheriff were released. The Additional Magistrate gave this order having perused a request made to this effect by the lawyers for the three suspect Directors. She thus advised the Court Registrar, to convey her decision to the Controller General of the Department of Immigration and Emigration. The three other Directors of the Hospital, whose passports have been impounded, are Mohammad Rinaz Sheriff, Omar Sheriff and Amitha Kasturiarachchi. The Court had previously imposed a foreign travel ban on the three aforementioned Hospital Directors, after considering submissions produced by the CCD, who stated that if the suspects were to leave the country, it could impact negatively on the ongoing probe into the case and hence sought to have their passports impounded. The CCD prosecuting had previously informed Magistrate Jayasuriya, that kidneys obtained from low income families had been handed over to the Hospital concerned, via a couple residing in Colombo 13 and had been sold to wealthy locals and foreigners, for prices ranging from 12 to 15 million rupees. The prosecution had added that following wide publicity, being given to the said incident, by the media, a spate of complaints had been received by the Borella Police regarding the kidney racket and that accordingly the SDIG of the Western Province, had transferred the probe into the case, to the CCD. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Sri Lanka, Thailand expect to sign FTA early next year
author: Author not found
Content: Thailand and Sri Lanka expect to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) in early 2024, as the two parties aim for three more rounds of talks this year to conclude negotiations, according to the Chief of Thailand’s Trade Negotiations Department.  Auramon Supthaweethum, Director-General of the department, speaking at the sixth round of negotiations for the Thailand-Sri Lanka FTA, held from 21-23 Aug in Bangkok, said the talks have advanced beyond the halfway point.  Both sides aim to conclude negotiations in 2023, paving the way for the trade ministers of both countries to sign the agreement early next year, she said. The sixth round comprised the trade negotiating committee overseeing overall progress and seven technical working groups covering trade in goods, rules of origin, trade in services, investment, technical barriers to trade, trade remedies, and legal issues. “We are more than halfway there, and both sides plan to hold three more rounds of negotiations in October, November and December to conclude all matters,” said Auramon. “Then both sides will proceed with internal processes to raise awareness among the public and relevant stakeholders, presenting the negotiation outcomes for the consideration and approval of their respective Cabinets for approval.” She said studies determined that despite Sri Lanka’s small size and population of only 22 million, it has an important geographic position in the Indian Ocean, making it a hub for maritime transport. It also possesses abundant natural resources such as precious minerals and seafood.  A Thailand-Sri Lanka FTA is projected to expand the Thai economy by 0.02%, equivalent to USD 80 million. This includes the expansion of investments and the value of Thai exports to Sri Lanka. The potential beneficiaries of this agreement include automobiles and auto components, machinery, electrical appliances, metals, sugar and plastics, according to the department. Industries in which Thailand could expand its investments in Sri Lanka include processed foods, beverages, textiles, garments and jewellery. (Bangkok Post)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Bribery case against SLPP MP deferred
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe, yesterday (28) deferred further hearing of the bribery case against SLPP MP Milan Jayathilaka, to 7 November. Jayathilaka, a former Chairman of the Dompe PS and its member Ajith Sisira Kumara, have been accused before the High Court by Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), of having sought a bribe to the tune of Rs 700,000, to facilitate a license towards the operation of a metal quarry, 11 years ago.  When the case was called, the two accused were present in Court. Judge Marasinghe, noticed the witnesses to the prosecution to be present before him, at the next hearing, to provide testimony in the trial. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Police officer found dead with gunshot injuries
author: Author not found
Content: A Police sergeant, who was on duty at the official residence of the District Judge on Beach Road in Matara, was found dead, with gunshot injuries, yesterday morning (28), according to the Matara Headquarters Police. Preliminary investigations revealed that the deceased had phoned his home yesterday (28) morning and asked whether his child had gone to school. He had also requested to prepare two lunch packets for him and his fellow officer, who had been deployed at the District Judge’s residence. His fellow officer had gone to the Headquarters Police to sign his duty report and the shooting had been taken place at that time, the Police said. The deceased, Bandula Pushpa Kumara (55), was a Police sergeant from Talpawila, Kekunadura. He leaves behind one child. The Police further said that the officer’s duty firearm, a T 56  and two discharged bullets from that weapon were discovered close to the main road near the location where the officer was shot. However, a senior Police officer stated that two teams have been appointed to determine whether this incident is a case of suicide or a murder. BY Udaya Kumara Ranaweera – Matara

title: MCPA seeks UNHRC intervention in State health service crisis
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) has taken the grievances, assailing the State Health Service, to the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) in Geneva calling for its intervention to arrest the current crisis affecting the State health service.  President MCPA, Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa yesterday (28) lamented that a considerable sum of money has been wasted during the last two years due to the poor health administration and management. Human lives have been lost as a result the corruption, fraud and irregularities in the State health system. Submitting a letter to the UNHRC, he alleged that Sri Lanka had failed to take legal action, despite the findings of the Committee On Public  Enterprises (COPE), the Auditor General’s Reports  and the documents submitted to the Commission To Investigate Allegations Of Bribery Or Corruption. He explained that tax payers’ money was being wasted and pilfered due to the creation of drug shortages resulting emergency purchasing and the questionable procurement process. The fraud with regard to antibiotics, lenses, Insulin, Oxygen Tender Transactions, and the setting up of the Medical Supply Information System, were only some of the fraudulent transactions that have taken place, The MCPA President alleged.  He mentioned that he is going to present facts regarding a large number of questionable transactions. Since, a considerable number of human lives have already been lost due to the purchase of substandard drugs, he pointed out that the Chairman of the National Drug Regulatory Authority (NMRA) himself admitted that human lives were lost as a result of substandard drugs being used in Sri Lanka. In its letter, the MCPA informed the UNHRC that it was regrettable that the President of the country and the law enforcement agencies had not investigated the shortage of drugs and the damage caused by substandard drugs for about a year and a half. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Protest against Govt decision on EPF, ETF
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held yesterday (28) in front of the Fort Railway Station, Colombo, to voice objection against the actions of the Government. The protest was held to object to the Government’s decision to recast the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) and Employees’ Trust Fund (ETF) as part of its Domestic Debt Restructuring process for economic recovery. Earlier yesterday (28), the Fort Magistrate’s Court issued an order preventing the protesters, including trade unionists and politicians, from entering several parts of Colombo during the protest.  Accordingly, representatives including Duminda Nagamuwa, Mujibur Rahuman, Prof. Charitha Herath and others were barred from entering several areas in Colombo such as premises of the Presidential Secretariat, President’s House, Finance Ministry and the Central Bank (CBSL).

title: Discussion between Minister Chandrakanthan, IGP
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion regarding the measures to be taken to curb the misconduct in the Batticaloa District due to organised criminal gangs was held between Chairman of the Batticaloa District Development Committee, State Minister of Rural Road Development Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan and IGP C.D. Wickramaratne at Police Headquarters. During the discussion, the State Minister requested the IGP to take necessary measures to set up a special Police point in the area to combat large-scale timber smuggling and illicit liquor production in the Mailattamadu reserve in Batticaloa District. The IGP also requested the State Minister to encourage the Tamil youth in the Eastern Province to join the Police service and inspire them to serve their people. A group including SDIG Ajith Rohana participated in this discussion.

title: JMO issues open verdict on death of infant
author: Author not found
Content: The possible cause of death of an 8-month-old infant from Thalapitiya, Galle, who passed away after being admitted for cold, fever and sudden respiratory failure, is suspected to be meningococcus bacteria, Chandrasena Lokuge, Coroner of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital said.  This bacterium is responsible for the recent deaths of two inmates at the Galle Prison. Lokuge made this statement following the autopsy. However, the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) Dr. U.G.B. Jayaratne, who conducted the post-mortem, issued an open verdict. The body parts will be sent to the Medical Research Institute and the Government Analyst to determine the cause of death. However, the Coroner has advised that the baby’s last rites should be conducted promptly. He also urged family members or contacts to seek immediate medical attention if they experience any symptoms. The baby’s name is Fathima Neama and she hailed from Talapitiya, Galle. When questions were raised about the situation, the Medical Officer of Health, Dr. Lasanta Obeysekera confirmed that measures are being taken to provide treatment to the family and contacts of the deceased. It was reported on 21 August that two inmates in Galle Prison lost their lives and several others were admitted to hospital due to an illness of unspecified origin. The Health Ministry later revealed that preliminary investigations link the fatalities and hospitalisations of Galle Prison inmates to meningococcal disease — an uncommon yet serious ailment caused by the meningococcus bacteria. Meanwhile, Epidemiology Chief Dr. Samitha Ginige reassured the public there is no necessity for the public to entertain undue fear of the disease. Dr. Ginige said last week that the Meningococcal infection caused by the Neisseria meningitides which causes meningitis was not an infection that was unknown and that annually there were a few isolated cases reported in Sri Lanka. BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle and S. Deeyagahage – Ahangama

title: 800,000 persons to get ‘Aswesuma’ benefits today
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe said ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefits for July will be disbursed to banks today (28) by the Welfare Benefits Board. Taking to ‘X,’ formally known as Twitter, to share this update, the State Minister said among the 1.5 million selected beneficiaries, funds will be transferred to the accounts of 800,000 beneficiaries whose information has been verified. He highlighted that after swift verification procedures, payments will subsequently be extended to the remaining beneficiaries. Semasinghe further said the ongoing process of reviewing appeals and objections is underway, and once this is concluded, payments will be expedited to all eligible beneficiaries. Additionally, the State Minister emphasised the Government’s commitment to upholding fairness and accountability. He warned that strong action will be taken against those who have provided false information to receive benefits. The Welfare Benefits Board will not only reclaim wrongly obtained funds but also pursue legal action, where necessary. He assured that the Government is dedicated to ensuring that every eligible citizen receives their rightful benefits, reiterating the commitment to inclusivity and equitable distribution.

title: Kandy Govt schools closed on 28, 29, 31 Aug
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the traffic congestion expected during the Kandy Esala Perahera, all State schools within the Kandy town limits will be closed for three days, Central Province Governor Lalith U. Gamage said. According to the Governor, these schools will remain closed on 28, 29 and 31 August. This measure is to minimise disruption caused by the increase in traffic and festivities associated with the Kandy Esala Perahera, Gamage said. To compensate for the temporary closure, classes will be held on Saturdays. This  ensures that educational activities are not compromised during the closure, the Governor added. Schools situated between Kandy City and Katugastota Bridge, Peradeniya Bridge and Gannoruwa Junction, Kandy City and Ampitiya via Lake round, the stretch between Kandy City and Thennekumbura Bridge and  Dodamwala Royal Primary School, Bowalawatta, Hanthana will be closed as per the decision.

title: Dayasiri seeks Parliamentary recognition
author: Author not found
Content: In a letter to Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, MP Dayasiri Jayasekara appealed for the official recognition of the MPs’ Forum for Economic Justice as a formal Parliamentary entity. Jayasekara highlighted the urgency of addressing the economic crisis that the people of Sri Lanka are presently facing and emphasised the need for equitable solutions. “To tackle this challenge, a collective effort is required, transcending party affiliations. With this goal in mind, we decided to initiate a non-partisan MPs’ forum dedicated to economic justice.” Expressing the forum’s aspirations, Jayasekara requested the Speaker’s assistance in bestowing formal recognition on this novel initiative. The forum brings together a diverse representation of MPs spanning various political parties, including the SLFP, SLPP, SJB, and the group led by MP Dullas Alahapperuma, he said. Meanwhile, a meeting with regard to this initiative was held in Colombo last week and around 45 MPs were in attendance, Jayasekara added. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Anura Kumara challenges FSP to prove allegation
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the allegation levelled by the Front Line Socialist Party (FSP), that the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) has invested in an European island, JVP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake challenged the FSP to prove the allegation. Dissanayake said the gravity of the situation was that the allegation wasn’t merely a simple accusation but a potentially complex political attack with broader implications. Dissanayake highlighted that the allegations seemed to be driven by a need to associate the JVP with corrupt practices, much like the other major political parties, in an attempt to undermine the JVP’s reputation. He said proving or disproving the accusation hinged on specific actions and processes. “They (FSP) can take legal action against us, or they can go to the CID if they have any evidence to support their allegation. If they can’t do that then they can disclose all the information they have to the public. If they can’t do any of these, it means what they said was a blatant lie. So they should apologise. They should acknowledge their mistake and retract the accusation,” the JVP Leader said. Dissanayake implied that failing to provide concrete evidence or take appropriate action would indicate that the accusations were baseless and politically motivated. BY Anuradha Herath

title: Criminal law to punish those involved in pyramid schemes
author: Author not found
Content: Those who engage in pyramid schemes will be dealt with under criminal law, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. Speaking to the media in Dehiowita, Siyambalapitiya said the Government plans to take strong action against both individuals and institutions involved in pyramid schemes. He stressed that pyramid schemes are not legitimate businesses; rather, they constitute criminal activities. As a result, those engaging in pyramid schemes will face penalties under criminal law. “Despite the Central Bank’s prohibition of such illegal schemes under the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988, these actions will now be subject to criminal law enforcement. Thus, the Attorney General’s Department will be informed, complaints will be lodged with the Police and the CID, and legal cases will be pursued against these deceitful entities and their so-called leaders,” he stressed. Speaking further, Siyambalapitiya said numerous people are falling victim to these fraudulent practices, despite the Central Bank’s warnings against seeking short-term gains from such schemes. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Namal proposes opening two Banks
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa has put forward a proposal to establish two Banks through a public-private partnership. Addressing the SLPP ‘Bala Mandala’ meeting held in Borella on Sunday (27), Rajapaksa introduced the concept of creating both an investment Bank and a development Bank operating under public and private collaboration. Rajapaksa said these Banks ownership could be shared between the Government and private sector. This is to cater to the diverse needs of businesses, ranging from large corporations to small and medium enterprises, adapting to the evolving global landscape. The development Bank, as envisioned, would offer both short-term and long-term loans. On the other hand, the investment Bank would serve as a platform to aid Sri Lankan entrepreneurs seeking to expand their ventures overseas, he said.

title: Bhutan cuts daily tourist fee by half to lure more visitors
author: Author not found
Content: The Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan is to halve the USD 200 daily fee it charges tourists in an effort to boost a sector still struggling to recover a year after the end of Covid-19 restrictions. Bhutan raised its ‘Sustainable Development Fee’ to USD 200 per visitor per night, from USD 65, when it ended two years of Covid restrictions in September last year saying the money would go to offset the carbon generated by visitors. The new rate of USD 100 per night would come into effect from September and last for four years, the government said in a statement on 25 August. “This is in view of the important role of the tourism sector in generating employment, earning foreign exchange and boosting overall economic growth,” it said. Isolated for generations, Bhutan opened to tourists in 1974 when it received 300 visitors. The number soared to 315,600 in 2019, up 15.1% from a year earlier, official data showed. Bhutan has always been wary of the impact of mass tourism and it bans mountain climbing to preserve the sanctity of its peaks. The tourist fee has limited arrivals to bigger spenders who make up a fraction of the numbers that visit nearby Nepal. Nevertheless, Bhutan hopes to raise the contribution of tourism to its USD 3 billion economy 20%, from about 5%. Dorji Dhradhul, director general of the Department of Tourism, said halving the tourist fee could boost arrivals in the September-December peak tourist period, which includes many religious and cultural events in the mainly Buddhist country. In June, the government eased rules on the length of stay and fees for tourists but numbers have not picked up as expected. Dhradhul said more than 56,000 tourists had visited Bhutan since January but about 42,000 were Indian nationals, who only have to pay a fee of 1,200 Indian rupees (USD 14.5) a day. About 50,000 Bhutanese are employed in tourism which earned about $84 million a year in the three years before the pandemic in foreign exchange. (CNN)

title: Veddas offer Bees’ Honey to Sacred Tooth Relic
author: Author not found
Content: The annual offering of bees’ honey to the sacred tooth relic, by Vedda tribe was conducted on 26 August. This bee honey offering is traditionally done on the day of the first Randoli Perahera of the Kandy Esala Perahera. Since the days of ancient kings, the Adivasi community annually offers the first raw bee honey harvest to the sacred tooth relic.  A group of about 65 Veddas participated in this occasion, including their Leader Uruwarige Wannila Aththa. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: National Project Management Excellence Awards 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The National Project Management Excellence Awards 2023, an event focused on evaluating National level projects that were undertaken before 2023 was held in grand style at Kingsbury Hotel Colombo on 16 August. The event was organised by the PMI Sri Lanka Chapter. Over 250 professionals participated, representing 35 leading organisations to receive 40 awards. The ceremony was graced by international representatives from the USA, Poland, and India. The grand winner was Orel IT Pvt Ltd while the Registrar of Companies received the government sector overall gold award. Everything is in place to hold the regional conference and the Awards 2024 in May next year, said President of PMI Sri Lanka Chapter Saman Kandanearachchi and Executive Vice President Dhammike Mendis.

title: Maj Gen Guneratna CG at ARFROMC-23
author: Author not found
Content: Defence Ministry Secretary General Kamal Gunaratne was the Chief Guest at the ‘Masterminds Competition-2023’, which was organised by the ‘Association of Retired Flag Rank Officers’ (ARFRO) at the Golden Rose Hotel in Boralesgamuwa on 26 August. The incumbent President of the ARFRO Air Chief Marshal Gagan Bulathsinghala (Retd) warmly received the Defence Secretary on his arrival at the venue. In keeping with the schedule, 86 (3-member) teams, comprising Tri-Forces officers, competed in the Competition-2023’ (ARFROMC-2023) which was conducted in several stages. The Chief Guest, Gen. Gunaratne, stated that this year’s competition focuses on the middle manager category of the military. He also stressed that, “Real victory lies in the pursuit of knowledge and the bonds we forge along the way. “I encourage you to approach these questions not just as a test of knowledge, but as an opportunity to learn, collaborate, and grow togethe.” During the session, 60 teams from the Army, 20 from the Navy, five representing the Air Force and a team from the KDU, competed in the competition which was designed to improve their general knowledge on military affairs, social issues, current global trends and the practice of reading at leisure. After the session, Gen. Gunaratne presented medals, trophies and cash prizes to the winners. Accordingly, the Regimental Headquarters Team of the Gajaba Regiment, earning the highest number of points won the champions cash prize worth of Rs 100,000. A Navy team representing the South Eastern Naval Command finished first  runner-up while the Army’s Signal Corps was the 2nd Runner-up. They received Rs 60,000 and 40,000 respectively. ARFRO in Sri Lanka came into being in 1996, as an organisation of senior retired military officers, who are collectively referred to as ‘Flag Rank Officers’. Flag Rank officers, who have held senior positions in Tri-Forces, with wealth of experience and expertise in military affairs, will no doubt be of great value to the military generation grooming to take up future challenges. Navy Commander Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, members of the ARFRO Executive Committee, Head of the Steering Committee members Maj. Gen. Upul Perera (Retd), Steering Committee members of the ARFROMC-2023 and senior military officers were present among the distinguished invitees.

title: Tamil grievances overlooked – Rasamanickam
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil ArasuKachchi (ITAK) Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam expressed his frustration yesterday (27), lamenting that all  appeals for President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s involvement to resolve the pressing political and economic issues faced by the Tamil people seem to have fallen on deaf ears. During a public event in Batticaloa, Rasamanickam alleged that they have persistently presented their pleas and requests both in Parliament and in meetings with the President. Regrettably, these efforts have yielded no response thus far, raising doubts about the peaceful coexistence and future of the Tamil people. Rasamanickam further conveyed that despite their efforts to bring attention to the injustices and discriminations occurring during District Development Committee meetings, no action has been taken to address these concerns by the political authorities. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Asia’s poor grew by 68M people after pandemic – Report
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 70 million more people lived in extreme poverty in developing Asian countries last year due to the Covid-19 pandemic and rising living costs, a Philippines-based development Bank  said. More than 155 million people suffered from extreme poverty in developing Asia in 2022, 67.8 million more than if the pandemic had not occurred, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) said in a report. The ADB estimated in 2021 that an extra 75-80 million people had been pushed into extreme poverty in the region during the previous year, compared with pre-pandemic estimates. Extreme poverty is defined, by the World Bank, as living on less than USD 2.15 a day, based on 2017 prices and adjusted for inflation. Despite expectations of continued progress in reducing poverty, an estimated 30.3 per cent of the region’s population – some 1.26 billion people – are expected to be living on USD 3.65 – USD 6.85 a day by 2030, the ADB said. The Manila-based development bank recommended that governments in developing Asia – which covers 46 economies across the region – strengthen social welfare, improve access to financial services, invest in infrastructure and support technological innovation, among other remedies. “Asia and the Pacific is steadily recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic, but the increased cost-of-living crisis is undermining progress toward eliminating poverty,” ADB Chief Economist Albert Park said. “By strengthening social safety nets for the poor and fostering investment and innovation that creates opportunities for growth and employment, governments in the region can get back on track.” (Al Jazeera)
