title: Asia’s poor grew by 68M people after pandemic – Report
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 70 million more people lived in extreme poverty in developing Asian countries last year due to the Covid-19 pandemic and rising living costs, a Philippines-based development Bank  said. More than 155 million people suffered from extreme poverty in developing Asia in 2022, 67.8 million more than if the pandemic had not occurred, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) said in a report. The ADB estimated in 2021 that an extra 75-80 million people had been pushed into extreme poverty in the region during the previous year, compared with pre-pandemic estimates. Extreme poverty is defined, by the World Bank, as living on less than USD 2.15 a day, based on 2017 prices and adjusted for inflation. Despite expectations of continued progress in reducing poverty, an estimated 30.3 per cent of the region’s population – some 1.26 billion people – are expected to be living on USD 3.65 – USD 6.85 a day by 2030, the ADB said. The Manila-based development bank recommended that governments in developing Asia – which covers 46 economies across the region – strengthen social welfare, improve access to financial services, invest in infrastructure and support technological innovation, among other remedies. “Asia and the Pacific is steadily recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic, but the increased cost-of-living crisis is undermining progress toward eliminating poverty,” ADB Chief Economist Albert Park said. “By strengthening social safety nets for the poor and fostering investment and innovation that creates opportunities for growth and employment, governments in the region can get back on track.” (Al Jazeera)

title: Kotelawala Defence University inaugurates it Hall of Fame
author: Author not found
Content: The General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University (KDU) proudly inaugurated its Hall of Fame, a distinguished platform aimed at honouring exceptional KDU alumni, who have made significant contributions to both military and civilian public service. This initiative draws inspiration from the remarkable achievements of inductees, in times of conflict and peace, motivating current and future generations of KDU affiliates to build upon the legacy established by these eminent personalities. On 25 August, KDU welcomed Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, an esteemed alumnus, into the Hall of Fame. Notably, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, a member of Intake VI, holds the distinction of being the inaugural KDU graduate to receive this recognition as the 19th Commander of the Sri Lanka Air Force. The ceremony, marked by solemnity, saw the unveiling of his portfolio within the university’s Hall of Fame. The event commenced with a floral tribute, as Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa paid his respects at the War Heroes’ Monument, which is a testament to the courageous KDU alumni from the Tri-Forces, who made the ultimate sacrifice for the nation. Following this commemorative gesture, the Commander revisited his military alma mater, KDU, engaging in a productive meeting with the Vice Chancellor, Major General Milinda Peiris. This interaction culminated in the exchange of commemorative plaques, signifying the significance of the occasion. During his visit, Air Marshal Rajapaksa delivered an inspiring address to the esteemed military and civil undergraduates of KDU, sharing insights into the challenges he encountered on his journey and personal traits to be inculcated for a sound personality. His motivational speech deeply resonated with the attending military undergraduates. The Commander also undertook an inspection of the Aeronautical Department, exploring avenues for its further development. The visit culminated with Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa leaving his mark in the Visitors’ Book, thus immortalising his presence at the revered Kotelawala Defence University. This remarkable event saw the presence of senior military and academic staff, providing an exceptionally inspirational experience for all military undergraduates who were in attendance.

title: Pre-fabricated terminal to minimise congestion at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Presently, passenger arrivals and departures have reached nearly 25,000, causing severe congestion at the BIA in Katunayake, authorities said. Construction of the second terminal to resolve the issue has been implemented while Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Pvt.) Limited (AASL) has decided to install a pre-fabricated terminal as an immediate measure. Authorities say it can be completed within six months. AASL is expected to spend about Rs 15 billion on the project. The pre-fabricated terminal will be utilised for domestic flight operations after the second terminal at BIA is completed. Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva conducted a special inspection visit at the construction site on 23 August. AASL Chairman, Major General (Rtd) G.A. Chandrasiri and several other officials were also in attendance. Expressing his views at a function held at the airport, the Minister said: “A large number of passengers are expected to call at the BIA in the near future. We are ready to fully facilitate them with practical solutions utilising our available resources. An increased number of flights have been planned at the Jaffna International Airport in Palaly and Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport in Hambantota. To cater to passengers arriving and departing from BIA, the installation of the pre-fabricated terminal is scheduled to be completed within six months with the investments of funds by AASL.”

title: Cinnamon Group warns of a job scam
author: Author not found
Content: The Cinnamon Group, based in Malaysia, has issued a cautionary statement regarding a fraudulent scheme, taking place in Colombo that involves an individual falsely posing as an affiliate of Cinnamon Group and offering unauthorised employment opportunities in different countries while collecting money from unsuspecting individuals. In a statement, the Cinnamon Group clarified that this person has no connection whatsoever with their organisation or any of its subsidiaries. Abbi Kanthasamy, CEO of Cinnamon Group, expressed deep concern over these unauthorised actions and misleading claims of affiliation. “We uphold the highest standards of professionalism and integrity,” Kanthasamy stated, “and we are taking immediate measures to address this situation.” Accordingly, a formal Police report has been filed in Colombo through local contacts. Also, internal teams are working diligently to identify the person responsible for these fraudulent activities. “If approached by this individual, report the encounter to local law enforcement immediately. Exercise caution when receiving unsolicited employment offers claiming to be from Cinnamon Group. Verify any employment opportunities directly through the official website (www.cinnamon-group.com) or authorised personnel,” the statement read.

title: Formal training for pre-school teachers vital – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe, underscored the Government’s commitment to enhance early childhood development through formal training for pre-school teachers. These remarks were shared by Kumarasinghe at a press conference held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC). Kumarasinghe emphasised the Government’s multifaceted approach, which encompasses not only providing salaries for pre-school teachers but also prioritising child health. Recognising the pivotal role of pre-schools in shaping children’s initial mental state, she stressed the importance of subjecting pre-school operations to specific regulations. Acknowledging the general lack of attention towards early childhood development, Kumarasinghe highlighted the Government’s decision to institute formal training for pre-school teachers. Drawing inspiration from countries such as Japan and Switzerland, she advocated to elevate the training standards of pre-school educators. To achieve this, she proposed to send pre-school teachers for training in these countries, thereby equipping them with advanced skills. Additionally, she spoke of the need to establish pre-schools within a legal framework, with teachers ideally holding graduate qualifications and undergoing specialised training. She noted the presence of teaching assistants in some pre-schools and expressed the Government’s intention to provide them with proper training and compensation through collaboration with the Ministry of Education. Kumarasinghe emphasised the importance of cultivating the right mindset among teachers and the positive impact on early childhood development. Her insights underscore the Government’s efforts to uplift the quality of pre-school education and subsequently, contribute to the holistic development of children. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Media has crucial, unbiased role to play in shaping society
author: Author not found
Content: “The media has a crucial and unbiased role to play in shaping society. Therefore, media personnel should possess comprehensive knowledge across various fields. They ought to consistently engage in reading and remain eager to learn about new developments and occurrences in contemporary society. Only then can they effectively guide the general public. Given that people repose their trust and faith in journalists more than anyone else, these professionals should equip themselves to uphold this position and confront any challenges that may arise,” Major General Vipula Chandrasiri, General Officer Commanding 24 Infantry Division, in Malwatte, Ampara said. He expressed these sentiments while addressing journalists at the Annual General Meeting of the Ampara District Journalists Forum. He commended the journalists for their dedicated contributions to the media during a ceremony held at the Auditorium of the AIMS International School. The meeting, chaired by Forum President Kalapoosanam M.A. Phakurdeen, was attended by Professor Rameez Abdullah of the South Eastern University of Sri Lanka and Former Chief Editor of Thinakaran,K. Kuanarasa, as special guests. As the Chief Guest, Major General Chandrasiri said journalists’ reports and stories must consistently maintain accuracy, given that readers rely on them. Simultaneously, he encouraged them to actively work towards fostering communal harmony, social integration, mutual understanding, and intercommunal accord. He advised against compromising their balance and impartiality merely for personal gain. Prof. Rameez Abdullah and Former Chief Editor Thinakaran K. Kuanarasa addressed media personnel on media ethics, outlining instances of irresponsible behaviour by certain social media platforms without fully comprehending their impacts. In recognition of their exceptional contributions to the media, Chief Guests and Special Guests were presented with mementos as tokens of appreciation. Members of the Ampara District Journalists Forum were also honored with mementos as a tribute to their devoted services to the media, marking the conclusion of the ceremony.

title: Govt has not received any foreign Intel – Premitha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, yesterday (24), assured that the Government has not been informed by any foreign intelligence service about national security concerns, or racial tensions within the country. Tennakoon made this remark in response to a question raised by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa in Parliament. Tennakoon emphasised that the Government cannot continually react to unfounded rumours and comments circulating on platforms like Facebook regarding these matters. However, the State Minister highlighted that the country’s intelligence agencies have noticed certain groups in specific regions, supported by political elements, attempting to stir up racial tensions. He affirmed that the Government and security forces are actively monitoring these groups and their activities. Premadasa raised concerns in Parliament about recent intelligence reports warning of religious and communal violence in Sri Lanka in the future. Premadasa pointed out that both local and foreign media have reported on the warning issued by several Intelligence Services. “As per the media reports, different intelligence services have warned of religious and communal outbreaks of violence and bomb attacks in Sri Lanka. This is a scary situation,” he said. Premadasa emphasised that such incidents reported in the media were a threat to national security. He requested the government to call for an urgent meeting of all political parties and notify them and the Parliament of the accuracy of the reports and their credibility. “Due to the security confusion created in this country with the Easter attack, the government and the parliament should pay attention to this sensitive matter and I also request that all parties and responsible parties be informed in this regard,” he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Nabiya Vaffoor

title: ‘Waayaama’ launched in memory of Mangala
author: Author not found
Content: Waayaama (Relentless Effort) written by the acclaimed author, Sujith Akkarawaththa, was launched yesterday (24), at the auditorium of the Lakshman Kadiragamar Institute Colombo 07, to coincide with the second death anniversary of veteran politician Mangala Samaraweera. The event was attended by Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles, former Speaker of Parliament Karu Jayasuriya, MP Premnath Dolawatte, former Minister Ravi Karunanayake, relatives, friends and fans of Samaraweera. The book is a composition of writings inspired by the conversations the author has had with the late Mangala Samaraweera, on a spectrum of topics varying from history to religion and politics, which originally had been published in the e-newspaper of The Leader.    Delivering speeches at the event Prof. R.H.S. Samaratunga and Dr. Mahesh Hapugoda highlighted the need to foster the late Mangala Samaraweera’s philosophy of liberty, equality and compassion for each other.  The author, Akkarawaththa, said in his speech, that Samaraweera had been an exceptional figure in the local political arena for his broad knowledge on various subjects and the visionary plan for a better society. Also, Samaraweera was repeatedly introduced, by the speakers, as the breeze that carried the scent of ‘Western Freedom’ to Sri Lanka. Pix by Sarath Kumara By Induwara Athapattu

title: Dutch delegation to visit SL next week
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation from the Netherlands, led by Gunay Uslu, the State Secretary for Culture and Media, is set to visit Sri Lanka from 27 to 31 August to finalise the legal arrangements for the transfer of ownership of cultural artefacts that will be returned to Sri Lanka later this year. Among the items to be returned are several significant pieces, including the renowned Lewke’s cannon, two ceremonial Gold kastanes (swords), traditional Sinhalese knives, a Silver kastane, and two historic guns. During the visit, the State Secretary is expected to hold meetings with senior officials from the Sri Lankan Government, marking a momentous occasion in the cultural exchange between the two countries. The official signing of the ownership transfer agreement is scheduled to take place on Monday, 28 August, at the Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs of Sri Lanka. In addition to the formal proceedings, the delegation will also take the opportunity to explore various sites of religious and Dutch historical significance across Sri Lanka, the Dutch Embassy in Sri Lanka said in a statement. BY Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Laptop containing CCTV footage of killing at NIMH vanishes
author: Author not found
Content: The lawyers representing the patient, who was allegedly murdered while being treated at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH), Angoda, told Colombo Additional Magistrate Tharanga Mahawatta, yesterday the laptop containing the CCTV footage, which captured the said incident, had disappeared. The deceased was alleged to have been murdered by a group of minor employees attached to the NIMH, while receiving treatment. The lawyers stated that they suspect, the disclosure of details pertaining to the disappearance of the laptop, could well be a well-coordinated attempt, made to bury evidence related to the case. They also alleged that some of the Court Productions, connected to the case, including CCTV footage which had been seized, had so far not been produced in Court, by the Mulleriyawa Police. The lawyers told the Additional Magistrate, that at dawn on the day of the incident, the employees of the NIMH, had assaulted their client, causing injuries to him and that till 10.00 p.m., he had not been administered any treatment by the Hospital. They mentioned that at the time of the incident, besides the arrested suspects, another group of workers of the Hospital had also been present at the scene of the crime and they urged the Court, to issue an order to the Police, for their arrest. Taking the submissions produced by the lawyers appearing on behalf of the aggrieved party and the Police, Magistrate Mahawatta, instructed the Police to further probe the incident and file a progress report at the next hearing. She also ordered the four suspects, arrested in connection with the incident, to be further remanded, till 7 September. Mulleriyawa Police and Nugegoda Crimes Division, prosecuting told the Court, that the relatives of the deceased had lodged a complaint with them, that the demise of their relative, who was being treated at the NIMH, was suspicious. They stated that following the post mortem conducted by the JMO, it had been revealed that the victim had died, following a haemorrhage. Police told the Court, that following inspection of CCTV camera footages installed at the Hospital, it had come to light, that a certain group had assaulted the deceased and that following detailed inquiries conducted, they had nabbed the four suspects. The prosecution added that the victim had received treatment regularly from the NIMH, for a psychosocial disability and that following his condition having aggravated, he had proceeded to receive in-house treatment. The incident had occurred in the morning of 25 July and it has also been alleged that the suspects had proceeded to assault him to death, after he had sprayed water on them. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Kanchana assures forensic audit into fuel distribution scam
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera, announced in Parliament yesterday (24) that a forensic audit will be conducted regarding the fuel distribution scandal that occurred in 2022. Minister Wijesekera responding to MP Thushara Indunil Amarasena, who said that the illicit activity had involved duplicate invoices, said to meticulously uncover the details, a forensic audit will be conducted by local experts from KPMG Ltd. MP Amarasena highlighted that a significant amount of refined fuel had gone missing during the import process last year. He also raised concerns about the unloading of fuel from 500 fuel tankers at a non-designated storage location. Furthermore, he alleged that three officials from the CPC, who were allegedly involved in the scam, had been promoted. In response, the Minister affirmed that all pertinent information regarding the incident will be disclosed through the forensic audit. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Seven dead turtles wash ashore
author: Author not found
Content: Muthurajawela Wildlife and Conservation Officer Tennyson Priyawardene said that seven dead turtles with scratch marks on their bodies had been washed ashore at the Sarakku Kanda and Nadungoda beaches in Pamunugama. He stated that according to initial inquiries they believe that the turtles may have died following some sort of an explosion on the sea bed or having crashed into rocks. According to Priyawardene the deceased turtles could be at least 100 years old and he noted that illegal use of equipment by fishermen at deep seas could have contributed to the deaths of these turtles. He added that following the post mortem tests, the precise cause of deaths could be determined. BY Prasanga Pavuluhewa – Ja-Ela

title: PSM strike forces patients to seek private lab services
author: Author not found
Content: Patients seeking treatment from State hospitals were compelled to turn to private laboratory services and pharmacies when professions supplementary to medicines struck work yesterday (24).  Acting Deputy Director General Medical Services –II, Dr. G. Wijeysuriya, said that testing and issuing medicines had proved a big issue but that steps had been taken to direct patients to pharmacies and lab facilities close to hospitals. He noted that the Government footed the bill for the expenses incurred in the private sector during the strike yesterday (24). Meanwhile, patients being treated in State Hospitals faced severe inconveniences due to the token strike. While some patients kept away from the pharmacy counters in certain State Hospitals, there were also a sizeable number of patients, who had come for laboratory tests, faced with the dilemma of how to have their tests carried out. Meanwhile, Co-Convener Joint Council of the Joint Council of Professions Supplementary to Medicine (JCPSM) Chanaka Dharmawickrama said that discussions held with the Health Secretary had been successful. However, the issue was their implementations owing to the machinations of those officials under him. He noted that his outfit would give the Health Secretary and his officials seven days to implement the demands that have been made before taking further action. The JCPSM struck work making seven demands, including expediting the recruitment procedure, delays in the issuance of the circular related to grade promotion issues, the decision taken by the Health Ministry to stop new recruitments and the suppression of trade unions by taking unfair disciplinary measures against the leaders. Dharmawickrama noted there were several trade union leaders who were being unfairly penalised by the Health Ministry. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: New Polpitiya – Hambantota transmission line connected to National Grid
author: Author not found
Content: The newly completed Polpitiya – Hambantota 220kV transmission line has now been successfully integrated into the national grid, following the conclusion of its initial tasks, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) said in a statement. Additionally, the recently established grid substation in Hambantota was energised yesterday (24). Financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the initiative received a USD 55 million investment aimed at enhancing the Polpitiya-Hambantota 220kV transmission line and constructing the new Hambantota grid substation. As stated by the CEB, this transmission line, stretching 150km, spans across 11 Divisional Secretariats from Ambagamuwa to Hambantota, boasting a line capacity of 580MVA. The Hambantota new grid substation has been finalised, featuring two power transformers with a combined capacity of 500MVA. This enhancement to the transmission network substantially reinforces the southern sector of the electricity grid. Consequently, the reliability of power supply and the capacity for power transfer to and from the Southern region are significantly improved, the CEB said. Earlier this month, the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) effectively mediated a resolution to a dispute involving the CEB and landowners in the Siripagama area of Ratnapura. This dispute centered around a portion of the transmission line connecting the national grid with the Southern Province, which traverses the aforementioned land. Initially, private assessors recommended a compensation of Rs 41 million for the land utilised in constructing a 630-meter segment of the transmission line. Following the criteria of the Asian Development Fund of the ADB, this figure was later revised to Rs 9.6 million. However, the CEB only agreed to offer Rs 1.69 million as compensation. With the intervention of the PUCSL, the matter was resolved. The landowners demonstrated their dedication to ensuring uninterrupted electricity supply for the public by consenting to donate the land to the government without any compensation. This development cleared the path for commencing the construction of the transmission line. The agreed-upon terms encompassed the installation of the electric cable through the private land, maintaining a minimum height requirement of 20m and adhering to regulations regarding condition and continuity.

title: SL spent USD 320M to launch Supreme SAT – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa claimed that India had spent only USD 263 million for the launch of the whole Chandrayaan project, while Sri Lanka had spent USD 320 million for the launch of Supreme SAT satellite in 2012. Addressing Parliament, Premadasa noted that India had successfully launched Chandrayaan-3 in 2023 after two earlier attempts by Chandrayaan-1 in 2008 and Chandrayaan-2 in 2019. He stated that for all three attempts, only USD 263 million had been spent. Premadasa urged the government to submit a report to Parliament regarding the massive expenditure on SupremeSAT and the success of the project in which Rohitha Rajapaksa, the youngest son of former Premier Mahinda Rajapaksa played a key role in the launch which is a Sri Lanka-China joint venture. “We, as a country, have gone backward after the satellite launch in Sri Lanka instead of landing on the moon,” he said. Leader of the House Susil Premajayantha said he was the Minister of Science, Technology and Research from 2015 to 2018 and that he was unaware of such a satellite being launched in Sri Lanka. Meanwhile, Premadasa congratulated the Indian Government on the successful landing of Chandrayaan 3 on the moon. Chandrayaan 3, launched on 14 July, completed its journey and reached the South Pole of the Moon, making India the only country to achieve such a successful landing so far. Premadasa also congratulated the Indian Government for initiating and succeeding in such a project. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: No need to import rice as existing reserves enough – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera emphasised that the need for rice imports is redundant due to the substantial existing rice reserves, which are capable of sustaining the upcoming Maha season. The Minister highlighted the success of the previous season, attributing it to the prompt distribution of essential fertiliser varieties to farmers, coupled with financial benefits. Robust yields in regions unaffected by drought further bolstered the season’s prosperity. Speaking at an expert gathering, hosted by the President’s Trade Union Relations Division, at the Presidential Secretariat, on the topic of ‘Modernisation of the Agro-Industrial Sector and its Challenges,’ Amaraweera provided an in-depth insight into the agricultural landscape. He shared his views on the necessity of enhancing the agro-industrial sector to tackle contemporary challenges. These perspectives underscore the Ministry’s commitment to optimising the agricultural landscape while reaffirming the nation’s capacity to fulfill its rice requirements through strong domestic resources. Amaraweera elaborated, “At the beginning of President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s tenure, a crucial objective was to enhance farmers’ involvement in agricultural activities, redirecting their focus from protests. This initiative was launched during a cultivation preparation phase. Despite aiming to cultivate 275,000 hectares, the scarcity of fertilisers posed a significant hindrance. While some were criticised for causing unwarranted panic, even the international community anticipated potential food shortages. “Through determined efforts, we succeeded in motivating farmers to return to their fields. This commitment led to the cultivation of 512,000 hectares during the Yala season. “Additionally, around 800,000 hectares were cultivated during the Maha season. In that specific year, our country imported 800,000 metric tons of rice. Nonetheless, the looming possibility of rice imports this year presents a substantial challenge, exacerbated by India’s ongoing embargo on rice exports.”

title: Customs destroys 63,000 fake items
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Customs destroyed nearly 63,000 fake items, worth Rs 88 million, on Wednesday (23). Among the counterfeits were oil filters, data cables and phone chargers, all falsely bearing the names of well-known international brands. According to a statement by Sri Lanka Customs, this act was conducted with a commitment to upholding Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) and enhancing business trust. The Director General of Customs, P. B. S. C. Nonis, supported by Additional Director General Asoka Ranjith and Senior Director M. S. J. De Silva, oversaw the the destruction. “The confiscated items included things like electronics, household stuff, trendy items, and car parts. The goal of destroying these goods is to stop fake products from spreading. These fakes harm real businesses and could be risky for people who use them. This move also reminds people to be careful when buying things. Especially online, it’s important to buy from real businesses that care about safety and quality,” the statement said. Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) are things like patents, trademarks, copyrights, and trade secrets. Fake goods hurt the economy, brand names, and can even be bad for people. It’s important to protect these rights so that new ideas can grow, and things can be fair for everyone. Customs help by stopping fake goods from coming into the market. Sri Lanka Customs has a special group called the ‘Consumer Protection Unit’. This group makes sure consumers are safe. They catch and take fake things based on information they find. Customs officials can do all of this because of the law and rules about intellectual property. They also follow agreements with other countries to do this job well, the statement said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Health system on verge of collapse – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa raised concerns about the availability of the meningococcal vaccine, which he claimed, hasn’t been in stock in the country for the past 12 months, and this scarcity remains unresolved even to this day. Premadasa made these statements yesterday (23,) during his response to questions under Standing Order 27 (2) in Parliament. He highlighted the potential collapse of the health system due to mismanagement of human resources. The departure of doctors without notice, reluctance of specialist doctors who study abroad to return, and the unwillingness of new doctors to work for the Ministry of Health were contributing to a shortage of medical professionals in the country. Premadasa warned that this shortage, including a dearth of specialists was jeopardising the quality of healthcare in Sri Lanka. Premadasa emphasised the need for the Government to implement a programme that provides satisfactory working conditions for doctors. He criticised the Government for not responding effectively to the brain drain issue that was highlighted months ago, leading to the departure of many healthcare professionals. He stated that the Ministry of Health took action only after the situation had escalated, and such problems could have been prevented if the Government had acted proactively. To address the shortage of doctors, Premadasa proposed alternative methods to produce high-quality medical professionals without compromising free education. He emphasised the importance of safeguarding free education. Premadasa also questioned the Ministry of Health’s alleged failure to obtain a vaccine recommended by the World Health Organization for infection control in the Galle prison. He pointed out that if the Health Minister or other top officials in the health sector are unable to answer simple questions posed under Standing Orders, it reflects poorly on the Government’s competence. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Dr. Jaishankar addresses India-SL Parliamentary Friendship Association
author: Author not found
Content: An interaction was held on 23 August at the Parliament of Sri Lanka between High Commissioner of India Gopal Baglay, members of the India-Sri Lanka Parliamentary Friendship Association and leaders of various political parties. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena convened the meeting, which was attended by more than 50 MPs. External Affairs Minister of India (EAM) Dr. S. Jaishankar addressed the gathering via video link. In his remarks, the Speaker reiterated the long-standing bilateral relations between India and Sri Lanka and emphasised the role played by the India-Sri Lanka Parliamentary Friendship Association as a vital platform for nurturing dialogue and cooperation between the legislative bodies of the two countries. The Indian High Commissioner, in his remarks, recalled the recent visit of President Ranil Wickremesinghe to India and reiterated the central role of connectivity in bringing greater economic prosperity to the two nations. In his remarks, Secretary of the India-Sri Lanka Parliamentary Friendship Association, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa appreciated India’s assistance to Sri Lanka and called for greater Parliamentary exchanges between the two nations. The Indian EAM, in his address, delved into India’s positive contributions to Sri Lanka’s development, stability, and prosperity based on geographical proximity and shared democratic values between the two countries. He highlighted the swift and substantial response by India to the economic challenges faced by Sri Lanka over the past year, exemplifying India’s commitment to the ‘Neighbourhood First’ policy. Dr. Jaishankar emphasised that the financial assistance of approximately USD 4 billion extended by India was unprecedented in both magnitude and swiftness, surpassing the response of international institutions and bilateral partners. He elaborated on India’s vision of fostering long-term and sustainable solutions, mentioning collaborative efforts to address Sri Lanka’s energy requirements through grid connectivity and a Petroleum, Oil, and Lubricants (POL) pipeline. Further, he highlighted the potential of renewable energy and regional economic activities, including the Trincomalee hub, for mutual benefit. Dr. Jaishankar emphasised that the key to a prosperous future between the two countries lies in enhanced connectivity in various domains, such as maritime, air, energy, trade, investment, and digital ties. Referencing the recent visit of President Ranil Wickremesinghe to India, he highlighted that the talks between the two Leaders reinforced the commitment to enhancing trade, investment, and people-to-people connectivity, exemplifying the shared vision of collaboration. On regional security, the EAM reiterated India’s ‘Security and Growth for All in the Region’ (SAGAR) outlook and its expression through forums such as the Colombo Security Conclave, the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) and BIMSTEC.  Dr. Jaishankar also reiterated India’s support for the preservation of Sri Lanka’s multi-ethnic, multi-lingual, and multi-religious identity. He expressed hope for a reconciliation process that addresses the aspirations of the Tamil community for equality, justice and self-respect within the framework of a united and prosperous Sri Lanka. He highlighted a meaningful devolution of power according to the 13th Amendment to the Constitution and early conduct of Provincial Council Elections as being facilitative towards this objective. The address by the Indian EAM served as a reminder of the enduring friendship between India and Sri Lanka and reinvigorated the commitment to strengthening ties for the mutual benefit of both nations and the broader region.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SLPA’s Mahapola Ports & Maritime Academy expands training
author: Author not found
Content: The Mahapola Ports & Maritime Academy (MPMA), a part of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA), has launched a programme to provide expanded educational opportunities for young individuals. This initiative has been set in motion under the guidance and instructions of Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. The effort aligns with the Government’s decision to direct the youth of Sri Lanka towards the burgeoning employment prospects within the swiftly advancing port and maritime sectors, driven by modern technology. Set up in 1987 by the late Lalith Athulathmudali, who served as the Minister of Ports and Shipping, the Mahapola Ports & Maritime Academy has evolved into a globally recognised institution for higher education under SLPA. Over the years, the institution has been dedicated to imparting knowledge to both port employees and young Sri Lankan students pursuing advanced education in navigation, port operations, and the maritime sector. Under the visionary leadership of Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, the MPMA has received directives to introduce new courses that specifically focus on the employment opportunities prevailing in the port and maritime sectors. The aim is to attract and enrol a larger number of young individuals into these programmes, providing them with the essential infrastructure and resources. The Minister has granted approval to recruit qualified professionals to deliver these courses effectively.  Presently, the academy awards around 2,000 diplomas annually, and the Minister intends to elevate this number by introducing fresh programmes and enhancing the existing ones. On 22 August, a special discussion concerning the implementation of these initiatives took place at the MPMA, initiated by the Minister. Further, the Minister conducted an inspection of the areas where modern infrastructure is slated to be installed and developed within the institution. SLPA’s Vice Chairman Gayan Algewattege, Managing Director Prabath Jayantha Malavige, Chief Training Manager of MPMA Nirmal De Fonseka, and several other senior officials were also in attendance.

title: Intex Sri Lanka 2023 concludes successfully
author: Author not found
Content: The 12th Edition of Intex – the Sri Lanka edition commenced on 9 August amidst great anticipation by the industry. Intex returned to Sri Lanka in 2023 to further revitalise international trade through face-to-face business interactions. The show was inaugurated on 9 August in the presence of Chief Guest Dr. Satyanjal Pandey, Acting High Commissioner, High Commission of India in Colombo and Guest of Honour Dr. Kingsley Bernard, Chairman & Chief Executive, Sri Lanka Export Development Board (EDB). Present in the audience were the Ambassadors from Indonesia, Malaysia and Korea as well as diplomatic representatives from other overseas missions like Turkey, Egypt and Bangladesh. Also present were heads of industry bodies such as SLABA, SLASA, SLAEA, SLCGE and FTZMA.  Intex, which took place from 9 to 11 August at BMICH, Colombo, is South Asia’s leading international textile sourcing show for fibres, yarns, fabric, denim, trims, dyes and more for the apparel industry. Intex Sri Lanka creates a new paradigm in textile sourcing by successfully integrating the entire value chain on a single, global business platform. In a country where demand for different types of input material is always high, Intex enabled businesses to explore new market opportunities as well as assist the Sri Lankan industry to connect with new suppliers and new products and services. Sri Lanka is considered one of the most ethical and trusted sourcing partners for apparel brands from around the world due to its commitment to maintaining supplies in the face of multiple challenges and Intex looked to further support the Sri Lankan industry to strengthen their global product range. Arti Bhagat, Executive Director of Worldex India, the organisers of Intex Sri Lanka stated, “Since 2015, Intex has been facilitating business collaborations, fostering innovation, and promoting trade opportunities and is recognised as the platform for strengthening international, inter-regional and inter-personal ties. I am confident that our collective efforts will create lasting partnerships that will undoubtedly lead to a brighter and better future for the textile and apparel industry.” The show brought global and South Asian suppliers to Sri Lanka through its exhibitors from 10+ countries including India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Hong Kong, China, Korea, Taiwan, USA, UK and more to showcase the latest products and services for the Sri Lankan textile and apparel industry with the India Pavilion having 50+ companies representing the entire textile value chain. Alongside the exhibition, The Interactive Business Forum (IBF) seminar series delivered high-quality market intelligence to support industry efforts to explore and expand their international offerings. Intex continues to grow its presence in Sri Lanka and looks forward to establishing new business opportunities for the Sri Lankan industry in South Asia and across the world.  For more information, please visit sl.intexsouthasia.com

title: Appeals for discipline and attention of the President
author: Author not found
Content: An incident that has reverberated through the plantation community has left many shocked and concerned. Veteran planter Suresh Nawarathnam narrowly escaped an assault allegedly initiated by Jeevan Thondaman, shedding light on the safety and respect challenges faced by individuals in the industry. The event unfolded amidst a group of estate workers and has triggered calls for enhanced discipline and unity within the plantation sector. Lieutenant Col. Suresh Nawarathnam, a recognised figure in the planter circle due to his unwavering commitment to ethical practices, is being lauded for his integrity and leadership. It is emphasised that his unwavering dedication to upholding what is right is an inherent part of his character. The incident has ignited discussions about the intricacies of preserving discipline among planters, particularly when confronted with situations of intimidation. A coalition of both active and retired planters came forward to condemn the incident as a blatant act of intimidation. It is underscored that this occurrence transcends political dimensions, representing an attempt to exert dominance over a planter within the presence of a sizable group of estate workers. The coalition asserted that the implications of this incident must be communicated to higher authorities to ensure the maintenance of discipline within the industry. The episode involving Suresh Nawarathnam has spurred a broader conversation about the role of planters within society. Once held in high esteem, and often likened to government agents for their leadership and contributions, planters are now grappling with diminishing influence and recognition. This incident has galvanised a renewed call for planters to assert their importance for the collective benefit of the plantation industry and the profession as a whole. The incident has united numerous members of the plantation community, who are demanding that planters reclaim their rightful position as leaders and contributors to society. This occurrence is being viewed as an opportunity for the industry to coalesce, fortify its discipline, and stand resolute against any form of intimidation. In a profession celebrated for its resilience and restraint, the attempted assault on Suresh Nawarathnam serves as a stark reminder that unity and discipline remain integral to upholding the core values and principles that have guided the plantation community through generations. As the industry takes stock of this incident, the trajectory of this collective plea for transformation and its implications for the role of planters within society remains to be seen. Plantation Community Joins Forces Against Attempted Assault on Esteemed Planter – Appeals for Discipline and the Attention of the President of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka. About the author: Lalin I. De Silva, Former Senior Planter, Agricultural Advisor/ Consultant, Secretary General of the Ceylon Planters’ Society, Editor of the CPS Bulletin and Freelance Journalist. By Lalin I. De Silva

title: Be a Canadian Platinum Sponsor of Educate Sri Lanka Colombo Expo
author: Author not found
Content: Be a Canadian Business Management, an experienced International Educational Consultant, has partnered with Evolution Events and Corporate Services (EECS) to become a Platinum Sponsor of the upcoming Educate Sri Lanka Colombo Expo 2023 to be held from 1 to 3 September at the BMICH. As one of the country’s leading International Educational Consultants, Be a Canadian (BAC) has built strong partnerships with many universities based in Canada where the students are offered a variety of programmes that would meet the qualifications they have already acquired. Starting from undergraduate to postgraduate programmes, students are offered an array of programmes in public and private universities based in British Colombia. Be a Canadian’s consultants are well-trained to meet every student’s needs by recommending the best university programmes in accordance with their backgrounds. They are available 24/7 to provide students with information and clear a pathway to further their educational aspirations. Starting from the registration process, each student is provided individual attention and guidance by the assigned consultant and they are also entitled to the ‘After Visa Service’, providing them an added advantage. The visa submission is professionally handled by the Sri Lankan office, while the post-visa services are handled by the Canadian office. As BAC is registered as a representative at ‘Global University System (GUS)’ it is able to provide students with the most accurate online registration portal that is able to register with any preferred university/college in less than ten minutes. The company guarantees that all information provided regarding the visa process is 100% genuine and transparent. Updated information is brought directly from Vancouver, British Colombia by the company’s CEO himself, giving students the opportunity to directly contact based on their convenience. Every single year, BAC registers over 200 students who apply for overseas student visas. By strictly maintaining their high standards and utilising the best-suited strategies the company has been able to maintain a visa success rate of 98 per cent per intake. Students are not charged any fees prior to their visa approval and only have to make a fixed payment at the end of the visa process. Overall, over the past few years, BAC has placed nearly 1,250 students in Canada, the United Kingdom and Australia, and has established direct partnerships with 15 universities by the end of 2022. Educate Sri Lanka Colombo Expo 2023 is the prestigious annual higher education and study abroad exhibition organised by Evolution Events and Corporate Services (EECS). The Colombo Career Expo 2023 will be held in parallel on the same days and venue. Educate Sri Lanka Colombo Expo 2023 serves as an informative event where aspiring students, parents, universities and higher education institutions gather on one platform in Colombo to explore a wide range of educational prospects for the students. The Colombo Career Expo 2023 is an exclusive career and internship fair designed to provide a platform for job seekers, students, and professionals to explore exciting career opportunities and connect with leading organisations in the country.

title: Mechanism needed to refund VAT – Export industry
author: Author not found
Content: If the Government removes the SVAT facility according to the proposal of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), an efficient mechanism should be implemented to refund VAT, export industry representatives informed the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Alleviating the Impact of the Economic Crisis which was held this week. The committee met under the chairmanship of MP Gamini Valeboda and representatives of all major exporters’ associations including the United Garment Manufacturers’ Association, the Rubber Products Exporters’ Association, the Tea Products Exporters’ Association and the officials of the Ministry of Finance, Department of Inland Revenue were present and there was a lengthy discussion regarding the Government’s decision to remove the SVAT facility. Finance Ministry officials pointed out that the Government expects to take this decision to implement a successful tax system like the tax system in developed countries. But the exporters’ associations pointed out that even if there is no opposition regarding the removal of the SVAT facility, a proper mechanism must first be established in this country as in the developed countries. It was also discussed that due to the long time taken for VAT refunds/repayments, it directly affects the cash flow of exporters and even after 7 years of RAMIS system was established in 2016 and spent billions, it is a problem that an efficient system for tax collection and refunds has not yet been established. According to the Act, although taxes should be reimbursed within 45 days, it was discussed that taking a long time is a problem. Accordingly, corrupt situations have arisen to the extent that certain third-party groups, including officials, act as brokers for quick reimbursement of tax money. It was also revealed that according to the Cabinet decision related to removing the SVAT facility, if this facility is removed, a proper system should be established first. Although officials of the Inland Revenue Department have said that the Government is losing revenue through the SVAT system, the committee pointed out that the problem is that they do not present sufficient figures to confirm it correctly. Therefore, the Chairman said a report on this matter should be submitted to the committee within a week. Also, he instructed the department to present clearly what is the alternative programme for VAT reimbursement if this SVAT facility is removed. He also called on export industrialists to  submit a comprehensive report with  quantitative data to the committee within a week. The chairman emphasised that protecting the export industries, which play a huge role for the economy of the country, is a national responsibility and that the Sectoral Oversight Committees will constantly advocate for it. He further said according to all these facts, recommendations are expected to be submitted to the Government through the Parliament. It was also revealed that according to the Cabinet decision related to removing the SVAT facility, if this facility is removed, a proper system should be put in place first.

title: Chandrayaan-3 rover takes ‘walk on moon’
author: Author not found
Content: The moon rover of India’s Chandrayaan-3 has exited the spacecraft to begin its exploration of the lunar surface, the country’s space agency said on messaging platform X, formerly known as Twitter. The spacecraft landed on the unexplored south pole of the Moon on Wednesday evening, days after Russia’s Luna-25 failed, making India the first country to achieve that feat. “The Ch-3 Rover ramped down from the Lander and India took a walk on the moon!” the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) said in its message on Thursday morning. The six-wheeled, solar-powered rover, named Pragyan (or wisdom” in Sanskrit) will amble around the relatively unmapped region and transmit images and scientific data over its two-week lifespan. Accomplished with a budget of about 6.15bn Indian rupees (USD 74.58m), this was India’s second attempt to touch down on the Moon. A previous mission in 2019, Chandrayaan-2, successfully deployed an orbiter but its lander crashed. Chandrayaan means ‘moon vehicle’ in Hindi and Sanskrit. The Moon’s rugged South Pole is coveted because of its water ice, which is believed to be capable of providing fuel, oxygen and drinking water for future missions, but its rough terrain makes landing challenging. People across the country tuned in to watch the landing on Wednesday, with more than seven million people viewing the YouTube livestream alone. Prayers were also held at places of worship, and schools organised live screenings of the spectacle for students. Prime Minister Narendra Modi said Wednesday that the successful lunar landing – previously achieved only by the United States, Russia and China – was a triumph for ‘all of humanity’. Elon Musk, whose firm SpaceX is a leader in commercial space launches, hailed the landing as “super cool”. India has a comparativelylow-budget space programme, but one that has grown considerably in size and momentum since it first sent a probe to orbit the Moon in 2008. Chandrayaan-3’s cost was far lower than many missions from other countries and a testament to India’s frugal space engineering. In 2014, India became the first Asian nation to put a craft into orbit around Mars and plans to send a probe towards the sun in September. ISRO is slated to launch a three-day crewed mission into Earth’s orbit by next year. It also plans a joint mission with Japan to send another probe to the Moon by 2025 and an orbital mission to Venus within the next two years. (Al Jazeera)

title: Salary disparity in In-Service Adviser roles of teachers
author: Author not found
Content: Concerns have emerged within the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Education regarding the transition of individuals from the teacher service to the In-Service Advisory service. A discrepancy has been highlighted between the promised pay grade and the actual pay grade provided upon absorption into the In-Service Adviser role. Those affected by this disparity assert that their remuneration falls below their previous salary. These issues were deliberated at a recent meeting of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Education, chaired by MP V. Radhakrishnan in Parliament. The committee collectively identified the unjust nature of offering a lower compensation than the salary earned after years of service when transitioning to an In-Service Adviser position. Consequently, the committee recommended a temporary suspension of appointments until the matter is resolved. During the committee meeting, Opposition Leader SajithPremadasa, sought clarification from officials about measures undertaken to fill the 1,982 vacancies in the In-Service Adviser positions. Additionally, he inquired about the evolving responsibilities and scope of the In-Service Adviser roles. The committee agreed that while numerous concerns persist, enforcing the absorption of teachers into the In-Service Adviser role without due consideration is unacceptable and warrants further discussion. The committee also engaged in discussions about establishing an effective mechanism to oversee Nursery Education and Nursery Schools in Sri Lanka. Officials disclosed that the National Policy for Pre-School Education had been available on the Ministry of Education’s website for public input for nearly a month. Consequently, an Action Plan for the National Policy for Pre-School Education had been collaboratively developed with the participation of relevant institutions and departments. The committee emphasised the need to unify the diverse provincial policies governing Nursery Education and Nursery Schools under a comprehensive national policy. Furthermore, with regards to early childhood and nursery education, conversations were held regarding the regulation of private tuition classes on Sundays and public holidays. The committee raised concerns about certain chapters in the syllabus that seemingly endorsed gender discrimination, advocating for their review. Accordingly, the committee recommended addressing these issues concurrently with the ongoing education reform programme. An inquiry into the progress of the Mid-Day-Meal programme implemented in schools across the country was also conducted during the committee meeting. Officials stated that the programme provides lunch to 1.8 million students across 7,926 schools. MPs Rohini Kumari Wijerathna, Manjula Dissanayake, and Dr. Charitha Herath, were in attendance at the meeting. Additionally, the Opposition Leader and MP Chandima Weerakkody participated in the meeting with the permission of the Committee Chair.

title: Partnership between the University of Vavuniya and Mines Advisory Group
author: Author not found
Content: The University of Vavuniya entered into a partnership with Mines Advisory Group (MAG) on the 22 August 2023. The event took place at the University of Vavuniya. On behalf of the MAG the Country director Cristy McLennan, Skills Development Specialist T Senthoran  and other MAG officials participated while on behalf of the University of Vavuniya the Vice-Chancellor Prof.T. Managaleswaran, Dean/ Faculty of Business Studies Prof. Y. Nanthagopan and Coordinator/ ICIC S. Sivanenthira participated in the signing of the agreement. The university officials and academic staff also attended this event. The overarching aim of this partnership is to strengthen the implementation of the staff transition strategy and support the local community in the Northern Province. The partnership is focused on creating a space where the University is supporting MAG in the implementation of the staff transition activities in order to prepare MAGs staff for new careers after the redundancy programme has taken place, due to Sri Lanka becoming landmine free. MAG will reach out to the university for specific training programmes that are required, and University will inform MAG about potential interesting opportunities for MAGs employees in the Northern Province. The University will benefit through increased exposure to university activities and programmes among MAG staff. On the other hand, MAG will assess the possibility of supporting the university with internship placements for students. The partnership for MAG will focus on the university to be the sole supplier for the implementation of the staff transition programme, without any monetary value. The Industry and Community Interaction Cell (ICIC) of the Faculty of Business Studies of the University of Vavuniya will facilitate the engagement between the university and MAG.

title: No need to fear Meningococcal disease – Epidemiology Chief
author: Author not found
Content: There is no necessity for the public to be unduly fearful of the Meningococcal disease, as no patient has been reported from outside the Galle Prison up to now, Epidemiology Chief Dr. Samitha Ginige reassured the public. Dr. Ginige said yesterday (24), that the Meningococcal disease, caused by the Neisseria meningitides, which causes meningitis, was not disease that was unknown and that annually there were a few isolated cases reported in Sri Lanka. He noted that safety measures had been taken to prevent the disease spread while around 10 inmates who had been in close contact with the patients at the Galle Prison had been admitted to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. Some of them were those who had fever symptoms. Of the ten, four have been discharged he said, reiterating that the public need not have undue fear of the disease as till now only those patients who had succumbed to the illness had so far been diagnosed with the disease. Precautions were taken within two hours of the patients’ reports being received, the Epidemiology Chief reassured. Measures were taken to provide the necessary medication to the remaining inmates of the Prison, also as a safety measure.  He noted that further measures had been taken at the Prison to temporarily halt inmates being taken out of the prison as well as admitting new prisoners to prevent disease spread.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Lightning kills child, another in shock
author: Author not found
Content: Two children were struck by lightning, resulting in the death of one, a 10-year-old boy at Nawa Medagama in Dehiattakandiya on 23 August. The other boy, aged six, who was suffering from shock, was admitted to the Mahiyangana Base Hospital, according to the Dehiattakandiya Police. This tragedy occurred while the victims were playing on a small tree in a paddy-field, while their parents were engaged in paddy harvesting. The boy who suffered from shock is now out of danger and is expected to be discharged within two or three days according to hospital sources. A hospital spokesman emphasised the importance of caution during thunderstorms and lightning. He strongly advised parents to ensure their children’s safety by keeping them indoors, especially during such weather conditions. By Naalir Jamaldeen
