title: Forty of 139 Permitted Pesticides Highly Hazardous
author: Author not found
Content: Forty (40) out of 139 permitted pesticides in Sri Lanka under the Gazette Extraordinary No. 1994/71 on 24 November 2016, have been found as Highly Hazardous Pesticides (HHPs), a report released by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) revealed. This is with reference to the Pesticide Action Network (PAN) International consolidated list of banned pesticides,6th Edition in May 2022. Accordingly, 14 out of those 40 HHPs, have been recommended for domestic use in Sri Lanka. Speaking at a media briefing yesterday (23), CEJ Senior Adviser Hemantha Withanage said according to global research the HHPs are linked to cancers, tumours, nervous system disorders, reproductive problems, immune system effects as well as endocrine system disruption. “Unfortunately, in Sri Lanka, the attention paid to these dangers is close to zero. There is not enough research conducted in Sri Lanka with regard to these pesticides. The impact of HHPs on women and children due to exposure while accompanying the family at crop fields has not been documented properly in Sri Lanka,” Withanage pointed out. According to the report, on average within five years, 2,181 MT of herbicides, 1,183 MT of insecticides and 896 MT of fungicides were imported annually. They are all released to soil, water and air creating many exposure pathways to the people, in addition to the farmers who directly deal with them. Meanwhile, CEJ Environmental Officer Supun Sanjeewa said they forwarded the findings with regard to the 40 HHPs to the Office of the Registrar of Pesticides as well. “A Deputy Director of the Office of the Registrar of Pesticides said recommendations are being given annually with regard to the pesticides and they were not aware of the PAN International list of HHPs when giving recommendations last time,” he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: A/L exam results out before 10 Sep
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Education Aravindh Kumar announced that the results of the G.C.E. Advanced Level examination 2022 will be released in the coming month. The State Minister said results are expected to be released before 10 September. From 23 January to 17 February this year, a total of 331,709 candidates faced the challenging national examination. Among these, 278,196 were school candidates, while 53,513 were private candidates. Evaluation of answer scripts of the 2022 A/L examination was impeded by a trade union strike involving university professors. This strike ended in early May.

title: Public warned against disturbing elephants
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion was held with Diyawadana Nilame of the Sri Dalada Maligawa Pradeep Nilanga Dela, five mahouts and the organisers of the annual Kandy Esela Perahera after five elephants taking part in the perahera ran amok during the second Kumbal Perahera on the night of 22 August. During the discussion it had come to light that trumpet sounds, whistling, flashing of lights via mobile phones and laser rays tend to disturb the concentration of elephants parading the streets. As a result, it was decided to request the public to desist from such actions while viewing the Pageant. Further, it was decided to take precautionary measures to prevent a further occurrence of such incidents in the future. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: X-Press Pearl compensation case deferred to 9 Oct
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Commercial High Court Judge Pradeep Hettiarachchi, yesterday (23), deferred further hearing of the compensation claim, filed against the owners of the cargo vessel MV X-Press Pearl, to 9 October. The aggrieved party in the case has moved the said Court, to issue an order to the owners of the cargo ship based in Singapore and the UK and from five other representative firms, to pay them compensation to the tune of USD 6.4 million, for the damages incurred by fishermen, their boats, trawlers and loss of income, arising from the tragedy. The case on behalf of the petitioners had been filed by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) General Secretary MP Ranjith Maddumabandara and its MP Dr. Kavinda Jayawardena. The prosecution has named eight firms as respondents in the case, including the Sri Lankan representative of the said vessel, Sea Consortium Lanka Private Limited, its owner and its insurer. The petitioners have prayed the Court, to issue an order to the respondents, to grant the compensation sought by them, as per the Marine Pollution Prevention Act No. 59 of 1981. The prosecution via its petition has stated that due to the cargo vessel having caught fire off Sri Lankan waters, a severe environmental catastrophe had occurred, as fuel had mixed with the water, and that it had also resulted in severe economic strain to the people of Sri Lanka, while air pollution had also taken place, while due to seeping of chemical material, more pollution had occurred. Hence the petitioners have prayed the High Court Judge, to issue an order to the firms concerned, to pay them adequate compensation, for the damages incurred by them. Considering the submissions, Judge Hettiarachchi, instructed the prosecution to substantiate their charges filed against the respondents, at the next hearing. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: India lands spacecraft on the moon
author: Author not found
Content: After a 40-day journey starting from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, the Indian Space Research Organisation’s (ISRO) Chandrayaan-3 mission has landed on the south pole of the moon successfully. The Vikram lander made a soft lunar landing at 6:04 p.m. IST yesterday (23). ISRO started the automatic landing sequence at 5:44 p.m. IST. The Vikram lander is now using its onboard computers and logic to try to make a soft landing on the Moon. While mission controllers at ISTRAC will monitor it closely, the onboard systems of the lander will be doing all the heavy lifting. The Chandrayaan-3 mission is the follow-up to the Chandrayaan-2 mission of 2019, when the Vikram lander crashed into the lunar surface. The primary objective of the mission is simple – showcase the space agency’s capability to complete a soft landing on the Moon. With the mission, India has joined a small and exclusive club of countries that have managed to soft land on the Moon. So far, the club has three members – the United States, the Soviet Union and China. Indian Premier Narendra Modi congratulated ISRO scientists for the success of the mission while speaking immediately after touchdown from South Africa. Says India is on the moon, adding that the success is a sign of a developed India “India’s successful moon mission is not just India’s alone,” he said. According to Modi, success belongs to all of humanity and will help future moon missions of other countries. ISRO chairperson S. Somanath congratulated project director P. Veeramuthuvel, assistant director Kalpana, mission director Srikanth and URSC director V. Sankaran for the success. Chandrayaan-3 project director P. Veeramuthuvel reiterated how ISRO is the first to land near the south pole of the moon. “Most memorable and happiest moment,” added assistant director Kalpana. (The New Indian Express)

title: Medical Officers urge Treasury to fund anaesthetic inhaler
author: Author not found
Content: The fast depleting stocks of a general anaesthetic inhaler in State hospitals has caused severe disruption to scheduled surgeries, All Ceylon Medical Officers’ Association (ACMOA) lamented urging the Treasury to release funds for the purchase of essential pharmaceuticals inclusive of the fast depleting stocks of a commonly used anaesthetic inhaling agent. General Secretary ACMOA, Dr. E.M. Jayantha Bandara addressing the media yesterday (23) urged the Treasury to release required funds for the purchase of essential drug stocks including the anaesthetic ‘Isoflurane’ which is a general anaesthetic administered by inhalation. He said the particular anaesthetic was given from a vapouriser. He said currently routine surgeries at District General Hospital Nuwara Eliya had been temporarily halted as a result due to the shortage of the anaesthetic. It has caused severe inconvenience to those who had received dates for their routine surgeries during this period. The anaesthetic inhaler is short supply in several other hospitals in the country which had prompted hospital authorities to limit routine surgeries being carried out in these hospitals. The General Secretary urged the Health Ministry to provide the essential medicinal drugs in sufficient quantities regularly rather than intermittently as was being practised at present. There should be buffer stocks of all essential drugs so as to provide continuous service, he said. Dr. Bandara urged the Health Ministry to ensure that the procedure of purchasing the drugs was carried out sans corruption.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Enforced disappearances key focus of OMP – Katulanda
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Office on Missing Persons (OMP), Mahesh Katulanda, highlighted a critical aspect of his institution, adding that their primary concerns were with cases of missing persons, but the central focus lies in cases of enforced disappearances that demand utmost attention. Addressing the present situation within the OMP, a media briefing was conducted yesterday (23), and Katulanda disclosed that on their assumption of the OMP’s responsibilities, they inherited 64 individual files containing information about their disappearance. He highlighted that they have since received and compiled additional data concerning the missing individuals. Notably, over the past year and a half, they have engaged with 3,819 families of missing persons, gathering valuable insights. Moreover, the OMP has taken proactive measures by establishing supplementary mechanisms and panels to conduct thorough investigations. A total of 15 independent panels have been instituted for this purpose, Katulanda emphasised, reaffirming that these panels operate autonomously, free from any external influence, be it from the Government or any other entity. During the briefing, he underscored the distressing scenario of individuals being taken against their will and vanishing without any trace, neither a body nor any sign of their existence. This issue has garnered heightened scrutiny due to the 30 years of conflict that engulfed the Northern and Eastern regions, culminating on 18 May 2009. Post the conflict; the international community directed their attention towards Sri Lanka, prompting inquiries from entities such as the UNHRC, United Nations, the Red Cross, and the UN Council. In response, the Government introduced the 2016 Act No. 14, aiming to address these concerns. Before this, there had been around eight commissions, including the LLRC Commission and the Paranagama Commission, but their findings did not provide solace to the families of the victims. Thus, an independent institution named the Office on Missing Persons (OMP) was set up in 2018. Since its inception, the office has undergone several transitions, with personnel changes and procedural adjustments. Drawing on the expertise of various professionals, the OMP’s framework was meticulously formulated, he said. At present, the OMP represents a facet of society where individuals, particularly parents and children, who continue to endure profound sadness, have become increasingly vocal and impassioned. However, efforts are now on a constructive trajectory. The Act introduced in 2016 encompasses events spanning from the 1971 civil unrest to the violent incidents in the South in 1989 and 1983 July, collectively aimed at addressing the issue of missing persons dating back to 1968. The search for these individuals has no set endpoint, but it was after the conclusion of the conflict in 2009 that heightened attention was directed toward it. While previous efforts such as the LLRC and Paranagama Commission offered some insights, the present OMP carries more authoritative capabilities in tackling this challenge. He said, transitioning to another commission would not be viable, as the issue demands immediate attention. The goal is to expedite resolutions, although it remains uncertain if the OMP will be able to uncover all details and conclude its work by issuing death or missing certificates along with compensation. Nevertheless, the primary aspiration is to provide clarity to the families of enforced disappeared persons – explaining what transpired, who was involved, and why. Closure might be achieved if physical remains are found, however, the absence of any trace, whether indicating life or death, remains profoundly agonising for mothers, regardless of whether they belong to soldiers, LTTE members, or civilians, the Chairman pointed out. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Rs 2.6B released for 35,000 needy, elderly persons
author: Author not found
Content: The Treasury transferred Rs 2.684 billion to all District Secretaries for July to cover allowances for approximately 35,000 kidney patients, disabled individuals, and low-income elderly citizens, as said by State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe. He said the initiative was carried out based on directives from the President. As a result, allowances for elderly citizens will be accessible for collection at post offices, while allowances for disabled individuals and kidney patients can be obtained from Divisional Secretariats starting from 25 August. In a statement last week, the State Minister said provisions had been allocated to maintain the allowances unchanged for a total of 647,683 beneficiaries—comprising kidney patients, disabled individuals, and elderly citizens—until a new scheme is formulated. Out of the total beneficiaries, 517,962 are elderly citizens, 88,602 are disabled individuals, and 41,119 are kidney patients, which includes individuals wait-listed in the Aswesuma welfare benefit programme. BY Anura Priyantha – Habaraduwa

title: Wasantha, Nalin removed from Chamber
author: Author not found
Content: MPs Wasantha Yapa Bandara and Nalin Bandara were removed from the Parliament Chamber yesterday (23) for repeatedly causing disturbance to the proceedings. Chaos erupted in the Chamber during the Oral Questions Round, as a verbal altercation escalated among multiple MPs. During the proceedings, MP Wasantha Yapa Bandara posed a question to Wildlife Minister Pavithra Wanniarachchi regarding tamed elephants. This was followed by objections raised by Minister Prasanna Ranatunga, who expressed concern over the extension of the session’s scheduled time. Subsequently, MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam directed his inquiry towards MP Nalin Bandara, involving irregularities within the district development committee and divisional development committees in Batticaloa. While Nalin Bandara was addressing Rasamanickam’s query, allegations emerged that his response was veering off topic. Nevertheless, Nalin Bandara persisted with his response despite the allegations. The situation spiralled into disarray despite the Deputy Speaker’s repeated calls for appropriate behaviour from the MPs. In light of the futile appeals, the Deputy Speaker adjourned the parliamentary session for 10 minutes. A meeting took place under the leadership of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena and after resuming the sittings, the Speaker ordered Wasantha Yapa Bandara and Nalin Bandara to exit the Chamber for the remainder of the day’s session due to their disruptive behaviour that hindered the smooth conduct of parliamentary proceedings. After the two MPs complied and left the Chamber, normal parliamentary activities resumed under the leadership of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Financial support in advancing climate initiatives vital – President
author: Author not found
Content: A climate change initiatives progress review meeting was convened at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (23), showing Sri Lanka’s interest to climate action and international cooperation, according to the President’s Media Division (PMD). Chaired by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the meeting brought together prominent advisers and experts to deliberate on strategies to enhance the nation’s response to climate change. During his address, President Wickremesinghe underscored the significance of resilience on both local and global scales. He emphasised the need for assertive action, both domestically and on the international front, noting the pivotal role of financial support in advancing climate initiatives. The President remarked that finance serves as the lifeblood of any endeavour and emphasised the need for Sri Lanka to bolster its capabilities on this front, as outlined in the PMD statement. The President’s call for action stemmed from his observation that while numerous climate change initiatives are proposed, insufficient attention was paid to  financing. He highlighted Sri Lanka’s expertise in international economics, particularly in climate financing associated with debt management, positioning the country in a unique position, the PMD said. President Wickremesinghe also introduced forming a National Consultative Committee that would involve both private and public sector entities. He said, “This committee should encompass relevant agencies from the public and private sectors and will comprise 100 to 150 members. Regular consultations with this committee, at least every six months, would facilitate discussions on the progress made. Establishing such a structure could yield the desired outcomes. I believe that collaboration between the Foreign Ministry and the Environment Ministry was crucial on international aspects. Further, it’s imperative that everyone contributes with a focus on international finance. We could align this effort with our Institutes of Economics and Trade, thus positioning Sri Lanka as a hub for global financial activities. Thus, we will work to consolidate this concept.” The President emphasised alignment with international agendas, including those of the UN Secretary-General and President Biden. He proposed the setting up of an International Climate Change University, serving as a global research hub and a testament to Sri Lanka’s commitment to climate change. The PMD added that Ruwan Wijewardena, Senior Adviser to the President on Climate Change, briefed the President about discussions with reputed universities, including those in the US and Cambridge regarding the setting up of the Climate Change University. The meeting unveiled key highlights for the upcoming COP28, encompassing the Climate Justice Forum, the launch of the Climate Prosperity Plan, the International Climate Change University, and the Tropical Red initiative. The significance of showcasing Sri Lanka’s practices through a dedicated platform and facilitating discussions was also stated. Ananda Mallawatantri, Adviser to the President on Environment, Climate, and Green Finance, presented a proposal to collaborate with international universities, spotlighting the agreement with Georgetown University and opportunities with Yale. Plans to partner with EU institutions to exchange expertise and promote sustainable practices were also discussed. Regarding green finance, the Green Financing Committee has been developing a roadmap for sustainable finance, supported by the UN Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP), UNDP, and the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI). The committee is engaged in initiatives such as Debt for Nature Swaps and has presented a project on the Kelani River Basin. The PMD said the meeting was attended by Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed, Senior Adviser to the President on Climate Change, Ruwan Wijewardane, President’s Senior Economic Adviser, Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, K. M. Mahinda Siriwardana, Secretary to the Ministry of Environment Dr. Anil Jasinghe and other relevant officials.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Inmates of Galle Prison to stay
author: Author not found
Content: Additional Commissioner General of Prisons, Chandana Ekanayake, said all suspects detained at the Galle Prison will remain in the premises while new prisoners will be accommodated at the Agunukolapelessa Prison. This is a sequel to the deaths of two inmates due to a bacterial infection in the Galle Prison. Ekanayake said this step was taken according to instructions given by the health authorities to take into account the fever situation spreading in the Galle prison and that no suspects should be taken out of the Galle prison and no new suspect ordered by Court should be detained in the Galle prison. Until further notice from the health authorities, suspects detained in the Galle prison will not be taken to Courts nor will any new suspect be detained in the Galle prison until further notice. The media spokesperson further said the disease spreading in prison has been largely controlled by the health authorities. Relatives of the detainees should not have any doubts about this. Meanwhile, Galle Chief Magistrate, Isuru Nettikumara has scheduled the preliminary examination regarding the two prisoners who died in the Galle Prison for 18 September.The Chief Magistrate arrived at this decision following facts submitted to Court yesterday (23). The Judicial Medical Officers who performed the autopsies have also been summoned to Courts on 18 September. The deceased, who are from Moragoda and Ahangama Idurannawila areas in the Galle District were aged 23 and 31 years. Meanwhile, preliminary investigations revealed that the deaths of the two inmates at Galle Prison had been due to Meningococcal disease. Health Ministry sources yesterday (23) said however further investigations revealed that the two inmates had died due to a disease caused by Neisseria meningitides bacteria. Another 16 inmates were being treated for the infection. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha and Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Inshore Patrol Craft Handling Foundation Course for woman crew
author: Author not found
Content: The Inshore Patrol Craft Handling Foundation Course held for the Navy’s woman crew successfully concluded at the Naval and Maritime Academy, Trincomalee. The initiative got off the ground as part of the Global Maritime Crime Programme of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. The certificate awarding ceremony was held under the patronage of Commandant Naval and Maritime Academy, Commodore Buddhika Liyanagamage on 18 August. The aim of this programme is to deploy woman crew of the Navy and female officers of law enforcement agencies for coastal and port security duties. The nine participants included one lady officer and two women sailors from the Sri Lanka Navy as well as three lady officers each from the Indonesian Marine Police and the Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency. The course, which spanned four weeks, aimed to equip the participants with the essential skills and knowledge required to effectively operate and manage Inshore Patrol Craft. Thus, these lady officers and women sailors sharpened their practical and theoretical knowledge of Navigation, Seamanship, Engineering, Electricity, Combat Medicine, Firefighting, Communication and Boat Handling during the programme. Programmes of this kind aimed at training would inevitably enhance the collaboration among partners who share similar goals, leading to improved overall performance and efficiency in naval operations involving woman crew.

title: Glittering Glimpses of Esala Perahera
author: Author not found
Content: The historic Kandy Esala Perahera Festival 2023 commenced on Monday, 21 August, with the first Kumbal Perahera taking to the streets of Kandy. The festival will culminate with the Grand Randoli Perahera on 30 August. (Pix by Manilka Jayasingha)

title: The 5th Cargills Square opens in Bandarawela
author: Author not found
Content: In a time marked by global economic challenges, Cargills, a pioneer in innovation and community development, unveils its latest endeavour: the Cargills Square Mall in the heart of Bandarawela. The Bandarawela mall becomes the fifth Cargills Square to be opened by the company, and the second mall to be opened during 2023.  A beacon of confidence The Cargills Square is more than just a mall; it is a symbol of resilience and optimism in Sri Lanka’s future. Through its decision to invest in the Cargills Square in Bandarawela, Cargills has shone a light of hope for the local community as well as the country at large, creating a unique shopping and entertainment hub for families, youth, and visitors to Bandarawela. The five-storey shopping and entertainment complex includes a Cargills Food City supermarket, a Food Court with multiple restaurants, retail shops, a KFC restaurant, and two cinema screens including a 3D facility to watch the latest cinematic releases. The complex also houses a Cargills Bank branch, to provide convenient financial solutions to customers. Empowering the youth, building dreams One of the primary visions behind Cargills Square is to empower the youth and ignite their aspirations. By creating family-friendly entertainment complexes, Cargills aims to provide spaces where dreams can flourish and where the younger generation can envision a future filled with opportunities. The meticulously designed entertainment facilities, thoughtfully curated retail outlets, and vibrant atmosphere are all aimed at inspiring creativity, innovation, and personal growth among the youth of Bandarawela and beyond. Beyond urban boundaries Cargills has always been committed to the uplift of communities across Sri Lanka, contributing towards the development of rural towns and the country as a whole. While many shopping and entertainment complexes are confined to urban areas, the Cargills Square mall defies this norm. The company envisions to transcend geographical boundaries and make modern, world-class entertainment and shopping facilities inclusive for all communities across the country. The Cargills Square concept was first introduced in 2013 with the objective of providing entertainment and shopping experiences for customers in areas outside the Colombo city limits. Following the success of the first Cargills Square in Jaffna, which was the first large-scale commercial investment in the North by a blue-chip company, Cargills subsequently opened three more malls in Gampaha, Dematagoda, and Katubedda. Cultural value and history The location of the Cargills Square mall in Bandarawela, once housed the infamous Cargills department store, which dates back to the 1800s. This heritage building has been preserved and transformed by the company to suit the demands of the modern consumer while retaining its rich history. Not too far from the location lies the iconic Bandarawela Hotel – another heritage building which has history going back to the year 1893. As the Cargills Square in Bandarawela opens its doors, the company invites the community to come together and create lasting memories. Built with an investment of Rupees 1.6 billion, the project stands as a testament to the Cargills Group’s confidence in the potential of the Sri Lankan economy and its commitment to fostering hope and opportunities for the youth.

title: SL High Commission in New Delhi felicitates long-serving local staff
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of Sri Lanka in New Delhi recently felicitated seven members of its local staff who have completed twenty-four years of service. Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda presented mementos to these staff members recognising their long service, at a simple ceremony held at the High Commission on 18th instant. The High Commissioner, with the support of the Sri Lankan private sector, has made arrangements for these long-serving seven staff members and their spouses/family members to undertake a visit to Sri Lanka with a five-night stay. High Commissioner Moragoda and Mrs. Jennifer Moragoda also handed over the air tickets to them at the felicitation ceremony. This was the third consecutive time that the High Commission felicitated its long-serving staff members. In 2021, five staff-members who had served more than thirty years were felicitated while in 2022, an equal number of employees who had completed twenty-five years of service were felicitated. Similar visits to Sri Lanka were arranged for them and their spouses/ family members as well. With the Sri Lanka visit of this group, the High Commission has been able to arrange such visits to all its local employees who have served more than twenty-four years, prior to the forthcoming final departure of High Commissioner Moragoda completing his tenure in India.

title: Lion Sriyani appointed Deputy Cabinet Secretary – Int’l Affairs
author: Author not found
Content: Lion Sriyani Aluthge, MAF, was installed as the Deputy Cabinet Secretary – International Affairs of Lions International District 306A2 for the year 2023 / 2024 in the presence of District Governor, Lion Nuwan Ballanthudawa, MJF. The Installation Ceremony was held on 22 July 2023 at White Haven Hotel, Panadura by the Chief Guest, Past International Director, Lion Vijay Kumar Raju, PMJF from Visakhapatnam, India. He is the LCIF Trustee for the period 2021-2024 and Constitutional Area Leader of Campaign 100 for Constitutional Area 6. Lion Sriyani is the Charter President of Lions Club of Colombo Pride and served as the Convention Secretary in the year 2014/2015. Her spouse is Past District Governor, Lion Nimal Aluthge, MJF, MAF, JP who served District 306 A2 as the District Governor in the year 2009/2010. He led the District with his four point programme and gave priority to the ‘Grow More’ programme with the theme ‘Serve with Pride’. Lions Club of Colombo Pride invites all friends to join hands with Lions International.

title: Japanese students meet the Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation of Japanese NPO UNSDGs Human Resource Development Institute met Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena in Parliament recently (18). Addressing the delegation, the Speaker recalled the long-standing close relationship between Japan and Sri Lanka in various fields, especially in the Buddhist, cultural and educational sectors. The Speaker also commended Japan’s support at a time when the country is facing an economic crisis. Later, the delegation had the opportunity to ask questions from the Speaker and after that, they engaged in a Parliament tour. Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera also participated in this event.

The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Special communication vehicles under Chinese grant delivered to Army
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Army gratefully accepted 11 special communication vehicles that had been gifted to the Ministry of Defence under the Chinese Military Grant Scheme during a simple formal ceremony, headed by Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, Acting Minister of Defence and General Kamal Gunaratne (Rtd) WWV RWP RSP USP ndc psc MPhil, Secretary to the Ministry of Defence at the Army HQ. Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage RWP RSP ndu, Commander of the Army, Major General W.A.S.S Wanasinghe RSP VSV USP ndu, Chief of Staff of the Army and Senior Colonel Zhou Bo, Defence Attaché at the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in Sri Lanka were among the distinguished invitees to the occasion.    At the beginning of the day’s programme, a short video documentary was presented displaying existing bonds of goodwill and understanding that prevail between militaries in both countries. Afterwards, the formal signing of documents, related to the grant of vehicles took place between Senior Colonel Zhou Bo, Defence Attaché at the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in Sri Lanka and Major General K.A.W.S Ratnayake ndu, Chief Signal Officer of the Army. Subsequently, ten Field Communication Vehicles and a Mobile Command and Control Vehicle were symbolically handed over to Minister Tennakoon by Senior Colonel Zhou Bo in the premises. Soon after, the gathering of Senior Officers and invitees had a close look at those new vehicles of much use to the Armed Forces of Sri Lanka. Major General C.D Ranasinghe RWP RSP, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Army, Senior Officers, Officers and Other Ranks took part in the arrangement.

title: LRC Chair questioned on delays in releasing Deeds
author: Author not found
Content: The Chairman of the Land Reform Commission (LRC) was questioned, by the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Tourism and Lands, on the prolonged delay of over 50 years in releasing Deeds to landowners. This topic was raised and thoroughly discussed during a recent meeting of the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Tourism and Lands chaired by the Minister of Tourism and Lands Harin Fernando. Representatives from the Land Reform Commission explained that the challenge at hand revolves around lands that have been transferred to multiple parties, now spanning three or four generations, who presently occupy these lands. The officials noted that this complex situation has hindered the smooth presentation of necessary documents. They added that efforts are currently underway to address and resolve this matter. However, Minister Harin Fernando stressed the need for an expedited resolution. He proposed initiating a swift process, commencing with a pilot project in the Kandy District. Subsequently, the project could gradually extend to other districts to address deed-related issues. Minister Fernando emphasised the importance of the Land Reform Commission taking a proactive stance on such matters and prioritising the concerns of the public. The committee also discussed the request to issue new annual licences for black stone quarrying to approximately 7000 individuals in the Damana in Balangoda, who are traditionally involved in the black stone quarrying industry.

title: China gifts Com Vehicles to SLA
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Army (SLA) on Tuesday (22)accepted 11 special communication vehicles that had been gifted to the Defence Ministry under the Chinese Military Grant scheme, the SLA website said. The vehicles, comprising ten field communication vehicles and a mobile command and control vehicle were handed over to Acting Defence Minister Premitha Bandara Tennakoon by the Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka Defence Attaché Senior Colonel Zhou Bo at Army Headquarters, Battaramulla. Among some of the others present at this occasion were Defence Ministry Secretary General Kamal Gunaratne (Rtd.), SLA Commander Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage, Chief of Staff, Major General W.A.S.S Wanasinghe, Deputy Chief of Staff Major General C.D Ranasinghe and Chief Signals Office Major General K.A.W.S Ratnayake. (PA)

title: ‘Karandu Eththu’ by Dr. Jagath Wellawatta launched
author: Author not found
Content: A novel written by Sri Lankan Ambassador to Italy, Dr. Jagath Wellawatta titled Karandu Eththu was launched at the Cinema Tiziano, a movie theatre in Rome, Italy, during the Sri Lankan Art and Literature Festival Wastu organised by the Sri Lankan Embassy in Rome. The novel revolves around a woman’s love towards her boyfriend, husband, and the complexities she has to encounter on realising that she had been betrayed. There’s an undercurrent political reading of the novel too. During the event, Sarasavi Publishers Managing Director H.D. Premasiri and Ambassador Wellawatta launched Karandu Eththu as the first novel that can be bought by Sri Lankans living worldwide via an Internet application. Indian Ambassador to Italy Neena Malhotra was the Chief Guest.  The Maha Sangha, Chinese Ambassador to Italy Jia Guide, Myanmar Ambassador to Italy Hmway Khyne, and a large number of diplomats, were in attendance. Author Mohan Raj Madawala and a number of artistes such as Shyam Fernando, Sarath Kothalawala and Manjula Senarathne were also present.

title: Nutmeg cultivation suffers bacterial infection
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Director of the Department of Export Agriculture, Shantha Bandara, said sizeable cultivations of nutmeg in the country have been affected due to the spread of a bacterial infection. He said due to the presence of the infection, the nutmeg plant tends to die and noted that already discussions had been launched with nutmeg growers on ways to control the spread of the bacteria. Bandara made these comments while taking part at a zonal inspection tour in several areas including Kandy, Alawathugoda, Dippitiya and Konakalagala with nutmeg growers on the measures that have to be adopted to safeguard the cultivations from the infection. According to the Deputy Director,the bacteria spread due to wind and rain. It has been suggested that spraying of chemical liquid could control its rapid spread and protect cultivations. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Devananda believes seafood export can bring sizeable foreign exchange
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda and Former State Minister Vinayagamoorthy Muralitharan engaged in extensive discussions on Monday (21), aiming to create opportunities for seafood export through collaboration with private sector investors. The meeting took place at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta, Colombo. A considerable number of private sector investors, who are keen to invest in seafood exports, were also in attendance during the discussion. Minister Devananda holds the belief that substantial foreign income can be generated through seafood exports. This, in turn, is expected to make a noteworthy contribution to bolstering the foreign currency reserves of the country and alleviating the ongoing economic crisis. Expressing confidence in his stance, Minister Devananda highlighted the potential for significantly enhancing the livelihoods of local fisher folk, thereby providing them with stable economic access. Moreover, Minister Devananda extended requests to Tamil investors in the Diaspora to explore the possibilities of channelling their investments into Sri Lanka, aiming to further boost the seafood export sector. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Impressive growth in gem exports
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister for Primary Industries, Chamara Sampath Dasanayake, on Tuesday (22) said there was an impressive growth in the National Gem and Jewellery Authority’s (NGJA) exports, marking a significant milestone in the country’s economic progress. He revealed that from January of the current year until now, the exports of gems and jewellery have generated USD 315 million in revenue. Speaking at a press conference, held at the President’s Media Centre, Dasanayake said that the gem and jewellery sector has achieved remarkable export growth, contributing substantially to the nation’s foreign exchange reserves. He emphasised that this sector’s export growth rate is an impressive 34%, a statistic confirmed by reports from the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL). He noted the historical concerns surrounding foreign exchange remittance earned through gem exports and mentioned the establishment of a new customs clearance system, under the current Government, to address these issues. This system ensures meticulous assessment of each exported gem to facilitate the inflow of foreign exchange, he said. In the past, the country’s gems were auctioned abroad without receiving equitable remuneration. To counter this, Dasanayake expressed the Government’s strategic efforts to maximise profits from gem and jewellery exports, which have seen a substantial boost. He also highlighted the NGJA’s effective communication with exporters to address challenges and ensure smooth operations. In the previous year, the authority’s revenue from licensing and assessment fees was Rs 144 million. However, in the current year alone, it has achieved a significant profit of Rs 288 million. The State Minister emphasised that strategies are in place to further increase the authority’s profits by an impressive 200% by the end of the year. Dasanayake underscored that the Ministry of Primary Industries has been instrumental in alleviating foreign exchange scarcity and the NGJA is a notable contributer to the nation’s economic well-being. He noted that the authority independently contributes between Rs 50 and 100 million to the Ministry of Finance, demonstrating its commitment to the country’s economic advancement. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Keheliya wants services to begin by mid-October
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella instructed his officials to commence maternal and child care services at the Specialised Maternity and Children’s Hospital in Gallassa, Kalutara by mid-October. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry, on Tuesday (22), said a special discussion was held at the Ministry with the aim of starting the treatment services at this newly constructed specialised Maternity and Children’s hospital. Attention was paid to the assigning of health staff, including specialists, doctors, nurses, and the development of infrastructure to provide the necessary medical equipment. Rambukwella said any issues arising over the allocation of staff should be promptly notified to him. Consisting of seven floors, this hospital is equipped with all facilities including operating theatres, suture rooms and intensive care units, he noted. Kalutara District MP Sanjeeva Edirimanna, Health Ministry Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta, Director General of Health Services Dr. Asela Gunawardena, several officials from Health Ministry and Directors of Kalutara and Mahmodara hospitals were present. (DJ)

title: Despite 45,000 teacher vacancies, none recruited so far – Union
author: Author not found
Content: General Secretary of the Sri Lanka Education Services Teachers’ Union Sawanathileke Gajadeera claimed that despite there being 45,000 vacancies in the teaching profession, the Education Ministry has failed to initiate the recruitment of new students to the National Institutes of Education (NIEs) since 2018. He issued a stern warning that if this trend persists, it could lead to the deterioration of the country’s education system. Gajadeera alleged that more than 10,000 students who sat the G.C.E. Advanced Level examination in 2018 and 2019 have been left in limbo, unable to secure admission to teacher training schools. He accused the Education Ministry of lacking a viable plan to integrate these young individuals into teacher training programmes. He cautioned that unless immediate action is taken to fill the current vacancies in the teaching sector, the education system could face a serious crisis due to the shortage of teachers. Gajadeera was speaking at a press conference in Kandy on Tuesday (22). BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: 13-acre land given to China undervalued – Jayasekara
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister for Ports and Aviation Premalal Jayasekara yesterday (23) alleged that the Ministry of Ports and Shipping, under Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, had leased 13 acres within the  Colombo Port to China’s CM Port to construct South Asia’s biggest logistic centre, without calling for tenders, procurement or government evaluation of the land. The CM Port also runs the Colombo International Container Terminal (CICT) and the State Minster alleged that the transaction was facilitated by a Chinese business figure, who secured the land at a seemingly low cost to construct the mega logistic centre.  Expressing concerns over the leasing of the land, the State Minister warned that this development poses a potential threat to national security and expressed worries that the revenue generated from the Port’s operations over the next 35 years would be diverted to the Chinese operators of the facility. The construction work on the logistic centre has not commenced as yet according to sources. He claimed that the land was undervalued, because land evaluation was not carried out by the State, but by a private party who undervalued the 13-acre plot at a time when there is a high demand for land inside the Port. He said he would expose the matter at the next press conference and that he, as the State Minister who is aware of corruption, was in the process of gathering inside information to bring it to the notice of the authorities. He claimed that he has been sidelined without any job given to him and he merely signs documents of requests for jobs and opportunities which are then forwarded to Minister de Silva. He said the 13 acres, located between the East Container Terminal and the West Container Terminal, has been given to the Chinese for a song. Further, he alleged that certain senior officials were reportedly involved in rampant corruption at the Ports ministry. Notably, the land that was leased for 35 years sans a tender process, proper procurement procedures, or a thorough evaluation was a serious matter of concern.  The State Minister said however, the striking paradox is where some trade unions, typically vocal about corruption and the sale of national assets, have remained silent regarding this issue.  Further, Jayasekara alleged that there had been proposals concerning the usage of this land since 2016. However, the leasing took place without transparent processes before it was given to China, he claimed. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Over 7000 PSM officers on the warpath, warn of strike
author: Author not found
Content: Over 7,000 officers, serving in professions supplementary to medicine (PSM) are on the warpath demanding the Health Ministry rectify the continuous delay in its recruitment procedures.  Co-Convenor of the Joint Council of Professions Supplementary to Medicine (JCPSM), Chanaka Dharmawickrema yesterday (22) cautioned that 7,000 PSM officers, from five categories, would stage a strike tomorrow (24) making seven demands, including the rectification of the continuous delay in recruitment procedures. The PSM, comprising professional associations of radiologists, laboratory scientists, pharmacologists, physiotherapists, and occupational therapists would stage the strike from 8.00 a.m. on 24 August 2023. Outlining their demands Dharmawickrema said they also comprised demands for the issuance of a circular related to grade promotions, leaving room for a collapse in services by putting a stop to new recruitments to the PSM categories and against the suppressing of trade union leaders and their members by issuing unfairly disciplinary orders. He warned that the strike would result in the breakdown in radiological tests, CT, MRI tests, all laboratory tests, issuance of medicinal drugs, collapse in the physiotherapist, and occupational therapists services. However the ‘Apeksha’ Hospital for patients with cancer, maternal and child hospitals and the National Blood Centre would be exempted from the strike. Apart from this, all emergencies and life saving services would be maintained. But should there be attempts to intimidate and obstruct the services of PSM engaged in voluntary services, measures would be taken to remove them from duty as well, he warned.  Meanwhile, the President of the JCPSM Ravi Kumudesh, in a letter to the Health Secretary, noted that the JCPSM was forced to resort to trade union action against  barriers that had been set up from within the Ministry in making timely changes. In a letter copied to the Health Minister, all Provincial Health Secretaries, Additional Secretaries (Administration I and II), Director General Health Services and heads of all State health institutions, he noted that although the PSM had patiently tried to resolve the issues that were affecting them, the professional hypocrisy of other services and the highhandedness of some health officials had placed an obstruction to making those changes a reality. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Galle prison inmates’ Court appearances suspended
author: Author not found
Content: Court appearances of inmates, at Galle Prison, have been put on hold for a duration of two weeks following the emergence of a bacterial infection. The Superintendent of Galle Prison said that arrangements would be made to facilitate virtual Court proceedings for prisoners as needed. It was reported on Monday (21) that two inmates in Galle Prison lost their lives and several others were admitted to hospital due to an illness of unspecified origin. However, the Health Ministry has revealed that preliminary investigations link the fatalities and hospitalisations of Galle Prison inmates to meningococcal disease — an uncommon yet serious ailment caused by meningococcus bacteria. Chandana Ekanayake, the Prisons Additional Commissioner General and Media Spokesman, isaid that seven other inmates are presently undergoing treatment at the prison hospital, while an additional nine are receiving medical attention at Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. Autopsies onr the two deceased inmates were conducted on Monday (21) and their remains have been submitted to the Government Analyst for further analysis. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Don’t take the law into your hands – Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles urged the public not to resort to vigilantism or engage in such activities following remarks of certain politicians that could spark tension in society. “Do not take the law into your hands,” Minister Alles requested. Further, the Minister cautioned that strict measures would be taken against individuals who attempt to circumvent the legal system and against those who enable such behaviour, by becoming victims of incidents manipulated by politicians and political parties aiming to secure votes during elections. The Minister made this statement over a comment made by a public representative, in relation to an incident at the Ratwatte Estate within the Elkaduwa Plantation, situated in the Matale District. Emphasising a firm stance against violence, Minister Alles said the public representative had asserted the right to take action in the absence of adequate government intervention and legal protection. Minister Alles appealed to the estate community and the public, urging them not to resort to vigilantism or engage in such activities. He cautioned against individuals attempting to administer justice on their own and discouraged such conduct.

title: Anura Kumara raises concern over Channel Eye lease
author: Author not found
Content: A heated exchange erupted in Parliament between Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena and Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake, concerning the leasing of State-owned Channel Eye to the Lyca Mobile Group. Dissanayake raised a question, under Standing Orders, expressing concern over the leasing of Channel Eye to the SDT Channel of Lyca Mobile, alleging that proper procedure was not followed. “You (Gunawardena) are trying to gain approval to hide the alleged fraudulent action. It is reported that the estimated monthly income was Rs 25 million and whether the Channel Eye Board of Directors had the authority to lease air time to a company without proper procedure was of concern. What is the basis for this?” he queried. Gunawardena: “Channel Eye was not leased but rented to VIS Broadcasting Company for six months at a monthly rate of Rs 25 million. What you say is incorrect.” Dissanayake: “You say that. But I can show you the Cabinet Paper that mentioned the lease for six months.” In response, Minister Gunawardane claimed he did not draft the Cabinet Paper and that the term ‘lease out’ was mistakenly used instead of ‘rent out’ by the Cabinet Secretary. “I will resign from all positions and politics if any wrongdoing in the transaction could be proved,” Gunawardena said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Hassle over LCs for heavy vehicle imports to be eased
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya announced yesterday (22) that immediate solutions will be provided to address issues related to letters of credit (LCs) arising from the importation of public transport buses, lorries, and trucks. Siyambalapitiya stated that he will intervene to resolve the challenges associated with the issuance of LCs for the import of buses used in public transport, as well as lorries and trucks required for special purposes. He said Sri Lanka’s commitment was to resolve concerns over the international recognition of LCs. He said this during a discussion with vehicle importers. During the meeting, vehicle importers highlighted that due to various measures implemented, amidst the ongoing economic crisis in Sri Lanka, LCs issued by local  Banks are currently not being accepted on the international stage. They also noted that despite receiving authorisation for the import of various vehicle categories, including public transport buses, the import process has encountered difficulties. In response, Siyambalapitiya reiterated his intention to engage in discussions with relevant stakeholders, including the Central Bank. He pledged to provide effective solutions. He further said the Government was exploring the feasibility of issuing Government guarantees in support of LCs.

title: Chinese national arrested for operating drone
author: Author not found
Content: A Chinese national was arrested for operating a drone within the Sri Dalada Maligawa premises in Kandy to capture pictures of the Kumbal Perahera. Kandy Police took the Chinese national into custody over suspicions arising from the incident. Preliminary inquiries revealed that the suspect, who was housed in a hotel in Kandy, launched the drone from the confines of his hotel room window at approximately 9.30 p.m. on Monday (21) Police said the suspect arrived in Sri Lanka on Sunday (20) and had subsequently gone to Kandy and checked in to his hotel on Monday (21). Kandy Police are conducting further investigations. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Two forcibly take away hearse with body
author: Author not found
Content: Hakmana Police are investigating an incident where two inebriated persons had forcibly taken away a hearse with a body inside it. The twosome, when given chase, had abandoned the hearse with the body at a distance and fled. According to Police a youth had living in Kebilipola, Hakmana had suddenly passed away on 19 August. Following the post-mortem, the body was handed over to the  relatives.  Later, the body was handed over to a funeral parlour for embalming. Once the process was over, funeral parlour employees were in the process of transporting the body to the residence, when  two inebriated relatives, who arrived at the  parlour, forcibly took away the hearse.  The funeral parlour owner had then informed Police and pursued the hearse in another vehicle. It was then that the two suspects abandoned the hearse with the body and fled the scene. The parlour owner then drove the hearse himself and handed over the body to the relatives. However, the two suspects, who had taken the hearse are evading arrest. Police are conducting investigations to arrest them.   BY Ariyasena Denagama – Hakmana

title: Sugar tax scam funds must be used to compensate farmers – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa proposed that the Government should utilise funds that should be collected to recover the loss caused by the sugar tax scam, to compensate farmers for crop damage due to the prevailing drought. Premadasa, speaking in Parliament yesterday (22), highlighted that numerous districts across the nation were grappling with severe water scarcity. “This shortage is affecting not only drinking water for people but also water availability for livestock, agriculture, and power generation. Wildlife is also facing challenges due to inadequate drinking water, while the drying grasslands have caused several crises, making this a matter of national significance,” he said. He emphasised the necessity for a comprehensive programme to assist those impacted by crop damage, extending beyond the coverage provided by the existing crop insurance scheme. If funding was insufficient for such an initiative, he pointed out that during the period from 14 October 2020, to 20 February 2021, the special commodity tax on sugar imports was reduced from Rs 50 to 25 cents. Premadasa recommended that these monies should be recovered and channelled to support farmers affected by crop loss. Referring to the import of 400,000 MT of sesame and the resulting loss of Rs 15.9 billion to the country, Premadasa called for the individuals responsible for this wrongdoing to be held accountable. He stressed that the recovered funds should then be directed to aid farmers who suffered losses due to the dry weather conditions. Additionally, Premadasa underscored the need for greater awareness among some ministers in parliament concerning water allocation priorities. He urged Parliament to be better informed in this regard. Furthermore, he highlighted the problems surrounding the guaranteed price for paddy given to farmers, emphasising that the current rate of Rs 80 to Rs 85 per kilo was insufficient to cover their expenses. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: JJB Leader demands Rs 20B from Sagara, Tissa
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake has sent Letters of Demand (LODs), seeking Rs 10 billion each from Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) General Secretary Sagara Kariyawasam and MP Tissa Kuttiarachchi, over alleged defamatory remarks made about him during a public gathering on 19 August in Colombo. During this event, SLPP General Secretary MP Sagara Kariyawasam and MP Tissa Kuttiarachchi made statements implying that the National People’s Power (NPP) party had allegedly made investments in Malta, the LODs stated. The LODs sent through Attorney-at-Law Sunil Watagala, strongly urges both Kariyawasam and Kuttiarachchi to pay a combined sum of Rs 20 billion within a period of 14 days, as compensation for the alleged harm caused. The letter underscores that failure to comply with this demand, within the specified timeframe, will result in legal action being pursued against them in a Civil court. Attorney-at-law Watagala, representing Anura Kumara Dissanayake, stated that his client maintains that the statements, made by the two MPs, were completely baseless, malicious, and untrue. The letter further emphasises that these statements were intended to defame and injure Dissanayake’s reputation, causing damage to his standing in the public eye. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: SL, Singapore ink joint venture on carbon credits
author: Author not found
Content: The Government of Sri Lanka and Singapore signed a Memorandum of Understanding yesterday (22) regarding a joint venture on carbon credits under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. The MoU was signed after President Ranil Wickremesinghe engaged in discussions with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong earlier in the day. The focal point of the discussions was the reinforcement of collaborative efforts between the two nations. The leaders emphasised the importance of sustained cooperation and explored avenues for increased economic involvement, the PMD said. The MoU was signed by Sashikala Premawardhane, High Commissioner of Sri Lanka to Singapore and Beh Swan Gin, Permanent Secretary (Development), Ministry of Trade and Industry, in the presence of President Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Lee. President’s Chief-of-Staff and National Security Adviser, Sagala Ratnayaka, Senior Adviser on Climate Change Ruwan Wijewardene and Senior Adviser on Economic Stabilisation Dr. R.H. Samaratunga accompanied the President.
