title: Strengthening rights of patients
author: Author not found
Content: Preparation of a proposal to strengthen the rights and responsibilities of patients was discussed at a recent meeting of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Health. The committee meeting was held under the Chairmanship of MP Mayantha Dissanayake in Parliament. Institutions such as the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Justice, Sri Lanka Medical Association, Sri Lanka Medical Council, Legal Aid Commission, Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission and representatives of many other institutions representing the protection of patients’ rights were present at the Committee discussion held. There was an exchange of views on further strengthening of existing regulations. The committee discussed the proposal on the rights and responsibilities of the patients discussed during the 8th Parliament and pointed out the need to pass it in Parliament. Experts related to the medical profession and other organizations that advocate for the rights of patients widely discussed in this regard during the Committee meeting held. The committee decided to prepare a final proposal by comparing the proposal submitted by the Ministry of Health and the proposal submitted by the Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMC). Dr. Shalala Ahmadova, the office representative for the World Health Organization Sri Lanka also agreed to the proposal. Moreover, the committee suggested to study the related proposals in countries such as India and Thailand and to contribute those proposals to strengthen this proposal. MPs Dr. Rajitha Senaratne, Dr. Gayashan Nawananda, Jagath Kumara Sumithraarachchi, Dr. Upul Galappaththi and Lalith Varna Kumara were present at the committee meeting.

title: IPESF discusses environmental security across Asia-Pacific Region
author: Author not found
Content: The 12th annual Indo-Pacific Environmental Security Forum (IPESF) took place from 14 to 17 August 2023, hosted for the first time by the Sri Lanka Navy and sponsored by the United States Indo-Pacific Command (USINDOPACOM). They successfully brought together environmental security stakeholders from across the Asia-Pacific region. The IPESF Forum saw the participation of 28 different countries. The main focus of the event was collaborative problem-solving, revolving around the theme of ‘Environmental Resilience through Cooperation’. During the forum, attention was drawn to the joint dedication of the United States and Sri Lanka towards strengthening resilient communities, safeguarding natural resources and establishing a secure Indo-Pacific region. The event covered critical topics such as climate security, maintaining sustainable resource practices, fostering multilateral cooperation and driving transformations in environmental security. United States Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Julie Chung, shared in her opening remarks: “Our vision of the world is one where all countries, big and small, have opportunities for success and stability.  Whether you’re sitting in Fiji or Australia or Mongolia or Sri Lanka, we are all vulnerable. We are seeing this year record-setting weather extremes hitting countries around the world, where everyone is feeling that impact.  Recent droughts here in Sri Lanka are impacting food security. It is imperative that we come together to share knowledge and find creative ways to address these common challenges.” Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, the Commander of the Sri Lanka Navy, said on Monday: “No matter the advances we make and achieve through technology and innovation, it’s more than evident that nature is always ahead with her unique surprises, and man needs to be more circumspect. Hence, as cognitive beings we need to pursue a path of rationale behaviour forging a relationship that would ensure the sustainment of our civilization and the environment alike.” Throughout the four-day event, participants engaged in presentations, panel discussions, and interactive group activities, fostering an environment of knowledge sharing and best practice dissemination covering subjects such as climate change, land security, maritime and water security, and urbanization’s security effects. By embracing a holistic approach to environmental security, the IPESF facilitated the development of actionable plans to address pressing environmental challenges. Project development and workgroup development workshops were instrumental in generating strategies to enhance environmental resilience and security across the region. The Indo-Pacific Environmental Security Forum (IPESF), launched in 2010 by USINDOPACOM, is an annual event focused on fostering regional cooperation, knowledge sharing, and collaborative action to address environmental challenges that impact national and regional security. Hosted by different nations across the Indo-Pacific, the forum brings together experts, policymakers, military officials, and stakeholders to develop actionable plans for environmental resilience and security. The 2024 Indo-Pacific Environmental Security Forum will be held in Vanuatu. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Three vehicle racketeers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The Panadura Divisional Crime Investigation Unit has arrested three individuals, one of whom is a teacher, in connection with a group involved in vehicle racket. This group used counterfeit identity cards, electricity bills and driving licences to fraudulently obtain vehicles through rental agreements. The suspects, aged 42, 37, and 36, are from Dambulla, Polonnaruwa, and Gampaha, respectively. Based on a complaint lodged by a local businessman in Panadura, the suspects were apprehended. The Police discovered two cars, counterfeit ID cards, drivers’ licences, electricity bills, transfer certificates and vehicle registration books in their possession. It was reported that a coordinated network is executing similar fraudulent activities across the entire island. Gampaha Police have already uncovered two vehicles linked to this operation. The Police revealed that the primary suspect, along with an accomplice, rented vehicles, dismantled the GPS devices, forged ownership documents within a span of 72 hours and subsequently sold the vehicles at discounted rates. Further investigation uncovered instances where the group falsely registered vehicles in the name of the teacher, particularly when the genuine owner was a female. Despite submitting residential documents from Panadura, the suspects used a counterfeit electricity bill originating from the North Central Province. BY Sumith Ranawaka–Pothupitiya

title: Sudden fire destroys large areas of forest
author: Author not found
Content: Residents have raised the alarm about a significant fire that had begun spreading within the protected forest plantation near the viewing centre of Moragahakanda Reservoir and the covered mountains within the reservoir area in the night of Sunday (20). By Monday (21) afternoon, a substantial portion of forest had been completely reduced to ashes due to the ongoing fire, as reported by local residents. Given the prevailing dry weather conditions, the water levels in the Moragahakanda Reservoir have significantly decreased in recent days. Consequently, many islands within the reservoir have already fallen victim to fires caused by human activities, according to statements from local residents. The fire initially ignited near the Moragahakanda Reservoir viewing centre. Vendors operating in the vicinity mentioned that they were unable to identify the originator of the fire. Remarkably, there was no sign of fire until the afternoon of Sunday (20). In recent times, students and various visitors have been flocking to the area to witness the beauty of the Moragahakanda Reservoir. These visitors have expressed their astonishment and disappointment upon witnessing the ongoing fire. The Department of Forest Conservation and the Mahaweli Authority established this protected forest with the intention of safeguarding the native trees and endemic wildlife in the region. These natural resources were impacted by the creation of the Moragahakanda Reservoir, which falls under the jurisdiction of the Mahaweli Authority of Sri Lanka. However, there appears to be a lack of effective protection for this area. Local residents have reported that the fire continues to spread, resulting in the death of numerous wild animals and the destruction of valuable trees by the morning of Monday (21). Surprisingly, neither the Sri Lanka Mahaweli Authority nor any other responsible agency had taken action to control the fire by that time. Instead, a foreigner from a nearby workshop and their private security officer were observed present at the scene. This incident is not the first of its kind, as many reserved forests near the Moragahakanda Reservoir have been subject to fires and subsequent destruction on multiple occasions in the past. BY K.K. Ariyadasa – Dambulla

title: Premalal takes Nimal Siripala to task
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Ports and Aviation Premalal Jayasekara levelled strong accusations against Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva yesterday (22), claiming that his ability to carry out responsibilities under his purview was consistently being hindered. He alleged that the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) stands as one of the most corrupt institutions in the country. Eleven months ago, Jayasekara was appointed to enable revenue generation. However, he lamented that he has been restricted from executing his duties and pursuing his goals. Jayasekara, who convened a media conference yesterday, said his current situation, as the State Minister, meant that he was jobless and unable to fulfil his role. He claimed that he communicated these concerns to President Ranil Wickremesinghe. “While recognising the challenge of shifting Ministries amidst the current circumstances, the President said if he (Jayasekara) were to switch, others would also demand similar changes,” Jayasekera said adding “I waited for so long and my Ministry, located in the World Trade Centre, has an outstanding rental due of eight million rupees and this expenditure  cannot continue, utilising public funds to pay for unused space. I asked the ministry to be housed within the ports authority but that has not been approved.” He alleged that corruption within the SLPA, was far worse than that in the aviation sector. He claimed that he is making this statement with a sense of responsibility. He said the people of his electorate are inquiring about the promised job opportunities and facilities. His capacity to function effectively in such a scenario has been questioned. “All the institutions under my purview are managed by the Cabinet Minister of Ports and Shipping. While I have secured one director-level appointment related to aviation, all other appointments, including directors and general managers, were made by the Minister. This dynamic has created a closed circle of like-minded individuals who operate collectively and withhold information from outsiders,” Jayasekara stressed. Speaking further, the State Minister claimed that the financial details of various projects remain undisclosed to him, with only the Minister of Ports and Aviation being privy to such information. He charged that through this practice they were hiding the truth from the public. In a stern warning, State Minister Jayasekara said he would expose corruption in the Port with documentary evidence at the next press conference, if he continues to be impeded in his role. He threatened to resign and said he intends to reveal corruption even if his duties were reinstated, as he could no longer tolerate the current state of affairs.  “Given that we (the Cabinet Minister and State Minister) cannot work in isolation, as a State Minister, I have put forth numerous proposals and brought in potential investors to start the development of ports like Oluvil and KKS. However, these efforts have encountered numerous barriers and obstacles. Despite being responsible for these institutions, officials within the Ministry have blocked our work.  These officials only operate on the instructions of the  Minister,” he said. He said there was no animosity between him and the Minister, but that when  proposals and investers were presented, progress was obstructed. He pointed out that for the KKS project, they had introduced an invester of Sri Lankan origin from France. However, the proposal was rejected solely because the invester was associated with the State Ministry. Consequently, the invester returned to his country after realising he couldn’t proceed, Jayasekara claimed. “While the Port Minister publicly announced the country’s openness to business and ferry services, he is, in fact, the person who has prevented such initiatives.  There are senior officials who remain entrenched in their positions for 15 to 20 years without any rotations of duties. These individuals, including accountants and other senior figures, hold the reins and contribute to corruption. They have formed a cohesive group,” he alleged. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Susil participates in GSC 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha represented Sri Lanka at the 2023 edition of the Global Smart Education Conference (GSC2023), co-organised by the Beijing Normal University (BNU) and the UNESCO Institute for Information Technologies in Education (UNESCO IITE), held at BNU, China. The Global Smart Education Conference is being organised as an annual event since 2016. GSC2023 was dedicated to the theme of ‘Education Transformation and Data Governance’, and included a Forum on Educational Digitalisation and Lifelong Learning, Forum on Data Governance and Cognitive Development, Forum on Generative Artificial Intelligence and Educational Innovation, etc.  The conference was joined by participants from around the world, including policymakers, researchers and practitioners.  At the Conference, Premajayantha shared experiences and challenges in implementing technology-empowered educational transformation in Sri Lanka. The Education Minister’s keynote speech attracted much attention from the attendees at the Conference. There, he also mentioned that the expert knowledge gathered at the conference was quite invaluable in furthering the ongoing educational reforms in Sri Lanka.

title: SL Int’l Religious Freedom Roundtable condemns attacks on Christians in Pakistan
author: Author not found
Content: Co-chair of Sri Lanka Unites and the Sri Lanka International Religious Freedom Roundtable, Soraya M. Deen, strongly condemned the violent attacks that transpired on 16 August 2023, targeting the Pakistani Christian community in Jaranwala within the Faisalabad District. In her statement, she emphasised, “We vehemently urge authorities to prioritise the safety of minority group members and uphold the fundamental principles of freedom of religion or belief for all. The senseless acts of violence, including the desecration of over 25 churches, the burning of Bibles, and the destruction of fellow Christians’ homes, are nothing short of tragic and deplorable.” She further asserted that such actions only serve to breed more resentment and hatred, leading to far-reaching consequences that undermine coexistence, harmony, and solidarity among people. Notably, with a significant quarter of the global population residing in South Asia — encompassing Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka — it is distressing that religious minorities across this region continue to endure substantial violence and discrimination. “The unfolding events in Pakistan serve as a sobering reminder for us to introspect on our treatment of minorities. The International Religious Freedom (IRF) Roundtable provides a safe space where individuals, NGOs, and government officials from diverse faith backgrounds collaborate to champion global freedom of religion or belief.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: MPMA starts expanded educational programme for the young
author: Author not found
Content: The Mahapola Ports and Maritime Academy (MPMA), a part of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA), has initiated a programme to provide expanded educational opportunities to young individuals. This initiative has been set in motion following instructions of Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. The effort aligns with the Government’s decision to direct the youth of Sri Lanka towards the burgeoning employment prospects within the swiftly advancing port and maritime sectors, driven by modern technology. Established in 1987 by the late Minister Lalith Athulathmudali, who served as the Minister of Ports and Shipping, the Mahapola Ports and Maritime Academy has evolved into a globally recognised institution for higher education under SLPA. Over the years, the institution has been dedicated to imparting knowledge to both port employees and young Sri Lankan students pursuing advanced education in navigation, port operations, and the maritime sector. The aim is to attract and enroll a larger number of young individuals into these programmes, providing them with the essential infrastructure and resources. The Minister has granted approval to recruit qualified professionals to deliver these courses effectively. Presently, the academy awards around 2,000 diplomas annually, and the Minister intends to elevate this number by introducing fresh programmes and enhancing the existing ones. On 22 August 2023, a special discussion concerning the implementation of these initiatives took place at the MPMA, initiated by the Minister. Furthermore, the Minister conducted an inspection of the areas where modern infrastructure is to be installed and developed within the institution. SLPA’s Vice Chairman Gayan Algewattege, Managing Director Prabath Jayantha Malavige, Chief Training Manager of MPMA Nirmal de Fonseka, and several other senior officials were present.

title: Two deaths at Galle Prison
author: Author not found
Content: Two inmates have reportedly died of a bacteria, which has spread in the Galle Prison and other inmates have been given necessary treatment by the Epidemiology Department of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, to stop further spread of the bacteria. According to the sources at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, these deaths have been caused by a bacteria named Meningococcal. Additional Commissioner General of Prisons and Prisons Spokesperson Chandana Ekanayake said that one inmate died yesterday (21) and another on the day before (20). Following an open verdict regarding those deaths, the body parts of the deceased have been forwarded to the Government Analyst for further tests, he added. Ekanayake also said that five inmates, who contracted fever, are being treated at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital and 10 others at the Galle Prison Hospital. Ekanayake further mentioned that in order to prevent the spread of fever, masks have been given to all the inmates and that if an emergency situation arises, a decision will be taken to close the prison. Meningococcal disease refers to any illness caused by bacteria called Neisseria meningitides. These illnesses are often severe, can be deadly and include infections of the lining of the brain and spinal cord (meningitis) and bloodstream. Keeping up to date with recommended vaccines is the best protection against meningococcal disease, according to the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in the USA. The doctors and other health personnel at the hospitals have been advised to wear face masks when treating patients with such symptoms. Director of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital Dr. Udesh Ranga, said that several patients who were brought from the prison in the last few days were admitted to the hospital and two of them have died. He said, further details about these deaths can be given following the final reports. However, an internal message issued to the doctors of the KarapitiyaTeaching Hospital states that the cause of death of the two persons was meningococcal bacteria. BY Sajeewa Wijeweera and Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: President Ranil meets Singapore President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe was engaged in a meeting with Singapore’s President Halimah Yacob yesterday (21), at the Istana in Singapore, according to the President’s Media Division (PMD). In a statement shared on her official Facebook page, President Yacob expressed that the discussions between the two leaders were highly constructive. The subjects covered, during the talks, included vital topics such as food security, renewable energy and regional economic collaboration. President Yacob highlighted the strong foundation of their friendship, fostered by robust people-to-people connections and cooperation across various sectors. She emphasised the potential for further deepening these ties and wished President Wickremesinghe a productive visit to Singapore. Embarking on a two-day official visit to Singapore on the 21st, President Wickremesinghe has an array of significant meetings scheduled. These include deliberations with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen, and Sustainability and Environment Minister Grace Fu Hai Yien. During the course of his visit, President Ranil Wickremesinghe also held discussions with Singapore’s Defence Minister Dr. Ng Eng Hen. The focus of the meeting was to enhance security and defense cooperation between the two nations.  Conversations encompassed geopolitical developments and the crucial role of regional stability, especially for smaller maritime nations. The discussions underscored the vital necessity of bolstering security partnerships within the South Asian region. Both President Wickremesinghe and Minister Ng Eng Hen emphasised the significance of ongoing communication and coordination to effectively address shared security concerns. The ultimate aim is to leverage the strengths of both countries to cultivate a synergistic partnership that enhances regional security. Furthermore, President Wickremesinghe also engaged with Singapore’s Minister for Sustainability and Environment Grace Fu Hai Yien.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Marching Towards the Restoration of Rightful Place/Identity
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘Malaiyaha Ezhuchchi-Payanam’ Walk by the Malaiyaha Tamil community in Sri Lanka from Tailamannar to Matale to commemorate the perilous journey undertaken by their ancestors who were brought from South India by British colonists over 200 years ago came to a conclusion in Matale on Saturday, 12 August. The last leg of the 14-day march commenced from the historic Nalanda GedigeVihara in Matale. At least, 3,000 people joined the march on the final day including Malaiyaha community members, clergy from all religious faiths, students, civil society representatives, and well-wishers. While the march concluded at the Sri Muthumariamman Temple in Matale, 70 persons who had walked the entire journey from Talaimannar to Matale were recognised and honoured for their effort. Speaking to Ceylon Today, human rights activist and an organiser of the walk, Jeevaratnam Suresh said his community should be officially recognised as ‘Malaiyaha Tamils’ instead of the commonly used term ‘Indian Tamil’. s “For the past 200 years, our community has been the largest contributor to Sri Lanka’s foreign exchange earnings. However, our identity is yet to be officially recognised. We are not seeking sympathy; we are striving for acceptance and the acknowledgement of our rights. This march marks just the initial step. Let’s come together to address these crucial matters and find the rightful place we deserve. After two centuries, we are eagerly awaiting the resolution of these issues at the earliest.” he said. Meanwhile, addressing the media, Wekandawala Rahula Thera emphasised the need for unity to restore the rightful pride and identity of the Malaiyaha Tamil community. “As religious leaders, it is our duty to honour the dignity and identity of every citizen. We must strive to uphold the vision they rightfully deserve. Our faith teaches us to refrain from discrimination. The community in question has been seeking recognition for their identity for many years, and it’s important that they receive the respectful responses they deserve,” Thera noted. “It is truly impactful to witness the Sri Lankan Malaiyaha Tamil community connecting with their heritage, thereby empowering themselves through this march. This effort has facilitated a broader societal conversation about the dignity of individuals and their rights as equal citizens of our nation.” SuchithAbeywikrama, an activist said. “Being part of this solidarity was crucial for me, as the Sri Lanka I desire is one where fairness prevails for everyone. It’s about standing alongside others and voicing their concerns. Additionally, as a Buddhist, I firmly believe that my practice involves striving for the overall welfare of all individuals and contributing to the healing of our fractured society. I’m convinced that it’s high time we acknowledge the challenges faced by the Malaiyaha Tamil community and focus on the essential social, economic, and political changes required for our coexistence,” he added. US Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Julie Chung, also conveyed her commendations for the event via her official Twitter account. She remarked, “With the completion of the 2-week walk commemorating the Malaiyaha Tamils’ struggle to become full and equal citizens with other communities, our thoughts are with those who marched from Talaimannar to Matale to mark the anniversary of their arrival in Sri Lanka’s hill country plantations 200 years ago”. Representing 11 Tamil schools within the Matale district, the students of these schools coordinated a procession in Matale city, which featured various Tamil cultural activities. Furthermore, 25 students from the Kandaloya Estate in the Kagalle district, who were selected for university education, also participated in this march. Remarkably, all these students are enrolled in different universities across Sri Lanka, having received their primary education in the schools of the Yatiyanthota area. The Malaiyaha Tamils encounter significant hardships stemming from their lack of land ownership. This predicament greatly complicates their ability to sustain themselves, often leading them to reside in low-income housing or on the outskirts of urban areas, where they grapple with various challenges. These difficulties extend to their children, who attend segregated, lower-tier schools, consequently hindering their access to promising career prospects and a pathway to socioeconomic advancement. Regrettably, this pattern of inequitable treatment reverberates into their professional lives as well, as they confront obstacles in securing employment opportunities and face wage disparities. Moreover, their underrepresentation within the government further exacerbates the injustices they experience. The challenges faced by this community serve as a poignant reminder of the imperative to champion equity and impartiality for all individuals. It is incumbent upon both the Sri Lankan Government and the international community to rally behind them, safeguarding the integrity of their rights. Although the recent protest marked a promising commencement, their quest for parity persists. With an enhanced network of support, they exhibit a resolute spirit, showcasing their unwavering resolve to the world. On the final day of the march, the Malaiyaha Tamils, adorned in the attire of tea plantation workers, covered a distance of 26 km. This symbolic act was carried out to advocate for the fundamental livelihood rights of their communities. Commenting on the march, a Professor from the Department of Economics and Statistics of the University of Peradeniya Dr. Kalpa Rajapaksha said the feat was historical. “This struggle, epitomised by the recent march, has brought to light various dimensions of the labour force within the estate sector. The participants of the march notably rejected the label ‘Estate Tamil’ and instead embraced the identity of Malaiyaha Tamil, signifying Tamils from the upcountry,” he said. According to Rajapaksha, this shift holds profound significance as it involves replacing a label imposed by capitalist norms with a name that resonates with their own history and identity. “This act holds historical importance as it signifies their refusal to adopt a name bestowed upon them by a system that historically oppressed, marginalised, and ruthlessly exploited them. This transformation holds immense meaning not only for the individuals involved but also for the broader society,” he noted. Rajapaksha commended the dedication of those who walked the entire trek from Talaimannar to Matale. “Certain individuals from this community, although born in the upcountry, ventured to various regions across Sri Lanka for work. However, regardless of their location, they remained subject to harsh exploitation by both the capitalist framework and the majority Sinhalese population, along with other communities. The level of commitment demonstrated by these individuals throughout the march carries profound meaning. It underscores their resilience in the face of adversity and sheds light on the depth of their dedication to their cause,” he said. He also recognised the communal harmony and cooperation displayed by those of other communities along the way. “It’s heartening to note that the Sinhalese community also played a supportive role during the march, offering sustenance such as food and drinks, and displaying a remarkable sense of hospitality. Equally noteworthy is the strategic approach of the march participants in conveying their message to others. Even in the midst of accepting food and engaging in conversations, they exhibited careful consideration and strategy to effectively communicate the essence of their cause. This collaboration between communities holds significant importance, particularly given Sri Lanka’s current socio-political context that necessitates such forms of communication and cooperation. In such circumstances, these efforts are not only valuable but essential for fostering understanding and unity,” he said. “Engaging in direct, face-to-face conversations with people is essential. The era of virtual communication and social media has its boundaries, particularly when it comes to driving substantial political change. To witness transformative shifts in Sri Lanka’s political landscape, prioritising human-to-human interaction, building connections, and offering political education becomes imperative,” Rajapaksha concluded. Pix: Kalpa Rajapaksha By Shabeer Mohamed

title: GMOA wants audit into increased child deaths at LRH
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry should take urgent steps to conduct a proper audit into the increase in the number of child deaths taking place at the Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH) for Children. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Prasad Kolambage, briefing the media, alleged that there had been an increase in the number of patient deaths at the LRH during the last period, which was under the administration of Dr. G. Wijesuriya. “Carry out a proper audit. Shouldn’t attention be given and is there no responsibility or accountability for incidents such as these, when the Hospital Administrator is also an official of the Health Ministry,” he queried. Although there are issues related to the Incumbent Director of the LRH, there are other officials in the Health Ministry who act like they don’t have the responsibility of taking action against administrators who have been refused permission to cover the work of Deputy Director General Medical Services II of the Ministry of Health, by the Public Services Commission (PSC). “Should the GMOA continue to agitate against this, strike or protest before the Health Ministry takes some action,” he queried lashing out that the Health Minister, Health Ministry Secretary and the Director General of Health Services should quit if they cannot even take action in a situation like this. The public can keep no hope in the State health service if the top most officials in the Health Ministry cannot take action even in this instance.  Dr. Kolambage warned that his outfit was ready to resolve this matter through trade union measures at the upcoming Central Committee meeting. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Unit set up at BIA to curb illegal migration
author: Author not found
Content: In a move to curb the issue of illegal migration, facilitated by forged visas, at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake, a Safe Migration Promotion Unit (SMPU) has been inaugurated within the airport’s departure terminal. The initiative has been led by Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara. Nanayakkara pointed out the occurrence of numerous cases where individuals departed for countries such as Oman, Malaysia, and the United Arab Emirates using fake visas, leading to significant complications. The establishment of the Safe Migration Unit, situated in accordance with recommendations from the Ministry of Defence and the National Task Force to Prevent Human Smuggling, aims to curb the movement of passengers using fraudulent travel documents. Comprising personnel from the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE), the CID, the Department of Immigration and Emigration and the State Intelligence Service (SIS), the SMU functions as a collaborative effort to counter this illegal activity. Minister Nanayakkara said this initiative is being launched as a pilot project for an initial period of three months, after which it will undergo further enhancements and improvements. The ceremony marking the launch of the SMU was attended by dignitaries including Chairman of the Airport and Aviation Company, Major General (Retired) G.A. Chandrasiri, Chief of Airport Management H.S. Hettiarachchi, Chairman of the SLBFE Hilmi Azeez, General Manager Priyantha Senanayake and several senior officials from the Police and CID. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Certified copies of birth, marriage, death certificates will no longer expire
author: Author not found
Content: The Registrar General’s Department has officially announced the discontinuation of the practice of invalidating certified copies of birth, marriage, and death certificates after a period of six months from their issuance. As part of this update, the department has revoked the prior regulation that mandated the expiration of these documents after six months. To clarify, individuals possessing certified copies of certificates from the Registrar General’s Department are no longer required to acquire new copies, as per the revised guidelines. The Registrar General’s Department has duly communicated this development to pertinent authorities, including the Ministries of Education, Foreign Affairs, and the Department of Immigration and Emigration, as well as the Department of Registration of Persons. Nevertheless, it is important to note that obtaining a fresh copy of the relevant documents is only necessary if modifications or amendments have been made to them, the department stated.

title: Shrimp farm polluting Vidathalthivu waterways – CEJ
author: Author not found
Content: A private shrimp farm, operated by a Seafood Company, has discharged toxic effluents in large quantities into the waterway which passes through the Vidathalthivu sanctuary, environmentalists alleged. According to the environmentalists, the toxic effluents are released into a highly environmentally sensitive Vidathalthivu lagoon leading to the contamination of the nearby sea waters. The shrimp farm operates 10 metres away from the other side of the A 32, on the road between the Vidathalthivu sanctuary and the shrimp farm. Vidathalthivu is the third largest marine protected area which was declared as a nature reserve by Gazette No 1956/13 on 1 March 2016, and covers 29,000 hectares. “The consequences of this pollution have been dire, with reports of small fish, and vegetation dead or dying in the affected area and seriously threatening the life and lifestyles of the Vidathalthivu community, who have lived there for generations,” says chair Friends of the Earth International and Senior Adviser Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) Hemantha Withanage. He says the flora and the fauna of the protected sanctuary are affected and there is a catastrophic impact on the marine ecosystem. “The wastewater from the private shrimp farm has been observed to be black in colour, indicating the potential presence of harmful pollutants and contaminants. The impact of this pollution on marine life and water quality must be thoroughly studied,” Withanage explained. He says this situation requires immediate attention to assess the damage and immediate corrective action taken. “According to the Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Act, No. 02 of 1996 Section No. 2 “no person shall discharge industrial or domestic effluent directly or indirectly to Sri Lanka Waters,” Withanage said. By Risidra Mendis

title: Kanchana issues directives on CEB promotions
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy, Kanchana Wijesekara, has issued directives to the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) regarding the procedure for approving promotions of senior management within the organisation. These instructions were given following the controversy in which a CEB official had been promoted a day before her retirement. During a meeting convened with the CEB’s Chairman, General Manager (GM) and Directors, the minister emphasised the importance of obtaining the ministry’s approval for senior management promotions within the CEB. Additionally, Minister Wijesekara instructed the immediate implementation of a decision made by the board in 2020. This decision, originally slated for execution in 2025, pertains to the minimum service period requirement for promotions to the positions of Deputy General Managers (DGMs) (3 years) and Assistant General Managers (AGMs) (2 years). Taking to Twitter, Minister Wijesekara elaborated that given the imminent retirement of the current General Manager next month, instructions were also given to nominate candidates for the position of GM. These nominees should possess prior administrative experience and a minimum of three years of service remaining before retirement.  Approval from the Ministry is required for these nominations. The meeting also addressed various topics including the ongoing reform process of the CEB, power generation plans, effective asset management, strategies to reduce administrative and operating costs and other matters related to the CEB, according to the minister. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sajith gives conditions for SJB assisting Govt
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa emphasised on the possibility of offering support to President Ranil Wickremesinghe and the Government in the near future, albeit for a limited duration. During a recent public gathering, Premadasa conveyed the SJB’s commitment to supporting the Government if it refrains from political manoeuvrings and earnestly dedicates itself to advancing the welfare of the nation. As the country finds itself in a state of crisis, grappling with a prolonged drought and significant challenges such as the departure of around 5,000 schoolteachers and a notable exodus of doctors, Premadasa underscored the necessity for a comprehensive national strategy. He advocated the initiation of new irrigation projects to harness the potential of water resources that currently flow into the sea. “SJB is poised to offer its expertise and collaboration to the government, provided the government demonstrates genuine intent.” Premadasa stressed their readiness to support the government’s efforts in implementing a holistic national plan to address the nation’s pressing challenges. However, he urged the government to abstain from engaging in political manoeuvres. It was emphasised by Premadasa that the SJB’s support would not be extended if the government continues to prioritise political games and the pursuit of ministerial positions over the welfare of the nation. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Wajira heaps praise on RW
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has introduced a multitude of legislations to Parliament within an impressively brief timeframe of one year, UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena said. Particularly noteworthy is his successful steering of the most robust anti-corruption legislation in Asia through Parliament, cementing its establishment as law and setting a course for the nation’s progress. Abeywardena made these remarks during a press conference held yesterday (21) at the President’s Media Centre (PMC). Abeywardena commended President Wickremesinghe’s exceptional leadership, highlighting his adeptness at fostering effective collaborations across diverse groups, irrespective of their alignment. He emphasised that the present juncture offers an opportune moment to tap into Wickremesinghe’s wealth of experience and knowledge for the greater good of the nation. Furthermore, he stressed the pressing need for a comprehensive overhaul of the entire system. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Impractical to ban doctors from leaving country – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: It is impractical for a Government to ban doctors from leaving the country, Minister of Transport and Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena said. The Minister of Health will shortly implement a special mechanism to retain the services of doctors who are otherwise prepared to leave these shores for greener pastures, Gunawardena claimed. He mentioned that by and large there were a sizeable number of doctors who are serving this country and noted that as a Government it would be impractical for it to prohibit doctors from leaving for overseas for better prospects. Gunawardena was of the view that majority of doctors, despite pressing issues, had rendered a sterling service to the public throughout the country. He made these remarks during an event held at the Homagama Base Hospital to handover medical equipment yesterday (21). The Minister added that Sri Lanka is the sole country in the world where medical degrees are granted sans incurring any fees, via its free educations system and stressed that those who emerge as fully- fledged doctors through that system have a bounden duty to serve the country and its citizens. BY Mithun Jayawardhana

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Agripreneurs’ Forum successfully concludes AGM
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Agripreneurs’ Forum, the premier forum for agribusiness in Sri Lanka, successfully held its AGM on 16 August at the Instituteof Engineers, Sri Lanka, Colombo 7. The AGM saw the participation of key stakeholders of the agri sector, including private companies, State agencies, NGOs, international organisations, and agri -academics. In view of the exceptional work done towards the growth of the association, Chairman Rizvi Zaheed was reappointed for another term. Dr. Selvanathan Anojan and Kulendran Sivaram remain as Secretary and Treasurer respectively. The Executive Committee for the years 2023/24 comprises Aruna Weerakoon, Jayantha Rajapakse, Parakrama Jayasinghe, Kavinda Dissanayake, Charaka Perera, and Visal Perera. Some key changes in the association saw the introduction of the individual membership category which is offered free of charge, the introduction of the Advisory Council to the association comprising eminent veterans of the industry, and the introduction of regional chapters of the association. The Chairperson highlighted some of the key initiatives conducted by the association in the past year such as the Agripreneurs Conference, Agcelerator Programme (a funding and capacity-building programme for budding agripreneurs and their agri-startups), National Jackfruit Value Chain Development Project, Capacity Building and Training Programmes, Funding Programmes, and various other State-level interventions. He stated that the association is looking to grow in the years to come and sought the support of all members to ensure that. SLAF calls upon all interested agri stakeholders to join its thriving membership and to contribute to the development of the Sri Lankan agribusiness sector.

title: Forging a Stronger Tax Foundation: Cross-party Summit Explores Equitable Policies
author: Author not found
Content: In a cross-party discourse titled ‘Unlocking the Power of Taxes’, representatives from major political factions converged to discuss the adoption of a sound tax strategy grounded in fundamental principles. Organised by NextGenSL, a cross-party youth political platform, the forum provided a stage for influential voices from both government and opposition ranks to present their perspectives on the nation’s tax framework and its way forward. Central to the discussion was the elucidation of guiding principles for a nation’s tax system. The cardinal principles underscored were impartiality, fairness, simplicity, and consistency. Notable speakers such as State Finance Minister Shehan Semasinghe, former State Finance Minister and SJB MP Eran Wickremaratne, Prof. Anil Jayantha from the NPP, and Duminda Hulangamuwa, Chair of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, unanimously emphasised avoiding the manipulation of taxes for bias or retaliation. A key takeaway from the event was the assertion that taxes should not be exploited or wielded to target specific individuals or groups. Instead, a foundation of integrity and transparency should underpin the tax structure. The speakers flagged the perils of using taxes as tools for personal gain or political vendettas, underscoring the importance of upholding the credibility of the tax system. Impartiality, another pivotal principle, was highlighted as paramount in establishing a tax structure that treats all entities equally, eradicating potential favoritism or undue influence. A neutral tax set-up guarantees uniform application of rules and regulations to everyone, forestalling any potential discrimination. Further, simplicity and stability were touted as indispensable components of an efficient tax framework. A simplified tax architecture diminishes intricacies, aiding businesses and individuals in grasping and adhering to tax regulations. Steadfast tax policies provide assurance and assurance for long-term planning, kindling investments and development. The speakers echoed that these foundational principles should constitute the bedrock of any tax strategy. By upholding impartiality, fairness, simplicity, and stability, nations can cultivate a tax structure that spurs economic progress, incentivizes investments, and nurtures an equitable and transparent ecosystem for all taxpayers. State Finance Minister Shehan Semasinghe underscored the need to consistently enact reforms within the IMF programme’s framework. He stressed that adherence to the programme could forestall the necessity for another IMF programme to stabilise the economy. Semasinghe also discussed the urgency of a centralised revenue body and a digitised system to enhance tax collection and transparency in tax administration. He also acknowledged the significance of tackling corruption and affirmed the government’s resolve to enforce newanti-corruption laws effectively. Duminda Hulangamuwa, Ceylon Chamber of Commerce Chair, voiced concerns about elevated tax levels in the nation. He contended that prevailing tax rates, particularly income tax, are burdensome, given Sri Lanka’s history of a low-tax culture. Hulangamuwa stressed that economic expansion is imperative to bolster revenue, rather than further tax hikes. He also tackled government expenditure, suggesting exploring options for interest relief to alleviate the load. Eran Wickremaratne proposed a tax policy committee to facilitate discussions between experts and politicians for informed tax decisions. He also advocated for a single tax collection authority to streamline revenue collection. Wickremaratne acknowledged the political complexities associated with these ideas but emphasised the necessity of radical action to plug revenue leakage. He cited instances of other nations successfully implementing like measures. Prof. Anil Jayantha voiced concerns about the disproportionate burden of indirect taxes on low-income individuals due to disparities in tax evasion. He stressed the need to root out leakages in the tax system to bolster the tax-to-GDP ratio. Prof. Jayantha also highlighted the significance of maintaining a consistent primary balance in Sri Lanka’s economy, mitigating fluctuations. Altogether, the forum’s speakers presented diverse viewpoints on tax policy, revenue collection, corruption, and government expenditure. These deliberations aim to illuminate the obstacles and possibilities that Sri Lanka confronts in unlocking taxes’ complete potential for economic growth and stability.

title: ‘Ran Sivili Perahara’ takes to the streets
author: Author not found
Content: The revered religious observances at the annual Esala Perahara festival, of the historic Bellanwila Raja Maha Viharaya, took place last week. During his visit, Sagala Ratnayaka engaged in a brief conversation with Venerable Dr. Bellanwila Dhammarathana Nayaka Thera, the Chief Incumbent of Bellanwila Rajamaha Viharaya. Venerable Atapatthukande Ananda Nayaka Thera, the Chief Incumbent of the Havelock City Peace Temple in Colombo, was also present on the occasion. As part of the festivities, ‘Ran Sivili Perahara’ of the 73rd Bellanwila Annual Esala Perehara Festival, took to the streets. This year’s Bellanwila Esala Perahara, which commenced on 29 July, concluded with the final Randoli Perahara last weekend. (Pix courtesy: PMD)

title: Public hearing on the Draft National Policy on Archives and Records Management
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of National Archives is holding a public hearing on the draft National Policy on Archives and Records Management on 25 August from 9.30 a.m. onwards at the Auditorium of the Department of National Archives, Colombo. All are welcome to attend the hearing. On that day, those who submitted written comments, on the draft policy before 14 August, as previously notified, will first be invited to present oral comments. Thereafter, other members of the public will be given the opportunity to comment. The draft policy can be downloaded from the official website www.archives.gov.lk of the National Archives. The main objective of this National Policy is to provide an appropriate framework for shaping the management, protection and accessibility of the country’s archives and records. The policy further emphasises the importance of ensuring access to evidentiary records in this country, preserving collective memory and embracing technological advances in records management.

title: Controlling drug menace discussed
author: Author not found
Content: The measures taken to control the drug menace in Sri Lanka were discussed at the Select Committee of Parliament, to look into and identify the mechanisms to be implemented in order to immediately control and eradicate the rapidly spreading drug menace in the country and to submit observations and recommendations to Parliament in that connection. This was taken into discussion when the said committee met in Parliament recently under the Chairmanship of Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. The Sri Lanka Police, National Dangerous Drugs Control Board and the National Authority on Tobacco and Alcohol were summoned before this Committee and the measures taken by these departments to control the drug menace in the country were discussed. Minister Alles said a special committee has been headed by Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon, to control the drug menace in this country. Moreover, the officials representing the Sri Lanka Police mentioned that many measures have been taken to stop bringing in drugs into the country on a large-scale. It was further said that the intelligence agencies of the neighbouring countries will also support this endeavour. Furthermore, the officials representing the National Authority on Tobacco and Alcohol presented to the Committee some suggestions that could be taken to reduce the use of tobacco and alcohol. Moreover, the officials further stated that the National Dangerous Drugs Control Board is working towards taking necessary measures for the treatment of people who are addicted to drugs. The MPs who were present also presented proposals and ideas regarding drug control and the Committee Chair Minister Tiran Alles stated that the proposals of the committee members should be taken into consideration and a report containing the proposals of these present sectors should be given to the committee. State Minister Sisira Jayakody, MPs Buddhika Pathirana, Jayantha Samaraweera, Dr. Upul Galappaththi, Upul Mahendra Rajapaksha, Rajika Wickramasinghe and Manjula Dissanayake were present at the Committee meeting.

title: SL must elevate prices while boosting tourist numbers – President
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka must not only boost the number of tourists but also consider elevating the pricing in order to invigorate the tourism industry, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said. He highlighted that the tourism industry stands as the paramount sector capable of swiftly advancing the country’s economic objectives. The Government, under his leadership, has implemented numerous pivotal measures to foster its growth, the PMD said. The President emphasised the significance of substantial contributions from both the public and private sectors. He stressed that the Government is diligently working to provide necessary amenities for all stakeholders involved. Addressing the audience at the inauguration of the Hilton Yala Resort, a luxurious establishment within the Hilton Hotel Group, the President underscored the urgent need for comprehensive development in the region. The Yala National Park, frequented by local and international tourists daily, was singled out as a key area for such development. He expressed his satisfaction in inaugurating the upscale Hilton hotel in the Yala region. He noted that this move would attract energetic tourists and invigorate the tourism sector. He extended his gratitude to Melwa and the Hilton Group for their contributions. Recalling the historical significance of the area, President Wickremesinghe alluded to the ancient shrines of Situlpawwa and Akasa Chaitya that once graced Yala. He praised the past fertility and collaboration that defined the area, as well as its remarkable architectural marvels. The President emphasised a resolute commitment to advancing the tourism industry, urging collective participation towards this goal. He envisioned the development of the Yala area as a unified tourist destination, incorporating nearby areas like Udawalawe. This interconnected approach, he suggested, would drive progress and further enhance the tourism experience in the region. “Furthermore, there is a pressing need to enhance the facilities catering to tourists visiting these regions. I kindly urge both the Minister of Wildlife and Forest Conservation and the Minister of Tourism, along with their respective Ministry officials, to collaborate on devising a comprehensive development plan for the Yala area. “This expansion should extend to encompass locales like Galoya, Maduruoya, Somavatiya, Minneriya and Wasgamuwa.” “The industry has to be involvedand that is a prerequisite. I have been also looking at this hotel and the areaand I thought we should also promote Yala. We will introduce the greater Yala. “Why are you going to call these places Udawalawe, Kumana and all? These are all connected, and the elephant path passage from Udawalawe will take you up to Kumana. So, let’s brand this as Greater Yala and make it Greater Yala for all promotional activities. “So, why only have luxury hotels here? You can have some near, I am sure, just outside Kumana before Arugambay and we can find some land for another set. Somewhere in Udawalawe, somewhere in Lunugamwehera, where those who want to can also access theKataragama shrines. “So, these are places. Why don’t we develop them? I am asking the Minister, together with the Minister of Wildlife and Conservation, as well as the officials of those two ministries, to come up with the Greater Yala concept. I don’t think we should stop there. If you take GalOya, MaduruOya, Somavathiya, Minneriya, and Wasgamuwa, you will have a unique brand. So, just have two brands and Wilpattu, which can stand on its own. And certainly, why don’t you get into a yacht in Colombo, come to Puttlam Bay, spend a day or two at Wilpattu and get back? So, you will have some wildlife reserves, which will be different from what you can get in other places. “Additionally, an intriguing prospect lies in establishing wildlife reserves that offer visitors a fresh and unique experience, reminiscent of the offerings in countries like India and Nepal. This avenue warrants significant attention as we formulate a new strategy to elevate the tourism industry. “It is essential that we set ambitious targets for the tourism sector, with the goal of doubling the influx of tourists to our country. Correspondingly, the revenue generated from tourism should witness a four to fivefold increase. “Reflecting on my visit to the Maldives in 1981, I recall that their tourist income amounted to USD 25. Interestingly, at that time, fewer tourists visited the Maldives compared to our nation. Today, the number of tourists arriving here, approximately 2.5 million, equals the visitors to the Maldives. “Presently, we charge around USD 200 per tourist, while the Maldives charges approximately USD700. Therefore, to invigorate the tourism industry, we must not only boost the number of tourists but also consider elevating the pricing. “Upon assuming the presidency, my responsibility extended beyond liberating the country from debt burdens. I was tasked with devising innovative avenues to generate income. Unlike industries and agriculture, which require time to yield returns, the tourism sector presents an avenue for swift contributions. “Hence, our primary objective revolves around promoting tourism to generate income and fulfil the needs of our people. As the year concludes, our hotels will brim with tourists—a trend that’s already underway. Looking ahead to the following year, we must not only fill our rooms with tourists but also double the resultant income. “Tourist accommodations across the nation are experiencing high occupancy rates in September, buoyed by the historic Dalada Perehara and the Asia Cup cricket tournament in Kandy. The upcoming Christmas season is anticipated to draw several internationally renowned artists and musicians, including the distinguished Western musician Andrey Mucher, who is slated to grace our shores in January. “The country hosts a myriad of events, such as the Galle Literary Festival, strategically designed to attract more visitors and generate vital revenue for the nation. Simultaneously, this endeavour should serve as a means of both income and employment, necessitating comprehensive training for the youth. In certain instances, this avenue has evolved into a gateway to international employment, highlighting the importance of collective engagement in shaping both individual futures and broader initiatives. “Numerous innovative proposals have been introduced to expedite the progress of our tourism sector. Notably, the government is working to extend support for individuals willing to allocate two rooms in their homes for tourists, providing excellent guest services while commanding rates upwards of a hundred dollars. “The imperative of achieving our tourism industry’s objectives is paramount. We aim to harness resources to swiftly generate income and employment prospects. In this pursuit, I appeal for the unwavering support of all individuals.” Meanwhile, President Wickremesinghe embarked on an inspection tour of the Yala National Park. During the visit, he highlighted the option of purchasing park tickets online for both local and foreign visitors. Acknowledging the arid climate, the President also observed efforts to rejuvenate dried-up water ponds within the park. Accompanying him were Minister Harin Fernando and American Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung. Also present were Jamie Mead, Senior Operations Director (South East Asia) of the Hilton Hotels Group, Josh Roberts, Senior Operations Director (Asia & Australasia), Sri Lanka Hilton Hotels Group Regional General Manager Manesh Fernando, Hilton Yala Resort General Manager GitanjaliChakravarthy, MurugaPillai, Director of Melwa Hotels & Resorts Private Limited, and several other officials.

title: President leaves for Singapore
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe left the country this morning (21) on a two-day official visit to Singapore. Throughout this visit, President Wickremesinghe has a series of significant meetings planned, including discussions with Singapore’s President, Halimah Yacob and talks with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen, and Sustainability and Environment Minister Grace Fu Hai Yien. The latter will engage in bilateral talks with President Wickremesinghe. Joining the President on this visit will be Chief of Presidential Staff and Senior Adviser on National Security Sagala Ratnayaka, Senior Adviser on Climate Change Ruwan Wijewardena and Dr.R.H.S. Samaratunga Senior Adviser on Economic Affairs. Simultaneously, during President Wickremesinghe’s absence from the country, four Acting Ministers have been designated to oversee the ministries under his purview. The appointments include Minister of State for Defence Pramita Bandara Tennakoon as the Acting Minister of Defence, Minister of State for Finance Shehan Semasinghe as the Acting Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policy for the duration of the President’s absence, Minister of State for Technology Kanaka Herath has been appointed as the Acting Minister of Technology and Minister of State for Social Empowerment Anupa Pasqual has been appointed as the Acting Minister of Women, Child Affairs, and Social Empowerment. Under the provisions of Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, countries have the opportunity to collaborate effectively with the objective of reducing global greenhouse gas emissions through international carbon trading. Accordingly, a cooperative understanding concerning carbon neutrality within the framework of the Paris Agreement will be established between the Governments of Sri Lanka and Singapore. The signing of this agreement is anticipated after deliberations between President Ranil Wickremesinghe and the Prime Minister of Singapore.

title: Ganemulle Sanjeeva arrested at Indo-Nepal border
author: Author not found
Content: One of the most feared underworld leaders, Sanjeeva Kumara Samararatne, alias Ganemulle Sanjeeva, for whom a red notice had been issued by the Interpol, has been arrested, along with another underworld gang member, Amila Nuvan alias Gotha Asanka, by foreign security forces at the Indo-Nepal border, reliable sources revealed to our sister paper ‘Mawbima’. According to unofficial reports, Ganemulle Sanjeeva, an accused in numerous contracted murders had fled to India while on bail and was apparently taken into custody while trying to cross the border into Nepal. Meanwhile, the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) is in touch with foreign security agencies on the alleged arrests and was not in a position to completely confirm the arrests by last night. Ganemulle Sanjeeva was also known as Makilangamuwe Sanjeeva for some time. Sanjeeva, was arrested by the Terrorist Investigation Division (TID) for attacking a Black Maria, when Dematagoda Chaminda, a suspect in the murder of Bharata Lakshman Premachandra, was being taken to Court in Hulftsdorp. He was allowed  bail after spending a long time in remand. The Colombo Chief Magistrate had ordered the release of 11 suspects, including ‘Ganemulla Sanjeewa’ from an arms trafficking case. The case was filed against 15 suspects for secretly transporting weapons including Claymore Bombs and T-56 firearms that were buried in the North-Eastern parts of the country, by the LTTE during the civil war period, to Colombo and other urban areas. The charges included the sale and purchase of such weapons to underworld gang members. By Keerthi Mendis
